column2: BOWIE, Md., Nov. 23 (AP) -- The voice of the $2 bettor was heard in the stands:

There are two periods of quietness in Nature's year. Before the major climactic changes in February and in August the countryside waits in hushed expectancy. There is also a late-autumn interlude when peace broods on the land. Climb a hillside in late November on a sunny, windless day and listen to the silence.

Although the official "Battle of the Bronx" will not be held until Saturday when N. Y. U. and Fordham clash in their traditional game at the Polo Grounds, ominous signs of the fray were evident yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 -- A special Air Force board is in the process of recommending a list of officers for temporary promotions to brigadier and major general to meet the needs of the expanding service, it was revealed today.
The State Liquor Authority sought advice yesterday on whether enforcement of the Alcoholic Beverage Control Act should be transferred to the state or left with the localities.

Daniel S. Weiss, 39year-old Manhattan attorney, was recommended yesterday by the City Council Committee on Rules, Privileges and Elections to fill the City Council vacancy created by the resignation of S. Samuel di Falco, recently elected to the State Supreme Court.

The special touch that makes so richly delicious the brownies concocted by the woman who calls herself simply Lucile is very much evident in her new butter-toasted pecans. Though Lucile and her partner themselves devised the formula for the brownies, they had help on the unbelievably buttery nuts.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 23 (AP) -Beau Jack, two-time former light weight champion now campaigning in the welterweight ranks, battered Chuck Taylor of Coalport, Pa., into helplessness with a bolo punch to win on a technical knock out in 2:43 of the third round tonight at Convention Hall.

CHICAGO, Nov. 23 -- Grain prices were on the upgrade in the early trading on the Board of Trade today, with December wheat selling at a new high since Feb. 4, December corn since Aug. 13, December oats since June 24 and December soybeans went into new ground since July 28.

The Federal Trade Commission will not challenge pricing practices of manufacturers whose systems are based upon independently meeting competition wherever and whenever they wish to do so. This clarification of governmental pricepolicing policies was issued yesterday by Corwin D. Edwards, director, the FTC Bureau of Industrial Economics, during a luncheon symposium of more than 200 lawyers and economists in the first meeting of the Institute of Trade and Commerce Professions at the Roosevelt Hotel.

If 74-year-old Jesse Jones, former Secretary of Commerce, is well enough to play poker until 2 o'clock in the morning he is surely well enough to appear personally for examination as a witness, Federal Judge Samuel H. Kaufman said yesterday.

LONDON, Nov. 23 -- Brigadier Lloyd N. Clayton, one of Britain's best known experts on Arab affairs, urged today that an international airlift be put into operation immediately to save the lives of tens of thousands of Palestine Arab refugees "who are now at the point of death.

BOSTON, Nov. 23Royal S. Little, president of Textron, Inc., today charged Senator Charles W. Tobey, New Hampshire Republican, with "un-American" tactics in conducting a hearing into the textile empire's charitable trusts.

Jack Schneider, business agent for the New York Furriers Joint Council, CIO, and manager of Local 101, cutters union, was arrested yesterday by immigration officers at the council's headquarters, 250 West Twenty-sixth Street, in deportation proceedings.

The right-wing executive board of Local 100, Transport Workers Union, CIO, did a sudden aboutfaceh)0*0*0*iyesterday and reinstated its suspended president, Austin Hogan, and two of his fellow left-wing officers.

LONDON, Nov. 23 -- Prime Minister Attlee was reliably said today to be preparing a statement that would offer a partial solution to the problems arising from Ireland's complete withdrawal from the British Commonwealth.

John J. Bennett, Deputy Mayor of New York, recalled yesterday the last message of the late President Theodore Roosevelt -- "no sagging back in the fight for Americanism" -- at a preview of an exhibition in honor of the twentyfifth President of the United States.

MEXICO CITY, Nov. 23 -- A message from President Truman was read at the Palace of Fine Arts this morning during the inaugural session of the eighth annual general assembly of the Inter American Federation of Auto Clubs.

VIENNA, Nov. 23 -- The Soviet announced through Tass, official news agency here tonight, that Dr. Margarethe Ottillinger, head of the planning, department in the Austrian Ministry of Economic Planning, had confessed to having been a spy in the service of the United States.
The telephone jangled insistently throughout the day yesterday in the offices of the Greater New York CIO Council at 1133 Broadway, but there was no one to answer the rings.

A series of educational meetings on psychiatric diagnosis and treatment is being planned by the Bronx Council for Social Welfare, it was announced yesterday in the organization's annual report. The meetings, no dates for which have been set, will be held in cooperation with the Bronx Society of Neurology and Psychiatry and the Bronx County Medical Society.

Dean James E. McCarthy of the College of Commerce, University of Notre Dame, said last night that the failure of American education in the field of American history, as shown by a survey by THE NEW YORK TIMES several years ago, was exceeded by its failure in the field of economics.
The second split season on waterfowl will get under way in New York on Friday at high noon, and due to mild weather the prospects for good shooting on Long Island are not as bright as they might be.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Nov. 23 -- Evans Ward, president of the Westchester Park Commission, said today that the County Board of Supervisors' plan to exclude non-residents from two county parks on busy days next year would be impracticable to administer.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Nov. 23 (AP) -Efforts of so-called liberal factions within the New York State Teachers Association to seize control of the organization collapsed at the 103d annual convention tonight for the second straight year.

The New York City Housing Authority received yesterday bids on $33,816,000 of short-term notes representing lowest qualifying interest costs ranging from 1.08 per cent to 1.19 per cent plus a slight premium. The best bids for theh)0*0*0*ilargest aggregate of the notes were submitted by Salomon Brothers Hutzler, who offered to take up $13,433,000 of the total at interest rates ranging from 1.14 per cent to 1.19 per cent.

Herbert Haseltine, American sculptor of animals, at last is to recover possession of four pieces of his own workmanship as the result of a ruling yesterday morning by Magistrate Harry G. Andrews in Mid-Manhattan Magistrates Court.

LONDON, Nov. 23 -- As messages of sympathy flooded into Buckingham Palace today from all parts of the empire, Parliament, echoing the thoughts of the nation, expressed hope for the speedy recovery of King George. In the House of Commons Prime Ministerh)0*0*0*iAttlee and Winston Churchill paid tribute to the King's unremitting toil since he ascended the throne twelve years ago.

A one-woman fashion show took place yesterday afternoon at El Morocco. The designer was Marusia, the exhibitor Saks Fifth Avenue. The West Coast designer's styles will be handled in New York exclusively by the Fifth Avenue store, it was announced.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 -- A permanenth)0*0*0*iReciprocal Trade Agreement Act, rewritten to draw it back to the formula of the 1934 Hull foreign trade policy program, was slated today for early consideration in the new Democratic Congress.

PARIS, Nov. 23 -- Facing a weakened position of his Cabinet today, Premier Henri Queuille asked for a twenty-four-hour delay on the vote of confidence he had requested of the National Assembly. He was expected to act to strengthen his majority in the meantime.

ESTORIL, Portugal, Nov. 23 - This resort area sixteen miles west of Lisbon is a curious political never-never land that apparently has a magnetic attraction for dispossessed monarchs and pretenders to non-existent thrones.

" The Law of the Soviet State," by Andrei Y. Vyshinsky, Russia's chief delegate to the United Nations, will be issued by Macmillanh)0*0*0*ion Dec. 14. This will make available for the first time in English, the classic university and law school textbook of Soviet administration and constitutional law.

One of the major mysteries of the current football season is the startling decline of the Green Bay Packers as a ranking power. Long before the campaign began, the word had been circulated throughout the league, "Watch out for the Packers. They really are loaded." Back in September the Chicago Bears were much more worried about the Packers as a pennant contender than they were about the Chicago Cardinals.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., Nov. 23 -A committee was set up today to study the possibility of turning Churchill Downs, home of the Kentucky Derby, into a nonprofit corporation.

Fifty-five per cent of the goal of the United Hospital Fund's seventieth annual campaign to benefit eighty-six nonprofit, voluntary hospitals has been attained, it was announced yesterday by Mrs. Frank E. Adair, chairman of the fund's women's division, at a report meeting at the St. Regis Roof.

RAWAL PINDI, Pakistan, Nov. 23 -- A rebel Government of Kashmir,h)0*0*0*ilaying claim to three-fourths of the Princely State's territory and about half its population, is functioning behind the fighting lines while India and Pakistan carry on an undeclared war for possession of the State.

The Walter W. Naumburg Foundation presented its third winner of the season yesterday afternoon at Town Hall. He was Sidney Harth, 23-year-old Cleveland violinist, and he proved once more that the Naumburg judges know talent when they hear it.

The summons from Commissioner A. B. (Happy) Chandler for Manager Leo Durocher and Freddy Fitzsimmons to appear before the commissioner on Tuesday, Dec. 14, brought no comment yesterday from President Horace Stoneham of the Giants.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 -- Early legislative action will be sought on public housing, slum clearance and other parts of President Truman's housing program that were blocked in the Republican-controlled Eightieth Congress, Raymond M. Foley, Housing Administrator, asserted today.

Rocky Graziano yesterday deniedreports that he was considering retirement from the ring. At the same time, however, the former middleweight champion of the world said that he was in such a disturbed state, emotionally, that he was concerned at present with nothing more than a long rest.
PARIS, Nov. 23 (AP) -- Excerpts from the speech by United States delegate Philip C. Jessup before the United Nations General Assembly's Political Committee today follow:
Four changes in Fordham's starting line-up for Saturday's contest with N. Y. U. were announced by Coach Ed Danowski yesterday as he put the Rams through their second light drill of the week.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 -- President Truman asked the press and radio today to cooperate in extending his thanks to those who had sent him messages of congratulation on his election.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 23 -- The Pennsylvania football team polished its passing attack today in the next to the last practice and final scrimmage before the Thanksgiving Day game with Cornell.
SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 23 (AP) -- Carrying a group of scientists, the giant flying boat the Marshall Mars developed engine trouble today and returned safely during a flight to Hawaii.

Some progress toward prevention and control of "swamp fever," the disease that struck down a number of thoroughbred horses in the season of 1947, was indicated in the Grayson Foundation's report distributed to interested parties this week.

The American Standards Association sectional committee on radio is being reactivated and its membership is being reviewed by participating organizations, Vrgil M. Graham, chairman, announced yesterday. He said that the immediate problem of the committee is to review Joint Army-Navy specifications with the cooperation of the Army-Navy Electronic Engineering Agency and coordinate them with civilian standards where this may be done.

The Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation is negotiating for outright purchase of the American Broadcasting Company, including all of its radio and television facilities, Spyros P. Skouras, president of the motion picture company, disclosed yesterday.

VIENNA, Nov. 23 -- The retiring head of the Marshall Plan mission here has informed the Austrian Government by letter that the Economic Cooperation Administration is not interested in any special private interests.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 -- President Truman will address the fifty-eight nation Food and Agriculture Organization at 4:30 P.M. tomorrow, it was announced today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 -- The battle to force Alabama's eleven Democratic electors to cast their votes for President Truman and Senator Alben W. Barkley, his running mate, reached the United States Supreme Court today in a citizens' action.

The Metropolitan Fair Rent Committee, composed of real estate boards and landlords comprising a majority of the housing industry here, announced yesterday that it would ask Congress to investigate the New York City Rent Advisory Board, which on Monday voted 8-to-5 to reject the committee's plea for a general 15 per cent rise in rents in this city and on Long Island.

Persistent trade reports that steel allocations to appliance producers will be reduced in the first quarter of 1949 because of increased European Recovery Program and industrial mobilizationrequirements were discounted yesterday by two leading appliance producers.

PARIS, Nov. 23 -- An invitation for representatives of the Government of the Republic of Korea to take part in the debate in the United Nations General Assembly on the Korean question formally was requested today by China.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Nov. 23 -- Certain "prophets of despair" who maintain that the world is too populated for its natural resources are offering "a remedy that is frequently worse than the despair it reflects," Gordon R. Clapp, chairman of the Tennessee Valley Authority, declared today.
TOKYO, Nov. 23 (AP) -- At least five of the convicted war crimes trial defendants have decided already to appeal to the United States Supreme Court.

A shift in emphasis of public relations activities to customer relations by many concerns because of the buyers' market in most fields was reported yesterday in a release issued by the National Industrial Conference Board. The release covered results of the board's latest survey on current business practices.
Thanksgiving services in the churches will be conducted tomorrow morning with the customary holiday adornment of altars and pulpits with harvest fruits and vegetables.
RICHMOND, Va., Nov. 23 (AP) North Carolina's undefeated but once-tied Tar Heels today dominated the 1948 All-Southern Conference football selections of The Associated Press.

Out-of-town buyers registered inh)0*0*0*ithe market for the week ended yesterday numbered 1,059, compared with 2,170 last week and 1,180 in the corresponding week a year ago, according to listings appearing in THE NEW YORK TIMES. There were 307 arrivals yesterday against 1,012 last Tuesday.
TEL AVIV, Israel, Nov. 23 The Israeli Government ordered a halt today in unrestricted recruiting for the army and announced the formation of a regular reserve of men up to 45 years of age.
TRENTON, N.J., Nov. 23 -There were two developments today in the Burlington County bridge deal, which has stirred New Jersey political and financial circles.

Four properties in Manhattan, one in the Bronx and one in Brooklyn were sold at auction for the City of New York yesterday for a total of $215,600. The Fred Berger Company conducted the sale in the Vesey Street Exchange for the Board of Transportation and the Board of Estimate.

Monday's Supreme Court decision "broadening" the Federal pure food and drug act's provisions against misbranding to cover claims in literature distributed separately from products was said by a number of advertising and legal authorities here yesterday as opening the way for inclusion of direct advertising under the regulations.

America's feminine golfers are toying with the idea of selecting qualifiers for their national championship before the tournament prop a system employed by the men since 1931. The Associated Press reports.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 23 -- Persons with rheumatic heart disease are no more likely to fall dead than the general run of individuals, according to a doctor who has made a study of their ability to work.
MOSCOW, Nov. 23 -- Soviet scientists just returned from Mongolia said today that they discovered the bones of millions of dinosaurs and other prehistoric creatures in the southwestern Gobi desert.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 -- President Truman started today his fourth effort to legislate an anti-inflation program, putting a team of Cabinet members to work on the project under the captaincy of Dr. Edwin G. Nourse, Chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers.

Four first-run film houses will present new offerings today. At the Paramount, the attraction is "Miss Tatlock's Millions," a Paramount comedy featuring John Hendrix, Monty Woolley, Robert Lund, Barry Fitzgerald, Wanda Stack, Ilka Chase and Dorothy Stickney.

Line officers of the Army, particularly in the higher ranks, should spend some time at sea with the Merchant Marine preparing for wartime duties, Leonard H. Nason, director of export of the Tailby Nason Company, asserted yesterday.

MONTREAL, Nov. 23 (Canadian Press) -- President Harry Davis of the Canadian Seamen's Union (AFL) said today Montreal members would ask all maritime unions in the world to refuse to load or unload Canadian - owned ships whose Canadian crews had been replaced with "foreigners."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 -- President Truman ordered Marshall Plan grain purchases retained in Government hands today and directed Economic Cooperation Administrator Paul G. Hoffman to rescind a projected shift of buying operations to private trade channels as of Dec. 1.
MOSCOW, Nov. 23 -- Soviet scientists just returned from Mongolia said today that they discovered the bones of millions of dinosaurs and other prehistoric creatures in the southwestern Gobi desert.

The joint enterprise of private benefaction and city support that today is the vast New York Public Library system rededicated itself yesterday to the principle of service upon which it was founded 100 years ago.
A telephoned report of a burglary in the Williamsbridge precinct reached Bronx police headquarters at exactly 9 o'clock last night. An alarm immediately went on the air.
Mayor O'Dwyer opened last night a B'nai B'rith drive for 200,000 food packages to send to Israel.

As a result of a five-month grand jury inquiry into a $250,000 damage suit that Supreme Court Justice Samuel Null had said was "permeated with fraud," two attorneys were arraigned yesterday in General Sessions on charges of subornation of perjury and conspiracy.

TOKYO, Wednesday, Nov. 24 -Gen. Douglas MacArthur today upheld all the sentences imposed by the International Military Tribunal for the Far East on Hideki Tojo and twenty-four others who were convicted as war criminals.

Although it wound up the season Saturday with a crushing 47-13 defeat at the hands of R.P.I., Brooklyn College's football squad equaled its best season in twentytwo years of intercollegiate competition and smashed virtually every Maroon offensive record.
Negotiations were at a standstill yesterday after 2,000 wholesale liquor salesmen struck against thirty liquor concerns for an increase in commissions on sales.

Your news report of the public library's centenary says that on Nov. 23 the library will be formally rededicated "to the service of the people of the city." Unfortunately, this is not wholly true, for the library does not serve the disabled and the shut-in; though they, too, are taxpayers entitled to service quite as much as others are.
PARIS, Nov. 23 -- Sir Alexander Cadogan delivered to Dr. Juan Atilio Bramuglia this evening the joint United States. British and French statement on four-power control, of currency in Berlin
Michigan held the lead as four of the top ten teams bettered their positions yesterday in the next-tolast Associated Press poll of the season on leading college football teams.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 -- The Bureau of Labor Statistics announced today the first drop in the consumers' price index since last March, a development bearing directly on the possibility of a "fourth-round" wage increase.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Nov. 23 -Considering that this is ArmyNavy week, news was more or less on the sparse side today when Earl (Red) Blaik submitted to a mass interview before sending his squad through its final scrimmage. However, lest the "no news is good news" feeling hits Annapolis, the Navy would do well to weigh Blaik's most important disclosure.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 -- Former Representative Roger C. Slaughter, the Missouri Democrat whom President Truman helped to defeat for renomination in 1946, was indicted by a Federal grand jury today on charges of violating the lobbying laws.

No one can write a complete history of the war "no matter what his position," Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower declared yesterday at the Astor Hotel. He spoke as author of his newly published "Crusade in Europe," at the book and author luncheon jointly sponsoredh)0*0*0*iby The New York Herald Tribune and American Booksellers Association.

The previously unbeaten Fort Monmouth basketball team met with a crushing 93-27 setback at the hands of the St. John's University quintet last night at DeGray gymnasium in Brooklyn. In handing the visitors their first reverse in nine games, the Redmen rolled up their biggest score in court history.

Although the 1948 football season has not quite run its official course, three backfield stars from so-called major colleges have gained more than 1,000 yards from scrimmage, the Associated Press reported yesterday.

It becomes increasingly evident that regulation of pedestrians, as well as of motorists, will be necessary to reduce the traffic hazard in our major cities. Last year more than 10,000 Americans of all ages walked to their deaths in traffic and 250,000 more were injured.

BRUSSELS, Nov. 23 -- Regent Prince Charles tonight asked Gaston Eyskens of the Christian Social (Catholic) party to form a new government after accepting Premier Paul-Henri Spaak's "final resignation."

TOKYO, Nov. 24 -- The Japanese today are not surprised by Gen. Douglas MacArthur's ruling upholding all the sentences of the international tribunal against Hideki Tojo and the other war criminals. All attention is now concentrated on the possible eventual results, particularly with reference to Emperor Hirohito.

LONDON, Nov. 24 -- It seemed apparent in London tonight that Britain and the United States were preparing to make concessions in the Ruhr question to the French fears of a future resurgence of Germany's war-making power. These two concessions appeared to be in the making:

The initiation of tax selling dealt a new blow yesterday to the stock market, which sagged to within striking distance of the post-election lows. Although liquidation never became acute, supporting bids were lacking in almost all instances and final quotations showed inroads of fractions to 2 points, with the composite rate down 1.71 points on the day.
DETROIT, Nov. 24 (AP) -- The nation's truck builders are catching up with their order lists on heavy-type vehicles, but are still behind on other types.
PARIS, Nov. 24 -- The United Nations Kashmir Commission's report is "an accurate account" of the situation," Sir Girja Shankar Bajpai, Secretary General of the Indian Foreign Office, said here today.
School let out yesterday for the four-day Thanksgiving week-end, but for pupils of the Professional Children's School there was no holiday.

Nick Bolkovac, Pitt tackle who startled the football world with the touchdown run that upset Penn State, gained further honors yesterday. He was named lineman of the week in The Associated Press poll.

CHICAGO, Nov. 24 -- Grain markets closed on a strong rally on the Board of Trade today after December wheat had declined 2 1/2 cents a bushel and corn, 2 1/4 cents in the early trading. Short covering to even up for the Thanksgiving Day holiday was said to be the main factor in causing the late rally.

The Isbrandtsen Steamship Company announced yesterday that it had received word from its Port Said agents that the Egyptian Government had released 4,000 bags of rice seized with thirty-eight demilitarized halftrack trucks from among the cargo of the freighter Flying Trader.

An interest cost of 2.49 per cent was reported as the best bid yesterday for $3,250,000 of road bonds of Wharton County, Tex., due from 1950 to 1968. Subject to award, a group headed by Drexel Co. reoffered the bonds at prices to yield 1.15 to 2.70 per cent.
While Coach Ed Danowski was sending the Fordham football squad through a final scrimmage yesterday, a squad of student volunteers also was put on the alert for N.Y.U.

A few states, including New Jersey, Connecticut and Pennsylvania, require thorough inspection of all motor vehicles, generally once or twice a year. It is not uncommon for a resident of one of these states to drive into nearby New York State to register his vehicle and thus avoid such an inspection.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday closed 5 to 16 points net lower.

The "fourth round" of wage increases has entered the negotiating stage in three Eastern industrial centers in the heavy metal casting and machining industries, it was learned here yesterday. Industry members said the negotiations usually precede other national wage talks by about three months and therefore are an indication of further negotiations by others next spring.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 24 -- A network of regional deposit libraries which would help to conserve building space and provide books otherwise unavailable to smaller institutions and communities was recommended here today by James T. Babb, librarian of Yale University, in his annual report.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -- The National Labor Relations Board took jurisdiction today in a secondary boycott case growing out of a strike of carpenters engaged in remodeling a home.

BRUSSELS, Nov. 24 -- A mass of statistical data and a long commentary will be submitted tomorrow to the Organization for European Economic Cooperation in Paris by the Netherlands, Belgium and Luxembourg in reply to criticism that the Benelux nations have failed to submit adequate detailed long-term programs for the Marshall Plan operations.
Santa Claus, that master of toy making, has gone budget-minded this year, judging by the gay array of toys now in department stores awaiting his official arrival tomorrow for pre-Christmas chats.

Mr. and Mrs. James M. Beck will give a reception tomorrow afternoon at their home, 300 Park Avenue, to introduce to society Mr. Beck's daughter, Miss Virginia Clare Beck. The debutante was graduated from Linden Hall Academy last June and is studying art in New York.

The first of a series of international ring matches planned by Promoter Harry Markson as part of his campaign to revive interest in boxing hereabouts, is scheduled for tomorrow night when Arthur King, British Empire lightweight champion, makes his local debut in a ten-round battle against Chester Rico, rugged Bronxite, at the St. Nicholas Arena.

Intervention by a Federal mediator yesterday ended for the time being the threat of a strike Saturday morning against the Hudson Manhattan Railroad Company that would have tied up the Hudson tubes to New Jersey and affected 215,000 commuters.

Dr. George Gallup proposed yesterday a new method of reporting election polls in which an effort would be made to find out how undecided voters will cast their ballots by learning how they voted in previous elections and where they stand on controversial issues.

Miss Muriel Patricia Cohan, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Andrew Cohan of Brooklyn, was married to George Drapeau Jr. of New York, son of Mr. and Mrs. Drapeau of Brunswick, Me., yesterday morning in the Lady Chapel of St. Patrick's Cathedral.

CAIRO, Egypt, Nov. 24 -- There are now 250,000 Arab refugees -- 100,000 of them without any shelter -- exposed to the autumn rains in "indescribably bad conditions" in the Palestine coastal strip between Gaza and the Egyptian border, Frederick Beard, Cairo representative of the United Nations Disaster Relief organization, said today.

LONDON, Nov. 24 -- Speakers in the House of Lords, who included some of Britain's greatest experts on airpower, asserted today that superior air forces were the Western Powers best safeguard against Soviet aggression.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 24 -- The present-day college undergraduate, to a far greater degree than his pre-war counterpart, has "a readiness to identify himself with religion," according to a survey by Dr. Donald B. Aldrich, dean of the Princeton University Chapel here.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Nov. 24 -- Brazilian marines dispersed with tear-gas bombs last night a noisy crowd of sailors from naval vessels in the harbor here, who marched in a body to the Senate chamber, where the governmental pay-rise bill was being discussed.

The fire at 1624 Fulton Street, Brooklyn, yesterday was only a one-alarm affair officially. To John Smith, 26-year-old truck driver, of 535 Throop Avenue, however, it was an important blaze. Mr. Smith, who is waiting for appointment to the Fire Department, rescued a 45-year-old mother from the building.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -- Secretary of State George C. Marshall refused to throw any light on his plans for continuing in office or resigning when he held his first news conference at the State Department this afternoon since returning from Paris.
LOWESTOFT, England, Nov. 24 -- The British Government, conducting a series of scientific investigations here, has explored the supersonic detection of the varieties of fish swimming under a trawler.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., Nov. 24 -- In a setting of white chrysanthemums in the Garden City Hotel this afternoon, Miss Laurine Elizabeth Collins, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Wilbur Mausby Collins, was married to Richard Lindsay Foote, son of Mrs. Helen Mann Foote of New York and of the late Walter Douglas Foote.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 (UP) -- The United States Circuit Court of Appeals today set aside an order by Secretary of Agriculture Charles F. Brannan establishing refined sugar allotments for Puerto Rico.
PROVIDENCE, R.I., Nov. 24 (AP) -- A spirited offensive duel between Brown and Colgate looms for the fortieth game of their football rivalry tomorrow morning at Brown Stadium.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 (AP) -- Strict Federal regulation of bank holding companies was recommended today to the House Small Business Committee.
LONDON, Nov. 24 -- The stock markets here were generally quiet today but prices remained firm. Leading industrials rallied after a dull start, with stores outstanding.

PARIS, Nov. 24 -- Premier Henri Queuille today obtained three favorable votes from the National Assembly and one specifically expressed confidence in Government action to eliminate Communist strategy from the current coal strike and from future labor conflicts in France.

NANKING, Nov. 24 (AP) -- Chinese Government planes flew back into the battle of Suchow today, and press accounts asserted that the new Communist offensive had been thrown back on both the east and south.

VIENNA, Nov. 24 -- Information obtainable in Catholic quarters in Budapest and from reports from a considerable number of refugees arriving in Vienna indicate that a "confession" is expected to provide the grounds for expelling or arresting of Joseph Cardinal Mindszenty, Primate of Hungary.

Work on the United Nations headquarters, between First Avenue and Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive from Forty-second to Forty-seventh Street, is two months behind schedule, Robert Moses, the city's construction coordinator, said yesterday.

The continued decline in the rate of savings held by the nation's 532 mutual savings banks shows that in the face of maintenance of national income at record levels, people are finding it harder and harder to make ends meet, William L. Maude, president of the National Association of Mutual Savings Banks, said yesterday.

I "Oedipus -- Myth and Complex: A Review of Psychoanalytic Theory," by Patrick Mullahy, will be published by Heritage Press on Tuesday. It is a study of the development of psychoanalytical theory, with an outline of the major theories of Freud, Jung, Adler, Rank, Horney, Fromm and Sullivan.

LONDON, Nov. 24 -- A British request for the assistance of United States technical experts in building a strategic railway link between British territories in Central and East Africa is being favorably considered by the Economic Cooperation Administration office here.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -- The lurid type of comic books have become such "a headache for city governments" that about fifty cities have taken steps toward regulation of sales, the United States Conference of Mayors reported here today.

Older people should not be "put on a shelf" for they are doing too many interesting things in the world, Welfare Commissioner Raymond M. Hilliard told the members of the William Hodson Community Center, Tremont and Third Avenues, the Bronx, yesterday.

Freedom Train is back in this city after a run of 35,000 miles through all forty-eight states, with stops in 320 cities. Three million two hundred thousand persons have seen its 127 exhibits. Forty-five million, or nearly one-third of our total population, are estimated to have taken some part in the "rededication" ceremonies held where the train has halted.

With very few out-of-town buyers remaining in the market over the Thanksgiving holiday, buying activity on women's apparel at the wholesale level was very light yesterday. The lull was reflected in production as well as selling, it was pointed out, as many firms will

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -- In a move to "police" retail automobile sales of mulcting practices disclosed recently before the House (Macy) Investigating Subcommittee, the Hudson Motor Car Company of Detroit advised that group today that it had adopted dealer policies under which sales would be made as follows:

The question at issue in Venezuela -- which apparently still can be answered either way -- is whether a small group of army officers, doubtless backed by many of those who profited most during the long dictatorial regime of Juan Vicente Gomez, are again to rule Venezuela or whether a democratically elected Government that is obviously supported by a great majority of the people is to govern.

TORONTO, Nov. 24 (Canadian Press) -- France's four-man military jumping team tonight won the International Officers' Team Challenge Trophy for the first time since 1927 at the final horse show program of the Royal Winter Fair.

The Salvation Army and the National Retail Dry Goods Association deserve a pat on the back for their joint plans to make many underprivileged children happier this Christmas through their proposed "Christmas Tree Caravan." The proposal calls for the installation of special Christmas trees in hundreds of department and specialty stores throughout the country.

TORONTO, Nov. 24 (AP) -- Defenseman Hal Laycoe scored his first goal of the season early in the third period tonight to enable the Montreal Canadiens to tie Toronto, 3 -- 3, before 13,987 fans. The deadlock was the third straight for the world champion Maple Leafs, who haven't won a National Hockey League game since Oct. 30.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -- Secretary of State George C. Marshall said today that the United States Government was considering what assistance it could properly give to the Chinese Government in the present critical situation.
Volume selling by trade and commissioned houses unsettled the rubber futures market on Commodity Exchange yesterday. Prices declined 50 to 65 points in a turnover of 1,370 long tons.

England is making the "most spectacular recovery" of any European country, Douglas Fairbanks Jr. declared yesterday at the Pierre Hotel. He made this observation after a three-month tour abroad in the dual role of chairman of the Share Through CARE (Cooperative for American Remittances to Europe) and vice president of the American Association for the United Nations.

A vacant plot 100 by 100 on the east side of Beach Sixty-seventh Street, 100 feet south of Larkin Street, in Arverne, Queens, has been sold by the Arverne Realty Corporation to Jack Kraminitz, who plans to improve it with one-family houses.

Would it be out of order to advise the statesmen and scientists who are discussing the question of international control of the atomic bomb to re-read some of the French philosophers of the eighteenth century, that period so justly called the "Enlightenment"?

The net income of Hiram Walker-Gooderham Worts, Ltd., and wholly owned subsidiaries rose to a new high of $24,870,572 in the fiscal year ended on Aug. 31, last, from $18,879,570 in the previous year, it was announced yesterday.

Formation of a Japan Christian University Foundation to promote support for the establishment of an international non-sectarian university of graduate standing near Tokyo, was announced yesterday by the Rev. Dr. Ralph E. Diffendorfer, foreign secretary of the board of missions and church extension of the Methodist Church.

LAKE SUCCESS, Nov. 24 -- The first United Nations International Children's Emergency Fund shipment of $150,000 worth of medical supplies will leave this country for Communist-held areas in northern China next month, it was announced here today by Maurice Pate, executive director of the fund.

PORTLAND, Ore., Nov. 24 -- The Congress of Industrial Organizations charted today a politically active future, with rejection of all proposals for a third party, and heard a challenge from Justice William O. Douglas of the Supreme Court to labor to step into the international field and undertake America's Ambassadorship to a "new Europe" in a fight against totalitarianism.

An hour's variety program patterned on the old Sunday night shows at the Winter Garden is planned for the NBC video network after the first of the year. It would be produced by Michael Todd and would be offered from 10 to 11 P. M. Sundays.

Mr. and Mrs. Russell C. Leffingwell and Mr. and Mrs. Edward Pulling gave a supper dance last night at Mr. and Mrs. Leffingwell's home, 38 East Sixty-ninth Street, for Miss E. Joan Pulling, debutante granddaughter and daughter, respectively of the hosts.
Visitors to the opening of the Freedom Train today in Arlington, S.I., will be witness to the un usual method by which Guatemala has been introducing herself to North Americans these last few weeks.

Top officers of the Brotherhood of Railway and Steamship Clerks, AFL, announced yesterday that they would urge 6,000 members of the union employed by the Railway Express Agency to end a slowdown strike against the company at midnight tonight.

EASTON, Pa., Nov. 24 (U.P.) -- A raging controversy developed today over whether Lafayette College rejected a bid to play in the Sun Bowl football game at El Paso, Tex., on New Year's Day because a Negro halfback would not be permitted to play.

The retirement of Moshe Rudinow as cantor of Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Avenue and Sixty-fifth Street, was announced yesterday by the board of trustees. He had requested retirement because of illness from which he had not completely recovered.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 24 (AP) -- Further progress toward settlement of the eighty-four-day-old West coast shipping strike was announced tonight by Harry Bridges' CIO longshoremen and the waterfront employers. They reached "tentative agreement" on three basic issues -- use of jointly controlled hiring halls, vacations and grievance and arbitration procedure.
The nation's security organization is slowly being modified to fit the dangerous pattern of the atomic age.

A news dispatch from Moscow, reporting that Soviet scientists had found the "greatest dinosaur graveyard in the world" in the Gohi Desert of Mongolia, was hailed here yesterday as an announcement of great paleontological significance.
Financial, commodity and livestock exchanges throughout the United States will be closed today in observance of Thanksgiving Day. Canadian and European markets will operate as usual.

MEXICO CITY, Nov. 24 -- First-aid stations will be established along the Pan-American highway soon for the first time in the motoring history of Mexico, delegates to the eighth annual meeting of the Inter-American Federation of Auto Clubs decided today.

A Republican leader in the Eleventh Assembly District, who refused to waive immunity in the grand jury investigation of alleged tampering with voting machines, was warned that his refusal may mean loss of a $3,340-a-year job with the Board of Elections, District Attorney Frank S. Hogan announced yesterday.

LONDON, Nov. -- 24 The majority of passengers on the liner Queen Elizabeth, who have been living absolutely free for five days in the greatest luxury of anyone in Britain, declared tonight that they would not leave the ship, which was stranded at Southampton by the New York dock strike.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 24 -- Pennsylvania and Cornell will end their successful football campaigns on Franklin Field tomorrow before a crowd expected to pass 78,000.

A hearty holiday atmosphere, with candle light, flowers and happy voices, pervaded the long, lonely halls of Bellevue Hospital last night. In anticipation of today's Thanksgiving feast that will include all that their therapeutic diets allow, more than 500 patients gathered in the main rotunda of the hospital to sing and laugh through a program presented by fellow victims of disease or accident.

DOBBS FERRY, N.Y., Nov. 24 -- The merging of the Tarrytown, Dobbbs Ferry and Ossining Hospitals came one step closer today when the Board of Trustees of the Dobbs Ferry and Ossining Hospiits approval of the plan "in principle," as had been done earlier by boards of the other hospitals.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -- The Columbia Pictures Corporation, New York, filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement covering 1,414 additional shares of its no-par value common stock that is to be sold by Harry Cohn and Jack Cohn, president and executive vice president, respectively, and members of their families.

Red Strader of the New York Football Yankees is a fact-facing coach. When he spoke to the assembled writers at yesterday's luncheon at the Yankee Stadium, Red didn't predict a victory over the Buffalo Bills next Sunday but neither did he predict a defeat.

ROCHESTER, N. Y., Nov. 24 (AP) -- Directors of the Stromberg-Carlson Company declared today a stock dividend of one-tenth of a share for each share of common stock, payable to stockholders of record next Dec. 15. Payments will be made Jan. 3.

Today the taut, tart, angry-red cranberry again wears the flush of triumph in his inimitable place on the groaning Thanksgiving table. His skin reflects his blood pressure justly -- his has been a tough grind. It takes three years to come up from a seed in the bog to the sauce on the board.

DUESSELDORF, Germany, Nov. 24 -- During the past six months a number of men who held positions of managerial and administrative importance in the Ruhr coal, iron and steel industries under the Nazi regime have returned to those industries.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 (AP) -- The Army apparently is picking and choosing its draftees more carefully than during the war, a Selective Service official said today.

PARIS, Nov. 24 -- A divergence of opinion on the manner in which the Berlin currency should be approached appeared today to have arisen among the Western delegations to the United Nations Security Council.
ROME, Nov. 24 -- News from Paris that the United States and Britain had reached agreement on final disposal of Italy's colonies caused an extremely profound and painful impression in Italy.
The determination of Chinese war brides to adapt themselves to the folkways of America and Chinatown simultaneously has created a sort of sociological chop suey that was not meant for tourists.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -- Publicly reported cash dividends by United States corporations rose 11 per cent last month over October of 1947 and 14 per cent in the three months ended with October over the like period of last year, the Department of Commerce announced today.

The success of a Western European federation in preserving peace would depend primarily on whether a resurgence of German economic strength could be controlled by such a union, speakers suggested last night on THE NEW YORK TIMES forum, "What's on Your Mind?" broadcast over station WQXR.

CARACAS, Venezuela, Nov. 24 -- The Venezuelan Army took over the nation today in a lightning coup that began at noon and ended in a few hours. No violence has been reported. The Army Chief of Staff, Lieut. Col. Marco Perez Jimenez, addressed the nation at 2 P.M., announcing that the Army had taken control "in view of the chaotic condition of the country."

PEIPING, China, Nov. 24 -- Peiping ceased being the major North China Supply base for the Chinese Air Force today as the final transfers of personnel, dependents and heavy equipment to Tsingtao were completed.

More than 50 per cent of the leather goods plants in this city are operating at 50 per cent of capacity or less, the Commerce and Industry Association of New York reported yesterday following a survey.

Seventy-six bids were made yesterday for the four-story tenement house at 1072 Third Avenue before it was knocked down for $34,000 at a sale conducted in the Vesey Street salesroom by Henry Brady, auctioneer. The final bid was $4,000 over the assessed valuation

NORMAN, Okla., Nov. 24 (AP) -- The University of Oklahoma football players voted unanimously today to "consider any bowl invitation" if they win their final regular game Saturday. Coach Bud Wilkinson said the Sooners had ruled their decision would hinge on defeating Oklahoma A. M. College.

Denouncing Great Britain as "still the No. 1 enemy" of Israel, Menachem Begin, former commander of the Irgun Zvai Leumi, underground group in Palestine, declared yesterday that the Bernadotte plan, "the child of British intrigue," should be rejected in its entirety.
CHICAGO, Nov. 24 (UP) -- Coach Bob Voigts, whose Northwestern Wildcats won the Big Nine Rose Bowl berth, today received a five-year extension of his football contract.

Moura Lympany, English pianist, who gave her first New York recital last night at Town Hall, aroused fervent enthusiasm from a large audience by her highly distinguished playing. In an exacting program of classic, romantic and modern works, the handsome, modest musician at once established herself as an artist of decided importance, both as technician and interpreter.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -- The United States is quietly urging Norway, Denmark, Iceland, Eire and Portugal to consider associating themselves with the proposed North Atlantic Security Pact. No direct proposals have been made to these countries. Their cooperation, in one form or another, with the United States, Canada and the so-called Brussels powers, however, is regarded here as necessary if an effective Atlantic security system is to evolve.

The recent statement of the Roman Catholic bishops in the United States criticizing the United States Supreme Court ruling that religious instruction in public schools was unconstitutional, was characterized yesterday by the Rev. Dr. Stanley I. Stuber, chairman of the Commission on Religious Freedom of the Baptist World Alliance, as "a dangerous weapon used for extremely selfish ends."

Having nothing cosmic in mind, Robert E. McEnroe has written a comedy about an old folks' home, "The Silver Whistle," put on by the Theatre Guild at the Biltmore last evening. This turns out to be quite a satisfactory idea. For Mr. McEnroe has an uncommonly amiable sense of humor, and he also has Jose Ferrer in the leading part.

SAN BRUNO, Calif., Nov. 24 (AP) -- A crowd of approximately 8,000 watched the first public workout of Calumet Farm's Citation at Tanforan between races today. With his regular exercise boy, Freeman McMillan, aboard, the 3-year-old colt breezed five furlongs in 1:01 3/5.

PARIS, Nov. 24 -- A limiting clause stipulating that all rights proclaimed in the International Declaration of Human Rights must be in consonance with the purposes and principles of the United Nations was added to the declaration today.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Nov. 24 -- Navy completed the rougher phases of its preparation for Army this afternoon in the muddy going of Thompson Stadium, and tonight the regiment of midshipmen gathered on Farragut Field with their drags for the bonfire and pep rally that annually marks the crescendo of the football season's fireworks here.

The nation's crude oil production averaged 5,658,550 barrels daily last week, according to the American Petroleum Institute. This is a new record high and an increase of 32,150 barrels over the figure for the preceding week. A year ago, production averaged 5,275,300 barrels a day.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 (AP) -- Following is the text of President Truman's speech today to the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization meeting.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Nov. 24 -- A United Nations spokesman announced tonight that agreement had been reached with the Israelis and Arabs for the fixing of the first provisional truce lines in the Bethlehem area and of a demilitarized zone within that area.

BOWIE, Md., Nov. 24 (AP) -- Mrs. O.L. Nyberg's Irisen, a filly that seldom runs a bad race, took the $10,000 added W.P. Burch Memorial Handicap today. With Jackie Robertson completing a double, the daughter of Sweep Like coasted into the wire five lengths in front of the Maine Chance Farm's Royal Blood, with the Brookmeade Stable's Dart By third, four additional lengths back.

The Long Island Railroad has purchased two large adjoining plots in Port Washington, L.I., for the erection of the eighth in a series of thirteen electric sub-stations. The land, acquired from the Brenda Realty Corporation, is on the east side of South Bayles Avenue, 250 feet north of Willowdale Avenue.

Austin Hogan resumed his full duties yesterday as president of Local 100, Transport Workers Union, CIO, and let it be known that he and two other officers intended to ignore the charges on which the local's recent acting officials had ordered them to stand trial on Dec. 11.

MINEOLA, L.I., Nov. 24 -- Nassau County's budget for 1949 was criticized for an hour and a half at a hearing in the Board of Supervisors room here today. Expenditures for relief, capital improvements and salaries were the principal targets.
LYONS, Ga., Nov. 24 (AP) -- A Negro was shot to death on a rural road near here Saturday night and tonight the state ordered an inquiry on how he met death.

ATHENS, Nov. 24 -- Greece's 88-year-old Premier Themistocles Sophoulis lay on a stretcher tonight in his office in the Parliament building, attended by three physicians, after he had collapsed at his desk earlier in the evening.
High above this city, in the crater of an extinct volcano, virtually all the known war dead who are not being sent home from the Pacific will be buried during the next year.

Most carpet retailers will finish the year with small dollar gains compared with 1947 despite serious sales slumps since July, buyers predicted yesterday. With the active selling season ending this week and further sales declines expected next month, they agreed that big volume chalked up last Spring is responsible for the expected slight over-all gains for the year.
ALBANY, Nov. 24 -- The Public Service Commission granted today a second temporary one-cent fare increase to the Surface Transportation Corporation and the Avenue B and East Broadway Transit Company.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -- The consent decree through which Eastman Kodak Company would refrain from alleged monopolistic practices in color motion-picture films was praised today by Attorney General Tom C. Clark. The agreement in the decree, he stated, would "open the color motion-picture industry to competition."
WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 (AP) -- Secretary of State Marshall's statement on control of the German Ruhr follows:

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 24 -- Business in the Pittsburgh district sagged a little last week, according to the Bureau of Business Research, University of Pittsburgh. Most of the drop was accounted for by a slightly larger-than-seasonal decline in freight shipments, although the volume of trade was somewhat lower also.

An agreement was reached early today in the longshoremen's strike that has tied up the Port of New York and shipping along the East Coast for more than two weeks, it was announced at 3:35 A.M. by Cyrus S. Ching, director of the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 (AP) -- Moscow radio broadcasts recorded today by Government monitors pictured life in the United States as pretty grim, especially for the American "peasants."

VIENNA, Nov. 24 -- Headquarters of the United States Forces in Austria charged today that the Soviet statement yesterday that Dr. Margarethe Ottillinger was a United States spy was a lie and an "insidious" example of Soviet opposition to "the reconstruction of Austria along sovereign, democratic lines."

Prof. Maurice Finkelstein and Louis Toth resigned yesterday from the City Rent Commission. Their decision apparently was made at a fifteen-minute conference with Mayor O'Dwyer and John M. Murtagh, Commissioner of Investigation, who is inquiring into the commission's activities.

Following submission of new statements on the Berlin situation by Russia and the Western Powers, the "neutral" members of the Security Council are again pressing their efforts to find a solution of a problem which is the key to all further peace negotiations. One must hope that these efforts will succeed, but the chances for success fade with each passing day.

HALIFAX, Nov. 24 (AP) -- Halifax longshoremen decided at a closed meeting tonight to handle all ships entering this port pending a decision on their status by a Federal arbitration board, according to usually reliable sources.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -- The National Labor Relations Board today ordered four days' back pay for workers whose employer locked them out as a penalty for striking without first using the grievance machinery of their contract.
SANFORD, Fla., Nov. 24 (AP) -- First Baseman Johnny Mize and President Horace Stoneham of the New York Giants came to terms here tonight on a 1949 contract.

Many top United States military and political leaders in Europe are agreed that this country should establish diplomatic relations with Franco Spain as a defensive measure against the spread of communism, James A. Farley, former Postmaster General and chairman of the Democratic National Committee, told members of the Overseas Press Club yesterday.

Thanksgiving came a day early yesterday to forty-six orphans who arrived in this country within the last month. The children, ranging in age from 8 to 18 years, are Displaced Persons who are awaiting adoption at the Bronx shelter of the United States Committee for the Care of European Children.

A new commercial and social venture for Harlem was announced yesterday by an investment group that plans to open a department store next Wednesday at 144 West 125th Street. Sections of the store will be sub-let to individual merchants, "as many of them Negroes as possible," it was said.

Each day of the year brings its own occasion for thanksgiving, but at this season by "old observance, deeply embedded in thought and habit," we hold a special celebration of our blessings. It is a day of leisurely and not too exacting inventory, appropriately set in the harvest season.

Mayor O'Dwyer and Borough President Cashmore will attend with members of the Board of Transportation Sunday at 11 A. M. the formal opening of the extension of the IND Fulton Street subway line in Brooklyn. The two-mile extension, which includes four new stations, cost the city $47,000,000 for the overall project.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 24 -- John Cromwell has withdrawn from his assignment as director of "I Married a Communist" at RKO, and Nicholas Ray is expected to take over the project, it was learned today. The photoplay has been much in the news as a special Howard Hughes project at the studio, but its cast and starting date are indefinite because of scenario revision, which is now in progress.

Production of paper and pulp should continue at present record-breaking levels during 1949 "unless we are in for something we cannot foresee," E.W. Tinker, executive secretary of the American Paper and Pulp Association, declared yesterday at the fifty-fifth roundtable luncheon meeting of the Baldwin Paper Company, Inc., in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.
MOUNT HOLLY, N. J., Nov. 24 (AP) -- An admission that Burlington County officials sought to conceal the bridge deal from Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll was made today by Freeholder Frank A. Snover.

ONE of baseball's most tragic figures died the other day. Hack Wilson could have become one of the all-time greats but he couldn't handle prosperity and faded out before his time. He was an incongruous looking chap who was built like two men sitting down. There probably never was a man to star in the big leagues who had less resemblance to a ball player than Hack.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 (AP) -- The Economic Cooperation Administration today granted a $47,000,000 recovery loan to Belgium. That completed its 1948 lending program.

Seaboard Western Airlines, Inc., largest non-scheduled international all-freight carrier, announced yesterday that its present westbound shipments over the North Atlantic were more than 100 per cent heavier than at this time last year.
BOSTON, Nov. 24 -- John L. Sullivan, Secretary of the Navy, said today that unification of the armed forces under the new National Security Act was proceeding "effectively and harmoniously."

AKRON, Ohio, Nov. 24 (UP) -- Officials of Peoples' Hospital today said they were "awfully sorry" over a surgical comedy of errors in which the wrong operation was performed on the wrong woman and added they probably wouldn't charge her for it.

LONDON, Nov. 24 -- The British Government introduced in the House of Commons today proposed legislation to extend the period of compulsory military training under the new National Service Act from twelve to eighteen months.

In an unusual operation yesterday the 10,000-ton liner Ancon, inbound from the Canal Zone with 126 passengers, was inched in between two other liners in the slip separating Piers 64 and 65 and was moored hull-to-hull with her sister ship, the Cristobal.

BOSTON, Nov. 24 -- Dr. Thomas H. Reed of Wethersfield, Conn., a Boston-born municipal consultant, called today for "an intelligent, aggressive, well-led citizen movement" to join in "uprooting Mayor James M. Curley from his official throne."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24, (UP) -- The long strike of National Airlines pilots was settled today on a "mutually satisfactory basis," representatives of the company and Airline Pilots Association, AFL, announced tonight.

By dividing and blockading Berlin, the Soviets have forced the city into a siege economy. The material needs arising from this situation are well understood and are being satisfied to a great extent by the airlift. But the financial needs do not seem to be as well understood by the Allied authorities.

STAFFORD, England, Nov. 24 (Reuters) -- The president of the National Society for the Retention of Corporal Punishment in Schools, who manufactures canes, was beaten tonight with one of his own canes by pupils of a school near here.

Fernand Martel, French-Canadian baritone, who has been heard here as Pelleas in the New York City Opera Company's production of Debussy's "Pelleas et Melisande," gave his first New York recital last night at Times Hall.

Miss Mildred Beckerman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Newman Beckerman of 165 West Ninety-first Street, was married yesterday afternoon in her parents' home to Mortimer B. Wolf, son of Henry Wolf and the late Mrs. Wolf, also of this city.
While oil company executives here have received only meager information concerning developments in Venezuela, they are a bit concerned over affairs there.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -- President Truman today urged before the fifty-eight-nation Food and Agriculture Organization the negotiation of a new international wheat agreement. He expressed the hope that two more great wheat-growing nations, Argentina and Russia, would join the FAO, which may become the new negotiating agency for agricultural commodity agreements.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 (AP) -- The United States needs at least 40,000 more nurses right now, Robert C. Goodwin, Director of Employment Security, said today.

Park Commissioner Robert Moses, whose vigorous attack almost brought down the walls of Battery Park's Castle Clinton (the old Aquarium), has mellowed in the matter of another historic landmark, it was noted yesterday.

PARIS, Nov. 24 -- The French Government was understood today to be exchanging views with other nations including Britain and the United States in an effort to find a common basis for final disposition of the Italian colonies that would strengthen its policy of collaboration and friendship with Italy.

Implications of a more competitive era behind the statistical dip in living costs is jolting advertising planners into sharper thinking much more than recent forecasts and warnings made in the atmosphere of rising costs, key advertising officials commented yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 (AP) -- The United States Chamber of Commerce asked Congress today to find out whether the Army and Navy are competing unfairly with private business through their post exchange stores.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Nov. 24 -- The United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization will be ready to distribute a world-wide radio program early next year, the Director General's office announced today.

A variety of lines of commercial and industrial optical goods have been reduced because of local overstocks, industrial distributors revealed here yesterday. Discounts extended for clearance sales range from 10 to 25 per cent beyond usual prices, they said.
PARIS, Nov. 24 -- "The Democratic Republic of Viet Nam" today filed an application for admission to the United Nations.

One of our friends, a scholar in the byways of erudition and one who takes the old traditions much to heart, startled us the other day by expressing relief that this traditional last Thursday in November had been designated by the President as the day of thanksgiving.

Dr. Edward M. Bernecker, Commissioner of Hospitals, promised yesterday a "complete investigation" into the case of a young woman who was pronounced dead by a Bellevue Hospital ambulance attendant and then found to be alive and revived by a patrolman assigned to watch the body.

BOSTON, Nov. 24 - -Senator J. Howard McGrath of Rhode Island, chairman of the Democratic National Committee, denied today that his appointment as a trustee of the Rhode Island Charities Trust was the result of poltiical influence.

Alvin Udell, treasurer of the state committee of the American Labor party, has submitted his resignation, it was learned yesterday. He had been state treasurer since last Jan. 7, when the state organization came under the complete domination of left-wing elements.

An extra dividend of 75 cents, together with the regular quarter]y 50-cent dividend on the common stock, both payable on Jan. 3, have been declared by the American Snuff Company. It is the first extra paid in several years.
TARRYTOWN, N.Y., Nov. 24 -- A woman and her teen-age daughter were murdered this evening by a man who then killed himself in a strange tangle of violence.

BERLIN, Nov. 24 -- The Soviet-sponsored, Communist-dominated "People's Council" issued an appeal to the occupying powers today to call a meeting of the Council of Foreign Ministers to pave the way for a peace treaty with Germany.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -- Sena- J. Howard McGrath of Rhode Island will continue as chairman of the Democratic National Committee, at the request of President nan himself. The decision was hed, it is understood, during Senator's visit with the President the week-end before last at West, Fla.

ALBANY, Nov. 24 -- New York City's municipal colleges must admit qualified up-state students to their teacher-training program tuition free and on the same basis as city residents if they wish to receive a $3,000,000 state subsidy authorized by the 1948 Legislature, the board of trustees of the State University of New York ruled today.

ALBANY, Nov. 24 -- Earl O. Shreve, president of the United States Chamber of Commerce, advocated today a sharp reduction in taxes on dividends, income and capital gains as the means to encourage new risk capital investment.

The prospective new chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, Mr. Dingell of Michigan, has announced that one of the first matters to be brought before Congress when it meets in January will be a reconsideration of the Hull Reciprocal Trade Agreements Act.

A young man befriended by a Good Samaritan for five weeks was among three brothers held in $1,000 bail each yesterday by Magistrate Samuel Orr in Bronx Magistrate's Court charged with having taken part in a $1,500 burglary in the benefactor's home.

Resort-minded individuals were given a quick look at some new beach and sportswear during luncheon yesterday at the Pierre Hotel. The fashion show consisted of designs by Carolyn Schnurer now at Best Co., Peck Peck, Saks Fifth Avenue, Henry Bendel, Bonwit Teller and Lord Taylor.
A touching reunion took place here yesterday between a pretty 25-year-old member of the l ian wartime underground and two American airmen whom she led through the German lines in 1943.

PARIS, Nov. 24 -- The British delegation to the united Nations General Assembly plans to oppose a United States amendment that would eliminate from a pending British resolution on Palestine a paragraph endorsing the Bernadotte report "as a basis for peaceful settlement," authoritative sources stated tonight.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities, the Federal Reserve Board announced today, shows the following principal changes for the week ended Nov. 17:

DUBLIN, Nov. 2 -- Prime Minister John A. Costello told the Dail today that despite passage of the Republic of Ireland bill the country would continue to enjoy all citizenship and trade preference privileges of a member state of the British Commonwealth.

F. J. Andre, president of Sheffield Farms, announced yesterday that if his company paid farmers a cent less for milk on Jan. 1 and another cent less on April 1, "these savings will be immediately passed on to the consumer" by similar reductions in retail prices.

New York public school officials tend to minimize deficiencies in the city's education system and thereby prevent adequate appropriations from the state, the United Parents Associations charged yesterday.

TULSA, Okla., Nov. 24 (AP) -- Sinclair Prairie Oil Company today posted an increase of 35 cents a barrel for crude oil, Chairman of the Board W.L. Connelly and President H.L. Phillips announced. The new price was effective at 7 A.M. today in all areas where Sinclair buys crude.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -- The Senate's Southerners, facing in the new Congress a strengthened phaanx backing the Truman civil-rights program, are considering a new type of delaying action, without abandoning their ultimate weapon, the filibuster.
Thankful for prosperity, despite rising costs, and with greater hope for future peace and security, New Yorkers were in a holiday mood last night for today's annual Thanksgiving Day.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Nov. 24 -- Keeping a firm rein on an Army team that will go into its big game with Navy on Saturday in the difficult role of an overwhelming favorite, Coach Earl Blaik today changed his previously announced plans and sent the cadet platoons through another full-dress scrimmage.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 (AP) -- The Air Force said today that it dumped a quantity of airplane engine valves at the end of the war because of "a critical storage problem."

Expressing satisfaction over the progress Italy has made, Ivan Matteo Lombardo, Italian Minister of Industry and Commerce, said yesterday that economic recovery of that country should be definitely in sight by 1952, when the European Recovery Program ends.

ALBANY, Nov. 24 -- The convictions of Harvey Stemmer and David Krakower, who were sentenced to five to ten years in prison for attempted bribery of members of the New York Giants professional football team, were unanimously affirmed today by the Court of Appeals.
Now old enough to be eligible for membership, the New York Public Library was formally inducted yesterday into the One Hundred Year Association, Inc.

LONDON, Nov. 24 -- British Communists are becoming so "audacious in their interference with labor unions that a fight to the finish must be waged against them by responsible labor leadership immediately," the General Council of the Trades Union Congress decided today.
PARIS, Nov. 24 -- Soviet Deputy Foreign Minister Andrei Y. Vishinsky made a frank declaration today that the veto was a political weapon and that Russia would not be "simpleton" enough to drop it.

DETROIT, Nov. 24 (AP) -- The Boston Bruins piled up a 4-1 lead in the first two periods and defeated the Red Wings, 5 to 3, tonight to take undisputed possession of the National Hockey League lead and force Detroit into a second-place tie with the Montreal Canadiens.
ALBANY, Nov. 24 (AP) -- The Court of Appeals affirmed today a lower court decision that part-time active duty in the armed forces did not entitle a reservist to civil service preference.

"What has happened to all the bucks?" seems to be the popular query of the New York deer hunters this season and many of them express concern over the future of the deer herds if the present ratio of bucks and does is not corrected.

CRANFORD, N. J., Nov. 24 -- Purchase of the former Nomahegan Golf Club property, a 56-acre tract adjacent to Nomahegan Park, as a site for a new campus was announcd today by Dr. Kenneth C. Mackay, president of Union Junior College and secretary to its board of trustees.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -- The intention of the United States and Great Britain to proceed with plans for placing industries in the Ruhr under German trusteeship subject to Western Allied supervision was announced today by Secretary of State Marshall notwithstanding French protests.
PARIS, Nov. 25 -- The Soviet Union indicated today that it might lift the veto that it cast to block United Nations membership for the new British Dominion of Ceylon.

WINNIPEG, Nov. 25 (Canadian Press) -- The Thanksgiving Day holiday in the United States resulted in decided lack of outside interest today in the Winnipeg Grain Exchange which caused oats and barley futures prices to move narrowly in a very dull session.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 -- In a message from Paris read to the opening session of the convention of Junior Hadassah, the Young Women's Zionist Organization of America today, Moshe Shertok, Israeli Minister of Foreign Affairs, called on the organization to become the "rallying point for young American Jewish womanhood in redoubling efforts for an effective response to the great historic challenge of our generation."

In the Spectator of London Sir Evelyn Wrench writes engagingly of places in England from which notable persons came to settle in this country. His point, quite frankly made, is that Englandh)0*0*0*ihas in these places a valuable dollar asset, and he is out to encourage American tourist traffic.

PARIS, Nov. 25 -- The renewed negotiations, now being conducted by the Kashmir Commission of the United Nations Security Council with India and Pakistan, hold out hope for a broad solution of the dispute between the two dominions, the Council was informed today.

Santa Claus will be available for interviews, starting today, at almost every department store in the city. Children who make the rounds this season will be reminded once again that old Saint Nick is indeed a remarkable fellow.

The Freedom Train was rededicated yesterday at a Thanksgiving Day ceremony when Mayor O'Dwyer officially welcomed back to the city the eight-coach exhibit of historical documents for a threeday stay on Staten Island before visiting other sections of the metropolitan area.

LAKE SUCCESS, Nov. 25-Within the last month, world-wide contributions to the global campaign of the United Nations Appeal for Children have been increased by more than $9,000,000, it was announced here today by officials of the organizations.

h)0*0*0*iAfter thanking God for the fruits of the earth, 150 members of the Vegetarian Society of New York crunched, munched, sipped and chewed for three hours the greens, nuts, potatoes and pies that millions elsewhere were using only as "trimmin's" in and around their turkey.

DETROIT, Nov. 25 (AP) -- Stalled on the ground, the Chicago Cardinals scored twice on passes and once on Jerry Davis' 69-yard punt return today to beat the stubborn Detroit Lions, 28 to 14, in a National Football League game. A Thanksgiving morning crowd of 22,957 fans saw the Cardinals take their eighth straight victory and their ninth in ten games this season.

NANKING, Nov. 25 (AP) -- The Chinese Nationalists reported some modest successes east of Suchow today, but heavy fighting farther south indicated that the Communists were maintaining their pressure on the approaches to this capital.

LONDON, Nov. 25 -- More than 500 guests attended the Thanksgiving Day dinner given here tonight by the American Society of London. Lord Goddard, Lord Chief Justice of England, speaking as guest of honor, said that the more the people of the United States and Britain understood each other whether in politics, business or social life, the closer friends they were likely to become.

The 45,000 striking longshoremen in East Coast ports from Hampton Roads, Va., to Portland, Me., are expected to ratify the agreement worked out early yesterday to end the walkout, and to be back on the job by Monday.

The defense discussions now in progress between Sweden, Norway and Denmark have some important implications for the Western Powers. These Powers are organizing their own defense, and for that purpose have already formed a West-European Union and are completing a North Atlantic Alliance to link the strength of the New World with that of the Old.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Nov. 25 -Brown added a final flourish to its most successful football campaign in sixteen years today by piling up the largest margin of victory it ever has registered in the traditional Thanksgiving Day battle with Colgate.

Though Mrs. Maud Ballington Booth has passed away, she has left to us the responsibility of remembering this Christmas time many mothers, wives and children in prisonshadowed homes. For over fifty-two years under her leadership, this ministry of bringing joy and the sense of someone's caring to those left fatherless and with little hope of Christmas cheer has been a vital part of her interest.
CHICAGO, Nov. 25 -- The postwar Army aims at producing a better citizen as well as a better soldier, Brig. Gen. C. T. Lanham, special assistant to Gen. Omar Bradley, Chief of Staff, declared tonight.

New Yorkers by the thousands took time out from their traditional feasting and gatherings at home yesterday to flock to places of worship in observance of Thanksgiving Day. They gave thanks for America's blessings and many attended interfaith services in demonstration of tolerance and unity.

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 25 -- An estimated crowd of 150,000, most of them children, massed on downtown sidewalks this morning to watch the L. Bamberger Co., annual Thanksgiving parade which started at the City Schools stadium.
LONDON, Nov. 25 -- A British policy of continued intimate association with the Irish Republic was announced by Prime Minister Attlee in the House of Commons today.
With traditional prayers, parades, feasts and sporting events, millions of Americans throughout the United States and the rest of the world celebrated Thanksgiving Day yesterday.

LONDON, Nov. 25 -- The Sadlersh) 0*0*0*iWells Ballet opened its season at Covent Garden tonight by unveiling "Don Juan," a new short piece with choreography by Frederick Ashton and music from Richard Straus.

Because of rising operating costs and diminishing cargoes a major reorganization has been ordered in the Pacific Coast structure of the American-Hawaiian Steamship Company, it was announced yesterday in a simultaneous statement here and in San Francisco by Lewis A. Lapham, president of the line.

Precautions have been ordered by Dr. Edward M. Bernecker, Commissioner of Hospitals, against any recurrence of an incident Tuesday, in which an ambulance attendant mistakenly left a young woman for dead. Dr. Bernecker, it was learned yesterday, has directed that internes be sent to check on all deaths reported by attendants responding to ambulance calls.

HACKENSACK, N.J., Nov. 25 -- Teaneck High overcame stubborn resistance by Hackensack to capture their annual football game, 13 -- 7, and with it the Northern New Jersey Interscholastic League championship with a record of five victories, one setback and one tie.

The American Smelting and Refining Company and its consolidated subsidiaries had a net income of $25,215,885 in the first nine months of this year, according to the statement signed jointly by Roger W. Straus, chairman, and H. Y. Walker, president, issued for publication today.

Progress in elimination of misleading and offensive advertising this year has been more than offset by new offenders, an official of the National Better Business Bureau, Inc., asserted yesterday. Some new concerns and older ones giving heavy promotion to new products, while not the most numerous among offenders, are conspicuous in making extreme claims, he said.

TANGIER, Morocco, Nov. 17 Putting Tangier on the equivalent of an airlift like Berlin's to circumvent an incipient Spanish blockade of this international city is being discussed in high administrative circles. The international zone, only a few hundred square miles in extent, produces almost no food, and is dependent chiefly on French Morocco for meat, vegetables, fruit and eggs.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 -- Associate Justice William O. Douglas of the Supreme Court is an unconventional man in speech, dress and ratiocination. Therefore it was appropriate that, if a Supreme Court justice was to make a political speech to a group with a special political interest, he should be the first in history to do so.

The policy advocated by your editorial of Nov. 20 might be summed up in these words "Let us increase our aid to China's Nationalist Government because the squeeze that Chiang's followers take out of our aid is a lesser evil than the squeeze that communism always takes out of human liberty."
