John Sterner of the Pioneer Club,h)0*0*0*icompeting in his first outdoor long distance walking event, captured individual honors yesterday in the thirty-eighth annual City Hall to Coney Island Thanksgiving Day handicap walk sponsored by the Walkers Club of America. Fifty-nine participated.

Jack Benny will appear with Bob Hope in a comedy sequence in Paramount's Bob Hope vehicle, "Easy Does It." According to the studio, Benny's stint, now being written and which is slated to be filmed on Monday, is "a gesture of friendship to Hope and Edmund Beloin, who is producing the comedy for Paramount and Hope Enterprises, Inc."

The article appearing under "Topics of the Times" on Nov. 15 is of great interest to Goodwill Industries of New York and its handicapped clients, who from "near trash" are enabled to obtain training and employment.

h)0*0*0*iO The resignations of two of Mayor O'Dwyer's appointees from the City Rent Commission have increased the need for a state legislative inquiry into the administration of city rent laws, Assemblyman Samuel Rabin, Republican, of Queens, declared yesterday. Prof. Maurice Finkelstein, chairman, and Louis Toth, member of the threeman commission, quit abruptly on Wednesday.

LONDON, Nov. 25 -- Investment stocks received a boost when it was announced on the stock markets that seventy subscriptions amounting to 70,000,000 ($280,000,000) had been offered for the 5,000,000 ($20,000,000) of Southern Rhodesia 3 per cent loan.

A community-wide program to curb juvenile delinquency in three areas of the Bronx is being mapped and will be released in January, J. Clarence Davies Jr., chairman of the steering committee of the Bronx Pilot Project of the New York City Youth Board, 500 Park Avenue, announced yesterday.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., Nov. 25 -This flourishing New Jersey suburban community has developed an unusual program to supplement the ordinary measures employed in combatting juvenile delinquency. Under the direction of Lieut. Joseph McHugh, special service officer in the Police Department, three playgrounds have been opened in the more densely populated areas.

LOS ANGELES, Calif., Nov. 25 (AP) -- The champion Cleveland Browns subdued the Los Angeles Dons today, 31 to 14, registering their twelfth straight victory in a drive for their third consecutive All-America Football Conference title.

CHICAGO, Nov. 25 (AP) -- Jim Conacher got four goals tonight and the Chicago Black Hawks escaped from the National Hockey League cellar with a 6-to-4 victory over the New York Rangers before 16,231 fans. The loss dropped the Rangers into last place.

CHICAGO, Nov. 25 -- Dean Thomas Clark Pollock of Washington Square College, New York University, cautioned tonighth)0*0*0*iagainst "overemphasis on the leveling tendency" in the American educational system.

I have read with approval the news item that Secretary Forrestal is considering official action to stop the present plethora of "Who dunnit not me" articles about military mistakes in the Second World War.

The Hudson Motor Company's quick reaction to the revelations of unconscionable trade practices in automobile sales -- revelations made by the House committee headed by W. Kingsland Macy -- should help regain goodwill for the automobile makers. It is a legitimate question to ask, though, why it required the adverse publicity of a Congressional investigation to bring this needed reform in trade practices.

The seven-story apartment house at 7 West Ninety-second Street, occupying a plot 84.2 by 100 feet, has been sold by Rosemont Realties, Inc., to the Irviss Realty Corporation for cash above mortgages amounting to $140,000, according to Jacob Streiner, lawyer, who represented the purchasers.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 25 -The conflict between RKO and Paramount over the subject of naval jet aviation has been resolved by an announcement from RKO that its film, "Jet Pilot," will not be "a service picture." Beirne Lay Jr. has completed a new draft of "Jet Pilot," which is now described by the studio as a "modern drama involving facets of the national defense program."

LONDON, Nov. 25 -- Lord Beaverbrook's Daily Express, the only major British newspaper that opposes United States aid to Britain, announced today the results of a poll showing that the majority of Britons disagree with the newspaper's opinion.

Capt. G. C. Cove, until recently temporary master of the Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary following the retirement last month of her previous master Capt. Cyril G. Illingsworth, has been appointed to the command of the world's second largest liner, it was announced here yesterday.

OLEAN, N.Y., Nov. 25 (AP) -- The St. Bonaventure football team had a close squeeze today, but escaped with a 20-14 victory over the Dons from the University of San Francisco before 9,000 fans in Forness Stadium.

To speak of reducing diets on the day after Thanksgiving may seem a little abrupt and perhaps even cruel. But it's possible that after yesterday's epicurean extravagances many people are earnestly resolving to do something about that excess poundage.

ROME, Nov. 25 -- The 42,000ton battleship Vittorio Veneto, once the pride of the Italian Navy, suffered the most ignominious fate that could befall a vessel of war when it was attached today as security for a debt that a private firm has claimed against the Government.
TORONTO, Nov. 25 -- Ending a year of speculation, the Evening Telegram today was purchased by George McCullagh, publisher of the Globe and Mail. The purchase price was announced as $3,610,000.

FROM 1865 until 1890 the Plains Indians of the old West fought their last heroic, pathetic wars to preserve their sacred hunting grounds and traditional way of life from the rapacious white men. Vastly outnumbered, pitifully inferior in equipment, never united among themselves, they had no more chance than did Luxembourg against Germany.

Brooklyn Prep's football operatives staged a courageous comeback in the waning minutes of their traditional game with St. John's Prep and secored two quick touchdowns te earn a twenty-five-all tie at Ebbets Field yesterday morning. A pre-noon crowd of 15,000 highly partisan spectators turned out to witness the thirty-first fray between the schools.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Nov. 25 (UP) -- Eight persons were sentenced to hang today for alleged murder and spying on orders of the United States Army Counter Intelligence Corps. Six of them were tried in absentia.
PARIS, Nov. 25 -- The proceedings of the United Nations:

PARIS, Nov. 25 -- Britain accepted today the United States view that a permanent settlement in Palestine should be reached on the dual basis of the United Nations General Assembly partition resolution and the Bernadotte plan.

CEDAR GROVE, N.J., Nov. 25 (AP) -- Mrs. Mildred Smith, 46 years old, town tax assessor, died of smoke poisoning and her husband, Howard, 53, was badly burned when flames and smoke rolled through their one-story home early today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 -- The Army announced today that enlisted men of the National Guard were eligible for twenty-five appointments to the United States Military Academy at West Point for the academic year beginning next July 1.

CARACAS, Venezuela, Nov. 25 -- Lieut. Col. Carlos Delgado Chalbaud, president of the new military junta formed in Venezuela today, declared that the Army would arrange for democratic elections as soon as possible and that the military leaders did not intend to remain in the government after the new elections.

LONDON, Friday, Nov. 25 -Gen. Lord Ismay, Chief of Staff to Winston Churchill in World War II, today described General Eisenhower's book "Crusade in Europe" as one worthy of its author despite its contentious passages on the invasion strategy.
BOWIE, Md., Nov. 25 (AP) -- Isidor Bieber's Palestinian, a son of the mud-loving Sun Again, was an easy winner today in the 25th running of the $10,000 added Endurance Handicap at Bowie.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Nov. 25 -Danish and Dutch delegates to the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization made a scathing criticism here today of the alleged inefficiency of the organization in its efforts to begin the "re-education" of the Germans.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 (AP) -The Department of Commerce reported tonight the United States pulp and paper business "has largely completed its post-war adjustment and for the most part is back to normal."

An automatic safety in the last quarter enabled Xavier High to top Fordham Prep, 9 -- 7, in their thrillpacked traditional clash yesterday at Fordham Field in the Bronx. A crowd of 7,000 looked on as Xavier retained the Mike Dunne Memorial Trophy for football supremacy between the Jesuit rivals.

Down Central Park West and Broadway to the accompaniment of lilting music and the continuous roar and applause of the crowds, Macy's annual Thanksgiving Day parade filed yesterday forenoon. From the West Side, East Side, all around the town and from far across the Hudson and East Rivers, came youngsters, fathers and mothers to line the route from Seventy-seventh Street and Central Park West, the starting point, to West Thirty-fourth Street, in front of Macy's.

PARIS, Nov. 25 -- For the first time in more than two years the United Nations reported tonight that it had made some progress toward ironing out the quarrels between Greece and her northern neighbors, Albania, Yugoslavia and Bulgaria.

GENEVA, Nov. 25 -- The United States has proposed a draft to the international convention on road traffic for eventual world-wide application. The document has been laid before the road transport working party of the Economic Commission for Europe.

PARIS, Nov. 25 -- Considerations of military strategy that were discussed and decided on at a meeting of high military officers in Washington about two weeks ago have determined the attitude that the United States delegation here has adopted on the question of the Italian colonies, diplomatic circles said today.

PARIS, Nov. 25 -- Dr. Herbert V. Evatt of Australia urged the peoples of the world today to bring the pressure of public opinion to bear on their Governments to get them to sign and ratify an international pact banning wholesale murders.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 -- A committee of the United States Chamber of Commerce charged today that the current "expansionist technique" of the Soviet Union presented the "most dangerous and baffling" threat to the Western non-Communist nations found in modern history.

Governor Dewey came back East yesterday morning, tanned and refreshedh)0*0*0*iby his vacation in Arizona. Mr. Dewey and his party arrived at La Guardia Field on an American Airlines plane at 4:42 A.M., and after a brief interview left by automobile for Thanksgiving dinner at home in Pawling.

COLUMBIA, Mo., Nov. 25 (AP) -Quarterback Bus Entsminger engineered Missouri to three firsthall touchdowns and a 21-to-7 victory over. the Kansas Jayhawks today. The triumph gave the Tigers undisputed possession of second place 5n the Big Seven Conference.

The large one-story factory building at the southwest corner of Plaza Avenue and Herkimer Street, in New Hyde Park, Nassau County, has been sold by Frank Spinetta to the Reinis Coat Suit Co, Inc., for $90,000, according to the Metropolitan Title Guaranty Company, which insured title.

An expanded educational program to bring home decoration information to consumers and store personnel was announced yesterday by Paul H. Gadebusch, treasurer and general manager of F. Schumacher Co., 60 West Fortieth Street.

Five young men who, the police said, were found late Wednesday night loading two large woodencrates of rifles, machine guns and revolvers onto a truck parked in a deserted garage area near the Hudson River on West 158th Street, were arraigned yesterday in the youth part of Felony Court on charges of violating the Sullivan Law.

CHICAGO, Nov. 25 -- The largest ship ever planned for the Great Lakes is taking form in the Lorain (Ohio) yard of the American Ship Building Company. It is the Wilfred Sykes, being built for the Inland/ Steel Company, Chicago, and named for the president of the company.
A slowdown strike against the Railway Express Agency ended early today, with "full crews" reporting to work on a "normal schedule," a company official announced.

A statement that the House Committee on Un-American Activities "deserves the thanks of every Christian" for issuing a booklet, "Communism in Religion," was made yesterday by the Rev. Carl McIntire, president of the International Council of Christian Churches and pastor of the Bibleh) 0*0*0*iPresbyterian Church, Collingswood, N.J.

It seems incredible that, while punishment for homicide is taken for granted everywhere, punishment for genocide -- the mass destruction of racial, national and religious groups -is still being argued about in the United Nations. Three years after the adoption of a Charter which affirms "faith in fundamental human rights," the world still has no genocide convention.

ESSEN, Germany, Nov. 25 -The Ruhr Basin, an area that can be the arsenal of a resurgent Germany or the workshop of a peaceful Europe, is on the road not only to recovery but to that pre-eminence in the economy of Western Europe it enjoyed until World War II.

BERLIN, Nov. 25 -- Soviet Foreign Minister Molotov dashed all German Communist hopes for any adjustment of the Oder-Neisse river frontier with Poland in a conference with the German People's Council leaders who visited Moscow early this month, reliable sources reported today.

The executive board of a local of the United Office and Professional Workers of America, CIO, rejected yesterday a proposal that its national leadership be deposed because of Communist proclivities Local 16, of the UOPWA, attacked Philip Murray, president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, who made the proposal on Tuesday and charged that he was speaking for elements in the CIO eager for power and "dictatorial control."

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Nov. 25 (AP) - Head Linesman Frank Jones receiv)d a blood transfusion tonight after being punched in the face during a football game in which the University of Chattanooga downed the University of Dayton, 21 -- 6.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Nov. 25 -- The strange affair of the Skoplje trial ended tonight with the sentencing of Asen Bogdanov and nine other Macedonian traitors who had served with the Bulgarian Fascist Army of Occupation. Bogdanov, occupation police chief of Skoplje, and his co-defendants were convicted of having organized the mass murder of Macedonians who opposed the "Bulgarization" policy of the Sofia Government and who supported Marshal Tito's National Liberation Army.

CHICAGO, Nov. 25 (AP) -- The Buffalo Bills, trailing the Chicago Rockets at the quarter, half and three-quarters, roared back with two touchdowns in the final four minutes to take a free-scoring 39-35 All-America Football Conference decision at Soldier Field today before 6,305 fans.

LONDON, Nov. 25 -- United States military officers will join Field Marshal Viscount Montgomery's Western European defense headquarters in Fontainebleau outside Paris as soon as United States adherence to the proposed Atlantic defense pact is completed, it was learned today on high authority.

ROANOKE, Va., Nov. 25 (AP) -Bobby Thomason ended his grid iron career with Virginia Military Institute today by passing the keydets to the most impressive victory in forty-four years of rivalry with Virginia Tech.

DUBLIN, Nov. 25 -- The Dail resumed its debate on the Republic of Ireland bill this evening with several Fianna Fail opposition speakers welcoming the bill as determining this state's position but most of them taunting Premier John A. Costello's Fine Gael party for departing from its former Commonwealth allegiance.
SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 25 -The CIO longshoremen and the Waterfront Employers Association have come to terms.

Dramatic school graduates from all parts of the United States will act in three plays for the National Theatre Conference at the Hunter College Playhouse, 695 Park Avenue, tonight and tomorrow at 8 o'clock.

Five seamen's groups, three union and two non-union, announced yesterday the formation of an Emergency Merchant Marine Council. The twofold aim of the new organization will be to seek deferment both for men who served in the merchant marine during the war and for seafarers who are active in the industry today.
LONDON, Nov. 25 (AP) -- Americans shared Thanksgiving Day today with Europeans who are strange to the old United States custom.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 -- Senator Homer E. Capehart, Republican, of Indiana, and head of the subcommittee on trade policies, was accused today by Representative Wright Patman, Democrat, of Texas, of using a Congressional committee to conduct a "propaganda drive against the anti-trust laws."

A Paris court yesterday upheld Jean-Paul Sartre, existentialist playwright, philosopher and original author of "Red Gloves," starring Charles Boyer, in an action brought against his publisheragent, Louis Nagel, according to a Reuters dispatch.

Federated Department Stores Inc., and its subsidiaries had the highest annual earnings in their history during the fifty-two weeks ended on Oct. 30, according to the report of Fred Lazarus Jr., president, to be released today.
SAN BRUNO, Calif., Nov. 25 (AP) -- Shannon II, great Australianbred 7-year-old, came from far back today to in the $25,000 added San Francisco handicap by a head at Tanforan.

Robert Rounseville, who was scheduled to do the role of Pelleas in the City Center's first fall production of Debussy's "Pelleas et Melisande," finally got around to appearing in the difficult part last night. It was the tenor's debut as a member of the New York City Opera Company, and he proved that it was wise casting to ask him to sing and play Pelleas. Vocally and histrionically he added persuasiveness to the production.

h)0*0*0*iOCLEVELAND, Nov. 25 -- The national planning committee of the American Veterans Committee will recommend that members of the Communist party be ruled ineligible for membership in the AVC when the organization convenes for its third national convention tomorrow.

City College's basketball team opened its season, the thirtieth for Coach Nat Holman, last night by routing Queens College, 77 -- 31, on the Lavender court. Outside of the early minutes, the victors were ahead by a commanding margin throughout the contest, leading at half time by 35 -- 11.

PARIS, Nov. 25 -- Christian Pineau, Minister of Public Works and Transport, conceded today that approximately one-half of the money converted into francs by tourists this year had been negotiated on the black market.

PARIS, Nov. 25 -- Secretary of State Marshall's statement on the Ruhr yesterday is interpreted by officials here as marking progress for the French view on one minor point and possibly on one major point, but as leaving the basic issues still in suspense.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 -- In support of the appeal of the railroads for increased freight rates, six railway executives have filed with the Interstate Commerce Commission statements that the increases are essential to meet operating costs and to improve freight services.

ATLANTA, Nov. 25 (AP) -- "A wool hat man from South Georgia" posted a $500 reward today for the ambush slayers of a Toombs County Negro, saying he believed in "white supremacy" but not in "murder and lynch violence."

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 25 -- A report released today by the industrial relations section of Princeton University indicates that the average company in American industry is apparently reluctant toh)0*0*0*iattempt to keep all of its employes fully informed of company planning and aims in its labor relations policies.

Pushing through piles of rubbish heavily overlaid with cobwebs, the police entered a dingy four-room flat at 340 East 105th Street yesterday afternoon and found a 78-year-old woman recluse half conscious on the living-room floor.

Because of increased difficulty in exceeding the "break-even" point due to higher operating costs, a strong trend is developing with Midwestern and Eastern retail bakeries toward stocking allied packaged items, according to food authorities here.

PARIS, Nov. 25 -- Six neutral members of the United Nations Security Council met this afternoon under the chairmanship of Dr. Juan Atilio Bramuglia to discuss whether replies of the four great powers on a questionnaire dealing with currency reform would justify further efforts to solve the Berlin dispute.

Striking back after being two touchdowns behind at half-time, Cardinal Hayes tied undefeated Mount Saint Michael, 13 -- 13, in their annual Thanksgiving Day football game at Triborough Stadium yesterday. A crowd of 15,000; largest ever to watch a scholastic contest at the stadium, witnessed the battle between the two Bronx schools.

VIENNA, Nov. 25 -- The serious Soviet charges brought against the United States command here and the Austrian Government in the Ottillinger case was based on the fact that Dr. Margarethe Ottillinger fell in love with a Sovieth)0*0*0*iofficer about two years ago, authoritative sources said today.
A proposed amendment to the City Charter establishing a traffic commission to grapple with the city's expensive traffic chaos was made public yesterday by Mayor O'Dwyer's office.

PARIS, Nov. 25 -- Two articles of the Declaration on Human Rights -- including that on the right to work that was rejected in its entirely last week after having been adopted in its parts -- were approved today by the Social, Humanitarian and Cultural Committee of the United Nations General Assembly.

PORTLAND, Ore., Nov. 25 -- The legislative assembly of the Congress of Industrial Organizations today gave the green light to a general drive for a fourth post-war round of wage increases and paved the way for drastic dealing with small unions, mostly leftist-led.

I noticed a recent press report that there is a movement to urge retirement of all United States court judges at 70. The United States Constitution guarantees the office during good behavior and places no restriction or any age limit. There is not only a practical reason for this but also a philosophical basis for it.

The concert given by Dimitri Mitropoulos and the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra last night in Carnegie Hall was one of uncommon interest. One can say more. One can say that music has rarely fulfilled its mission in a distracted world.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 25 (UP) -A Trans-World Airlines Constellation burst into flames during a landing at the Municipal Airport today and the eighteen passengers and five crew members leaped and scrambled to safety through an emergency door.

GENEVA, Nov. 25 -- The International Labor Organization announced today the first in a series of projects designed to place it at the forefront of the European recovery drive in the fields of manpower utilization and labor productivity.

LONDON, Nov. 25 -- Smiling faces abounded today on the world's largest liner, the Queen Elizabeth, when an announcement was posted saying the vessel would sail from Southampton at 8 o'clock Sunday morning. About 1,500 passengers have been held up for nearly a week at Southampton, owing to the New York dock strike and refusal of the Elizabeth's crew to sail until the strike was settled.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 (AP)--Administration sources predicted today President Truman will ask the new Congress to keep export controls in force throughout the prospective four years of the Marshall Plan.

Because of the delay in the final determination of the status of the Army overcoat, the Quartermaster has no immediate need for large amounts of rayon cloth, it was learned yesterday from the Office of Technical Information, Office of the Quartermaster General in Washington.

ONE last whirl on the merry-go-round, folks. So grab a firm holt and let's go. As a farewell gesture we'll toss in as lagniappe next week's Notre Dame-Southern California prediction. The Fighting Irish will zoom through their twenty-eighth consecutive game without defeat. Closer at hand, though, we find. . .

BELLMORE, L.I., Nov. 25 -Detectives of the First Precinct Nassau County police at Merrick, L.I., were searching today for an unidentified man who forced his way through a rear window at the home of Walter A. Brimlow at 722 Sunrise Avenue, here, about 4 A.M. today, and hit Mr. Brimlow's wife, Gwendolyn, 29 years old, on the head, knocking her unconscious, when she tried to telephone police.

LONDON, Nov. 25 -- Herve Alphand, chief of the French delegation to the six-power Ruhr conference in London, voiced France's gratification tonight over a United States and British invitation to the French to participate in control of the German coal and steel industries.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 (AP) -President Truman worked more than four hours today before relaxing to enjoy the Thanksgiving holiday and a traditional turkey dinner with his family.

Senator Sparkman's announced intention to propose a national survey of the social and economic problems of all minority groups in the country would seem to be an attempt to delay adoption of federal legislation to carry out the President's civil rights program. We can see no necessity for such a survey.

MOUNT HOLLY, N.J., Nov. 25 (AP) Maj. Gen. Clifford R. Powell, Burlington County Republican leader, said tonight "there has been no subterfuge, no fraud, no duress and no misinformation" in the sale of two Delaware River bridges.

BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 25 -While there has not yet been any official Government pronouncement on President Truman's invitation to Argentina to join the Food and Agriculture Organization, Miguel Miranda, head of the National Economic Council, said today:
GENEVA, Nov. 24 (AP) -- The Seafarers Section of the International Transport Workers Federation voted today to boycott ships flying under Panamanian and Honduran registries starting May 1.

AUSTIN, Tex., Nov. 25 (AP) -- The never-say-die Texas Aggies fought the University of Texas to a 14-14 tie before 68,000 persons today, knocking the Longhorns out of a chance to share the Southwest Conference championship with Southern Methodist.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Nov. 25 -- The rapid elimination of the middle class and a revolutionary change in the relative positions occupied by the various social groups in Yugoslavia since the end of the war are strikingly illustrated by statistics published here today.

PHILADELPHIA. Nov. 25 -Cornellians enjoyed the rare experience of sitting down to their turkey with a hearty appetite tonight. After nine long years of waiting, the Big Red team conquered its ancient Thanksgiving Day rival, Pennsylvania, on Franklin Field today, in brilliant sunshine, 23 -- 14.

Arab forces must be withdrawn from Israel so that the Palestine situation can be settled in a peaceful atmosphere, Representative Abraham Multer of the Fourteenth Congressional District in Brooklyn told more than 500 delegates last night at the opening of the ninth annual convention of the Junior Mizrachi Women's Organization of America in the New Yorker Hotel.

Lou Boudreau, shortstop and manager of the world champion Cleveland Indians, has been named the American League's most valuable player for 1948, it was announced yesterday by Edward H. Burns, retiring president of the Baseball Writers' Association of America.

PARIS, Nov. 25 -- Gaston Monnerville was re-elected today president of the Council of the Republic, France's advisory second house, which has replaced the Senate. M. Monnerville obtained 199 votes, while his only official opponent, Henri Martel, Communist, won 19 votes, and Jules Gasser, dean of the body, who was not a candidate, 14.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Nov. 25 -- The artistry of a tiny half-back, Don Blackwell, got the White Plains Tigers a pair of secondperiod touchdowns, but the Rome Free Academy eleven, from up-state New York, triumphed, 14 to 12, in the morning battle at the High School Stadium today.
GREAT YARMOUTH, England, Nov. 25 -- The kippered herring, like the old gray mare, ain't what she used to be.

BOSTON, Nov. 25 -- All action on the acceptance in this area of the terms ending the sixteen-day East Coast longshoremen's strike hinged tonight on the return from New York of Daniel J. Donovan, international vice president for New England.

When President Truman addressed the Food and Agriculture Organization this week he threw in a friendly reference to Argentina and to the Soviet Union, expressing the wish that both of these countries would become members of FAO. "I think," he declared, "that if we could discuss with the Russians our mutual interest in agriculture it would not be so difficult to discuss our differences in some other fields."
Television will cover the opening performance of the Metropolitan Opera Association's season Monday night, marking the first transmission of an opera in its entirety by that medium.

PESHAWAR, Pakistan, Nov. 25 The wild northwest frontier that separates this country from Afghanistan is enjoying its version of peace. This means that the fierce Moslem tribesmen, the inhabitants of these craggy deserts, are not killing anybody except one another.

Richard Fisk, pianist, gave a recital last night at Times Hall. The program consisted of Bach's Toccata in D major; Beethoven's Sonata, Op. 31, No. 3; Prokofieff's Sonata, No. 7; Copland's Passacaglia; Liszt's "Feux follets" and "Mephisto Waltz," and offerings Chopin, Brahms and Albeniz.
SEOUL, Korea, Nov. 26 -- The Korean Republic will "soon be able to defend itself," President Syngman Rhee told his weekly press conference today.
BOSTON, Nov. 26 (AP) -- They threw flowers from India wharf into the dark waters of Boston Harbor for the last time tonight.
ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Nov. 26 (AP) -- This is what happened to Howard Threatt when he called on the police to help him collect alleged winnings on a 52-cent numbers bet.

The leader of the military junta that unseated the Gallegos Government in Venezuela has said that he and his Army colleagues took their action to save democratic principles, which were being abused by a "minority," and that they intend soon to call for general elections so that "the Venezuelan people can choose the government they wish."

Production of women's coats and suits for the current fall season has gone ahead of a year ago by approximately 10 per cent, it was learned yesterday. The research department of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union confirmed manufacturers' reports that since the beginning of July, when fall production began, the industry in New York has produced about 750,000 more units than in the corresponding period in 1947.

Mayor O'Dwyer filled out the three-member City Rent Commission yesterday by appointing Herbert T. Wechsler, Professor of Law at Columbia University, and Nathaniel Sorkin, Deputy Commissioner of Investigation, to the unpaid posts from which two of Mr. O'Dwyer's original appointees resigned on Wednesday.
An appeal for volunteers to help with the recreational activities of patients in city hospitals was issued yesterday by Dr. Edward M. Bernecker, City Commissioner of Hospitals.

The Columbia Broadcasting System announced last night the acquisition of the Jack Benny program, which has been a fixture on the National Broadcasting Company's chain for sixteen years. The comedian will start on CBS at 7 P.M. Sunday, Jan. 2.
BERLIN, Nov. 26 -- Inspection teams will guarantee the democratic execution of the city elections Dec. 5, the three commandants of the Western sectors of Berlin announced today.

VIENNA, Nov. 26 -- Col. Gen. Vladimir Kurasov, the Soviet High Commissioner, refused today even to discuss with the three other high commissioners his order to the Austrian Government to turn over for removal 540 locomotives and 5,575 railway cars that the Russians claim as war booty of German origin.

The head of the house now has a personal devil. Since it is not everyone who can reach out and actually touch his devil, this sets him apart somewhat. The figure is Balinese, a fierce object three feet or so in height, with a curved tail, one clenched fist and an expression suitable for frightening children.

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 26 -- Bernie F. Martin Jr., 21-year-old ex-GI art student was so bewildered when he learned that the oil painting he bought for $5 in a second hand furniture shop was worth $1,000 that he forgot the name of the artist.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 (AP) -- Retail sales totaled $11,580,000,000 in October, the Department of Commerce estimated today.

The problem of new school construction because of the recent high birthrate is so widespread and pressing that it promises to be, along with other phases of aid to education, the major issue facing the next session of the New York Legislature. Other states have a like problem.

In The London Daily Telegraph and Morning Post I read a paragraph that in a letter to your paper Edith Johnson gives her impressions of England this past summer. She is quoted as writing that "one is surprised on arriving in a London hotel to find an abundance of food, if not as wide a choice as in the United States."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 -- President Truman authorized the Economic Cooperation Administration today to use the full amount of its first $5,300,000,000 appropriation in the twelve months ending April 2, 1949, instead of spreading the fund over fifteen months as suggested by Congress.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 (AP) -- A defense establishment committee is studying the multi-million dollar business of Army post exchanges and Navy ship stores to see, among other things, if there is unfair competition with private business.

BOSTON, Nov. 26 -- A demand that the White House release the report by the evaluation board of the Joint Chiefs of Staff on the atom bomb as a military weapon as shown in the Bikini tests was published today by Bradley Dewey, Cambridge, Mass., industrialist, who was a civilian member of the board at the tests, made in 1946.

DETROIT, Nov. 26 -- A minimum wage increase of 10 cents an hour, amounting in the aggregate to $4 to $6 a week, was one of seven recommendations made today by a Governor's fact-finding commission inquiring into labor-management disagreement involving 19,000 employes and the Michigan Bell Telephone Company.

Joseph Schildkraut is seriously considering appearing on Broadway this season in one or two plays held by the American Theatre Group, of which Gertrude Rozan is managing director. The actor, now on the West Coast, has promised Miss Rozan that he will confer with her on the matter when he arrives here on Dec. 9.

The recent discovery that at least one European rat has crossed the ocean while surreptitiously enjoying a meal aloft in the luxurious cabin of a transatlantic airliner has posed a new problem for doctors at the United States Quarantine Station here.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 26 -- Universal-International has named Yvonne de Carlo to play the leading feminine role in "The Western Story" instead of Deanna Durbin, who is now scheduled to go to Italy for a picture early in 1949. "The Western Story" will start in January and will precede "Bagdad" on Miss de Carlo's program.

PARIS, Nov. 26 -- A French Antarctic expedition sailed from Brest today bound for Adelie Land, a small segment of the Antarctic continent south of Australia. The expedition, it is understood, is principally interested in doing some "flag waving" in territory that has probably not been visited by man since the explorer, Capt. Dumont d'Urville, claimed it for France in 1840.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 -- An Interstate Commerce Commission examiner today recommended that the ICC approve a nation-wide scale of rates worked out by the Railway Express Agency at discretion of the ICC. An increase of from one to 16 per cent would result in the East and South.

Mayor O'Dwyer's plan to establish a powerful traffic commission with authority to deal fully with the problem of congestion met yesterday with the general approval of civic groups. However, they raised three specific objections that they hoped would be ironed out before the proposals become law.

LONDON, Nov. 26 -- Interest in stock market here today centered on British Government bonds in which rises up to 1/4 point were seem. The continued strength of gilt-edge stocks has hardened market opinion that opportunity will be taken to speed up plans for more new issues, probably for Tanganyika and Australia.

More than 5,000 persons leaned over the parapets at Rockefeller Center yesterday to witness a half-hour ceremony in the lower plaza commemorating the third anniversary of CARE (Cooperative for American Remittances to Europe). Hollywood and Broadway stars and unexpected "thrills and spills" marked the event.

Despite the downward trend in savings, account balances with members of the Council of Insured Savings Associations of New York State are increasing, according to a report issued yesterday by David Ford, the council's president.

On Nov. 16, in a thirteen-page "decision" replete with restrictions, Yeshiva of Nitra, a duly authorized and incorporated group of rabbinical scholars, was granted after prolonged delay permission by the New Castle Zoning Board of Appeals to conduct an Orthodox Talmudic School for men on the old Brewster estate on Croton Lake Road near Mount Kisco, New York.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Nov. 26 -- Delegates from thirteen suspended chapters of the American Veterans Committee in New York City were barred from convention seats tonight in a first-round, factional battle between anti-Communist administration forces and a "progressive" group headed by Morris Pottish, lawyer and former member of the organization's top executive committee.

HACKENSACK, N.J., Nov. 26 -- A steam shovel and bulldozer were completing today the demolition of the historic Westervelt-Lozier house at Main and Ward Streets here from which Gen. Enoch Poor, with Generals Washington and Lafayette in attendance, was buried in 1780.
An event unprecedented in the annals of Brooklyn courts was scheduled to take place yesterday in the Central Courts Building, but it never materialized.

The Harlem Globe Trotters, making their first appearance here in several years, defeated the Philadelphia Sphas of the American Basketball League in an exhibition game at the Sixty-ninth Regiment Armory last night. With Goose Tatum leading in the scoring with 22 points, the Harlem five won by 54 to 45.

Menachem Begin, former commander in chief of the Irgun forces in Palestine, was received officially yesterday at City Hall. Mayor O'Dwyer extended the city's welcome at ceremonies held in the City Council chamber.
SANTIAGO, Chile, Nov. 26 (AP) -- Chilean boxers are learning to keep their guard up as a result of what they learned at the Olympic Games in London.
PARIS, Nov. 26 (AP) -- Following are the texts of the Big Four replies to Dr. Juan Atilio Bramuglia, United Nations Security Council President, on questions of the Berlin currency problems:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 (AP) -- The National Military Establishment said today Secretary Forrestal recommended that the final official report on the 1946 Bikini atom bomb tests be withheld from publication for reasons of national security.

A seven-cent fare will become effective at midnight tonight on fifty-six bus lines of the Surface Transportation Corporation, operating in Manhattan and the Bronx, it was announced yesterday. The new tariffs were signed yesterday by the Public Service Commission.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 (AP) -- The Economic Cooperation Administration said tonight it will honor some $50,000,000 in grain contracts between European nations and private American dealers.

Deaths from accidents over the Thanksgiving Day holiday were fewer this year than last, according to a survey yesterday by The Associated Press. Mishaps on highways accounted for two-thirds of the fatalities, the report showed.
CHARLESTON, S.C., Nov. 26 (AP) -- Federal District Judge J. Waties Waring ruled today that Negroes have established their right to full membership in the South Carolina Democratic party.

ROME, Nov. 26 -- The Government instructed the Italian Ambassador in Washington, Alberto Tarchiani, today, to speak to President Truman about the unfavorable reaction of public opinion here that would follow any decision against Italy by the United Nations in the matter of colonies held prior to the Fascist regime.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 -- During the week ended Nov. 24, member bank reserve balances decreased $19,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

Van Wyck Loomis, who has sailed his sloop Hound in the Long Island Sound regattas for years, last night was re-elected fleet chairman of the Atlantic Class Association. That action was taken at the annual dinner-meeting of the group held in the New York Yacht Club.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 (AP) -- Democratic party strategists plan to ask Senator Robert F. Wagner of New York to retain his Senate place for the next two years.

Demands are being prepared by liquor retailers in the metropolitan area for larger mark-ups from distillers, it was learned here yesterday. Officials of two of the largest trade associations stated that present mark-ups do not yield sufficient profit to furnish the retailer with a "fair living."
CHICAGO, Nov. 26 (AP) -- Scientists lifted the curtain a little today on a new atomic furnace -- the "hottest" and biggest in the Government's atomic research program.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 (UP) -- The State Department announced today that the United States had formally ratified an agreement with Russia and five other nations providing for conservation of the world's whale population.

LAKE SUCCESS, Nov. 26 -- Many of the Chinese refugee children who are streaming into Peiping and Tsientsin are close to starvation, Dr. P.Z. King, chief medical adviser to the United Nations International Children's Emergency Fund, reported here today, shortly after his arrival in this country from China.

PESHAWAR, Pakistan, Nov. 26 -- The self-reliant little kingdom of Afghanistan is very pro-United States at the moment, according to travelers arriving recently from Kabul, the Afghan capital, to this city, which is Afghanistan's primary link with the outside world through the Khyber Pass.

TOKYO, Saturday, Nov. 27 -- (UP) -- Gen. Douglas MacArthur's headquarters took over today the matter of publication of any news concerning Gen. Hideki Tojo and his six fellow Japanese war lords condemned to die on the gallows.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 26 -- The seventeen-day trial of Police Court Magistrate John J. O'Malley on 641 counts of misconduct and malfeasance ended this afternoon when Judge W. Russell Carr discharged the jury of eight men and four women who had been unable to agree on a verdict after deliberating seventy-one hours.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Nov. 26 -- Francis H. Russell, director of the State Department's Office of Public Affairs, said tonight that in view of the present period of tension in world affairs, it was extremely improbable that the various Governments could agree to any form of organization stronger than the United Nations.

A new book by Earl Parker Hanson, author of "Stefansson: Prophet of the North" and editor of "New World Guides to the Latin-American Republics," will be brought out in March by Duell, Sloan Pearce. "New Worlds Emerging" is a study of the social and economic implications of postwar geographic expansion in the Arctic and the tropics.

Retail sales here this week continued to decline as the temperature remained above "normal" for this time of the year. Department store sales were estimated as about 9 per cent under the corresponding week last year. Sales last week were down 9 per cent.

ROSLYN, L.I., Nov. 26 -- After a delay of more than fifteen years, motorists from the North Shore of Long Island probably will be able by next summer to avoid the traffic bottleneck on the curving, hilly highway through Roslyn Village and cross the new Roslyn vioduct spanning Hempstead Harbor.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 -- Important revelations concerning German pre-war diplomatic negotiations with Russia, Spain and other countries will be revealed in five volumes of correspondence to be published next year from 450 tons of documents captured from the hidden archives of the German Foreign Office by the United States First Army close to the end of the war.

ALBANY, Nov. 26 -- A resolution condemning euthanasia and calling on the New York State Legislature "to continue to resist firmly the efforts of those doctors who would legalize mercy killing in New York State" was introduced tonight at the joint convention of the American Physicians Association and the New York State Naturopathic Association.

The six-story apartment house at 253 West Sixteenth Street has been sold by the K.U.K. Realty Corporation to an investing syndicate represented by Leo Galletta and Barbieri Brothers. Paul P. Zinner, Inc., was co-broker with Barbieri Brothers in the transaction.
GENEVA, Nov. 26 -- Yugoslavia is seeking metallurgical coke in Western Europe to make up for deficiencies caused by the clamping down on Polish exports to Yugoslavia, it was learned here today.
PITTSBURGH, Nov. 26 (AP) -- Pitt may spike its football purism program with some punch.

The medical boards of seven of the thirteen municipal hospitals here voted yesterday to return to the pre-war practice of sending internes instead of first-aid attendants on emergency ambulance calls, Dr. Edward M. Bernecker, Commissioner of Hospitals, announced last night.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 (AP) -- Senator Millard E. Tydings, Democrat, of Maryland, served notice on the armed services today that the new Congress would aim at a $15,000,000,000 ceiling on defense costs next year.

PARIS, Nov. 26 -- Twelve countries that had been turned down for membership in the United Nations were assured of another chance today. But for eleven of them a new round of voting in the Security Council was expected to be a formality before another rejection.

The Battle of the Bronx -- collegiate football variety -- will be enacted for the twenty-sixth time today when Fordham's Rams tangle with the Violet of New York University at the Polo Grounds before 25,000 fans.
During the past few years we have been made conscious of the fact that there is a shortage of public schools with the resultant overcrowding of classes and consequent overwork of teachers.
NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 26 (AP) -- Louis Cook pushed Checkerhall all the way to win the featured Minden Purse over six furlongs at the Fair Grounds today.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 (AP) -- Miss Margaret Truman received today a blouse made by a child in the children's village of Meier Shfeyah, near Haifa, Israel.
MIAMI, Fla., Nov. 26 (AP) -- Kentucky's Wildcats walloped the Miami Hurricanes in a bruising, football game, 25 to 5, before 30,361 shirt-sleeved spectators in the Orange Bowl tonight.

The "tautness" of inflation is raising the pressure on market research and sales-forecasting technicians to guard business against sudden slips from its present peaks, it was asserted here last week by Richard E. Moulton, director of marketing for General Foods Corporation.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 -- New and improved devices for aircraf and further developments in the electrical and electronic fields and in the radio industry shared honors this week with inventions of highly varied purpose and design in the total of 491 approved by the United States Patent Office.

Meir Grossman, head of the World Zionists Revisionists and member of the executive of the Jewish Agency for Palestine, predicted yesterday that in the event a coalition government is formed in Israel after the Jan. 25 elections, it would advocate transfer agreements with the Arab states.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 -- Bold slashing of the President's budget for the next fiscal year, if such action is necessary to head off deficit spending and to provide sound payment on the national debt, was pledged today by Representative Clarence Cannon, Democrat, of Missouri.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 -- Department store sales in the week ended Nov. 20 were 6 per cent below sales in the corresponding week of last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. The following lists percentage changes from like periods of 1947:

The men who negotiated new terms for settlement of the costly longshoremen's strikes on the two coasts appear confident of ratification. Shipping operators either had to submit to their workers' terms or face further weeks of disastrous maritime paralysis. If the voting that begins this morning does not bring approval of the new terms, there is something seriously wrong with the thinking among dock laborers.

The Hunter College Faculty Year Book, published for the first time this year, revealed that fifty-six faculty members have had work published in the last year including seven books, 172 reviews and articles, and five musical works. Four faculty members also have exhibited paintings.

PRETORIA, South Africa, Nov. 26 -- As a token of good-will toward American manufacturers and exporters the Department of Commerce and Industries announced tonight that it had obtained permission from the Treasury Department for the entry of goods on South-Africa's order that were held up by United States longshoremen's strike.

By its very nature life in barracks never can be the same as life at the home. But as General Latham said in his address before the National Council of Social Studies in Chicago, life in the Army need not be "a civic vacuum," "an educational wasteland," "a moral slum."

PORTLAND, Ore., Nov. 26 -- Re-elected president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations for his ninth year, Philip Murray announced today at the closing session of a tempestuous convention that the CIO was prepared to meet with representatives of the American Federation of Labor to consider "plans of a social, political and economic nature designed to advance the cause of the American people."

Dr. Henry H. Kessler, president of the National Council of Rehabilitation, paid tribute yesterday to the work of the Near East Foundation's rehabilitation center in Athens in bringing back many disabled Greeks to enjoy a productive life.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 (UP) -- The Navy revealed today it had built a 24-inch gun. Its caliber is 50 per cent bigger than the largest guns now mounted on battleships.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 (AP) -- Ten nations of Western Europe, Trieste and Indonesia today received $25,301,014 in new foreign aid grants by the Economic Cooperation Administration.

CHICAGO, Nov. 26 (AP) -- Two Midwest teams scored victories and another was blanked, 10 to 0, by strong Middle Atlantic eleven today in the second-round matches of the Women's National Field Hockey tournament.

The Dana Corporation, manufacturer of parts for the automotive industry, and its subsidiaries reported yesterday for the fiscal year ended on Aug. 31 a net income of $11,124,449, equal to $7.17 a common share. This compared with $8,219,568, or $5.23 a common share, in the previous fiscal year.
MOSCOW, Nov. 26 (AP) -- A recent decree discloses that M.P. Khrapchenko is to head the important Committee on Art of the U.S.S.R. P.I. Lebedev has headed the committee since early this year..

BONN, Germany, Nov. 26 -- The three Western military governors have warned the Germans writing the constitution for a new Western German state against too much centralization. They have reminded the Germans that "a democratic, decentralized federal government" is the Western objective and that any constitution that does not provide for such a state will not be accepted by the Western occupation powers.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 -- The Interstate Commerce Commission today approved a plan of reorganization for the Georgia, Florida Alabama Railroad Company, providing for a capitalization of $3,400,000, compared with present capitalization and debt of $5,901,162.50, plus 10,000 shares of no-par-value common stock.

PARIS, Nov. 26 -- Substitution of voting for individual candidates on a double-ballot majority system for the proportional representation that has been used in France since the war is ordered in a bill submitted today to the National Assembly.

PARIS, Nov. 26 -- The Political and Security Committee of the United Nations General Assembly halted its debate on the Palestine question today to give to a "coordinating" subcommittee time to sort out the subjects proposed in the various proposals for a permanent settlement.
Twelve foreign students who are studying in United States schools and colleges under auspices of the American Field Service were greeted yesterday by Mayor O'Dwyer at a brief ceremony in City Hall.
Viewed from any angle the local ring debut of Arthur King, Canadian boxer, last night at the St. Nicholas Arena was a huge success.

CHICAGO, Nov. 26 (UP) -- Retail butter prices have declined sharply over the nation in the last two months, a survey showed today. The prices of most other dairy products, except for eggs, also were down. Eggs increased in price during the two-month period, chiefly because of a normal seasonal drop in production.
A spirited clash on the issue of discrimination in college fraternities marked the fortieth annual session of the National Interfraternity Conference, which opened yesterday at the Commodore Hotel.

The tense three-way struggle for the All-America Conference's Eastern Division title may be decided here tomorow. A Buffalo victory over the Yankees at the Stadium, combined with a Dodger triumph over Baltimore at Ebbets Field, would end the race in favor of the Bills.

BOSTON, Nov. 26 (AP) -- Boston College, which was favored to beat Holy Cross in each of the their last three formal games, excluding two war years, but lost each one, is again picked to win tomorrow's forty-fourth football clash of these Jesuit rivals.
BRUSSELS, Belgium, Nov. 26 -- Paul-Henri Spaak settled Belgium's political crisis today by forming a Socialist-Catholic coalition substantially the same as his Cabinet that had resigned last Friday.

A three-day embargo on almost all air and rail shipments into and out of the metropolitan area was lifted yesterday by the Railway Express Agency after the end of a slowdown strike by 6,000 terminal employes.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, Nov. 26 -- Statistics on German intentions to obtain immigration visas since the reopening of the quota last Sept. 20 have caused members of the United States Consulate here to revise sharply downward their estimates of the total registration for permits.

Unlike other possessions of the United States with a civil form of government, the three Virgin Islands -- St. Thomas, St. John and St. Croix -- do not have a resident Commissioner or any native on the mainland charged with the responsibility to represent them in Congress.

OTTAWA, Nov 26 (Canadian Press) -- Shipment of Canadian tablestock potatoes to the United States will be stopped Dec. 1, but a price-support program will be introduced to protect growers, Trade Minister C.D. Howe and Agriculture Minister J.G. Gardiner announced tonight.

Carroll (Whitey) Lockman, Giant centerfielder, is the latest entry in the growing list of ball players who have found it necessary this current off-season to go in drydock for repairs. The fleet-footed gardener today will enter Harkness Pavilion and early next week will undergo a skin grafting operation on his left ankle.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 -- Secretary of Labor Maurice J. Tobin will submit to President Truman on Monday a general labor policy program for inclusion in his State-of-the-Union message.

ALBANY, Nov. 26 -- The New York State death rate from automobile accidents during the first nine months of this year was "the lowest since motor vehicles became a common means of transportation" except for the war years when motor travel was at a minimum, the State Health Department reported today.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, Nov. 26 -- German frustration over obstacles encountered in the rush to purchase surplus United States equipment handled by Steg, Germany agency set up to market these wares, is growing into a clamor against the bureaucratic methods employed.
Bayonne, N.J., announced yesterday that it would receive bids on Dec. 9 on $1,500,000 of emergency housing bonds dated Jan. 1, 1949; due on Jan. 1, 1950 to 1972, and callable in 1954.

ERNEST HEMINGWAY said in his preface to "Men at War" that a Government interested in keeping its people's confidence should "tell them everything that they can know, bad as well as good, so long as their knowing of it does not help the enemy. Covering up errors to save the men who make them can only lead to a lack of confidence which can be one of the greatest dangers a nation can face."

PATERSON, N.J., Nov. 26 (UP) -- Abe J. Greene, president of the National Boxing Association, announced today that Rocky Graziano was suspended in all N.B.A states for his withdrawal from a fight scheduled at Oakland, Calif., next Wednesday night.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Nov. 26 -- The Lebanese Government, it was disclosed tonight, has declined to release the Lebanese labor leader, Mustafa el-Ariss, who was arrested a week ago on the premises of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization although he was holding a certificate of immunity as an accredited observer for the World Federation of Trade Unions.

The decision of C.W. Robinson, Maritime Commission hearing examiner, on the application of Shepard Steamship Company for an operating differential subsidy for its service to the east coast of South America was interpreted yesterday in local shipping circles as tantamount to commission approval.

Today's events: Children's Concert, presented by the Jefferson School of Social Science, Pete Seeger, Ruth Vinitsky. Laura Duncan. Lucy Brown and orchestra, Town Hail, 2:30 o'clock; Loewenguth Quartet, Times Hall, 3; American Youth Orchestra, Dean Dixon, conductor; Davis Shuman, trombone; Paul Tripp, narrator, Brooklyn Academy, 3; Eleanor Spencer, piano, Town Hall, 5:30.

The clear thinking of an office manager helped the police yesterday to put an end to the short career of the "polite burglar" who had held up at least two finance offices in the midtown area within the last ten days.

The letter from N.I. Stone in your issue of Nov. 9 concerning the relative merits of the present farm price support program and an alternate program of subsidies shows the result of considerable thought, and the logic up to a certain point appears sound enough.

LANSING, Mich., Nov. 26 (AP) -- General Motors Corporation tonight raised prices on some of its 1949 Oldsmobile cars and announced that production of two "Olds" series, the "66" and "68" would be discontinued for 1949. These were the least expensive of Olds' 1948 series.

CHICAGO, Nov. 26 -- The Theatre Guild on the Air, heard over the American Broadcasting Company network, and the documentary unit of the Columbia Broadcasting System have won the awards of the National Council of Teachers of English as "the best literature on the air" in the 1947-1948 school year.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended Nov. 20, 1948, totaled 857,492 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today.

PARIS, Nov. 26 -- Poland's demand that the United Nations find the United States guilty of an attempt to control other nations through the Marshall Plan was overwhelmingly rejected today by the General Assembly.

Nine of the fifteen coffee-makers awarded the Seal of Recommendation of the National Coffee Association are now on the market, according to the head of the association's brewing committee, Edward Aborn. Coffee brewed in a pot receiving the seal, in compliance with the directions that come with the utensil, "is satisfactory on all counts, in the opinion of the coffee industry."

CAIRO, Nov. 26 -- Seven politically prominent Egyptian lawyers, defying the ban by the Government of the Anglo-Egyptian Sudan, tried today to fly ,to the Sudan to defend Mohammed Nur el Din, secretary of the pro-Egyptian Ashigga party, and sixteen others who were arrested during election riots at Atbara twelve days ago.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 26 -- They'll be having a game of football in Municipal Stadium tomorrow that shapes up on the record as the mismatch of the century. A team that has beaten nobody all season is to play one that ranks among the top three of the country with eight successive victories to its credit.

Lumber production for the week ended Nov. 20 was 1.9 per cent below the like week last year but was 6.3 per cent above the previous week. Shipments were 24.4 per cent below last year and orders were down 27.1 per cent according to reports wired yesterday to THE NEW YORK TIMES by trade associations.

Supreme Court Justice Felix C. Benvenga denied yesterday Tammany Hall's petition to declare General Sessions Judge John A. Mullen, Democratic candidate, the New York County Surrogate instead of George Frankenthaler, Republican-Liberal nominee, because of alleged irregularities on election day.

With an emphasis on newspapers, Schenley Distillers Corporation will continue to stress its "look-at-the-back-label" theme throughout its 1949 advertising campaign, it was learned yesterday. The theme, which directs consumer attention to the aged whiskies listed on Schenley's back label, has produced good results through its initial tryout, largely in newspapers, it was noted.

The Metropolitan Garage Board of Trade asserted yesterday that a city-wide survey of public garages showed an average of 14.8 per cent vacancies. The board said that the report compiled by independent accountants would be submitted to the City Council in support of the garage men's contention that legislation to control garage rents was not needed.

PARIS, Nov. 26 -- Edouard Herriot, President of the French Assembly, was chosen today as chairman of the committee named by the Foreign Ministers of the five Brussels Treaty Powers to consider a "greater measure of unity between the European countries."

Jesse Jones, former Secretary of Commerce, testifying for ninety minutes yesterday before Federal Judge Samuel H. Kaufman, said that he never kept a diary while a member of President Roosevelt's Cabinet.

N[rs. Thomas Hitchcock gave a supper dance last night in the ballroom suite of the Ritz-Carlton to introduce to society her elder daughter, Miss Louise E. Hitchcock. The debutante also is a daughter of the late Thomas Hitchcock Jr., the well known polo player.

DUBLIN, Nov. 26 -- Without demonstration or any outward show of feeling, the Daft Eireann unanimously approved tonight, on second reading, the major legislative stage, the Republic of Ireland Bill, cutting the last legal connection between Eire and the British Crown.'

CHICAGO, Nov. 26 -- The National Council for Social Studies took a series of liberal positions today on questions of civil rights and freedom of inquiry ranging from qualified disapproval of loyalty probes to condemnation of the ban on The Nation in the public schools of New York City.

The memory of a little boy's faith in Santa Claus, incubating for ten years in the mind of an artist, is this year's true story behind the Christmas Seal to be sold in the 1948 campaign of the National Tuberculosis Association.
TEL AVIV, Israel, Nov. 26 -- An impasse has been reached in negotiations being conducted by the United Nations for an armistice in southern Palestine.

BARNEGAT, N.J., Nov. 26 -- In the old days they used to say: "A man who guns on Barnegat always comes back," and although the "fowl" were more abundant, the gunners fewer, and the day's bag much heavier in those happy times, the bay seems to have lost none of its old appeal.

BOWIE, Md., Nov. 26 (AP) -- Mrs. J.V. Stewart's Dr. Almac was much the best in the Cherrystone Purse today. Trainer J.V. Stewart forgot to claim an apprentice allowance for the 3-year-old, but Benny Civitello rode regardless. Dr. Almac proved his ability by carrying 115 pounds to a six-length triumph in the test of a mile and a sixteenth involving six horses.

Despite rumors of defections, shipping men and longshore leaders expressed the belief last night that seventy-one locals of the International Longshoremen's Association would ratify their new contract at voting halls today, ending the eighteen-day-old Atlantic maritime strike.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 -- Rate-cutting, pressure of shippers, rising costs of wage and equipment and unbalanced movements are cited by northeastern motor carriers in a petition flied today with the Interstate Commerce Commission asking authority to increase all freight rates and charges and for an investigation of the rate level in that section of the country.

British manufacturers of bone china dinnerware and their American distributors and retailers have taken action to prevent stores from advertising dinnerware imported from countries other than England as "bone china," it was learned yesterday.

PARIS, Nov. 26 -- The United Nations General Assembly opened a full dress debate tonight on the Balkan controversy and heard a Yugoslav charge that the United States was waging a war against the Greek people.

RANGOON, Burma, Nov. 26 (AP) -- The Supreme Council of the White Band (Nationalist) People's Volunteer Organizations ordered a cease fire today in all sectors where the Organization's forces are operating against the Government.

Negro real estate dealers issued an appeal yesterday to colleges, fraternal and social organizations and churches to invest more in mortgages insured by the Federal Housing Administration. The appeal was drawn up by officers of the National Builders Association and the National Association of Real Estate Brokers at a meeting at the United Mutual Life Insurance Company, 310 Lenox Avenue.

The Advent season will begin tomorrow in the churches. Forty hours' devotion will be started in St. Patrick's Roman Catholic Cathedral, Fifth Avenue and Fiftieth Street, at 10 A.M. Men of the Nocturnal Adoration Society will attend a holy hour tomorrow night, offering prayers of thanksgiving, adoration, reparation and supplication.

Donald M. Mumford, who has risen from coffee boy in a Tampa hotel to top rank among hotel executives in the last twenty-one years, will assume the post of general manager of the Statler Hotel in St. Louis next Wednesday, the Pennsylvania Hotel announced yesterday.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange were moderately active yesterday, closing unchanged to 8 points lower.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 (UP) -- The Commerce Department announced today appointment of Ernest J. Christie as head of the New York City Weather Bureau office. He will replace Benjamin Parry, who is retiring after forty-five years' service with the Weather Bureau, the department said.

Television station WNBT will hold a one-performance tryout at 6:30 P.M. next Tuesday of a program entitled "Cave of the Winds." Described as "a conversation piece" whereon guests will discuss a variety of subjects, the first performance will have the services of Gypsy Rose Lee, James Michener, Henry Morgan and Basil Davenport, with Ben Grauer serving as moderator.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 -- President Truman vetoed today a proposal of Representative Sol Bloom, Democrat, of New York, that he invite Generalissimo Chiang Kaishek to visit the United States and give this Government a first-hand account of the situation in China.

Sid Tanenbaum, former N.Y.U. star and Goebel Ritter, rookie from Eastern Kentucky State College who turned in top-flight performances in his last two starts, will be in the opening line-up of the Knickerbockers when the New Yorkers oppose the Fort Wayne Pistons in a Basketball Association of America test at the Sixty-ninth Regiment Armory tonight.

At least four nations are ready to be represented by teams of speed boats propelled by aircraft engines of fantastic, unheard-of power in a resumption next summer of racing for the famous British International Trophy, better known as the Harmsworth.

CHICAGO, Nov. 26 -- The National Council on Family Relations, opening its annual conference here today, was told that "psychiatry is gradually centering less on psychopathology and is embracing within its field wider concepts of mental hygiene as a whole."
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Nov. 26 -- Many nations have indicated interest in the new high-speed gun for use against jet planes now in the testing stage in the famous Swedish Bofors factory.

An unprecedentedly wide range of prices is being quoted on brass goods by New York distributors, purchasing sources disclosed here yesterday. Products now have a "wider spread" of prices between competitors than has appeared in regular quotations for many years, they pointed out.

DETROIT, Nov. 26 (AP) -- Ward's Automotive Reports said today prospects are strong the automotive industry this year will hit the second highest production volume in history with an estimated 5,513,000 units.

India will produce 40 per cent more pepper this year, compared with the subnormal output in 1947, with production estimated at from 22,000 to 25,000 tons, Vallabhdas V. Mariwala, president of the Pepper and Ginger Merchants Association, Ltd., Bombay, said here yesterday.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 26 -- West Coast operators accelerated negotiations with three seagoing unions today in the hope of quickly reaching agreements to match that reached yesterday by the CIO longshoremen and the Waterfront Employers Association.
Hide futures prices declined 55 to 60 points on the Commodity Exchange yesterday under the influence of liquidation of the December contract.

Frank Ciraolo, 27-year-old laborer, of 2164 East Fourth Street, Brooklyn, was held without bail yesterday by Magistrate Morris Rothenberg after he refused to waive extradition on a fugitive complaint charging homicide and armed robbery in Pennsylvania.
LAKE SUCCESS, Nov. 26 -- The text of the United Nations General Assembly resolution on South-West Africa, as made public today:

The purchase of the fifty-six-acre Nomahegan Golf Club property on Springfield Avenue in Cranford, N.J., from the Nomahegan Company by the Union Junior College as a future site for the educational institution was announced yesterday by Dr. Kenneth C. MacKay, secretary of the board of trustees.

BELGRADE, Nov. 26 -- In a speech marking a turning point in the struggle against the Communist Information Bureau, Premier Marshal Tito yesterday told the second congress of the Croatian Communist party in Zagreb that economic difficulties with the Cominform states had now obliged the Yugoslavs to "reorganize and regroup" the five-year plan to industrialize their country and to eliminate all secondary projects.

Possibly indicating a seasonal trend, commercial lending in this area has declined for the second week in succession, falling $18,000,000 during the week ended on Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York disclosed yesterday.
CARACAS, Venezuela, Nov. 26 -- The Junta governing Venezuela since the recent coup worked rapidly today to establish normality throughout the country. Various state governors were named.
MOSCOW, Nov. 26 (Reuters) -- Ivan Zaikin, "modern Hercules" of the Soviet Union and a former wrestling champion, died in his home town of Kishinev at the age of 66.

CEDAR GROVE, N.J., Nov. 26 -- Agitation for a paid fire department is in progress in this north Jersey community, after the death of Mrs. Mildred Smith, 46 years old, town tax collector, and the narrow escape from asphyxiation of her husband, Howard.

The Journal of the American Medical Association reiterates the charge that because of our cumbrous and inadequate system of coroners' inquests far too many murderers escape the law. The charge is probably true. In olden times a coroner's inquest was held by those who knew all the local witnesses and sometimes the murderer, so that rough justice was done.

PARIS, Nov. 26 -- The United States came out today in support of a world-wide United Nations Appeal for Children next year in a sudden move that amounted to a reversal in principle of its previous stand.

SUCHOW, China, Nov. 26 -- Tension has eased here following the end of round one in the Communist offensive directed at the heart of the Central Government in the Yangtze Valley. But large concentrations of Communist troops still operating in East-Central China provide a real threat for the harassed Nanking regime.

Directors of the Babcock Wilcox Company declared extra dividends of $1 in.cash and 5 per cent in stock, both payable Dec. 20, and a dividend of $1 payable Jan. 31. Previous payments this year were $1 each in October, July and April. In 1947 the organization paid 50 cents in April and $1 each in July, October and December.

CHICAGO, Nov. 26 -- The railroads cannot continue to meet a never ending series of wage demands without getting their rates so high that loss of business to their competitors will result, L.W. Horning, vice president of the New York Central System, testified today before a Presidential Fact-Finding Board.

Mayor O'Dwyer officiated yesterday at the laying of the cornerstone of the $5,632,000 James Ewing Hospital, the city's latest contribution in the fight against cancer. With completion next year of the ten-story structure on First Avenue, between Sixty-seventh and Sixty-eighth Streets, the city will have another 300 beds at its disposal for cancer patients.

A plot containing 300,000 square feet on the west side of Middle Neck Road between Cloverdale Avenue and Old Mill Road in Great Neck, L.I., has been purchased for improvement with a garden type apartment house by the Josar Holding Corporation of Great Neck.

Despite the public concern and statewide disapproval of the invasion of the Adirondack Preserve by the proposed construction of the Panther Mountain Reservoir, the Black River Regulating District Board has declared that it intends to carry out the plan. If this is done, it will flood one of the most important deer-harboring areas in the Preserve.

ALBANY, Nov. 26 -- State Senator Harold I. Panken, Manhattan Democrat, announced today that he intended to press for early consideration and passage in the coming legislative session of a measure to outlaw segregation in the New York National Guard.

The Army transport Comfort, which became disabled at sea Nov. 17 while en route to Bremerhaven, Germany, arrived back in port yesterday to discharge her 361 passengers. The vessel, which docked at Pier 11, Tompkinsville, S.I., at 9:55 A.M., will undergo extensive engine repairs before sailing again.

ROME, Nov. 26 -- An Anglo-Italian agreement was announced by the Foreign Ministry this evening to permit sterling to reach its parity of $4.03 to the pound on the Italian market and to unblock at least part of the Italian credits that have been piling up in London.

ALBANY, Nov. 26 -- The State Education Department reported today that college enrollment in New York State this year set a new high of 314,009, as compared with last year's all-time record of 309,385.

PARIS, Nov. 26 -- The United Nations General Assembly adopted today by a vote of 43 to 1 a resolution criticizing South Africa for her refusal to place the adjacent territory of South-West Africa under the trusteeship system.
TOLEDO, Ohio, Nov. 26 (AP) -- Good luck in a game of matching silver dollars with strangers ended in a beating for a Dayton, Ohio, industrialist, he told authorities today.

BEIRUT, Nov. 26 -- The United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Committee chose Jaime Torres Bodet, Mexican Foreign Secretary, today as Director General for the next six years, and invited him to come immediately to Beirut to join in the work of its conference.

PARIS, Nov. 26 -- Solution of the Berlin dispute appeared to be farther off than ever today. The publication of the Big Four replies to Dr. Juan Atilio Bramuglia's questions about the problem showed that the Soviet Union had refused to make a conciliatory gesture and the Western powers had made it clear that they considered the unity of the Berlin city administration as the basic prerequisite for an agreement.

Kenneth H. Burns of the Montclair Golf Club will succeed Theodore G. Law of the Briar Hills Country Club as secretary of the Metropolitan Golf Association in the only change of officers that will be submitted to the membership at the annual meeting of the organization at the Hotel Roosevelt on Tuesday, Dec. 28.

St. John's University, paced by Dick McGuire, Ivy Sumner and Al McGuire, romped to an 85-53 victory over John Marshall College of Jersey City at DeGray Gymnasium, Brooklyn, last night. The triumph was the third in succession for the Redmen, who are unbeaten this season.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 -- The Food and Agriculture Organization Commission, which is considering world food needs, today adopted a resolution asking for an investigation as to what financial facilities were available to world agriculture and calling for closer cooperation between FAO and the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development.

Joe E. Brown received a gold rabbit, four live white rabbits and a cherry meringue pie in his face as the "fall guy" of the Circus Saints and Sinners at a luncheon in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel yesterday.

Financing for the natural-gas industry will figure prominently in the public offerings of securities next week. The marketings will include $26,500,000 of 5 per cent notes of the Transcontinental Gas Pipe Line Co. along with 265,000 shares of common stock and warrants for the purchase of 265,000 common shares.

The stock market took another swing yesterday into lower territory and touched the lowest marks since last March. Weakness in the textile issues gave an air of softness not representative of the market as a whole, for the composite rate showed the slight advance of 0.02 point on the day.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., Nov. 26 (AP) -- Undefeated Notre Dame will meet the University of Washington's Huskies on the football field here tomorrow for the first time in history. The Irish will be shooting for their twenty-first consecutive triumph.
COLUMBIA, Mo., Nov. 26 (AP) -- The University of Missouri today accepted a bid to play in the third annual 'Gator Bowl at Jacksonville, Fla., on Jan. 1.
LOS ANGELES, Nov. 26 -- Winds approaching hurricane force buffeted southern California today, stirring up a dust storm in the arid inland area and causing many disruptions.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 -- Leaders for the Truman civil-rights program have now arrived at a conclusion that the foreshadowed Southern filibuster against it actually can be broken this time in the Senate. This was learned today in responsible quarters which disclosed also the techniques by which they feel that the Southerners ultimately can be silenced in a Democratic Congress where the last Republican Congress had failed to do so.
JERUSALEM, Nov. 26 (UP) -- The British and the Jews have agreed to export potash from the Dead Sea through the disputed Negeb desert to southern Palestine, authoritative sources said today.

After a detective testified in Mid-Manhattan Court that a police investigation failed to connect Alan Harris in any way with the recent outbreak of air rifle sniping in the midtown area, Magistrate Benjamin Brenner released the 23-year-old insurance agent under a suspended sentence for violating the administrative code by possessing an air rifle.

BARTLESVILLE, Okla., Nov. 26 -- K.S. Adams, president of the Phillips Petroleum Company, announced today that the company has increased its prices for crude oil 35 cents a barrel at all points in Montana where it purchases. The increase was made effective retroactively to 7 A.M., Nov. 24.
