WALTHAM, Mass., Nov. 27 -- A gift of $250,000 to be used for the construction of a library building has been received by Brandeis University, Dr. Abram L. Sachar, its president, announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 (AP) -- Junior Hadassah, the Young Women's Zionist Organization of America, adopted a $201,300 budget today at the closing session of a three-day gathering here. The money will be used for the organization's work in Israel in aid of youth and immigration.

EVER since those nuggets were found in President Polk's day, history enough for an empire has piled up in San Francisco. That was a tumultuous past. Or rather, a start. For all its hymned serenity, a reasonable amount of tumult has always animated San Francisco.

LITHOPOLIS, Ohio, Nov. 27 (AP) -- The affection of an heiress for her father's birthplace has most teen-agers in this one-street central Ohio village engrossed in a welter of college catalogues. Every boy and girl living in Lithopolis -- population 288 -- can have a grant of $450 a year to attend college just for the asking.

ELSWYTH THANE has written plays, biographies and novels -- and always turns out a readable book with abundant love interest. "Kissing Kin," the fifth novel in a series about an interesting Williamsburg, Va., family, offers a typically entertaining story, full of lightness -- and sorrows too, since its setting is World War I and the darkening shadows of the postwar years.

The release last week by the Navy Department of some of the key documents dealing with the now - famous "Smith - vs. - Smith" controversy adds a new chapter -- though by no means the final one to the history of a wartime episode.

IT is becoming the fashion to say in Hollywood that the "take-that-you-rat" school of drama is going out, and if I am not as sanguine about this as some of the practitioners of a gentler mode of drama, it is not merely because I earn my living in this department of the workaday world.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 (UP) -- World food planners today quietly dropped a proposal urging the surplus producing nations to guarantee prices received by their own farmers.

ATLANTA, Ga., Nov. 27 -- Equal educational facilities for Negroes and an effort by a group of citizens in a Georgia city to enact a law which would unmask the Ku Klux Klan were among subjects of topmost public interest in the Deep South this week.
LAFAYETTE, Ind., Nov 27 -- Highway engineers of Purdue University here have developed a new cement slurry which is said to correct highway "pumping" and thus prevent pavement breakdowns.

SALONIKA, Nov. 27 -- A handful of energetic international public servants are the unsung heroes of the Greek civil war. They are the thirty-six military observers for the United Nations Special Committee on the Balkans.

BOSTON, Mass., Nov. 27 -- Although their Thanksgiving dinners cost about 17 per cent more than last year, New Englanders expressed thanks this week for word from the Bureau of Labor Statistics that food prices had dropped somewhat between September and October.

DETROIT, Nov. 27 (AP) -- Bill Mosienko scored four goals and the Chicago Black Hawks overcame a 3-0 deficit tonight for a 5 to 3 National Hockey League victory over the Detroit Red Wings before 13,112 fans.
MOBILE, Ala., Nov. 27 (AP) -- Clemson's undefeated Tigers rallied to trim Auburn today, 7 -- 6, and then landed in Jacksonville's Gator Bowl. They will play Missouri there in the New Year's Day game.

THIRTY years ago Frederick H. Koch, who had been stimulating his students in North Dakota to write pageant plays about community life, was called to the University of North Carolina to take charge of the drama work there.

CHICAGO, Nov. 27 -- The serious repercussions of the recent East and West Coast longshoremen's strikes on the wheat and corn belt farms and the high prices of Christmas toys and holiday turkeys aroused complaints this week among Central Westerners.

NANKING, Nov, 27 (AP) -- Chinese Government armies, evidently abandoning their old positional warfare, were battling the Communists in the open today in a zone extending from thirty-five to 200 miles northwest of Nanking.

THE Philadelphia Orchestra is now so sure that the difficulties of visiting England can be surmounted that it has revealed it expects to start its tour there on May 13. And a cable has come from London announcing that the Royal Philharmonic Orchestra, led by Sir Thomas Beecham, will come to this country.

The zeal of those whose letters have been printed in your columns, attempting to justify the military invasion of Hyderabad by the Dominion of India, is obviously due to a guilty conscience, the most zealous of all justifiers.

American Aid to France and the Goddard Neighborhood Center will be the joint beneficiaries of a loan exhibition of the paintings of Gustave Courbet, which will open Wednesday night with a preview at the Wildenstein Gallery, 19 East Sixty-fourth Street. The showing will be open to the public on Thursday and will continue there through Jan. 8.

New Yorkers will be treated to a new type of sports show tonight when the Roller Derby, a combination of ice hockey, football and a six-day bicycle race, opens at the Sixty-ninth Regiment Armory, Lexington Avenue and Twenty-fifth Street.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 27 (AP) -- The American College of Physicians announced yesterday scholarship appointments for eight young physicians preparing for a teaching and investigative career in internal medicine.

SALT LAKE CITY, Nov. 27 -- Conditions abroad pressed more sharply than ever upon Westerners this week with word that the big World War II airbases at Mountain Home, Idaho, and Las Vegas, Nev., will be reactivated Dec. l. At Great Falls, Mont., citizens already feel the impact of overseas affairs, with dozens of Air Force planes roaring above the town daily on flights duplicating Berlin airlift conditions.

SINCE my first performance on Broadway as Blanche in "A Streetcar Named Desire" some -- December 3, 1947, to be exact -- two motion pictures I had made in Hollywood prior to coming east flickered briefly across local screens, then departed and, for all I know, are still being shown somewhere in this broad land or beyond the seas.

NANKING, Nov. 27 -- Not more than a month ago the shopkeepers of Nanking were trying to hide their goods to keep from being ruined in the mad buying sprees that broke out during the Government's ill-fated price-control program.

RICHMOND, Va., Nov. 27 -- Residents of the Upper South, who have been feeling pretty good about things lately, let an old familiar refrain creep back into their conversations this week -- the high cost of living -- and, related to it, the high cost of government.
LONDON, Nov. 27 (Reuters) -- Heavy fog and Manchester City provided the soccer news in Britain today.

CAMELLIAS are associated in our minds with warm climates and heated green-houses, but the hope persists that they will grow as house plants. Interest in this flower has definitely revived -- witness the rapid growth of the American Camellia Society, which is not yet three years old.

Dr. Jakob Bjerknes, Professor of Meteorology at the University of California at Los Angeles, addressing the recent meeting of the National Academy of Sciences at Berkeley, Calif., offered an explanation of one of the standing enigmas of meteorology -- the tides in the atmosphere produced by the sun.

HERE is a detective story in reverse. Instead of a detective seeking a murderer, we have a murderer seeking a detective. Margot Weatherby is tired of waiting for her husband to die and has already made an unsuccessful effort to put him out of the way.

ANDREW MELLICK'S rambling story of a New Jersey farmstead is a curiosity discovered in the attic heaps of forgotten literature by Mr. Schmidt, Rutgers history professor. One is moved to think of those incredibly circumstantial and localized jottings into which frustrated historians of the WPA projects poured their hearts.

The CIO, whose conventions customarily are tumultous affairs, outdid itself last week. Its tenth annual convention, at Masonic Temple in Portland, Ore., proved to be the noisiest in CIO history. The reason was a wide-open fight -- the first at a national convention -- between the CIO's right and left wings. Most of the noise came from the right. There were frequent shouts to the leftists of "Take a walk!" and "Go back to Russia!"
CEDAR LAKE, Ind., Nov. 27 -- A part of Henry Huppenthal's farm near here has bulged up fifteen feet.
WHEN President Miguel Aleman took office in December, 1946, he meant to most of Mexico nothing less than a new era.

TO provide improved service between Philadelphia, Reading and Pottsville, the Reading Railroad has placed in service the Schuylkill, a modernized streamlined train powered by a Pacific type 4-6-2 locomotive.

Huntington T. Morse, chief American delegate to the Inter Governmental Maritime Consultative Organization's preparatory committee meeting opening at Lake Success on Tuesday, predicted yesterday unqualified success for the new world shipping agency.

DALLAS, Nov. 27 -- Southern Methodist rode with the passing arm of Gil Johnson to a 7-7 thrill-packed tie against Texas Christian in the season's finale today, then heard its opponent in the Cotton Bowl would be the University of Oregon.

CHRISTMAS gifts for gardeners this year include a few bright new ideas, plus a host of older, tried and true presents. Living plants for both outdoor and indoor use, tools and equipment, furniture and dozens of accessories from buttonhole vases to more-than-life-size statues present a kind of garden show all their own this month.
PROVIDENCE, R. I., Nov. 27 -- What Cheer Lodge No. 5, Masters, Mates and Pilots Association, AFL, has begun a campaign to make this one-time flourishing port a beehive of shipping activity again.

ONLY one news photographer is invited to be present when John Caldwell, head of a vast industrial empire, is to make an important announcement over the radio. Kent Murdock is chosen for the job, although had the Caldwells known of his reputation as a sleuth they might have made a different choice.

DETROIT, Nov. 27 -- Bob Black, Rhode Island State College's 120-pound national collegiate cross-country champion, won the national A. A. U. senior 10,000 meters (cross-country) title today by the unbelievable margin of two inches over Curt Stone, defending champion from Philadelphia.

MADRID, Nov. 27 (Reuters) -- Seven United States Congressmen arrived unexpectedly in Madrid from Rome tonight and were expected to see leading Spanish military personalities before leaving for Paris and London Monday.

CASSVILLE, N. J. -- Those whose plans to travel abroad never seem to come to realization can take comfort in the fact that it is quite possible to be abroad at home. The growth of the United States has enabled all the many cultures of the Old World to settle and thrive beside our oldest American communities.

MORGANTOWN, W. Va., Nov. 27 (AP) -- The toe of a 147-pound drop-kicker and a costly Maryland fumble in the fourth quarter gave West Virginia University a 16-14 decision over the University of Maryland today.
FROM the time the Yuletide season begins until normalcy returns to the American home, some three dozen plays and musicals will be available to shoppers at the Broadway box offices.

PARIS, Nov. 27 -- After eight weeks of resistance, the Communist-led French General Confederation of Labor called off the coal strike tonight and instructed all its miners in France to return to work on Monday.

The letter published on Oct. 31, signed by a former counsel and review board member of the United States war crimes staff in Germany, is a strange exhibition of special pleading which should not remain unanswered.

In his book, "The Nightmare of American Foreign Policy," Edgar Ansell Mowrer declares "all human beings are born with a lust for power. * * * Power is the primary purpose of people in politics. * * * Balance or division, of power is the main safeguard of freedom, whether within the single state, or within a system of sovereign states.

A program for improving the nation's public schools, calling for education for democracy and the "responsibilities of marriage and family relations," was announced this week by Teachers College, Columbia University. Drafted by the Institute of Field Studies and based on a survey of the school facilities of Montclair, N. J., the report says:

BRATISLAVA, Czechoslovakia, Nov. 27 -- The Czechoslovak state, according to Catholic sources, has resumed the efforts of the strong absolutist monarchies of centuries ago to control the appointment to bishoprics, parishes and other positions within the hierarchy of the church.

A PART of the drama of the United Nations General Assembly session here is the rise to prominence in the diplomatic corps of professorial Philip C. Jessup, who left Columbia University on a sabbatical for the spotlight of the international stage.

The Rev. Dr. James Christopher Healey, who was an ordinary seaman on a British merchant ship at the turn of the century, and later a Methodist minister, became a Protestant Episcopal deacon yesterday morning at the age of 66, and started his second career as a clergyman.

PARIS, Nov. 27 -- The rights of minorities will not be specifically dealt with in the International Declaration on Human Rights, the Social Committee of the United Nations General Assembly decided here today. By 24 to 0, with sixteen abstentions, the committee adopted a Haitian resolution asking the Economic and Social Council, the Human Rights Commission and its subcommission on the protection of minorities to study the question.

MISS BROWN, for very many years teacher of history at Vassar College, and Professor Carson, who teaches social science at New Paltz, N. Y., have written an excellently illustrated textbook for introductory college courses in European history.

LAKEWOOD, N. J., Nov. 27 -- Once in a while we encounter an individual, or a small group, with sufficient interest in good hunting to devote some expenditure of time and effort to get it, and in each instance we are surprised by the results.
Longshoremen who have paralyzed the Atlantic seaboard in an eighteen-day strike ended the walkout yesterday by a 9 to 1 vote.

SANIBEL ISLAND, Fla. -- One of the finest places in the world to collect rare sea shells is this tiny island off the west coast of Florida, where shells worth hundreds of dollars have been found. Rumor has it that pirate gold is buried along the shores, and Spanish treasure from the galleon ships of long ago.

BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 27 -- Trade between the United States and Argentina will henceforth cancel out almost to the dollar, so that neither country will have a favorable or unfavorable balance, according to the latest pronouncements of President Peron's economic chief, Miguel Miranda.

LONDON, Nov. 27 -- Britain is in danger of losing touch with the West Indies through her failure to provide adequate steamship services to the eastern Caribbean, the Commonwealth Shipping Committee said in a report to be published tomorrow.

MR. HOBBS' ability to imitate animal noises -- a sideline to his ability to repair bicycles and clocks -- helped him cure the little dog, Bun, of chasing cars. Randy, the small boy next door, had brought Bun home from school, hoping to keep him.

TOKYO, Sunday, Nov. 28 -- A warrant for the arrest of former Premier Hitoshi Ashida in connection with the notorious Showa Denko bribery scandal was sought today. The Tokyo District Court requested Premier Shigeru Yoshida to ask the Imperial Diet to authorize the arrest of Mr. Yoshida's predecessor, who as a member of the Diet would otherwise be immune from arrest while the Diet is in session.
PORTLAND, Ore., Nov. 27 (AP) -- Oregon State power overcame the Nebraska Cornhuskers today, 28 -- 12, on a sloppy gridiron swept by a raw wind.

Twelve years after the Federal Government set up an old-age insurance program to free aged men and women from the need for public charity, taxpayers are spending seven times as much to provide relief for the needy as they did in the last year before the insurance program began operating.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Nov. 27 (UP) -- Vanderbilt humbled Tennessee for the first time since 1937 today, 28 to 6. After starting with two losses and a tie, Vandy has won seven in a row. The Commodores play Miami next week.

THANKS to the presence of Madeleine Carroll, "Goodbye, My Fancy" turns out to be one of the most delightful comedies of the season. No doubt any one of several other actresses would be thoroughly capable of acting the leading part in Fay Kanin's literate drama and would bring to it qualities of skill and personality that would also be interesting.

Eleven counties in eight states from New Hampshire to Oregon carried on this year their records of voting with the winning side in all Presidential elections since 1896, it was shown yesterday in a survey. A twelfth county with a similar record -- San Joaquin in California -- failed to keep it up.

CHICAGO, Nov. 27 -- Dr. Ernest G. Osborne, Professor of Education at Teachers College, Columbia University, in his presidential address today before the National Council on Family Relations, admonished that "various professional people -- working human beings -- must avoid becoming complacent."

Continuing the decline noted for several weeks, retail trade volume here last week fell below that of the like week last year by a considerable margin. Department store sales were estimated at 9 to 10 per cent under last year. Unseasonable weather and price resistance were cited as major factors.

Thrilling the largest crowd of the indoor season with some topflight polo last night, Del Carroll led Arlington Farms of Chicago to a 15 to 13 triumph over the Manhattan trio of Paul Miller, Al Parsells and Billy Rand at Squadron A Armory. Carroll, who captained Arlington Farms to the national open indoor championship last season, slapped seven goals off the backboard, four of them in the last period.

MADRID, Nov. 27 -- The Cabinet under the Presidency of Generalissimo Francisco Franco last night devoted the major part of its weekly meeting to the grave economic strain on the nation resulting from the drought, which is one of the worst in recent history. The attendant power shortage is serious.

OXFORD, Miss., Nov. 27 (UP) -- Big Barney Poole said his long-delayed farewell to collegiate football today, catching two touchdown passes to pace Mississippi to a 34-7 victory over sluggish Mississippi State.

The first semblance of a threat to the continued integrated operation of the world's largest corporate enterprise, the $8,000,000,000 American Telephone and Telegraph Company, is shaping slowly in the powerful National Association of Railroad and Utilities Commissioners.

BOWIE, Md., Nov. 27 -- Henry L. Straus' Pilaster scored his fifth stakes victory of the Maryland fall season in the $20,000 added Bryan and O'Hara Memorial Handicap today before a crowd of 16,988 as the major Eastern racing season ended.

MARY MARGARET McBRIDE is the first major figure indigenous to the medium of radio to prove an early fatality in the field of television. After her performance on Dec. 14 she will be taking leave of the NBC video network.

DODGE CITY, Kan., Nov. 27 (UP) -- The Kansas Highway Patrol warned motorists tonight to "get off the highways in western Kansas and stay off," and indicated it feared loss of life in a new midwestern blizzard.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 (AP) -- The GI loan and unemployment-allowance programs dropped to two-or-three-year lows during October, the Veterans Administration said today.

MITCHEL AIR FORCE BASE, L. I., Nov. 27 -- When Col. John V. Hart, commanding the Air Force Reserve Training Center here, looked out the window of his office above the operations room yesterday afternoon and saw four T-6 single-engine training planes come in to land, peeling off in neat tactical approach, he remarked:
WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 (UP) -- James C. Petrillo, president of the American Federation of Musicians, has been selected to whip together an inaugural eve entertainment show in honor of President Truman.

SUCHOW, Nov. 27 -- Although the Chinese Communists have switched their emphasis from lightning-like raids to positional warfare, they are still attacking the Nationalists with their traditional guerrilla tactics aimed at "cutting down the big tree slice by slice"

VIENNA, Nov. 27 -- Seen from Vienna, close up against the Iron Curtain, Czechoslovakia seems to be repeating the common pattern being created by the Communists and stretching from Vladivostok to the farthest western point of the Czechoslovak frontier.

HAMILTON, Mont., Nov. 27 -- Measures to control encephalitis, or sleeping sickness, in human beings are sought in a long-range study being conducted by scientists at the United States Public Health Service Rocky Mountain laboratory here. This is the same base from which other scientists earlier successfully battled Rocky Mountain spotted fever.

PEIPING, Nov. 27 -- The redistribution of troops that the Nationalist North China Commander, Gen. Fu Tso-yl, has effected within the last week, is believed to indicate that he intends to put up a bitter fight for the defense of the railroad corridor from Peiping to the sea.

THE second volume of the personal letters of Franklin D. Roosevelt supplies revealing and intimate glimpses of the most remarkable American of our time. The first volume, published last year, exhibited young Roosevelt as a student at Groton and Harvard, and ended with his marriage to Anna Eleanor Roosevelt in 1905.
CHICAGO, Nov. 27 (AP) -- Middle Atlantic's No. 1 team today maintained its perfect record in the finals of the women's national field hockey tournament, finishing with its third straight victory.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 (UP) -- The Veterans Administration told the story tonight of a legless war veteran who recently harvested a 120-acre corn crop twice as rich as the estimated national average. The veteran is Ralph G. Neppel, aged 25, of Carroll, Iowa.

WITH the approach of winter, homemakers are beginning to plan a variety of seasonal entertainments -- Sunday night suppers, buffets and holiday parties. Setting the mood of the gatherings are table arrangements such as those shown here. Many are happy combinations of simple and elaborate accessories arranged to meet the needs of servantless households.
TEL AVIV, Israel, Nov. 27 -- E. S. Hoofien, newly appointed Israeli Economic Director, called on the population today for an era of "severe austerity" to combat the spiralling cost of living.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Nov. 27 (AP) -- William and Mary utilized a bruising line and sharp punting to defeat the Arkansas Razorbacks, 9 to 0, today. The Indians punched over a third quarter touchdown and kept the Razorbacks hemmed against their own goal the remainder of the game.

DURING the long months before even the earliest bulbs begin to flower, the freshly tamped soil which covers them is apt to present a bleak, barren view. For some gardeners, the promise of bold bloom yet to come is enough; to others, these bare spots are unpleasant and unsightly. What is more, they are unnecessary, for a low-growing ground cover camouflages them and adds interest to the garden.

Y., some very provocative and suggestive reflections on the subject of psychological analysis in fiction.

Students at Colgate University must now meet a minimum foreign language requirement before promotion to the junior class. Four options are available for meeting the requirement. CAMPO GRANDE, Brazil, Nov. 26 -- This town in the State of Mato Grosso is just about the geographical heart of South America. Within less than a month two governments have fallen west and north of here; within eight months it has been ringed by plots, coups and states of siege.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 -- President Truman is getting more free advice these days than a man who has just won the Irish Sweepstakes. WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 -- The Government defended the ouster of the CIO United Electrical Workers Union from atomic energy plants today on the basis of security regulations authorized by the Atomic Energy Act of 1946. THE coastal regions of South America, innumerable islands, the Antarctic, and vast stretches of the South Atlantic and South Pacific Oceans are the habitat of the littoral, inshore, offshore and pelagic birds considered by Dr. Murphy in this absorbing book.

NORTH AMERICA'S biggest meat-eating creature is increasing in numbers so rapidly that biologists and foresters have begun worrying about where his next meat is going to come from. BELGRADE, Nov. 27 -- Premier Marshal Tito's decision to revise aid consolidate the five-year plan was the first basic one taken as the result of the conflict with the Communist Information Bureau. LIQUID stainless steel, which can be brushed or sprayed, is offered by the Lockrey Company, College Point, N. Y., as a standard finish for darkroom benches and sinks. The new material is designed to replace the traditional asphaltum paint used for these purposes.

Retail activity continued at a brisk pace here last week, according to a survey made especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Meyer Both Reports. Christmas gift sales showed a marked increase in main floor and toy departments.

The interesting ruminations a few days ago in which Robert W. Dowling stated the case for the "vertical city" as the answer to some of our problems in the quest for good living make their useful contribution to the rather considerable discussion lately on planning for tomorrow.
MOSCOW, Nov. 27 (AP) -- The advertising industry is growing by leaps and bounds in the Soviet Union.

NO popularity poll was needed to establish that the best, brightest and fastest vaudeville show the British Broadcasting Corporation has ever staged on television was its recent presentation of the Lido Cabaret, brought over complete from Paris by air.

MADISON, Ill., Nov. 27 -- Residents of this city of 8,000 population will get a free ride within three years at the expense of motorists who use the Chain of Rocks Bridge over the Mississippi River. The city is across the river from North St. Louis.

Heavy industries in the New York area have fixed production budgets for the first half of 1949 at 5 per cent over schedules for the last six months. This was made clear yesterday in a canvass of leading companies whose products include machinery, railroad equipment, castings, power plant equipment, metal refining products and automotive parts.

HERE is another novel about a novelist. But it is a curious one; its exposition, its Italian scene are mere excuses for an elaborate defense of the "thriller." You see, the hero writes them. Not only that, but he himself has been tried for the murder of his wife.

SCATTERED pink flowers lingering on the low mounds of garland flower (Daphne cneorum) remind the gardener of the plant's numerous merits. Off and on until very late in the year, a few blossoms may appear, and I've had some as far along as early December.

TACOMA, Wash., Nov. 27 (UP) -- Penn State, forced to fight bitterly for every yard, defeated an inspired Washington State team, 7 -- 0, today before 18,000 fans on a 55-yard march late in the second period.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 27 -- For the first time since daily prayers were instituted at Harvard 312 years ago, they are being attended by a woman, the current Harvard Alumni Bulletin discloses.

"THE Drug Addict," a film subject on a theme gingerly avoided by Hollywood for Production Code reasons, has been completed by the National Film Board of Canada only to run into a hurdle. According to one recent trade paper report from Toronto, the United States Treasury Department requested, through the Canadian Ambassador in Washington that the picture not be distributed in the United States.

TOKYO, Nov. 27 -- There will be "no explanation and no comment" from Gen. Douglas MacArthur's headquarters regarding the policy of secrecy imposed by the Army concerning the execution of Hideki Tojo and other Japanese war criminals whose death sentences were upheld by the Supreme Allied Command Wednesday.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 27 -- In the opinion of President Truman the Navy won the football game today.
CLEVELAND, Nov. 27 -- The "pocketbook nerve" decided the 1948 Presidential election.

GENEVA, Nov. 27 (UP) -- The seafarers' section of the International Transport Workers Federation decided today to boycott permanently ships "spuriously" transferred to Panamanian or Honduran flags. The boycott would begin May 1, 1949.

Observance of the Thanksgiving holiday slowed activity in the wholesale apparel market here last week, according to a report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell Company, resident buying office. Buyers of better coats and suits completed spring orders, but orders for spring dresses were very light.

GREAT cook books, like great cooks, are rare; but as in other literary fields, there is a tremendous output of useful, though not classic, material. Generally one progresses from the single volume of basic cookery to more specialized books -- those that have a particular angle or concentrate on certain types of foods, regional or national foods.
CHICAGO, Nov. 27 -- Good language was defined today as "language that is comfortable both to the speaker and to the listener, calling attention to itself as little as possible."

PRETORIA, South Africa, Nov. 27 -- Although the General Assembly of the United Nations for the third year in succession recommended last night that South-West Africa be placed under trusteeship, all indications here today were that the recommendations would again remain a dead letter.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Nov. 27 -- Four and one-half months of political warfare between the Yugoslav Communist party and the countries of the Communist Information Bureau bloc find Premier Marshal Tito going from strength to strength, while his Cominform enemies are left to contemplate the dismal failure of their plans to overthrow him.

GENEVA, Nov. 27 -- As the Christmas season approaches, the thoughts of many Americans in Europe are on Europe's neediest -- 148,000 of the old, the injured, the mentally deficient, the blind and maimed victims of war and concentration camp whom nobody wants.

CHICAGO, Nov. 27 -- The Presidential fact-finding board studying the railroad dispute over the demands of sixteen non-operating unions for higher wages and shorter working hours ended its sessions here today. Its next task will be to digest the immense amount of testimony for and against the demands.
SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 27 -- The University of California's African expedition, one of the largest scientific ventures ever attempted, has justified its $500,000 investment, its organizer said today.

RETURNING to Israel from a musical "blitz" tour of Europe and the United States, still reveling in the memories of a beautiful summer at Tanglewood and of Serge Koussevitzky's unique music center, I was all the same thrilled to experience again the bustling musical activities in the land of Israel.

APPARENTLY a question which this reviewer raised in a recent Sunday article on "The Snake Pit" set some of our readers by the ears. The question was simply whether the system of saturation exhibition which now prevails in the motion picture business permits the most fitting -- and the most profitable -- retailing to the public of exceptional films.

CHIEFLY known as an indefatigable pioneer in behalf of Hasidism, the mystic philosophy which originated within eastern European Jewry, Martin Buber, now Professor of Social Philosophy at Jerusalem's Hebrew University, is also an original thinker in his own right.

PARIS, Nov. 27 -- In a series of roll-call votes, the ad hoc Political Committee of the United Nations General Assembly decided today to ask the Security Council to reconsider the membership applications of six states vetoed by the Soviet Union.

THERE are few in America who have not learned, if they did not know it before, that on Jan. 24, 1848, gold was discovered in California and that the Golden State has, this year, celebrated that centennial. Less widely broadcast than the advertising of the chambers of commerce, but probably more enduring, are the many publications which have appeared in connection with the anniversary.
During the temporary absence of Catherine Mackenzie, her column is being conducted by Mr. Frank, who is director of the Caroline Zachry Institute of Human Development.
At first the six young people were frightened. They realized they were on the air and that momentous fact disturbed them. Their words came out slowly and tensely.

HOW should history be written? Until well into the nineteenth century, most authors would have agreed that it is necessarily a chronicle of events. Why events occurred was only dimly understood -- and then, only when a dynasty fell or a war was lost.
Twenty-one persons who died in the last year remembered THE NEW YORK TIMES Neediest Cases Fund in their wills. Many left individual gifts, while others set up trust funds.

PARIS, Nov. 27 -- French officials were keenly interested in today's leading editorial in The London Times, which expressed sympathy with the French views regarding the Ruhr and largely blamed the United States for a tendency to rebuild the German industry more rapidly than the French.

The battle of the Bronx was little more than a one-sided skirmish yesterday as Fordham's young Rams romped to 26-0 victory over N. Y. U. at the Polo Grounds. Never in jeopardy, the Rams scored twice within the opening five minutes and triumphed going away before 26,000 spectators, whose sentiments appeared to be equally divided.

TUSCALOOSA Ala., Nov. 27 (UP) -- Trailing for three periods, Albama placed all its hopes on a fourth-period surge by Ed Salem today and he came through for a 34-to-28 victory over Florida before 25,000.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 -- A nation-wide enlistment of women beginning Feb. 2, aimed to enroll in the National Council of Negro Women 500,000 new members of all races, colors and creeds willing to unite for human and civil rights, was announced here this week by President Mary McLeod Bethune.
Mayor O'Dwyer will officially open the last extension of the West Side Express Highway at ceremonies tomorrow at 11 A. M. The extension will be a link in southern Manhattan to the East Side Drive.

John D. Rockefeller 3d has accepted an invitation to attend City College's Annual Alumni Dinner Thursday evening in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, it was announced yesterday by Dr. Nelson P. Mead, president of the Associate Alumni.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 (Science Service) -- The moon will be new next Tuesday, the second new moon this month. The moon was last new on Monday, Nov. 1. The last time the moon was new twice in the same month was in May, 1946.

PORTRAITS of two of the foremost French physicists in modern times were added to philately's gallery through 5-francs red-brown and 8fr azure-blue stamps received from Paris last week by Curt Lenz. They were Paul Langevin (1872- 1946), who was adviser to the French Bureau of Atomic Energy, on the 5fr; and Jean Perrin (1870-1942), who had served as Under-Secretary of State for Scientific Research, on the 8fr.

DUESSELDORF, Germany, Nov. 27 -- The Communist party and its following in the industrial Ruhr has suffered seriously in both prestige and power as a result of the Soviet blockade of Berlin. Right-Wing groups in other political parties, notably the Christian Democratic Union, have won new strength in the last six months.

I DON'T know how much of a test of poetry this book is, but it contains a fair amount of very good verse and a very good amount of fair verse. As such, though it may fail on the level of intention -- and I am not sure that it does -- it becomes (unintentionally, perhaps) an interesting anthology of verse.

DUBLIN, N. H. IT won't be as cold this winter as last, but watch out for ice. This is the long-range forecast by the best-known weather man in the country. He's one of the oldest heads in the business and some say the wisest. Long before the United States Weather Bureau would venture out with predictions five days in advance Abraham Weatherwise was telling farmers what to expect a whole year ahead.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 27 -- The day of the big game did not "dawn crisp and clear" as it does in all good football stories. But, to the intense delight of the 102,500 enthusiasts who
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 27 (AP) -- The Army-Navy football game ended in a 21-21 tie today but you never would have guessed it from the bedlam that broke loose in the middies dressing room.

JUDGING from Miss Kimbrough's candid and witty recountal of her adventures as a traveling lecturer, lecture tours and the delivery of discourses occasion as many perils as the peregrinations of Sindbad. She has had a lectern explode in front of her and nearly catapult her into the first rows of the audience ("Worms!" the janitor shouted in explanation).

SHANGHAI, Nov. 22 -- United States business men here, though on the whole accepting the inevitability of Communist occupation, are almost to a man determinned to remain in China and keep Pacific trade moving between the United States and China no matter what the complexion of the Chinese Government.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 27 (AP) -- More than 6,000 CIO longshoremen in the San Francisco Bay area voted today to accept a new waterfront contract aimed at ending the eighty-seven-day West Coast dock strike.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 -- The summary discharge of five public school teachers at Chandler, Ariz., was cited by the National Education Association today as an example of "the evil results of an unfair dismissal procedure."

THE first comprehensive member exhibition of the Photo League, entitled "This Is the Photo League," will open Saturday afternoon at the club's quarters, 23 East Tenth Street. In addition to pictures by talented unknown photographers, the three hundred prints will include the work of such known league members as Edward Weston, Ansel Adams, Paul Strand, Berenice Abbott and Richard Avedon.

A NEW experiment in the methods of selecting salon photographs, aimed at the placing of photography judging on a more progressive basis, has been announced by the Miniature Camera Club. Instead of the usual quota of three or four recognized salon judges, the club will inaugurate on Dec. 6, at a show open to the public, a jury consisting of two photographers and two artists.

WHAT has promised to be a most enjoyable trip from New York to Florida via the inland waterway is completely spoiled for Linden King when she discovers a corpse in the dinghy of the yawl Myabelle III. This is only one of the many terrifying experiences that await Linden.

The wind sweeps out of the west, with the faint breath of blizzard far away; but the skies are clear, without even the shredded, high-flying clouds of storm. And so November leans toward December, and late autumn creeps past, silent as the stars. The hush of winter approaches, and short days lie upon the land.

"Fine Arts of a Profession" will be the topic of a lecture, in the series of the free Art Education Project of the New York Public Library to be held Tuesday evening in Room 213, Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street. The speaker will be George Binet.

ALTHOUGH readers accustomed to the usual run of books about Russia will find it dull, N. A. Voznesensky's volume on the Soviet economy is undoubtedly one of the most important and revealing volumes on the U.S.S.R. in several years.

BIG JIM and the story about him have been steeped so long in Walt Whitman that there is little of their original flavor left to taste. Jim, "axman, slave, rebel, brawler, dreamer, mystic, plowman, full mongrel American" (and I quote) is a poor Western boy who comes up the hard way in the early twentieth century.

For some time my national pride has been offended by the insistence of my foreign-born friends that the United States is not a music-loving country. I have always contradicted these slighting remarks, but I am now forced to admit that they are not wholly lacking in truth.

PROVIDENCE, R. I., Nov. 27 -- The Association of American Universities, its blue ribbon membership currently confined to thirty-four colleges and universities, has broken with tradition and dropped its approved list system.

RIVERHEAD, L. I., Nov. 27 -- Suffolk County potato growers are manifesting resentment over the announcement last week by Charles F. Brannan, Secretary of Agriculture, of drastic cuts in both potato price support and acreage control goals effective for the 1949 crop.

TOMORROW is the first anniversary of the U. N. vote to partition Palestine. To celebrate this occasion -- if celebrate is the right word -- Boni Gaer have brought out I. F. Stone's compressed history of the fledgling state and its embattled existence through an embattled year.

The replies of the four powers occupying Germany, the United States, Russia, Britain and France, to the questionnaire of President Bramuglia of the Security Council of the United Nations do not appear to bring the Berlin issue any nearer a settlement. They emphasize that there is not wide difference on principles, as they appear on paper, but make it plain that the questions of procedure remain unsolved.
This was the strategic situation last week on two major battlefronts in the Chinese civil war:

THIS is a particularly effective animal book in the sense that it can be read -- and looked at -- with pleasure by adults and children alike. Mr. Bridges, curator of publications at the New York Zoological Park, writes very simply, as he must, yet does not patronize the mature reader.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 (AP) -- The Veterans Administration today set minimum building standards for GI-loan houses.

Delegates of the United Nations would be eligible for the Nobel peace prize if they devoted themselves whole-heartedly to the task of making peace in the Near East a reality, Rabbi Samuel M. Segal said in a sermon in Mount Neboh Temple, 130 West Seventy-ninth Street, yesterday.

BERLIN, Nov. 27 -- Soviet reciprocal payments for reparations due to fourteen nations, including three satellite countries have been held up for more than six months as a result of "transportation difficulties" resulting from the Berlin blockade, it was learned today.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 -- Requirements of national defense and foreign aid have made it almost certain that President Truman will ask the new Democratic Congress to increase taxes.

NEWARK, N. J., Nov. 27 -- The Princeton University indoor polo team opened its season impressively tonight by defeating Westbury, L. I., 17 -- 7, at Essex Troop Armory with Randy Tucker scoring six times. Held scoreless in the second chukker, the hard-riding Tigers rebounded with eight goals in the third.

Chairman David E. Lilienthal of the United States Atomic Energy Commission, speaking before a Boston audience a few days ago, explained some of the difficulties and some of the hopes involved in trying to "make the split atom work to improve the lot of humankind."

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Nov. 27 -- Lebanese and Syrian officials met here today to discuss the question of a United States Trans-Arabian pipeline, and a well-informed source said tonight that he expected early ratification by the Syrians of an agreement to let the pipeline cross Syria.

American iron and steel companies have embarked on an intensive effort to increase imports of foreign iron ore and to locate new domestic deposits which will decrease the industry's dependence on the great ore wealth of the Lake Superior area.

TORONTO, Nov. 27 Pudgy "Turk" Broda got his second shutout in three nights as Toronto defeated New York, 3 -- 0, before 13,931 fans at Maple Leaf Gardens. The victory pulled the Leafs up within one point of third place in the National League standing and left the Rangers in the cellar.

TOKYO, Nov. 27 -- Japanese consumers in this fiscal year will get a subsidy of 18,000,000,000 yen, according to Government figures revealed to the Diet. The first two years' occupation deficit aggregated 22,000,000,000 yen.

CARACAS, Venezuela, Nov. 27 -- Reliable sources said tonight that former President Romulo Gallegos was under arrest at the Military School in Caracas. At the Defense Ministry officials said he was "in perfect health" and was permitted to see the members of his family.
STILLWATER, Okla., Nov. 27 (AP) -- Oklahoma's powerful Sooners shouldered aside stubborn Oklahoma A. M., 19 -- 15, today and moved into the Sugar Bowl for a New Year's game with North Carolina.

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 27 -- The Mississippi River may recapture the glory it held in the early days of the country. River traffic is pushing toward new peaks and there are plans afoot to sail ocean-going steamers into the heart of America and to make a barge line link to New York by way of the Allegheny River.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 27 (AP) -- A review of the Presidential election ballot in Ohio, Illinois and California has been requested by Hugh Scott Jr., Republican national chairman, to determine the possible need of a recount, McIntyre Fairies, national committeeman, said today.

An encouraging subscription has been reported for the performance of the motion picture, "Hamlet," with Laurence Olivier in the leading role, on the night of Dec. 8 at the Park Avenue Theatre, which has been taken over to raise funds for the Outdoor Cleanliness Association.

BOSTON, Nov. 27 -- The United States Navy, interested in the ability of its personnel to deal with service "chow," has set up a research "in the field of mastication" with the cooperation of the Tufts College Dental School.

MUSICIANS and near-musicians cluster about Mildred Taft-Manning like flies about a honey pot and for the same reason. Mildred has millions inherited from her first husband, who founded the Taft Institute of Music which she now controls.

HOUSTON, Tex., Nov. 27 (UP) -- Rice and Baylor battled to a 7-deadlock here today, sharing this place Southwest Conference honors, but for Baylor it meant an invitation to play Wake Forest the Dixie Bowl at Birmingham on Jan. 1. The bid was accepted.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., Nov. 27 -- The American people reject the notion that atomic energy is a military secret "which can be locked in a safe when not in use" and is therefore none of their business, S. J. Bonds Jr., of Washington, director of training for the United States Atomic Energy Commission, said today.

LONDON, Nov. 27 -- Despite its original views, the British Government has accepted the existence of the State of Israel. However, Britain's retreat from her former position on the Palestine problem has been slow and reluctant, and, although the British have conceded the triumph of the Israelis, they have not forgotten the interests of the Arabs -- or of Britain.

Younger members of society at home from colleges and schools for the Thanksgiving recess thronged the ballroom suite of the Ritz-Carlton last night for the annual Grosvenor Debutante Ball. Many of the girls attending the fete made their formal debuts either at the dance or at dinners given in advance.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 27 -- Increased grants from industry in support of research and advanced education at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology were reported today by Dr. Karl T. Compton, president. Making his final report, he said there had been encouraging response by industrial organizations to projects for research "along lines of mutual interest" and "wholly consistent with free educational objectives."

IT has taken fifty years to round out the story of the fabulous gold rush to the Klondike. This unpretentious volume supplies a missing chapter concerning the "lost battalion" of the adventurous army that stampeded north.

CLEVELAND, Nov. 27 -- The payroll income tax, fought by many employers, union leaders and individuals for two years, has gained a firm foothold in Ohio and, according to officials of four cities which have adopted it, it is here to stay.

PORTLAND, Ore., Nov. 27 -- Acting within the framework of an "organizing the unorganized" policy adopted by the tenth constitutional convention of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, the CIO executive board today ordered the left-wing United Farm Equipment and Metal Workers to merge within sixty days with the United Automobile Workers, headed by Walter P. Reuther, a right-winger.
BERLIN, Nov. 27 (AP) -- Soviet authorities ordered today sharp reductions in electric power usage in the entire Russian zone of Germany.
I AM writing on account of the Mahler controversy. Olin Downes in his reply to Charles Cole has apparently chosen the most beside-the-point letter to chalk up an easy victory.

One hundred years ago life in this country was lived still pretty much in the raw. Although gracious living had come to some persons in the larger communities and to the plantations and estates of the South and North, most of the people were still living under the hardships of the developmental and even the pioneering stage of our history.

LONDON, Nov. 27 -- Intermittent fog, which has plagued the eastern part of England for more than a week, closed in in earnest last night and remained through today. It paralyzed surface and air transport from the southeastern Channel coast northward to Sheffield and Nottingham in a blanket 250 miles long and fifty or more wide.

TROY, N. Y., Nov. 27 -- A Kerry blue terrier, Ch. Deed's Showoff, belonging to Mr. and Mrs. William Fox of Piedmont, Calif., from farthest away of 546 dogs competing in the eleventh all-breed event of the Troy Kennel Club, gained best in show tonight.

BOSTON, Nov. 27 -- For the first time since 1941, Boston College wound up its football season with a victory over Holy Cross. But Denny Myer's boys made it close for him, squeezing through by a 21-20 score.

PARIS, Nov. 27 -- The United States delegation to the United Nations General Assembly has tentatively pledged a contribution of $13,000,000 to $15,000,000 to the United Nations relief for Palestine refugees, which was established a few weeks ago for the benefit of Arabs who fled from their homes in Palestine, it was learned today.

In the article, "Eisenhower at Columbia," Ira Henry Freeman says that when the General arrives in his office, he confers briefly on the day's work with his general staff, which includes, among others, his military aide.

BAKERSFIELD, Calif., Nov. 25 -- California's sun-baked San Joaquin Valley is beginning to harvest a $200,000,000 cotton crop which may nose out South Carolina's for fourth place in the national production picture and present a stiff challenge to third-place Alabama.

THE American airplane manufacturing industry is now wrestling with one of the toughest problems it or any other major industry ever faced. It is the problem of making the transition from propeller-driven to jet-propelled aircraft, and it is of particular concern to companies specializing in military planes.

A RETIRED pirate captain who steals a rainbow, a little boy who fights a duel to get it back and hundreds of fairy painters who cheer him on to victory are the characters in this realistic fairy story. Capt. Forthright Jones and the boy Jonathan were good friends until the former decided to catch a rainbow.

Numerous and probably vigorous proposals on export controls are scheduled to come before the committees of the new Congress when they meet to consider renewal of Public Law 395, under which earlier this year these controls were extended to Feb. 28, 1949.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Nov. 27 -- "Brave New World," portraying two European refugee children behind barbed wire, won for Florence Tresider of Dobbs Ferry the first prize in oils today in judging preliminary to opening of the eighteenth annual exhibition of the Hudson Valley Art Association tomorrow at the Westchester County Center here.

ATHENS, Ga., Nov. 27 -- The Georgia Bulldogs pounded Georgia Tech in a convincing 21-13 victory on Sanford Field today and later accepted an invitation to play in the Orange Bowl football game at Miami, Fla., on Jan. 1. From Miami, the Orange Bowl Committee announced that no opponent for Georgia had been chosen, but that it planned to select another Southern team.

Last Thursday, when America sat down to the traditional Thanksgiving turkey dinner, many persons omitted the rolls and butter, ate sparingly of the stuffing, potatoes and cranberry sauce, and passed up the pumpkin pie. Seeking to keep within the limits of their carbohydrate restrictions, they were those among the nearly 1,000,000 diabetics in the United States who have learned, with insulin, exercise and diet, to live with their disability.
Britons short of tobacco ("Smoking Purgatory," by Mervyn Jones) may well adopt the practices of (a) painters or (b) Frenchmen.

THE flowering branches of native witchhazel (Hamamelis virginiana) look most unusual and handsome this month. The yellow blossoms, singular enough for their strange time of bloom, are even more notable for their odd formation.

PORTLAND, Ore., Nov. 27 -- When several millions of West Coast families sat down to their Thanksgiving dinners -- California alone produced 4,500,000 turkeys this year -- it was a safe bet this week that a good percentage got into arguments over the selection of the University of California's football team to represent the Coast at the Rose Bowl on Jan. 1.

THIS readable anthology contains over eighty selections about Virginia or by Virginians, spanning some three and a half centuries of literary, intellectual, social and political history. A good many of the selections are all too little known, out of print, or difficult to obtain.

FOR gay and fragrant bloom indoors, it is none too soon to start forcing bulbs in pebbles and water. And fortunately, there are a number which will provide this cheerful note, if planted successively at two-week intervals.

MEXICO CITY, Nov. 27 -- Thomas D. O'Keefe, special assistant to the United States Secretary of Commerce, is flying back to Washington today with a long list of Mexico's urgent raw material and machinery needs.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Nov. 27 -- The war in Palestine has changed the one rule of measure with which Israeli leaders always drew the projected boundaries for a Zionist state. The rule called for an area large enough and with sufficient economic possibilities to absorb every Jew who might wish to come to Palestine.

THOSE of us who spend a large part of our lives with music know that the ear alone can be a matchless agent for evoking memories of all kinds and for inducing emotions too deep for words. Music, of course, need not be the only medium for stimulation through the aural sense.
Suspicions that the East Coast dock strike was used as an "excuse" by foreign Governments or importers abroad to effect the cancellation of some of their orders here were cited last week.

MANVILLE, N. J., Nov. 27 -- Anthony Demuro, 49 years old, and his wife, Adeline, 48, of 242 North Fifth Avenue, were killed by gas fumes in their first-floor bedroom today at 3:30 A. M. Their daughter-in-law, Mrs. Felix Demuro, 24, also occupying a first-floor room, was saved by artificial respiration by the Manville rescue squad.
Four thousand members of Local 282, International Brotherhood of Teamsters, AFL, who went on strike last Monday, will choose today the terms under which they want to work.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 27 -- A medical care program designed to protect unemployed or disabled western Pennsylvanian coal miners went into full-time operation this week and is expected to be free of "bugs" soon.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Nov. 27 -- To counteract academic overspecialization and to provide "a common intellectual experience for the entire university family," students and faculty at Rutgers University next week will start a "Book-of-the-Year" reading plan.

A former Vanderbilt town house in a choice residential section of Manhattan's upper East Side will become the New York headquarters of the Government of Israel, as the result of a three-way real estate deal announced yesterday.

FAY KANIN and her husband, Michael Kanin, author and co-producer, respectively, of the happy hit, "Goodbye, My Fancy," will be leaving this week, headed back to Hollywood and son Joel, age 3 1/2. Mrs. Kanin, who can cheerfully remark following the success of her first play that roadway is wonderful and New York is her town, has several more ideas "bumbling around up there."

CHICAGO, Nov. 27 -- Social studies teachers are making a conscientious effort to understand the children they teach, are showing unswerving devotion to the ideals of democracy, and are using improved methods of teaching, Stanley E. Dimond, of the Detroit public schools, outgoing president of the National Council for the Social Studies, said today.

PROVIDENCE, R. I., Nov. 27 -- The International Association of Machinists, District 64, has gone into the retail clothing business in an effort to beat inflation. As a result of a special arrangement with a clothing manufacturer, the independent union local has opened a ready-to-wear shop on Elmwood Avenue, a short distance out of the business center.
RANGOON, Burma, Nov. 27 (AP) -- The Burmese are watching closely the trend of events in India, across the Bay of Bengal, for a line on their own political future.

Illuminated manuscripts, French illustrated books and other fine literary works, the property of several anonymous collectors, will be auctioned in three sessions at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 30 East Fifty-seventh Street. The sale will take place tomorrow at 8 P. M. and on Tuesday at 2 A. M. and 8 P. M.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 27 (AP) -- The Army football team was suffering from acute dysentery when it played Navy in the annual service classic, it was disclosed today.

Aided considerably by the superb backboard work of their two lanky centers, Lee Knorek and Irv Rothenberg, the New York Knickerbockers defeated the Fort Wayne Pistons, 80 -- 70, before 5,187 at the Sixty-ninth Regiment Armory last night. It was the third Basketball Association of America triumph in a row for the locals.

PARIS, Nov. 27 -- The United Nations Secretariat took strong measures today to bring the General Assembly to a close on Dec. 11, even if this makes it necessary to hold a special session -- or a continuation of the present session -- at Flushing Meadow next February or March.

The responsibility of the church for older people, displaced persons, human rights and methods of combating juvenile delinquency and promoting increased church attendance will be discussed Wednesday at the opening sessions of the biennial meeting of the Federal Council of the Churches of Christ in America in the Gibson Hotel in Cincinnati, it was announced here yesterday.

SCARSDALE, N. Y., Nov. 27 -- The Boulder Brook Club's biggest horse show, attracting a record of over 1,100 entries for the two-day event in the big arena, got under way with morning, afternoon and evening sessions today. Another three sessions tomorrow, with fifty-seven events being decided by then, will be capped by the awarding of eight championship rosettes.

LONDON, Nov. 28 -- Although currently involved in a misunderstanding, the British, French and United States authorities on Germany are talking in similar terms about the ultimate solution of what one of them calls the "terrible dilemma" of Germany's industrial future.

A physician and a nurse prevented a panic among forty mothers and expectant mothers in the Brooklyn Women's Hospital, 1395 Eastern Parkway, early yesterday after a fire had broken out in an adjacent three-story building. The fire caused the death of one man and burns to seven other persons.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 -- An appeal was directed today to several hundred Americans serving on the reception committee for the visit of Menachem Begin, former commander-in-chief of Irgun Zvai Leumi, to withdraw their support "as publicly as it was pledged."

New York State's scheduled rowing tomorrow of $51,450,000 for housing aid accounts for more than half of the week's roll of new tax-exempt bond issues. The State last June sold $28,175,000 of housing obligations at an interest cost of 1.5723 per cent.

CLEVELAND, Nov. 28 -- Candidates pledged to purge Communists from the ranks of the American Veterans Committee scored a decisive victory in today's elections at the World War II organization's national convention.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Nov. 28 -- The Israeli and Arab military commanders of the Jerusalem area met under United Nations auspices today and made "excellent progress" in the opening of negotiations for an armistice in the city, it was announced tonight.

CARACAS, Venezuela, Nov. 28 -- Activity in this city today continued to be normal. Bull fights and horse races were permitted and the city wore its usual air. Banking and communications officials stated last night that operations were proceeding normally.

The latitude of interpretation that should be given under modern urban conditions to the constitutional privileges of freedom of assembly and freedom of speech may be ruled upon today by Judge William McKinley of the White Plains City Court, with appeals to higher courts probable until the question is finally settled.

I read the editorial of THE NEW YORK TIMES of Nov. 17 in which it was suggested that CARE might serve the needs of the International Children's Fund by raising funds in the United States, with a great deal of interest.
ANN ARBOR, Mich., Nov. 28 -History proves that all those stories about women drivers are no accident, for as far back as 205 B.C. the Romans passed a law prohibiting women from driving chariots.
CHICAGO, Nov. 28 (UP) -- Torrential rains that have been pouring for three days sent rivers and streams surging over their banks today in Georgia, Alabama and Tennessee.

The strike of 2,000 members of Local 282, International Brotherhood of Teamsters, AFL, which since it began last Monday had threatened to develop into a runaway taking in other teamsters' locals, was ended officially yesterday.
CAIRO, Nov. 28 -- Two students were killed and fourteen injured by police who opened fire today on a demonstration at Zagazig, center of the agricultural district forty miles northeast of Cairo.

The National Theatre Conference amended its constitution here yesterday to enable Sawyer Falk of Syracuse University, its president for the last four years, to continue in that post for another two years. The action was taken at the concluding session of the conference's three-day annual convention.

ITHACA, N.Y., Nov 28. -- Dr. Henry G. Booker of Cambridge University, one of the world's foremost authorities on the propagation of electric waves, has been appointed a professor of electrical engineering at Cornell University and will join the staff in midDecember, President Edmund E. Day announced today.

BERLIN, Nov. 28 (UP) -- Gen. Lucius D. Clay said today that the Anglo-American airlift into Berlin had beaten the worst weather Germany could offer and announced that in celebration he was ordering a special distribution of coal to German civilians.

With the last outside oyster-white brick in place, the $15,000,000 Veterans Hospital adjacent to Fort Hamilton, Brooklyn, which is expected to be completed next fall, has taken on the proportions of being the "most modern skyscraper hospital in the world."
Intensive transport planning for the next national emergency got under way in Washington last week in the transportation section of the National Security Resources Board, it became known yesterday.

The retirement of Frederick A. Goetze, treasurer of Columbia University since 1916, was announced yesterday. Joseph Campbell, assistant treasurer since 1941, has resigned upon completing his wartime duties of being in charge of the university's Government contracts office.

The Rev. Dr. Henry Pitney Van Dusen, president of Union Theological Seminary, said yesterday that the international church conference in Amsterdam last summer had shown the "unforeseen and unexpected scope and strength of Christian unity."

ZURICH, Nov. 28 -- Since the extraordinary general shareholders meeting of the Interhandel A. G. (International Industrie und Handelsdeteilighngen A. G.) Holding Company in Basle last Monday sanctioned a proposal by the board of directors to call in all unpaid capital, conjecture about their motives has been widespread.

MIAMI, Fla., Nov. 28 (UP) -- An opponent for the University of Georgia in the Orange Bowl game here New Year's Day will not be named until tomorrow afternoon, but the Bulldogs definitely will not be pitted against another Southeastern Conference team, it was announced today.

GLEN COVE, L.I., Nov. 28 -- On the North Shore of Long Island there were once many mansions. Some of these have been razed, some have been converted into profssional centers for research and scientific study and two of the most famous have become monasteries.

Dividend Shares, Inc., an investment company under the management of the firm of Calvin Bullock, had record net assets of $63,118,181 as of Oct. 31, according to the annual report released for publication today by Hugh Bullock, president.

PARIS, Nov. 28 -- A resolution proposed by the United States and six other countries to extend the life of the United Nations Appeal for Children would cause its failure, Aake Ording, former head of the Appeal, who had resigned his post to press the fight for its continuance, declared today.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., Nov. 28 -- In an effort to keep fees within reach of qualified students and still meet inflated operating costs, Sarah Lawrence College will begin a new tuition plan next September, it was announced today.

Marking the start of the Advent season at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, the Very Rev. Dr. Hughell E. W. Fosbroke, honorary Canon of the Cathedral, declared yesterday that no one could be content with life as it is today "when all the struggle and tragic cost of war seems to have resulted only in a suspension of hostilities."
PARIS, Nov. 28 -- John Foster Dulles credited the United Nations today with creating a strong solidarity against aggression that has "increased the chances of peace."
AMSTERDAM, Nov. 28 -- Public opinion is perturbed over enormous arrears in the final settlement of Netherlands purchases under the European Recovery Program.

Spotting the Dodgers a 20 to 17 lead in the first half, the Baltimore Colts, sparked by the running of Billy Hillenbrand and the passing of Yelberton Abraham Tittle, came back in the second half yesterday to score three touchdowns and win the game, 38 -- 20.

PARIS, Nov. 28 -- Argentine Foreign Minister Juan Atilio Bramuglia tonight saw Soviet Deputy Foreign Minister Andrei Y. Vishinsky to discuss what Argentine circles said was a "plan for the final solution of the Berlin dispute."

Television has produced many problems for housing owners and tenants. Of the 500,000 receivers installed throughout the country, more than half have been bought by New Yorkers, of whom a large number have had to engage in disputes with their landlords in order to enjoy this newest entertainment phenomenon.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 -- The chief of the President's Council of Economic Advisers is convinced that much of a rise in military spending would bring "a number of direct controls." He fears that a sizable advancebeyond $15,000,000,000 would unleash"new forces of inflation."The present spending rate is about$12,000,000,000.

With the longshoremen's strike disposed of, the Port of New York can turn its attention to negotiations between Local 333, United Maritime Division, which represents 3,500 harbor craft workers, and the owners of 400 tugs, barges, tankers and self-propelled lighters.
Passenger service began at 7 o'clock yesterday morning on the $47,000,000 addition to the Fulton Street subway line of the IND in Brooklyn.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 -- The United States Government has reached certain conclusions on the principles that will govern its actions in the forthcoming negotiations for a North Atlantic security pact.

Freight damage claims by grocery manufacturers have reached an all-time high, food industry officials disclosed here last week. As a result, one large trade association is urging that closer attention be paid to the selection of shipping containers and their general standardization.

United States-flag vessels engaged in dry cargo liner services on foreign trade routes listed as essential by the Maritime Trade Commission transported a total of 24,182,000 tons of cargo during 1947, the first complete post-war year under private operation, according to statistics made public by the commission yesterday.

BOSTON, Nov. 28 (AP) -- The Boston Bruins put Goalie Turk Broda out of the whitewashing business tonight by romping over his Toronto Maple Leafs, 6 -- 2, before 13,900 fans at the Boston Garden. Broda had shut out the Montreal Canadiens and the New York Rangers in his previous two starts.
PATERSON, N. J., Nov. 28 (AP) -- Richard Snedecker, Princeton University harrier, won the New Jersey A.A.U. junior individual cross-country championship today.

Plans have been completed for thebenefit performance of "Bravo?at the Lyceum Theatre tomorrowi evening, proceeds of which, will bedevoted to the work of the So-ciety of St. Johnland, which main-tains a community near Kings Parkon the North Shore of Long Islandfor the care of children and elderlypersons.

Jewelry and clothing valued at several thousand dollars were stolen yesterday afternoon from the apartment of Mr. and Mrs. Alban Conway at 19 1/2 East Sixtysecond Street, while the Conways were out automobile driving with friends, the police reported.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 28 -- Again the steel industry kept its furnaces going at full blast last week. Ingot production was unchanged at 99.5 per cent of rated capacity. If later figures were available for figuring the percentage of operations, the rate would not be as high, but it would be close to full output.

PARIS, Nov. 28 -- The Provisional Government of Israel is expected to submit its application for membership in the United Nations tomorrow, the first anniversary of the passage of the Palestine partition resolution by the General Assembly.

PARIS. Nov. 28 -- French economic and financial circles have received a shock with the setback of Franco-Swiss negotiations, which have just been broken off in Berne. These negotiations, started on Nov. 10, were intended to settle all outstanding commercial and financial questions between the two countries.
LONDON, Nov. 28 -- A thick fog that covered most of Britain caused today the fifth postponement of the sailing of the liner Queen Elizabeth for New YorK.

CHICAGO, Nov. 28 -- This year's record corn crop thus far has failed to stimulate any marked expansion in cattle feeding operations, figures on the movement of animals from leading markets disclosed today.

ANOTHER twenty-four hours of contemplation cannot supply any logical or reasonable explanation of Navy's utterly astonishing "victory" over Army in their now historic 21-21 tie at Philadelphia on Saturday. The midshipmen hadn't won a game all this season and for most of the last one. The cadets were spinning an all-winning skein.

MADRID, Nov. 28 -- With but one exception the Government and Falange-supported slate won places on the Madrid Municipal Council in today's second section of the municipal elections. Throughout the nation syndicate members elected their one-third of the representatives to the council.

Two of the outstanding art events of this week will be the openings on Thursday of a comprehensive benefit loan exhibition of Gustave Courbet's paintings at the Wildenstein Galleries and the ninth annual exhibition of the Audubon Artists Society at the National Academy.

PARIS, Nov. 28 -- Australia has agreed to join the United States in sponsoring a resolution providing for the de facto recognition of the Seoul Government in southern Korea by the United Nations General Assembly.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 (UP) -Operating expenses for the nation's thirty-seven largest cities in 1947 were about 18 per cent greater than in 1946, the Commerce Department reported today.

The first Sunday of Advent, which is the first day of the ecclesiastical year, was marked yesterday in St. Patrick's Cathedral with a solemn mass of exposition, opening the liturgical devotion known as "The Forty Hours Adoration of the Blessed Sacrament."

The Infants Welfare League and its men's club announced yesterday the purchase of a summer camp in the Pocono Mountains in Pennsylvania for the benefit of underprivileged children. A report on the purchase and plans for use of the camp next summer will be made Sunday night at a dinner dance to be held by the league and the club at the Biltmore Hotel.

Thanksgiving starts off what might be called "the mince pie season." From that feast on through Christmas and New Year's, the dessert that originated in England centuries ago has its day. Mince meat, which once was prepared at home every autumn, now may be bought in any neighborhood store.

Cotton prices in the domestic market moved within a relatively narrow trading range last week. Active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange showed net changes ranging from an advance of 4 points to a decline of 13 points, compared with net gains of 2 to 32 points in the previous week.

ATLANTA, Ga., Nov. 28 (UP) -Streams swollen by almost nine inches of rain in twenty-four hours burst their banks in three Southern states today, sending hundreds fleeing. But tonight the floods were reported receding.

New York's waterfront resounded to the familiar clatter of pier trucks and escalators yesterday as longshoremen reported for work after a paralyzing eighteen-day strike. Indications were that normal activity would be resumed today in all other ports affected from Maine to Virginia.

The fifty-eight bus lines operated in Manhattan and the Bronx by the Third Avenue Transit System began yesterday to collect the seven-cent fare authorized last Wednesday by the Public Service Commission. The seven-cent fare went into effect also on the bus lines operated in lower Manhattan by the Avenue B and East Broadway Transit Company.
Despite threatening weather, 9,000 persons filed through the Freedom Train yesterday on its return visit to Brooklyn at the Army Base, Second Avenue and Sixty-fourth Street.

A peaceful world without a healthy Asia is impossible, if only because the immense continent is still as big as ever, while the world itself has drawn its ends together and grown small. With well over a billion inhabitants, Asia contains more than half of the total population of the earth. Its good people were always our brothers, but they have now become our neighbors as well.

WALTER KARIG, who has seen much more of the world than most of us, has lost his heart to Micronesia. That an American writer should succumb to the charms of the South Seas is nothing new. From Herman Melville to Donald Frisbee the tradition has been observed. But Captain Karig doesn't seem to be the type.

NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 28 -- The Allied States Association of Motion Picture Exhibitors will act tomorrow on a resolution demanding that motion picture players who misbehave be banned from the screen until they have cleared their names.

Sylvia Marlowe, narpsichordist, gave a recital Saturday night at Times Hall. The program featured twelve sonatas by Domenico Scarlatti and also included Bach's "Italian" Concerto and "French" Suite in G major. Special interest centered in the Scarlatti offerings, as all of them were presented in their original form, entirely free of editing.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 -- New construction in 1949 will hit a dollar-volume record of $18,750,000,000, the Department of Commerce predicted today. The expected total represents an increase of more than 5 per cent over the $17,800,000,000 figure now in prospect for 1948.

LONDOON, Nov. 28 -- The great efforts being made to increase Britain's exports to hard-currency countries have received some encouragement from a study of reports of overseas trade for October and also for the third quarter of the year ended with September.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 (AP) -The United States Employment Service reported today that aircraft manufacturing is at its greatest peacetime level.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 28 (AP) -The Los Angeles Rams outpassed and outran the Green Bay Packers today and sent 23,874 supporters home celebrating a 24-to-10 National Football League victory in Memorial Coliseum.

In their eagerness for high returns, a large number of travel and resort advertisers are mistakenly aiming nearly all of their advertising efforts at the topbracket income groupu, an agency executive in this field asserted over the week-end.

Because the American Foundation for the Blind is deeply concerned about the many news stories appearing in magazines and newspapers describing two inventions purporting to enable blind people to "read" printed material by means of sound, I hope you will allow me to point out the imperfections of both machines and to warn against the false hopes which these reports will give to people who cannot see.

One law amending the City Charter will not miraculously solve New York City's traffic problem overnight, but we believe that the proposed measure written under Mayor O'Dwyer's supervision can, in the months ahead, work a tremendous improvement. The bill setting up a Traffic Department and a Traffic Commission is not perfect; some defects can, perhaps, be corrected before it becomes law; others may not appear until it is tested in experience.

WILMINGTON, Del., Nov. 28 (AP) -- The way was cleared yesterday for the Panhandle Eastern Pipe Line Company to pay stockholders a dividend of 810,000 shares of capital stock of the Hugoton Production Company. Federal District Judge Paul Leahy handed down an opinion denying the Federal Power Commission an injunction against payment of the stock.

CHICAGO, Nov. 28 -- Grain markets turned downward late last week following early strength. The lowest prices on the Board of Trade were on Saturday after general selling. This included liquidation by holders of December contracts, especially in corn, in which there was a large open interest.

Edward Corsi, State Industrial Commissioner, called yesterday afternoon on the United States Government "to extend the same recognition to the Republic of Israel that Soviet Russia already has extended."

LONDON, Nov. 28 -- Although the stock markets here have lost none of their confident tone, there has been in the last few days a noticeable slackening in demand, especially for gilt-edge securities, which for weeks past have been leading the markets generally steadily upward.

Dr. Frank C. Laubach, veteran educator and missionary, has a stupendous, although simple, plan to teach within a few years 1,200,000,000 illiterates in Asia, Africa and Latin America -- that's three-fifths of the human race -- how to read their own languages.

CHICAGO, Nov. 28 (AP) -- The Chicago Bears touched off three touchdowns on recovered fumbles in the first four minutes of the game today to gain momentum for a 48-13 rout of the Washington Redskins. It was the Bears' ninth National Football League triumph in ten starts.

What is said to be the world's first underpass for carrying vehicular traffic while giant commercial aircraft move overhead was opened yesterday morning at New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens.
