Continuing the celebration of its hundredth anniversary, the New York Public Library late yesterday afternoon presented a program of twenty-two songs, most of which were inspired by, different sections of New York or by the city as a whole.

Kean Kean, Inc., Lincoln Rosen, president, has purchased for investment from the 421 Seventh Avenue Corporation the fourteen-story and penthouse building at 421 Seventh Avenue, northeast corner of Thirty-third Street, for cash over mortgages amounting to $562,000.

Many Jewish organizations throughout the country observed the first anniversary of the United Nations Palestine Partition Plan of Nov. 29, 1947, with statements yesterday predicting peace and prosperity in the Holy Land.

Around 1944 and 1945 a number of studies made their appearance which dealt with the problem of post-war taxation. One of the most thoughtful and comprehensive of these prognoses made its appearance in September, 1945. After discussing the various forms of taxation and the place that each of them should properly occupy (if any) in the revenue system, this report set up three sample peace-time budgets ranging in size from $15,000,000,000 to $22,000,000,000.

I Dorothy Parrish, pianist, gayeI recital devoted entir%ly to tkl works of Bela Bartok in CarnegHall late yesterday afternoon. Tk:program featured the Piano Sonatland included the late Hungariaicomposer s short works.

More than 3,000 industrial executives from every section of the country will attend the fifty-third annual meeting of the Congress of American Industry which will be held in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel from Dec. 1 through Dec. 3, it was announced last week.

The foreign exchange market last week was listless, the modest turnover involving but one major variation in rates, and that in the Swiss free franc which slumped sharply on Friday on selling orders from abroad which piled up on Thursday, while we were on holiday (Thanksgiving Day). At Friday's close of 25.12 cents, the franc showed a decline of 27 points from the preceding week.

Although concerned with main-raining a high standard of serviceto the community, spokesmen forthe New York Public Library inannouncing its campaign for funds,exhibited yesterday complete opti-mism over the future of thc freeinstitution.
Justice Albert Cohn of the Appellate Division was honored last night for his public service and philanthropy at the thirty-second anniversary dinner of the Hebrew Home for the Aged.

The last of the contracts between the big CIO-dominated industries and their unions providing for a third post-war wage increase were signed only in mid-July of this year. As early as last Nov. 8, less than four months later, representatives of the textile workers of New England and the Middle Atlantic States, meeting at Boston, were already firing the first gun in a campaign for increase Number Four.
Another college football season ends with Michigan and Notre Dame again at the top.

With two large audiences that filled the City Center to its 3,000 capacity both afternoon and evening, the New York City Opera Company yesterday completed its fifth fall season in New York. Today the expanding company heads for Chicago to open its first season there on Wednesday night.

Protection of life and property has been a principal function of the city administration since its first fire wardens were appointed on June 23, 1648, "to inspect the chimneys between Fort Amsterdam and the Fresh Water Pond."

After 100 years of existence without recourse to a drive for financial support, the New York Public Library announced yesterday the opening of its first public appeal for funds for its Reference Department with $10,000,000 as part of its ultimate goal.

The concert of the New Friends of Music yesterday afternoon in Town Hall would have been more than worth the journey, had it been only for the opening performance, under the directorship of Ignace Strasfogel, of the adorable Serenade for wind octet, K-388, of Mozart.

SAVANNAH, Ga., Nov. 28 (AP) -Mrs. Amy James Mallard, widow of Robert Mallard, who was arrested at the funeral of her Negro husband yesterday and charged with his murder, was released nine hours later last night at Lyons, Ga., in the custody of her attorney without bond or explanation.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Nov. 28 -- The Yugoslav Communist party and its numerous front organizations began celebration tonight of the fifth anniversary of the founding of the present regime.
Only two films, including an importation from France, are slated to open in first-run theatres this week. The programs follow:

"Your Lucky Strike" will be opened next Monday on CBS by Don Ameche as an avenue of advancement, for professional entertainers considered deserving of greater recognition. Engagements in the various branches of show business will be the rewards of aspirants competing successfully on the programs, which will be broadcast Mondays through Fridays from 4:30 to 5 P.M.

ATHENS, Nov. 28 (AP) -- Lieut. Gen. James A. Van Fleet, chief of the United States military mission here, said tonight the Greek army was unable at the present time to prevent the Communist led guerrilla forces from invading Greek soil.

Charles Petremont, gifted young violinist from Boston, who gave his second New York recital last night at Town Hall, made known the possession of a real temperament. Blessed with this rare attribute, combined with a highly romantic approach to the music he performed, he was in his element in a work like the Franck Sonata, which he played with a mature grasp of its style and content unawaited from one of his years.

ALBANY, Nov. 28 -- An imported wire-haired foxterrier, the Benrook Kennels' Ch. Chief Barmaid from Barrington, R.I., became best in show in the fifth and biggest allbreed event of the Albany Kennel Club tonight.
NANKING, Nov. 28 -- Madame Chiang Kai-shek, who is flying to Washington, will make an eleventhhour appeal for full United States support of the hard-pressed Chinese Government.

The Edison Electric Institute, trade organization of the $16,400,000,000 private electric light and power industry, will release today a 32-page booklet answering, for the first time in compact form, 24 questions covering a wide range of subjects relating to public and private power, both in the United States and abroad.

VAN NUYS, Calif., Nov. 28 (AP) -- Two hundred privately owned planes were immobilized yesterday at the Metropolitan Airport when the War Assets Administration barricaded landing strips for nonpayment of landing fees.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Nov. 28 -- A reshuffle among the Swedish Communist party leaders has placed the Kremlin faithfuls in absolute command and consigned "lukewarms" to more modest posts.
Columbia University had $16,383,429 of net operating expenses in the fiscal year ended June 30, against operating income of $15,365,912, it was announced yesterday.

Socony-Vacuum Oil Company has transferred administration of human relations activities from its industrial relations department to its medical department, Dr. Arthur E. Hoag, medical director, disclosed in an interview last week. He said the move was made because the company feels that the traditionally confidential doctor-patient relationship will prove more effective in solving intimate personal employe problems not connected with jobs.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 28 (AP) -- The Philadelphia Eagles whipped a stubborn Pittsburgh Steelers team, 17 to 0, today to clinch the Eastern Division championship of the National Football League for the second straight year.

TOKYO, Nov. 28 -- A warrant for the arrest of former Premier Hitoshi Ashida was submitted today to Komakichi Matsuoka, Speaker of the lower house of the Diet. Since Dr. Ashida, as a member of the Diet, is protected from summary arrest, the action must be approved by the house steering committee and a vote on the floor.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 28 (AP) -- Cleveland's Browns, scoring four touchdowns, a field goal and all conversions, won the Western Division title of the All-America Football Conference today with a 31-28 victory over the San Francisco Forty-Niners. It was the Browns' thirteenth straight victory of the season.

One-third of the operating deficits of general hospitals that maintain out-patient departments is due to the loss they sustain in this service, the Hospital Council of Greater New York reported in its monthly bulletin yesterday.

After spending twelve successful days in New York, sixteen members of a Guatemalan good-will mission were beset yesterday by two misfortunes that upset their Central American temperaments considerably.

SCARSDALE, N.Y., Nov. 28 -Eight championship rosettes were awarded this afternoon and tonight as the Boulder Brook Club rang down the curtain on its record-breaking two-day fall horse show, the eighteenth such annual event, which brought over 1,100 entries to the big indoor arena.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 -Spokesmen for the Association of American Railroads said tonight that a requested 13 per cent rise in freight rates would not "materially affect" the railroads' ability to compete with other forms of transportation.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Nov. 28 (AP) -- The scoreboard might have showed a tie but 2,000 Navy midshipmen chanted "We Beat Army" today and broke tradition by ringing the "victory" bell brought back from Japan by Commodore Perry.

The National Association for American Composers and Conductors gave the first concert of its sixteenth year at Times Hall last night. The program, which included string quartets, songs and music for two pianos, opened with a speech by Robert Russell Bennett, president.
BOCHUM, Germany, Nov. 28 -Hermann Bracht, who has been a miner in the Ruhr for twentyfour years, is a very important but far from contented person these days.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 -- The National Planning Association urged farmers today to spend their "boom-time" profits on better housing, clothing and education rather than on more land at inflated prices.

MADRID, Spain, Nov. 28 (U.P.) -An estimate of Spain's military needs will be included in a special House Armed Services Committee report to Secretary of Defense James Forrestal, a committee member said today.

Obtaining furniture of the best contemporary design at retail is a problem in Sweden just as it is in this country, Swen Erik Skawonius, managing director of the Swedish Society of Arts and Crafts, said yesterday.
CLEVELAND, Nov. 28 -- Gov. Thomas E. Dewey failed to win the Presidency in the farm belt.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 (UP) -The Army has adopted a new and "superior" field ration. An improved version of the "C Ration," familiar to millions of soldiers in World War II, it bears the official designation "Ration, Individual, Combat, C-4."

SEATTLE, Nov. 28 (AP) -- An Army transport carrying 365 persons split its plates above the water line after docking at Whittier, Alaska, Saturday at the end of a voyage through a storm from Adak in the outer Aleutians.

For the second time within a month, Soviet Russia has been found guilty by the United Nations of creating threats to peace in violation of the Charter, and has been requested to abandon its policy of force. These condemnations have been indirect and by implication, but they are unmistakable.

LONDON, Nov. 28 (UP) -- Lieut. Gen. Sir Frederick Morgan, wartime deputy chief of staff to Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, wrote to The Sunday Times today, protesting the newspaper's criticism of General Eisenhower's book "Crusade in Europe."

The Thanksgiving holiday reduced the number of buyers in the wholesale apparel market here last week, but reorders showed a marked increase, according to reports prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices.

"The Universe and Dr. Einstein," by Lincoln Barnett, an analysis of known facts about the universe, will be published on Jan. 17 by William Sloane Associates. The book is an expansion of three articles by Mr. Barnett that Harper's Magazine published.

Miss Gloria Welsh, an 18-year-old brown-eyed blonde typist from Jersey City, was chosen yesterday as the "Daughter of the Regiment" from among twelve young women placed in a beauty contest by companies of the 107th Infantry, New York National Guard (the old Seventh Regiment).
A rush of travelers who had stretched their Thanksgiving holiday to include the week-end developed yesterday afternoon and last night at the air and rail terminals of the city.

CHICAGO, Nov. 28 -- The annual conference of the National Council on Family Relations closed today with decisions to reorganize and expand the organization, to foster community-level "cross section" councils and committees to study family needs and to develop state and regional affiliates in a decentralization effort.

AMBOISE, France, Nov. 28 -- There is little doubt that the United States Government would like to see a normalization of its relationships with Spain but that it has not at least as yet altered its view that this must be preceded by a liberalization of the actions of the Franco Government.

Chuckin' Chuck Conerly's longawaited debut as the man behind center in the Winged T proved a sorry experiment yesterday at the Polo Grounds. However, the Giants, comfortably in front when they switched from the A to the T, lost only face by the failure and were content with a 28-14 victory over the Boston Yanks.
PATERSON, N.J., Nov. 28 (AP) -- The Paterson Panthers moves into the final of the American Football League playoffs today on a 30-7 triumph over the Jersey City Giants.

Six hundred building lots in Brentwood, L.I., have been sold by the Yudell Realty Corporation of Brentwood to the Skillcraft Construction Corporation of Central Islip, L.I., for improvement with homes to sell for $7,500 to $10,000.

Paper and paperboard production during October amounted to 1,928,000 tons, or about 1,623 tons below the all-time production record established in March, according to a summary, based on preliminary data, issued over the week-end by the American Paper and Pulp Association.

Fifteen hundred persons were present yesterday afternoon at the official opening of a four-story structure at 305 Henry Street presented to the Henry Street Settlement by former Gov. Herbert H. Lehman and his wife. The building is a memorial to their son Peter, killed in England in 1944 while a officer of the Army Air Forces.
BOYS TOWN, Neb., Nov. 28 AP -- The memory of the Right Rev. Msgr. Edward J. Flanagan, founder and director of Boys Town, was honored today by the Variety Clubs International.
ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Nov. 28 -- The luxury yacht Tennessee, property of Henry G. Fownes, New York yachtsman, burned four miles offshore here today.

Mayor O'Dwyer and his top administrative aides already are wrestling with the problem of preparing for 1949-50 an expense budget that will be little, if any, higher than the current record-breaking budget of $1,160,538,857.

Announced as a local entry for Dec. 15, "Along Fifth Avenue," the Arthur Lesser revue, co-starring Willie Howard and Nancy Walker, is apt to be delayed until the week of Dec. 27. But Mr. Lesser wasn't certain yesterday. He said he would make up his mind after studying the Philadelphia reviews on Wednesday.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Nov. 28 -In a faint and shifty northerly breeze that finally switched east and then fell flat, another fleet of thirty-nine craft, the same number for the past three weeks, engaged today in the dinghy sailing at the Larchmont Yacht Club.

Seeking to determine the cause of a slump in dress sales, manufacturers last week said they were inclined to agree that a primary weakness lay in poor methods of merchandising from which the industry suffers at all levels of distribution.
Seven of the eight schools are represented on the 1948 Ivy League all-star football team selected yesterday by The Associated Press with the help of the circuit's coaches.

The Metropolitan Opera Association will open its sixty-fourth season at 8:15 tonight with a performance of Verdi's "Otello." The opening will be telecast, and the audience will be part of the show for the arrival of the opera-goers, as well as the complete performance, will be televised.

The Greater New York Safety Council, in its current effort to make home a safer place in which to live, has assumed a task as tremendous as it is commendable. Householders have been conditioned by song and story to think of home as a haven, a little island of safety in a world full of pitfalls.

New Yorkers were introduced to a new type of sports show last night when the roller derby, a combination of hockey, football and a six-day bicycle race, opened a seventeen-night stand at the SixtyNinth Regiment Armory.

Paced by George Ratterman, Chet Mutryn, Lou Tomasetti and Rex Bumgardner, the explosive Buffalo Bills blasted the football Yankees out of the race for the All-America Conference Eastern Division title yesterday.

TOKYO, Monday, Nov. 29 (UP) -- Gen. Douglas MacArthur's press office has established a twentyfour-hour-a-day watch to provide for the impending announcement that Hideki Tojo and his six doomed fellow Japanese war leaders have been hanged at Sugamo Prison.

DANBURY, Conn., Nov. 28 -- A tragic ending to the season's most fashionable wedding here caused the death early today of Mrs. Elaine Williamson, 25 years old, of Dayton, Ohio, who had been the matron of honor in the wedding party.

Murray King, formerly assistant buyer of budget shoes of Bloomingdale's, has been appointed assistant buyer of all shoes of Bloomingdale's, New Rochelle. Henry Glassberg was appointed to succeed Mr. King in the New York store.

The ten-man executive council of the Phi Kappa Psi fraternity unanimously upheld yesterday the action of the fraternity's president in suspending the Amherst College chapter for admitting a negro to membership. The council met at the Hotel Commodore.

Florence Nicolaides, violinist, and Kitta Brown, pianist, presented a program of contemporary music yesterday afternoon at Times Hall. Their schedule included George Antheil's Second Violin Sonata, which was played for the first time anywhere, and the same composer's Sonatina.

The Rev. Dr. Theodore Cuyler Speers spoke out yesterday from his pulpit in the Central Presbyterian Church, Park Avenue and Sixty-fourth Street, against "the technique of condemnation" that he said the church had used all through history even to the present day.

Soldiers will carry social security cards if Congress goes along with the Federal Security Agency in plans for liberalizing the old-age and survivors' insurance program established under the Social Security Act. So will doctors, lawyers, shopkeepers, policemen, farmers and house servants.
SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 28 (AP) -- Longshoremen in the three major West Coast ports have approved a proposed new contract after its endorsement yesterday by the Waterfront Employers Association.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 28 -- The Screen Directors Guild has voted Howard Hawks' "Red River" as the best directorial achievement for the three months ended Oct. 31. Hawks' dramatic western film received more votes from guild members than any of the ninety-five other films released in the Los Angeles area during the period.

LONDON, Nov. 29 -- King George's doctors issued a bulletin today stating that the arterial ailment in his right foot and leg had improved. There is "less cause for immediate anxiety" and therefore no question of amputation at present.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture reported today that average prices of farm products dropped 2 per cent between mid-October and mid-November. This brought the total decline in farm prices to 11 per cent from the post-war peak reached last January.

GENEVA, Nov. 29 -- A stepped up program for the International Labor Organization in the fields of manpower utilization, technical training and migration was outlined today by David Morse, Director General of the specialized United Nations agency.
While other wartime island bases have been abandoned and have fallen to ruin, this island has grown into the key base between Hawaii and the Far East.

Reflecting lower quotations in foreign markets, the price of natural crude rubber on the Commodity Exchange here dropped 81 to 100 points yesterday to new low levels for the year. Transactions expanded to 241 contracts, or 2,410 long tons, the largest turnover in one session since May.
LONDON, Nov. 29 -- End of account considerations checked business sharply in the stock market here today.

Bill Coffman of San Francisco, general manager of the annual East-West Shrine football game, said here yesterday that Don Faurot, coach at Missouri, and Matty Bell, S. M. U. mentor, had been released from their promise to help coach in this year's Jan. 1 game.
LOS ANGELES, Nov. 29 (AP) -- The Russian Orthodox Greek Catholic Church Abroad was ruled the supreme Russian church administration outside of Russia in Superior Court here today.

A psychologist who has never been there analyzed yesterday the riddles of Easter Island and suggested a cultural relationship between the hieroglyphics engraved upon its strange stone images and wooden tablets and the symbols of ancient Egypt.

Realistic pricing of rayon gray goods for the first quarter of 1949 is anticipated to meet the competitive condition of the piece goods market, it was pointed out in the trade yesterday. Reductions ranging from 7 to 10 per cent were predicted, although mills as yet have not made any firm offers to their converting customers.

The seven-cent fare met its first business day test yesterday on the routes of two privately owned bus companies in Manhattan and the Bronx. It was marked by slight delays and the usual complaints, with the reaction of passengers summed up as: "Well, I suppose it will be up to eight cents tomorrow."

CHICAGO, Nov. 29 -- A proposal aimed at carrying out the drive of the National Congress of Parents and Teachers against unwholesome comic books, motion picture and radio programs, and for the encouragement of good books and programs was drawn up here today by the group's action committee of which Mrs. Joseph W. Eshelman of Birmingham, Ala., is chairman.
Ten thousand persons attended the annual Star-Spangled Carnival at Madison Square Garden last night for the benefit of the Hospitalized Veterans Music Service of the Musicians Emergency Fund.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 -- An Administration foreign affairs spokesman on Capitol Hill declared today that China generally, and Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek especially, should have done more to help themselves in the battle against Chinese Communist forces before pressing an eleventh-hour appeal for more American aid.

CHICAGO, Nov. 29 -- Grain markets fluctuated in a very nervous manner on the Board of Trade today within a fair range of prices, a feature being evening-up operations in December contracts, on which cash grain can be tendered tomorrow.

CLEVELAND, Nov. 29, (UP) -- The American Veterans Committee, ending its third annual convention, came out today for "complete repeal of the Taft-Hartley Act," immediate re-enactment of the Wagner Act, and the admittance of Israel to the United Nations.
LONDON, Nov. 29 (AP) -- A dense blanket of fog today crippled most of western Europe's transportation for the third day in a row.
Army, despite last Saturday's tie with Navy, yesterday was named the winner of the August V. Lambert Memorial Trophy, symbolic of Eastern gridiron supremacy.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 (UP) -- James Maloney, head of the United States Secret Service, today was named chief coordinator of the Treasury Department's law enforcement agencies.

Despite increases in commodities, lower priced new models are being introduced by many of the 400 equipment manufacturers whose exhibits were displayed on four floors of Grand Central Palace yesterday at the opening of the 18th National Exposition of Power and Mechanical Engineering.

Two more of the dishes that have won favor for the fare at the Bird and Bottle Inn in Garrison now may be served at home. Owners Charles and Constance Stearns are packaging the oyster and herb poultry stuffing that goes into their famous baked chicken and the India curry sauce that also is popular in the Inn's dining room.
The board of directors of the Todd Shipyards Corporation declared yesterday a special year-end dividend of $4 and another dividend of $1 a share, payable to common stock holders on Dec. 13.
MIAMI, Fla., Nov. 29 (AP) -- It's Georgia vs. Texas for the Orange Bowl.

Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores dropped 8 per cent last week below the corresponding period last year, according to the "flash" report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. The decline for the four weeks ended last Saturday was 9 per cent.

" Death Be Not Proud," by John Gunther, a memorial to his only son, who died last year after a series of operations, will be published by Harper on Feb. 2. It is an account of the boy's fight against a fatal disease.
LOS ANGELES, Nov. 29 (AP) -- The University of Oregon will gain financial returns in two New Year's Day bowl football games.

The great trouble with the Christian religion in America is that too many Americans ignore or refuse to accept the fact that Jesus Christ was God, the Rev. Bryan Green, one of England's foremost evangelists, told 3,500 persons last night in a mission sermon at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 -- Paul G. Hoffman, Economic Cooperation Administrator, described the basic aim of the Marshall Plan today as an increase in the average per capita income of Western Europeans from $320 to around $500 a year and said that its achievement would prevent World War III.

" Distortion of fact" and "part of a smear campaign" were the phrases with which Menachem Begin characterized yesterday the charges against himself and the Irgun Zvai Leumi contained in a letter sent on Sunday to members of the Begin reception committee.

As thirteen men and two women carrying placards urging resistance to the draft paraded in the snow and rain yesterday morning in front of the Federal Building, 24-year-old Sander Katz, who served a prison term for wartime draft evasion, surrendered to begin serving a year and a day for refusing to register under the new draft law.

TIENTSIN, China, Nov. 29 -- Government forces not only abandoned the port but destroyed the harbor installations at Chinwangtao this week-end. Civilians who arrived at Tangku harbor last night reported that they had watched huge fires spread through the Kailan Mining Administration's stock yards, and said troops set fire to the docks as they boarded tugs before dawn on Saturday.

RIVERHEAD, L. I., Nov. 29 -- A total of $18,783,987 has been levied in state, county and town taxes in the ten towns of Suffolk County. This is an increase of $2,940,282 over the total levied last year. The warrants for the collection of the state, county and town taxes were signed today by Charles H. Duryea and Benjamin D. Blackman, chairman and clerk respectively of the Suffolk County Board of Supervisors.

Application of artifical heat to highways to reduce winter accidents in Oregon is being watched with interest by the Automobile Club of New York. If the experiments prove successful over a period of time the club will urge installation of similar pavement heating here as protection to motorists.

The Appellate Division set for 2 P. M. today the argument on an appeal from a ruling of Supreme Court Justice Felix C. Benvenga, who refused to set aside on jurisdictional grounds the election of George Frankenthaler, Republican-Liberal, as Surrogate.

The televising of the Metropolitan Opera's opening performance of "Otello" last night was an exciting and rewarding achievement, the Verdi masterpiece being brought into untold hundreds of thousands of homes with a new and arresting quality of intimacy.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 (AP) -- The Immigration Service has asked the State Department to negotiate with Sweden for the return of eighty-four Estonians who came to this country without permits.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 29 -- West Coast longshoremen, ratifying an agreement reached last Thursday with the Waterfront Employers Association, were ready to go back to work today after nearly three months of strike idleness, but continuing negotiations between shipowners and seagoing unions failed to end the walkout.

Demands described as "very moderate" by representatives of 3,500 harbor craft workers were presented yesterday to the Marine Towing and Transportation Employers Association in a meeting at the New York Towboat Exchange, 17 Battery Place.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 -- President Truman, approving plans for the Presidential reviewing stand for the inaugural parade, Jan. 20, urged the District of Columbia committee for the celebration today to keep the cost of seats low "so we can have a truly democratic inaugural."

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, Nov. 28 -- If what you can see from a corner prospective is only nine-tenths of a bomb-blasted structure, it still is not necessarily uninhabited in Germany. That freshly plastered touch at the far end of one side probably means a newly opened shop.

MINEOLA, L. I., Nov. 29 -- Nassau County's 1949 budget, providing for the same tax rates as this year, was adopted by the Board of Supervisors here today as proposed by J. Russel Sprague, county executive. The rates are county, $1.05 for each $100 of assessed valuation; Supreme Court, one cent; county police, 35 cents.

This is written in strong commendation of your editorial, "Fraternity Leadership," published Nov. 28. The young men (and women, for there are signs that the sororities may soon take courage) who are leading the effort to abolish discrimination deserve your help.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 -- The armed services showed a net gain of about 20,000 enlistments over discharges in October, James Forrestal, Secretary of Defense, said today.

DETROIT, Nov. 29 -- At least one course in the social sciences should be compulsory for every American student in each of the four high school years and the first two college years, it was argued today by Dr. John W. Studebaker of New York, vice president and chairman of the editorial board of the Scholastic magazines.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was steady yesterday and final prices were 2 to 15 points net higher.

" Joan of Arc," the Ingrid Bergman vehicle now playing the fourth week of its continuous-run stand at the Victoria, will start a concurrent, two-a-day, reserved-seat engagement at the Fulton Theatre, beginning Tuesday, Dec. 14, it was announced yesterday by RKO, distributors of the Technicolor historical drama.
New Jersey archers will again have an opportunity to prove their skill at stalking and using the long bow, for a special deer season for archers will open on Dec. 7 and run through Dec. 11.

Some encouraging progress in eradicating the survey "racket" in direct selling was reported yesterday by the National Better Business Bureau. Seven concerns have voluntarily agreed to end the practice, through which door-to-door salesmen camouflage sales talks with research survey techniques, it was disclosed.

LONDON, Nov. 29 (UP) -- With ermine wraps hugging bare shoulders and coat collars turned high, British royalty and Hollywood and English movie stars braved a chill London fog tonight to attend the royal command film show.

Surmounting a crisis that last summer had imperiled its very existence, the Metropolitan Opera opened its new season last night with the usual splash of excitement. For the time being at least the troubles of the past were put aside, and the shows before and behind the footlights blended to add color and brilliance to one of the big evenings of the year on the artistic and social calendar.
Major milk companies should reduce their prices 4 cents a quart by April 1, Commissioner of Investigation John M. Murtagh said yesterday.

An estimated 88,069 long tons of new rubber was consumed in October, according to the monthly report of the Rubber Manufacturers Association, released yesterday. This was 3.34 per cent less than the 91,109 tons consumed in September.
FORT WAYNE, Ind., Nov. 29 (UP) -- Lester Eisenhut, police chief, asserted today that he had about the most contented policemen in the country.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 -- Representatives of the supply divisions of the Army and Navy said today that, to maintain the degree of flexibility necessary to the protection of the best interests of the Government, they favored a program that would permit business to use freight absorption, freight equalization or f.o.b. pricing systems.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 (AP) -- A top government economist said today that recent price declines are unlikely to snowball into a general price collapse which could lead to a depression.
Ill health will cost the United States more than twenty-five times as much in lost production time as strikes this year, according to Government statistics.

An association of plastering contractors, four plastering concerns and twenty-one persons were arraigned yesterday afternoon in Kings County Court on a seventeen-count indictment charging fraudulent practices that added at least $1,000,000 to building costs in Brooklyn in the last three years.

NANKING, Nov. 29 -- Elements of two Government Army Groups in the Suchow area were reported to be moving southward tonight on orders from Nanking to evacuate that isolated northern Kiangsu rail junction. This evacuation attempt was regarded as hazardous in view of new Communist dispositions in the area of Suhsien, fifty rail miles south of Suchow, and the infiltration of Red units down to the north bank of the Huai River.

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 29 -- Federal Judge George H. Moore directed the Missouri Pacific Railroad today to send its cars across a picket line at a stove-manufacturing plant. He maintained that the court could not compel union trainmen to cross the line but that the railroad could discipline union crews for refusing to do so.

After hearings at City Hall yesterday, Mayor O'Dwyer reserved decision on three proposed local laws designed to curb rent gouging. Representatives of landlord groups appeared to protest the proposed laws.

Thirty-five families facing orders to vacate their apartments in four tenements owned by St. Clare's Hospital in West Fifty-second Street will receive a period of grace from the hospital, it was said yesterday. The buildings are to be demolished, and replaced with a nurses' home.
PARIS, Nov. 29 -- Four of the Big Five -- all but the Soviet Union -- sponsored a resolution today calling for a drastic voluntary reduction in the right of veto.

The stock market backed down yesterday to new low ground since last February when tax selling uncovered no supporting bids. Stocks offered at the market found by the time orders reached the trading floor that prices had fallen. The only firmness of the session appeared at the opening.
Mayor O'Dwyer appealed yesterday for "bright ideas from faultfinders" to back up "intelligent city planning, the only cure I know of for our traffic ills."

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 29 -- With Army and Navy transports and commercial planes pressed into service to bring home armed services' dependents from China in "Operation Orient," the services and the Red Cross announced themselves today as ready to handle an influx, the full extent of which is not yet determined.

HOUSTON, Tex., Nov. 29 -- As the National Association of Attorneys General opened business sessions of its annual convention here today J. Tom Watson of Florida, association president, attacked "the usurping of state power by the Federal Government."

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Nov. 29 -- In a test case here involving constitutional privileges of freedom of assembly and freedom of speech, two Westchester County leaders of the American Labor party were found guilty today of disorderly conduct for having refused to disband a street-corner election rally.

GUATEMALA, Nov. 29 (AP) -- A Government Minister said tonight that authorities in Puerto Barrios, chief seaport of Guatemala, had captured arms and ammunition and prevented what apparently had been a plot to seize the city's military base.

CAPE TOWN, Nov. 29 (Reuters) -- South Africa's Supreme Court today reserved judgment in a claim for 12,500 ($50,000) for salvage service rendered by two Cape Town tugs to two United States cargo vessels that lost propellers in Cape waters.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 -- A registration statement covering 200,000 shares of $2.50 par value common stock has been filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission by Mrs. Tucker's Foods, Incorporated, Sherman, Tex.

Due to the housing emergency and present temporary rent laws, most tenants in New York City have not renewed their leases nor entered into new ones. It is, therefore, propitious at this time to give thought to the age-old problem of lease forms and clauses in small print.

ELIZABETH, N. J., Nov. 29 -- Harold Simandl, a defense attorney in the gambling trial of Councilman John C. Boyle and three other Elizabeth men, which opened here today before County Judge Walter L. Hetfield, told the jury of eight women and four men that the indictment against Boyle was prompted by Police Chief Frank Brennan to "get even.

Social workers in this country were called upon yesterday to learn how they may be of help to social workers throughout the world. The plea was made at the opening session of the forty-seventh annual conference of the New Jersey Welfare Council, held at the Hotel New Yorker, by Mrs. Mildred Buckwalter Beck, assistant executive secretary of the New York Committee on Mental Hygiene.
ST. LOUIS, Nov. 29 -- A special draft of doctors, if sufficient numbers do not volunteer to meet the needs of the armed services, was predicted today by Dr. James C. Sargent of Milwaukee.

AMBOISE, France, Nov. 29 -- The city of Madrid, situated in a harsh landscape under a brilliant castillian sky, is inhabited by a courteous, dour people whose thin bodies contain powerful but repressed emotions. Strength and at the same time repression of these feelings have given color to Spanish political history of the past that carries on into the present.

A WEEK ago in this space a rather amusing tale was told by Hol Slutz, a referee in the All-America Conference, concerning Fred Mitchell Walker, his coach at DePauw more than a quarter of a century ago. One trouble with good football stories, however, is that they invariably get more and more embroidered with each retelling until it's difficult to distinguish between fact and fancy.

PARIS, Nov. 29 -- After a long discussion of the opposing views of Radical and Socialist Ministers on balancing the budget, the Government has decided to try to compromise by covering about one-half the deficit by cutting expenses and about one-half by new taxation.

PARIS, Nov. 29 -- Argentine Foreign Minister Juan Atilio Bramuglia has asked the Big Four for formal acceptance of his mediation plan, which calls for a thorough study by a commission of "neutral" experts of all the technical and political problems involved in a permanent settlement of the Berlin dispute, it was learned today.

TOKYO, Nov. 29 -- Gen. Douglas MacArthur today lifted a corner of the veil of secrecy with which the Army has surrounded the fate of Hideki Tojo and six other Japanese war criminals who have been sentenced to death by the International Military Tribunal.

PARIS, Nov. 29 -- By a preponderant majority, the Legal Committee of the United Nations General Assembly adopted today an Egyptian draft resolution calling on member states that have not yet acceded to the convention on privileges and immunities of the United Nations to do so at the earliest possible moment.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Nov. 29 -- Despite protests from some communities, the Westchester Board of Supervisors moved today toward increasing to $795 the annual cost-of-living bonus for 2,000 county employes. In addition to the current bonus, the employes have received $300 of the original wartime bonus frozen into base pay.
CLEVELAND, Nov. 29 (AP) -- The Cleveland Browns today gave season ticket holders the first chance at seats for the championship game of the All-America Conference.

Thirty-two instruments for the detection of the various types of radiations, including two miniature detectors used to protect workers handling highly radioactive materials, will be displayed today by the United States Atomic Energy Commission at the Conference on Electronic Instrumentation in Nucleonics and Medicine.

Maurice Wilk is a young violinist whose second recital at Carnegie Hall last night showed that he continues to mature and develop both technically and interpretively. Most notable of his growing equipment was a remarkably big, pleasing tone, for his left-hand technique always has left little to be desired.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 -- Koki Hirota, former Premier of Japan, and Gen. Kenji Doihara today asked the United States Supreme Court to save them from being hanged as war criminals.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Nov. 29 -- The Italian Government has asked the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization that the general conference of next year be held in Rome, a spokesman for the organization said today. It is believed probable that the invitation would be accepted.

The Appellate Division unanimously upheld yesterday a 12 per cent rent increase for tenants of Knickerbocker Village, East Side Housing Development, approved last March by Herman T. Stichman, State Commissioner of Housing.

A man suffering from insomnia and high blood pressure recently was examined by his doctor, who could find no organic cause for the symptoms. The patient was advised to go to a psychiatrist and, under psychoanalysis, he revealed that he had evaded his state income tax.

CHICAGO, Nov. 29 -- With a crucial convention fight between right and left-wing forces for control of the Transport Workers Union, CIO, one week off, leaders of the factions disagreed sharply today on their relative strength.
BERLIN, Nov. 29 -- The success of the Marshall Plan is threatened by a possible run-away inflation in Western Germany, United States finance officials declared today.

NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 29 -- Motion-picture producers were urged to take disciplinary action against erring movie tars in a resolution adopted here today by the Allied States Association of Motion Picture Exhibitors at the opening session of its national convention.

Within a few days the United States will begin formal discussion of perhaps the most significant peacetime diplomatic move it has undertaken since the announcement of the Monroe Doctrine, in 1823. This will be an attempt to reach agreement with Britain, France, Belgium, the Netherlands and Luxembourg -- and perhaps other nations later on -- for the common defense of Western Europe and the islands and shores of the whole North Atlantic.
Michigan is the mythical national football champion in the final Associated Press poll of the 1948 season.

PARIS, Nov. 29 -- An increase of 7 1/2 per cent in the cost-of-living allowance for the United Nations Secretariat members working at Lake Success was approved today by Administrative Budgetary Committee of the General Assembly.

Parlor-game competition among teams drawn from the studio audience is the idea behind "Messing's Prize Party," the television program WCBS-TV will introduce on Monday from 8 to 8:30 P. M. Bill Slater and Minnabess Lewis will be the hosts on the program, each championing an opposing team.
JERUSALEM, Nov. 29 (AP) -- A cease-fire for Jerusalem was ordered today by the Arab and Israeli military commanders.

After having read "hundreds of musical books," Lorraine Lester reports that she finally has found one that fills the order. It is a play with music, quite folksy in style, according to Miss Lester, called "Careless Love." The authors are Paul Milton and Bud Fishel and the score is by George Lessner.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 -- Robert E. Stripling, chief investigator for the House Committee on Un-American Activities, announced today that he would offer his resignation when the committee is reorganized in January under Democratic control.

CLEVELAND, Nov. 29 -- The Republican Eightieth Congress, deemed "anti-labor" by workingmen, was responsible for a strong and effective political effort by labor at the precinct level to roll up the bulk of the popular vote by which President Truman won his surprising victory over Gov. Thomas E. Dewey.

My good friend, Justice Charles S. Colden, has written you asking that THE NEW YORK TIMES support his proposal to Governor Dewey that the operation of the old Day Line excursion steamers be taken over by the Conservation Department of this state.

During the Hollywood hearings held last year by the House Committee on Un-American Activities, THE TIMES stated editorially: "We do not believe that the committee is conducting a fair investigation. We think the course on which it has embarked threatens to lead to greater dangers than those with which it is presently concerned."
KANSAS CITY, Nov. 29 (AP) -- Paul (Buddy) Burris and Jack Mitchell of Oklahoma were named today as the Big Seven Conference's most outstanding players this season.
ATLANTA, Nov. 29 (AP) -- The 1948 Associated Press All-Southeastern team not only speaks well for the caliber of football played this season, but it promises well for the next two years.

A railroad engineer on the "fastest non-stop freight run in the country" shared the limelight yesterday with the grand national crochet champion for 1948 in the seventh annual nationwide contest sponsored by the National Needlecraft Bureau.

Voluntary hospitals will carry out as rapidly as possible Dr. Edward M. Bernecker's recommendation that they replace ambulance attendants with internes. This was announced yesterday by Louis Schenkweiler, president of the Greater New York Hospital Association, after a meeting at 233 Broadway, at which thirty-two hospitals were represented.

Firm prices, a trend toward lower ranges and heavy buyer attendance marked the opening yesterday of the first industry-sponsored Popular Price Shoe Show of America at the Commodore Hotel. The show, under the joint auspices of the National Association of Shoe Chain Stores and the New England Shoe and Leather Association, continues through Thursday.

The New York Public Library closes its celebration of one hundred years of service to our people here and to scholars all over the world with a statement of financial condition that makes far from pleasant reading. The Reference Department, at Fifth Avenue and Forty-Second Street, faces "the gravest crisis in its history."

The Crown Zellerbach Corporation and its subsidiaries in the six months ended with October had sales of $85,049,716, a gain of 14 per cent over the $74,211,648 for the same period last year, according to the report for release today.

Two public utility bond issues totaling $14,500,000 were sold at deadline bidding yesterday to banking syndicates here. Reoffering to investors will take place later in the week. The awards were as follows:

BERLIN, Nov. 29 -- Berlin's Communists today made the first definite move toward establishment of a separate "government" of the city in the Soviet sector and Marshal Vassily D. Sokolovsky, Russian commander in chief, assured them of his support and protection in a letter to Gen. Lucius D. Clay, United States Military Governor.

Characterized by all the pomp and elegance traditional with Metropolitan Opera premieres for more than six decades, the opening performance last night at the Metropolitan Opera Rouse resumed its heritage of the most important "first night" for members of society in the new season.

Factory dollar volume of the commercial and industrial air-conditioning and refrigeration industry will reach a record peak this year, O. W. Bynum, general sales manager of the Carrier Corporation, predicted yesterday. He spoke before 275 company distributors, dealers and associate dealers from twelve Northeastern States and the District of Columbia at a meeting in the Building Trades Auditorium, 2 Park Avenue.

Engineers practicing today are in danger of using techniques that have been made obsolescent by modern scientific discoveries, Dr. Harold Vagtborg told members of the American Society of Mechanical Engineers at the Pennsylvania Hotel yesterday.

Two young men staged a delayed-action hold-up in the Bronx yesterday afternoon, and thereby gained $20 and the momentary possession of two dark, conservatively cut suits of clothing. Police of the Simpson Street station are now looking for them.

BOSTON, Nov. 29 -- The Boston Bar Association petitioned the State Supreme Judicial Court today for an investigation of "professional misconduct and unethical practices" in the municipal court and the district courts of Suffolk County.

LONDON, Nov. 29 -- Thick, pea green fog once again blanketed most of England today, slowing transportation over a wide area. At Southampton the liner Queen Elizabeth, which has been held in dock by strikes in the United States and bad weather since Nov. 17 again was unable to begin her voyage this morning because of the fog.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 -- Average primary market prices advanced 0.4 per cent in the week ended on Nov. 23, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. The index is 164.9 per cent of the 1926 average, or 0.1 per cent higher than four weeks ago and 3.2 per cent higher than in the comparable week of 1947.

The Metropolitan Opera Association opened its doors last night for the winter of 1948-49 with the most ermine audience we have beheld in seasons. Enthusiasm ran high; a festive spirit reigned. No doubt the possibility which had threatened some months ago of losing the Metropolitan Opera added to the gratification of this gathering.

OMAHA, Nov. 29 (AP) -- The World-Herald said today that Dr. Walter Beggs, chairman of the University of Nebraska athletic board, has given a vote of confidence to Patsy Clark, football coach, whose team completed the season Saturday with eight defeats in ten games.
Throngs of fashionable women in jewels and orchids, ermine and mink, packed the foyers last night at the Metropolitan Opera House for the opening of the sixty-fourth season.

NEWARK, N. J., Nov. 29 -- The first highway bus postoffice service in the East got under way here today in thirty-nine North Jersey and five New York communities. Two postoffices on wheels left the Newark postoffice loading platform at 8:15 A. M., one to cover the route from here to Wanaque and the other to Middletown, N. Y.
As part of New York State's program of school sports and health activities, 1,200 elementary and high school children in this state have added skiing to their reading, writing and arithmetic.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 (AP) -- Industrial production rolled to a new peacetime record in October, breaking through a previous peak which had stood for seven months, the Federal Reserve Board reported tonight. An upturn in output of durable goods sent the board's index of production up 3 points last month to a level 95 percent above -- or nearly double -- the 1935-39 average.

PORTLAND, Ore., Nov. 29 (AP)-- A waterfront explosion rocked a wide area of the city tonight, but a fire which started in a municipal terminal building and among piles of lumber was soon under control.

NEW ORLEANS, La., Nov. 29 -- As "the dominant economic and financial power in the world" the United States must assume the position in international trade in this century that the European nations held in the nineteenth century, William McChesney Martin, president of the United States Export-Import Bank, declared tonight.

CINCINNATI, Nov. 29 -- Education for marriage begins at birth, the Rev. Dr. Roy A. Burkhart, pastor of the First Community Church, Columbus, Ohio, told the opening session here today of the third annual National Conference on Church and Home.

Before one of the smallest crowds in the club's history, Eugene (Dummy) Hairston, Bronx deaf mute, last night pounded out a decision over Al Mobley, Newark middleweight, in the eight-round feature at the St. Nicholas Arena. But when the battle was over, Hairston knew that he had been in a fight.
RICHMOND, Va., Nov. 29 (AP) -- Wilmington's Clippers whipped the Richmond Rebels, 22 -- 14, tonight to gain the final round of the American Football League championship play-off.

The trial of Dorothy and Pearl Bloom, wealthy spinster sisters charged with rent gouges totaling $4,407, began in Special Sessions yesterday. A number of witnesses, called by Assistant District Attorney James J. Fitzpatrick, testified that they had been obliged to buy broken-down furniture as a condition to leasing cold-water flats in tenements owned by the sisters.
SEOUL, Korea, Nov. 29 -- The Korean Government will ask the Allies to turn over two convicted Japanese top ranking war leaders to the Korean courts, Foreign Minister C. C. Chang declared today.

A good Federal budget policy rather than Government control of prices, production, wages and profits will bring about economic stability, Howard B. Myers, associate director of research of the Committee for Economic Development, told 200 members of the League of Women Voters yesterday.
FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, Nov. 29 (AP) -- A former unit of the huge I. G. Farben Chemical Trust was awarded a contract today for setting up Germany's biggest penicillin plant.

Miss Agnes Franklin Keyes heads the executive committee for the annual Christmas bazaar in aid of the Cenacle of St. Regis to be held tomorrow afternoon and evening in the main ballroom of the Plaza. A wide variety of articles suitable for holiday gifts will be on sale.

The first regular workday after the crippling eighteen-day longshoremen's strike saw thousands of dock workers return to their jobs yesterday in the Port of New York, despite a rain that prevented work at some of the piers until late afternoon.

PARIS, Nov. 29 -- Final disposition of the former Italian colonies will be deferred until next year because it is obvious now that time is lacking for thorough debate by the United Nations General Assembly's Political and Security Committee, United States circles said tonight.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Nov. 29 (AP) -- Frank Burns, Rutgers University's sensational quarterback, is the top man in the Starlet's offense department for the 1948 season, a compilation of the season's football statistics revealed today. The feat was the fourth in a row for the 21-year-old Roselle Park star.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 29 (UP) -- Chuck Bednarik, Pennsylvania's star center, was named the football player of the year by the Philadelphia Maxwell Club today and simultaneously was drafted by the Philadelphia Eagles of the National Football League.

The carelessness of the public and not the Department of Sanitation is responsible for the dirty condition of the city's streets, a report of the committee on public health and welfare of the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York charged yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 -- Walter White, secretary of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, asserted today that President Truman had "expressed his determination to go straight through with his civil rights program."
PITTSBURGH, Nov. 29 (AP) -- The University of Pittsburgh tonight delayed until tomorrow its selection of an athletic director.

NEW DELHI, India, Nov. 29 -- India's 60,000,000 "Untouchables" officially became equal citizens instead of pariahs today when the Constituent Assembly gave final approval to a clause in the new Constitution.

The question whether Robert F. Wagner, Senator from New York for twenty-two years, will continue as a member through the Eighty-first Congress, or will resign some time before next May, has become a matter of increasing political concern.

The eye injury which threatened a handicap for Tommy Yarosz, Pittsburgh middleweight, in his ten - round bout Friday night against Jake LaMotta at Madison Square Garden, yesterday was found to be of negligible consequence by the State Athletic Commission.

The seventh annual exhibition by the Audubon Artists has been installed in the galleries of the National Academy of Design, Fifth Avenue and Eighty-ninth Street. A preview reception will be held on Wednesday evening and the exhibition will be open to the public thereafter through Dec. 15.

The Realty Advisory Board on Labor Relations, Inc., announced yesterday that it had reached an "impasse" on wage and hour negotiations with 20,000 elevator operators and other employes in Manhattan apartment houses.

LAKE SUCCESS, Nov. 29 -- The strike of longshoremen in this country, which paralyzed Atlantic shipping until Saturday, almost disrupted the plans of the United Nations' own future organization in the maritime field, it was learned here today.
Boston, Mass., announced yesterday that it will accept bids until tomorrow for $5,000,000 of temporary loan notes dated Dec. 6, 1948, and due on Oct. 3, 1949.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Nov. 29 -- A final agreement tomorrow among the three Western Military Governors on the contents of occupation statutes is dependent, Gen. Lucius D. Clay said tonight, on the solution of at least two remaining points of difference.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Nov. 29 -- The impressive official celebrations of the fifth anniversary of the founding of Premier Marshal Tito's regime in the Bosnian mountain village of Jajce have been notable for the public acknowledgment of aid rendered by the British and United States Governments to Marshal Tito's Partisan movement during the war.

LONDON, Nov. 23 -- Britain's major ports, partly crippled by war damage and ravaged by years of enforced neglect, are struggling slowly back into shape. Last year the volume of trade passing through the United Kingdom's forty-nine ports was 70 per cent of pre-war (approximately 125,000,000 tons compared with 179,000,000 tons in 1938).

At various times since the end of the war farm prices, union wage policies or the tendency of some business men to take advantage of the prevailing sellers markets have been singled out as the principal motivating force or forces behind the ascending spiral of price inflation.

GENEVA, Nov. 29 -- Europe's requirements for United States coal will be 500,000 tons less in the first quarter of 1949 than in the current quarter of 1948, the Economic Commission for Europe, a United Nations affiliate, announced today.

The Merchants Club has purchased its clubhouse property at 22-26 Thomas Street, southeast corner of Trimble Place, from Samuel Levy and Charles F. Noyes in an all cash transaction. The Charles F. Noyes Company was the broker in the transaction.

The Dutch may have bought Manhattan from the Indians for $24 in trinkets, but Westchester acquired its first large park from the state for $1. And the county obtained the Bronx River Parkway, granddaddy of all automobile parkways in the world, by having New York City foot three-quarters of the bill.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 (AP) -- Coach George Sauer of the Navy disclosed today that he remodeled his team's formation before the Army game.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 -- Norman J. O. Makin, Australian Ambassador to the United States, urged all schools of higher learning today to include courses in the science of peace in their curriculums.
LONDON, Nov. 29 (UP) -- As night fell, continental Europe from Scandinavia to Italy lay under the massive fog bank. Meteorologists predicted only spotty relief in the next forty-eight hours.

On Nov. 24 you published a letter from Taraknath Das in which the writer stated that recent dispatches in THE NEW YORK TIMES had confirmed his information that the Government of Pakistan had been seeking the support of the Anglo-American powers and the United Nations to make a success of its aggression in Kashmir.

Harold Littledale's letter struck a familiar chord, both for the shut-in and the depleted library funds. We all know the wonderful service the library gives our metropolis and the opportunity it affords for those who want to lose themselves in a good book.
PRINCETON, N. J., Nov. 29 (AP) -- The Poe Memorial Football Cup "for ability, loyalty and sportsmanship" was awarded to Val Wagner, a senior, tonight.

CAMDEN, N. J., Nov. 29 (AP) -- The Delaware River Joint commission studied today an engineering firm's recommendation for a $91,000,000 modernization and improvement plan for the combined Philadelphia-Camden port area.

The Education Writers Association will make four awards for the best writing on education done in 1948, Harrison W. Fry, education editor of The Philadelphia Evening Bulletin and president of the association, announced yesterday. He spoke at the second annual regional meeting of the association, held in the conference room of Columbia University's American Press Institute.
HONOLULU, Nov. 29 -- Mme. Chiang Kai-shek paused briefly in Honolulu tonight before proceeding by air to the mainland of the United States on her mission to enlist American aid for China.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 -- Secretary of Agriculture Charles F. Brannan announced today plans looking toward a new international wheat agreement following the closing session of the United Nations Food and Agricultural Organization, of which he is chairman.

TOKYO, Nov. 29 -- Perhaps the most significant feature of the new supplementary budget -- which the Government will introduce tomorrow and hopes to see passed before mid-December -- is the fact that the basic wage for public workers has been set at 5,300 yen (about $20) monthly.

The young state of Israel filed its official application yesterday for membership in the United Nations. Apparently enough votes are in sight, both in the Council and in the Assembly, to assure favorable action on this appeal. Such action is clearly warranted.

The fishing equipment manufacturing industry, said to be extremely sensitive to national economic changes, has been feeling since August a slump in sales of merchandise for next spring. John M. Holmes, secretary-treasurer, of the Associated Fishing Tackle Manufacturers, a group whose members now produce about $45,000,000 of equipment annually at distributors' levels, made this disclosure yesterday at the annual convention in the Pennsylvania Hotel.

Johnston, Lemon Co. and other underwriters will offer to investors today a new issue of 60,000 shares of 6 per cent $25 par value convertible preferred stock of State Loan and Finance Corporation, a Washington, D. C., holding company in the personal loan business. The stock is priced at $25 a share.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 (UP) -- There was an increasing demand today that Mme. Chiang tell her story to the Congressional committees directly concerned with American foreign aid and foreign policy.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 -- The Ways and Means Committee in the new Congress, controlled by Democrats, will not rush out a new tax bill without full study of revenue needs and of all proposals for changes in the present tax law, according to Representative Robert L. Doughton, who will return to the chairmanship of the committee in January.
For the first time this season, sleet fell on the city yesterday and was followed by the first snow, but both vanished rapidly, the Weather Bureau reported.

Despite the recent buoyancy of the market for tax-exempt securities, distributors of municipal bonds are not too cocksure about the pricing of the issue of $51,450,000 of New York State housing bonds coming up for sale today.

The city will receive $121,200 annually for the lease, as a parking lot, of the two-block area on which the old Tombs Prison and the Criminal Courts Building used to stand. The figure was the top bid at an auction yesterday at the Board of Standards and Appeals in the Municipal Building.

HONOLULU, Nov. 29 -- The eighty-nine-day West Coast maritime strike has hit Hawaii's cane sugar industry hard and losses will "run into millions," John E. Russell, retiring president, told the sixty-eighth annual meeting of the Hawaiian Sugar Planters Association here today.
MELBOURNE, Australia, Nov. 29 -- Australian rain-making experiments have convinced scientists they have practical value.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Nov. 29 -- For the past four days Lebanese and Syrian leaders have been in a fever of activity that has been attributed to the threat of losing the lucrative trans-Arabian pipeline project. There is reason to believe, however, that their discussions were concerned also with a meeting called by King Abdullah of Trans-Jordan at Jericho in Palestine on Wednesday.
The silver anniversary Christmas sale sponsored by the New York State Commission for the Blind was off to a record start yesterday at 11 West Fifty-seventh Street. It will continue through Dec. 18.

Buddy O'Connor, New York Rangers' center, is to rejoin his teammates tonight when the Blue Shirts resume National Hockey League warfare against the rugged Chicago Black Hawks at Madison Square Garden.

BELLEVILLE, N. J., Nov. 29 -- A bus driver and five women passengers were injured slightly today when a Newark-bound Public Service bus carrying twenty-eight passengers crashed into a plate glass display window of Landau's Department Store here at 22 Bloomfield Avenue.

PARIS, Nov. 29 -- Israel submitted her application for admission to the United Nations to Secretary General Trygve Lie at 6 o clock this evening, exactly one year after the passage of the General Assembly's Palestine partition resolution.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 -- An Interstate Commerce Commission examiner recommended today the approval of a plan of the Central of New Jersey Railroad for the voluntary adjustment of its outstanding securities. If approved, the plan would terminate the bankruptcy proceedings in the Federal District Court for New Jersey.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 -- Early repeal of the Taft-Hartley Act is expected to be one of President Truman's main labor proposals in his State-of-the-Union message.

Representatives from seven clubs last night attended the clinic for prospective cross-country and jumping officials sponsored by the Metropolitan Ski Jumping Committee at the Norwegian Club in Brooklyn.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 -- The State Department revealed today the story of Mrs. McGary and the Kunming lepers.

Fred Wendt of Texas Mines Scored 42 points -- six touchdowns and six extra points -- Thanksgiving Day, but wound up second to Ted Scown of Sul Ross (Tex.) State in the season's national football scoring race.

Unless substantial budgetary surpluses can be achieved at present levels of national income without further increases in taxes, "there would seem to be little likelihood that further inflationary increases in the national debt can be avoided over the long term," according to the Guaranty Trust Company of New York.

TOKYO, Tuesday, Nov. 30 (AP) -- Legislation suggested by General MacArthur outlawing strikes and collective bargaining by Government employes was passed by the Japanese House of Representatives today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 -- Red-faced buyers of new automobiles were shown by the House subcommittee investigating alleged questionable trade practices today how late model used cars which they had traded in were resold promptly for up to nearly $500 more than they had paid for their 1948 models.

On twenty-five of the twenty-seven nights allotted to college basketball at Madison Square Garden this season there will be a public sale of tickets. This disclosure was made by Ned Irish, executive vice president of the Garden, at the first meeting of the Metropolitan Basketball Writers Association at Leone's Restaurant yesterday.

Marian Anderson, contralto, was the guest soloist with the Little Orchestra Society last night at Town Hall and earned the ovation of the evening with her performance of Liszt's "scene dramatique," "Jean d'Arc au Bucher."

One of the big problems of distribution is that 85 per cent of the products supplies only 15 per cent of the business, G. H. B. Davis, of the marketing coordination department of Standard Oil Company (New Jersey), declared yesterday.
DALLAS, Nov. 29 (AP) -- Lindy Berry, Texas Christian's versatile quarterback, captured the ball-carrying and total offense laurels in Southwest Conference football for the season.
The Public Service Commission denied a motion yesterday to set aside interim increased gas rates that became effective last Feb. 2 for customers of Long Island system gas companies.
ATLANTA, Nov. 29 (AP) -- Gov. Herman Talmadge said today that he wanted the murderers of Robert Mallard, a Negro, arrested regardless of "what color they are or who they are."

A veteran of World War II who lost both his legs in military service may teach in the New York public school system if he can meet the necessary academic requirements, according to a decision of the Board of Examiners.

It is indeed good news that American visitors to Britain no longer need a visa. But even if there is to be no reciprocity apart from the waiving of the $2 fee, need the procedure in the reverse direction be quite so lengthy and humiliating?

Directors of American and Foreign Power Company, Inc., have deferred until Dec. 15 consideration of the declaration and payment of dividends on the company's two series of preferred stock, W. S. Robertson, president, announced yesterday.

PARIS, Nov. 29 -- Dec. 13 is now the most likely date for the adjournment of the United Nations General Assembly, it was learned today. The Secretariat still is pressing its efforts to quit in the small hours of Dec. 12, but in any event Dec. 13 now appears to be the absolute deadline.

In an appeal to President Truman to defer from the draft active merchant marine officers, Capt. William C. Ash, vice president of the National Organization of Masters, Mates and Pilots of America, yesterday questioned the enrollment of new men in maritime academies.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 (AP) -- The Office of Defense Transportation accused the Department of Commerce today of backing a plan under which it would take 23 years to meet present-day needs for new freight cars.

ALBANY, Nov. 29 -- Governor Thomas E. Dewey, back at his capitol desk after a three-week Arizona vacation, disclosed today that he intended to go ahead with sorely needed mental-hospital facilities despite vastly increased building costs.

ATHENS, Nov. 29 -- Kapitanios Perdikas, long considered among the ablest of guerrilla chiefs in the Peloponnesus, was killed by order of rebel headquarters within recent days on the ground that he showed too much independence, according to information reaching the General Staff here tonight.

TOKYO, Tuesday, Nov. 30 -- At least two and possibly all seven of the former Japanese leaders sentenced to the gallows for war crimes have now received a last-minute reprieve pending action by the United States Supreme Court.

JERSEY CITY, N. J., Nov. 29 -- Miss Helen Griffin, Democratic Party women's executive of the Second Ward, here, has been discharged from her $4,000-a-year position as senior contract clerk in the office of the Jersey City law department.

LONDON, Nov. 29 -- Sales of British goods to the Soviet Union during the twelve months that ended last September totaled 5,386,000 (about $21,544,000), A. G. Bottomley, Secretary for Overseas Trade of the Board of Trade, informed the House of Commons today.
SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 29 (AP) -- Oregon and California, co-champions of the Pacific Coast Conference, between them captured all but four places on the Associated Press All-Pacific Coast football team.
PARIS, Nov. 29 -- Colonial peoples the world over were made beneficiaries of an international Declaration on Human Rights today.

A potentially dangerous situation is arising in Korea. The immediate issue is whether the National Government, created under the auspices of the United Nations and recognized by the United States as the government for all Korea, shall also be recognized as such by the United Nations, or recognized only as a government for that part of Korea where its authority is effective, which is the American-occupied southern zone.

Organized in 1938 and at. one time wielding great power over thousands of union members, the Greater New York Industrial Union Council, CIO, passed out of existence yesterday with the transfer of its physical properties to the right-wing state unit of the Congress of Industrial Organizations.
PARIS, Nov. 29 (AP) -- The text of Israel's letter, submitted by Foreign Minister Moshe Shertok, to Trygve Lie, Secretary General of the United Nations, applying for membership in the United Nations:

TOKYO, Nov. 29 -- The steering committee of the Japanese Diet's lower house today stalled on the arrest of former Premier Dr. Hitoshi Ashida on charges of corruption preferred by the Tokyo prosecutor's office.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 -- An early end to the Berlin crisis, with the Russians lifting their blockade and the Western Allies accepting the Soviet mark as the city's currency, was predicted today by Senator Tom Connally, Democrat, of Texas.

BOSTON, Nov. 29 (AP) -- Sandy Saddler of New York, the world featherweight champion, came from behind to pound out a unanimous ten-round decision over rough and rugged Dennis (Pat) Brady of Hartford, Conn., in their nontitle bout tonight before a capacity crowd of 12,007 at the Boston Garden.

Now that the cold weather is settling in, Mae West has mercifully brought "Diamond Lil" to the Montclair Theatre, where it opened for a short engagement last evening. In addition to the Montclair patrons of art, quite a number of Broadway scholars hopped across the river to see how well Mae is holding out.

The Justice Department's refusal to agree to bail for two alleged alien Communists was characterized yesterday as a step toward turning Ellis Island into "the first concentration camp in the United States." The charge was made by John Williamson, member of the national board of the Communist party, who is under indictment for conspiracy to overthrow the Government, and also facing deportation proceedings.
NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 29 (UP) -- William McChesney Martin, president of the United States Export-Import Bank, said today that the bank would not even consider a loan now to the Government of China.

The caliber of American business leadership will have an important impact upon the course of freedom and liberty all over the world, Harold E. Stassen, president of the University of Pennsylvania, declared here last night.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, Nov. 30 -- Only one relatively minor point remains to be adjusted before the completion and promulgation of a three-power military security pact affecting the future Western German state.

PARIS, Nov. 30 -- The British Government today introduced a revised resolution deleting its previous endorsement of the Bernadotte Plan, under which Israel would not obtain the Negeb, as a basis for the peaceful settlement of the Palestine question.

BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 30 -Argentina's Ambassador to Washington, Dr. Jeronimo Remorino, who has come home for consultations, said today that he would transmit President Truman's invitation to this country to join the United Nations Food and Agricultural Organization.

As another development in its "general program of offering to the public a better and more efficient banking service," Title Guarantee and Trust Company has installed teller machines for commercial deposits in the bank's midtown office, according to an announcement yesterday by Barnard Townsend, president.

A suit to set aside a 23 per cent rent increase granted by the City Rent Commission to the Park Crescent Hotel, 150 Riverside Drive, has been filed in Supreme Court in behalf of 100 tenants of the hotel.

Orders for heavy equipment in 1949 have definitely started to move toward a new peacetime record, and current inquiries for prices are setting a new high for any individual exposition, exhibitors declared yesterday in the second day of the Eighteenth National Power Show at Grand Central Palace.

THE invitation had read, "The Giants, Yankees and Dodgers cordially invite you to attend 'World Series of 1948'" and so forth and so on. It was to be the annual preview for the baseball folk of the films of the Cleveland Boston post-season affair which Lou Fonseca has just completed under the joint sponsorship of the National and American Leagues.

Because he is so thoroughly satisfied with training conditions in his native Cincinnati, Ezzard Charles, Ohio's potential heavyweight champion, has delayed his arrival in this city until Sunday, according to word he sent yesterday to the Twentieth Century S.C.

Because consumers in Washington pay five cents less for milk, although the price there to farmers is only a penny lower than in New York, John M. Murtagh, Commissioner of Investigation, said he was "being very charitable" in asking local milk distributors to cut retail prices four cents.
Two men were sentenced yesterday in Federal Court, Brooklyn, to long prison terms on their pleas of guilty to stealing from the mails and a third was indicted by the grand jury on a similar charge.

Dr. Coffin, Father LaFarge and Rabbi Lazaron deserve our gratitude for having tried to awaken the consciences of those who signed the welcome to Menachem Begin. Can the signers be unaware that by welcoming Mr. Begin they approved the terrorist acts committed by his Irgun Zvai Leumi and made themselves enemies of peace in the Holy Land?

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Nov. 30 -- American Labor party leaders won a belated victory here today in a fight for the privilege of conducting political rallies on public streets. Mayor Silas S. Clark, an attorney, declared that the municipal Department of Public Safety had erred in flatly denying the privilege.

Consolidated net sales of the City Stores Company for the nine months ended last Oct. 31, increased 9 per cent to $114,282,746 from the $104,778,283 volume for the corresponding period of the previous year, according to the report released today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -- The Senate Subcommittee on Trade Policies was told today that Wyoming would lose a $25,000,000 soda ash plant and Maine would be deprived of a paper manufacturing plant which produces $18,000,000 of paper a year, if American business was forced to adopt an f.o.b, mill pricing system.

A sweeping investigation of thousands of uncontested divorce actions in New York County over the last two years was foreshadowed by District Attorney Frank S. Hogan last night after the arrest of six persons said to be implicated in a "divorce-mill racket" here.

CALDWELL, N. J., Nov. 30--A four-engine transport plane with all of its propellers rotating backward made a controlled descent from 15,000 to 1,000 feet in 1 minute 22 seconds here today in the first public demonstration of the Curtiss-Wright Corporation's new reversible propellers.

TOKYO, Nov. 30 -- If the United States would allow Japan to use 120 Liberty ships on bareboat charter and permit the Japanese to use their own vessels in overseas trade the American taxpayer would save $147,000,000 of his present annual bill for the financing of the revival of Japan, according to a report by Kumakichi Nakashima, president of Japan's Foreign Trade Council.
A star is born in one of several innovations featuring the Christmas presentation opening today at the Hayden Planetarium, Seventyninth Street at Central Park West.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -- The railroads today opened their latest effort before the Interstate Commerce Commission for an increase in freight rates.
