They ran into shipper opposition based on the ground that 1948 income figures for the railroads had been bettered only in three war years, and in the middle and late Nineteen Twenties.

A bitter, running fight between two factions in Local 802, American Federation of Musicians, AFL, will come to an end tomorrow when members of the union go to the polls to elect a complete slate of officers.

Having been rejected last week by Supreme Court Justice Felix C. Benvenga, Tammany Hall's attempt to void the election of George Frankenthaler, RepublicanLiberal nominee for Surrogate, was argued yesterday afternoon before the Appellate Division, First Department.

LAKE SUCCESS, Nov. 30 -- A twelve-nation preparatory group representing 78 per cent of the world's shipping agreed here today on the budgetary formula that should be followed by the InterGovernmental Maritime Consultative Organization, when the organization would be established formally as a new United Nations agency.

Trading on the New York Stock Exchange last month was the heaviest since June and for a corresponding month since 1945. Sales exceeded a million shares in fifteen sessions, the heaviest of which was 3,236,700 shares on Nov. 3, the day following the Presidential Election.

As a former teacher and county superintendent of schools in West Virginia, I have always considered that New York's school system was probably the best in the United States. The controversy aired in THE TIMES concerning the single salary schedule gives me reason to think that I may have been in error.

In the name of the International Peasant Union and of the peasant parties of all nations behind the Iron Curtain as well as in that of the SocialistDemocratic parties affiliated with the International Democratic Front, permit us to express sincere thanks for your editorial, The Balkan Terror, which appeared in your issue of Nov. 24 in connection with the termination of the democratic opposition in Bulgaria and the condemnation of the Socialist Deputies.

The first event in a four-day festival of contemporary French music was presented by the Juilliard School of Music in its Concert Hall last night. The series is under the honorary patronage of Ambassador Henri Bonnet of France.

For the past two years, wildflowers who have hunted in Mexico have charged that American hunters have been put on short waterfowl rations in order to improve the Mexican hunting, and they point to the generous bag limits and the length of the season.

MONTREAL, Nov. 30 (AP) -- Dr. Raymond Boyer, fighting conviction on a charge of conspiring to violate the Official Secrets Act, indicated today that he would take his case before Canada's highest court after losing his initial appeal.

MIAMI, Fla. Nov. 30 (AP) -- Nine sprinters, headed by William H. Veeneman's Phar Mon, have been named in the $5,000-added Inaugural Handicap at Tropical Park tomorrow -first day of the 1948-49 winter racing season.
PARIS, Nov. 30 -- The proceedings of the United Nations:

Daniel S. Weiss, 39-year-old Manhattan attorney, was elected a member of the City Council yesterday to succeed S. Samuel di Falco, who was elected to the State Supreme Court at the last general election. Mr. Weiss is a Democrat.

Adults and children who came to picket cornerstone ceremonies for a Queens housing project yesterday remained to applaud, when they were assured that they would not be evicted precipitately from neighboring buildings marked for demolition. The pickets were from some of fifty families whose incomes are too high to permit their admission to the low-rent, publicly subsidized Astoria Houses.
ALBANY Nov. 30 (AP) -- A syndicate headed by the Chase National Bank of New York bought today a $51,450,000 issue of state serial housing bonds at a 2.148 per cent interest.

We hied ourselves with much pleasure to the revival of Donizetti's "Elixir of Love," given last night, after an interval of six years, in the Metropolitan Opera House as the second performance of the present season. Perhaps this delicious piece would not stand annual repetition as the strongest operas of the repertory do.

ALBANY, Nov. 30 -- Governor Dewey said today, after a long conference with officials on the mental hygiene situation, that the state would embark immediately on an extensive hospital program. But the program will fall far short of meeting the needs of the state for improved facilities at mental hospitals, he added.
CLEVELAND, Nov. 30 (AP) Republic Steel Corporation and nineteen other concerns manufacturing culvert pipe were sued today by the Government on charges of violating the Sherman Anti Trust Act.

Major increases in output no longer can be squeezed out of Great Britain's economic system unless productivity is raised by reorganization of industry and new investment in plants and facilities, according to the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

Domestic No. 5 sugar futures advanced yesterday in active trading on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange. Futures were firm with active commission house and trade house buying in evidence. Prices closed 1 to 3 points higher on sales aggregating 22,300 tons.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Nov. 30 (AP) -- After grabbing the lead in the opening minutes the New York Knickerbockers remained in control all the way tonight as they defeated the Providence Steam Rollers, 88 -- 61, in a Basketball Association of America game before 1,664 fans.
LONDON, Nov. 30 -- British shippingwhich has gone far toward recovering pre-war tonnage, will be virtually freed tomorrow from Government control for the first time since 1939.

A five-year program of Bible production and distribution at home and abroad, entailing the raising of $11,888,484 to cover total costs for more than 60,000,000 Bibles and parts of the Bible, was announced yesterday by the American Bible Society.

Excavations for a permanent structure to replace the seasonal and temporary summer quarters of Stadium Concerts, Inc., are already under way in Lewisohn Stadium, at 138th Street and Convent Avenue. The $400,000 structure, being built with dry funds, will be ready next June for the thirty-second season of outdoor summer concerts.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -- Senator Robert F. Wagner of New York has no intention of giving up the seat from which illness has forced his long absence, it was stated today in high Democratic quarters.
MIAMI, Fla., Nov. 30 (AP) -- The possibility of a football "doubleheader" here on Jan. 1 was reported in the making today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -- The United States has got itself involved in a complicated and, in the view of some observers here, an unnecessary controversy over its proposed military alliance with Canada and the Western European powers.

Underwriting syndicates will place on the market today three new issues of public utility bonds totaling $29,500,000. The offerings follow upon award of the new issues of securities to bankers at competitive sale. The offerings are as follows:
AMBOISE, France, Nov. 30 There is fairly general agreement among informed observers within Spain that organized opposition to the Franco regime has been pretty well smashed and splintered.

A golden opportunity exists for parents and child welfare organizations to see that the Eightyfirst Congress enacts constructive legislation on health and education of children, George J. Hecht, chairman of the American Parents Committee, declared yesterday.

Fears that pending Philippines' import control regulations will seriously disturb trade relations with the United States were allayed yesterday by Emilio Abello, Minister Plenipotentiary and Charge d'Affaires ad interim for the Philippine Embassy in Washington.

Government finance may "stump the experts," but the League of Women Voters will try in two years to teach 83,000 members in several states the direct ties between penny-wise household budgets and the billions of dollars on federal account books.

DETROIT, Nov. 30 -- Somewhere in the United States or Canada, an unheralded automobile, bus or truck has become the five-millionth unit built in the greatest production year in the industry since record-breaking 1929.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -Strikes declined in October, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -Charles Sawyer, Secretary of Commerce, cleared a speech today with President Truman that he hinted broadly would outline administration views on the relationship between Government and industry during the next four years.
MOBILE, Ala., Nov. 30 (AP) -Christmas came early today for Alvin Dark, the National League's rookie of the year.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 30 -RKO has acquired screen rights to "The Man Who Played Santa Claus," a magazine story by John Weaver, and has assigned the property to Don Hartman for production, with Cary Grant and Betsy Drake in the leading roles early next year.

Rather than be place in the untenable position of stifling production alleged, the Dramatists Guild has approved the royalty concession requested by John Golden for the revival of Sidney Howard's "They Knew What They Wanted," starring Paul Muni.

LONDON, Nov. 30 -- In what is believed to be the first case of its kind before a British divorce court, a degree of nullity was granted today to a mother of a child by artificial insemination on the ground of her husband's incapacity to consummate their marriage.
The Weather Bureau confirmed yesterday what every overcoat salesman in the city has known all along -- November, 1948, was the warmest in the history of the bureau.

NORFOLK, Va., Nov. 30 (AP) -The Navy said today that letters of admonition had been sent to the commanding officer and three other senior officers of the aircraft carrier Kearsarge as a result of the swamping of a launch in Hampton Roads May 31 that cost thirty lives.

IF there weren't so many bad historical novelists perhaps the good ones would get a little more of the credit which is their due. Buth)0*0*0*iGresham's Law, that in the circulation of money "bad money drives out good," also seems to work in the distribution of books. The enormous popularity of cheap and shoddy historical novels has cast a blight upon a number of good ones.

The women's division of the $425,000 campaign of the Visiting Nurse Service of New York has raised $102,761 so far, it was announced yesterday at the division's first report meeting, held at the service's headquarters, 262 Madison Avenue.
A six-year transit construction program requiring $900,000,000 was recommended yesterday by the city's Board of Transportation.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -- Representative Hugh Scott of Pennsylvania, Republican National Chairman, advised 22,000 Republican leaders today that they could win in 1950 and 1952 if they "audit and police the Truman New Deal" and "slug toe-to-toe * * * with the demagogues" against price controls and higher individual income taxes.

Basil Rathbone will serve as both star and narrator for a new series of adventure dramas in which he will play himself, more or less, when CBS introduces the program Jan. 8 from 10 to 10:30 P.M. Basic material for each weekly broadcast will be drawn from the actor's life, which, the announcement states, includes "adventurous wanderings over half the earth from South Africa to Hollywood."
PITTSBURGH, Nov. 30 (AP) -Pitt today picked Navy Capt. Tom Hamilton to direct its athletics provided Uncle Sam will release him for the job -- and Hamilton wants it.
LONDON, Nov. 30 -- Sir William Strang will be Permanent UnderSecretary of State at the Foreign Office on Feb. 1 next, succeeding Sir Orme Sargent who is retiring,h)0*0*0*iit was announced tonight.

Although preparations have been made for the placing of large surgical equipment orders by the Government in the event of war, there is no stock piling at the present time, it was learned yesterday. Officials of the Manufacturers Surgical Trade Association, now holding its semi-annual meeting in the Commodore Hotel, also disclosed that due to wartime alloy developments, no steel shortages are being felt by the industry.

LONDON, Nov. 30 -- An "immediate danger" to the freedom of British scientists was seen tonight by Sir Robert Robinson, president of the Royal Society and professor of chemistry at Oxford University, in commenting upon the political suppression of the classical school of genetics in the Soviet Union.

NANKING, Nov. 30 -- In the face of advancing Communist armies, Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek was reported today to be preparing to assume personal command of the defense of the capital while the Government discussed plans to take refuge in Canton and Chungking.

Mixed trends prevailed in new security financing in November. Bonds offered to the public, although below October levels, were the largest for any November since 1927. Stock emissions, on the other hand, dropped to the lowest total since July and to the smallest figure for any November since 1942.

CHICAGO, Nov. 30 -- Michael J. Quill, international president of the Transport Workers Union, CIO, alleged today that the left-wing faction in the union was seeking to put across a "deal" under which it would keep some key union offices. The statement was characterized as a "plain, unadulterated lie" by Douglas L. MacMahon, the union's international secretary-treasurer, and Austin Hogan, president of its big New York local.
BATAVIA, Java, Wednesday, Dec. 1 (AP) -- Antara, Indonesian news agency, said today that former Premier Amir Sjarifudin, Communist leader, had been arrested yesterday by Government troops.

Although it would be a slight misstatement to say that the three local professional football clubs are going nowhere -- because the A.A.C. Yankees and the N.F.L. Giants are heading, respectively, for Chicago and Pittsburgh next Saturday -- it would be very slight.

Brig. Gen. C. M. Walson, administrator of the Red Cross Blood Program of the Greater New York Chapters, appealed yesterday for special Christmas donations of blood for the city's ill and injured during December. He made his special appeal, he said, because December, with its general preoccupation with holiday preparations, was recognized as the most difficult month of the year for recruiting donors.
GENEVA, Nov. 30 -- A bitter struggle over the price of coal for Europe's industries is under way, involving Germany, Britain and ultimately the whole of Europe.
PARIS, Nov. 30 -- The Soviet Union warned today that the United Nations would not survive "one day" without the veto.

Seven hundred foster mothers of children under supervision of the Jewish Child Care Association of New York will cooperate with the organization in a drive to find additional, urgently needed homes for dependent and neglected Jewish babies up to 3 years of age, it was announced yesterday.

CARACAS Venezuela, Nov. 30 -Dr. Pedro Ignacio Aguerrevere, new Venezuelan Minister of Development, declared today that for the time being there would be no changes in oil policies or in the granting of concessions.

CAMDEN, N.J., Nov. 30 -The oldest real estate firm in South Jersey -- it has had offices in this city for 101 years -- will be given away tomorrow by its owners. At ceremonies at its office, 13 Haddon Avenue, all stock of the Burr-Smith Company will be handed over by its co-owners, Mrs. Edith Burr and I. Mulford Smith, to two of the oldest employes.
CHICAGO, Nov. 30 (AP) -- Dates for Chicago's 1949 racing season were announced today by Ednyfed H. Williams, chairman of the Illinois racing board.
CHICAGO, Nov. 30 (UP) -- The National Safety Council said today that traffic fatalities rose 8 per cent in October, threatening hopes for an improved safety record this year.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -- Herbert Hoover plans to recommend a $25,000 tax-free expense account for President Truman, to pay the cost of running the White House. The former President thinks the Chief Executive should, in effect, have "room and board" furnished by the Government, in addition to his salary.

Edwin L. Tatro, who has been associated with Hoit, Rose Co. twenty years, announced yesterday the formation of the Edwin L. Tatro Company to transact a general business in investment securities. The new concern will maintain offices at 50 Broadway. John A. Doyle is in its trading department.

Soviet authorities have now set up their own puppet government in Berlin. In taking this action, backed by the Russian Military Governor and executed under the eyes of the Soviet police, they are trying to push aside the regular Berlin Government, elected under a Constitution approved by all four occupying Powers, and continuing their effort to drive the Western Powers from the city in defiance of the occupation agreement.
PARIS, Wednesday, Dec. 1 -- The Universal Declaration of Human Rights was completed here early today after three years of work by the United Nations.
John L. Sullivan, Secretary of the Navy, dismissed last night as a "divisive canard" all talk of conflict between the Navy and the Air Force for control of strategic air warfare.

Less emphasis on the building programs of hospitals for chronic and mental diseases and more on obtaining personnel with "appropriate temperaments and skills" was urged yesterday by Dr. George Draper, medical director of the Burke Memorial Foundation in White Plains, N.Y.

Chairman Reid of the Board of Transportation has used the occasion of City Planning Commission failure to include a requested several million dollars in the capital budget for renovating old power plants to tell the Board of Estimate what tremendous outlays of money lie ahead to modernize and enlarge the city's transit system.

TRENTON, N.J., Nov. 30 -- Election results in New Jersey, prepared formally by the Secretary of State, showed today that the total vote for President was: Governor Dewey, 981,124; President Truman, 895,455, and Henry A. Wallace, 42,683.
STATE COLLEGE, Miss., Nov. 30 (AP) -- Allyn McKeen, head football coach at Mississippi State College for ten years, resigned today, effective Jan. 1.

PARIS, Nov. 30 -- Dr. Juan Atilio Bramuglia, retiring president of the Security Council, issued tonight a declaration in which he urged the appointment of a commission of experts to study the application of currency reform in Berlin. His declaration said the commission should take into account as terms of reference for its work the "directive of Aug. 30, 1948, as well as information concerning events subsequent thereto."

Home accessories and jewels selected to show that beauty of design is not restricted to any one price level were displayed as Christmas gift suggestions yesterday by Black, Starr Gorham during a luncheon showing at the Ritz-Carlton Hotel.
LONDON, Nov. 30 -- End of account influences again brought dullness to the stock market here today.
NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 30 (AP) -W. H. Bishop's Handsome Beau drove home a length and a half ahead of his nearest rival at the Fair Grounds today to win the featured International Trade Mart Purse.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -- Eager prospective buyers of new automobiles who deposited $100 or so to get on dealers' priority lists received another jolt today.
President Truman will continue to develop the over-all pattern of American support for the legitimate aims of Israel, Oscar Ewing, Federal Security Administrator, predicted last night.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 30 (AP) -The Washington Redskins cannot do any better than second in the Eastern Division of the National Football League, but their passing experts are making a strong bid for aerial honors in the circuit.

Mayor O'Dwyer is scheduled to participate Tuesday in ceremonies marking the opening of a drive for funds for hospital work by the American Theatre Wing. The Mayor is listed as a speaker at the site of the wartime Stage Door Canteen in West Forty-fourth Street, now occupied by THE NEW YORK TIMES.

Engineers in this city for the sixty-ninth annual meeting of the American Society of Mechanical Engineers deserted their usual scientific sessions last night for a worried glance backward to see whether a creature of their making -- the machine age -- had undermined human morality as easily as it had learned to bite through stone and steel.

Although Anna Jarvis, who died a few days ago at the age of 84, spent a large part of her life combating the commercialization of Mother's Day, which she founded, she probably never became fully aware of what she let loose upon America in 1907.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, Nov. 30 (UP) -- Following is the text of the letter sent by Gen. Lucius D. Clay, United States Military Governor, to Marshal Vassily D. Sokolovsky, Soviet commander in Germany:

SANTIAGO, Chile, Nov. 30 (UP) Jose Nogues, army prosecutor, charged today that a military uprising suppressed here recently had been inspired from Argentina and closely synchronized with similar military movements in other LatinAmerican countries.
MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif., Nov. 30 -- Mme. Chiang Kai-shek arrived in the United States today to plead for all-out aid to China.
ST. LOUIS, Nov. 30 -- The American Medical Association prepared today to draw its lines for another skirmish with the Administration over Federal proposals for compulsory health insurance.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -- A Federal investigation into the activities of Menachem Begin, former head of the Irgun Zvai Leumi, was sought today by the Executive Committee of the Washington chapter of the American Council for Judaism.
ALBANY, Nov. 30 -- Milo R. Maltbie, whose retirement as chairman of the Public Service Commission was announced last summer to be imminent, is expected to continue indefinitely in that position.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -George C. Marshall, Secretary of State, is in Walter Reed Hospital undergoing "further tests and examinations," it was announced at the State Department today.

Eugene Ormandy and the Philadelphia Orchestra extended their list of Virgil Thomson premieres last night at Carnegie Hall when they gave the first New York performance of "Louisiana Story," a fifteen-minute orchestral suite that the composer has arranged from his music for Robert Flaherty's documentary film.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -- Repeal of some state labor laws, which "are worse than the TaftHartley (law)," was advocated today by Secretary of Labor Maurice J. Tobin.

EAST SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Nov. 30 -- More than a dozen heavylifting hand operations have been eliminated by mechanical, automatic and push-button devices in a $1,250,000 mechanization program in the foundry of the Westinghouse Electric Corporation, Frank Elliot, superintendent, disclosed here today.

PARIS, Nov. 30 (AP) -- Following is the text of the proposal of Dr. Juan Atilio Bramuglia, Argentine Foreign Minister and President of the United Nations Security Council, for continued neutral mediation of the Berlin dispute:

None of the seven Japanese war leaders sentenced to death as a result of the Tokyo trials will be executed until the Supreme Court of the United States has had time to pass on the appeal now before it. In a very real sense, therefore, these citizen of an Oriental imperialism now come under the protection of the United States Constitution.

PARIS, Nov. 30 -- A proposal that the international authority to be created to divide the Ruhr exports should exert the same powers over the exports of coal and steel of all Western Europe was made today by Andre Philip, Socialist and former Finance Minister, in a debate on the Ruhr in the National Assembly.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today that the Mississippi Power and Light Company, Jackson, Miss., had filed a registration statement with it covering $7,500,000 of first mortgage bonds, due 1949, that are to be offered at competitive bidding.

Visiting buyers registered in the market for the week ended yesterday totaled 1,146, against 1,059 last week and 1,091 in the similar week of 1947, according to lists published in THE NEW YORK TIMES. There were 788 arrivals yesterday compared with 307 last Tuesday.

Net income of the Southwestern Public Service Company for the fiscal year ended Aug. 31 amounted to $3,615,682, equal to $2.63 on each of the 1,237,346 common shares outstanding, compared with $2,616,452 or $2.31 a share on the 1,134,242 shares outstanding in the preceding twelve months.
Even Buddy O'Connor couldn't help the Rangers in their National Hockey League game with the Chicago Black Hawks at Madison Square Garden last night.

Judge Thomas D. Thacher has resigned because of ill health from the heavy duties of Judge of the Court of Appeals. Before mounting the bench of the highest court of the state, Judge Thacher was a leader of the bar of this city. His experience, knowledge of the law and strength of character provided a combination of judicial capacity and stature such as we have grown to expect of that Court.

CINCINNATI, Nov. 30 -- The mushroom growth of emergency housing developments and the contemplated construction within the next decade of 10,000,000 new homes constitute one of the greatest challenges ever to confront the Protestant churches of America.

Today Bloomingdale's starts off the great month for Christmas shopping by opening its new epicure shop. "New" is not quite the right word. The former delicacy department has moved from its corner near Third Avenue to the south side of the building; it has its own entrance on Fifty-ninth Street just east of Lexington Avenue.

PARIS, Nov. 30 -- In his jeunes filles department Jacques Heim presents a summer collection for teen-agers. Probably the youngest buyer ever to come to Paris, 15-year-old Miss Shirley Cain, flew over for this showing to choose what she thinks her set would like to wear.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -- Some American corporations have refused, because of the "timidity" of their lawyers, to appear before the forthcoming price and profits investigation of a Congressional subcommittee, its chairman, Senator Ralph E. Flanders, said today.
TOKYO, Nov. 30 -- The steering committee of the Japanese Diet's lower house decided today to permit the arrest of Dr. Hitoshi Ashida, former Premier and leader of Japan's Democratic party.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -- President Truman put his stamp of approval today on a proposal that the Eighty-first Congress undertake a thorough investigation of lobbying.

Sales for the purpose of recording tax losses yesterday again dropped the stock market back closer to the year's low mark. Some resistance to the decline was exhibited by the steels and a few individual issues reacted to favorable corporate developments, while the air transports drew considerable support.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Nov. 30 -Propriety of attempts by Iron Curtain countries to participate by remote control in the work of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization became a live issue tonight as the nominations committee elected an Italian to succeed a Czechoslovak on the UNESCO educative board.

The letter of George C. O. Haas, Director of Fellowship of Faiths in THE TIMES of NOV. 20 reveals a common misconception about the National Conference of Christians and Jews. Mr. Haas speaks of the conference as an "interfaith" organization. It is not.

Marie Hays Heiner, president of the Cleveland Hearing and Speech Center, has written in "Hearing Is Believing" an account of her life in terms of her battle against deafness. Mrs. Heiner, who lost her hearing at the age of 18, has worked with countless children and grownups to help overcome their handicap.
HOUSTON, Nov. 30 -- Continuation of interstate cooperation against threatened Federal controls was urged here today as the National Association of Attorneys General ended its annual convention.

Younger members of society serving with Miss Janne Martineau on the junior committee for the supper dance in behalf of undernourished French children to be held on Friday night at the home of Mrs. Aubrey Cartwright, 820 Fifth Avenue, met yesterday at Miss Martineau's home at the Pierre to complete plans for the benefit.

Teamwork among Government, management, labor and the public, and among the nations, will be the theme of the fifty-third annual Congress of American Industry, opening here today under the auspices of the National Association of Manufacturers.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -- The Army today cut back its draft call for January from 20,000 to 10,000 men and announced a February request for only 5,000 men. A draft call for February had not been announced, but an extension of the month - to - month draft pattern would have meant a probable call of 30,000 men.

The three-story building and one-story taxpayer, together with seven garages, at 52-22 Roosevelt Avenue, Woodside, Queens, have been sold by Mrs. Johanna Notine to James P. and Thomas L. Duffy. The property, assessed at $26,000, occupies a plot 40 by 111 feet.

Cotton futures trading on the New York Cotton Exchange became more active yesterday, and closing prices were 6 to 33 points higher, with old-crop months moving into new high ground for the current move.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -- Mme.Chiang is expected at the National Airport tomorrow morning.

BERLIN, Nov. 30 -- It was a dreary atmosphere in which to commit an act of history, one university student commented as he watched thousands of his countrymen file into Bebelplatz once known as Kaiser Wilhelm Platz to mark the establishment of a Communistled administration in Berlin.

Because of lack of funds, many schools in the New York Public school system are not complying with the Health Department's sanitary code in the matter of washing facilities for pupils, it was charged yesterday at a Board of Education budget hearing.

PARIS, Nov. 30 -- Sir Stafford Cripps, British Chancellor of the Exchequer, is expected to visit Paris in the near future to discuss with Premier Henri Queuille and French experts a crucial problem now facing Marshall Plan countries.

Buyer attendance continued heavy yesterday at the Popular Price Shoe Show of America at the Commodore Hotel. Officials of the sponsoring organizations -- the National Association of Shoe Chain Stores and the New England Shoe and Leather Association -- revised upward their figure of attending store representatives to 4,000 for the four-day period of the show.
BRUSSELS, Belgium, Nov. 30 -Premier Paul-Henri Spaak announced in the Chamber of Deputies today the program of Belgium's new Government.

To the chant of "We want milk!" 150 mothers, fathers and their children paraded for several blocks through East Harlem yesterday demanding that milk prices be reduced. The parade was staged as part of the campaign by the East Harlem District Health Committee of the Health Council of Greater New York, 158 East 115th Street, to "dramatize" the high cost of milk and its effects on low-income families.

VIENNA, Nov. 30 -- The Economic Cooperation Administration announced today its first major investment in re-equipping Austria to make her own living by the end of the European Recovery Program in 1952.

The last chapter varies in length. There are years when autumn posts the ledger early and December brings staying ice and snow. There are seasons when the chapter is a long one and brown fields and woodlands wait until man's calendar is well advanced before winter locks the land.

EASTBOURNE, England, Nov. 30 (AP) -- Lee Savold, the veteran Paterson, N.J., heavyweight, fairly danced through a workout today in the presence of British boxing writers. The blond American, who meets Bruce Woodcock, British Empire champion, in London Dec. 6, impressed the scribes with his skill.

Many Christians promote Zionism in the mistaken belief that it will act as a guarantee against future persecutions of the Jews, Dr. Richard Niebuhr, Professor of Christian Ethics at Yale University, declared here yesterday. He spoke at a luncheon of the American Council for Judaism at the George Washington Hotel.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -- Former President Herbert Hoover, chairman of a commission considering organization of the executive branch of Government, said today that President Truman had approved a proposal to tie into "one housekeeping unit" a substantial number of agencies that now operate separately.

To set at rest rumors of drastic reductions in personnel "through retirement and otherwise" on the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad, Laurence F. Whittemore, president of the line, said yesterday that these apparently were inspired by an overhauling of departments now in progress.

LONDON, Nov. 30 -- A detailed "master plan" for the joint defense of the five Western Union Countries, including a survey of their present military strength and a description of aid they hope to receive from the United States has now reached its final stage here.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -- A simulated air speed more than five times the speed of sound, or about 3,960 miles an hour, was achieved by the Navy with improved German wind-tunnels last week, it was announced today.

A loan exhibition of paintings by Gustave Courbet, held for the joint benefit of American Aid to France and the Goddard Neighborhood Center, will open at the Wildenstein Galleries with a preview this evening, under the patronage of Henri Bonnet, the French Ambassador to this country, and Mme. Bonnet.

By order of the Civil Aeronautics Board, airlines flying heavy fourengined planes must carry a flight engineer in addition to two pilots, beginning today. The one exception is American Airlines, whose DC-6 planes have not yet been wholly adapted to the three-man crew.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -- Economic Cooperation Administrator Paul G. Hoffman may ask substantially more from Congress than the $4,500,000,000 projected for the European Recovery Program next year as a result of scheduled conferences in London early next month with American mission heads and representatives of participating countries.

Prospective travelers who have been unable to purchase railroad tickets, particularly for Florida, without paying premiums were urged yesterday to get in touch with the Bureau of Inquiry at the local office of the Interstate Commerce Commission in 90 Church Street.

Dr. Maurice J. Lewi, president of Long Island University's College of Podiatry, president of the Foot Clinics of New York and among the first to undertake to put foot care on a scientific basis, will be 91 years old today. Tonight at Tony's Restaurant, 212 West Seventyninth Street, 100 of his friends and co-workers will hold a dinner in his honor, with Dr. Tristram Walker Metcalfe, president of L.I.U., as principal speaker.

Indonesian tin production this year is estimated at 35,000 tons and exceeds pre-war output by 10,000, according to Netherlands East Indies trade officials. By 1950 production can reach 50,000 tons, it was indicated, provided restrictions are not placed on mining operations.

LONDON, Nov. 30 -- The cold, clammy fog that has lasted longer than any on record in London and produced one of the worst transportation tie-ups in British history was responsible tonight for a train crash that killed four persons, seriously injured twenty-one and caused minor injuries to many others.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -- A year's experience with the national emergency section of the TaftHartley Act probably assures a continuance of these strike curbs in some form, including the injunction, Government labor experts asserted today.

PARIS, Nov. 30 -- The General, or steering, Committee of the United Nations General Assembly meet Thursday afternoon to discuss the question whether it will be possible to avoid a special session next year if the Assembly stays in session a few extra days.
BERLIN, Nov. 30 -- The Communist party, its political dependents and its Russian masters completed today the division of Berlin by installing a city government in the Soviet sector of the city.

Directors of the Standard Oil Company of California, at a meeting held in San Francisco yesterday, declared a dividend of one share of stock for each twenty shares held, equivalent to a 5 per cent distribution. The dividend will be distributed on Jan. 28, to holders of record of Dec. 10.

A high level of prosperity in this country for the next year or two was forecast yesterday by Alfred P. Sloan Jr., chairman of the General Motors Corporation and chairman emeritus of the National Highway Users Conference. However, he added, a long-range decline in industrial expansion may be expected.

Doak Walker, Southern Methodist's stellar quarterback, has been named as the winner of the Heisman Memorial Trophy, an award annually given by the Downtown A.C. The presentation will be made at the clubhouse Tuesday evening, according to Willard B. Prince, chairman of the trophy committee.

I read in THE TIMES of Nov. 18 about Merchant Marine officers asking exemption from the draft. Their demand certainly is justified, but I think it highly undemocratic and contrary to all our principles and hopes to make a very insidious distinction between "officers" and men in the Merchant Marine veterans.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -- The Soviet Union is "doing a damn good job" in a campaign to disarm the United States economically, Senator Ralph E. Flanders, Republican, of Vermont, asserted today. Moreover, he contended, in sharpening an earlier declaration to the same effect, this country was "losing the cold war" in the economic sense.

The letter by Charles K. Imbrie, published in THE TIMES on Nov. 26, advocates that we let China work out her own difficulties because "any evil system carries in itself the seeds of its own destruction" and because "it will keep us busy for many years to fight communism in the West."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 (AP) -Secretary of Agriculture Charles F. Brannan today set the 1949 national marketing quota for burley type tobacco at 545,000,000 pounds. This quota will permit growers to plant about the same acreage as they were allotted for this year's crop.

CLINTON, Ill., Nov. 30 -- The National Labor Relations Board today ordered the Goodyear Rubber Footwear Corporation -- a concern with headquarters in Providence, R.I., that has no connection with the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company -- to return jobs and back wages of employes laid off two years ago when the company temporarily suspended operations of its new plant here.

SAIDU SHARIF, Swat State, Pakistan, Nov. 27 -- Until a few years ago, there was no more turbulent spot in Asia than the stark, snow-capped mountain and lush valley of Swat. It was a place of plunder and pilgrimage for thousands of years, where the Buddha left his mark and Alexander marched.

ROME, Nov. 30 -- The left-wing parties' winter offensive against Italy's Christian Democratic Government got under way today with a debate on foreign policy in the Chamber of Deputies. The debate was opened by former Foreign Minister Pietro Nenni, chairman of the Left-Wing Socialists' parliamentary group, who emphasized Italy's failure to regain her former colonies and argued that Foreign Minister Carlo Sforza's policies had left Italy completely empty-handed.

BERKELEY, Calif., Nov. 30 -Discovery near Johannesburg of fossil remains of a new type of ape man which might have been larger than the nine-foot-tall primitive Java man found several years ago was reported today by the University of California.
Mrs. Dom J. Burg of 289 East 161st Street is a "lady of leisure" who, having no children of her own, was honored yesterday as the No. 1 "substitute mother" at Bellevue Hospital.

From various sources The Associated Press learned yesterday that both the All-America Conference and the National Football League have held secret draft meetings in hopes of outsmarting each other in the race for the top players of 1948.

With Fresno having filed a bid and other Pacific Coast cities interested in the meet, there are strong indications that the National A.A.U. track and field championships next summer will be staged in California. If the Pacific Coast gets the title meet it will mark the first time since 1940 that the games will be held there.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -- The Civil Aeronautics Board has put over until next year hearings regarding possible transfer of the routes of National Airlines, Inc., to other companies, the first such case of its kind, it was learned today.

The American Jewish Congress will test the constitutionality of the New York State Sunday Laws as they are applied to Orthodox Jewish merchants who close shop on Saturdays but wish to conduct business on Sunday, it was announced yesterday by Leo Pfeffer of the organization's commission on law and social action.

" The Secret Land," the Technicolor feature-length documentary dealing with Rear Admiral Richard E. Byrd's Antarctic expedition, which is being released by MetroGoldwyn-Mayer, will open engagements today at Loew's first-run neighborhood theatres in Manhattan, the Bronx and Queens.

CHICAGO, Nov. 30 -- Grain markets fluctuated nervously today on the Board of Trade, but the undertone was heavy generally. Corn closed about the bottom with losses of 5/8 to 1 7/8 cents a bushel, December showing the most strength despite tenders of 1,011,000 bushels cash corn on contracts.
TEL AVIV, Israel, Nov. 30 -Israeli Communists have lost their opening gambit to move their tiny organization in on the powerful United Workers party [Mapam].

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -- The Reconstruction Finance Corporation, disclosed today that it had no loan application of the Tucker Corporation, Chicago automobile manufacturer, under consideration at the present time.

Mrs. Helen Hay Whitney, who was the First Lady of the American turf and widow of Payne Whitney, financier, left a net estate of $6,128,304 when she died in 1944, an estate tax appraisal filed yesterday with the state showed. The state tax on the estate was estimated at $643,000.
The failure of police measures to improve the appearance of the littered streets and garbage-strewn lots of East Harlem and some other slum areas was admitted yesterday by city officials.

ROME, Nov. 30 -- A New York came into being today when a boys' town of that name was established near Palermo, Sicily. It was made possible by $70,000 contributed by members of the men's clothing industry of New York, including employers and members of the Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America, and by other organizations through the Relief for War Orphans of Italy Committee.

With many ship operators employing extra longshoremen to work the large backlog of freight released by settlement of the eighteen-day dock workers' strike, the Port of New York experienced one of the busiest days of the year yesterday.

The Welch Grape Juice Compassed the $1,000,000 mark inpany, which is %now having its earnings for the first time in itseightieth anniversary, reported a long history, but that more signifinew high in sales and earnings for cantly, the program initiatedits fiscal year ended on Aug. 31. three years lgo is lrepcly demonaccording to the annual report of st. rating its potentialities," theg. 1VL Kaplan, president, issued report says.yesterday.
The enlarged and remodeled Garden City branch of Oppenheim Collins Co. was officially reopened yesterday with a series of festivities arranged by Philip N. Cohan, the store's president.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -- Allegations that residents of the Baltic States coming into the United States under the Displaced Persons Act aided the Nazis, were disputed today in a resolution adopted by the National Catholic Resettlement Council.

LONDON, Nov. 30 (AP) -- The International Amateur Athletic Federation announced today that it had recognized ten new world records in track and field, including Herb McKenley's 45.9 seconds for the 400 meters.

Columbus took seventy-one days to reach the New World from Spain. Of these only thirty-six were spent between his last familiar port in the Canaries and the new land which he found. The Mayflower required sixtysix days before its crew sighted the sand bars of Cape Cod.

NEW ORLEANS, La., Nov. 30 -New Orleans' International Trade Mart, a $1,500,000 civic non-profit venture in international trade and relations, was dedicated formally today in colorful ceremonies attended by foreign diplomats and business and political representatives from cities throughout the country.

Using a strong left hand to advantage, Georgie Small, 162, Brooklyn, won a unanimous decision over Richie Dallas, 162 1/2, St. Louis, in the feature clash of eight rounds before 3,500 fans at the Broadway Arena, Brooklyn, last night. Small was the aggressor throughout.
LOS ANGELES, Nov. 30 (UP) -Attorney Neil S. McCarthy tonight announced he had sold the great Australian race horse, Shannon II, to a syndicate headed by Leslie Combs of Kentucky for $300,000.

Louis Toth, former City Rent Commission member, said yesterday that his accounting firm never had been retained by the Park Crescent Hotel, some of whose tenants have filed a court action to void a rent increase authorized by the commission before Mr. Toth's resignation last week.

Now that waistlines have returned to pre-Thanksgiving dimensions and the turkey has long since traveled the route from cold cuts to hash to soup, it is time to stop thinking nebulously about our next holiday and to begin taking specific action in preparation for its arrival.

LOWELL, Mass., Dec. 1 -- The need for training persons who wish to enter the textile industry was stressed here today by Robert L. Huffines Jr., president of the Burlington Mills Corporation, New York, in a talk at the Lowell Textile Institute.

"The Belle of New York," a two-act musical comedy favorite of the Nineties, was revived here last night for the first time since its premiere in 1897, by the Columbia Theatre Associates in the Brander Matthews Theatre at Columbia University.

Madame Chiang Kai-shek has come to America on a United States Navy plane to present to the American Government and people the needs of the Chinese Government for extensive financial and military aid. Madame Chiang is very persuasive and will doubtless have a marked influence on American opinion and Congressional attitude on this difficult but important problem of American policy.

Henry R. Luce, editor-in-chief of Time, Life and Fortune magazines, and Charles D. Maginnis, Boston architect, were honored for their services to art last night by the Artists Fellowship, Inc., at its annual dinner in the Salmagundi Club, 47 Fifth Avenue.

One hundred and ten insignia will be presented at the annual Award Dinner of the Varsity C Club in John Jay Hall on the campus at 6:30 tonight as Columbia honors her varsity athletes of the past year.

Operation of the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad in New York State is resulting in a $60,000 monthly loss, Edward R. Bromley, general counsel, said yesterday, after the Public Service Commission granted his request to defer the hearing to Jan. 4, 1949.

The municipal transit system yielded revenue of $575,088 in excess of operating expenses during the first two months of the fiscal year that began on July 1, the Board of Transportation announced yesterday. For the same two months in 1947, operating at a five-cent fare, the system showed an operating deficit of $5,779,846.

Top executives from America's largest industries crowded the Eighteenth National Power Show at Grand Central Palace yesterday afternoon, attracted by a series of reports of large equipment contracts pending or closed in both domestic and foreign markets.

The most poetical and aristocratic of modern Italian operas, Italo Montemezzi's "L'Amore dei Tre Re," was revived last night in the Metropolitan Opera House, when the composer was present. The opera stands by itself in the repertory.

An intersectional program inaugurates the fifteenth straight year of college basketball at Madison Square Garden tonight, with St. John's University facing Tennessee in the opener at 8 o'clock and New York University opposing the Baylor Bears, Southwest Conference champions, in the nightcap.
Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores showed a drop of 4.5 per cent in November, compared with the same month last year, according to the survey made yesterday by THE NEW YORK TIMES.
CHICAGO, Dec. 1 (AP) -- Preston Tucker today told men who hope to sell Tucker automobiles that "the door for a substantial Government loan is still open."

The Yankees and the New York Chapter of the Baseball Writers Association of America will erect a memorial to Babe Ruth at the Yankee Stadium next year, it was announced jointly yesterday by the Bombers and the local scribes.

Wiretapping should be used only to protect the national security or in cases of the most atrocious type of crimes, kidnapping and murder, Robert P. Patterson, former Secretary of War, declared yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 (AP) -- Five major changes in State Department organization have been recommended to the Hoover Commission which is studying the setup of the executive branch of the Government, officials reported today.

PARIS, Dec. 1 -- The Political Committee of the United Nations General Assembly tonight beat down a series of Australian amendments intended to establish the partition resolution of a year ago as the basis for a permanent settlement of the Palestine question.

A book dealing with the "other," pro-Communist, side of the Polish question will be brought out in February by Greenberg, entitled "Poland Struggles Back." William Cary, the author, went to Poland as an American relief aide and it is his story of how the now-in-power Polish People's party is reconstructing the country along proletarian lines. The book is illustrated with photographs taken by Mr. Cary.

A panel discussion of the effect of television on horse racing proved the highlight of the seventh annual meeting of the Thoroughbred Racing Associations of America at the Hotel Plaza yesterday. With executives from thirty of the thirty-three member tracks of the organization in attendance, the discussion, while thoroughly informal, evoked the opinion that the great majority of those concerned were in favor of video coverage of turf activities, in moderation.
Cottonseed oil futures on the New York Produce Exchange rallied sharply yesterday.

The fast-nearing Christmas season began manifesting itself in earnest around Rockefeller Center yesterday with the setting up of a ninety-foot Christmas tree on Rockefeller Plaza and the opening of the annual Toy Show at the New York Museum of Science and Industry in the RCA Building.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 (UP) -- The National Labor Relations Board will have to decide for itself whether peaceful picketing by large numbers of strikers is legal, after getting conflicting views from two of its trial examiners.

The economic uptrend which has existed during recent years has definitely reversed itself, Howard T. Lewis, Professor of Marketing, Harvard University, told members of the Manufacturers Surgical Trade Association yesterday at its semi-annual meeting in the Commodore Hotel.

The Tishman Realty Construction Company marked its fiftieth anniversary with a new high record in earnings for the fiscal year ended with September, the annual report to stockholders showed yesterday.

Military equipment must be given generously to Western Europe to give meaning to the Brussels Treaty, James Forrestal, Secretary of Defense, said last night at the annual dinner of the English Speaking Union in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- The Fifteenth National Conference on Labor Legislation unanimously favored today repeal of the Taft Hartley Act, but a split among those conferees representing labor led to rejection of a proposal that the Government exercise "its power in the field of labor legislation by restoring the Wagner act as the law of the land."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- Public expressions of alarm about Federal Trade Commission decisions on pricing practices are "not solidly based upon the commission's activities but only weakly based upon incidental words used in describing those activities," Corwin D. Edwards, director of the FTC's Bureau of Industrial Economics, said today.

VANCOUVER, B. C., Dec. 1 -- Sale of the department store and mail order business of David Spencer, Ltd., pioneer British Columbia mercantile organization, to the T. Eaton Company, Ltd., was announced tonight.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Dec. 1 -- As a meeting of Palestine Arab leaders at Jericho acclaimed King Abdullah of Trans-Jordan as "King of all Palestine," three days of disorder in Damascus over the Palestine situation reached a climax today.

Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, president of Columbia University, has contributed a favorite recipe of his for vegetable soup to the new edition of "What's Cooking at Columbia" published yesterday. First issued in 1942, the book contains the favorite recipes of more than 200 Columbia faculty members.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, Dec. 1 -- Far behind schedule and working "against the calendar," German legislators of the Economic Council tonight adopted the first of measures designed to equalize burdens Created by the war and by the dislocation of economies.

Arrangements have been completed for the Fordham football team to meet Yale University at the Yale Bowl, Oct. 1, 1949, Jack Coffey, graduate athletic manager of Fordham, announced yesterday. The contest will mark the first gridiron encounter between the two schools.

Motorists' laments that the post-war cars are so oversized that they will not fit into the pre-war garages and parking spaces were brushed aside yesterday by the Automobile Manufacturers Association as figments of the imagination. Specifications were offered to prove that skillful designers had achieved the "new look" and provided more interior space by adding only an inch or two here and there to over-all dimensions.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- The creation of the Soviet-backed government in Eastern Berlin, it was said authoritatively at the State Department today, makes a solution of the Berlin crisis much more difficult or might make it impossible.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Dec. 1 -- Sir Sarvepalli Radhakrishnan of India was tonight elected chairman of the executive board of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization to succeed E. Ronald Walker of Australia.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- Senator Joseph C. O'Mahoney, Democrat, of Wyoming, predicted today after a conference with President Truman that the O'Mahoney-Kefauver bill plugging up loopholes in the Clayton Anti-Trust Law would be passed in the coming session of Congress.
Although they expressed conflicting views on the future of the State of Israel, four speakers agreed last night that British policy in the Middle East had impeded democratic progress.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture today resumed purchase of all grains for export to cash-paying governments outside the Western Hemisphere and the Philippines.
PEIPING, Thursday, Dec. 2 (AP) -- Chinese Nationalists today were reported battling the vanguard of 50,000 Communist troops moving into the province directly above Peiping and Tientsin.
Gen. Douglas MacArthur's "leapfrog" bases up the north coast of New Guinea have become stepping-stones into one of the world's deepest wildernesses.

ASUNCION, Paraguay, Dec. 1 -- After having helped save his own regime by quick action on Oct. 25, President Juan Natalicio Gonzalez is now attempting to placate and control all factions of the Army and to achieve a united front in his own Colorado party.
Ceremonies marking Freedom From Fear Day were held at noon yesterday on the steps of Brooklyn's Borough Hall.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 (AP) -- Installment credit increased $30,000,000 in October to a new record high of $7,748,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported tonight. The increase, however, was the smallest one for any month since the war.

A pleasant collection of simle handmade accessories of the type hat is becoming increasingly popular for contemporary interiors is on hand for holiday buying at the Lighthouse Craftshop operated by the New York Association for the Blind at 111 East Fifty-ninth Street.

THE TIMES reports that at the closing session of the forty-first annual convention of the National Association of Real Estate Boards "uncompromising resolutions" were adopted "favoring prompt liquidation of all Federal housing and elimination of residential rent controls." The president-elect of the association, it is reported, "then promised the convention that 'we are going to fight as never before' for the accepted policies." This is a disturbing footnote to the recent national election.

Forty-four years of street-car service across the Williamsburg Bridge will end on Sunday at 5 A. M. when twenty-seven buses begin to operate, Mayor O'Dwyer announced yesterday. The trolley service began on Nov. 9, 1904, according to the Board of Transportation, which will operate the new facilities.

WASHINGTON, Dec 1 (AP) -- Loans by the nation's commercial banks declined during October for the first time in six months, according to the Federal Reserve board. The decline, coming in a season when loans usually rise, amounted to $100,000,000 -- exactly ten times as much as the last decrease in April.

LONDON, Dec. 1 -- The British Government's proposal to extend the period of military conscription from twelve to eighteen months won Parliamentary approval tonight after a debate in which the Conservative Opposition joined with the Government to defeat a leftwing Labor motion to reject the bill.

Many great public problems remain unresolved today, at least in part, because the public does not understand the issues involved or their implications, former Gov. Herbert H. Lehman declared last night.

Three new one-man shows, which widely vary in manner, are on view in the galleries this week. They include gouaches by Joseph Kaplan, recently announced winner of a prize at the Audubon annual, and debuts in oils and gouaches by Keith Shaw Williams and Celia Hubbard.

Goodman Ace's comedy show, entitled "mr. ace and JANE," will be finishing its run under the sponsorship of General Foods on Dec. 31 over the CBS network, it was disclosed yesterday. Although cordially greeted by the critics, its Hooper rating reportedly was not up to the sponsor's expectations. "My Favorite Husband" may be substituted, it was said.

The Appellate Division of the Supreme Court, First Department, unanimously rejected yesterday Tammany Hall's attempt to contest the election of George Frankenthaler as Surrogate of New York County. An appeal on a point of law was allowed.

CHICAGO, Dec. 1 -- Michael J. Quill, president of the Transport Workers Union, CIO, took time out from his anti-Communist campaign today to outline his plans for spending a few billion dollars of New York City's funds.
The cotton market continued to show strength yesterday and closing prices on the New York Cotton Exchange were 8 to 13 points net higher.

YONKERS, Dec. 1 -- The longstanding dispute over how to balance the Yonkers city budget resulted today in City Manager Thomas V. Kennedy's announcing his resignation. Mr. Kennedy said he would start at once the thirty-day vacation to which he was entitled and would formally quit his post on Jan. 1.

East Harlem revisited, in news story and photograph as published in yesterday's TIMES, reveals that sanitary conditions in vacant lots and tenement courtyards are about as bad now as they were ten weeks ago when our reporter, Charles Grutzner, visited the same area with a camera man.

CHICAGO, Dec. 1 (AP) -- Charles (Red) Ruffing, once the pride of the Yankee pitching staff, will make his debut as a baseball manager next season for Muskegon, Mich., in the Central League. Rufing's appointment to succeed Benny Huffman was announced today by Johnny Rigney, director of the White Sox farm system.

LONDON, Dec. 1 -- The tribunal inquiring into allegations of fraud in the Board of Trade began to reach its climax today when Sidney Stanley, the man around whom all the accusations revolve, went to the witness stand.

India's huge requirements of capital goods and food during the next three years will leave that country little capacity for purchase of consumer products, members of the Export Advertising Association, Inc., were told yesterday at the Shelton Hotel.

A vigorous protest against an "overdose of streamlining" in the design of many articles manufactured by American industry was registered yesterday at the sixty-ninth annual meeting of the American Society of Mechanical Engineers.

Preliminary work has been completed on a city laboratory that will attempt to reduce infant mortality through determination of the Rh factor in human blood, David M. Heyman, president of the Public Health Research Institute of the City of New York, announced yesterday in his annual report.

Matthew Woll, vice president of the American Federation of Labor, told the annual Congress of American Industry yesterday that the AFL did not intend to take advantage of the election returns to force restrictive legislation upon management.

BERLIN, Dec. 1 -- Communists, Social Democrats and policemen fought with fists and clubs against the gray surrealistic background of the battered borough of Neukolln this evening in the first open clash between Eastern and Western Berlin.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- The Interstate Commerce Commission continued today its hearing on a request of the railroads for an immediate 8 per cent emergency increase in freight rates.

A syndicate of investors headed by Paul Futterman and Mitchel Fein has purchased the six-story Jackson Hotel at 139 West Forty-fifth Street, between Broadway and the Avenue of the Americas, in the Times Square area, from the 137-39 West Forty-fifth Street Corporation.
Comment in your Topics of The Times column o Christmas Club Savings seems to need a little editing to bring the facts into clearer focus.
Ira Mosher, chairman of the finance committee of the National Association of Manufacturers, said yesterday that the election returns showed that government was in business to stay.

CHICAGO, Dec. 1 -- This city, second largest in the country, has no opera company of its own, but it had a gala opera opening totonight. Like the season's inaugural of the Metropolitan in New York two nights ago, leading citizens turned out in all their finery to make a big thing of the season.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Dec. 1 -- Two hundred new factories have been erected in Yugoslavia during the first two years of the current five-year plan to industrialize the country, according to information made public today. The size and the capacity of these factories were not made known, nor was the degree to which they are in operation.

Representative Ellsworth B. Buck appeared in Mid-Manhattan Magistrates Court yesterday morning as the complainant in a charge of simple assault against a 40-year-old operator of a wholesale carpet business, although he was not involved except as a spectator.

KALAMAZOO, Mich., Dec. 1 -- Several hundred strikers and sympathizers blocked streets here with their cars this morning while they conducted a thirty-minute reign of terror and destruction at the two plants of the Shakespeare Company, manufacturer of fishing tackle and auto parts.

"Savage Brigade," a French-made romantic drama, which arrives at the Apollo on West Forty-second Street, is this morning's lone film newcomer. Marcel L'Herbier directed the offering which features Charles Vanel, Vera Korene, Roger Duchesne and Lisette Lanvin. Dialogue of the Distinguished Films release is French and there are English titles.

SOFIA, Bulgaria, Dec. 1 -- Deputy Minister of Justice Angel Timer rebutted today charges made in the United States and Britain that the recent trial of Kosta Lulchev and eight other Bulgarian Socialists who were sentenced to from ten to fifteen years was a travesty of justice.

The retirement of Leonard M. Wallstein as president of the New York Guild for the Jewish Blind was announced last, night at a reception in his honor at the headquarters of the guild at 1880 Broadway. Mr. Wallstein, who has been associated with the guild since 1927 and has been its president for the last thirteen years, will continue as chairman of the board.
TOKYO, Thursday, Dec. 2 -- Former Premier Hitoshi Ashida cannot be arrested for alleged involvement in the Showa Denko bribery scandal until the Diet recesses about two weeks hence.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 1 (UP) -- Shannon II will not race against Citation in the $50,000 added Tanforan Handicap or anywhere else, Leslie Combs 2d, head of a syndicate that purchased the West's greatest handicap star, reiterated tonight.
LONDON, Dec. 1 -- Firmer conditions were seen in the stock market here today as the new account opened.

Business concerns can save as much as half of their losses from "sick absenteeism and latent illness," Dr. John J. Wittmer, assistant vice president of the Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., said yesterday. He advocated pre-employment examinations at a conference at the Commerce and Industry Association of New York, Inc., 232 Broadway.
LAKE SUCCESS, Dec. 1 -- Representatives of twelve nations, who are laying the groundwork for a new United Nations agency in the maritime and shipping field, wound up a two-day session here today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 (AP) -- The Duke Power Company of Charlotte, N. C., has asked the Federal Power Commission for authority to issue $40,000,000 in 3 1/8 per cent first and refunding mortgage bonds due in 1978.
Bathing is a human right that takes precedence over property rights, Magistrate Frances W. Lehrich declared yesterday

A check for $500,000 and three packages of urgently requested drugs will be taken to. Israel today by Mrs. Rebecca Shulman of Stamford. Conn., who will serve four months in Jerusalem as liaison between American and Israeli members of Hadassah, the Women's Zionist Organization of America.

AUSTIN, Tex., Dec. 1 (AP) -- Operators in fifteen oil fields today apparently had won the first round in their legal battle to prevent the State Railroad Commission from enforcing shutdown orders for those fields.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 (AP) -- The Government asked farmers today to produce more of some foods, including milk. It forecast "continued high consumer demands," a standard barometer of prosperity.

Efforts of the Johnstown (Pa.) Alumni Association of Phi Kappa Psi to amend the fraternity's constitution to exclude from membership not only Negroes but "adherents of all Semitic creeds" were revealed yesterday in a resolution addressed to the fraternity's executive council.

MOSCOW, Dec. 1 (AP) -- The Literary Gazette charged today that United States military authorities in Germany were sending to the United States some Russian children sought by their parents in the Soviet Union.
MOSCOW, Dec. 1 (AP) -- Pravda announced today that the Council of Ministers of the Soviet Union had adopted a new special five-year plan for the Moscow coal basin.

An alliance between sports and entertainment promotion interests for the extensive development of sports attractions as a television medium was formally announced yesterday by the Tournament of Champions, Inc., which has heretofore confined its activities to three boxing promotions in New Jersey.

With iron will, Soviet Russia clings to the right of a single-Power veto in the Security Council of the United Nations. Any and all attempts to limit or shade that right are met with furious denunciation. Without the veto, Mr. Vishinsky told the Assembly's Political Committee on Tuesday, the United Nations would not survive "one day." The plain implication is that Soviet Russia would break it wide open.

May I ask for the correction of a misstatement that appeared in your columns? Orville Prescott, in reviewing my life of Rupert Brooke, announced that I was the author of that movie masterpiece known as "The Perils of Pauline," the obvious implication being that an author so immersed in sensationalism would be ill-equipped to understand a poetic genius or interpret him to the world.

District Attorney Frank S. Hogan received carte blanche yesterday to scrutinize any and all matrimonial records in the New York County Clerk's office during his investigation into fraudulent divorce actions.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 (AP) -Marriner S. Eccles, a member of the Federal Reserve Board, will not take part in the board's decision on the anti-trust case that it has brought against the Transamerica Corporation.

Fifty inmates of Walkill Prison, after working 362 days, have built a Catholic chapel in an attic space, it was announced yesterday here by the Rev. George F. McKinney, Catholic chaplain of the prison. The chapel will be dedicated Tuesday by Auxiliary Bishop Stephen J. Donahue of New York.
Bellevue and six other municipal hospitals reinstated yesterday the pre-war practice of sending doctors, instead of first-aid attendants, on all emergency ambulance calls.

Maxon, Inc., national advertising agency, has purchased the five-story building at 12 East Fifty-third Street from the City Investing Company, of which Robert W. Dowling is president. L. J. Phillips Co. were the brokers.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- Mme. Chiang Kai-shek, obviously fatigued by her long airplane journey from Nanking, arrived in Washington today and went at once to the Leesburg, Va., home of Secretary of State George C. Marshall. She did not make any comment on her plans to obtain more American help for China.

Paul G. Hoffman, head of the Economic Cooperation Administration, declared yesterday that the Marshall Plan was working and would succeed in preventing World War III if the United States and other free nations would stick together.

The New York Central Railroad announced yesterday a drastic curtailment of suburban schedules on its Harlem, Hudson and Putnam divisions, effective Sunday. The railroad said the reduction was because of a sharp decline in commuter travel.
There was a note of optimism in yesterday's reports from the football Dodgers concerning their final game of the season next Sunday at Ebbets Field with the Cleveland Browns.

AMBOISE, France, Dec. 1 -- It is no secret, either to the Spanish Government or to the Spanish people, that the principal interest of the United States and the Western powers in Spain is strategic and that this interest has grown as the Russian crisis has increased.

Plans are now being made for the National Sportsmen's Show, which will open in mid-February at the Grand Central Palace, and this year the show management has offered assurances that the show will be designed entirely for "sportsmen" and will not take on the aspect of a carnival midway which it has assumed in recent years.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows, the Federal Reserve Board announced today, the following principal changes for the week ended Nov. 24:

The recent policy rift in the ranks of the United Palestine Appeal, one of the beneficiaries of the mammoth fund-raising drives of the United Jewish Appeal, has cost Israel and Jews throughout the world "precious time" in facilitating and accelerating immigration and resettlement in the new state, Dr. Israel Goldstein treasurer of the Jewish Agency for Palestine, declared yesterday.

A world-wide campaign to combat illiteracy was urged yesterday by Dr. Jaime Torres Bodet, newly elected Director General of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization, before leaving to attend the current UNESCO meeting in Beirut, Lebanon.

The American Cable and Radio Corporation had a net consolidated loss of $1,628,286 for the first nine months of this year, it was reported yesterday. In the preceding comparable period the company and its subsidiaries suffered a net loss of $1,835,751.

Rear Admiral Lord Ashbourne, D. S. O., R. N., "declared open" yesterday the twenty-eight annual bazaar of the Daughters of the British Empire in the State of New York, in the ballroom of the Biltmore Hotel.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 1 -- The Congress of Industrial Organizations was called on today by West Coast longshoremen to promote the merger of all CIO and independent maritime unions into one big industrial union.

BOGOTA, Colombia, Dec. 1 (UP) -- Tiempo, Colombia's leading newspaper, urged all American democratic countries today to heed the warning implied in the charge of the Chilean Army prosecutor that the recent military coups in Latin America were part of a concerted plan inspired from Argentina.

PARIS, Dec. 1 -- A convention outlawing the crime of genocide and providing specific processes for bringing violators to justice was completed here this afternoon by the Legal Committee of the General Assembly after two years' work by various United Nations bodies.

After disclosing the discouraging information yesterday that "no snow was in sight in the North Country," 65-year-old Benjamin (Ben) Parry, the veteran Weather Bureau meteorologist winked and said to this correspondent, "But there should be plenty of snow and good skiin' by the time I retire to my Fairhaven, Vt., home the beginning of next month."

Claude Deharo, 15 years old, after being detained almost three weeks at Ellis Island when no relatives met his plane from Casablanca, was on his way yesterday to the home of his stepfather's sister in Rainier, Ore.

Cotton ginghams have been sold through March, it was learned yesterday in Worth Street. These goods have been in strong demand by dress manufacturers for spring lines, it was pointed out, and have held a relatively firm price level compared to other types of cottons.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 (AP) -- The Treasury announced today it had decided to re-establish the Seventeenth Coast Guard District in Alaska with headquarters at Juneau.

Although sales of R. H. Macy Co., Inc., and its subsidiaries for the thirteen weeks ended on Oct. 30 were substantially larger than those of the similar period of last year, earnings were somewhat lower, according to the quarterly unaudited report issued for publication today. Sales and earnings for fifty-two weeks, however, were higher than the previous year's totals.

Many recitals seem to drag on forever, but there are a rare few that end too soon. Nathan Milstein's annual violin recital at Carnegie Hall last night was certainly one of the latter. The word must come out He played wonderfully.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 1 -- The followers of Father Divine, Negro cult leader, today bought the 246-room Lorraine Hotel, long a landmark here at Broad Street and Fairmount Avenue, from the Metropolitan Hotel Real Estate Company for $485,000.

President Truman carried this city by a plurality of 488,329 over Governor Dewey out of a total of 3,215,940 votes cast in the Nov. 2 election, the Board of Elections announced yesterday after completing its official canvass.

I regret to see by the newspapers that the conference proposed by President Truman to consider the labor act repeal does not include someone to represent the large majority of workers who are not members of some organized labor union. Any so-called two-sided agreement reached between labor unions and management certainly will be discriminatory against a large majority of workers.

The nation's gasoline stocks rose 2,558,000 barrels last week to 93,802,000 on Nov. 27, according to the weekly report of the American Petroleum Institute. A year ago gasoline supplies were 86,319,000 barrels.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- Grade school teachers in twenty-seven states are receiving salaries of $500 per year or more below high school teachers on the average, the National Education Association reported today.

The Health Department's experimental campaign in Staten Island for the elimination of rabies has been received apathetically by dog owners in the second year of its operation, it was learned yesterday.
BERLIN, Dec. 1 -- The fog, which lifted for a while this morning, settled down over blockaded Berlin this afternoon and the airlift by which the Western half of the city lives, was halted again.
BERLIN, Dec. 1 -- The procession of high-ranking Soviet-zone German leaders fleeing to the bizonal area has been joined by Ernst Thape, Minister of Education in Saxony-Anhalt.

Seeking reinstatement as city director of airports, from which post he was dismissed on May 20, 1947, Maj. Elmer Haslett in an argument presented by his attorney yesterday before the Appellate Division, First Department, denied misconduct and said he had not received a fair, impartial hearing.

PARIS, Dec. 1 -- The French Government is reluctant for Sir Stafford Cripps, British Minister for Economic Affairs, to visit Paris to discuss the French and British four-year programs under the Marshall Plan, and it was embarrassed by a hint from London that he desired to come.

Two six-story apartment houses occupying a plot 200 by 125 feet at 566 and 582 Beck Street, in the Bronx, have been sold by Philip Goldfein and Julius Perlbinder to the 566 Realty Corporation, an investing client of Gerard M. Bloomfield and Albert Margolin, attorneys.

Out of the web of his wife's dreams a Chicago printer, abandoned forty-two years ago as an infant, has started a search for a brother. Unsure that he has such an elder brother, the printer is acting on a hunch that as in the past his wife's "dreams and intuitions" will prove correct.
MONTCLAIR, N. J., Dec. 1 -Mrs. Theodore W. Hawes of Baltusrol was elected president of the Women's New Jersey Golf Association today at the Montclair Golf Club.

LONDON, Dec. 1 -- British and United States spokesmen expressed general agreement today with a large part of the French proposals for assuring the future international control of Germany's industrial potential for war, but they raised objections on critical points.
A pair of terrific triple-threat men and two fleet-footed backs who excel on end sweeps comprise the high powered backfield of The Associated Press All-America football team announced yesterday.
PARIS, Dec. 1 (AP) -- The text of the United States-British-French statement on the proposal to set up a United Nations commission to study the Berlin currency problem follows:

MARLBORO, N. Y., Dec. 1 -- A bird sanctuary will be established this winter on the rambling old country estate of the late Frederic W. Goudy, noted type designer, it was revealed today by a committee of mid-Hudson River Valley bird lovers.

Miss Fannie L. Gibson, destined to be one of Liberia's first dieticians, admitted yesterday that she was worried about Liberia's lack of lettuce, now that she has developed a penchant for American salads.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 1 (UP) -- Lefty Lou Brissie signed his 1949 contract with the Athletics today.

The United States liner America sailed for Europe yesterday after being delayed for fifteen days by the longshoremen's strike. She carried 760 passengers, many of whom had been forced to cancel accommodations on Cunard White Star ships.

Dr. John A. Krout, Professor of History at Columbia University, has been named acting director of the university's School of General Studies and of the summer session, Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, president of the university, announced yesterday.

Appointment of John J. Dwyer as traffic manager of the Robin Line was announced yesterday by S. J. Maddock, vice president of the Seas Shipping Company, Inc., operator of the line. Mr. Dwyer succeeds the late David J. Elmore.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- A small seasonal gain of about 60,000 raised non - agricultural employment to the record level of nearly 46,000,000 in mid-October, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today.
