SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, Dec. 1 -- Provisional President Jose Figueres today disbanded the national Army that had carried him to victory in a five-week civil war early this year. He returned the country to its democratic tradition of having more school teachers than soldiers.

The death early yesterday of Frank Brett Noyes, chairman of The Evening Star Newspaper Company, publisher of The Washington Star, marked the close of a chapter in the history of one of the country's leading independent newspapers.

Pork, which has declined steadily in price this month, has been featured in retail stores for the last few week-ends. Indications are that it will be the outstanding offering at meat counters again this Friday and Saturday. It's an item that thrifty housewives will be wise to consider, for prices on some cuts are as much as 10 cents a pound less than they were the first of November.

BOSTON, Dec. 1 (AP) -- The Bruins scored all their goals in the last fifteen minutes for a 5-1 victory over the Chicago Black Hawks tonight before a crowd of 13,900 at the Boston Garden. The burst was set off by Jim Conacher's tally for the visitors after more than forty-four minutes of fast but scoreless action.
GENEVA, Dec 1 -- The United States has asked for the allocation of 1,800,000 tons of steel scrap from Europe for the second quarter of 1949, it was learned today.

CHICAGO, Dec. 1 -- Grain markets made a strong close on the Board of trade today after an early sell-off. Short covering and commission-house buying absorbed the offerings, and there was little pressure when the markets started upward.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 (AP) -- A funeral service will be held here on Friday at 2 P. M. for Frank B. Noyes, chairman of The Evening Star Newspaper Company and for thirty-eight years president of The Associated Press, who died this morning at the age of 85.

PARIS, Dec. 1 -- The Western powers indicated today that the increasing deterioration of the situation in Berlin might force them to take steps to check what they regarded as measures enacted by Soviet authorities to drive them out of Berlin.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- Communism or "its totalitarian counterpart" is increasing in western Europe in spite the Marshall Plan, Eric Johnson, member of the ECA public advisory board, said today in urging legislation to facilitate investment of American private capital in democratic countries.

LONDON, Dec. 1 -- An agreement that will reduce the transportation expenses of United States citizens who send gift parcels to Britain was signed by British and American representatives at the Foreign Office today.

A fifty-one-foot-long cylindrical steel boiler drum, nine feet in diameter, weighing a hundred tons, was loaded aboard the French Line passenger cargo vessel Oregon at Pier 88, North River, yesterday morning for another lap on its journey to France. The huge drum be carried as deck cargo to France.

JERUSALEM, Dec. 1 -- Dr. Chaim Weizmann, President of Israel, today paid his first visit to Jerusalem since the state was established while the city welcomed the first day of the new cease fire, which was effectively observed.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 (AP) -Messages of condolence on the death of Frank B. Noyes, a pioneer in the field of modern news gathering, streamed in from all quarters of the nation today.

CINCINNATI, Dec. 1 -- Recurrent attempts to label the Federal Council of the Churches of Christ in America as "communistic" were scored here today by the Rev. Dr. Samuel McCrea Cavert of New York, its general secretary, as "deliberate misrepresentations" of the council's effort to apply Christian principles of justice and freedom to daily life. He addressed the opening session of the organization's fortieth anniversary meeting.

The Grumman Aircraft Engineering Corporation announced yesterday a dividend of $1 a share on the common stock, payable Dec. 21. Including the $1 distribution in July, total dividends this year amount to $2 a share, or 50 cents more than 1947 disbursements, based on present capitalization.

DETROIT, Dec. 1 (AP) -- Coming from behind three times, the Detroit Red Wings defeated the Toronto Maple Leafs, 5 to 3, tonight in a slam-bang National Hockey League game in which 18 penalties were called by Referee Bill Chadwick.

ATHENS, Dec. 1 -- One of the sharpest defeats inflicted upon the Communist-led rebels in recent weeks was announced today by official military sources, which stated that in the Third Corps area, based at Salonika, 183 rebels had been killed, eighty-seven taken prisoner and another 119 had surrendered.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 (AP) -- An employer's inquiry to his private secretary about how she intended to vote in a union election was held by the National Labor Relations Board today to be unfair labor practice.

LONDON, Dec. 1 -- Sunshine and a sharp breeze dispelled the fog over most of England and Wales today, releasing the world's three largest passenger liners after the longest traffic hold-up in the history of their owners, the Cunard Line.
PARIS, Dec. 1 -- Argentina defied all members of the Big Five today by demanding a world conference in April, 1949, to write the veto out of the United Nations Charter.

To many of us, the news from Swat, sent by Robert Trumbull and published in THE TIMES yesterday morning complete with map, will be that there is a Swat -- not a legendary realm of baseball fame, or the playful invention of humorous versifiers, but a remote Asiatic domain of mountain and valley "where the Buddha left his mark and Alexander marched" and where today has emerged an oasis of peace.

Public financing for natural gas distribution enterprises figures prominently in the new issues of interest-bearing securities totaling $68,500,000 which underwriting syndicates will offer to investors today. The offerings are as follows:

New York's four municipal colleges will require $25,000,000 in the next ten years for development and expansion to perform the minimum services for which they were established, Dr. Ordway Tead, chairman of the Board of Higher Education, said yesterday.

From the unexpectedly large number of early arrivals yesterday, it was anticipated that attendance at the sixtieth annual convention of the Amateur Athletics Union of the United States would reach an all-time record high of nearly 400. Officials and delegates from all sections of the country were already on hand last night.

CAIRO, Dec. 1 -- One of the leading Sudanese advocates of Egyptian-Sudanese unity, Mohammed Nur el Din, secretary general of the Ashigga party, was today sentenced by a British criminal court at Atbara in the Sudan to six months' imprisonment and a fine of 25.

Subsidiaries of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company have pending before state and local regulatory bodies, applications for rate increases totaling $240,000,000 a year, it was disclosed yesterday.
The State of Maryland announced yesterday that it will receive bids until Dec. 20 for $6,695,000 of certificates of indebtedness dated Jan. 1, 1949, and due on each Jan. 1 from 1952 to 1964.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Dec. 1 (UP) -- The first secretary of the Argentine Embassy, Luis Zervino, was declared persona non grata today for having allegedly advocated the overthrow of the Chilean Government.

A showing that encompassed the fashion needs of women bound to warmer climes for the winter months was held by Milgrim's yesterday at the luncheon hour in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. There were clothes for travel, spectator sports, sun-tanning and evening entertainment, formal and informal.

The formation of a citizens' corporation to take respensibility for converting refuse-strewn lots into neighborhood recreation centers was disclosed yesterday by J. Raymond Jones, deputy commissioner of housing.

A resolution endorsing extension of the Reciprocal Trade Agreements Act on a permanent basis was adopted unanimously yesterday by the Foreign Credit Interchange Bureau at a meeting in the Governor Clinton Hotel.
The announcement on Tuesday that draft calls for the first two months of 1949 would be reduced sharply should not be construed as "crippling" our military program, as some persons say it does.

A lull in the selling of stocks to establish tax losses was seized upon yesterday to give prices the most substantial lift in almost a month. The list received its first lift at the opening with the uncovering of supporting orders and, as trading broadened out, the advance continued.

Erik Satie, Darius Milhaud and Francis Poulenc were the composers represented on the second program of the Juilliard School of Music's festival of contemporary French music, given last night before a packed house at the Juilliard Concert Hall.

The four-story English basement dwelling with garden at 228 East Sixty-eighth Street, between Second and Third Avenues, has been sold by William A. Hanway, secretary of the International Paper Company, to John Gart, musical director for various radio stations.
The insurance industry in this state lives up to high moral standards, Robert E. Dineen, State Superintendent of Insurance, asserted yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 (AP) -- Sweden win decide the fate of eighty-four Estonian refugees from Soviet rule who crossed the Atlantic in small boats last summer to reach the United States.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- The Union Electric Company of Missouri was authorized today by the Securities and Exchange Commission to split its common stock so that the utility might file a consolidated tax return with its parent, the North American Company.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Dec. 1 -- Twenty-three years after leaving college, Richard. F. Crandell of this city, picture editor of The New York Herald Tribune, will receive the degree of Bachelor of Arts in Journalism from Montana State University at Missoula.

PARIS, Dec. 1 -- The United States delegation will propose a special session of the United Nations General Assembly for next February or March to give a final decision on the disposition of former Italian colonies, it was announced today.
CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 1 (AP) -- Florida opened its 1948-49 thoroughbred racing season at Tropical Park today with 12,079 fans attending.

Forty-eight years of service with The Associated Press from its earliest days to its present great estate, thirty-eight of these years as its president, made Frank Brett Noyes the elder statesman of American journalism. His was not a mere titular leadership as the last surviving founder of the organization. Within himself he embodied many of the qualities which have given this nation a free and responsible news service.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- The Newport Shipbuilding and Dry-dock Company today bid $67,350,000 to construct a proposed 8,000-ton liner to crown the United States merchant fleet. The bid was opened in the office of the Maritime commission, along with one other for $75,649,000, submitted by the Bethlehem Shipbuilding Company.
ST. LOUIS, Dec. 1 -- The American Medical Association turned down today a proposal for a national insurance company as a means of combating federal compulsory health insurance plans.

VIENNA, Dec. 1 -- On the ground that the costs of Austria's four-power occupation are draining away through one channel the Marshall Plan aid pouring in through another, the Austrian Government is believed to have asked Washington not to vote for the payment of such costs in 1949.

ATLANTIC CITY, Dec. 1 -- Leading realtors and building experts from various parts of this state expect their business during the coming year to hold close to the high levels of 1948, with new emphasis on long-term property investments and a general effort to tap the vast market for lower-priced homes.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 1 -Fred M. Packard, son-in-law of J. Arthur Rank, British film leader, has signed a contract with Columbia as a producer, the studio announced today. He will report to Columbia after he completes "Quicksand," his own independent production, which Twentieth Century-Fox will release. "Quicksand" is scheduled to go before, the cameras in January with Elliott Nugent directing.

Donald Bass bought the building containing store and lofts on a lot 21 by 100 feet at 303 Livingston Street, Brooklyn, from the Brodey Brodey Fur Company and insured title with the Metropolitan Title Guaranty Company. The property was sold for $42,000, subject to a mortgage of $20,000.

A critism of many states for the "imbalance" of their benefit systems in that old age assistance programs are expanding much faster then child care was made yesterday by Jane M. Hoey, director of the Bureau of Public Assistance, Social Security Administration, federal Security Agency.

Arnold Risen tossed in twenty-eight points for the Rochester Royals last night and the last of his markers gave a 73-72 triumph to the Basketball Association of America's Western Division leaders over the New York Knickerbockers in a tense struggle witnessed by 13,859 spectators at Madison Square Garden.

NANKING, Dec. 1 -- Artillery fire was heard today at Pengpu, 100 miles north of Nanking, as the Communists began probing the western flank of the Nationalist Huai River line in an apparent attempt to envelop that northern Anhwei rail city.

LONDON, Dec. 1 -- Conservatives in the House of Lords urged today that the British lion should roar louder and retaliate more effectively against the cavalier treatment of this country by the Soviet Union and her satellites.

ALBANY, Dec. 1 -- State expenditures for education in the 1949-50 fiscal year are expected to increase by at least $40,000,000 over the current figure, bringing the total outlay to $194,000,000 Governor Dewey said today. Mr. Dewey added that he expected the education allotment in the 1950-51 budget would approximate $205,000,000.

MAYOR O'Dwyer announced yesterday the resignation of City Collector John J. Fagan, whose office is under investigation by Investigation Commissioner John M. Murtagh in connection with sales of real estate tax liens.

VIENNA, Dec. 1 -- The Hungarian Government will permit CARE packages to be distributed in Hungary next year only if the dollars collected in the United States for the purchase of the packages are sent to the Hungarian National Bank here and the food is bought in Hungary.
PARIS, Dec. 1 -- Following is the text of the genocide convention adopted today by the United Nations Legal Committee:

Du Pont's newest synthetic textile fiber has a combination of properties which will give it a wide variety of uses where nylons and rayons will not equal its performance, it was pointed out yesterday by Dr. Joseph B. Quig, assistant manager of the development section of E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- The American Navy's top air admiral is at sea with a British fleet.

CHICAGO, Dec. 1 -- In this year's deer season at least 111 hunters have died so far from gunshot wounds in twenty-one states. At least that many more have perished from causes relating to hunting, such as heart attacks induced by excitement or overexertion, drowning and auto accidents.
CHICAGO, Dec. 1 (AP) -- A Federal judge today described some customer, lists used by mail-order houses as "sucker lists," and said he wondered how he happened to be on some of them.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 (AP) -- Twelve European bike riders walked out on Promoter Jimmy Proscia and Washington's first international six-day bike race late today.

President Truman had a Southern visitor yesterday who described the poll tax as "stupid," said lynching cases should be tried in the federal courts, and when asked about the civil rights program replied that "the Federal Government should protect all its citizens in their civil rights and should see that they are treated as Americans."
SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 2 -- Two more maritime unions reached agreements with West Coast shipowners today, easing further the snarled labor situation here.

John J. Berger, representative of a landlords' association, writes in your issue of Nov. 29 concerning the so-called justifiable refusal of landlords to allow tenants to install television aerials on the roof because accident hazards are created.

An overwhelming majority of 500 business men attending a panel discussion on the outlook for labor-management relations at the Congress of American Industry at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel last night raised their hands when asked whether industry or the National Association of Manufacturers should fight to preserve the "sound principles" of the Taft-Hartley Act.
PARIS, Dec. 2 -- Interest is diverted from skirts to bodices and especially to necklines by Pierre Balmain in his colorful midseason collection starring basque red, tunnel gray and black.
Long Island golf officials went into action last night to prepare the groundwork for another year. They also did a bit of reminiscing of the past season.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 2 -- Negotiations have been instituted between David O. Selznick and Eagle-Lion looking toward the reissue of eight Selznick films and the residual selling of at least two new Selznick releases, it was learned today.

The Appellate Division reserved decision yesterday on two appeals from a decision of Supreme Court Justice Felix C. Benvenga who dismissed actions brought against the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, and its subsidiary, Stuyvesant Town, East Side housing project, for alleged discrimination in selecting tenants.
New York is being flooded with the greatest amount of counterfeit money in the history of the country.

An intimate study and biography of Georges Clemenceau by Wythe Williams, entitled "The Tiger of France," has been scheduled for release in February by Duell, Sloan Pearce. Mr. Williams was a foreign correspondent for twenty-six years and a close friend of M. Clemenceau.

The recently completed two-story garage building on a plot 75 by 100 feet at 921 Sherman Avenue, the Bronx, has been sold by the Elba Estates, Inc., to the Chester Park Realty Company. Sale of the property, which accommodates about 100 cars, was subject to a mortgage of $64,000.

PARIS, Dec. 2 -- The French National Assembly asked the Government tonight to inform Britain and the United States that "the French people unanimously reject" the policy regarding the Ruhr expressed in an ordinance of the British and American Military Governors issued Nov. 10. This ordinance put the Ruhr industries into the hands of German trustees and proclaimed that the final ownership of those industries would be determined by the eventual German regime.

After citing generally pessimistic reactions to the election outcome last month, the December letter of the National City Bank of New York, being released today, noted, among other observations on economics, several financing problems that confront local governments.

TOKYO, Dec. 2 -- Gen. Douglas MacArthur's new labor policy -- that labor must create wealth before attempting to divide it: in other words, increase production to earn pay rises -- appears to be winning out.

Edward Johnson, general manager of the Metropolitan Opera Association, yesterday received the Swedish Order of Vasa, Class of Commander, in tribute to "his eminence in the world of opera and as a token of appreciation of the hospitality and assistance shown to Swedish guest singers" at the Metropolitan.

Two hundred leaders of the entertainment industry, gathered yesterday for a luncheon meeting at the Toots Shor Restaurant, were told the important role they are scheduled to play in the revival of the United Service Organizations.

A large subscription has been reported for the performance of "Red Gloves," a new play by Jean-Paul Sartre, with Charles Boyer in the leading role, on the night of Dec. 21 at the Mansfield Theatre which has been taken over by members of Chapter Number One of the Berkshire Industrial Farm to raise funds for the institution.

Merchants and service organizations throughout the country joined yesterday in a movement that hopes to bring "a modern touch to the old-fashioned Community Christmas tree" through a program sponsored by the Christmas Tree Caravan Committee, 122 West Fourteenth Street.

JEFFERSON CITY, Mo., Dec. 2 -- The University of Missouri board of curators recommended today that state laws be amended to permit the admission of Negroes to state-supported institutions of higher learning to pursue courses not offered at Lincoln University, the Negro school here.

A meeting was held yesterday in Le Coq Rouge, 65 East Fifty-sixth Street, by members of the junior auxiliary of the Silver Cross Day Nursery to complete plans and to wrap the nursery children's presents for the annual Christmas party to be held Dec. 21 at the beneficiary's headquarters at 251 East 117th Street.
Soft colored chambray dresses were featured yesterday by Gimbels at the opening of the cruise shop on the third floor.

The bodies of two laborers who were buried alive when unshored walls of a sewer excavation at City Island, the Bronx, collapsed at 3:55 P.M. yesterday were recovered last night. The first victim was brought to street level after six hours of ceaseless rescue work.

Dr. Karel Fink, Commercial Attache at the Czechoslovak Consulate-General here, announced yesterday the new $43,000,000 trade agreement between Czechoslovakia and the Western Allied Military Governments in Germany, which he said was proof that the Prague Government was supporting "trade with the West."

THAT the best English is written by Irish authors is a highly partisan generalization that is not true now and never was. But that many Irish authors write English wonderfully well is incontestable. Has any nation of comparable size ever produced such a long list of distinguished writers, from Jonathan Swift to Anne Crone?
VIENNA, Dec. 2 -- The Austrian Government has formally decided to use $4,500,000 of Marshall Plan funds to build a rayon textile plant.

DUNEDIN, Fla., Dec. 2 (AP) -- Joe Novak of Los Angeles defeated Horton Smith today for the leadership of the Professional Golfers Association. Novak succeeds Ed Dudley of Augusta, Ga., who retired after seven years as president. He received 47 votes to 26 for Smith, who is a Detroit pro.

NEWARK N.J., Dec. 2 -- A report filed with Superior Court Judge Frederick R. Colie by John J. Winberry, who was dismissed by Attorney General Walter Van Riper on Nov. 16 as a special deputy attorney general, described New Jersey as "the national gambling capital."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- Department store sales in the week ended Nov. 27 were 5 per cent above sales in the corresponding week last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. The following compilation lists percentage changes from like periods of 1947:

Harry A. Bullis, chairman of the board of General Mills, Inc., warned the Congress of American Industry yesterday that business must provide job security for its employes and must treat them as human beings, not as cogs in the machine.
When Lucia Szczepanska stepped off the S.S. General Black thirty-four days ago, officially she was a displaced person.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 (UP) -- Federal Judge Matthew F. McGuire today refused to order the Maritime Commission to turn back to private ownership the American President Steamship Line.

The National Association of Manufacturers adopted a resolution yesterday urging four restrictions on any compulsory economic controls that might be adopted by the new Congress to strengthen national security against possible foreign aggression.

A syndicate of investors has purchased the building containing ten stores and eight apartments at 1483 to 1491 York Avenue, southwest corner of Seventy-ninth Street, from Murray H. Gershon and George Strell for cash over a mortgage of $111,000. The F. Tuoti Company was the broker in the sale of the property, which was held at $210,000.

This is the season for the turkey shoot. It is a short season as forms of entertainment go, lasting only from the Sunday before Thanksgiving until New Year's. Small packages very often contain concentrated essence, however, and in this the turkey shoot is no exception.

Arrangements for showing of General Motors 1949 transportation products at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, Jan. 20 to 27 were announced yesterday from the Detroit headquarters of the corporation. This will be the first complete General Motors automobile show since 1940.

TRENTON, N.J., Dec. 2 -- Magistrates and judges in New Jersey's lesser courts were urged today by Chief Justice Arthur T. Vanderbilt to make "a fresh start" on Jan. by putting aside any political pressure or favoritism that might affect any of their decisions.

Production of price-competitive power from atomic energy can be accomplished with little more than present-day engineering technology according to speakers who addressed the annual meeting of the American Society of Mechanical Engineers at the Pennsylvania Hotel last night.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 (AP) -- The Securities and Exchange Commission tonight indicated it would soon approve a request of Milwaukee Gas Light Company to borrow $4,500,000 from banks.

The property acquired by the city in 1937 as a site for a new home for the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court on the east side of Park Avenue between Thirty-ninth and Fortieth Streets will be sold at public auction early in January.

The stock market ran into some difficulties yesterday and made only fractional gains, in contrast to the sharp rally of Wednesday. The reappearance of tax loss selling account slowed the advance, although the list leaned heavily to the higher side at the finish.

CHICAGO, Dec. 2 -- Grain markets closed irregular on the Board of Trade today after showing considerable strength early under leadership of December soy beans. The latter was 5 cents higher at one time on top of a 6 1/4-cent upturn yesterday and despite hedging and profit-taking sales.

Donald P. Ross, president of Delaware Park, Stanton, was named president of the Thoroughbred Racing Associations yesterday as the two-day convention of that organization closed at the Hotel Plaza. Ross succeeds James E. Dooley of Narragansett Park, Pawtucket, R.I., who served two terms.

A double-barreled attack against the city's smoke and air pollution problem and the increasing volume of debris and litter on its streets was approved yesterday by the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York at its regular meeting at 65 Liberty Street.

CHICAGO, Dec. 2 -- A plan to give Chicago a modern art center embracing music, the theatre and the plastic and graphic arts has been maturing quietly under the auspices of the University of Chicago, it was learned here today.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- The United Mine Workers Journal today scolded labor leaders who qualify their demands for repeal of the Taft-Hartley Law.

Efforts to expedite a decision on a proposed new superliner for the American merchant marine were made known yesterday by the Maritime Commission, following a low bid filed with the agency on Wednesday by the Newport News Shipbuilding and Dry Dock Company of Virginia.

Industrialists attending the fifty-third annual Congress of American industry had special cheers yesterday for Lewis P. Reese, central figure in a success story that was dramatized for those attending the convention.

PARIS, Dec. 2 -- Apparently unanimous agreement has been reached in the General Assembly of the United Nations that the United Nations Appeal for Children shall be continued. The only question now is whether it is to be maintained as an independent non-governmental organization or be made an adjunct of the International Children's Emergency Fund, which is an intergovernmental body.

Today's events: Philharmonic Symphony, Bruno Walter, conductor, Nadine Conner, soprano, Jean Watson, contralto, Westminster Choir, Carnegie Hall, 2:30 P.M.; "Il Trovatore," Metropolitan Opera, 8:15; Jorge Bolet, piano, Carnegie Hall, 8:30; Paul Makovsky, violin, assisted by Jerzy Witas, piano, and Frank Brieff, viola, Town Hall, 8:30; Mathilde McKinney, piano, Times lIall, 8:30; Festival of Contemporary French Music, Juilliard School, 8:30; Eisenberg Quartet, iVfannes School, 8:30.
BOSTON, Dec. 2 -- The National Tavern Association closed its annual convention today by adopting a resolution calling for standard measuring glasses at the nation's bars.

"Street Corner," a melodrama featuring Joseph Crehan, Marcia Mae Jones and John Treul, will have its local premiere this morning at the Ambassador. Albert Kelley directed and George McCall produced the Wilshire Pictures offering, which is being distributed by Viro Pictures, Inc.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- Five Japanese leaders urged the Supreme Court today to upset their conviction as war criminals. Tried by the International Military Tribunal in Tokyo, four of the men received life terms, and the fifth was sentenced to twenty years.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- President Truman has decided to do without a personal chief of staff when Fleet Admiral William D. Leahy retires next month, it was learned tonight, and thereafter will take his daily briefing on military-politico affairs from Sidney W. Souers, Executive Secretary of the National Security Council.

Air, land and sea facilities were employed yesterday by the Coast Guard to speed a fisherman from a boat ten miles off the eastern Long Island shore to the United States Marine Hospital in Staten Island for an emergency operation.

Looking ahead to Jack Benny's leave-taking from its network, NBC is considering possible fence mending steps, one of which would switch the Red Skelton show from Friday nights to the 7 o'clock Sunday night spot of the departing comedian. Mr. Benny is scheduled to move his program to CBS on Jan. 2.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- The drive to swing Alabama's eleven electors from Gov. J. Strom Thurmond to President Truman was carried to the Supreme Court today by Gov. James E. Folsom of Alabama.

ATHENS, Dec. 2 -- The total number of Greek children now held in the Communist-bloc Balkan and Danubian states is 23,696, according to data submitted to the offices here of the United Nations Special Committee on the Balkans by Geneva headquarters of the International Red Cross organizations.

THE football picture at Fordham has been constantly taking on a newer and a brighter sheen. It fairly glowed yesterday with the announcement that the Rams would face Yale on the sacred sod of the Yale Bowl next season. Since Army already is on the Maroon list of opponents it would seem that Fordham finally has taken a few sprigs of ivy off its hallowed walls and festooned its schedule with it.

One man was killed and another critically injured late yesterday afternoon in the Sheepshead Bay section of Brooklyn when the house the two were moving to a new site brushed a high-voltage overhead electric cable.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 (AP) -- The United States will set a new record in exports of grains and grain products this crop year if a foreign shipment program outlined today by the Department of Agriculture is carried out.

It is the good fortune of the world that although Wagner wrote the librettos of the "Ring of the Nibelung" backwards, from "Goetterdaemmerung" to "Rhinegoid," he composed them forward, so that when he had reached the consummate opera of the trilogy he could create with a plenitude of inspiration and a spontaneous mastery of his means that produced a work of overwhelming richness and splendor.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- An effort to pledge the Labor Department's fifteenth annual conference on labor legislation to President Truman's civil rights program was defeated today by a vote of 23 to 21 after an acrimonious debate. In general American Federation of Labor delegates opposed the resolution and officials of the Congress of Industrial Organizations favored it.

The Community Service Society could not have chosen a more appropriate theme for its emergency campaign to raise $1,400,000 in the coming weeks. Its slogan, "Protect the Family -- Bedrock of Democracy," is a reminder that the family is the training ground of democracy.

Strong opposition to legislation to regulate interest rates and other practices of finance companies in connection with installment sales was voiced by industry representatives at a hearing conducted here yesterday by the Joint Legislative Committee to Study Installment Sales.

CINCINNATI, Dec. 2 -- The University of Cincinnati announced today that its College of Applied Arts would design a setting and structure adapted to a system of reflective radiant conditioning proved workable under laboratory conditions ten years ago by Dr. Clarence A. Mills, Professor of Experimental Medicine in the university's College of Medicine.

CHICAGO, Dec. 2 -- Stock insurance companies have misused new rating laws to set up monopolistic rate practices and have failed to provide needed coverage, Ernest L. Clark, assistant treasurer of J.C. Penney Company, said today. Speaking at a meeting of the American Management Association, he asserted the Government will take over the insurance business unless private insurers meet the demand for their product.

In a post-election statement addressed to fellow party members the present chairman of the Republican National Committee, Representative Hugh D. Scott Jr., outlines what he believes should be the proper policy and program of the Opposition during the two years that will elapse before there is another test of public sentiment, in the Congressional elections of 1950.

For some reason Sean O'Casey, one of Ireland's great playwrights, hasn't been represented by a new full-length play on the local boards in a number of years. Not that he doesn't have any scripts on tap. He has. But the vagaries of show business are inscrutable.

ASUNCION, Paraguay, Dec. 2 -- Some of the best resident observers here feel that if President Juan Gonzalez can get by January his Administration may survive. But, right now, its peaceful continuance for the five-year term that began in August is regarded as by no means assured.

An extra of $4 a share and the regular quarterly dividend of 50 cents a share have been v ed on the common stock of the Bates Manufacturing Company for payment on Dec. 28, making 1948 payments $6, compared with $4 last year.

SCHENECTADY, N. Y., Dec. 2 -- The General Electric Company today formally opened the first wing of its research laboratory's new $18,000,000 home which is under construction on a near-by Niskayuma hilltop.

CHICAGO, Dec. 2 -- Scientists hope to get a record of prehistoric climatic conditions by use of a "thermometer of fossils" buried in the rocks for hundreds of millions of years, Dr. Harold C. Urey of the University of Chicago's Institute for Nuclear Studies said tonight in an address to the local chapter of Sigma Xi.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- The United States Government, in a stinging note delivered through its legation in Budapest to the Hungarian Foreign Ministry and made public today, declared that the Hungarian Government "must bear full legal and financial responsibility" for the seizure of the Hungarian-American Oil Company (MAORT) and the Maort Gas Company.

A method of turning bluish white mercury light into a flattering warmer color without sacrificing its high efficiency has been discovered by a twenty-six-year-old scientist at the Bloomfield, N.J., plant of the Westinghouse Electric Corporation, it was announced yesterday.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 2 (AP) -- Education, owned by Mrs. Fred W. Hooper of Coral Gables, made his first start since Oct. 14, 1947, in the six-furlong Legerdemain Purse at Tropical Park today and won to the satisfaction of most of the 6,229 racegoers who bet only $290,786 on the eight events.

TANGSHAN, China, Dec. 2 -- Here in the coal mining area, which, in normal times, keeps 50 per cent of China's industry going, the population is more frightened of a "scorched earth" policy by the Nationalists than domination by the Communists. They are faced with the possibility of both.

The Elmira College Club of New York will hold its fifth annual bridge party tonight in the small ballroom of the Pierre to raise funds for the new academic building at the college. Erection of the building is part of the program for the centennial celebration of Elmira College, which will be held in 1955.

Nineteen fire alarm boxes were inoperative for almost an hour and traffic lights on First Avenue from Houston to 125th Streets were out of order temporarily at 7:50 o'clock last night as the result of a collision in which a five-ton truck and two private automobiles were involved at First Avenue and Thirty-fourth Street.
NANKING, Dec. 2 -- The Communist radio asserted tonight that Communist troops, under Gen. Chen Yi had occupied Suchow, important northern Kiangsu railway junction.

CARACAS, Venezuela, Dec. 2 -- Dr. Luis Emilio Gomez Ruiz, new Minister of Foreign Affairs, said today his Government had requested recognition of all nations with which Venezuela had previously maintained relations, including Russia.

The American System of higher education must be strengthened and improved if the democratic way of life is to survive in this country, Henry Ford 2d declared last night. Strong, privately endowed colleges are essential to provide a well-balanced, democratic education, he said.

Extensive repairs on the British freighter Leicester, abandoned by her crew 400 miles off Halifax in a mid-September hurricane and later towed to Bermuda and Baltimore, are now nearing completion in the last named port, it was announced yesterday by the New Zealand Shipping Company.
A congregation numbering 5,500 attended last night the fifth of the series of mission services conducted at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine by the Rev. Dr. Bryan Green of Birmingham, England.
I have no personal interest in the Hudson River Day Line, but for sixty years I have watched it go by my house.
HOUSTON, Tex., Dec. 2 -- A state draft law may be sought in Texas, a member of the Texas State Guard Association disclosed here today.

Two men were arrested last night accused of having in their possession narcotics estimated to be worth $750,000 when sold "on the street." The narcotics were said by the police to have been reaching a trade of "theatre people," many of them women.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 2 (AP) -- A university president complained today about what has happened to college football. The game has been kidnaped from the players, he said, and made a sacrifice to victory and box-office success.

PARIS, Dec. 2 -- Six months of stalemate in Indonesia have produced periodic "acute fears" of the resumption of warfare between the Dutch and the Republic of Indonesia, the United Nations officially was told today.

Dr. Albert Einstein, Prof. Sidney Hook and nineteen other scholars and teachers joined yesterday in a public statement denouncing the Freedom party of Israel led by Menachem Begin, who is now visiting in the United States, as one that until recently "openly preached the doctrine of the Fascist state."

Officials of the American Silent Guest Committee yesterday received a check from Harold W. Dodds, president of Princeton University, representing contributions that had been made by students and faculty in Princeton Chapel.

Give New York's asphalt-conditioned children a little top soil and they will hoe their own row. This was proved last summer when youngsters in the city's public school system grew nearly four tons of vegetables in their school gardens.

First action toward carrying out a recently announced plan for using American companies' overseas advertising to combat Communist propaganda, while also "selling" the American way of life, was taken yesterday at a meeting attended by representatives of major export concerns in the Pierre Hotel.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 2 -- Robert E. Garrett, division manager of sales for the Gulf Oil Corporation, announced today that the company would spend upward of $40,000,000 to expand its present refining and storage facilities in South Philadelphia.

OTTAWA, Dec. 2 -- Canada's attitude toward the proposed North Atlantic pact appears to be developing along the same lines as she adopted toward her association with the United Kingdom and the other nations of the Commonwealth in the years before the war.

The first John H. Finley Award for outstanding civic service was bestowed last night upon the Rockefeller family at the ninety-fifth annual dinner of City College's Associate Alumni in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. John D. Rockefeller 3d accepted the award for his family.

After an ownership of forty-five years, the six-story apartment house on a plot 63 by 100 feet at 316 West Ninety-fourth Street, adjoining the south corner of Riverside Drive, was purchased for investment by Mor Katz in a transaction reported yesterday by A.V. Amy Co., brokers in the deal. It is assessed for $115,000 and was sold for cash over a first mortgage of $47,000.

NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 2 -- The first test in the nation to meet communication, evacuation and other problems that are likely to result from an atom bomb attack will be made in northern New Jersey in a three-day program beginning tomorrow in which more than 1,000 personnel of the Civil Air Patrol and the Red Cross will participate.

PARIS, Dec. 2 -- Ignoring a request by the Israeli Government for an urgent decision, the Security Council today referred Israeli's application for membership in the United Nations to its membership committee for study.

Stanley F. Musial, brilliant Cardinal outfielder who swept all but one of the National League's batting laurels last summer, has been named the most valuable, in his circuit for 1948, according, to announcement made yesterday after a poll of the twenty-four-man committee chosen from the ranks of the Baseball Writers Association of America.

LONDON, Dec. 2 -- The busiest section in an otherwise quiet stock market today was the gold-mining group. There was a big turnover in Orange Free State issues, and prices closed near the best of the day with useful gains.

LONDON, Dec. 2 -- British diplomatic observers were astonished and dismayed tonight by the action of the United Nations Assembly's Political Committee in emasculating the Anglo-American resolution for conciliation in Palestine. The first unofficial comment was that it was "hopeless" to establish a Conciliation Commission, as proposed in the resolution, without giving it instructions.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- Increased mailing facilities to Israel have been put into effect, the Post-office Department announced today.

BASSETERRE, St. Kitts, B.W.I., Dec. 2 -- Ward M. Canaday, United States Chairman of the Caribbean Commission, called for a regional approach to the problems of the area at the opening of the third West Indian Conference. He said the most important problems were industrial development, greater economic productivity, better transportation and the development of tourist trade.

PARIS, Dec. 2 -- The Marshall Plan nations have told United States officials that, in seeking to solve their dollar shortage, they count on exporting to the United States in the first year after the Plan ends -- from June, 1952, to June, 1953 -- goods worth about three times those exported there in 1947 and nearly 50 per cent more than those so exported in 1938.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 (AP) -- Walter S. Franklin, vice president of the Pennsylvania Railroad, said today his company's earning rate is wholly inadequate for its needs.

In a surprise move said to have been caused by labor difficulties between liquor wholesalers and their salesmen, Distillers Corporation-Seagrams, Ltd., severed all business relations with its local distributors yesterday. Later it was announced that the company will distribute its own brands here through the Sea-Cal-Frank Corporation, a name coined from the first syllables of three of the company's subsidiaries.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- President Truman announced today his intention to see Mme. Chiang Kaishek, here to make an urgent appeal for more United States aid to China. He refrained again, however, from issuing the statement requested by her husband, the Generalissimo, promising more United States help and more active participation by the United States in the direction of the Nationalists' civil war effort.

DETROIT, Dec. 2 -- Present Federal taxes were described today by James E. Webb, Director of the Bureau of the Budget, as inadequate to thwart the danger of a deficit in the next fiscal year, starting July 1. Mr. Webb, one of the speakers at the opening session of the ninth biennial General Assembly of the Council of State Governments, indicated that increased taxes would be required to meet "mounting requirements on almost every side."
PARIS, Dec. 2 -- The United States warned tonight that the veto was a weapon in a "cold war" that might get out of hand and threaten the peace of the world.
SYDNEY, Australia, Dec. 2 (AP) -- The United Nations Economic Commission for Asia and the Far East was told today that Asia needed something like Marshall Plan aid to rehabilitate itself.

Jake LaMotta, veteran middle-weight from the Bronx, will meet Tommy Yarosz of Monaca, Pa., in the feature bout of ten rounds at Madison Square Garden tonight. The match will be the first Garden main event for Yarosz, whose brother Teddy once held the championship of the 160-pound class.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- President Truman said this afternoon that there would be no cabinet changes at this time and that, having asked Secetary of State George C. Marshall and James Forrestal, Secretary of Defense, to retain their portfolios, they were willing.
Twenty-five hundred schoolboys joined yesterday in the drive to clean up the streets and vacant lots of Harlem. They brought pomp and pageantry to the effort.

Due to large purchases by Italy, France, the United Kingdom and Russia, wool prices in Australia have advanced from 15 to 20 per cent since the opening of the wool auctions in September, it was reported yesterday by Curt E. Forstmann, president of the Forstmann Woolen Company, who has returned from a trip to Australia.
ENID, Okla., Dec. 2 (AP) -- The Air Force raced a half-blind baby toward New York tonight to save his one remaining eye from a quick-spreading malignant tumor.
WETUMPKA, Ala., Dec. 2 (AP) -- An all-white Alabama jury sent a white man to prison for forty-five years tonight for the rape of a young Negro woman.
Activity and strength were evident yesterday in coffee futures contract "D" on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange. March delivery was the exception, declining 6 points for the day.

Led by newspapers, major advertising media recorded in October the largest dollar expenditures for national advertising on record, it was reported yesterday by Printers' Ink. The newspapers' gain was 30 per cent over the comparable month of last year, and 6 per cent above the September level.
The Board of Estimate voted yesterday to defer action "without date" on a new formula for establishing parking lots in shopping sections of the five boroughs.

Economic Cooperation Administrator Paul G. Hoffman and Eric Johnston, a member of the ECA's advisory board, looked at the European Recovery Program this week from two somewhat different points of view, Mr. Hoffman is convinced that the program is working and was able to cite some striking increases in the production of coal, coke, steel, fertilizer and other necessities.

The Columbia University Varsity C Club held its annual dinner in John Jay Hall last night and presented 110 letters in twelve sports to Columbia athletes. But the big surprise of the evening was Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower's request to be allowed to speak.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on Nov. 27 were 723,090 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 134,402 cars or 15.7 per cent fewer than for the preceding week, 69,241 cars, or 8.7 per cent, fewer than for the corresponding week last year and 62,179 cars or 9.4 per cent more than during the corresponding week two years ago.

A 3,600-year-old transcription of a medical treatise written 1,000 or more years earlier, was presented last night to the New York Academy of Medicine by the New York Historical Society and the Brooklyn Museum. It is known as the Edwin Smith Papyrus.
BERLIN, Dec. 2 -- The new Communist city government in the Eastern sector of Berlin received a promise of "full support" from the Soviet command tonight.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- During the week ended Dec. 1 member bank reserve balances decreased $57,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.
PARIS, Dec. 2 (AP) -- Following are excerpts from the speech today of Dr. Philip C. Jessup, United States delegate on the Security Council, urging immediate admission of Israel to the United Nations:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- The Rohm Haas Company, Philadelphia, filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement covering a proposed offering by the Attorney General, office of alien property, of 15,815.80 shares of 4 per cent cumulative preferred stock, series A, and 197,679.13 shares of common stock of the company.

Julius Perlbinder has sold the six-story fifty-nine-family apartment house at 94-06 Thirty-fourth Road, Jackson Heights, Queens, to a client of Peter Gluck, attorney. The property is assessed at $175,000 and was acquired subject to mortgages of $177,000. Herbert Charles Co. were the brokers.

Two veteran nurses who have served the Methodist Hospital in Brooklyn for a total of sixty-seven years were honored last night by their friends and associates at a dinner marking their retirement. The dinner came on the eve of their departure to Florida for a holiday.

Despite the greater business activity this year, carloadings for the nation are expected to show a drop of almost 3.5 per cent below those of 1947. Through Nov. 13, carloadings this year have amounted to 38,302,077, a drop of 1,340,887 from the 39,642,964 reported to that date in 1947.

The Commonwealth of Massachusetts sold yesterday bond issues totaling $6,950,000 to banking Syndicates. A group headed by First Boston Corporation bought $6,090,000 of Harbor Terminal and Metropolitan Water District bonds maturing from Nov. 1, 1949, to 1968 at a bid of 100.15 for 1 1/2s and 1 3/4s, an interest cost of 1.639 per cent.

The National Maritime Union, CIO, in accordance with the dictates of its membership, has commenced compliance with the non-Communist affidavit provision of the Taft-Hartley Law, it was made known yesterday afternoon.

Fire Commissioner Frank J. Quayle received two scrolls at Fire Headquarters yesterday. One came from the volunter fire brigade of Breukelen, the Netherlands, and the other from the Uniformed Fire Officers Association.
Mrs. William Hockenjos Jr. of Baltusrol was re-elected president of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association at its annual meeting yesterday at the Hotel Sheraton.
ST. LOUIS, Dec. 2 -- The American Medical Association plans to raise a $3,500,000 political war chest to fight "socialized medicine."

PARIS, Dec. 2 -- The United States, British and French delegations to the United Nations and their economic advisers are scheduled to meet tomorrow to draft a memorandum containing a list of the measures enacted by Soviet authorities since Sept. 1 to split Berlin, authoritative circles said today.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Dec. 2 -- Religion will never "save the world" as long as it remains aloof from the day-to-day problems of the rank and file layman in the pew, Charles P. Taft declared here tonight in his presidential address to the biennial meeting of the Federal Council of the Churches of Christ in America.

Plans for an expanding state program of higher education were discussed last evening by Governor Dewey, Dr. Oliver C. Carmichael, chairman of the board of trustees of the New York State University. System, and Arthur H. Dean, vice chairman, at a conference in the Governor's suite in the Roosevelt Hotel.

BERKELEY, Calif., Dec. 2 -- Kern County, in the southern part of California's central valley, had its first rainfall in eight months not long ago. Franklin Fenenga, an archeologist of the University of California, was right there in the downpour. And when he returned to Berkeley, the rain came down here in torrents.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- Soviet Ambassador Alexander S. Panyushkin is not precisely a communicative individual, especially with the press, but in recent weeks he has been dispatching communiques to the National Press Club like an enterprising lobbyist.
A squad of football Giants, brimming with good health, confidence and determination, will leave for Pittsburgh today to play its next-to-last game of the season Sunday afternoon against the Steelers.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- President Truman made it unmistakably clear today that he neither sought nor desired the votes of Southern Presidential electors who ran on a pledge to support the States' Rights Democratic ticket.

On Nov. 27 you published an editorial entitled "Adirondack Encroachment" Inasmuch as that editorial contained certain errors of fact, I am writing to correct them and point out certain other items which you apparently overlooked.

Mayor O'Dwyer and three other officials reported to a meeting of 150 Harlem community leaders yesterday their plans for bringing physical improvements to that area, reducing milk prices and lessening racial discrimination, of which the Mayor said there was much evidence in this city.

St. John's figured to win and did, 67-45, against Tennessee last night. New York University figured to lose to Baylor, but achieved a 67-47 upset of the Southwest Conference champions. Thus, the start of the fifteenth season of college basketball at Madison Square Garden was a marked success for the metropolitan teams.
PARIS, Dec. 2 -- The interest of French internal politics centers on the national congress of the Radical party, which opened a four-day session in Paris today.
THE NEW YORK TIMES plans to establish a Foreign Air Edition, to be flown to several European cities, if pending airline applications for lower newspaper airfreight rates are officially approved.

Earl (Red) Blaik, accepting the Lambert Trophy for the fourth time in recent years yesterday in behalf of Army's football team, said: "I don't think we will be back to get it again next year but we will be back some time in the future."
The Board of Estimate adopted yesterday a 1949 capital outlay budget of $336,909,773, the largest in the city's history.

Eric Johnston, president of the Motion Picture Association of America, called on American business men yesterday to "recognize the economic facts of life," and to remove the threat of socialism in America by cooperating in the passage of "soundly conceived" social legislation.
A small glass gadget that looks very much like a coaster for iced drinks has been introduced by Lightolier as the first lighting device that combines the advantages of a louvre shield and a lens.

Your excellent editorial in THE TIMES of Nov. 17 stressing the great need for a reliable fund-raising campaign to undertake the task of collecting adequate funds to relieve the needs of millions of the world's hungry children was most gratifying.

Real estate bond prices eased off 0.3 per cent in November, marking the second successive month of decline, according to Amott, Baker Co. Based on 200 eastern issues, the index showed an average price of $792 for a $1,000 bond on Nov. 30 as compared with $795 on Oct. 31 and $783 at the beginning of the year.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- The Export-Import Bank announced today a loan of $5,000,000 for further development of Steep Rock Iron Mines of Ontario, Canada, as a source of supply for the United States steel industry.

In the previous column this department sought to explain the reasons for the sweeping popularity of modern-day skiing -- a rise probably unprecedented in the annals of sports -- and now we'd like to tell how to prepare for this new ancient activity, which history proves dates from the Stone Age.

It's nice to be of good cheer at the holiday season, Police Commissioner Arthur W. Wallander conceded yesterday, but he would rather that New Yorkers would "be suspicious," at least of strangers, when in crowded shopping centers.
The American Car and Foundry Company and its subsidiaries reported yesterday for the six months ended on Oct. 31, last, net income of $3,601,897 after taxes and all charges.
LONDON, Dec. 2 -- Today's session of the Tribunal of Inquiry into allegations of fraud at the Board of Trade provided a remarkable lesson in how to make a lot of money out of nothing but nerve.

NEW DELHI, India, Dec. 2 -- India accused Pakistan forces today of aggressive action in Kashmir in violation of an undertaking by both dominions with the United Nations Security Council Commission on India and Pakistan not to "aggravate the situation."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- The Transamerica Corporation of San Francisco took the position today that the announcement by Marriner S. Eccles that he had disqualified himself from sitting as a Federal Reserve Board governor during the board's anti-trust proceedings against the corporation was "the phenomenon of a man removing himself from a spot but leaving his shadow behind."

The Trieste Trio displayed some communicative music-making in its American debut at Town Hall last night. The group, Dario De Rosa, piano; Renato Zanettovich, violin, and Libero Lana, 'cello, has been together for fifteen years. The average age is under 28, but the trio plays with discernment beyond its years.

BOSTON, Dec. 2 -- State Auditor Thomas J. Buckley charged the Port of Boston Authority today with "ignoring" a 1945 law in planning construction of the new $3,300,000 pier to replace the Hoosac pier at East Boston.

The American Standards Association, in cooperation with representatives of housewares and food manufacturers and other groups, took first steps yesterday to set up uniform national standards for several kinds of cooking and baking equipment and food mix measuring devices.

This week saw one of the dullest trading periods in months in the wholesale meat market, the Department of Agriculture reported yesterday. A check of city stores by the Department of Markets showed that to some extent at least, retail stores reflected the apathetic demand.

Vitamin B-12, the anti-pernicious anemia vitamin present in minute amounts in liver, has been isolated in crystalline form from the same mold that produces streptomycin, it was announced yesterday by a team of scientists of the research laboratories of Merck Co., Inc., Rahway, N.J.
Plans for the construction of Hyde Park Inn, a restaurant and hotel to be controlled by Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt and her son, Elliott, were announced yesterday by Reisner Urbhan, architects.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- The armies of Italy, a key area in the defense strategy of Western Europe, are at present weak and ill-equipped and will not be effective until they receive new and modern armaments, Gen. Efisio Marras, Chief of the Italian Army General Staff, said today.

Columbia's American Press Institute will open a week-long seminar for seventeen newspaper librarians Monday, it was announced yesterday. It is the first seminar of the institute's regular program to include women in its membership.

District Attorney Hogan's brilliant expose of one of New York's divorce mills has dramatized an existing evil which is one of the most urgent problems of the state. The fraud and perjury which surround New York's divorce courts have been an open secret for many years, but all efforts to eliminate them have been consistently thwarted.
LOS ANGELES, Dec. 2 -- Ohrbach's Inc., New York apparel concern, opened its new $5,000,000 store in the "Miracle mile" Wilshire Boulevard shopping sector today with a spectacular public response.
A woman who jumped from the sixteenth floor of the Pennsylvania Hotel in a suicide attempt yesterday was still alive last night in St. Vincent's Hospital, although her condition was critical.

ROME, Dec. 2 -- Michelangelo's unfinished David, one of the most admired pieces of sculpture in the museum of the "Bargello" in Florence, is about to visit the United States, where it will be exhibited in the National Gallery in Washington.

Each fall brings a fairly large volume of mail from hunters who are interested in going to a race where they will get a shot at a goose, but this year, with the bag and possession limits cut to the minimum, the interest in this bird seems to have reached a new high.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 (AP) -- Federal Judge J. Waties Waring of Charleston, S.C., who attracted national attention by ruling out South Carolina's all-white Democratic primary system, was a caller at the White House today.

Government regulation of some branches of the milk industry was defended yesterday by E.O. Mather, president of the Dellwood Dairy Company, against a charge of "socialization" made by Representative Ralph W. Gwinn, Republican, of the Twenty-seventh Congressional District.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Dec. 2 -- Indications that many real estate men will not go along with the National Association of Real Estate Boards in its uncompromising stand against all forms of public housing appeared here today at the state convention of the New Jersey realty group.

Two youths and a 16-year-old girl were arraigned in Felony Court yesterday after they had been arrested earlier in the day for violation of the Sullivan Law by possessing concealed weapons. The three were seized when a patrolman became suspicious of them as they walked down Park Avenue at 4 o'clock yesterday morning.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- Alexander S. Panyushkin, the Soviet Ambassador, charged today before the Far Eastern Commission that the policy being pursued by the United States in Japan "does not correspond" to the Cairo and Potsdam declarations and to decisions of the Commission.

Expanded activity in this country and increased participation in the international administration of amateur sports were set up by James A. Rhodes, national president yesterday as goals toward which the Amateur Athletic Union of the United States should strive.

ALBANY, Dec. 2 -- In a move aimed at increasing the strength of the New York National Guard, Governor Dewey issued a proclamation today directing that youths between the ages of seventeen and eighteen and one-half years who enlisted in the Guard be exempted from the draft during their period of Guard service.

For the concert of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra last night at Carnegie Hall an unusually impressive program was given under the leadership of Bruno Walter, who was on the podium for the first time this season. Mahler's Second Symphony, with the Westminster Choir, Nadine Conner, soprano, and Jean Watson, contralto, as the assisting participants, was the principal offering.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- I.W. Duggan, governor of the Farm Credit Administration, today turned over to the United States Treasury a dividend check of $10,000,000 on stock held by the Government in the Federal Farm Mortgage Corporation.

LONDON, Dec. 2 (Reuters) -- Harold Wilson, president of the Board of Trade, said tonight that the Americans had made a "very poor showing" in carrying out "one of the essential things underlying the Anglo-American film agreement of last March."

The Board of Estimate approved yesterday a proposed allocation of $2,500,000 of Health Department appropriations to set up a city-wide system of diagnostic clinics for early detection of cancer, heart disease, diabetes, tuberculosis and mental ailments.

GENEVA, Dec. 2 -- The draft of a new convention to govern international highway transport has been approved by a working party representing twelve European nations and the United States meeting in Geneva under the auspices of the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe.

Leading members of the heavy equipment industries have decided to take a firm stand against another round of price increases and are determined to resist increases in copper, lead, brass, zinc and aluminum prices, spokesmen disclosed yesterday at the Eighteenth National Power Show at Grand Central Palace.

Both syphilis and gonorrhea can be stamped out if united world action can be obtained, Dr. William F. Snow, president of the International Union Against Venereal Diseases and chairman of the board of directors of the American Social Hygiene Association, declared yesterday.

PARIS, Oct. 2 -- The Chilean delegation in the Legal Committee of the United Nations General Assembly today began delivery of a 20,000-word attack upon Russia for "violating fundamental human rights, diplomatic practices and principles of the United Nations charter" in preventing Russian wives of foreigners from joining their husbands abroad.
BERLIN, Dec. 2 -- The food rationing program in the Western zones faces the threat of almost complete collapse within the next half year, German and Western Allied food officials said today.

PARIS, Dec. 2 -- A great deal of good old-fashioned lobbying and pressure diplomacy has been going on during the last few days in Paris, Washington, London and other capitals on whether Israel shall be admitted to the United Nations.

The executive committee of the American Jewish Congress called yesterday on the Eighty-first Congress to enact six major amendments to the Displaced Persons Act of 1948 "to bring it into conformity with American democratic practices and principles."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- President Truman expressed the opinion today that business had nothing to fear from his new, four-year administration and offered as evidence his record of the past three and a half years.

As 223 members of feline aristocracy assembled yesterday at the McAlpin Hotel for the thirty-second championship show of New York's Empire Cat Club, the event was overshadowed by the meeting of a waif and her long-sought-for Prince Charming.

Jay D. Runkle, vice president and general manager of Crowley, Milner Co., Detroit, and chairman of the board of directors of the National Retail Dry Goods Association, will receive the association's gold medal award emblematic of distinguished service to the retail trade, it was announced yesterday.

ALBANY, Dec. 2 -- The Court of Appeals reserved decision today on a Tammany-sponsored appeal for an order directing the New York City Boards of Elections and Canvassers to nullify the election of George Frankenthaler, Republican-Liberal party nominee for Surrogate of New York County, and to issue a certificate of election to John A. Mullen, the Democratic nominee.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- The board of directors of the United States Chamber of Commerce called on the Federal Government today to speed up stockpiling of strategic and critical materials for national security. It said the program was "seriously behind schedule."
Musicians by the thousands laid aside their instruments yesterday to vote in one of the most hotly contested elections in the history of Local 802, American Federation of Musicians, AFL.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- Speedy repeal of an enactment by the Republican-led Eightieth Congress which removed an estimated 500,000 to 750,000 workers and their families from the social security program was pledged today by Representative John D. Dingell, Democrat, of Michigan, a key member of the Ways and Means Committee.

ROME, Dec. 2 -- Speaking in the Chamber today in a debate on foreign politics, Palmiro Togliatti, the Communist leader, reserved his heaviest broadside again for the United States and American "warmongers" whom he called "fiends and enemies of the human race."

District Attorney Frank S. Hogan's "all-out" investigation into the "widespread practice" of collusive divorce actions based on perjured testimony gained momentum yesterday when accountants on his staff removed files on 300 uncontested matrimonial actions from the New York County Clerk's office.

SEOUL, Korea, Dec. 2 -- Postponement of discussion of the Korean question in the General Assembly evoked sharp disappointment today in Government quarters here. A Government spokesman said the Government created under the United Nations sponsorship had looked eagerly to Paris for approval and acceptance before the year's end.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- The National Labor Relations Board ruled today that an employer may legally discipline employes who cause a strike in violation of a no-strike agreement, even though the cause of the strike was an unfair labor practice by the employer.

Seasonal considerations again accounted for a drop in lending activities of the banks in New York during the week ended on Wednesday, for the third consecutive time. The weekly condition statement of the New York member banks, issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, showed a drop of $22,000,000 in commercial, industrial and agricultural loans to $5,599,000,000.

The appointment of Dr. Karl W. Bigelow, Professor of Education at Teachers College, Columbia University, to represent the National Conference of Christians and Jews on the Unite States National Commission for the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization was announced yesterday.

To commemorate the printing of the first lithograph just 150 years ago in 1798, the Metropolitan Museum of Art will open to the public today an exhibition of nearly 200 lithographs from Europe, Mexico and the United States.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Dec. 2 -- Damascus was an armed camp today, with its streets heavily patrolled and machine-guns at strategic points while President Shukri al-Kuwatly of Syria was trying vainly to have a new cabinet formed, according to a message received here tonight.
In an attempt to obtain well-adjusted, emotionally stable and intellectually alert teachers, the New York City Board of Examiners is placing greater stress on the personality traits of applicants.

Jean-Paul Sartre's "Red Gloves," starring Charles Boyer in his first stage appearance in this country, win open here tonight at the Mansfield. Jean Dalrymple is presenting the Jed Harris production of the play by the French author, whose name is closely associated with the philosophy of existentialism.

As its fifth production of the new season, the Metropolitan Opera last night presented an opera that has only been skipped for three seasons in the last thirty-four years, Verdi's "Il Trovatore." And it was run off with the smoothness and skill of a work in which every one has had lots of practice.
Christmas will be a little merrier for some of New York's needy children and for the men for whom the war is not over, as a result of two drives started here yesterday.

CINCINNATI, Dec. 3 -- A statement condemning racial segregation in all its ramifications and calling upon the churches of this country to press for the extension of full social, economic and political rights to every citizen without discrimination as to race, color, creed or sex was overwhelmingly adopted here today by the Federal Council of the Churches of Christ in America.

CAMDEN, N.J., Dec. 3 -- Attorney General Walter D. Van Riper petitioned the New Jersey Superior Court today to nullify the $12,400,000 deal in which the Tacony-Palmyra and Burlington-Bristol Bridges across the Delaware were sold to the recently created Burlington County Bridge Commission.
Staff members representing 300 high school publications in the metropolitan area attended the ninth annual conference on school publications yesterday at New York University.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 (AP) -- Dennis A. Fitzgerald, food and agriculture director of the Economic Cooperation Administration, said tonight that Britain will have to renegotiate almost $50,000,000 in cotton purchase contracts with American exporters.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 3 -- Rita Hayworth has been suspended from salary because she failed to report to Columbia yesterday for the leading role in "Lona Hanson," the studio announced today. She had been instructed to come to the studio for wardrobe and make-up tests, the picture being

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- Average primary market prices advanced 0.1 per cent in the week ended Nov. 30, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. The index is now 165.1 per cent of the 1926 average, 0.5 per cent higher than four weeks ago and 2.5 per cent higher than in the comparable week in 1947.

Dormitory students at Barnard College, Columbia University, may have to pay increased rent or help to clean their own rooms and perform other maintenance duties, it was announced yesterday after a conference at the girls' institution.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- On the plea that large quantities of petroleum are being drained away the Federal Government asked the Supreme Court today to expedite the examination as to whether California or the Government owns certain oil lands.

A committee of Protestants from churches of the city is being formed to raise funds to maintain the Wiltwyck School for Boys, Esopus, N.Y., and The Training School and Home for Young Girls, 1483 Pacific Street, Brooklyn, under the auspices of the Commission on Human Relations of the Protestant Council of the City of New York.
The labor dispute that has beset the Manhattan and Brooklyn stores of Oppenheim Collins Co. for several months appeared to be settled last night.

A 15 per cent increase in basic wages and overtime pay was sought yesterday morning by the National Maritime Union, CIO, at the first of a series of meetings with shipowners' representatives at a contractual semi-annual wage review.

PARIS, Dec. 3 -- The United States Government, it is understood, has made it clear to five members of the Western Union alliance that it desires inclusion of Italy in any Atlantic pact resulting from present negotiations for an over-all occidental alliance.

Defending the patriotism and purpose of American colleges and universities, Dr. Robert C. Clothier, president of Rutgers University, declared yesterday that professors were not communistic nor were they engaged in subversive propaganda.

PARIS, Dec. 3 -- The Radical party had to call out today its heavy guns to check a split over "divided loyalty" between members of this leading, center, Cabinet group and some of its partisans who also favor the movement of Charles de Gaulle, the Reunion of the French People.
SEOUL, Korea, Dec. 3 -- President Syngman Rhee today declared postponement of discussion of the Korean question by the United Nations would prove a severe blow to democracy in Korea.

BERLIN, Dec. 3 -- The United States, British and French Military Governments are expected to introduce the Western Deutsche mark as the only legal currency in the Western sectors of this city before the end of this year.

Secretary of Commerce Charles Sawyer, in a conciliatory speech approved by President Truman, reassured American business last night that it had no reason to fear the program being planned at Washington, although he indicated that further military expenditures might mean more economic controls and higher taxes.

The first complete English translation of "Essay on the True Art of Playing Keyboard Instruments," by Carl Philipp Emanuel Bach, second son of Johann Sebastian Bach, will be published Monday by Norton. It presents the practice of music in the time of Frederick the Great, with 480 musical illustrations.

The more than half-a-million Arab refugees in the Levant who lack food, blankets and shelter will soon receive adequate aid to assure their survival. Stantan Griffis, United States Ambassador to Egypt, declared yesterday at La Guardia Field after a fifteen-day visit to the United States made expressly to discuss the Arab refugee problem.

Another step to eliminate traffic jams aggravated by parked cars was taken yesterday by Police Commissioner Arthur W. Wallander when he ordered daytime parking barred on three more major north-south arteries in heavily congested mid-Manhattan.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- French Ambassador Henri Bonnet delivered to Under Secretary of State Robert A. Lovett today what was described as an urgent note setting forth definite proposals for the control and operation of the Ruhr industries.
PITTSBURGH, Dec. 3 (AP) -- A group of Pittsburgh industrialists today organized for a campaign aimed at legalizing the traditional "basing point" method of selling steel and other goods.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 3 (AP) -- Southern California's loyal Trojan rooters hit a high pitch in their home-coming celebration today, fully aware that the party may flatten out along about sundown tomorrow after the football team finishes its encounter with Notre Dame.
MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 3 (AP) -- The Vanderbilt Commodores routed the outclassed University of Miami Hurricanes, 33 to 6, tonight in the Orange Bowl before 28,952 football fans.

Retail trade here this week again showed a decline despite the "official" start of the Christmas shopping season. Department store sales were estimated as about 7 per cent below the corresponding week last year. Sales last week also were down 7 per cent.

Another Congressman -- an official representative of the United States -- said this week after a visit to Spain that the United States must recognize Spain's strategic importance and should help that country economically and militarily.
Members of Local 15, Bartenders Union, AFL, will vote tomorrow whether to strike at 8 o'clock Monday morning against 700 bars, grills and restaurants in Manhattan, it was announced yesterday.

Negligent tenants, absentee landlords, the housing situation and the State Legislature were held responsible for deplorable sanitation conditions in East Harlem at a conference of community leaders held yesterday at Benjamin Franklin High School, 115th Street and Pleasant Avenue.
The nineteenth annual Christmas bazaar of the Japanese Methodist Church and Institute. 323 West 108th Street, which was kept going all through the war, opened yesterday morning for two days.

The Boy Scouts of America installed Troop 111 last night at the Lighthouse, the New York Association for the Blind, 111 East Fifty-ninth Street. Three of the ten new Scouts are sightless and the others have only slight vision. The Lighthouse will be sponsor for the troop.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Dec. 3 (AP) -- Severe economic depression is practically an impossibility now, Dr. Theodore O. Yntema of Chicago, research director of the Committee for Economic Development, said today at a luncheon of the Bond Club.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Dec. 3 -- It was learned tonight that a new obstacle had arisen in protracted negotiations for an Anglo-Yugoslav trade agreement -- an agreement of vital importance to the Yugoslavs in their present economic difficulties -- that might delay indefinitely the final signing.
PARIS, Dec. 3 -- The United Nations General Assembly was told officially today that it did not stand a chance of finishing its work by the target closing date of Dec. 11.

By revising constantly its large file on the courses preferred and studied by adults in some 2,000 public and private institutions, and by revamping its program frequently to meet these preferences, the New York Adult Education Council, at 254 Fourth Avenue, New York 10, has proved itself deserving of the $125,000 it needs from the public to help carry on its work.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- The armed services expressed various degrees of "support" of the forthcoming unified military budget today and indicated they would refrain from pleading their separate cases before the public.

Committee ratification of bids by Fresno, Calif., for the men's outdoor track and field championships, Oklahoma City for the men's basketball tournament and Boston for the boxing tournament indicate those major title meets will be so awarded at the National Amateur Athletic Union convention today.
