BETHLEHEM, Pa., Dec. 3 (AP) -- A man-made star so bright it can be seen for twenty-five miles shone down tonight on Bethlehem.
YONKERS, N.Y., Dec. 3 -- City Controller John A. Peterson was designated Acting City Manager tonight by the Common Council and he accepted.

ROME, Dec. 3 -- Foreign Minister Count Carlo Sforza today accused Russia's Balkan allies -- Hungary, Bulgaria and Rumania -- of breaking the peace treaties limiting their armed forces. He told the Chamber of Deputies some important rearmament was proceeding with Russian aid.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 (AP) -- Dennis A. Fitzgerald, food and agriculture director of the Economic Cooperation Administration, said tonight Britain would have to renegotiate almost $50,000,000 in cotton purchase contracts with American exporters.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Dec. 3 -- Damascus, capital of Syria, virtually was cut off from the rest of the world tonight, with the military in full control and a curfew imposed from 6 P.M. to 6 A.M. Disorders were reported in Homs and elsewhere in Syria, with an unknown number of casualties.

The New York, A.C. basketball team won its second straight victory when it defeated the Fordham University quintet, 61 -- 53 last night before a capacity crowd on the N.Y.A.C. court. The game was the first for the Rams this season.

The name Monte Pignatore had little meaning to the spectators in the Court of Special Sessions, Brooklyn, yesterday. But to Justice Bernard A. Kozicke, a prizefight fan, it brought back memories of a hard-hitting Bay Ridge lightweight who always put up a good battle in the ring.

ST. LOUIS, Dec. 3 (AP) -- A verdict for $290,000 was returned by a Federal court jury tonight in favor of Mrs. Beulah Greenwalt Walcher in her $400,000 suit against Loew's, Inc., maker of the war movie "They Were Expendable."

PRAGUE, Dec. 3 -- The Czechoslovak Cabinet completed today a law for the reorganization of the police. Conflict over control of the police led to the February crisis and the installation of the present Government.

Four eastbound Long Island Rail Road commuter trains from Pennsylvania Station were canceled last night and seven other eastbound trains were delayed from seven to twenty-five minutes when a westbound train from Port Washington became stalled in an East River tunnel at 6:02 P.M., blocking it for more than forty-five minutes and causing a shortage of empty cars to make up eastbound trains, the railroad announced.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- The loyalty investigations invoked by the Federal Government on Oct. 1, 1947, have led to the dismissal or resignation of about 400 persons, the Civil Service Commission reported today. It added that the actual figure might be less than that total.

Gen. Joseph T. McNarney, Commanding General of the Air Materiel Command at Wright Field, warned yesterday that while America must not consider itself prepared for push-button warfare, it "can no longer afford to fight a war of the future with the strategy, tactics and the conventional weapons of the last."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 (AP) -- Representative Emanuel Celler, Democrat, of New York, plans to "get after" insurance companies, which he calls a "menace to the economy of the nation." He told reporters today he wants the House Judiciary Committee to make a "full investigation" of insurance concerns with the aim of "curbing their powers."

Three newcomers and a veteran exhibitor are among interesting artists whose shows opened this week. Making their New York debuts are Jay Robinson at the Milch Galleries, Edna Hibel at the John Levy Galleries, and Lucia at the Sidney Janis Gallery.

A disposition among sports leaders in this country to lift the sanctions imposed on the vanquished nations was evident yesterday as the sixtieth annual convention of the Amateur Athletic Union of the United States swung into full stride at the Hotel Astor, with nearly 400 officials and delegates in attendance.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Dec. 3 -- The provisional Government of Israel has withdrawn its application to join the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization, Director General Julian Huxley announced tonight.

The best-laid plans of Miss Addie H. Summerson, who retired yesterday as assistant executive secretary of the American Museum of Natural History after forty years' service, to "sneak out quietly" on her last day, went very much astray.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Dec. 3 -- Strange occurrences all week in the vicinity of the County Center here, with policemen racing over dark highways, finding two "corpses," making plaster casts of footprints and automobile tracks, turning huge floodlights onto woodland thickets, and finally finding themselves held up by an armed man, was explained tonight.
SHANGHAI, Saturday, Dec. 4 (AP) -- Up to 3,000 refugees from war-torn Central China were feared drowned today when an overloaded ship sank after an explosion near the mouth of the Yangtze River.

LAKE SUCCESS, Dec. 3 -- Two hundred and fifty Protestant orphan children now under the care of the International Refugee Organization in Germany, where they were found after the war, have received an offer from the Lutheran World Federation to sponsor their resettlement in the United States, William Hallam Tuck, director general of the refugee organization, announced in Geneva today.

In cooperation with three other agencies, the Board of Education is conducting "pilot" classes in which, for the first time, children who suffer from cerebral palsy receive training in a normal school environment.

DETROIT, Dec. 3 (AP) -- Al Fallon, Detroit manufacturer whose Miss Great Lakes won the 1948 Gold Cup emblematic of the national speedboat racing championship, said today he had not been approached with any offer to shift the 1949 cup defense away from Detroit.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 3 (AP) -- Governor-elect Fuller Warren of Florida and a party of legislators were among 5,607 fans who witnessed the racing at Tropical Park today. Wagering totaled only $252,583 for the eight events.

The Columbia Broadcasting System, which a week ago announced the acquisition of the Jack Benny program, has initiated negotiations to obtain the "Fibber McGee and Molly" show, another mainstay on the NBC schedule, it was learned yesterday.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., Dec. 3 -- The military draft has had a "paralyzing effect" on the apprenticeship program, William Patterson, Washington, D.C., director of the United States Bureau of Apprenticeship, told the annual convention of the American Vocational Association here today.

SAN DIEGO, Calif., Dec. 3 (AP) -- Three United States tuna clippers were fired on by an "unidentified plane" off the coast of Nicaragua yesterday morning. Harold Cary, executive manager of the American Tunaboat Association, reported today.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- Mme. Chiang Kai-shek conferred for nearly four hours today with Secretary of State Marshall at Walter Reed Hospital and told reporters later that the talks had been encouraging.

When two men, identified as Jack Gordon, 40 years old, and Edward Eichler, 49, were arraigned in Felony Court yesterday on a narcotics charge, Assistant District Attorney Paul F. Reilly asked Magistrate Samuel Orr for more time to complete investigation of the case.
CINCINNATI, Dec. 3 (AP) -- James C. Petrillo, president of the American Federation of Musicians, today sent word to the American Guild of Variety Artists to "lay off our members."

STOCKHOLM, Dec. 3 -- The Swedish imports program for the next year was approved today by the Cabinet. Imports will total the equivalent of $1,170,000,000 an 18 per cent paring of the current year's imports, which were slightly below those of 1947.

LONDON, Dec. 3 -- The United States will have to look to its laurels in the television field if British enthusiasts who brought the matter up in the House of Commons today have their way. Several members of Parliament warned the Government that the United States was setting a faster pace than Britain and asked what was being done to promote the export of British television sets and transmitters.

TOKYO, Dec. 3 -- All the major Japanese political parties have begun feverishly to prepare for a new general election -- the first since April, 1947 -- which, they are now assured, will be held in January of next year.
LONDON, Dec. 3 -- Activity in the stock markets here declined today under the influence of the uncertainties of Berlin.

A 15-year-old boy who had spent the evening playing basketball in a Bronx community center was shot and seriously wounded at 8:45 o'clock last night as he left the center in the Franklin Junior High School 55, on St. Paul's Place between Washington and Park Avenues.

ST. LOUIS, Dec. 3 -- Leaders of the American Medical Association prepared today to map a campaign to defeat Federal proposals for national compulsory health insurance as the AMA ended its annual four-day interim meeting.

ATHENS, Dec. 3 -- The Communist-led guerrilla forces that were beaten and scattered two days ago in a large-scale engagement in eastern Macedonia, near Serres, were reported today to have been defeated again by Greek Army units.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- President Truman took new steps today to reduce traffic fatalities on the country's highways in 1949. In a letter to Maj. Gen. Philip B. Fleming, Federal Works Administrator, the Chief Executive said that he would call a President's highway Safety Conference in 1949.
BERLIN, Dec. 3 -- Friedrich Ebert, Communist Mayor of the new Eastern Government for Berlin, acknowledged today the Soviet Military Administration as "the only authority" for his administration.

District Attorney Frank S. Hogan announced the arrest yesterday of Joseph Mandell, 49 years old, of 215 West Eightieth Street, vice president of Bonne Mandell, Inc., furriers, who had been indicted on eight counts of grand larceny, seven counts of filing false ship manifests and one count of conspiracy.

Elsewhere on this page we print a letter from Mr. Athanassov, Bulgarian Charge d'Affaires in Washington, replying to our editorial "The Balkan Terror." We pass over the remarks of Mr. Athanassov regarding the policies and practices of the country to which he is accredited, preferring to leave judgment of their validity to our readers and of their propriety to the State Department.

VIENNA, Dec. 3 -- Austria expects to receive $3,270,000 worth of cotton from the United States under the Marshall Plan for sale to Hungary to help promote trade between Austria and the Eastern bloc states.

Battering Jake LaMotta of the Bronx came back to Madison Square Garden fistic activity last night after a lapse of a year and celebrated by hammering the championship aspirations out of Tommy Yarosz, Monaca, Pa., middleweight, a younger brother of Teddy Yarosz, former champion of the division.

DETROIT, Dec. 3 -- The $100,000,000 Willow Run plant, erected by the Government for the production of bombers during the war, has been purchased by the Kaiser-Frazer Corporation for $15,100,000, it was disclosed today by the company.
ALBANY, Dec. 3 -- State care for children who are psychopathic, emotionally disturbed, or of border-line mentality was asked today by the New York State Association of Judges of Children's Courts.

Jorge Bolet, Cuban pianist, has become an artist of outstanding merits both as technician and interpreter, as was conclusively proved by his remarkable negotiation of a highly varied program last night at Carnegie Hall.

CHICAGO, Dec. 3 -- The two top-ranking officials of the Congress of Industrial Organizations in this area rejected invitations today to speak at the opening of the Transport Workers Union convention here next Monday. Their action was unprecedented in CIO annals.
ALBANY, Dec. 3 -- The validity of the election of George Frankenthaler on Nov. 2 as New York County Surrogate was unanimously affirmed today by the Court of Appeals. There was no opinion.

Columbia will present a starting five consisting of two returning lettermen, two sophomores, and a junior when it opens its forty-ninth basketball season against Kings Point in the Morningside Heights gymnasium tonight. The game will get under way at 8:30.

ROME, Dec. 3 -- Foreign Minister Carlo Sforza strongly defended his policy of friendship for the Western democracies today in reply to speakers who had attacked it in the current debate on foreign politics in the Chamber of Deputies.

Members of the University of Michigan Club last night paid their respects to Benny Oosterbaan, who has completed his first season as head coach of the powerful Michigan football team. The occasion was a dinner at the Downtown A.C., attended by 300 persons.

LONDON, Dec. 3 -- Official contact was established today for the first time between the United States Air Force in Europe and the newly created Air Forces of Western Europe, which represents the combined air power of the five Brussels treaty powers, Britain, France, Belgium, the Netherlands and Luxembourg.

PARIS, Dec. 3 -- In the event that the United Nations General Assembly decides to close the present session on Dec. 11 or 12, the United States delegation is expected to propose that discussion on the question of the former Italian colonies be deferred to a special session in February, well-informed sources said this evening.

The 103-year-old Fordham University Church, completely, remodeled and redecorated, will be dedicated as a War Memorial to the 229 sons of Fordham who died in World War II, by Cardinal Spellman on Wednesday, Feast of the Immaculate Conception.
Cotton futures were steady on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday and final prices were 10 to 17 points net higher.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- The Treaty of Rio de Janeiro, binding nations of the Western Hemisphere to mutual defense against any and all aggression, became operative at 12:27 P.M. today.

Seeking to keep inventories at a safe level, dry goods jobbers are exercising caution in the matter of new purchases, it was learned yesterday. Inventory-taking at the end of November, according to Worth Street sources, showed that most wholesalers had been successful in reducing their stocks in the previous ninety days.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 (AP) -- President Truman will travel to Norfolk, Va., this week-end for a ceremony aboard the battleship named for his State of Missouri.
Following are excerpts from an address by Secretary of Commerce Charles Sawyer last night before the fifty-third Congress of American Industry:

Net income of the Food Machinery and Chemical Corporation for the first nine months of this year declined to $5,191,853 from $5,328,348 in the 1947 period, as a result of a smaller sales volume and a narrowing margin of profit based on increased costs of labor and material, Paul L. Davies, president, reported yesterday.

When the Christian churches again preach honestly the basic truths of Christianity they will regain their grip on the people, the Rev. Dr. Bryan Green, the leading evangelist of the Anglican Church, said yesterday.
ATLANTA, Dec. 3 (AP) -- Gov. Herman Talmadge said today that he would protect the wife of a murdered Negro against lynching by "calling out the National Guard if necessary."
Three hundred young army pigeons were the principals yesterday in a pre-Christmas season United States Savings Bond rally on the steps of the general post-office here.

CAIRO, Dec. 3 -- Brig. Gen. William E. Riley of the United States Marine Corps, Chief of Staff for the acting United Nations Mediator, said on his arrival here from Haifa today that the Negeb was quiet, that the Jerusalem ceasefire was "very hopeful" and that he felt that "we now have an opportunity to clean up the situation and have peace."

WE have with us this morning two men of art who have created absolutely complete worlds of the imagination -- as all true artists do. Happily enough, the worlds they have made are utopias, of sorts, staggeringly different from, and with all the appropriate disrespects to, the world we know. In them the ordinary perplexities that hamper, hobble and harass existence are amiably thrust aside in favor of extraordinary ones.

ST. DONAT, Que., Dec. 3 -- Despite the scarcity of snow -- most unusual in the Laurentians at this time of year -- the Canadian Ski Instructors Alliance ski school launched its week-long period of rigorous examinations today at picturesque Jasper-in-Quebec.

ALBANY, Dec. 3 (AP) -- Elmer Rice, the playwright, has protested as "censorship" the Albany County District Attorney's threat to prosecute distributors of comic books and magazines he contends violate state law. Mr. Rice is chairman of the National Council on Freedom from Censorship, which is affiliated with the American Civil Liberties Union.

New serving accessories gay in color and pattern are ready for holiday entertainments. Aware of the ever-increasing popularity of buffet service, designers both here and abroad seem to favor extra-large-size serving pieces and drinking accessories.

Clair Bee has been coaching top-flight basketball teams at Long Island University for seventeen years. Over that period, such outstanding court aces as Marius Russo, Dolly Stark, Ken Norton, Jules Bender, Irv Torgoff, to mention a few, were developed by the wily mentor of the Brooklyn Blackbirds.

Advertising in the eight major New York City newspapers during November totaled 14,523,288 lines, a gain of 2.57 per cent over the like period of last year, an analysis of Media Records showed yesterday. Categories recording gains were automotive, up 36.52 per cent; financial, 16.73 per cent; classified, 5.26 per cent, and retail, 2 per cent.

Regarding the traffic situation in New York City, especially in midtown Manhattan, I wish to comment on the areas between Forty-third and Forty-sixth Streets between Ninth and Twelfth Avenues, where the signs state "No Parking on This Side." It really is a shame that the city wastes these signs since they do not bother to enforce them.

At the close of the third annual convention of the American Veterans Committee the slogan of the organization, "Citizens First, Veterans Second," is still the guidepost for its motives and activities. In the few years of its existence the AVC, composed of veterans of the Second World War, has shown a strong sense of balance by its legislative support of forward-looking measures for the benefit of the citizen and the citizen-veteran.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- Legislation to strengthen the Marshall Plan, including a broad authorization for the purchase of essential defense materials, will be sought of the new Congress.

In your editorial of Nov. 24 entitled "The Balkan Terror" you comment on the recent trial of nine "Socialists" in Bulgaria and state that "all rights and freedom have disappeared and the Communist dictatorship rules supreme."
PARIS, Dec. 3 -- The United Nations Little Assembly received another year of life today in the face of clear Soviet-bloc announcements that the boycott of the last ten months would continue.

CHICAGO, Dec. 3 -- There was no material pressure today on the wheat market on the Board of Trade, and buying by houses with Southwestern connections lifted the December 1 5/8 cents a bushel at one time to a new high since Feb. 4. Despite profit-taking the close was up 1 1/8 to 1 3/8 cents net.

Two of the things that interest Mrs. Harriet de Onis most when she visits a South or Central American country are its literature and its cuisine. About her more erudite enthusiasm, she has just written a book, "The Golden Land: An Anthology of Latin American Folklore in Its Literature."

Samuel Johnson Woolf -- "Sam" to almost everyone who had ever met him -- didn't want a permanent salaried job and never held one. He was a free lancer in the way he worked and in the way he attacked life. We on this newspaper, however, felt that he was particularly ours.
BUCHAREST, Rumania, Dec. 3 -- Three days of disorders between Zionists and non-Zionists here and in Iasi (Jassy), Moldavia, have resulted in casualties but no fatalities.

Swimming and Bob Kiphuth have been synonymous for more than three decades, so it is little wonder that graduates and students will join in honoring the stocky, gray-haired Director of Athletics as the fiftieth year of swimming is celebrated this weekend at Yale University.

Cigarette consumption during the current fiscal year will exceed 385,000,000,000, a new high record, according to a study of the tobacco industry just completed by Fiduciary Counsel, Inc., 40 Wall Street, results of which were made Available here yesterday.
ALBANY, Dec. 3 (AP) -- Hereafter, if you fall into a hole in a sidewalk you need not worry about the depth in suing to collect for injuries.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- The Central Illinois Electric and Gas Company, Rockford, Ill., filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement covering 30,000 shares of additional common stock that it proposes to offer to its common stockholders at $15 a share.
Mayor O'Dwyer proclaimed yesterday the seven days beginning Monday as Diabetes Detection Week and urged the public to cooperate with the medical profession by getting physical check-ups.

Officials of the Westchester Electric Railroad Company and the Westchester Street Transportation Company, Inc., estimated at a Public Service Commission hearing yesterday that the proposed interim increase in single-zone fares from 5 to 7 cents would raise yearly passenger revenues by $297,305.

Having finished the task of setting their house in order with the signing of managers, supervisors, scouts and all else that goes into the operation of their vast baseball empire, the Yankees are about ready to tackle their major objective for 1949, that of strengthening the Bombers on the field.

The Brooklyn Football Dodgers devoted most of their practice session at Cedarhurst, L.I., yesterday to pass defense against the expected aerial onslaught by Otto Graham of the Cleveland Browns, tomorrow. The season's largest Ebbets Field football crowd may turn out to watch the finale of the local All-America Conference campaign.
An Air Forces' mercy flight from Oklahoma delivered to the care of New York eye specialists yesterday forenoon a 7-month-old boy whose remaining eye is being attacked by a malignant tumor.

Paul Makovsky's career as a violinist has had more than its share of vicissitudes. His first Town Hall appearance, in 1940 at the age of 19, was delayed by wartime transportation difficulties, and it was not until two years ago that he was again heard.

CHICAGO, Dec. 3 -- The Inland Steel Company will increase its steel ingot capacity by 15 to 20 per cent and will enlarge its facilities for producing tin mill products, Wilfred Sykes, president, announced today. Portions of the programs have been started.

The copper supply in this country is in the most critical condition of recent years and emergency action should be taken by the Economic Cooperation Administration to spur output of foreign copper, especially in Africa, C. Donald Dallas, chairman of the board of Revere Copper and Brass, Inc., declared in an interview at his offices yesterday.

Directors of the Connecticut General Life Insurance Company increased its quarterly dividend yesterday with the declaration of 50 cents a share, in addition to a special dividend of 30 cents which are both payable Jan. 3. Quarterly dividends of 40 cents have been paid since Jan. 2, this year when the rate was advanced from 35 cents.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 3 -- Pickets were missing this afternoon from West Coast waterfronts for the first time in ninety-two days. The maritime strike, second longest in this coast's history, was declared ended at noon by the five unions involved, and hope was expressed that ships could begin moving early next week.

Today's events: Little Orchestra Society Young People's Concert; Thomas K. Scherman, conductor; Claudette Sorel, piano, Hunter College Auditorium, 11 A.M.; "Mignon," at 2 and "Rigoletto" at 8:30 (the latter for the benefit of the Hebrew National Orphan Home)
One of the rarities of sport challenge match for the world championship in court tennis, will start today at the Racquet and Tennis Club on Park Avenue.

PARIS, Dec. 3 -- The Political and Security Committee of the United Nations General Assembly virtually completed action tonight on the resolution that would give to the proposed conciliation commission a virtually free hand in its efforts to work out a permanent settlement in Palestine.

NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 3 -- The role of Chicago University in the projected art and cultural center for Chicago will be auxiliary, rather than exclusive, Dr. Robert M. Hutchins, the university president, explained here today on a visit with Carol M. Shanks, president of the Prudential Insurance Company.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- The House Committee on Un-American Activities declared tonight that it had "definite proof of one of the most extensive espionage rings in the history of the United States" and that it possessed "microfilm copies of documents of tremendous importance" which had been removed from the State Department for transmission to "Russian Communist agents."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 (UP) -- Oscar R. Ewing, Federal Security Administrator, today assailed as "futile and tragic" the American Medical Association's plan to spend $3,500,000 for health education and to combat compulsory health insurance.

In your excellent editorial in THE NEW YORK TIMES for Dec. 1, where you discussed the vacancy in the Court of Appeals of this state caused by the resignation of Judge Thacher because of his failing health, you point out aptly that "the best available person" should be designated by the Governor to fill this highly important vacancy.

SAN BRUNO, Calif., Dec. 3 (AP) -- Citation, wonder horse of the American turf, made his West Coast debut an impressive one today when he ran away from four rival 3-year-olds in the $5,000 Challenge Purse at Tanforan. The Calumet Farm champion, defeated only once in nineteen starts this year, won the six-furlong dash in the good time of 1:12 on a muddy track.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 (UP) -- President Truman and his daughter Margaret tonight gave a piano duet rendition of the "Jenny Lind Polka" at the National Press Club's first father-daughter banquet.

By a narrow margin the incumbent administration of Local 802, American Federation of Musicians, AFL, has been returned to office in one of the most fiercely fought elections in the union's history, it was announced yesterday.

Nat Moss, 55-year-old former president of the 400 Restaurant, Inc., was sentenced yesterday to a year and a day in Federal prison for failing to pay $62,000 cabaret taxes. The sentence was imposed by Judge Samuel H. Kaufman, who said in answer to a plea for clemency "punishment is called for and an example has to be made of persons who are delinquent in their taxes."
Herb Seidell, veteran center from Indianapolis, yesterday was chosen by members of the varsity to captain Fordham's 1949 football team.

NANKING, Dec. 3 -- The Nationalist evacuation of Suchow, which was officially confirmed here today, has caused Gen. Chen Yi to pull back his Communist forces to cope with three Nationalist Army groups that are now moving south from that northern Kiangsu railway junction.

District Attorney Frank S. Hogan successfully moved yesterday for a two-month extension of the November Grand Jury now investigating evidence of collusive divorce actions presented by his office even as it was learned that the Association of the Bar of the City of New York would press for more liberal divorce legislation in this state.

" Live Today for Tomorrow," starring Fredric March and his wife, Florence Eldridge, with Edmond O'Brien and Geraldine Brooks, will open this morning at Loew's Criterion. The drama, produced by Universal-International, is based on the novel "The Mills of God," by Ernest Lothar, and was directed by Michael Gordon.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, Dec. 3 -- A United States Military Government directive just issued provides for the abolition of all existing German licensing laws in the United States zone, except those affecting public health, safety or welfare, unless they are brought into conformity with the requirements of a free economy before Dec. 20.

Fresh buying in the final hour on the Stock Exchange returned an indecisive market yesterday to the recovery trail. Gains of fractions to a point were spread liberally through the list at the finish under the leadership of the industrials, while the composite rate gained 0.69 point.

Looking ahead to 1952, college rowing coaches called for a new deal on the next American Olympic Rowing Committee yesterday and recommended that the Olympic distance be lengthened from 2,000 to 2,500 meters for eight-oared crews.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Dec 3 -- A $1,100,000 suit charging libel was filed today in Superior Court in Trenton against The Newark (N.J.) Evening News by Edgar H. Rossbach, former United States Attorney for the District of New Jersey, it was reported here by Ruan Saros, attorneys for the plaintiff. Eleven counts in the suit ask compensatory damages of $100,000 each.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- An American Federation of Labor committee, headed by President William Green, outlined a labor legislative program today to Secretary of Labor Maurice J. Tobin at its first session on this subject since the election.

A new and wholesome treatment of the subject of discrimination has been offered by THE TIMES. Sports columnist Arthur Daley writes: "The election of Jackson as Yale captain is a momentous event. However, the congratulations of this reporter don't go to the Eli players who named him as much as they go to Levi for meriting the honor."
BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 3 (UP) -- President Juan D. Peron today rededicated Argentina to a struggle for world peace so that the peoples may not be "dragged to the disaster of new wars."

GLENS FALLS, N.Y., Dec. 3 (AP) -- The Glens Falls insurance group reported today that premiums written during the nine months ended on Sept. 30 totaled $32,727,681. This represented an increase of about $2,000,000 over the amount written for the same period of 1947.

First post-war retail price cutting of refrigerators has begun on a substantial scale in the city, dealers and distributors disclosed yesterday. They attribute the practice to heavy dealer inventories resulting from the serious sales slump in the last thirty days.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 (AP) -- Prompt action on the railroads' plea for an "emergency" freight rate increase was indicated by the Interstate Commerce Commission today.

About a quarter of Shakespeare's "Hamlet" can be discovered in the Cherry Lane Theatre, where the New York Repertory Group is currently mounting a production. The missing three-quarters are not so much the text as the acting. For the most part the actors do not
KALAMAZOO, Mich., Dec. 3 (AP) -- A Congressional subcommittee joined state officials today in an investigation of a dawn raid on two struck plants of the Shakespeare Company here Wednesday.

ATLANTIC CITY, Dec. 3 -- Concerned over declining residential sales to war veterans and the failure of many mortgage institutions in the state to participate in home financing under the "GI" Bill of Rights, the New Jersey Association of Real Estate Boards will ask all the lending agencies to subscribe "the proper proportion" of their assets to support this program.

Outside the yard there stood a telephone pole. Antedating the house itself, it differed from other poles in the line mainly by being much grayer and showing more scars by the linesmen's spikes. It had stood so long that even the cool corporation which set it up regarded it with considerable affection and regularly twice a year sent a man around to tap it and listen, like a doctor with a stethoscope.

A vacant plot about 175 by 200 feet at the northwest corner of Warner and Railroad Avenues in Roslyn, L.I., has been purchased by Warner-Roslyn Heights, Inc., from the Roslyn Park Foundation, Inc., for cash above a purchase money mortgage of $30,000.

Audrey Department Stores, Inc., has purchased the five-story building containing six stores, three offices and six apartments on a lot 20 by 85 feet at 824 Lexington Avenue, northwest corner of Sixty-third Street, from the trustees of Anna G. Bryan in a deal negotiated by the M. Morgenthau-Seixas Company.

B.E. Hutchinson, chairman of the finance committee of the Chrysler Corporation, urged the National Association of Manufacturers yesterday to come out flatly in favor of a return to a gold standard, in which paper money would be redeemable in gold, as the most effective anti-inflation measure that could be taken.
PITTSBURGH, Dec. 3 (AP) -- The Carnegie-Illinois Steel Corporation displayed today a new continuous process for coating steel with zinc.
Ch. Lavender Liberty, a blue male Persian, was judged the best cat last night at the closing session of the thirty-second championship show of the Empire Cat Club, Inc., in the McAlpin Hotel.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- Glen H. Taylor of Idaho, who left the Democrats to campaign for Vice President on the Wallace ticket, resumed today his label as a Democratic Senator, but denounced anew the Administration's policy of containing communism abroad.
CINCINNATI, Dec. 3 -- Following is the text of the statement on human rights adopted today by the Federal Council of the Churches of Christ in America:

A woman clerk was bound and gagged and two customers were knocked unconscious by thugs yesterday in a combination photographic studio, jewelry shop and real estate office at 106-57 New York Boulevard, Jamaica, Queens.

CHICAGO, Dec. 3 -- The tempo of Chicago's response to the New York City Opera Company, which is making its first visit here, has been stepping up. Tonight's "Carmen," the company's third production thus far, attracted a sold-out house at the Civic Opera House.

With only one more week to go before the New Jersey waterfowl season closes, and less than a week for New York hunters, it will take really cold weather and some strong winds to bring the classification of the season up to "fair."
A full-scale investigation of waterfront gangster activities that prevent full utilization of the city's dock properties has been ordered by Mayor O'Dwyer.
OTTAWA, Dec. 3 (Canadian Press) -- Prime Minister Louis St. Laurent believes the outlook to be bright for early action on the Great Lakes-St. Lawrence River power and seaway project.

For the third consecutive day, rubber futures advanced yesterday on the Commodity Exchange. Prices at the close were 23 to 30 points above the previous levels. WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 (AP) -- Fraud and other irregularities in the Michigan Senatorial election Nov. 2 were charged today by Frank E. Hook, Democratic candidate, in asking the Senate for a recount of the vote. Mr. Hook, a former House member who ran against Senator Homer Ferguson, said a recount by the Senate Elections Committee would show that he, Mr. Hook, won by "a vast majority."

PARIS, Dec. 3 -- The United Nations Appeal for Children was made a part of the United Nations International Children's Emergency Fund tonight by a decision of the Social Committee of the General Assembly.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- More than fifty new and improved devices, electrical and electronic, of widely varying purpose and design, and fifteen approved developments in aircraft construction, were among the 587 inventions patented this week by the United States Patent Office.

PARIS, Dec. 3 -- The United States and the United Kingdom came to the support of Chile today in her charges before the United Nations that the Soviet had violated fundamental human rights in not permitting Russian wives of foreigners to join their husbands abroad.
ALBANY, Dec. 4 -- New York State will embark this winter on a multi-million-dollar long-range program aimed at expediting the cure of the mentally ill, a top administration source revealed today.
TRENTON, N.J. -- A repetition of last winter's cold and snow during the coming three months will find New Jersey's supervised ski tows ready.

Collins, president of the association, said yesterday.

ALTHOUGH a certain amount of the vocal music of the Tudor period in England is still performed, the instrumental music of this period is generally obscure. Most of it was the product of William Byrd, John Bull and Orlando Gibbons.

WALLKILL, N.Y., Dec. 4 -- The first Catholic Chapel of the State Prison here, built by thirty-eight inmates who worked under the supervision and instruction of skilled civilian personnel, will be dedicated Tuesday by the Most Rev. Stephen J. Donahue, Auxiliary Bishop of the Archdiocese of New York.

LONDON, Dec. 4 -- Three vessels loaded with 70,000 bales of American cotton are unloading in Liverpool and Manchester over this week-end. The shipment is the largest single consignment of the American-grown staple since the European Recovery Program went into effect.

In the small village of Saranac Lake, high up in the Adirondacks in upper New York, is an unusual statue of an unusual man. The statue is of a man sitting in bed, a bathrobe around his shoulders and his legs covered by a blanket. The man is Dr. Edward Livingston Trudeau, one of the world's great leaders in the fight against tuberculosis, the centenary of whose birth is being observed this year.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -- A broad program of United States assistance to the Chinese Nationalist Government, including aid at an estimated cost of $3,000,000,000 over the next three years, has been proposed in connection with the visit here of Mme. Chiang Kai-shek, it was learned from Chinese sources today.

While judges awarded ribbons yesterday to some of the 600 gathered aristocrats at the fifteenth annual New York Bird Fancier's Association Show at the Twelfth Regiment Armory, Sixty-second Street and Columbus Avenue, two Indian hill mynas entertained the visitors.

LYONS, Ga., Dec. 4 -- Five white men surrendered today and were held under suspicion of murder in the ambushing Nov. 20 of Robert Mallard, Negro, near his home, 18 miles southeast of Lyons. The widow, Amy James Mallard, said her husband was killed by five or six robed but unmasked white men.

IN an old red brick structure in Washington, across the south parking lot from the shiny modernity of the State Department building, a new approach is being developed to one of America's most pressing problems -- that of producing a Foreign Service expertly equipped to grapple with the difficulties which our diplomacy faces in the post-war world.

IT is possible to have some wild flowers bloom in the house in winter. Completely different from most indoor plants, they bring a pleasant reminder of spring woodlands at a time when it is most appreciated.

The American Pharmaceutical Manufacturers Association will present its Award of Distinction for 1948 to the National Institutes of Health for outstanding contributions to public health through fundamental medical research at a dinner Tuesday night in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, it was announced yesterday.

A familiar feature of the Christmas season of entertaining for young members of society will be the annual Debutante Cotillion and Christmas Ball, to be held Dec. 20 in the grand ballroom suite of the Waldorf-Astoria. The event is sponsored by Coty, Inc., as a benefit for the New York Infirmary.

The Indianapolis Jets, in last place in the western division, continued to indicate they are finding the switch from the National League to the Basketball Association of America a tough one to make. Playing before a matinee crowd of 7,683 the Hoosiers dropped another decision yesterday as they bowed to the Knickerbockers, 66 -- 63, in Madison Square Garden.

SAN BRUNO, Calif., Dec. 4 (AP) -- Charging into the lead on the home stretch turn, Petite Star, 3-year-old chocolate filly owned by the W-L Ranch of Hollywood, won the $10,000 added Portola Handicap before 13,497 fans at Tanforan today.

BERLIN, Dec. 4 -- The struggle for Berlin entered a new phase this week. There is nothing novel, of course, in the steady progress toward the city's division, which has been going on since June. The new phase is the gradual withdrawal of the Soviet Military Administration as the overt instrument of foreign policy of the Soviet Union behind a "People's City Government," which will be dominated by Russian power.

Weil.

Peron's determination to "reform" the Argentine Constitution will move toward realization tomorrow when the voters elect representatives to the Constitutional Convention. In fourteen seasons of college basketball at Madison Square Garden -- this is the fifteenth -- only one other team did what Bowling Green of Ohio achieved last night. At the expense of a Long Island University quintet that collapsed in the closing minutes of the first half, Harold Anderson's Falcons accounted for the tying of two all-time records for the Eighth Avenue hardwood en route to a 97-64 rout of the Brooklyn Blackbirds.

EVANSVILLE, Ind., Dec. 4 -- The forty-one-game winning streak of Missouri Valley's Vikings -- longest in collegiate football history -- came to an end today when underdog Evansville College scored a 13-7 triumph in the Refrigerator Bowl game.

Earnings of the nation's manufacturing industries for the third quarter of this year outstripped the previous two quarters, lifting the combined earnings in the first nine months of 1948 to a peacetime high for the period.

DENVER, Col. -- Skiing this season will be Colorado's main winter attraction. In the Rocky Mountain region new tows have been installed, lodges and hotel accommodations expanded, local transportation to slopes improved, and top-ranking instructors "imported" from various parts of the country.

PARIS, Dec. 4 -- The campaign of the United States, Britain, France and China to put the whole United Nations on record as favoring a dilution of the Big Five veto right won heavy committee approval today and appeared certain of the support of the full General Assembly.

More generous Federal legislation in the interest of displaced persons was advocated last night by Carl Levine, a field worker of the American Friends Service Committee, who returned recently from a tour of duty with displaced persons in Germany.

HARTFORD, Conn., Dec. 4 -- Sand alone, without the aid of salt, will be used as ice protection for vehicles traveling the Wilbur Cross Highway during this winter's storms. This information was made public today by State Highway Commissioner G. Albert Hill.
UNUSUALLY heavy rail travel during the coming winter resort season is forecast by passenger traffic officials. They base the belief on advance inquiries and reservations.

LONDON. IN Paris recently Mr. Vishinsky objected indignantly and at length to the phrase "Iron Curtain." He insisted it was a figment of Western propaganda, designed to camouflage or justify Western aggression.

LONDON, Dec. 4 -- King George VI, as the reigning monarch of Great Britain, Northern Ireland and the commonwealth, is an institution. When in the early hours of Nov. 23, it was announced that he was seriously ill with an arterial complaint, he became quite simply a man, and there was a curious poignancy about the attitude of the ordinary Briton.
LONDON, Dec. 4 (Reuters) -- Derby County, first division leader in English soccer, triumphed over Charlton Athletic by 5-1 today before a home crowd of 53,000.

The acid test will be applied to Brooklyn's worth as a professional football town today, when the Dodgers engage the undefeated Cleveland Browns at Ebbets Field. Everything points with favor to the year's best turnout in the Flatbush ball park, where the 1948 high has been approximately 14,000 in paid attendance.

IT will be forty years, come next Friday, since a short, bushy-haired, blue-eyed lad of 17 stood for the first time on an American stage and undertook to prove that his European reputation as a flaming prodigy of the violin was warranted. The eager and determined boy was Mischa Elman, and the triumphant debut that night set in motion a career exceeded here in longevity among current major violinists only by that of Fritz Kreisler.

Columbia opened its 1948-49 basketball season with a resounding 69-27 victory over Kings Point on the Morningside Heights floor last night. Leading by 36 -- 13 at halftime, the Lions displayed a tight defense and surprising backboard strength in registering their opening triumph.

IT appears that Pat Abbott is distantly related to the Stryker family of the Hawaiian Islands, but currently residing at the Villa Black Cypress near Laguna Beach in California. Pat and Jean Abbott are invited to the villa because it is feared that Mrs. Hiram Stryker, nee Enid Ponsonby, is going to be murdered.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 4 -- The medical alumni of the University of Pennsylvania this week launched a drive for $500,000 to finance the erection of a medical alumni hall as its contribution to the university's new $10,000,000 Philadelphia medical center.

If General Douglas MacArthur gives his sanction and approval to the Olympic Committee which has been formed in Japan that nation probably will be invited to participate in the 1952 Olympic Games at Helsinki, Finland.

The New York Postoffice has dug itself out of the mountains of incoming and outgoing foreign mail amassed here during the eighteen-day East Coast longshoremen's strike and is now back to a normal working schedule, Postmaster Albert Goldman said yesterday.

EVERY now and then a bridge player comes across the rare case in which he has the three of a suit, and, although it is not the last card, it will win a trick because the only outstanding card of the same suit is the deuce.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -- The staff of the Joint Congressional Committee on the Economic Recovery Program reported today that substantial industrial and agricultural progress had been made by the European Recovery Program countries but that "real unification" of Western Europe was not yet in evidence.

BUSINESS received assurances from the recently elected Administration last week that there was "nothing to fear." President Truman made this clear at his press conference and Secretary of Commerce Sawyer in a speech "cleared" by the President said about the same thing before the convention of the National Association of Manufacturers.

IN the coming months many photographers will take to the darkroom who were once content to let the drugstore finisher complete the job of picture-making. For the conviction is growing that a picture cannot really be considered the finished product of the photographer until he has nursed it through the routines of the printing process.
CHICAGO, Dec. 4 (AP) -- Today's report of the markets in the Union Stockyards by the United States Department of Agriculture follows:

MEXICO CITY -- It is possible that a hard wall of prejudice will have to be breached before American tourists begin to travel widely in Mexico by bus, but until that day comes they will be missing a lot.

IT is altogether fitting and timely that an exhibition of paintings by Gustave Courbet should be held this year. In 1848 Europe was racked with revolutions. New social theories were in the air. In France the great struggle among romanticism, a hangover classicism and realism was under way.

THE gay and exotic cabanas which line Florida's private beaches and swimming pools have become much more than a place to change modestly into a bathing suit. The cabana, a modern version of the seaside bathhouse is almost a must to the winter vacationist.

SPECIALIZATION has reached out into the world of babies and here is a book devoted exclusively to the newcomer in the family. There are ten chapters crammed with things to knit or crochet for the comfort, well be ing and appearance of His (or Her) Royal Highness, from the period of waiting to the tea-party-for-two stage.

HAVANA, Dec. 1 -- A peace movement designed to keep Latin America neutral and to cut off the supply of vital raw materials to the United States in case of war with Russia is being promoted by agents of the Communist Information Bureau and leaders of the Communist party throughout these countries.

HOUSTON -- Despite construction problems, Texas will be in a little better condition to welcome winter visitors this year than at any time since the beginning of the war. Highways have been improved, new hotels built, and old ones remodeled.

NEW ORLEANS, La. -- Resort and hotel operators of Louisiana and Mississippi happily report that the number of early winter vacationists arriving at these Gulf Coast states is already 10 per cent above the total of early holidayers who helped to open the winter season a year ago.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 4 -- Paced by its captain, Tony Lavelli, who holds all Yale basketball scoring records, the Eli quintet opened its season tonight by defeating Rutgers, 72-52. Lavelli tallied 26 points to lead both teams.

PARIS, Dec. 4 -- The Soviet Union made clear today in a note to the United Nations that it would very likely reject a proposal, privately discussed among the delegations, for the formation of a permanent commission composed of "neutral" members of the Security Council with authority to mediate among the four involved powers in the event of differences arising after the establishment of hoped-for quadripartite control in Berlin.

With most apparel and accessory lines peaked unintentionally as the result of lagging demand, retailers are in a position to press for dollar volume in their soft goods departments, it was pointed out by resident buyers last week. Apparel clearances will crop up frequently in the pre-Christmas season, it was predicted, and should result in a definite increase of unit sales.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Dec. 4 -- Nathan Friedman-Yellin, leader of the Stern Band, which specialized in political assassination during the British mandate, will go on trial tomorrow before an Israeli military court. The trial will have wide political implications, principally because the outside world is wondering what Israeli will do with her erstwhile terrorists.

The winners of four architectural competitions held by the New York State Division of Housing to produce designs for sale and rental housing for persons in the lower income brackets were announced yesterday by Herman T. Stichman, State Housing Commissioner.

RALEIGH, N.C., Dec. 4 -- Football is always a major topic of conversation and very serious matter in this area in October and November. This year, though, the season is being prolonged and more reservations than ever before are being made for New Year's bowl games.

IF there is one foreign correspondent who would fit the description of an old-time police reporter, a man with iron legs, iron lungs and a slightly misanthropic view of his fellow man, who believed nothing he didn't see with his own eyes and only half of that, it would be Mark Gayn.

ATLANTA, Dec. 4 -- The Deep South anxiously eyed early arrivals for the winter tourist season this week, seeking some indication of how business would stack up with the boom 1945-46 and 1946-47 periods. The Florida season officially got under way with the opening of the Tropical Park race meeting, but the peak of visitors there will not be reached until January and February.

THE American Society of Planning Officials recently held a three-day jamboree in New York, delivered themselves of some eloquent tirades on planless cities, announced that the revolution is at hand, and sketched the steps or rather leaps and bounds, by which the so-called planning profession will shatter this sorry scheme of things, and remold it nearer to the heart's desire.

A number of sportsmen considering a winter hunting trip to the Carolinas, Georgia or Florida are exhibiting an unusual interest in turkey shooting, and several report they plan spending a "day or two" hunting for these birds.

ART books in America nowadays turn up on a remarkable variety of subjects. Here is a comprehensive study of that contemporary American solitary. John Marin, whose sparse telescopic water-colors have been turned out abundantly and judiciously kept off the market, like Amsterdam diamonds, until they approach the status of the legendary.

PARIS, Dec. 4 -- With the fined surrender in the eight-week coal strike, in which Communist leaders of the General Confederation of Labor ordered the miners back to work, the coalition Cabinet of Premier Henri Queuille has won a well-earned breathing spell.

THE Canadian Cooperation Project, initiated between American film interests and the Canadian Government last January to forestall possible curbs on the flow of some $12,000,000 in Canadian film revenue annually to the United States, has met with partial success only, a survey among government officials and members of the Canadian film industry has revealed.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla. -- Each winter since the end of the war the Florida west-coast tourist centers have experienced their "biggest season since boom days." The outlook this season is no exception, nor is the optimistic view just wishful thinking on the part of chambers of commerce.

Colored beads, building blocks, modeling clay and a twentieth century version of the ancient abacus are being utilized by the city's schools in an effort to make arithmetic easy for first-grade pupils.

MORE than twenty-five years ago a brilliant young Alsatian gave up an excellent teaching post, abandoned his organ recitals, his writings on music, theology and philosophy, and finally left behind him the Western world to open a hospital in Lambarene, in darkest Africa.

BY and large, cartoon books are the best books to have around, and the children who read the comics obviously come by it naturally. Cartoon books look well on the piano in the living room and they serve a necessary purpose on the bedside table of the guest room.

BERLIN, Dec. 4 -- German youth has been deprived of its share of power in post-war Germany because Allied policy in Germany has tended to return "the old economic ruling class" to management of Germany, Adrian Liddell-Hart, member of the governmental structures branch of the British Control Commission, declared.

One hundred debutantes have been invited by a committee of patronesses to attend the first Mayfair Assembly of the season, which will take place the night of Dec. 18 on the roof of the St. Regis. The supper dance is one of two arranged for this winter under the direction of Miss Clementine Miller.

WASHINGTON -- The Mid-south vacation area, halfway between New York and Florida, is ready for a lively winter season with millions of dollars already spent for resort improvements, renovations of hotels and motor courts, improving golf courses, building new stables and preparing a full schedule of events at the larger resorts.

PANAMA -- Tourist travel to Central America this winter may depend to a considerable extent on political conditions. The repeated threat of political upheavals, even of war, possibly involving the five countries from Guatemala to Panama, are less serious now than they have been and they probably will grow less important as time passes.

THIS newspaper's drama critic has recently taken the pulse, applied the stethoscope and looked at the tongue of the "fabulous invalid," the Broadway theatre. He suggests that "there ought to be a more relaxed and informal theatre where new playwrights, new actors and new audiences can enjoy themselves," and he wrote that he had found a group at the Master Institute uptown that about met his specifications.

YONKERS, N.Y., Dec. 4 -- City Controller John A. Peterson was sworn in as Acting City Manager today to fill temporarily the vacancy left by the resignation of Thomas V. Kennedy. Mr. Peterson was selected by the Common Council last night.

NEW DELHI, Dec. 4 -- After a fortnight spent motoring about western Pakistan, the return to the capital of India reaccentuates the curious individuality of the two new nations founded upon the same ancient soil less than a year and a half ago.

STOCKHOLM -- Official red tape has put a big crimp in Sweden's tourist winter season. The three major establishments at Are, most fashionable of the winter resorts, will not open this year because of having been refused hard-liquor licenses, their revenue mainstay.

The majority of glassware retailers will end the year with dollar volume about equal to 1947, buyers declared yesterday. Some stores, they said, will suffer 3 to 5 per cent losses, with only a few showing gains of not more than 5 per cent.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Dec. 4 -- The Yugoslavs published today, for the first time, a statistical analysis of pre-war capital holdings in Yugoslavia, designed to demonstrate the degree of control over this country's industry and resources exercised by foreign capital groups and, by inference, the losses sustained by international capitalism as the result of the Yugoslav revolution.

VANCOUVER, B.C. -- This is the time of year when Kipling's description of Canada as "Our Lady of the Snows" is borne out by a vast white blanket sheathing the great mountains of the Dominion. These mountains extend from the boundary between British Columbia and Alberta to the Pacific Ocean.

A special children's celebration of "Jewish Book Month" will be held today at 10 A.M. by the East Side Council of Jewish Schools at the Educational Alliance, 197 East Broadway, it was announced yesterday.

SUET puddings, seed cakes or tidbits may sound more like concoctions for the kitchen than combinations of food for birds. They are, nevertheless, the means of assuring the avid interest and well-being of these winter visitors to the garden.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 4 -- Old Blues and young Blues alike joined tonight to celebrate Yale's golden jubilee of swimming in the Payne Whitney Pool and to pay tribute to the longtime Eli and four-time Olympic coach, Robert J.H. (Bob) Kiphuth.

Much buyer resistance commonly attributed to high prices is the result of incredible "puffery" and vagueness in a large part of recent and current advertising, Walter Weir, New York advertising agency president, declared in an interview last week.

Eight centuries ago the philosopher Maimonides said: "Anticipate charity by preventing poverty. Assist the reduced fellow man, either by a considerable gift, or a sum of money, or by teaching him a trade * * * so that he may earn an honest livelihood. * * * This is the highest step and the summit of charity's golden ladder."

The Communist opposition to European recovery is probably the most serious obstacle to restoration of the European economy, Aubrey H. Harwood, director of operations of the Economic Cooperation Administration, reported yesterday.
LONDON, Dec. 4 -- If the Conservative party wins in the next general elections, it will bring nationalization of industry to an end, Richard K. Law, Conservative Member of Parliament said today.

TOLEDO, Ohio, Dec. 4 (AP) -- The University of Toledo's Rockets made it three for three in the third annual Glass Bowl game today by taking a 27-14 decision from out-manned but scrappy Oklahoma City University before 8,500.

A strong plea to abolish the released time program in public schools for religious instruction, because it has "created a bitter conflict between the churches that is tearing asunder our communities, our society and our nation," was made yesterday by Mrs. Eugene Meyer, a member of the President's Commission on Higher Education.

Pierre Etchebaster, world open-court tennis champion, gained a lead of 3 sets to 1 over James Dear of England yesterday as their challenge match opened at the Racquet and Tennis Club. The titleholder won the first three sets, 6 -- 1, 6 -- 5, 6 -- 3 and lost the fourth, 6 -- 3.
CHICAGO, Dec. 4 -- Running up a 21-0 margin in the first half, the New York Yankees ended their All-America Football Conference season today when they defeated the Chicago Rockets, 28 -- 7.

THE most vital film news of the week came out of New Orleans where the Allied States Association of Motion Picture Exhibitors proposed at their annual convention that the Production Code be amended to include disciplinary regulations against personalities guilty of "misconduct."

A denial that communism had infiltrated Protestant organizations was made public here yesterday on behalf of the Council of Bishops of the Methodist Church, who gave a formal answer to charges made last month in a pamphlet of the House Committee on Un-American Activities.

Plans are being advanced for the benefit performance of Jean-Paul Satre's play "Red Gloves," starring Charles Boyer, on the night of Dec. 14 in the Mansfield Theatre, which will aid the Homemaker Service of the Children's Aid Society.

NEW YORK CITY'S 843 employment agencies find themselves these days in a situation which, some years ago, would have been considered improbable -- they are looking for clients. This is because the visionary estimate, made during the years of World War II, that a 60,000,000 national employment figure should be achieved in order to keep the wheels of American progress turning, is currently a fact.

MORRISTOWN, N.J., Dec. 4 -- Northern New Jersey's civil defense reaction to an imaginary atom bomb disaster in Manhattan was as imaginary as the "disaster" itself, participants and officials agreed here tonight.

Steadiness prevailed yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange and closing prices for cotton futures were 9 to 27 points net higher. The market started unchanged to 10 points up and rose to gains of 13 to 30 points on active months.

Manhattan College made it two in a row for the new basketball season by beating American International of Springfield, Mass., 96 -- 35, in the Jasper gymnasium last night. Manhattan led by 40 -- 6 at half-time. Bob Kelly, with 23 points and Charlie Jennerich, with 21, were the main scorers.

A RESTLESS rocking horse named Pinto gets the urge to sow his wild oats, and leaves his rockers behind him. Once he runs away from the toyshop, Pinto tries successively life on a farm and in the city, on a prairie and in the park, even with a circus, but finally discovers happiness, of course, in his own back yard -- in this case the crowded toyshop where he really belongs.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Dec. 4 -- Borba, official newspaper of the Yugoslav Communist party, acknowledged today the substantial financial and material support received by the present regime from numerous Yugoslav-American societies in the United States.

The National Collegiate Athletic Association's Constitutional Compliance Committee, most important body in the enforcement machinery of the N.C.A.A. "Sanity Code," wound up a two-day meeting at the Hotel Biltmore yesterday.

Stockholders of the Tucker (automotive) Corporation must have been somewhat confused over the news developments of the last week or so in relation to the company's finances. First, Preston Tucker, president, told reporters he was attempting to form a financial syndicate to raise $10,000,000 and had applied to the Reconstruction Finance Corporation for a $30,000,000 credit.

ALBANY -- A record ski-jump -- in the form of new facilities for the sport -- is being established by New York State this season. Sixteen new public ski centers will be opened for the first time this winter.

THE words of operas are seldom remembered. If they make sense, you readily forgive them for not being quotable. If they don't make sense, you are grateful when they are incomprehensible. In the case of Four Saints in Three Acts, the opera with music by Virgil Thomson and libretto by Gertrude Stein, you want to hear the words.

THE miracle by which man first made language and thus created a new world above and beyond the ever-changing, ever-vanishing world of nature -- that is a basic aspect of the growth of language. The second, and perhaps lesser, miracle by which man has evolved spatial symbols to represent the sound symbols of oral language is basic to the growth of writing.

WHEN a revolution overturns a Government in South America, when a Greek Cabinet falls, or when a Chinese war lord is ousted, there is usually a period of confusion while newspaper offices try to get acquainted with unfamiliar names and careers.

The present stringent restriction on automobile parking in the midtown business area of New York City is creating an increasingly serious problem for wholesale salesmen and the concerns they represent, as well as business in general, it was brought out at a meeting last week of the traffic committee of the National Council of Salesmen's Organizations.

The heavy frosts have come, and the first light snows have come and gone. The earth in these latitudes enters its season of cold dormancy. Down in the ground lie the corded roots and the fat corms and bulbs of green life, torpid and waiting for the summons of another spring.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 (AP) -- Alabama's eleven Presidential electors told the Supreme Court today that it would be "unheard of" to require them to vote for a man "denounced" as President Truman was by Gov. James E. Folsom.
For reasons of national security, the United States is accelerating its efforts to import large quantities of foreign scrap metal, particularly from Germany but also from Japan.
One person was killed and six injured in automobile accidents late Friday night and in the early morning hours of yesterday.

The recent breaks with tradition in the procedure surrounding the showing of pure-bred dogs were augmented yesterday with an announcement by the Saw Mill River Kennel Club that it would eliminate group judging and, consequently, best in show from its annual all-breed event at County Center, White Plains, next March 13.

SALT LAKE CITY, Dec. 4 -- Hopes for an industrial boom in the area between the Rockies and the Sierras are being dimmed by a shortage of steel. Business men, contractors and steel fabricators are indignantly placing the major share of the blame for the slowdown upon the policies of the Geneva steel plant, operated by the U.S. Steel Corporation at Provo, Utah.

THIS fourth and final volume in Mr. Adams' illustrated history of America is, perhaps, a symbol of our Times. It begins with a depression and ends with a war. In its first pages are the smokeless factory buildings of 1893 with gaping windows, bread lines and Mary Elizabeth Lease, who urged her Kansas friends to raise "less corn and more hell."

BOSTON, Dec. 4 (AP) -- A steaming 35-foot drive by Bud Poile, proud owner of one of the National lifted Detroit to a 3-2 victory lifted Detroitt o a 3 -- 2 victory over the pace-setting Bruins tonight before a capacity crowd of 13,900 at the Boston Garden.

THE delirious excitement following the discovery of the mysterious Inca city of Machu Picchu is now almost forgotten, but in the halcyon days of 1911, it set off a chain reaction of curiosity which has had few parallels. The National Geographic Magazine, then in its incunabula, gave an entire issue to it (and numerous subsequent articles).

LILLIAN WALD was the daughter of a prosperous German-Jewish family. But she gave up her pleasant social life to live and work in the East Side slums. Trained as a nurse, she became a social worker in the early Nineties, although no such title then existed.

The first Junior Assembly for this season was held last night in the ballroom suite of the Ritz-Carlton. A green and white floral decor had been devised for the fete, which was attended by some one hundred debutantes and their escorts. Formalities that have been maintained for the last few decades at the "Juniors" were manifest last night.

A continuation of consumer buying apathy for the fifth consecutive week had many retailers believing yesterday that they are finally facing conditions that have been predicted widely and frequently since the end of the war.

OMAHA, Dec. 4 -- Surrounded by bountiful crops and faced by falling prices in some lines, farmers singly and in groups were bombarding Washington for assurances that agricultural support-price programs would continue at a rate high enough to satisfy rural demands after current legislation expires.

With the development of a new method of making face plates for television picture tubes, the Pittsburgh Plate Glass Company announced yesterday in Pittsburgh that it has broken one of the major bottlenecks in the production of television tubes.

The Atlantic alliance -- the program to knit the North American Continent to the Western European Union in a regional defensive pact -- made preliminary progress last week as the spotlight shifted from Europe to Washington.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 (AP) -- The profits of business will be studied next week by a joint Senate-House committee.

TO the series of stamps which Yemen has been issuing in commemoration of admission to the United Nations have been added postage 12-bogshas blue and violet and airmail 12b brown and black with a design showing President Truman and Yemen's Prince Abdullah, head of his country's delegation to the U.N., seated in conference in the White House, with a framed portrait of Franklin D. Roosevelt in the background.

It is contended that the poll takers, in discussing their permissible range of deviation, have always meant four percentage points. If this is what they have meant, then why haven't they said so before now?

A pressing of the record made by Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower of his Normandy D-Day Order of the Day on June 6, 1944, and on its reverse the Guildhall Speech of June 12, 1945, together with the general's book, "Crusade in Europe," will be auctioned tomorrow eveing for the benefit of Wellesley College.

Retail sales volume here last week again slipped below figures for the comparable week last year. Department store sales were estimated at about 7 per cent under 1947. Indications were that Christmas gift buying is tending to develop late.
City commissioners embarking on an intensive drive against dockside criminals warned yesterday that special squads would cover the entire 700-mile waterfront of the port.

HAMILTON, Bermuda -- Reestablishment of luxury liner service between New York and Bermuda on Feb. 12 by the Furness-Bermuda Line's refitted Queen of Bermuda is being eagerly awaited by the islanders. They hope it will give a pronounced lift to their tourist trade, carried on since the war principally through the medium of air transport.

Was it deliberate or just a wonderful coincidence that placed an article about John Masefield ("King's Versifier," by Mervyn Jones) on Pages 34 and 35 -- and an advertisement by the Alexander Smith Carpet Company .on Pages 36 and 37 of the Oct. 24 issue of THE NEW YORK TIMES Magazine? The carpet company's mill is in Yonkers, N.Y.

PHOENIX, Ariz. -- Encouraged by the 1947-48 winter, which was hailed as the best tourist season in Arizona travel history, a new flood of eastern capital has invaded the Grand Canyon State resort business and concentrated primarily in the sixty-mile-wide Valley of the Sun which surrounds Phoenix.

A 47-year-old former bookkeeper who, the police said, received Western Union money orders from nearby communities by posing as a "home town boy" in financial distress, was arrested on a charge of forgery yesterday.

PARIS, Dec. 4 -- Herbert V. Evatt of Australia, president of the United Nations General Assembly, has recommended the creation of a mediation commission to try to establish amicable diplomatic and frontier relations among Greece and her northern neighbors, Albania, Yugoslavia and Bulgaria, it was reported today.

Dr. E. Boyd Barrett, who left the Roman Catholic Church and the Jesuit Order in 1924 after twenty years of education for and in the priesthood, publicly announced his reconciliation with the church yesterday.

A difference of opinion among researchers on the ability of hyaluronidase, a chemical enzyme, to overcome male infertility marked the closing session yesterday of a two-day conference sponsored by the biology section of the New York Academy of Sciences at the American Museum of Natural History.

MONT TREMBLANT, Quebec, Dec. 4 -- The Canadian Laurentians, mammoth winter playground that starts forty miles north of Montreal at Shawbridge and extends to the lofty heights of Mont Tremblant, is late this season in getting its usual quota of deep snows.

With gloomy conjectures abounding it was reassuring to read the straightforward, simple proposals in the article "If We End the Occupation of Germany," by Max Beloff. * * * "War talk" in the United States expresses a demand for preparedness against possible aggression.

TOKYO, Dec. 4 -- The steering committee of Japan's all powerful Lower House decided tonight not to permit the arrest of Dr. Hitoshi Ashida, former president of the Japanese Democratic party. Dr. Ashida had been indicted, on a charge of corruption by a Tokyo District Court.

WHITTLING is one of the best ways to do "nothing," and this amusing-little book will afford the hobbyist many hours of constructive loafing. Virtually all of the projects concern animal subjects. Materials needed to practice this art are few and simple, "a sharp knife, a piece of wood, an off stone, a coping saw and an idea."

The current scarcity of risk capital in the investment field no longer presents a theoretical problem; further expansion, or even the maintenance of a status quo, of the private enterprise system calls for an increased flow of risk capital into business ventures.

NANKING (By Wireless). THE Chinese civil war has been called one of the "worst covered" and "least understood wars of this trouble-packed century" -- and in many respects the charge is warranted. As in the case of the war itself the reasons for lack of a full American understanding with regard to China are altogether simple, and they do not justify criticism of any single group or individual.
PARIS, Dec. 4 (AP) -- The text of the amended British resolution on Palestine, approved today by the Political and Security Committee of the United Nations General Assembly, follows:

PARIS, Dec. 4 -- The Steering Committee of the United Nations General Assembly voted today to end the 1948 Assembly session the night of Dec. 11-12, but the British delegation served notice that it would continue the fight to keep at work in Paris until all items on the crowded agenda were finished.

Four Brooklyn youngsters were taken into custody yesterday morning after admitting to the police that they had started a two-alarm fire last Friday night that swept the Alabama Stables, 219 Alabama Avenue, Brooklyn, resulting in the death of eleven horses and serious injury to one stable employe.

Pressing forward in a drive for $600,000 for a gymnasium for Power Memorial Academy, a Catholic high school conducted by the Irish Christian Brothers at Sixty-first Street and Amsterdam Avenue, Thomas J. Shanahan, president of the Federation Bank and Trust Company, and other business men appealed to the public yesterday to "invest in the men of tomorrow."

Fordham successfully launched its swimming season yesterday, turning in a 54-20 triumph over Brooklyn College in a meet held at the Rose Hill pool. Failure of the Rams' diver, Charley Aiken, to appear for the contest cost his squad an opportunity for a clean sweep, the Fordham swimmers taking firsts in the eight other events.

HAVANA -- With additional transportation facilities and plenty of accommodations available, Cuba is looking forward with her perennial enthusiasm to the winter season. Following the pattern set last year, hotels are preparing for a large number of tourists on visits of two to three days, instead of guests who remain several weeks as in former years.

ATLANTA, Ga. -- Governments and business men of the South Atlantic States are now recognizing, a little late it is true, that tourists are a valuable natural resource, and that tourism can be a pleasant and highly profitable industry.
BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Dec. 4 -- Alabama celebrated renewal of gridiron relations with Auburn, after a 41-year lapse, with an over-whelming 55-to-0 victory today before 46,000 fans.

THE scheduled airlines that belong to the International Air Transport Association have set their sights on the pleasure traveler having two weeks vacation with pay. There are a lot of such Americans. Perhaps about 60 million vacationists fall in that group, and the airlines say they want to persuade them that by plane they can stretch their two weeks to cover most of the world.

The mentor of contemporary design continually emphasize that :Modern" is not a style but a philosophy -- an approach to home furnishings which insists upon commonsense values like efficiency, space saving and ease of maintenance. Their quarrel with furni ture of the past -- when they have a quarrel -- is based on the undeniable fact that much of it was designed for a manner of living that is neither possible nor desirable today.

THE condescension and unreasoning antagonism of the so-called liberal intellectual (the last two words constituting one of the fuzziest phrases ever used in this column), toward the big business or industrial tycoon has for a long time seemed to this department one of the most ridiculous prejudices -- when it is not merely a pose -- in recent American life.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Dec. 4 -- A United States compromise resolution for the partial use of Spanish as a working language was adopted without opposition by the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization Procedure Committee tonight.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., Dec. 4 (AP) -- The Navy is "very happy" to accept the football which Army won but decided the middies earned in their 21-21 tie last Saturday.

CHICAGO, Dec. 4 (AP) -- Grains on the Board of Trade ended with only minor price changes today after showing a new burst of strength in early dealings. Profit-taking knocked prices down from their best levels in the last half of the session, although the undertone in wheat remained firm.

WITH seven of the nine aisle-sitters rising to salute Jose Ferrer and "The Silver Whistle" -- our man called Mr. Ferrer the "most versatile actor of his generation" and the play, "original, friendly and fabulous" -- the Theatre Guild correctly considers itself the sponsor of a hit.

THERE are anthologies that are simply catch-alls; one wastes neither sympathy nor time on them. There are anthologies, however, that are prompted by a valuable idea, and these command our respect and attention. "The Limits of Art," edited by Huntington Cairns and published by Pantheon (Bolingen Series XII, $6.50), is a first-rate example of an anthology that is initiated by a brilliant idea.

STUDENTS of audience psychology have a fascinating theory which holds that filmgoers favor those performers with whom they can most closely identify themselves. The picture which stars a younger actress will be most liked by younger women, they say.

In a move that may have far-reaching significance, the Association of American Universities, a body of great prestige and influence, has abandoned its thirty-five-year-old practice of accrediting colleges and universities.

THE silvery discs of honesty shine in many a winter flower arrangement and bouquet. These eye-catching, inch-wide, flat seed pods, which dangle from stiff stems, last for months in the house. It is easy to grow a supply of them for indoor decoration.

CHICAGO -- Michigan leads the way with the Middle West's only completely new winter sports development. However, there is a great deal of winter sports activity being planned in the region, as evidenced by the increased membership clubs of the Central Ski Association and in the generally stepped-up programs of snow sport centers.
