THE novelty of the week is the formal Broadway debut of Mariemma, the Spanish dancer, at the Ziegfeld tonight. (The purist who tries to maintain that the Ziegfeld is pretty far off Broadway will have to contend with Mr. Rose.)
PARIS, Dec. 4 -- A resolution providing for establishment of a Palestine conciliation commission was approved today by the Political and Security Committee of the United Nations General Assembly.

AS director of the National Zoo in Washington for the past twenty-three years, Dr. Mann has been weighed down by administrative cares, tied to the desk of a Government institution, immobilized by responsibilities to his animals -- and the general public.

Steps aimed at further extension of the reciprocal trade agreements program of the United States will begin on Tuesday in Washington when concurrent hearings will be held by the United States Tariff Commission and the revamped interdepartmental Committee for Reciprocity Information.

GOVERNMENT CAMP, Ore. -- On this mountain shoulder of the Cascades, where blue-coated cavalrymen bivouacked nearly a century ago, snow began falling on election day. Rotary plows have reared high white stockades on each side of Oregon State Highway 50, clearing a route for automobiles and buses. Many of these vehicles already have been loaded with skiers and other winter sports fans.

The end of the long wrangle over the control of amateur ice hockey in this country was brought into sight yesterday with the announcement that a compromise agreement had been reached between the Amateur Athletic Union and the Amateur Hockey Association of the United States.

LONDON. THE American members of the Joint Anglo-American Council on Productivity, which was established at the request of Paul Hoffman as part of the European Recovery Program, have found British opinion bristling with sales resistance. The idea of making American know-how in industry available to Britain as a means of raising the output of the average British worker has had to be tactfully defined.

AN old idea, but every so often it pops up like the phoenix. Newspapers and magazines carry ads; so do certain books. Why not books in general? Some one could buy those pages now lying fallow at the end of novels, and there would always be room for inserts on anything from automobiles to tobacco, soap powder and mayonnaise.
A program to make every bank employe an active "salesman" for banking as an essential operation of the private enterprise system is being considered in banking circles.

Customer attendance was heavy in department stores here last week, according to a survey made especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Meyer Both Reports. Buying was brisk in main floor departments and ready-to-wear sales were steady.

THIS home owner's handbook has been written in dictionary form, with subject-matter indexed alphabetically. The book's main objective is to save the home owner money in repairs, and in this it is quite successful. Both authors have drawn on a world of experience gleaned as editors of The American Home magazine.
PARIS, Dec. 4 -- Within a week or ten days the European outlook for the Marshall Plan, which will be presented in a report to Congress in January, will be greatly clarified.

THE man who made "Ballerina" and "La Maternelle" is very busy these days, although he knows all too well that his new film productions will have tough going to rival the success of his earlier pictures. Still, Jean Benoit-Levy appears quite content to have traded the name producer for the more pretentious title of Director of the Films and Visual Information Division of the United Nations.

ONE of the extracurricular services which the Ballet Society renders to its subscribers is a series of books on appropriate subjects, the latest of which is "Chronicles of the American Dance." Happily, one need not be a member of the society to buy a copy at any book store, and the chances are that many a non-member who happens to be interested in dancing will spend happy hours browsing around in it.

PRINCESS ANNE, Md., Dec. 4 -- A controversy over Negro education with issues that cross political and racial lines has arisen in this state over the planned expansion of the Old Princess Anne Academy here into the Maryland State College, a land-grant institution under the control of the University of Maryland, educational leaders confirmed today.

THE war is not over for many thousands. In hospitals across the country they are trying to mend shattered bodies and minds. For some, the only prospect is one losing fight after another. For others, there is hope of rehabilitation and return to normal living.

NORFOLK, Va., Dec. 4 -- Standing on the Japanese surrender deck of the battleship Missouri, President Truman today said the "Mighty Mo" was "a symbol of might and strength in war as well as in peace" and he emphatically killed rumors that she would be put in moth balls.

The Disabled American Veterans of Brooklyn will hold at 1:30 P.M. today on the steps of Borough Hall, Brooklyn, the second annual DAV Day Memorial Services, it was announced yesterday. President Truman has proclaimed today as DAV Day.

In Nanking last week the government of Generalissimo Chiang Kaishek braced itself for what might be the decisive phase of the war against the Chinese Communists. The battle for the Nationalist capital was in the preliminary stage.

BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 4 -- The Argentine peace policy on a world scale as redefined by President Peron yesterday cannot obscure the fact that the nation's role within a continent ridden with plots and coups is currently distrusted by a large number of other South Americans.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -- Public reaction to Mr. Truman's surprising victory at the polls last month is still strongly colored by the assumption that it heralded a full-bodied reincarnation of the New Deal of 1933-38. The stock market has not recovered from its shock-induced downward spiral. Several prominent industrialists, including Henry Ford 2d, accepted it as meaning the inevitability of a fourth round of wage increases.

PRESIDENT TRUMAN paid an election-campaign call on John Nance Garner of Uvalde, Tex., not many weeks ago and, more recently, Uvalde celebrated its chief resident's eightieth birthday. Apart from those two publicity-laden moments, President Roosevelt's first Vice President has been, for some years, as private a citizen as he could make himself.
PRAGUE, Dec. 4 (AP) -- The Czechoslovak Resistance Movement told Roman Catholic church leaders today that this week's press and radio attacks on the church were the "last warning."

SHANGHAI, Dec. 4 (UP) -- At least 1,100 persons are missing, many of them believed to be dead, in the explosion and sinking last night of the refugee steamer Kiangya, a spokesman for the owners of the ship said today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -- A Presidential commission appointed to study the labor relations problems of the atomic energy program is expected to recommend a system of voluntary procedures that will not require legislation, informed sources said today.

Overhanging Germany for much of last week there was what meteorologists call a "stagnant low." A massive fog bank 1,000-feet thick, was moving slowly eastward across Europe. It was a severe setback to the airlift operation that has supplied the more than 2 million people in the western sectors of beleaguered Berlin.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture stepped in today to oppose a requested emergency freight rate increase of 8 per cent for railroads. It filed a motion asking the Interstate Commerce Commission to deny the increase.

PROFESSOR MORGAN'S account of the economic history of Hawaii from 1778, when the islands were discovered by Captain Cook, to 1876, when the first reciprocity treaty with the United States made American predominance certain, is exceptionally valuable.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 4 (AP) -- St. Joseph's 15-point spurt in the stretch broke up a spine-tingling battle with the University of Tennessee as the Hawks registered a 83-68 triumph in the second part of a Convention Hall basketball double-header tonight before 4,497 spectators.

THIS handsome volume that condenses a year of the world's news highlights in intelligent, comprehensive and highly readable, as well as seeable, form is described on the flyleaf as the first of an annual series. For quick reference or review, the series will serve a worth-while purpose.

IN the darkened theatre curtain lights spring up with their promise of enchantment. For hundreds of the children who make up the audience the experience is strange, they respond with absolute silence. Jack, making his time-honored agricultural experiment with the beanstalk, gets into a fight with the Giant and by sheer courage and acrobatic skill ties up the lummox.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -- A grass-roots, long-range farm bill, described by its backers as a 1948 election mandate, was introduced around official Washington this week by two South Dakota business men.

Most visitors to the Pacific islands, especially Polynesia, have come away with the feeling that in overrunning these small areas and imposing on their inhabitants his morals, his manners and his wars, the Westerner has destroyed something that was very precious and that he has not replaced with anything as good.

HENRY VIII, Edward VI, Mary, Elizabeth, Latimer, Cranmer, the Seymours, the Dudleys -- it was a vivid group of characters that crowded the pages of Miss Irwin's earlier story of Elizabeth, "Young Bess." In this second volume many of the same historical characters are again in evidence, but we miss the sheer bigness of Henry and the pale pathos of young Edward.

Young Alexis de Tocqueville, avocat a la cour royale de Paris, noted more than a hundred years ago this political phenomenon: that immediately after an American national election a period of great calm falls upon the country.
In connection with your interesting cover photo entitled "Israeli Forces Dig In," may I report that a new term "Israelian" was recently introduced to replace "Israeli."

A subscription supper dance entitled The Bachelors Ball will be held on Dec. 18 in the ballroom of the Ritz-Carlton. Subscriptions to the fete are limited to young women who were introduced to society a few seasons ago, and to men from 22 to 35 years of age. No married couples may subscribe.

Middlebury College, Middlebury, Vt., is planning to open next autumn a Graduate School of French to be established in France. According to an announcement from the college, at present there is no unified and coordinated program of graduate study in the French language and culture for American teachers in France.
DESPITE the highest rates in the history of American winter cruising, the 1948-49 season is expected to be the heaviest in travel volume in more than a decade.

The Vassar Club of New York has taken over the performance of "Madama Butterfly" at the Metropolitan Opera House on the night of Jan. 29 to assist its scholarship fund. It will be the twenty-seventh annual opera benefit to augment the fund, which provides financial aid for deserving students from the metropolitan area.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Dec. 4 -- Six special investigators from the Hudson County Prosecutor's office raided the Communipaw Democratic Association clubrooms at 329 Communipaw Avenue here today, took into custody twenty persons and confiscated gambling and horse-racing paraphernalia.
LOS ANGELES, Dec. 4 -- Mighty Notre Dame was held today to a 14-14 tie by Southern California and ten minutes after the game a real earthquake shook huge Memorial Coliseum.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 (UP) -- The Government tonight announced creation of fourteen "river basin offices" to handle a program of water pollution control authorized by the Eightieth Congress.

IT is called "bop." Its exponents will tell you it is nothing more than a liberated style of playing jazz. Its semicontrolled frenzy, however, epitomizes a strong new tendency toward popular music for listening -- rather than dancing -- and thus deserves a closer look this morning.

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 4 -- Business in the Pittsburgh district last week showed little change from the preceding week, according to the Bureau of Business Research, University of Pittsburgh. The bureau's seasonally adjusted index of business last week was 198.5 per cent of the 1935-39 average; it was 198.9 in the preceding week and 200.7 in the week ended Nov. 13.

Harry Schwartz's article delineating the differences between "news" fed the Russian masses and "news" offered the Americans ("'News' -- In Moscow and New York") is an excellent idea ably executed. One sees clearly the difference between a nation "indoctrinated" and one that is "informed."

HOWARD HUGHES' projected production of "I Married a Communist" has been generally viewed as significant of the switch from liberal to conservative ideology in RKO Pictures which was expected when he acquired control of the studio last summer and Dore Schary resigned as production chief.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -- Labor unrest in the coming months is likely to manifest itself mainly on the political level -- in the halls of Congress and the state legislatures.

LOS ANGELES -- The number "49" has long carried romantic connotations in California, and when it appears on the calendar a few weeks hence it will herald long-awaited centennial festivities. The coming year will be the second in California's three-year centennial program.

Eleven committees are completing arrangements for the Military Ball of the Seventh Regiment (107th Infantry, N.Y.N.G.), to be given Saturday night in the drill hall of the regimental armory at Park Avenue and Sixty-seventh Street.

CIUDAD TRUJILLO, Dominican Republic, Dec. 4 (AP) -- The office of President Rafael L. Molina Trujillo said in a communique today the President's brother, Gen. Anibal Trujillo, who died Thursday, had committed suicide.

MAMARONECK, N.Y., Dec. 4 -- A new assault on comic books that depict crimes of violence was begun today in this village and neighboring Westchester communities, when a group of irate parents placed on sale at news stands a different type of 10-cent animated picture book.

DETROIT, Dec. 4 -- The creation by Congress of a commission to study the relationship of the Federal and state governments was recommended today by Senator John W. Bricker of Ohio at the closing session of the ninth biennial general assembly of the Council of State Governments.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Dec. 4 -- Winning seven out of its eight contests, the Barnard College debating team took first place in the first annual Hofstra College debate tournament in the institution's Little Theatre, today. Rutgers University, with a record of six wins and two losses, was second and Brooklyn College, which won five of the eight contests was third.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -- President Truman has instructed Administration lieutenants preparing his legislative program for the next Congress that his campaign pledges are to be kept and that there is to be no deficit financing, it was learned today.

DONALD SADDLER, formerly of the Ballet Theatre and now dancing in "High Button Shoes," has choreographed three poems by Tennessee Williams with music by Paul Bowles, and Alicia Markova and Anton Dolin will dance them as a suite on their forthcoming tour of South Africa.

TYPES of nautical or fishermen's knots, based on their intended use, can be divided roughly into four general classifications, although many an old salt might not be satisfied with less than a dozen. However, this book has settled for the minimum four.
I would like to add a few observations to the article. "For Broader and Deeper Social Security," by J. K. Lasser.
In metropolitan arenas bouts of major importance will occupy the attention of boxing followers during the coming week, each attraction carrying championship significance.

BASSE TERRE, Guadeloupe, Dec. 3 -- Many delegates to the West Indian Conference expressed the general opinion today that the policies of the Caribbean Commission would be changed radically. Ward M. Canaday of the United States and Maj. Gen. Sir Hubert Rance of the United Kingdom have been appointed within four months and the trend is expected to follow the lines of Pierre Pelieu of France and Dr. Johannes Kielstra of the Netherlands.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -- Members of the House Committee on Un-American Activities were called to Washington today for hastily arranged hearings to bring into the open new documentary evidence that, a spokesman said, would show who gave State Department secrets to Whittaker Chambers when he was a Communist agent in the Nineteen Thirties.

I'M afraid I take exception to A.W.'s remarks on the Equity Library Theatre. Neither Equity nor John Golden, who originally financed ELT, intended the project to serve solely as a showcase for the neophytes of show business.

AN English critic has made out an interesting case for the writings of Henry Miller as a demonstration of the impossibility of a major literature, at least until such time as the world shakes itself out into some more satisfactory mold.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -- In wedding lore the fifteenth anniversary's memento is crystal -- especially fitting for the fifteenth anniversary tomorrow of the repeal of the prohibition amendment to the Constitution.

The world's largest electric utility company, the $1,364,000,000 Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., and the nation's most influential state regulatory body, the New York Public Service Commission, last week wound up two and a half years of hearings on the PSC-initiated investigation of the utility's rate structure.

PARIS, Dec. 4 -- Four proposals aimed at promoting the economic development of underdeveloped countries, including thorough technical training and assistance, were approved by the United Nations General Assembly in a plenary session today.

ROME, Dec. 4 -- By a vote of 266 to 45 the Chamber of Deputies reaffirmed its confidence in Premier Alcide de Gasperi's sixth government this evening after a stormy four-day debate on foreign politics. One hour earlier the Chamber have voted 302 to 140, with six abstentions, to reject the left-wing Socialist motion criticizing the Government's foreign policy.

A traffic jam has developed in the Supreme Court, handling important litigation in this city, to the extent that court calendars are falling behind a year for each year's work completed. As a result, conferences are now under way to prepare a constitutional amendment for submission to the next session of the Legislature.
A broken twenty-inch water main on Broadway, just south of Forty-second Street, snarled Times Square traffic all day yesterday.

PRINCETON, N.J., Dec. 4 -- Training of students for leadership in public and international affairs was urged tonight by Ferdinand Eberstadt, New York banker, in an address at the annual dinner of The Daily Princetonian. Such training, already in progress at Princeton, can be of outstanding aid in dealing with present chaotic world conditions, Mr. Eberstadt said.

TOGETHER New England's six states offer the winter sports enthusiast the widest possible variety of skiing facilities, whether he be the rankest novice or the veteran with a full assortment of championship trophies, and maybe a fractured leg or two.

BOSTON, Dec. 4 -- Even before the last of the Thanksgiving turkey had become soup, New Englanders began to think and talk about Christmas. To those in cities, the talk was translated into shopping, and this week the rush was on in the big department stores, though downtown stores reported business off by 6.4 per cent.

A CLARET that's 79 years old "interests" all of us even at a suggested retail price of $24 a fifth! Two clarets of this impressive maturity and others hardly more youthful were among the wines and spirits bought recently from Robert Goelet of New York and Newport. Greig, Lawrence Hoyt purchased the "cellars," which may be resold only in this state.

VISITORS to the West Indies this winter will find the islands from Haiti to Trinidad in the midst of a resort-building boom that is adding new hotels, guest houses, private vacation cottages and other facilities to attract the resident vacationist and also to offer more conveniences to cruise passengers.

THE contrast of these two books cannot be stated in words more clearly than John O'Hara Cosgrave 2d (the artist who designed their dust jackets) has stated it in color and line. The jacket on Miss Coatsworth's book is a wallpaper pattern on which are hung four miniatures, three old buildings and a landscape.

Taking command in the second chukker, the Manhattan trio headed by seven-goal Al Parsells did a great job to defeat George Oliver's Florida Gauchos, 16 -- 10, in the feature of the indoor polo double-header last night at Squadron A Armory.

Two more women were questioned yesterday in the office of District Attorney Frank S. Hogan as he continued his inquiry into the divorce mill racket here. The names of the women, who allegedly helped to fake evidence for collusive divorces, were withheld.

The members of the French Orchestre National, who will complete a forty-concert tour in Teaneck, N.J., this afternoon, have many grievances against Jack Adams, their American manager, and they have asked the American Arbitration Association to weigh the merits of one of their complaints -- a matter of $7,000 they say the manager withheld after they refused to play a concert in Minneapolis.

THERE are many ways of auditioning for an acting role but few persons have won a part as Elsa did: by having front teeth that held firm when the school principal tried them for shakiness. Miss Tait, the principal wanted the Second Grade's production of "Snow White" to have nothing in it that would start the Norwegian and Canuck fathers of the village to laughing.

TORONTO, Dec. 4 (AP) -- The Chicago Black Hawks scored four goals in the last period tonight to whip Toronto at Maple Leaf Gardens, 6 -- 4, and broke their tie with the Maple Leafs for fourth place in the National Hockey League.

As of yesterday 213 exhibitors had obtained space allocations for the National Motor Boat Show which will start its thirty-ninth annual run on Jan. 7 at Grand Central Palace on Lexington Avenue. Already New York's midwinter dry land port of call for pleasure boatmen has all sizes, shapes and models promised for the display, from little dinghies up to seaworthy offshore twin motor power cruisers.

Declaring that the divorce laws of New York State met neither the legal nor the moral requirements of a modern age, Rabbi Jonah B. Wise in Central Synagogue, Fifty-fifth Street and Lexington Avenue, called yesterday for revision of the State divorce laws.

THE whole subject of the relationship between women and money is hair-raising, and no man in his right mind would have anything to do with it. Bj Kidd seems to be in her right mind, but then, the Bj stands for Betty Jane and she is a woman.

BOSTON -- New England is centering its plans for entertaining winter visitors on the development of new skilands and on improving and augmenting travel services to bring winter sports enthusiasts to ski areas.

ALTHOUGH more deer than hunters were shot in some sections, the 1948 hunting season in Maine has been pronounced successful One hunter entered the woods intestate, and the upper court is deciding if a will punched in birch bark with a porcupine quill and witnessed only by the guide can be legally probated in Piscataquis County.

THE recent upsurge of interest in antique dolls has made an authoritative volume on the subject necessary. Mrs. St. George, a collector in her own right, has compiled what amounts to an encyclopedia on dolls and a history of their invention and use.
THE leaves of succulents many of them tipped with brilliant threadlike markings around the edge, make these plants attractive window-sill candidates. This, even though they may bear no flowers.

MADISON, S.D., Dec. 4 (AP) -- Representative Karl E. Mundt said tonight that he felt certain that Communist agents got "all or most of" the secret information on microfilms turned up at the Maryland farm of Whittaker Chambers.

The State of Israel last week gained what was generally regarded as a considerable victory -- as the result of a long and vigorous debate in the United Nations. The General Assembly's Political Committee adopted a resolution which in effect accepts the present boundaries of Israel as the basis of a settlement of the Palestine problem.

IN the books of the travel and resort industry, this year will be noted as the one of the big building boom. One of the biggest since the Pilgrims stopped work for a day of thanksgiving and presumably established the precedent of a holiday (with pay) out of which grew the multi-billion dollar vacation and travel business.

YUMA, Ariz., Dec. 4 (AP) -- Louis B. Mayer, movie producer, and Mrs. Lorena Danker were married today by Justice of the Peace R.H. Lutes in the office of Sheriff J.A. Beard amid a lively pursuit by reporters and photographers.
LOS ANGELES, Dec. 4 -- Horses, in various ways, attracted considerable attention in the Pacific Southwest this week.

THE amateur photographer, accustomed to summer field trips under a guide's leadership, may feel lost when winter puts him on his own. Rather than despair of finding picture subjects, he should accept the challenge to work things out for himself.

IN 1917 the publication of the "Cambridge History of American Literature" was as much a battle-cry as a work of scholarship. It was a manifesto of the Americanists that American literature was no longer to be merely a subsection of the English, but was henceforth to be coequal in dignity and repute.

BUENOS AIRES -- Whenever the political atmosphere in Europe gets stormy, norte-americanos with travel dollars to spend look south; and, accordingly, ten South American republics are looking hopefully to their shares of a banner tourist season. Remember, winter is summer below the Equator.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 4 -- Cat Bridge, racing for Sheriff G.R. Watkins of Delaware County, Pa., surprised the greater number of 9,612 racing fans who bet $423,757 at Tropical Park today when he beat the 3-to-4 favorite, the Bermill Stable's Bug Juice, in the second running of the $7,500 added E.R. Bradley Memorial Handicap.

ONLY a man with a heart of stone and a head to match could fail to find among the books of 1948 a covey he would like to give or receive this Christmas. It is the best year we have had in a longish interval. There are new books that will undoubtedly become classics, others that we need feel no ungovernable urge to share with posterity.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -- The censorship regulations in the Soviet Union are now such that American and other foreign correspondents are operating under the most difficult conditions, according to authoritative reports received here.

Pirandello wrote a play in which Death passed by one of his intended victims and placed a flower in his buttonhole, saying, "Keep it; I'll be back to get it a little later on." Diabetes doesn't have a "pretty" name like epithelioma, but it might have been represented by Pirandello's flower.

PARIS, Dec. 4 -- Word has been received here that if the military siuation in China continues to deteriorate, Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek's Government plans to establish itself in the former Japanese-owned island of Formosa, which was returned to Chinese sovereignty after World War II.

EVEN a casual survey of gardens and other landscape plantings at this time of year reveals the home owner's relatively small use of native shrubs and trees. Wherever they do grow, however, many display vivid color.

IT is always dangerous, and peculiarly so in the case of motion pictures, to declare categorically that this or the other is a "first" or precedential accomplishment. For the motion picture is one of the most loosely documented of the arts and researchers are constantly amazed by the contradictory nature of available screen history.

Reading Louis Stark's interesting article on Secretary of Labor Maurice Tobin ("Tobin Plans for Labor Peace") brought back memories of my, and Mr. Tobin's, early days in Boston. The "owl trolley" that the young newsboy Tobin rode into Boston to buy his papers more cheaply must have been one of the old-time "open" cars for which Boston once was famous.
THERE'S a seat to Florida this winter for every sun-seeker, whether his preference is train, plane or bus. This means that there need be no black market this season for southbound transportation.

The city's newest auction house, the Kende Galleries, 119 West Fifty-seventh Street, will hold its first sale on Tuesday and Wednesday evening, offering the famous $1,000,000 "French" library of the late Cortlandt F. Bishop.

POTTED plants, returning to artificially heated rooms after a long sojourn outdoors, need careful handling if their indoor adjustment is to be a success. Proper containers are a determining factor in this adjustment, for they can mean the difference between the life, death or mere existence of the plants.

NANKING, Dec. 4 -- The arrival of Mme. Chiang Kai-shek in Washington to make an eleventh-hour personal appeal for assistance provides a clearly apparent source of embarrassment for both President Truman and Secretary of State Marshall.

ENTERTAINMENT will be more lavish than ever at Miami Beach night clubs. The night spots are again concentrating on Broadway names. Although club owners say that prices will be a little lower than last year for the guests, salaries for entertainers will be higher.

BERLIN, Dec. 4 -- About 5,000 workers of Bewag (Berliner Elektrizitaets Werke Aktiengesellschaft), Berlin's largest power company, today openly defied the newly imposed Communist Government in the Soviet sector of Berlin and threatened to strike.

SAN FRANCISCO -- The perpetual to-do about California's sunshine, warmth, and palm trees generally obscures the fact that the Golden State also possesses unquestionably the most extensive array of winter resorts of any state in the union.
SANTIAGO, Chile, Dec. 4 (AP) -- Chile today offered asylum to Romulo Gallegos, ousted President of Venezuela.

FOR THIS WEEK: Hold leaf mulches in place by means of branches, and place evergreens for winter protection so that their ends can be stuck in the ground before it freezes. . . . Sow seeds of radish and lettuce in the greenhouse. . . . Prop open the sash of cold-frames in order to ventilate on warm, sunny days. . . .
IF the cities were all America, as they pretend, fifty years would see the march of progress brought to a standstill, as a locomotive is stopped by heated bearings. * * *
NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 4 -- Aided by a five-goal handicap, the Ramapo Cubs defeated the Newark Polo Club, 14 -- 12, in the feature contest tonight at Essex Troop Armory.

Encouraged by gains in the Nov. 2 election, Paul E. Fitzpatrick, Democratic state chairman, and other party leaders will discuss plans for pressing a Democratic legislative program at a conference tomorrow at the Biltmore Hotel.

The 57-year-old steam tug El Toro, second vessel to be built at the Hampton Roads yard of the Newport News Shipbuilding and Drydock Company, has returned home, according to the latest issue of The Shipyard Bulletin.

CAIRO, Egypt, Dec. 4 -- Cairo Police Chief Selim Zaki Pasha was killed by a hand grenade hurled from the roof of the Medical College this morning while some 5,000 university and secondary school students rioted and stoned the police.

FROM 1821 to 1846 New Mexico was the northern province of old Mexico and was considerably larger than it is today: in fact, the Gobernador in Santa Fe ruled a huge empty empire stretching more or less from Oregon to Missouri.

PRINCETON, N.J., Dec. 4 -- "All in Favor," the fifty-seventh annual production of the Triangle Club, Princeton University undergraduate dramatic organization, will open in McCarter Theatre here Friday night in the first of three local performances preceding a 2,500-mile road tour during the university's Christmas recess.
THE winter sports competitive schedule in this country is expected to reach record-breaking proportions this season, with several hundred skiing events listed.

A $280,000,000 contract, under which the Swedish Government was to have supplied Soviet Russia with industrial equipment, will be only one-third filled in the opinion of Thorsten Ericson, Swedish industrialist and president of the General Swedish Electric Company, who sailed yesterday for Goeteborg aboard the Swedish American liner Gripsholm.

BOSTON, Dec. 5 (AP) -- The Boston Bruins took advantage of the only penalty against Montreal's Canadiens, called on Defenseman Kenny Reardon, to score twice in 37 seconds for a 2-1 victory tonight before 13,900 at the Boston Garden.

BERLIN, Dec. 5 -- Heinrich Schwieterka who runs a saloon on the corner of Weser and Weichsel Streets just 200 yards from the Soviet sector border had today his biggest day of business since the final weeks of the war.

Judges, lawyers and litigants have become increasingly aware of the delays on the calendars of the Supreme Court in New York City. Justice is too slow when it takes two and one-half years to bring a lawsuit to trial, and justice delayed can turn out to be no justice at all.

BERLIN, Monday, Dec. 6 -- The Social Democratic party appears to have won a smashing victory in yesterday's municipal elections in the three Western sectors of blockaded Berlin and German communism has suffered a striking defeat.

Mack G. Klosty, prominent shipping executive, announced today that he would resign as vice president and director of T. J. Stevenson Company, Inc., and affiliated interests to organize his own shipping business. His resignation will become effective Dec. 24.

CHICAGO, Dec. 5 (AP) -- The Chicago Cardinals, capping a battle in the mud with three touchdowns in the final period, smashed the Green Bay Packers, 42 -- 7, today while their place-kicking star, Pat Harder, may have set two National Football League records.

Engaging in a little light exercise at the expense of the hapless Brooklyn Dodgers, the All-America Conference champion Cleveland Browns closed out an undefeated campaign at Ebbets Field yesterday. The score was 31 -- 21, all the Dodger points coming after Paul Brown's regulars had amassed their winning total.

A slight, meek-looking 48-yearold man, who, according to the police mulcted as much as $300 a week in the last six years from more than 1,000 gullible New York housewives by posing as a utility company bill collector, was arraigned yesterday in Brooklyn Felony Court on a charge of forgery.

Walter Hendl, who is in his fourth year as assistant conductor of the New York PhilharmonicSymphony, conducted Saturday night at Carnegie Hall the first of the six concerts he will give with the orchestra this season. There was a large audience, and the soloist was Szymon Goldberg, Polish violinist, who gave a distinguished performance of Brahm's Violin Concerto.

BOSTON, Dec. 5 -- Advocating the removal of the wartime Federal excise tax on spirits at the earliest possible moment, James J. Donovan, Norwood, Ohio, retiring president of the National Tavern Association, declared here today that liquor sales and tax collections are down because of these excises.

Members of St. Thomas Protestant Episcopal Church, Fifth Avenue and Fifty-third Street, celebrated yesterday the 125th anniversary of the founding of the church. At a special service of thanksgiving, the Rev. Dr. Roelif H. Brooks, the rector, outlined an expanded program of social service and charitable work.

Mayor O'Dwyer's three-cornered investigation of charges that waterfront racketeering has made some city piers unrentable will get under way today when Investigation Commissioner John M. Murtagh issues subpoenas to "many" concerns and individuals in the shipping and stevedoring industries.

PARIS, Dec. 5 -- The Governments of the United States, Britain and France told the Soviet Union today that if it wanted to solve the Berlin dispute it must first disown the Communist "government" established since Nov. 30 in the Soviet sector and "permit elections to be held on a city-wide basis."
PARIS, Dec. 5 (UP) -- The text of the United States-British-French statement on Berlin, as made available informally to members of the United Nations Security Council.
SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 5 -- The Embarcadero is expected to boom into activity here tomorrow after ninety-seven days of strike-caused idleness.

Although the reality of God cannot be proved like the "multiplication table," He exists as the life force in men and the source of truth, beauty and justice, Miss Lily H. Montagu, president of the Union of Liberal and Progressive Synagogues of the United Kingdom of Great Britain, declared yesterday.

The Salvation Army will need a considerably larger sum this year for Christmas cheer and winter relief for the needy because of the decreased purchasing power of the dollar, Commissioner Ernest I. Pugmire, the national commander, said yesterday.
VIENNA, Dec. 5 -- Hungary's Communist regime is having trouble with the industrial proletariat on whom, according to Marxist doctrine, its rule must be founded.

The country is attempting for the first time in its history to finance a peacetime boom under the handicap of high corporate and individual income taxes, asserts the current issue of Business Comment, published by the Northern Trust Company of Chicago.

A dramatic demonstration of the meaning and the processes of real democracy was staged yesterday a hundred miles behind the Iron Curtain in what was technically a municipal election in Berlin but actually an important battle in the "cold war" between Russia and the West.
CHICAGO, Dec. 5 (AP) -- Michigan State's application to join the Western Conference will be considered during the four-day annual winter meeting of the Big Nine, beginning Friday.
The Williamsburg Bridge trolley cars, which have rumbled across the span since Nov. 9, 1904, went into the discard yesterday as the forerunner of a $1,345,395 traffic improvement.
SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 5 -On June 1, 1942, a German submarine commanded by Otto V. Bulew, of Hanover, sank the Steamship West Notus 300 miles off Cape Hatteras.

American Christians must speed up the job of evangelizing the Orient before communism takes over the Rev. Barnerd M. Luben. field secretary of the Board of Foreign Missions of the Reformed Church in America, declared yesterday.

From the caldron of mixed races and mixed faiths concentrated in twenty-two low-rent projects the New York City Housing Authority has evolved a program of interfaith and inter-racial good-will that is setting a pattern for large cities in the nation.

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 5 -- The steel industry this year will ship more steel than ever before in its history. On the basis of experience so far there is every reason to expect shipments to exceed 65,500,000 tons of finished steel. This will be 88 per cent more than was shipped in 1939 and more than 4 per cent above the previous record made in 1944.

A nation-wide study on the effectiveness of liquor advertising in national magazines having a general mass circulation, as compared to newspapers circulated in major marketing areas, is expected to produce large-scale shifts to the papers, it was learned over the week-end.

LONDON, Dec. 5 -- Paul G. Hoffman, head of the Economic Cooperation Administration, arrived here today en route to China and Korea. Before he leaves Wednesday he will not only have some talks on the progress of the European Recovery Program but will get his first impressions of the results of the trip made by the Humphrey Committee to Germany to study dismantlement of German industrial plants for reparations.

ACRE, Palestine, Dec. 5 -- In a courthouse that was guarded like a besieged fortress, Nathan FriedmanYellin, leader of the Stern group, came to trial here today with one of his chief lieutenants. They were accused of having been members of a terrorist organization and of having engaged in its activities before and after Sept. 29, when the State of Israel outlawed all such underground units.
The American consumer may be forgiven, perhaps, if he finds it difficult to go along with the economic reasoning behind current proposals to revive the FAO's international wheat agreement.

Plans to increase the state income tax to the levels of the "normal tax" rates in effect in 1941 are being seriously considered by the Dewey administration to finance increasing state governmental costs.
Linda Iris Brown, not quite 4 years old, will soon be one of the best-known "poster girls" in the country.

TIENTSIN, China, Dec. 5 -- Both Chinese and American business men here are bluntly outspoken in their criticisms of any proposal for further United States aid to the regime of Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek. Both groups, talking in terms of trying to do business with the Communists, say that further United States aid now would make United States-China trade impossible later.

The Board of Higher Education will act on a recommendation to promote sixty-eight faculty members of twenty-four departments at City College, it was learned yesterday. The promotions are to be effective on Jan 1.

HONOLULU, Dec. 5 -- An Air Force C-54 transport plane carrying thirty passengers and seven crewmen crashed at sea 340 miles southwest of Johnston Island and 1,000 miles southwest of Honolulu, early this morning. Air Force officials on Oahu tonight were still awaiting word of the fate of the men.
TOKYO, Dec. 5 -- General MacArthur expressed hope today that "world conditions" would permit Japan to participate in the 1952 Olympic Games.

All was quiet on the Eastern Front of Manhattan, where, hopefully, the Parliament of Man is to have its seat. But that was because it was a Sunday and work was suspended on the six blocks of tumbled earth alongside the river, which have been cleared for action at least thus far -- that the buildings which so long turned cattle on the hoof into meat for our tables have been leveled with the ground.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Dec. 5 -- A Long Island Sound record frostbite fleet for a regular weekly regatta of forty-six boats, consisting of thirty-two penguins and fourteen Class B dinghies, competed in the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club's fall series today.
BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 5 -Argentines turned out in great numbers today to elect representatives to a convention that is going to reform the nation's Constitution.

CHICAGO, Dec. 5 -- Calls for the elimination of all pro-Communists from the leadership of the Transport Workers Union, CIO, were applauded here tonight by 200 delegates and alternates to the union's sixth biennial convention.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 (AP) -- Bob Waterfield threw four touchdown passes, Fred Gehrke ran back a kick-off 92 yards for another score and the Los Angeles Rams handed the Washington Redskins their third consecutive one-sided defeat today.
Quiet continued the predominating characteristic of the foreign exchange market, with just two flurries in the smooth surface of rates and business to disturb an otherwise dull week.

On Thursday at 2 P.M. in the kitchen-auditorium of the New York State Extension Service, 124 East Twenty-eighth Street, Miss Lucile Brewer will give a cookery demonstration of holiday bread and rolls. Homemakers who would like to attend may register for the "school" by writing to the service or calling it at LExington 2-4083. Admission is free.

MORRISTOWN, N.J., Dec. 5 -The two-day civil defense exercises during which Northern New Jersey was mobilized against the effects of an imaginary atom bomb attack ended today with a successful series of operations.

VIENNA, Dec. 5 -- Austria's most widely known communist, Ernst Fischer, who has just returned from a visit to the Soviet command and Communist leaders in Berlin, broadly hinted to his party today that the Berlin affair was being used as a feint to distract attention from the Communist conquest of China.

The season's first performances of "Carmen," "La Boheme" and "Lucia Di Lammermoor" will take place during the third week of the Metropolitan Opera season, it was announced yesterday. Lily Pons will appear for the first time this year as Gilda in "Rigoletto" and Frank Guarrera, baritone, will make his Metropolitan debut in "Carmen."

LONDON, Dec. 5 -- Seasonal factors may be largely responsible for the idleness into which the stock markets have now drifted, but it is not the only cause. The markets have had an extraordinarily good run in recent months, and sooner or later they were bound to experience some reaction.

Two major downtown Manhattan arteries, Broome and Grand Streets, will be converted soon to partial one-way operation to serve as express links between the Holland Tunnel and the Williamsburg and Manhattan bridges, it was learned yesterday.

A strong finish enabled Ernest Weber of the German-American A.C. to take the National A.A.U. 25,000 meter walking championship yesterday. The Police Sports Association sponsored the event, held here for the first time.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 5 (AP) -Quarterback Frankie Albert and the San Francisco Forty-Niners whipped the Los Angeles Dons, 38 to 21, and wrote some new records into the professional football book in the wind-up of the All-America Conference campaign here today.
JOGJAKARTA, Java, Dec. 5 (UP) -- Netherlands-Indonesian peace talks have bogged down and "we are unable to continue discussions," Premier Mohammed Hatta of the Indonesian Republic asserted today.

NANKING, Dec. 5 -- After a 500-mile trip through both Communist and Nationalist territory, Miss Geneva Sayre of the Free Methodist Mission at Kaifeng has arrived here with an invitation from the Communists urging all missionaries who had left the Honan area to return and resume their normal activity.

Senator Glen H. Taylor of Idaho, recent Progressive party candidate for Vice President, condemned yesterday the Franco regime in Spain as "a menace to world peace" at two rallies sponsored here by the Joint Anti-Fascist Refugee Committee.

ALBANY, Dec. 5 -- Governor Dewey will meet with legislative leaders and state officials tomorrow to consider proposals for paying sickness disability benefits under the Unemployment Insurance Law to workers who are unemployed because of illness.

Yardsticks used for measuring values of securities which have been accepted standards for guiding investment policy for many years seem strangely to have lost much of their potency in stimulating investor interest in securities this year.

PATERSON, N.J., Dec. 5 (AP) -The Paterson Panthers, charter members of the American Football League when it was formed in 1936, captured their first championship today by trouncing the Wilmington Clippers, 24 -- 14.

More than 9,000 churchgoers, representing the largest throng of worshipers ever to assemble in the Cathedral of St. John the Divine since it was opened to its full length on Nov. 30, 1941, gathered there last night to hear the Rev. Bryan Green, rector of St. Martin's Church, Birmingham, England.

The Kinor Sinfonietta of the Hebrew Arts Foundation, conducted by Siegfried Landau, was heard in an elaborate program, entitled "Stars of Israel," presented for the benefit of Hechalutz Hamizrachi, last night at Carnegie Hall under the sponsorship of the Mizrachi Organization of America.

MINEOLA, L.I., Dec. 5 -- Allweather flying will become "routine" for the commercial airlines only after an elaborate electronic computer has been developed and proved capable of handling a national traffic control pattern, Hector R. Skifter, president of the Airborne Instrument Laboratory here, said today.
Whether for peace or for war, the United States must increase its knowledge and understanding of Russia, the thirty-seventh annual report of the Carnegie Corporation of New York warned yesterday.

Seventy-one paintings, prints pieces of sculpture and examples of decorative aets valued at $750,000 have been sent by the Metropolitan Museum of Art to Toronto for a two-month showing, it was announced yesterday by Theodore Rousseau Jr., curator of the department of paintings.

Parents who adopt "a hush-hush attitude or give the stork story" to children who inquire about their origin were reprimanded yesterday by the Rev. Anselm Leahy, Advent preacher at St. Patrick's Cathedral.
Your editorial of Nov. 18 warns the automobile industry that it must set its house in order with regard to exploiting customers, or face legislative action.

Patients who fall in love with dentists, try to bite them, refuse to pay them or bore them half to death were discussed yesterday at the midwinter meeting of the American Academy of Dental Medicine at the Pennsylvania Hotel.
A new kind of picket line will be thrown around the liner Queen Elizabeth when she arrives here late today.
Dr. Edward M. Bernecker, Commissioner of Hospitals, announced yesterday that he planned to retire from city service at the end of this year.

Because of the deadlock that exists between the airlines and the Port of New York Authority, the Connecticut Aeronautics Commission is seeking to have Bradley Field at Windsor Locks, Conn., considered by the transatlantic operators as a local terminal, it was learned yesterday.

DETROIT, Dec. 5. (AP) -- Sid Luckman threw three touchdown passes as the Chicago Bears whipped the Detroit Lions, 42-to14, today for their sixth straight National Football League victory. Detroit's biggest crowd of the season -- 27,485 fans -- saw the Bears score three touchdowns in the last nine minutes of the game.

ST. DONAT, Que., Dec. 5 -While the Canadian Ski School sought sufficient snows to enable its sixty-five candidates to continue the week-long course today, Leon (Swiss) Renaud, long a popular figure in the Laurentian ski area, took time out to tell of a vast development that should appeal to skiers from the eastern United States.

A spokesman for the Creole Petroleum Company, a subsidiary of the Standard Oil Company (of New Jersey) and the largest producer of oil in Venezuela, said last night that his company had "always taken a non-political position" in the country.
CHICAGO, Dec. 5 (AP) -- Three private planes crashed in the Midwest last night and early today, killing nine men.

PRINCESS ANNE, Md., Dec. 5 -- The increase of land ownership by Negro farmers in this state by 4.1 per cent over 1940 estimates supports plans to develop the old Princess Anne Academy into Maryland State College, a landgrant college for Negroes under the charter of the University of Maryland, Dr. John T. Williams, president of the new college, said today.

With an anticipated $150,000 surplus over its 1948 budget approximately $600,000, the United States Olympic Association already is looking ahead to 1952. Meeting at the New York Athletic Club yesterday, the association voted to start immediately on its fundraising campaign for the next Olympic Games at Stockholm.

CHICAGO, Dec. 5 -- Prices of corn averaged somewhat lower last week on the Board of Trade. Tenders of more than 5,000,000 bushels of cash corn on December contracts resulted in the current month going to 5 3/4 cents a bushel under May at one time.

We of the Metropolitan Fair Rent Committee, seeking to have rent control made fair and equitable, thought we had heard almost every theory expressed as to why apartments should continue to operate at depression rentals despite the property owners' inability to earn a reasonable return.

If your children come away from the telephone with reports that Santa Claus has acquired a feminine voice and a French accent, don't be surprised. They probably have been discussing their Christmas wishes with Miss Louise Binsfield of 305 East Fifty-third Street, who last week, through the vagaries of the telephone dialing system, suddenly found herself impersonating Saint Nick.

Leland H. Rosemond, formerly vice president and director of the Sonotone Corporation, has been appointed vice president in charge of sales of the Eastern division of Microtone Company, Minneapolis, hearing aid manufacturer.

As a means of making New Yorkers aware of the family-counseling services available to them,"Family Closeup" will be broadcast over WJZ Tuesdays from 7:30 to 8 P.M., beginning Dec. 14. The ten-week dramatic series will based on case histories drawn from the files of the Jewish Family Service, a non-sectarian, non-profit organization, which is one of seven family welfare agencies in this city.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., Dec. 5 -Francesco La Sala, who was 100 years old last Thursday, celebrated his centennial tonight with 150 relatives and friends at a cocktail party and dinner-dance in the orchid room of the Gramatan Hotel here.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 5 -- There will he a play-off in the All-America Football Conference next Sunday, but it will be here and not at Cleveland. Furthermore, it will be for the Eastern Division championship only, with the Baltimore Colts and Buffalo Bills struggling for the right to engage the Browns for the top prize a week later.
BERNE, Switzerland, Dec. 5 -The European Recovery Program is in grave danger of becoming a plan for strengthening economic nationalism in Europe, in the opinion of high Swiss Government sources.

Distiller Adjusts Price System to Enable N. Y. Wholesalers Meet Salesmen Demands Liquor distribution in the metropolitan area today was sharply divided into two camps following the announcement over the weekend that Schenley Distillers Corporation will continue to operate through established wholesale channels.

You have Jed Harris' assurance that Lee Tracy definitely will appear in "The Traitor." The work of Herman Wouk, Mr. Harris' next offering will bring back Mr. Tracy, who lit up the sky in "Broadway" (the Harris presentation of hallowed memory), after an absence since "Every Man for Himself," which lasted only three performances in 1940.

CHICAGO, Dec. 5 (AP) -- Winds reaching to 60 miles an hour brought widespread property damage and disruption to Chicago today. They felled power lines, trees and signboards, damaged roofs and cornices, and interrupted electric power in a number of areas.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 5 (AP) -Southern University's Jaguar Cats, completely outclassing their opponents on a muddy field, defeated San Francisco State College, 30 -- 0, today in the second annual Fruit Bowl game before approximately 5,000 fans.

Mel Patton's clocking of 0:09.3 for 100 yards was given belated recognition as an American track record -- a necessary prerequisite of its acceptance as a world mark -- yesterday as the Amateur Athletic Union of the United States wound up the business of its sixtieth annual convention at the Hotel Astor.

Nearly 500 cases of relief goods and gifts from American organizations to groups in the Netherlands will be shipped to Holland next Friday on the Noordam of the Holland-America Line. Many of the presents will not be received before 1949, however, because of delays occasioned by the longshoremen's strike.
SOUTH PLAINFIELD, N.J., Dec. 5 -- An early morning fire that swept a two-and-a-half-story frame dwelling here today resulted in the loss of four lives and sent two survivors to the hospital.

Figuring prominently in another week of much gallery activity are an exhibition of drawings by Degas at the Durand-Ruel Gallery, opening today and a group of new oils and water colors by John Marin starting tomorrow at An American Place.

CHICAGO, Dec. 5 -- The two-andone-half-year-old Tucker Corporation still has not got into mass production of automobiles, but has got into almost every situation that shouldn't happen to a corporation.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Dec. 5 -Still another record number of craft for one of the regular series regattas at the Larchmont Yacht club was out today. Forty-five dinghies, six more than the previous high mark of thirty-nine, which was reached three times this season, competed.

The New Friends of Music, who have reached their 226th concert, presented their new group of "players" at Town Hall last night. The group, consisting of three strings, four winds and piano, is an experienced lot of musicians, youthful in ensemble, but still first rate in concert.

In the twelve days beginning Friday, 12,000 volunteer workers will seek contributions to the current $16,500,000 campaign of the Federation of Jewish Philanthropies of New York, Ralph E. Samuel, president of the federation, 71 West Forty-seventh Street, announced yesterday.

In his recent sermon Dr. Paul Wolfe pointed out that one hundred years ago Europe was in the throes of revolutions; that in 1798, fifty years earlier, Napoleon was emerging from the French Revolution, and that fifty years later, as of 1898, the end of the established order was predicted.

The enemies of the church have "manufactured the principle of separation of church and state in order to oppose religion," the Most Rev. Stephen J. Donahue, auxilliary bishop of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York, said yesterday at the silver jubilee communion breakfast of the New York Circle, International Federation of Catholic Alumnae, held in the Hotel Commodore.

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 5 (AP) -- The New York Giants' sensational freshman, Chuck Conerly, set a new passing record for the National Football League today but the Pittsburgh Steelers' power won the ball game, 38 -- 28.

PARIS, Dec. 5 -- The Radical Socialist party of Premier Henri Queuille and Edouard Herriot paid tribute tonight to United States aid but asked for French neutrality in a clash of the two world blocs of the West and East.

ZURICH, Dec. 5 -- Without any visible cause the free dollar exchange rate, which had been steady for weeks past, rose day by day from 3.95 francs to the dollar on Nov. 24 to 4.03 on Dec. 1, the official parity being 4.30 to the dollar.
HAVANA, Dec. 5 -- United States petroleum companies and local reactionary groups were responsible for the recent Army coup in Venezuela, Romulo Gallegos, exiled President, said here today.

The dramatic side of a Congressman's life is often emphasized. He makes speeches, during campaigns and sometimes on the floor of the House. When he goes home people feed him and ask him for favors. He can put an "Hon." before his name. If he is on an important committee, whose investigators find documents in a pumpkin, sermons in stones or books in the running brooks, his name appears in the papers.

The Brevoort Management Company, industrial realty brokers, bought the four-story building at 235 Duffield Street, near Fulton Street, Brooklyn, and will convert it into an office building for the buyers own use.

Paul Boepple, conductor of the Dessoff Choirs and the Bennington College Chorus, led both groups late yesterday afternoon at Carnegie Hall in a program of religious music, in which the contemporary works were sung by the forty-five college girls and thee early works by the 185 Dessoff singers.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Dec. 5--The clock ran out on Memorial High School in its Hudson County Interscholastic Athletic Association invitation football classic with Camden Catholic with the result that the visitors from Southern New Jersey were able to march off the field on top of a 19 to 13 count today.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 -- American motion-picture companies will receive about $100,000,000 this year from foreign showings of their films, the Department of Commerce said today.

STEWART HOLBROOK is a member in excellent standing of the "I'll be readable if it kills me" school of writing. A Vermonter by birth and a resident of the State of Washington by choice, he has long specialized in the shaggier, friskier and more unbuttoned aspects of American history. The author of nearly a dozen books and quantities of effervescent journalism, Mr. Holbrook delights in material which more solemn historians pass by.

PARIS, Dec. 5 -- Experts of the Organization for European Economic Cooperation report that the first settlement of accounts under the plan for intra-European payment is taking place in a satisfactory manner. This plan was adopted and signed by countries party to the Marshall Plan at a special meeting here on Oct. 17.
CHICAGO, Dec. 5 -- Liquidation developed in lard futures on the Board of Trade last week and prices dropped below 18 cents a pound at one time, except on the December.

Although apparel sales showed some improvement at the retail level last week, retailers continued to place only light orders for spring merchandise, according to reports prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices.
AMSTERDAM, Dec. 5 -- Finance Minister Pieter Lieftinck has asked the Bank of the Netherlands to be prepared to draft a bill for Government control on private banking.

The first of three collegiate basketball twin-showings at Madison Square Garden this week will unfold tonight when St. John's University tackles the Denver Skyline Conference Pioneers and New York University matches shots with the Red Raiders from Colgate.

The Workers Defense League, which twice requested the United Nations to conduct an inquiry into forced labor in many parts of the world, announced yesterday that it would hold public hearings of its own in February.
WARSAW, Dec. 5 (AP) -- The Communists have just strengthened their hold on Poland by taking over the nation's trade unions.

PARIS, Dec. 5 -- A definite improvement in the health situation of Central and Southeastern Europe over that of ten months ago was reported today by Dr. Berislav Borcitch, Deputy European Director of the United Nations International Children's Emergency Fund.

Karin Branzell, the eminent Swedish contralto, gave her annual New York recital yesterday afternoon at Town Hall. In a program composed of German, Scandinavian and English songs, and excerpts from Wagner's "Das Rheingold" and Tchaikovsky's "Pique Dame," the artist evoked ovations from her audience by the splendor of her voice and the nobility of her interpretations.

PRETORIA, South Africa, Dec. 5 -- One minute after midnight tonight somewhere in the Antartic the largest fleet in the annals of whaling is due to open four-month hunting season with the objective of making 33,000 kills. This represents the limit fixed by the international agreement negotiated in Washington two years ago.

The second annual memorial service of the Kings County Council of the Disabled American Veterans was held yesterday afternoon on the steps of Borough Hall, Brooklyn, with 1,000 persons taking part in the exercises.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 5 -W. R. Frank, independent producer, and John Taintor Foote, author and scenarist, have announced that the first production of their newly-formed partnership will be a screen adaptation of "Opus 43," a short story by Foote published twenty years ago.
The thirty-seventh annual Christmas appeal for THE NEW YORK TIMES Neediest Cases Fund opened yesterday with gifts of $56,746.12 from 191 contributors.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Dec. 5 (UP) -An investigating committee of the National Association of Baseball Leagues, ruling body of the minors, today recommended that the televising of night games be banned.

ONE of the most authoritative spokesmen for intercollegiate sports in this neck of the woods is Asa S. Bushnell, the Commissioner of the Eastern College Athletic Conference and the unquestioned Mr. Big of practically every phase of collegiate activity along the Atlantic Seaboard. Whenever he speaks he's well worth listening to, particularly when he discusses that most provocative, annoying and cantankerous rule, free substitutions.

LONDON, Dec. 5 -- During the last week the Arab countries have felt the first tremors of the political upheaval that British and Arab experts on the Middle East had predicted would follow the Arabs' defeat in Palestine.

PARIS, Dec. 5 -- The General (Steering) Committee of the United Nations General Assembly decided today that the Assembly should reconvene in New York early next year for a second half of this session.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Dec. 5 -- Mrs. Robert S. Horne's Ch. Hobbyhorne Cintorson, a fawn and white dog not yet 4 years old, was selected best of breed in the fiftyfourth specialty show of the Bulldog Club of America at the Westchester County Center today.

BOSTON, Dec. 5 (AP) -- Boston's lowly Yanks ended their National Football League season in a blaze of glory today by breaking a six-game losing streak at the expense of the Philadelphia Eagles, the Eastern Division champions, 37 -- 14, before a crowd of 9,652 at Fenway Park.
Boys and men have been taking an increasing part during the last seven years in the activities of the Young Women's Christian Association in thirteen large cities, it was made known yesterday.

The Chast Realty Corporation representing a syndicate of investors, bought the ninestory apartment house with penthouses on a plot 50 by 100 feet at 17 East Eighty-fourth Street in a transaction negotiated by Samuel J. Landau, broker, and the Rowley Realty Management Corporatiom, cobroker.

LONDON, Dec. 5 -- The British Government rejected today a proposal to ask the United Nations to dispatch a mediator or mediation commission to Greece. The suggestion was made by the Union of Democratic Control, an organization interested in international affairs.

PARIS, Dec. 5 -- The possibility that a complete debacle of Nationalist forces in China might wreck the structure of the United Nations is being quietly studied by diplomatists. This conjecture is postulated upon certain assumptions: That the Communists overrun Nanking and the Yangtse Valley; that Moscow grants diplomatic recognition to a new Communist "government"; that the Western Powers continue to recognize the Chiang Kai-shek Government wherever it might be situated.

CHICAGO, Dec. 5 -- The wheat market continued its gradual advance on the Board of Trade last week with December selling at a new high since Feb. 4 and up 15 3/4 cents a bushel from the low price immediately preceding the Presidential election.

Menachem Begin, former commander of the disbanded Irgun Zvai Leumi, reviewed here yesterday 200 youthful members of Brith Trumpeldor (Betar), the militaristic, nationalistic Zionist organization founded by the late Vladimir Jabotinsky.

The statement in THE TIMES of Nov. 28, attributed to Ashley L. Totten, secretary-treasurer of the Brotherhood of Sleeping Car Porters, relative to the work of the New York State Commission Against Discrimination reveals a lack of information or a faulty memory, either of which is unfortunate in one who essays to speak for labor.

Bob Porterfield, 25-year-old righthander of the Newark Bears, posted the best earned-run average among International League pitchers in the 1948 season, according to final official averages released yesterday, The Associated Press reported.
Six first-run theatres will present new firm attractions this week. The programs follow:

When we speak of social security we think of millions of people. It is a noble concept. We don't want anyone to go hungry, anyone to go cold, anyone to go inadequately clothed, anyone to live in a house that is grimly dangerous to health and happiness. We don't want the creeping sickness of fear in American homes.

PROVIDENCE, R. I., Dec. 5 -Although some local textile mills report a drop in sales and national surveys indicate production and prices are beginning to level off, the textile machinery business here is forging ahead with payrolls consistently totalling more than a million dollars monthly.

Ground-breaking ceremonies for the new $500,000 Mount Sinai Synagogue and Jewish Center were held yesterday at 305 State Street, Brooklyn, site of the original synagogue that was destroyed by fire last January.

" Israel: A History of the Jewish People," by Rufus Learsi, will be published on Feb. 25 by World. The one-volume history of 726 pages will cover the 4,000 years up to the establishment of the State of Israel. It will be illustrated with sixteen maps.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 -- Dr. Juan Atilio Bramuglia, Foreign Minister of Argentina, has been officially invited to the United States and will stop in Washington for two days on his way home from the meeting of the United Nations, it was learned tonight.

If things seem considerably brighter in the choreographic field this morning, it is because Mariemma and her company in their formal New York debut at the Ziegfeld Theatre last night gave far and away the best performance of Spanish dancing that has been seen in these parts in many a long day.

The local towboat industry is concerned over the proposals presented last week by Local 333, United Marine Division, International Longshoremen's Association. It disagrees completely with John J. Corrigan, the union's counsel, who has described the demands as "very moderate," it was learned yesterday.

CHICAGO, Dec. 5 (AP) -- Turk Broda turned in his third shut-out of the National Hockey League season tonight as Toronto defeated the Chicago Black Hawks 2 -- 10 before 16,982 and thereby restored themselves to a fourth-place tie with the home team.

Another defeat was added to the New York Rangers' fast-growing list last night. The Detroit Red Wings, buttressed by as strong a defense as can be found currently in the National Hockey League, put Frank Boucher's Blue Shirts deeper into the cellar by handing them a 3-to-1 setback before a crowd of 15,346 fans at Madison Square Garden.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Dec. 5 -Troops were keeping order today in the troubled cities of Damascus and Cairo, it was reported here. Former President Hashen el-Atassi was trying to form a new Cabinet in Damascus but was insisting on broad powers of reform, it was understood.

Councilman Edward Rager, Manhattan Republican, said yesterday that he would introduce at the next meeting of the City Council a resolution calling for realistic and enlightened divorce laws in this state. The existing law makes divorce.
More than 700 life insurance executives from companies all over the country will meet this week for three annual organization meetings. All sessions will be in the Waldorf-Astoria.
If the recommendations of three New York educators are taken seriously by the comic book publishers, Junior's comics will be "improved" for him whether he likes it or not.

Federal, state and local governmental non-wage payments now exceed total wages and salaries in the automotive, iron and steel and rubber industries combined, according to an analysis of welfare payments just completed by the National Industrial Conference Board and released over the weekend.

HOLLYWOOD, Fla., Dec. 5 -- A three-point program for promoting the wider and more frequent publication of reports of earnings of public projects financed out of revenues instead of taxation was presented to the Investment Bankers Association convention here today by a special committee headed by Phillips Barbour.

The late S. Parker Gilbert, who served in Berlin from 1924 to 1930 as Agent General for Reparations Payments, had an excellent opportunity to witness at first hand the evil consequences of reckless government spending policies. He once observed of deficit financing:
WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 (UP) -Soviet Russia has reduced its official Government staff in the United States by more than a fifth during the last three months, it was disclosed today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 -- Sumner Welles, former Under-Secretary of State, evaluated for the House Committee on Un-American Activities today the contents of the microfilmed State Department documents obtained from Whittaker Chambers, admitted member of a Communist spy ring that operated here a decade ago.

It was a dismal and most unsatisfactory homecoming that the New York Rovers experienced yesterday at Madison Square Garden. Their attack fizzling at almost every turn, the New Yorkers absorbed their worst beating of the season in bowing to the Boston Olympics, 9 to 1, in a Quebec Senior Hockey League fracas.

That traditional post-holiday pastime -- returning Christmas presents -- has been given a new twist this season by Bellevue Hospital and the Madison Square Boys Club. The presents, an array of scooters, tricycles and big red wagons, were gifts from the boys to Bellevue two years ago.

PARIS, Dec. 5. -- The United States, Australia and China will submit to the General Assembly of the United Nations a joint resolution that will leave individual members of the United Nations free to decide whether they should recognize the Seoul regime as the "lawful Government" for all Korea, it was learned today.

Although Jean-Paul Sartre has some penetrating things to say in "Red Gloves," you would hardly suspect it from his play. Apart from Charles Boyer's acting, the exercises conducted at the Mansfield on Saturday evening looked and sounded bogus.

Prices of cotton in the domestic market showed marked improvement last week. Active futures on the New York Cotton Exchange registered net gains of 64 to 99 points, against changes ranging from a decline of 13 to a gain of 4 points at the close of the previous week.

Plans for a business building to be occupied by the realty and insurance business of the A.G. Masucci Corporation were reported in connection with the purchase by Anthony G. Masucci of a lot 25 by 100 feet on the south side of Bedford Park Boulevard, sixtyfour feet west of Decatur Avenue, in the Bronx.

ALBANY, Dec. 5 -- The Joint Legislative Committee on Insurance Rates and Regulation will hold hearings on Dec. 16 and 17 to discuss proposed legislation providing for injunctions and criminal action to prevent the sale of unauthorized mail order accident and health insurance policies, Walter J. Mahoney, chairman, announced today.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 5 -Warning that American universities are threatened by "educational mediocrity" as the result of record enrollments, President Charles Seymour of Yale University, in his annual report to the alumni, asserted today that independent colleges and universities must set an example of quality.

ALBANY, Dec. 5 -- The Joint Legislative Committee on Insurance Rates and Regulation will hold hearings on Dec. 16 and 17 to discuss proposed legislation providing for injunctions and criminal action to prevent the sale of unauthorized mail order accident and health insurance policies, Walter J. Mahoney, chairman, announced today.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 5 -Warning that American universities are threatened by "educational mediocrity" as the result of record enrollments, President Charles Seymour of Yale University, in his annual report to the alumni, asserted today that independent colleges and universities must set an example of quality.

The Commissioner of Hospitals, Dr. Edward M. Bernecker, is retiring from that post at the end of the year and has performed the valuable service of bringing the public up to date on conditions in the municipal hospitals. His letter of report to Mayor O'Dwyer covers the last three years, since Mr. O'Dwyer took office, and some solid accomplishments are recorded.

Continuing its drive to tighten its purse strings, the Veterans Administration announced yesterday it was requiring all privatelyoperated, profit-making schools in the city to enter into contracts for teaching veterans.

Alger Hiss issued last night an unqualified denial of accusations made in sworn testimony of Whittaker Chambers that the former State Department official had furnished to him "restricted" Government documents for underground transmission to the Soviet Union.

A blond-haired, blue-eyed little girl of 3 stole the thunder of a group of city officials at a Bronx ground-breaking yesterday by doing the job with a toy red shovel before the dignitaries arrived with their ceremonial silver-plated spades.

The initial presentation to metropolitan area dealers of Zenith Radio Corporation's first television receiver line was made yesterday at a dealer meeting in the showrooms of the company's local factory branch, Zenith Radio Corporation of New York.

HOLLYWOOD, Fla., Dec. 6 -- Although the drift toward socialism is persisting in the United States "through accepted democratic methods" and "in an orderly way," investment banking still can be a thriving private business for firms that are resourceful and aggressive in their advertising and merchandising methods.

Ignoring American and British recommendations that it continue work until its immediate program is completed, the General Assembly of the United Nations has voted to adjourn its first European session next Saturday night and to reconvene in a special session in New York on April 1.
Twenty-seven-year-old David Sarser, a violinist with the NBC Symphony Orchestra for the last three years, yesterday became the owner of a famous musical instrument, the "Lamoureux Stradivarius."

Consumer statements reflecting general ineffectiveness of most perfume advertising, contained in research findings disclosed yesterday by a manufacturers' group, is expected to produce extensive changes in future perfume product ads, according to S. L. Mayham, executive vice president of the Toilet Goods Association.
Southern California's stunning 14-14 tie against Notre Dame Saturday reduced to thirteen the final number of unbeaten and untied college football teams in the nation for the 1948 season.

The New York City Rent Advisory Board rejected yesterday a proposal for a general 10 per cent decrease in rents on 1,800,000 Federally controlled apartments and other dwelling units in the city and Nassau and Suffolk Counties. This was announced by Joseph D. McGoldrick, chairman, after a meeting in the Empire State Building.

TOKYO, Dec. 6 -- Conflict over Japan's civil service has only begun with the passage of the National Public Service Law, according to Blaine Hoover, chief of the Supreme Allied Command's Civil Service Division.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 6 -- The United States Public Health Service and cooperating Southeastern states are making "rapid progress" in their five-year, $6,000,000 program to reduce malaria infection to "a negligible public health problem," it was announced today before a national convention on tropical medicine.
Dr. Clyde E. Minges, president of the American Dental Association, reiterated last night its opposition to President Truman's stand for national compulsory health insurance.
PORTLAND, Me., Dec. 6 (AP) -- The nation's housewives have bought more canned fruits and vegetables this year than ever before, the executive secretary of the National Canners Association said today.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Dec. 6 -- The United Nations Educational Scientific and Cultural Organization moved today into the final stages of preparing next year's program, as the Budget subcommittee reviewed its decisions for submission to the Budget Committee and to the plenary session.
MOUNT HOLLY, N.J., Dec. 6 -- The two Delaware River bridges bought by Burlington County will net a $4,000,000 profit within twelve years, the Burlington County Bridge Commission declared today.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 -- The Supreme Court, splitting 5 to 4, ruled today that a United States military base in Bermuda was, for purposes of the Federal Wage-Hour Law, a "possession" of this country.

The Lord's Day Alliance of the United States went to the aid yesterday of New York grocers and delicatessen owners who want a few free hours on Sunday, when it unanimously adopted a resolution calling on city magistrates to enforce the state Sunday closing law.

Hearing of testimony on a writ of habeas corpus brought by Mrs. Belle Popper Gramunt, 25-year-old former Marine Corps sergeant, to regain custody of her 18-month-old son, Mark, from the Free Synagogue's Child Adoption, started yesterday before Supreme Court Justice Bernard Botein.
