News of the theatre for both professionals and the general public will be dovetailed to form "Show Business," which WNEW will introduce Sunday night at 10:15 o'clock. The quarter-hour program will bear no relationship to the show of the same name which the station puts on week-days at noon.

ALBANY, Dec. 6 -- The official count of the New York State vote cast for President, announced today by the State Board of Canvassers, shows that Gov. Thomas E. Dewey's plurality over President Truman was 60,959, and that 769,046 persons registered for the election did not cast ballots.
ALBANY, Dec. 6 (AP) -- A special deputy state attorney general will start an on-the-spot investigation tomorrow of alleged election fraud in Utica.
PARIS, Dec. 6 (UP) -- Russia fears its women may get dishpan hands if they are permitted to leave the Soviet Union with foreign husbands, the United Nations was told today.

Seasonal declines in the wholesale prices of meat brought announcements yesterday from leading chain stores of reductions at retail of 4 to 8 cents a pound in beef, pork and lamb. Veal was virtually unchanged as the Department of Agriculture noted that "high-good to choice grades continued scarce."

PARIS, Dec. 6 -- In a new memorandum handed to the United States Embassy here today, the French Government expressed the hope that the level of steel production in Western Germany would not be raised as a ceiling for the combined United States-British bizonal area.

This is the first in a series of four columns on food products for the holidays. Gift suggestions from the small specialty shops are reviewed today, and tomorrow those from the larger retailers, including the department stores, will be presented.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Dec. 6 -- After visiting the Arab capitals of Amman and Cairo, Dr. Ralph J. Bunche, acting United Nations Mediator for Palestine, arrived here today with more confidence than ever that peace was just around the corner.
Robert P. Patterson, former Secretary of War, was elected president of Freedom House for the coming year, it was announced yesterday after a meeting of the board of directors.

MONTREAL, Que., Dec. 6 -- In the heart of this picturesque city is an imposing winter sports center fashioned out of a twin-headed extinct volcanic mountain known as Mount Royal. Maintained by the city, Mount Royal has been kept as a park, with motor travel barred. Here, too, more than two and one-half miles of ski slopes and trails are to be found.

Bidding for some of the oils lent an improved appearance yesterday to the stock market. Activity in some medium-and low-price issues again sent volume above the million-share level. However, the advance was fleeting, and some of the electronics came under realizing, although the airlines fared better.

More than a month after election day, Surrogate-elect George Frankenthaler received his certificate of election yesterday morning from Commissioner David B. Costuma, secretary of the Board of Elections. Mr. Frankenthaler, the Republican-Liberal candidate, had defeated General Sessions Judge John A. Mullen, Democrat, by an official plurality of 1,150 votes, but litigation by Tammany Hall delayed confirmation of the result.
Twenty new single season team records and eight all-time major league marks were written in the All-America Football Conference books during the '48 season.
The Long Island Rail Road denied yesterday that the Pennsylvania Railroad compelled the former to pay exorbitant rates for use of Pennsylvania Station.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 -- Sworn testimony by Whittaker Chambers, confessed courier for a pre-war Communist underground, that Alger Hiss, as a State Department official, slipped him "restricted" documents for delivery to a Russian agent was made public by the House Committee on Un-American Activities today.

Commodity prices generally are continuing their decline, indicating to some persons that the post-war peak may have been passed. The post-war high for the Bureau of Labor Statistics' Index of whole-sale prices was reached in the week ended on Sept. 18, last, when it stood at 169.4.

LONDON, Dec. 6 -- Thousands of persons are going to start painting furiously and happily, for Winston Churchill's book "Painting as a Pastime" is being published here tomorrow. The boundless enthusiasm of this most famous of all living amateurs is conveyed fully in this long essay, reprinted from the little-read book "Thoughts and Adventure," published in 1932, when Mr. Churchill was in eclipse.
BUCHAREST, Rumania, Dec. 6 (AP) -- Rumania has taken over all property of the Uniate (Rumanian rite) Catholic Church.
CHICAGO, Dec. 6 (AP) -- It was signals off today on Cardinal Fullback Pat Harder's claim of a new National Football League record for consecutive extra-point conversions.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 -- Senator Homer E. Capehart, head of the Senate subcommittee on trade policies, declared today that Representative Wright Patman's recent criticism of the subcommittee's inquiry into the pricing policies of American business was the "cheapest sort of petty politics ever indulged in by any man."

LONDON, Dec. 6 -- A crowd of more than 10,000 sat down at Harringay Arena tonight to witness what the program called "the eliminating contest for the heavyweight championship of the world." In one minute 35 seconds of the fourth round they saw Lee Savold of Paterson, N.J., disqualified for a low punch that had Britain's top heavyweight, Bruce Woodcock, squirming on the canvas.

Home decorators burdened with a hodgepodge of furnishings accumulated over the years used to envy anyone who could start over from scratch. But today, the young families who have to buy everything from box springs to table lamps in one big order face the problem of high prices.

LONDON, Dec. 6 -- Britain's nationalized coal industry will show a deficit for the third quarter of this year, the National Coal Board reported tonight. Instead of an expected profit of 3,477,057 [about $14,000,000] the board will show a los of 372,943.

The Queen Elizabeth of the Cunard White Star Line docked at 10:05 o'clock last night at Pier 90, North River, fourteen days behind schedule as a result of weather and the recent dock strike here. She had 2,209 passengers, more than half of whom had been aboard the giant vessel for the last nineteen days.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 -- Former Gen. Kenji Doihara and former Premier Koki Hirota, two of the seven Japanese war leaders sentenced by the International Military Tribunal to death on the gallows, won today the right to a hearing by the United States Supreme Court.

ST. LOUIS, Dec. 6 -- State Committeemen whose views from the "grass roots" serve as an important guide for Administration agricultural policy heard today from their chief that the period of "virtually unlimited demand" for farm products may be coming to an end.

William Green president of the American Federation of Labor, has filed a formal protest with the National Labor Relations Board over the board's handling of problems affecting a jurisdictional dispute between West Coast seagoing radio unions.

SHANGHAI, Dec. 6 -- A block-long phalanx of shouting Chinese pushed through the heart of this city's financial district today halting all traffic as they passed. Scattered police stood aside helplessly.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 -- The Supreme Court today completed a trilogy of rulings by which -- against the strongest challenge in many years -- it stanchly upheld the powers of the states over the "manner" of choosing their Presidential electors and other aspects of their political processes as guaranteed in the Constitution.

NANKING, Dec. 6 -- The Communist radio declared tonight that Gen. Chen Yi's Communist columns had clamped an "air-tight" encirclement on three Nationalist army groups in a triangular area along the Honan-Kiangsu border southwest of Suchow.

Since the function of the Equity Library Theatre is to give actors and directors opportunities to work, it is illegal for this department to comment on the value of Georg Kaiser's "From Morn Till Midnight," produced for a few overprivileged theatregoers at 1880 Broadway yesterday afternoon.

Cotton and rayon textile exports this year will fall short of those in 1947 by about 40 per cent, it was estimated yesterday by New York exporters. But hose selling textiles abroad may derive comfort from the fact that exports will prove stronger than was anticipated earlier in the year, when predictions of a 50 per cent cut were made.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 6 (AP) -- James Roosevelt, son of the late President and Democratic National Committeeman from California, who opposed the nomination of President Truman at Philadelphia, told the Democratic gathering here tonight:

Examination of matrimonial files unsealed by court order last week and the questioning of persons suspected of complicity in collusive divorce actions continued yesterday in District Attorney Frank S. Hogan's office as the extended November Grand Jury reconvened to hear further testimony presented by the prosecutor.

The esteem in which several stock market operators held the financial forecasts of Frederick N. Goldsmith, 82-year-old analyst of market trends, was not shared by Supreme Court Justice Benjamin F. Schreiber who yesterday enjoined publication of the Goldsmith Financial Service.
ALBANY, Dec. 6 (AP) -- Gov. Thomas E. Dewey today appointed Supreme Court Justice John MacCrate of Brooklyn to serve a full five-year term in the Appellate Division, Second Department.

PARIS, Dec. 6 -- United States currency reached today a record quotation of 500 francs to the dollar in the unofficial or so-called black market. In the Government-controlled free market the franc is still being quoted at 313 francs to the dollar.

LONDON, Dec. 6 -- Efforts were started in London today to settle on a practical and factual basis the disagreement between the United States on the one hand and Britain and France on the other, over the dismantling of industrial plants in Western Germany.

Basketball is a sport in which teams often live or die by the clock and last night at Madison Square Garden St. John's and N.Y.U. proved it. St. John's came from behind to tie Denver and then went on to win in overtime, 55 -- 53, averting a second extra session by ten seconds and Colgate beat the Violets, 64 -- 63, on a last-second goal.

PEARL HARBOR, Dec. 6 -- The Navy escort carrier Rendova informed Pacific Fleet headquarters here this evening that its crew had picked up thirty-three of the thirty-seven men who were aboard the Air Force C-54 transport plane when it ditched at sea southwest of Johnston Island early Sunday.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 6 -- Decrying the notion that political campaign promises are something to attract votes and then be cast aside, Senator Alben W. Barkley, the Vice President-elect, tonight affirmed the intention of the Democratic uarty to carry out its election pledges explicitly.

Fifteen years ago this week many millions of Americans discovered that they could get a drink without identifying themselves to a man named "Joe" or buying imitation Scotch from a shady character who said he had got it off a man off a boat. Speakeasies in states not having sumptuary laws of their own became legitimate restaurants.

PARIS, Dec. 6 -- Gen. Charles de Gaulle denied today a statement by Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower that two days after his entry into Paris in August, 1944, the French leader asked the Allied Commander in Chief for the loan of two American divisions to assure his authority as self-proclaimed head of the French Provisional Government.

CHICAGO, Dec. 6 -- With supporters of Michael J. Quill in full control, the convention of the Transport Workers Union, CIO, eliminated all of the left-wing members of the union's international executive board here tonight.
Contributions from out of town helped to swell the donations to THE NEW YORK TIMES Neediest Cases Fund yesterday, the second day of the thirty-seventh annual Christmas appeal.

TRENTON, N.J., Dec. 6 -- State Senator Samuel L. Bodine of Flemington became the Republican Senate majority leader for 1949 tonight after a deadlock within a caucus was broken after almost unprecedented secret balloting.
PRAGUE, Dec. 6 (AP) -- The bad economic health of Czechoslovakia is being carried to Moscow for diagnosis.

TOKYO, Dec. 6 -- Repudiating a report of its Steering Committee, the Japanese House of Representatives voted tonight to permit the arrest of former Premier Hitoshi Ashida on charges of political corruption. A warrant for Dr. Ashida's arrest had been issued by the Tokyo District Court.

The Glendale Unified School District of Los Angeles County, Calif., will receive bids next Tuesday on a $2,200,000 bond issue, not exceeding a coupon rate of 5 per cent, it was announced yesterday. The bonds will be dated Jan. 1, 1949, and will come due Jan. 1, 1950 to 1974.

Ania Dorfmann's piano recital at Town Hall last night revealed two distinct facets of her performing personality. One was a crisp ingenuousness of style with which she treated the classical selections that began her program; the other was a bold fervor which she applied to the romantic works that made up the balance of the evening.
The Department of Sanitation will extend the program of public education now being carried out in East Harlem to eight other congested and refuse-strewn areas in Manhattan, Brooklyn and the Bronx.

MIAMI, Dec. 6 -- Robert Barrett of Houston, Tex., and William Joseph of Syracuse, N.Y., were leading with 212 points at the close today of the first of the two-session Orange Blossom Pairs contest in the twenty-second annual winter National Tournament of the American Contract Bridge League here.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 -- A recommendation that an exchange rate for the Japanese yen should be established as soon as possible to increase trade between Japan and other nations was made public today by the Far Eastern Commission on which eleven nations are represented.

A request that the eight-second-count rule in New Jersey boxing be suspended for the Ray Robinson-Steve Belloise middleweight battle in the Jersey City Armory Thursday night was rejected by Abe J. Greene, New Jersey's State Athletic Commissioner who is also president of the National Boxing Association.

NEW DELHI, Dec. 6 -- India's Army will be almost completely Indian-led by next Jan. 15 when Lieut. Gen. K. M. Cariappa takes over as the first Indian commander in chief. He succeeds Gen. Sir Roy Bucher.
PARIS, Dec. 6 -- The proceedings of the United Nations:

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 6 (AP) -- Hearth Mouse, racing for H. Hessie Miller of Chester, Pa., was a driving winner of the mile-and-a-sixteenth Salpinctes purse, sixth and feature race at Tropical Park today before a crowd of 6,684.

While two dozen pickets paraded in front of Carnegie Hall last night, shouting slogans that named Menachem Begin as a "Fascist," the former commander of the disbanded Irgun Zvai Leumi addressed a public meeting inside the hall.

BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 6 -- The Peronistas saw a complete victory today throughout the country in yesterday's elections. As the counting of ballots has not yet begun, the optimism is based on the heavy vote, which reached 83.8 per cent of the registered voters in the Federal capital.
PARIS, Dec. 6 -- The United Nations General Assembly, which convened here Sept. 21, decided today to adjourn Saturday night or early Sunday morning and resume its work in Flushing Meadow on April 1.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 -- The National Labor Relations Board insisted today that it alone had jurisdiction to hold elections and certify collective bargaining representatives in a Utah steel plant despite the assumption of jurisdiction by the Utah State Labor Relations Board.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Dec. 6 -- Members of the New Jersey State Horticultural Society by a vote of about four to one approved today a proposal that fruits and vegetables be included in the Federal Government's price support program for farm products.

Indications are that toy volume will set a record this year, despite some slowness noted in the retail field, according to views expressed yesterday at the opening of the annual convention of the Toy Manufacturers of the U.S.A. at the McAlpin Hotel.

SAN BRUNO, Calif., Dec. 6 (AP) -- Citation won't run atone in the $50,000-added Tanforan Handicap here next Saturday. The 4-year-old Stepfather and 8-year-old Happy Issue are definitely in, the Tanforan track announced last night.

LONDON, Dec. 6 -- Before the examination of Sidney Stanley by Attorney General Sir Hartley Shawcross in connection with allegations of fraud in the Board of Trade ended today Mr. Stanley brought in for the first time the name of Hugh Dalton, former Chancellor of the Excequer.
LONDON, Dec. 6 -- Business was at a low ebb in the stock market here today.

Walter (Boots) Davis, 21-year-old trucker's helper, was found guilty of murder in the first degree last night on a charge of having stabbed to death Miss Mary Gray, 80, a spinster, in her Brooklyn apartment on Oct. 9. He had been on trial two weeks in Kings County Court.
CARACAS, Venezuela, Dec. 6 (UP) -- The military junta today relaxed emergency regulations imposed during last month's coup and took new steps to reorganize Venezuela.

PARIS, Dec. 6 -- The membership committee of the Security Council will meet tomorrow morning to take up Israel's application for membership in the United Nations. It is recognized, however, that the impending adjournment of the General Assembly makes acceptance of the application at this session doubtful.

New York's public elementary and junior high schools are in dire need of more teachers, textbooks and various services, representatives of twenty-five parent, teacher and civic organizations warned yesterday at a Board of Education budget hearing.

CHICAGO, Dec. 6 (AP) -- The Chicago Rockets of the All-America Conference have been consistent, if nothing else, and their one victory in fourteen starts for two straight seasons leaves their future a big question mark.

In search for more accurate weather forecasting, the Army Signal Corps will attempt for the first time to measure wind velocities at heights of 100,000 to 200,000 feet by shooting V-2 rockets containing special instruments into the stratosphere.
PARIS, Tuesday, Dec. 7 -- Following is the text of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights approved early today by the Social Committee of the United Nations General Assembly:

Democratic strategy in the 1949 session of the State Legislature was outlined and discussed yesterday at a meeting of the policy committee of the Democratic State Committee at its Biltmore Hotel headquarters. A detailed platform of Democratic legislative ideas will be made public today, it was indicated.
An Army lieutenant lost yesterday a suit to recover the value of a diamond engagement ring lost by his former fiancee.
Ben Hogan, the mighty mite from Texas who plays out of Hershey, Pa., was named professional golfer of the year yesterday by Fred Corcoran, editor of the Official Golf Guide.
Four new centers for detection of diabetes were opened yesterday in an effort to find an estimated 100,000 New Yorkers who suffer the debilitating effects of diabetes without knowing it.

Resumption of trailer-truck delivery service between New York and Albany with two converted tank landing ships was announced here yesterday by J.H.D. Macy, vice president of Trailerships, Inc., of 274 Madison Avenue.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 (AP) -- The Supreme Court directed the Federal District Court in Los Angeles today to reopen a case in which it refused naturalization to Shulim Wixman, a Russian immigrant who became a college professor.

PARIS, Dec. 6 -- A plenary session of the European Council under the Marshall Plan will be held in Paris Dec. 18 to receive an interim report drawn up by experts on the efforts made to frame a single European recovery program for four years.

Ed Danowski has signed a contract to coach the Fordham football team in 1949, Jack Coffey, graduate athletic manager, announced yesterday. The announcement followed a meeting of the University Athletic Board, which decided on a single year instead of the previous three-year agreement.

PARIS, Tuesday, Dec. 7 -- The Social Committee of the United Nations General Assembly approved early today the text of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights, completing the long drawn-out process of hammering the document into final shape.
PAWTUCKET, R.I., Dec. 6 -- Maintenance of the old Slater mill in Pawtucket, the first successful cotton mill in America, as a textile industry museum is being planned by a national group of mill men.

The Joy Manufacturing Company of Pittsburgh, a large producer of underground mining equipment, has completed arrangements with a group of eight banks for a self-liquidating credit not to exceed $10,000,000 J. D. A. Morrow, president, announced yesterday.

Gian-Carlo Menotti's two musical dramas, "The Medium" and "The Telephone," will set up shop at the New York City Center of Music and Drama this evening for a limited engagement of four weeks. The twin bill, offered for the first time at popular prices, is to be presented by arrangement with Chandler Cowles, Efrem Zimbalist Jr. and Edith Lutyens, the triumvirate that brought it to Broadway in May, 1947.

PEIPING, Dec. 6 -- Communists pushing southward from the Great Wall past Koupeikow reached a point eighteen miles northeast of Peiping today in what may be the opening move in a battle for East Hopeh.

Reflecting a new high volume of sales, net earnings of the Nash-Kelvinator Corporation and its subsidiaries increased in the fiscal year ended with last September to $20,132,954, from $18,097,697 in the preceding fiscal year, George W. Mason, president, reported yesterday.

" BEING a backward and weak nation is a bitter thing," said the Chinese industrialist. "There is too much poverty and hunger, too much ignorance and superstition, too much inability to cope efficiently with even relatively simple problems tied up with this business of being backward." This polite understatement of the plight of modern China is quoted by Gerald F. Winfield in his useful and profoundly depressing book, "China: The Land and the People."*

PARIS, Dec. 6 -- By an overwhelming majority of 39 to 6, with one abstention, the United Nations General Assembly's Political Committee approved today a Chinese proposal to invite the delegation of the Seoul regime of South Korea to attend the current debate on Korea's independence.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 6 -- Hal Wallis, independent producer, has signed a new contract with Paramount to make twelve pictures for distribution by the company, it was announced today. The total cost of the films will be $18,000,000 and they will be produced by the Wallis Company at Paramount, with the studio participating financially.

Tojo and the other six Japanese was leaders have been sentenced by the International Military Tribunal for the Far East to death by hanging. In accordance with the charter of the Tribunal, the verdict has been reviewed and subsequently affirmed by the Supreme Commander for the Allied Powers (SCAP), General MacArthur.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 (AP) -- Following is the text of a statement issued today by Supreme Court Justice Robert H. Jackson explaining his participation in the appeal in the Japanese war cringes ease:
WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 (AP) -- American military aid to China is running somewhat under one-third of that to Greece and Turkey.

" Hitler and His Admirals," by Anthony K. Martienssen, has been scheduled for Jan. 3 publication by Dutton. Based upon the thousands of top-secret documents captured from the German Navy, it is a definitive study of the part played by naval strategy in the over-all German war plans.

Jeremiah T. Mahoney, veteran Tammany district leader of the Ninth Assembly or "silk stocking" district, withdrew from party activities last night and became sponsor for Samuel M. Gold as his successor.

Burl Charity, Youngstown (Ohio) middleweight, hammered his way to the decision over De Witt Dean, Detroit, last night in the feature eight-round bout at the St. Nicholas Arena, but, though he twice had his rival on the verge of a knockout, Charity had to be satisfied with a split verdict.

CHICAGO, Dec. 6 -- Police Commissioner Prendergast today refused to remove his ban on "The Respectful Prostitute," a play scheduled to open Dec. 27 at the Studebaker Theatre. The refusal was given to Winston O'Keefe, managing director of the producing company, after Mr. O'Keefe flew from New York to ask reconsideration.

One of the largest local collections of Canadian paintings, representing all contemporary schools flourishing there, is being shown at the Canadian Club in the Waldorf-Astoria. The Canadian Club expects to purchase a number of the seventy-odd canvasses before the close of this exhibition which was originally assembled by the National Gallery in Ottawa, with the assistance of an advisory committee of leading Canadian artists.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Dec. 6 (UP) -- An ex-marine war hero with a bullet in his heart is living a normal life here but said today he wanted to remain anonymous. "If people know," he said, "they might think I can't do a man's work."
LONDON, Dec. 6 -- The arterial ailment of King George's legs is continuing to improve very slowly, his doctors announced today.

The Federal Reserve Board in its most recent review of the business and price outlook found that inflationary forces were diminishing. It observed in this connection, among other things, that people were showing a tendency to save a little more out of each dollar.

A man described by the police as four feet tall and weighing ninety-five pounds caused an eighteen-minute delay on the IRT subway late yesterday by shadow-boxing with a knife in one hand. He demonstrated in front of fifty passengers on a train of the Broadway-Seventh Avenue line. The police said that he was intoxicated.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Dec. 6 -- A wave of disorder and terrorism will sweep all Middle East Arab countries as a result of the move to unite Trans-Jordan and Arab Palestine under King Abdullah and reach a settlement thereby of the Palestine question, a reliable source stated here tonight.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 -- Professor Sumner H. Slichter of Harvard University told a Congressional committee today that corporate profits have been substantially overstated and he found no fault with their true level, while Professor Seymour E. Harris, also a Harvard economist, found profits too high and advocated a rise in taxes on them.
Trading in cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday was moderately active and final prices were 8 points lower to 4 points higher than Saturday's closing levels.

We were pleased to read the article in THE TIMES on Dec. 1 on the proposal by J. Raymond Jones, deputy commissioner of housing, concerning the use of empty lots in East Harlem for recreational purposes.
After a variety of wartime and post-war uses the C-4 type vessels have come into their own as high-class, speedy cargo carriers, for which they originally were designed.

Supreme Court Justice Cortland A. Johnson directed yesterday that Prof. Maurice Finkelstein and Louis Toth show cause why they should not be punished for failure to comply with a decision handed down while they were members of the City Rent Commission.

Re-entering the field of contemporary American art, the Metropolitan Museum of Art announced yesterday the creation of a new department for that purpose and the appointment of Robert Beverly Hale as its head.

BANGKOK, Siam, Dec. 6 -- Malcolm MacDonald, British Commissioner General in Southeast Asia, has returned to Singapore after five-day talks here. During his visit he had discussions with Field Marshal Pibul Songgram and senior members of the Government.

PRETORIA, South Africa, Dec. 6 -- Theophilus E. Donges, Acting Minister of Economic Affairs flew from Pretoria to Salisbury today to sign the trade agreement recently concluded between the Union of South Africa and Southern Rhodesia. The occasion was noteworthy for two reasons:

Dedicated to the proposition that making fine music is a joy unto itself, the Musicians Guild, Inc., proved once again, as it began its second season of concerts at Times Hall last night, that its deeds are as eloquent as its profession of faith.

At this time it is "both too late and too early" to abandon support of Treasury security prices and thus far no "suitable alternative" has been provided, Aubrey G. Lanston, executive vice president of the First Boston Corporation, New York, asserted yesterday.
Any nation that embarks on a national health plan of socialized medicine is "taking the downward path," Dr. Morris Fishbein, editor of The American Medical Association Journal, declared yesterday.

Crude rubber futures had another sinking spell on the Commodity Exchange yesterday and final prices of the No. 1 contract were 58 to 68 points net lower on sales of eighty-seven lots. Reports from Singapore that Malayan shipments of rubber in November were at the highest level for any month this year were a factor.
PITTSBURGH, Dec. 6 (AP) -- Navy Capt. Tom Hamilton today accepted Pitt's athletic directorship and the university hailed his decision as "an early visit from Santa Claus."

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 6 -- Cargo started moving again today on West Coast waterfronts after the second longest maritime strike in the Coast's history. The three month tie up left winches rusty, however, and delayed the gangs of longshoremen, eager to get back to work to get grocery bills paid and catch up with overdue rents.

Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores dropped 7 per cent last week below the corresponding period last year, according to the "flash" report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

An American Theatre Wing drive to raise $150,000 to continue its work in veterans' hospitals gets under way officially today on the seventh anniversary of Pearl Harbor. It is the Wing's first public appeal for funds, its operations having been financed in the past through earnings of the movie, "Stage Door Canteen," and a radio program.

Two union business agents and five members of a plastering contractors' association were arraigned yesterday in Kings County Court on an indictment charging them with participating in a scheme that boosted building costs in Brooklyn more than $1,000,000.

TRENTON, N.J., Dec. 6 -- Consumers and distributors united here today, at a hearing before State Milk Director Arthur P. Foran, in demanding a reduction in the price of milk, over the protests of producers.
LOS ANGELES, Dec. 6 -- A ceremony involving a "loyalty oath" by all city employes was interrupted by union representatives today.

RIVERSIDE, Calif., Dec. 6 (UP) -- Douglas Schneider, acting chief of the State Department's worldwide information program, said tonight that he believed the United States was winning the "propaganda" war with Russia.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Dec. 6 -- An Army officer who had brought suit against a fellow inmate of a Japanese prison camp today accepted a settlement of the case, in which he attempted to collect $5,100 for merchandise and money allegedly transferred to his comrade.

CHICAGO, Dec. 6 -- Grain markets were higher in the early trading on the Board of Trade today, December wheat at a new 10-month high, but the markets developed irregularity later, with wheat closing 5/8 cent higher to 3/8 cent lower.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 -- The Reconstruction Finance Corporation announced today the sale of its neoprene synthetic rubber plant at Louisville, Ky., to E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc., for $13,200,000. RFC's investment in the plant amounted to $37,740,000 but the plant had earned about $25,000,000 for RFC exclusive of depreciation.

Smarting from five straight setbacks, the New York Rangers will attempt to pull out of their tailspin tonight when they face the Boston Bruins in a National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden. The battle starts at 8:30 o'clock.

To the surprise of no one who follows horse racing, Citation was named Horse of the Year in the annual poll conducted by Turf and Sports Digest, Baltimore racing publication, the Associated Press reports.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 -- President Truman accepted today the resignation of Arthur M. Hill, first chairman of the National Security Resources Board, and congratulated him for making an "outstanding contribution to the public service." Mr. Hill's services will end on Dec. 15, after which he will resume his position as an official of the Greyhound Lines.

VIENNA, Dec. 6 -- The Austrian Government is understood to have prepared a letter to the four occupation powers for presentation before Chirstmas that will request reopening of negotiations for a peace treaty.

The Rev. Dr. Samuel Trexler, retired, first president of the United Lutheran Synod of New York, presented to the synod yesterday his personal check for $10,000 as the initial gift in the establishment of a $50,000 fellowship fund.

Stabilization of wages in the city's building industry should encourage construction although material prices remain uncertain and building costs are not expected to drop next year, spokesmen for contractors and construction labor told Mayor O'Dwyer yesterday.

" Now abideth faith, hope, charity, these three." In the Christmas season our thoughts invariably return to the question, How fares my neighbor? Your neighbors, in spite of the prosperous times most of us have been enjoying, are not all faring well. The Hundred Neediest Cases records reveal the contrasts that may exist within this great city of ours.

The Atlas Corporation of New York, an investment trust, entered a bid of $45 a share yesterday for capital stock of the Barnsdall Oil Company of New York in an effort to add 200,000 shares to the 500,000 already held.

TOKYO, Dec. 6 -- For the first time in Japanese history, Parliament tonight sharply called the Emperor to account for private dealings with foreign powers without reference to the elected representatives of his country.

The Port of New York Authority yesterday urged the Interstate Commerce Commission to reconsider its recent sanction of terminal unloading charges here on fresh fruits and vegetables. The authority asserted that the ICC ruling had resulted in "a $3,000,000 burden" on New York consumers.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 -- Refusal of the United States Supreme Court today to order Alabama's eleven Presidential electors to cast their ballots for President Truman virtually foreclosed the last hope of swinging any big bloc of States' Rights Democratic electors to the National Democratic ticket.

The police issued 208 warnings yesterday as the extension of the no-parking rule went into effect on three more major north-south arteries in efforts to relieve traffic congestion in mid-Manhattan. Compliance was particularly poor while it rained, the police said, with motorists preferring a warning to a wetting.

Two thousand bartenders went on strike yesterday for a five-day, forty-hour week and other demands upon 650 Manhattan taverns where they had been working a six-day, forty-eight hour week for a minimum wage of $60.
PARIS, Dec. 6 -- United Nations circles expect the issue of war or peace in Indonesia to be decided within a few weeks.

The State of Maryland is paying the tuition of Negro students in the undergraduate and graduate schools of Johns Hopkins University and St. John's College at Annapolis, records revealed yesterday. Because of their race these students are barred from the University of Maryland.

A member of the Electoral College remains constitutionally free to cast his vote for whomever he chooses. The Twelfth Amendment says so and the Supreme Court, refusing yesterday to order the Alabama electors to shift to Truman, needed no other authority. The only strange feature of this episode is that Governor Folsom of Alabama and those who backed him in his injunction appeal appear to have thought the Court could amend the Constitution by decree.

BERLIN, Dec. 6 -- About 2,000 workers in the administrative department of Bewag, Berlin's most important electric power combine, today agreed to walk out of the Soviet sector and start work in the British sector tomorrow unless their newly installed Communist bosses met their demands.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture has conducted a survey among 3,300 housewives to find out what they knew and liked or did not like about Irish potatoes. Results indicate that farmers and shippers should see to it that the potatoes they prepare for market are:

Ceremonies honoring the arrival of 2,045 war dead of World War II aboard the Army transport Lieut. James E. Robinson were held at the Brooklyn Army Base yesterday. Several hundred persons were present despite the rain.

The world championship court tennis match between Pierre Etchebaster and his challenger, James Dear of England, will be resumed this afternoon at 2 o'clock at the Racquet and Tennis Club, 370 Park Avenue.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 -- Mme. Chiang Kai-shek today issued a statement urging that all possible be done to avert another war.

HACKENSACK, N.J., Dec. 6 -- P. James Pellecchia, former Newark Police Court Magistrate and vice president of the Columbia Trust Company of Newark, who is charged with appropriating $651,000 of the bank's funds for gambling purposes, testified in county court here today that John Lennon of 451 Palisade Avenue, Cliffside Park, acted as his gambling banker and received $92,000 in gambling debts from him.

" What's On Your Mind," the feature-length compilation of psychoanalytical films, originally an nounced as opening at the Elysee Theatre on Saturday, instead will arrive at that house on Christmas Day, it was reported yesterday by a spokesman for Oxford Films, the distributors.

CHICAGO, Dee. 6 -- A new combination of standard insulins gives persons with severe diabetes more freedom from the hypodermic needle and more social freedom, a Northwestern University medical specialist said today.

The National Security Resources Board has requested the American Nurses Association to conduct an inventory of all professional registered nurses in the United States and its territories. Pearl McIver, president of the ANA, announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 -- A United States Circuit Court of Appeals opinion, handed down here today, ruled that air-mail subsidy payments awarded by the Civil Aeronautics Board were not intended to guarantee profits for airline operations.

The city's inquiry into alleged waterfront racketeering got under way yesterday when the subpoenaed records of five steamship companies and two stevedoring concerns were hauled into the offices of John M. Murtagh, Investigation Commissioner, at 50 Pine Street.

In recent weeks the newspapers have carried accounts of the execution in Greece of persons opposing the present Greek Government, reminding us of the existence in Greece of a legal code and a court procedure that are incompatible with the legal standards of our own country.

Pearl and Dorothy Bloom, sisters and associates in the operation of twenty-five tenements, were convicted of conspiracy and rent-gouging yesterday. The decision was made by Justices Nathan D. Perlman, William B. Northrop and Joseph V. Loscalzo in the Court of Special Sessions, at the end of a trial that began Nov. 29. Sentencing was set over to Dec. 22.

I am deeply impressed with the closing paragraph of your editorial in THE TIMES on the Freedom Train, in which you admonish your readers to remember "that the battle for human freedom still goes on. The list of freedom's documents is not yet complete; this generation must produce more of these for some future Freedom Train, if government by, of and for the people is to be secure."

NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 6 -- Roman Catholic churches in the Archdiocese of Newark offered prayers today in observance of the seventy-fifth birthday of Archbishop Thomas Joseph Walsh. Tonight the Archbishop was honored at a concert and dinner in the Villa Walsh in Morristown.

Larger sales promotion efforts on aerosol insecticide bombs are envisaged for 1949, manufacturers revealed during an open forum session of the annual convention of the National Association of Insecticide and Disinfectant Manufacturers, Inc., at the New Yorker Hotel yesterday.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 6 -- The first Monday German of the Bachelors Cotillon, a dance which for several generations has been considered the most important fete for debutantes in the Baltimore winter season, took place tonight in its traditional locale -- the old Lyric Theatre.
The Police Department went on record yesterday as favoring a proposed amendment to the city's administrative code allowing a 30 per cent increase in taxicab fares.

When the new buses came to town the other day and began rolling their tortuous way up and down Fith Avenue, the man who tried one of them for the first time pulled the cord and then unaccountably stood still, making no effort to get to the door.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 -- Four Congressional primary or election cases involving "serious connotations of willful violations of Federal or state elections laws" have been turned over to the Department of Justice by the special House Committee on Campaign Expenditures.
A total of $21,500,000 of debentures and bonds were awarded by three utility concerns at competitive bidding yesterday.

LYONS, Ga., Dec. 6 (AP) -- Mrs. Amy Mallard, a Negro, returned to her home today under police protection and signed a warrant charging a white man with murder in the Nov. 20 ambush slaying of her husband.

BERLIN, Dec. 6 -- The Social Democratic party leaders who won an overwhelming victory at the polls yesterday said today they needed double the tonnage now being brought in by airlift to continue their fight against Soviet totalitarianism.
Admiral Louis E. Denfeld, Chief of Naval Operations, declared here last night that anti-submarine devices developed since the war had given shipping the "edge" over submarines.

The Republic of Chile yesterday formally invited holders of the Republic's $131,262,000 principal amount of dollar bonds outstanding due from 1949 to 1963, to turn them in for new bonds. These would bear progressive interest rates limited to 3 per cent and would mature Dec. 31, 1993.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 -- President Truman told Congress today that Greek army efforts to liquidate Communist guerrilla forces in that country had produced "a military stalemate" despite the delivery of $170,000,000 of United States arms and supplies and the advice of a United States military mission.

The hound dog is coming into his own these days, for with most of the big game and game bird seasons closed in the northeastern states, the foxes, coons and rabbits will continue to lure hunters, even after the first big snow arrives.

The fact that Mayor O'Dwyer has asked the Port of New York Authority to review its previous proposal for modernization of the waterfront and submit a new offer does not necessarily assure acceptance of that offer. The original program was developed under pressure of a time limit, but it is not likely that fundamentals will be greatly changed in reconsideration.

VIENNA, Dec. 6 -- Reports reaching Vienna indicate the future of American films in Hungary, despite their popularity, is dark. Communists indicated beyond a doubt that they consider the films one of the most dangerous weapons of infiltration for alien ideas into the increasingly hermit world behind the iron curtain.
ALBANY, Dec. 6 -- Governor Dewey and Republican legislative leaders agreed unanimously at a Capitol meeting today on a new $300,000,000 state bond issue for slum clearance and public housing.

President Truman's fifth report on American aid to Greece and Turkey, filed yesterday with Congress, covers only the period July to September of this year, but the essentials of the situation as they stood then are still unchanged. Fighting continues, the guerrillas seem to be about as numerous as they ever were, and the day when the emphasis of American aid can be shifted from military defense to civilian reconstruction is still deferred.
TIENTSIN, China, Dec. 6 -- Some 20,000 defeated Nationalist soldiers are swarming over Tientsin and the harbor town of Tangku, twenty-two miles east of here, creating a serious problem in morale.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Dec. 7 -- The Yugoslav weekly newspaper Republika published today a dispatch from its Trieste correspondent reporting that five Marshall Plan countries of Western Europe were consulting with each other for the purpose of negotiating a joint commercial agreement with four countries of the Soviet bloc, including Yugoslavia, and with Austria.

Thanks to the hospitality of the City Center, where art does not cost a fortune, Gian-Carlo Menotti's "The Telephone" and "The Medium" are on view again for a limited engagement. Those are the modest little operas that took up an entrenched position on Broadway in the spring of 1947 and have been trudging around America ever since.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 (AP) -- Indications are that the inaugural reception for the President and Mrs. Truman on Jan. 20 will be one of the largest ever held.

LONDON, Dec. 7 -- The Economic Cooperation Administration is most eager that its desire to see evidence of what Europeans expect to do with their economic resources over the next four years should not be taken as insistence upon extended planning of national economies, Paul G. Hoffman, ECA Administrator, said today.

More money is available for research "in certain restricted fields than can be used effectively," Dr. Isaac Start, Hartzell Professor of Therapeutic Research at the University of Pennsylvania's School of Medicine, declared yesterday.

ALBANY, Dec. 7 -- Gov. Thomas E. Dewey announced today that New York State, with the expenditure of $735,000,000 for public housing, would have provided only about the same number of dwelling units as were contemplated under the original $300,000,000 housing bond issue authorized by the people in 1938.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 -- The Affiliated Gas Equipment, Inc., filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement covering a proposed public offering of 40,000 shares of $3 cumulative preferred stock, $50 par value, and 1,000,000 shares of $1 par value common stock.
At the conclusion of his first year as head football coach of the University of Michigan, Bennie Oosterbaan has been named "Coach of the Year."

The drive to raise $15,575,000 for the projected New York University-Bellevue Medical Center is making "encouraging" progress and has now reached $9,428,565, Nevil Ford, general chairman of the New York University - Bellevue Medical Center Fund, said yesterday.

The Bureau of Mental Hygiene of the State Attorney General's office has saved $1,500,000 for mental patients in the state hospitals of New York since January by tracking down frauds on their estates and preventing excessive expenditures by guardians, it became known yesterday.

One hundred clergymen of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York were among 5,000 persons who attended a service last night in the Cathedral of St. John the Divine "to return thanks to God" for the preaching mission that was conducted in the diocese last month by the Rev. Bryan Green, one of Great Britain's leading evangelists.

BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 7 -- A policy of no loans to Latin American nations for oil development was laid down at a recent United States foreign service conference in Rio de Janeiro to discourage Venezuela from thinking in terms of nationalization, it was confirmed today.

The city's intensive investigation into waterfront crime appeared to have struck a minor snag yesterday as Mayor O'Dwyer and District Attorney Frank S. Hogan fired long-range verbal arrows at each other over the lack of grand jury action.

Alf M. Landon, Republican candidate for President in 1936, declared here yesterday that the immediate role of the Republican party must be to discuss and debate the policies of the majority party, to make sure that the public understands the issues and the way the problems are being met.

Directors of the Seaboard Air Line Railroad Company declared yesterday an initial dividend of $1 a share to holders of voting trust certificates for the common stock. The dividend is payable on Dec. 31 to holders of record of Dec. 17. Legh R. Powell Jr., president, said, in making the announcement, that action with respect to future dividends would depend upon earnings and the trend of business.
HONOLULU, Dec. 7 -- Thirty-three exhausted Air Force men were aboard the escort carrier Rendova today en route to Kwajalein after being picked up at sea last night

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, Dec. 7 -- Two former Soviet Air Force officers placed today the Berlin air lift at the top of the list of wonders they had encountered since their flight from Russia nearly nine weeks ago.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 -- A State Department official told the House Committee on Un-American Activities in closed session today that the latest evidence in the so-called Hiss-Chambers case, involving an alleged pre-war Communist underground in Washington, indicated that for two years the most vital codes of American diplomacy were being "cracked" by foreign countries.

The Westchester Surface Ways, Inc., operators of a bus service in Mount Vernon as well as a summer operation between that city and Glen Island, asked the Public Service Commission yesterday for permission to raise its present 6-cent fare to 8 cents.

Refusal of the Pan American Union to break up when the United Nations was formed left the way open for regional defense pacts against aggressors, Mauricio Nabuco, Brazilian Ambassador to the United States, declare here yesterday.

A slight increase in imports of capital goods and raw materials by the Union of South Africa is likely under the new import control and exchange regulations, W.A. Horrocks, commercial secretary to the South African Legation, Washington, D.C., said here yesterday.

Herman T. Stichman, State Housing Commissioner, has begun preparations for expanding the state's housing plans in line with Governor Dewey's announcement that he would call on the Legislature for $300,000,000 of new housing loan funds.

Initial steps were taken last night in what is hoped will widen into a drive in more than 800 Protestant churches in the various boroughs to raise $286,000 needed immediately to maintain institutions to which juveniles frequently have to be committed by the courts.

The British people, who never before have been "tourist minded," have suddenly realized that one of the most important factors in European recovery may well be the tourist trade, Sir Alexander Maxwell, chairman of the British Tourist and Holidays Board, said here yesterday.

MINNEAPOLIS, Dec. 7 -- The Giants and Yankees became the focal points of the trading mart today as the baseball clans converged on this snow-covered metropolis for the minors' annual National Association of Professional Baseball Leagues convention which officially opens tomorrow.

A "more adult attitude" toward mental illness was noted yesterday by a contributor to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, who sent $450 to care for a woman who had spent six of her twenty years in a mental hospital.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 -- Former Under Secretary of State Sumner Welles came back to the Capitol Hill today as a star witness in the Hiss-Chambers, pumpkin mystery, and he could not have been more surprised if he had been asked to fly over the Capitol dome on a Halloween broom.

American and British management and labor for the first time have teamed up to smash production bottlenecks in British industries by using American "know-how." Soon the first teams of British management and labor representatives will visit plants in this country, eventually to be followed by thousands, to study, without cost or obligation, American mass production for this purpose.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 -- President Truman announced today that he would ask Congress to appropriate up to $16,000,000 for aid to refugees from the Palestine fighting, the sum being about 50 per cent of the total wanted from members of the United Nations.

ROME, Dec. 7 -- According to some well-informed Italian sources, three-cornered negotiations are at present in progress among Italy, the United States and Yugoslavia to permit the exportation from Italy to Yugoslavia of Italian-manufactured goods produced with European Recovery Program materials. Such exports were hitherto forbidden to countries behind the Iron Curtain.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 (UP) -- A record 2,408,249 students enrolled for the fall term in the country's 1,788 colleges and universities, the Federal Security Administration reported today, an increase of 3 per cent over the previous peak enrollment of 2,338,226 in the fall of 1947.

ROME, Dec. 7 -- Foreign Minister Count Carlo Sforza this morning inaugurated the second session of the executive committee of the International Refugee Organization which expects to complete its work by next Monday.

A Bronx physician and his wife, owners of two apartment houses on the Grand Concourse, were charged yesterday with exacting bonuses ranging up to $1,000 each for renting apartments in their buildings.

The Democratic State Committee charged Governor Dewey yesterday with attempting belatedly to catch up with all of the things that the Democratic party has been demanding for the state for a number of years.
SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, Dec. 7 -The strictest political neutrality was urged on all election officials today by President-elect Otilio Ulate and Jose Figueres, junta President.

The New York City Housing Authority accepted yesterday a check for $48,256,000, the proceeds from bonds sold to finance the first four projects in the city's program of public housing without cash subsidy. It was the first sale of bonds for this purpose in the country.

Virtually assuring the establishment of a record this year, steel shipments for the first ten months of 1948 amounted to 54,183,000 net tons, an increase of 1,879,000 tons over the total for the similar period of last year, the American Iron and Steel Institute announced yesterday.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 7 -- A "staggering" cost to the country's taxpayers and a "tragic" fate for thousands of war veterans are foreseeable results of a widespread failure to recognize tropical disease infections as a current major national health problem.

CHICAGO, Dec. 7 -- Grain markets were on the downgrade on the Board of Trade in the late trading today following a showing of strength early. Wheat lost 1 cent to 1 1/2 cents on the day; corn 1/4 to 3/4 cent; oats were unchanged to 2 1/8 cents lower; rye lost 2 1/2 to 3 cents and soy beans, 1 3/4 to 4 cents.

NANKING, Dec. 7 -- After a month of sustained battle action, the longest uninterrupted offensive yet waged by the Chinese Communists, Red columns under Generals Chen Yi and Liu Po-cheng continued their attempts tonight to eliminate two major Nationalist concentrations encircled south of the Lung-Hai railway and west of the Tientsin-Pukow railway.
BERLIN, Dec. 7 -- Western Berlin's City Assembly unanimously elected a Socialist professor, Ernst Reuter, as Lord Mayor today.

The taxpayer building completed this year at the southeast corner of Hempstead and Walton treets in West Hempstead, L. I., has been sold by David H. Green to Thomas GirilitiarL The property, 93 by 43 by 118 by 96 feet, is occupied by the AssOciated Food Stores.
Mayor O'Dwyer asserted yesterday that three years of effort by his administration had succeeded in eliminating almost all Communist influence from the cites Department of Welfare.

Representatives of three New York institutions, at a luncheon to be given today by Cardinal Spellman at his residence, will accept part payments on research projects from the New York City Cancer Committee of the American Cancer Society.

MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 7 -- Going into the third day of contract bridge championship play, Mrs. E.A. Copper of Hollywood, Fla., and Dr. Arthur Salasky, Newport News, Va., led the record field of ninety-six world master pairs with a score of 252 out of a possible 390 here today.

The problem of American aid to China may be brought into clearer focus if due attention is paid to a fact reported from Washington yesterday. The Associated Press quotes government sources as estimating that, because of a lag in actual deliveries, fighting equipment valued only at $63,000,000 has been delivered to the Nationalist armies of China during the last eighteen months.

HE didn't have the nickname when he was playing football for Fordham but he did acquire it after he had joined the Giants. The fans began to refer to him affectionately as Potato Ed Danowski. Perhaps it was because he could throw a ball as easily as the average person could fling a potato. Whatever the reason, it fit him perfectly because Danowski always has had the down-to-earth qualities of mankind's most popular staple.

BERLIN, Dec. 7 -- The flight of Germans from Soviet rule into the Western zones of occupation has varied between 25,000 and 40,000 a month in recent months, according to statements made by United States and British authorities here.
PARIS, Dec. 7 -- The proceedings of the United Nations:

TEL AVIV, Israel, Dec. 7 -- The Egyptians brought tanks yesterday into their campaign to sabotage water and communication lines to Jewish settlements in the Negeb, and almost precipitated a renewal of the war. Of fourteen medium-size British-made tanks that they threw into the field, five were disabled and the entire force withdrew, according to Israeli sources tonight.

Many parties will be given at the luncheon and fashion show in behalf of the New York Infirmary to be held today in the Cotillion Room of the Pierre under the auspices of the Social Service Committee of the Infirmary. Guests have been requested to thing packages of rummage to be sold later at the Bargain Box for the benefit of the New York Infirmary.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 -- The President, Mrs. Truman and Miss Margaret Truman will spend Christmas at their home in Independence, Mo., it was announced today by Mrs. Truman's secretaries, Mrs. James M. Helm and Miss Reath Odum.

Headed by the high-scoring Ernie Calverley and Kenny Sailors, the Providence Steamrollers move into Madison Square Garden tonight to tackle the New York Knickerbockers in a Basketball Association of America contest. The game features a double-header which opens with National City meeting Met Life in a Knickerbocker League game at 7:30 o'clock.
Charles Evans Hughes Jr., chairman of the Mayor's Committee on Unity from its inception in February until last June, was honored yesterday for his "unselfish and effective efforts."
In an editorial on Nov. 28 you amplify Robert Dowling's suggestion for a "Vertical city" by proposing that tall buildings rise over steamship piers.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 -- The Brotherhood of Firemen and Enginemen has fixed Dec. 15 as the date for a strike of its 3,000 members employed by the Southern Pacific Railroad.

The First Boston Corporation and associates will offer today $8,500,000 of the Rochester Telephone Corporation's issue of 4 per cent sinking fund debentures due in 1963. The securities are priced at 102, to yield 3.82 per cent to maturity.

PARIS, Dec. 7 -- First difficulties with the newly elected Council of the Republic, France's advisory second house, developed today when it rejected a bill creating a commissioner of supplies and when de Gaullist members refused to accept the seats assigned to them.

RICHMOND, Va., Dec. 7 (AP) -- The Fourth Circuit Court of Appeals upheld today the right of an interstate carrier to segregate the seating of Negro and white passengers "providing there is no discrimination in the arrangement." The opinion affirmed a Federal Court judgment denying $25,000 to Mrs. Adeline Atwell Day of Syracuse, N.Y.
CHICAGO, Dec. 7 -- November sales of several of the country's leading merchandisers fell below those of a year ago, sales figures disclosed today.

More than thirty physicians who graduated from either the Bellevue Hospital Medical College or the University Medical College before the merger of the two institutions in 1898 were honored yesterday at ceremonies marking the fiftienth anniversary of the event.

There never is a guest of honor at the weekly luncheon tossed by the football Giants, but Charley Conerly came close to being just that when the final feed of the season was held at the Polo Grounds press room yesterday.
BANGKOK, Siam, Dec. 7 (AP) -- Siamese Army headquarters revealed today plans to call up thousands of reservists for three months' special training in the use of modern weapons and commando tactics.

Buyers' Total Higher Out-of-town buyers registered in the market for the week ended yesterday numbered 1,350, compared with 1,146 last week and 1,127 in the corresponding week a year ago, according to the listings appearing in THE NEW YORK TIMES.

The National Retail Furniture Association has asked the Federal Reserve Board to amend Regulation W to eliminate inclusion of sales taxes in determining cash ilst prices of items retailing for less than $50, it was learned yesterday. Under the regulation such items are exempt from provisions governing terms in installment selling.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 -- Two new plans for the voluntary allocation of steel products to stimulate production of critical and strategic materials for stockpiling probably will be approved within two or three weeks.

If there is any case among the Hundred Neediest that illustrates clearly the contrast between the human warmth and good-will of Christmas and the cold, drab bleakness of the lives of those who, through unfortunate circumstances, know only deprivation and want, it is the case that leads all the rest -- Case No. 1.

A compass is a thing of mystery to many hunters, who would not know an azimuth from an isotherm, but a simple and practical substitute for this instrument has now been evolved which is almost as foolproof as a direction-finder can be made.

Two years of effort, patient waiting and the expenditure of $90,000 culminated yesterday when the Community Service Society opened its new Boys House building at 33 Madison Avenue. Several hundred members of the society's board of trustees, welfare authorities and guests toured the five-story building, once the home of William Seward, Secretary of State under Abraham Lincoln.

A campaign to raise $2,100,000 to help provide maintenance and education for 15,000 orphaned Jewish children who are expected to arrive in Israel during the coming year was started last night at a dinner of Hadassah, the Women's Zionist Organization of America, at the Plaza Hotel.
The announcement of the new fee at Sarah Lawrence College for "cost of education" stirs two thoughts.
At a dinner here to support the drive of the Federation of Jewish Philanthropies of New York for 916,500,000, the women's fashion division last night named "five key women of the year."

Rising production costs of dramatic shows on television resulted yesterday in a decision by the Theatre Guild and the General Foods Corporation to abandon negotiations for a resumption of the guild's video show on Sunday nights over NBC. It had been expected the show would resume next month in the 8-to-9 spot.

Legislation that would provide a job counseling service for older workers and establish a bureau devoted to expanding employment of the elderly will be introduced at the next session of the State Legislature by Thomas C. Desmond, Republican, of Newburgh.

The American Theatre Wing's $150,000 fund-raising campaign to finance a broadening of its work in Veterans Hospitals got off to a flying start yesterday after the unveiling of a plaque commemorating the site of its war-time Stage Door Canteen in Forty-fourth Street, just west of Broad way.

Three bronze plaques, honoring he 1,101 men and women employes THE NEW YORK TIMES who served in both World Wars, were unveiled yesterday afternoon at brief ceremonies in the remodeled entrance hall of the TIMES Building, 229 West Forty-third Street.

PARIS, Dec. 7 -- As the French Government prepared to tackle at a Cabinet meeting tomorrow the crucial question of a budget for the coming year, it counted on United States financial aid to enable it to check inflation and fulfill its recovery program under the Marshall Plan.

No more welcome news could come out of Albany than we published yesterday reporting that Governor Dewey and Republican legislative leaders had agreed unanimously to support a further $300,000,000 state bond issue for slum clearance and low-rent housing. This guarantee of continuity in a program started ten years ago offers the promise, for New York City, not only of a considerable alleviation of the housing shortage but also of the rebuilding of certain problem areas.

Net operating earnings of the Bank of the Manhattan Company this year are estimated at $5,300,000, or $2.65 a share, compared with $4,118,000, or $2.05 in 1947. J. Stewart Baker, chairman of the board, reported to stockholders at their 150th annual meeting yesterday.

Consolidated net income of the Ashland Oil and Refining Company for the fiscal year ended on Sept. 30, last, was $7,856,991, compared with $2,898,033 a year earlier, the annual report disclosed yesterday.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange turned easier yesterday and closed 13 to 20 points net lower on active months.

The famed "French library" of the late Cortland F. Bishop went on sale last night in the new Kende Galleries, 119 West Fifty-seventh Street. Three hundred collectors, library representatives and dealers, several here from Europe, attended the first session, which realized a total of $149,000.

Efforts of certain business interests to exclude basing point systems as evidence of trade collusion will set the anti-trust laws back fifty years, Robert Elliott Freer, chairman of the Federal Trade Commission, asserted yesterday. Part of the campaign to legalize an organized system of selling at identical prices, he said, included spreading misleading information to the effect that sellers are not permitted to absorb freight costs.

PARIS, Dec. 7 -- The Membership Committee of the United Nations Security Council reported to the Council today that it did not possess all the elements necessary to reach a conclusion on Israel's application for membership in the United Nations and could not present a recommendation at this time.
BOSTON, Dec. 7 (AP) -- A Senate subcommittee was told today that Textron, Inc., is building one mill in Puerto Rico, plans five others and will be free of taxes on them for fifteen years.
For obvious reasons, I have read quite a bit about bologna and Bologna. I even went to that famous city in 1937 to become better informed.

The current price structure in men's and boys' clothing "is not only valid but fully warranted by present costs," Isidore Grossman, president of the New York Clothing Manufacturers Exchange, said in a statement yesterday. The Exchange represents 90 per cent of the manufacturers of men's and boys' clothing in the New York metropolitan area, which produces over 50 per cent of the country's output and employes over 50,000.

" The Last Miracle," a first novel by the late Dr. Karl Vollmoeller, has been listed for spring publication by Duell, Sloan Pearce. Dr. Vollmoeller, playwright, poet, aviator, designer and industrialist, was best known for his drama, "The Miracle," which was first produced here by Max Reinhart and Morris Gest.

BERLIN, Dec. 7 -- About 650 workers, including 150 technicians, walked out of the Soviet sector's offices of Bewag, Berlin's biggest electric power company, this morning and went to work in the British sector.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 7 -- Judge William R. McKay, of the Los Angeles Superior Court, told a state legislative investigating committee today that he considered the prevailing judicial and penal system unsound, "stupid," and a "disgrace" to the public that sponsored it.
LONDON, Dec. 7 (AP) -- The movies show that Bruce Woodcock was struck a low blow by Lee Savold last night, but that is slight consolation to the British heavyweight champion.
PROVIDENCE, R.I., Dec. 7 (UP) -- The Berlin crisis cannot be solved until this country makes a basic change in its foreign policy, James P. Warburg, banker, economist and author, asserted tonight.

" Best eggs," large Grad A nearby whites, will go down to 75 cents a dozen in two leading chains today, spokesmen for the companies announced yesterday. The price, a new low for the year, represents a drop of 4 to 6 cents from the last price and a total drop of 20 cents from the peak of 95 cents on Nov. 1.

BERLIN, Dec. 7 -- Industrial production in Western Germany set another post-war record during October when the index of production reached 73 per cent of the 1936 level, Gen. Lucius D. Clay, United States Military Governor, announced today in his semi-monthly report.

The Elew Realty Corporation, represented by ,J. Norman Lewis, attorney, has purchased the onestory taxpayer building at 1166 Clay Avenue, northeast corner of East 167th Street, the Bronx, from Beatrice G. Haymes and Anna, Netta and Henrietta Harris.
MELBOURNE, Australia, Dec. 7 (Reuters) -- Cricket today lost its Babe Ruth when Donald George Bradman, idol of Australia and terror of opposing teams, ended his first-class match career.

Surrogate James A. Delehanty rejected yesterday the claim of Charles J. Wynne, a former United States Army captain, that he was the common-law husband of Mrs. Margaret Hawkersworth Bell Content Wynne, a former Ziegfeld Follies dancer, and entitled to one-half of her $1,000,000 estate.
KANSAS CITY, Dec. 7 (AP) -Fourteen retail coal dealers and six coal companies were indicted today by a Federal grand jury on charges of fixing prices and suppressing competition.

" Harpoon," an adventure partly filmed in Alaska, and "S.O.S. Submarine," an Italian-made melodrama dubbed in English dialogue, are the film newcomers arriving today at the Rialto. "Harpoon," which features John Bromfield, was produced and directed by Ewing Scott and is being presented by the Danches brothers.
PEARL HARBOR, Dec. 7 (AP) -- Pearl Harbor observed with simple ceremonies today the seventh anniversary of the sneak Japanese attack.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 -- The National Labor Relations Board today entered its first decree under the Taft-Hartley act against the United Mine Workers of America.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 7 -- Santana Productions, the Robert Lord-Humphrey Bogart producing company, has acquired screen rights to "In a Lonely Place," a 1947 novel by Dorothy Hughes, as a prospective film vehicle for Bogart, to be made next fall, Lord disclosed today.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 -- The Interstate Commerce Commission completed today the taking of testimony on a request of the railroads for an emergency increase of 8 per cent in freight rates.

SOUTHBORO, Mass., Dec. 7 -- St. Mark's School announced today the appointment of William Wyatt Barber Jr. as headmaster. Mr. Barber, a teacher of Greek, has been assistant headmaster for four years and has been acting headmaster since the resignation of the Rev. William Brewster in June.

SEOUL, Korea, Dec. 7 -- Korean Army headquarters today reported continuing successful operations against scattered rebel forces in several remote areas. In clashes during the last three days two rebels were reported killed by Army task force units and twenty guerrillas captured.
LONDON, Dec. 7 -- Apart from routine business, brokers had little to keep them busy in the stock market here today, and jobbers complained of the lack of business.

With spirituous beverages still flowing in large quantities in the taverns affected, the strike vote by Local 15, Bartenders Union AFL ended its second day yesterday with an announcement that more intensive picketing would begin today.
CLEVELAND, Dec. 7 -- Apex Electrical Manufacturing Company has laid off 300 employes, plans to lay off 400 more Jan. 1 and has gone on a four-day week, C.G. Frantz, president, announced today.

This is the second in a series of four columns on food products for the holidays. Gift suggestions from the larger retailers, including the department stores, are included today. Tomorrow fruit cakes and plum puddings will be discussed. The final article will deal with products especially suited to home entertaining.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 -- Six years spent in the Nazi concentration camp at Buchenwald, Germany, faded far into the background for Dr. Paul Heller today as he took the oath confirming American citizenship.

HOLLYWOOD, Fla., Dec. 7 -- Industry is likely to run at a slower pace next year, with spending of capital for new plant declining by two to three billion dollars, and with business generally able to supply most of its own capital needs, according to an Investment Bankers Association study made public here today.
Pierre Etchebaster, world open court tennis champion, was challenged yesterday as he has been in no other match since his reign started in 1928.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 (AP) -- Senator William Langer, Republican, of North Dakota, said today that many married women working for the Government were childless because they were not allowed time off with pay to have babies.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 -- Two experts testifying before a joint committee on the Economic Report agreed today that profits reports are misleading and that the tax collector takes undue advantage of this abnormal situation. They disagreed, however, on the correctives that would best reflect true profits to stockholders and others.

LAKE SUCCESS, Dec. 7 -- Unless the United Nations succeeds in obtaining outside sources of income, the ability of the world organization to carry on its far-flung activities may be hampered and even crippled, a group of international relations experts warned today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 -- The Federal Reserve Board began hearings today in its anti-trust battle with the Transamerica Corporation of San Francisco but the first session was short-lived. Attorneys for the country's largest bank-holding company stalled the proceedings by filing four motions which requested that the Reserve Board dismiss its Clayton Act complaint.

Soviet officials have embarked on campaigns to raise the productivity of factory labor in Russia similar to those in Britain and France, but they are meeting with substantial resistance, according to published information from Soviet sources that has just arrived here.

Dr. Karl T. Compton, new chairman of the Research and Development Board of the National Military Establishment, said last night that he did not believe Russia had the atomic bomb or would have it in the near future.

A plan to supply retailers with hand-made French coats and suits to retail under $100 was announced yesterday by Simon Cohen, president of Simon Cohen Co., Inc., manufacturers of women's outer apparel. An initial order for 3,000 coats and 3,000 suits has been placed with French manufacturers, he said, and the first shipments will arrive in February.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 -- The retail automobile sellers through their national organization declared today that they were "smeared" without proof by the House subcommittee headed by Representative W. Kingsland Macy, Republican, of New York, which conducted an investigation of car sales involving "tips" and trade-ins far below market values.

The first thing that a pianist who performs in public must do is to be interesting. When one listened to Miklos Schwalb, the Hungarian pianist, last night in Carnegie Hall, one was interested, whether he missed notes or not, whether or not he distorted a tempi, as frequently he did.

PARIS, Dec. 7 -- The Soviet Union was censured by the Legal Committee of the United Nations General Assembly today for its practice of preventing Russian women married to foreigners from leaving Russia to join their husbands abroad.

PARIS, Dec. 7 -- Stanton Griffis, head of United Nations relief for refugees, said today that, aside from the $16,000,000 that President Truman would ask from Congress next month, his organization already had obtained a $5,000,000 advance from the United Nations working capital fund.
PARIS, Dec. 7 -- Spanish was approved today as a third working language of the United Nations General Assembly.

Promptly at 8 o'clock this evening, the curtain will rise on the first performance of "Anne of the Thousand Days" at the Shubert. It marks the twenty-seventh play of Maxwell Anderson over a span of twenty-five years. During that period he earned the accolade of the Pulitzer Prize, two successive awards from the Critics Circle, and, when the going became a bit rough, took pot shots at the critics.

Cottons destined for the sunlight were in the limelight yesterday when Zachary Bogert's Cotton Shop displayed its resort fashions in the Oval Room of the Ritz-Carlton Hotel. These gay and colorful dresses were by some of the leading designers in the field of resort wear, a highly specialized field in which Americans excel.
All who have the welfare of the country at heart should welcome the program for government health insurance as outlined in the interview with your paper by Oscar Ewing and backed by President Truman.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Dec. 7 -- New cost of living bonuses for 2,000 Westchester County employes were both attacked and defended tonight at a public hearing on the 1949 expenditures proposed by the County Board of Supervisors.

Enola Laws, a charming young soprano from Raleigh, N. C., made her New York debut last night at Times Hall. In some senses her brief program seemed more like an evening among friends than a formal recital, but it also had some of the pleasures of such evenings.

MINNEAPOLIS, Dec. 7 (AP) -Collective problems of the National Association of Professional Baseball Leagues occupied a meeting today of presidents of some fifty-eight leagues holding membership. They started discussion of sixty proposed changes in the association's regulations and in the major-minor league agreement.

LONDON, Dec. 7 -- The British, French and United States officials who resumed today their review of the program for dismantling German industrial plants were understood to be making a determined effort to settle this troublesome question finally, completely and quickly.
YONKERS, N.Y., Dec. 7 -- Settlement of the estate of Valentine Everitt Macy, philanthropist who died in 1930, was made known here today by a transfer tax report putting the amount at $30,428,385.

With 2,300,000 boys and girls 14 to 17 years old employed, there is strong need for extending Federal and state child labor laws and improving their enforcement, according to the annual report of Mrs. Gertrude Folks Zimand, general secretary of the National Child Labor Committee.

Yesterday was a gala day at City Hall for two former Brooklyn lawyers. They were Mayor O'Dwyer and Kings County Judge George J. Joyce. The two had been law partners nearly twenty-five years ago, sharing space in a Court Street office building.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 (AP) -- United States exports rose in October after a two-month decline.
