The largest corporate financing operation thus far in 1948, embodying one of the largest issues ever sold through competitive bidding, will be climaxed today as a group of 159 underwriters, headed by the First Boston Corporation and Halsey, Stuart ,Co., Inc., offers to the public $150,000,000 of twenty-five-year 3 3/8 per cent debentures, due on Dec. 1, 1973, of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company.

LONDON, Dec. 7 -- American names figured prominently and sometimes unpleasantly today in concluding testimony connected with Sidney Stanley before the Tribunal of Inquiry into allegations of fraud in the Board of Trade.

LAKE SUCCESS, Dec. 7 -- The British administering authorities of the African Territory of Tanganyika have been urged by an on-the-spot United Nations mission to encourage the 6,000,000 African inhabitants in the area to seek increased participation in government affairs.

WASHINGTON, Dec, 7 -- President Truman, in his capacity as Commander in Chief of the Armed Forces, today ordered into effect on Feb. 1 a new Army manual for courts-martial which the service promised would make "sweeping improvements" in the administration of military justice.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 (AP) -- David E. Lilienthal, Atomic Energy Commission chairman, said today that an experimental atomic energy plant might be producing electricity within three years. This first plant would be purely experimental, he added, but within twenty years a sizable percentage of electricity would be produced by such plants.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Dec. 7 -- The United Nations must have a world police force stronger than any nation's armed forces or those of any "likely combination of states" if it is to enforce world peace, Milton Eisenhower, United States delegate to the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization, told students of American University here tonight on the anniversary of Pearl Harbor.

Several weeks ago Jean Sibelius, Grand Old Man of Finland, one of the greatest of living composers, remarked to an American who visited him at his home a few miles from Helsinki, the Finnish capital, that the only present he wanted on his next birthday was a box of real Havana cigars, unobtainable at that time in his native land.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 -- Paul G. Hoffman, Economic Cooperation Administrator, maintains that American shipping is being subsidized by unreasonably high ocean freight costs at the expense of the European Recovery Program and he has threatened to divert bulk cargo shipments to foreign vessels unless by Jan. 1 American bottoms are available at "competitive rates."

LUENEBURG, Germany, Dec. 7 (UP) -- The lower Saxony denazification council announced today that Hjalmar Schacht, twice tried and acquitted for his activities as a top Nazi, would be tried again befor the Lueneburg denazification court.

On two occasions the New York Rangers enjoyed an advantage of a goal over the Boston Bruins in the National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden last night, but each time the swashbuckling crew from the Hub was able to draw even with the local forces to bring about a 2-to-2 deadlock.
CHICAGO, Dec. 7 -- The routed left-wing elements in the Transport Workers Union, CIO, sued for peace at the union's convention here today.

The Freedom Train was officially opened to Queens residents yesterday morning at a ceremony attended by Borough President James A. Burke, Supreme Court Justice Charles S. Colden and 600 persons including 400 school children.

An extensive advertising campaign will be carried on in 1949 to promote Puerto Rican rum in the United States, it was announced yesterday by the Puerto Rican Industrial Development Company. Leading national and local mass publications will be used.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Dec. 7 -- Ernest S. Race of Belvidere was elected president of the New Jersey State Horticultural Society at its seventy-fourth annual meeting here today. He succeeds Raymond Anderson of Bridgeboro.

PRETORIA, South Africa, Dec. 7 -- With discussion of the treatment of Indians in South Africa left over until next spring by the United Nations Assembly, it is believed that racial segregation in this country will be applied more and more rigidly.

BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 7 -- President Juan Peron received Senator Dennis Chavez, Democrat, of New Mexico, and seven Representatives this morning. While Robert B. Chiperfield, Republican, of Illinois, summed up the group's impressions in a formal statement, Pete Jarman, Democrat, of Alabama, said:

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 7 (AP) -- Imperator, racing for the Canadian sportsman, R.S. McLaughlin, ran six furlongs in 1:10 2/5, just one second slower than the track record, to win the featured October Purse at Tropical Park today.
The first skirmish in New York's first political libel suit in many years was fought yesterday.

The fate of one of the country's oldest military establishments -- Madison Barracks at Sackets Harbor, N.Y. -- will be decided today when the War Assets Administration publicly opens sealed bids for the property at 3 P. M. in the offices of the Real Property Division of the WAA at 40 Wall Street.

Ten small dining tables that Lord Taylor has on display on its ninth floor, show that settings for two can be as decorative and worthy of heirloom pieces as tables planned for large gatherings. Carefully chosen antique plates and hand-made table cloths embellished with delicate lace, are combined on many of the tables.

Coffee futures on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange closed irregular yesterday. After early steadiness, scattered trade offerings, and small liquidations of the nearby months, prices eased. Final prices in the contract "D" were 16 points lower to 9 points above the previous levels.

The peace and quiet of Supreme Court were broken yesterday, and in their place there was a series of chases, with lawyers and clients pursuing one another in and out of elevators and revolving doors, all because of a dispute between a divorced couple over the custody of their four children.

There will be no buyers' market in Oldsmobile cars for at least two years, S. E. Skinner, vice president of the General Motors Corporation and general manager of the Oldsmobile division, forecast yesterday in an interview at the Essex House. He based his estimate on a backlog of 1,200.000 unfilled orders for Oldsmobiles.

MOSCOW, Dec. 7 (UP) -- Czechoslovak Premier Antonin Zapotocky and his party arrived by train today at 11:30 P. M. Soviet Foreign Minister V.M. Molotov led Russian officials who greeted the Czechoslovak delegation at Byelorussian station, which was decorated with Czechoslovak flags for the occasion.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 (UP) -- The Motion Picture Association of America today urged a reduction in trade barriers to permit the free flow of both American and foreign movies throughout the world.

CLEVELAND, Dec. 7 (AP) -- Jabbing Joe Maxim left - handed his way to a ten-round split decision over Jimmy Bivins tonight and advanced several notches in the scrambled heavyweight picture. Maxim weighed 182 pounds, Bivins 178.

Mrs. Ted Horn of Patterson, N. J., widow of the famous automobile racer, received the trophy last night awarded to her late husband as the national champion driver of 1948. The presentation was made at a dinner given by the Contest Board of the American Automobile Association.

LONDON, Dec. 7 -- The Austrian request that the four powers reopen negotiations toward an Aus trian peace treaty is fully supported by the British Government, it is reported here in responsible circles. The British Government is ready to resume discussions whenever they are reopened by the United States Government, whose deputy holds the chairmanship of the next meeting.

With several hundred guests attending, Doak Walker, Southern Methodist back, received the Heisman Memorial Trophy last night at the Downtown Athletic Club as "the outstanding college football player of the 1948 season."

PARIS, Dec. 7 -- John Foster Dulles, United States delegate, told the United Nations General Assembly's Political Committee today that the Soviet Union "threatens to seize control of the whole of Korea through its puppet government of North Korea."

NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 7 -- A male shoplifter, trailed to the street yesterday by a woman store detective and arrested after pocketing a $23 electric shaver, was identified today as a fugitive from justice wanted in Chicago as ringleader of a band that netted $2,000,000 in war bonds and $100,000 in cash in a 1945 hold-up.

Kenneth P. Fallon was re-elected president yesterday of the Toy Manufacturers of the U.S.A. at the conclusion of the annual convention of the association at the McAlpin Hotel. He is vice president and general manager of the A.C. Gilbert Company, New Haven, Conn.

Pari-mutuel betting at the nation's race tracks during 1948 dropped 8 per cent from last year, while attendance slumped 5 per cent, a United Press survey showed yesterday. The actual betting drop was $126,000,000 and the attendance drop 1,300,000.
SYRACUSE, Dec. 7 (AP) -- Federal income tax adjustments for school teachers was requested today by representatives of the state's grade school principals.
LONDON, Dec. 7 -- Britain already has achieved her export target for 1948, Harold Wilson, President of the Board of Trade, announced here tonight.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 7 -- Orders to cut red tape to speed millions of dollars' worth of merchandise from ship holds into Christmas trade channels went out today as an aftermath of the three-month strike of West Coast maritime unions.

Cooperation among Protestants in the promotion of religious education was urged yesterday by the Rev. Dr. Henry Smith Leiper, associate general secretary of the World Council of Churches, at the Advent meeting of the New York diocesan Woman's Auxiliary to the Protestant Episcopal National Council.
EAST ORANGE, N. J., Dec. 7 -- Sponsored by the Antique Club of New Jersey, the New Jersey Antiques Show opened its fourteenth annual exhibition this morning at the Suburban Hotel.

SHANGHAI, Dec. 7 -- With this city's American community becoming increasingly fearful of mass looting and anti-foreign rioting in the event of a Nationalist collapse, United States consular and military authorities have prepared a plan for the protection and final evacuation of those still here.

PARIS, Dec. 7 -- The United Nations General Assembly adjourned tonight before deciding whether the question of the former Italian colonies should come before the ad hoc political Committee for preliminary discussion before the close of this session next Saturday.

While Air France's ship, The Golden Comet, winged its way from New York to Bar Harbor, Bonwit Teller showed the press, aboard for this special flight, a nine-piece wardrobe ideal for any air traveler but selected with a fortnight's holiday in Paris and the south of France in mind.
ALBANY, Dec. 7 -- Governor Dewey urged New Yorkers today to buy Christmas seals and "share in our fight on tuberculosis." In a proclamation setting December as "Christmas Seal Month," he said:

The return to Holland of the Dutch delegation that had gone to Indonesia with power to arrive at a "definite solution" with the Republic, and the pessimistic report of Republican Premier Hatta that further discussions are useless, have brought the justifiable fear in Paris that affairs in Indonesia are near a crisis.

Speaking at the annual meeting of the Lawn Tennis Writers of America yesterday at the Hotel Pennsylvania, Norman J. C. Makin, Australian Ambassador to the United States, expressed the hope that his country would continue to challenge for the Davis Cup despite its 5-0 defeat in the challenge round last September.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 (UP) -- Federal Trade Commission restrictions on basing point price systems were opposed today by spokesmen for railroad management and labor and small business organizations.

Charles C. Platt, an architect in this city for thirty years, disclosed yesterday a plan he will present to Mayor O'Dwyer and Governor Dewey for the elimination of unsightly and disease-bearing conditions in slum areas throughout the city.

Representative Fred A. Hartley of New Jersey, co-author of the Taft-Hartley Law, defended the legislation last night as a potential force for "great industrial peace." He told 950 members of the Queens Chamber of Commerce in the Commodore Hotel that since Nov. 2 there had been "a great deal of emphasis in the wrong direction that was not justified" in connection with the law.
CAIRO, Egypt, Dec. 7 -- Executives of the Arabian-American Oil Company and of Trans-Arabian Pipeline Company are conferring here this week on expansion plans in the Middle East.

The stock market accomplished nothing yesterday, dipping slightly in the morning, then recovering to close irregular. Price changes were fractional and in terms of numbers the list leaned to the lower side, although the composite rate showed a rise of 0.40 point on the day.

A joint Army-Navy-Air Force board will conduct a public hearing in City Hall at 10 A. M. Jan. 12 to consider military approval of the plan to build a bridge across the Narrows, linking Brooklyn with Staten Island.

Your editorial treatment of the recent Venezulean change of government drawing a parallel with the Peron coup in Argentina and drawing the conclusion that the new junta in Venezuela, because it happens to be headed by a colonel, Carlos Delgado Chalbaud, is a step toward dictatorship and the negation of democratic principles, does not stand the light of sober reflection.

Halsey, Stuart Co., Ladenburg Thalman Co., and a group of associates bought yesterday $7,000,000 of The Port of New York Authority's Marine Terminal Bonds, First Series. They are re-offering the bonds at 96 1/2 to yield about 2.67 per cent in 1978.

PARIS, Dec. 7 -- Weeks of private negotiations toward solving the Balkan controversy took a critical turn today as an official United Nations spokesman accused Bulgaria of spreading misleading information and endangering the success of the talks.
PARIS, Dec. 7 (Reuters) -- Le Corbusier, leading French architect, said today he should have been recalled to New York to supervise the construction of the United Nations palace in New York.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 -- A better home plant for the country preacher and his wife is advocated in a booklet of 111 pages just recommended by the Department of Agriculture to all home management and housefurnishing specialists and home demonstration leaders.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 -- Postmaster General Jesse M. Donaldson forecast today that second, third and fourth class and special service postal rates would be increased next year.

Accidents here in the first ten months of this year killed 2,860 persons, a decrease of 1 per cent from the corresponding period in 1947, Frank L. Jones, president of the Greater New York Safety Council, reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 -- Parking congestion was termed today the "major inconvenience which prevented taking the car downtown" in virtually all of the urban areas of the country, with consequent detriment to the downtown districts.

TOKYO, Dec. 7 -- Japanese were pleased but somewhat puzzled today by a decision of the United States Supreme Court to hear the appeals of former Gen. Kenji Doihara and former Premier Koki Hirota, sentenced to death by the International Military Tribunal here as war criminals after a two and one-half year trial.
Mayor O'Dwyer said yesterday that his Administration since it took office on Jan. 1, 1946, had granted city employes salary increases amounting to $120,000,000.
A little on the sedate side, but popular with youngsters, the annual Children's Holiday Fair at the Museum of Modern Art, 11 West Fifty-third Street, began its month's run yesterday.

The customer may not always be right, but when he orders ham and fried eggs, his wishes should be respected. This is the opinion of Magistrate Abner C. Surpless and of Richard Edde, a student of international trade. But it seems there are those who disagree.

Whittaker Chambers disclosed yesterday that for ten years he had had "constructive" but not actual possession of the microfilms of top secret Government documents he asserts were filched from official files by a pre-war Soviet espionage ring.

A check for $1,000,000 was presented last week to the Presbyterian Board of Foreign Missions by an anonymous donor identified only as a "Chinese Christian businessmen," it was announced yesterday by the Rev. Dr. Lloyd S. Ruland, board secretary for China missions.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Dec. 7 (AP) -- The main item on the agenda when the American Association of College Football Coaches convenes in San Francisco on Jan. 4 will be the free substitution rule, President Harvey Harman said today.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 -- The State Department notified the Austrian Government today that the United States was "fully prepared to participate in renewed discussions on the Austrian treaty."

SEATTLE, Dec. 7 -- Many newspaper executives of the country gathered here this afternoon to congratulate the Hearst organization and the management of the Seattle Post-Intelligencer on the opening of a new $5,000,000 home for the newspaper, oldest in continuous publication on the Pacific Coast.

Dentists should study psychiatry for the aid it would give them in determining mouth disturbances caused by emotional conflicts, it was reported yesterday at the twenty-fourth annual Greater New York Dental Meeting.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., Dec. 7 (AP) -- A Navy captain who has been "closely associated" with football coach George Sauer this past season, was chosen today as Navy's athletic director.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 -- A bipartisan campaign to put through early in the next Congress a bill increasing the pay of all high Government officials was disclosed today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 -- Secretary of State George C. Marshall underwent an operation at Walter Reed Hospital this morning. Although the exact nature of the operation was not announced officially, it was learned authoritatively that two cysts had developed on one kidney and that the kidney was removed. There was nothing malignant, it was said.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- President Truman welcomed Dr. Carlos Prio Socarras, new President of Cuba, here today for a state visit and declared that no two countries of the Western Hemisphere had friendlier relations than Cuba and the United States.

Higher London cablegrams and a stronger primary market at Singapore abetted the advance of crude rubber futures on Commodity Exchange yesterday. The market opened 25 points above the previous close and continued to advance throughout the day.

PARIS, Dec. 8 -- Despite strenuous opposition from the Soviet bloc, the United Nations General Assembly's Political Committee tonight voted to recognize the Seoul regime as the only legal Government of the Republic of Korea. It approved the joint United States-Australian-Chinese resolution by 41 votes to 6.

E. L. Stephens in his letter in your issue of Dec. 2 mixes up the total labor force of sixty,million with the forty million working for wages and salaries. Even in thaT twenty million of owner operators, of farmers and of professional workers, there are many effective unions and professional associations, because most American citizens redognize that regulation and group action are indispensable in modern society.
Dr. Edwin S. Burdell, director of Cooper Union, recommended yesterday that grades in American education be de-emphasized in favor of a re-emphasis of- "overall achievement" by the student.

HOLLYWOOD, Fla., Dec. 8 -- Investment bankers in convention at the Hollywood Beach Hotel here were told that the broad interests of the country call for a cautious rather than a bold approach to any major change in the debt management policies that are now anchored in par-pegged prices for the Governments 2 1/2 per cent bond.
SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 8 -- The tempo of activity on West Coast waterfronts increased today as piled-up cargoes resulting from the three-month maritime strike melted slowly.

A 13-year-old boy who was in Warsaw when the German armies entered in 1939 and who has just become an American citizen gave $3 to THE NEW YORK TIMES Neediest Cases Fund yesterday to express his gratitude at being in "this great country."

Theodore W. Kheel, who resigned recently as director of the city's Division of Labor Relationsh)0*0*0*ito practice law, stressed the importance of "fairness" in the mediation of labor disputes when honored yesterday by the Young Men's Board of Trade for his contribution to the welfare of the community.

SYDNEY, Australia, Dec. 8-The Netherlands delegation withdrew today from the conference of the United Nations Economic Commission for Asia and the Far East meeting in Lapstone. after the Indonesian 'Republic and Indonesia (the Netherlands East Indies) had been separately admitted as associate members.

Quartermaster purchasing of clothing, equippage and subsistence items currently is running at a rate double that of last year and the year before, it was revealed last night by Brig. Gen. L. O. Grice, commanding officer, New York Quartermaster Purchasing Office.

The start of a new service between New York and Pakistan and the west coast of India, via the Mediterranean, was announced yesterday by the Atlantic Overseas Corporation, 10 Pearl Street, agents in this country for the Belgian Line.

The little village of Mentor, Ohio, has delivered a food and clothing gift estimated at $35,000 for shipment to its "adopted" community of Suolahti in Finland, it was announced yesterday. The material will be kept at the warehouse of Help Finland, Inc., 8 Washington Place, until shipping space is available.
PARIS, Dec. 8 -- The United Nations Assembly asked today for admission of twelve countries blackballed by the Security Council but put special emphasis on the seven vetoed by Russia.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- The new Army court-martial procedure which will become effective Feb. 1 is better than the normal civilian system of justice, Kenneth C. Royall, Secretary of the Army, said today.
Mayor O'Dwyer inspected yesterday in City Hall Plaza twenty new Diesel-powered buses to be operated in Manhattan, Brooklyn, Queens and Staten Island.
GREENUP, Ill., Dec. 8 (AP) -- A C-47 transport plane required only 600 feet for a take-off today from a wheat field with the aid of jet propulsion.

There are more than twenty foreign students in the United States for every American undergraduate studying abroad, Dr. Gordon R. Silber, head of the department of modern languages at Union College, declared here last night in a plea for greater foreign study opportunities for our students.
Thirteen was a lucky number in Bellevue yesterday, as that many children received Santa Claus in his first official visit of the season to the hospital.

I was surprised at THE NEw YORK TIMES editorial of Dec. 3, "Our Municipal Colleges," in which you stated that we have much to learn from some Midwestern universities on cooperative programs between business or industry and colleges.

ALBANY, Dec. 8 -- Dr. Herman E. Hilleboe, State Health Commissioner, called upon hospitals, pharmacists and physicians today to take greater care in guarding narcotic drug supplies. There have been more than twenty major thefts of such supplies from New York State hospitals during the last year in New York City, Buffalo, Troy, Syracuse, Rochester, Schnectady and Jamestown.

The Retirement Fund of the Coat and Suit Industry in the New York Metropolitan area celebrated last night its fifth year with a dinner at the Astor Hotel. Two hundred representatives of labor and management took part.

ACRE, Israel, Dec. 8 (AP) -- A letter allegedly referring to terrorist plans to "deal" with Count Folke Bernadotte, slain United Nations Mediator, was read by the prosecution today at the trial of two leaders of the outlawed Stern Gang.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- Secretary of Interior J. A. Krug was advised today that estimates of the nation's coal resources are too high and that there should be a rapid reappraisal of the bituminous coal deposits east of the Mississippi River.

Consolidated net income of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation for the nine months to Sept. 30 amounted to $6,051,622, contrasted with a net loss of $3,009,512 for the comparable period of 1947. For the parent company alone, net income was $1,315,925, compared with $1,621,265 in the 1947 period.
ATLANTA, Dec. 8 (UP) -- Police Chief G. Neal Ellis of Fulton County said today that he was powerless to prevent Ku Klux Klan parades but that it was his duty to police them.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 8 -- The problem of increasing labor efficiency on banana, oil and lumber plantations in the tropics through mass suppression of malaria infections has apparently been solved with the use of two new drugs, chloroquine and paludrine, Dr. Herbert C. Clark, director of the Gorgas Memorial Laboratory in Panama, declared today.

FORT WORTH, Tex., Thursday, Dec. 9 -- The Air Force said early today that a B-36 bomber, the world's largest, had completed a non-stop flight from Fort Worth to Honolulu and back, the longest flight it had ever made.

How to detect whether a telephone wire is being tapped will be explained today at a public hearing of the special committee investigating wire-tapping for the New York County Criminal Courts Bar Association.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- Sufficient American shipping is available at Shanghai to evacuate American civilians in the event of a serious emergency, Acting Sec retary of State Robert A. Lovett said today.

Purchases of new life insurance in the United States during 1948 are estimated at $22,700,000,000, Bruce E. Shepherd, manager of the Life Insurance Association of America, announced yesterday. This figure is within 2 per cent of last year's all time record, and will bring the total of insurance in force to an estimated $201,000,000,000 at the year end.

In connection with condemnation proceedings in the vicinity of East Twenty-third Street for the site of a 1,000-bed veterans' hospital on the East Side, the Government has deposited $2,967,550 with the United States District Court the Veterans Administration announced yesterday.

John E. Slater, long a bitterh)0*0*0*iopponent of Pan American Airways and its policies, has resigned as chairman of the board of American Overseas Airlines, it was announced last night. The announcement came from American Export Lines, Inc., the steamship company with which Mr. Slater has been identified.

Merchandise displayed in a raised position, and in a promotional setting was found the most effective point - of - sale "traffic stopper" of three main types of display covered in a pilot study reported yesterday to more than 1,000 members and guests of the National Association of Display Industries in the New Yorker Hotel.

PARIS, Dec. 8 -- In an effort to balance the budget for the coming year, the French Cabinet today cut productive investments to a point that experts consider is inadequate to fulfill the commitments that the French Government has taken in its four-year recovery program under the Marshall Plan.

Afternoon, cocktail and evening fashions designed by Oleg Cassini for resort and spring wear were presented yesterday at the Pierre Hotel for the benefit of the New York Infirmary's social service committee.

THE HAGUE, The Netherlands, Dec. 8 -- The Dutch Cabinet will debate the extremely delicate question of Indonesia tomorrow. All day today this city was buzzing with rumors about the situation. However, nothing substantial will be learned until Foreign Minister Derek U. Stikker and anuel Sassen, Minister of Overseas Territories, submit their report to the Government.

CAIRO, Egypt, Dec. 8 -- Yussef Bey Sahyun, Minister of Information of the All-Palestine Government established at Gaza last September, issued an angry denunciation tonight of the moves of King Abdullah of Trans-Jordan toward becoming King of Palestine in addition to Trans-Jordan.

The second and final session of an auction at the Kende Galleries, Inc., 119 West Fifty-seventh Street, of the French library formed by the late Cortlandt F. Bishop, resulted in sales totaling $157,000 last night.

The role of craftsmen in turning out distinctive handmade accessories for homes is amply demonstrated by three pottery exhibitions that opened yesterday. Two consisting of works by professional ceramists and students are gathered under one roof in the Arts and crafts Building of Greenwich House, while the third is a private showing designed to introduce new pottery from Puerto Rico.

The Port of New York Authority is going ahead with the development of the New York International Airport at Idlewild despite the fact that present tenants use only about 5 per cent of its runway capacity, and that no move has been made to break the deadlock between the Authority and the American flag airlines.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Dec. 8 (AP) -The Navy-Notre Dame football game will continue next year to be the "big" game in the East for the Irish, with Baltimore the locale, according to the plan of the new academy athletic director.

TOKYO, Dec. 8 (AP) -- Marquis Koichi Kido, Emperor Hirohito's closest wartime adviser, barely escaped the death penalty handed out to Hideki Tojo and six other Japanese warlords, it was learned today.

VIENNA, Dec. 8 -- Fraeulein Margarethe Ottillinger, chief of the government's Planning Department, has been sentenced to twenty years in prison on the charge that she had spied for the United States, officials said tonight.

PEIPING, Dec. 8 -- An eerie stillness pervaded this war front today when three Americans in a jeep arrived at the last Nationalist outpost on the Peiping-Kupehkow railway, some twenty miles, as the crow flies, northeast of Peiping.

The National Distillers Corporation, of which Seton Porter is president, plans to move its metropolitan sales division from 120 Broadway to larger quarters at 285 Madison Avenue, where it has leased about 6,000 square feet for executive offices.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 (AP) -- A House Labor subcommittee recommended today that labor unions be barred from organizing farm workers. The group, headed by Representative Wint Smith of Kansas, said in a published report:
The bartenders' strike was still on yesterday even if there was still no agreement among the principals affected on how many men were involved or how many bars were being picketed.

Chairman Wayne Coy indicated yesterday that the Federal Communications Commission's temporary suspension of action on pending or prospective applications for new television stations might be extended beyond the six months originally estimated.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- Organized labor took its turn today at analyzing corporate profits for the joint committee on the Economic Report and protested that business was taking its new capital from consumers through high prices instead of borrowing it from investors.

A letter in THE TIMES, entitled "Adirondack Reservoir," published over the name of David C. Knowlton of Watertown, refers to many points, outstanding of which is reference in the last paragraph to the benefits claimed by him and by the Black River Regulating District Board for the people on the Black River.

The country will welcome the reassuring bulletins that come from Walter Reed Hospital and rust that they fore-shadow the prompt and complete return to good health of Secretary Marshall. There have been frequent reports in recent months that Mr. Marshall faced the necessity of a surgical operation.

Three checks totalling $61,750 were presented yesterday to representatives of St. Vincent's Hospital, the Columbia University College of Physicians and Surgeonsh)0*0*0*iand the American Museum of Natural History by the New York City Cancer Committee for use in research projects established by the American Cancer Society.

BOSTON, Dec. 8 (AP) -- Senator Charles W. Tobey, Republican, of New Hampshire, closed today a long inquiry into Textron, Inc., and its associated charitable trusts by serving notice that he was going to try to plug "distinct loopholes" in tax laws to assure "humble" Americans "a fair deal."

OTwo men were killed and five were injured about 10:30 o'clock last night when the automobile in which they were riding, allegedly rammed and overturned a thick loaded with whiskey and then bounced off into a brick factory building near Atlantic Avenue and Cleveland Street, Brooklyn.

PARIS, Dec. 8 -- The administrative budgetary committee of the United Nations General Assembly was confronted tonight by a report from Secretary General Trygve Lie pointing out that the total of the moneys voted for various projects and needs of the United Nations in 1949 amounted to $41,544,189, whereas the ordinary budget for the coming year had been placed at $31,695,200.

The nation's gasoline Stocks increased 1,433,000 barrels last week to 95,235,000, according to the American Petroleum Institute. This compared with 93,802,000 at the end of the preceding week and 86,968,000 a year ago.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- The dispute in Washington over the future policies and leaders of the Republican party is gradually moving toward a compromise solution.

Strong support tempered by reservations from Republican party elders greeted the proposal of Philip Willkie, 28-year-old member of the Indiana Legislature and son of the late Wendell Willkie, for a Republican "revitalization conference" in 1949, it became evident yesterday from a survey of a crosssection of Republican opinion.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- A Senate investigation of the military clemency granted to Ilse Koch, wife of the German commandant of Buchenwald, went outside Army testimony today to hear former victims of that Nazi "horror camp."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- The periodic publications, by accident or design, of secret diplomatic exchanges on grave matters always demonstrate that the success or failure of an Ambassador's mission is based in part on his private sources of information. Recent illustrations of this are provided in the secret documents dealing with Soviet-Nazi relations which were. captured by our troops in Germany and made public last January by the 'DePartment of State.
Mme. Abel Ferry, "ambassadress" of St. Die, France, which was devastated by the Germans in World War II, was honored last night in the Legion Auditorium, 500 Park Avenue.

BERLIN, Dec. 8 -- The United States Military Government's decision to abandon licensing of the press has aroused widespread fear among German publishers and legislators that control of newspapers and other publications soon will return to the hands of former Nazis and lead to the revival of giant press trusts.

New York's four municipal colleges received a record $24,293,587 in receipts from all sources during the fiscal year ending June 30, 1948, J. Harvey Cain, accounting officer of the Board Of Higher Education, announced yesterday. Theh)0*0*0*iprevious high of $21,073,416 was established in 1946-47.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- Paul G. Hoffman, head of the Economic Cooperation Administration, was attacked today by shipping and allied labor interests for his threat to divert some shipping from American lines unless they offered rates competitive to those of foreign lines.

LONDON, Dec. 8 -- Enlarging upon information given to the United Nations committee in Paris, the British Foreign Office said that one Israeli column crossed the Trans-Jordan frontier on Nov. 29 and another had crossed a day or two earlier, but neither column remained for very long.

An old hand at scribbling about kings and queens, Maxwell Anderson has written one of his most stirring dramas, "Anne of the Thousand Days," which opened at the Sam S. Shubert last evening. His Anne is Anne Boleyn, second wife to that merry but bloodstained monarch, Henry VIII.
Justice Henry Clay Greenberg granted yesterday in Bronx Supreme Court an application of a family to change its surname from Sullivan to Solomon.

TRENTON, N. J., Dec. 8 -- The Appellate Division of the New Jersey Superior Court overruled today a lower court decision that barred a Negro woman from the swimming pool at Palisades Amusement Park, Palisade Park, N. J.

PARIS. Dec. 8 -- Britain proposed today that a Security Council committee begin a study of action under Chapter VII of the United Nations Charter to compel Israel to agree to comply with the Council's resolution of Nov. 4 regarding the withdrawal of forces in the Negeb.

Represenatives of the entertainment industry will meet here tomorrow to take action against the recent ban by Chicago police against the staging of Jean-Paul Sartre's play, "The Respectful Prostitute," in that city.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- Traffic and parking congestion problems in New York City be solved by the makeshift methods now being applied, Prof. Robert B. Mitchell of Columbia University said here today.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., Dec. 8 -- The Naval Academy basketball team opened its season today with a 48-30 victory over Penn Military College.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninetyfour leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended Dec. 1, the Federal Reserve Board announced today:
LONDON, Dec. 8 -- Quiet again ruled in the stock market here today.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 8 -- Louis B. Mayer, head of the Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer film studio, testified in Federal Court today that the UnAmerican Activities Committee of the House brought pressure on him to discharge alleged Communists prior to the committee's hearings in Washington last November.

Mayor O'Dwyev and Thomas F. Farrell, chairman of the New York City Housing Authority, will discuss with Presidents Truman tomorrow the prospect of Federal legislaton to aid the city in its housing program. The Mayor said last night that he and Mr Farrell would leave for Washington by automobile this afternoon.

University professors, accountants 2nd labor union economists have shared and the spotlight in the first three days of hearings this week before a joint committee on the Economic Report. The committee, under the chairmanship of Senator Flanders of Vermont, is seeking to determine whether present corporate profits are too high, and if so what should be done about it.

Mr. and Mrs. Frederic A. Ley of 1 East End Avenue will give a dinner on Dec. 23 in the Oval Room of the Ritz-Carlton in advance of the second Junior Assembly to introduce Mr. Ley's daughter, Miss Janet Wallace Ley. The debutante was graduated from the Chapin School in New York and is attending Smith College.

A new $100,000 personnel testing program has been developed following five years of research, which may have widespread application in the selection of personnel for business and industry, it was announced yesterday by Harold R. Caffyn, chairman of the committee on selection of personnel of the American Institute of Accountants.

iOA banking group headed by B. J. Van Ingen Co., Inc., is reoffering a new issue of $1,044,000 City of Clifton, N. J., 2 1/4 per cent various purpose bonds, maturing from Nov. 1, 1949 to 1978, it was announced yesterday. The issue was awarded to the banking group by Clifton at 100.249 for the 2 1/4. s.

PARIS, Dec. 8 -- One hundred and sixty-six organizations, representing nearly a quarter of a billion persons all over the world, petitioned Dr. Herbert D. Evatt today for final action on the genocide convention before the United Nations General Assembly adjourns its Paris session.

Our desk is "snowed" under with correspondence describing the vast program of improvements and expansion in the Northlands and a load of inquiries from beginners, especially, who want to know "everything that should be known in the sport of skiing."
All M. Landon, Republican nominee for President in 1936, declared yesterday that Republican acquiescence in the bipartisan foreign policy had led both the party and the country into a "booby trap."

Plans for a quasi-governmental organization that would interpret American thought and culture to the world and stimulate public interest in the United States were announced yesterday by Carleton Smith, director of the National Arts Foundation.

Four new witnesses appeared yesterday before the Federal grand jury that is conducting a renewed investigation of Communist espionage as a result of charges by Whittaker Chambers, admitted former courier for a Soviet spy ring.

No longer do people starve or shiver through the winter. The concept of the word "neediest" in the Hundred Neediest Cases has changed during the years. Public welfare provides the essentiss. There is, however, a need perhaps greater than the physical ones, and that is the hunger of the soul.

The constitutionality of Section 965 of the State Penal Law, the statute under which hundreds of persons have been prosecuted as rent gougers, is being questioned in an action in Federal Court, Brooklyn, it was learned yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- A demand that the Republican party adopt an follow up a strong, affirmative and liberal program, addressed to party leaders by young Republican clubs at four New England colleges, attracted widespread attention today in high party circles.

Long Island University and City College will face Southwest Conference opponents in tonight's college basketball double-header at Madison Square Garden. The Blackbirds will meet Arkansas in the opener at 8 P.M., with the Beavers tackling Southern Methodist in the nightcap. A crowd of 15,000 is expected.

TOKYO, Dec. 8 -- Important changes in Japan's foreign trade procedure are in the making, according to occupation sources. Chief among these would be arranegments permitting foreign concerns to export from Japan on the same basis as the Japanese and permitting any exporter to retain a proportion of the resulting foreign exchange for business uses.

The Radio Manufacturers Association is considering establishment of a voluntary industry conservation program for tin supplies, an association spokesman revealed yesterday. He said that the critical shortage of the metal constitutes a grave threat to expanded television receiver production and pointed out that production of a television receiver unit requiresh) 0*0*0*iapproximately ten times as much tin as a single radio set.

City officials joined consumers and social and welfare workers yesterday at a noisy United States Department of Agriculture hearing to demand that the retail price of fluid class 1A milk be reduced beyond the price proposed by the milk industry.

The changes in Army and Air Force court-martial procedures and penalties announced by army Secretary Royall bring military justice closer to civilian concept, s, especially as they make its dispensation more even between officers and enlisted men. As explained by the Secretary, the changes ordered are a part of the revisions of the Articles of War outlined in Title II of the Selective Service Act passed by the Eightieth Congress in its closing hours.

Radio and television issues were the strong spots again yesterday in an otherwise limpid stock market, although the list closed firmer after sagging moderately. Only a few stocks, and these generally in the high price category, showed price changes of more than a point, with the index up 0.13 point.

The projected non-championship battle between Ray Robinson world welterweight champion, and Steve Belloise, veteran Bronx middleweight, scheduled for tonight in the Jersey City Armory under the auspices of the Tournament of Champions, Inc., yesterday was postponed indefinitely.

New York has "blazed the trail" for communities all over the country in informing the public of new methods of curing venereal diseases, Dr. Harry S. Mustard, Health Commissioner, declared last night in a report to Mayor O'Dwyer on the first phase of thc city's campaign to bring under treatment hidden cases of early syphilis and gonorrhea.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- The basic question for Congress and the American people to decide with respect to the pricing policies of business is "whether or not they desire to preserve and restore the principle of competition in the American economy," Dr. Vernon A. Mund, department of economics of the University of Washington, said today.

Two well-dressed men posing as detectives robbed a business man and his wife yesterday morning in their home in the Beechhurst section of Whitestone, Queens. They got $3,500 in cash and jewelry valued at $7,840.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 (AP) -Eastern railroads today asked the Interstate Commerce Commission to approve their practice of exchanging rate and operating information.

A dramatic attempt to save the life of a 1-year-old Brooklyn infant who had accidentally swallowed poison proved unavailing yesterday despite police cooperation in racing a new drug, still in the medical experimental stage, from a Manhattan chemical house to Brooklyn Hospital.

Detectives of the Charles Street station have been assigned to catch two well-dressed, well-spoken robbers who on Tuesday night took $3 and a $100 diamond ring from a young mother whose child is ill in St. Vincent's Hospital.

Mortimer J. Davis, executive manager, New York Credit Men's Association, was honored last nighth)0*0*0*ion the completion of twenty years of service to the credit profession at a testimonial dinner in the New Yorker Hotel.

The Allied Stores Corporation and its subsidiaries, in a quarterly statement covering the three months ended on Oct. 31, reported yesterday an increase of 8.2 per cent in net sales to $100,125,018 from the $92,534,776 volume for the similar period of a year ago.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Dec. 8 -- The parents of the late M/Sgt. Meyer Levin, the Brooklyn hero who flew with Capt. Colin Kelly in the Pacific fighting, received yesterday eight of their son's posthumous medals from Maj. Gen. Robert M. Webster at First Air Force Headquarters, Fort Slocum.

THE beak-busting business is hustling with activity this week. There will be a heavyweight brawl in Madison Square Garden tomorrow night between Ezzard Charles and Joe Baksi. On that same evening in Chicago a couple of promising young heavyweights will stage an exhibition. Their names? Oh, yes. Joe Louis and Billy Conn.

PRINCETON, N. J., Dec. 8 -Princeton's varsity basketball team began it 1948-49 campaign successfully tonight, but had to do it the hard way. The Tigers came from behind with less than two minutes to go to down Gettysburg College, 51 -- 48, in a thrilling battle in the new Dillon Gymnasium.

MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 8 (AP) -- The nation's top golfers took final practice swings around the palmlined Miami Springs course today in preparation for the twenty-fifth annual $10,000 Miami open tournament starting tomorrow.

Two parcels containing about sixty-eight acres of farm land at East Meadow in the town of Hempstead, L. L, have been purchased by Conti-Square Homes, Inc., from William T. and Estell B. Lowden for improvement with one-family dwellings.

Gasoline trickling from a punctured tank of a five-ton truck left a running trail of fire yesterday along a Brooklyn street Before firemen extinguished the blaze the truck was almost destroyed, two cars were singed and flames nibibled at tires of a line of fifty parked automobiles.
PARIS, Dec. 8 -- Black markets and profiteering in food and wastage of foodstuffs were condemned by the General Assembly of the United Nations today.

Directors of the New York Central Railroad Company declared yesterday a dividend of 50 cents a share on the capital stock, payable Jan. 15, to stock of record Dec. 22. This will be the first dividend to be paid by the company since the $1 a share payment in January, 1946.

Castro A. Martinez, 18 years old, of 75 Johnson Street, Brooklyn, describedh)0*0*0*ibefore Magistrate Paul Palsam as having admitted a series of thefts from women who were attending mass, was arraigned on a charge of petit larceny last night in Brooklyn-Queens Night Court.

Zdenek Smetacek, Czechoslovak Consul in charge or information under his country's Consul General, Dr. Rudolf Kuraz in New York, announced his resignation last night, saying he could no longer associate himself with his country's Communist-dominated regime.

The 153-year-old Fordham University church, completely remodeled and redecorated, was dedicated yesterday by Cardinal Spellman as a war memorial to the 229 sons of Fordham who were killed in World War II.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange were somewhat irregular yesterday and at the close prices were 4 points higher to 9 points lower.
SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, Dec. 8 --Returns tonight from the day's National Assembly election give a commanding lead to President elect Otilio Ulate's National Union party.

The statement of Under-Secretary Lovett that the state Department's code system has been completely changed during the past ten years, and that there has been a general tightening up on security regulations in all sensitive Government agencies, provides reassurance that Washington is alive to the basic issue raised by the latest developments in the espionage inquiry.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- Assurances that the State Department's diplomatic codes had been made as secure against espionage as it was humanly possible to make them were given by Acting Secretary Robert A. Lovett today. This new security, Mr. Lovett told a news conference, had been effected during the last ten years by steadily improved peace and wartime procedures and devices.

King Peter of Yugoslavia questioned yesterday the wisdom of extending United States economic aid to Marshal Tito in an effort to widen the rift between the Yugoslav dictator's government and the other members of the Cominform.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 8 (AP) -Siddons, first of two winners ridden by Apprentice Clarence Picou at the Fair Grounds today, stood off a strong challenge by Village Beau to capture the Hammond Purse feature.

Volunteer workers in the city's diabetes detection centers reported yesterday that public response to their offer of free tests for the disease had been "splendid," with all four stations working nearly at capacity.

Although the long-range interest in professional football is centered upon the battle between the two Chicago National Football League teams, the Bears and Cardinals, for the Western Division title next Sunday, the Giants still enlisted some local attention.

There is an old (and probably apocryphal) anecdote about an ambitious but penniless young man who asked a multimillionaire how to get wealthy quickly. The multimillionaire is supposed to have replied, "Invest ten thousand dollars In * * *," at which point the young man said, "Thank you, but never mind going any farther."
Russia has more to fear from its own "iron curtain" than we have, Associate Justice Robert H. Jackson of the United States Supreme Court declared here last night.

Advertising in the eight major New York City newspapers during the eleven months, January to November, this year totaled 136,338,809 lines, a gain of 6.12 per cent over the like period of 1947, an analysis of Media Records showed yesterday.

BERLIN, Dec. 8 -- The Soviet Military Administration and German Communists are considering the incorporation into Eastern Berlin of a number of outlying villages and towns in order to bolster the claim of the Communist City Government as the city's only legitimate ruling body.

MINNEAPOLIS, Dec. 8 -- In a day of intensive skirmishing and heavy lobby pounding that had arches groaning under the strain, it remained for the Pirates and Cubs to break through with the first major player deal today as the minors' National Association of Professional Baseball Leagues convention got under way.

Humphrey F. Redfield is slated to be elected commodore of the American Yacht Club at its annual meeting at the clubhouse in Rye tomorrow night. The other officers will be William L. Crow, vice commodore; Garrison R. Corwin, rear commodore; Roger Sherman, secretary, and Lindsay RI. Goodeve, treasurer.

Histories of two of the world's greatest scientific bodies, the English Royal Society and the American Smithsonian Institution, will be published Jan. 13 by Henry Schuman. The companion books will be "Scientists and Amateurs: A History of the Royal Society," by Dorothy Stimson, and "Sons of Science: The Story of the Smithsonian Institution and Its Leaders," by Paul H. Oehser.

CHICAGO, Dec. 8 -- Formally stating its position regarding the Tucker Corporation, the Tucker distributors and dealers committee today termed the corporation's management "inadequate" and outlinedh)0*0*0*ia plan for replenishing the company's treasury and putting it on a production basis.

" NEW DIRECTIONS, 10,"* edited by James Laughlin, is a lively collection of ventures along the untrodden and the downtrodden ways of writing. It is briskly devoted to the experimental, hospitable to new ideas, animated by the spirit of exploration without which all writing would wither, stagnate and generally go to pot.

CHICAGO, Dec. 8 (AP) -- Doug Bentley's two third-period goals for the Black Hawks beat the Boston Bruins, 4 -- 3, tonight before 15,206 spectators at the Stadium. The victory moved Chicago into third place in the National Hockey League.

The old left-wing Greater New York Industrial Union Council, whose charter was lifted three weeks ago by the national Congress of Industrial Organizations, died in poor financial condition, an audit of its books showed yesterday.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 8 -Carrying the first evacuees from China to reach this port by ship,h) 0*0*0*ithe Army transport General Simon B. Buckner docked at Fort Mason today with 1,542 passengers. They included eighty-five women and eighty children from that country, representing about the last of the Army and Air Force dependents there, according to the San Francisco Army Base.

The price of eggs still is dropping. Two major chains announced yesterday that they would chip another 2 cents a dozen off the cost of their best quality eggs, bringing them down to 73 cents, the lowest in years, according to store spokesmen.

h)0*0*0*iOBUDAPEST, Hungary, Dec. 8 -The political committee of the Smallholders party -- second largest of the Government coalition parties -announced today the resignation from office of five Under-Secretaries of State who were members of the party.

BELHAVEN, N. C., Dec. 8 -- The broad thumb of marshland, several hundred square miles in area, that sticks out into Albemarle and Palmico Sounds at most points is no higher than a man above waterlevel, but the goose, quail, deer and bear shooting found here would keep any hunter both active and happy.

A sizzling drive which netted 12 consectuive points carried the New York Knickerbockers to a stirring overtime triumph over the Providence Steam Rollers at Madison Square Garden last night. The local quintet won by 83-74, after the regulation playing time had ended with the teams deadlocked at 68-all.

An offering of $12,000,000 Alabama lower Company first mortgage bonds, 3 3/8% per cent series, due Dec. 1, 1978 at 102 3/4% per cent and accrued interest, will be made today by au underwriting group headed by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc. The group won the award ofthe bonds at competitive sale onits bid of 102.109991.

This is the third in a series of four columns on food products for the holidays. The subject today is fruit cakes and plum puddings. A later article will deal with products especially suited to home entertaining.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- The State Department said today that it had no knowledge or evidence to support a Venezuelan's charge that United States oil companies had backed the recent right-wing Army overthrow of the Caracas government.
" Don't kill junior with kindness by getting him the wrong kind of toy for Christmas," Frank L. Jones; president of the Greater New York Safety Council, warned yesterday.

MINNEAPOLIS, Dec. 8 (AP) -Jimmy Brown was appointed coach of the Braves today, replacing Freddy Fitzsimmons, who switched to the Giants recently in a similar capacity. Brown, who played under Billy Southworth on the Cardinals, last year managed New Orleans in the Southern Association.

Directors of the United States Rubber Company yesterday elected Herbert E. Smith, the company's president, to be chairman of the board and chief executive officer, and Harry E. Humphreys Jr. to be president and chairman of the executive committee.

Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., will seek authority to issue $28,000,000 convertible debentures, it was announced last night by Ralph H. Tapscott, president. The debentures, he said, would be offered in voluntary exchange for the common stock which will be issued by the Long Island Lighting Company if plans to merge Queens Borough Gas and Electric, and Nassau and Suffolk Lighting Companies into Long Island Lighting are approved.

TORONTO, Dec. 8 (AP) -- Stocky Jim McFadden's second goal of the game late in the third period tonight snapped a 3-3 tie and carried the Detroit Red Wings to a 4-3 triumph over Toronto's, defending National Hockey League champions at Maple Leaf Gardens.
CHICAGO, Dec. 8 -- Grain markets staged a good rally on the Board of Trade today after easiness early.

Two of the nation's leading dental educators warned yesterday of the dangers involved in overspecialization within the dental profession, saying that it might ultimately prove harmful to both the general public and the profession itself.

Predictions of a leveling off, or even a decline, of construction activity and the beginning of what may, with some reservations, be called a buyer's market in the residential field bespeak a change in the housing picture. Our real estate editor, Lee E. Cooper, reports that "construction programs are reflecting a more cautious attitude on the part of investors and operators."

As the poets insist, women They men are darlings. They run Have the house, bring up, the children, a List fill the chorus lie at the theatre and decide on the most likely restaurant for real home cooking. As the poets insist, it would be hard to do without them.

LONDON, Dec. 8 -- Paul G. Hoffman, Economic Cooperation Administrator, declared today that the problem of deciding what industrial plants should be retained in Germany for purposes of the European Recovery Program had been exaggerated "all out of its proper proportions."

Government in this country "has its hands around the throat of American business and the power to strangle it to death," Lowell B. Mason, member of the Federal Trade Commission, charged here yesterday. He spoke at the closing session of the American Pharmaceutical Manufacturers Association's three-day conference at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

The problem of financial security for the New York Public Library was laid before Mayor O'Dwyer yesterday in an unprecedented meeting, which produced an order from the Mayor to Budget Director Thomas J. Patterson to study the library's request for an annual allocation of $500,000.

PARIS, Dec. 8 -- The United Nations General Assembly decided this morning to postpone consideration of the question of the former Italian colonies until it resumes its meeting at Flushing Meadow April 1. The Assembly voted 31 to 11, with 9 abstentions, to reject a proposal that the question be transferred from the over crowded Political and Security Committee to the ad hoc committee that was established a few weeks ago.
CAIRO, Egypt, Dec. 8 -- Premier Mahmoud Fahmy Nokrashy Pasha, as Military Governor of Egypt, ordered tonight the dissolution of the Moslem Brotherhood.

The one-story taxpayer containing two stores at 94 Ashburton Avenue in Yonkers, N. Y., has been sold by Allan Good to the Achva Realty Corporation, of which Fred Hardy is president. A purchasemoney first mortgage of $6,@00 was taken back by the seller.

The United Palestine Appeal and the Committee of Contributors and Workers settled their differences yesterday, assuring united fundraising in this country in 1949 in behalf of Jewish needs throughout the world.

The oversubscription to the American Telephone and Telegraph Company's $150,000,000 3 3/8 per cent twenty-five-year debenture issue yesterday emphasized, to the entire satisfaction of underwriting circles, and particularly the group headed by the First Boston Corporation and Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., that sold the issue, just how receptive the investor can be if attracted with a higher interest rate.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- The Waukesha Motor Company, Waukesha, Wis., filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement covering a proposed offering of 200,000 shares of its $5 par value common stock to its stockholders.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Dec. 8 -- The United States Government is re-examining with great care the possibility of permitting Yugoslavia to obtain export licenses for American goods of a non-strategic character as a measure of relief from the economic pressure exerted upon her by the states of the Soviet bloc.

PARIS, Dec. 8 -- The Social, Humanitarian and Cultural Committee of the United Nations General Assembly decided today to adjourn until the April session at Flushing Meadow instead of continuing work on the remaining five items on the agenda until the close of the Paris session on Saturday.

LONDON, Dec. 8 -- More testimony was offered today by Sir Hartley Shawcross, Attorney General, against the character of Marcus Wulkan, naturalized United States citizen, who is a brother of Sidney Stanley, central figure in the investigation concerning allegations of fraud at the British Board of Trade.

New York City will insist on $240,000,000 of the $300,000,000 increase proposed in State Housing loan funds, Herbert Bayevsky announced last night in a forum discussion of the housing shortage, broadcast over Station WQXR. Mr. Bayevsky is legal adviser to Joseph Sharkey, majority leader of the City Council, and spoke in Mr. Sharkey's behalf.

Four of five persons accused as members of a ring that had mulcted insurance companies of $200,000 by filing fraudulent automobile accident claims received prison sentences in General Sessions yesterday. The four had pleaded guilty to grand larceny last week.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- The first 100 CARE packages resulting from the plea made by Gen. Lucius D. Clay in behalf of German children will be distributed immediately in Berlin, the CARE organization announced here today.

HELSINKI, Finland, Dec. 8 (AP) Jean Sibelus celebrated his eighty-third birthday today at his isolated country home with members of his family. The musical genius and his wife, Aino, live the Villa Ainola at Jarvenpaa, twenty-five miles north of Helsinki.

Miss Louise E. Thompson, who has just completed a twenty-state survey of American musical tastes, said yesterday that while residents of Missouri liked "Turkey in the Straw," in California they were still dewy-eyed over "The Rosary."
The Contest Board of the American Automobile Association voted last night to set up a Hall of Fame for racing drivers.

The nation looks to the next Congress to make "decided progress" in putting new, forwardlooking legislation, particularly in the fields of labor, social security, health and housing, on the statute books, William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor declared last night.

BUCK HILL FALLS, Pa., Dec. 8 -- A Communist-dominated China offers little hope for the maintenance of even a limited form of religious freedom in that country, the Rev. Dr. Ralph E. Diffendorfer of New York declared here today at the annual meeting of the Board of Missions and Church Extension of the Methodist Church.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 (UP) - President Truman will move to postpone for at least sixty days a threatened strike on the Southern Pacific Railroad if the dispute is not settled before the Dec. 15 deadline for a walkout.

Dr. Russell A. Dixon, dean the Howard University College of Dentistry, Washington, was installed last night as president of the Pan-American Odontological Association. He was elected a year ago by unanimous vote, the first Negro to be chosen for that position in the fourteen-year history of the organization.

NANKING, Dec. 8 -- A highplaced Chinese source said today that Nanking's appeals for more American aid were being fashioned with the "full realization" that the United States did not wish to become involved in a direct conflict here either with the Chinese Communists or with the Soviet Union.
PARIS, Dec. 8 (AP) -- The text of the United States - Chinese - Australian resolution on Korea which was approved today by the United Nations Political Committee follows:
WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 (AP) Overpayments totaling $52,000,000 made to about 600,000 veterans are being whittled down through repayments, the Veterans Administration said today.

ATHENS, Dec. 8 -- United States Ambassador Henry F. Grady and Mrs. Grady left Athens by air today for a brief visit to Washington. Mr. Grady, who is expected to confer during a stop-over in Paris with Greek Foreign Minister Constantin Tsaldaris, took with him a note drafted yesterday by the Cabinet's Coordinating Council on military requirements.
Mayor O'Dwyer has two champion typists in his official cabinet, but neither is receiving a pay check from the municipal treasury at this time for clerical work.

ALBANY, Dec. 8 -- Governor Dewey announced today that he would confer here on Dec. 20 with representatives of state business groups on some of the practical phases of a proposed sickness disability insurance program.

As the site for a new showroom building and service station, a vacant plot 100 by 100 feet at the southeast corner of Bruckner Boulevard and Close Avenue, the Bronx, has been leased by Ray Sacci and Michael De Goreo to Joseph Joton, Austin dealer.

KINGS POINT, L.I., Dec. 8 -Leading all the way, the Manhattan College basketball team notched its third victory in a row tonight by routing the United States Merchant Marine Academy, 74 to 45. The Jaspers showed theh)0*0*0*iway by 41 -- 23 at intermission.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 8 (AP) -- Mrs. Moody Jolley's Mr. Jay, making his first start since July 17 at Arlington Park, Chicago, displayed high speed today in winning the Peregrine Handicap before 6,491 fans at Tropical Park, where $318,893 was wagered on the eight races.

William F. McCarthy, 36-year old former national director for organization of the National Maritime Union, and Albie Salz, 31, section organizer of the waterfront section of the Communist party, were convicted in Special Sessions yesterday of third-degree assault.
TEL AVIV, Israel, Dec. 8 -- The Egyptians suffered more than 100 men killed or wounded last nighth in an attempted attack in the southern Negeb desert area, Israeli Army headquarters announced today.
BOSTON, Dec. 8 (UP) -- The American Academy of Arts and Sciences awarded tonight $21,000 prize money to six scientists for research in disorders of the human reproductive organs.

A small red-haired girl, who had spent most of her 11 years fleeing from the Nazis, handed former Gov. Herbert H. Lehman a silver plaque last night, honoring him as a statesman, humanitarian and philanthropist.

NEW DELHI, Dec. 8 --- Police in several cities arrested leaders of Rashtriya Swayam Sewak Sangh, militant Hindu organization, today after plans for nation-wide demonstrations by the society on Dec. 13 were uncovered. R. S. S. S. was one of the communal groups banned after the assassination of Mohandas K. Gandhi.

CHICAGO, Dec. 8 -- Michael J. Quill, whose wage drives have kept the New York City transit system in a turmoil for years, announced tonight that the 1949 goal of his Transport Workers Union, CIO, would be a flat wage of $2 an hour and a forty-hour week.

Contacts by military procurement authorities with pharmaceutical and surgical concerns have been increased in preparation for a possible emergency, Lieut. Col. Harry J. Nelson, USA, chief of the Industrial Mobilization and Procurement Planning Division of the Army-Navy Procurement Office, declared yesterday.

The American Handicrafts Company, Inc., 12 East Forty-first Street, will hold "open house" in its studio next week, it was announced yesterday as items that may be made by amateurs in a two-hour class or in an eight-week course were displayed.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Dec. 8 -Prizes for the year's best work in music, arts, the theatre, literature, education and the humanities are among the new projects in a program for next year released tonight by the United National Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 (AP) -- The Barker Dome field in San Juan County, New Mexico, has a gas reserve of 1,776,000,000,000 cubic feet; sufficient to produce 127,000,000 cubic feet of marketable gas daily for more than twenty years, Fazen Dixon, consulting geologist for the El Paso Natural Gas Company, told the Federal Power Commission today at a hearing.
NANKING, Dec. 8 (UP) -- Chinese Nationalist reinforcements, armed with new United States supplies, were rushed to the Suchow front today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- A committee of more than seventy trade association representatives, appointed recently by Secretary of Commerce Charles Sawyer, called on industry today for a winter "housecleaning" of obsolete equipment which can be converted into vitally needed scrap iron.

The slogan "a chicken in every pot" became a reality to a hundred or so West Side families yesterday when a truck, bearing 500 of the fowl to market, became involved in an accident and spilled 200 into the street.

A $10,000 check to establish fifty Christopher Columbus scholarship prizes of $200 each was presented to the Board of Education yesterday by Generoso Pope, president of the Columbus Citizens Committee, Inc.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- The foreign worker program for farmsh)0*0*0*iis declining and will continue to decline, Robert C. Goodwin, director of the Bureau of Employment Security, told the Special Farm Labor Committee today.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 8 -plans for production of seven thirty-minute motion pictures on the life of St. Paul have been announced by the Rev. James K Friedrich, an Episcopalian clergyman and president of Cathedral Films.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- The entire membership of the Interstate h) 0*0*0* iCommerce Commission today began to listen to argument on a motion of the railroads of the country for an 8 per cent emergency increase, after a seven-day hearing conducted by four members.

Moving quickly yesterday to avert the threatened resignation of twenty-eight of Bellevue Hospital's sorely needed nurses. Dr. Edward M. Bernecker, Commissioner of Hospitals, promised immediate action to relieve overcrowding in the tuberculosis wards.

Paul E. Fitzpatrick, Democratic State Chairman, called yesterday for continuation of Federal rent controls and announced that the Democrats in the Legislature would press for extension of state rent control.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Dec. 8 -- Dr. Robert C. Clothier, president of Rutgers University, called today for a higher salary scale for faculty members and a more adequate physical plant.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 (AP) -Three major steel companies indicated today that if Congress would let them they would go back to their former policy of figuring equalized freight rates into their prices.
The separatist guerrilla army of the Ukraine is strong despite its need of help from the Western powers against Russia, Mrs. Daria Rebet, worker for the Ukrainian underground, said here yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 (AP) -- A 1948 cotton crop of 14,937,000 bales, 3,080,000 more than in 1947, was estimated today by the Department of Agriculture.
SEOUL, Korea, Dec. 8 -- An immediate application for membership in the United Nations by the three-months-old Korean Republic was expected here tonight.

A slight easing of portable electric tool prices has appeared in some items in retail hardware stores, a canvass of New York retailers revealed yesterday. Typical reductions included a $13.50 cut from $88.50 to $75 for 8-inch tilt arbor saws equipped with 1/3 horsepower capacitor motors and a reduction from $34.50 to $29.95 for an electric hedge trimmer.

BERLIN, Dec. 9 -- The Communist Government of Soviet Berlin increased the isolation of the three Western sectors tonight by issuing orders that all vehicles carrying goods from the Eastern sector into the Western areas must receive special permits and pass through one of four check-points.

Zdenek Smetacek, former Czechoslovak press officer here, "probably would have been recalled" to Prague if he had failed to obey Dr. Ervin Munk, counselor of the embassy, and denounce Dr. Jan Papanek, anti-Communist Czech, to the American press, Dr. Munk admitted here yesterday.

Always striving to furnish the best type of entertainment at bargain prices, the City Center has a treat in store for theatregoers. "Carousel," the Richard Rodgers-Oscar Hammerstein 2d musical which the Theatre Guild presented here from April 19, 1945, to May 24, 1947, is to pay us a repeat visit of four weeks at the City Center, starling Jan. 25.

Marcus Wulkan, whose character was impugned in testimony this week before a British inquiry into charges of fraud in the British Board of Trade, denied all allegations yesterday and offered in refutation letters of praise from prominent Americans.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Dec. 9 -- The mass arrests of Albanian Communist leaders friendly to Premier Marshal Tito of Yugoslavia by the Albanian Government of Enver Hoxha, which supports the Communist Information Bureau, was reported tonight by Tanjug, the Yugoslav news agency.

MINNEAPOLIS, Dec. 9 -- Baseball's first official steps toward combating ever-increasing television activities, along with wiping out much of radio's already vast expansion, were taken today when the minor leagues, sitting in convention, passed amendments to the major-minor agreement that would force drastic curtailment in telecasting and broadcasting of major league games.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- The shipping controversy in which Paul G. Hoffman finds himself as director of the Economic Cooperation Administration (the Marshall Plan) marks another instance in which two settled courses of government action run headlong against each other.

The Vinaver Chorus, under Chemjo Vinaver, opened its second annual series of three concerts, last night at Town Hall, under the sponsorship of the Friends of Choral Art, Inc. Mr. Vinaver, a leading authority on Hebraic music had arranged an elaborate program, interesting in itself and admirably sung by the ensemble of mixed voices.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- The Department of Justice charged tonight that "premature and ill-advised" disclosures were being made by the House Committee on Un-American Activities in the Hiss-Chambers espionage case, and that these were hurting its chances for prosecution of spies against the United States Government.

PARIS, Dec. 9 -- The United States, British and Canadian delegations decided today to eliminate all controversial provisions from the pending resolution on Palestine in the hope of getting the required two-thirds majority in the United Nations General Assembly.

Nations which shut themselves off from the world flow of knowledge hurt themselves more than they hurt anybody else. This was the substance of some observations made by Supreme Court Justice Robert H. Jackson in his address to the New York County Lawyers Association.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- Secretary of the Treasury John W. Snyder is expected to make an early ruling on whether bituminous coal operators may deduct, for income tax purposes, pensions to coal miners which probably will aggregate $40,000,000 during the current year.
Yesterday in a small room on the second floor of the Plaza Hotel an inspiring exhibit of designs and fabrics brought from Greece by Muriel King was presented to an invited audience.

Radio manufacturers' volume this year will equal or exceed the record $700,000,000 in 1947 despite a production cutback of 4,000,000 radio receiver units, a spokesman for the Radio Manufacturers Association predicted yesterday. Following concluding sessions of the group's meeting in the Roosevelt Hotel, he said that the increase in television receiver volume resulting from greater unit production will "offset or more than offset" losses suffered in radio volume.

Stockholders of Schenley Distillers Corporation at the annual meeting held yesterday in Wilmington, Del., voted to change its name to Schenley Industries, Inc. more adequately to describe its diversified business.

MADISON, Wis., Dec. 9 -- The annual meritorious awards of the National Rehabilitation Association for outstanding service in the field of rehabilitation were awarded here tonight to Dr. Howard A. Rusk of New York and H. B. Cummings of Atlanta.
CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 9 (AP) -- Bootalong, making his winter racing debut, carried P. Stavros' silks to victory in the Montgaris Purse at Tropical Park today.

Dolls for young and old, bringing to the theatregoer of the early Nineteen Hundreds echoes of the time when stage stars were "toasts of the town," were shown yesterday in a special preview of an exhibition at the Museum of the City of New York, Fifth Avenue and 103d Street.

Dyers and printers of rayon piece goods are working from three to four days a week, according to trade sources. With activity still very light, gray goods in storage have not diminished to any appreciable extent, dyers reported yesterday.

The Navy has invented a device that will bring about the rescue of the crew of a sunken submarine "from any depth to which the vessel may go without being crushed," Rear Admiral Charles B. Momsen declared here last night.

MONTREAL, Dec. 9 (AP) -- Looting by organized British hijackers preying on export shipments has resulted in reimbursement claims exceeding $1,000.000 against three Canadian transport systems, a Canada Steamship Lines representative asserted last night.

Bayonne, N. J., has awarded $1,500,000 emergency housing bonds to a banking group headed by Stroud Co., Inc., and the group is reoffering the bonds at prices to yield from 1.20 per cent for those maturing Jan. 1, 1950, to 2.50 per cent for those maturing Jan. 1, 1972, it was announced yesterday. The group's bid for the bonds was 100.11 for 2 1/2s.
The dentist drill, anathema to millions all over the world, may disappear as a form of human torture within the next hundred years as a result of new drugs and scientific professional techniques.

In the most active trading since the war, cottonseed oil futures on the New York Produce Exchange declined 85 to 135 points yesterday. Sales aggregated 595 lots. Selling was of a general character and little rallying power was in evidence. The market closed weak.

An experiment in diabetes detection which, if successful, will be repeated on a national scale for the greater part of the American population is under way on Staten Island, Nicholas Geosalde, executive secretary of the New York State Pharmaceutical Association, reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 (AP) -- A House Labor subcommittee said today that the methods of the AFL Teamsters Union Local 202 in New York were "little less than piracy and a challenge to the Department of Justice."

Joe Louis will be occupied with an exhibition against Billy Conn in Chicago tonight, but, it is a pretty safe bet the world heavyweight champion will be trying to visualize what is happening in Madison Square Garden. For, in the Eighth Avenue arena, Joe Baksi, Kulpmont, Pa, heavyweight, and Ezzard Charles, overgrown Cincinnati light-heavyweight, will be waging a battle which may determine whether Louis abandons retirement plans.
