WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- A representative of the steel industry and an attorney of the Federal Trade Commission clashed verbally today on the question of pricing policies for American business. Both men spoke at the Economic Institute of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States.

VIENNA, Dec. 9 -- The death sentence imposed in Budapest today day on Dr. Simon Papp was interpreted here by persons intimately associated with the matter as intended to justify confiscation of the properties at the moment when they were expected to increase sharply in value.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 9 -- With Omar Hoskins, a Federal conciliation commissioner, sitting in on the meeting, Harry Lundeberg, secretary of the Sailors' Union of the Pacific, AFL, today formally presented his wage demands to the negotiating committee of the Pacific American Shipowners' Association, headed by J.B. Bryan as president.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- The United States formally abandoned before the Far Eastern Commission today the policy proposal it had originally presented for deconcentration of Japanese industry and finance on the ground that it had already been substantially achieved by Gen. Douglas MacArthur.

IN the ancient city of Frankfort, where Holy Roman Emperors were crowned, there were two eminent Jewish banking families. The Rothschilds built a financial and social empire. The Bonns, whose bank was so much smaller, did nothing so conspicuous. But they lived in Frankfort for more than 400 years and in 1873 a Bonn was born who was destined to represent much that was best in German culture.
On Dec. 4 you printed a letter from Samuel Grabel concerning liability for damage to motor vehicles owned by the Division of State Police.

PARIS, Friday, Dec. 10 -- Russia made an eleventh-hour attempt in a meeting lasting until early today to scuttle acceptance by this session of the General Assembly of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights.

President Truman should appoint Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt as Secretary of State in the event that Secretary George C. Marshall resigns, the executive committee of the Committee on Women in World Affairs decided unanimously yesterday at a meeting in the home of Mrs. William H. Davis, national chairman, at 300 Park Avenue.

BELHAVEN, N.C., Dec. 9 -- Deer and bear are hunted with hounds in this country, and after one day of sloshing through the marshes we are convinced that dogs, deer and hunters should be web-footed to move through these thick, swampy covers with anything approaching ease.

A collection of mirrored-top coffee tables, mirrored cabinets and other occasional furniture, and mirrors to hang on the wall was introduced yesterday by I. Schwartz Glass and Mirror Company at its showroom at 412 East Fifty-ninth Street.

More than seventy coal preparation plants now being built or rebuilt comprise the first stage of a $500,000,000 plant modernization program undertaken by coal industry members, officials of the National Coal Association revealed here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- Henry Julian Wadleigh, a tall, gaunt 44-year-old former State Department economist, refused to tell the House Committee on Un-American Activities today whether he had delivered secret Government documents to anyone for forwarding to Soviet agents.

A bright picture for the paint and allied products industry on a national basis was painted last night by Joseph F. Battley, president, National Paint, Varnish and Lacquer Association. He spoke at a meeting of the New York Paint, Varnish and Lacquer Association in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 (AP) -- The total vote for President on Nov. 2, with all figures official except Connecticut's, was 48,680,009, second highest on record.

The dynamic qualities of Latin-American politics are well illustrated in the person of Dr. Carlos Prio Socarras, this country's distinguished guest of the moment, who is to be welcomed in New York City tomorrow. Fifteen years ago Dr. Prio was in the streets with the students and fellow teachers of Dr. Ramon Grau San Martin as a leader of the revolution that finally put Dr. Grau in the Presidency.

LONDON, Dec. 9 -- Foreign Secretary Bevin in a foreign affairs debate today could not forbear getting his little dig in at the United States for having been such a champion of free enterprise at home and such a stickler for planning abroad.

Operations of the B.V.D. Corporation in the fiscal year ended on Aug. 31, last, resulted in a net income of $3,035,715 after all charges including $3,071,083 for taxes and $500,000 provision for contingencies, the annual report disclosed yesterday.

DETROIT, Dec. 9 -- American business was told tonight by Charles Sawyer, Secretary of Commerce, to face without fear a continued Truman Administration which he said was well aware of the interests of all in dealing with inflationary problems and avoiding "a disastrous depression."

VIENNA, Dec. 9 -- The Austrian Government has decided to grant to Oscar Kohorn Co., Ltd., of New York a contract to build a rayon plant with European Recovery Program funds. The proposal has been sent to the restitution, delivery and reparation section of the United States Forces in Austria for its approval.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 (AP) -- Frank B. Noyes, chairman of the board of the Evening Star Newspaper Company, left a gross estate of about $493,000, the petition for probate of his will showed today. Mr. Noyes, one of the founders of The Associated Press, died Dec. 1. He was 85 years old.

Directors of the New England Service System reduced the dividend yesterday on the common stock with the declaration of 20 cents a share payable Jan. 3. Shareholders had been receiving 25 cents quarterly.

High Government officials, including the late Harry Hopkins, considered the State Department code "very vulnerable" as far back as 1941, Robert E. Sherwood, author and Pulitzer Prize dramatist, said yesterday.

"The Decision of Christopher Blake," which arrives at the Strand, is this morning's lone film newcomer. The Warner Brothers' adaptation of the Moss Hart play, was produced and written for the screen by Ranald MacDougall with Alexis Smith and Ted Donaldson, the child actor, heading the cast.

The biggest upset of this young college basketball campaign was fashioned by a smartly drilled Southern Methodist quintet last night at Madison Square Garden. Against Nat Holman's C.C.N.Y. speedsters, prohibitive 11 1/2-point favorites, the spirited Mustangs from Dallas, Tex., recorded a 62-56 victory that thrilled 16,187 fans.

In a resale for cash of a Yorkville property acquired last summer the two four-story apartment houses with stores at 1634-35 York Avenue, northeast corner of Eighty-sixth Street, have been disposed of by Mrs. Sarah Stolitzky in a transaction reported yesterday by Byrne, Bowman Forshay, Inc., brokers in both deals.

Nat Holman, City College basketball coach, revealed last night that he had received an invitation from the State of Israel to visit that country next spring to organize a basketball squad that would tour the United States, perhaps as soon as 1950 or 1951.

LONDON, Dec. 9 -- Diplomatic moves have been made in Baghdad for the reopening of the oil pipeline from Iraq to Haifa, although not for oil to be refined in Israeli territory but to be shipped out for refining elsewhere.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9--The Announced plan of the Economic Cooperation Administration to save freight on cargoes of assistance goods by sending more of these on foreign ships threatened today to reopen Congressional debate over the whole question of support for United States shipping.

This year's ten biggest newspaper stories, to date, in every part of the world, included the election of President Truman and the Berlin airlift. So much The United Press has ascertained, in its annual survey of what news editors played up -- and presumably what newspaper readers were interested in.

The question of the policy of college Greek letter fraternities in regard to Negro membership has received much attention during recent weeks. Of course, no final decision has been reached or could be reached on a matter which is fraught with so many possible interpretations and accompanied by so much personal feeling.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 9--The Railway Labor Executives Association, spokesmen for more than 1,000,000 railroad employes, decided today to go ahead "full speed" to seek amendments to the Railway Labor Act.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 9 -- The two top executives of the Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer film studio testified in Federal Court today that underlying the anti-Communist employment policy in which the studio joined the other major producers a year ago was the fear of possible Federal censorship and a box-office decline of as much as 50 per cent, and a feeling that public opinion should be "appeased."

PARIS, Dec. 9 -- Lester B. Pearson, Canadian Minister of External Affairs, said today that the Paris session of the United Nations General Assembly presented "a depressing and discouraging picture" but that it "has at least served to consolidate the forces of world opinion against reactionary communism."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- Modification of the Federal Reserve Board's policy of maintaining the value of Government bonds above par by open market purchases was urged today in a report by the Committee for Economic Development. It condemned the practice as inflationary and making for multiple expansion of bank credit.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- Loadings of revenue freight in the week ended on Dec. 4, 1948, totaled 804,183 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 81,093 cars or 11.2 per cent more than for the preceding week, 74,405 cars, or 8.5 per cent fewer than for the corresponding week of last year, and 75,099 cars, or 10.3 per cent more than during the corresponding week two years ago.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- The Economic Cooperation Administration flatly rejected today a French Government proposal anticipating the availability of more than $1,000,000,000 of franc counterpart funds desired to avoid new taxation and a possible political crisis.

MIAMI BEACH, Dec. 9 -- Two contract bridge championships were decided here this afternoon in the twenty-second national championship tournament -- the men's and the women's teams-of-four. Another contest ended last night.

PARIS, Dec. 9 -- Premier Henri Queuille told the Finance Committee of the National Assembly today that France's investments for industrial expansion in the recovery program would be covered by the counterpart fund under the Marshall Plan, which the United States is expected to release for this purpose.
A contribution in memory of a Navy man killed while flying on anti-submarine patrol was received yesterday by THE NEW YORK TIMES Neediest Cases Fund.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- A House Education and Labor subcommittee recommended today a "thorough investigation" of "indications of Communist activity" in a New York City teachers' union and its parent organization, the United Public Workers of America.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- President Truman again branded the current spy investigation as a red-herring issue and asserted today that the House Committee on Un-American Activities was a dead agency.

Two dozen of the country's most prominent artists, illustrators and sculptors put aside their brushes and artist tools yesterday and acted as "salesmen" at the twenty-fifth annual Christmas sale of articles made by the handicapped.

Plans for what is described as one of the largest newspaper campaigns promoting a bathroom tissue were announced yesterday by the National Paper Corporation of Ransom, Pa. The drive will coincide with introduction of Swanee two-ply bathroom tissue, napkins and towels, and will have an initial budget of more than $250,000.
The four-day-old strike of New York bartenders remained deadlocked yesterday with both sides reporting little change in the situation and no plans to bring it to an early end.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- Oil industry profits which some persons regard as excessive were the means of overcoming the country's oil shortage, an expert told a Joint Congressional Economic Committee today.
The city has applied sharp rental increases to the piers that it admits cannot be utilized fully because of waterfront crime, it became known last night.

LONDON, Dec. 9--Soviet actions in Berlin have "seriously prejudiced" the prospects of a satisfactory settlement of the Berlin dispute, Foreign Secretary Bevin told the House of Commons today. He spoke at the opening of a two-day debate on foreign affairs, the first since Sept. 27.

In the biggest deal in the history of the club, the New York Rangers yesterday acquired the services of Allan Stanley, husky defenseman, from the Providence Reds of the American Hockey League. Frank Boucher, manager of the local entry in the National League, made the announcement at the luncheon of the New York Hockey Writers Association at Leone's.

VIENNA, Dec. 9 -- A serious problem threatens to arise in Austria -- and doubtless in other Marshall Plan countries that overvalue their currencies -- in connection with the allocation of Marshall Plan funds.

In a two-pronged attack to ease traffic congestion in mid-Manhattan and to help the twenty United States and foreign airlines serving this city out of an untenable situation, the Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority has agreed to build a new airline terminal on the short block west of First Avenue between Thirty-seventh and Thirty-eighth Streets, it was learned yesterday.

All familiar with the lifelong service in this city rendered by Dr. Edward M. Bernecker, New York's Commissioner of Hospitals, will regret, as you do, his prospective retirement at the end of the year. Allow me, however, to bring to your attention the need of a slight correction in your editorial of Dec. 6 on "The City Hospitals Report."

Another one cent increase in fares, to seven cents, will be charged on three Manhattan bus lines -- the Madison Avenue Coach Company, New York City Omnibus Corporation and the Eighth Avenue Coach Corporation -- by Public Service Commission approval, the commission announced yesterday.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange turned downward yesterday, with final prices 13 to 30 points net lower.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, Dec. 9 -- Dr. Simon Papp, Hungarian citizen and formerly chief geologist! and general manager of the Hungarian-American Oil Company, was sentenced to death here today after a trial of two weeks. He was found guilty of attempting to overthrow state authority by sabotage.

Word has reached New York, N.Y., that a new New York has been dedicated in Sicily, near the capital city, Palermo. Though New York, N.Y., has a population pushing eight million and New York, Sic., is more exclusively limited to a few hundred at the moment, there is something more New Yorkerish about the town washed by the Mediterranean and warmed over by the Libyan sirocco.

MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 9 (AP) -- One of the nation's leading amateurs and a comparatively unknown professional led the field in the opening round of the twenty-fifth annual $10,000 Miami open golf tournament today.
EATONTON, Ga., Dec. 9 -- Georgians gathered here today to celebrate the 100th anniversary of the birth here of the state's beloved Joel Chandler Harris, creator of "Uncle Remus."

NANKING, Dec. 9 -- With the Sixteenth Army Group already heavily battered by the Communists, the two other Nationalist groups trapped southwest of Suchow were reported to be attacking tonight in an attempt to break through the Communist encirclement.
PARIS, Dec. 9 -- The proceedings of the United Nations:

Charges of violation of the Sullivan law that had been brought against five young men caught in the act of loading two crates of arms and ammunition into a truck in the night of Nov. 24 were dismissed yesterday by Magistrate Vernon C. Riddick in the Youth Part of Felony Court.

It simply does not meet the test of common sense to expect the operators of taxicabs in New York City to get along today on the same fare that they charged fifteen years ago. If the rate was fair then it is not fair now. The cost of everything that goes into the ride has gone up. This starts with the price of the car, which has doubled.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Dec. 9 (AP) -- Asserting their supremacy in the final minutes of play, the New York Knickerbockers notched their third straight triumph over the Providence Steamrollers, 74 -- 63, before 2,579 Basketball Association of America fans tonight.

Forty-one nations voted aye and only the six votes of the Soviet bloc were cast on Wednesday in the Political Committee of the United Nations against acceptance of a United States-Australia-China resolution recognizing the Korean Government at Seoul as the only legal government of that country and establishing a permanent Commission on Korea to work for unification of the country and to observe and to report on conditions there.

HOLLYWOOD, Fla., Dec. 9 -- There is no lack of savings to satisfy industry's demand for debt capital, but the flow of equity capital from external sources is likely to lag behind demands unless Congress adopts certain remedial legislation or unless banking can tap investment money now out of its reach, Dr. Marcus Nadler, Professor of Finance at New York University, said here today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- The Department of Commerce expressed doubt today that the railroads were prepared to support at this time a freight-car building program of the size demanded by J.M. Johnson, director of the Office of Defense Transportation.

CHICAGO, Dec. 9 -- The needy people of the nation are being discriminated against in several states which are heading in the direction of pension plans and away from an assistance program based on need, Howard L. Russell, director of the American Public Welfare Association, charged today.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 9 -- The first signs of a revival of production activity at Eagle-Lion, which shut down for financial reasons early in November, appeared today with the announcement that Bryan Foy will put his picture, "Secret Service, U.S.A.," formerly titled "Trapped," before the cameras late in January.

Norman dello Joio's "Variations, Chaconne and Finale" were played for the first time at a Philharmonic-Symphony concert under Bruno Walter's baton last night in Carnegie Hall. Two main facts consequent upon this ceremony may be cited quickly: 1. The composition is the best work that we have heard of Mr. dello Joio's; in it his writing is freer, much more lucid, more released in the flow of the ideas and genuinely creative.

Completion of the merger of American Overseas Airlines with Pan American Airways, it was learned authoritatively yesterday, awaits only the arrangement of details and Government approval. Both boards of directors have approved the move though on slightly differing terms.

Gay cottons for winter as well as summer wear provided the theme for the showing Gimbels presented yesterday in their new Tommie Austin Shop, which will be opened officially on Monday. Giving a wintery touch to the pretty chambrays and other fabrics were trims of jet, taffeta and velvet.

An "affirmative recommendation" on the procedure to be followed in promoting the sales of men's wear will be made by the promotion sub-committee of the industry in its report to be submitted later this month, it was disclosed yesterday by M.J. Lovell, director and counsel of the National Association of Shirt and Pajama Manufacturers.

ALBANY, Dec. 9 -- Governor Dewey was petitioned today by the Joint Rent Action Committee, a tenant organization, to recommend to the Legislature renewal for another year of the commercial and business rent control laws without change in the present ceilings.

More public and private housing construction was started or completed on New York's Lower East Side in 1948 than in any other section in the city, R. H. Brownell, president of the Union Square Savings Bank, declared yesterday.

ST. LOUIS, Dec. 9 -- Restoration of higher farm price supports and a stockpiling program to help soak up surpluses of grains and other storable commodities were recommended today by the national conference of the Production and Marketing Administration at the close of a four-day session.

Business loans by banks in this area dropped $63,000,000 during the week ended on last Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York disclosed yesterday. Repayments of borrowings by oil companies and public utilities were the principal factors in the latest reduction, the fourth in succession, in the commercial, industrial and agricultural loans item of the reporting New York City member banks.

Competitive bidding is not in the best interest of the investor, Leroy A. Lincoln, president of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, told 500 members of the Life Insurance Association of America attending the forty-second annual meeting of the association at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel yesterday.

Mayor O'Dwyer left City Hall at 2:10 P.M. yesterday for an automobile trip to Washington, where he will attend a meeting of the United States Conference of Mayors and discuss the city's housing problems with President Truman. The Mayor was accompanied by David R. Martin, a personal friend.

president, was named vice chairman of the board. He will continue to serve as chairman of the executive committee, other members of which, in addition to Messrs. McCann and Harper, are John L. Anderson, vice president and treasurer, and L. S. Briggs, vice president and manager of Eastern operations.

The job security and economic independence of the American working man over 45 years old came under close scrutiny yesterday at a public hearing of the New York State Joint Legislative Committee on Problems of the Aging at the State Office Building, 80 Centre Street.

While asserting that Europe's 1,300,000 Jews would achieve economic security within three years, barring unforeseen circumstances, Edward M. M. Warburg, chairman of the Joint Distribution Committee, described yesterday deplorable conditions among 1,000,000 Jews in North Africa and other Moslem areas.

College football, continuing to ride the post-war sports boom, enjoyed an increase in attendance this season of almost 6 per cent over 1947, a United Press survey of ninety-nine major schools disclosed yesterday.

PATERSON, N. J., Dec. 9 -- With Christmas rapidly drawing closer, Mr. and Mrs. Walter B. Bell of 516 East Twenty-fourth Street, this city, were completing today a toy project destined to gladden the hearts of hundreds of orphans and underprivileged children.

Tax selling to establish losses before the year-end became more insistent yesterday on the stock market and altered the irregular course pursued previously this week. Activity on the Stock Exchange again centered in the low-price shares although the heavy turnover in Barnsdall helped send business to 1,220,000 shares against 1,140,000 shares on Wednesday.

Arthur Lourie, Consul General of Israel in New York, yesterday labeled as "unfounded" British charges in the United Nations General Assembly in Paris that the Israeli Army had violated Trans-Jordan territory.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- Senate investigators closed late today their inquiry into the Ilse Koch case and simultaneously decided to hold no open hearings into the Army's clemency to the infamous "woman of Buchenwald."

A variety of contrasts is offered by three new exhibitions in local galleries this week. These include a group of paintings by nineteenth-century American masters and contemporaries, and two one-man shows.

SHANGHAI, Friday, Dec. 10 -- Vice Admiral Oscar C. Badger, commander of United States naval forces in the western Pacific, indicated today that a floating reserve of marines would shortly arrive in Shanghai to familiarize themselves with the city and to be used ashore, if necessary, to protect American citizens and possibly the power plant and fuel tanks.

CHICAGO, Dec. 9 -- A civil complaint against the Chicago Mortgage Bankers Association and thirty-five of its member mortgage banks was filed today in Federal district court by the Anti-Trust Division of the Department of Justice.
C. Mott Shavers has resigned as Tammany leader of the Fourteenth Assembly District and Assemblyman Hulan E. Jack is scheduled to succeed him, it was said yesterday at Tammany headquarters.

The executive business advisory committee of the city's Department of Commerce recommended yesterday that Mayor O'Dwyer name a special committee to consider establishment of a nationwide promotional program to publicize the city's attractions to business, industry and tourists.

BUCK HILL FALLS, Pa., Dec. 9 -- Fewer than thirty Methodist missionaries out of a total of more than 300 now stationed in China are being evacuated to the United States, the Rev. Dr. Frank T. Cartwright of New York said here today at the annual meeting of the Board of Missions and Church Extension of the Methodist Church.

The resignation of Miss Helen Kenyon as moderator of the Congregational Christian Church, because of a partisan attitude favoring merger with the Evangelical and Reformed Church, was suggested in an open letter made public yesterday by the Rev. Malcolm K. Burton of New London, Conn.

NEARLY every one of us works like a horse and has trouble in making both ends meet. Citation works like a horse and he's got $833,350. There must be some sort of a moral in that but whatever it is, it escapes us at the moment. The Calumet Comet will work like a horse again tomorrow and probably will march off with the major portion of the $50,000 loot in the Tanforan Handicap.

Plans for enlisting state financial aid for the child day - care program in this city as well as in other New York communities were made yesterday at a meeting attended by executives of fourteen welfare groups at the New Weston Hotel, East Fiftieth Street and Madison Avenue.

HONOLULU, Dec. 9 -- News that a B-36 bomber flew undetected over the Hawaiian Islands and dropped a "useful bomb load" offshore on the seventh anniversary of the Pearl Harbor bombing was being viewed with considerable concern here tonight, although the military has not yet issued an official statement on whether the flight was considered a test of Hawaii's undermanned defenses.

A proposed constitution for the state of Israel that draws its inspiration from the Bible and ancient Jewish law and combines salient features of the United States, British and French systems of government was made known here last night. It will serve as a basis for deliberations by the Constitutional Assembly to be held in Israel after the elections on Jan. 25, 1949.
SAN BRUNO, Calif., Dec. 9 (AP) -- Citation, the Calumet wonder colt, will be opposed by six Western handicap performers in Saturday's $50,000 added Tanforan Handicap.

Like most other deliberative bodies, the General Assembly of the United Nations has run into a log jam in its closing hours. This situation has been further aggravated by the setting of a definite date for adjournment. As a result, many things that should and could have been done with wiser management will remain undone, and some things that are done will not be done as well as they might have been.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- Death rays glitter at will on the heavily traveled Merritt Parkway in Connecticut, according to a report presented today at the annual meeting of the Highway Research Board here.

College graduates of liberal art schools should be prepared with at least one wage-earning skill, speakers at a panel discussion session sponsored by the Welfare Council of New York City said yesterday.

Ski enthusiasts, who even envision snow-clad mountains and slopes throughout the summer months, then can't wait to don hickory wings at the slightest drop of the temperature, will have to be a bit more patient before running trails.

HOLLYWOOD, Fla., Dec. 9 -- A panel of nine financial writers told investment bankers in convention here today that distributors of stocks and bonds should adopt business practices and a simplified trade jargon if they are ever going to get over to the public the part which investment banking plays in a private enterprise economy.

The New York affiliates of Confederate societies are preparing an exhibition of historic memorabilia of the Confederacy to open at the New York Historical Society, Central Park West and Seventy-seventh Street, on Jan. 19, it was made known yesterday.

NEWARK, N. J., Dec. 9 -- Delivery of freight from Essex and Union Counties to the principal cities on the Atlantic Seaboard north of Richmond, Va., will be affected by a strike of 225 drivers, helpers and platform men employed by five long-haul trucking companies, it was said here today.

The seasonal slump in wholesale meat sales this year has begun earlier than it usually does. Housewives will find the United States Department of Agriculture's explanation for this a heartening one. It believes that the men who buy meat for retail outlets are looking for further price declines.

The warning frequently sounded in the last two years that increases in material and labor costs would price some customers out of the market has already come to pass, Warren J. Heldman, president of the National Association of Uniform Manufacturers, declared last night.

"America Divided," by Arnold and Caroline Rose, a survey of the religious, racial and ethnic groups in the United States, will be published on Jan. 11 by Knopf. The authors discuss minority problems in economics, law, politics and social life.

PARIS, Dec. 9 -- Sailors of a Communist-led labor union today voted to end their strike, which, with the sporadic strike of dockers, has disrupted shipping in Marseille for the past forty-one days. Dockers of this union had agreed to go back to work a few days ago, and ships were leaving port with crews from non-Communist unions in increasing numbers.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -Department store sals in the week ended Dee. 4 were 4 per cent below sales in the corresponding week of last year, the Federal Reserve ]ard reported today. The following lists percentages changes from like periods of 1947:

ROME, Dec. 9 -- The first move toward delivering to Russia the warships assigned to her by the peace treaty was made by Italy today when the 25,000-ton battleship Giulio Cesare left Taranto for an unknown destination. Just before her departure, the battleship's name was changed to Z-11.

Chairman Reid of the Board of Transportation has put the cost of expansion and renovation of our transportation system at about $900,000,000 for six years, a sum which far exceeds capital budget funds, even if these were wholly devoted to transit. With the need of a Second Avenue subway, new connections and other improvements generally admitted, the question that must now be thought out is where this tremendous sum can be found.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- During the week ended Dec. 8 member bank reserve balances decreased $150,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

LONDON, Dec. 91 -- Trading in the stock market here today continued in the quiet pattern that has been prevalent of late. Where moved, British Government bonds generally were up as much as an eighth, but industrials followed no general trend.

LONDON, Dec. 9 -- Britain's sensational bribery investigation showed its first concrete results today when a Minister of the Labor Government made known his intention to withdraw from his office under fire from inquiry.
With the arrest yesterday morning of five youths and an 18-year-old girl, the police believe they have broken up a gang that has committed twenty holdups in the Bronx within the last three weeks.

Independent brewers in the United States are gradually being forced to package their output in flat top cans to meet increasing invasion of their market by larger competitors, it was disclosed yesterday by officials of the Small Brewers Association at a meeting in the Commodore Hotel.

Development of an automatic telephone accounting machine that records all the necessary "bookkeeping" data for 25,000 phone calls in the form of perforations on a single roll of paper three inches wide, thus reducing to almost nil the heavy job of telephone accounting work, was announced yesterday by the Bell Telephone Laboratories.

The return of the French Line to "big" ship passenger operations was forecast yesterday by Guy de Berc, general manager for the company in the United States and Canada, who returned from a month's trip abroad in the liner De Grasse.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- Mme. Chiang Kai-shek and President Truman finally will meet face to face tomorrow under conditions suggesting that her mission for China's hard-pressed Nationalist Government thus far must be regarded as a failure.

Supreme Court justices and General Sessions and County Court judges who have signed orders permitting wiretapping were asked yesterday to demand of the police and other persons who obtained such orders a full report on how they used the privilege, what they overheard and what crimes, if any, were solved as a result.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- The Federal Power Commission ruled today for the first time in the history of the natural gas industry that a bond issue to finance new construction had to be sold at competitive bidding.
PARIS, Dec. 9 -- A convention outlawing genocide was adopted unanimously by the General Assembly this afternoon. The convention now is open for signature.

Brown University was admitted as the tenth member of the Heptagonal Games Association yesterday as that Ivy League track and field and cross-country group held its annual meeting at the Hotel Biltmore in conjunction with the twelfth schedule-making convention of the Eastern College Athletic Conference.
PARIS, Dec. 9 -- The United Nations was asked by the majority of its fifty-eight members today to put emphasis on conciliating disputes, instead of debating them to a deadlock.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Dec. 9 -- The arrival here tonight of members of the so-called Royall Commission marked the beginning of the investigation by this group of charges alleging failure to date of the United States Military Government in Germany to carry out the decartelization program.

The approach was irregular but singularly poignant and irresistible. For three hours yesterday afternoon housewives and anyone else with business on Manhattan Avenue in the Williamsburgh section of Brooklyn were stopped by pairs of purposeful children, the eldest 13, to be told: "There's a baby sick.

West Side Federal Savings and Loan Association became yesterday the first such institution to declare a dividend at the rate of 2 1/4 per cent, an increase of 1/4 per cent above the association's previous rate. Herman L. Reis, president of the association, in making the announcement, said that the action would mark his organization's sixtieth anniversary.

While Steve Owen and his assistants were working assiduously at the Polo Grounds yesterday preparing a defense against the passing of that Terrible Texan, Sammy Baugh of the Washington Redskins, who must be faced next Sunday, Tim Mara moved into the football picture.

TOPEKA, Kan., Dec. 9 (AP) -- A series of explosions rocked the Kansas Power and Light Company's main plant near here late today, killing at least eight workers and injuring seventeen others. The boilers of the big steam installation were believed to have blown up.

Sparkling as well as startling hair-do's provided a unique motif for a gala Bal de Tete given last night in the ballroom suite of the Plaza. Patterned after a dance with similar title given by the Duchess of Kent in London last May and another given by members of the Rothschild family in Paris before the war, the event was a benefit for the Hospitalized Veterans Music Service, of which Mrs. Lytle Hull is president.

PARIS, Dec. 9 -- Maud Roser opens the spring millinery season with a small advanced collection stressing flower blues from deep rich cornflower and delphinium through the medium forget-me-nots to palest gray-blues. Dark cornflower takes the place of navy.

CAIRO, Egypt, Dec. 9 -- Egyptian police last night and this morning arrested thirty-one of a total of fifty-one persons wanted as members of the Moslem Brotherhood and placed red wax seals over the doorjambs of Moslem Brotherhood organizations.

The rivalry between the Columbia Broadcasting System and the National Broadcasting Company for the services of major comedy artists broke into a new flurry of activity yesterday. These were the major developments:

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 9 -- After holding about unchanged in the second half of November, business in the Pittsburgh district last week rose to a level only moderately below the 1948 peak reached about the middle of August, according to the Bureau of Business Research, University of Pittsburgh.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Dec. 9 -- After a determined fight by the Cuban delegate, Ernesto Dihigo, the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization's program committee voted today for the establishment of a Western Hemisphere cultural office in Havana before the end of 1949.

CHICAGO, Dec. 9 -- Liquidation developed in December grains and soy beans after the markets had given a moderately good account of themselves in the early trading on the Board of Trade today. December soy beans developed pronounced weakness and at one time the price was down 7 cents a bushel, with little rallying power disclosed.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- President Truman concluded a half-hour meeting with his topmost defense and budget officials this afternoon, still believing, according to well-informed officials, that his budget limit of $15,000,000,000 for fiscal 1950 could provide for the military security of the United States.

Although steel production during November was about 223,000 tons below the monthly record, domestic steel-making furnaces last month produced more steel per day than in any other month on record, the American Iron and Steel Institute announced yesterday.

CHICAGO, Dec. 9 -- Communists and their supporters were barred from holding office in the Transport Workers Union, CIO, under provisions of a new constitution unanimously adopted at the closing session of the organization's biennial convention here today.

A fire in a dress goods store at 49 West Forty-second Street, near the Avenue of the Americas, although brought under control in a few minutes by firemen, attracted 5,000 persons yesterday afternoon and snarled traffic in the area for ten minutes.

The National Society for the Prevention of Blindness, Inc., marked yesterday the fortieth anniversary of its founding at its annual meeting at the Russell Sage Foundation, 130 East Twenty-second Street. Mason H. Bigelow, president of the society, told the seventy-five members present that its 1949 budget would be $324,585, an increase of nearly $8,000 since last year.

The Carnegie-Illinois Steel Corporation, chief operating subsidiary of the United States Corporation, announced yesterday increases ranging from 11.2 to about 14 per cent on a variety of its tin-mill products. The increases will be effective on Jan. 1 and are applicable for the entire year.

LONDON, Dec. 9 (AP) -- Charles Donmall, secretary of the British Boxing Board of Control, today defended the foul rule that cost Lee Savold of Paterson, N.J., his fight with Bruce Woodcock here on Monday.
MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 9 (AP) -- Miami's bookies reportedly went underground today until a muddled situation brought on by sagging state revenue from reduced betting is cleared up.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- In the vanguard of the great inaugural parade on Jan. 20 President Truman will ride foremost, it was announced today. Authorities concerned with arrangements said this would be history, as no President has done this before.

MINNEAPOLIS, Dec. 9 (AP) -- Two managers were named for Florida State League clubs at the minors' baseball convention today. Lou Finney, former outfielder for the Athletics, Red Sox and Browns, was signed by West Palm Beach club, while Myril Hoag, ex-Yankee outfielder, was appointed by St. Petersburg.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, Dec. 8 -- Premier Lajos Dinnyes resigned today. The resignation was accepted by President Arpad Szakasits and followed the resignation yesterday of five Under-Secretaries of State who, like Mr. Dinnyes, were members of the Smallholders party -- the second largest party in the coalition Government.

The City Rent Commission ruled yesterday that hotels that collected tentative rent increases from permanent guests between Oct. 1 and Nov. 17, when permission to do so was rescinded, must return the sums collected. It rejected a request of the Hotel Association of New York City that the hotels be permitted to place the sums, estimated at $600,000 in escrow.

Despite President Truman's renewed "red herring" charge against the Congressional investigation of pre-war Communist espionage, Federal attorneys continued yesterday to present evi dence growing out of that investigation to a special grand jury here.

ALBANY, Dec. 9 -- The milk industry's proposals to stabilize prices on Class 1A fluid milk would result in only seasonal retail reductions but would cost the consumer more in 1949 than it has this year. This was revealed here today at a Department of Agriculture hearing on two proposed amendments to the tentative milk marketing agreement for the New York metropolitan area.

"Hunger has no nationality," said President Truman in a recent address before the Food and Agricultural Organization of the United Nations. The same might be said of broken health, bruised hopes, loneliness and other forms of human misfortune. These are circumstances which may befall the best, as well as the worst, of us -- at least until society is better ordered than it is now.

The United Nations has been asked by the Lutheran World Federation for the return of all Christian church properties to their owners and compensation for any damage inflicted on them in Palestine, it was disclosed here yesterday by the National Lutheran Council, 231 Madison Avenue.
Following is the text of the proposed Constitution for the State of Israel, made available here yesterday:

CINCINNATI, Dec. 10 -- Television has grown faster during the last year than any other new industry in the nation's history, John W. Craig, vice president of the Avco Manufacturing Corporation and general manager of its Crosley Division, told a joint luncheon meeting here today of the Ohio Valley Transportation Advisory Board.
CRAB ORCHARD LAKE, Ill., Dec. 10 (AP) -- Seven dogs were eliminated today in two stiff land tests given the twenty-three entries in the second annual English springer spaniel field trials.

Andy Niederreiter, matchmaker since the organization was launched, yesterday resigned and precipitated a board of directors meeting which led to an announcement that the Tournament of Champions was suspending operations until after Jan. 1.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- Guesswork garaging and piece-meal parking only make a bad situation worse for New York or any other traffic-bound large city, delegates were told today at the closing session of the annual meeting of the Highway Research Board.

CHICAGO, Dec. 10 (AP) -- Preston Tucker offered publicly today to quit as president of the Tucker Corporation. He made the offer, he said, "if it would insure adequate financing to produce automobiles" by the company.

Africa is becoming increasingly important in the world picture economically, politically and strategically, in the opinion of John D. Rockefeller 3d. Mr. Rockefeller, a trustee of the foundation that bears his name, discussed impressions he gathered on a recent trip through the section south of the Sahara Desert in an interview yesterday in his offices at 30 Rockefeller Plaza.

Retailers are pressing for loweF prices on the limited quantity of dress buying now being done, iq was pointed out yesterday by me* dium and popular price manufae* turers. In planning clearances, Ka ment merchandisers are seeking to reduce the impact of large scale mark-downs by bringing in fresh merchandise at lower figures, they said.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture announced today conditions under which it will sell Government-owned or controlled farm products for general domestic use in 1949. Under present laws, the sales price for the most such products must not be less than the parity price. In 1949, however, the law permits sales at less than full parity.

Public subsides must come to the aid of private capital if slum areas in this city and in other municipalities in the metropolitan area are to be redeveloped along sound lines of city planning, Paul Windels, president of the Regional Plan Association, said yesterday.

The sixty-sixth annual meeting and convention of the United States Intercollegiate Lacrosse Association started last night at the Hotel Pennsylvania. The first session consisted of a closed meeting of the executive board with the head of the organization, Capt. Morris D. Gilmore, USN, retired, presiding.

A sharp increase in the number, size and variety of inquiries for machinery for Africa have been received by manufacturers here during the past week, it was learned yesterday. The inquiries have been spurred by Economic Cooperation Administration efforts to push Marshall Plan funds behind increased exports of metals.
LONDON, Dec. 10 -- Formation of a new concern, the Shell Venezuelan Investment Company, with a capital of only u1,000 (4,000) in u1 shares was announced today.

This week has witnessed the publication of two important new documents which concern themselves with the great and endless problems of human freedom. One of these documents is the proposed constitution of the new State of Israel. The other is the Declaration of Human Rights of the United Nations .

Whittaker Chambers, the avowed courier for a pre-war Washington spy ring "apparatus" that he says extracted vital Government documents for transmission to Russia, resigned yesterday as a senior editor of Time magazine.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- A secret radio signaling system developed by Brig. Gen. David Sarnoff, chairman of the Radio Corporation of America, and an improved grenade launcher, by John C. Garand of Springfield, Mass., designer of the Garand rifle, were among the 562 inventions approved this week by the United States Patent Office.
A 55-year-old master of the racquet proved again yesterday that he is still the world's best court tennis player, twenty years after he first won the title in England.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- Dr. Juan Atilio Bramuglia, the Argentine Foreign Minister, said today that in his opinion a solution of the Berlin crisis must be based on a simultaneous lifting of the Russian blockade and currency reforms. He said he was optimistic.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- Clarence Francis, chairman of General Foods Corporation, told a joint Congressional economic committee today he believed profits "cannot be arithmetically too high if they are made competitively in fair dealings in a competitive economy."
Western Air Lines, Inc., announced yesterday that beginning Jan. 1 it would not serve "free meals" on flights and would pass on to air passengers a saving of about 5 per cent on airplane tickets.

Equally famous with his midnight ride, the silver of Paul Revere continues in high esteem -- and price -- a pair of mugs bringing $7,000 at auction yesterday. Among the rarest examples of the patriot's work, the six-inch high mugs were unusual both for their large size and for the fact that they were a matched pair.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- For a half hour this afternoon President Truman heard Mme. Chiang Kai-shek plead her case for new aid to Communist-beleaguered China. The terse comment of the White House afterward was that the Chief Executive had listened "sympathetically" for a half hour.

James Reston, your chief diplomatic correspondent, in a post-election commentary published in THE TIMES of NOV. 4 pointed out that "we were wrong not only on the elections but, what's worse, on the whole political direction of our time." Unfortunately, this succinct diagnosis of our fundamental political naivete is even more valid today.

LONDON, Dec. 10 -- Family secrets were divulged today to the tribunal of inquiry into allegations of fraud at the Board of Trade when Mrs. Louise ("Lulu") Belcher and her husband, John W. Belcher, Parliamentary Secretary of the Board, testified.

CHICAGO, Dec. 10 -- In his address at the Executives Club luncheon, Mr. Symington said that "now that air power has made every country vulnerable to a modern air force, it is too obvious for further discussion that in order to guarantee its safety the United States must maintain air supremacy over any other nation on earth."

Senator Joseph C. O'Mahoney of Wyoming, member of the Joint Committee on the Economic Report, said last night that preservation of the capitalistic system in the United States could not be assured unless the economic concentration wrought by the operation of "Big Business" were curbed.

WESTPORT, Conn., Dec. 10 -- The August Matthias Post, American Legion, set up a committee today to seek out communism in local schools after a member charged that the educational program was "guided more or less communistically."

The annual Brooklyn winter horse show began its two-day run in the Teevan Riding Academy last night featured by a big field of jumpers starting the competition that will lead to the jumper championship tonight.

NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 10 (AP) -- The Port of New York Authority said today it may abandon its partly completed $7,000,000 truck terminal here because of the American Federation of Labor teamsters' union demands for exclusive jurisdiction over all transfer freight.
BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 10 -- From the tally to date of the votes in last Sunday's elections, the Peronista party seemed well on the way to the expected triumph.
PARIS, Dec. 10 -- A formal denial was issued by the French Foreign Ministry today that there had been a four power agreement upon public ownership of the industrial and mining properties of the Ruhr.

MINNEAPOLIS, Dec. 10 (AP) -- Herman White, president of the Northern League and a member of the executive committee of the National Association of Professional Baseball Leagues, today informed the minors that more than $80,000 had been collected in two funds for the benefit of players killed and injured in last year's bus-truck crash involving the Duluth team.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- Racial segregation is more prevalent in the national capital than it was fifty years ago, it was charged today by a committee of civic leaders after a two-year study.

CHICAGO, Dec. 10 -- Liquidation was on in the grain markets again today on the Board of Trade and prices ranged lower, although a mid-day rally carried nearby deliveries of wheat above the previous close. December soy beans led the decline and at one time were off 5 cents a bushel from yesterday at 17 1/2 cents from the high on Monday.

Representatives of various phases of show business yesterday urged Mayor Martin H. Kennelly of Chicago to revoke that city's recently imposed police ban against the presentation of Jean-Paul Sartre's "The Respectful Prostitute."

Your editorial of Nov. 30 "Toward an Atlantic Peace" considers two major aspects of the projected North Atlantic pact, the question of commitments and its essential nature. Both of these appear to have important long-range implications which need to be taken into account now.
CHICAGO, Dec. 10 (AP) -- The American Medical Association told of plans today for its battle against compulsory health insurance -- a proposal it is seeking to raise $3,500,000 to fight.

MOSCOW, Dec. 10 (UP) -- Vice Mayor I.P. Protserov announced today that Moscow had fulfilled its five-year plan for production of consumer goods ahead of schedule but he strongly criticized the quality of some products.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- President Truman today assigned his assistant, Dr. John R. Steelman, to take over the chairmanship of the National Security Resources Board to direct planning for total mobilization in the event of war.

An investment group headed by the Chase National Bank has purchased $4,935,000 of a $6,035,000 issue of New York City Housing Authority temporary loan notes at an interest cost of 1.19 per cent, it was announced yesterday. Other low bidders, with amounts, were Bear, Stearns Co., $1,000,000 at 1.17 per cent, and William E. Pollack Co., Inc., $100,000, at 1.18 per cent.

Military people call it esprit de corps, the dictionary definition of which is: "A spirit of common devotion, honor, interest, binding together persons of the same profession, society, etc." The armies which possess it in greatest measure are the ones that win the wars. Esprit de corps is primarily a feeling held by the individual that his group will not let him down .
NEW DELHI, India, Dec. 10 -- The Government of India has put down with apparent ease an incipient national uprising of Hindu extremist elements in the past three days.

Sales Of leading mail-order and chain-store companies increased 1.5 per cent in November, compared with the corresponding month last year, according to compilations of forty-three companies made yesterday by THE NEW YORK TIMES. An increase of 11.2 per cent was shown for the first eleven months of the year.
Three payroll robberies, all within a two-block area and all staged within half an hour, kept the police of the West Twentieth Street station busy yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today that the Gulf States Utilities Company, Beaumont, Tex., fried a registration statement with it covering an offering at competitive bidding of $15,000,000 of twenty-year debentures and an unspecified but sufficient number of additional shares of common stock, no par value, to yield $4,500,000.

Six small children in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn visited fifty families along Manhattan Avenue in their neighborhood yesterday and obtained signatures of ten persons who pledged a pint of blood to the Red Cross blood bank to be used for Suzanne Giordano, 2 years old, of 606 New Lots Avenue.

CHICAGO, Dec. 10 -- Furniture retailers will increase prices to consumers if Eastern railroads carry out their proposal to cancel furniture freight exception ratings on less than carload lots, Roscoe R. Rau, executive vice president, National Retail Furniture Association, warned here today. He said that the cancelation would add $25,000,000 yearly to freight expenses because of rate increases ranging from 35 to 110 per cent.
LONDON, Dec. 10 (UP) -- Following is the text of statements by Winston Churchill on Palestine and Spain during his speech in Commons today on foreign policy:

Walter F. Schmid has been appointed manager of the refrigeration department of the De Laval Separator Company. He succeeds H.S. Eastwood, who has been appointed manager of the Poughkeepsie office of De Laval Sales and Service, Inc.

The proposal to move airline terminal operations, now concentrated across Forty-second Street from the Grand Central Terminal, to a First Avenue location convenient to the Queens Midtown Tunnel offers the hope of much relief from traffic congestion in midtown Manhattan.

Thousands of churches in the United States will have special services tomorrow celebrating Universal Bible Sunday, a project for which the American Bible Society is sponsor. Similar services, promoted by foreign agencies of the society, will be held in other countries.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Dec. 10 -- William Belt Folger, Westchester Budget Director, is perhaps the "most cussed at" man in the county. While the 1949 budget is taking shape he is thumping the tom-toms of economy again on the theme that "twenty nickels saved make a dollar earned."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 (AP) -- Here is the state-by-state vote for President. The table shows the comparative vote in each state for 1944 and 1940 with percentages each candidate polled of the total, and the pluralities.

Hard-thinking liberals must create a second New Deal not only in this country but throughout the world, Chester Bowles, Governor-elect of Connecticut, declared last night. He addressed 1,000 persons attending a testimonial dinner tendered to Hubert H. Humphrey, Mayor of Minneapolis and Senator-elect from Minnesota, in the Roosevelt Hotel.

MINNEAPOLIS, Dec. 10 -- As the baseball clans hastily packed their grips for a swift evacuation following the closing session of the minors' National Association of Professional Baseball Leagues convention, a few developments loomed today as likely to produce results when the major league conclaves get under way in Chicago next Monday.

PARIS, Dec. 10 -- The meeting of the United Nations Security Council's committee of seven on the Negeb, desert area in southern Palestine, scheduled for this afternoon, was canceled after Dr. Ralph J. Bunche, acting Mediator, had reported that the Israeli Government had accepted his proposal for the withdrawal by stages of the surrounded Egyptian forces in the Faluja pocket.

Today's events: "Tristan und Isolde," 2 P.M., and "Il Trovatore," 8:15, Metropolitan Opera Company; Maryla Jonas, piano, Carnegie Hall, 3; Albert Brusilow, violin, Town Hall, 2:30; Leo Nadelmann, piano, Town Hall, 5:30.
Increased contributions this year by Christians as well as Jews have put the Federation of Jewish Philanthropies of New York $9,750,000 nearer the current campaign goal of $16,500,000.

HOLLYWOOD, Fla., Dec. 10 -- The references to "Wall Street" which President Truman made in the recent Presidential campaign were denounced here today by Hal H. Dewar, Texan, who has been elected president of the Investment Bankers Association.

My attention has been called to a letter from John E. Kelly which was published in the Nov. 17 issue of your paper. Since I believe Mr. Kelly is mistaken in some of his remarks comparing the impetus given to uranium prospecting by the Canadian and American Governments, I would like to correct. what I think are erroneous conclusions.

Taking advantage of Brooklyn College's loose defensive play, Fordham surged to an early lead and coasted to a 62-48 victory over the Kingsmen last night on the Flatbush court before 1,600 fans. The Rams held a 35-ll half-time lead.

A committee of lawyers, it was learned yesterday, has recommended that Congress set up higher standards for all its investigating committees. The recommending group is the Bill of Rights committee of the Association of the Bar of the City of New York.

Retail trade here this week made another decline despite heavy holiday promotions. Department store sales were estimated about 5 per cent below the corresponding week last year. Sales last week were down 6 per cent.

The popular Rhode Island State College basketball team will be the big attraction at Madison Square Garden tonight. The Rams, making their annual visit to New York, will oppose the undefeated St. John's University quintet in the feature game of a double-header.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- A B-50 bomber has completed a 9,400-mile non-stop flight by being refueled in mid-air from B-29 Superfortresses converted into airborne tankers, the Air Force said today.

TOKYO, Dec. 10 -- American business men, although generally still anxious to have the Occupation Authorities permit establishment of a single yen-dollar exchange rate, are beginning to wonder whether that move will actually speed trade as much as they have been hoping. What will result, they say, depends principally upon the answer to the key question: "Who will buy Japan's imports?"

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- Participants in a seminar for industrialists agreed here today that the Supreme Court decision outlawing the basing point pricing system in the cement industry had been emphasized out of all proportion to its significance.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- The United States Government is distressed and divided over the deterioration of its relations with France. Not since the Roosevelt-De Gaulle feud in 1945 have Washington and Paris been so far apart, and there is no real agreement here over who is to blame for the rift or how it is to be overcome.

Bird lovers, biology students and many nature groups received reassurance yesterday that the marsh area at the north tip of Van Cortlandt Park Lake would be preserved by the Park Department as the only fresh-water wildlife sanctuary in the five boroughs.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 10 (AP) -- Joe Fulks accused a poolroom operator today of trying to fix games in the Basketball Association of America.

BELHAVEN, N.C., Dec. 10 -- The opening of the waterfowl season is an event wherever you go, but down here, on the wintering grounds of the big honkers, it has something of the aspect of a pilgrimage, and annual visitors from a dozen states began arriving last night.

The police were still working last night trying to solve the mysterious circumstances in the death early yesterday in Brooklyn of a 71-year-old grandmother who was found with her wrists tied and a handkerchief in her mouth. After an autopsy it was reported that there was no external violence evident to show cause of death.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 10 -- A series of contradictory declarations by leaders of the motion picture industry at the time of the House Un-American Activities Committee's communism investigation a year ago were presented in Federal District Court today by opposing counsel in arguments on whether Lester Cole, screen writer, had the executives' tacit approval in his actions before the committee.

Scrap Prices Prices of scrap metal during the last week exhibited considerable nervousness. In most steel-making centers prices either held steady or advanced about $1 a ton, but one local dealer yesterday lowered his quotation 50 cents a ton. Pittsburgh and Cincinnati have recently noted some price buoyancy, while Chicago, Philadelphia and Birmingham report price stabilization.

HERE are two pictorial only yesterdays of life on our frantic planet. They are both huge books of photographs, like immobile newsreels, festooned with yards upon yards of written text that tries valiantly to give order and reason to the record of these incredible years. One is called "Year 1948,"* a sketchy, high-hitting and enthusiastic venture into unfinished history.

MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 10 (AP) -- Frank Stranahan, Toledo, Ohio, amateur golfer, showed the way to professionals today with another four-rounder par 66 for a total of 132 and five-stroke lead at the halfway mark in the $10,000 Miami open tournament.

Rugged and fit-looking, the result of skiing the Chilean Alps (Andes) the past four months -- it's winter down there while summer prevails in this neck of the woods -- Emile Allais, former two-time World downhill champion and founder of the French ski technique, with Mrs. Allais, were introduced to the press at the Stork Club before entraining last night for Sun Valley, Idaho.

A gentleman whose practice it is to make a weekly purchase of postage stamps in quantity sufficient to meet the needs of his family of prolific letter-writers has suggested to this corner that unless something is done about the wholesale authorization, by Congress, of commemorative stamps, the postal service eventually may become demoralized

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- President Truman had broadcast by the Voice of America to the world today a statement of appreciation for the congratulatory messages he has received from abroad on his election. Sent in many languages to Europe, Latin America and the Far East, the message said:
With the city's investigation into waterfront crime proceeding behind closed doors, five gangs of longshoremen refused for the second successive day yesterday to shape-up for work at a Brooklyn pier.

The lifting of the ban of the American Federation of Musicians on the manufacture of new records was regarded as imminent last night following the selection of Samuel R. Rosenbaum, a director of the Philadelphia Orchestra Association, as impartial trustee of the union's royalty welfare fund.

Governor Dewey awarded $3,600 in cash prizes yesterday to eight winners of four architectural competitions held by the State Division of Housing for the best housing designs for persons in the lower income brackets. Thirty-five other winners also were congratulated by the Governor in a ceremony in his suite at the Roosevelt Hotel.

NANKING, Dec. 10 -- Martial law was extended to virtually all Nationalist China tonight as more than 5,000 teams, operating under Nanking garrison headquarters, went from house to house in the capital looking for "Communist" agents.
The first drop in monthly volume for wholesale drugs since the last month of 1941, a 5 per cent decline in October, was attributed yesterday to a combination of market factors.

ALBANY, Dec. 10 -- The trustees of the State University will meet in New York Dec. 17 to consider plans for integrating their medical school program with the state's long-range program for the curing of the mentally ill.

Edgar Bergen's decision to leave the air on Dec. 26 added further yesterday to the programming trials of NBC, which by mid-February now stands to hold only two of the five Sunday night comedy shows with which it started the season.
LONDON, Dec. 10 -- The stock market ended the week today on a quiet note with British Government bonds and industrial shares recording hardly any changes.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 (AP) -- The Navy is building a half dozen new high-speed snorkel submarines. Several older types equipped with the "breathing" apparatus already are in operation.

The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange had a slow start yesterday but finished strong, 19 to 28 points net higher. Starting 3 points lower to 2 points higher, it gradually worked to the best levels of the day at the close. A spot firm sold about 3,000 bales of March cotton against purchases of May at 25 points.

New Yorkers were busy yesterday preparing for the arrival of Santa Claus fourteen days from new. When St. Nick, accompanied by his trusted reindeer, Dasher, Dancer, Donder and Blitzen, visits the city, he will be greeted with the brightest Yuletide setting in years.
Russell E. Ryan, 44 years old, of 333 East Forty-third Street, a retired newspaper man, died Thursday in his apartment, it was reported yesterday.

Farming is as unpredictable "as a poker game, only the stakes are higher." This was the verdict of Mrs. Delon Kirk of Spearman, Tex., as she and her farmer husband arrived yesterday at the Taft Hotel en route to the American Farm Bureau Federation convention in Atlantic City tomorrow.

John E. Schuhert, 22 years old, of 43 Van Siclen Avenue, Floral Park, L.I., was sentenced yesterday in Queens County Court to serve seventy-five years to life in prison for the murder of a 62-year-old bank vault clerk.

J. Austin King of Farmingdale, L.I., wrote to this department that he paid $1.78 for a fifth of a California Sweet Semillon, which was discussed here recently, when he could have gotten imported Graves for $1.25, he discovered later. Why, he asked, should fine American wines cost more than the French imports?

Fritz Sternberg, author of "The Coming Crisis" and "How to Stop the Russians -- Without War," presents his views for a new and progressive foreign policy in his forthcoming book, "Living With Crisis: The Battle Against Depression and War," which will be published in February by John Day.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Dec. 10 -- A new threat to peace was disclosed here tonight with the announcement by an Israeli Army spokesman that the Egyptians had launched a large-scale attack against the settlement of Nirim, in the Negeb, desert area in southern Palestine. The attacking force was said to have been composed mainly of infantry supported by at least sixteen tanks.

The Port of New York Authority announced yesterday that it had asked the Maritime Commission to refuse a request by Seatrain Lines, Inc., that the commission take action with the steamship concern in Federal Court in a rate action involving New Orleans-Cuba freight.

YONKERS, N.Y., Dec. 10 -- A tax rate decrease of slightly more than 5 cents on each $100 of assessed valuation is provided in the tentative budget for 1949 submitted tonight to the Common Council by Acting City Manager John A. Peterson. Mr. Peterson was appointed to the post, after Thomas V. Kennedy announced that he would resign on Jan. 1 and took a thirty-day vacation.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- A delegation of Mayors representing the United States Conference of Mayors urged President Truman today to seek 800,000 public housing units in five years, to provide more Federal funds for schools and to eliminate traffic congestion in cities.

BINGHAMTON, N.Y., Dec. 10 -- Builders who are interested in cashing in on current high prices for housing, but fail to cooperate in improving labor and other conditions in the industry were assailed by Herman T. Stichman here tonight.

Year-end buying appeared yesterday in the share market on the Stock Exchange -- it was early for the season -- and although gains were not impressive, the list pulled out of its indecisive state. A wide variety of selective issues provided the spark for the upturn and accounted for the steepest additions, while the industrials continued to hold back.

PARIS, Dec. 10 -- Nicolas Zachariades, secretary general of the Greek Communist party, has called upon Greek National Army troops to disregard the Athens Government, form "reconcilation committees" in their units and establish contact with the guerrilla formations of Gen. Markos Vafiades to facilitate conclusion of a compromise peace in the civil war.

Lifting of the ban against participation for pay in summer baseball by athletes from the fifty-eight member institutions of the Eastern College Athletic Conference was strongly urged last night by Governor Ernest W. Gibson of Vermont.

Three old yards and shops of the IRT division of the city subway system will be abandoned by the end of this year, the Board of Transportation announced yesterday. Two of them will be sold to the New York City Housing Authority as sites for housing projects in Manhattan.

ALBANY, Dec. 10 -- Governor Dewey moved today to get action by the Truman Administration on New York's application for permission to develop jointly with the Province of Ontario the power resources of the St. Lawrence River.
After early irregular trading, coffee contract D futures closed firm yesterday on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange.

Louis Kaufman, violinist, gave a recital last night at Carnegie Hall. As usual the modest, sincere artist had arranged an unhacknayed list of offerings, which he performed with taste, insight and sound musicianship.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., Dec. 10 (AP) -- Triple ties for first and second place were registered tonight at the end of the second session of the national open team-of-four championships at the American Contract Bridge League tournament.

Dr. Lawrence S. Kubie, clinical Professor of Psychiatry and Mental Hygiene at Yale University School of Medicine, called last night for carefully controlled, long-term research, instead of confusion and controversy, concerning the aims and techniques of psychoanalysis.

ROME, Dec. 10 (AP) -- Twenty-four Midwestern American farmers, who have been touring Europe for four weeks, turned homeward today, convinced, they said, that European farmers "are doing the best they can." They added that they also were convinced that United States aid to Europe should continue.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- It is the "obligation of Congress" to tell American business men what standard of pricing, practices is required of them so that they may comply with the law, William Simon, general counsel of the Senate Subcommittee on Trade Policies, said today.

CHICAGO, Dec. 10 -- Federal participation in the country's general assistance program, now wholly in the hands of states and localities, was urged today by Donald S. Howard, dean of the School of Social Work, University of California at Los Angeles.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- Average primary market prices declined 0.8 per cent during the week ended Dec. 7, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics.

WALLA WALLA, Wash., Dec. 10 (AP) -- Guards tonight captured two convicts trying to tunnel out of the Washington State Prison. Prison officials described it as one of the most desperate escape attempts in many years.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Dec. 10 -- John J. Winberry, former Assistant Attorney General, challenged today Attorney General Walter Van Riper, who deposed him as head of a long gambling investigation in Middlesex County, to cooperate with New York officials to stamp out a gambling syndicate he said was operating in two states.
NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 10 (AP) -- Jockey H. Lemmons piloted Cashmere to a one-and-one-half length victory in the Louisiana Orange Festival Purse at the Fair Grounds today.

A sweeping program on dental health is to be projected by the State Department of Health, it became known yesterday. The first plan of its kind, it is aimed at improving the welfare of the people of the state through the prevention and control of tooth decay, oral cancer and crooked teeth.

Although some weeks will elapse before we get a fairly complete picture from Albany of the state's budgetary needs for the new fiscal year, and New York City's expense budget will take form still later, it is already apparent that the demands on both state and city in the coming year will be of staggering size.

A day-long conference between C.R. Smith, chairman of the board of American Airlines, and Juan Terry Trippe, president of Pan American Airways, to work out details of the sale of American Overseas Airlines to Pan American ended early last night with no announcement of progress.

Considering the acclaim Menahem Pressler has earned in his appearances with orchestra, the young pianist's first recital at Town Hall last night was a letdown. It may be that too much was expected of him and that one's disappointment was greater than warranted.

Charpentier's "Louise" was the opera last night at the Metropolitan, with Dorothy Kirsten in the title part; Charles Kullman as Julian the poet; Margaret Harshaw, the mother; John Brownlee, the father, and Emil Cooper, the conductor. The long list of small parts must be passed here, although these parts are significant details of a crowded picture, and although they bear witness, in numbers and in character, to the nature of the opera.

A former registrar at the United States Marine Hospital, Stapleton, S.I., whose promotion led to the discovery of the theft of $9,340 from the hospital's safe, was under arrest yesterday charged with larceny.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- The "Iron Curtain" separating communism and Western democracy is certain to cripple scientific research under communism, Dr. Vannevar Bush, president of the Carnegie Institution of Washington, said here today in delivering the institution's annual report.

LONDON, Dec. 10 -- Alarmed by the mounting success of Communist arms in China, the British Government is sounding out quietly various governments in southeast Asia on an over-all program for fighting the spread of Communism.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture said today weather and soil conditions in late November laid the groundwork for another big crop season in 1949. It said conditions which contributed heavily to this year's record crop output continued.

In editorials in this and last week's issues and in letters mailed to its 13,000 subscribers. The Socialist Call, published by the national executive committee of the Socialist party, has appealed for $10,000 in contributions to avert suspension.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- Gov. Thomas E. Dewey held a reunion tonight with the correspondents who have reported his two Presidential campaigns, surviving a railroad crash and two wrecks of Republican hopes at the November polls.

SAN BRUNO, Calif., Dec. 10 (AP) -- Citation, undisputed king of the American turf, will meet the latest challenge to his lofty position tomorrow in the $50,000 added Tanforan Handicap. A crowd of 30,000 is expected and the handicap is scheduled at 6:52 P.M. (Eastern Standard time).

LONDON, Dec. 10 -- Denials on really high authority came from Buckingham Palace today that King George VI's arterial ailment had taken a critical turn, that a United States specialist was flying over to visit the King or that there was any intention to amputate one or both of his legs.

LONDON, Dec. 10 -- Former Prime Minister Churchill intimated today that he would give his side of wartime strategic disagreements with Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower in his war memoirs, the second volume of which is to appear next year.
The field of acceptable challengers for World Heavyweight Champion Joe Louis was whittled to a single individual last night in Madison Square Garden. His name is Ezzard Charles.

THE HAGUE, Dec. 10 -- The Netherland Government has resolved to fly in the fence of Indonesian Republican denunciations and proceed with the setting up of a federal system, as scheduled, for the end of the year. What no man can foretell is whether such a decision will lead to peace or a clash of arms.
CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 10 (AP) -- Wing Messenger, claimed by P.L. Grissom for $10,000 after a recent winning race here, took the Delamont Purse at Tropical Park today.

A declaration of war on the "cold war" through a world-wide mobilization of a people's lobby for peace to assemble in Paris next year was announced yesterday by Dr. Kirtley F. Mather, Harvard University Professor of Geology and chairman of the One World Congress.

Five-year-old Susanne Lawston was shot and killed by her 8-year-old brother, Charles, yesterday afternoon soon after he had found a rusty .32-calibre pistol in a yard next to their home at 1985 Crotona Avenue, the Bronx.
LYONS, Ga., Dec. 10 (AP) Two white men were indicted on murder charges today in the ambush slaying of Robert Mallard, Toombs County Negro.

New York State will make a bold approach to the problem of dealing with the mentally ill if it adopts the long-range psychiatric program now under consideration by Governor Dewey and his advisers. Hitherto, the state's emphasis has been on the care of mental patients in need of custodial treatment.

There was once a Secretary of the Treasury who decided that it was not in keeping with the dignity of his department to issue an educational bulletin on syphilis. Times have changed. The Public Health Service, which is part of the Treasury, is now proceeding actively against the venereal diseases.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- Maj. Gen. Frank R. McCoy, as chairman of the eleven-nation Far Eastern Commission, of which he is the United States member, struck out today at Soviet Ambassador Alexander S. Panyushkin for his announcement to the press yesterday of the rejection by the commission at an executive session of the Russian proposal on industrial policy for Japan.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 10 -- American industry faces a new wage-increase demand of at least 20 per cent, a spokesman for the United Automobile Workers, CIO, indicated here tonight.

PRINCETON, N.J., Dec. 10 -- Two United States Olympic swimming champions, Joe Verdeur, La Salle College breast-stroke ace, and Allen Stack, Yale's backstroke star, will attempt to set new international records in their specialties tomorrow evening as Princeton University formally dedicates its new pool in the Herbert Lowell Dillon gymnasium with an exhibition swimming and diving meet.
