PARIS, Dec. 10 -- United Nations officials worked today to try to salvage some hope for the future out of the stalled Balkan conciliation talks.

A 15-year old girl in the Bronx sent her annual contribution to THE NEW YORK TIMES Neediest Cases Fund yesterday with the recommendation that every contributor give at least $1 for each year of his age.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 10 -- The eighteen film makers who compose the Society of Independent Motion Picture Producers will meet Sunday night to vote formally on the appointment of Ellis Arnall, former Governor of Georgia, to the presidency of the society, it was announced today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 (AP) -- A total of 49,363,798 ballots were cast on Nov. 2, but only 48,680,416 were marked for President. This means that 683,382 voters balloted for state, county and local candidates, but did not make a choice for the highest office in the land.

The return to Italy of her colonies as they existed prior to the Fascist regime was advocated yesterday by Senator Irving M. Ives when he returned aboard the Italian liner Saturnia from a month's tour of western Europe.

At a reconvened hearing yesterday before the Public Service Commission on the proposal of the Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., to acquire the Long Island Lighting Company, Ralph H. Tapscott, president of the Edison company, assured Milo R. Maltbie, chairman of the PSC, that there would be no change in administration of the Long Island utility.

ALBANY, Dec. 10 -- The State Banking Department announced today that the National City Safe Deposit Company, 17 East Forty-second Street, New York, was authorized to open a branch at 89-50 164th Street, Jamaica, conditioned upon the discontinuance of any office now maintained at 92-09-11 Union Hall Street, Jamaica.

SHELBY, N.C., Dec. 10 (AP) -- Charles E. Wilson, president of the General Electric Company, said tonight industrial cutbacks and unemployment might result from a fourth round of general wage increases. He spoke at a community dinner here on the occasion of the opening of a new power plant by the Duke Power Company.

CHICAGO, Dec. 10 (AP) -- Like professional baseball, Big Nine athletic leaders are casting a worried eye at television. The Western Conference, which today opened its annual winter meeting, has had no standard policy governing television of football games or re-televizing game movies.

BINGHAMTON, N.Y., Dec. 10 (AP) -- A mound of 2,000 comic books and pictorial magazines was burned here today as students of St. Patrick's Parochial School sought to dramatize their movement to boycott publications which they say stress crime and sex.

NOTRE DAME, Ind., Dec. 10 -- With 600 judges, lawyers, legislators, educators and others in attendance, the 1948 Natural Law Institute was opened today at the University of Notre Dame. Speakers upheld the natural law as the basis for all personal rights.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- The State Department today denied a charge made in Havana by Romulo Gallegos, the exiled President of Venezuela, that Col. Edward F. Adams, the United States Military Attache in Caracas during the military revolt of Nov. 24, had acted as "cooperator or counselor" for the revolutionists.

The Metropolitan Garage Board of Trade has "set out to confuse the public and the City Council" with a survey that contended the city-wide average of garage vacancies was 14.8 per cent, the Automobile Club of New York charged yesterday.

Communist successes in North China have virtually halted exports of hand-hooked Chinese rugs to the United States, Hilton Hodges, partner, of Pande, Cameron Co., disclosed yesterday. He spoke at the annual meeting of the Oriental Rug Importers Association.

The National Multiple Sclerosis Society has made plans to raise a research and educational fund of $225,000 in 1949 for use in a concentrated attack on this baffling and paralyzing disease of the central nervous system, it was announced yesterday by Ralph I. Straus, president of the society.

VIENNA, Dec. 10 -- The Soviet charged at today's meeting of the Allied Council that Austria and the bizonal area of Western Germany had concluded a secret trade agreement in violation of Allied Council decisions and the Austrian Control Agreement.

PARIS, Dec. 10 -- A universal Declaration on Human Rights nearly three years in preparation, was adopted late tonight by the United Nations General Assembly. The vote was 48 to 0 with the Soviet bloc, Saudi Arabia and the Union of South Africa abstaining.

Beatrice Lillie received last night the first Civilian Award of the first Annual Military and Naval Ball of the Reserve Officers Association, in the Essex House, Central Park South. She was honored for her entertainment activities during the war.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- The new Congress will pass additional measures against subversives unless the Department of Justice "demonstrates by action" that additional laws are not needed, Senator Homer Ferguson, Republican, of Michigan, asserted today.

Italy bids fair to become a factor in shipments of worsted and cotton textile machinery to the United States, particularly to Southern mills, it was reported here yesterday by R.J. Tesar, export manager of the Rostan Machinery and Equipment Company, 75 West Street.

PARIS, Dec. 10 -- The French Government has tentatively fixed its appropriation for direct productive investments under the recovery plan in the coming year at approximately 200,000,000,000 francs -- far less than the sum it expects to receive from the counterpart fund under the Marshall Plan.

A two-alarm fire that destroyed the contents of the five-story building of the Pearl Desk Company at 10 Barclay Street and had to be fought for a half-hour from the rear of the New York County Lawyers' Building at 14 Vesey Street, snarled traffic during the noon hour yesterday in the City Hall and Wall Street areas.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- The microfilms of secret Government documents found in a pumpkin shell on the Maryland farm of Whittaker Chambers, confessed pre-war courier for a Communist espionage underground, remained hidden and untouched for ten years in a residence at 260 Rochester Avenue, Brooklyn, N. Y., the House Committee on Un-American Activities was told today.
Exiled King Peter expects that when they are able to express their choice freely, the people of Yugoslavia will call him back to his throne, he said yesterday in an interview at the Carlyle Hotel.

A 50-year-old woman was charged with violation of the Sanitary Code yesterday after a city inspector told Magistrate Doris I. Byrne in Mid-Manhattan Court that the woman had filled her four-room apartment, the adjoining hallways, the cellar and back yard with rubbish and junk that she collected on night-time tours of the midtown streets.

Coal and petroleum products valued at $19,869,411 constituted the principal commodities furnished to the Federal Government by New York manufacturers and dealers under the Walsh-Healey Public Contracts Act in July, August and September, it was announced here yesterday by Arthur J. White, New York and New Jersey regional director of the Wage and Hour and Public Contracts Divisions of the United States Department of Labor.

TOKYO, Dec. 10 -- For the first time since the surrender a person barred from public life under an occupation directive and then reinstated now has assumed a high political role here. This is Ken Inukai who today was elected president of Japan's "Democratic party" in place of Dr. Hitoshi Ashida, now in jail awaiting trial on corruption charges.
Army trucks will be used in the delivery of Christmas mail during the rest of the holiday season, it was said yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- The United States, Canada and the Brussels Treaty nations of Western Europe opened today another phase of the negotiations for a North Atlantic security pact.

ALBANY, Dec. 10 -- An attempt to remedy the housing shortage and cut building costs by ridding the state of its antiquated building codes will be made by Governor Dewey during the 1949 legislative session, it was learned today.

The president of an independent milk-dealers' organization urged the dairy farmer yesterday to take a more realistic view of the milk price situation because "he is pricing himself out of a part of the fluid milk market."

LONDON, Dec. 10 (AP) -- Following is the text of a letter sent to Premier Stalin on April 29, 1945, by Winston Churchill, then Prime Minister, as read today by Mr. Churchill in the course of his speech in the House of Commons:
Secretary of the Army Kenneth C. Royall said last night that the surest single guarantee of peace was a sound and unified national defense.

LONDON, Dec. 10 -- In a single sweep of oratory, Winston Churchill proposed three changes in British Foreign policy today: Ending of the Labor Government's "sulky boycott" of Israel and conditional recognition of the new state, quick cessation of dismantling of nonwarlike industries in Germany and admission of Spain to the United Nations.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- A two-week proceeding to aid the Interstate Commerce Commission to decide whether or not the railroads of the country should be granted an immediate increase of 8 per cent in freight rates came to an end today with argument, in the course of which the ICC was called the "Santa Claus" and the "wet nurse" of the railroads.

BUCK HILL FALLS, Pa., Dec. 10 -- Methodist missionaries who elect to remain in Communist-dominated areas of China received the unqualified and "whole-hearted" support of their church today at the closing session here of the annual meeting of the Board of Missions and Church Extension of the Methodist Church.

Wage review discussions between representatives of the National Maritime Union, CIO, and a committee representing about forty Atlantic and Gulf Coast steamship operators continued yesterday with "some progress" reported by a spokesman for the operators.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- President Carlos Prio Socarras predicted today that Communist influence in Cuba would have disappeared "totally" by the end of his term as chief executive four years hence.

WICHITA, Kan., Dec. 10 (AP) -- Congressional reversal of the United States Supreme Court's decision that tidelands oil belongs to the Federal Government was forecast today by Gov. Beauford H. Jester of Texas.

ATHENS, Dec. 10 -- The highway reconstruction program of the Economic Cooperation Administration's mission will be completed by the year's end with the exception of a recently added base road project between Kozani and Kastoria, according to an announcement made today by the ECA Reconstruction Division. The work has been done by private contracting concerns under the direction of the United States Army corps of engineers.

CHICAGO, Dec. 10 -- The new anti-Communist International Executive Board of the Transport Workers Union, CIO, ousted sixteen members of the union's organizing staff in New York and other cities today.

There is one matter of civil rights which is not often emphasized, but which is of first importance in our national attitude toward caste and public insult. That is interstate travel. Here there is no question of states' rights: the jurisdiction of the Federal Government over this subject is clear in statute and court decision.

CARACAS, Venezuela, Dec. 10 -- Lieut. Col. Carlos Delgado Chalbaud, president of the military junta now governing Venezuela, termed "absurd" today statements by former President Romulo Gallegos concerning alleged foreign intervention here.
CHICAGO, Dec. 10 (AP) -- Joe Louis administered a neat but none too impressive boxing lesson to Pittsburgh's Billy Conn in their six-round exhibition in the International Amphitheater tonight.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Dec. 10 -- Dr. Jaime Torres Bodet of Mexico, at a formal welcome today as new Director General of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization, told the general conference that the organization was on trial before world public opinion and must prove itself.

CAMP LEE, Va., Dec. 10 -- The first 111 members of the Women's Army Corps to finish eight weeks of basic training as part of the Regular Army put on snappy graduation exercises and drill today at this Army post twenty-five miles south of Richmond. They were carefully selected from twenty-six states.

Four Archbishops and forty-five bishops of the Roman Catholic Church in America will march in the procession and be seated in the sanctuary at the consecration next Thursday of Bishop-elect Joseph F. Flannelly, administrator of St. Patrick's Cathedral, it was announced yesterday.

Jewels valued at $30,000 were stolen Wednesday from a suite in the Ritz-Carlton Hotel, to add one more to the series of hotel jewelry thefts that have plagued New York police for the last several months. The police delayed until yesterday to announcing the theft, hoping that the jewelry might only have been misplaced in the hotel suite.

SEOUL, Korea, Dec. 10 -- Representatives of the United States and the South Korean Governments signed today an agreement providing for at least $300,000,000 aid to South Korea during the next three years.

The Right Rev. Msgr. Robert E. McCormick, presiding judge of the Archdiocesan Tribunal of New York, issued a statement yesterday calling upon the State Legislature to ban divorce entirely and assailing the "present movement to liberalize divorce in our state" as a "menace to society."

BELGRADE, Yuogslavia, Dec. 10 -- Murdo MacKenzie, head of the Mackenzie Engineering Co. Ltd. of London, designers and builders of steel plants, announced here yesterday that an agreement had been reached with the Yugoslav Ministry of Heavy Industry for technical assistance in the preparation of plans to expand the iron and steel industry under the five-year plan.

The Right Rev. Msgr. Robert E. McCormick, presiding judge of the Archdiocesan Tribunal of New York, issued a statement yesterday calling upon the State Legislature to ban divorce entirely and assailing the "present movement to liberalize divorce in our state" as a "menace to society."

BELGRADE, Yuogslavia, Dec. 10 -- Murdo MacKenzie, head of the Mackenzie Engineering Co. Ltd. of London, designers and builders of steel plants, announced here yesterday that an agreement had been reached with the Yugoslav Ministry of Heavy Industry for technical assistance in the preparation of plans to expand the iron and steel industry under the five-year plan.
A three-cornered jurisdictional dispute simmering for the last week erupted yesterday into a series of violent skirmishes in front of several well-known restaurants.
SAN BRUNO, Calif., Dec. 11 -- Citation, king of the American turf, won the $50,000-added Tanforan Handicap today by five lengths, galloping easily. The time for the mile and one quarter was 2:02 4/5.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- The secreg diplomatic reports cabled to the State Department in 1938 from its representatives abroad and published by the House Committee on Un-American Activities tonight as among those it has found to have been obtained by Whittaker Chambers, the admitted Communist go-between, contained vitally important information for other foreign governments at that time, according to diplomatic opinion here.

STAFF changes are notoriously frequent on the chain of daily newspapers owned by Carleton Bruce, but nowhere have they ever been so frequent as on The Morning Globe, which loses three publishers in as many days. The first of these is believed to have committed suicide; the other two are unquestionably the victims of murder.

THE Horticultural Society of New York will hold a flower show and lecture at the Colonnades Ballroom of the Essex House on Wednesday from 2:30 to 4:30 P.M. Ben Blackburn will speak on "Distinctive Shrubs" and show kodachrome slides.

At the end of the first full week of the thirty-seventh annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, $125,077 had been contributed by readers for the first 100 cases. This sum was $5,000 greater than that on the corresponding date last year.

MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 11 -- Melvin (Chick) Harbert, Detroit professional, set a course record eight-under-par 62 in the $10,000 Miami open golf tournament today, but amateur Frank Stranahan of Toledo,-Ohio, still led the field with a card of 200 for 54 holes.

In Paris the first part of the third regular session of the United Nations General Assembly went through its final hours last night. The delegates of fifty-eight nations gathered in the Palais de Chaillot eighty-two days ago, at the beginning of autumn. The delegates have spoken around 17,000,000 words in more than 600 meetings.

" I AM so convinced of the advantages of looking at mankind instead of reading about them," said Lord Byron about his uncommonly adventurous grand tour of the Mediterranean countries in 1809-11, "that I think there should be a law amongst us, to set our young men abroad, for a term, among the few allies our wars have left us."
DENVER, Dec. 11 -- The Rocky Mountain Big Six voted unanimously today to employ a fulltime commissioner with "broad discretionary powers to enforce the athletic policies of the conference."

TOKYO, Dec. 11 -- Washington's withdrawal from the Far Eastern Commission's consideration of the directive on Japanese economic concentration, known as FEC 230, will have virtually no effect, according to occupation officials, because its objectives either have been achieved or abandoned.

WASHINGTON -- The parking situation is uniformly bad throughout the country and the feeble efforts made to remedy conditions have had little or no effect, according to data presented to the Highway Research Board here last week.

PRINCETON, N.J., Dec. 11 -- Thirty-two Rhodes Scholarships were awarded today by committees meeting in eight districts of the nation, each district embracing six states. The names of the appointees were reported tonight to Dr. Frank Aydelotte, American secretary for the Rhodes Scholar Trust, who made them public as soon as they were received.

Gowns in the current style, yet influenced by the Gibson Girl fashions popular at the turn of the century, will be worn by women guests at the Gibson Girl Ball to be given Dec. 20 in the main ballroom of the Plaza as a benefit for the Child Placing and Adoption Committee of the State Charities Aid Association.

THOUGH it sometimes shows more Pride and prejudice than Sense and Sensibility, O'Connor's book of esthetic criticism is an unusual intellectual achievement -- unusual because it is equally informative for the practicing poet and for the bewildered reader of modernist poetry.

FROM St. Petersburg, Fla., comes a report that inquiries received by the Chamber of Commerce from prospective winter visitors are now more than double the number received a year ago. During November the chamber received 10,307 letters seeking information about winter accommodations compared to 4,640 inquiries for the same month last year.

MAXWELL ANDERSON has written and produced at least twenty-five plays. The first goes back as far as 1923 -- which was about the time when several other still-active writers for the stage began their careers. But except for Eugene O'Neill, no other serious American dramatist. corm'picuou,ly on the scene, has been writing for a significantly longer time.

THE inauguration of President Truman on Jan. 20 promises to be probably the most thoroughly covered event in television's history. Also it will be seen by more televiewers than ever before, since it will be carried as far West as St. Louis over the new coaxial cable scheduled to open on Jan. 11.

A committee of debutantes has been formed for the fifty-seventh annual production of the Princeton University Triangle Club, entitled "All in Favor," which will be presented on the evening of Dec. 23 in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria.

Despite reports last week that Seagram Distillers Corporation will re-establish business relationships with local distributors, plans for the formation of the Sea-Cal-Frank Corporation, the company-owned distributing outlet, are continuing without change, it was learned yesterday.
LODI, Calif., Dec. 11 (AP) -- In a display of razzle-dazzle football, the College of Pacific and Hardin Simmons University fought to a 35-35 tie in the second annual Grape Bowl game today.

The local entries swept both ends of last night's college basketball double-header at Madison Square Garden. St. John's slick quintet ran away from Rhode Island State, 167 -- 50, for the undefeated Redmen's fifth straight triumph after once-beaten New York University had made Georgetown its second victim by a count of 70 -- 59.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- The Gridiron Club put its own misled political experts on the griddle first tonight, then moved on with its traditional satire and fun-poking to President Truman, Governor Dewey, the Dixiecrats, Congress, and the spy hunt of the House Committee on Un-American Activities.

Recent studies on meteorites strongly indicate that these solid bodies, arriving on the earth from outer space, provide man with a cosmic Rosetta Stone that may well prove a major key to the origins of the universe, according to Dr. Harrison S. Brown, Associate Professor of Chemistry at the Institute for Nuclear Studies, University of Chicago.
A large subscription has been reported for the performance of "The Barber of Seville" on the night of Dec. 28 at the Metropolitan Opera House for the benefit of the Near East College Association.

IN his article, "The China Crisis Is a Crisis For Us," Nathaniel Peffer outlined three courses of action in China for the United States: "One is to continue as it has, frittering away money in the name of aid, which has already proved useless and must be abandoned at once.

AND now we come, ladies and gentlemen, to today's question. What celebrated Englishman stated, in a published interview, "I don't really like Shakespeare on the screen at all: the shot is too big for the camera"? No, sir, not George Bernard Shaw (although he is alleged to have said of "Henry V." "Fifteen minutes of cinema and the rest just Shakespeare").

THE HAGUE, Dec. 11 -- The breaking off of negotiations by the Dutch Government with the Republic of Indonesia this week has given rise to fears of an imminent explosion in the fabulous islands of the Dutch East Indies.

New regulations for the bareboat chartering of government-owned tonnage to American-flag steamship companies operating berth services in regular trade routes were made public yesterday by the Maritime Commission.
AN exhibition at the Museum of Modern Art of less than fifty pictures by four photographers of widely divergent points of view provides quick proof of photography's unlimited range and flexibility.

Deputy Mayor John J. Bennett and Brooklyn Borough President John Cashmore will participate in ceremonies at the laying of a cornerstone of an addition to the Long Island College Hospital, 340 Henry Street, Brooklyn, on Friday, Carroll J. Dickson, president of the hospital, announced yesterday.

In the last twenty-five seconds of play, the New York Knickerbockers defeated the Baltimore Bullets at Madison Square Garden yesterday afternoon as John Palmer's goal from the floor made the score 72-71 to the delight of 11,352 wildly cheering spectators.
Local 15 of the Bartenders Union, AFL, has filed charges of unfair labor practices with the State Labor Relations Board against forty bar owners, a union spokesman said yesterday.

GENEVA, Dec. 11 -- The governing body of the International Labor Organization concluded its 107th session here today after having approved the undertaking of important new activities in the labor field.

While the majority of prospective employers call for undergraduate students to fill positions as baby sitters, companions, office workers, salesgirls and doctors' and dentists' assistants, unusual requests like a recent call for an Italian girl to keep the bride's little brother occupied at an Italian wedding are also filled by the Hunter College Placement Bureau.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., Dec. 11 -A 14-year-old girl, Virginia Wilson, lost her life early this morning in attempting to rescue a pet dog during a fire in her home at 80 Oxford Boulevard here. The fire was discovered about 3 A.M.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Dec. 11 -- Spokesmen for the Eastman Kodak Company said here today that "the company's freedom from labor unrest and an absence of any interruption in production since 1912 stems directly from a policy of enlightened industrial relations." High up, but only a part of this policy, the spokesmen said, is a program of wage dividends.

For all practical purposes the technical knockout victory of Ezzard Charles over Joe Baksi on Friday night in Madison Square Garden complicated rather than clarified the heavyweight situation. It made uncertain, too, whether Joe Louis will undertake another defense of the crown he has been wearing for eleven years and through twenty-five title encounters.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange broke yesterday and closed at net losses of 21 to 28 points on active months.

PARENTS everywhere this Christmas will join in the fervent hope for "peace on earth and good-will to men." But to most of them the problem of maintaining peace seems far removed from the duties of child-rearing and homemaking.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., Dec. 11 -- Navy led all the way to capture a low-scoring basketball game from Harvard, 45 -- 38, at Dahlgren Hall today.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- Warren R. Austin, chief delegate of the United States to the United Nations, praised the accomplishments of the General Assembly in a statement today.

AS the greatest common denominator of all the entertainment media, reaching as it does some 70,000,000 theatregoers per week in America alone, the screen constitutes a tremendous channel of education, enlightenment and influence.

Isaac Hamlin, general secretary of the National Committee for Labor Israel, fund-raising organization for Histadrut, Israeli labor federation, announced yesterday a six-point program for the Israeli labor movement.

NEW YORKERS, who for ten years have watched a parade of parasol ants at the Bronx Zoo, each porter ant bearing a fragment of rose petal bigger than itself, can now view this pageant more easily than before. The determined little army with banners has been moved into better and larger quarters.

IT would be presumptuous for any one who has spent three days in a city to attempt a complete account of what goes on in it artistically. In so short a time one may see big things, but one may overlook subtle, hidden forces that are germinating the new ideas that will be of importance tomorrow.

PASADENA, Calif., Dec. 11 (AP) -- Compton College of California, displaying superiority in nearly every department of play, routed an outclassed Duluth (Minn.) Junior College eleven, 48 to 14, in the third annual Little Rose Bowl game before 50,638 fans.

THERE has been a second major rift in the ranks of the Lemonade Opera. After the first season Kenneth Hieber, the original musical director, broke with Max Leavitt, the managing director. Some of the singers went with him and they formed a new company entitled Opera Tonight, which came to grief after preparing "Norma" and "The Barber of Seville."

Columbia University's School of Business will be advanced to graduate status next year. Several curriculum changes have already been made, including the opening of marketing courses taught by leading retail executives and the offering of a graduate lecture series featuring talks by twenty-five business and government executives.

HELSINKI, Finland, Dec. 11 -- Finnish Premier Karl August Fagerholm said tonight that Finland would "become estranged from her Nordic neighbors" if Sweden abandoned her traditional neutrality and Scandinavia became involved in any anti-Russian bloc.

As a Westerner with a record of Thanksgiving din ners in Alaska -- where the snow really falls and sticks -- I am wondering where Grandma Moses received the inspiration for her picture ("Catching the Thanksgiving Turkey," TIMES Magazine, Nov. 21, Page 19).

CHICAGO, Dec. 11 -- Hotpoint, Inc., will introduce a completely automatic washing machine in January as the final step in its $20,000,000 post-war program of plant expansion and product development, James J. Nance, president, said today.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 11 -- The one-time plater Loriot, carrying B.L. Thomas' racing silks, scored her first stakes victory in the De Soto Handicap today before a crowd of 9,629, largest so far of the Tropical Park meeting, opening day excepted. Wagering on the eight races totaled $483,847.
BUFFALO, N.Y., Dec. 11 (AP) -- Southern Methodist's Mustangs continued their triumphant basketball tour of the East tonight by defeating Niagara, 67 -- 57, in Memorial Auditorium.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11--Soft coal production has so far out-stripped demand and cut some working schedules that the industry would not be surprised, and most of it would not be disturbed, if John L. Lewis called an extended holiday for his miners.

Barbara Ward's splendid article, "The Marshall Plan Is Not Enough," summing up the Soviet menace and how we can meet it, should be read by everyone interested in preserving our democratic society. As Miss Ward says, our difficulty in dealing with Russia is not that we do not know that "Russia regards the West with implacable hatred and will continue to do so.

Describing last week's diabetes detection campaign as "an overwhelming success," a spokesman for the New York Diabetes Association reported yesterday that one out of every fifteen of the thousands of persons who visited the test stations showed an indication of the disease.

TRADITIONALLY there have been only two excuses for turning on the radio before breakfast. The first was to learn during the winter whether the condition of the roads would prevent the school buses from carting off the younger generation for a few hours of merciful quiet.

SOME pretty, exciting events are on the current week's agenda, with both the newly arrived Mariemma and the somewhat more familiar but rarely seen Carmelita Maracci in action.(It has been two years, as a matter of fact, since Maracci was last here, and then for a single performance.)
The special police squad assigned by Police Commissioner Arthur W. Wallander to comb the waterfront for crime has been enlarged to eighteen officers and men, the commissioner announced yesterday.

Stimulated by demand for shoes in the lower price ranges and the level of hide quotations, the use of soles of plastic and other composition materials has become an important factor in the footwear industry, reports here yesterday indicated.

THE art of engraving on wood, commonly known as the woodcut, is ancient and its origins are obscure. It is not known, in fact, whether wood-engraving came to Europe from the East or was rediscovered by some continental craftsman. One of the earliest examples, dated 1418, can still be seen in the library at Brussels.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- Twelve documents produced by Whittaker Chambers to substantiate his charges that Government officials passed secret data to him while he was a Communist spy in the Nineteen Thirties were made public today by the House Committee on Un-American Activities.

RICHMOND, Dec. 11 -- Problems of public education and politics -- old familiar problems in the Upper South -- held top interest in this region this week along with reflections on communism and some budding Christmas spirit.

" L'Ecole de Ballet," masterpiece in oil by Degas, French modernist, who completed the work between 1874 and 1878, was sold for $25,000 yesterday at an auction sale of paintings and works of art to terminate the C.S. Wadsworth Trust.

ONE of the most important new plays of the month should have been J.B. Priestley's "Home Is Tomorrow," but unhappily it proved a flop -- the more unhappily because it was full of good writing and good acting.

The third General Assembly of the United Nations has unified the Western world against Russia on the issue of international control of atomic energy, Frederick H. Osborn and Gen. A.G.L. McNaughton, United States and Canadian representatives respectively, reported on arriving from Paris yesterday.

TOKYO, Dec. 11 -- Japan's first political need is greater responsibility and a sense of public service among her politicians, Ken Inukai, newly elected leader of Japan's powerful Democratic party, said in an interview today. Mr. Inukai succeeded former Premier Hitoshi Ashida as the Democrats' leader after Dr. Ashida was indicted on corruption charges.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 11(AP) -- James A. Farley and Alf M. Landon gave their views on the election results to White House reporters today after congratulating President Truman on his victory.
Christmas shopping made headway here last week, but dollar sales again fell below last year at this time. Department store sales were estimated at ranging 5 per cent below the 1947 week.

Brigadier General Carlos P. Romulo of the Philippine delegation to the United Nations Assembly remarked last week. "In this session United Nations has been on trial for its life." As the delegates turn homeward today the question naturally comes up as to how the trial turned out.
GENEVA, Dec. 11 -- The movement of displaced persons to the United States under the Displaced Persons Act of 1948 continues to lag.

PRINCETON, N.J., Dec. 11 -- Two Olympic swimming champions, Breast-stroker Joe Verdeur of La Salle and Back-stroker Allen Stack of Yale, failed in their attempts to set new international records in their specialties tonight as Princeton University dedicated its new pool in the Herbert Lowell Dillon Gymnasium with an exhibition swimming and diving meet.

American producers of aluminum, a metal now in tight supply in this country, are protesting Western Europe's utilization of the $26,000,000 provided by the Economic Cooperation Administration for purchases of aluminum.
We were much pleased to see the Juliette Gordon Low stamp included in the feature layout on this year's special stamps in THE TIMES Magazine, but regret that Mrs. Low was reported as of Scotch birth.

Pointing out that certain provisions of the Lanham Act had deterred registrants of trade marks under prior statutes from republishing the marks under the new legislation, the United States Trade Mark Association will undertake to recruit a coordinating committee to review and recommend amendments. It was learned yesterday.

NANKING, Dec. 11 -- Usually reliable Chinese military quarters said tonight that air reconnaissance had revealed the disappearance of Gen. Sun Yuan-liang's Sixteenth Army Group from the front southwest of Suchow. The remaining elements were reported to have surrendered to the Communists after this group, which originally included four divisions totaling close to 40,000 men, had lost more than one-half of its effectives.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 11 -- In his first major public appearance since the recent Presidential campaign, former Vice President Henry A. Wallace predicted here today the complete collapse of America's policy in China.

CHICAGO, Dec. 11 (AP) -- A heavy selling wave swept soy beans sharply lower and weakened grain prices on the Board of Trade today. At one time beans were down 10 cents a bushel, the limit permitted in a single session. Losses in grains were much smaller.
Radio "thrill" programs that cause sleepless nights and crime movies that incite mayhem were deplored yesterday by six junior high school students appearing on the WQXR Youth Forum.

OMAHA, Dec. 11 -- Industrial progress and various types of conservation were keynote topics at a string of heavily attended Midwest meetings this week. Meetings were held in Lincoln, Neb.; Kansas City, Mo., and Mitchell, S.D.

Expanding its offerings dealing with the causes and control of crime, New York University this term is presenting an extensive program of ten graduate courses and seminars on correctional and penal administration.

TOMORROW -- if all goes according to plan -- an ancient ceremony will be held in each of the state capitals. The 531 members of the Electoral College will gather in their forty-eight separate "state colleges" to cast their ballots for Presidential candidates. Aside from the roll-calls, there will be speeches and perhaps free meals and souvenirs.

Sub-debutante members of the Junior committee for the Brooklyn Home for Children will meet this afternoon at the home of Miss Constance Doyle, 77 Remsen Street, Brooklyn, to discuss their Christmas plans for the home. In addition to entertaining the children and arranging for their presents, the group is assisting in the sale of tickets to a Holiday Tea Dance on Dec. 29 in the Heights Casino in Brooklyn.

AS long as anti-Semitism exists in the United States, it will continue to be fair subject-matter for fiction. Bianca Bradbury's first novel "The Curious Wine" bases its plot on the anti-Jewish prejudice of a small Connecticut town, and although it says little about the problem that is new or startling, as a story it is told with commendable simplicity and competence.

A fund of $8,000 is sought by a committee of alumni of Columbia University to maintain the interfaith activities of students in Earl Hall for the current year and meet a deficit of $3,000 for last year, Daniel W. O'Connor, executive secretary of Earl Hall, said yesterday.

The big town house of the late Mrs. Orme Wilson at 3 East Sixty-fourth Street has been purchased by the Government of India as headquarters for its diplomatic representatives in New York, it became known yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 (AP) -- Reports of a heavy flow of cash to consumers made the November and early December lag in department store sales below last year's records seem strange unless price resistance by shoppers has become the strongest influence in the sales picture or shoppers are going back this year to the habit of buying at the last minute.

IN his four weeks as guest conductor of the Pittsburgh Symphony, Victor de Sabata broke all the box-office records that had been established in the orchestra's twenty-one years. The Pittsburgh Post-Gazette thereupon came out with an editorial which as much as suggested that Mr. de Sabata be engaged as the permanent conductor.

Plans for the Mid-Winter Ball in behalf of the Ellin Prince Speyer Hospital for Animals on Jan. 20 in the Terrace Room of the Plaza will be advanced when the committee in charge of arrangements meets tomorrow afternoon in the home of Mrs. Walter J. Salmon, 16 East Sixty-ninth Street.

HOLLYWOOD film producers are finding their attention drawn these days to a young Londoner, Angela Lansbury, who is exhibiting on the screen a mixture of charm and authority generally found only in a Churchill speech.

A revolutionary new low-cost British process for alloying ordinary steel surfaces with chrome to produce high temperature, wear and corrosion resistant metals is being introduced to this country. Producing materials similiar to stainless steel, the process promises to greatly increase plant capacities available to national defence, automotive and aircraft parts production, it was learned.

Crunch Adams and Desperate Smith, master and mate, respectively, of that sturdy god of the sea, the Poseidon, had to cultivate the philosophic spirit and a sense of humor to boot, by the very nature of their business, or profession, as you will.
NEW YORK CITY'S plant-a-tree campaign in observance of its golden jubilee raises the natural question: How and when should a tree be planted?

Leo Nadelmann, Swiss pianist who made his New York debut last year, returned to Town Hall late yesterday afternoon and again demonstrated that he is a musician of parts and a performer of uncommon ability.

NOW that "Force of Evil," Roberts Productions' adaptation of Ira Wolfert's novel, "Tuckers People," is set for its premiere at Loew's State on Christmas Day, Abraham Polonsky, director and co-scenarist with WoLfert on the John Garfield vehicle, is en route to Paris on further company business.

Publication of a special airmail edition of THE NEW YORK TIMES for the United Nations Assembly has been deeply appreciated by all delegations and by the Secretariat as foretold. This has really helped the work of the United Nations at a very critical time in world history.

EVERGREENS are an integral part of holiday decorations. Spreading branches over the hearth to bring prosperity and health during the coming year is an old, old custom, while the Christmas tree is a comparatively recent one.

AMERICAN film stars and French technicians are putting the finishing touches to the first post-war Franco-American productions, "The Last Port," with Maria Montez, Jean Pierre Aumont and Lilli Palmer, and "The Man on the Eiffel Tower," with Charles Laughton, Franchot Tone and Burgess Meredith.

MOST of all, it is the feeling of being alone. Food is needed, to be sure, and a roof, and, too often, medicine. But these are almost the least part. Unless there is a friend to remove the terrible loneliness, life is almost unbearable.

EVERY blue moon or two something like Mariemma happens and makes it fun once more to be a sampler of dance events. When last week's formal New York debut, at the Ziegfeld was announced, Mariemma was just another Spanish dancer.

Four children, ranging in age from 7 months to 5 years, narrowly escaped death last night in their home in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn when one of them opened five gas jets on a stove while their mother was out shopping.

The controversy over the Government's policy of supporting the market for its long-term obligations received new impetus last week, despite the recent improvement in prices. According to financial observers, the decline in pressure on the "pegs" has merely removed the immediacy of a problem which may again become acute in the near future.

Residents of Puerto Rico, receiving income from local sources, as by working there, are not subject to income taxes under the United States Internal Revenue Code. Likewise, estates of deceased residents of Puerto Rico, who were citizens of the United States and also citizens of Puerto Rico, are not taxable under the Federal Estate Tax in respect of property located in Puerto Rico.

Harold E. Stassen, president of the University of Pennsylvania, called last night for "modernized" legislation to protect American freedoms from foreign-directed agents who would sabotage and destroy this nation's liberties from within.
" WHO is greater, the Emperor or Christ?" was a favorite question of Japanese police when they quizzed suspect foreigners in Japan during the darkening days before Pearl Harbor.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 11 (AP) -- An order went out to police today to eject all gamblers from the scene of amateur and professional sports competition.

MOST physicians conversant with the great progress which has been made in the diagnosis and treatment of emotional disturbances and psychosomatic diseases in the past two decades credit Dr. Franz Alexander of the Chicago Institute for Psychoanalysis as the prime mover in this revolution of medical thought.
NORFOLK, Va., Dec. 11 (AP) -- The Quantico Marines whipped a scrappy football team representing the San Diego Marine Corps Recruit Depot, 21 to 0, today to retain their title as all-Navy champions.
World production of six of the seven main foods in the 1948-49 crop year is equal to, or better than the pre-war average, it became known yesterday.

Mrs. Gerard Donovan's The Heckler took the climactic jumper stake and with it the jumper championship last night at the conclusion of the two-day Brooklyn winter horse show before a gallery that taxed the seating capacity of the Teevan Riding Academy and spilled to standing room on one end of the riding floor.

The Committee on the Bill of Rights of the City Bar Association will present to a meeting of the association this week a report on Congressional investigations which makes seven recommendations to protect the rights of individuals called before Congressional committees of investigation, without unduly hampering the purposes of such committees.

PARIS, Dec. 11 -- John Foster Dulles of the United States thanked today press and radio correspondents who, he said, had stimulated interest in the United Nations through their accounts of proceedings at the General Assembly session.

PROVIDENCE, Dec. 11 -- It has been something of a surprise to modern residents of this colonial town to discover that the city has been paying $125 a year for a long time to have the bell of the 200-year-old First Baptist Meeting House tolled three times a day.

THE intentional production of movies so that they'll be all things to all men without ruffling anyone's feathers or violating any honored creeds is classically exampled in "Live Today for Tomorrow," a conspicuously cross-purposed drama now showing at Loew's Criterion.

As I always do, this week I read my copy of Punch, which I have sent to me regularly, and my copy of your NEW YORK TIMES Magazine within a few minutes of each other. They are my two favorite magazines and I reserve a good part of each Sunday, after church, for reading them.
OTTAWA, Dec. 11 -- Canada and Newfoundland today signed the terms of union by which the ancient British colony will become a province of Canada.

Now comes that holiday season when evergreen decks the mantel and brightens the doorway and stands in tinsel and glitter in the living room, the green of life in the midst of winter, symbol of hope and faith reborn.

Commissioner of Hospitals Edward M. Bernecker has thrown his "whole-hearted" support behind the efforts of a group of leading citizens to obtain a state medical college for Queens, it was learned yesterday.

FAYSTON, Vt., Dec. 11 -- Vermont's newest skiland, Mad River Glen on General Stark Mountain, was officially dedicated today as Gov. Ernest Gibson and a host of civic dignitaries as well as some of skiing's greatest figures, joined in the impressive ceremonies.

There's some interesting and little-known background behind the statement in "Spokesman at Chaillot" by George Barrett, which characterizes Prof. Philip C. Jessup of the United Nations as "Part dreamer * * * and yet a hard realist."

The increased number of school children in New York since the war -- 250,000 -- will require large expansion of school facilities within the next five years, Mayor O'Dwyer declared yesterday at the Youth Forum sponsored by The New York Mirror in the Astor Hotel.

DETROIT, Dec. 11 -- Pete Horeck's third-period goal cracked a 3-all tie as the Red Wings gained their sixth straight National Hockey League victory tonight, 5 -- 3, over the last-place Rangers before 13,337 fans at Olympia. Goalie Chuck Rayner was out and the New Yorkers had six skaters playing for a tie when Ted Lindsay hit an open net in the last nine seconds for the fifth Detroit goal.

Beginning today and continuing through next Saturday, National Hotel Week will be celebrated by the country's 15,000 hotels for the first time since the end of the war. Local and national programs will focus on the industry's 1948 slogan, "American Hotels -- the World's Finest."

The Ramapo polo team scored five goals in the last three minutes of play to defeat the Squadron A regulars by 17 to 13 in the feature game of an indoor double-header last night at the Squadron A Armory.

Maj. Gen. Karl F. Hausauer reviewed the Seventy-first Infantry, New York National Guard, last night while 5,000 persons watched in the regiment's armory at Park Avenue and Thirty-fourth Street. It was the first time General Hausauer had reviewed a National Guard regiment since his appointment as Commanding General of the New York National Guard.

NOW that Jean-Paul Sartre's "Red Gloves" has opened for business at the Mansfield Theatre, it is difficult to understand what all the bickering has been about. Mechanically built, composed of long arguments about abstract political ideas, it is a tiresome piece of work, redeemed only by the acting of Charles Boyer and John Dall in the two chief roles.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- The combination of continued Democratic strength in large cities and unexpected gains in rural areas gave President Truman his surprising victory over Gov. Thomas E. Dewey in the Nov. 2 elections, an analysis of final vote tabulations showed today.

Times have changed since Laurence Sterne put in his portmanteau half a dozen shirts and a black pair of silk breeches ("The coat I have on," said I, looking at the sleeve, "will do"), booked a place in the Dover stage and set off on his famous sentimental journey to France.

WHAT are "tops" in garden books this holiday season? While a number of new and unusual volumes have great merit, many of the old reliables are still available and eagerly desired by discriminating "dirt gardeners."
THE classic guessing situation in contract bridge occurs when dummy has K-J of a suit and declarer has a doubleton. Declarer leads low toward dummy.

General Clay has set Dec. 31, 1948, as the deadline for filing claims for the restitution of confiscated property in the American Zone of Germany. Claims in the French Zone must be filed before May 15, 1949, while the British have set a tentative deadline of Dec. 31, 1949.

SHANGHAI, Dec. 11 -- The fall of the Chinese Government headed by President Chiang Kai-shek is inevitable in the opinion of most Americans here. The arrival tonight of Paul G. Hoffman, chief administrator of the Economic Cooperation Administration, therefore is believed to highlight the decision facing the aid administration and the United States Government.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- The United States and Rumania each demanded today the recall of two ranking diplomats in the legation of the other country. The demands are being complied with.

PARIS, Dec. 11 -- The Rev. Michael Scott, South African clergy-man who has frequently denounced the Pretoria Government for its treatment of the natives, appealed to the General Assembly of the United Nations today to befriend the Herero tribe of South-West Africa.

A TWO-POINT program for improving the work of photographers is offered by Ansel Adams, prominent photographer and holder of a current Guggenheim Fellowship in that field, in the 1949 Annual of the Photographic Society of America, just published. Mr. Adams proposed, first, that the photographer study the work of the leading expressive photographers, both of the present and the past.

TO create may be to miss a step in a dance. To cut stone crookedly. The result of the gesture does not matter. If this effort appears futile to you as you keep your nose to the grindstone, step back. From a distance consider the activity of this part of the city.

Albert Brusilow, young Philadelphia violinist, who made his debut here the season before last, gave his second New York recital yesterday afternoon at Town Hall. He is still not a mature artist, but he has unquestioned gifts.

BRUCE BENSON often day-dreamed of a mother who would be home when school was over and a father who worked from nine to five. When his busy, famous explorer father and mother told him he was to accompany them on their next expedition to collect snakes in British Guiana, he thought he preferred to keep his place on the school basketball team, an honor won not by their fame but by his own skill.

ALTHOUGH Vincent Massey's book was undoubtedly intended primarily for Canadian reading, it developed, in the writing, a much wider interest. The author, one of the most knowledgeable of his countrymen in literature, painting and drama, as well as in public affairs, served three years as the first Canadian Minister to the United States -- and eleven years (including the whole term of the last war) as Canadian High Commissioner in London.

IN the preface to "Peter Salt," Mr. Gardner explains why he wrote the novel: "Life went along in a well-ordered way during the first few decades of the last century. We have lost confidence in the way of life our fathers trusted."

BOSTON, Dec. 11 -- As time neared for the inaugurations of new Governors in four of the six New England states, a "social rebellion" appeared in the making in New Hampshire. Governor-elect Sherman Adams and his council were reported in favor of plain business suits for the occasion.

THE plight of Broadway is something which concerns the theatre-going public as much as the professionals. As an old ticket buyer and a lover of the drama from the front side of the footlights, I should suggest that some of the trouble with the stage rests with the critics.

Cooperating with the newly founded Society for Forgotten Music, the New York Public Library will present tonight the second in a series of four concerts of little-known music. The program will be broadcast over WNYC at 8:30 P.M.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- Formulation of a strong, positive United States policy toward China, considered in the light of the march of events, looks more important than dollar aid, even when extended by the billions.

LAST week's experiment in judging at the Miniature Camera Club, with a jury consisting of two photographers and two artists, found the artists more concerned with the effectiveness of the pictures than with their technique.

NEWPORT, R.I., Dec. 11 -- Volunteer workers, unwilling to await the collection of a $50,000 building fund, have begun remodeling the old Pell Street house which will become a national Portuguese museum, the only one of its kind in America.

This is the story of the two men who have been involved in one of the strangest headline dramas of recent years. It is the story of Alger Hiss and Whittaker Chambers and of their relationship. It is far from complete because finis is not yet written and, more than that, because so much of it is shrouded in mystery and contradiction.
LONDON, Dec. 11 -- In the pub at the bottom of the road the beer drinkers put down their pints long enough to sign a petition tacked to the wall.

AMAGANSETT, L.I., Dec. 11 -- A booklet with a cover drawing of a dory with oars and gear, entitled "Amagansett Lore and Legend," is the village's final achievement in a year of celebrating the founding of East Hampton township 300 years ago. The booklet is a community-wide undertaking financed by old-timers and recently arrived writers and artists who find Amagansett's quiet elm-lined Main Street and unspoiled sand dunes just what they've been searching for.

MONTREAL, Dec. 11 ((AP) -- The Chicago Black Hawks built up a three-goal edge and coasted to a 5-2 decision over the Montreal Canadiens in a National Hockey League game at the Forum tonight. Jim Conacher and Bill Gadsby led the Chicago attack with two goals each.

In a great variety of offerings this week, the auction houses are exhibiting books, English and American period furniture and decorations, and Continental silver and gold ornaments at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 30 East Fifty-seventh Street; contemporary and old prints at the Kende Galleries, 119 West Fifty-seventh Street, and modern furniture and decorations at the Plaza Art Galleries, 9 East Fifty-ninth Street.

BUENOS AIRES -- Despite the diplomatic huzzahs with which the "Marshall Plan for Tourists" was greeted on the opening day of the Bogota conference last March, the fact remains that so far virtually nothing has been done to eliminate the kind of travel restrictions in Latin America that the Secretary of State deplored.

The Taft -- Hartley law's chief fault is that it does violence to a cardinal principle of democracy. Power placed elsewhere than in the control of the whole people is as wrong under our form of government as in a totalitarian state.

THIS place in the Ardennes, where the battle of the Bulge centered four years ago this month, is becoming an American shrine. A monument to the American dead will be completed here next spring, as well as a war museum.

Announcement by the Netherlands Government in The Hague that it is abandoning further negotiations with the Republic of Indonesia and will proceed forthwith to set up an Interim Government for the East Indies, with or without the participation of the Republic, has ominous possibilities for the future that the Security Council of the United Nations should not longer ignore.

A motherly-looking Greenwich Village matron, a personable man who described himself as a magazine writer from London and an Army veteran who has been on the police force for only five months figured yesterday in a series of hectic events that culminated in the arrest of the self-styled writer on charges of grand larceny and violating the Sullivan law.

MANHASSET, L.I., Dec. 11 -- An unexpected victory for Robert L. Gerry Jr. and Dr. Robert Millen over Alastair and Esmond Martin enabled the Long Island team to defeat New York, 2 -- 1, today in the annual Payne Whitney Memorial court tennis doubles tournament in the court of John Hay (Jock) Whitney at Greentree.

CANNES -- The winter season on the French Riviera will include this year a week-long festival on the theme "Cannes welcomes Europe and presents it to the United States." Beginning Feb. 13 Cannes will be transformed into an international music capital where the folklore of a great many nations will be displayed.

BERLIN, Dec. 11 -- The British policy of continuing trade between the British sector of this city and the Soviet zone is meeting opposition from United States economic officials, it was learned today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- The Communist victories in China will necessitate a reappraisal of the United States military position in the Far East, in the opinion of military observers. Some of the first major strategic repercussions of those victories already have made themselves felt in Washington; others will follow.

BINGHAMTON, N.Y., Dec. 11 (AP) -- Builders and contractors are using every known improved method or new material available to produce buildings under existing code requirements, a spokesman for the Building Industry Employers of New York State said today.

FOR THIS WEEK: Hill up soil around roses, even though canes are still green. Without protection, sudden cold will cause damage.... No matter how hardy established plants may be, mulch newly set-out perennials and shrubs for their first winter.... Support the foliage of freesias by inserting four bamboo stakes around the inside edge of the pot and connect with twine.

Committees of young matrons and debutantes of this season and former years are completing plans for the annual Silver Spoon Cocktail Party and Tea Dance to be given on Dec. 21 at the Stork Club.

All divisions of the wholesale apparel market here last week reported heavy fill-in orders for holiday merchandise, according to a report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell Company, resident buying office.

IN a time when too much of our art is hedged around by program and protocol, it is tonic to come on drawings by Degas. To no artist could the idea of preconceived scheme have been more remote, and few in the past hundred years have been more fascinated and stimulated by the spectacle of life itself.

BELA BARTOK'S Concerto for Orchestra was completed by the ailing composer in the fall of 1943, a couple of years before his death. Since its premiere by the Boston Symphony Orchestra under Serge Koussevitzky in December, 1944, it has won increasingly wide acceptance.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- Personal income rose to a new high in October, reaching an annual rate of $215,600,000,000, the Department of Commerce reported today.

A program of rehabilitation for the victim of multiple sclerosis, aimed "to teach him to live, and if possible to work, with what he has left" was outlined yesterday at the annual conference of the Association for Research in Nervous and Mental Diseases, at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

Contracts totaling $1,157,384 for new construction at its facilities in the New Jersey-New York area were awarded yesterday by the commissioners of the Port of New York Authority at their regular monthly meeting in the Port Authority Building, 111 Eighth Avenue.

RICHARD JEFFERIES was born exactly a century ago and died before he was 40. The editor of this volume of hitherto unpublished work, Samuel J. Looker, has devoted his life to collecting and making available Jefferies' nature writings (Jefferies also wrote novels) in order to secure for him "a lasting place among the great writers of the English genius."
SYDNEY, Australia, Dec. 11 (AP) -- The fourth conference of the United Nations Economic Commission for Asia and the Far East ended today.
PARIS, Dec. 11 -- France gave her best wishes and her best champagne tonight to the chiefs of the United Nations delegations this afternoon.

EVERY hostess has two lists. The first is the large, democratic one, consisting of those people whom she invites to cocktail parties, in order to widen her circle, to pay back obligations, or to maneuver some project.

Prices of shares on the New York Stock Exchange ended the week on a firmer note yesterday after fluctuating irregularly during the day's abbreviated session. Activity in the final hour, when prices were at their best levels, expanded trading to the largest Saturday session in a month. Sales aggregated 550,000 shares, compared with 510,000 shares a week ago.

Godfrey Kang, representing the New York Athletic Club, won two events in the New York State men's swimming championship meet at the Winged Foot pool last night. Kang, a resident of Honolulu and presently attending Rutgers University, captured the 220-yard back stroke and the 440-yard freestyle.

THE furtive science of wiretapping currently is under close legal scrutiny. The New York County Criminal Courts Bar Association has under way an investigation from the point of view of state law. The American Civil Liberties Union is conducting a nation-wide survey of police policies on tapping.

ROME, Dec. 11 (AP) -- A Senate commission reported last night that it had found no evidence to support charges that Communist Senator Gicomo Li Causi and his Sicilian supporters had made an election deal with the notorious bandit Salvatore Giuliano.

On the third floor of a wing of the Army's sprawling Walter Reed Hospital, in Washington, is a room where Secretary of State George Marshall has been a patient for almost two weeks. There is only one street door to that wing. It is carefully guarded by an M.P.

ATHENS, Dec. 11 -- Press reports from Patras today said Greek Army units that had been engaged in the north, had moved through that northern Peloponnesian port -- to the welcome of the people -- and that full-scale operations to clear the Peloponnesus of the Communist-led rebels were beginning.

CHICAGO, Dec. 11 -- As with the automobile a good half century ago, it is beginning to look as though night baseball in the majors is here to stay. Not only that, but it already provides such a substantial revenue to the over-all "gate" that anyone even remotely considering its curtailment or combating its further expansion can only be put down for an out-and-out crackpot.

EARLY winter character can be given to a foundation planting or shrub border by including a few out-of-the-ordinary plants. Three shrubs with fine foliage and fruit are particularly worth considering now for spring planting.

BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 11 -- With returns complete from seven of the fourteen provinces, there is no longer the slightest doubt that the Peronista party swept last Sunday's elections for delegates to the constitutional reform convention and other offices.
PARIS, Dec. 11 (AP) -- The final official text of the Palestine resolution adopted by the United Nations General Assembly:

OF the islands which are American Micronesia and which lie like an inverted "T" north of the Equator and between Hawaii and the Philippines, two are well known: Guam and Bikini, the former as an island legacy from our war with Spain and the second as less of a place than a thing.

After a season's absence due to illness, Maryla Jonas returned to the local concert stage yesterday afternoon at Carnegie Hall, where she was warmly welcomed by an audience which she roused to ovations after each of her many offerings.

Two leaders in the field of medical care, Dr. William B. Rawls and Louis H. Pink, reiterated last night their opposition to compulsory health insurance and a Government-controlled system of medicine. They urged continuation of voluntary cooperation between various groups of society to promote efficiency in medical treatment.

Brooklyn Law School won the final argument of a competition among law schools of nine Eastern colleges, it was announced yesterday. The debate was arranged by the junior bar committee of the Association of the Bar of the City of New York on Friday night at 42 West Forty-fourth Street.

HUMAN beings may be billed as the features on CBS' "Inner Sanctum" at 8 P.M. Monday but actually the real stars of the show don't say a word during the entire thirty minutes. They're the sound effects.

A warning that public automatic washing machines may spread disease among families who use them was issued yesterday in The Military Surgeon, official publication of the Association of Military Surgeons of the United States.

Winston Churchill, then Prime Minister of Britain, was on very good terms with Marshal Stalin of Russia in the spring of 1945, when the task of beating Germany had not been completed and the Soviet armies were moving westward toward the Reich. That is why there is peculiar interest in a letter which the British leader wrote the Russian leader then about post-war conditions in the world.

In THE NEW YORK TIMES Magazine of Nov. 28 there are some pictures of Maxwell Anderson's new play. "Anne of the Thousand Days," in which Anne is shown saying to King Henry (who thinks the baby must be a boy): "Her name's to be Elizabeth."

For the first time, makers of copper products are worried about the competition of stainless steel because of price advantages now appearing in stainless steel household and building products, industrial enginering experts disclosed here last week.

AS a postal Christmas gesture, Austria has issued a 60-groschen red stamp for the 130th anniversary of the Yuletide carol "Stille Nacht, Heilige Nacht" (Silent Night, Holy Night). Edwin Mueller received from Vienna last week a black die proof of the design.

Clearing of a section of Brooklyn characterized as a "breeder of delinquents" and its transformation into a park site was furthered yesterday. An order of Supreme Court Justice Henry L. Ughetta directed the city to pay $93,925 for twenty parcels of real estate in the area.

William F. Talbert, national indoor champion, has been placed at the head of the proposed men's singles rankings of the Eastern Lawn Tennis Association for 1948. These ratings will be submitted for approval at the annual meeting of the tennis body at the Hotel Astor on Jan 15.
PARIS, Dec. 11 (AP) -- France bluntly blamed Britain tonight for one of the snags on which European recovery planning is stuck.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Dec. 11 -Young lawyers of the New York State Bar Association were assured today that if they ever entered the armed forces in the future every consideration would be given to their legal abilities, in order that examples of misplaced talents during past conflicts might be avoided in the future.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 (AP) -- Dr. William Frederick Durand of Stanford University will be the first to receive the Wright Brothers Memorial Trophy. The award is for "significant public service of enduring value to aviation in the United States."

HERE are four Christmas books and a complete folding Christmas manger, one or more of which will bring something of the spirit of the season to any child, from the very youngest up to the age of 12. Children of any age, as well as adults, will find pleasure in assembling "The Golden Christmas Manger" into a Christmas creche.

Several dinners were given before the Military Ball of the Seventh Regiment (N.Y.N.G.) last night in the Seventh Regiment Armory, at Park Avenue and Sixty-sixth Street. It was the regiment's sixty-fifth ball and marked the revival of the series since the war.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 (AP) -- House Committee on Un-American Activities released tonight twelve of the spy inquiry's documents, containing twenty-one diplomatic messages. The committee says it believes all of the messages were filed during 1938.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Dec. 11 -- While the Palestine issue remains one of the principal problems confronting the United Nations, there are nearly three-quarters of a million Arabs who do not care much what happens as long as they can survive.
THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Dec. 11 . -- The Netherlands Government announced today that nego'tiations for a settlement with the Indonesian Republic had broken down irretrievably.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 (UP) -- President Truman said today that Americans must maintain the "virility" of their democratic heritage if they are to protect themselves against hazards from abroad.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 11 -- A higher professional outlook among engineers was advocated today at the winter meeting of the Middle Atlantic section of the American Society for Engineering Education.

JEWELL BELLUSH is preparing a study of Ernestine L. Rose (1810-82), a naturalized American who was active in such reform movements as abolitionism, universal suffrage and "establishment of international peace."

Conclusive evidence resolving the controversy among military commentators about whether Germany seriously attempted to invade England in 1940 is given in the private war journal of Col. Gen. Franz Halder that has just become available.

Urging American business to increase its investments in Cuba and expand and diversify that country's agricultural and industrial economy, Dr. Carlos Prio Socarras, President of Cuba, declared here yesterday that his administration would provide "ample facilities and security for every productive enterprise."

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Dec. 11 -- The United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization formally closed its third general conference here tonight after the unanimous adoption in plenary session of the budget and program for next year.

CHICAGO, Dec. 11 -- The Big Nine today deferred action on Michigan State College's application for membership until tomorrow, but approved a new scholarship code fixing limits on financial aid to athletes.

WHEN Rollo Walter Brown arrived at Harvard early in this century to study, nice old Cambridge ladies spoke in only-yesterday tones about "Mr." Longfellow. "Mr." Emerson's occasional visits down from Concord, and the terrible puns of Dr. Oliver Wendell Holmes, the Bob Hope of Beacon Street and father of a rising young lawyer.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Dec. 11 -- The Presidium of the Yugoslav Parliament issued today a decree establishing a Ministry of Railroads and a separate Ministry of Transport for air, river and road traffic in an effort to break the transportation bottleneck that has been retarding the rate of industrial expansion and development of Yugoslavia's internal economy under the five-year plan.

PARIS, Sunday, Dec. 12 -- A decision by the United Nations General Assembly on a joint United States, Australian and Chinese resolution on Korea was postponed until this afternoon when Dr. Herbert V. Evatt, the Assembly president, suddenly recessed the meeting at 2 A.M. until 3 P.M. today.

HOLIDAY trade last week narrowed its margin of decrease under a year ago but was still falling short of 1947 volume in spite of higher prices. The weather argument had become a little worn. Retailers, however, continued to be hopeful that a closing rush of shopping would turn the scales in their favor.

ROME, N.Y., Dec. 11 -- Television is moving closer to the Mohawk Valley. By spring a video station built to serve the Utica-Rome-Herkimer-Oneida area will begin a series of test telecasts, to be followed by a regular program schedule.

WELLESLEY, Mass., Dec. 11 (AP) -- After seventy-five years, Wellesley now has a portrait of its first student, Anne Poe Harrison of Virginia, whose tuition was paid by the sale of family silverware hidden during the Civil War.
A "Cabaret Noel" is being planned for the evening of Dec. 21 in the Sert Room of the Waldorf-Astoria, under the auspices of the New York chapter of the Sister Kenny Foundation.

CAIRO, Egypt, Dec. 11 -- The royal Cabinet disclosed today that King Farouk had transmitted a message to the Chiefs of State of all the Arab countries except Trans-Jordan declaring that the Jericho conference resolutions calling for a Palestine-Trans-Jordan merger under King Abdullah "do not represent the decision of the Palestinian people."

Assurances were given yesterday that the House Committee on Un-American Activities would accede to the demand of Federal officials and permit the special spy grand jury to view tomorrow the original microfilms secreted by Whittaker Chambers in a hollowed-out pumpkin on his Maryland farm.

An aerial duel between Charlie Conerly, the rookie sensation, and Sammy Baugh, the old master, is in prospect at the Polo Grounds today when the New York Football Giants close their 1948 campaign against the Washington Redskins.

COMMUNIST success in China highlights the fact that peasant Asia is not Main Street, U.S.A., and that Chinese peasants may embrace communism at the very same time that the American electorate eschews it. This is our basic enigma, how to maintain the American way of life in the same world with the Chinese peasant's low standard of living.

I have followed the discussion of the "Polls Versus the Election" appearing in THE TIMES with considerable interest. A recent exchange of opinion between Prof. George Smith and Cabell Phillips prompts me to make the following comments:
Columbia's basketball team won its third consecutive game last night, defeating Pratt Institute by 58 -- 24 on the University Hall court. The loss was the Engineers' first in three games.

BERLIN, Dec. 11 -- The specter of inflation in the United States-British occupation zones of Germany is haunting the Western Military Governments. Hoarding and the gray and black markets, which disappeared in the first days after the currency reform, are again commonplace.
BERLIN, Dec. 11 (UP) -- Gen. Lucius D. Clay, American commander in Germany, said today that he believed that the Russian blockade of Berlin had reached its saturation point.

A NOTABLE sculpture by Michelangelo, who is represented in our country only by drawings, will soon arrive in America. It is being lent by the Italian Government as a good-will gesture. Thus, for about a year, at the National Gallery in Washington, Americans will have a chance to see a magnificent work by the towering genius of the Renaissance.

IN times like these when the "cold war" has turned relations between America and Russia into a nightmare of distortion, invective, hysteria and old-fashioned tar-bucket propaganda a man like Soviet Citizen Kniazen is pleasant to run across.

PROBABLY not since Constantinople fell to the Turks thirty-nine years before Columbus discovered America had there been such an exodus of scholars as took place when Hitler came into power. Men world-famous for their learning suddenly found themselves homeless, disgraced, deprived of academic stature.

George D. Widener, president of the Westchester Racing Association, and Marshall Cassidy, executive secretary of the Jockey Club, will share the distinction of having contributed outstanding services to the sport of horse racing in 1948, it was announced yesterday.

CHICAGO, Dec. 11 -- The failure of local communities throughout the nation to make provisions for displaced persons was deplored today by Raymond M. Hilliard, Commissioner of Welfare of New York City.

CHICAGO, Dec. 11 -- This city by the lake was slightly football crazy today, the immediate cause of the dementia being the battle royal for all the blue chips between the two local National Football League teams, the Bears and the Cardinals.

" Tristan and Isolde," the matchless threnody in the literature of opera, was performed yesterday afternoon in the Metropolitan Opera House, before an absorbed and exceedingly responsive audience. So much is assured when this music drama is adequately presented.
PARIS, Dec. 11 -- Plenipotentiaries of twenty countries subscribed to the newly completed convention outlawing genocide when it was opened for signature here this afternoon.
SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 11 -- Although the Pearl Harbor anniversary this week turned the thoughts of the West Coast back seven years, greatest attention was on Christmas shopping.

AS a filmgoer with definite convictions about visual factors as related to cinematic production, I find the current crop of short subjects increasingly disappointing. Even in the best of them, such as "The March of Time" and "This Is America," there is a curious reluctance to permit the camera to tell the major share of the story.

ALBANY, Dec. 11 -- Governor Dewey is expected to ask the trustees of the State University to approve plans to set up under the university system an upstate medical center specializing in research and treatment of chronic illness, a top administration source said today.

Retail activity, stimulated by higher sales in all gift departments and main floor hat bars, moved at a faster pace here last week compared with previous weeks, according to a survey made especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Meyer Both Reports.

ISRAEL'S plans to popularize its postal paper among the world's philatelists were outlined by Zvi Prihar, the new State's Postmaster General, at a luncheon given in his honor by stamp club officers, stamp dealers and philatelic writers last week at the Waldorf-Astoria.

The big new fact in the Hiss-Chambers case is this: In the late Thirties more than 200 secret papers were stolen from the American State Department and copied for transmission to a foreign power -- Soviet Russia.

The nation's capital ought to be a show-place, not merely of monumental architecture but of democratic virtues and practices -- those intangible structures without which the marble front of the Republic means little. Unhappily, Washington is, in this respect, still defective.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 11 -- Yale University, a strong contender for the Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball League title, easily defeated Pennsylvania tonight by 72 -- 60 for its second victory of the season and its first in the loop. Yale was never headed and led by 21 points three minutes before the end of the game when Coach Howard Hobson sent in his reserves.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Dec. 11 -- In a slashing attack on American foreign policy, Sumner Welles, former Under-Secretary of State, charged here tonight that the Government was paying "lip service" to the United Nations while turning over to "the military" an "increasing measure of control" of our affairs in Europe.

ALTHOUGH constitutional experts of Western Germany have gathered at the pleasant university town of Bonn on the Rhine to write a constitution for the West German State and Russian political strategists and their German Communist allies have fashioned a similar document for "all Germany" amid the fading splendors of Potsdam, Germany's future is being forced in neither place, but in the gray haze-hung valley of the Ruhr and in the battered streets of Berlin.
