BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 11 -- The Government press campaign to play down Dr. Juan Atilio Bramuglia reached its most revealing point today when neither the Government morning papers, Democracia and Mundo, nor any of the four afternoon papers printed a line on the Foreign Minister's twenty-minute talk with President Truman.

Two middle-aged women were rescued from a fire in a three-story frame dwelling at 343 Seventeenth Street, Brooklyn, yesterday afternoon by two patrolmen cruising in the neighborhood in a radio car who were at the scene before the Fire Department.

Proposed legislation for the rehabilitation of alcoholics, recognizing alcoholism as a disease rather than as a crime, has been drafted jointly by committees of the Association of the Bar of the City of New York and the New York Academy of Medicine for introduction into the State Legislature, it became known yesterday.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., Dec. 11 -- Play in the open team-of-four event of the twenty-second annual contract bridge tournament ended early today, with the 1948 championship being won by the Canadian-American combination of Miss Charlotte Sidway and Mrs. Ralph Gordon, Buffalo, Bruce Elliot and George Boechk, Toronto. They won forty-five of their seventy-two matches.

LAKE SUCCESS, Dec. 11 -- Delegates and staff members, rushing home from the United Nations Paris meeting in time for Christmas, will find that their headquarters in this country has undergone some sizable alterations, officials said today.
LOS ANGELES, Dec. 11 -- The twin eternals, weather and war, were topics of prime interest in the Pacific Southwest this week.

Green Bus Lines, Inc., has been granted an additional one-cent fare increase effective today, raising the interim rate to 7 cents, the Public Service Commission announced yesterday. The company operates various routes in Queens.
SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, Dec. 11 -- An invasion of Costa Rica was launched today from Nicaragua by opponents of Provisional President Jose Figueres, who immediately mobilized the country.

SOUTH HADLEY, Mass., Dec. 11 -- Pledges totaling $1,038,100 have been made in Mount Holyoke College's current campaign for $2,000,000, Miss Gertrude V. Bruyn, field secretary, reported today. Included in the amount, which was announced at the semi-annual meeting of the Central Fund-Raising Committee of trustees, administration, faculty, student and alumnae, are pledges of $723,200 from alumnae and of $314,900 from other sources.

Message volume of the Western Union Telegraph Company during October continued depressed by the "super-luxury" war tax of 25 per cent which is still being levied on even emergency telegrams, the company announced yesterday. Sales of services to the public, it reported, declined to $15,535,276 from $16,012,733 in September and from $17,366,051 in October, 1947.

With increased emphasis being directed toward economy of store operation by recent disappointments in retail sales, acute business observers showed interest last week in "unexpected" volume recorded at the new Macy Flatbush store, opened more than a month ago.

MATTAMUSKEET, N.C., Dec. 11 -- This is a happy hunting ground of the wildfowler, for, while the law has placed a drastic limitation on the number of geese he may shoot, it cannot prevent him from sitting in a blind and watching the garrulous echelons of geese flying overhead.

PARIS, Dec. 11 -- Delegates to the third regular session of the United Nations General Assembly will start leaving for home after today with an uneasy realization that something has gone wrong with the organization.

LONDON, Dec. 11 (Reuters) -- Derby County went down to surprise defeat before Stoke City, 4 -- 2, in the first division of the English Football League today. Beaten in only two other games this season, the league's top team took a 2-1 lead in the first half on the Stoke field.

CAMP KILMER, N.J., Dec. 11 -- For the third time in less than a year more than 500 officers and men of the Seventy-seventh Infantry Division joined here today in a command post exercise based upon actual combat conditions of World War II.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., Dec. 11 -- The Society of the National Shrine of the Bill of Rights announced today it would celebrate the 157th anniversary of ratification of the bill at 8 P.M. Wednesday here in St. Paul's Church, national shrine of freedom of press and the Bill of Rights.

ONE-MAN shows of recent work by three of our most widely known American artists opened last week. At An American Place are oils and water-colors by John Marin; at Frank Rehn's are oils, temperas and compositions in Chinese inks by Reginald Marsh; and at the Downtown Gallery are watercolors by William Zorach.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- The acrimonious dispute between the United States and France over the future of German industry has inspired criticism of the State Department for failing to exert stronger control over the direction of our German policy.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Dec. 11 -- More than 6,000 people representing a million and a quarter farm families in forty-five states and Puerto Rico will attend a series of national meetings headed by the annual convention of the American Farm Bureau Federation starting tomorrow in Municipal Auditorium.

As the period before Christmas narrowed down to a thirteen-day interval, activities were stepped up yesterday in Yule parties, festive decoration of the city, increased holiday musical programs and facilities for taking care of the needy.

THERE must, of course, be a plum pudding for the Christmas feast, heavy with fruit, steaming hot, blazed the last moment with a ladleful of brandy. And to sauce it? Custom says hard sauce, butter and sugar creamed together with a dash of brandy or rum.

Concern over layoffs in the Stamford-Greenwich section in Connecticut became serious enough last week to bring a call for a meeting tomorrow. This situation has been duplicated in some other manufacturing centers. Inquiry here, however, developed that the layoffs meant only a reduction from peak operations and an approach to normal pre-war schedules.

GENOA -- For the first time since the war an American flag service is now carrying passengers between the United States and the Italian Riviera. One of the American Export Lines' "Four Aces" leaves New York every other week and calls at Genoa, which is the natural base for vacationists on the Riviera di Ponente and the Riviera di Levante.

Evidence that faulty metabolism (utilization) of cholesterol, a fatty substance found in egg yolk, nerve tissue and other substances, may play an important role in the causation of heart disease and hardening of the arteries, leading diseases of Western peoples, is presented in The American Heart Journal by Drs. Ernst P. Boas, Albert D. Parets and David Adlersberg of the Mount Sinai Hospital, New York City.

Many members of society have subscribed to the performance of "Kiss Me, Kate," a new musical, on the night of Jan. 3 at the Century Theatre, which has been taken over by members of the New York City Hospital Visiting Committee of the State Charities Aid Association to raise funds for the organization.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- Dr. Edwin G. Nourse, chairman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers, assured an audience of business men and industrialists today that the Administration was insistent upon a balanced budget and did not "contemplate a reckless spending program."

Since the inception of this column, three years ago this week, continual emphasis has been placed on the need for the establishment of civilian rehabilitation centers to provide the third phase of medicine, that trains for productivity.

Evidence that faulty metabolism (utilization) of cholesterol, a fatty substance found in egg yolk, nerve tissue and other substances, may play an important role in the causation of heart disease and hardening of the arteries, leading diseases of Western peoples, is presented in The American Heart Journal by Drs. Ernst P. Boas, Albert D. Parets and David Adlersberg of the Mount Sinai Hospital, New York City.

The famous old sloop-of-war, St. Mary's, known at one time as the fastest ship in the United States Navy, sailed the seas again last week -- at least in the memories of a group of "old-timers" who marked the fortieth anniversary of her scrapping with a dinner at Fraunces Tavern.

The Neediest put their trust in the social workers -- for it is their skilled training, education, insight and human understanding which often works the "magic," turning them from hopelessness to new courage and new life. Like nursing and teaching, social work is a recognized profession today, the social workers of the seven private agencies which participate in this Appeal holding Master of Science degrees from graduate schools of social work.

Many members of society have subscribed to the performance of "Kiss Me, Kate," a new musical, on the night of Jan. 3 at the Century Theatre, which has been taken over by members of the New York City Hospital Visiting Committee of the State Charities Aid Association to raise funds for the organization.

Since the inception of this column, three years ago this week, continual emphasis has been placed on the need for the establishment of civilian rehabilitation centers to provide the third phase of medicine, that trains for productivity.

THE hotel room was hot. The debate was hotter. Fifty of the most influential leaders in the American Federation of Labor were gathered in Chicago to decide what they should do in the national elections.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 11 -- The most comprehensive children's recreational program in the South is being completed in this city at a construction cost of $1,000,000. It has provided nine new free swimming pools and sixty-one play centers.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 11 (AP) -- Little Muhlenberg College ended a five-year jinx tonight turning back previously undefeated Temple, 46 to 40, in the second game of a basketball double-header before 7,082 at Convention Hall. Unbeaten St. Joseph's College upset highly-rated Oklahoma A. M., 46 to 43, in the opener.
THE thought-provoking article by Emil Hauser on chamber music in THE TIMES of Nov. 21 will, no doubt, arouse sympathetic interest in every string player, be he professional or amateur.

The annual meeting of the Association for Research in Nervous and Mental Diseases was held last week to report on a year's study on multiple sclerosis, the disease of the central nervous system, which Dr. Thomas M. Rivers, director of medical research of the Rockefeller Institute, characterized as the "number one neurological problem of today."

Eight of the ten selected players received All-America certificates as the second day of the sixty-sixth annual meeting of the United States Intercollegiate Lacrosse Association closed last hight at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

Rising procurement of clothing by the Armed Forces has not received adequate attention as a factor that may well serve as a stabilizing force in the men's clothing industry during the coming year, according to views in trade quarters here yesterday.
HELSINKI, Finland, Dec. 11 (AP) Finland has shut down two plays in Helsinki theaters at the suggestion of Russia, which described the plays as "hostile to the Soviet Union."

An addition of 800 tons a month to the industry's total monthly output of 40,000 tons of cast iron soil pipe is being made by the Consolidated Foundry and Machine Company, New Castle, Pa., K. Bert Bowman, president, disclosed yesterday.

Four hundred pounds of Christmas toys collected by the Girl Scouts of Greater New York were loaded aboard a Frankfort-bound plane yesterday for distribution by the American Friends Service Committee in Frankfort on the Main, Germany.

The performance of Sonja Henie's Hollywood Ice Revue on the evening of Jan. 24 in Madison Square Garden will benefit the Carroll Club, Inc., the proceeds to be devoted to the club's welfare and volunteer activities for more than three thousand self-supporting Catholic girls in the Greater New York area.

WOMEN live longer than men. Even to mention such a thing is flying in the face of all the ancient male lore about the "weaker sex," but there it is. The United States Public Health Service says so, and its vital statistics are more reliable than the self-satisfying maxims contrived by male wits.

LIMA, Peru -- The new million-dollar international air terminal at Limatambo -- a Quechua Indian word meaning "Lima resting place" -- is unquestionably one of the finest in the hemisphere and should do a great deal to help Peru's tourist program.

Going a step beyond the "sanity code" provisions adopted by the National Collegiate Athletic Association last January, the Eastern College Athletic Conference yesterday completely outlawed financial aid to athletes, as such.

PARIS, Dec. 11 -- Despite the political disagreements that featured the Paris Assembly of the United Nations, some notable and great achievements were registered here, Dr. Herbert V. Evatt said in an interview reviewing the work of the session.

Cross currents of opinion on economic conditions held the attention of financial observers last week. The principal target was business profits, although the readjustment in industry to post-war realities through cut-backs in employment also contributed to the confusion.

Although improvements have been made in the teaching profession during the past year, there are still 100,0O0 elementary and high school teachers in this country on emergency substandard certificates, a nation-wide survey conducted by the National Education Association has disclosed.
THE Rev. Edgar DeWitt Jones, who in the past thirty-eight years has delivered over 1,000 sermons on Abraham Lincoln, now adds a book to his labor of love.
BY Dec. 31 American publishers will have produced about different book titles. This is at the blood-curdling rate of one new title (or new edition) every hour of every day throughout the year.

SANTA FE, N.M. -- This season brings the opening of the Aspen Basin ski run in the Big Tesuque recreational area of the Santa Fe National Forest, eighteen miles north of Santa Fe at the foot of Lake Peak in the Sangre de Cristo Mountains.

HOLLYWOOD'S self-appointed counselors turned their ire upon Rita Hayworth last week in the wake of her refusal to play the title role in "Lona Hanson" at Columbia, a decision which resulted in the star's suspension from salary by the studio.

IN considering a work of fiction it is almost a necessity, these days, for the reviewer to make an initial discrimination: is the book to be considered as a serious novel (does it offer an illumination of human experience), a timely one (does it elucidate the contemporary situation), or purely as a "pass time," a diversion?
LONDON, Dec. 11 -- Britain suffers from an entirely unnecessary newsprint "famine," Edgar Granville, Liberal member of Parliament, said in a speech at Suffolk tonight.

IN the vicinity of Broadway there is a growing feeling these days in some quarters that angels sometimes have horns and smell slightly of sulphur. This is a sure indication that for the first time this decade the boys and girls whose cash brings script, actor and theatre together are now on the long end of supply and demand.

The only Knickerbocker Assembly for this season will be held Dec. 30 in the main ballroom of the Ritz-Carlton, traditional locale of the fetes for many years. The dances, governed by a committee of patronesses, have as subscribers young women who made their debuts in the last few seasons.
CHICAGO, Dec. 11 (AP) -- John T. McCutcheon, noted Hoosier-born cartoonist now in retirement, was honored today at a luncheon celebrating the publishing of a complete book of his work.

PARIS, Sunday, Dec. 12 -- The United Nations General Assembly, which had set up late yesterday a Conciliation Commission to attempt to work out a permanent settlement in Palestine, early today named the United States, France and Turkey to the Commission.
Admission to the United Nations was urged as a Christmas gift for Israel by Rabbi Louis I. Newman in a sermon yesterday in Temple Rodeph Sholom, 7 West Eighty-third Street.
LONDON, Dec. 11 (Reuters) -- All Britain's shipping losses during the last war will have been replaced by the time present building and orders in British shipyards have been completed.
A spirit of aggression, screened by caution, is developing in the $16,000,000,000 private electric utility industry.

Speculators and ticket offices usually have the best seats in the house of any recognized hit. I will not pay a premium to buy a ticket when it should be available at the box office at the theatre. Very often I stay away from certain shows because of the unavailability of seats in the orchestra.

LONDON, Dec. 11 -- The problem of unofficial strikes will be dealt with in Parliament next week when Sir John Graham Kerr, Conservative member from the Scottish Universities, will ask for the establishment of some sort of "supreme court" where disagreements between employers and employes can be settled.

King Peter of Yugoslavia performed the traditional "breaking of bread" ceremony in honor of St. Andrew the Apostle yesterday at the Serbian Orthodox Cathedral of St. Sava, 15 West Twenty-fifth Street. Queen Alexandra and their son, 3-year-old Prince Alexander, also took part in the ceremony, which is in honor of the patron saint of the royal family of Yugoslavia.

Where the cultivation of the inner life is concerned, Americans are "without aptitudes and skills," the Rev. Dr. Robert James McCracken, pastor of the Riverside Church, 122d Street and Riverside Drive, said in his sermon yesterday morning.

As the Food and Agriculture Organization has consistently supported the conclusion of an international wheat agreement, I cannot refrain from commenting on the criticisms you advance against such an agreement in your issue of Dec. 6. The more so because there was very strong support at the recent FAO conference for such an agreement from the vast majority of the fifty-seven nations represented at the conference.

CAMP KILMER, N. J., Dec. 12 -- Five hundred officers and key enlisted men of the Seventy-Seventh Infantry Division, Organized Reserve Corps, completed a three-day command post exercise here today with general agreement that the exercise had provided beneficial reserve training.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 (AP) -The National Guard has room for more than 16,000 officers under its large-scale expansion program.
Harry P. Obermeyer has been appointed to the executive staff of Breinig Brothers, Inc., Hoboken paint manufacturer. He was formerly president of Affiliated Paint Company, Inc., Brooklyn.

PEIPING, China, Dec. 12 -- The Communists took over today the main coal-producing area seventy miles northeast of Tientsin. They walked into the town of Linhsi, center of the three largest coal mines in North China, unopposed, at shortly after noon today.
The New York Teachers Guild, AFL, in a report released yesterday, sharply criticized and rejected the Board of Education's proposed Code of Ethics for the city's teaching profession.

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 12 -- The steel industry's rate of production of ingots last week was unchanged at 100.5 per cent of rated capacity for the nation. There may be some variations over the next few weeks but they will be insignificant and will not represent a trend, according to information in this steel center.

If the spirit of Jesus Christ is to encircle the world, that spirit must be free of narrowing limits, the Rev. Dr. Frederick May Eliot, president of the American Unitarian Association, declared yesterday at the morning service of the Unitarian Church of All Souls, Lexington Avenue at Eightieth Street.

Most of us are under the impression that this nation chose a President on Nov. 2. As a matter of fact, we did; but not as a matter of law. The actual election will take place today, when 531 members of the Electoral College, meeting in the capitals of the forty-eight states, will mark and sign their ballots.

STOWE, Vt., Dec. 12 -- The Mount Mansfield ski development, one of the nation's pioneer centers which today compares favorably with the best in the world, has a definitive appeal for every type of runner -- downhill, slalom and cross-country.

Adolf Busch and Rudolf Serkin have not missed a season with the New Friends of Music in the last nine years, and so they were greeted like old friends when they stepped on the stage of Town Hall late yesterday afternoon to provide the organization's seventh concert of the current series.

CHICAGO, Dec. 12 -- The week-end brought a statement on a national voluntary prepaid health insurance plan and a comment on behalf of the American Medical Association in the controversial field of medical economics.

Ardent support given by a number of trade associations during the Eightieth Congress to a bill requiring the Federal Trade Commission to try its cases in the District Courts was reported here last week to have diminished considerably among members of one group.

PARIS, Dec. 12 -- The United Nations General Assembly ended the first part of its third session today by implicitly condemning Soviet tactics and policy in Korea. It approved by 48 votes to 6 with one abstention, a United States, Chinese and Australian resolution recommending the recognition of the Government established in Seoul as the only legitimate Government of the Republic of Korea.

THE obituary notices on Frank Bowerman, the old Giant catcher, carried some slightly garbled information and there has been a considerable stream of mail into this office on the subject, some in curiosity and some in correction. By way of satisfying all the customers at once, we hereby turn the use of the hall over to the noted baseball historian, Fred Lieb, an acknowledged authority.

ABERDEEN PROVING GROUND, Md., Dec. 12 -- This 75,000-acre, $100,000,000 installation, probably the greatest proving ground in the world, is still echoing to the thunder of exploding bombs and shells and the rattle of small arms fire as the Ordnance Department on the Army tests the weapons and equipment of our expanding land forces.

CHICAGO, Dec. 12 -- Business activity in textiles, clothing, leather goods, alcoholic beverages, amusements, industrial expansion, home appliances and a few other lines is declining from post-war peaks, the Credit Policy Commission of the American Bankers Association said today.

Leon Henderson tendered his resignation as chairman of the Americans for Democratic Action, to become effective Jan. 15, at a meeting of its national board yesterday at the Hotel Astor. Mr. Henderson explained that he intended to go to Europe soon and that his absence from the country and the pressure of private business made it impossible for him to continue as chairman.

Prominent among the art events opening today are an exhibition of recent graphic work by European and American contemporaries at the Buchholz Gallery and the Clay Club's annual retrospective "Sculpture of the Year."

BOSTON, Dec. 12 (AP) -- Rookie winger Ray Ceresino's first National Hockey League goal gave the Toronto Maple Leafs a 4 -- 3 victory over the Boston Bruins tonight before 13,900 fans at the Boston Garden. It came with less than three minutes to play and enabled the Leafs to score their second one-goal triumph over the Bruins in their 24-hour home-and-home series.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Dec. 12 -- The Jerusalem commanders of Israel and the Trans-Jordanian Arab Legion agreed today to open the Bethlehem road at Christmas time. Aside from its religious aspects, which will be appreciated by Christians throughout the world, this move indicates clearly a willingless on both sides to revert in some measure to confraternity.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 (AP) -- The National Military Establishment tonight announced formation of a board of prominent doctors to advise the armed forces about medical policies and programs.

The eight airlines that have been deadlocked with the Port of New York Authority over leases made with the City in 1943 for the use of New York International Airport at Idlewild, and over practices at La Guardia Field, have decided to take their case to the courts, they announced yesterday.

Whittlesey House has signed a contract for the American rights of the book by the 1948 Nobel Prize winner, Prof. P. M. S. Blackett of the University of Manchester, England. It will be issued here in February under the title, "Fear, War and the Bomb," with the British title, "Military and Political Consequences of Atomic Energy," as a subtitle.

The New York Heart Association announced yesterday the appointment of Ford C. Frick, president of the National ]aseball League, as general chairman o! its 1949 fund-raising campaign. The goal for the campaign, which will start on Feb. 14, has been set at $1,000,000.
CRAB ORCHARD LAKE, Ill., Dec. 12 (AP) -- Stoneybroke Sheer Bliss won the national English springer spaniel field trials, it was announced today.
MIAMI BEACH, Fla., Dec. 12 (UP) -- Princess Eristavi-Tchitcherine, former actress Lucy Cotton, died in a hospital here tonight, apparently from an overdose of sleeping tablets, police reported.

While declining to give details on the results, John M. Murtagh, Commisioner of Investigation, made known yesterday that he had questioned twenty persons in the last week, mainly operator officials, in connection with the city's investigation of crime along the waterfront.

The annual $1,000 Mordecai Ben David prize of Yeshiva University was awarded last night to Dr. Isaac Halevi Herzog, chief rabbi of Palestine, at a dinner at the Hotel Astor. The affair marked the twentieth anniversary of the founding of the university's college of liberal arts and sciences.

Analee Camp, 'cellist, gave a recital yesterday afternoon at Times Hall. With Ernst Bacon, composer-pianist, at the keyboard, the gifted young artist presented an unusual and interesting program containing several works which received their first performance.

MANHASSET, L. I., Dec. 12 -- The Payne Whitney Memorial court tennis doubles tournament was won by Long Island today with a 2-1 victory over Philadelphia in the final round. By the same score, Long Island had defeated New York and Philadelphia eliminated Boston yesterday.

CAIRO, Dec. 12 -- The Council of Ulemas (scholars) of El Azhar University, highest spiritual authority in the Moslem world, issued a proclamation today warning that if King Abdullah of Trans-Jordan proclaimed himself King of Palestine, he would violate the pledge he had made to Allah.

The performance of "As the Girls Go," the new musical comedy with Bobby Clark and Irene Rich in the leading roles, on the night of Jan. 11 at the Winter Garden has been taken over by the Foster Homes Division of the Labor Zionist Committee for Relief and Rehabilitation, Inc., to raise funds to further the organization's work among Jewish war orphans.

The anticipated passing duel between the veteran Sammy Baugh and Charles (Chuck) Conerly of the Giants took place at the Polo Grounds yesterday, but it was Slingin' Sam who took the honors as the Washington Redskins beat the New Yorkers, 28 to 2, in the final game of the National Football League season for both teams.

Kirsten Flagstad gave a recital last night before a cheering audience which left few empty seats in Carnegie Hall. Outside, before the event began, the picket-line which seems to have permanently appended itself to the Norwegian soprano bore placards urging concertgoers not to enter.

GENEVA, Dec. 6 -- In its first official half year the European Recovery Program has established itself as an effective method of countering the immediate challenge of communism in the West. As a staying operation preventing a decline in European production, a breakdown of intra-European trade and the collapse of consumption standards, ERP is a demonstrated success.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 12 (AP) -- Tommy Thompson tossed four touchdown passes today as the Eastern Division champion Philadelphia Eagles tuned up for next week's National Football League play-off with a 45-to-21 victory over the Detroit Lions.
CHICAGO, Dec. 12 (AP) -- Michigan State College today was granted membership in the Western Conference, making the powererful athletic league the "Big Ten" again.

The career and character of the late Chief Justice Charles Evans Hughes were extolled at a meeting held in his memory yesterday afternoon at the House of the Association of the Bar of the City of New York, 42 West Forty-fourth Street.

Activity in the wholesale apparel market here last week centered mainly on last minute holiday fill-ins and reorders, according to reports prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices. Despite the cautious buying which has prevailed in all divisions of the market and dampened prospects for a record year, one buying office estimated that Christmas sales so far were fairly close to last year's record high.

ZURICH, Dec. 12 -- To gain time the France-Swiss trade and payments agreement of July 29, 1947, which, after having been extended once, expired on Nov. 20, has been prolonged again until Feb. 28, 1949.

HAVANA, Cuba, Dec. 12 -- President Carlos Prio Socarras told the Cuban people late today that he had found understanding and sympathy for Cuba's economic problems in the United States and was highly satisfied with his visit there.
LONDON, Dec. 12 -- In London the political wind now seems to be blowing in the direction of de facto British recognition of the State of Israel.

FORT WAYNE, Ind., Dec. 12 (AP) -- Fort Wayne's three tall performers fouled out in the last six minutes tonight and New York's Knickerbockers went on to defeat the Pistons, 89 -- 78, in a Basketball Association of America game marred by a fight between players. About 3,100 fans attended.

Shower curtains in fresh new designs -- many of them handpainted on plastic film -- are now available to give a decorative pick-up to bathrooms. Deep colors and metallics add to the wide choice. Plain taffetas in colors often used in bedroom ensembles and pastel Fleece-nap curtains made of rubber with a suede-like finish have returned in ample supply.

LONDON, Dec. 12 -- Seasonal influences are making themselves felt in the stock markets here. The turnover of securities has dropped again to its mid-summer low level, while usual year-end selling of holdings to put annual balance sheets into a more liquid position has tended, together with lack of support, to weaken prices.

That was a nice little story about the lady whose telephone number was two digits removed from that of a store-sponsored Santa Claus. At first surprised, then irritated by the constant wrong-numbering, she demanded an explanation of the telephone company. Her number ended in 3 instead of 1 and childish fingers were too rapturous with anticipation and minds too atingle with Santa-slanted sales talk to bother with accurate dialing.

The Spanish dancer, Mariemma, who made her local debut last week in distinguished style, last night gave her second and last recital of the season at the Ziegfeld Theatre, and proved herself to be just as charming and gifted an artist as she had seemed on first seeing.

PARIS, Dec. 12 -- Robert Schuman, Foreign Minister, has gone to the Saar to examine the results of the economic union of that region with France. It is in fact just a year since the French franc was substituted for the Saar mark, which had been created in June, 1947, to replace the former reichsmark.

It is appropriate that the first award of the Wright Brothers Memorial Trophy should be made to another pioneer in the field of flight, Dr. William Frederick Durand, now in his eighty-ninth year. Dr. Durand has been selected to receive the trophy because of his "significant public service of enduring value to aviation in the United States."

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., Dee. 12 -- The twenty-second annual national contract bridge championships neared completion here today as surviving contestants went into the semi-final round of the open pairs championships.

It is a tribute to the memory of the late Governor Alfred E. Smith and to the diligence of many state and city officials who worked with him and carried on after him that Robert Moses, New York City Construction Coordinator, can now report to Mayor O'Dwyer that railroad grade crossings in the city "will soon be a memory and before long will be entirely forgotten."

NEW DELHI, India, Dec. 12 -A definite indication that India would abandon her dominionhood, but would retain some other type of relationship with the British Commonwealth of Nations, was given tonight by the high command of India's governing political party.

Details never before published on the diplomatic maneuverings of Nazi Germany and Soviet Russia between the signing of the Stalin-Hitler pact and the German attack on Russia are given in the private war journal of Col. Gen. Franz Halder, which has just become available. General Halder was Chief of Staff of the German Army High Command.
HAVANA, Dec. 12 -- A law forcing landowners to lease tillable land and regulating sharecropping has just gone into effect in Cuba.

CHICAGO, Dec. 12 -- With only one player deal completed since these baseball conclaves got under way in Minneapolis last week, the sixteen clubs of the two major loops tonight were desperately looking for something to break the deadlock as they prepared to open their own three-day session tomorrow.

Charges by union witnesses in Washington that the textile industry is curtailing production for the purpose of maintaining high price levels "are completely without foundation" and the facts reveal exactly the opposite situation, it was declared over the week-end by W. Ray Bell, president of the Association of Cotton Textile Merchants of New York.
Divorce is not justified by any circumstance of marriage, however "painful or brutal," the Rev. Anselm Leahy declared yesterday in his second Advent sermon at St. Patrick's Cathedral.

Hearing but the major part of the program given by the Society for Forgotten Music last night in the New York Public Library, one asked whether the society had been as successful in the compilation of this program as it had in the first one of its season.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -- President Truman will soon be urged to mobilize his Cabinet into a series of high-level committees and form an "executive secretariat" to help formulate and coordinate the foreign and domestic policies of the nation.

Municipal issues scheduled for sale this week amount to $34,701,834, compared with $37,158,300 last week, according to The Daily Bond Buyer. The weekly average of offerings for the year to date is now $61,494,548.

Even though the drys were defeated in the national election last month, the liquor industry must prepare itself for the national test of dry strength which will come soon after Congress convenes in January, Admiral F. E. M. Whiting, USN (Ret.), president of Licensed Beverage Industries, Inc., declared yesterday.
PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., Dec. 12 -- Forty boats turned out for today's frostbite regatta on Manhasset Bay and had lively going in a brisk southwest wind that faded toward sundown.

Thirty lighted memorial Christmas trees lining Park Avenue from Thirty-fourth to Ninety-sixth Streets were lighted last night in memory of the members of the American armed forces who fought for peace and freedom.

Maj. Aubrey Eban, Israeli representative to the United Nations, maintained yesterday that Israel was determined to effect an alliance with the Arab world "for the advancement and stability of the Middle East" and would continue efforts for admission to the United Nations.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Dec. 12 -- The Arab states are facing a crisis in their relations with each other as the Trans-Jordanian Parliament prepares to meet tomorrow on the question of uniting Arab Palestine with Trans-Jordan under King Abdullah's rule.

As soon as Joseph M. Hyman, producer of "Make Mine Manhattan," obtains a breathing spell from the arduous task of preparing his revue for the road, he'll swing into action with the delayed presentation of the Edward Chodorov comedy, "Signor Chicago," it became known yesterday.

The fifteenth annual meeting of the National Association of Stevedores will open this morning in the Pennsylvania Hotel for a one-day session. The main topic still will be the "overtime on overtime" dispute that resulted principally from a decision last June by the United States Supreme Court ruling out premium pay as overtime compensation.
Bishop Titus Lowe of Indianapolis, executive director of the Methodist Committee for Overseas Relief, advised the Christian world yesterday morning to reject "peace at any price."
CHICAGO, Dec. 12 -- Jimmy Conzelman's Cardinals today became champions of the Western Division and will meet the Eagles in Philadelphia next Sunday for the National Football League crown.

Preparations for the annual Christmas music programs at St. George's Protestant Episcopal Church, on Styvesant Square, were proceeding yesterday under George W. Kemmer, organist and choirmaster. The Christmas season will be his twenty-fifth in the parish.

The refusal of the Supreme Court to issue an injunction in the case of the Alabama Presidential electors is good news to all supporters of democracy in this country -- including those who in the last election favored President Truman's victory.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -- Export and other controls over the distribution of scarce materials should be continued by the new Congress to help check inflationary effects of supply shortages, Charles Sawyer, Secretary of Commerce, said today.

WORCESTER, Mass., Dec. 12 -- Chief honors in the Worcester County Kennel Club show today went to Ch. Carillon Colin of Puttencove, black standard poodle from the Puttencove Kennels of Mr. and Mrs. George Putnam of Boston and Manchester.

The recent longshoremen's strike in this port, which caused the Cunard White Star Line to divert three of its passenger vessels to Halifax, N. S., cost the company an estimated $200,000 to handle passengers and baggage alone, it was reported yesterday.

The judges of the City Court are actively seeking their first pay rise in twenty-two years, it was announced yesterday. The salary of the office, when created by an amendment to the State Constitution in 1926, was fixed then by law at $17,500 a year, and it has remained unchanged since that time.

A team of bays with flashing hoofs drawing an old steam pumper, the warning shriek of a fire siren or the clanging of the bell in the Presbyterian Church, the excitement the time the chemical works and the match factory burned down, that was the talk yesterday, the reminiscing of men who were volunteer firemen in the days when Queens was mostly farmland.
SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 12 -- Ship operators and union officials will meet here tomorrow to complete wage readjustments for various shipboard jobs.

On the heels of publication by the House Un-American Activities Committee of a diplomatic memorandum that it says was in his handwriting, Alger Hiss, former State Department official, denied yesterday having turned over this or any other Government document to Whittaker Chambers.

To combat a steadily rising break-even point in manufacturing, management is using improved machinery, efficient application of cost controls, a drive for quality, and all-out production by employes. This is revealed in a survey of 103 manufacturers in the Cleveland area, released over the week-end by The Associated Industries.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 12 (AP) -- The Los Angeles Rams said goodby to the 1948 National Football League season today -- and to teammate Kenny Washington -- with a 31-14 triumph over the Pittsburgh Steelers before 27,967 fans.

PARIS, Dec. 12 -- Following is a tabulation of agenda items left over by the Parts session of the General Assembly to the second part of the third session which will convene in April at Flushing Meadow:

It was another week of unimportant price changes and business in the foreign exchange market, something of the pattern that has been ruling for the last month. Trading opinion for the slack was mixed, some being inclined to the belief that year-end accounts have largely been taken care of, while others pointed to the irregularly lower trend of stocks and commodities, and the slowness of capital payments.
Charley Rayner proved the difference in the Rangers' defeat of the Detroit Red Wings at Madison Square Garden last night.

Criticism of persons who stay at home and listen to the sermon over the radio instead of going to church was voiced yesterday by the Right Rev. James Pernette De Wolfe, Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of Long Island, in a sermon at the Church of St. Mary the Virgin, 139 West Forty-sixth Street.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 12 -- Warner Brothers studio has announced that Gordon MacRae and Dorothy Malone will play the leading roles in "Rise Above It," a musical version of "Brother Rat" which has been scheduled for spring production.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -- Retailers of men's clothing throughout the country believe that if better stores join in cooperative promotions of a single fashion item, consumer interest in men's wear will be increased and lagging sales stimulated, according to a survey of sixty-eight retailers issued here today by the Business Committee of the National Association of Retail Clothiers and Furnishers.
Santa Claus isn't scheduled to arrive for another twelve days, but he made a special trip this year to 5 1/2-year-old Joseph Ruotolo of 129 Cook Street, Brooklyn.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 12 -- Surging from behind to score three touchdowns in the final period, Buffalo beat Baltimore, 23 to 17, in the play-off for the All-America Conference Eastern Division title today. The Bills will meet the champion Browns for the Conference crown in Cleveland next Sunday.

Permit me to thank you for the editorial entitled "The Balkan Terror," published Nov. 24, and to comment upon the dispatches of Nov. 23 and 26 from Belgrade regarding the war crimes trial in Skoplje in which Yugoslavs were found guilty of collaboration with the Bulgarian army of occupation of the Yugoslav part of Macedonia during the last war.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 12 -- A multi-purpose pneumatic self-starter for jet and turboprop aircraft engines, a milestone in the nation's race for a superior air force, has been developed by the Navy and industrial research.

When the United Nations Assembly adopted the Declaration on Human Rights, Dr. Evatt of Australia, the Assembly's President, paid a well-earned tribute to the chairman of the commission which drafted it. She had, he said, "raised a great name to an even greater honor."
Contributions from two Latin-American Republics and thirteen states in the United States were received yesterday by THE NEW YORK TIMES Neediest Cases Fund.

CHICAGO, Dec. 12 -- Original tenders of about 2,000,000 bushels of No. 3 yellow corn on December contracts last week on the Board of Trade were largely responsible for the easiness in that grain. This grade of corn can contain up to 17.5 per cent moisture, whereas the Government will not buy corn for export with over 15.5 per cent moisture.

Their shelves filled with glittering holiday merchandise, established business men are wishing some seasonal bad will on the itinerent peddlers whose only overhead is the blue sky. Through the New York Board of Trade, 2,000 merchants yesterday asked Mayor O'Dwyer to crack down on sidewalk competition.

The state-aided program for elimination of the city's railroad grade crossings has been completed, except for two major and seven minor projects, according to a report to Mayor O'Dwyer made public yesterday by City Construction Coordinator Robert Moses.

A gentleman with extraordinarily large ears, from whose head appeared to protrude a small antenna, and who was attired in a garment not unlike a union suit, green in color, bounded into this department yesterday with the announcement that he had just arrived from Mars to make a study of certain aspects of life on this globe for the newspaper he represented, The Mars Daily Planet.

Walter Hendl conducted the Saturday night Philharmonic - Symphony concert at Carnegie Hall in a program which included the first performance of Hershey Kay's arrangement of Orlando Gibbons' Suite for Orchestra, Shostakovich's First Symphony and the Tchaikovsky B flat minor Piano Concerto, with Hilde Somer playing the solo part.

SEA CLIFF, L. I., Dec. 12 -- The Most Rev. Thomas E. Molloy, bishop of the Roman Catholic diocese of Brooklyn, officiated this afternoon at the dedication of St. Christopher's Home, a child care institution of the diocese. Msgr. Lawrence H. Bracken, diocesan director of Child Care, assisted Bishop Molloy.

A generally lower level characterized the results of trading in the domestic cotton market last week, reflecting profit taking. At the close on Saturday, active futures contracts on the Cotton Exchange were off 30 to 61 points on the week. In the previous five-day session the market registered net gains of 64 to 99 points.

CHICAGO, Dec. 12 -- Liquidation was on in the grain markets on the Board of Trade last week, lowest prices being established yesterday. Holders of December contracts sold freely and this had a depressing effect on the distant months. Support was not aggressive, although government buying of wheat and flour and corn caused small rallies at times.

SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, Dec. 12 (AP) -- Costa Rican authorities said today they had weathered the initial shock of an invasion that they maintained had been launched from Nicaragua with Communist support.

Copy testing, or the effort to organize knowledge on the elements that prompt the greatest selling action in advertisements, must be made more understandable by those now immersed in the technicalities of this field, it was urged last week by a veteran copy man.

May I add to your admirable tribute to Frank B. Noyes that of one whose great privilege it was to serve with Mr. Noyes and Adolph S. Ochs on the board of The Associated Press? No human institution can be perfect, but that fact is a constant challenge to the real leader.
Universal Bible Sunday was observed in many churches in this city yesterday.

Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt voiced the hope last night that Gen. George C. Marshall would remain as Secretary of State "for the good of the country." She arrived at La Guardia Field aboard a Trans World Airline plane from Paris, where she had attended the United Nations Assembly.

THE HAGUE, The Netherlands, Dec. 12 -- A warning that outside intervention in the dispute between the Netherlands and the Indonesian Republic might result in a weakening of the Western European structure and might diminish Western influence in the Far East was reported today to have been given by the Netherlands Government to critics of its Indonesian policy.

The hearings conducted before the Flanders committee in Washington last week were a reminder that, while labor's annual wage theme is basically unchanging, it has a variation to fit any and every occasion.

SAVANNAH, Ga., Dec. 12 -- The Governors of eleven Southern states and 150 leading educators representing Negro and white colleges in the South assembled here today to implement the country's first regional school compact.

YONKERS, N. Y., Dec. 12 -- Cardinal Spellman received an official welcome from the City of Yonkers today when he came here to preside at a pontifical mass in celebration of the centennial of the Church of the Immaculate Conception, the first Roman Catholic parish in the community.

ROME, Dec. 12 -- Pope Pius sent his "affectionate blessing" to Generalissimo Francisco Franco and to the Spanish Government at the same time that he sent it to the Spanish people today upon receiving the new Spanish Ambassador to the Holy See, Joaquin Ruiz Jimenez Cortes,

NANKING, Dec. 12 -- A new and major threat has developed for 80,000 to 100,000 Chinese Government troops that are concentrated around Pengpu. Pengpu, an important Government base 100 miles north on the railway from Nanking, has been flanked and isolated by the two Communist columns that recently crossed the Huai River, east of Pengpu.

A total of seventy-seven merchant vessels of 1,000 gross tons and over and two large dredges were on order or under construction as of Dec. 1 in private shipyards in the United States, it was announced yesterday by the Shipbuilders Council of America.
Manhattan street traffic will enter a new stage at 12:30 P.M. today when an improved signal control center will be placed in operation.

Purchase of the routes and assets of American Overseas Airlines for stock in Pan American Airways was agreed upon yesterday, the two companies announced last night. The merger agreement is subject to approval by the stockholders of both concerns and the Civil Aeronautics Board.

MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 12 (AP) -- Frank Stranahan of Toledo, Ohio, today became the first amateur golfer to win a P.G.A.-sponsored tournament this year when he bagged the $10,000 Miami open with a 72-hole score of 270.

The four-story dwelling with garden at 216 East Sixty-second Street has been sold by Stephen Hurlbut to John Gunther, the writer, in a deal negotiated by Douglas Gibbons Co. It is 18.9 by 100.5 feet and will be occupied by the new owner.

EAST LANSING, Mich., Dec. 12 (AP) -- Michigan State president John A. Hannah expressed himself as "very happy" at the decision in Chicago admitting the Spartans to membership in the Western Conference.
LEBANON, Pa., Dec. 12 (AP) -The Lebanon Steel Foundry today released detailed information on secret British-developed processes for production of super-alloy steel castings for aircraft jet engines.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -- At the request of Gen. Lucius D. Clay, United States Military Governor in Germany, and General Geoffrey Keyes. American commander in Austria, CARE has undertaken two fund-raising campaigns for the children of occupied areas.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., Dec. 12 -- Bob deCoppet scored again with his interclub dinghy, Zotom, at the Larchmont Yacht Club today, winning the eighth winter championship regatta with four firsts in seven contests. He also had a third, fourth, and fifth for a total of 201 points.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 12 -- Ellis Arnall, a former Governor of Georgia and a leading figure among Democratic party liberals, tonight accepted the presidency of the Society of Independent Motion Picture Producers. He was elected to the office by he membership of the society at a business meeting earlier.

The League of Composers' first concert of the season was given Saturday night at the Museum of Modern Art in honor of Francis Poulenc. The French composer-pianist presided at the piano throughout a program devoted to his own works, which were expertly performed before a capacity audience and received with prolonged demonstrations of approval.

Probability of an increase in the state income tax was indicated yesterday by Governor Dewey in an interview at La Guardia Field on his way back to Albany from a three-day trip to Washington, where he attended the Gridiron Club dinner Saturday evening.

DENVER, Colo., Dec. 12 -- The largest anti-tuberculosis project in history, which will test more than 100,000,000 children in twenty-one countries and provide preventative vaccination for those showing a need for it, was described here tonight by Dr. Frank A. Calderone, director of technical liaison of the World Health Organization.

BUTLER, N. J., Dec. 12 -- A woman and her three children were killed and three other persons were injured tonight when a private plane crashed and burned in the Smoke Rise real estate development in Kinnelon Borough on the outskirts of this town.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 (UP) -- The nation's next President will be elected formally tomorrow.
MOSCOW, Dec. 12 (AP) -- The Paris session of the United Nations General Assembly was described by Pravda today as a "moral-political victory for the Soviet Union."

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., Dec. 12 -- A bitter intra-organization fight over support price levels for farm products began developing today on the eve of the opening here of the American Farm Bureau Federation's thirtieth annual meeting.

AMSTERDAM, Dec. 12 -- Prof. Jan R. M. van den Brink, Minister of Economic Affairs, said in an interview here last week that he remained convinced that conditions for the Benelux Economic Union could be fulfilled by the Netherlands before 1950.

The last cadet class in training under reduced wartime tenures at the United States Merchant Marine Academy will be graduated on Wednesday in ceremonies attended by Maritime Commission, Navy and Coast Guard officials.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -- The United States must develop an Overseas Information Service which "frankly supports" the foreign policy of the country, a Brookings Institution study stated today.

BERLIN, Dec. 12 -- Leaders of the Socialist Unity (Communist) party in Berlin and the Soviet zone of occupation have been told by the Russians that an "all German" government will be formed in the Eastern zone by April and that overt Russian control will be withdrawn shortly thereafter.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 (AP) -Business inventories went to a new record high of $54,400,000,000 at the start of November, the month when retail sales began dropping below last year's.

PARIS, Dec. 12 -- The Italian Government has conveyed private assurances to Washington that it will agree to British trusteeship of Cyrenaica provided that Italy receives a similar trusteeship for Tripolitania, it was learned today.

An additional state payroll tax of 1 per cent, the burden of which probably would be shared equally by employers and employes, is being seriously considered to finance a program of disability insurance benefits, it was disclosed yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 - Although electric generating capacity in the United States is expected to reach the unprecedented total of 72,000,000 kilowatts by 1951, the power situation will remain critical this winter, according to a study of the National Security Resources Board made public today.

BROOKINGS, S. D., Dec. 12 (AP) -- Representative Karl Mundt, acting chairman of the House Committee on Un-American activities, said today that publication of some of the "pumpkin" documents would have jeopardized American security. He spoke at a dinner of Sigma Delta Chi, honorary journalism fraternity, at South Dakota State College.

Time was when the big railroad unions stood on a lofty eminence by themselves. They were the acknowledged aristocrats of the labor movement, and this fact was mirrored in all their attitudes and policies. Because they regarded theirs -- with much justification -- as an outstandingly powerful and exclusive group of organizations, they considered it beneath their dignity to solicit members.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -- Recent disclosures before the House Committee on Un-American Activities make it vital that proposals to tighten the Espionage Law receive "the highest priority in the new Congress," Representative Richard M. Nixon declared today.
PARIS, Dec. 12 -- The United Nations Security Council picked up two of the General Assembly's problems today, added a third all its own and called a meeting for Wednesday to debate all three.
To increase their income, many colleges and universities throughout the country are investing their endowment funds in real estate, large-scale commercial ventures and various other businesses.
Dr. Carlos Prio Socarras, President of Cuba, ended his five-day state visit to this country yesterday, flying back to Havana aboard President Truman's plane The Independence.

The New York bus riders' game of penny ante had its stakes raised again yesterday. On the routes of three major lines in Manhattan and one in Queens an additional cent went into the companies' pot; on one Queens line there was a two-cent increase.

Only one new film is slated to open on Broadway this week. This is "The Paleface," the Bob Hope comedy, which will arrive at the Paramount on Wednesday. Norman Z. McLeod directed and Robert L. Welch produced the Paramount presentation, which was filmed in Technicolor from an original screen play by Edmund Hartman and Frank Tashlin.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -- Members of the Council of the Organization of American States voted at a special meeting tonight to ask their Foreign Ministers for instructions on the question whether they should serve as a provisional council of consultation in the situation created by the reported crossing of the Costa Rican border by armed forces from Nicaragua.

PARIS, Dec. 12 -- The first session of the United Nations General Assembly to be held on the continent of Europe ended at 6:10 this evening after a final attack on the United States and Britain by Andrei Y. Vishinsky, chief Soviet delegate.

Regina Resnik, the Metropolitan soprano, was heard in her first New York recital last night at Town Hall. For the occasion she had prepared a program devoted almost entirely to seldom presented offerings of widely varied origin.

In a move to remove unnecessary roughness from the game, delegates attending the sixty-sixth annual meeting of the United States Intercollegiate Lacrosse Association yesterday at the Hotel Pennsylvania voted for stricter enforcement of the rules.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 (UP) -Two Republicans in Congress said today that more wage increases for labor may only mean heavier income taxes for the "little fellow."
BERLIN -- Dec. 12 (AP) -- The Russians offered free Christmas sugar today as bait to win embattled western Berliners to the Soviet side in the East-West struggle for Berlin.

ELEVEN and a half months ago, when the present year of doubtful grace was new and deep in record snows, there was one book about which "everybody" was talking. It was Ross Lockridge's huge, intermittently brilliant and frequently sophomoric "Raintree County." A little later the new book about which everyone talked a great deal more vociferously and much longer was "Sexual Behavior in the Human Male," by Alfred C. Kinsey and his insatiably curious colleagues.

Defeating a final Russian attempt to sabotage its work, the General Assembly of the United Nations has adjourned its Paris session after prodigious labors in which the delegates of fifty-eight nations held more than 600 meetings in twelve weeks and spoke some 17,000,000 words in sometimes acrimonious debate on the outstanding problems of our times.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -- An accusation that high Government officials are taking exception to the Anti-Trust Laws they should enforce was contained today in a letter to Lowell B. Mason, a Federal Trade Commissioner, from George J. Burger, director of the National Federation of Small business, Inc.

Henriette Michelson, who gave a piano recital at Times Hall on Saturday night, played a lot of Beethoven. It was not merely that she devoted her entire program to the master's works, but that she conveyed so much of his thought and feeling.
Mothers and fathers were defended yesterday by the United Parents Associations against criticism that they are largely responsible for juvenile delinquency.

BERLIN, Dec. 13 (Reuters) -- British, French and United States military commandants in Berlin have discussed German demands for use of the Western Deutsche mark as sole legal currency in their sectors of the city, Dr. Ernst Reuter, the Western Mayor, stated today.

CAIRO, Dec. 13 -- Premier Mahmoud Fahmy Nokrashy Pasha, Abdul Rahman Azzam Pasha, Secretary General of the Arab League, and Ahmed Hilmi Pasha, Premier of the All-Palestine Government, indignantly denounced tonight the Trans-Jordanian Parliament's action in approving the Jericho conference resolutions.

KANSAS CITY, Dec. 13 -- Apparel trades associations should drop the "quarantine" of non-member salesmen at exhibitors' markets if they are to escape the possibility of a Congressional hearing and disciplinary action, Andrew P. Federline today told members of the National Association of Women's and Children's Apparel Salesmen.

IN 1874 the northern tip of the southern peninsula of Michigan was one of the last unsettled forest regions east of the Mississippi. It was a land inhabited only by a few Ottawas, Chippewas, French-Canadians and halfbreeds. Since the days of the fur trade and the Jesuit missionaries it had been named after a landmark which stood high on a bluff above the waters of Lake Michigan, L'Arbre Croche, the country of the crooked tree.

ALBANY, Dec. 13 (AP) -- A court action contesting the election of John C. Davis, Utica Democrat, to the House of Representatives may stay certification temporarily of all of the state's forty-five Representatives elected Nov. 2.

BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 13 -- An alleged 11,000,000-peso [about $2,300,000] scandal involving three men close to the regime of President Juan D. Peron was disclosed today. A Federal judge announced he had ordered the imprisonment of fourteen persons accused of fraud against the Government.

Increased corporation taxes can be expected next year if Congress is to avoid renewed deficit financing, said Adrian W. DeWind, former tax legislative counsel to the Treasury Department, speaking at a tax symposium before the New York State Society of Certified Public Accountants in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

SOUTH ORANGE, N. J., Dec. 13 -- Edward Everett Phillips Jr., president and treasurer of the Harrison Supply Company. East Newark, was killed at 9:15 A. M. today when he apparently fainted and fell into the path of an eastbound Lackawanna Railroad passenger train at the South Orange station.
ARMY CHEMICAL CENTER, EDGEWOOD, Md., Dec. 9 (Delayed) -- New and more deadly war gases far more toxic than Lewisite or mustard are under test and development here by the Chemical Corps of the Army.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- President Truman is keeping informed on the Costa Rica situation, the White House said today, as that country awaited a decision, expected tomorrow, on possible emergency action by the Council of Foreign Ministers of the American Republics.

Dorothy and Pearl Bloom of 210 Riverside Drive, wealthy spinster sisters who had been convicted on rent gouging charges in Special Sessions on Dec. 6, were fined $500 each in Municipal Term yesterday for failing to repair a tenement that they own and operate.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- President Truman strongly endorsed today the urgent efforts of a bipartisan Senate group to raise early in the next Congress the salary scale for every high, appointed executive official of the Government.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 (AP) -- Ambassador Henry F. Grady said today that there is a "good chance for a decided improvement" in the situation in Greece by next summer.
PEIPING, China, Dec. 13 -- Peiping citizens either packed or prayed for a peaceful turnover of the city today as they listened to artillery fire in the distance and to a series of fantastic rumors.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 13 -- Joan Crawford has concluded a deal with Columbia for the production of "Miss O'Brien," a photoplay which the actress bought from Warner Brothers last summer, the studio disclosed today. Curtis Bernhardt will direct the film at Columbia starting in March, with Miss Crawford in the starring, role.

Sixteen steamship and railroad companies filed a vigorous protest with the Board of Estimate yesterday against an over-all increase of 45.5 per cent in North River pier rentals instituted last week by G. Joseph Minetti, Commissioner of Marine and Aviation.

MATTAMUSKEET, N. C., Dec. 13 -- Opening day was a happy one for the majority of the hunters spread out among the 200 blinds on Mattamuskeet Lake. But those who shot from field blinds did not do as well as expected.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 (AP) -- The electors of the forty-eight states cast their votes for President today. The net result was that President Truman lost one electoral vote in Tennessee to the States Righters.

A trade fair designed to prove that "Czechoslovakia believes in world trade and really wants to do business with Western countries" will be opened at the New York Museum of Science and Industry early in January, a representative of the Czechoslovak Consulate said yesterday.

TEHERAN, Iran, Dec. 13 -- An American professor, who dared death every day for three weeks, said today he had learned the secret of the inscriptions Persian King Darius had carved on Mount Bisitun 2,400 years ago.

ELIZABETH, N. J., Dec. 13 - Jerome Zarowitz, 35 years old, one of the central figures in the Alvin J. Paris football "fix" case in New York, which brought about a Grand Jury investigation of gambling in this city two years ago, was arraigned here today before Union County Judge Edward A. McGrath on a bookmaking charge.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 (AP) -- The Federal Court of Appeals today unanimously affirmed a lower court decision that Universal Carloading and Distributing Company, Inc., is subject to certain provisions of the Railroad Retirement Act.
Louis Elkan of New York and Art Judice of Brooklyn scored double victories yesterday as play started in the New York sectional three-cushion billiard tournament at the Eighty-sixth Street Academy.

Suits by eight airlines to enforce their leases for New York International Airport at Idlewild were brought yesterday against the Port of New York Authority, its individual commissioners and two executive officers.

CHICAGO, Dee. 13 -- As the two major leagues, voting to increase their night ball activities, moved with such alacrity today that they will be able to hold their joint session tomorrow instead of Wednesday, it remained for the Yankees to break through with the first player transaction since the baseballers moved into this Windy City.

A Chinese point of view of the Burma campaigns of 1942-1945 will be presented in a book to be issued Thursday by the Exposition Press of 1 Spruce Street. It is "The Big Circle" by Ho-yungchi, who served as "t'ung shao chiang" (a one-star general) with the Chinese New First Army in the China- Burma-India Theatre.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 13 -- In a review of the progress to date of the codification of commercial law, Prof. Grant Gilmore of the Yale Law School reported today that the results so far amount to "an impressive piece of work, both in substance and form."

The new Organization of American States, born amid the ruins wrought by a Communist uprising in Bogota last May and designed to keep the peace in the Western Hemisphere, is being put to its first crucial test. This is the result of what the Government of Costa Rica charges is an invasion of its territory from the neighboring State of Nicaragua.

Guy W. Vaughan, president of the Curtiss-Wright Corporation since 1935 and president of its subsidiary, Wright Aeronautical Corporation, since 1930, relinquished active management of the business yesterday with the election by the board of directors of William C. Jordan as president of both companies.

The Legislature must allow more rapid use of state housing funds if the best results are to be obtained from the $300,000,000 sought by Governor Dewey for loans, according to James H. England, executive director of the New York City Housing Authority.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 13 (AP) -- Statisticians reported today that the National Football League season, which ended yesterday, was the roughest and loosest on defense of all time.

CHICAGO, Dec. 13 (AP) -- Michigan State, the Western Conference's new member, will not enter championship football competition in the league until 1953. This was announced tonight as coaches and athletic directors closed the annual conference meeting by mapping gridiron schedules for 1950, 1951 and 1952.
East Harlem community leaders and students agreed yesterday to campaign for an amendment to the city Sanitary Code as one phase of their local clean-up drive.

Endowed with hands that he employs like precision instruments and a fluid voice that he projects to suit the context with uncommon skill, Maurice Schwartz is a performer of profound ability. In "Hershel, the Jester," Moshe Livshitz's folk comedy-operetta, which opened Saturday night at the Yiddish Art Theatre, Mr. Schwartz has found a delightful vehicle for his talents.

TWO national centers for research into rocket and jet propulsion will be established at Princeton University and the California Institute of Technology with funds provided by the Daniel and Florence Guggenheim Foundation, it was announced yesterday.
ROME, Dec. 13 -- The Italian Foreign Ministry said tonight Italy had signed a series of trade and reparations agreements with Russia.

SAVANNAH, Ga., Dec. 13 -- The Governors of eleven Southern states unanimously approved today an "action program" for establishing the country's first regional school compact and paved the way for Negro educators to serve as top-level policy makers in the South's plans for providing higher education facilities.

As the Washington representative of the International Longshoremen's and Warehousemen's Union, including among its members the sugar workers of Hawaii, I had an intimate acquaintance with the legislative history of the Sugar Act of 1948.

ALBANY, Dec. 13 -- Abolition or modernization of the present system of electing the President and Vice President of the United States was urged by leading Republicans today. They made their views public as the State Electoral College met to cast their forty-seven votes for Gov. Thomas E. Dewey and Gov. Earl Warren for President and Vice President, respectively.

Direct mail advertising agencies, facing an average 2 per cent cost increase under higher postal rates effective Jan. 1, 1949, were reported by trade officials yesterday as "extremely worried" over further boosts expected to be recommended in the new Federal budget.

The largest transaction in the department store field in recent years took place yesterday when Federated Department Stores, Inc., acquired the Boston Store, largest retail business under one roof in Wisconsin. Announcement of the affiliation was made by Richard Herzfeld, president of the Boston Store, and Fred Lazarus Jr., president of Federated.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- Among the prominent persons who came to Washington last week-end for the dinner of the Gridiron Club one who was of unusual interest to the assemblage was the Governor-elect of Illinois, Adlai E. Stevenson. The reasons are apparent.
DAYTON, Ohio, Dec. 13 (AP) -- A group of stockholders of Standard Thomson Corporation sued eighteen directors or former directors today for accounting of all profits since 1943.

LONDON, Dec. 13 -- Appointment of a United States officer as chief deputy to Field Marshal Viscount Montgomery, chairman of the Western Europe Commanders-in-Chief Committee, is an immediate aim of the five Western union powers, it was learned here on high authority.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Dec. 13 -- Earl Bunting, managing director of the National Association of Manufacturers, called today for a "thorough overhauling of the Federal tax structures," if the American economy were to hold its own and progress.

In work at the Child Guidance Clinic of Beth David Hospital as well as in my private practice I have had reason to become rather disturbed by the increase of a long-standing hazardous mental health condition among the school children of this city.
LONDON, Dec. 13 -- An official spokesman said today that the British Government had no doubt that aircraft from Eastern Europe had reached the Israeli Air Force.

City-owned and operated buses made their first appearance on Manhattan streets yesterday when twenty new blue-green vehicles carrying the Board of Transportation seal went into service at a seven-cent fare.

On instructions of Joseph G. Moriarty, a vice president of the International Longshoremen's Association, 100 longshoremen yesterday resumed cargo handling of an Isthmian Steamship Line freighter at Pier 17, Brooklyn. The men had refused to work the ship last Thursday in protest against the dismissal of a shop steward who, company officials said, had admitted a theft.

BONN, Germany, Dec. 13 (UP) -- Top Western German politicians suggested to the three Western occupation powers today that they keep hands off the forthcoming trizonal government once it has been formed.
In a great battle of offensive and defensive units, friends and foes of college football's, unlimited substitution rule have fought to a lusty but bloodless draw.

Extension of the state unemployment insurance law to cover a half million workers now unprotected, and also a broad revision of the entire state labor law, which has become a "patchwork of amendments," were urged yesterday by Industrial Commissioner Edward Corsi.

Lieut. Gen. Elwood R. (Pete) Quesada promised the Advertising Mens Post of the American Legion at a luncheon at the Lexington Hotel yesterday a thorough revision of the Air Force's plans for training reserves.
Capitalizing on speed and superior marksmanship, Fordham registered a 68 -- 58 basketball victory over John Marshall College last night before a crowd of 1,000 at the Rams' gymnasium.

Mayor O'Dwyer put into operation at 12:30 P. M. yesterday the Police Department's new traffic control center, which for the present will automatically control traffic lights on five avenues in Manhattan.
AMMAN, Trans-Jordan, Dec. 13 -- King Abdullah's Parliament today unanimously approved the plan to unite his Kingdom of Trans-Jordan with Arab Palestine.

The saving of life and the prevention of injury are the first considerations of all efforts to reduce traffic accidents. The huge economic losses involved should reinforce such efforts. In a single year the National Safety Council has estimated that traffic accidents cost the nation more than two billion dollars.
TOKYO, Dec. 13 (UP) -- Opposition parties today asked Premier Shigeru Yoshida to resign, and Mr. Yoshida's Conservative party welcomed the proposal.

THE last of the famed Four Horsemen of Notre Dame has retired from the football business. Harry Stuhldreher, an admitted success as athletic director at Wisconsin but a gridiron coach of controversial status, has yielded his later post. So peace will settle over Madison, Wis., which has long been torn by a feud between the Stuhldreher adherents and those who launched the "Goodbye Harry" campaign.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange turned somewhat irregular toward the close yesterday, and final prices were 8 points higher to 11 points lower than Saturday's last quotations.

Many colleges and universities are endangering their endowments by investing in real estate, industry and business ventures, in the opinion of a considerable number of responsible educators and financial authorities.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 (UP) -- The penny post card, or "poor man's letter," costs the Post Office 2 1/2 cents for pasteboard, printing and delivery. The Hoover Commission believes it would still be a big bargain at 2 cents.
CHICAGO, Dec. 13 -- Grain and soy beans staged a strong rally today after opening sharply lower on a continuation of the liquidation that depressed the markets on Saturday.

CHICAGO, Dec. 13 -- A policy of increased selectivity in making loans, with consideration of their effect in stimulating the production and distribution of needed goods and services, was urged today at the National Credit Conference of the American Bankers Association.

The Little Orchestra Society, conducted by Thomas K. Scherman, presented three concertos at its Town Hall concert last night. They were Alexei Haieff's Violin Concerto, in its first performance, the solo by Fredell Lack, the concert master; Prokofieff's Third Piano Concerto, with Frank Sheridan as soloist, and Chausson's Double Concerto, in which both soloists were heard.
NEW DELHI, India, Dec. 13 -- A commission appointed by the Indian Parliament has unanimously recommended against the rearrangement of the Indian Provinces into linguistic areas.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 13 (AP) -Joe Louis said today he and demand $250,000 from television and radio rights when he defends his heavyweight title next June in New York.

The organized labor movement in Japan, although numerically healthy after three years of postwar revival, still suffers from a pronounced feudal hangover, according to Dr. Shichiro Matsui, Professor of Economics at Doshisha University in Kyoto, Japan.

FRANCONIA NOTCH, N. H., Dec. 13 -- This extensive downhill skiing center on 4,200-foot high Cannon Mountain first attracted the attention of the winter sports world in 1938 when the aerial tramway, the only one of its kind in North America, was inaugurated.

PARIS, Dec. 13 -- Jean Monnet, director of France's plan for modernizing her industry and agriculture, presented today a hopeful picture of rising French production, but coupled it with a warning that it was "artificial," being supported by Marshall Plan credits.
The Soviet Central Statistical Administration has been removed from the control of the State Planning Commission and placed directly under the Council of Ministers, it became known yesterday.

Both wool tops and wool futures were in heavy supply yesterday on the local exchange despite reports of further active buying by Russia at the wool auctions in Australia. Offerings generally were absorbed by scale-down dealer buying. At the close, wool top futures were 1 to 2 cents a pound net lower and wool futures were down 0.5 to 3 cents.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- Organized labor is virtually agreed on the main outlines of legislative policy that it hopes will be enacted by the Eighty-first Congress.

TOKYO, Tuesday, Dec. 14 -- Finance Minister Sanroku Izumiyama resigned today from the Japanese Cabinet after a 47-year-old woman member of the Diet charged he had made "improper advances" to her in the lobby.

LONDON, Dec. 13 -- On the eve of King George VI's fifty-third birthday, which he will spend as an invalid in Buckingham Palace, his doctors issued today the longest statement that they had yet made about his illness. They reported that he had made "substantial progress."

Under approval by the Government last night of the trust and labor agreements entered into by James C. Petrillo's American Federation of Musicians the first new records to be made with the union's approval since Dec. 31 are scheduled to be "cut" late this afternoon.

Another airlift has come out of the blue. Tangier, too, is being besieged, or, more accurately, needled; in the Big Picture it is the little lift. The dispatches say that this international zone, only ten miles across the Mediterranean from Gibraltar, is under an incipient blockade from Spanish Morocco, thereby cutting it off from its French Moroccan food sources.

FRESNO, Calif., Dec. 13 -- One hundred and seventy-nine years ago a Franciscan missionary, Fray Junipero Serra, arrived in California with a small band of followers and began establishing missions along the Coast. He came by way of Mexico, where he had labored among the Indians for nineteen years after going there from his native island of Majorca.
PITTSBURGH, Dec. 13 (AP) -- The Aluminum Company of America intends to cut allocations to customers temporarily in 1949 because of "increasingly critical" demands, including those of the military.

Puccini's "Madame Butterfly," with Dorothy Kirsten in the title role, and Verdi's "Aida" will be heard for the first time this year in the fourth week of the Metropolitan Opera Company's season, beginning Dec. 20. The Christmas matinee broadcast will be "La Boheme," it was announced, and Giuseppe di Stefano will make his first appearance of the season as Wilhelm Meister in "Mignon."
