PEARL HARBOR, Dec. 13 -Ruth Farnsworth, 27-year-old Navy employe on Guam, died in an Army hospital there today as result of a brutal attack by an unknown assailant Saturday night, it was announced by the Pacific, Fleet's Public Information Office, here this afternoon.
LONDON, Dec. 13 -- The stock market here today was quiet in anticipation of the closing of the account tomorrow.

Beaunit Mills, Inc., of New York, a yarn and fabric company, submitted yesterday the high bid of $17,111,126 for the majority stock holdings of the Office of Alien Property in the North American Rayon Corporation and the American Bemberg Corporation.

The National Maritime Union, CIO, has agreed to a monthly wage increase of $3.50 across the board in settlement of its demands made last week in a contractual wage review, it was announced yesterday. Union officials said a recommendation that the agreement be ratified by the union's membership had been sent to all branches.

Irving Goodman, a 46-year-old dress manufacturer of 215 Bush Street, the Bronx, fought three armed thugs in his apartment yesterday morning and won the decision. While was occupied with two of them, the third beat and kicked Mr. Goodman's wife, but the manufacturer took him on too and the three fled without loot.

James D. Mooney returned to the New York University School of Commerce in Washington Square yesterday, twenty-one years after he finished his college studies in economics there, to demonstrate his new method of explaining complex economic principles with "dynamic graphics."

INDIANAPOLIS, Dec 13 (AP) -- New York's Knickerbockers came from 12 points behind to defeat the Indianapolis Jets tonight, 80 to 74, in the second game of a Basketball Association of America double-header.

The General Shoe Corporation, in its twenty-fourth annual report covering the fiscal year ended on Oct. 31, reported yesterday an increase in total business to a record high of $99,580,268 from $97,248,511 in the preceding fiscal year.

It may be that the art of bel canto is dying, as the gloomy ones say, but you couldn't tell it last night at Carnegie Hall, where Ebe Stignani made her New York debut. The mezzo-soprano from Italy proved that she belonged to the great line of singers.

American "militarists and imperialists" are driving this country into war with the Soviet Union despite Russian aversion to another armed conflict, it was charged last night by speakers at a Madison Square Garden "Rally for Peace" sponsored by the National Council of Soviet-American Friendship.

New York's 140-year-old aquarium received a new lease on life yesterday when Supreme Court Justice Samuel Null issued an injunction barring its demolition unless approved by the New York City Art Commission.

NANKING, Dec. 13 -- Railway officials announced today that Red units that had cut the Tientsin-Pukow line midway between Nanking and Pengpu had fled before the arrival of Government reinforcements. They said that the railway already had been repaired and that traffic had been restored on this 100-mile section of the track.

Sandy Saddler Harlem's newest boxing champion, and Terry Young, husky East Side lightweight, yesterday underwent the State Athletic Commission's pre-battle physical examination, in advance of their ten-round clash Friday night in Madison Square Garden.

The Yale Towne Manufacturing Company announced yesterday a stock dividend of 5 per cent to shareholders, payable Dec. 31, the first such distribution since 1922. The action of the directors followed a special stockholders' meeting at which authorized capital stock was increased from 486,656 to 686,656 shares.

LANCASTER, N. H., Dec. 13 (AP) -- More than 1,000,000 Christmas trees are rolling out of New Hampshire hills by train and truck destined for homes in New Engand, New York, Pennsylvania, Virginia and New Jersey.

LONDON, Dec. 13 -- Kenneth C. Royall, United States Secretary of the Army, who arrived here to begin an inspection of United States military establishments in Europe and the Mediterranean, conferred today with British Ministers and military leaders.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- President and Mrs. Truman expect to have about twenty-five of their kinfolk for Christmas dinner at their home in Independence. Mo., and today they received two turkeys for the feast.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 13 -- Vigorously expressing his opposition to the film industry's "economy of scarcity in good entertainment," Ellis Arnall, former Governor of Georgia and newly elected president of the Society of Independent Motion Picture Producers, told a press conference today that his first objective in his new job will be "to intensify the fight against the monopolies which are retarding the industry."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- A decline in the number and frequency of sunspots for several years was forecast today by the Naval Observatory. These spots on the sun, which are believed to affect both weather variations and transmission of short-wave radio, reached in 1947 the peak of cycles timed by the observatory as lasting eleven years each.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- Army and Navy paymasters will start withholding Federal income tax from pay of privates, sailors, generals and admirals alike next month.

A new million-dollar theatre embodying several important innovations in stage lighting and equipment will be erected soon in the Oakland district of Pittsburgh along plans drawn by Jo Mielziner, well-known theatre designer, in collaboration with Charles N. and Edward Stotz, architects and engineers.

A recommendation for direct aid to domestic shipping by the Government -- both for construction and for operation -- as a means of preserving an industry that is "vital to the national defense and economy" was made last night by Joseph K. Carson Jr., member of the United States Maritime Commission.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 (AP) -- The Supreme Court today refused to review a decision that the GI Bill of Rights empowers a court to award a veteran a year's damages of $7,956 because he did not get a year's re-employment on his prewar job.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- Vice President-elect Alben W. Barkley, who will continue on as a Senator until he is sworn into his new office on Jan. 20, attended his first Cabinet luncheon meeting today at Blair-Lee House.

TRENTON, Dec. 13 -- The division against discrimination in the State Department of Education reported today that its three years of observation indicated "Negroes suffer discrimination to a greater extent than all other so-called minorities in New Jersey."

" Rogue's Regiment," a Universal-International romantic adventure, starring Dick Powell and Marta Toren, will have its local premiere at Loew's Criterion on Saturday. Robert Buckner wrote the screen play and produced the offering, which was directed by Robert Florey.

Omission from the city's 1949 capital budget of items calling for the expenditure of $11,250,000 was recommended yesterday by the Citizens Union at a hearing before the Finance Committee of the City Council.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- Attorney General Tom C. Clark held today that the trust and labor agreements entered into by James C. Petrillo's American Federation of Musicians and the phonograph recording industry do not violate the Taft-Hartley Act.
Premature announcement in a late edition of an afternoon newspaper of a settlement in Brooklyn Supreme Court of a $150,000 suit against the city resulted yesterday in a mistrial.

LONDON, Dec. 13 -- With one emphatic word -- "never" -- John W. Belcher, Parliamentary Secretary of the Board of Trade, rejected today a suggestion that he had allowed gifts he received from business men to influence his actions as a British Minister.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- President Truman's devotion to the cause of human rights was praised today in a message in which the Federal Council of Churches of Christ in America asserted that the United Nations' adoption of the Declaration of Human Rights inspired the hope that the world was developing a conscience.

ROME, Dec. 13 -- The executive committee of the International Refugee Organization has decided to take up the problem of whether the organization should finance the immigration of refugees to Israel at its next special session on Jan. 25.

There is no single index of industrial markets which reveals where steel consuming buying power is located and what changes are occurring in markets, Bay Estes Jr., manager, commercial research, United States Steel Corporation, Pittsburgh, declared yesterday.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 13 -- Problems arising from the swiftly expanding television industry will be met by a merger of unionized talent in the entertainment business, under an agreement announced today by committees representing eastern and western talent unions.

After a day of legal skirmishing and recrimination between the Department of Justice and the House Un-American Activities Committee, a compromise was effected late yesterday over custody of the original pumpkin microfilms.

ATHENS, Dec. 13 -- Karditsa, a large Thessalian town and agricultural center southeast of Trikkala, has been recaptured from a rebel force that seized it early Sunday, according to a General Staff statement made tonight.
In its drive for $600,000, in additional annual income, the New York Public Library announced yesterday the formation of five committees to solicit funds from business and industry.
Just about anything that can be done legally on a public street may be done in Pennsylvania Station without fear of arrest, Magistrate Harry G. Andrews ruled yesterday.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., Dec. 13 -- The successful removal of a knife blade two and one-half inches long from its resting place for twenty-three years -- squarely in the middle of a man's spinal column -- has been effected at the University of Michigan Hospital.
BERLIN, Dec. 13 -- The newly elected city government will seek elimination of sector boundaries in the western part of Berlin, Lord Mayor Ernst Reuter said today.

SEOUL, Korea, Dec. 13 -- The overwhelming approval by the United Nations General Assembly of the Korean Government set up here last August under the world organization auspices was acclaimed by Government officials here today.
Oklahoma A. and M., a perennially successful visitor to these parts, will meet Long Island University in the feature contest of a college basketball double-header at Madison Square Garden tonight.

Christmas is the time of year when widely scattered members of families make special efforts to reunite. The hearth, the stockings "hung by the chimney, with care," the brilliantly lighted Christmas tree, the children gathered before the log fire on Christmas Eve to hear again the wondrous Yuletide story are all integral parts of the American family mosaic at Christmas time.

Gabriel Heatter has assigned his services in both radio and television exclusively to the Mutual Broadcasting System, under a five-year contract becoming effective Jan. 1, Edgar Kobak, president of the network, announced yesterday.

An appeal for immediate recognition of Israel was issued yesterday by Benjamin Mintz, member of the Jewish Higher Security Council, upon his arrival from Paris. A witness of the closing sessions of the United Nations General Assembly at the Palais de Chaillot, Mr. Mintz said that so many things had changed in Palestine recently that any action for internationalization of Jerusalem and the repatriation of the Arabs into Israel could not be acceptable.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- The purpose of the Federal Reserve Board's anti-trust proceedings against the Transamerica Corporation, huge bank holding company of San Francisco, is "to curb unlawfully and improperly" the natural and legitimate growth of the Bank of America, Samuel B. Stewart Jr., counsel for the corporation, said today.

SHANGHAI, Dec. 13 -- Paul G. Hoffman, Economic Cooperation Administration chief, today pledged the continuance of aid to China even if the present Government falls, as long as the essential freedoms are preserved.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Dec. 13 -- Dr. William A. Holla, Westchester County Health Commissioner, expressed concern today over the up-state spread of the "most severe rabies epidemic on record in the state." He asked that steps be taken to prevent it from reaching into Westchester.
MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 13 (AP) -- Nineteen golf superlatives for 1948 -- the best and worst in play all across the country -- were announced tonight by the Professional Golfer's Association.

The Motion Picture Export Association will recover up to $230,000 expenses involved in the distribution of American motion pictures in Germany, under an official guarantee made by the Economic Cooperation Administration to the MPEA, it was announced yesterday.

PRINCETON, N. J., Dec. 13 -- Princeton University has received a bequest of $551,000 from the estate of the late Lillian Cooper Cane of Jersey City, N. J., for the establishment of a scholarship fund bearing the name of her husband, William I. Cane, it was announced today by Dr. Harold W. Dodds, president of Princeton.
LONDON, Dec. 13 -- Another year of austerity in food supplies lies ahead for Britain in 1949, Government officials told the House of Commons tonight in debate over food prospects.

LONDON, Dec. 13 -- A check for 1,000 ($4,000) was donated today by Viscount Kemsley, publisher of The Sunday Times and other newspapers, to a fund to help Miss E. Arnot Robertson, British film critic, carry her legal fight against Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer to the highest court in the land.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- Three out of every four anti-trust complaints prosecuted by the Department of Justice come from business itself, Attorney General Tom C. Clark disclosed today. The Government, he added, initiated action in only "one or two" big cases in 100.

In a heavyweight battle that was a throw-back to primitive days Bernie Reynolds, Fairfield, Conn., last night lowered the curtain on 1948 boxing at the St. Nicholas Arena by lowering the boom on Harry Berntsen, giant Norwegian.

LOS ALAMOS, N. M., Dec. 13 (AP) -- A Congressional subcommittee was told today that it cost $14,000,000 last year to operate the Atomic Energy Commission's community of Los Alamos, which has about 9,000 population.

" Fair treatment" to Cuban sugar, involving possible readjustment upward of the 28 per cent of United States consumption now permitted to enter this country, was urged yesterday by Senator Jose Manuel Casanova, president of the Asociacion Nacional de Hacendados de Cuba (sugar mill owners).

In his letter of Dec. 6, W. J. Schieffelin Jr. quotes from Creasy's "The Fifteen Decisive Battles of the World" to the effect that Russia, in 1851, "with a standing army of 800,000 strong; with powerful fleets * * *" and so forth, was "the arbitress of the movements of the age."

SAN SALVADOR, El Salvador, Dec. 13 -- A project for a Mexican and Central American marine modeled somewhat on the Grand Colombian Merchant Marine in which the Governments of Colombia, Venezuela and Ecuador are stockholders, has been presented to the local chamber of commerce by the Permanent Committee for Closer Relations Between Mexico and Centro-America.

Alger Hiss, former State Department official accused by Whittaker Chambers of connection with a pre-war Communist spy ring, sought yesterday to resign his $20,000-a-year position as president of the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace.

SAN JOSE, Dec. 13 (UP) -- An earlier Government announcement listed the first official casualties of the war -- four unidentified men killed in a clash with an Army patrol near Guapiles, in the eastern foothills, more than 100 miles southeast of the La Cruz-Liberia border area, which reportedly is held by the invaders.
MANAGUA, Nicaragua, Dec. 13 (AP) -- Nicaragua rejected her neighbor's protest than an invasion of Costa Rica had been launched from Nicaraguan soil, and filed a counter-protest today.

Col. Edward P. F. Eagan, chairman of the State Athletic Commission and president of the Circumnavigators Club, arrived at La Guardia Field at 10:15 o'clock last evening to make a round-the-world record of 147 hours and fifteen minutes for commercial airline flight.

The seizure of thirty-two ounces of pure cocaine, with an illicit market value of $12,000, that a crew member of the American freighter Santa Olivia was trying to smuggle ashore late Sunday night at Pier 3, Hoboken, was announced here yesterday by Joseph J. Flynn, assistant Surveyor of Customs.

Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores declined 7 per cent compared with the corresponding period last year, according to the "flash" report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. The decline for the four weeks ended last Saturday was 8 per cent.

Delegates the Eastern College Athletic Conference, in session at the Hotel Biltmore, heard a debate yesterday on the proposition, "Resolved that television will be beneficial to college athletics, especially football."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- Dr. Soemitro, Minister-Plenipotentiary of the Indonesian Republic, today disclosed that the Republican regime had been invited to set up a government-in-exile in India, "if necessary," and to mobilize for the imminent resumption of fighting against the Dutch.

After surrendering yesterday on a three-count indictment charging him with fraud in the recent elections, Sidney E. Davis of 137 West 145th Street, 57-year-old Republican leader in the Eleventh Assembly District, was arraigned before General Sessions Judge George L. Donnellan.
TRENTON, N. J., Dec. 13 (AP) -- New Jersey's Presidential electors cast their sixteen votes for Thomas E. Dewey today -- with the hope that President Truman would have a successful administration.

Steps to increase imports of French merchandise into the United States, emphasizing lower prices to build larger volume and direct trade relations between retailers here and French manufacturers to meet specific requirements of the American market, were urged yesterday at a special luncheon sponsored by Saul Cohn, president of the City Stores Mercantile Company, Inc., at the Empire State Club.

Michael J. Quill, international president of the Transport Workers Union, CIO, announced yesterday that a committee "to study the problem of Local 101 [of the TWU] and its representation on the international executive board" would begin deliberations "at once."

Budget Director James E. Webb told a Senate subcommittee yesterday that "the Federal Government is the largest single enterprise in the world." If the Russian Communist Government is considered a single enterprise, this statement might have to be qualified. But our Government, in its expenditures, in its army of employes and in its consequent influence on the national life, is certainly prodigious.

PARIS, Dec. 13 -- Premier Henri Queuille will appear before the Finance Committee of the National Assembly tomorrow to present a budget calling for nearly 50 per cent more revenue in 1949 than was collected in 1948 -- even through the major part of recovery investments are expected to come from the counterpart fund under the Marshall Plan instead of from the normal resources of the state.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- A registration statement covering 25,000 shares of $2.50 par value capital stock was filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission by the Sterling Insurance Company of Chicago.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Dec. 13 -- Borba, the official newspaper of the Yugoslav Communist party, today denounced as baseless persistent reports in the Italian press that the Yugoslav Government had concluded secret political and military pacts with the United States and Britain or was engaged in negotiations with the United States for the purpose of participating in the Marshall Plan.

Pierre Etchebaster, world champion, and Robert Grant 3d, former national amateur title holder, defeated William L. Van Alen and Jimmy Dunn of Philadelphia yesterday as a new court tennis doubles tournament for amateurs and professionals was inaugurated at the Racquet and Tennis Club.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 (AP) -- Barring a bad crash in the next three weeks, American aviation will chalk up one of its safest years on record.

CHICAGO, Dec. 13 -- Peoples Gas Light and Coke Company today announced plans to acquire 100 per cent ownership of Natural Gas Pipeline Company of America and Texoma Natural Gas Company, which supply all natural gas used in Chicago and northern Illinois.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., Dec. 13 -- The American Farm Bureau Federation's annual meeting rocked today with rising disagreement among regional interests over high, rigid support prices for farm commodities.

DETROIT, Dec. 13 -- A counter-attack against vilification of American business and an improvement in relations between corporations and the public were urged today as alternatives to a continuing trend toward socialism by Christian E. Jarchow, board chairman of the Controllers Institute of America and vice president of the International Harvester Company.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- Protection of the individual from abuses by officers of the law was further strengthened by the Supreme Court in three decisions today.

The stock market made an irregular but labored advance yesterday. Price changes were generally in fractions and although gains were more numerous than losses at the close, the composite rate fell 0.18 point owing to weakness in some of the prime industrials which compose the averages.

LONDON, Dec. 13 -- The Times of London will publish tomorrow a letter urging the creation of a fund for a Benjamin Franklin Foundation to assure maintenance of the London house in which Franklin lived and to promote British-United States relations.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 13 -- Agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation declined comment today on a published report that three or four typewritten sheets of paper, regarded as important clues in the Hiss-Chambers spy case, had been found near this city.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 (UP) -- The Supreme Court today refused to pass judgment on an Oklahoma statute that requires Negro political candidates to be identified by race on the ballot.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- Progress was made here today at an "exploratory" conference for the reaffiliation of the 665,000 members of the International Association of Machinists to the American Federation of Labor.

One of the various good decisions made by the United Nations at its Paris meeting was to give the so-called "Little Assembly" at least another year of life. On this question the vote was 40 to 6. As on so many other occasions, the six votes in opposition were cast by Soviet Russia and its satellites.

Park Department plans to utilize seven acres of marshland at the northern tip of Van Cortlandt Park Lake for two holes of a remodeled golf course were denounced yesterday afternoon at a protest meeting of animal lovers, naturalists and conservationists, held in the offices of the City Gardens Club, 598 Madison Avenue.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- In an atmosphere of mounting tension between the Department of Justice and the House Committee on Un-American Activities in their dual investigations into communism and espionage, these developments came today:

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 13 (AP) -- Hypostyle, belonging to W. A. Mikel took the six-furlong Rataplan purse, sixth and featured race at Tropical Park today, surviving a claim of foul lodged by Apprentice P. Cocco, who was astride Allie's Pal. second to finish in the seven-horse field of 3- year-olds.

CHICAGO, Dec. 13 -- Profits of department stores and specialty shops in the nine months ended Oct. 31 decreased to 3.8 per cent of sales from 4.1 per cent a year earlier, the National Retail Dry Goods Association said today.
ALBANY, Dec. 13 (AP) -- Purchasing power of factory workers' pay checks in New York State in October dropped an average of $1.07 from the same 1947 month, the State Labor Department said today.

Employers of draftees with service-connected disabilities are required to re-employ them at approximately their former seniority and pay privileges under the Selective Service Act of 1948, Hugh Bradley, deputy national director of the bureau of veterans re-employment rights of the United States Department of Labor, said yesterday.

Rayon weaving mills will make known their first-quarter 1949 prices for the general run of gray goods by Thursday or Friday of this week, it was learned yesterday. These prices, according to rayon goods converters, will enable them to figure costs on finished goods for delivery after the first of the year and should stabilize the market, which had sagged considerably.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Dec. 13 -- Every question mark in German minds about American aid to Western Germany will be erased within the next few months, if and when the program already well under way here has found its mark.

STAMFORD, Conn., Dec. 13 -- The unemployment problems of Stamford and Greenwich were taken up here today in a conference of management, labor and government. Representatives of the three groups joined to relieve the situation, that Walter H. Wheeler, president of the Manufacturers Council, called "not too serious now" but of considerable concern.

PARIS, Dec. 13 -- Benjamin A. Cohen, Assistant Secretary General of the United Nations for public information, said today that the decision to hold the General Assembly in Paris had more than justified itself from the point of view of increased interest among the people of Europe.

Practices of automobile finance insurance companies, most of them said to favor dealers and the companies at the expense of the car purchaser, were criticized yesterday by J. Edwin Larson, president of the National Association of Insurance Commissioners.
LOS ANGELES, Dec. 13 (UP) -- Bert LaBrucherie, head football coach at University of California at Los Angeles, resigned tonight and his entire staff walked out with him.
This is the last in a series of "shopping columns" on foods for the holidays. It deals with some of the products found in shops here that are especially helpful in home entertaining.
BALTIMORE, Dec. 13 (UP) -- The Baltimore Ohio Railroad announced today that it would lay off a number of employes throughout its system from Dec. 20 to Jan. 3 because of a loss of business.

The Inner Circle, an organization of political writers, past and present, held its Annual meeting at City Hall yesterday and elected Fred Curran of The New York Journal-American its president fort 1949.

American interest in Italian travel has grown to such an extent that most of the planned tours of the country in the summer of 1949 are already sold out, it was announced yesterday by Alberto Bigi, executive manager of Oltremare, one of the largest travel agencies in Italy.

The Greater New York Safety Council last night presented awards to ninety industrial plants and business concerns as winners in its sixth annual accident reduction contest. The presentation was made at a dinner at the Hotel New Yorker.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- The housing section of the American Municipal Association today urged enactment of the Taft-Ellender-Wagner housing bill as the first duty of the next Congress

The money market was easier yesterday and Federal funds were quoted at 1/2 to 3/4 per cent, compared with 1 1/2 per cent on Thursday and on Friday. Member banks here, which reported a deficiency in reserves of $5,000,000 on Wednesday night, closed the week with excess reserves of $33,000,000 on Friday, after holding $283,000,000 on Thursday.
GENEVA, Dec. 7 -- The European Recovery Program has given a definite stimulus to the trade of European countries with one another.

Under the terms of an order issued yesterday by the United States Maritime Commission, the free time allowed to importers for the removal of foreign shipments from piers in this port will be limited to five days. The new rule, which implements a decision reached by the commission on Oct. 19, will take effect tomorrow.
SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, Dec. 13 -- Limited air activity marked the last twnty-four-hour phase of the invasion, while ground operations apparently have stalled.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Dec. 13 -- Rioting in northern Syria yesterday and Saturday, particularly in Aleppo, was reported here today. Although normal communications have been cut off, reports said that the gendarmerie had fired on mobs and that there were casualties, but the number was unknown.

More than 6,000 representatives of the American Farm Bureau Federation, the largest farmer organization in the United States, have been gathering at Atlantic City for the A. F. B. F.'s thirtieth annual convention. The first session is not scheduled until today, but news reports indicate that a serious split of the membership is already virtually a certainty.
Everybody tried to get into the Battle of the Long Island Rail Road yesterday at a hearing before the Public Service Commission in the Woolworth Building, 233 Broadway.

In the first fifteen months of the World War II campaign in Russia the German Eastern Army lost 50 per cent of its personnel in battle casualties, the private war journal of Col. Gen. Franz Halder, which has just become available, reveals.

TUCKAHOE, N. Y., Dec. 13 -- Sgt. Milton A. Gibbons, whose adroit curbing of juvenile delinquency here for the last eighteen years has set a pattern nov. followed in most of the larger cities, resigned tonight from the Tuckahoe Police Department to work nationally on his plan for keeping youths out of trouble.

PONTIAC, Mich., Dec. 13 -- Despite an expected increase of about 10 per cent in production in 1949, a lag of at least eighteen months in the delivery of new Pontiac models from the date of order was predicted today by Harry J. Klingler, general manager of the Pontiac Division of the General Motors Corporation.
As in two previous years, the sale of pot-holders made by a young girl in Rockville Centre, L. I., resulted yesterday in a contribution for THE NEW YORK TIMES Neediest Cases Fund.

EAST ORANGE, N. J., Dec. 13 -- Overtime parkers in metered shopping areas in this city are finding Christmas greeting cards on their windshield wipers instead of Polic Court summonses. Not only that, but the police themselves are inserting nickels in the parking meters to pay for the shoppers' overtime.

LONDON, Dec. 14 -- In the midst of a debate in the House of Commons today free beer was offered to members -- beer from the Government-owned brewery in Carlisle. Only five went into the lobby to accept the offer and they were all members of the opposition.

"The Paleface," which opens at the Paramount, is this morning's lone film newcomer. Bob Hope is starred in the Western comedy, which was photographed in Technicolor. Jane Russell, Robert Armstrong, Iris Adrian, Robert Watson, Jack Searle and Joseph Vitale are among the featured players.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- David Dubinsky, president of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, predicts that "a new and genuine international federation of free trade unions is in the making, though we cannot yet set a date for its birth."

Stand on any of the avenues of New York and watch the buses stop at their usual every-other-block stops. You'll frequently find, especially during rush hours, that they pile up one behind the other, waiting to discharge or take on passengers at the bus stop. Watch the would-be passengers scurrying along the block, endeavoring to board the second, third and sometimes even the fourth bus in line.

LONDON, Dec. 14 -- United States efforts to meet France's wishes on control of Germany's industrial power are reported authoritatively tonight to have proved unsatisfactory thus far to the French, whose fears of German resurgence still have not been allayed.

ALBANY, Dec. 14 -- A protest against New York City's proposal to convert the former Camp La Guardia at Chester, N.Y., into a tuberculosis hospital to relieve overcrowding at Bellevue and other hospitals in New York has been lodged with the State Health Department by a group of Chester residents.

John Robertson of 3931 Bedford Avenue, Brooklyn, Metropolitan Athletic Association four-wall handball champion, died, apparently of a heart ailment, last evening after winning an exhibition game at the Central Young Men's Christian Association, 55 Hanson Place, Brooklyn. Hig age was 37.

A cold war between government and business can only result in "unemployment, a shrinkage in production, and a slump in government revenues," Emil Schram, president of the New York Stock Exchange, declared yesterday.

"Socialist Britain: Its Background, Its Present and an Estimate of Its Future," by Francis Williams, will be issued by the Viking Press Jan. 3. Mr. Williams was adviser to Prime Minister Attlee for two years on public relations and was in the Ministry of Information during the war.

The Association of the Bar of the City of New York adopted unanimously last night a resolution recommending that Congress adopt principles to govern the conduct of Congressional investigations that would assure fairer treatment for individuals involved.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Dec. 14 (AP) -- Featuring the return of Old Orchard Beach, Me., addition of Sedalia, Mo., and dropping of Milwaukee, directors of the Grand Circuit today set up a coast-to-coast program of light harness racing for 1949 extending through twenty-seven weeks.
As a British motion-picture cameraman who recently emigrated to the United States may I request the courtesy of being permitted to voice my opinion on a recent letter, "Better Motion Pictures Asked"?

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- Herbert Hoover came out strongly today for more generous financial treatment of the Government's administrative officials, not excluding the Democratic President of the United States, Harry S. Truman.

ALBANY, Dec. 14 -- Paul E. Fitzpatrick, Democratic state Chairman, announced here today that Democrats in the Legislature would fight any attempt to finance disability payments to the unemployed with an additional payroll tax, as Republicans are reported to be contemplating.
GENEVA, Dec. 14 -- A second round of tariff negotiations, scheduled to begin April 11, 1949, will be held in Annecy, France, instead of Geneva, it was announced here today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 (UP) -- The "save Woodlawn" foundation believes it will be able to raise $170,000 and establish as a national shrine the home that George Washington built for his adopted daughter, a spokesman said today.

PARIS, Dec. 14 -- The United Nations already has passed through the "incubator stage of its existence" and now represents a "most formidable" barrier in the way of any effort to foment aggressive war, Secretary General Trygve Lie said today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- Three pioneers in supersonic flight this year will share the Collier Trophy, presented annually for outstanding achievement in aviation, the National Aeronautic Association announced today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- The Control Yuan of China appealed directly to Congress today for increased aid to the Nationalist Government of Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek in its struggle for survival against the Communist forces.

The Girl Scout Council, of Greater New York is only half way toward its goal of $350,000 for 1949 activities with only two weeks left for fund raising, Mrs. Howard Phipps, president of the council and campaign chairman, announced yesterday.

Kathryn Reeves Veleber of 417 West 118th Street, 23-year-old bank employe, was arraigned in Felony Court yesterday on charges of forgery and grand larceny after her arrest in Brooks Hall, Barnard College dormitory, on Monday.

HAVANA, Dec. 14 (AP) -- Sammy Snead of White Sulphur Springs, W. Va., maintained his lead today in the Havana best-ball golf tournament. The long-hitting American had a best-ball score of 127 with only eighteen holes to play in the 54-hole event.

CHICAGO, Dec. 14 -- Creation of an unusual trust, eventually leaving a $300,000 business concern to the University of Chicago, but with the provision that the university run the business for twenty-one years to insure jobs for old employes, was disclosed today with the filing of the will of William Gaertner.

Medical science is gradually amassing a large fund of knowledge on virus diseases with the result that "recently the prospect has begun to appear that chemotherapeutic agents may be found which will act against viruses," Dr. John G. Kidd of the Department of Pathology of New York Hospital said last night.
Delegates of the American Kennel Club, acting upon two controversial issues on dog show procedure at their quarterly meeting in the Hotel Commodore yesterday, passed one and rejected the other.
LAKE PLACID, Dec. 14 (AP) -- State grange leaders predicted today continued high returns to farmers for their products next year.
MARBURG, Germany, Dec. 14 -- A young American mother, on trial for her life in the murder of her soldier husband, lost her fight for trial by jury in a United States military court today.

Angel Reyes, Cuban violinist, has associated himself closely with contemporary composers and last night, at his fourth Carnegie Hall recital, he gave the first performance of a new work that he asked his friend, Norman Dello Joio, to write for him last spring.

Most of the names signed to a letter which appeared in THE TIMES of Dec. 4 attacking Menachem Beigin and the Israeli Freedom party are unknown to us. But we are sure that Sidney Hook will be astonished to learn that the contents of the letter to which his name was appended are a compilation of the irresponsible fulminations which appear at intervals in The Daily Worker.

PEIPING, Dec. 14 -- Gen Fu Tso-yi seems to be preparing to defend Peiping from the city walls, following ancient Chinese strategy, although it may be only a token defense by which he will hold out long enough to gain a bargaining position with the Communists.

First results of a new series of studies on newspaper reproduction were issued yesterday in a manual prepared by the American Newspaper Publishers Association and the American Association of Advertising Agencies' joint committee on newspaper advertising.

Several thousand school children welcomed the Freedom Train on its return visit to the Bronx yesterday. From morning till late afternoon the children, supervised by their teachers, filed through the train viewing the historic documents on exhibit and purchasing souvenirs.

A 14-year-old freshman at the Erasmus Hall High School, Brooklyn, was arrested yesterday on a charge of juvenile delinquency after it was learned he had a .25 caliber automatic pistol. The boy's case will be heard in Children's Court.

If the enduring nature of a declaration be the true measure of its value, the first ten amendments to the Constitution of the United States are among the great state papers of all time. On this date they have been in operation one hundred and fifty-seven years.

Because the Long Island Rail Road, after a two-day hearing before the Public Service Commission, failed to produce statistics to show the cost of transporting a commuter passenger. Philip Hodes, commission attorney, renewed his motion yesterday to dismiss the road's application for an immediate 25 per cent commutation fare increase.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Dec. 14 -Palestinian Arabs have told the Arab League that they will stand by the Jericho decision to unite Palestine with Trans-Jordan and defend that decision "by all means" according to the, Trans-Jordanian-controlled Ramaliah radio tonight.

PARIS, Dec. 14 -- Dr. Herbert Evatt, President of the General Assembly of the United Nations, announced today that efforts of his conciliation committee to bring about a settlement of outstanding problems between the Greek Government and the Governments of Yugoslavia, Albania and Bulgaria had failed because of the Greek Government's refusal "to treat existing boundaries between Albania and Greece as definitive."
Guy W. Vaughan has retired to the chairmanship of the board of the Curtiss-Wright Corporation. There is a significance in the juxtaposition of those names in the news.

Election of Stanley A. Russell Jr. as president of the Investment Association of New York to succeed Philip Moore of Schroder, Rockefeller Co., Inc., was announced following the annual meeting of the association yesterday. Mr. Russell of Blyth Co., Inc. for the last year has been program director of the Investment Association, which was organized originally as the Junior Investment Bankers and Brokers Association.
Canada will reduce its shipments of aluminum to the United States by 30 to 40 per cent in the first quarter of 1949.

CAIRO, Dec. 14 -- Whether Trans-Jordan would be expelled from the Arab League as a result of Abdullah's proclamation as King of a unified Trans-Jordan and Palestine was a question on the lips of Arab League and Egyptian leaders today.
DUESSELDORF, Germany, Dec. 14 (AP) -- An official German spokesman said today sixty concerns in Western Germany were engaged in large-scale smuggling of steel and other products into the Soviet zone.

The New York Rangers, already short-handed on the back line, may be without the services of Bill Moe, stalwart defense man, in tonight's National Hockey League contest with the Stanley Cup champion Toronto Maple Leafs at Madison Square Garden.
GENEVA, Dec. 14 -- The United States is the biggest single buyer of steel from Belgium and Luxembourg, Europe's largest steel exporters, it was learned here today.
TOKYO, Dec. 14 -- Japan's intelligentsia, according to observers close to them, are showing declining affection for the United States.

Forty-eight young wives and fiancees of Army personnel in Europe arrived yesterday at the New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens, on planes from Hamburg and Munich. The women arrived on planes of the Scandinavian Airlines System and the Alaskan Air Line, the latter a plane chartered by the Army.

CHICAGO, Dec. 14 -- Sweeping through their final deliberations with a flourish that enabled them to hold their joint session a full day ahead of schedule, the American and the National League club owners concluded their December baseball conclaves today leaving several important developments in their wake.

JAMES E. SULLIVAN was the father of amateur athletics in the United States and one of the founders of the Amateur Athletic Union, the largest sports governing body in the world. The old-timers still speak with awe whenever they mention this quite remarkable man but there aren't many left who knew him because Sullivan died in 1914.

ALBANY, Dec. 14 -- By holding expenditures below the amounts authorized, the state will end its fiscal year March 31 without an operating deficit despite the failure of tax collections to reach the estimates made last spring when the budget was adopted.
Foreign Minister Juan Atilio Bramuglia of Argentina, in behalf of President Juan D. Peron, yesterday invited American capitalists to invest in Argentina.

The question of what union is to represent the 7,000 employes of Macy's moved a step nearer an answer yesterday with the opening of a hearing by the regional office of the National Labor Relations Board.
The Poughkeepsie Regatta, college rowing's biggest event of the season, will be held Saturday, June 25.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 (AP) -Senator Tom Connally, Democrat, of Texas, said today that the aluminum resales were looked into by the Senate-House ECA "watch-dog" committee at a meeting Dec. 2. Mr. Connally, a member of the group, added:

ALBANY, Dec. 14 (AP) -- The state's October death rate of 10.2 for each 1,000 persons set an all-time low record for the month. The Health Department reported today that this mark, which bettered the 10.3 set in October, 1939, "reflected a reduction in practically all causes, especially in the chronic diseases."

ROME, Dec. 14 -- The Italo-Russian agreements concluded in Moscow last Saturday are thought in Rome to solve all the major technical problems outstanding between the two countries. They leave the political situation substantially unchanged, as was emphasized by the fact that whereas most commercial treaties are titled "Treaty of Friendship, Commerce and Navigation," that between Italy and Russia is titled only "Treaty of Commerce and Navigation."
Council President Vincent R. Impellitteri urged yesterday that the state government restore financial aid toward the support of child day care centers in this city.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- Great Britain was charged with thirteen violations of the embargo on munitions to Arab countries of the Middle East in a statement issued here today by the Israeli Office of Information.
Directors of the Barnsdall Oil Company ordered yesterday an extra dividend of 50 cents a share payable to common stockholders on Jan. 12, and another dividend of 75 cents payable on March 5.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- The American republics that are party to the Rio de Janeiro Treaty of Mutual Defense for the Western Hemisphere tonight invoked that pact in the situation created by the reported invasion of Costa Rica by an armed force from Nicaragua.

A "slowdown" in durable goods orders has occurred, reducing production and delivery rates in this area by a considerable amount. For the first time this year some industrial purchasing agents are asking suppliers to defer deliveries. These facts were learned here yesterday in a canvass of durable goods manufacturers in the Greater New York industrial area.
VIENNA, Dec. 14 -- The Czechoslovak Radio announced tonight that the Cabinet had issued a law transferring 65,000 civil servants from the swollen Government service into production.

More than 400 building supply dealers and jobbers from four Eastern states were warned here yesterday to prepare to increase sales despite the possibility of a "shakedown" in business in their home communities. R.W. Lea, president, Johns-Manville Corporation, during a regional sales meeting at the Roosevelt Hotel, stressed that a period of stiff competition for the consumer's dollar is approaching.
Harry A. Lombard, formerly general manager of the Currier Lumber Company, Detroit, has been named assistant treasurer of Burroughs Adding Machine Company.

The Windsor Terrace Memorial Association Post of the American Legion has purchased the building it occupies as a headquarters at 8 Reeve Place in the Park Circle section of Brooklyn. The Budget Holding Corporation, of which Irving Geller is president, was the seller.
One burglary suspect was shot dead and two others were captured by the police at 11:15 o'clock last night at the Nassau Welding Company plant, 271 Fourth Avenue, Brooklyn.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Dec. 14 (AP) -- The Metropolitan Cooperative Milk Producers Bargaining Agency proposed today that all taxes on oleomargarine be lifted in a move apparently aimed at protecting the butter market.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- International control of the Ruhr along with the rest of the coal and steel industries of Western Europe is advocated in a study by the Public Affairs Institute, which lists a number of labor and liberal leaders as sponsors.

ALBANY, Dec. 14 -- Federal delay in advancing New York's application to proceed with the development of St. Lawrence River hydro-electric power was characterized as "entirely inexcusable" today by Gov. Thomas E. Dewey. By inference, he accused President Truman of holding up the application to increase pressure for Congressional action on the proposed St. Lawrence Seaway.

Anna Lisa Bjoerling, soprano, wife of Jussi Bjoerling, the tenor, will make her American debut by joining him in singing a duet from "Boheme" at the Christmas party to be given the day after Christmas at the Metropolitan Opera House for the maintenance and welfare fund of the American Guild of Musical Artists.

The Government of the Republic of China, both through its Ambassador in Washington and through the United States Ambassador in China, has several times asked the United States for a declaration of policy. The Chinese have presumed that such a declaration would be a declaration of sympathy and support.

PRETORIA, South Africa, Dec. 14 -- It became known today that the South African Treasury has bought $10,000,000 from the International Monetary Fund. The news depressed South Africans, dashed hopes of a dollar loan on acceptable terms and accentuated a call for austerity.

Although unions are organized to obtain quick and broad wage increases, union members do not consider themselves as well off in the scale of living at present as do non-union members who have had to rely on themselves to improve their condition, according to a survey made through 5,000 personal interviews throughout the country by the Psychological Corporation, it was reported yesterday.

CAIRO, Dec. 14 -- In the capacity of Premier and Military Governor of Egypt, Mahmoud Fahmy Nokrashy Pasha issued a military order tonight barring students from political organizations of all kinds unless these had been approved by the Government and making it a military offense to "disturb the order of educational institutions."

An ensemble of sunshine yellow tweed gave the direction to the Franklin Simon showing yesterday noon in the Oval Room of the Ritz Carlton. The styles, including travel costumes, beach wear, suntan dresses and evening gowns, were all destined for sunny climes.
GUATEMALA, Dec. 14 -- Direct reports from El Salvador said tonight President Salvador Castaneda Castro had resigned his office and the military was in control of the country.

JACKSON, N.H., Dec. 14 -- The scarcity of snow in this mountainous hamlet is appreciated by the 340 natives as carpenters, trail crews and steel riggers continue to work at a furious pace in an endeavor to finish the two vast ski areas being carved out on Black and Thorn Mountains.

Mrs. Kathryn Behrens of 427 West Twenty-sixth Street, 27-year-old mother who had attempted to commit suicide last May after smothering her two infant daughters to death with a pillow, was paroled yesterday in the custody of her husband, Martin, by General Sessions Judge George L. Donnellan.
LONDON, Dec. 14 (AP) -- The Ministry of Supply denied today that Britain had resold to buyers in the United States aluminum and lead scrap metal bought with European Recovery Program dollars.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- The Economic Cooperation Administration warned Great Britain, Belgium and Holland today to stop capitalizing on the shortage of nonferrous metal in this country by reselling to American companies almost one-fifth of about 100,000 tons of aluminum and lead scrap they bought with Marshall Plan dollars.

The mystery of the disappearing barge -- the sixty-foot, $35,000, self-propelled lighter Belford, which vanished from its Staten Island berth last week and then inexplicably returned, badly damaged -was solved in Felony Court at Stapleton yesterday.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Dec. 14 -- A victory for Midwesterners in their fight to retain flexible support prices for farm products was indicated today at the annual meeting of the American Farm Bureau Federation.
The Board of Health amended the Sanitary Code yesterday by adopting regulations to control the use of a rodent-exterminating poison for which there is no known antidote.

A direct approach to the solution of the housing problem of that segment of the population whose yearly earnings are between $2,000 and $4,000 was suggested by Alfred Gross of Gross-Morton, builders, in an address last night at the annual meeting of the Long Island Home Builders Institute at the Stewart Manor Country Club in Stewart Manor, L. I.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 (AP)--The Marshall Plan hit the bottom of its foreign aid barrel today after earmarking $536,600,000 for European recovery in the first quarter of next year.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange developed some irregularity yesterday. Final prices were 5 points higher to 13 points lower.

A resumption of selling to establish tax losses yesterday stalled the moderate lift enjoyed in the last week by the stock market. The trading indicated also heavy switching operations, and this, it was said, probably accounted, as much as tax liquidation, for the upset condition of the share list.

The first new recordings to be made by members of the American Federation of Musicians since Dec. 31 were "cut" yesterday afternoon after the formal signing of the new five-year agreement between James C. Petrillo's union and representatives of the major disk concerns.

Oklahoma A. and M. congealed Long Island University into a state of complete paralysis with its patented "deep freeze" last night. Forging another link to their long chain of successes against local opposition, Henry Iba's possession-minded Cowboys beat the fluttering Blackbirds, 46 -- 38, before 15,719 spectators at Madison Square Garden.

While the number of leases embodying voluntary rent increases was still far below the corresponding figure for last year, November leases showed a relative increase over those filed in October, reports of the Office of Rent Control here showed yesterday.

QUEBEC, Que., Dec. 14 -- Recent announcement that prices of Canadian bleached and unbleached sulphate pulp have dropped from $10 to $12 per ton are believed to indicate a general weakening in the United States pulp and paper market.

"Carmen" was performed for the benefit of the scholarship fund of the Smith College Club of New York last night in the Metropolitan Opera House. The question immediately arises as to how frankly one should speak of a "benefit" performance.

"Santa Claus visits only people with money," a sad mother told her three puzzled children a few days ago. But the tears that trickled down their pale cheeks as they tried to keep warm in an almost bare flat somewhere in New York forced her to write to Santa Claus and hope for a miracle by one of his local agents.

Giving the first vocal acknowledgment of the current Christmas season in Wall Street, a youthful choral group from St. Thomas Church presented yesterday a program of Christmas carols at the Title Guarantee and Trust Company. Under the direction of Dr. T.F.H. Candlyn, choirmaster of the church, the boys' concert included French and English carols before an audience of bank officials and employes and their neighbors in the financial community.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 14 -The Sailors Union of the Pacific, AFL, today notified the Pacific American Shipowners Association that the association's wage offer submitted yesterday to Harry Lundeberg, secretary of the union, was unsatisfactory.

CHICAGO, Dec. 14 -- December soy beans broke 8 3/4 cents at one time on the Board of Trade today as the result of liquidation induced by tenders of 380,000 bushels on December contracts. The break unsettled grains and a sharp dip followed, but the market firmed later on short covering and buying of May wheat by mills.

A 12-year-old boy who complained recently of pains and palpitations in his chest requested his school doctor to examine his heart. The doctor found nothing wrong, but in obtaining the child's history from the parents he learned that the boy's uncle had died a year before of heart disease.

Ike Williams, world lightweight champion, yesterday was named winner of the Edward J. Neil Memorial Plaque by the Boxing Writers Association of New York at the organization's annual meeting. The James J. Walker Memorial Plaque was voted to Dan Morgan, venerable manager of fighters, who will be best remembered by old-timers of the sport as the pilot of the late Knockout Brown and Jack Britton, once welterweight champion of the world.

GENEVA, Dec. 8 -- One of the most disturbing aspects of the European Recovery Program to Europeans is the repeated American expressions of impatience that Europe is not getting any closer to economic unity.

PARIS, Dec. 14 (AP) -- The United Nations Good Offices Committee in Indonesia expressed fears today that large-scale fighting might flare again as a result of the breakdown of Dutch-Indonesian negotiations.
John W. Gibson, Assistant Secretary of Labor, said yesterday that his department would publish figures on peaceful settlements in labor disputes to counteract strike statistics reports.

John Cashmore, Borough President of Brooklyn, called for the re-election of Mayor O'Dwyer last night at a testimonial dinner for Abe Stark, the Mayor's new Commissioner of Commerce, in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

A group of New York lawyers has called for revision of the Elston Act on courts-martial, terming the law passed by the Eightieth Congress "piecemeal legislation" and completely at odds with American concepts of justice."

Probably one of the reasons that serving cookies at Christmas has become a tradition is that it's such fun to make them. First, there's the great variety of recipes from which to choose. One may prepare ginger snaps, sand tarts, drop cookies, butterscotch wafers or any of the unusual cookies that are Yuletide favorites in European countries.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 14 (AP) -An all-night fire turned a moored freighter into a floating furnace in the Delaware River.
The New York Young Republican Club urged last night that "the party, in and out of office, take effective steps to change" the Republican national leadership.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- American secrets "of great military significance" leaked to Russia direct from the Army's proving ground for weapons at Aberdeen, Md., through an alleged Communist spy ring which included key placed Government employes, the House Committee on Un-American Activities stated today.

Tammany Leader Hugo E. Rogers, during his visit in Washington Monday, asked the Truman Administration to "clear" New York County reappointments to the Federal service with the Tammany organization that he represents, it was made known yesterday.

LONDON, Dec. 14 -- The tribunal of inquiry into allegations of fraud in the Board of Trade virtually completed its hearing of testimony today after three weeks of sessions, during which fifty-six persons went to the stand. Politically speaking, it is now confirmed that it has all been very embarrassing for the Labor Government, but not very serious.

Low-end dress manufacturers are reluctant to show dresses selling for 3.75 wholesale because of the obvious limitation of quality features on both fabrics and construction, it was pointed out in the trade yesterday. Union labor prices, manufacturers said, preclude production of any large quantity of such dresses in the New York market.

Certificates of Appreciation were awarded jointly by the Army and Navy yesterday to forty-four scientists and engineers of the metropolitan area, at a ceremony at the Manhattan Reserve Corps Headquarters, 30 West Forty-fourth Street.
INDIANAPOLIS, Dec. 14 -- Consumers should be able to get more varieties of furniture next year, especially in lower price lines, and prices will probably be slightly lower than those prevailing now.

CHICAGO, Dec. 14 -- Clarence Francis, chairman of the board of the General Foods Corporation, tonight suggested five major policies which he said industry can adopt to make its relations with "big government more productive of benefits to all."

BOSTON, Dec. 14 (AP) -- In a wild overtime game in which the score was tied fourteen times the Holy Cross Crusaders battled to a 72-68 victory over a much taller Bowling Green of Ohio basketball team tonight at Boston Garden.
The official American League pitching records, released for publication yesterday, constitute a resume of Cleveland Indians' achievement that amounts almost to monopoly.

SHANGHAI, Dec. 14 -- A force of 695 United States Marines sailed from Tsingtao to Shanghai today "to protect American citizens in the event of danger." They will be billeted aboard the transport Bayfield, on which they are due to arrive tomorrow.

SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, Dec. 14 -- Government troops clashed with invading forces early this morning at Potrerillos, near La Cruz in the northwestern corner of Costa Rica, capturing thirty-eight, a San Jose bulletin said today. The encounter apparently was bloodless, all thirty-eight reportedly surrendering after the first volley, including their leader, Pedro Jose Ordenes.

Bishop Germanos of the Greek Orthodox Church blessed a new station wagon yesterday that will be used by the recently opened headquarters of the Foster Parents Plan for War Children. The brief ceremony took place in front of the Greek Cathedral, 319 East Seventy-fourth Street.

Under the guidance of the city's veteran weather man, Dr. Benjamin Parry, the first unit in what may become a vast new electronic system to help solve the knotty problems of detecting incoming storms and of spreading weather warnings throughout the area began operation yesterday.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 14 (AP) -- Nance's Ace, owned and trained by Hilton Dabson, former jockey of note, made her first start today since April 17, this year, and won the featured six-furlong Bucksnort Purse at Tropical Park.
Organized labor is reported to be virtually agreed on the main outlines of the legislative policy that it hopes will be enacted by the Eighty-first Congress.

Reprieve: Vinton Freedley and Richard W. Krakeur meant it when they said their presentation of "The Young and Fair" did not end its Broadway engagement Dec. 11 at the Fulton, where it was seen for three weeks. After a fortnight's gap the all-feminine play by N. Richard Nash, with a cast headed by Frances Starr, Audra Lindley, Doe Avedon, Julie Harris, Lois Wheeler and Patricia Kirkland, will set up shop Dec. 27 at the International.

PARIS, Dec. 14 -- Gen. Charles de Gaulle, leader of the Reunion of the French People, urged tonight the workers of France to "work hard for a long time" to lift France out of her present "state of stagnation." This program, General de Gaulle told a mass meeting of 18,000, should be carried out through a system of "associations" made up of labor, capital and management.

Mr. and Mrs. Thomas W. Palmer of 40 East Fifty-fourth Street and Scarsdale, N. Y., will give a dinner on Monday night in the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria for their debutante daughter, Miss Marguerite E. Palmer, who will be introduced formally at the Debutante Cotillion and Christmas Ball in behalf of the New York Infirmary on the same night in the Grand Ballroom of the hotel.

The increasing pressure since the election for a federal compulsory health-insurance plan has been notable, and the response to that pressure by the American Medical Association, for one, in calling for an assessment of $25 each upon members through their county societies to fight this move is equally notable.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- The administrative committee of Labor's League for Political Education today planned to "streamline" its organization on the educational and political levels.

CHICAGO, Dec. 14 (AP) -- Consumer credit expansion is "the least of all offenders" causing inflationary prices, Thomas C. Boushall of Richmond, Va., president of the Bank of Virginia, said today at the credit conference of the American Bankers Association. Installment credit is far below its pre-war percentage of sales or of national income, he explained.

Payments on accounts are slowing up, accounts receivable are at a post-war peak, higher bad debt losses are expected, and inventories are higher than usual, according to the monthly business review by Henry H. Heimann, executive manager of the National Association of Credit Men, released yesterday.

The Traffic Executives Association, Eastern Railroads, will ask the Interstate Commerce Commission for permission to cancel exception freight ratings on less than carload-lot furniture shipments in official territory, John J. Fitzpatrick, chairman, disclosed yesterday. The association is composed of top traffic officers of twenty-eight railroads operating in the territory, which comprises more than twenty states east of the Missippi River and north of the Ohio and Potomac Rivers as well as the District Of Columbia.

Adolf A. Berle Jr., former Assistant Secretary of State, indicated yesterday that current disclosures had necessitated a reappraisal by him of the charges of Communist infiltration in high Government places that were brought to him by Whittaker Chambers in 1939.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 14 -RKO will shut down its production activities for a period which may last a month after completion of "It's Only Money" about Dec. 22, it was learned today. That film, in which Groucho Marx, Jane Russell and Frank Sinatra are appearing, is the only one now in work at the studio.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 14 -Senator William F. Knowland, author of an amendment to the Foreign Assistance Act of 1948 relating to the amount of Marshall Plan goods to be carried in American bottoms, said today that Congress clearly intended that at least 50 per cent of the bulk cargo total from this country should be shipped on American vessels.
Net profit of the Guantanamo Sugar Company and its subsidiary amounted to $1,014,378 for the fiscal year ended with September, the report disclosed yesterday.

The International Trade Committee of the Advertising Club of New York plans to confer with Economic Cooperation Administration officials on the status of importers abroad in the allocation of ECA funds, according to a resolution adopted yesterday at a luncheon meeting of the committee at the club.
The State of Louisiana announced yesterday that it will receive bids on Jan. 25 on an issue of $50,000,000 of war veterans' bonus bonds authorized by the state's voters last month.

THE NEW YORK TIMES on Dec. 12 editorially observed the rising cost of city and state government, the necessity for increased taxes, and noting that the cost of living seems to be leveling off, concluded that the answer to the public school teachers' request for salary increases must be "no."

ALBANY, N.Y., Dec. 14 (AP) -The Public Service Commission granted today temporary annual gas rate increases totaling $1,671,000 to the Iroquois Gas Corporation of Buffalo which supplies gas in Buffalo and adjacent communities.
The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People declared yesterday that it was opposed to the plan of Southern officials and educators that would continue segregation of Negroes.
Pierre Etchebaster, world champion in court tennis, and James Dear of England will face each other again today.

NUTLEY, N.J., Dec. 14 (AP) -Ray Blum and Ken Bartholomew, Olympic speed skaters, today had the United States Olympic Committee arrayed on their side in their disagreement with the Amateur Skating Union.

TOKYO, Dec. 14 -- While Americans are discussing the idea of reinforcing the United States position in Asia in view of a possible Communist triumph in the Chinese civil war, the British Commonwealth is quietly ending its share of the Japanese occupation, according to information available here today.

Bob Hope yesterday filed a competitive bid with the Federal Communications Commission for the television and radio stations of The Courier-Journal and Louisville Times in Louisville, Ky., The Associated Press reported from Washington.

A state minimum wage rate of 90 cents an hour and broadening of the Workmen's Compensation Act to permit higher maximum weekly benefits are highlights in labor's proposed program to be submitted at the next session of the Legislature, labor leaders told a joint legislative committee yesterday.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Dec. 14 -- Secretary of the Army Kenneth C. Royall said tonight that he was discussing with European military leaders the United States role in the Western Union Defense Pact but he denied that creation of a West German army was under consideration.

PARIS, Dec. 14 -- Premier Henri Queuille called on France for her greatest financial effort since her liberation today in presenting a 1949 budget of 1,250,000,000,000 francs to the National Assembly's Finance Committee.

SAVANNAH, Ga., Dec. 14 -- The Southern Governors' Conference adopted today a resolution expressing "continued opposition" to President Truman's proposals for national legislation in the field of civil rights.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- Scientists from the Army, Navy, Air Force and Research and Development Board will join their British and Canadian colleagues in a three-day conference in Ottawa sponsored by the Canadian Defense Department, beginning tomorrow, the National Military Establishment announced today.

The Long Island Rail Road borrowed $5,445,000 yesterday to finance the purchase of thirty-eight Diesel locomotives and sixty double-deck motor passenger cars. The borrowing was on an issue of equipment trust certificates maturing serially from 1949 to 1963.

Marking the revival of an organization that has been dormant for more than twenty years, the National Association of Concert Managers was formed yesterday at a meeting of leaders in the field from all parts of this country and Canada in the Hotel Woodstock.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- The Republican National Committee turned to the rank-and-file of the party today for an explanation of its defeat in the national election.

MATTAMUSKEET, N.C., Dec. 14 -- Although the weather was all in favor of the waterfowl and not the hunters, we put in another day on the fringe of this big lake and managed to get another big honker to take the place of the one Axson Smith's chef stuffed with oysters for last night's supper.

The United Restaurant Liquor Dealers, an association of bar owners against whom a bartenders' union has been on strike for nine days, reported yesterday that it had been cleared by the State Labor Relations Board of charges of violating the state labor law.
Emil Hendrickson is not one to greet with delight a streamlined taxicab, capable of high speed, full of luxurious comforts.
As a result of $3,000 contributed by neighbors, 10-year-old Karen Goodman will arrive here today by plane from her home in Muzenberg, South Africa, for training for a normal life.

NANKING, Dec. 14 (AP) -- The rising peril to Peiping, ancient Chinese capital, touched off new peace rumors in Nanking today. A feeling that all was lost in North China had some of the nation's highest officials talking privately of a coalition Government with the Communists (presumably without President Chiang Kai-shek) or a negotiated peace.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 14 -- Three Los Angeles Communist party figures, charged with criminal contempt, asserted in Federal District Court today that the Federal Grand Jury investigation in which they are involved was "not bona fide but a witch hunt aimed at the Communist party."
LONDON, Dec. 14 -- Princess Elizabeth and the Duke of Edinburgh have chosen the old Royal name Charles for their infant son who is second in line of succession to the throne.

An exhaustive analysis of Premier Stalin's writings back to 1919, made public yesterday, concludes that Stalin's statements to foreign visitors that the Soviet Socialist system can co-exist and compete peacefully with capitalist states are propaganda for cooperation as a temporary tactic in the struggle to undermine capitalism.

The Maritime Association of the Port of New York will present a testimonial to Benjamin Parry, retiring meteorologist in charge of the New York office of the Weather Bureau, at a ceremony at 2:15 P.M. today. The event will be held on the floor of the Maritime Exchange, 80 Broad Street, it was announced yesterday by Cornelius P. Callaghan, executive vice president.

Fears of adoption by Eastern grocery chains and supermarkets of a coupon discount system being used in the Middle West were dissipated here yesterday when it became known that this practice is being discontinued there after Dec. 31.

William C. MacMillen Jr. has been elected vice president of Pathe Industries, Inc., it was announced yesterday. He will continue as vice president of Eagle Lion Films and of Eagle Lion Studios, motion picture distributing and producing subsidiaries of Pathe Industries, Inc.

NANKING, Dec. 14 -- The Communist radio at Harbin asserted tonight that Gen Lin Piao's Communist forces, in stepping up their North China offensive, had seized virtually the entire 100-mile section of the Peiping-Kalgan Railway and "annihilated" four Nationalist divisions under Gen Fu Tso-yi.

A heavy schedule of negotiation meetings faces the representatives of the tugboat workers and owners following their joint session this morning in the Maritime Exchange, 80 Broad Street, it was reported yesterday.

Defending the investments in commercial concerns or real estate made by educational institutions, several leading educators declared yesterday that American colleges and universities were not attempting to abuse their tax-exempt privileges.
Consolidated Edison Company 3 per cent bonds due Nov. 1, 1972, are exchangeable for temporary bonds at the National City Bank.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 (AP) -Doctors are winning their fight against infectious diseases hut deaths from heart ailments continue to climb. The public health service reported today that 460,580 deaths, or 31.9 per cent of all deaths reported in 1947, could be blamed on heart diseases.

The recently completed sevenand-a-half-week cross-country bus tour of the French Orchestre National was an artistic triumph but lacked sadly in material comforts, it was testified yesterday at an arbitration hearing between the orchestra and its American concert manager at the American Arbitration Association, Rockefeller Center.
A young Brooklyn chemist who was kidnapped early yesterday morning lost a $65 watch and a $40 ring in an adventure that for two hours seemed uncomfortably like an old-fashioned "ride."

PARIS, Dec. 14 -- The Nawab Moin Nawaz Jung, head of a Hyderabadi delegation to the United Nations, charged in a letter to the Security Council today that the Nizam [ruler] of Hyderabad was "now virtually a prisoner of the Indian military authorities" and that the Nizam's previous instructions to lay aside his complaint to the Council had been "given under duress."

ALBANY, Dec. 14 -- An early reorganization of the Republican State Committee to put the party in better condition for next year's local elections in New York, Buffalo and other cities and to improve its chances for the state election in 1950 is being urged on Governor Dewey.

Visiting buyers registered in the market for the week ended yesterday totaled 886, against 1,350 last week and 576 in the similar week of last year, according to lists published in THE NEW YORK TIMES. There were 366 arrivals yesterday, compared with 661 last Tuesday.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Dec. 14 -- Without reference to recent complaints of German administrators on the proportion of European Recovery Program deliveries for Western Germany in comparison with total funds committed, an announcement was issued today jointly by the Bipartite Control Office and the Joint Export-Import Agency that in the two weeks ending Nov. 30 receipt of supplies for the bizonal area added $10,260,000 to the value of shipments already in the area.

Credit collections from Latin-American countries as a group declined $2,000,000 in value during November, although there was an increase over October in the number of items paid, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.

Oscar R. Ewing, Federal Security Administrator, renewed last night his attack upon the American Medical Association's $3,500,000 fund to fight compulsory national health insurance and predicted that the money would "go down the drain."
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 14 (AP) -- Joe Louis took on an old playmate tonight and the script was pretty much the same as he buffeted Arturo Godoy in a sluggish six-round exhibition bout at Convention Hall.
SAN FRANCISCO, Dec 14 -- The Radiological Society of North America put under way today a survey to determine how much radiation would be required to kill or seriously injure a human being.

BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 14 -- The $2,300,000 fraud alleged to have been perpetrated against the Government by men close to the Peron regime could have mounted to nearly three times that figure if discovery had lagged. The 11,000,000-peso expose was announced yesterday.

In the light of a report made yesterday by Tommy Whelan to Admiral Jonas Ingram, commissioner of the All-America Football Conference, there is no chance of favorable action on a threatened protest of Buffalo's victory over Baltimore in last Sunday's Eastern Division play-off.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Dec. 14 -- Without reference to recent complaints of German administrators on the proportion of European Recovery Program deliveries for Western Germany in comparison with total funds committed, an announcement was issued today jointly by the Bipartite Control Office and the Joint Export-Import Agency that in the two weeks ending Nov. 30 receipt of supplies for the bizonal area added $10,260,000 to the value of shipments already in the area.

Credit collections from Latin-American countries as a group declined $2,000,000 in value during November, although there was an increase over October in the number of items paid, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.

Oscar R. Ewing, Federal Security Administrator, renewed last night his attack upon the American Medical Association's $3,500,000 fund to fight compulsory national health insurance and predicted that the money would "go down the drain."
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 14 (AP) -- Joe Louis took on an old playmate tonight and the script was pretty much the same as he buffeted Arturo Godoy in a sluggish six-round exhibition bout at Convention Hall.

CHICAGO, Dec. 14 -- Secretary of the Treasury John W. Snyder declared today that the Administration would continue its policy of supporting the market in Government bonds as an essential to promoting confidence in the credit of the Government. He denied charges that this policy was inflationary.

Events in Palestine have entered into a new phase as a result of the move by the Government of Trans-Jordan to unite that kingdom with Arab Palestine and to proclaim King Abdullah "King of Trans-Jordan and Palestine." The details of such a union are still to be revealed, including such matters as borders.

SAN BRUNO, Calif., Dec. 14 (AP) -- Citation, "horse of the year," will race no more this winter because of a leg injury. Trainer H. A. (Jimmy) Jones disclosed today an unsuspected injury to the Calumet Comet's left foreleg had prompted a decision to ship him back to Florida at once for a two-or three-month rest.

Twenty per cent of the 3,000,000 involuntarily childless couples in the United States could have children after proper medical treatment, it was estimated yesterday by Dr. William T. Kennedy, gynecologist and chairman of the medical executive committee of the Planned Parenthood Federation.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 (AP) -- A Communist official's report, rereived here today, indicates Russia may be having a hard time imposing her rule on Lithuania.

LAKE SUCCESS, Dec. 14 -- A $2,000,000 campaign to combat syphilis and protect new-born infants from the disease is being undertaken by the United Nations International Children's Emergency Fund, it was announced here today.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, Dec. 14 (Reuters) -- Istvan Dobi, new Hungarian Prime Minister, told Parliament today that his Smallholders party had adopted a program for "a complete showdown with capitalism and its total liquidation."

Coordinated plans for promoting New York both as a business center and a vacation spot will be discussed by city department heads, members of the New York Convention and Visitors Bureau, Inc., and the Business Executive Advisory Committee of the City's Commerce Department at a luncheon on Friday in the Biltmore Hotel, it was learned yesterday.
