WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- The American Municipal Association today took the stand that if the Federal Government required cities to supply civilian defense, local governments must be able to withhold key men from draft.

ATHENS, Dec. 14 -- Constantin Rodopoulos, Under Secretary for War who returned tonight from Karditsa, told the Cabinet that 500 citizens of the town had been carried off as hostages by rebels who left fifty dead and 100 wounded civilians in the streets. He said that some twenty-five of the town's main buildings had been destroyed.

Urging all Christians to apply the principles of the United Nations' Human Rights Declaration to their immediate social and political surroundings, Dr. O. Frederick Nolde, director of the Commission of the Churches on International Affairs of the World Council of Churches, predicted yesterday that its adoption would strengthen President Truman's civil rights program.

Mrs. Minnie Musitano, 54 years old, of 830 East 232d Street, the Bronx, will remember this Christmas for the next three years and seven months. Bronx County Judge James M. Barrett saw to that yesterday when she appeared before him and pleaded guilty to a charge of petit larceny.

Two shipping industry proposals designed to place the city's waterfront property virtually on a selfsustaining basis are to be considered today at an executive session of the Board of Estimate, it was reported yesterday.

Federal Judge John W. Clancy dismissed yesterday a suit for $250,000 in damages brought against Attorney General Tom Clark and four other present and former Government officials by Armand Gregoire, a former French attorney who charged that he had been interned unjustly for nearly five years.
LONDON, Dec. 14 -- Although the stock market again was quiet today, the last day of the account, prices generally held up fairly well.

The role of private agencies in easing the burden of the city's overloaded welfare program was praised yesterday by Mayor O'Dwyer at a testimonial luncheon at the Astor Hotel given in his honor by the amusement division of the Federation of Jewish Philanthropies of New York.

The hide futures market on the Commodity Exchange was subjected to price pressure yesterday due to weakness in the western spot centers. At the close prices of the different active delivery months had declined 30 to 40 points.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 (AP) -Full barge service along the Mississippi, Missouri and Illinois River's is being restored by the Federal Barge Lines, the Inland Waterways Corporation announced today after a two-day meeting of its advisory board.

IF literary criticism were only the noble pleasure of praising, as Swinburne once incautiously said it was, the feuds and tribal wars which are a permanent feature of the world of books would expire from lack of nourishment. Luckily, there is no danger of such an insipid state of affairs ever afflicting us, for criticism deals with combustible matters, emotion and opinion.
From a bed in the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center, a patient facing a brain operation sent $100 yesterday to THE NEW YORK TIMES Neediest Cases Fund.

The Office of Alien Property announced last night that it had accepted the bid of $17,111,126 made by Beaunit Mills, Inc., of New York for the Government's controlling interest in both the North American Rayon Corporation and the American Bemberg Corporation. The Beaunit offer was highest of four bids submitted on Monday.

KANSAS CITY, Dec. 14 -- Nat Roth, Miami, Fla., was elected president of the National Association of Women's and Children's Apparel Salesmen here today after a warning from an official of the organization that the "industry has reached a point where supply has caught up with demand."

LONG BEACH, L. I., Dec. 14 -President Truman's confidence in his own re-election as far back as last spring, when things looked blackest for him and his party, was recounted here tonight by Paul E. Fitzpatrick, Democratic state chairman.
MOSCOW, Dec. 14 (AP) -- The Soviet Academy of Sciences issued a long statement today denouncing Dr. Herman J. Muller of Indiana University and his views on genetics.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 (AP) -The text of a statement issued today by the House Committee on Un-American Activities follows:

Hope of a bright future in an adopted land of freedom entered the lives of eighty-five Estonians at Ellis Island yesterday when they learned that the National Lutheran Council had accepted their parole and hopes to locate the entire group before Christmas.

A recommendation that four-power censorship of all international communications in Vienna be ended was submitted Monday to the State Department and the Secretary of the Army in a memorandum from Roger N. Baldwin, director of the American Civil Liberties Union.

PARIS Dec. 15 -- The projected visit to the United States by former Premier Eduoard Herriot who now is President of the National Assembly, or another special emissary was discussed by the Cabinet today. M. Herriot is understood to be eager to make the trip.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- The Air Force has a new Constellation outfitted as an alternate for the President's private airplane, the DC-6 Independence, it became known here today. The new plane was delivered three weeks ago.

State ownership and operation of the Long Island Rail Road, as "the only way to bring some sanity into this situation," was recommended yesterday by Michael J. Quill, president of the Transport Workers Union, CIO.

Housewives who had been put on the city payroll as voting machine technicians will be weeded from the appointive lists for temporary employes, Commissioner David B. Costuma, secretary of the Board of Elections, said yesterday.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 15 (AP) -- Tennessee Kid finished first by a head in the featured Bienville Purse at the Fair Grounds today. Athlete, the favorite, was second with Repand third, over the six furlongs. Tennessee Kid, owned by R. A. Brown, paid $22.60, $5.60 and $3.60.

ROME, Dec. 15 -- "Something in the nature of a revolution" in Italian agriculture through introduction of hybrid corn under the auspices of the European Recovery Program was foreseen by James D. Zellerbach, chief of the ERP mission in Italy, in a lecture that he gave today to the Italian Center of Studies for International Reconciliation.

By way of a "practical" Christmas gift, instead of the conventional desk pad or calendar, the Colonial Trust Company has sent as a Yuletide remembrance to its correspondent banks abroad bilingual dictionaries in English and in the language of each recipient.
Four inches of snow fell in the city yesterday and up to seven inches in the suburbs, causing a major slow-down of motor traffic.

WHEN Branch Rickey traded Eddie Stanky to the Boston Braves last season, most baseball men were of the opinion that the Mahatma had thereby given the pennant to Boston. It was a pretty shrewd analysis because the Brat not only strengthened the Braves at second but also at shortstop where he helped make a real major leaguer out of Alvin Dark.
WASWHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- The Ford Motor Company disclosed today that it had canceled the franchises of twenty-four dealers because of "gray market" transactions.

The leaders of Soviet Russia have quite frankly put down their plans, their goals and their strategy in their own books, which are now the bibles of the Communist world. They were compelled to do so because, like the author of "Mein Kampf," they were building a movement which had to have fundamental doctrines for its own orientation.

The musical revue, "Lend an Ear," win open at 8 o'clock tonight at the National Theatre under the sponsorship of William R. Katzell Franklin Gilbert and William Eythe. Sketches, lyrics and music for the show are the work of Charles Gaynor.

Factory dollar volume of vitrified hotel chinaware has dropped substantially in the last few months, A.M. Walker, outgoing president of the Vitrified China Association, revealed yesterday. He made this disclosure following concluding sessions of the annual meeting of the United States Potters Association in the Astor Hotel.
Twenty-four Christmas trees that have been erected and decorated in parks throughout the five boroughs will be illuminated tomorrow at 5 P.M., it was announced yesterday by the Park Department.
Contributors from fourteen states in this country sent donations yesterday to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

SYRACUSE, Dec. 15 -- Carrying forward the right-wing policies adopted at last week's international convention of the Transport Workers Union, CIO, anti-Communist leaders of the union's big New York local announced today their readiness to file formal recall petitions looking to the ouster of Austin Hogan, the local's president, and two other top leftist officers.

Of all radio-owning families in the United States, 15,376,100, or 40.9 per cent, have more than one home set, according to a survey report issued yesterday by the Broadcast Measurement Bureau, Inc. The survey placed the number of sets in working order at 74,000,000, and those not in working order at 5,000,000.

In an effort to strike at the core of Harlem's disease-breeding and unsanitary conditions, the Peoples Civic and Welfare Association of that area will put a new program into effect, it was made known yesterday.
Contributions totaling $288,062 have been received in the first two weeks of the Colby College Mayflower Hill development drive, it was announced yesterday.

The twelve-story and penthouse apartment building for seventy-six families at 817 West End Avenue, southwest corner of 100th Street, has been sold by J.G. and M. Wallenstein to an investing client of Goodman Mabel, attorneys, for cash over a first mortgage of $355,000 maturing in 1956.

The stock market drifted aimlessly in a narrow range yesterday, to the accompaniment of the smallest dealings in almost a month. Highly professional in character, interest proved diversified, although radio and television issues continued to claim the bulk of the group trading.

LONDON, Dec. 15 -- Another incident between Israel and Britain came to light tonight. The Air Ministry announced that a British Mosquito bomber, missing in the Mediterranean area, was believed to have been shot down by an Israeli fighter on Nov. 20.

TRENTON, N.J., Dec. 15 -- With municipal tax rates generally rising in New Jersey, real estate owners may not have noticed any tax relief. Nevertheless, J. Lindsay de Valliere, State Budget Director, reported today they have been relieved in the last two years of paying $31,000,000 in school taxes.

Voicing his belief that no other nation has a plane that can fly faster than the speed of sound, about 760 miles an hour at sea level, John F. Victory, executive secretary of the National Advisory Committee for Aeronautics, declared yesterday that both Navy and Air Force experimental planes in the United States have bettered the speed of sound by 30 per cent.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- The State Department vetoed today New York State's proposal to proceed immediately in conjunction with the Province of Ontario in the independent development of the hydro-electric power potential of the St. Lawrence River.

SYRACUSE, Dec. 15 -- Samuel Wolchok, president of the Retail, Wholesale and Department Store Union, CIO, said tonight that he would call a special meeting of the union's international executive board in New York early next week to consider the national CIO's transfer of jurisdiction over store workers to the Amalgamated Clothing Workers.

WARSAW, Dec. 15 -- A further stage in the unification of Polish political activity began here today with a meeting of the delegates of the Socialist party (PPF) and the Communists or Workers party (PPR) in a joint conclave to give effect to a decision to merge the two parties into one consolidated United Workers party.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Dec. 15 -- The Israeli Government is no longer interested in piecemeal military talks with Arab commanders on the various fronts but from now on will consider only high level discussions directed toward a truce and an armistice.

The nation's gasoline stocks increased last week 1,875,000 barrels to 97,110,000, according to the American Petroleum Institute. At the end of the previous week they were 95,235,000 barrels and a year ago 87,608,000.
LONDON, Dec. 15 (AP) -- Freddie Mills, world light-heavyweight boxing champion, signed today for a fight that may put him in the world heavyweight picture.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 15 -- The Society of Independent Motion Picture Producers today repudiated the film industry's anti-Communist hiring policy in a letter from Gunther Lessing, chairman of the society's executive committee, to Robert W. Kenny, counsel for the "contemptuous ten" in their $61,000,000 blacklist-conspiracy suit against the film producers.

The Jerusalem Executive of the Jewish Agency for Palestine, in a cabled message to the American section of the agency, hailed yesterday the settlement of the dispute within the United Palestine Appeal and expressed hope that the appeal would continue "as a unifying central fund-raising agency for the upbuilding of Israel" in this country.

SAN SALVADOR, El Salvador, Dec. 15 -- A revolutionary Junta or Military Council was selected and took over the rule of the country today. It is composed of Lieut. Col. Manuel de Jesus Cordoba, Maj. Oscar Osorio, Maj. Oscar Bolanos and Drs. Humberto Costa and Reinaldo Galindo Pohl.

The Southern Pacific Company borrowed $15,740,000 yesterday on one-to-ten-year equipment trust certificates at an interest cost of about 2.32 per cent. The railroad sold the issue, designated Series Z, to a banking group headed by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., at a bid of 99.06991 for 2 1/8s.

VIENNA, Dec. 15 -- A trade treaty with the bizonal area that Soviet Gen. Vladimir Kurasov said at last week's meeting of the Allied Council had been concluded by Austria is understood to have been actually signed today by Gens. Lucius D. Clay and Sir Brian Robertson for the United States and Britain.
Alger Hiss, former State Department official, was indicted by a Federal grand jury yesterday on two counts of perjury.
The American and Foreign Power Company, Inc., deferred yesterday to a date not later than Feb. 15, 1949, consideration of dividends ordinarily paid on Dec. 15 on the $7 and $6 preferred stocks.

VIENNA, Dec. 15 -- Arbeiter-Zeitung, long-time organ of the Austrian Socialist party, today vehemently accused Wiener Kurier, the official German-language newspaper of United States forces in Austria, of openly supporting the Austrian People's party "and all that is Catholic and conservative."

The need for special prayers and devotional literature for hospitalized Jewish veterans was stressed yesterday at the closing session of a two-day conference of the Division of Religious Activities of the National Jewish Welfare Board at the board's headquarters, 145 East Thirty-second Street.

CHICAGO, Dec. 15 -- It appears that we are at an economic crossroads, with both deflationary and inflationary forces at work or in prospect, round-up speakers said today at the close of the three-day national credit conference of the American Bankers Association.

The 1948 Hoover Medal, awarded by the American Society of Civil Engineers, the American Society of Mechanical Engineers, the American Institute of Electrical Engineers and the American Institute of Mining and Metallurgical Engineers has been won by Malcolm Pirnie, consulting engineer here, it was announced yesterday.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., Dec. 15 -A field al by Bill Wilson with fiftyfie seconds to play gave Navy a 58-to-56 victory over the Univerairy of Virginia basketball team today.

The Fifth Avenue Jewelers Exchange at 32-34 West Forty-seventh Street was formally opened yesterday afternoon with a brief ceremony at which James W. Johnson, Collector of Internal Revenue for the Third District, performed the traditional rite of snipping the white ribbon with a pair of scissors.

Two backs, Frank Wenner and Harry Forbes, shared the Everett Bacon Cup that annually goes to the outstanding individual of the Wesleyan football team at the presentation ceremonies last night during the 1948 Victory Dinner given by the Wesleyan Club of New York at the Downtown A.C.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- The resale in this country of aluminum and lead scrap bought by Great Britain, Belgium and Holland with Marshall Plan dollars does not "constitute a breach of faith," Howard Bruce, acting head of the Economic Cooperation Administration, said today.

The Cuban Atlantic Sugar Company, in its consolidated annual statement covering the fiscal year ended with last September, reported yesterday a consolidated net income of $8,595,138 after taxes and all other deductions.

Rubber futures, reflecting continued weakness in London and Singapore, declined sharply on the Commodity Exchange yesterday. At the close, prices were down 40 to 54 points on the day. The price level is below the Government's price for synthetic rubber for the third time this year.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- The United States is continuing its efforts to get aid to China under the policy previously laid down by Congress but is not embarking, at least at this time, on any greatly expanded program such as is reported to have been urged by Mme. Chiang Kai-shek during her present mission here, it was revealed authoritatively today.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., Dec. 15 -- Freedom of information is threatened on three major fronts, Erwin D. Canham, editor of The Christian Science Monitor and president of the American Society of Newspaper Editors, said here tonight at a ceremony marking the 157th anniversary of the ratification of the Bill of Rights.

Georg Unger Vetlesen, chairman of the board of Scandinavian Airlines System, Inc., was invested with the insigne of the Swedish Royal Order of Vasa, Rank of Commander, yesterday at the residence of Lennart Nylander, Swedish Consul General of New York, at 600 Park Avenue.

ALBANY, Dec. 15 -- Governor Dewey declared today that there was urgent need for an immediate easing of some restrictive building code requirements that he contends are contributing unduly to the inflation of home-building costs. He will ask the Legislature to act when it meets next month.

BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 15 -- The Prensa today editorially deplored the delay in making public the facts in the aluminum plant scandal in which fourteen Argentines, including three close to President Juan Peron, are accused. The independent newspaper also notes that two sets of brothers-in-law. are involved and says that this indicates once more the "grave evils of nepotism."

CHICAGO, Dec. 15 -- The grain markets showed a heavy undertone in the late trading on the Board of Trade today, corn developing independent weakness and closing 3/4 to 1 7/8 cents lower, May leading. Wheat was 1/2 to 7/8 cent lower; oats, 1/8 to 1/2 cent lower, and rye, 1/2 to 1 cent lower.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Dec. 15 -- In an apparent attempt to avert a decisive split within the American Farm Bureau Federation, the organization's resolutions committee voted today to recommend that the controversial issue of Federal price support levels for farm products be referred to the board of directors.
I have read with interest and regret Judge Null's decision to give a reprieve to the ruins of the old Aquarium, which is now being called Castle Clinton.

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 15 (AP) -- A spokesman for the Westinghouse Electric Corporation said today that five United States companies are dickering to build a $50,000,000 steel mill in France with Marshall Plan funds.
The text of the indictment against Alger Hiss follows:
LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Dec. 15 (AP) -- The State Grange was urged today to apply a brake to Government controls of agriculture and "keep Government out of the markets."

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 15 -- The Sailors Union of the Pacific, an affiliate of the American Federation of Labor, has served a sixty-day notice on the Pacific American Shipowners Association for modification or termination of its contract, it was disclosed today.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- Consolidation of the Air National Guard into the Air Force Reserve was recommended today in a report sent to the White House by James Forrestal, Secretary of Defense.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 15 -- In an action which produced a heated exchange of statements, Samuel Goldwyn today terminated Teresa Wright's acting contract with him, which still had four and a half years to run. The actress has been under contract to the producer for seven years.

ATHENS, Dec. 15 -- Vice Premier-Foreign Minister Constantin Tsaldaris, who was chief Greek representative to the United Nations General Assembly in Paris, said tonight that responsibility for collapse of the Balkans mediation conversations rested not with Greece but with Albania, Yugoslavia and Bulgaria.
Several new pieces of both upholstered and wood furniture were introduced yesterday by Harvey Probber at the opening of his new decorator showroom at 136 Fifth Avenue.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 15 (AP) -- Irisen, belonging to Mrs. O.L. Nyberg of Baltimore and winner of the W.P. Burch Memorial Handicap her last time out at Bowie, was best of seven sprinters in the Claire Purse at Tropical Park today.

Mayor O'Dwyer was assured of support for renomination by all five Democratic county leaders in New York yesterday, when James A. Roe of Queens and Jeremiah A. Sullivan of Richmond announced that they were for Mr. O'Dwyer.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 15 (AP) -- The thirteen recording companies which signed an agreement with the American Federation of Musicians ending the year-old ban on records are expecting gross sales of $250,000,000 next year.

LAKE SUCCESS, Dec. 15 -- The United Nations received today a "token" present from a group of 600 travelers who arrived safely in New York from Ireland despite a series of incidents that disabled and delayed their ship.

A program for the New York State Democratic delegation in the House of Representatives in the Eighty-first Congress will be discussed today at a luncheon of the members of the delegation at the Biltmore Hotel, with State Chairman Paul E. Fitzpatrick as the host.

CHICAGO, Dec. 15 -- Two court actions against the Tucker Corporation were consolidated into a single bankruptcy suit today by Federal District Judge Michael L. Igoe. The company was given until Dec. 22 to file an answer to the joint action and a hearing in the case was set for Jan. 4.

Something green and rustic is about to be added to one of the city's most intensely urban neighborhoods, it was reported yesterday. The site of the old Tombs Prison and Criminal Courts Building soon will be enclosed by a split-rail fence and planted all around and about with shrubs, in country -- or anyhow suburban -- style.

George A. Brownell has been named chairman of the special gifts committee of the Community Service Society's current campaign for $1,400,000, it was announced yesterday by S. Spencer Scott, general chairman of the drive.
We read with whole-hearted approval the letter from Rita Morgan, Maryal Knox and Clyde E. Murray in THE TIMES on Dec. 7, calling for an experiment in integrated planning in East Harlem.

LONDON, Dec. 15 -- At the Aldwych Theatre tonight the stalls were filled with friends and admirers of Gertrude Lawrence, welcoming her back to the London stage after an absence of twelve years in America.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- William Wesley Waymack resigned today as a member of the United States Atomic Energy Commission and President Truman accepted it as of next Tuesday.
HAWTHORNE, Calif., Dec. 15 (AP) -- The X-4, with which the Air Force hopes to learn more about handling airplanes near sonic speeds, made its first test flight today.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Dec. 15 -- Mr. and Mrs. Henry A. Haines of 853 Seventh Avenue, New York City, formerly of this city, entertained at a family dinner at their home this evening in observance of their sixty-third wedding anniversary. The couple were married in Westminster Presbyterian Church, Elizabeth, with the Rev. Francis Stoddard Haines, a brother of Mr. Haines, officiating.

NEW DELHI, India, Dec. 15 -- India and Pakistan have made a fresh start toward composing their numerous difficulties with the conclusion last night of an inter-Dominion conference in which "very substantial agreements" were reached.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 (AP) -- Hard-pressed China shipped more goods to the United States in October than she got from this country. It was the second consecutive month the civil war-besieged Chinese had done so.

Shakespeare has moved into Park Avenue. It happened quite a while ago -- when he took up his quarters there with Sir Laurence Olivier and his "Hamlet." This corner is not directly concerned with the drama, whether it's played on the flat or in the round -- on the screen or on the stage.
Woman's anxiety over the family budget and increased living costs was emphasized yesterday as a major factor in car buying by Powel Crosley Jr., president of the Crosley Motors, Inc.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Dec. 15 -- For the past two days the Dutch Cabinet has been studying the significance of a letter which it has received on behalf of Indonesian Premier Mohammed Hatta. In his letter Dr. Hatta expressed a desire to bridge the outstanding differences between the Indonesian Republic and the Netherlands.

PEIPING, Dec. 15 -- Nationalist troops moved forward today for the first time since they withdrew on all fronts with the announced intention of defending Peiping. The noise of artillery fire shook city buildings tonight as one Gen. Fu Tso-yi's best armies began to drive west from a point fewer than three miles from the city's walls.

LONDON, Dec. 15 -- Confusion over the origin of legitimate shipments of aluminum from Great Britain to the United States apparently is responsible for Washington charges that the British have been profiting by selling in the United States aluminum they had bought with Marshall Plan dollars.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, Dec. 15 -- The Hungarian Government advised the United States today to "mind its own business," and warned that American property here might be confiscated in retaliation for "damages" caused by the United States Government.

A method of operating two or more television stations on the same channel, which reduces inter-station interference and thus extends the useful range of each transmitter, was announced yesterday by Brig. Gen. David Sarnoff, chairman of the board of the Radio Corporation of America.

Last Monday morning Karen Goodman left her home in St. Ives in Muizenberg near Capetown, Union of South Africa. Before noon she was on a plane. At 4:40 A.M. yesterday she saw Manhattan from the Pan-American Constellation Paul Revere.

The art and industry award of the Educational Foundation of the Apparel Industry was presented to Miss Virginia Pope, fashion editor of THE NEW YORK TIMES, last night at the foundation's fourth annual meeting at the Needle Trades Auditorium, 225 West Twenty-fourth Street.

A guide to the "complete mastery" of the skills of baby-sitting has been scheduled for Jan. 3 publication by Little, Brown. It is "A Manual for Baby Sitters," by Marion Lowndes. The book also discusses the qualities the sitter should bring to the job, as well as the obligations of those who hire the sitter.
FRANKFORT, Germany, Dec. 15 -- A plan is under Military Government consideration whereby the three Western sectors of Berlin would be incorporated into the projected West German Government.

OTTAWA, Dec. 15 -- Following a notable improvement in her gold and United States dollar reserve position, Canada has announced further relaxations, effective Jan. 1, of the restrictions on imports of customer goods from the United States, imposed in November, 1947, when dollar reserves were discovered to be falling dangerously low.

Labor industry and insurance companies were sharply divided yesterday on a state program of disability insurance at the annual meeting of the joint legislative committee on industrial and labor conditions.

The New York Army Day Committee announced yesterday that Col. James Demarest of the Army and Rear Admiral Reginald R. Belknap of the Navy (retired) would be co-chairmen of the annual Army Day exercises here on April 9.

"All lost things are in the angels' keeping," a poet has written. The Hundred Neediest Cases fund welcomes this year a unique contribution from a Brooklyn family, who told the story of their stewardship in a letter yesterday to THE TIMES. Sending their check for $5.35, they wrote as follows: "The enclosed check represents the amount many individuals will unwittingly contribute toward the Neediest Cases this year.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 (AP) -- Foreign aid under the Marshall Plan passed the $4,000,000,000 mark today when the Economic Cooperation Administration approved recovery grants amounting to $59,313,624. The total now stands at $4,030,196,423.

The State Temporary Commission to Study Rents will recommend extension of the state residential and commercial rent control laws to the Legislature at its approaching session. Assemblyman D. Mallory Stephens, chairman of the commission, announced last night.

KINGS POINT, L.I., Dec. 15 -- Despite the fact that American-flag shipping has fallen off considerably in recent months, with the result that many men and ships are idle, there remains a good future for the nation's merchant fleet and the men who man it, Vice Admiral W.W. Smith, chairman of the United States Maritime Commission, said today.

Little progress was made yesterday in efforts to negotiate a new contract for tugboat workers as employers' representatives rejected the demands of Local 333, United Marine Division, on the ground that they would increase the operating cost of a standard type, three-crew tug by "at least 130 per cent."

Consumer reaction to early showings of spring suits has been excellent, according to New York manufacturers of women's apparel. Heavy reorders have been received from all sections of the country, they said yesterday, indicating that the stores which have featured the merchandise have chalked up sizable early business.

FAIRBANKS, Alaska, Dec. 15 (UP) -- Six airmen stranded in the frozen wastes of Yukon Territory when their plane crash-landed were saved yesterday in the first glider-snatch rescue in the region's history, the Air Force announced today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- A subcommittee of the House Committee on Foreign Affairs, upon returning today from a twenty-five-day tour of Latin America, implied that the revolt in E1 Salvador had been en couraged by the resolution adopted at the Pan American Conference in Bogota, Colombia, last April providing for "automatic" recognition of governments that come into power by force in this hemisphere.

LONDON, Dec. 15 -- The British Government has no present intention of publicly reaffirming support of the Chinese Government. On the contrary, certain high British officials now regard the formation of a coalition regime as not only certain but preferable to the administration of President Chiang Kai-shek.

The formation of Teleconcert, Inc., a company with offices at Steinway Hall, 113 West Fifty-seventh Street, to produce and distribute "musical motion pictures for the telescreen, regular motion-picture theatre presentation and 16mm, use for the home," was announced yesterday by the company.

Another Soviet veto -- No. 29 -- fell on the table of the Security Council yesterday when Russia, supported only by the Soviet Ukraine, blocked Ceylon's bid for admission to the United Nations. The merits of the case were clear enough. Under the Independence Act of 1947 Ceylon has achieved fully responsible status within the British Commonwealth.

Resort fashions for sports, spectator and cocktail wear were shown yesterday by Russeks at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. For those flying south, a slim suit of bittersweet gabardine with a trim jacket buttoning to a small, high scalloped collar was offered.

SYRACUSE, Dec. 15 -- Left-wing elements in the State Congress of Industrial Organizations suffered a series of setbacks today as the State CIO executive board met in preparation for the opening of the organization's annual convention here tomorrow.

The illness of a juror caused a mistrial yesterday in one case being heard in Bronx County Courthouse and interrupted a second trial there for more than half an hour so that its defendant, a physician, could treat the ill man.

Benjamin Parry, who retires Dec. 31 from the Weather Bureau after forty-five years of service, was honored yesterday by the Maritime Association of the Port of New York with a reception at the Maritime Exchange, 80 Broad Street.

The Marion Power Shovel Company's offer of exchange dated April 9, 1948, to holders of its 7 per cent cumulative preferred stock was withdrawn yesterday because of the number of undeposited shares, Elmer G. Diefenbach, board chairman, announced.

The Midwest and the Southwest will supply the visiting teams in tonight's college basketball double-header at Madison Square Garden. The pairings are Bradley against Manhattan and Texas against New York University, in that order of presentation.

A holiday exhibition and sale of 650 paintings by twenty-one contemporary Italian, Swiss and Austrian artists opens tomorrow to aid the New York Heart Association at 546 Fifth Avenue. Although, for the most part unknown in this country, a number of the group's members have had their pictures exhibited in various cities in Continental Europe.
Bernard H. McGuinness has been appointed vice president of the Robins Conveyors division of Hewitt-Robins, Inc., materials handling equipment manufacturers.

Marshal Tito is starving the Yugoslav people by pushing through "the mirage of his five-year plan" in an effort to prove that he still is a Communist, King Peter of Yugoslavia declared here yesterday.

Your editorial "Aid to China," on Dec. 8, gives hope that the case of China may eventually be understood. In comparing the sums apportioned "to two small Mediterranean countries, Greece and Turkey," with those of China with its 450 million population, you rightly conclude that "the whole operation of American aid has obviously been conducted on a shoestring."
LOS ANGELES, Dec. 15 -- Three members of the Communist party who twice refused to testify before a Federal grand jury were found guilty tonight in Federal District Court of Criminal contempt.

NORTH CONWAY, N.H., Dec. 15 -- North Conway's fabulous Cranmore Mountain, with its ingenious system of getting uphill by skimobile, is all set to entertain the biggest throngs that have visited this popular Eastern slope region since its creation in 1938.

The first Harmsworth race in fifteen years has become a certainty with the filing of a challenge by Canada in its effort to lift the famous trophy given by the late Lord Northcliffe and won repeatedly by Gar Wood of Detroit.

Rarely have two more astonishingly contradictory stories been told than those of Alger Hiss and Whittaker Chambers. In the dramatic course of the puzzling hearings it became increasingly plain that someone was lying. Yesterday, through its perjury indictments, the grand jury said it was Mr. Hiss.

CAIRO, Egypt, Dec. 15 -- The Arab League Council will be reconvened to consider the consequences of Trans-Jordan-Palestine unification under King Abdullah as soon as the new Syrian Government is formed, the chairman of the Council, El Kadi Mohammed el Emeri of Yemen, announced today.

Women in Russia undoubtedly have more equality in a greater variety of jobs than do American women, but "it is an equality of slavery," Dorothy Kenyon, United States delegate to the United Nations Commission on the Status of Women, declared here yesterday.
Luncheon guests sheltered from the snow in the Cotillion Room of the Pierre Hotel yesterday, viewed some of the scanty play clothes soon to be worn on the beaches in warmer climates.

A gift of $3,600,000 is to be distributed during Christmas week by the Greater New York Fund, Henry C. Brunie, president of the Empire Trust Company and head of the fund, announced yesterday. The fund's total distributions for the year will be $4,348,551, against $3,939,305 in 1947.

Joe Louis returned to New York yesterday, primed for the final installment of his 1948 exhibition boxing tour and declaring with more emphasis than before that he planned a defense of his title next June.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- About once every month or so, the United States Government finds itself in an extremely awkward position at home and abroad entirely because of some casual remark, some inadvertent observation, or some impetuous decision.

A model who tried unsuccessfully to skid on a specially treated scatter rug helped introduce a new group of "super non-skid" cotton rugs shown yesterday by the Aldon Rug Mills, Inc., during a luncheon meeting at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

GUATEMALA, Dec. 15 (AP) -- A United States Embassy spokesman in San Salvador said today no injuries to United States citizens and no damage to United States property occurred yesterday during three hours of fighting in the Salvadorean capital.

BOSTON, Dec. 15 (AP) -Monreal's Cs_nadiens, who had been finding the National Hockey League a rocky road of late, put on a three-goal scoring burst in the: final period to defeat the Boston Bruins, 4 -- 2, tonight before 12,882 fans at th Boston Garden.

The headline "State Maps Cure of Mentally Ill in Long-Range Outlay of Millions" is one more case of putting the cart in front of the horse. Why not use accessible simple prevention besides attempted cure?

VIENNA, Dec. 15 -- Austrian sources said tonight that United States intelligence officers have at last been admitted to the Franz Josef Hospital, in the Russian zone of Vienna, obviously to interrogate Dana Superina, the Yugoslav woman who was with Irving Ross of the Economic Cooperation Administration when he was beaten to death last Oct. 30.

LONDON, Dec. 15 -- All countries represented in the six-power Ruhr conference are understood today to have agreed in principle to the French demand that powers of supervision over the management and policy of the Ruhr industries should be vested in an international Ruhr authority that the conference proposes to create.

James Dear, British open court tennis champion ended his American visit yesterday by pairing with Alastair B. Martin to win the invitation doubles tournament at the Racquet and Tennis Club. After the match, held in the morning, he sailed for home aboard the Cunard liner Britannic.

ALBANY, Dec. 15 -- The need for building new schools and modernizing existing buildings together with means for financing the costs will be examined by Governor Dewey and legislative leaders in the next few weeks, the Governor said today.
PRAGUE, Dec. 15 -- Soviet Russia will lend Czechoslovakia some of her gold and dollar stores to put the Czech economy in repair, it was disclosed tonight.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- Gen-Dwight D. Eisenhower, now president of Columbia University, is still advising top-level defense officials and will continue to do so.

Driving home two goals within the short space of 27 seconds in the final period, the New York Rangers subdued the Toronto Maple Leafs, 3 to 1, at Madison Square Garden last night. The brace of tallies served to double-rivet an advantage the Blue Shirts held over their National Hockey League rivals from the first chapter.

CHICAGO, Dec. 15 (AP) -- The Chicago Black Hawks gained in the National Hockey League standings tonight with a 5-1 victory over first place Detroit before 14,728 fans. The Hawks, in third place, thus moved to within 3 points of Boston and 4 of Detroit.

Speaking at Chicago this week, Secretary of the Treasury Snyder told the American Bankers Association that the Administration has no intention of abandoning its program of supporting the government bond market. His statement removes any possible doubt that the Treasury is aligned squarely with the country's other monetary authorities -- the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System and the Federal Open Market Committee -- on this basic and controversial issue.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- Secretary of the Treasury John W. Snyder, confronted by charges that the Federal Government is taking 75 per cent of the American tax dollar, today told the American Municipal Association that "we will try to get together and work this thing out, where you have your field and the Federal Government has theirs."

With its dairy business expanding, the Cornell Dairy Farms bought the forty-two-acre Clark Farm at South Washington Avenue, adjoining the Lake Nelson development, in Piscataway Township, Middlesex County, N.J., from Louis Kamm.

ALBANY, Dec. 15 -- The Democratic program for financing disability benefits for those who become ill while unemployed would violate Federal law, Senator Benjamin F. Feinberg, President pro tem of the State Senate, asserted today in a reply to a recent proposal of Paul E. Fitzpatrick, Democratic State Chairman.

Action on the long-standing question of city pier rentals will be taken up today at an open hearing of the Board of Estimate, it was announced yesterday. At an executive session the board decided to take action on the pending report of Controller Lazarus Joseph recommending reversion to the 1928 formula of pier rentals, which the shipping industry charges will drive business from the port.

The Council of the Organization of American States has taken a step which marks an encouraging advance in inter-American relations. This is its decision calling for consultation among the Hemisphere's Foreign Ministers and ordering the dispatch to Costa Rica of a mission of inquiry to determine the validity of the Costa Rican charge that an invasion of its territory from Nicaragua has been aided by the Government of that country.

Efforts are under way to obtain approval by the Joint Export-Import Agency, at Frankfurt, Germany, of a barter deal whereby Greece and Turkey will supply 55,000,000 pounds of cigarette tobacco during the next two years in return for German manufactured goods, it was reported here yesterday.

PRETORIA, South Africa, Dec. 15 -- South Africa's new Nationalist Government began recruiting today a new citizen force to be known as "Rifle Commandos" in rural areas among men from 17 to 60 years of age.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Dec. 15 -- Rutgers took the lead over Columbia in the early seconds tonight and didn't lose it to gain its first basketball victory over an out-of-state opponent this season, 59 -- 52.

Representatives of two maritime unions reached agreements yesterday with employer groups that will give their membership wage parity with other waterfront labor organizations previously granted rises in pay.

Early and decisive action by the United States in promoting non-Communist self-governing democracies in Indonesia and Indo-China might have prevented the present impasse in China, it was agreed last night by four participants in a forum discussion broadcast over Station WQXR.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- Formation of a top-ranking advisory group of military and civilian specialists to throw the full strength of the nation's scientific resources into an appraisal of all weapons and "weapons systems" was reported today by James Forrestal, Secretary of Defense.

The United States must take greater interest in African education if American ideals are to have any permanent influence on that continent, Prince A.A. Nwafor Orizu of Nnewi, Nigeria, warned here yesterday.
CHICAGO, Dec. 15 -- Wilhelm Furtwaengler, noted German conductor, found himself in the position today of accepting an offer which apparently had not been made.

A Christmas Eve television show entitled "Surprise From Santa," with Whitford Kane playing the snowy bearded gentleman against a fictional setting in Central Park, will be put on the air from 7 to 8:30 P.M. by WCBS-TV. The story line will develop when Santa encounters several New York children.

COROLLA, N.C., Dec. 15 -- The Whalehead Club, where we shot today, has a history and tradition that goes back to the days when waterfowl laws and seasons were unknown, and to a time when "damyankee" was two words applying only to an obnoxious individual from above the line.
LONDON, Dec. 15 -- Although the start of the new account in the stock market here today produced no marked revival of business, the day was brightened by some sharp movements in prices.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 (AP) -- Pan American Airways and American Overseas Airlines asked the Civil Aeronautics Board today to approve a proposed sale of AOA's Trans-Atlantic route and equipment for a minimum of $18,845,615.

TOKYO, Dec. 15 -- Both the Japanese and the Americans are watching with considerable interest the discussion in Washington of means of guaranteeing Japanese security in face of a possible Communist triumph in China.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- A commission of five members was approved by the Council of the Organization of American States today to investigate the border situation in Costa Rica, where an armed force of 1,000 men is reported to have crossed into that country from Nicaragua.

HAVANA, Dec. 15 (AP) -- Sam Snead of White Sulphur Springs, W. Va., leading all the way, won the Havana best-ball golf tournament today with a score of 193, twenty-three strokes under par. E. J. (Dutch) Harrison of Little Rock, Ark., who fired a 67 over the par-72 course on his final tour, finished second, one stroke back.

THE man alone has had many names in the history of our country. He has been Thoreau in Walden's neighborly solitude and Hemingway writing of Spain in American ranch lands that may have reminded him of Castile. He has been the white-maned Mark Twain in bed with the foolscap pages sliding to the floor and the living Hawthorne in dying Salem.

To their many other notable achievements through the baseball campaign of 1948 the champion Cleveland Indians added the distinction of leading the American League in defensive skill, announcement of the official fielding averages yesterday disclosed.

GENEVA, Dec. 9 -- Apart from the obviously overwhelming role of the United States in determining whether there will be war or peace, two aspects of American policy strike Europeans as critical determinants of the success of the European Recovery Program.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- The Congress of Industrial Organizations turned over the job of organizing department store and allied workers today to the Amalgamated Clothing Workers, one of its strongest unions.

BOISE, Idaho, Dec. 15 (AP) -- The National Sugar Beet Growers Federation voted today to ask the Department of Agriculture to publish a cost survey on beet production and sugar manufacture and to break it down in the smallest possible areas.

NANKING, Dee. 15 -- Dr. Hu Shih, president of the National Peiping University and a former Chinese Ambassador to the United States, arrived here tonight from Peiping by a special plane dispatched by President Chiang Kai-shek.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- The way for a resumption of negotiations with the Soviet Union for an adjustment of her wartime lend-lease account was paved today with an announcement by Acting Secretary of State Robert A. Lovett that Moscow had agreed to return three American icebreakers and twenty-eight frigates lent to Russia during the war.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows, the Federal Reserve Board announced today, the following principal changes for the week ended Dec. 8:

PARIS, Dec. 15 -- The Soviet Union vetoed the application of Ceylon for membership in the United Nations at a meeting of the Security Council here today. The vote was 9 to 2, with only Russia and the Ukraine in opposition, the Russian vote constituting a veto.
Youngsters selected as outstanding "good citizens" of the play centers were honored yesterday in 175 community centers in ceremonies marking Youth for Freedom Day.

Lily Pons, who has been a leading light at the Metropolitan for almost twenty years, made her first appearance of the season at the Opera House last night as Gilda in "Rigoletto." It was the season's second "Rigoletto" and the only other important change in the cast had Cloe Elmo in the role of Maddalena.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange turned easier yesterday. Final prices were 11 to 30 points net lower.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 15 -- "The First Legion," Emmett Lavery's 1934 play about the Society of Jesus, will be filmed in France next year by Julien Duvivier, the playwright has disclosed.

TOKYO, Dec. 15 -- Perhaps the outstanding fact about the national indignation over Japan's latest sensation, the forced resignation of Finance Minister Sanroku Izumiyama, is the fact that it does not quite ring true. The incident itself is merely another illustration of the Imperial Diet's growing cynicism over being merely a rubber stamp for occupation policies.

PARIS, Dec. 15 -- France is renouncing part of her sovereignty to a higher international sovereignty, according to the preamble of a bill on military organization, passed by the Defense Committee of the National Assembly today.

In order to provide for the expansion of its New York sales office and showroom, the Hobart Manufacturing Company has leased the large corner store and basement at 260 Fourth Avenue. Bastine Co., Inc., and Cushman Wakefield, Inc., renting and managing agent of the building, were the brokers in the transaction.

LONDON, Thursday, Dec. 16 (AP) -- The Moscow radio said today that twelve directors and engineers of Soviet factories had received prison terms of five to seven years each for turning out defective products.

The Port of New York Authority has canceled $854,000 worth of essential equipment required for the completion of the Newark Union Motor Truck Terminal because of action by a Newark local of the Teamsters Union "intended to kill" the development, Austin Tobin, executive director of the bi-state agency, declared yesterday.
LOS ANGELES, Dec. 15 -- The J.W. Robinson Company, downtown department store, is taking over the retail business of Gilbert Adrian, the designer, in Beverly Hills, it was announced tonight.

BERLIN, Dec. 15 -- Despite the overwhelming anti-Communist vote in the recent elections, Communist party leaders in Berlin believe that the "revolutionary" situation still exists in the city and have pledged themselves to "break" the power of the democratic parties in 1949.

CHICAGO, Dec. 15 -- With major league magnates and their retinues evacuating the city in battalions it remained for the lingering Dodgers today to close a startling deal after the wind-up of the annual December baseball conclaves.

Dr. Victor K. LaMer, well-known Columbia University chemist, was elected president of The New York Academy of Sciences at the 131st annual dinner and meeting of the society at the Astor Hotel last night. He will direct a $1,000,000 fund-raising drive, recently started to purchase a permanent building for the academy.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- The Michigan election authorities were asked today by the Senate not to destroy the Nov. 2 ballots by which a Republican Senator, Homer Ferguson, was declared re-elected.

NEW DELHI, India, Dec. 15 -- United States money, through the Marshall Plan, is supporting colonial powers against freedom movements in Southeast Asia and this is costing the United States the good-will of native peoples, Senator George W. Malone, Republican, of Nevada, declared today.

Capt. Harold G. Bradbury, who has been stationed here for the last three years as chief of staff of the Third Coast Guard District, was relieved of his post yesterday to assume a similar assignment in the First District, with headquarters in Boston.

Meat prices have fallen as much as 17 per cent in retail food stores throughout the country since the highs of late summer and early fall, the National Association of Retail Grocers announced yesterday in Chicago.
At least one scientist of suspected Communist sympathies worked at the Army's Aberdeen Proving Ground in Maryland during the war years, according to reliable informants.

MARBURG, Germany, Dec. 15 (AP) -- A German maid testified before a United States military court today that Mrs. Wilma Ybarbo of Walden, Mass., bloodied the nose of her husband, then shot him in a quarrel.

Speaking of the dirt of Harlem streets, THE TIMES intimated several weeks ago that the residents were largely to blame. Another New York newspaper is now offering cash prizes to Harlem residents who keep their streets clean.

LONDON, Dec. 15 -- The tiniest of Royal Highnesses, Princess Elizabeth's baby, was christened this afternoon Charles Philip Arthur George. This was the first of innumerable cere monies that should some day or other include a coronation as King of England and it was a singularly happy one.

LONDON, Dec. 15 -- Deportation orders on charges of fraud had been issued against Sidney Stanley, central figure in the tribunal of inquiry here, and his brother Marcus Wulkan, now a naturalized American, Sir Hartley Shawcross, Attorney General, brought out today in the questioning of the final witness.

The first jump in holiday sales yesterday brought estimates by retailers of a 5 to 10 per cent increase for the week compared with the corresponding week last year. For the past six weeks sales have been behind last year.
CHICAGO, Dec. 15 (AP) -- The nation's savings associations were called on by leaders of their policy-making body today to channel half their 1949 mortgage funds into new low-priced homes.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- Spokesmen for two of the smaller companies in the oil and automobile industries argued today against an excess profits tax on grounds that it would arrest or retard essential industrial growth, one of them declaring that even talk of such a tax was "proving a disruptive force."

New regulations affecting streets that carry traffic feeding into Canal Street from tunnels, highways and bridges were announced yesterday by Police Commissioner Arthur W. Wallander. The regulations, which will go into effect at 8 A.M. Saturday for a sixty-day trial, are aimed at breaking the traffic bottleneck along the crosstown artery.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- Secret mathematical formulae vital to duplication of bomb sights and believed to concern the famed Norden sight were stolen and delivered to Russia in 1938, reports reaching the House Committee on Un-American Activities indicated today as it pursued its spy hunt.

The rising birth rate and the increasing school population may deprive the city of its last remaining "one-room" school. Public School 10, Richmond's ochre-colored "little red school house," may be forced to use an overflow classroom next term, thereby ending the distinction of New Dorp's fifty-four-year-old building.

ROME, Dec. 15 -- The President of the Italian Republic, Luigi Einaudi, accompanied by Foreign Minister Count Carlo Sforza, was received in solemn audience by Pope Pius XII in the Vatican this morning.
ENDICOTT, N.Y., Dec. 15 (AP) -- George W. Johnson resigned today as president of the Endicott Johnson Corporation and was elected chairman of the board.

Anticipating Christmastide festivity, this column has taken a look into international cookery to borrow from other lands their favorite holiday toast. The result is a collection, "Six Christmas Punches," that may be had free from Dept. FN, THE NEW YORK TIMES, 229 West Forty-third Street, New York 18, N.Y.

Two goals by Steve Leonard in a ten-minute overtime period gave the St. Paul's School hockey team a 3-2 triumph over the Princeton Freshmen at Madison Square Garden yesterday afternoon before 3,000 fans. The victory stretched the New Hampshire schoolboys' streak to nine straight in this annual contest and also gave them the series edge over the Princeton cubs, 16 victories to 15, with one game ending in a tie.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- Koppers Coke Company, Inc., Pittsburgh, Pa., filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement covering 400,000 shares of $10 par value common stock that is to be offered through a group of underwriters headed by the First Boston Corporation.

LONDON, Dec. 15 -- Jaromir Weinberger's "Schwanda, the Bagpiper," was revived here tonight by Sadlers Wells to provide some gay Christmas fare. For eight or nine years after its first performance in Prague in 1927, "Schwanda" was immensely popular in central and eastern Europe and even had its day at New York's Metropolitan Opera House in November, 1931.

Changes in assignments of officers of the Title Guarantee and Trust Company, affecting the head office and branches in Brooklyn, Jamaica, Queens, Suffolk and Westchester, were announced yesterday by Barnard Townsend, president.

President Truman called Vice President-elect Alben W. Barkley the "finest and most capable partner any President could ever have." He declared that Senator Barkley would be his "good right arm" in the work ahead to make the nation and the world peaceful and prosperous.

The 200 per cent increase in the number of radio stations since 1940, contrasted with a decrease in the number of daily newspapers, provides strong evidence of the publications' greater power as an advertising medium, according to a business letter being sent out today by the American Newspaper Advertising Network Inc.

PARIS, Dec. 16 -- Premier Henri Queuille won a parliamentary skirmish today against Pierre de Gaulle, brother of Charles de Gaulle and leader of the de Gaullist forces in the Council of the Republic. But his majority was only twenty.

ALBANY, Dec. 16 -- Voluntary hospitals in the state are in urgent need of better financial foundations but their situation is not so precarious as to warrant emergency stop-gap state legislation at this time, according to Dr. Eli Ginzberg of Columbia University.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- President Truman announced at his weekly news conference today that he would personally deliver his State of the Union message at a joint session of Congress at 1 P.M. on Jan. 5. He also said he would send a special message later on foreign affairs.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- The United Steelworkers (CIO) has called upon Secretary of Labor Maurice J. Tobin to raise the minimum wage rates in the iron and steel industry for work on Government contracts.

The Board of Estimate voted yesterday to acquire title to property at Tudor City Place in the vicinity of East Forty-second Street to permit street widenings that would expedite plans for development of the United Nations headquarters project in mid-Manhattan.

Reginald Kell, generally considered to be England's No. 1 clarinetist, has decided to try his luck in this country. Following his "wayward instinct," he has pulled up his stakes at home, brought over his wife and young son and taken a house in Larchmont, N.Y.

Dr. Dezso Sulyok, former leader of the Hungarian Liberty party, has begun an action in Supreme Court for $77,966 against the Penzintezeti Kozpont Budapest also known as the Central Corporation of Banking Companies for services as president of the corporation.

A sweeping investigation by a Federal grand jury looking into possible violations of the anti-trust laws by electrical contractors in the metropolitan area was disclosed yesterday when an attorney for thirty-five concerns moved in Federal Court to quash subpoenas calling for the production of their business records.

No progress was reported last night after a two-session, all-day meeting between committees representing tugboat workers and owners. The meeting was held under the auspices of the United States Mediation and Conciliation Service at its regional offices, 341 Ninth Avenue.
BERLIN, Dec. 16 (AP) -- The text of a statement by General Ganeval on the destruction of the towers of the Russians' Radio Berlin:
Thank you for your two splendid editorials on the subject of our "Fishing-Boat Immigrants." Your position was well taken and the Government has already followed your advice.

N.Y.U. suffered its second one- point setback of the season last night, bowing to Texas, 58 -- 57. But even in defeat, the Violet gained stature via an amazing comeback that captured the admiration of 15,423 spectators at Madison Square Garden.

Richard J. Walsh, president of the Correction Officers Benevolent Association, Inc., was questioned late yesterday afternoon at the offices of John M. Murtagh, Investigation Commissioner, at 50 Pine Street, concerning a report that he had received a cash gift of $2,700 from members of the association.

Joseph E. O'Grady, deputy director of the city's Division of Labor Relations, was sworn in yesterday by Mayor O'Dwyer to head the division beginning Jan. 1. Mr. O'Grady will succeed Theodore W. Kheel, who recently submitted his resignation, effective Jan. 1, to enter private law practice.

TOKYO, Friday, Dec. 17 (AP) -- Paul G. Hoffman, Chief of the Economic Cooperation Administration, said today that he was "not accurately quoted" in stories on his Shanghai press conference regarding aid to China in case the Communists or a coalition government took over.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- More than a score of diplomatic documents were given out by the House Un-American Activities Committee today. They reveal that Germany late in 1937 and in 1938 made what appeared to responsible officials to be a sincere effort to improve relations with the United States, only to be rebuffed.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- The Eberstadt committee of the Hoover Commission revealed today that "mistaken" intelligence analyses made by one department last spring might have led to "serious consequences," presumably war, had the errors not been detected by other governmental intelligence groups.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- The Eberstadt Committee of the Hoover Commission called attention today to "a growing belief" among high officials that "victory by bankruptcy may be the Machiavellian aim of the Kremlin."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- Henry F. Grady, United States Ambassador to Greece, estimated after a White House visit today that about $400,000,000 would be needed to continue the Greek aid program next year. This would include a renewal of the $200,000,000 allotted to Greece under the European Recovery Program, he explained.

HOLTSVILLE, L.I., Dec. 16 -- Local volunteer firemen and Brookhaven town police were preparing tonight to start searching through the still-smoldering wreckage of a home on Woodycrest Drive, here, for the body of 6-year-old Carol Louise Sabine, who was burned to death there early today.

LONDON, Dec. 16 -- The damage that the tribunal of inquiry into alleged frauds at the Board of Trade has caused to reputations formed the keynote of today's proceedings. The tribunal is hearing speeches from a distinguished array of "King's Counsel" on behalf of clients who were brought into the proceedings.
Six players from the National League and five stars from the All-America Conference have been named on The Associated Press 1948 All-Pro football team announced yesterday.

Jacob S. Potofsky, president of the Amalgamated Clothing Workers, CIO, announced yesterday that his strong and wealthy union would begin an immediate, intensive and costly organizing drive among the nation's hundreds of thousands of department store workers.

Unless state and Federal governments cooperate, inefficiency in tax administration will continue to burden the taxpayer, Mortimer M. Kassell, counsel to the New York State Department of Taxation and Finance, declared last night at the 1948 Tax Institute symposium at the Pennsylvania Hotel.

The fifteen-billion-dollar mark in defense spending will constitute the border line between return of a seller's market and a resuming spiral of wages and prices, it was predicted last night by Dr. Marcus Nadler, Professor of Finance at New York University.

"For entertainment and recreation," a watchman in 1934 and 1985 tapped the telephone wires of the White House and several offices of members of Congress. This disclosure from a former Naval officer provided the high-light yesterday at the seventh meeting of a special committee investigating wire tapping for the New York County Criminal Courts Bar Association.

Slimmer season collection of members of the Fashion Originators' Guild of America will be introduced in a market period beginning Monday, Feb. 7, it was announced yesterday by Leonard W. Gendler, executive secretary. Member firms, Mr. Gendler said, have no second spring lines and will devote their efforts to prepare outstanding summer collections.

ATHENS, Dec. 16 -- Kenneth C. Royall, United States Secretary of the Army, here on a two-day visit, paid tribute at a press conference today to "the courage, determination and patriotic spirit of the Greek nation." The Greek people, he predicted, would make "further progress in combatting the cruel and oppressive forces of totalitarianism."

With nearly 25,000 temporary employes slowly being pressed into service, the Post Office is girding itself for the last week of what is predicted will be the greatest pre-Christmas mailing rush in its history.

PRAGUE, Dec. 16 (AP) -- Czechoslovak political police have been holding an American-born woman incommunicado in prison since last Saturday. This was disclosed today when the police refused to reveal the charges against her or allow United States consular officials to see her.
Edward S. Frese has been appointed a vice president of the Grace National Bank. He has been with the bank seventeen years and was previously president of the Bank Credit Associates of New York.

The recent letter "The Third Labor Factor." by E.L. Stephens, in THE NEW YORK TIMES interests me as a nonunion worker and a firm believer in self-determination of minorities and majorities. But it fascinates me as an exercise in illogic.

LONDON, Dec. 16 -- Winston Churchill and Anthony Eden wanted to know in the House of Commons today how a British Mosquito photo reconnaissance plane reportedly shot down by an Israeli fighter happened to have been in such a dangerous area. They did not find out.
BERNE, Switzerland, Dec. 16 -- A Socialist was elected President of the Swiss Federation today for the first time in history.

Several carpet manufacturers are considering price increases because of steadily rising carpet wool costs since the last industry-wide price advance in September, mill executives revealed yesterday. Two leading mills reported that they have the question "under study" and a third smaller but very important mill is known to be contemplating a price increase.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Dec. 16 -- Sister Elizabeth Kenny, the Australian nurse who originated the widely acclaimed Kenny treatment for infantile paralysis, charged today that thousands of American children and adults who fall victims to polio "become needlessly deformed and crippled" because they do not receive the Kenny treatment "in its entirey."

Thirty years ago Quentin, a shy 7-year-old boy who had been deserted by his parents, was one of The New York Times Neediest Cases. Through its help he was cared for and adopted, and today, a war veteran, an electrician and a father, he leads a happy, useful life in the community.

Three solicitous robbers interrupted their thievery shortly after noon yesterday to care for a child who became ill at seeing her mother tied up, then ransacked the house in Brooklyn and escaped with $5,000 worth of valuables.

Ordinarily we do not sum up results on the Neediest Cases appeal until Christmas Day, but we feel impelled this year to make an interim report. Friends of the Neediest will be concerned to learn, we believe, that the number of those giving to the fund in this thirty-seventh annual appeal is running considerably behind last year.
Msgr. Joseph Flannelly was consecrated titular Bishop of Metelis, and auxiliary to the Archbishop of New York before a host of some 3,000 in St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday.

A Government civil anti-trust suit against three optical concerns and seven of their officers in connection with the sale of bifocal lenses was dismissed by Federal Judge Sylvester J. Ryan yesterday with the consent of both sides.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 (AP) -- The Bureau of Mines estimated today that there are 500,000,000 tons of iron in Iron County, Utah, much of it good enough for use in western steel production. It said its estimate is based upon wartime surveys of about half of the major iron-bearing areas of the county.
Peter Harisiades, former secretary of the Greek bureau of the Communist party here, was ordered yesterday to be deported as a Communist alien.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- The advantages of collective bargaining over paternalism are emphasized in the National Planning Association's newest case study of "the Causes of Industrial Peace."

The Packard Federal Corporation has enlarged its holdings in the Bronx where it has purchased approximately 10,000 square feet of vacant land at 342-348 Walton Avenue from Arthur A. Evans. The James H. Burns Company was the broker in the transaction.

As a member of the President's Committee on Civil Rights, and of the National Committee on Segregation in the nation's capital, I want to thank you whole-heartedly for your recent editorial giving support to the President's Program of Civil Rights, and especially for your forthright condemnation of discrimination in Washington, which was published in THE TIMES of Dec. 12.

CLEVELAND, Dec. 16 (UP) -- Peace in jig time was both the desire and the prophecy of All America Football Conference officials as they gathered here tonight for a meeting tomorrow, Saturday and Monday.

Directors of the J. Henry Schroder Banking Corporation and Schroder Trust Company announced yesterday the payment of a Christmas bonus to all personnel. Depending on length of service, employes will receive up to 10 per cent of their annual salaries.

LONDON, Dec. 16 -- Shell's offer of two ordinary shares for one share of Venezuelan Oil Concessions enlivened the oil section of the stock market here today. In a crowded market, prices fluctuated rapidly and gave jobbers their busiest day for some time.

Benjamin Parry is a kindly, soft-spoken man, a hunter, a fisherman, a gardener, a Boy Scout counselor. As such he is treated charitably. In his alter ego, daytime role as an official weather man Mr. Parry has been within firing range of the slings and arrows of outrageous fortune for forty-five years.

VIENNA, Dec. 16 -- Clyde King, new chief of the Economic Cooperation Administration mission in Austria, vetoed today an Austrian ration increase and brought to an abrupt halt the effort by the Austrian Ministry of Food to repeat so-called political blackmail tactics successfully practiced during recent years to obtain from the United States increased deliveries for relief.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Dec. 16 (AP) -- The Netherland Government refused today to accept a letter from Indonesian Premier Mohammed Hatta as the basis for new negotiations with the Indonesian Republic.

LONDON, Dec. 16 -- The first tangible results of United States aid policy of reviving confidence among Western European nations in the currencies of their neighbors appeared here tonight in a trade and financial pact concluded between Britain and Sweden.

Re-enactment of the wartime excess-profits tax by the Eighty-first Congress will become a reality only if increased income should be necessary, or if Congress is convinced of its potency as an essential weapon in its anti-inflation program, Vice President-elect Alben W. Barkley predicted yesterday.

TULSA, Okla., Dec. 16 (AP) -- Phillips Petroleum Company announced tonight that the price of crude oil would be reduced 35 cents a barrel at 7 A.M. tomorrow -- cutting it back to the $2.65 level in effect on Sept. 28 when an increase was posted.

LONDON, Dec. 16 -- The 14,000-ton light aircraft carrier Terrible was renamed the Sydney today and was formally transferred to Australia in ceremonies in the Royal Naval Dockyards at Devon-port. Viscount Hall, First Lord of the Admiralty, on behalf of the British Government, turned the vessel over to J. B. Beasley, Australian High Commissioner.

WMCA's new frequency-modulation station, WMCA-FM, will open Christmas Day, according to an announcement yesterday by Nathan Straus, president of the station. The outlet will operate on Channel 222, or a frequency of 92.3 megacycles.

What the trade describes as the regular pre-holiday slump in meat buying is reflected today in lower beef and lamb prices. In retail stores six cuts of beef and four of lamb are from 2 to 4 cents lower than a week ago. The United States Department of Agriculture reports that veal is the only meat in limited supply.

SEOUL, Korea, Dec. 16 -- Paul G. Hoffman, chief of the Economic Cooperation Administration, today said at a press conference, "Korea can very well be one of the proving grounds of democratic principles for all of Asia."

After a try-out period of about seven years "Lend an Ear" has finally come to New York where it took up residence at the National last evening. This seems to be an admirable way of getting ready for a Christmas opening. For Charles Gaynor's intimate musical revue is a model of skill and taste in this style of fooling, and it is performed by some fresh-grown youngsters whose talents have not been corrupted yet.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- President Truman said today that his opinion of the Congressional spy hunt -- that it was a red herring to divert public attention from the record of the Eightieth Congress -- had not been changed by the indictment yesterday of Alger Hiss, former State Department official.

CAIRO, Dec. 16 -- The Egyptian-held section of Palestine, between Gaza and the Egyptian frontier, is at present jammed with 250,000 refugees whose care officially will become the responsibility of the Society of Friends on Jan. 1 as part of the new United Nations Palestine refugee organization headed by Stanton Griffis, United States Ambassador to Egypt.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- Several changes affecting rules and regulations under the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 and the Securities Act of 1933 and a decision to abandon its "liberal policy" of granting extensions of time for filing annual and other periodic reports under the former act were announced today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- H.G. Batcheller, president of the Allegheny Ludlum Steel Corporation predicted today that a fourth round of wage increases would force another round of price rises.

The first of last February I began sending out personal letters along with a mimeographed proposal, or memorandum, for aid to Europe and elsewhere, which I believed might be included in the Marshall Plan. I sent over 300 copies to leaders in this country and abroad.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- A committee of distinguished Americans published today a detailed and basic criticism, not only of the national security organization, but of the nation's thinking about the problems of modern defense.

Sudden strength in the gold-mining issues produced no appreciable change yesterday in the irregularly lower pattern followed this week by the shares market on the Stock Exchange. Narrow movements persisted throughout the session and, aside from gains of a point and more by the gold shares, fractional changes predominated, with the price average down 0.37 on the day.

The Egyptian military officials who boarded the Isbrandtsen Line's Flying Trader at Port Said on Nov. 14 were determined to remove the thirty-eight boxed half-track trucks included in the ship's cargo "regardless of who owned them or what their destination might be,"

James J. Wadsworth, special assistant to Paul G. Hoffman, Adminstrator of the Economic Cooperation Administration, declared last night that "howls" of anguish and the furor of strikes in Communist areas were "proof that we are successfully combating the chaos so dear to their hearts."

TEL AVIV, Israel, Dec. 16 -- A British announcement today that a missing Royal Air Force Mosquito fighter plane was believed to have been shot down over Tel Aviv on Nov. 20 has solved a mystery that had the Israeli Government baffled up to now.

The man who would register complete amazement if someone suggested that he make the family car available to his 14-year-old son seems to consider it quite reasonable to put a rifle or shotgun in the boy's hands and turn him loose in the woods or fields.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- Exceptions to be filed shortly with the Interstate Commerce Commission by John Speed Elliott and the protective committee representing owners of more than a million dollars of Missouri Pacific secured serial 5 1/4 per dent gold bonds, contain objctions to proposals of I.C.C. Examiner R.H. Jewell for winding up the reorganization of the Missouri Pacific system.
The trial of Alger Hiss, indicted for perjury to conceal evidence of espionage, was tentatively set yesterday for Jan. 24.

England soon will extend socialization to the practice of law and as soon as American lawyers become better informed about it, the subject will be a matter of debate in this country, Prof. John N. Hazard predicted last night.

POINT PLEASANT, N.J., Dec. 16 -- Two members of the crew of the sixty-five-foot commercial fishing boat Ballantrae were lost early this morning when high seas pounded over the vessel as she was attempting, during a northeast storm, to put into Manasquan Inlet after a week at sea.

BERLIN, Dec. 16--The French Military Government silenced one of Russia's most powerful propaganda outlets in Western Europe today by destroying two towers of Radio Berlin that were in the French sector. The towers were blown up by French engineers upon orders of Brig. Gen. Jean Ganeval, French Commandant in Berlin, because they interfered with airlift operations into Tegel Airfield in the French sector.

GENEVA, Dec. 10 -- The trade policy of the United States authorities in Germany is widely regarded by responsible Europeans as one of the biggest obstacles to reorienting the European economy toward greater unity.

CHICAGO, Dec. 16 -- Wheat prices were lower, but corn was firm on the Board of Trade today, spreading operations being a factor in shaping the trend of both grains. Wheat closed 7/8 to 1 3/4 cents lower, May leading, going to 10 3/4 cents below December, against 10 1/4 cents the previous day.

Almost a year after the assassination of Mahatma Gandhi the greatest of the internal reforms he urged on India is recognized by the Constituent Assembly in its adoption of a clause in the new Indian Constitution outlawing "untouchability." Forty million Indians now legally can leave their ghettos, use the village wells, bathe in the rivers and enjoy the privileges of citizenship denied them by obscure tradition for centuries.
DURBAN, Dec. 16 (Reuters) -- In a race against the weather, England's bowlers dismissed South Africa for 161 runs at the tea interval today in the first cricket test here.

Sarah Osnath-Halevy, who came to New York from her native Yemen in Southern Arabia thirteen years ago, delighted a sizable audience in Times Hall last night with her artful singing, mimicry and dancing. Her colorful program was divided into Yemenite, Persian and Biblical songs, songs of faith, of love and of new Israel. She sang in Yemenite, Persian, Sephardic and Hebrew.
NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 16 -- The department store Santa smiled and nodded amiably as the youngster asked for an electric train.
