CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 16 (AP) -- End of Strife, belonging to G.C. Hunt, scored a popular victory in the featured mile-and-a- sixteenth Hidden Spring claiming purse at Tropical Park today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- President Truman laughed and said today that the daisy-picking was on the other side of the fence when informed that Governor Dewey had accused the Administration of "trying to pick political daisies" in holding fast for a combined St. Lawrence seaway and power project.
PEIPING, Dec. 16 -- Shells landed on Peiping's south airfield today and several hundred evacuees in nine planes were frightened into a panicky take-off.

The $500,000,000 Niagara Hudson Power Corporation will move closer to a simplification of its complex corporate structure today when it files with the Securities and Exchange Commission an amended plan for merger of its principal operating subsidiaries into a single operating unit, bearing the parent company's name.

Commuters rushing through Grand Central Terminal to catch the 5:15 and weary women homeward-bound to the suburbs with armfuls of Christmas parcels paused in the main hall to listen to Yuletide choral music yesterday afternoon.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- Excerpts from the text of the report of the Hoover Commission's subcommittee on the National Security Organization follow:...
A picket line outside the Federal Courthouse in Brooklyn to protest the arrest of two youths for failing to register in the peacetime draft received a hostile reception from bystanders yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- The State Department declared today that the United States Marines sent by naval transport from the United States base at Tsingtao to Shanghai would protect American lives but would not be landed to "maintain law and order in Shanghai" nor become involved in any "defense of the city."

As you ride along in the bus, if you listen carefully, you will hear among the passengers a scattered patter of exclamations that tell an unconsciously true story of human character. They are occasioned by the stepping on toes, the insertion of elbows in ribs, the little jostlings and collisions that take place when the bus turns quickly, stops suddenly or cuts up generally.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- President Truman stands ready to approve a bill increasing the salaries of Government executives, including his own.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- The shipping industry directed new criticism at the Economic Cooperation Administration today because of a decision to permit removal of sacked-flour cargoes from American liner services to foreign tramp steamships.

Election of Dr. Arthur H. Ruggles of Providence, R.I., to the presidency of the National Committee for Mental Hygiene was announced yesterday by Dr. George S. Stevenson, medical director of the committee.
BOSTON, Dec. 16 (AP) -- Kentucky's national collegiate basketball champions shaded the Holy Cross Crusaders, 51-48, tonight before a capacity Boston Garden crowd of 13,909.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Dec. 16--Faced with a general decline in winter business, the Resort Chamber of Commerce has proposed a three-point program whose objects are to attract more visitors and raise--or at least maintain--the city's level of prosperity.

A heavy rain dissolved yesterday most of the 4-inch snowfall of Wednesday and left many slushy thoroughfares here and in the suburbs. The first major fall of the 1948-49 season started at 10:45 A. M. Wednesday and ended at 8:15 P. M. Precipitation for the twenty-four-hour period ended at 7 o'clock last night measured .54 inch, according to the Weather Bureau.

One of the most encouraging phases of the work of the Greater New York Safety Council is the progress being made in the cooperative safety education project now being carried on jointly by the Council, the Board of Education, New York University Center for Safety Education, and the American Museum of Safety.

Bag manufacturers are not stocking textiles for export flour containers, even though the volume of business from millers has proved very substantial in the last few months, it was pointed out in the trade yesterday. The bag industry will depend on spot deliveries from textile manufacturers, they said, to keep pace with the day-to-day orders that millers are placing.

All the gay trimmings of pre-war years plus a few new baubles are ready for this year's Christmas trees. Glittering decorated glass ornaments from Czechoslovakia and Belgium add to the varied array from American firms. Mirrored balls in all sizes and colors are offered by local stores.

Prices of hides futures, gaining strength from an upturn in the Western spot markets, advanced 39 to 74 points yesterday on Commodity Exchange in active trading. Near-by December led the advance, closing 74 points higher. The spread between December and March widened to 391 points.
DAYTON, Ohio, Dec. 16 (AP) -- Americans laden with food and the Yuletide spirit flooded Christmas trains for forty-three nations with gifts today.

The Erie Railroad announced yesterday that its 1949 program includes improvements costing about $3,300,000 on its main line commuter trains and local trains operating between New Jersey points and Port Jervis. M.G. McInnes, general manager at Jersey City, said that besides the dieselization of these trains, the program included the remodeling of 144 coaches and the installation of cooling system improvements in the commuter coaches.

SEOUL, Korea, Dec. 16 -- The commander of the Soviet troops in north Korea has asked Maj. Gen. John B. Coulter, United States commander in Korea, to recall two United States Army liaison officers from Pyongyang, headquarters of the Soviet forces in north Korea.
DENVER, Dec. 16 (AP) -- The National Congress of American Indians today endorsed Will Rogers Jr. for the post of United States Indian Commissioner.
LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Dec. 16 (AP) -- The New York State Grange lauded the Eightieth Congress today for its action on farm price supports and took a stand against higher supports.

CHICAGO, Dec. 16 -- Armour Co., food packers, incurred a net loss of nearly $2,000,000 in the fiscal year ended on Oct. 30, George A. Eastwood, chairman, disclosed today. In the preceding year Armour's net profit was $30,950,000, equal to $4.91 per share of common stock.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- Labor leaders in two separate moves today pressed ahead toward their objective of having the Taft-Hartley Law repealed.

Visions of early skiing, so bright when snow started falling recently, were dashed as rain followed and the reports from the North Country last night offered little encouragement, at least, for this week-end. The snowfall was of a coastal nature and did not extend too far North, so that the metropolitan area and Pennsylvania, oddly enough, had most of the cover.
Among provocative new exhibitions in local galleries this week are one-man shows by Herman Rose, Jean Hugo and Paul Bodin.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 (UP) -- Industry will spend a record total of $18,840,000,000 on new plant and equipment this year, the Department of Commerce announced tonight.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- The members and advisers of the Hoover commission's committee which reported today on national security organization were as follows:
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange were moderately active yesterday. Final prices were 3 points lower to 10 points higher, with near months relatively easier than distants.

PATERSON, N.J., Dec. 16 -- Before three other great champions of boxing history, Joe Louis tonight concluded his 1946 exhibition tour at the Armory with a six-round joust against Pat Comiskey, local heavyweight, that was as near actual fighting as is possible with over-stuffed 12-ounce gloves.

Producers of industrial materials are making a new concession in sales contracts which promises to provide an important factor in stabilizing prices of scarce items, purchasing agents revealed here yesterday. This step comprises approval of guarantees on orders for the first quarter, on which delivery dates are specified, that fourth-round price increases will not apply if deliveries are made after the agreed delivery dates on which shipments were promised.

NANKING, Dec. 16 -- The position of Nationalist Gen. Huang Wei's Twelfth Army Group, which had been encircled about fifty miles northwest of Pengpu, remained obscure tonight as both sides told completely different stories about its fate.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- John J. McCloy, wartime Assistant Secretary of War and now president of the World Bank, recommended today that the Armed Services be headed by a Chief of Staff senior to all commanders, serving as adviser to the President and the Secretary of Defense.

A lone bandit, brandishing a pistol, held up the New York City Housing Authority office at 1352 Fifth Avenue yesterday, scooped up $1,877 from a cash drawer, and escaped in a taxicab before the police arrived.

LINCOLN, Neb., Dec. 16 (AP) -- The resignation of Dougal Russell as assistant football coach at the University of Nebraska was announced today by George (Potsy) Clark, head coach and athletic director.

THE HAGUE, Dec. 16 -- Dr. Alan Valentine, chief of the ECA's mission to the Netherlands, asserted today he was satisfied that this country had not improperly exported non-ferrous metals bought with Marshall Plan funds.

Early in 1949 Columbia University will begin construction on a $2,000,000 cancer research unit at the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center, Broadway and 168th Street, Dr. Willard C. Rappleye, dean of the university's Faculty of Medicine, announced yesterday.

Henry S. Morgan last night was elected commodore of the New York Yacht Club. He was chosen at the annual meeting of the organization, held in the clubhouse at 37 West Forty-fourth Street, and will take office on Jan. 1.

Attorney General Tom Clark yesterday made his film debut in Universal-International's forthcoming production, "Illegal Entry," it was reported by the company. Mr. Clark and Commissioner Watson B. Miller of the Immigration and Naturalization Service faced the cameras in Washington, D.C., to provide a prologue for the picture, described as the "first documentary film to be made with the full cooperation of the Immigration Department."

THAT unreconstructed rebel from Old Kaintuck, Adolph Rupp, will bring his University of Kentucky basketball team into the Garden tomorrow but it can't be the climactic high spot for him that it always was in the past. Mr. Rupp has been spoiled. Last summer his dribble heroes combined with the Phillips Oilers to win the Olympic court title and thereby gained a half share in the championship of the world.

Puccini's "La Boheme" received its first presentation of the season last night at the Metropolitan. Given with a familiar cast, headed by Bidu Sayao as Mimi and Jussi Bjoerling as Rodolfo, the lovable work was performed in a laudably smooth and effective manner.

Most American educators agree that colleges and universities should not invest their endowment funds in commercial businesses, reports to THE NEW YORK TIMES indicate. They point out that this practice gives the educational institution an unfair advantage, since it does not have to pay a Federal corporate tax.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 (AP) -- The doves of peace may be fluttering over pro football, but none has dared drop any olive branches in the vicinity of George Preston Marshall, owner of the Washington Redskins.

ALBANY, Dec. 16 -- John E. Burton, State Budget Director, reported to Governor Dewey today that all but $2,000,000 of the accumulated state surpluses of the war years, amounting to $697,300,000, had been spent or was in process of being used.
A year-end dividend of 20 cents and a quarterly dividend of 50 cents, both payable on Jan. 15 was voted by the Continental Insurance Company. No extra was paid, a year ago.

The two-story taxpayer at 535-37 Madison Avenue, northeast corner of Fifty-fourth Street, which was erected by the Otto H. Kahn estate in 1935 and sold four years later to Webb Knapp, Inc., was resold yesterday by the latter to the William Waldorf Astor Estate.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 (AP) -- The average price of home-delivered milk in twenty-three major cities declined two-tenths of a cent a quart between early November and early December. That left it still 1.3 cents a quart higher than a year ago.

Approval of a $650,000 advertising budget for continuance of the Anthracite Institute's present promotional campaign during 1949 was announced here yesterday. Newspapers in the major anthracite markets will again be the chief medium. Insertions of 1,000 and 600 lines have been scheduled for twice-a-month appearance in the papers.
CLEVELAND, Dec. 16 -- The Department of Justice moved today in Federal court here to break up what it charges is a huge international rubber cartel.

Talk in the investment houses of continued high taxes or even higher levies may blow an ill wind over the desks of specialists in corporate equity securities, but for the municipal bond men the Truman market is spelling out the happiest holiday season in several years.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- Arguing that Gen. Douglas MacArthur, Supreme Commander for the Allied Powers, had illegally created the International Military Tribunal at Tokyo, Japanese warlords condemned to die or serve prison sentences today begged the Supreme Court to assume jurisdiction and examine their convictions.

One of the discreditable things the Eightieth Congress did was to pass a misleading and discriminatory Displaced Persons Act, drawn up, as President Truman said, "without a single public hearing," and so formulated that it excluded many thousands of Catholic and Jewish refugees.

BOSTON, Dec. 16 -- Adequate forest protection as an incentive to better management of timberlands was stressed today in panel discussions that opened the three-day forty-eighth national meeting of the Society of American Foresters.

Charles Munch, returning as guest conductor of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra last night in Carnegie Hall, virtually handed the show to his compatriot, Robert Casadesus, who as pianist played the solo part of the Mozart C major concerto, Koechel 467, and took the piano part of d'Indy's "Symphony on a Mountain Air for the final feature of the concert. This confidence was vindicated.

MARBURG, Germany, Dec. 16 (UP) -- Mrs. Wilma Ybarbo told her soldier husband he was not the father of her 6-year-old son on the night she allegedly shot him dead, a German girl testified today. And the late Sgt. John Ybarbo of Goliad, Tex., told his maid shortly before he was slain that he fathered a German girl's baby, another witness said.

An article by James Reston, published in this newspaper yesterday, strengthens the arguments advanced in one of last week's preliminary reports of the Hoover Commission on Organization of the Executive Branch of the Government. The report suggested the need for more consistency in the formation and expression of our foreign policy.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on Dec . 11, 1948, totaled 783,276 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 20,907 cars, or 2.6 per cent fewer than in the preceding week, 70,883 cars, or 8.3 per cent fewer than in the corresponding week of last year, and 45,475 cars, or 5.5 per cent fewer than in the corresponding week of two years ago.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Dec. 16 -- A serious breach in the unity of the country's largest farmer organization was averted today as delegates to the American Farm Bureau Federation convention here tossed the explosive issue of high support prices for farm products to the board of directors.
George A. Krug, founder and head of several baking companies, announced yesterday the formation of a new corporation, Krug Enterprises, Inc., capitalized at $12,000,000.

Sandy Saddler, Harlem Negro who holds the world featherweight title, will appear in the Madison Square Garden ring tonight for the first time as title holder, but not in defense of his crown. The lad who knocked out Willie Pep to become champion last Oct. 29 is to battle rugged Terry Young, East Side lightweight, in a bout scheduled for ten rounds.
Rejecting the warnings of steamship men that the future of the port was being threatened, the Board of Estimate adopted yesterday an increased rental schedule for North River piers.

SOFIA, Bulgaria, Dec. 16 -- Delegations of foreign Communists are converging on Sofia to attend the thrice-postponed congress of the Bulgarian Communist party. Scheduled to convene on Saturday, not only will it open a new chapter in the further development of Communist control of Bulgaria, but also will define the new party line to be followed in other "people's democracies" except Yugoslavia.

Your thoughful editorial on the Tokyo war crime judgments may give rise to comment. The Tokyo opinions even more than the Nuremberg judgements emphasize the principle that a conspiracy to prepare and conduct a war of aggression is a crime, and that international law has "teeth" at least where the victim of aggression remains victorious in the end.

Abolition of the post of chairman of the proposed city traffic commission as a separate highly paid office was recommended yesterday by city spokesmen. It was one of several revisions suggested to the General Welfare Committee of the City Council at a public hearing on a proposed local law to establish an independent traffic agency.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- Department store sales in the week ended Dec. 11 were 1 per cent below sales for the corresponding week of last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 16 -- The Screen Extras Guild and the major motion-picture producers have agreed on a new collective contract covering employment of film supernumeraries for a period to end July 31, 1953, and providing for a union shop and preferential hiring for the 3,800 extras now registered with Central Casting, the producer-run hiring hall.

A foundation to perpetuate the ideas and ideals of the late Dr. Judah L. Magnes, former president of the Hebrew University and chairman of the Ihud (Union) of Palestine, was announced last night at a memorial meeting in the Temple Emanu-El Assembly Hall, 1 East Sixty-fifth Street.

The New York State Democratic delegation in the House of Representatives in the Eighty-first Congress will support President Truman's legislative program, as outlined in his campaign speeches and in the Democratic national platform, Paul E. Fitzpatrick, Democratic State Chairman, said yesterday after a luncheon conference at the Biltmore Hotel.

ALBANY, Dec. 16 -- State revenue, betting and attendance at New York State's harness racing tracks topped all previous records during 1948, Spencer E. Bates, president of the State Tax Commission, revealed today in a report on this year's pari-mutuel operations.

ROME, Dec. 16 -- About 1,100,000 state employes and workers will stage a twenty-four-hour strike next Monday to protest against the partial rejection by the Government of their demands for salary increases. Included in the strike are railroad men, who will bring the Italian transport system to a standstill, but according to present plans, state telephones and telegraph should continue working.

Financial interests controlled by the Graham-Newman Corporation, an investment concern, have acquired 70,000 shares of the Atlantic, Gulf and West Indies Steamship Lines, resulting in reorganization of the company, it was announced yesterday.
PARIS, Dec. 16 -- Charles de Gaulle's proposal for the association of labor and capital to solve French social difficulties was received with coldness in trade union circles today.

Percy MacKaye, author of some sixty volumes of published poems, plays and operas, has a new work scheduled for publication next year by the Bond Wheelwright Company, 145 East Sixty-third Street. It is a sequence of four plays, entitled "The Mystery of Hamlet, King of Denmark, or What We Will," which covers the life of Hamlet from his birth to the time he appears in Shakespeare's play.

BEBLIN, Dec. 16 (AP) -- The United States Military Government gave a new lease on life tonight to German newspapers in the United States zone. It announced that they could use their present publishing plants for at least eight more years.
PITTSBURGH, Dec. 16 (UP) -- A "mechanical miner" that can dig two tons of coal a minute will revolutionize the industry, its builders claimed today in revealing details of the machine.

CARACAS, Venezuela, Dec. 16 -- Romulo Betancourt, president of the defunct Accion Democratica party, has applied for safe conduct to be able to leave the country, but no action has yet been taken, a Ministry of Interior official said today. Dr. Betancourt is a refugee in the Colombian Embassy.

PARIS, Dec. 16 -- There was a strong possibility today that the United Nations Security Council might postpone action until January on the Indonesian question despite an urgent request from the Republic of Indonesia for a meeting before the Council took its Christmas recess.

ALBANY, Dec. 16 -- A strong suspicion developed here today that President Truman plans to jettison the 1933 agreement providing for state development of St. Lawrence hydro-electric power and proceed with Federal development under an agency modeled after the Tennessee Valley Authority.

SYRACUSE, Dec. 16 -- A coalition between the Democratic party and the Congress of Industrial Organizations in this state to promote New Deal legislation and elect pro-labor candidates was predicted here today by Louis Hollander, president of the State CIO.

PARIS, Dec. 16 -- Frederic Joliot-Curie, head of the French Atomic Energy Commission, said here today that France's development of a self-sufficient atomic energy pile placed her in a position to bargain for atomic raw materials along with the United States and the British Empire.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 (UP) -- Great Britain exported ten times as much aluminum scrap to this country in the first ten months of the year as it shipped in all of 1947, Commerce Department figures showed tonight.

American hotels, faced with reduced earnings and steadily mounting operating costs, are spending more than $2,000,000,000 on modernization and rehabilitation to obtain new sources of revenue, Howard F. Dugan, chairman of the board of the American Hotel Association, declared yesterday following a conference of hotel leaders here to plan for the coming year.

Younger members of society headed by Miss Julia N. Beals are serving on the debutante committee for the performance of 'Kiss Me, Kate," a new musical comedy, on the night of Jan. 10 at the Century Theatre which has been taken over to raise funds for furthering the scientific research of the New York Botanical Garden.

Your editorial of Dec. 12 on segregation in Washington calls attention to the fact that an edict by the Federal Government in regard to the city of Washington would not violate the constitutional rights of any state.

Assemblyman D. Mallory Stephens, Putnam County Republican and chairman of the State Temporary Commission to Study Rents, announced yesterday that he had designated three members of a subcommittee to begin an immediate study of the City Rent Commission's administration of the city rent laws.

Gen. Douglas MacArthur, Supreme Allied Commander in Japan, and Emperor Hirohito support the establishment of a great Christian University for Japan in 1950 or 1951, Dr. James L. Fieser, executive director of the sponsoring agency, reported here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- Wasteful operations and serious upsets in the private shipping industry were predicted today by the CIO Maritime Committee for the defense department plan to place the Army's sea transport service under the Navy.

The Women's Trade Union League took its annual turn at bat yesterday before the state Joint Legislative Committee on industrial and labor conditions on behalf of young bootblacks, newsboys, caddies and farm workers, women discriminated against by employers, and finally, day care for children of working mothers.

A survey by the Commerce and Industry Association of New York, Inc., of 262 leading local business concerns to ascertain whether they planned to compensate for the fact that Christmas and New Year's Day fall on Saturdays this year by giving some form of extra time off on the previous days shows, it was announced yesterday, that 232 would do so on Dec. 24 and 206 on Dec. 31.
Holiday dinner and dance gowns were presented by Gimbels in a showing of evening fashions yesterday on the third floor.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Dec. 16 -- The three Western military governors were unable to agree today on terms of the occupation statute that the three powers had promised the projected West German Government in lieu of a peace treaty.

Before Leland Hayward departed yesterday for a Cuban vacation, he closed a deal that gave him immediate possession of Sidney Kingsley's latest drama, "Detective Story," which as the title implies deals with life among the sleuths.

The city's animal lovers got a unique Christmas present yesterday when the Department of Parks unveiled the only albino leopard in captivity, a handsome tawny female named Jinx, at the Lion House of the Central Park Zoo.
Whether racing will return to the Empire City track at Yonkers next year may be determined within the next ten days.

With Christmas only eight days away, Loft Candy Corporation opened stores yesterday in four IND subway stations and in the Hudson and Manhattan tube. The stores are the first that the Board of Transportation has permitted to be installed in the subways.

The threat of a concerted defensive attack by proponents of public power against private power systems that allegedly have "begun a war unto death against rural electric cooperatives, power districts and the Government's wholesale power projects," has been sounded by Federal officials and several hundred public power men.

The report of the Committee on the National Security Organization -- covered in detail elsewhere in this newspaper -- draws the general conclusion that the unification of military services in a Department of National Defense was a sound idea, but one that is not yet working well.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- The Eberstadt committee of the Hoover commission strongly endorsed today the present separation of the Air Force and naval air arm on the grounds that a merger of the two now might imperil their "combat efficiency."

New York's greatest office building of the post-war era will rise shortly on the former site of the old Murray Hill Hotel on Park Avenue, according to final plans made public yesterday after nearly five years of negotiations and preparation.
Twelve thousand millinery workers in the New York area will receive increases amounting to $3,000,000 a year under terms of agreement announced yesterday.

A new policy, designed to speed action on the growing number of complaints against landlords accused of failure to paint and decorate apartments in this city and Nassau and Suffolk Counties was announced yesterday by John J. Pendergast, Regional Housing Expediter.

The Port of New York Authority has a staff of twenty experts working on revisions of its $114,000,000 plan for the reconstruction and modernization of the city waterfront, chairman Howard S. Cullman said here yesterday.

CAIRO, Dec. 16--Israeli forces in the Negeb, desert area in southern Palestine, launched today a full-scale attack against the Egyptian garrison at Faluja, an official Egyptian spokesman announced tonight. The Israelis used artillery, tanks and aircraft, he said.

WESTPORT, Conn., Dec. 16 -- Vivien Kellems, who, with her brother operates a cable grips manufacturing plant here, made public today a letter to Secretary of the Treasury Snyder in which she urged him, for the third time, to "indict me."

Orrin Hunter, for six years chairman of the New York executive committee of Bricklayers Unions, will become on Jan. 1 the construction and labor adviser to Herman T. Stichman, the State Housing Commissioner.

The indoor track season will be launched tonight at the Jersey City Armory, where the Metropolitan A.A.U. junior championships will be contested. Fifteen titular events, three invitation relays and two women's races have attracted nearly 1,000 athletes.

GENEVA, Dec. 16 -- The entire European requirement of fuel for steel-making will be met in the first quarter of 1949 for the first time since the war, the Coal Committee of the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe announced today.

Saying that the Democratic party always has been the agency for progress in this country, Senator Alben W. Barkley, Vice President-elect, declared last evening that the result of the last election gave the party a mandate, responsibility and opportunity to continue to serve the people of the United States.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- During the week ended Dec. 15 member bank reserve balances increased $708,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

Advocates of the preservation of Van Cortlandt Park's seven-acre marshland as a wild life sanctuary made public yesterday an appeal to Mayor O'Dwyer for an immediate hearing, which they said Robert Moses, Park Commissioner, had refused to grant.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Dec. 16 -- After attaining national heights in football, with teams so proficient that several states had to be combed for opponents, the White Plains High School is adopting a modified position that the Board of Education believes will be more tenable in secondary education.

SAN SALVADOR, El Salvador, Dec. 16 (UP) -- The Revolutionary Junta today lifted martial law, which had been in effect since the Army overthrew the Government of President Salvador Castaneda Castro two days ago.

SAN SALVADOR, El Salvador, Dec. 16 (UP) -- The Revolutionary Junta today lifted martial law, which had been in effect since the Army overthrew the Government of President Salvador Castaneda Castro two days ago.

NANKING, Dec. 17 -- Tonight the opposing forces in China's National Government were frozen in what appears to be an insoluble impasse, yet the relentless progress of the Communists means that something will have to "give."

THE grand design of the new "Literary History of the United States,"* which we made some preliminary remarks about on Thursday, takes in the whole vast, sprawling and magnificently unruly pattern of American writing. That is not an ignoble aim to have ventured in the midst of our time's fashionable despair. It is in itself quite a tribute to the rugged vitality of America's tradition.

LONDON, Dec. 17 -- After spending most of the last three months in the realms of high politics and finance, the House of Commons got down today to a subject that everybody in Britain knows, understands and worries about -- the cost of living.
New York broke out in its brightest sparkle of the season yesterday with the lighting up of twenty-four Christmas trees in gay Yule ceremonies in city parks throughout the five boroughs.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 -- Average primary market prices were 0.4 per cent lower during the week ended Dec. 14, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 -- The CIO United Automobile Workers charged today that business was concealing a large part of its profits by "varied and ingenious" accounting devices.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Dec. 17 -- A joint program for the Benelux countries within the framework of the Organization for European Economic Cooperation, issued to day by the Belgian Ministry of Foreign Trade, stressed the need for multilateral trade and payments because the vast amounts of the raw materials ordered by the Western Hemisphere and paid for in dollars were re-exported to European countries after manufacture.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 (AP) -- The Department of Commerce said today the British "token import plan," will be continued during 1949.

With the exception of Soviet Russia, all the nearly two score countries that received wartime Lend-Lease aid to a total of more than fifty billion dollars have settled their accounts with us on the generous terms offered them, amounting to about three cents on the dollar.

The hearings that have been in progress for the past ten days before the Senate-House joint committee, under the chairmanship of Senator Flanders of Vermont, have proved exceptionally informative. What effect, if any, they will have on the Administration's policies it is, of course, too early to say.
ITHACA, N.Y., Dec. 17 -- Yale defeated Cornell, 64--57, in their first Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball League meeting tonight by staging a rally to overcome a 35-26 deficit at the half.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 17 -- Experiments on animals at the Yale University School of Medicine have revealed that mice born of young parents possess resistance against cancer, according to a report published today in Science, official journal of the American Association for the Advancement of Science.
BUDAPEST, Hungary, Dec. 17 (UP) -- A Catholic consistory may be called to help settle the dispute between church and state in Hungary, the Hungarian Board of Bishops announced today.

SAN SALVADOR, El Salvador, Dec. 17 -- The Supreme Court, after a session today, issued a decree providing for cessation of its functions, but it did not resign. After this action, the Council of Revolutionary Government, or Junta, which took over after Tuesday's revolt, assumed all powers of the state.

ROME, Dec 17 (AP) -- A one-hour strike, called by the Communistled Chamber of Labor, failed today to make itself felt in Rome. A two-hour work stoppage in Milan apparently was almost equally ineffective

ALBANY, Dec. 17 (AP) -- A State Supreme Court justice reserved decision today on Representative Hadwen C. Fuller's petition for a temporary injunction to delay certification of his opponent's election because of alleged vote irregularities.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 (AP) -- Sales of retail dealers in household appliances and radios totaled $234,000,000 in October, a decline of 3 per cent from the preceding month although even with sales in October last year, the Department of Commerce reported today.

The largest single gift accruing yesterday to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund came from the students of the Horace Mann School for Boys. The boys collected $5,050 for the fund, the largest pre-Christmas contribution that the school has made for the Neediest in the twenty-one years it has been a donor.

PARIS, Dec. 17 -- Marcel Peyrouton, the former Vichy Minister of the Interior whose appointment as Governor of Algeria in 1943 had made him a symbol of criticism directed against the French policy of the United States Government, went on trial today before the High Court of Justice here for his acts as a minister in the Vichy Government.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 (AP) -- Texts,. some in full, some only in part, of seven more documents were released tonight by the House Committee on Un-American Activities. The Committee says these are among those taken from secret State Department files of 1937-38 and found Dec. 2 in the possession of Whittaker Chambers, self-styled former Communist courier in Washington.

Christmas this year will be brighter and more bountiful for thousands of hospitalized veterans and underprivileged and orphaned children owing to the efforts of the city's school children. In public, private and parochial schools and in Y.M.C.A.'s and community centers Yuletide gift "stockings" are being filled, presents prepared and parties planned.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 -- Dr. Juan Bautista de Lavalle of Peru, on the instruction of his Government, withdrew from the commission of inquiry looking into the reported invasion of Costa Rica from Nicaragua, it was announced today.

Fair administration of European Recovery Program allocations in Italy was seen yesterday by Peter G. Treves, editor of "Economic News From Italy," who reported that detailed information on how the Italian Government administers ERP funds is now becoming available here.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 17--Attorney-General Tom C. Clark said today that legislation to tighten up the country's espionage laws would be proposed for early action by the incoming Eighty-first Congress.

LAKE SUCCESS, Dec. 17 -- Benjamin A. Cohen, United Nations Assistant Secretary General for public information, is scheduled to inaugurate on Wednesday noon a series of broadcasts of new United Nations songs in a radio program originating here over WNEW.

The Department of Marine and Aviation is now engaged in writing a new form of pier leases for the approval of the Board of Estimate, following the board's decision to increase pier rentals, it was announced yesterday. The new form is expected to be ready to submit within a week, but it is not expected that the steamship companies, who opposed the increases, will sign before the first of the year.

YONKERS, N. Y., Dec. 17 -- In the hope that a definite step will be taken to force the return of the thoroughbred sport to Yonkers, State Senator William F. Condon arranged today for a meeting on Tuesday morning among the State Racing Commission, city officials and members of the Yonkers Chamber of Commerce.

U.S. NAVAL SUBMARINE BASE, New London, Conn., Dec. 16 (Delayed) -- Another class ended its course at the Submarine School here today as the United States Navy continues its emphasis upon submarine and anti-submarine operations.

The share market on the Stock Exchange idled along yesterday in another irregular session as interest moved to the film issues, although the gold-mining section still exhibited strength. Price changes continued narrow, except for a few high-price stocks and, although the list was fairly balanced in terms of losses and gains, the composite rate slipped 0.29 point on the day.

A firm price policy in sales of heating and plumbing equipment has been adopted by American Radiator and Standard Sanitary Corporation it was announced in Pittsburgh, Pa., yesterday, by Theodore E. Mueller, president. Becoming effective immediately, the policy was made possible by improved deliveries of raw materials at the company's plants at prices which are expected to remain substantially at present levels, he said.

Robert W. Symes, 27 years old, of 2223 Greene Avenue, Ridgewood, Queens, a bus driver for the Surface Transportation Company, was arraigned before Magistrate Morris Rothenberg in Felony Court yesterday on a felonious assault charge incident to a complaint lodged against him by Mrs. Margaret Machaels, 48, of 501 West Fifty-seventh Street.

Christopher Morley has a new novel on Doubleday's spring list, entitled "The Man Who Made Friends With Himself." Described as "a blend of surface mischief and underground despair," it is a story about a literary agent in love with a lady psychiatrist.

John J. Lamula, in your issue of Nov. 23, says "we strongly believe that * * * the average landlord, notwithstanding rent control, is better off today than he was in 1938." I wonder how much of this "belief" is the result of shallow thinking and how much is influenced by political considerations?

Holiday liquor sales in the metropolitan area reversed their earlier downtrend and increased sharply this week, a survey of package stores and bars disclosed here yesterday. A late buying surge, which put sales of many package stores ahead of last year for the week, was believed by many operators to be strong enough, if continued, to carry total holiday sales ahead of those of a year ago.
CHICAGO, Dec. 17 -- About all that is left of the onetime $1,000,000,000 empire of Samuel Insull today became just a lot of scrap.

Joe Novotny, 26-year-old full-back, and Joe Rogoff, 26-year-old center, were elected co-captains of the 1949 New York University eleven at the school's annual football dinner held at the Faculty Club, Washington Square North, last night.

On the eve of his return to Israel. Berl Locker, chairman of the Jerusalem executive of the Jewish Agency for Palestine, told of the need for assistance by American Jews in building up the agricultural life of his country.

Shipments of steel products to most industries in the first nine months of the current year were 6 to 80 per cent higher than in the corresponding period of 1947, the American Iron and Steel Institute announced yesterday. Several industries received in the nine months of 1948 almost as much steel as in all of last year, with the oil and gas industries among the leading beneficiaries.

Both north and southbound traffic on the uptown IRT Broadway Van Cortlandt Park subway line was halted for thirty-seven minutes yesterday morning when the power was shut off, because of a fire in a northbound train at 215th Street and Tenth Avenue. No one was injured.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 -- Total civilian employment in the executive branch of the Federal Government declined in October for the second consecutive month. This was reported today by the Joint Committee of Reduction of Nonessential Federal Expenditures, of which Senator Harry F. Byrd, Democrat, of Virginia, is chairman. The committee reported that employment in October was 2,092, 180, as compared with 2,114,994 in September.

A taxicab driver, his two passengers and a Fire Department lieutenant were injured yesterday morning when the truck of Hook and Ladder Company 9 collided with the cab at Great Jones and Lafayette Streets at 4:40 A.M. The cab was tossed seventy-five feet by the impact.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Dec. 17 -A dispute arose today among German political leaders representing the Parliamentary Assembly in conversations here with the three Western military governors that may affect the leadership of Dr. Konrad Adenauer, right-wing president of the body that is writing a constitution at Bonn.

A booklet containing twenty fundamental questions and answers concerning the values and services of advertising in the American economic system is being released to the 25,000 members of the Advertising Federation of America, it was announced yesterday.

Patrolmen Otto Peters and William Casey were cruising through Greenpoint at 6 o'clock yesterday morning when a "Signal 32" in their radio car dispatched them to 37 Sutton Street for what the announcer vaguely called "emergency."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 -- The combined strength of the armed forces was increased by 15,238 officers and men during November to reach a total of 1,582,411 on Dec. 1, James Forrestal, Secretary of Defense, announced today.
First efforts to organize affected industries for a joint drive to repeal the Federal 20 per cent retail excise tax were stalled temporarily yesterday by a dispute over use of publicity.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 (AP) -- The Federal Reserve Board said tonight its installment credit controls will not apply after Jan. 1 to sales in which the sales tax pushes the price of an article above $50.

Lumber production for the week ended Dec. 11 was down 14.4 per cent compared with last year. Shipments were down 24.4 per cent and orders 20.2 per cent, according to reports wired yesterday to THE NEW YORK TIMES by trade associations.
"Selling" New York City is a venture in big business that should concern every New Yorker, business leaders and officials of the city administration agreed yesterday.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 17 -- A Federal District Court jury tonight returned a finding favorable to Lester Cole in his suit against Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer Studios for reinstatement in the $1,350-a-week screen writing job from which he was removed for his defiance of the House Un-American Activities Committee a year ago.

American aid to Europe can be reduced in the fiscal year of 1950 and substantial cuts made in such outlays in 1950-51, the third year of the Economic Cooperation Administration program, Senator Robert A. Taft, Republican, of Ohio, declared here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 (UP) -- Farmers' cash receipts may total $30,800,000,000 this year, up $600,000,000 from 1947, the Department of Agriculture said today in its monthly survey of farm income. However, operating expenses have gone up so much that net income will be down from 1947.

In these parts the fox is pursued with the assistance of the hound pack right up until the first skier falls. This information was vouched for by a fellow who recently had an experience that left him able to provide a critique on foxhunting in the New York area.

SYRACUSE, Dec. 17 -- Left-wing elements in the State Congress of Industrial Organizations were overwhelmingly defeated today in their efforts to force a condemnation of the European Recovery Program through the state CIO convention. The 980 convention-delegates supported the ERP and criticized Soviet foreign policy by a margin of more than four to one.

OKLAHOMA CITY, Dec. 17 (AP) -- Bill Veeck, president of the Cleveland Indians, announced tonight that he and two partners had purchased the Oklahoma City Indians of the Texas League for an undisclosed amount.
PARIS, Dec. 17 -- The Foreign Ministers of the five Brussels treaty nations will make a decision as to future efforts for a constitutional union of European countries, it was learned today.

"Rogues' Regiment," an adventure melodrama starring Dick Powell and produced by Universal-International, will open an engagement this morning at Loew's Criterion. Marta Toren and Vincent Price also share top billing with Mr. Powell in this contemporary story of the French Foreign Legion in Indo-China.

KINGSTON, R.I., Dec. 17 -- Sparked by Ken Goodwin and Sal Sclafani, who scored 27 and 25 points, respectively, Rhode Island State coasted to a 94-60 victory over the Brooklyn College quintet tonight. High man for the Kings-men was Al Goodlerner with 19 points.

PARIS, Dec. 17 -- France, Portugal and Eire, the last three Western European nations requiring Americans to obtain visas for travel, are expected to drop those regulations in time for the next tourist influx in the spring of 1949.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 -- An emergency board in a report to President Truman recommended today that the railroads cut the basic work week of a million employes from forty-eight to forty hours without wage loss and add 7 cents an hour to their present earning rate.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 (UP) -- A Business Advisory Council voted today to advise Congress against putting all industry on an f.o.b. basis.

OXFORD, Ohio, Dec. 17 -- The wind tunnel in which the Wright brothers performed all of their experiments and on which some of today's aeronautical formulas are based has been given to Miami University here by a group of heirs of the Wright estate, John E. Dolibois, executive secretary of the university's alumni association, announced here today.

Strong exceptions to administration of steel export controls on three counts were embodied in a resolution adopted last night by the National Association of Steel Exporters, Inc., at a meeting at the St. Moritz Hotel.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 -- The United States directed the Japanese Government today to enter upon a stringent economic stabilization program aimed at curbing inflation and speeding the country toward self-sufficiency.
Stout-hearted Terry Young of the East Side went as far as he could against a human tornado in Madison Square Garden last night, then suffered the first knockout of a career that goes back to 1939.

NORTH PLAINFIELD, N.J., Dec. 17 -- Birth of triplets, a boy and two girls, brought an unexpected Christmas gift but an added burden last night to Mr. and Mrs. William Jenkins of 16-A Stony Brook Place, who are also parents of four other children ranging in age from 2 to 6 years.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 -- The Pan-Atlantic Steamship Company of Mobile, Ala., today asked the Interstate Commerce Commission to revise its operating authority so that it might serve Jacksonville, Fla., in connection with its service at New York Harbor and other Atlantic and Gulf ports.

CHICAGO, Dec. 17 -- John T. Jarecki, Collector of Internal Revenue, filed a lien against the Tucker Corporation in the County Recorder's office today to collect $49,129 in allegedly unpaid withholding tax collections for July, August and September.

New York City's weatherman is a kindly white-haired gentleman, calm as a Christmas-card snow scene, who has been admired for his ability to maintain a magnificent facade of optimism through the years in a situation that would have broken the spirit of a lesser man.

Granting of extended civil liberties to Germans in the three Western zones of Germany was proposed yesterday by the American Civil Liberties Union, which said it would support establishment of Germany's first national civil rights agency.

SOFIA, Bulgaria, Dec. 17 -- One of the most important items on the agenda of the fifth congress of the Bulgarian Communist party, which convenes tomorrow, is the new set of party by-laws, to be drafted to restore an absolute monolithic structure on the basis of what the Communists describe as "democratic centralism."

"No progress" was still the official report yesterday, as tugboat workers and owners entered the final two weeks of negotiations for a new contract to replace the agreement that expires at midnight on Dec. 31.
Construction of the Brooklyn-Queens Connecting Highway has reached the point where engineers are ready to put on the "sophisticated, finishing touches," it was reported yesterday.

ALBANY, Dec. 17 -- Attorney General Nathaniel L. Goldstein, citing constitutional and statutory provisions, said today he was powerless to act officially in opposition to or support of the proposed $6,000,000 Panther Mountain reservoir project.

The refusal of Chicago authorities to rescind the ban against the staging of Jean-Paul Sartre's "The Respectful Prostitute" in that city has resulted in the cancellation of a projected tour for the New Stages' production, it was learned yesterday.

BERLIN, Dec. 17 -- Russian authorities were unaware officially that the French Military Government intended to blow up the transmission towers of Sovietcontrolled Radio Berlin as a menace to the airlift, the Soviet news bureau announced tonight.

LONDON, Dec. 17 -- One of the most sensational items of news in today's British newspapers was handled with typical restraint. It was the announcement of the impending marriage of one of the six sons of Dr. Geoffrey Fisher, Archbishop of Canterbury, Primate of All England, and a Roman Catholic.

State Insurance Superintendent Robert B. Dineen proposed yesterday legislation to help policy holders collect valid claims against unauthorized mail-order accident and health insurance companies from other states.

CHICAGO, Dec. 17 -- The increase of 7 cents an hour recommended by the board drew critical comment from Thomas C. Carroll, president of the Brotherhood of Maintenance of Way Employes, and Jess Clark, president of the Brotherhood of Signalmen.

KALAMAZOO, Mich., Dec. 17 (AP) -- Representative Clare E. Hoff man, Republican, of Michigan wound up another stage of his inquiry into the Dec. 1 raid on the struck Shakespeare plants here after three CIO officials refused today to testify.

LONDON, Dec. 17 -- A detailed agreement for the integration of the United States occupation forces in Germany with the military forces of the five Western Union powers in the event of an emergency in Europe has been drawn up and transmitted to Washington for review, according to a highly placed source here.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 (AP) -- The Post office Department has asked Classified Advertising, Inc., of Philadelphia to explain its methods of selling advertising space in city directories. Louis J. Doyle, the department's assistant solicitor in charge of such investigations, said that complaints against the company will be heard here on Monday.

BOSTON, Dec. 17 -- Dr. William P. Tolley, chancellor of Syracuse University, warned today that those who believed Central and South America could supply North American needs when lumber here became exhausted were being "dangerously misled."
Steadiness prevailed in cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday and final prices were 6 to 20 points net higher than the day before.

CHICAGO, Dec. 17 (AP) -- Northwestern's high-spirited football warriors will leave by special train for the Pacific Coast tomorrow for what all concerned hope will be a victory over undefeated University of California in the Rose Bowl game at Pasadena on New Year's Day.

Mayor O'Dwyer has referred to Robert Moses, Park Commissioner, a request from the Federated Garden Clubs of New York State for an immediate hearing to preserve a seven-acre section of a swamp in Van Cortlandt Park as a wild life sanctuary, the Mayor's office said yesterday.
STUTTGART, Germany, Dec. 17 (AP) -- A United States Military Government board of review has ruled here that United States occupation personnel, including dependents, are not subject to German law.
The Park Central Hotel changed hands yesterday and its new owners are planning for it a dignified life that befits the city's fifth largest hotel.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 -- Supplies of rice for the first half of 1949 meet only half of the stated world requirements, the International Emergency Food Committee of the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization reported today.

Several West Coast lumber mills, now closed for inventory and repairs, may not reopen until after Jan. 1, a spokesman for one of the country's largest lumber operations disclosed yesterday. He said extension of the normal seasonal shutdown period of one week is being considered because of the steady softening of the market for West Coast lumber since late September.
VIENNA, Dec. 17 -- The central organ of the Czechoslovak Communist party in Slovakia, Pravda, announced today that religious youth organizations must disappear.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 -- A joint program of research on atomic energy as it applies to soils and plant life was announced today by the Department of Agriculture and the Atomic Energy Commission. Greenhouses and "hot" laboratories for handling radio-active chemicals will be constructed by the commission at the department's large experimental farm at Beltsville, Md.

Low price variety stores yesterday reported a pick-up of business here for the week and all operators were confident that sales for the holiday season will show an increase over those of last year. This business, however, is not being stimulated by consumer desire for lower prices, according to opinions expressed by variety executives.

There is nothing strange about a woman working for the Y.M.C.A., not even if she has done so for the last thirty-seven years. At least that is the opinion of Miss Elsie Brink, financial secretary of the Y.M.C.A. Schools of New York City.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 -- American corporations reported cash dividend disbursements of $206,600,000 in November, 1948, the Office of Business Economics of the Department of Commerce announced today. This amount was 17 per cent more than the $176,900,000 paid out during November, 1947.

In THE TIMES of Nov. 6 there appeared a letter purporting to clarify a statement recently made before the Fourth Committee of the General Assembly by Gen. Carlos P. Romulo, chairman of the Philippine delegation, concerning the inadequacy of educational facilities in certain trust territories under the administration of the United Kingdom, Belgium and Australia.

A contractual wage review for the American Radio Association, CIO, was closed yesterday by the Committee for the Companies and Agents for Atlantic and Gulf coasts on the same basis used to settle with two other Congress of Industrial Organizations affiliated maritime unions earlier this week.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 -- The question whether the Supreme Court of the United States will interfere with the convictions of the Japanese war leaders by the International Military Tribunal at Tokyo was left for consideration by the court as arguments on the issue ended today.
BUDAPEST, Dec. 17 (AP) -- The newspaper Vilgossag said today that 2,000 workers and students had demonstrated yesterday against Cardinal Mindszenty, calling him a warmongering "American agent."

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Dec. 17 -The police sent out tonight an alarm for three soldiers who are accused of having stolen a taxicab from its driver. One of those sought allegedly stabbed the driver in the neck as he tried to escape from the vehicle.

PRETORIA, South Africa, Dec. 17 -- For the present South Africa's financial salvation lies in the acquisition of dollars either directly from the United States or indirectly through Switzerland, it was made clear today by Dr. Michiel H. de Kock, governor of the Reserve Bank, in a special statement that he stressed was issued after consultation with Minister of Finance Nicholaas C. Havenga.

Taking advantage of a loophole in the state's labor relations laws, a left-wing New York teachers' union has unionized radio and television schools in the city, although the majority of instructors prefer not to be associated with a union that follows the party line, it was charged yesterday.

The situation in Indonesia appears to have reached a point where only United Nations intervention can bring about a peaceful solution. When the Security Council intervened a year ago in July during the Dutch "police action" against the Republic it would seem to have assumed an obligation to see the matter through to a happy conclusion.

Evander Childs, Bronx champion, gained its third straight city P.S.A.L. dual meet swimming championship by defeating Andrew Jackson, the Queens titlist, 45 -- 22, in the Brooklyn Tech pool yesterday. The Bronx swimmers captured six of the eight first places in scoring their eighth successive victory.

CLEVELAND, Dec. 17 -- The All-America Football Conference will continue operations in 1949 with the same eight clubs that comprised its membership during the season that comes to a close here Sunday with the championship game between the Cleveland Browns and the Buffalo Bills.

Station WKBS, operating on 1,520 kilocycles, will start formal operations today in Oyster Bay, L.I. The principal speaker at the ceremony, running from 1 to 2 P.M., will be Dr. Tristram Walker Metcalf, president of Long Island University.

TRENTON, N. J., Dec. 17 -- Surrounded by old tin cans, cigar boxes, cardboard cartons and paper bags filled width thousands of pennies and silver coins totaling $3,568,63, an 84-year-old recluse was found unconscious today in a filthy shanty near a cemetery wall suffering from malnutrition and gangrenous feet.

Rubber futures advanced 35 to 45 points in active trading on the Commodity Exchange yesterday. Continued rising prices in the London and Singapore primary market were held factors in giving strength to the market.
NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 17 (AP) -- The Fair Grounds racing card bounced over rough bumps today.

PARIS, Dec. 17 -- Israel's application for membership in the United Nations was rejected today by the Security Council as a result of the abstention of France and Canada. They had been expected earlier to support the application.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 17 (AP) -- The Philadelphia Athletics today announced the sale of right-handed pitcher Bob Savage to the St. Louis Browns for an unannounced sum of cash.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 (AP) -- The final harvest reports today stamped the 1948 crop year as perhaps the most remarkable in the nation's history. The Department of Agriculture announced that the season broke many production records and also gave the country bountiful supplies of many of the products which it needed most.

PARIS, Dec. 17 -- The Finance Committee of the Assembly passed Premier Queuille's 1949 budget for parliamentary consideration today after having amended it so as to reduce the aggregate revenue and leave a large hole to be filled.

So far as the marketing of new issues of securities is concerned, the curtain for the year 1948 is nearly drawn. No new corporate deals of market consequence are scheduled for next week. Tax-exempt bond marketing will be at a minimum, too.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 (AP) -- Efforts to rescue nine Air Force men marooned on the Greenland ice cap failed today when a glider sent to pick them up bogged down in deep snow.

SEOUL, Korea, Dec. 17 -- Abandonment of China to the Communists "is suicidal in policy and immoral in principle," President Syngman Rhee declared today in a written statement issued at his weekly press conference.

LAKE PLACID, N. Y., Dec. 17 (AP) -- The state Grange came out today for a St. Lawrence power project and put its 142,000 members on record against repeal of the Taft-Hartley Law or "any attempt to legalize the closed shop."

The number of relief cases was reduced 4,145 and the number of persons on relief rolls 9,572 between June 1 and Nov. 30, Raymond Hilliard, Commissioner of Welfare, told Hunter College social work students yesterday.
PROVIDENCE, R.I., Dec. 17 (AP) -- The eight O'Briens of Providence were preparing today for the happiest Christmas of their lives. Yesterday they were getting ready for the most tragic.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., Dec. 17 -- Superior Judge Frank T. Lloyd ruled today that if a special agent for the Federal Bureau of Investigation can give the answers to questions from his own personal knowledge, he can be compelled to supply them before a county grand jury.

CHICAGO, Dec. 17 -- Final estimates on 1948 production of major grains as announced by the Department of Agriculture late today showed virtually no change as compared with preliminary returns, and the report is not expected to be a price-making influence tomorrow, although many brokers expected a fair increase in corn.

A woman was seriously injured last night in a freakish three-car collision at the intersection of Willow Avenue and East 134th Street, the Bronx, in which one of the machines kept on going under its own power, dragging the woman with it, after its driver had been thrown out to the ground by the impact.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 (UP) -- The Federal Power Commission said tonight that the steel shortage is the main cause of delay in construction of pipelines to meet the "rapidly growing demands for natural gas."

Plans for a city-wide conference on the problem of unstable families and its companion problem of the divorce evil, as a step toward revising the State Divorce Law, are being drafted by a committee of the New York County Lawyers Association, it became known yesterday.
Alleghany County, Md., sold yesterday $2,000,000 of school bonds due Jan. 1, 1950 to 1974, to Lehman Brothers and associates at a bid of 100.027 for 1.90s, an interest cost of 1.89 per cent.

An astonishing debut recital was given by Jacob Lateiner, 19-year-old pianist, last night in Carnegie Hall. It was astonishing because of the maturity of technique and musicianship by a musician of such years in the performance of an exceptionally formidable program.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 17 -- Capt. Charles F. May, national president of the Masters, Mates and Pilots of America, AFL, voiced a protest today against a Coast Guard requirement that all officers employed on subsidized vessels and on ships operated under governmental general agency agreement be members of the Naval Reserve.

CLEVELAND, Dec. 17 (UP) -- A Federal grand jury today indicted eight companies, six of their officers and a trade association on charges of eliminating competition and fixing prices in the photo frame industry.

GREAT NECK, L. I., Dec. 17 -- Reorganization of Board of Education procedures and closer cooperation between public school officials and civic groups are recommended in a special report made after a two-year study of this community's education system.

The holly is one of the appealing trees of the woodland. Many people who have never seen the tree's beauty know the leaves and fruit so commonly used for Christmas greens. In many areas the evergreen trees are growing fewer as thoughtless men slash and cut without thought of the future.
DAMASCUS, Syria, Dec. 17 (AP) -- Khaled el-Azem, Foreign Affairs and Justice Minister in 1939, formed a new Cabinet last night to tackle Syria's difficult problems.

ALBANY, Dec. 17 -- Governor Dewey announced today that, effective Jan. 1, state aid to general and convalescent hospitals for the rehabilitation of physically handicapped children will be increased from $750,000 to $900,000 per year.

I have just read the editorial entitled "The 'Closed System'" in THE NEW YORK TIMES of Oct. 20. I find that it contains such fantastic nonsense about our country, coupled with hostile sallies against the Soviet people, that I feel it is my duty as a writer to address this letter to you in the hope that you may bring it to the attention of your readers.
The State Board of Regents voted yesterday to devote a major part of its meeting late next month in Albany to reappraising the teaching of American history in the schools and colleges of the state.

The police substitute for the abandoned $23,500,000 Lower Manhattan Crosstown Expressway will go into operation today when an intricate network of crosstown arteries in the Canal Street zone will be restricted to one-way operation.

MANAGUA, Nicaragua, Dec. 17 -- Gen. Anastasio Somoza, former President of Nicaragua and now Defense Minister, in an interview today predicted the charges that Nicaraguan forces were fighting in northern Costa Rica with Costa Rican rebels who were based just across the border in Nicaragua would be disproved by the special investigating commission of the Organization of American States.

PEIPING, Dec. 17 -- Communist mortar shells landed within several hundred yards of the runway on which a special courier plane arrived today at Peiping's abandoned south airfield, about six miles below this encircled city.

Although showing an increase last month over October, foreclosures of property in Manhattan for the first eleven months of this year were at a lower level than for any comparable period since the Real Estate Board of New York began compiling figures on the subject, the board reported yesterday.

A consent decree signed by Federal Judge John C. Knox brought to a close yesterday a civil anti-trust suit by the Department of Justice against Bendix Home Appliances, Inc., of South Bend, Ind., and the Telecoin Corporation of New York City.

DETROIT, Dec. 17 -- Larry S. Davidow, prominent Detroit lawyer, confirmed published and broadcast reports today that two years ago he had told John Foster Dulles that Alger Hiss had a "provable" Communist record.
NANKING, Dec. 17 -- Some foreign military observers here are beginning to use the expression "mopping-up operations," to refer to the actions north of Nanking and in the Peiping and Tientsin areas.

Purple tones, black and pumpkin are the coming colors in decorative fabrics, according to a forecast by a committee of the Home Fashions League that was made public yesterday. The report on trends prepared under the guidance of Lillian Weiss, editor of Home Furnishings Merchandising, was presented by Gladys Miller at a luncheon meeting of the league at the Roosevelt Hotel.

CHICAGO, Dec. 17 -- Chicago area headquarters of the Atomic Energy Commission today disclosed that Armando Rodrigues, 27 years old, a chemist previously employed by that agency at its Los Alamos (N.M.) site, died in Billings Hospital here, Dec. 11, from the effects of Beryllium poisoning.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 17 (AP) -- An early scoring splurge enabled the Philadelphia Warriors to crack the six-game winning streak of the New York Knickerbockers, 87--78, in their Basketball Association of America game tonight before 4,500 spectators.

Many fishermen, both in the sports and commercial category, have the idea that the supply of salt water fishes is inexhaustible, and it is not until a species, widely sought for food or sport, is approaching scarcity that conservation regulations are drafted.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 17 (AP) -- Roaring tides pounded the coast today as welcome rain, accompanied by heavy snow in the mountains, eased southern California's record drought and ended, at least temporarily, a critical fire hazard.
PARIS, Dec. 17 (AP)--An Indonesian representative at the United Nations has charged that the Netherlands plans to invade the Indonesian Republic.

There is special significance this year in the award of the Robert J. Collier Trophy, both because of the achievement for which it was made and because three phases of that achievement are recognized in the award. The 37-year-old trophy was presented yesterday by President Truman to the three men regarded as most responsible for the attainment of supersonic flight.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Dec. 17 -- Manhattan College virtually clinched its third consecutive Metropolitan A. A. U. junior team championship tonight at the completion of the meet that opened the indoor track and field season at the Jersey City Armory.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 -- John E. Bierwirth of New York, a bankler, who called on President Truman today, told reporters after his visit that he felt the President agreed with him that "taxes are awfully high and people ought to get some relief."

Gowanus Houses, a subsidized low-rent public housing under construction by the New York City Housing Authority, received its first tenants yesterday. The development is being built with funds borrowed from the state.

GENEVA, Dec. 17 -- Three voluntary relief agencies and the United Nations signed agreements today providing for the administration of relief to refugees from the war in Palestine, the overwhelming number of whom are Arabs.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 -- A new and improved top lining for automobiles described as having "superior sound absorption and heat insulation values, combined with low installation cost and ease of cleaning," was one of 697 inventions approved this week by the United States Patent Office, a post-war record number, exceeding by 107 the highest previous total, established Oct. 15 of this year.

Rebecca Gendler has sold the two-family dwelling at 1758 Seventy-sixth Street, Brooklyn, to Amedeo Lombardi. Slomka Brothers, Inc., brokers in the transaction, arranged mortgage financing for the buyer with the Dime Savings Bank of Brooklyn.
A group of Harlem civic leaders met yesterday at the office of Borough President Hugo E. Rogers in the Municipal Building to organize a program for the use of vacant lots as playgrounds.

"There wasn't any system of signing receipts for secret papers in the State Department when was I there," Henry Julian Wadleigh, one of the men accused by Whittaker Chambers of furnishing secret State Department documents to a Communist organization and who has consistently appeared before the New York grand jury investigating espionage, said in an interview yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 -- Registration statements covering $600,000 of debentures and 167,430 shares of common stock were filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission by two corporations.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 (AP) -- Jack Dempsey won a decision today over the Internal Revenue Commissioner. Involved was a tax bill on $12,000 of the $36,724 "Jack Dempsey's" Restaurant in New York paid the former heavyweight boxing champion for personal appearances and the use of his name in 1942.

Panic-stricken when a fire broke out on the third floor of a five-story tenement at 473 Lenox Avenue, between 133d and 134th Streets a little after 11 o'clock last night, one woman was killed in a leap to the ground from a third floor window and another woman and a man were seriously injured when they also jumped out of the same window.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 -- Lawrence D. Bell, producer of the rocket plane X-1--first airplane to fly faster than sound--said here tonight that aircraft builders now knew how to build much...
WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 (AP) -The United States has in effect rejected a Czech Government plea for more United States shipments of critically-needed machinery and equipment, it was disclosed today.

At an arbitration hearing between the French Orchestre National and its American concert manager yesterday, Charles Munch, conductor of the orchestra, testified that its members played artistically, properly, adequately and entirely to his satisfaction.

NEW DELHI, India, Dec. 17 --Absorption of French and Portuguese colonies in India into the Indian Union was adopted as an aim of the Indian National Congress party at today's meeting of the Government party's Subjects Committee in Jaipur. Formal approval of this and other preliminary resolutions is expected as a matter of course when the party's plenary session opens tomorrow.

While anxiously awaiting the fall of snows and freezing temperatures -- most essential for good skiing -- Metropolitan winterlands continue their preparations for the season. Ken Littlefield, regional chairman of the National Ski Patrol System, sends an appeal on behalf of the Taconic State Park, Commission, operators of the Fahnestock Ski Slope, less than sixty miles from Times Square, for skiers to serve as paid patrolmen during 1948-49.

Today's events: Philharmonic Symphony, Children's Concert, Igor Buketoff, conductor; Saul Goodman, percussion; Diana Steiner, violin, Carnegie Hall, 11 A. M.; National Orchestral Association, Leon Barzin, conductor; Dessoff Choirs; Anita Zahn and Duncan Dancers, Carnegie Hall, 2:30; Trapp Family Singers, Town Hall, 5:30.

Ezio Pinza, basso and a leading member of the Metropolitan Opera Company for more than twenty years, will not sing with the company this season, it became known yesterday with the release of the prospectus of the opera's sixty-fourth season.

"It was the season of light, it was the season of darkness," said Charles Dickens about another time--words which might well do for Christmastide. Today Swedes in America will open their Christmas season with the traditional Lucia Day, the Festival of Light.

LONDON, Dec. 17 -- For more than four hours today the tribunal of inquiry into allegations of fraud at the Board of Trade heard a defense of Sidney Stanley, the stateless alien on whom the whole investigation hinges.

TRENTON, N.J., Dec. 17 -- State education officials from New Jersey, New York and the six New England states studied today the feasibility of interstate reciprocity in accepting teachers for positions without extensive qualifying tests.
NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 19--The Christmas rush at the West Side Trust Company at 247 South Orange Avenue here saved the $5,700 payroll of a garment factory from two hold-up men today.

Representative John McDowell, a subcommittee of one of the House Un-American Activities Committee, examined two witnesses in secret here yesterday and announced later that he had developed something "very new" in the espionage inquiry.

The city's confectioneries are quite evidently determined this Christmas to divest candy of any of the hackneyed aspects it may have as a gift. Boxes are more imaginative than they've ever been; their contents are almost bewilderingly varied.

The $1 bail in which Mrs. Geraldine Vetter, 38 years old, of 790 Columbus Avenue, had been released pending disposition of a complaint that she had punished her 8-year-old son, Philip, by burning his hands over a gas stove, was raised to $1,000 by Magistrate Morris Rothenberg in Felony Court yesterday when he was informed that one of the child's fingers had been amputated.

ALBANY, Dec. 17 -- Plans for a major realignment of functions in the State Civil Service Department, with a single director assuming the administrative duties of the present three-member Civil Service Commission were revealed today by a high state official.

The rivalry for honors in the American League between the Yankees and the Boston Red Sox, which went right down to the season's play-off ending, carried over into the chain of record performances achieved by the junior circuit through the 1948 campaign.

Christmas has turned Fifth Avenue into a wonderland, where pine trees sprout gum drops and red roses, where snowballs, are filled with chocolate and snowflakes with bottles of perfume, where snowstorms rage in two square feet of space, and where stores have put up window glass barriers to keep mere mortals in the world of hard pavements and high prices.

Gzeslaw Grzelak, a Polish steamship official, was arrested yesterday in deportation proceedings as an alien Communist. The arrest was made by agents of the Federal Immigration and Naturalization Service at the offices of the Gdynia-America Line, Inc., 32 Pearl Street, a Polish national concern.

A tract of forty-six acres on Dogwood Avenue adjacent to the Southern State Parkway in West Hempstead, L.I., has been sold by the Isabelle Realty Company to the Gardland Realty Company of New York City. Edward J. Brown represented the seller and Howard C. Taylor acted for the buyer.
LONDON, Dec. 17 -- Oils were were best in an otherwise quiet and trendless stock market here today.

KITTY HAWK, N.C., Dec. 17 (AP) -- The forty-fifth anniversary of the first flight by the Wright brothers was observed here today. That 12-second, 40-yard venture into the sky took place on Kill Devil Hill on Dec. 17, 1903.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 (AP) -The retail cost of the family "market basket" declined in October for the third month in a row.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Dec. 17 -- The Rutgers basketball team made a brilliant comeback in the second half tonight to defeat Princeton, 65--53. The Scarlet is now on the long end of a 4-1 record while the Tigers have two victories and the same number of losses.

DURBAN, Dec. 17 (Reuters) -- England was only 17 runs behind South Africa's first innings total of 161 when rain stopped play for the day with its score at 144 for two wickets in the cricket test match today.
Kentucky's N.C.A.A. champions will take the floor against St. John's at Madison Square Garden tonight in the second part of a basketball twin bill.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 17 (AP) -- Erigeron of the Grandview Stables, owned by Harry Massey of Pittsburgh, won the six-furlong Brendan Purse at Tropical Park today. Eleven good sprinters started and the first five staged a blanket finish.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 (UP) -- The Federal Housing Administration today announced a new office to handle cooperative housing and yield insurance.

The New York City Housing Authority, with Mayor O'Dwyer's backing, favors a new Federal housing law which would be aimed at the building of 800,000 apartments without limit as to cost and which would permit cities to clear slum areas for other than residential use, Gen. Thomas F. Farrell, chairman of the Authority, said yesterday.
The first step was taken yesterday to carry out Governor Dewey's request that the new State University's medical program be integrated with the state's long-range plan for curing the mentally ill.

WEST ORANGE, N. J., Dec. 17 -- Mrs. Dolores Mitchell Singleton, 18-year-old mother of three children, pleaded not guilty this afternoon to a charge of manslaughter made against her as a result of the fatal scalding Wednesday of her youngest daughter, 8-months-old Sandra. Mrs. Singleton pleaded not guilty before Recorder James Degnan and was released in custody of her attorney.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 17 (UP) -- Montana University "definitely is on the way out" of the Pacific Coast Conference, the United Press learned from a reliable source today. The northern school's status will be a major topic for discussion at the annual P.C.C. meeting in Palm Springs on Jan. 2.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 17 (AP) -- If the records mean anything, the Chicago Cardinals and Philadelphia Eagles probably will need the Shibe Park lights and a sudden-death extra period to determine the National Football League championship Sunday.
