Retail trade here this week made a small increase despite several days of bad weather. Department store sales were estimated as about 3 per cent over the corresponding week last year. Sales last week were up 2 per cent.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Dec. 17 -- The refusal of the Federal Post Office Department to relinquish a lease on a dilapidated garage building here, used for the repair and overnight storage of eighteen trucks, is preventing construction of a $5,500,000 low-rent housing development, Emil Strateman, chairman of the White Plains Housing Authority, charged tonight.
ATLANTA, Dec. 17 (AP) -- Gov. Herman Talmadge and his legislative leaders came out today with a "white supremacy" program frankly aimed at barring 80 per cent of Georgia Negroes from voting.

A gain of $43,137,958, the largest increase in 8 months, was registered during November by the savings banks of New York State, it was reported yesterday. According to the figures issued by the Savings Bankg Association of the State of New York, there are now mover 10,193,562,275 on deposit in the 131 mututal savings banks of this state.

Alvin G. Schmale has been appointed director of sales and advertising for the Honey Butter Products Corporation of Ithaca, N.Y., with headquarters in New York at 250 East Forty-third Street. He was formerly grocery sales manager of the Sweets Company of America.

While children's wear buying for spring has taken on the same slow pace as the purchasing of women's and misses' apparel, present indications point to a marked improvement shortly after the first of the year, according to resident buyers. Orders thus far on children's wear for spring, buyers said yesterday, fall short of covering 50 per cent of the season's requirements.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 17 -- Because of a postponement of his Anglo-French project, "Rachel," in which Edana Romney was to have starred, William Dieterle will direct "Rope of Sand" for the Hal Wallis company at the Paramount Studio here, Wallis announced today.

TOKYO, Dec. 17 -- Two new names cropped up in Japan's sensational political bribery scandals today. They were Tanzan Ishibashi, former Finance Minister, and Hiroo Wada, former director of the Economic Stabilization Board. According to the procurators, both were named as bribe recipients by Jiro Hoshijima, former Commerce Minister.

Celebration of Christmas will be heralded by the church choirs of the city tomorrow. Sermons will be preached on the Christmas theme and congregations will join in the singing of Christmas hymns and carols. Gifts for the needy will be deposited at the altars in many parishes.

Mayor O'Dwyer announced yesterday the appointment of a five-man committee to prepare slum clearance plans "in anticipation of the passage of the slum clearance provision of the proposed Taft-Ellender-Wagner Bill by the Eighty-first Congress."

A 14-year-old boy was found dead in bed at his Forest Hills, Queens, home yesterday with his head tied up by a maroon tie looped over the nose and mouth, his neck by a handkerchief, and his lower body by twine. His hands were free. Last night Dr. Richard Grimes, assistant medical examiner of Queens, pronounced the death a suicide.
Miss Marion Gurney leased an apartment in 27 West Eleventh Street through the Houghton Company.
That was an interesting news story, recently about the litter problem of Washington Market.

The Judah L. Magnes Foundation, Inc., which set a goal of $250,000 to be used to promote the educational and humanitarian ideals of the late Dr. Magnes, former president of the Hebrew University in Palestine, was established yesterday as Supreme Court Justice William C. Hecht Jr. approved the organization's certificate of incorporation.

One out of every five New Yorkers personally has experienced discrimination in employment, it was said yesterday on the basis of a survey recently sponsored by the Commission on Community Interrelations of the American Jewish Congress and the Research Committee on Intergroup Relations, an independent body of social scientists from universities and colleges throughout the state.
American educators are sharply divided on the question of encouraging colleges and universities to invest a substantial part of their endowment funds in real estate or commercial ventures.

LONDON. THIS is the way a London playbill of 1730 assessed the great Christmas institution of pantomime. Now "panto" is about to come into its own again. However much fashion may change in other parts of the theatrical world, this annual show, with all its splendors and absurdities, is likely to continue to delight British audiences for years to come.

The nominating committee of the New York A.C. yesterday released the slate of officers and governors which will head the organization after the annual election to be held on Tuesday. The nominations are tantamount to election.

SWEET BAY (Laurus nobilis) is an unusual and appropriate Christmas gift plant. Because it does not require sunshine but needs only light and water, it ought to be especially appreciated by apartment dwellers.

With the demand for new currency for gift purposes reaching its peak this week, no difficulty will be experienced by the banks here in meeting the requests, bankers indicated. Larger allotments of new bills have been made by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York to meet the increased requirements.

AMMAN, Trans-Jordan, Dec. 18 -- Christmas Eve pilgrims to Bethlehem will forsake the traditional route this year for the first time and use a new road through Arab-held territory because Israeli forces bar the other road, the Arab Military Governor of the Old City of Jerusalem said here today.

Traffic-weary motorists obtained little relief yesterday as the inexpensive police plan to speed travel through the congested Canal Street zone started a sixty-day trial. Aimed at breaking the endless jams between the Holland Tunnel area and downtown East River bridges by an intricate network of one-way crosstown arteries, the plan bogged down along the Bowery where there is an immovable barrier to free traffic movement -- the iron pillars of the Third Avenue Elevated Line.

I AM very nappy to be acting on Broadway again. It is truly wonderful to have received such a friendly welcome, and I am deeply appreciative. And I also appreciate the present opportunity to set the record straight.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 (AP) -- Senator Edwin C. Johnson of Colorado, president of the Western Baseball League, said today that Joe Gordon, second baseman for the Cleveland Indians baseball club, is interested in acquiring a franchise for Wichita, Kan.
A vision of international peace through the promotion of understanding among the youth of all nations is the inspiration behind a plan to develop in Riverdale, N.Y., a new "American World School."

CARMELITA MARACCI this afternoon gives her final performance of the season at the Y.M. and Y.W. H.A., with three new solos by way of novelty. Last-week's performance (an exciting one, as Maracci performances always are) attracted an audience which was virtually a social register of the dance.

THIS copious anthology of contemporary English verse is important for the same reason that a slim volume entitled "New Signatures" was important back in the early Thirties. "New Signatures" introduced for the first time to the American poetry-reading public the work of Auden, Spender, Day Lewis and their confreres.
AT Christmas time the fund for The Hundred Neediest Cases works a kind of miracle. Consider, for example, these three out of last year's Neediest and what help has meant to them:

IN THE second century before Christ the aristocratic Greek intellectual Polybius pointed to the Roman Constitution as the key to the most important question of his time. Why was Rome able to control more territory more effectively than any previous empire known to man? Rome's government, wrote Polybius, is the successfull synthesis of monarchic, oligarchic and democratic elements, each checking the others and maintaining the whole in proper balance.

GLANCE down the list of plays, poetry, fiction and general works of John Masefield and two diverse reflections come to mind: England's Poet Laureate, whose "Salt Water Ballads" started him toward world recognition, has been among the most industrious of literary creators; he seems to have had St. George, England's patron saint, on his mind for a considerable time.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- Business Week, a McGraw-Hill publication, said editorially today that the Taft-Hartley Law had failed and that in some circumstances it conceivably could wreck the labor movement.

"If any place in Nanking has been a nerve center of Chiang Kai-shek's Government it is the Ministry of Communications building on North Chungshan Road. In it there is a war room where officials meet to study situation maps -- maps showing how the Communists have cut Nationalist communications in preparation for their final drive against Nanking.

Prof. Paul Pigors of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology has won the first $1,000 award of the Lieut. Ben Toland Memorial Fellowship. This was announced yesterday by Earl Bunting, managing director of the National Association of Manufacturers, which is to make two such awards annually.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- The House Committee on Un-American Activities, aiming at a quick wind-up of its espionage investigation, arranged today for Francis B. Sayre, former Assistant Secretary of State, and his personal secretary to appear as witnesses early next week.

ROLAND HAYES, the first Negro to achieve an international reputation as an all-around concert singer, made his career as an interpreter of the songs and arias of many nations. Whatever else he sang, however, he always made room for the music of his people, and when he sang these songs he turned them into gems of expressiveness.

PEIPING, Dec. 18 -- This is a strange war that is taking place on the outskirts of historic Peiping, which Gen. Lin Piao's Manchurian Communist Army has surrounded with a minimum of fighting and little expenditure, either in human lives or firepower.

ROGER PARIZOT knows how to roast goose. He does so often at this season in the kitchen of the Chateaubriand Restaurant at 148 East Fifty-sixth Street. He mixes chestnuts with sausage meat, adds a little onion and brandy for flavoring, tosses in three or four tablespoons of diced truffles, binds the whole thing together with egg yolks, then uses this mixture to stuff the bird.

New York manufacturers of women's and children's apparel will step up their spring selling effort with intensified road campaigns, it was learned last week. In the next ten days salesmen will begin seven to nine week trips for second showings of spring lines and first showing of summer merchandise which will take them into hundreds of small communities and the principal cities of the country.

LONDON, Dec. 18 -- King Abdullah of Trans-Jordan has been running true to form. Ambitious and self-sufficient, he has set himself against all other Arab Kings and Presidents, and with single-minded determination has gone about enlarging his domain.

DESPITE perennial wails about the theatre's alleged decline, at least one of its children has grown and developed steadily since 1936. The American Educational Theatre Association, one of the sturdiest and busiest groups in the so-called off-Broadway theatre, includes upward of 1,500 teachers, directors, artists, and craftsmen, representing institutions large and small from every state in the Union.

Admission of Israel into the United Nations "is being delayed in a sort of game to appease the Arab countries," Rabbi William F. Rosenblum said in a sermon in Temple Israel, 210 West Ninety-first Street, yesterday.

DEPARTMENT store figures have yet to be reported but it is likely that trade last week finally exceeded the dollar volume of last year after almost two months of lag. This was foreshadowed earlier when for the week ended Dec. 11 sales were only 1 per cent under a year ago.

Igor Buketoff, conductor of the Fort Wayne Philharmonic Orchestra and the touring company of "The Medium" and "The Telephone," made his first appearance with the Philharmonic-Symphony in its Young People's concert yesterday morning at Carnegie Hall.

EXCITEMENT and beauty crowd the pages of the first of these two volumes, an account of a flight by car from the wintry North into the heart of the Florida wilderness. The first stopover was on an island close to Daytona, where a colony of brown pelicans furnished not only interesting and intimate family studies but also some unbelievably grotesque camera shots, later included in the book.
LOS ANGELES, Dec. 18 -- Even in advance of Christmas bills and income taxes, fiscal problems were a prime topic of concern in the Pacific Southwest this week.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 (AP) -- It cost $46,407,904 to operate the newly formed Military Air Transport Service in its first three months.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 18 -- The double-barreled "spy probe" in New York and Washington ran neck-and-neck with the vagaries of the weather in the West Coast conversational sweepstakes this week. Dinner parties were enlivened and barber shop talk pointed up by arguments over the veracity of witnesses and their sometimes bizarre testimony.

THE ideal bed, from the bedmaker's point of view, has neither headboard nor footboard and would presumably stand like a solitary island in the middle of the room. Thus concluded United States Department of Agriculture experts in the course of their attempts to cut down the twenty-four hours of time and four miles of walking that the average housewife spends a year in spreading the sheets and tucking in the blankets on just one bed.

THIS beautifully illustrated and written story is a graphic dramatization of the way in which prehistoric man may have tamed first horse. For the horse lover it offers thrilling sensations of wild, free rides, and without sentimentality, the love of a boy and his horse.

VIENNA, Dec. 18 -- M.A. Koptelow, Soviet political representative, told the Austrian Government this afternoon that Moscow would not oppose the resumption of Austrian treaty negotiations. At the same time Tass, the Soviet news agency, issued a Russian statement on the message given to the Austrian Minister to Moscow, Norbert Bischof.

STAMP collectors who regard themselves as philatelic purists, including some who specialize in commemorative postal paper, have looked askance on some of the Postoffice Department announcements describing the twenty-nine special stamps issued during 1948.

The American Medical Association, in assessing its members $25 each to raise funds to fight health insurance legislation, is violating its own constitution and possibly the Constitution of the United States, it was asserted last night by the board of directors of the Physicians Forum, a national organization of physicians.

The colonial powers should establish a political, social and economic program to hasten the development of self - government among the colonial peoples, in the opinion of high school students who participated yesterday in the Youth Forum sponsored by THE NEW YORK TIMES and broadcast over WQXR.

BERLIN, Dec. 18 -- The United States Military Government has succeeded in getting thirty-five "mandatory" contracts signed with former Nazi printing plant owners providing leases for publishers who have been licensed by the Military Government, it was learned today.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Dec. 18 -- Muted but unmistakable across the rumble of traffic in midtown Frankfort comes a haunting refrain. Some unseeen, strolling musicians are grinding out on antiquated hand organs one of the sweetest of carols, "O Little Town of Bethlehem."

A forecast of things to come may be seen in the midseason showings of the Paris designers. Town coats shrink from tent lines to loose but straight and narrow ones. Last spring, peplums of fitted jackets rippled in back; now the flare is transferred to the front, leaving the back in undisturbed smoothness. Sports frocks and those for the hours fading into night still show moderate fullness.
DURBAN, Dec. 18 (Reuters) -- England finished an eventful day's cricket, in which twelve wickets went down for 199 runs, in a commanding position against South Africa in the first test match.

A CURIOUSLY mixed study, "The Human Side of Music," emerges as part pamphlet, part political science -- and part music. Its author seems unable to resolve his scholarship on the one hand and his tortured social consciousness on the other.

BACK in 1928 and 1934 Dr. David levy published studies which showed that young babies who did not get enough sucking at feeding time were inclined to suck their fingers. Just recently another study by Mary S. Kunst was made on thumb and finger-sucking with children in an orphanage.

Columbia's swimming team defeated Fordham, 47 -- 25, yesterday at the Morningside Heights pool in the season's opener for both squads. The Lions picked up seven first places in the nine events on the card, losing the 200-yard breast stroke and the 440-yard free style to the Rams.

With Clark Driemeyer scoring all three goals, a smooth Philadelphia soccer team shut out the New York All-Stars, 3 -- 0, in the fourth annual inter-city scholastic game before 400 frost-bitten spectators at the Brooklyn College field yesterday.

The city's public housing program was expanded 40 per cent during 1948, with fifteen out of sixteen new projects placed under construction to provide homes for 16,661 families, according to a report sent yesterday to Mayor O'Dwyer by the New York City Housing Authority.

DETROIT, Dec. 18 -- Although auto racing avoids tabulating deaths, a check just completed shows that the sport cost thirty lives and sent forty-three critically injured to hospitals this year in the United States.

ALTHOUGH Capt. James Cook took possession of the eastern coast of the southern continent now known as Australia in 1770, and settlement was begun there by the English in 1788, almost sixty years elapsed before the British asserted claim to the whole continent.

PARIS, Dec. 18 -- In response to a request from United States officials for early completion of the "progress report" by the Marshall Plan nations for submission to Congress, it was decded today that the European Council of those nations would meet on Dec. 28 to approve the report.

EXPERIMENTAL color movies, which are hand-drawn directly on movie film instead of being photographed, yet produce motion and sound when run through a regular motion-picture projector, will be shown by Cinema 16 Wednesday evening at the Hunter College Playhouse.

NANKING (By Wireless). ON the basis of concrete accomplishments and modification of the traditional Marxist-proletarian approach to conditions existing in China, Mao Tze-tung, 55-year-old founder and leader of the Chinese Communist movement, seems to merit the title of the "Chinese Lenin.

On reading Brayton Eddy's article on the Bronx Zoo's Parasol Ants I went up to see them in their new quarters. A strange contraption like a traffic circle built into the bridges between their nest and their rose garden puzzled me.

GARY COOPER, Hollywood's strong, silent man, both on and off screen, was celebrating his twentieth anniversary as a movie star by speaking freely for an interview. Cooper, who has never been noted for his loquacity, recently acquired a public relations counsel and the Hollywood press contingent has been amazed by his unaccustomed volubility.

A NEW apportionment of the transatlantic air passenger traffic seems clearly indicated as a result of last week's announcement that American Overseas Airlines is planning to merge with Pan American Airways.

THE death of Elizabeth Duncan in Europe last month, news of which has just reached this country, removes from the field one of its heroic figures. Not all the great people of the dance are dancers; Elizabeth Duncan was one of its supreme idealists, a teacher with a vision and a mission, neither of which ever dimmed over a long life of practice.

SOFIA, Bulgaria, Dec. 18 -- Vassil Kolarov, dean of the Bulgarian Communist party and Foreign Minister, opened the fifth congress of the Bulgarian Communist party this afternoon in the National Theatre with a reaffirmed pledge of loyalty to the Soviet Union.

In a policy shift at variance with the emphasis of the 1948 capital investment plan on development of the Soviet interior, the Soviet Government plans sharp expansion for the central industrial area around Moscow, according to official information just received from Moscow.
RICHMOND, Va., Dec. 18 -- The Upper South had its eyes on little things this week.

CLEVELAND, Dec. 18 -- The mighty Browns of Cleveland, unbeaten in their last twenty-three games, will unleash their blinding speed, crushing power and devastating aerial attack against the Buffalo Bills in the play-off for the All-America Conference title tomorrow.

IN the welfare field, private philanthropy experiments and demonstrates. When the validity of its programs have been proved and the broad needs of the populace determined, the trend is for the Government to assume the responsibility and to adapt the methods of private agencies into public service.

HOLLYWOOD. THE breaking of relations last week between Samuel Goldwyn and Teresa Wright, who had been under contract to the producer for seven years and still had four and a half years to work out her present agreement, provided Hollywood with its latest conversation piece.

James B. Young, president of the Security Bureau, Inc., urged yesterday establishment of set tariffs for unloading of export freight from trucks or lighters onto piers, to reduce racketeering. This port is one of the few in the nation that does not have published tariffs for such work.

After reading several reviews of "Red Gloves," including the one by your critic, I cannot help but agree with the current controversies that the English adaptation or more specifically perhaps, the Broadway interpretation is far from the original Sartre play still being performed in Paris.

DR. DAVID BRADLEY'S recently published log book and awesome appraisal of the Bikini experiments and the atomic age in general, "No Place To Hide," has been acquired for filming by Pare Lorentz Associates as a "documentary feature," Lorentz revealed last week.

Francis B. Sayre, Alger Hiss' superior in the State Department, will go before the special Federal grand jury here investigating espionage to be asked to identify copies of State Department documents that found their way into the possession of Whittaker Chambers, it was learned yesterday.

LONDON, Dec. 18 (Reuters) -- Defeated today by Manchester United, last season's Football Association Cup winner, Derby County lost the First Division lead in the English League. A crowd of 31,000 witnessed the 3-1 game.

Debutantes of the season were feted at a round of parties given yesterday as a prelude to Christmas week, which will find many more young women of society making their debuts at receptions, dinners, private dances and balls arranged for philanthropic enterprises.

The fifteenth annual meeting of the National Association of Stevedores, last week in the Pennsylvania Hotel, elected John W. McGrath, president of the John W. McGrath Corporation of 29 Broadway to the organization's presidency.

CHICAGO, Dec. 18 (AP) -- Harness racing at the nation's pari-mutuel plants in ten states this year attracted 6,530,417 fans who wagered $193,781,300, an attendance increase of 64 per cent over 1947 and a betting increase of 41 per cent over the previous year.

THE long winter evenings will offer countless opportunities for accomplishing things in the home workshop. This book of hints and short cuts will assist in this. Photographs and line drawings illustrate counties tricks around the work bench that will make simple repairs or creative building a pleasure rather than a chore.

Offering new "Rocket" and "Big Six engines, improved styling and other improvements, the "98" and "76" series of the 1949 Oldsmobile line were announced yesterday from Lansing, Mich., by S.E. Skinner, vice president of General Motors Corporation and general manager of the Oldsomobile division.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Dec. 18 -- Making up in spirit what it lacked in finesse, the Army basketball team, in its first start of the season, powered its way to a convincing 60-to-45 victory over Union College in the Academy Field House today.

If "unilateral" is the right word to describe the proposed action of the Dutch in Indonesia toward the restoration of older and prosperity in the areas under their jurisdiction, the legality of such action, the extent of it, and the result for the entire population are factors which must be considered.
BERLIN, Dec. 18 -- Ever since the Russians began clamping their blockade around and in this city, a new class of entrepreneur, the blockade runner, has developed steadily.

Howard Taubman, in his article "Why Opera Should Not Pay," attempts to inveigle the reader into believing that one more special interest group should be supported or subsidized by taxes or other mass support.

Richard (Pancho) Gonzales of Los Angeles, the rankest outsider to win the national amateur championship within memory, heads the ratings of the United States Lawn Tennis Association as announced yesterday for the season of 1948.

WHILE the outdoor gardener is at the mercy of the elements, the gardener under glass is able to control the weather with exacting accuracy. This is especially true with the introduction of several new automatic devices, calculated to make life even simpler for the greenhouse owner.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- Unification is again the key word in Washington this week-end -- unification in the international field to provide a common defense of the West; unification within the whole Government to bring the nation's foreign, domestic and military policies together; and unification within the armed services to remove selfishness, inefficiency and waste.

Three college basketball double-headers at Madison Square Garden highlight the week in the court sport. The Violets of N.Y.U. and the Blackbirds of L.I.U. will see action in two of the bargain bills, both playing tomorrow and Thursday nights.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- Senator Robert A. Taft said today that he had given no consideration to relinquishing his Republican leadership role in the Senate, as suggested by some colleagues, to permit installation of a fresh and more liberal regime.

MADISON, Wis., Dec. 18 (AP) -- John W. Gibson, former CIO director in Michigan and now Assistant Secretary of Labor, proposed today that the National Labor Relations Board be put in the Labor Department as well as the conciliation service, United States Employment Service and the unemployment compensation system.

Some of the reasons for which Stan Musial recently was voted the National League's most valuable player are brought into focus in the senior circuit's official batting averages released for publication yesterday. A resume of the Cardinal slugger's achievements just about establishes Musial as Mr. Baseball himself.

ALBANY, Dec. 18 -- Governor Dewey, seeking to avoid a lag in the state's low-cost housing and slum-clearance program, announced today that he would recommend to the 1949 Legislature that the ceiling on the amount of housing subsidy contracts which may be outstanding at any one time be raised from $13,000,000 to $25,000,000.

BEHIND technical production improvements and the people's recent vote there is one hope in common, an increasing amount of leisure for the ave rage person. For many of us, an over-sized Sabbath is already here with the "five-day week."

Further improvement in the import picture and a better balance between United States exports and imports are likely next year, provided underlying business conditions here continue favorable, was the consensus in foreign trade circles last week.
SAN BRUNO, Calif., Dec. 18 (AP) -- Closing with a rush, Tick Along, owned by Mrs. C.C. Cate of Los Angeles, won the $10,000-added Sequoia Stakes at Tanforan today at 21 to 1.
TRENTON, N.J., Dec. 18 -- Appointment of Brig. Gen. Donald W. McGowan of Lawrenceville as the commanding general of the New Jersey National Guard was announced today by Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll.
HOBOKEN, N.J., Dec. 18 -- (AP) Lafayette College put on a closing spurt tonight to halt Stevens Tech basketball team by a 49-33 score in what had started as a close-fought contest.

The Arab League, formed in Cairo in 1945, is a tenuous union of the seven Arab states of the Middle East -- Saudi Arabia, Egypt, Syria, Lebanon, Yemen, Iraq and Trans-Jordan. Of these states Trans-Jordan has always been a sort of black sheep.

The new look to be given Battery Park in the aero-photo accompanying the article by Park Commissioner Robert Moses ("'Practical' or 'LongHaired' Planning?") leads me to remark that if the park is to be tree-clogged as shown in the picture, then there should be a howl of protest, a howl more vociferous than the one that followed his narrow decision to demolish the historic Aquarium landmark.

The United Jewish Appeal will hold a three-day national conference in Atlantic City beginning Jan. 12 to plan its 1949 campaign for funds to aid settlement and upbuilding in Israel, relief and rehabilitation in Europe and North Africa and refugee adjustment in the United States, it was announced yesterday.

IN the belief that it helps to universalize the plays they write, dramatists make use of stereotyped characters. Occasionally this may be excusable. Their pat, highly caricatured conception of the American Liberal, though, seems most unjust and certainly does no one honor.

THE author of this book is an experienced teacher, a skilled musician and the mother of four youngsters. She has drawn on the special talents and interests required for these activities to produce an intriguing and ingenious book.

THE time was afternoon, Sept. 20, 1863. The setting was a ridge near Chickamauga Creek, with a backdrop made of the spectacular last fling of the Alleghenies, where the Tennessee River bursts through the mountains at Chattanooga.

There seems to have been in the news lately a plethora of eye-catching words describing inhabitants of cities, states, countries and larger geographical areas whose names do not turn up with the expected suffixes. Perhaps our attention was sharpened last May by the new State of Israel's announcement that its people would be known as Israelis and not by the Biblical "Israelites."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- The United States has provided the Chinese Government with military supplies and equipment worth more than $2,000,000,000 since V-J Day, not counting 6,500 tons of dumped ammunition without assigned value. Relief and economic aid has increased the total to $2,884,065,000.

SINCE all yachtsmen are shameless dreamers anyway, there is really no harm in stimulating that water-on-the-fancy a little more. Here -- Neptune and the First National Bank help us! -- is a book full of the stuff on which cruisers' bigger and better dreams are made.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 18 (AP) -- Tennessee Kid, a 3-1 shot owned by R.A. Brown, found the heavy footing just right and dashed out in front by eight lengths to win the Gulf Coast Purse at the Fair Grounds today.
BATAVIA, Java, Sunday, Dec. 19 -- The Republic of Indonesia said Dutch airplanes bombed Jogjakarta, the Republican capital, today. Jogjakarta is in South Central Java about 200 miles east of Batavia.

BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 18 -- Two political secretaries and the public affairs officer of the United States Embassy have been assigned to prepare a report on two cases of censorship of outgoing press and radio dispatches that are believed to constitute violations of the Chapultepec Pact and other international commitments on freedom of communication.

PRETORIA, South Africa, Dec. 18 -- Negroes in South Africa outnumber whites four to one, but another endeavor to achieve nonwhite unity failed today in Bloemfontein, where several African Negro groups have held conferences throughout the week.
Retail activity moved at a brisk pace here last week owing to increased Christmas shopping in all gift departments, according to a survey made especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Meyer Both Reports.

The hearing which the United States Supreme Court is presently giving to defense counsel representing several former Japanese war leaders occasions a reconsideration of the validity of the Allied Powers' endeavors to implement the terms of the Potsdam Declaration of meting out "stern justice to all war criminals" through the recently concluded proceedings before the International Military Tribunal for the Far East.

Manhattan College, protecting the big lead it ran up in the track events on Friday night at the Jersey City Armory, added twelve points to its total in the four field events held at Columbia's South Field yesterday to capture the Metropolitan A.A.U. junior team title.

ABBE HUC was neither a rugged explorer nor a brilliant chronicler. Nevertheless, the French priest's account of his torturous trek from Peking to Lhasa a hundred years ago places him among famous writers of travel.

OVER forty-five years ago, when I was a student in college, I bought a large English dictionary which had just been published. On its title page it bore this legend: "Designed to give * * * in the light of the most recent advances in knowledge * * * all the words * * * in the speech and literature of the English-speaking peoples.

ATHENS, Dec. 18 -- A rebel radio broadcast monitored here today set forth the aims of the Communist-led guerrillas' large-scale raid on Karditsa early in the week. They were: (1) To recruit men for the rebel army. (2) To increase the "auxiliary services" through recruiting young women.

The performance of the opera "La Boheme," with Bidu Sayao and Richard Tucker, on the evening of Jan. 25 at the Metropolitan Opera House has been taken over by the New York Protestant Episcopal City Mission Society in behalf of St. Barnabas House.

FRITZ REINER will not make his debut with the Metropolitan Opera until some time in February. The likelihood is that his first opera will be "Salome." His opera-conducting career in this country has been closely associated with Strauss, for it was with "Elektra" that he had his first notable success with the Philadelphia Grand Opera Company, and back in November, 1932, he conducted excerpts from "Salome" in a concert at the Metropolitan Opera.

NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 18 -- The Squadron A low-goal trio made it two straight victories over the Newark Polo Club tonight by handing the local malletmen a 12-10 defeat in the main contest at Essex Troop.

The race to enter the seventy-third Westminster Kennel Club show in Madison Square Garden Feb. 14-15 got under way last week with the distribution of premium lists and entry blanks. It isn't actually a race, of course, but in effect it has become one because only a little over 2,500 dogs can be listed.

FOR THIS WEEK: Mulch lily of the valley with manure as a means of fertilizing, not winter protection. A manure mulch is also beneficial for the semi-hardy shrubs, buddleia and abelia. . . . Increase frequency of watering Christman cactus as soon as buds show. Two or three times a week are necessary. . . . Move amaryllis into a warm place (60 degrees or a little more) when the flowering stalk appears.
ELLISYILLE, Miss., Dec. 18 (AP) -- A Navy veteran was under conviction today for miscegenation, and District Attorney Paul Swartzfager said he believed it was the first in the state's history.
WARSAW, Dec. 18 (Reuters) -- Poland today announced a six-year plan -- including industrialization of "depressed areas" -- and the end of all rationing from New Year's Day.

NEXT Wednesday in New York Times Hall seven American pianists, or let us say harpsichordists and pianists, playing pianos of different vintages, will contribute their services in a benefit concert to raise money for the purchase of manuscripts of Louis Moreau Gottschalk for the American Music Collection of the New York Public Library.

Announcement that Newfoundland, after a separate existence of 450 years, is now prepared to merge its identity with Canada as the tenth province did not cause a ripple in international affairs but it did cause a great stir among the shades of great mariners dead and gone who were gathered in the Elysian Fields.
CHAMPAIGN, Ill., Dec. 18 (AP) -- Illinois, sparked by Dike Eddleman's 22 points, ran away from Pennsylvania in the second half for an 80-to-61 basketball triumph over the Quakers tonight.

ROME, Dec. 18 -- Foreign Minister Count Carlo Sforza for Italy and Ambassador James C. Dunn for the United States signed an agreement today for financing studies, research instruction and other educational activities of United States citizens in Italian schools and institutes of higher learning and vice versa.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 18 -- That New York will be represented by two teams in the National Football League next season was ascertained tonight. A simultaneous announcement by John V. Mara, president of the Giants, and Ted Collins, owner of the Boston Yanks, revealed that both parties have agreed on all except minor details, and the switch of the Boston franchise awaits only official league sanction.

The City College basketball team beat Kings Point by 87 to 35, at the C.C.N.Y. gymnasium last night. The Beavers' total, highest in three seasons, was distributed among fifteen players, Irwin Dambrot and Joe Galiber leading the way with 12 and 11 points respectively.
CHICAGO, Dec. 18 (AP) -- The Rose Bowl special pulled out tonight, carrying forty-four Northwestern University football players to Pasadena for their New Year's Day game with California's Bears.

Financial markets followed an uncertain pattern last week as the continuous flow of tax selling dominated trading on the Stock Exchange. Year-end adjustment overshadowed market operations as financial leaders centered their attention on the possible effects of tax and labor proposals now being advocated for the next session of Congress.

LONG before white men got around to doing anything about it, Maine had what it took to be an important place for maritime activity. (It still has, for amateur mariners.) It had magnificent timber close to the water, it had gently sloping shores on tidal waters for shipways, it had deepwater harbors protected offshore by rocky islands, it had a wealth of fish and seals and other creatures of the deep.

The recent publication of Prof. Norbert Wiener's book, "Cybernetics," with the subtitle "Control and Communication in the Animal and the Machine" (John Wiley Sons, Inc., New York), has brought to public attention the new science of cybernetics.

BERLIN, Sunday, Dec. 19 -- The British-licensed newspaper Telegraf said today the Russians had requested the French to evacuate the village of Stolpe, in the French sector of Berlin, and that the French had complied. The report had not been confirmed officially.

BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 18 -- The possibility that has haunted Britain for the last several months, that Argentina would not fulfill frozen meat shipments required by the Andes Agreement of last February, is rapidly turning into reality.

On the face of the record the Security Council has rejected Palestine's application for membership in the United Nations. However, Friday's vote means only that the required seven nations were not ready to vote for membership. Of those who voted, five, including the United States, the Soviet Union, the Ukraine, Argentina and Colombia, were in favor.

The New York Athletic Club indoor polo team opened its 1948-49 metropolitan season with a 12-11 victory over the Squadron A Regulars last night at the Squadron A armory. Herb Pennell's shot in 0:19 of a sudden-death overtime period decided the game which was tied six times entering the extra session.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 (AP) -- G.T. Baker of Miami, Fla., president of National Airlines, announce tonight a proposal under which ten airlines would use each other's routes to provide through-plane service to travelers.

George Piperno, 49 years old, a broker, was arrested early yesterday morning after the police had received complaints that he was unable to account for stocks and bonds entrusted to him by some of his clients. He was arraigned on a grand larceny charge in Felony Court and Magistrate Eugene R. Canudo released him in $2,500 bail for a hearing tomorrow.

Drs. H.A. Spoehr and Harold W. Milner of the Carnegie Institution of Washington described last week in the institution's annual report a discovery that holds great promise for a vast new food source for the world's hungry populations. They found that the single-celled fresh-water alga known as Chlorella, which needs only water, sunlight and mineral salts for its growth, can be made to produce high yields of either protein or fat at will.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Dec. 18 -- The Larchmont Yacht Club's top frostbide dinghy skippers took five straight races in today's match with winter sailors from the Essex (Conn.) Yacht Club and retained possession of the challenge cup which Essex had first won in competition with the Royal Bermuda Yacht Club at Hamilton back in 1934.

I REMEMBER with great pleasure, a ride in a Viennese fiacre through the renowned Hoellenthal. The fiacre went very slowly and we could discuss and admire all the beauty and, even more, the frightening aspects which gave the name to this valley of the hell.
CLEVELAND, Dec. 18 (AP) -- Facts and figures of the third annual All-America Football Conference championship game between the Cleveland Browns and the Buffalo Bills:

RADIO and television will observe the Christmas season this week with many special programs. In addition, most of the regular offerings on the air also will incorporate the Yuletide theme into their productions.

A new-type blast furnace, featuring operational economies and said to possess considerably greater longevity than the conventional type, has been offered to the domestic iron and steel industry by Dr. G.A. Zotos, a noted European process engineer, who developed the facility in 1946.

EACH of the seven chapters in this book deals with a separate phase of the graphic arts: Linoleum block printing, wood engraving, etching, silk-screen printing, lithography, bookbinding and letterpress printing. Each is discussed completely within its own chapter and each is discussed in terms pertinent to its own unique qualities among the arts and crafts.

IN 1931 E.M. Butler, an Englishwoman, published her entertaining evaluations of Sheridan's biographers ("Sheridan: A Ghost Story"), concluding with the distressing notion that there had never been a good one. Thomas Moore seemed to her envious and untrustworthy.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Dec. 18 -- A plan to establish better educational facilities for Southern Negroes adopted this week by eleven Southern Governors at Savannah, Ga., and the prospects are bright that it may start bearing fruit by the opening of the 1949 collegiate term next fall.

NEW DELHI, India, Dec. 18 -- Dominionhood in the British Commonwealth is a "transitional" phase in India's political development, and therefore "Dominion status must go," Dr. Pattabhi Sitaramayya, the new president of the Indian National Congress party, declared today in his presidential address to the party's fifty-fifth annual convention in Jaipur.
MOBILE, Ala., Dec. 18 (AP) -- Eddie Stanky underwent an apparently successful operation today to correct an ankle injury which the Boston Braves' second sacker suffered last July.

Poor Saint Nicholas! From a person of dignity and spiritual beauty he has degenerated into a fat elf with a round belly. Any parent who is trying to keep Christmas the religious festival it is has a hard time reconciling to a child's merciless logic the great saint of the Fourth Century with Clement Moore's caricature.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- Opposition to the threat by Paul G. Hoffman, Economic Cooperation Administrator, to divert shipping from American vessels unless their rates were lowered to "competitive" levels gained significant bipartisan strength today.

CLEVELAND, Dec. 18 -- The Chicago Rockets will take part in the draft of college players, but their status as a 1949 member of the All-America Football Conference today was not as clear as it was made to seem yesterday when it was announced that the circuit would operate again with the "same eight" members.

Wholesale salesmen, who he said comprise "potentially the most powerful professional group in America," suffer a greater share of inequalities than any other group of professional workers, according to Louis A. Capaldo, president of the National Council of Salesmen's Organizations, who made his annual report to more than 100 delegates attending the annual meeting of the council on Friday night at its headquqarters, 80 West Fortieth Street.
United States, British and a few French aircraft have hauled more than 656,000 tons of supplies into Berlin in 174 days of the greatest airlift operation in history.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- Two groups of Army civilian employes in Germany have protested the abolishment of a 25 per cent overseas pay differential in a joint resolution submitted to the Secretaries of State and Defense and the Civil Service Commission.

EDGAR BERGEN'S abrupt decision to leave the air after his broadcast next Sunday night throws into sharp relief the confusion which has overtaken radio in the light of television's rapid progress. Coming on top of Jack Benny's switch to CBS and the resultant general upheaval in much of nighttime programming, it may be regarded as another symptom of the many surprises in store as broadcasting makes the transition from radio to TV.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 18 -- A wet, slippery gridiron is in prospect for tomorrow's National Football League championship play-off between the defending Chicago Cardinals and the Philadelphia Eagles at Shibe Park. Rain or snow has been forecast and if either develops, both sides agree that the breaks will determine the outcome.

THE Christmas holiday traffic rush that will be crowding Pennsylvania Station and Grand Central Terminal most of this week means extra work for the many people who keep busy making the sandwiches that nourish coach passengers en route.

MADELEINE CARROLL, as packed houses at the Morosco will testify nightly, is giving one of the most rewarding performances of the season in "Goodbye, My Fancy." No less rewarding, as thousands of ex-GI's will testify, were the impromptu performances she staged in the war-years, from Africa to Aachen -- on one of the most grueling, self-effacing tours of duty ever undertaken by an actress.
An acting police lieutenant was shot and severely wounded yesterday day by his own revolver in a room above the Brooklyn Traffic Court.

A colorful spectacle and a program of Christmas music was presented to an audience largely of children at Carnegie Hall yesterday afternoon. The event was one of the National Orchestral Association's Gabrilowitsch Memorial family series and took the form of a collaboration of the orchestra, under Leon Barzin, the Dessoff Choirs and Anita Zahn, with her pupils of the Duncan dance.

PEIPING, Dec. 18 -- A new flurry of "peace" rumors and talk of a new "coalition" government developed this week in Nanking as the Communists launched a major offensive in North China and scored impressive initial successes against Nationalist troops under Gen.

The Liberal party has prepared a program of legislation in the fields of civil rights, housing and rent control, taxes and finance and education that it will present to the Legislature, it was announced yesterday by its monthly paper, The Liberal.
OMAHA, Dec. 18 -- How can we stretch the states' financial cloth to fit the expanded budget pattern?

MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 18 (AP) -- Rival coaches Herman Hickman of Yale and Andy Gustafson of Miami checked equipment and greeted arriving players today prior to opening practice for the Shrine's first North-South football game in the Orange Bowl Christmas night.

INDUSTRIAL productivity is the obvious source of economic and military strength and the indirect source of social and political strength. The visible and spectacular device for achieving productivity is the machine. Less obvious, though more fundamental, is the management know-how which guides not only the machine but the men of industry themselves.

Officials of a utility holding system that operates extensively abroad have charged one of the world's richest men, Juan Albert March of Spain, with using the Spanish Government to acquire the $350,000,000 Barcelona Traction, Light and Power Company, Ltd., through an order issued last February by a Spanish court in an alleged false bankruptcy case.
May an American who has recently returned from a trip to England -- a first visit -- take issue on some points with Osbert Lancaster in his article "Keys to Understanding the English"?
PROVIDENCE, R.I., Dec. 18 -- Providence College, led by Mel Nissel who scored 27 points, scored a 80-74 victory over Brooklyn College tonight in a rough game at the Mount Pleasant High School Gym.

Mrs. I.J. Fox, business woman and philanthropist but better known as "Mrs. Santa Claus" to thousands of New York youngsters, was the guest of honor last night at a testimonial dinner in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel under the auspices of the Loyal League Philanthropies, Inc.

Although the national headquarters of the American Power Boat Association have been located during recent years in New York, Washington and Detroit because of the residence in those cities of incumbent presidents, the National Council at last week's meeting here decided to continue it for the year of 1949 in Detroit, where it was moved in 1946 on the election of Leonard H. Thomson to the presidency.

THERE are ways and ways of assembling group exhibitions and the successful ones bend to no hard and fast rules. But when one is done with distinction it leaves its mark. The eye demands riches to begin with but will boggle at too spendthrift a presentation.

LONDON, Dec. 18 -- The committee of American industrialists appointed by Paul G. Hoffman, ECA Administrator, to consider how much further the dismantling of German industry should go has now returned to the United States to report.

In his excellent article, "The Negro Since 1900," Dr. W.E.B. DuBois writes: "The present situation therefore is the direct result of the continued refusal of the liberal South to make a front forward fight on at least the more outrageous aspects of race discrimination."

FRANK GUARRERA will probably never work harder on a part for the Metropolitan Opera, where he made his debut as Escamillo last Tuesday, than he did on one role last spring. The role was Fanuel in Boito's "Nerone," and his coach was Arturo Toscanini.

Ernest Ansermet made his first appearance of the season as guest conductor of the NBC Symphony Orchestra late yesterday afternoon at Radio City. The eminent Swiss director, who gave a noteworthy series of concerts with the same organization last season, led an excellently contrived program, in which he augmented the profound impression created at that time.

PEIPING, Dec. 18 -- Peiping has received only 1,500 tons of American flour out of 14,000 tons allotted for the December rationing program -- not even enough for a two-day ration for the 2,000,000 civilians in the city.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Dec. 18 -- An official Israeli spokesman charged here today that Egypt had sabotaged Israel's application for United Nations membership by a false but timely accusation of aggression. The Egyptians had alleged in widely circulated reports from Cairo that the Israelis had launched, an attack on Egyptian forces trapped in Faluja, in the Negeb, desert area in southern Palestine.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 18 -- Yale today tore up Herman Hickman's three-year appointment as head football coach and handed him one for five years. The 300-pound poet laureate of the Big Smoky Mountains who took over this year offered no objection.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- Washington pride was smarting once more this week from a lashing attack on race discrimination. Many of the facts and charges contained in a widely publicized report of the National Committee on Segregation in the nation's capital were old, but the ninety-page document hit local citizenry with fresh impact.
HONOLULU, Dec. 18 -- Nevada's Wolfpack ran wild last night, tearing up the University of Hawaii Rainbows, 73 to 12, for the islanders' worst football shellacking.

SINCE it must be assumed that in the theatre serenity is the offspring of success, it follows that both Maxwell Anderson and Leland Hayward, author and co-producer, respectively, of "Anne of the Thousand Days," should be among Broadway's most contented citizens.

THIS encyclopedia is one of the most ambitious undertakings of this sort yet seen. Just about every possible situation that might arise in the course of making a home has been taken under consideration from deciding whether to build, buy or rent a house to a consumer's guide that outlines the best methods for shopping and stretching household dollars.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 (UP) -- A White House spokesman indicated tonight that President Truman would ask the new Congress to adopt universal military training legislation.

THE first collective effort of the American Society of Magazine Photographers to present the work of its members as a group provides, in a book of nearly 200 prints, a composite impression of what has been achieved in a phase of camera work that was first recognized only a dozen years ago as a new creative outlet.

Four of the six equipment shortages which have caused the power shortage have been ended. Another will end next year. The last one will end in 1951. And before that time, generating capacity will exceed demand and the national power shortage will be over.

COTONEASTERS reach the height of their all-year garden usefulness in fall and winter. The fine autumn coloring of some, the dense evergreen foliage of most, and the brilliant berries of nearly all, make them a valuable group of shrubs.

ALBANY, Dec. 18 -- Gov. Thomas E. Dewey announced today that the state, as of Dec. 15, had paid $311,101,476.71 in bonuses to 1,422,464 veterans of World War II or their next of kin. The average check was $218.

PARIS, Dec. 18 -- Official French sources estimated today that the Paris session of the United Nations General Assembly had resulted in the expenditure of an equivalent of $5,000,000 to $6,000,000 by the delegates, the Secretariat and the correspondents.

Pressed throughout by an aggressive St. Lawrence quintet, Fordham had to go all-out last night to score its fifth consecutive basketball triumph, 68 -- 55, before a crowd of 1,500 at the Rose Hill Gymnasium.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 18 -- Marchons II, belonging to F. Hammer and imported from Argentina, remained undefeated on this side of the Equator when he won the Governor Caldwell Handicap by a length before 9,159 fans at Tropical Park who bet $492,148 on the eight races today.
KEARNY, N.J., Dec. 18 -- Today marked the end of an era of shipbuilding that extended over thirty-one years.

ROME, Dec. 18 -- Rioting broke out in Rome today as the Chamber of Deputies began discussion of a Communist motion calling for "emergency measures to alleviate the economic condition of the workers and peasants."

PARIS, Dec. 18 -- Reorganization and reform of the system under which a large percentage of French industry had been nationalized was examined by the Cabinet today, and it was decided that a program would be introduced in the form of a bill before the end of this year.

THE new eight-cylinder Rocket engine is offered as one of the major improvements in the 1949 Oldsmobile. It is described by the company as a valve-in-head unit which affords 135-horsepower, twenty more than the 1948 engine, and it achieves a new peak in high compression.

Bounding back with a victory after a setback at Philadelphia Friday night, the New York Knickerbockers defeated the St. Louis Bombers at Madison Square Garden yesterday afternoon by 88 to 79 before a gathering of 14,647.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- Most Western European nations this year will have their "best Christmas" since before the war, the Economic Cooperation Administration predicted today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- Mr. and Mrs. F. Eberhart Haynes of this city and Mountain Lake, Lake Wales, Fla., presented their daughter, Miss Frances Gore Haynes, to society this afternoon at a reception in the Sulgrave Club. The debutante received with her mother and her grandmother, Mrs. Albert J. Gore.
BOSTON, Dec. 18 (AP) -- Outfielder Jim Russell, who was stricken by illness in mid-season, today signed his 1949 contract for the Braves.

CHICAGO, Dec. 18 -- The liveliest topic of conversation in this area last week centered in Detroit. Reports of the discovery of uranium deposits near the Michigan border in Canada have aroused considerable excitement in the Motor City.

THE death of the British explorer Robert Falcon Scott and his companions returning from the South Pole in 1912 was one of the great tragedies of exploration. The famous diary which he kept is a classic. Now the British have made it into a moving picture, "Scott of the Antarctic," a J. Arthur Rank production, starring John Mills in the title role.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Dec. 18 --The state convention of the Congress of Industrial Organizations closed today with warnings to President Truman and the Democratic majority in Congress that they would retain labor support only if they lived up to their campaign pledges.

TOKYO, Sunday, Dec. 19 -- Japan's experiment in democracy has been suspended. Gen. Douglas MacArthur told the Japanese people today that until economic stability was re-established, they must surrender temporarily "some of the privileges and immunities inherent in a free society."

A baby's temper tantrum, which disrupted a homework assignment, provided the inspiration for an original musical composition played last night at the semi-annual concert of the High School of Music and Art.

Banking, concerned and confused over the direction of the economic, political and social winds, took a fresh look last week at the current prospects. At the national credit conference in Chicago, sponsored by the American Bankers Association for that purpose, the only major conclusion of banking executives was that the outlook is uncertain.

Despite the repeated intention of President Chiang Kai-shek to continue the war, reports persist from China of the possibility of some sort of compromise. Some of these reports are to the effect that the Communists demand the resignation of the Generalissimo and his disappearance from the political scene while others refer to the setting up of a coalition government of Nationalists and Communists with Chiang still head of the government.

Enshrinement in the Smithsonian Institution of the Wright brothers' "Kitty Hawk," the first airplane to fly, and the simultaneous prediction that man soon may be able to travel through the air at a speed of 3,000 miles an hour dramatically illustrate how rapid has been the development of the machine.

ON May 20, 1907, George F. Kerr, a resident of Brooklyn, met a woman identified only as a person not his wife, at Grand Central Station. Together with her luggage they entered a cab and were driven to the Hotel Navarre, where they registered as "George Knight and wife, New Haven."

The United States coinage system is creaking and groaning under the demands made on it by the American economy and needs bolstering by more small coins, according to the American Institute for Intermediate Coinage, formed here yesterday.

SALT LAKE CITY, Dec. 18 -- Skiers are the happiest people hereabouts these days, with slopes at Sun Valley, Idaho; Alta, Utah; Jackson, Wyo., and Aspen, Col., buried under the heaviest early season snow of the past dozen years. Merchants in major cities are not quite so enthusiastic about the advent of a white Christmas.

In T.J. McInerney's article "Odd Types" he did not mention Mr. Tytell's real problem in filling the order for typewriters for the Israeli Government -- the carriage would have to move from right to left, as the Hebrew language is written that way.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- While business waits anxiously, and the various political factions mark time on their long-range planning, a small group in the White House is preparing the document on which their future courses will be based. This is the address "on the state of the Union" that the Constitution requires a President to make to Congress "from time to time."

The brothers Gilbert, together with James Fuller of Hartford, Conn., restaurant fame, are the outspoken minority stockholders of the United States. They "get into the hair" of management, most particularly the presiding officer, at almost every annual meeting of any well-known corporation, but with their bean-shooters they have accomplished some far-reaching innovations.

A year ago today President Truman asked Congress to authorize a seventeen-billion-dollar program to aid in the rebuilding of Europe, with an appropriation of $6,800,000,000 to run from April 1, 1948, to June 30, 1949. If we had not just emerged from a World War which had left us with a debt of about a quarter of a trillion dollars, these figures would have astounded us.

Retailers swamped the wholesale apparel market here last week with last-minute fill-in orders for holiday apparel, according to a report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Kirby, Block Co., Inc., resident buying office The spurt of retail business, it was said, will probably bring the Christmas sales total very close to last year's record.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- The dramatic denouement in the Hiss-Chambers case Wednesday, wherein the former State Department official was indicted on charges of perjury, has led to some sober conclusions in Washington about the whole subject of security of confidential information, and a sharp re-evaluation of opinion about the merits and the role of the House Committee on Un-American Activities.

PARIS, Dec. 18 -- A wholesale purge of Eastern European Communist parties has been ordered by the Communist Information Bureau. This step apparently has been taken to counteract continued tendencies toward "Titoist" independence that, according to the Hungarian Communist leadership, is being encouraged by Belgrade.

MOUNT SUNAPEE, N.H., Dec. 18 -- This pioneer winter area where the ski has been the symbol for more than a score of years today possesses a state-sponsored development destined to become one of the most practical, if not the best, in this part of the country. For many years New Hampshire has shown the way in the promotion of skiing.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 18 -- Alfred Earl Neale and James Gleason Dunn Conzelman, a pair of amiable and delightful whacks, will match brain waves at Shibe Park on the morrow as the Philadelphia Eagles collide with the Chicago Cardinals for the championship of the National Football League. They did it a year ago, too, when Jimmy out-thought Greasy, 28 to 21, by the simple method of springing loose his half-backs for long-gaining touchdown plays.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Dec. 18 -- High Allied and German officials, including persons who have been most enthusiastically in favor of the formation of a Western German government, fear that unless the three Western powers quickly settle the differences and the Germans refrain from squabbling among themselves the entire project will either collapse or take an innocuous form.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- The recovery of the railroads from the depression years was described this week by the Bureau of Transport Economics and Statistics of the Interstate Commerce Commission, which reported greatly increased freight revenues and expenditures for road improvements of Class I steam railways during 1948 compared with 1940.

TORONTO, Dec. 18 -- Pulling Goalie Chuck Rayner out of the nets in the last minute, the last-place New York Rangers came from behind to tie the world champion Toronto Maple Leafs, 3 -- 3, before 13,421 fans in a National Hockey League game tonight.

Columbia College in September, 1949, will reintroduce a required two-year course in the natural sciences for freshmen and sophomore students who are not science majors, Dr. Harry J. Carman, dean of the college, announced yesterday.

WHILE most domestic commercial airlines are still weighing the matter of serving or not serving so-called "free" meals aloft, Western Air Lines announced last week that it is going out of the "restaurant business."

ALL the ancient apothegms of bridge appeal to those who write about the game, largely because there are so many exceptions to them. A typical one is "cover an honor with an honor." Anyone who bothered to add them up would no doubt find 16,392 bridge columns written about times when one should not cover an honor with an honor. This, then, will be column number 16,393 on that subject.

THEY are making records again in the United States, thanks to the agreement between the companies and the American Federation of Musicians. The new disks being pressed are largely in the popular field. Certainly it will be the records in this field that will reach the public soonest.

Buyer resistance to unprocessed and lower grade coal has increased recently to the point that an unprecedented demand has appeared for equipment for processing, cleaning and sorting bituminous coal, it was disclosed yesterday by Thomas Robins Jr., president of Hewitt-Robins, Inc., builder of coal and other bulk handling material.

PARIS, Dec. 18 -- The European Council on the Marshall Plan is expected to agree next week on the report it will make to the United States on the four-year programs of the countries receiving dollar aid in Europe. The report will be a substitute for the single European "master plan" which Paul G. Hoffman, ECA Administrator, requested but which has so far proved impossible to draw up.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- Almost any afternoon this time of year, as the Washington Monument's shadow lengthens across the mall, a rather young and athletic-looking man can be seen to emerge from an east door of the old State Department Building on Pennsylvania Avenue.

STYLE is manifest in language. The vocabulary of a writer is his currency but it is a paper currency and its value depends on the reserves of mind and heart which back it. The perfect use of language is that in which every word carries the meaning that it is intended to, no less and no more.

Paced by Bob Kelly and Jack Byrnes, a pair of sharp-shooting forwards. Manhattan's basketball team had no difficulty in defeating John Marshall of Jersey City, 88 to 60, in the victors' Alumni Gymnasium last night. The triumph was the fifth this season for the Jaspers, who have lost one game.

In a report of the subcommittee on the National Security Organization of the (Hoover) Commission on Reorganization of the Executive Branch of the Government made public last Thursday, the nation's top military planners, headed by F. Eberstadt, New York banker, have recognized the importance of medical are in a program of total defense.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Dec. 18 (AP) -- Canisius kept its basketball slate clean tonight by downing Iowa State, 58 -- 45, and Georgia made it six straight without a loss by edging the University of Buffalo, 56 -- 51, in a Memorial Auditorium basketball double-header before 7,349 fans.

Boys High made a successful defense of its team honors and stretched its string of consecutive meet triumphs to thirteen in the 42d annual indoor track and field games sponsored by Stuyvesant High School before 2,500 spectators at the 71st Regiment Armory last night.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, Dec. 18 -- United States Army Secretary Kenneth C. Royall may change his schedule and pay a second visit to Greece to inspect American military mission groups on the Greek front, a member of Mr. Royall's party stated here today.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 18 (AP) -- Bradley University shook off a stubborn Temple quintet in the late minutes of the first half tonight and extended its unbeaten string to five games with a 59-50 victory at Convention Hall. A crowd of 4,985 saw Texas snap St. Joseph's (Philadelphia) six-game winning streak in the first game of the basketball double-header, 55 -- 54.

President Truman draws a salary of $75,000 a year, plus $30,000 earmarked for official travel expenses. He is not getting rich on what he draws. After paying income taxes and expenses -- he turns over $1,800 a month to Mrs. Truman for family expenses alone -- he winds up at the end of the year with about $4,450.

BASSE TERRE, Guadeloupe -- The West Indian Conference meeting that adjourned here last week recommended to the Caribbean Commission that it establish a permanent Caribbean Tourism Committee to promote and coordinate the tourist industry throughout the islands.

Although the central building of the New York Public Library, Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street, will close all its special divisions on Christmas and New Year's Day, the main reading room and the information desk will be open from 9 A.M. to 10 P.M.

BOSTON, Dec. 18 -- Although industry leaders maintained an outward show of optimism, a severe pre-Christmas tightening of the cotton-goods market was causing some concern in New England. As a result of heavy inventories and ultimate consumer to high prices, there were lay-offs in Fall River and New Bedford, Mass.

OGDEN, Utah, Dec. 18 (AP) -- The westbound streamlined train "City of San Francisco" was derailed five miles west of Lakeside, Utah, last night but none of the 250 passengers was seriously hurt. A bypass track was opened today around the spot where the accident occurred.

IT would be almost impossible to think of Christmas festivities without thinking of Charles Dickens, for the whole world knows that if any man possessed the knowledge of how to keep the Christmas spirit alive it was he.

In chaotic price conditions of year-end inventory disposals, manufacturers of metal products are buying back excess inventories from jobbers dumping stocks here at 20 per cent below market prices. More than 75 per cent of the year-end liquidation now appearing, amounting to sizable inventory disposals, is coming from jobbers, but few stocks are reaching consumers' hands, it was learned.

GEORGE COSTELLO, proprietor of Costello's Launch Service, at Pier 1, North River, runs New York's most unusual taxicab service. His cabs are six sturdy seagoing motor launches, one of whose function is seeing that when tardy transatlantic travelers and cruise-ship passengers get left on the dock, they catch their ship before it leaves the harbor.

IT was Thomas Wolfe's early ambition to be a great dramatist. In 1918, attending the late Frederick Koch's initial Carolina Playmakers semester at the University of North Carolina, he composed his first published work, "The Return of Buck Gavin: The Tragedy of a Mountain Outlaw," a one-act Guignol shocker in which -- at the original performance -- he played the lead.

IN September, 1859, a dignified middle-aged gentleman presented himself to the editor of The San Francisco Bulletin with a notice he wished published. It was the caller's proclamation of himself as "Norton I, Emperor of the United States."

HUNTINGTON STATION, L.I., Dec. 18 -- Two hundred and nineteen men paid fines totaling $2,080 this morning after they had been arrested at a "floating dice game" during a raid on the plant of the Independent Coal and Ice Company here.

PARIS. IN envisioning the approach to filming "The Eagle With Two Heads," I thought it imperative to retain the pristine theatrical character of the play as it was written for the stage, even though the technique must be different.

IF Maxwell Anderson's record were not so rich in good works, it would be easy to describe "Anne of the Thousand Days" as his finest drama. Perhaps it is. But unless superlatives are to be tossed about indiscriminately, the new play about Henry VIII and Anne Boleyn has to be weighed against the worth of several other fine works from Mr. Anderson's earnest and talented pen.
Theodore W. Kheel, retiring head of the city's Division of Labor Relations, was praised yesterday by Union leaders in the printing industry and an Assistant Secretary of Labor.

THE election of Ellis Arnall, former Governor of Georgia, to the presidency of the Society of Independent Motion Picture Producers last week is regarded by the members of the society as a shot in the arm for their organization.

HERE are two brain teasers that are bound to be standard equipment in the coming winter months. They will break up the long nights, fill the gap in your party. They will fit your guests in any number, sex or combination thereof.
THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Dec. 18 -- The Netherlands Government announced tonight the opening of military operations in Indonesia.

AN enterprising London publisher has just announced that he will consider, "with pleasure and attention," unpublished fiction by American authors. "Rising costs of book production in the United States," he notes, "often limit the publication of manuscripts with merit but unproved commercial possibilities."

LAKE SUCCESS, Dec. 18 -- Four of New York's largest building contractors are joining forces in a new omnibus corporation to construct the first skyscraper unit for the United Nations on its permanent East River home site.
NANKING, Dec. 18 (AP) -- A general Government retreat was reported in progress today from the broken Huai River line to positions little more than thirty miles north of this Chinese capital.
THE number of Soviet radio stations and radio receivers now both exceed the pre-war figures, according to a recent issue of Pravda.

AMMAN, Trans-Jordan, Dec. 18 -- Lieut. Col. Abdullah el-Tel, Trans-Jordan's Governor of the Old City of Jerusalem, denied today that he had been engaging in negotiations with Israeli leaders. The denial is prompted, he said, by "the campaign carried on in the Egyptian press against the Government of Trans - Jordan and against me personally, charging that I am negotiating with the Jews for a truce."

HONOLULU, Dec. 18 -- Marshall Plan money is being used in China mainly for the relief of the population rather than toward the nation's economic recovery, because of the "present unhappy situation" there, Paul G. Hoffman, Economic Cooperation Administrator reported here this morning during a brief stopover en route back to Washington after a round-the-world survey of Marshall Plan countries.

TWO top-ranking European tourist officials who happened to be in New York simultaneously last week reported, separately, that the recovery of international travel in 1948 far outran all other aspects of the Marshall Plan recovery program.

The first snow of the season seems to bring on a sudden interest in Southern hunting and fishing prospects, and last week's flurry was no exception, for the inquiries began showing up before the fall had reached the slush stage.

The Federal Court for the Southern District of New York is so seriously undermanned that its Senior Judge, John C. Knox, has informed Administration and Congressional leaders that he does not know how the court will be able to carry on much longer without assistance.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 18 (AP) -- Facts and figures of the sixteenth annual National Football League championship game between the Philadelphia Eagles and Chicago Cardinals tomorrow:

SPEAKING of holiday pictures, as this corner invariably does (for a rather obvious reason) along about this time of year, we note with initial anxiety that there will be no new films on Christmas screens which can be unqualifiedly recommended as entertainment for the grammar-school-age kids.

As far back as the race memories and the ancient legends of mankind run, the winter solstice has been a time of questioning and wonder; followed by re-discovery of basic certainties. To see the daylight steadily shorten and the nights lengthen and deepen with cold, was to feel the approach of doom.

PRETORIA, South Africa, Dec. 18 -- An early announcement that the United States and the Union of South Africa will raise the status of their respective Legations to that of Embassies is expected next week. South Africa has been conducting simultaneous negotiations with France and the Netherlands, but if, as seems probable, the United States takes the lead its Ambassador will become the dean of the diplomatis corps.

THE original publication some ten years ago of A.Y. Vishinsky's "The Law of the Soviet State" was an important landmark in the history of Soviet jurisprudence. It was preceded by a fierce ideological purge which involved a repudiation of the then reigning orthodoxies of N.V. Krylenko, the People's Commissar of Justice, and Prof. E.B. Pashukanis, Director of the Institute of Soviet Structure and Law of the Academy of Sciences of the U.S.S.R.

LONDON, Dec. 18 -- The grim danger of starvation confronts the world today, Sir Hartley-Shawcross, Britain's Attorney General, warned a gathering in Barnstaple, Devon, tonight. If the world starves, chaos and Anarchy must follow, he said, in pressing a plea for international cooperation to build up food production.
In New York last week a Federal grand jury handed up an indictment with this heading:

A court decision in Chicago by United States District Court Judge La Buy has dismissed twenty-nine counts at $15,000 each against three of the individual defendents in the "Free Book" case involving the sale and delivery of encyclopedias in interstate commerce, Henry Ward Beer, attorney and president of the Federal Bar Association of New York, New Jersey and Connecticut, disclosed in a statement here on Friday.

SEOUL, Korea, Dec. 18 -- Foreign Minister T.S. Chang said today that, although the problem of the unification of Korea was in the hands of the United Nations Korean Commission, "We regard Communist-controlled North Korea as lost territory to be regained at any cost."

EAST LANSING, Mich., Dec. 18 (AP) -- Michigan State won its first game against a Big Nine team since being welcomed into the Western Conference by upsetting unbeaten Iowa, 49 to 43, to delight 5,069 Spartan fans tonight.

HOLLYWOOD. IN Hollywood the business of making motion pictures is based on simple arithmetic. The more people who see a movie the more money that movie will make. Hence, the movie that will please the most people will make the most money.

TO write an excellent book about a great Irish poet without giving the reader the slightest sense of Ireland -- the character of its people or the tradition of its literature -- is a remarkable feat. Yet this is what Mr. Ellmann has done in "Yeats: The Man and the Masks."

The University of Kentucky's tall, fast and accurate basketball team, showing little regard for the five-game winning streak that the Redmen of St. John's University had put together, fairly blasted the Brooklynites off the Madison Square Garden floor last night to win the feature game of the college double-header, 57 to 30.

The magic of the fast-nearing Yuletide days became a little more apparent for thousands of children who met Santa Claus and his helpers yesterday and received his gifts at scores of Christmas parties held throughout the city.
