PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 18 -- Commissioner Bert Bell of the National Football League declared tonight "on the record and off the record there has been no truce" between his league and the rival All-America Conference.

MONTREAL, Dec. 18 (AP) -- The Montreal Canadiens rallied for three goals in the last period to defeat the first-place Detroit Red Wings, 5 to 3, tonight in a National Hockey League game at the Forum. Ken Mosdell collected three Montreal goals.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Dec. 18 (AP) -- Hardin-Simmons University came from behind with 34 points in the second half to rout the Ouachita Tigers, 40 -- 12, in the inaugural Shrine Bowl game in Arkansas War Memorial Stadium today.

Harvard students -- both freshmen and upperclassmen -- are making "far better" academic records than at any time in the 312-year history of the college, a report from Harvard College discloses. Thirty-five per cent of the students last year earned places on the Dean's List, as compared with 31 per cent in 1940-41. The number of students required to leave college decreased from 5 per cent in 1940-41 to 2 per cent last year.

Postmaster Albert Goldman announced yesterday that four post offices, including the main office opposite Pennsylvania Station, would remain open today and tonight. The three others are at 90 Church Street, Fourty - fourth Street and Lexington Avenue and 149th Street and Grand Concourse, the Bronx.

As prodigious a wunderkind as our Orson Welles, as flamboyantly versatile as the British Noel Coward, is Sweden's jack of all theatre-trades, Hasse Ekman. Actor, playwright, director, author, song writer, scenarist, producer (and just for good measure, champion shot-putter), the 33-year-old Ekman is a living refutation of the old saw that the talents of the fathers shall not be visited upon the children.
SCHENECTADY, Dec. 18 (UP) -- Union College received this week the first installment of a $375,000 gift from an educational foundation which elected not to have its name revealed.
Children continue to be the most imaginative, if not the heaviest, contributors to THE NEW YORK TIMES Neediest Cases Fund.

DELLE, Utah, Dec. 18 (AP) -- The crash of two Burlington Trailways buses on a snow-bordered highway in western Utah killed thirteen persons today and injured forty-four. Twelve bodies were taken from the burning wreckage. Another victim died at a hospital several hours later.
CLEVELAND, Dec. 18 (AP) -- Employes of the Lincoln Electric Company went Christmas shopping today with annual incentive payment checks averaging $3,392, as the company announced yesterday.

Warning that there is no such thing as a fireproof natural Christmas tree, the Greater New York Safety Council made public yesterday suggestions on how the Christmas tree fire hazard might be controlled.
TED STEELE is a man of easygoing ways for a good reason: he could hardly survive his formidable schedule were he given to the normal tensions of Radio Row.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- The number of households in this country increased by 5,620,000 from 1940 to 1948, the Census Bureau estimated today. The figure was 35,100,000 in 1940 and it is given as 40,720,000 now.

THE spirit of Christmas all too often disappears in the hectic business of shopping and other details preparatory to the holiday celebration. Decorating will restore this spirit, for it will set the stage and inspire the mood of gaiety and good-will.

ONE of the most frequently repeated inquiries from readers of the art page concerns books on art. These inquiries are especially numerous from out-of-town readers in places where exhibitions are few or nonexistent.

A growing demand for research scientists and engineering specialists, which will continue for the next ten years, has been forecast by the nation's leading business and industrial executives, Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute reports.
With the defeat of Princeton by 2 1/2 -- 1 1/2, Columbia's players took the lead yesterday in the annual tournament of the C.H.Y.P.D. College Chess League at the Marshall C.C.

FOR over a generation now Keats has been one of the most written-about literary men of England. He has been the subject of more full-length biographies than has Wordsworth, Coleridge or Shelley -- or, for that matter, any other modern English writer. His writings have evoked a stream of interpretation and evaluation -- long books, monographs, chapters, articles -- that continues to flow with unabated force.

SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, Dec. 18 -- The investigating committee of the Organization of American States, which arrived yesterday, began its work here early today, first hearing officials of the Costa Rican Government on their charge that the rebel invasion in the northwest came from and has been aided by Nicaragua.
After a quiet session on the New York Cotton Exchange, futures prices closed yesterday 2 to 5 points higher.

ABOUT twenty-three years ago I appeared as an actor in a play by Samson Raphaelson called "The Jazz Singer." Because this play was about a boy who came from a generation of religious singers of the synagogue, I began to take an interest in religious books and acquired a large library re Christianity and Judaism.

Depreciation is an accounting device by which business enterprise may recover, or set aside, out of earnings, amounts representing wear and tear, exhaustion and obsolescence of business property. Being deductible from earnings for tax purposes during the life of property, these amounts are reserved for the purpose of replacing investments in plant and equipment.

BASSE TERRE, Guadeloupe, Dec. 13 -- The Third West Indian Conference concluded here today its consideration of recommendations of policy to be followed by the Caribbean Commission during the next two years.
CHICAGO, Dec. 18 (AP) -- Today's report of the markets in the Union Stockyards by the United States Department of Agriculture follows:

JOHN REID is the villain, of course, the man who is responsible for that feeling of mass frustration which creeps over a large segment of the American population every week-end. A transplanted Scot from Dunfermline, Reid felt curiously dissatisfied with hunting, shooting, tennis and other outdoor sports.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- Secret State Department documents reporting the pressure Germany applied against Austria a little less than one month before that country was taken over by the Nazis were given out today by the House Un-American Activities Committee.

The Christmas concerts of the Trapp Family Singers, begun eight years ago, have become a regular feature of New York's musical life, and an audience of 1,000 assembled at Town Hall late yesterday afternoon for the first of the two such concerts the family will give there this holiday season.
Night baseball, which made some appreciable gains for itself during the major league conclaves in Chicago the past week, has just picked up some additional ground.

BOSTON, Dec. 19 (AP) -- The Boston Celtics overcame a 4-point deficit in the final two minutes of play to top the New York Knicker-bookers, 77 -- 75, tonight in a Basketball Association of America game before a 5,894 crowd. It was the first meeting of the season between the two teams.

BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 19 -- The Peronista party won the election of Dec. 5 for delegates to the constitutional convention with 63.1 per cent of the total. Returns are complete except for the small province of Tucuman, where balloting was repeated today in eighty districts because of irregularities.

HOLLYWOOD, Dec. 19 (AP) -- Irene Dunne was named today by[ the National Gonference of Chris-I tians and Jews as the person '%zvhoI has done most in 1948 to promoteI batter understanding among peoples of all faiths."a Spyros Skouras, film promoter[ and a director of the conference,[ said the award would be presented] to the actress on Feb. 4 at a New] York luncheon. ]V[iss Dunne, he added, had been active in charitable and religious

ALBANY, Dec. 19 -- Governor Dewey announced today that he would recommend to the Legislature next month continuation for another year of the state's stand-by residential rent control law and of the New York City commercial rent controls.

Taking a cue from the deepening blanket of snow that mantled the city with holiday atmosphere, New Yorkers opened Christmas week yesterday by opening their hearts to the city's children in scores of parties, plays, and tableaux featuring the familiar themes of the season.

PARIS, Dec. 19 -- The United Nations Security Council will hold an emergency meeting tomorrow morning at the Palais de Chaillot to reconsider the Indonesian situation in the light of the resumption of operations by Dutch troops on Java.

After three years of effort to solve the Indonesian problem by intermittent military measures and negotiations, the Netherlands Government has now taken matters into its own hands and has started a double-pronged action of still unforeseeable consequences for Asia and for the West.
LONDON, Dec. 19 -- A parson who distributed free circus tickets to poor children in his parish had his church picketed today by two members of the Performing Animals Defense League.

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 19 -- A check here last week showed that flat-rolled items such as sheets and strip were still leading the parade of products in heavy demand. Because of the big requirements of oil and gas companies plates were more in demand than ever.

THE NEW YORK TIMES has received a letter from Academician L.A. Leontyev, Professor of Economics at the Moscow State University, discussing THE TIMES' reports on Sept. 23, 24 and 25 of the publication of an English translation of the book by Deputy Premier N.A. Voznesensky, "The Economy of the U.S.S.R. During World War II."

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 19 -- Returning from a week's inspection trip through the Orient, Paul G. Hoffman, chief of the Economic Cooperation Administration, expressed mild dissent tonight with any notion that his organization was committed to support or nonsupport of a possible Chinese coalition government containing Communists.

Caging four goals in the third period of a contest that was not wanting for action, the defending champion Ottawa Senators handed the hapless New York Rovers a 7-to-6 setback in a Quebec Senior Hockey League tussle at Madison Square Garden yesterday afternoon.

The Right Rev. Henry Knox Sherrill, presiding bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Church in the United States, yesterday issued his annual Christmas message "directed to all Christian people." It follows:
FRANKFORT, Germany, Dec. 19 -- It may have been different before the war, but for millions of German children since then Kris Kringle has an American accent.
I have just observed your name among the list of persons recommending "The Naked and the Dead" by Norman Mailer. I have read most of the book.

Relief costs during November rose to $10,905,798 because of increased food allowances, despite an over-all reduction in the public assistance caseload, Raymond M. Hilliard, Welfare Commissioner, reported yesterday.

Former Assistant Secretary of State Francis B. Sayre said here yesterday that he had no knowledge of any documents having been stolen from his office. He was at a loss, he declared, to account for the extraction of Government papers at a time when they were at least nominally in his keeping.

TOKYO, Dec. 19 -- After two years of experimentation with the outward forms of democracy, Gen. Douglas MacArthur has announced that he will commence running Japan once more. The biggest question confronting this new American policy is whether -- rather than how -- it can be enforced.

Twentieth Century-Fox's production, "Gentleman's Agreement," directed by Elia Kazan, produced by Darryl F. Zanuck from a screen play by Moss Hart and the novel by Laura Z. Hobson, was voted the best picture of 1948 in the twenty-seventh annual poll of film critics of the nation's newspapers, magazines, syndicates, wire services and radio stations conducted by the trade publication. The Film Daily.

A male ring-necked pheasant, apparently lost in the Brooklyn snow, landed wearily at 11-A.M. yesterday on the lawn in front of the home of Mrs. Ella Macaulay at 243 East Fifth Street, between Caton Avenue and Albemarle Road.

CAIRO, Dec. 19 -- Brig. Gen. William E. Riley of the United States Marine Corps, Chief Truce Supervisor in Palestine, who arrived this morning for a conference with Dr. Pablo Azcarate, United Nations representative here, and Egyptian officials, declared:

A considerable number of responsible public officials and interested private citizens are doing some hard thinking about the housing problem right now. Some of this relates directly to the federal and state programs for low-rent subsidized housing; some of it is aimed at cutting costs, supplying inducement to investment capital, or removing other deterrents to private construction.

Luise Vosgerchian is a pianist with an uncommon fondness for music. Such, at least, was the impression she gave yesterday afternoon in Times Hall, where she played an interesting recital with warmth and musical candor.

With the first big post-war special cruise program scheduled to get into full swing this month, the response of the public has been so limited that some of the steamship companies are expressing concern, it was reported yesterday.

A great deal of muddy water has gone up and down the East River with the tides since the United Nations Charter was signed at San Francisco three years ago last June; and there have been some muddy tides in world affairs, too. But the dream of a world organization for peace has not died.

A capital outlay program of traffic and parking improvements to safeguard the city's commercial interests and enable it to cope with the demands of thirty years hence was called for yesterday by the Thirty-fourth Street-Midtown Association.

VIENNA, Dec. 19 -- United States companies, profiteering on a loophole in the European Recovery Program's intra-European trade agreement, with the tacit understanding of certain participating European countries, are hurting the reputation of both the United States and the ERP in this part of Europe.

LONDON, Dec. 19 -- In last week's report by the Bank of England its note circulation was shown to have expanded by no less than 27,750,000. This increase constituted a record for any one week and made a total expansion of 53,000,000 in four weeks.

Stephen D. Stephanidis, president of the Prudential Steamship Corporation, 17 State Street, announced yesterday appointment of John E. Schmeltzer Jr. as vice president in charge of traffic, effective Jan. 1. Mr. Schmeltzer has been operating manager of the line.

Little net change was shown in the prices of cotton for future delivery in the domestic market last week. At the close of trading on Saturday active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange registered no change to a decline of 19 points, compared with net declines of 30 to 61 points at the close a week previous.

My attention has been called only recently to an article in THE TIMES of Oct. 27 under the headline "Wartime Errors in Geology Cited." This was a report of a speech made by Dr. Kenneth C. Heald at the presentation of the Kemp Medal to Prof. Charles P. Berkey.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 (AP) -- A House Labor subcommittee reported today that Russia controls the strategic United States electrical industry through Communist domination of the CIO Electrical Workers Union.

Harry N. Rosenfield, one of three commissioners of the United States Displaced Persons Commission, assailed parts of the Displaced Persons Act yesterday as "discriminatory" and "flagrantly un-American" and urged that Congress alter these aspects of the act.

God's "soiled creation, sex," was changed by Christ from the "leprous deformity of paganism" to a "spiritual beauty which is the sacred basis of marriage," the Rev. Anselm Leahy declared yesterday in his Advent sermon at solemn mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral.

The Women's City Club of New York made ten specific requests in a letter sent yesterday to Governor Dewey to include in his annual message and recommendations to the Legislature. Eight of these recommendations relate to the city's fiscal problems and were made "because the situation is so critical that immediate action is imperative."

SOMERS POINT, N.J., Dec. 19 -- One young couple died instantly and another was saved by clinging to a piling after their automobile skidded 550 feet early this morning, crashed through a bridge guard rail and plunged into fifteen feet of water in Bass Harbor Creek near here.

PANAMA, Dec. 19 -- The investigation of charges that Costa Rica has been attacked by a revolutionary force, including Nicaraguan National Guardsmen, may result in a draw, according to uncensored information brought here by observers from San Jose.

PARIS, Dec. 19 -- Charles de Gaulle, in an address to the national council of his Reunion of the French People, tonight asked for a solution of the German problem by an integration of the proposed German federation into European economic union, which would be extended to include at least a part of Africa.

The yellow, black and brown races of the world want recognition as equals, the Rev. Dr. Frank C. Laubach, Conregational Christian missionary and educator, warned yesterday. He added that if Americans failed to help them up, they would "blow up."

The impact of the recent East Coast longshoremen's strike was reflected in the announcement yesterday of United States Customs figures for last month, which showed 968 ship arrivals and departures during November, a drop of 212 ships from the figure for November, 1947.

LONDON, Dec. 19 -- International democratic socialism has delivered an ultimatum to Pietro Nenni's Italian Socialist party to terminate its association with the Italian Communist party by the middle of next March.

Permanent use of the site of the old Tombs Prison and Criminal Courts Building as a parking lot would be "indefensible," Park Commissioner Robert Moses declared yesterday in recommending adoption of the Park Department's plan to set aside the area as a public park.

" People Like Us" will displace "Small Wonder" at the Coronet. The opening date of the Frank Vosper play, starring Margaret Sullavan and Leo Genn, is Feb. 23. On the night immediately preceding, a benefit preview will be given to aid the Damon Runyon Cancer Fund, it has been announced by William L. Taub, sponsor of the attraction.

CHICAGO, Dec. 19 -- The corn market was unsettled last week, prices on the Board of Trade averaging somewhat higher because of smaller receipts from the country, a good demand in the cash market and a belief that the peak of the after-harvest movement of wet grain had passed and farmers would not sell freely until later in the season as prices are well below the Government loan.

Two distinguished artists, Italo Tajo, Italian bass-baritone, and Reginald Kell, English clarinetist, were heard for the first time in this city at the concert of the New Friends of Music given late yesterday afternoon in Town Hall. Both newcomers scored heavily in a program which they shared with the Busch Quartet.

Another history of World War II by another Briton has been set for Jan. 20 publication by Duell, Sloan Pearce. It is "The Second World War," by Maj.-Gen. J.F.C. Fuller, an authority on modern warfare, author of many books and writer of the "War Tides" column for Newsweek during the war.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Dec. 19 -- It is the belief and the hope of the Netherlands that the military action opened yesterday against the Republic of Indonesia will be over within another twenty-four hours, except for mopping up operations and lingering guerrilla warfare.

SOFIA, Bulgaria, Dec. 19 -- Premier Georgi Dimitrov told the fifth congress of the Bulgarian Communist party and representatives of eighteen foreign Communist parties today that victories of the Chinese Communist Army had tipped the scales in the world struggle between the British and Americans on one side and the Soviet bloc on the other in favor of the latter group.

PEIPING, Dec. 19 -- A visiting official American party, including United States military, naval and air attaches was still marooned in Peiping today as the Communists hurled back a Government attempt to recapture the south airfield, six miles below this encircled city.

The exhibit stressing peacetime uses for atomic energy, presented at the city's recent Golden Jubilee celebration, reduced feelings of fear and insecurity and gave many greater hope, according to a poll of 4,000 of the persons attending the show.

An additional towing and repair service for motorists whose cars are disabled on any of the facilities of the Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority will go into effect today, George E. Spargo, general manager of the authority, announced yesterday.

LONDON, Dec. 19 -- By cutting costs and carrying a heavier load, Britain's state-owned airlines reduced their deficit during the first six months of the current fiscal year, but they are still millions of pounds in the red.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 19 (AP) -- "A great ball game, and the better team won it," was the near-unanimous chorus in the dressing rooms today after the National Football League championship game.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- A Senate subcommittee called upon Government export control authorities to tighten their operations to stop untold millions of dollars' worth of American goods from being shipped overseas illegally.
Children who break laws in New York City get little lasting help with their real problems. This was revealed in a survey conducted by THE NEW YORK TIMES.

Gerald O. Kaye has been appointed vice president in charge of sales of Bruno-New York, Inc., distributor of radios, television receiver and home appliances. He as formerly the company's sales manager. WilliAm M. Sheeser, incharge of all accounting and internal operational divisions, has been appointed controller.

Chubb Son, insurance underwriters of this city, have announced that on Jan. 1 William A. Bonner, Albert Carey Wall and Robert E Wallace will be admitted to the firm, and that Thomas J. Goddard, a member of the firm for twenty-seven years, will retire.
A storm that covered New York and its suburbs with 19.6 inches of snow yesterday moved out to sea early this morning. The storm was officially ended at 2:10 A. M. today.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 19 (AP) -- Commissioner Bert Bell of the National Football League announced tonight that he and a National League owners' committee would meet here tomorrow with All-America Conference officials to discuss the professional football situation.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 19 -- Perhaps the National Football League play-off between the Philadelphia Eagles and the Chicago Cardinals should not have been held today at Shibe Park. A driving snowstorm providing a 4-inch fall that completely covered the gridiron eliminated any pretense of a true football test.

Ratification of the agreement for the purchase of American Overseas Airlines by Pan American World Airways will have to wait action of the stockholders of Pan American and of American Airlines and the sanction of the Civil Aeronautics Board. There would appear to be no reason why either should be withheld.

AMSTERDAM, Dec. 19 -- Authoritative quarters of the Department of Economic Affairs here hold that industrialization of the Netherlands in the next four years would require investment in new and extended industries of 3,000,000,000 guilders.

A complete check of the ledgers of George Piperno, broker accused of the larceny of stocks and bonds entrusted to him by clients, was under way yesterday. Representatives of the District Attorney's office and of the Police Department were cooperating in an investigation to see how extensive the alleged defalcations would turn out to be.
DETROIT, Dec. 19 (AP) -- The Detroit Red Wings ended a three-game losing streak by beating Toronto, 5 to 1, in a National Hockey League game before 13,771 fans tonight.

ZURICH, Dec. 19 -- Impatient at the apparent sterility of the efforts of the Association of Swiss Bankers for the last year to induce the Netherlands Government to recognize the rights of investors in Switzerland holding Royal Dutch Shell shares acquired in good faith by straightforward purchase through reputable banks.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Dec. 19 -- A scrubwoman at General Hospital, who put four children through school on her small pay, announced yesterday that she planned to retire soon in a house she bought for $6,500 cash.

A plaque was presented yesterday to Marian Anderson in recognition of her efforts for equal civil rights, at the formal opening of WVNJ, Newark, the newest and most powerful radio station in New Jersey.
An exhibition of American paintings from its own collection is to open Wednesday at the Museum of Modern Art and is the leading event in a mild Christmas week of gallery activity.

Local basketball fans will see a double invasion from Georgia at Madison Square Garden tonight when Georgia Tech hooks up with Long Island University in the opener and Georgia takes on New York University in the afterpiece of the collegiate program.

The twenty-fifth anniversary of the founding of the Deborah Tuberculosis Sanatorium at Browns Mills, N.J., was observed last night at two dinners held simultaneously in the grand ballrooms of the Astor and the Commodore hotels.

A former Navy air crewman only thirty months in the Police Department was cited six times for heroism in general orders issued yesterday by Police Commissioner Arthur W. Wallander. The orders grant awards for meritorious duty to 464 members of the force and include all cases acted upon by the Honor Committee since Oct. 4.

ROME, Dec. 19 -- Leading Italian colonial experts are preparing a plan for the creation of an Arab state in Tripolitania that would collaborate politically and economically with Italy, it was revealed here today.
There was an irregular trend in the foreign exchanges last week, changing the complexion of that market which had ruled firmly on light dealings for more than a month.

HELSINKI, Finland, Dec. 19 -The Soviet Union has written off a debt of $600,000 owed by Finland as fines for overdue reparations deliveries, Uuno Takki, Minister of Trade, announced tonight. The remission, he said, is a Russian gesture in connection with the new Russo-Finnish trade agreement initialed in Moscow this week-end.

CHICAGO, Dec. 19 -- Evening up operations in the December deliveries of grain and soy beans resulted in confused price movements in the various markets on the Board of Trade last week. Trading in December contracts will cease at the close Dec. 22, and any contracts outstanding thereafter can be closed only by a tender of the actual commodity.
Fourteen new films, including importations from France, England and Russia, are slated to arrive between today and Christmas Day in first-run theatres. The programs follow:

Berl Senofsky, an excellent young violinist who made his debut last season as a Naumburg Award winner, gave his second New York recital yesterday afternoon as part of the series of twilight concerts at Carnegie Hall. Brahms' A major Sonata, Bach's Chaconne. Hindemith's C major Sonata and Chausson's Poeme were his major selections.

MOBILE, Ala., Dec. 19 -- Major Jack Friend, vice president of the Southern Kraft Division of International Paper Company, announced this week the division will have an annual payroll of $2,500,000 when the paper company's new $20,000,000 rayon mill is completed at Natchez, Miss.

The Federal Reserve System's program of supporting Government bonds could not bog down by reason of the Federal Reserve's running out of short-term obligations to sell in exchange for bonds, according to a study to be published today by New York University.

VIENNA, Dec. 19 -- The shipment to Israel under protection of "an occupation power" of arms and munitions, whose purchase was financed by black-market operations in Austria carried on under the same protection, was censured at a Socialist party meeting tonight by Oskar Helmer, Austria's Minister of the Interior.

Two newly acquired combination passenger and cargo vessels, the former transports J.W. McAndrew and George F. Elliot, will provide frequent service and first-class passenger accommodations between New York and Cape Town and Durban, in South Africa, starting next July, it was announced yesterday by John J. Farrell, chairman of the board of Farrell Lines, Inc.

There were plenty of faults last night in Joyce Robinson's recital at Times Hall. But they hardly seemed to matter. What one remembered were a few songs rendered exquisitely, many fascinating changes of vocal color and some sustained passages of lovely sound.
LONDON, Dec. 19 -- Great Britain's production and export of office machinery have increased nearly six-fold in the past decade, the Ministry of Supply disclosed today.
CLEVELAND, Dec. 19 -- The All-America Football Conference announced this financial summary for today's championship play-off game here:

Each "Merry Christmas" greeting during the holiday season should be a symbol not only of good-will for friends but of renewed faith in God, the Rev. Dr. Edgar F. Romig declared yesterday at the West End Collegiate Church, West End Avenue at Seventy-seventh Street.
ATHENS, Dec. 19 (AP) -- The Greek Navy banned sea traffic in a five-mile-wide belt along the Peloponnesus coast tonight because of impending major operations in that sector of southern Greece.

The members of the Oratorio Society of New York obviously give Handel's "Messiah" year after year because they love to sing the work. Their 125th performance of the oratorio on Saturday night showed there also are many who love to hear it just as often. Carnegie Hall was full.

Frank Guarrera, 25-year-old baritone who made his debut at the Metropolitan Opera last week in "Carmen," sang his first Italian role there Saturday night. He impersonated the deceived and love-torn Manfredo in "The Love of Three Kings," a role that is vocally grateful for the young singer's mature, masculine tones.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 (AP) -- Nine or more airmen stranded in 40-below-zero cold on Greenland's ice may have to stick it out several more days.
LOS ANGELES Dec. 19 (AP) -International good-will suffered a temporary setback today when Hawaii beat Mexico, 37 -- 0, as an international amateur football tournament game wound up in a row.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 (UP) -- Representative John E. Rankin, Democrat, of Mississippi, voiced "surprise" today that Mr. Nixon had criticized the committee's handling of the Condon case.

Last of the stores to show evidences of Christmas are perhaps the city's bakeries. Because of the perishability of their delicious wares, they cannot set forth their holiday cakes and cookies and breads till relatively near the day of the great feast.

The guiding principle of a liberal democracy must of necessity be, "The truth shall make you free." In spite of this, there is a gap which has developed in the democratic process composed of the individual's inability to make his needs and desires known to someone in authority.

The wholesale apparel market here was kept busy last week with retailers' last minute calls for fillins of holiday merchandise, according to reports prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices. As a result of careful budgeting, it was said, most stores should have well depleted stocks when the holidays are over.

PARIS, Dec. 19 -- One of the greatest upheavals that has occurred on the market here since liberation has broken out in the last few weeks on the black market for gold and foreign exchange. A gold bar weighing one kilogram was sold on Friday for 865,000 francs.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- The House Un-American Activities Committee announced today the two new names on the list of witnesses it seeks to question before preparing its final report on "current phases of the Communist espionage conspiracy."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 (UP) -- The National Association of Real Estate Boards said today it probably would ask the Eighty-first Congress to enact a cooperative program in place of public housing in any new housing legislation.

The Right Rev. Horace W.B. Donegan, Suffragan Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York, said yesterday that Christmas comes to remind us that "the Love of God came down in Bethlehem and brought the greatest message of all: God's forgiveness and salvation."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 (UP) -- The Red Cross announced today it was making sure that Christmas would be something more than "sterile white sheets and cold bare walls" to about 150,000 service men and veterans who are in hospitals.
Dr. Ralph J. Bunche, acting United Nations Mediator for Palestine, asserted yesterday that the Israeli-Arab war was ended, and the Palestine problem was well on the way to final solution.

Dollar volume of advertising placed by national advertisers in daily newspapers in 1948 will reach a third consecutive all-time high of $434,000,000 if year-end figures confirm the rate of gain shown for the first ten months by the Printers' Ink Index, it was announced over the week-end by the Bureau of Advertising, ANPA.

The desire of Park Commissioner Robert Moses to have the old Tombs and Criminal Courts site set aside as a landscaped open space to provide an appropriate setting for adjacent public buildings will be shared by all of those who feel as he does that New York City should create a useful and fitting downtown Civic Center.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 19 -- An immediate loan to Israel by the United States was advocated tonight by the national administrative committee of the American Jewish Congress.

READING, Pa., Dec. 19 -- The Pennsylvania Regional National Student Association passed resolutions today attacking racial discrimination and religious prejudices, at the close of its three-day conference here at Albright College.

The life insurance companies of the United States have total resources today estimated at more than $54,000,000,000. They think nothing of stepping into Wall Street and swallowing in a single gulp a $100,000,000 bond issue. The other day, however, they found themselves confronted with a project that they decided was too big even for them to take on.
NANKING, Dec. 19 (AP) -- The Communists edged closer to Nanking and increased their pressure around Tientsin today, but only scattered fighting was reported from any China war front.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 (AP) -- American machinery makers can expect a continual rise in orders from Europe as Marshall Plan buying shifts increasingly from food to industrial goods, the Economic Cooperation Administration reported today.

ROME, Monday, Dec. 20 -About 1,100,000 state employes were called out on a twenty-four-hour strike today by the Communist-dominated Italian Confederation of Labor. It is not known yet how many of the men on the Government payroll will obey the strike orders, but the probabilities early this morning were that the Communists would succeed in bringing all the Government services to a virtual standstill.
John M. Murtagh, Commissioner of Investigation, said yesterday that he had examined thirty-five witnesses in his study of waterfront racketeering.

What started out as a comparative romp for the rollicking Rangers developed into the narrowest of squeaks as the Blue Shirts beat the Canadiens of Montreal in the National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden last night, 3 to 2.

ATLANTA, Ga., Dec. 19 -- The assertion of some political leaders in Southern states that separate public school facilities for both races meet legal requirements that they be uniform and equal is largely a matter of "fiction," according to the Atlanta Urban League.

The Rev. Dr. F. Howard Callahan, pastor of the Methodist Church of St. Paul and St. Andrew, West End Avenue and Eighty-sixth Street, reminded his congregation in a morning sermon yesterday that "the spirit of humility is part of the spirit of Christianity."

Since his birth in Paris fifty-two years ago, Jean Barry Bart has been a World War I ace, the aviation tutor of Col. Edward V. Rickenbacker, a cyclist, a gardener, a dog fancier and a traveler. But most of all he has been a creative artist whose paintings and drawings began when he was 4 years old and have dominated his life ever since.

Thousands of men and pieces of snow-removal equipment were ordered on the job yesterday in suburban areas surrounding New York in an effort to keep the principal arteries open. Officials in the outlying communities were thankful that the Sunday traffic was exceptionally light and that motorists in the main used good sense in keeping their automobiles in their garages.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 (AP) -If spending on business expansion is to continue as one of the props under prosperity, more of it will have to be done by concerns already established.

ALBANY, Dec. 19 -- An emergency state capital grant of $100,000,000 for new school construction and renovation of old school buildings will be demanded by the Democratic minority at the 1949 session of the Legislature, Paul E. Fitzpatrick, state Democratic chairman, announced today.

Mrs. Theresa Kelly, 82 years old, was saved from being burned to death in her rear ground floor apartment at 235 East Twenty-eighth Street at 8:45 o'clock yesterday morning by Fireman Franklin T. Screder of 328 East Thirty-first Street, who was off duty at the time, it was reported last night at the quarters of Engine Company 16, 223 East Twenty-fifth Street, to which he is attached.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- A report to the House Labor Committee tomorrow or Tuesday will recommend a close examination of labor unions in Alaska in connection with evidence that the Soviet Government "knows what is going on" around United States defenses in the territory.
PADUCAH, Ky., Dec. 19 -- Senator Alben W. Barkley said tonight that he would spend Christmas with American airmen flying the airlift to Berlin.

CLEVELAND, Dec. 19 -- Rolling to seven touchdowns with practiced ease, the mighty Browns of Cleveland routed the Buffalo Bills, 49 -- 7, in the play-off for the All-America Conference title today. The debacle took place on a snow-framed grid-iron, amidst intermittent flurries, with a scant crowd of 22,981 paying spectators shivering in the towering stands of Cleveland Stadium.
BATAVIA, Java, Dec. 19 -- Dutch parachute and airborne troops seized Jogjakarta today and immediately interned the top leaders of the young Indonesian Republic.

In the old days -- that vague time, say, when mother was a girl -- it was the custom of the kitchen always to add one for the pot, no matter what was cooking. For anything from soup to coffee, heads were counted -- family and guests -- and then an extra "one" was added for the pot.

An anti-gossip and anti-extortion statute to implement proposed wiretapping legislation has been drafted by the special committee investigating wiretapping for the New York County Criminal Courts Bar Association, Robert Daru, counsel to the committee, announced yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 (AP) -- The Department of Commerce said tonight that business continues on the upgrade for industries of most importance in the economy.

JAIPUR, India, Dec. 19 -- Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru, Indian Prime Minister, said here tonight that the Dutch action in resuming hostilities in Indonesia, "will have serious repercussions in India, in Asia, and perhaps some other countries too."
A group of 10-year-old girls in Scarsdale, N.Y., dipped into the treasury of their "Helping Hand Club" to send $2 yesterday to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.
LONDON, Dec. 19 -- Christmas shopping, now in full swing here, can be nearly as much fun as it was before the war -- provided that one's pocket is four times as well lined as it was then.

New cargo and transport aircraft of far greater capacity than those now supporting the Berlin airlift are included in the procurement plans of the services, but far larger numbers would be needed if the goal of an "air transportable" army were to be realized.

An appeal to Prime Minister Clement Attlee of Great Britain and to former Prime Minister Winston Churchill for the immediate release of the 11,000 Jewish refugees on the Mediterranean island of Cyprus was made yesterday by Henry Morgenthau Jr., general chairman of the $250,000,000 United Jewish Appeal campaign.
ALBANY, Dec. 19 (AP) -- Stocks of cold storage apples and frozen poultry in New York State as of Dec. 1 dropped sharply from the 1947 period, the State Agriculture Department said today.

Net profit of Willys-Overland Motors for the fiscal year ended on Sept. 30 was $6,528,583, the highest since 1928, James D. Mooney, chairman and president of the company which manufactures the Jeep, stated in the annual report to stockholders, issued for publication today.

Criticism of the British Government for failure to recognize and cooperate with Israel was voiced last night at the thirty-second annual dinner of the Histadrut Ivrith (Hebrew Federation) of America, in the Astor Hotel.

LONDON, Dec. 19 -- Besides reopening an area of conflict in an unsettled world, the renewed fighting in Indonesia today posed a diplomatic dilemma for Britain and other countries associated with efforts for European rehabilitation and the military integration of the Atlantic powers and their far-flung dependencies.

Team of eight leading American and French chess experts, stationed at the Marshall Chess Club in this city and the Caissa Chess Circle in Paris, and linked by cable, competed yesterday. Play started at 9 o'clock in the morning and continued until early evening.

Mayor O'Dwyer announced yesterday that he had sent to Cyrus S. Ching, director of the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service, two reports indicating that almost every phase of the city's community, business and industrial life would be paralyzed if the 3,500 tugboat workers in New York Harbor should strike on Jan. 1.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 (AP) -- Strikes apparently had less impact on the country this year than in 1947, but the two years were remarkably similar in strike statistics, according to latest figures of the Bureau of Labor Statistics. These cover the first ten months of 1948, plus unofficial estimates for November and December.

Earth follows its path around the sun and the time of great change approaches. Twice each year, at the solstice, Nature readies itself for transformation and man senses the wonder and mystery of an ages-old plan. Stand by ocean's edge and you can see, feel, hear and smell the gray waters.

Grant Johannesen displayed some remarkable piano playing at his Town Hall recital last night. His strong fingers made Bach's Fugue in A minor coruscate, evoked the heat and richness of Schumann's rarely heard Intermezzi Op. 4 and did justice to Poulenc's "Suite Francaise," in what was said to be its first New York performance.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 (UP) -- America's merchant fleet is nearly 50 per cent larger than it was before the war, the Joint Committee for the American Merchant Marine reported today.

Unlike happiness, joy has a "very positive quality and intensity of feeling," the Very Rev. Dr. Hughell E.W. Fosbroke, former dean of the General Theological Seminary, said yesterday in a sermon at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 19 -- That was rather a fantastic football game the Chicago Cardinals and Philadelphia Eagles played in Shibe Park this afternoon. The place looked like Little America but without the penguins. Despite the supposed protection of tarpaulins, the embattled heroes were playing ankle deep in snow. No sooner had the canvas been removed for the start of hostilities than the junior-size blizzard instantly blanketed the gridiron.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Dec. 19 -- In sharp reaction to recent Egyptian and Syrian criticisms of Trans-Jordan, Ramallah radio, which is in the hands of King Abdullah's Arab Legion, broadcast today a scornful report of the failure of Egyptian arms in southern Palestine.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 19 -- Howard Hughes is negotiating a new financing-distribution deal for Independent Artists, the Fred Brisson-Rosalind Russell-Dudley Nichols Company, whose pictures are distributed by RKO, in which Hughes owns the controlling interest, it was learned today.

A gastronomic five-alarm fire was dished up yesterday for members of the Gourmet Society who apparently had decided that their sixtieth dinner should feature curries that could melt snow. Many perspired but none were charred in the two hours the diners devoted to proving the palate has a dash of asbestos.

On the strength of her victory over Louise Brough in the marathon final of the national singles championship, Mrs. Margaret Osborne du Pont of Wilmington, Del., has been ranked as the top women's tennis player in the nation, it was announced yesterday.

Columbia's chess players, after their 2 1/2-1 1/2 victory over Princeton in the first round of the annual tournament for the championship of the C.H.Y.P.D. College Chess League, yesterday made a fine showing against the champion Harvard team in the third and final round at the Marshall Chess Club.

CHICAGO, Dec. 19 -- The price changes in lard futures on the Board of Trade were erratic last week but closing trades yesterday showed little change in the week. Scattered liquidation was on at times, in sympathy with weakness in vegetable oils, and some selling was attributed to hedging by packers as the make of lard is now large and distribution is reported slow.

Swift Co., meat packers and food processors, made a new high record in sales during its fiscal year ended on Oct. 30, but earnings were less than a year earlier, according to the sixty-third annual report issued yesterday by John Holmes, president.

The National Broadcasting Company's plan to provide organized education for listeners, in collaboration with various universities, will be expanded on Feb. 5 with the introduction of "Pioneers in Music," a seventeen-week concert series tracing the evolution of orchestral music from the beginning of the seventeenth century to the present.
The reign of left-handed pitchers in the National League continued uninterrupted through the 1948 campaign, official pitching averages, released for publication yesterday, reveal.

Twelve days after his name had been mentioned in secret testimony before the espionage inquiry of the House Committee on Un-American Activities, Laurence Duggan, former high official of the State Department, jumped or fell to his death at 7 o'clock last night from his sixteenth-floor office in West Forty-fifth Street just off Fifth Avenue.

CHICAGO, Dec. 20 -- Dr. Gerhart Groetzinger, 40 years old, Assistant Professor in the Institute for Nuclear Studies at the University of Chicago, was identified today as the one of "about five" American scientists reported to have suffered damage to their vision as a result of radiation from cyclotrons.

Plagued by a high truancy rate, an inadequate number of school buildings and a shortage of teachers, the Soviet Union's school system has seriously deteriorated in recent years, reports reaching THE NEW YORK TIMES indicate.

Samuel Dushkin, who appeared in a violin recital at Carnegie Hall last night, has won an honorable place in the musical history of our time, thanks to his connection with Igor Stravinsky. It was Mr. Dushkin who played a part in inducing the composer to write a violin concerto, and Mr. Dushkin was the soloist in the Berlin premiere in 1931.
DURBAN, Dec. 20 (Reuters) -In one of the most thrilling finishes ever seen in a cricket test match, England gained a twowicket victory in the opener against South Africa today.

Joseph Curran, president of the National Maritime Union, CIO, was ordered yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Thomas A. Aurelio to appear in Supreme Court on Thursday to answer charges that he interfered with the rights under the union constitution of Joseph Stack, left-wing labor leader and former union vice president, and two others.

The annual Debutante Cotillion and Christmas Ball, which for several years has been an outstanding fete for the entertainment of younger members of society during the Christmas season, was held last night in the grand ballroom suite of the Waldorf-Astoria.

The frantic scramble for bedrooms, drawing rooms and other scarce railroad accommodations has been made worse by the practice of some firms of buying much unneeded Pullman space and later canceling the unwanted reservations, it was testified yesterday at an Interstate Commerce Commission hearing into alleged black marketing.

What is believed to be the first comprehensive merchandising calendar for the men's and boys' apparel trade has been prepared for the National Association of Retail Clothiers and Furnishers by the Alfred J. Silberstein, Bert Goldsmith, Inc., advertising agency, 16 East Fortieth Street, it was announced yesterday.
THE TIMES on Oct. 17 devoted fiftyfour lines of text to stomach ulcers, under the subhead "Protein Hydrolysate Therapy Is Found to Be Ineffective."

A committee representing holders of the $7 and $6 preferred stocks of the American and Foreign Power Company, Inc., announced yesterday through its chairman, C. Shelby Carter, that it had asked the Securities and Exchange Commission to prohibit the company from paying to its parent, the Electric Bond and Share Company, interest on $30,000,000 of indebtedness.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 (AP) -Representative Walter Judd, Republican, of Minnesota, said today that Secretary of State Marshall "is the one man responsible" for the present situation of the Chinese Government forces.

Supreme Court Justice Denis O'Leary Cohalan granted yesterday an injunction against picketing with "misleading and untruthful signs" in a three-cornered labor union jurisdictional dispute involving restaurant operators and unions.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Dec. 20 -- Ralph D. Klebes, City Manager of Elmira, N.Y., for the last eleven years, was appointed City Manager of New Rochelle at a meeting tonight of the City Council. He will receive a salary of $12,500, which is $2,500 higher than has been paid here and $2,500 more than the salary paid any other city or village manager in Westchester County.
LONDON, Dec. 20 (AP) -- Following is a summary of a White Paper on Britain's four-year recovery program, issued today by the Treasury:

A warning to "persons past middle-age" that over-exertion in a heavy snowfall "may have serious consequences" was issued yesterday by the Department of Health after the deaths of four men and a woman in Queens, presumably of heart attacks brought on as a result of the storm.

At Yuletide the delicacy shops do their briskest business in caviar and the goose liver pate that all of us, French or not, call pate de foie gras. It's not surprising, because for most of us these are luxuries too dear for ordinary entertaining. Christmas is one of the few occasions when budgets can be stretched to accommodate them.

From cubbyholes in subway arcades, with rumbling trains in the background, to Park Avenue shops, all plate glass and pianissimo Christmas carols, the poinsettia still is king among holiday flowers, New York florists agreed yesterday.
AMMAN, Dec. 20 (UP) -- Official circles said today that Trans-Jordan and other Arab countries were studying the desire of the United Nations Security Council for a permanent armistice in Palestine.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- Dr. D. Soemitro, the Indonesian Republic's Minister to the United States, formally asked this country today for "political and economic support" in its conflict with the Netherlands, including discontinuance of "American aid to the Netherlands under the European Recovery Program or otherwise."
ALBANY, Dec. 20 -- Six representatives of industry told Governor Dewey today of their opposition to the proposed program to extend unemployment insurance benefits to include sickness disability.

Youthbuilders should make a special effort to make friends with "so-called objectionable neighborhood youngsters," Edwin Lukas, director of the Society for the Prevention of Crime, told a group of twenty boys and girls from Youthbuilder clubs in public schools throughout the city.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 (AP) -Spokesmen for the General Motors Corporation and the General Electric Company said today that their post-war profits had not kept pace with their volume of business or payrolls. They testified before a Congressional economic subcommittee that is studying corporate profits.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- Because the military tribunal in Tokyo that sentenced the Japanese war leaders to death or prison is international in character, no court of the United States can interfere in any way with the convictions, the Supreme Court announced by an overwhelming vote today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- The Workers Defense League protested today that deportation of about twenty Indonesians who came to this country either as seamen or students would violate the traditional American freedom of asylum and embarrass our representatives before the United Nations Security Council.

VIENNA, Dec. 20 -- Receipt in Vienna today of the text of an answer by the Russian Government to a proposal by the Austrian Government that negotiations for a peace treaty be resumed indicates that the Russians made their reply a vehicle for a little propaganda.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- Senator Irving M. Ives declared today that he was "not remotely interested" in a post in the Republican Senate leadership but said he believed that the liberal element in the party was entitled to such representation.

LONDON, Dec. 17 -- Little attention has been devoted by scholastic and cultural circles to the intense intellectual activities of that select body of men known as the Central Committee of the Communist Party of the Soviet Union (Bolshevik).

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 20 -- The American President Lines wants to obtain the 26,000-ton Monterey of the Matson Navigation Company for use with its Pacific fleet, George Killion, APL president, disclosed today. He has discussed the question with the Maritime Commission in Washington.

Miss Dorothy Bloom, who has been involved with her sister, Pearl, in a series of courtroom appearances on charges of rent gouging and failure to maintain sanitary conditions in tenement houses they operate, was sentenced yesterday to ninety days in the workhouse.

The first slight hope of averting a tugboat strike that threatens to paralyze almost every aspect of the city's life emerged yesterday when towboat operators, for the first time, agreed to submit a written counter-offer to union demands.

" That Wonderful Urge," which arrives at the Roxy tonight, is today's lone film newcomer. The romantic comedy, starring Tyrone Power and Gene Tierney, was directed by Robert B. Sinclair and produced by Fred Kohlmar for Twentieth Century-Fox from a script by Jay Dratler and a story by William R. Lipman and Frederick Stephani.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 (AP) -Farmers have planted a record acreage of winter wheat to open the way for possible production next year of the largest United States wheat crop ever harvested.

THE HAGUE, The Netherlands, Dec. 20 -- The spectacular assault by Netherlands forces upon the Republic of Indonesia was deliberately planned to achieve quick results with the object of saving lives, Premier Willem Drees told the Parliament this afternoon.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- The Army and the Air Force formally opened today their commissioned rolls to women with announcement of the appointment of 319 to permanent commissions in the regular establishments. The appointments, made in the name of the President, carry ranks up to major under post-war laws authorizing permanent commissions on a limitedduty basis.

Failure of rayon converters to liquidate large portions of their inventories has made them wary of discussing first quarter gray goods prices with mills on the majority of fabric types, it was learned yesterday. Mills on their part have not come forward with a general list of prices for the coming quarter and will await, they said, a more propitious time.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 20 -Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer will institute a series of experimental lowbudget films next year with "Border Incident," which will start in mid-January at an estimated budget of $550,000, as the initial venture in the project, it was learned today.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 (AP) -Companies in three major American industries rang up record net sales of $22,026,159,000 last year, a Government report disclosed tonight.

Good gains by the chemicals section were the feature yesterday of an otherwise uneven and highly selective performance of the stock market on the New York Stock Exchange. Although the list leaned heavily to the lower side, with losses generally confined to fractions, the spurt in some of the chemicals lifted the price index more than a point.

Referring to my letter entitled "Punishing War Criminals," which appeared in your issue of Nov. 28, I find that I have been severely criticized for an inaccuracy in the paragraph published in the heading for which I was not responsible.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., Dec. 20 (AP) -- Notre Dame tonight continued an unbroken string of basketball victories over Pennsylvania by defeating the Red and Blue for the fifteenth time. The score was 55 to 42.

" Marley was dead, to begin with. There is no doubt whatever about that." Thus did Charles Dickens, who bowed to no one in his love of Christmas and his reverence for its traditions, begin one of the great Yuletide classics of all time. This was "A Christmas Carol," hailed by many as the most inspired of all his writings.

RHINEBECK, N.Y., Dec. 20 -William Gordon Sorrells, nineteen years old, of 673 East Parkway South, Memphis, a freshman in Bard College near here, was in critical condition today at the Northern Dutchess Health Center. He had an abdominal bullet wound, accidentally self-inflicted, according to State Police.

The Appellate Division upheld yesterday Supreme Court Justice Felix C. Benvenga, who had denied a motion by three Negro war veterans seeking to enjoin Stuyvesant Town from allegedly practicing racial discrimination in selecting tenants.

Three members of the staff of the Port of New York Authority who returned from a month's inspection trip of European airports and seaports on Saturday, said yesterday that in general the United States was ahead of Europe in the development of airports.

CAIRO, Dec. 20 -- A member of the group accompanying Brig. Gen. William E. Riley of the United States Marine Corps, Chief Truce Supervisor in Palestine, declared here today that negotiations for implementation of the Security Council's truce resolutions of Nov. 4 and 16 had reached a stalemate.

ROME, Dec. 20 -- The twentyfour-hour strike of state employes that was designed to bring the whole of Italy to a standstill today resulted in a palpable setback for its Communist organizers. With the exception of the railroads in some regions of Northern Italy, all public services were kept going, though with reduced staffs, and in some parts of Southern Italy, with almost 100 per cent of their normal efficiency.

Two of Dixies unbeaten basketball teams had their perfect records sullied at Madison Square Garden last night. Georgia, which had a seven-game winning streak, fell before New York University's blazing second-half drive, 83 -- 72, and Georgia Tech was stopped after four straight victories by Long Island University, 74 -- 60.

LONDON, Dec. 20 -- Attorney General Sir Hartley Shawcross opened his final address to a tribunal of inquiry into allegations of fraud today with a plea against anti-Semitism and with a defense of Britain's civil service and system of government.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 20 -- Ten hours of deliberation among officials of the warring National Football League and the All-America Conference ended tonight in a deadlock. Status quo was maintained when the parley failed to reach common ground.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 20 -- Reinstatement of Lester Cole, suspended screen writer, in his $1,350a-week job at the MetroGoldwyn-Mayer studios was ordered today by United States District Judge Leon Yankwich in a ruling which included an extraordinary half-hour denunciation of Eric Johnston as the author of the film industry's anti-Communist employment policy.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today that it had granted to the Standard Gas and Electric Company, Chicago, permission to resume payment of current dividends on its $6 and $7 cumulative prior preference stock.

The first study of homeless men in New York to be made since the depression shows that the demand for free lodging is growing at an alarming rate. This was announced yesterday in the report of a committee formed by the Welfare Council of New York, which was made public by G. Howland Shaw, its president.

MANAGUA, Dec. 20 (UP) -- The four-nation commission of inquiry was greeted at Mercedes Airport today by Foreign Minister Oscar Sevilla Sacasa and other Nicaraguan officials, who promised full cooperation.

Metropolitan ski enthusiasts had plenty of reason to be jubilant yesterday as the recent snowstorm provided opportunities to don hickory boards. Farther north, popular areas either got a tracing of white powder or none at all.

MANAGUA, Nicaragua, Dec. 20 (AP) -- The Nicaraguan War Minister, Gen. Anastasio Somoza, said tonight he had told a hemispheric investigating commission "truthfully and frankly that Nicaragua was not involved in the invasion of Costa Rica."
A small boy who shoveled snow to earn $1 sent it yesterday to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 20 (AP) -- Dick Cramer, Rutgers halfback, broke his right collar bone during a rough scrimmage session today as North and South squads trained for Mahi Shrine's all-star football battle in the Orange Bowl Christmas night.

SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, Dec. 20 -- Five assailants were killed when they fired on a military staff car at Devil's Elbow, in the Atlantic littoral, late last night, said a Government report today. The occupants of the car, uninjured by the attackers' blast, returned a hot fire, killing five, the report said.

PARIS, Dec. 20 -- France's first and only atomic energy pile was proudly displayed to the press today. Everyone was allowed to look at, touch and photograph the concrete installation but detailed figures concerning the apparatus were kept secret by a commission that often in the past has announced that all its work was devoted to the good of mankind and would be open and available to the world.
ALBANY, Dec. 20 -- The Democratic party proposal for an emergency grant of $100,000,000 for schools was characterized today as a "hollow proposal" by Charles D. Breitel, counsel to Governor Dewey.

As the long days until Christmas continued to pass slowly for most of the city's children, hundreds of members of local welfare groups took time out yesterday to give thousands of underprivileged boys and girls a preview of what the others must wait five more days to enjoy.

CHICAGO, Dec. 20 -- The sellers' market definitely is at an end in most lines of goods. Success of numerous enterprises will depend on their ability to sell to customers who once again are thinking about price before buying. However, because of various factors the months ahead promise to continue active for general business, though not at the post-war record pace.

If the child who is branded "delinquent" and committed to an institution is to return to a useful place in the community he should be helped to understand the reasons for his rebellion. This is the opinion of authorities as disclosed in a survey conducted by THE NEW YORK TIMES.
LONDON, Dec. 20 -- Late this afternoon 10 Downing Street said it had not yet received Henry Morgenthau's appeal to Prime Minister Attlee for release of Jewish immigrants interned in Cyprus.

NEWTON, Mass., Dec. 20 (AP) -Radiation from atom-smashing cyclotrons has almost blinded several American scientists, according to Dr. Shields Warren, head of the medical department of the Atomic Energy Commission.

Directors of E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc., of Wilmington, Del., the nation's largest chemical company, voted yesterday to recommend to stockholders a four-for-one split of the common stock. The proposal will be acted upon at the next annual meeting of shareholders on April 11, 1949.
BERLIN, Dec. 20 -- The world's first piloted supersonic rocket projectile is the spearhead of a new, gigantic Soviet Air Force, a Russian science magazine claimed today.

AMMAN, Trans-Jordan, Dec. 20 -- King Abdullah of TransJordan, whose declared policy is to unite his country with Arab Palestine, announced today that he had appointed a new Mufti of Jerusalem as a rival to Haj Amin el-Husseini, for twentyfive years the generally accepted leader of the Palestine Arabs.

Adherence of the United States to the proposed International Trade Organization will be strongly supported by the National Council of American Importers, it was made known yesterday by Morris S. Rosenthal, president of the import organization.

DETROIT, Dec. 20 -- A committee of six distinguished educators in the social and natural sciences and education was named today to determine the areas of human welfare, in which the resources of the $205,000,000 Ford Foundation can be most effectively expended.

The Retail, Wholesale and Department Store Union, shorn of its jurisdiction by the Congress of Industrial Organizations, moved last night to put itself back in business as a functioning CIO union. The union's international executive board gave an "indefinite leave of absence" to Samuel Wolchok, whose resignation as president had been demanded by Philip Murray, national CIO head.

NANKING, Dec. 20 -- After three weeks of effort, Dr. Sun Fo announced tonight that he had succeeded in forming a Chinese Government. The result appeared to be neither a "war Cabinet" nor a "peace Cabinet."
DETROIT, Dec. 20 (AP) -- Hudson Motor Car Company declared today a special stock dividend of one share for each twenty shares payable on March 1, 1949, to stockholders of record of Feb. 4, 1949.

ROME, Dec. 20 -- A vast plan for modernizing Italian agriculture was unfolded in a speech to the American Chamber of Commerce in Milan today by Harry McClelland, chief of the Food and Agriculture Division of the Economic Cooperation Administration mission in Italy.

PASADENA, Calif., Dec. 20 (AP) -- A business-like Northwestern University football squad arrived on the Rose Bowl scene today and hardly took time to unpack its belongings before going to work for the game with California on New Year's day.
CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 20 (AP) -- Hash Night, racing for Torrence C. Melrose, led all the way in the Blakestown purse, sixth and featured race at Tropical Park today.

The annual holiday jamboree of college basketball at Madison Square Garden will continue with another double-header tonight. Iowa State and Oklahoma, both of the Big Seven Conference, are the visitors. They will oppose St. John's and City College, respectively.

Under a misleading headline, "Government in Saxony to End Junker Memories," you printed on Dec. 12, in an Associated Press dispatch, one of the saddest and most distressing reports to come out of occupied Germany. It states that the Russian Government of Saxony will immediately raze 301 castles and 2,155 mansions that "once belonged to the rich nobility."

Because of the unique problems it brings to a large, congested city any considerable snowfall produces excitement and some apprehension in New York. The mere forecast of snow a week before the anniversary of the great storm of Dec. 26, 1947, was enough to start blizzard talk all over again.

The British pottery industry has completed 50 per cent of all major new projects in its post-war modernization program, Major George M. Greaves, head of Booths Colclough, Ltd., one of England's largest pottery operations, disclosed in an interview.

CHICAGO, Dec. 20 -- Grain traders placed a bearish construction on an estimate by the Department of Agriculture on the 1949 winter wheat crop, which is placed at 965,000,000 bushels, or only 26,000,000 bushels less than this year's bumper return, when the crop made a poor start and ended up with an excellent yield.

This is St. Thomas' Day. Dedicated to Thomas, one of the twelve Apostles, it is commonly recognized as ushering in the Yuletide festivities. It is also the day of the winter solstice, the shortest day of the year, though the difference between its length and that of Dec. 22 is virtually imperceptible.

Rosalie Moore's "The Grasshopper's Man and Other Poems" has been selected by W. H. Auden as the winning manuscript in the 1948 contest for the Yale Series of Younger Poets. The book will be published by Yale University Press in April, with a foreword by Mr. Auden.

A beginning teacher in the New York public school system who supports her parents has less takehome pay than she would receive under the minimum home relief standards provided by the Welfare Department, Dr. William Jansen, Superintendent of Schools, was told yesterday.

If stockholders approve next April the four-for-one split of the common stock recommended yesterday by directors of E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc., the company will become the largest American corporation in terms of the number of shares of stock outstanding.

The $6,000,000,000 plant expansion program of public utilities will increase the national market for bituminous coal by about 30 per cent and within a few years the manufacture of electricity will be bituminous coal's largest single customer, officials of the National Coal Association disclosed here yesterday.
The Copperweld Steel Company has called for redemption its outstanding debentures in the amount of $2,475,000, all of which are owned by the Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States.

CHICAGO, Dec. 20 -- Laszlo Halasz, artistic and music director of the New York City Opera Company, which last night completed eighteen performances at the Chicago Civic Opera House, asserted today that "the greatest achievement" of the company's season here was that "we proved the star system unnecessary to successful opera production."

Members of youthful street gangs should be invited to become members of projects designed to combat juvenile delinquency, G. Howland Shaw, president of the Welfare Council of New York City, declared yesterday.
LONDON, Dec. 20 -- Although business in the stock market here today was on the small side, some sections were firm.

TRENTON, N.J., Dec. 20 -Federal District Judge Phillip Forman indicated during legal argument today over jurisdiction of the Burlington County bridge case that the New Jersey issues might be dispatched to a state court and those involving Federal statutes retained in Federal District Court.
PROVIDENCE, R.I., Dec. 20 -Price cutting to unload big inventories in the face of weak demand has developed in startling fashion in recent weeks among the pearl manufacturing houses here.

Abraham Munitz, in a purchase for investment, has acquired the Galanthea, a residence hotel, at 510 West 113th Street, from Nettie Ruckstuhl of St. Louis, Mo. The property, assessed at $48,000, was bought for cash above a mortgage of $29,000.
BATAVIA, Java, Dec. 20 (AP) -Dutch troops raced unchecked through Java and Sumatra today threatening the remaining important centers of the young Indonesian Republic.

The New York City Ballet Company, which came into existence as part of the general program of the City Center during the recent season there of the New York City Opera Company, will have a short season of its own beginning Jan. 13.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange were moderately active yesterday and final prices were 8 to 17 points net lower than on Saturday.

ALBANY, Dec. 20 -- Governor Dewey began today a series of conferences with Republican county chairmen to discuss the organization of the Republican party in general and the Republican State Committee.

PARIS, Dec. 20 -- Total dollar aid requested by the Marshall Plan countries of Europe for the year that will begin July 1, 1949, is $4,636,800,000, or $238,200,000 less than the $4,845,000,000 voted for the first year by the United States Congress last spring.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 20 -- Dr. J. G. Hamilton, director of the Crocker Laboratory in which the sixty-inch cyclotron is housed at the University of California, said yesterday the final result of eye cataracts due to radiation from neutrons from cyclotrons could be a gradual development of blindness.
Ten thousands books are expected to arrive from abroad within the coming year for American libraries under the Farmington Plan, it was announced yesterday.

PARIS, Dec. 20 -- The United Nations Committee of Good Offices in Indonesia called upon the Security Council today "to consider on the basis of the utmost urgency the outbreak of hostilities in Indonesia in violation of the Renville Agreement, signed by the Governments of the Netherlands and the Republic of Indonesia 17 January 1948."

Political unsettlement in Indonesia resulted yesterday in a mild recovery in crude rubber futures on the Commodity Exchange. Although prices eased a bit near the close, final quotations showed net advances of 26 to 30 points in the No. 1 contract on sales of 690 long tons.
MOBILE, Ala., Dec. 20 (AP) -- A registrar testified today that Negroes and whites are treated differently when they apply to the Mobile County Board for registration to vote.

Foster boarding homes are needed for 428 Protestant boys and girls, many of them brothers and sisters who ideally should be kept together, W. Noel Hudson, executive vice president of the Federation of Protestant Welfare Agencies, announced yesterday.

A Gibson Girl Ball was held last night in the main ballroom of the Plaza for the benefit of the Child Placing and Adoption Committee and in tribute to Mrs. Charles Dana Gibson, marking her seventy-fifth birthday and her twenty-fifth anniversary as chairman of the beneficiary.

The Board of Education's budgetmaking process is being more fully exposed to public view this fall, under Superintendent Jansen's leadership, which is good policy. The people have a vital interest in the amount that is spent, and how it is spent. About a fourth of our city budget goes to education, yet who would deny that it is the most important obligation of the city?

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- President Truman conferred the Medal of Merit today on Myron C. Taylor, his personal representative to the Vatican. The presentation was made at an informal ceremony in the President's office.
Fire Commissioner Frank J. Quayle renewed yesterday his request to Chief Magistrate Edgar Bromberger and his associates to give more severe penalties to false alarm offenders.

LONDON, Dec. 20 -- After fortyeight hours of hard thinking, the British Government is "damned annoyed" over Dutch "police action" in Indonesia. At the same time, one ranking officer admitted privately today that the Government frankly was puzzled as to what to do about it.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 20 (AP) -- Sanitary Products and Paper Co., a department of Crown Zellerbach Corporation, which distributes products of its Carthage, N.Y., mill and those of other manufacturers, has sold its five branches to individual business groups in New York.

THE football folk were punching the conversational bag in Philadelphia on the eve of the Snow Bowl game between the Eagles and the Cardinals. Into the room strode a man who was tall enough to have been a tackle but hardly wide enough to fill the bill. Those bulky coaches crowded around him and shook his hand with as much pleasure as if he'd been a member of their fraternity.
LONDON, Dec. 20 -- A program of austerity carrying through the years of American aid to Europe was outlined in a British Government White Paper issued today.

The sharp loss in export business is principally responsible for the slackening in operations now apparent in a number of cotton manufacturing centers, according to a survey by the Cotton-Textile Institute made public yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 (AP) -The Supreme Court today affirmed by a 4-4 vote the conviction of Carl Aldo Marzani, a former State Department employe, on charges that he concealed Communist party activities from Government loyalty examiners.

The "pick-up man" in the attempted extortion of $100,000 from Edgar F. Luckenbach Jr., 23-yearold heir to a shipping fortune, pleaded guilty yesterday in General Sessions before Judge Jacob Gould Schurman. The defendant, Dale Neidich, 24, of 32 Landscape Avenue, Yonkers, was one of three men arrested last Oct. 21 on charges of conspiracy and attempted extortion.

MOSCOW, Dec. 20 (UP) -- On the eve of Premier Stalin's sixty-ninth birthday the bulk of Pravda's front page, and Izvestia's and of other newspapers, was devoted to what has become a long established and peculiarly Soviet institution -letters to Premier Stalin from workers, engineers, party leaders, pledging increased industrial and agricultural output.

Because of a change in "political climate" there is little hope for any extension of the Dec. 31 deadline for filing claims to recover property lost under the Nazi regime in Germany, William J. Dickman, former deputy chief, property control and external assets branch of the property division, Office of Military Government, said yesterday.

TOKYO, Tuesday, Dec. 21 -- The lower house of the Japanese Diet, after an all-night session, this morning finally carried the controversial wage bill setting the new basic pay for Government employes at 6,300 yen monthly (about $24).

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 (AP) -President Truman has delayed his trip home for Christmas. He plans to be gone a week, taking off at 10 A.M. (E.S.T.) Wednesday for Independence, Mo., and returning about Dec. 29. He will go in the White House plane "Independence."
LOUISVILLE, Ky., Dec. 20 (AP) -With only two more sales days before the Christmas holidays, the 1948 burley tobacco crop already has netted growers in the eightstate belt more than $153,000,000.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- Eight members of the Republican Congress most directly responsible for the Taft-Hartley Act doggedly reaffirmed faith in its principles today. In effect, moreover, they counter-attacked the pro-repeal forces gathering for the incoming Democratic Congress.

The "gray market" in fir plywood has disappeared and there is now an adequate supply of this building and industrial product for all needs, it was declared yesterday by Lawrence Ottinger, president of the United States Plywood Corporation, largest factor in the plywood industry.
Despite the poor hunting conditions which persisted throughout most of the open season, both in the Adirondacks and the Catskills, New York deer hunters made a record deer kill this fall.

The two-story taxpayer building at 19-27 Prospect Street, Ridgewood, N.J., has been sold by Seymour Forman to the Ridge Realty Company, of which Martin J. Then of Tenafly is president. The building which contains ten stores, occupies an irregular plot 150 by 50 feet.

NORWALK, Conn., Dec. 20 --- Mrs. John M. Gloetzner Jr., a member of the Board of Education, who proposed the motion adopted by the board in September denying teachers the privilege of accepting Christmas gifts from students, today declared that the ruling was not "mandatory."
