SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 20 -Sam Kagel of this city, who has represented many labor unions, including the International Longshoremen's and Warehousemen's Union, CIO, in contract negotiations and arbitrations, has been agreed upon as Pacific Coast arbitrator under the new long-term agreement signed by the ILWU and the Waterfront Employers Association.

The State of Maryland sold yesterday an issue of $6,695,000 of general construction certificates of indebtedness of 1947, due on each Jan. 1 from 1952 to 1964, to the Harris Trust and Savings Bank and associates at a bid of 101.30 for 1 1/2s.

The first action toward setting up of a business advisory committee to cooperate with the Office of International Trade's transportation and communications branch on a program for improvement of American shippers' packaging will be taken next month, it was learned yesterday.

BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 20 -Thomas Maleady, first secretary of the United States Embassy called on the Under-Secretary of Foreign Affairs, Pascual Larosa today to acquaint him with the United States readiness to re-examine the recognition policy for the Hemisphere in the light of the recent military coups in Latin America.
DALLAS, Tex., Dec. 20 (AP) -The University of Oregon football squad flew into Dallas tonight to open training at the site of the Cotton Bowl football game with Southern Methodist on Jan. 1.

The large gymnasium on the two top floors of the old West Side Y.M.C.A. Building at 316-18 West Fifty-seventh Street is being converted into television studios and a broadcasting station for the School of Radio Technique, which recently leased the space.

Charges that Communist party sympathizers have been using public school buildings for after-school children's classes have been under investigation for the last five weeks, and the results of the inquiry will be given tomorrow to Dr. William Jansen, Superintendent of Schools, it was learned yesterday.

CHICAGO, Dec. 20 -- The sixteen non-operating railroad unions, dissatisfied with a fact-finding board recommendation providing a fortyhour week and a 7-cent-an-hour pay rise, will meet with railroad officials Jan. 5 in hopes of negotiating a better settlement, a railroad spokesman said today.

Since Mme. Chiang's visit to the States, opinions are sharply divided regarding the problem of giving further aid to China. The unanimous reason of the opposing camp is that the Chiang Government is "inefficient and corrupt," and that therefore we had better wait for the time when the Chinese Communists have taken over the country and established a coalition government.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Dec. 20 -- Now that the campaign has been launched in Indonesia, the dominant thought in official quarters here concerns the coming meeting of the Security Council in Paris and, above all, the attitude to be taken by the United States.

BERLIN, Dec. 20 -- The Russianlicensed news agency ADN accused French units today of having stolen livestock from the village of Stolpe, on the border of the French sector of Berlin and the Soviet occupation zone of Germany.
Frank Boucher, manager of the New York Rangers for the last seven years, will announce his retirement from that post today, it was learned authoritatively last night.

SOFIA, Bulgaria, Dec. 20 -- The world-wide struggle of the Soviet bloc against the British and Americans and the mendin of internal party fences continued today as the two main themes of the Bulgarian Communist party congress.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Dec. 20 -- Evidence tending to show that the decartelization program was not being carried out and that, in at least one case, a German cartel was being revived internationally, has been presented to the special commission of Army Secretary Kenneth C. Royall, it was learned today.

For the first time in recent years city officials and business leaders are joining in a coordinated effort to make New York City the nation's outstanding convention and vacation center. Ambitious plans have been announced for a centralized promotion agency to focus attention on New York's facilities and attractions.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- The Atomic Energy Commission closed today a long debate over the status of Dr. Frank Porter Graham, president of the University of North Carolina and president of the Oak Ridge Institute of Nuclear Energy, by granting him complete "security clearance."

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Dec. 20 -- Disturbed by the recent series of military coups in Latin America, the United States has begun informal discussions on the Foreign Minister plane to ascertain how hemispheric democracy can be strengthened, it was learned today.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 (AP). -The Supreme Court ruled 5 to 4 today that a trial jury might properly be composed entirely of Federal employes.

PARIS, Dec. 20 -- The talk between French Foreign Minister Schuman and Italian Foreign Minister Count Carlo Sforza at Cannes today dealt mainly with the question of the former Italian colonies in relation to Italy's possible participation in the proposed Atlantic pact, according to informed officials here.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Dec. 20 -- Unaccustomed as they are to public plaudits, heavily criticized staff members of the decartelization branch of the United States Military Government are reeling from the impact of a flood of fan mail from Germans.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- The House Committee on Un-American Activities agreed today not to question, in open hearing or for public record, five witnesses deemed by the Department of Justice to be essential to the perjury trial of Alger Hiss, former State Department official.

Planning to enlarge its development of one-family homes, Salisbury Manor has purchased a tract of forty-two acres at Prospect Avenue and Fifth Street in East Hempstead, L.I., from Village Homes. King King, Inc., was the broker.
EAST LANSING, Mich., Dec. 20 (AP) -- A sharpshooting, "iron man" Cornell University team gave Michigan State a basketball lesson tonight as the Ivy League visitors won 56 to 45 before 5,029 fans.

BERLIN, Tuesday, Dec. 21 (UP) -- Russia today accused the Western powers of creating an artificial crisis in Berlin to cloak anti-Soviet alliances that were formed in an effort to eliminate the Russians from the four-power rule over Germany.

Bernard Reines' four-character play, "Forward the Heart," has been sold again, and this time apparently there is to be a production. The new owners are Theatre Enterprise, Inc., of which Anthony Parella is president, and Leon Bronesky.

Assistant Chief Inspector August W. Flath, one of the most highly regarded members of the Police Department, was named yesterday by Police Commissioner Arthur W. Wallander as Acting Chief Inspector. Mr. Flath, heretofore chief of staff, replaces Chief Inspector Martin J. Brown, who fell dead of a heart attack Sunday night directing snow removal at his home, 13-03 144th Place, Whitestone, Queens.

New York City took its third greatest snowstorm in one gigantic stride yesterday and appeared to be winning its battle in impressive fashion until last night, when a Weather Bureau bulletin forecast more snow for today.
NEW DELHI, India, Dec. 20 -The Indonesian Republic's office here issued an appeal today to all Asian nations for aid "not only morally but also materially" in the new armed struggle with the Dutch.

The New York Foreign Trade Zone is expecting favorable action before Christmas on an appeal from a United States Customs ruling on the mixing and coloring of rum that may have far-reaching effect on the entire spirits import business, it became known yesterday.

General agreement that SovietAmerican relations had improved in the last year was expressed yesterday by leaders of the United States delegation to the Paris meetings of the United Nations General Assembly. They arrived here last night on the Cunard White Star liner Mauretania.

Retail sales yesterday, which many retailers had expected to be the largest of the year, were hard hit by heavy slush that kept some shoppers at home and snow drifts in outlying areas that curtailed transportation facilities. It was pointed out that the final shopping days before Christmas last year all had favorable weather and the heavy snowfall did not come until Dec. 26.

SOUTHAMPTON, England, Dec. 20 -- The biggest liner built in the world since the war -- Cunard White Star Line's Caronia -- finished her last trial trip this afternoon and is all set for her maiden voyage to New York on Jan. 4. The event is a great landmark in North Atlantic travel, for the colossal cost of this luxury liner makes her undoubtedly the last of a long, distinguished list of British passenger vessels.

Yesterday, after the close of the markets, the Department of Agriculture released the first official figures on winter wheat plantings this fall, together with a preliminary estimate of yield per acre and total production. Although grain experts have been predicting an acreage equal to that of a year ago, and perhaps slightly more, the Government's actual figures far exceed anything that could be called an average estimate for the grain trade.

The conviction last June of Isidore Ginsberg on a charge of grand larceny was reversed on the law by the Appellate Division, Second Department, yesterday. The court ordered a new trial for the 53-yearold Queens lawyer and building materials broker, who was described as the "most vicious of gray marketeers" at a Congressional investigation last January.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- Michigan can legally forbid women from being barmaids unless they are wives or daughters of a man owning a licensed liquor establishment, the Supreme Court held by six to three today.

Following is the text of a memorandum submitted yesterday by Dr. D. Soemitro, acting head of the Indonesian Republic's delegation to the United Nations, to Acting Secretary of State Robert A. Lovett in Washington, as released by Dr. Soemitro's New York office:

ATHENS, Dec. 20 -- Secretary of the Army Kenneth C. Royall and his party made an unexpected return to Greece from Turkey today and despite severe weather conditions insisted upon stopping at Kozani and Argos Orestikan, near Kastoria, in the operational theatres.

Junior high school student council leaders discussed yesterday projects in which students may train themselves for responsible citizenship. They presented a summary of their views at a conference of city-wide borough councils before an audience of 300 in Times Hall, 240 West Forty-fourth Street.

The Supreme Court has refused to act on the appeal of the Japanese war leaders. It does so on the ground that the International Military Tribunal which sentenced them to death is not a tribunal of the United States but (like General MacArthur, who created it) an agent of the Allied Powers and therefore outside American jurisdiction.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Dec. 20 (AP) -- Yugoslavia charged today that Bulgarian leaders, through "an anti-Leninist attitude" toward the Macedonian question, had made impossible a South Slav federation in the Balkans.

A meeting of fifty health and conservation officials from the North Atlantic and Middle Coastal States was held yesterday by the United States Public Health Service, 125 Worth Street, to discuss the recently enacted Federal Water Pollution Control Law.

The National Association for American Composers and Conductors, Inc., gave a concert in Times Hall last night. The performers were Alice Howland, soprano; a string quartet of Sandor Salgo, Harvey Siegel, Nicolas Harsanyi and Shepard Coleman, and the NAACC singers, directed by Dolf Swing.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- A record annual rate of national income, $227,300,000,000, was recorded in the third quarter of 1948, the Office of Business Economics of the Department of Commerce reported today. This is an increase of $5,600,000,000 over the rate for the second quarter.

FROM the third millennium B.C., when Babylonian gentlemen wore kaunakes, shaggy skirts made of hanks of wool, to 1867, when hoopskirts were in fashion, without overlooking much in between, is the long journey Millia Davenport has made in her exhaustive "The Book of Costume."* This "chronological survey of dress" is the most comprehensive book on the subject ever compiled.

The Bowery Savings Bank and the North River Savings Bank will be merged, the presidents of both announced yesterday. They said that the Superintendent of Banks had consented to the consolidation and that the boards of the two banks would meet soon to fix a merger date.

NANKING, Dec. 20 -- The capture of Gen. Huang Wei, Twelfth Army Group commander, and several of his generals was reported tonight by the Communist radio. These officers have been unreported since the Army group was cut to pieces northwest of Pengpu last week.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 -- Eleven sets of exceptions were filed today with the Interstate Commerce Commission, requesting modifications of the plan of reorganization for the Missouri Pacific Railroad recommended for adoption by R. H. Jewell, examiner for the ICC.

Representatives of the Empire City Racing Association, backed by the State Racing Commission, yesterday explained to a nineman delegation from Westchester County why the thoroughbreds "will never run again" at Empire's old track in Yonkers.

PARIS, Dec. 21 -- The French Government has instructed its Ambassador in Washington, Henri Bonnet, to try to ask modification of the report of the committee headed by George M. Humphrey on German dismantling before it is presented to Paul G. Hoffman, head of the Economic Cooperation Administration.

If all Christmas concerts had the sheer joy of singing that the Collegiate Chorale under Robert Shaw brought to its special program at Carnegie Hall last night, one could wish for them at least once a month. There was nothing perfunctory in program or performance, and nothing routine in this annual holiday devotion.

BOSTON, Dec. 21 (AP) -- Colgate's veteran-studded Red Raiders were just too strong for Boston University's basketball team tonight, downing the Terriers by 74 -- 52 in the first game of a Boston Garden double-header.
ROME, Dec. 21 (AP) -- The Vatican radio station said today the Christmas Eve message of Pope Pius XII would be broadcast in twenty languages.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Dec. 21 (AP) -- A high authoritative source said tonight that the'"democratic countries" of the Americas might issue a joint statement calling for some "sort of economic blockade" against governments installed by force.
CHICAGO, Dec. 21 (AP) -- Will a national television broadcast of a Notre Dame football game affect attendance at Ivy League, or Eastern Seaboard college games?

Democratization of Germany may succeed under certain conditions, but if it does it "will be a long, slow progress," two officials of the American Civil Liberties Union who recently returned from Germany agreed here yesterday. They spoke before 250 persons at a forum held by the union in the auditorium of American Common, 40 East Fortieth Street.

George Mikan, basketball's most glittering showpiece, will be on display tonight at Madison Square Garden. The sharpshooting 6-foot 9-inch pivot artist, most prolific scorer in the court game, will lead the Minneapolis Lakers against the New York Knickerbockers in a Basketball Association of America contest.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 -- Philip Murray, president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, refused today on the advice of counsel to honor a subpoena directing him to appear tomorrow before Representative Clare Hoffman, Republican, of Michigan, sitting as a subcommittee of the House Labor Committtee.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 21 (AP) -Eric Johnston, president of the Motion Picture Association of America, took issue today with Federal Judge Leon R. Yankwich, who yesterday called Mr. Johnston "dogmatic, a doctrinaire and an absolutist."

Some months ago it was occasionally asserted, in calling attention to the shortcomings of our own public schools, that even Russia devoted a larger percentage of national income to education than we did. Those who may have been alarmed by this state of affairs will take comfort, perhaps, from the account of conditions in Soviet schools by Benjamin Fine, based on editorials in Pravda and other information reaching this newspaper.

NANKING, Dec. 21 -- The industrial center of Tientsin, last remaining entrance to Nationalist North China, was the focal point of China's war tonight with fighting in the suburbs heavy, Communist columns converging and the city's rail and water routes cut off.

The renewed bid for a higher price level which has been manifest in the Government bond market lately carried practically the whole list upward yesterday. The longest bank-eligible 2 1/2s went through the high bid point of 101.25 registered in the post-election flurry and the bank-ineligible 2 1/2s of 1972-67 moved up to 100.13 bid.

Attired in the 1912 costumes of South England. "Make Way for Lucia" begins its tenancy at the Cort tonight at 8:15. A dramatization of the E. F. Benson novels by John van Druten (he also directed), the plot depends on six of the Benson stories for its motivation.

The belief that the United States is following the lead of Europe toward nationalization of industry was expressed here yesterday by Representative Katharine St. George, Republican, of Tuxedo Park, N.Y.

A picture of "A Pair of Sandals" walked off with first prize yesterday at the opening of the first annual exhibit of the New York City High School Salon of Photography. The exhibit, which is being held in the photographic gallery of the Brooklyn Museum, Eastern Parkway and Washington Avenue, will continue through Jan. 9.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Dec. 21 -- For the first time in Christian history pilgrims to Christmas services at Bethlehem will be prevented from using the traditional Jerusalem highway, which was the route of Joseph and Mary and was used by the three wise men.
Although winter officially moved in at 5:34 P. M. yesterday, the 19.6-inch snow of last Sunday plopped and dripped from the city's skyscrapers under the influence of rising temperatures.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 -- A proposal to consolidate and protect the Federal Government's official records was placed today before the Commission on Organization of the Executive Branch of the Government, headed by former President Herbert Hoover.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 -- The United States was reliably said today to be determined upon demanding that the Netherlands stop her "police action" in Indonesia and liberate Republican leaders who have been captured.

PARIS, Dec. 9 -- If visible proof was needed at the end of World War II that France was a physically shattered country, a visit to her devastated ports from Dunkerque to Marseille would have dispelled all doubts.

Most of us like to put off until the last. This year -- the first in many -the last-minute shopper is really dominating Christmas buying. During the last six weeks, retail sales have lagged behind last year's. With merchandise plentiful the consumer is presumed to be shopping around for the best buys.
John A. Sargent, vice president of finance of the Diamond Alkali Company, has been elected executive vice president, effective on Jan. 1, it was announced yesterday.
COLUMBUS, Dec. 21 (AP) -Liquid hydrogen now could send a rocket to the moon at a speed of 30,000 miles per hour.

More than 450 persons, business concerns, civic societies, public bureaus and other groups that assisted in the city's fiftieth anniversary celebration last summer received plaques yesterday for their services.
SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 21 (AP) -- The Shrine players saw today the reason for the East-West football game here New Year's Day.

There will be no effective care for children called "delinquents" until the community feels that dollars spent on them today are dollars saved later in prisons and mental hospitals. This is the opinion of authorities interviewed in a survey by THE NEW YORK TIMES.

SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Dec. 21 (AP) -- Women of the Air Force held the spotlight today at the Lackland Air Force Base, where 10,000 airmen joined high air-training command officers in honoring the first graduating class of basic WAF's.

BERLIN, Dec. 21 -- Gen. Sir Brian Robertson, British military governor, categorically declared today that all rumors about the remilitarization of Western Germany are "silly and unfounded." Any attempt to solve the problem of security in Western Europe by rearming Germany "instead of relying upon the resources and couraeg of the countries in Western Europe" would get little support from him, he added.

Philip Willkie, son of the late Wendell Willkie, came East yesterday to further the idea of a 1949 national convention of Republican leaders aimed at formulating a party program. Mr. Willkie, 28year-old member of the Indiana State Legislature told The Associated Press he thought such a convention would "give party leaders, especially Congressional leaders, an opportunity to let their views be known to the country on national questions."

The American people never were healthier than in 1948 and the prospect is for continued improvement in 1949, Dr. Louis L. Dublin, second vice president and statistician of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, reported yesterday.

Your leading editorial of Dec. 20, War in Indonesia, speaks of the "doublepronged action of still unforeseeable consequences for Asia and for the West," concluding with the statement: "On the solution of this issue -- or the lack of it -- will depend both the future course of events in Asia and the fate of Western Europe."

Out-of-town buyers registered in the market for the week ended yesterday numbered 390, compared with 886 last week and 292 in the corresponding week of 1947, according to the listings appearing in THE NEW YORK TIMES. There were ninety-four arrivals yesterday against 366 last Tuesday.

In peace and in war, Quentin Roosevelt followed the vigorous traditions of his branch of the Roosevelt family. Grandson of President Theodore Roosevelt, son of the late Brig. Gen. Theodore Roosevelt Jr. and namesake of his uncle, Quentin Roosevelt, who died in France while serving with the Lafayette Escadrille in World War I, he patterned his life in many respects on theirs.

Mr. and Mrs. Douglas Kane and their three children will be together for the Christmas holiday even though a judge in Kings County Court refused yesterday to allow Mrs. Kane to put up $25 of a relief check as bail to effect her husband's freedom.

THE HAGUE, Dec. 21 -- It was learned here today on competent authority that the Netherlands planned to spend 100,000,000 guilders [about $37,700,000] during the coming year as her share of the Western European defense program coordinated by Field Marshal Viscount-Montgomery.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 21 (AP) -The AFL International Longshoremen's Union announced tonight that the three-day old tie-up at the Port of Philadelphia had been settled. Workers will begin returning to work tomorrow morning.
The tremendous effort to bring Christmas cheer into the lives of sick and needy children and others of the less fortunate throughout the city held the Yuletide spotlight here yesterday.

A thorough investigation into the death of Laurence Duggan, former State Department official listed as having jumped or fallen from his sixteenth-floor office at 2 West Forty-fifth Street on Monday, was begun by the New York police yesterday after intimations that he might have met with foul play.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 -- The nation's railroads told the Interstate Commerce Commission today that wage increases recommended by a Presidential emergency board would cut estimated net operating income by $41,800,000 in 1948 and by $349,400,000 in 1949.

Three small children, ranging in age from 19 months to 3 years, were found burned to death yesterday clasped in one another's arms. Firemen had fought their way through flames to reach them in the basement apartment of a two-story brick building at 27 Montieth Street, in the Bushwick section of Brooklyn.

A GREAT many books about India have been published in recent years, but most of them have been about the India of Gandhi and Nehru. Western readers, who have had so many opportunities to inform themselves about modern India, have had hardly any to inform themselves about the history of India's ancient civilization.

STATE COLLEGE, Pa., Dec. 21 (Science Service) -- The firmness of the average woman in resisting being pushed too far by either the "new look," or any other fashion trend, is revealed in a study of fashions, over a nine-year period, by Nancy Koplin Jack and Betty Schiffer of the Pennsylvania State College.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 -- A recommendation for the enactment of measures to give union members and local unions the right of "legal redress" against "arbitrary" actions by their international officers or international unions was filed today by a House Labor Subcommittee.

Two associations of shipping lines in the North Atlantic trade were temporarily enjoined yesterday by a Federal statutory court from putting into effect the socalled exclusive patronage system of doing business with shippers.

GENEVA, Dec. 21 -- The Union of South Africa has advised other contracting parties to the Geneva tariff agreement of the necessity of imposing special import controls to protect South African monetary reserves against further depletion.
LONDON, Dec. 21 -- The best section in a generally quiet stock market here today was that for base metal shares.

In reply to Russian efforts to disrupt the legal Government of Berlin, the three Western Commandants of the city, representing the United States, Britain and France, have announced that the Allied Kommandatura, the supreme authority of the German capital, will resume its work forthwith -- with Russia if possible, without Russia if necessary.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 -- Communist and Communist-front organizations in the United States have grown in number to 562 and their publications to 190, the House Committee on Un-American Activities said today, offering a compilation of findings by official agencies at Federal, state and municipal levels.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Dec. 21 -- Air Chief Marshal Sir James Robb, Commander in Chief of the Western Europe Air Force, said today that the main accomplishments of defensive preparations initiated with the Brussels Western Union Pact had been "very largely psychological and for planning purposes."
The Retail, Wholesale and Department Store Union, CIO, apparently won a new lease on life as a result of three-way conversations in Pittsburgh and New York yesterday.
MEXICO CITY, Dec. 20 (AP) -Mexico plans a vast land reclamation program to halt erosion and produce more food.

High-level sales and production during 1949 are expected by General Electric Company, despite the fact that many significant economic indicators have taken a downward turn as the year-end approaches, it was said yesterday.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 21 -Hal Roach, independent producer and owner of the Hal Roach Studios, today announced plans for production of six half-hour films for television transmission, the first of which, "Sadie and Sally," will go before the cameras tomorrow, with Joy Lansing and Lois Hall in the leading roles and Leslie Goodwin directing.
MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 21 (AP) -- Horsemen today rejected a proposal to take a purse reduction at Tropical Park.
The Post Office indicated yesterday that it was getting ready for a last minute mail rush that was expected earlier but did not come.

CLEVELAND, Dec. 21 (AP) -Directors of the New York, Chicago St. Louis Railroad (Nickel Plate) declared today an extra dividend of $7.50 a share on preferred stock, payable on March 15, 1949, to stock of record of Feb. 25, 1949.

Mr. Hoffman's return from China and his announcement yesterday that the Economic Cooperation Administration has suspended all reconstruction projects in that country, until the present situation clears, raise the question whether some further clarification of American policy is not possible and desirable at this critical stage in China's affairs.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 -- Proponents of the combined St. Lawrence seaway and power project are highly confident that, with the continued strong support of President Truman, its construction will be approved by the Eighty-first Congress.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 -- The Public Service Company of Indiana filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement covering $12,000,000 of first-mortgage bonds, Series H, due in 1979, that are to be offered at competitive bidding.
A formal announcement that Lynn Patrick succeeds Manager Frank Boucher as coach of the New York Rangers of the National Hockey League was made yesterday at a press conference conducted at Leone's.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 -- Appointment of Mrs. Jack B. Fahy, of Washington, D.C., as executive director of the American Parents Committee, was made known today by George J. Hecht, New York City, chairman of the committee, and publisher of Parents' Magazine and School Management.
Parting with a treasure second only to his violin, Fritz Kreisler said yesterday that his collection of fine, early books would be auctioned for the benefit of destitute children.

Charging that the Dutch had jeopardized the future of the United Nations, Dr. D. Soemitro, minister plenipotentiary of the Republic of Indonesia, declared yesterday that the Dutch would find no peace in Indonesia "no matter how many so-called victories they win."
Trading in cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange was quiet yesterday. Final prices were 8 to 11 points net higher.
BRUSSELS, Dec. 21 (UP) -- Fritz Thyssen, German industrialist who bankrolled Hitler in the early days of nazism, has slipped into Belgium and is living incognito at the sedate Astoria Hotel here.

Trade between Brazil and the United States is being maintained at relatively high levels, despite continued slowness in obtaining dollar exchange for collections, according to an analysis here yesterday.

Several young women of society made their debuts yesterday at various parties given from afternoon hours into late in the evening. Richard C. Patterson Jr., United States Ambassador to Guatemala, and Mrs. Patterson of this city and Locust Valley gave a reception at the Plaza, where they make their home here, for their daughter, Miss Alice Rodes Patterson.

Harry C. Kane, an attorney who was appointed by Supreme Court Justice Ferdinand Pecora to take testimony and report on the advisability of merging the Surface Transportation Corporation with its parent organization, the Third Avenue Transit Corporation, filed his report yesterday.

LONDON, Dec. 21 -- A demonstration flight of the world's first propeller-turbine airliner, the Vicker's Viscount, was made today with a great reduction in the noise and virtual elimination of the vibration as the result of using the new type of engine.

Dr. James T. Shotwell, actinglwith a view to .expedit'mg the expresident of the Carnegie Endow- change of. students and professors ment for International Peace, ex' between the United States-and foreign countries.

CINCINNATI, Dec. 21 (AP) -Thomas C. Smith, superintendent of the Baltimore Ohio Railroad here, said today the first phase of a $12,000,000 "master plan" to consolidate freight operations in Cincinnati was scheduled for completion April 1.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 21 -Peace negotiations with the All-America Conference sidetracked for the time being, the National Football League devoted this entire day to drafting collegians for possible future delivery to the professional ranks.

Judge and Mrs. Muir Weissinger of Larchmont, N.Y., gave a dinner dance last night in the Crystal Room of the Ritz-Carlton to introduce their daughter, Miss Delphine Weissinger. The debutante, who received with her mother, wore a gown of silver and white lace made with an accordion pleated skirt and carried a fan of white flowers.

MANAGUA, Nicaragua, Dec. 21 (AP) -- A former Costa Rican official accused by the Nicaraguan War Minister of having tried to smuggle war materials into Costa Rica was called today before the four-nation commission investigating the border incident between the two nations.
The Salvation Army will eventually receive more than $1,300,000 under two wills offered for probate yesterday in Surrogate's Court.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Dec. 21 -- In hundreds of thousands of German homes where hope has flickered high this past year for family reunions by the end of this month, gloom hangs heavy as the holidays grow near.

A biography of Justice Hugo L. Black of the United States Supreme Court, by John P. Frank, who was for a time Justice Black's clerk, has been scheduled for Jan. 10 publication by Knopf. "Mr. Justice Black: The Man and His Opinions" will also contain a selection and analysis of the jurist's most significant opinions, as well as an introduction by Charles A. Beard.

SEATTLE, Dec. 21 (UP) -- Seattle's entire waterfront was suddenly tied up tonight for an indefinite period after American Federation of Labor foremen and checkers gave employers a 30-minute notice and walked off their jobs.

TOKYO, Dec. 21 -- Under last week' directives from Washington, the occupation has cracked down hard on the Japanese. It has ordered the Diet to pass bills over which there has been bickering for weeks. Three strikes involving 812,000 workers have been called off and a fourth is likely to end tomorrow morning.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Dec. 21 -- Edward Zimmerman, who built a $300,000 colony of small houses in 1946-48 on Weaver Street in New Rochelle, was indicted here today on five grand larceny charges for alleged frauds in the speculative operation.

TEL AVIV, Dec. 21 -- A United Nations plane manned by an American crew leaves Beirut every morning for Haifa, Tel Aviv, Gaza, Jerusalem and return. The trip is called "the milk run" and its purpose is to carry truce observers, mail and supplies back and forth between various U.N. headquarters in Palestine.

TOKYO, Dec. 21 -- The Japanese today received without much interest the news that the United States Supreme Court had refused to hear the pleas of the Japanese warlords convicted by the international tribunal. The intimation is that former dictator Hideki Tojo and six others will be hanged within a few days.

Details of adapting the Advertising Council's basic advertisements on the free enterprise educational program for use by retailers has caused an approximate two-week postponement on issuance of material for newspapers' participation in the campaign, it was learned yesterday.

Three of the city's larger savings banks announced plans yesterday to increase their dividend rate from 1 1/2 to 2 per cent a year. The action, by Greenwich Savings Bank, Dry Dock Savings Institution and the Union Dime Savings Bank, may mark the beginning of a series of such announcements by the larger savings banks, according to financial observers.
SEOUL, Korea, Dec. 21 (UP) -The Agriculture Ministry announced Cabinet approval today of a program designed to redistribute farm land among small farmers.

After small declines in early trading, coffee futures on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange steadied. Demand from Brazilian interests strengthened the market. Profit taking and scattered hedging provided the selling. Contract "D" advanced 12 to 27 points.

AMMAN, the Trans-Jordan, Dec. 21 -- While the Arab League is using all means of pressure to persuade King Abdullah to renounce the idea of uniting Trans-Jordan with Arab Palestine, the Trans-Jordan ruler is going quietly ahead with his plans.
The police intensified their search yesterday for a 15-year-old Bronx girl, daughter of the commanding officer of the 105th Artillery, New York National Guard, who has been missing since Dec. 6.

Those who can stand the cold and would like to get some duck shooting before the northern areas close can get some excellent broad-bill shooting and an opportunity to pick up an occasional big red-leg black along the Rhode Island shore.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 (AP) -Senator Ralph E. Flanders, Republican, of Vermont, endorsed today a decision by Economic Cooperation Administrator Paul G. Hoffman to waive temporarily a requirement that 50 per cent of foreign aid shipments move in American ships.

LUCEDALE, Miss., Dec. 21 (UP) -- A grandmother, her daughter and granddaughter, and a county Sheriff were killed by shotgun blasts here tonight and angry townspeople turned out by the hundreds to search for the grandfather, missing since the shooting.

Because a grand jury had not completed its inquiry, hearings for six persons accused of helping to "rig" illegal divorce actions in New York County were postponed until Jan. 24 by Magistrate Ambrose J. Haddock in Felony Court yesterday.

PARIS, Dec. 21 -- Marcel Peyrouton, former Vichy Minister of Interior, on trial before the High Court of Justice, today gave backstage details of his arrest in Vichy on Dec. 13, 1940, of Pierre Laval, former Vichy Chief of Government.

Netherlands Foreign Minister Dirk U. Stikker, in a statement released here yesterday, told the people of the United States that the Dutch military action in Indonesia had been taken in the name of ultimate Indonesian freedom.

Birds for the Christmas table -turkey, goose, duck and chicken -are higher in price now than they were last Friday. Small turkeys, for example, were 75 to 89 cents a pound, a week ago. Today chain stores offer them for 79 to 85 cents a pound, and in some shops the tariff is as high as 98 cents.
BATAVIA, Wednesday, Dec. 22 (AP) -- The Dutch announced today the capture of Surakarta, the second largest city of the Indonesian Republic.

Now that the peak of the Christmas shopping is upon us, there are strange things afoot in the town. Not the ringing of bells by Santa Claus at the corners, nor the red and green and the lighted trees, nor the unimaginable gifts in the store windows, nor even the last-minute husbands and fathers scurrying about with lists in their hands bundles in their arms and desperation in their faces.

CAIRO, Dec. 21 -- The Arab League today championed the Indonesian Republic by cabling an appeal to the Security Council to order the Netherlands to halt military operations and relaying to its member states an Indonesian appeal to recognize the Republic and intervene to "halt Dutch aggression."
A gift in memory of three American airmen killed while flying over Germany in World War-II was made yesterday to the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

The principle that funds appropriated for housing may under certain circumstances be used for other purposes was upheld yesterday by the City Council when it approved without deletions the city's $323,500,151 capital budget.

PARIS, Dec. 21 -- It is now abundantly clear that France is supporting the Italian effort to resume authority over at least part of Rome's former African empire by devising a compromise formula acceptable to London and Washington and satisfactory to Rome.

" Paisan," Roberto Rosselini's Italian-made war drama, now in its thirty-ninth week at the World Theatre, has been voted the best picture of the year in the twentythird annual poll conducted by the National Board of Review of Motion Pictures, it was announced yesterday.
SOFIA, Bulgaria, Dec. 21 (Reuters) -- Bulgarian Premier Georgi Dimitrov has called for closer coordination of the work of the Communist parties in all countries under Soviet leadership.

Dec. 21 -- An agreement in principle on all points under discussion was reached today by the six power conference that has been engaged for six weeks in creating an international authority to oversee the industries of the Ruhr.

SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, Dec. 21 -- A note of savagery entered into the twelfth day of the reported invasion of Costa Rica today. The Government issued a report that a Red Cross party had been slaughtered by the "invaders" on a farm near La Cruz last night.

The City Council abandoned yesterday its attempt to find a formula whereby hotel room rents would be based upon the assessed valuation of the property and the amount and nature of the landlord's investment.

With headlight glare rated by the American Automobile Association as the No. 1 Enemy in night driving, data gathered yesterday indicated that in post-war automotive construction virtually nothing has been done to eliminate this menace.

ROME, Dec. 21 -- The 500th ship carrying European Recovery Program goods to Italy arrived in Naples today. It was a former Liberty ship now flying the Italian flag and renamed the Punta Alice. The cargo was 10,000 tons of coal that will be distributed to small industries and civilian consumers in the Naples area.

Badly buffeted by high seas but eager to build their lives anew in this country, 549 displaced persons from American-sponsored camps in Europe arrived here yesterday afternoon aboard the United States Maritime Commission ship Marine Flasher.

LONDON, Dec. 21 -- The tribunal of inquiry into allegations of fraud at the Board of Trade concluded its public hearings today. All Government and civil service officials, most members of the Opposition and all citizens who have the good name of their country at heart are undoubtedly sighing with relief tonight that it is over.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 -- The Federal Government moved one step further today in its battle to control the oil lands beneath the marginal sea. Attorney General Tom C. Clark filed suit in the Supreme Court to assure Federal jurisdiction over the "tidelands" off the Texas and Louisiana coasts.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 -- Suspension of the reconstruction and replacement program for China, for which $70,000,000 had been earmarked by the Economic Cooperation Administration, was announced today by Administrator Paul G. Hoffman after a conference with President Truman.

Despite the disclosure that Laurence Duggan was "mentioned" in the espionage inquiry, the Federal grand jury confined its investigation yesterday to the original charges of Whittaker Chambers that Alger Hiss had supplied to him restricted Government documents.

Declaring that the recession in the men's clothing industry has been "unduly exaggerated, and does not represent a continuing trend," Michael Daroff, president of H. Daroff Sons, Inc., reported yesterday that his company was sold up until June, 1949.
CHICAGO, Dec. 21 (AP) -- The Cudahy Packing Company, meat packer and food processor, reported today for 1948 a net income of $1,012,737, against $7,121,707 a year earlier.

I was disturbed by the announced inability of the private hospitals to provide internes on their ambulances. It seems to me that the problem of proper safeguarding of lives must be met more forcibly than waiting until "just as soon as sufficient doctors are available." Why would it not be possible to use senior or junior medical students on the ambulances?

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 -- The National Planning Association expressed concern today that the American people might lose sight of the "ultimate aims" of foreign policy and thus open the way for "temporary bargains and alliances that will advertise the uncertainty of our course."

NEW DELHI, India, Dec. 21 -United States relations with India are soon to be formalized on a treaty basis, Loy W. Henderson, new Ambassador to India, said today in his first press conference here. He added that representatives of both Governments were awaiting final instructions for the conclusion of a treaty of commerce and friendship and that the associations of the two nations "already rest upon a sound basis."

LONDON, Dec. 21 -- Criticism of the British Government's defense policies has grown steadily in political press circles here in the last four weeks. This criticism is now accompanied by speculation that Prime Minister Attlee is planning a major reshuffle of his Cabinet that will affect specifically Ministers of Defense and the three fighting services.

Metal lamp producers will increase wholesale prices 5 to 15 per cent on Jan. 1, Murray Drexler, president of the Arrow Lamp Company and former head of the National Lamp and Shade Manufacturers Association, declared yesterday.

PEIPING, Dec. 21 -- Outside Peiping's east gate a village was being demolished today so that the Communists approaching from the east could have no cover and so that the Nationalists defending the city from the wall could see their targets.

Midnight mass on Christmas Eve in St. Patrick's Cathedral, to be celebrated by Francis Cardinal Spellman, will be televised this year for the first time, the Most Rev Joseph F. Flannelly, Auxiliary Bishop of New York and administrator of the cathedral, announced yesterday.

ALBANY, Dec. 21 -- A five-point legislative program that would bring state assistance to schools to $235,700,000 in the next school year, compared with the present outlay of $154,100,000, was proposed today by the Board of Regents.
MONTREAL, Dec. 21 (Canadian Press) Charlie Conacher's rampaging Chicago Black Hawks continued their merry scoring ways in the National Hockey League last week counting 12 goals in two games.

Mayor O'Dwyer and the Board of Higher Education are being petitioned to see that "no loss in salary is sustained" by ninetythree provisional clerks employed in the four municipal colleges who are due to suffer sharp decreases in pay when they are appointed in January on a permanent basis, it was learned yesterday.

ALBANY, Dec. 21 -- Governor Dewey continued today a series of conferences with state Republican leaders begun yesterday for consideration of the future organization of the state Republican party and the state committee.

CHICAGO, Dec. 21 -- Executives of the sixteen non-operating railroad unions said today that the report of the Presidential FactFinding Board could be used as a basis for further wage and hour negotiations.

The National Council of American Importers has just announced that it will "strongly support" the proposed International Trade Organization, the charter for which was signed at Havana last March by representatives of fifty-three nations. This is the first action of the kind to be taken by any foreign trade group in this country.

PARIS, Dec. 21 -- Paul Reynaud, former Minister of Finance and wartime Premier, in one of the most notable speeches of the long budget debate, told the National Assembly today that the essential question at stake was to see that "France can stand on her feet when the Marshall Plan comes to an end."

MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 21 (AP) -- Hialeah Park's $50,000 added Flamingo stakes, Florida's mile-and-afurlong feature for 3-year-olds, has attracted 71 thoroughbreds, each hopeful of following in the hoofprints Citation.

Wider distribution of larger and more carefully planned Christmas mail-order catalogues by more department and specialty stores this year than in recent years has brought disappointing results in most cases, it was learned here last week.
CANNES, France, Dec. 21 (UP) -The Foreign Ministers of France and Italy announced today they had agreed that closer FrancoItalian collaboration was "a necessary basis for a European organization."

CLEVELAND, Dec. 21 (AP) -- A pair of All-America halfbacks, Doak Walker of Southern Methodist and Bobby Jack Stuart of Army, were drafted by the league champion Cleveland Browns at today's fourth annual auction of football talent in the All-America Conference.

Being of necessity resigned to the usually unerring laws of migration, I had settled down to get what comfort one may have in watching and feeding the winter birds when I was startled only yesterday to see what I took at first glance to be a rosy apparition. Looking again, I found myself staring wide-eyed at a plump and certainly bona fide robin.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 -- The President's Committee on Guidance and Welfare for the Armed Forces ended a two-day meeting at the Pentagon today after having heard more than thirty witnesses discuss the problem of providing adequately for the social, moral and spiritual life in the off-duty hours of the newly enlisted man.

" The Dark Past," a Columbia melodrama based on the play, "Blind Alley," and featuring William Holden, Lee J. Cobb and Nina Foch, will have its local premiere this morning at the Ambassador. Rudolph Mate directed and Buddy Adler produced from a screen play by Philip MacDonald, Michael Blankfort and Albert Duffy and an adaptation by Malvin Ward and Oscar Saul.

Published stories recently about New York City divorces might lead decent citizens to believe that a new scandal has come out -- that our courts, judges and law-enforcement agencies have suddenly gone to pot. The Richard H. Wels letter, which you published, added fuel to the flame of public indignation.

Individual manufacturers of apparel and textiles will be invited to express their opinion on the progress of unified buying by the armed forces, according to trade association executives who attended a meeting sponsored by the Munitions Board at the Yale Club yesterday.

LA JOLLA, Calif., Dec. 21 (UP) -- Mrs. Patricia Canning Todd, National and Wightman Cup tennis star, today described officials of the United States Lawn Tennis Association as "doddering old fogies," because she was dropped from fourth to sixth place in the annual rankings.

Re-examination by the United States and other American governments of the policy officially adopted at the Bogota Conference, which provides for recognition of any government that appears to have de facto control of a country, suggests that we are moving toward reversal of a cynical doctrine.

PARIS, Dec. 21 -- Dr. Philip C. Jessup, acting United States representative, will ask the United Nations Security Council tomorrow to call on the Netherlands to agree to an immediate cease-fire in Indonesia, authorized sources said tonight.

CHICAGO, Dec. 21 -- Grain markets advanced sharply on the Board of Trade today under the leadership of wheat and soy beans, and closing trades were about the top. Wheat gained 1 1/2 to 2 1/8 cents, December leading, and soy beans rose 3 to 5 cents.

The Sons of Liberty Boycott Committee, a group critical of England's Palestine policy, announced yesterday the termination of its campaign, begun last June, against the showing of British motion pictures in this country.
LONDON, Dec. 21 -- Britain's adverse balance of trade continued at imposing levels last month, the Board of Trade conceded today.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 21 (AP) -A fire in a Philadelphia hotel early today trapped and killed a 51-yearold man and a 73-year-old woman. Two other guests and a fireman were burned; ninety-five persons fled to safety.

John Donald Walker, a 47-year old swindler who specialized in marrying well-to-do women and fleecing them, began serving yesterday a ten-year sentence imposed on him late Monday night when a Federal Court jury found him guilty of defrauding one of the women of more than $50,000.
TEL AVIV, Israel, Dec. 21 -- The "Voice of Israel" will broadcast the Christmas Eve service from the Church of the Annunciation in Nazareth, an Israeli Government spokesman announced today.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 -- The State Department today condemned as "deplorable" the use of military force in Latin America for overthrowing popularly elected and constitutional governments.

SHANGHAI, Wednesday, Dec. 22 -- Chinese National Airlines said today a rescue party had identified the body of Quentin Roosevelt, grandson of President Theodore Roosevelt, among those killed in a plane crash near Hong Kong yesterday.

The board of directors of the Associated Fur Manufacturers, Inc., declined immediate comment yesterday on an Appellate Division decision directing arbitration of the issues involved in a $5,000,000 damage suit brought by the association against the Furriers Joint Council, CIO.

A substantial number of liquor stores and night clubs, financed by gangsters, racketeers and black marketeers who are using ex-servicemen as "fronts" to obtain licenses, have been springing up since the end of the war in various parts of New York State.

A plan to coordinate the acitivities of all city departments and agencies at the scene of a disaster has been formulated by the Mayor's Board of Planning and Operations, it became known yesterday. The proposals are for an emergency endangering the life or health of a large number of persons.

Harvard's players yesterday lost the championship of the College Chess League and custody of the Belden-Stephens Trophy when their captain, Julian J. Leavitt of Brookline, was defeated in the adjourned game from the first round by Joseph Faucher of Garden City, L.I., No. 1 player for Princeton at the Marshall Chess Club.

Lessing J. Rosenwald, president of the American Council for Judaism, urged last night that the United States Government insist as a condition of American friendship that Israel promote Israeli and not "Jewish" nationalism there.

PARIS, Dec. 21 -- The executive committee of the European Council for the Marshall Plan and the council itself will both meet tomorrow to prepare the final program for the year 1949-50 and a "progress report" on the unfinished four-year plan to be submitted to the United States officials.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 (Science Service) -- Three Yale School of Medicine scientists report a blood test that spots cancer in 75 per cent of the cases. It may prove valuable in detecting cancer before it shows clinical signs, just as X-ray photographs can discover early tuberculosis.

The solution to almost any homemaking problem -- including how to make husbands handy in the kitchen -- may be found in new courses to begin in various schools next month. Registration for some of the classes is open now, while catalogues for others are to be ready soon so that homemakers may plan their programs.

GENEVA, Dec. 17 -- Paul G. Hoffman's threat to suspend enforcement of the clause in the Economic Cooperation Act requiring 50 per cent of bulk cargoes to be carried in United States ships is regarded in Europe as potentially one of the most courageous and positive steps the Economic Cooperation Administration has taken to promote European recovery.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 (AP) -The text of the State Department's statement follows:

Two museums will open to the public today exhibitions of work by well-know contemporary American artists. The Museum of Modern Art has placed on view in its third-floor galleries more than 150 examples of American oils and water-colors by 115 artists -- about half of the institution's permanent collection in this field.

School districts in Louisiana and California announced yesterday bidding dates for bond issues totalling $15,966,000. On Jan. 19, East Baton Rouge Parish, La., Consolidated School District No. 1 will take bids on $8,000,000 of bonds maturing from 1950 to 1968.

It is so difficult for many young conductors to get a start in this country that many have found that, if they want to show what they can do, they have to organize orchestras of their own. One of the latest to take this step is Frank Brieff and last night he introduced the Frank Brieff Chamber Orchestra at Town Hall.

Norman Mager tapped in a rebound just three seconds before the final buzzer to give City College a thrilling 53-51 triumph over Oklahoma last night at Madison Square Garden. The victory of the Beavers made it a clean sweep for the locals over Big Seven rivals, St. John's having routed Iowa State, 71 -- 47, in the opener.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 -- Development of an automatic pilot capable of flying large transport planes in the "most unfavorable" weather was announced today by the Navy.

The Brooklyn Football Dodgers of the All-America Conference announced yesterday that they had signed Lou Kusserow, high-scoring Columbia fullback, to a 1949 contract. Terms were not divulged. The Dodgers acquired exclusive dealing rights with Kusserow within the conference by naming him in the secret draft held by the eight member clubs last summer.
MOSCOW, Dec. 21 -- Today is Premier Stalin's sixty-ninth birthday.

BERLIN, Dec. 21 -- The Western Military Governments today announced formal reconstitution of the Allied Kommandatura on a three-power basis. In announcing the move Brig. Gen. Jean Ganeval, French sector Commandant, said that four-party administration of the city could be resumed any time that Soviet authorities decided to abide by agreements to which the four powers are committed.

The main sections of the stock market continued to move over an irregular and narrow course yesterday, with some reinvestment demand in evidence. Tax selling was on a reduced scale and activity centered in low-price issues which accounted for a slight expansion in business.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 -- American business "has presented a better case for high profits than I expected," Senator Ralph E. Flanders, Republican, of Vermont, said today. He added, however, that he did not know whether he would retain this idea after he had the opportunity to peruse more thoroughly testimony on the profits issue.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Dec. 21 -- Prime Minister Joseph B. Chifley announced in Canberra after a Cabinet meeting today that Australia would seek an immediate cessation of hostilities in Indonesia and a return of Dutch forces to the lines held before the renewal of fighting.
The Police Department will mark the Yule season in several ways today with the aid of Commissioner Arthur W. Wallander.

Railroad officials, rebutting travelers' testimony about black marketing in Pullman space, asserted yesterday that most of the trouble stemmed from a growing insistence by the train-riding public upon de luxe accommodations.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 -- Representative J. Parnell Thomas failed today in an attempt to obtain dismissal of his indictment on charges of conspiracy and fraud.

Magistrate John A. Dwyer had before him in Flatbush Court yesterday the complaint of a mother of eleven children, as tenant, against a landlord, a disabled veteran, who bought the house in question for his own use. Magistrate Dwyer sped the case on to the Court of Special Sessions, for trial.

The ill feeling between the Port in New York Authority and the eight airlines forming the Airport Leaseholders Committee broke into the open again yesterday with an exchange of charges and counter-charges.

Senator-elect Margaret Chase Smith of Maine and the eight women elected to the House of Representatives in the Eighty-first Congress will be honored by a special trainload of eminent women scheduled to arrive in Washington on Jan. 2, it was announced here yesterday.

BERLIN, Dec. 21 -- The Western Military Governments today announced formal reconstitution of the Allied Kommandatura on a three-power basis. In announcing the move Brig. Gen. Jean Ganeval, French sector Commandant, said that four-party administration of the city could be resumed any time that Soviet authorities decided to abide by agreements to which the four powers are committed.

Railroad officials, rebutting travelers' testimony about black marketing in Pullman space, asserted yesterday that most of the trouble stemmed from a growing insistence by the train-riding public upon de luxe accommodations.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 -- Representative J. Parnell Thomas failed today in an attempt to obtain dismissal of his indictment on charges of conspiracy and fraud.

Magistrate John A. Dwyer had before him in Flatbush Court yesterday the complaint of a mother of eleven children, as tenant, against a landlord, a disabled veteran, who bought the house in question for his own use. Magistrate Dwyer sped the case on to the Court of Special Sessions, for trial.

The ill feeling between the Port in New York Authority and the eight airlines forming the Airport Leaseholders Committee broke into the open again yesterday with an exchange of charges and counter-charges.

Senator-elect Margaret Chase Smith of Maine and the eight women elected to the House of Representatives in the Eighty-first Congress will be honored by a special trainload of eminent women scheduled to arrive in Washington on Jan. 2, it was announced here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 -- The St. Lawrence Seaway can be expected to carry 57,000,000 to 84,000,000 tons of cargo a year, a special Department of Commerce report to the Senate Judiciary watchdog committee on the project stated today.

Russeks Fifth Avenue will distribute year-end bonuses totaling about $150,000 to employes of its New York, Brooklyn and Chicago stores, it was announced yesterday. Every regular employe with the organization two months or longer will share in the distribution.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 -- Pay rises early in the new year for every high executive official of the Government, from President Truman down, became a strong possibility today.

Cardinal Spellman of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York announced yesterday the elevation in rank of several priests by Pope Pius XII. According to word from the Vatican through the Apostolic Delegate the following have been honored with the indicated rank:

Dr. Ernest A. Opacity of Duismere, Calif. has purchased the six-story building with elevator at 131-33 East Seventieth Street from Grosvenor Atterbury, the architect, in whose family it had been held for more than fifty years. The buyer plans to alter it into professional suites.

Hideki Tojo, chief of the Japanese war criminals executed yesterday, whose first name means "brilliant opportunity" and whose countrymen frequently referred to him as "The Razor," was the first military officer on the active list to head his Government.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 -- President Truman hinted broadly weeks ago that he wanted inaugural costs kept down to make the celebration "truly democratic," but it is already apparent that more than $300,000 will be spent on the celebration.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows, the Federal Reserve Board announced today, the following principal changes for the week ended Dec. 15:

AUBURN, N.Y., Dec. 22 (AP) -- Children of SS. Peter and Paul Parochial School made a bonfire of comic books that dealt with crime and sex yesterday. They collected the books from their homes and from the homes of neighbors.

In these times when many hopes seem frustrated, and when the peace that everyone is anxiously waiting for still seems far from fulfillment, there will be thoughtful persons who will want to give some special meaning to Christmas. A ready-made opportunity is near at hand.

BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 22 -- Senator Dennis Chavez of New Mexico said this morning in summing up his impressions of Argentina after more than two weeks here that he did not think "things are as bad as intimated in many quarters, including Argentina."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 (AP) -- Jack W. Bain, trial examiner in a proceeding of the Department of Agriculture against Ralph W. Moore, a local commodity trader, asked the Secretary of Agriculture today to clarify his authority. He reported that he had denied a plea for dismissal of the proceeding on Aug. 31 and later had rejected a motion "to certify" the case to the Secretary.

For some persons last Sunday's weather report read: Snow, followed by fair financial returns. Such was the case with the towing companies and tire chain retailers, fuel dealers and mitten manufacturers, and Leo Birdy, who is the proprietor of a shoe store at 122 Moore Street in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Dec. 22 (AP) -- The Kentucky basketball team maintained its perfect record by defeating Tulane, 51 -- 47, tonight and ran its victory streak to seven straight. The defeat was Tulane's first in nine games this season.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 (AP) -- An easing of the impact of foreign demand on the United States economy was reported by the Commerce Department today. Economic improvement abroad was coupled with a lessening of inflationary pressures at home.

With Christmas Eve coming up, market sentiment in the bond houses bears little resemblance to last year's December jitters which culminated in the Federal Reserve System dropping its support prices for Government bonds on the holiday eve.

LONDON, Dec. 22 -- Little response was seen in the stock market here today to good figures of exports and coal production, but prices generally held firm. Small buying fractionally raised quotations for British Government bonds while in the industrial section coal and coke-oven shares rose at favorable estimates.
On Jan. 17 this newspaper published a dispatch from its correspondent in The Hague which began with these words:
TOKYO, Dec. 22 (UP) -- Following is the official report from General MacArthur's Public Relations Office of the executions of the Japanese war lords:

The announcement that the 1,000,000th Bell System rural telephone to be added since the war has been installed in a North Carolina farmhouse calls to public attention the speed with which the Telephone Company has moved in recent years to extend and improve telephone service.

DENVER, Dec. 22 (AP) -- A punch on the chin which Jerry Rizzo, Syracuse player, gave Referee Ralph Fowler here Monday night resulted today in suspension of Rizzo from the National Professional Basketball League.

Although heavy Christmas food purchases began yesterday, retail grocers reported sales this week were off between 8 and 10 per cent as compared with holiday food sales last year. Although sales of fruit cake and plum puddings were reported to be strong and about as large as those of last year, other holiday items such as assorted nuts, fancy fruits and assorted chocolates were said to be off sharply this year.

The New York A.C. indoor polo team lost by 12 -- 9 to the Ramapo Polo Club in the feature of a double-header at the Squadron A Armory last night. Ramapo had a 6-to-0 lead early in the second period before Herb Pennell scored for the Winged Foot team.
Street traffic churned yesterday through slush, and festive crowds quickened their steps toward last-minute Christmas shopping, partying and traveling.

Shortly after 6 o'clock Monday evening Laurence Duggan, Director of the Institute of International Education and formerly a trusted adviser of the State Department on Latin-American affairs, fell, leaped or was pushed to his death from the window of his sixteenth-floor office in a building in West Forty-fifth Street.

Two important developments came yesterday in the case of Laurence Duggan, former State Department official who was found dead in the snow under his office window in West Forty-fifth Street at 7 P.M. last Monday.

The United States Television Manufacturing Corporation substantially reduced suggested list prices yesterday on two television receivers using fifteen-inch direct-view cathode ray tubes. The action is the first price cut by any television receiver producer.

Life being sad enough without brooding about it, the Theatre Guild is squiring a comedy with no social significance. It is John van Druten's "Make Way for Lucia," based on a series of English countryside novels by E.F. Benson. Acted with rare charm and style, Mr. van Druten's mannered drollery was put on at the Cort last evening.

TOKYO, Thursday, Dec. 23 -- Hideki Tojo, former dictator of Japan, and six of his most prominent collaborators in the war against the Allied powers, were hanged this morning at Sugamo Prison on the outskirts of Tokyo as criminals against international law.

CHICAGO, Dec. 22 -- Tucker Corporation, of which Preston Tucker is president, denied it is insolvent today in replying to two petitions filed against it by creditor groups under Federal bankruptcy laws. One, filed by three companies that asserted that Tucker owes them a total of $3,000, asked the court to place the corporation under involuntary bankruptcy proceedings.

There is good news out of London in the report that the Western six-nation conference has reached agreement in principle on all outstanding points dealing with the International Authority to control the Ruhr. This Authority, intended to harness the Ruhr to European recovery without permitting it to become the cradle of new aggression, was first agreed upon at a previous London conference last spring.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 -- Vice-President-elect Alben W. Barkley, departing by plane today to spend part of the Christmas season with American airlift pilots and the United States Army in Germany, appealed to fellow Americans to give all possible aid to the feeding and clothing of children in the occupied areas.

Jean Kerr's comedy about the domestic tribulations of a parish priest, "Jenny Kissed Me," will open tonight at 8:15 at the Hudson Theatre. Sponsored by James Russo, Michael Ellis and Alexander H. Cohen in association with Clarence M. Shapiro, the production stars Leo G. Carroll in the role of Father Moynihan.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Dec. 22 -- The standard of living in the Soviet Union is 40 per cent below that of Norway, according to a report of the Norwegian Federation of Labor committee that has just returned from a visit to that country.

Pre-Christmas entertaining for debutantes of the season was continued yesterday with a round of parties drawing as guests the majority of young women who are making their debuts this winter and many of their friends who are now at home from finishing schools and colleges for the holiday recess.

A full-dress report on the recent United Nations General Assembly in Paris was delivered last night by John Foster Dulles acting chairman of the united States delegation, in a nation-wide radio broadcast. Mr. Dulles characterized the session as a productive one, and the theme throughout his speech was that the threat of war had been lessened, rather than increased, by the events in Paris.
The stock market operated within such a narrow channel yesterday that results were meaningless. But while fluctuations were small, trading was fairly active.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Dec. 22 -- Establishment of the three-power Kommandatura in Berlin is regarded here as a testing ground for cooperation among the United States, France and Britain for governing all of West Germany. A three-power military government organization on the old control council style is presently being fashioned by working parties but most of the discussion already has reached the top levels for decision.

The city will wait until the 1950 session of the Legislature before asking for a constitutional amendment permitting it to borrow $500,000,000 outside its debt limit to finance construction of a Second Avenue subway and the connections required to link it with other lines of the municipal transit system, Mayor O'Dwyer declared yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 -- The Missouri Pacific Railroad Company today renewed its plea to the Interstate Commerce Commission that recognition be accorded the holders of the company's common stock in view of the increased revenues anticipated from the expansion of the citrus and chemicals industry in the Southwest.

Traffic congestion clouds over New York and other large cities in this country have silver linings for British automotive manufacturers, Sir William Rootes, chairman of the Rootes Group of London and Coventry, England, said here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 -- The Civil Aeronautics Board today blamed the Civil Aeronautics Administration for a large share of responsibility for fires in two early Douglas DC-6 luxury airliners, one of which crashed, killing fifty-two persons.

TOKYO, Thursday, Dec. 23 -- Japanese sources, none of which wishes to be identified, today afforded a quite extensive glimpse behind the veil of secrecy that the United States Army threw around former Dictator Hideko Tojo and his fellow-war criminals in their last hours before their execution.

ALBANY, Dec. 22 -- Milo R. Maltbie, chairman of the State Public Service Commission and one of the leading experts on utility questions, has filed an application for retirement, effective Jan. 22. He is 77 years old.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 (AP) -- Carl A. Loeffler, Secretary of the Senate, will retire early next month after fifty-nine years' service in the upper chamber.

Marking the first action of its kind by the company in ten years, F. Jacobson Sons, Inc., one of the "big four" shirt manufacturers, authorized its retail dealers yesterday to participate in a nationwide 25 per cent price reduction sale on Jayson shirts and pajamas between Jan. 12 and Jan. 29.

ATHENS, Dec. 22 -- Reports from Western Macedonia tonight said that Edessa, an industrial town about twenty miles from the Yugoslav border and Naoussa, an agricultural community twelve miles to the south, had been subjected to an all-out attack by the Communist-led rebels.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 (AP) -- The Navy told today the story of a cabin boy killed by sharks when he fell overboard from a merchant ship in Cuban waters and how another cabin boy tried vainly to save him.

BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 22 -- President Juan Peron and members of his Cabinet met Foreign Minister Juan Bramuglia this morning when he debarked from the British ship Alcantara after an absence of nearly four months. The President threw his arms around Dr. Bramuglia in the traditional "abrazo" the moment he stepped ashore.

A large shopping center is planned for Paramus, N.J., where the National Suburban Centers, Inc., composed of a group of Boston investors, has contracted to purchase 193 acres from Mrs. August Hunziker and the Fisher estate.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 -- The Economic Cooperation Administration, with State Department concurrence, today suspended further Marshall Plan aid to Indonesia (Netherlands East Indies) pending "clarification" of the situation growing out of "police action by Netherlands authorities there.

"Classical Landscape with Figures," a commentary on ancient and modern Greece by Osbert Lancaster, will be published by Houghton Mifflin on Jan. 13. Described as "a personal travelogue in the Johnsonian manner," the text is accompanied by many illustrations in line and color drawn by the author.

The annual celebration of Christmas in the city's churches will get under way tomorrow when carols will be sung at the usual Christmas Eve services. The Christmas story will be heard again as it is read from Scriptures and sung by choirs and congregations.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 (AP) -- A new attempt to rescue eleven United States fliers marooned in sub-zero weather on a 7,500-foot ice cap in Greenland was reported imminent today.

BERLIN, Dec. 22 (AP) -- A Leipzig University professorship was reported today to have been given to Gerhart Eisler, the man the House un-American Activities Committee calls the No. 1 United States Communist.

Francis B. Sayre, formerly Alger Hiss' immediate superior in the State Department, was questioned yesterday before the Federal grand jury investigating espionage. After hearing Mr. Sayre, the grand jury adjourned for the Christmas and New Year holidays until Jan. 3, when it will resume hearing witnesses.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 22 -- Scheduled sailing of two passenger liners and four freighters from San Francisco was delayed today by members of the Sailors Union of the Pacific, an affiliate of the American Federation of Labor, who stayed in port to attend a late afternoon meeting.
CHICAGO, Dec. 22 (AP) -- Notre Dame outlasted Navy, 70 -- 62, for the fourth straight Irish victory tonight in the opener of a college basketball double-header before 8,627 at the Chicago Stadium.

The New York Knickerbockers muffled the thunder of the great George Mikan, uncovered a few secret weapons of their own and quite surprisingly romped to a 97-79 victory over the vaunted Minneapolis Lakers last night. The largest crowd of the local professional season -- 15,527 -- watched the Basketball Association of America contest at Madison Square Garden.
BLOCK ISLAND, R.I., Dec. 22 (AP) The 800 year-round inhabitants of this island, who buried their only physician this morning, got a new one late tonight.

The Queens County Jockey Club, which owns the Aqueduct race track in the Ozone Park section of Queens, has purchased an adjoining tract of twenty-five acres on the west of its property from the New York Water Service Corporation.
PARIS, Dec. 22 (UP) -- Following is the text of the statement today on Indonesia by Dr. Phillip C. Jessup, United States representative, before the United Nations Security Council:
The spirit of hearty, robust festivity that used to be an indivisible part of the Christmas season appears to be waning year after year, remarked the scholarly old gentleman in the easy chair.

Part of the increases in automobile insurance rates can be attributed to accidents caused by illegal headlight glare on the highways, it was learned yesterday. The cost is shared by innocent as well as guilty drivers.

President Truman began to gain early in the last campaign if the attitudes of 1,029 residents of Elmira, N.Y., reflect national attitudes, according to findings announced yesterday by Columbia University's Bureau of Applied Social Research in cooperation with Cornell and Chicago Universities.

IT was a pleasure to see all the characters from the year's books at Walgrove Snood and Kim Carruthers' early Christmas party. They had given enjoyment, enlightenment and occasional touches of gout to thousands of readers from Campobello to Santa Fe. Many of the fictitious men and women by now seemed more real than the living authors among them.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 -- Married women workers in the United States considerably outnumber single women workers, a reverse of the pre-war condition, the Census Bureau said today in a report on a survey made in April.

An immensely long and none too well chosen list of American piano music was played, turn by turn, by six pianists last night in the New York Times Hall. The occasion was a benefit concert to purchase manuscripts of Louis Moreau Gottschalk for the American Music Collection of the New York Public Library.

William J. Erwin, vice president of J.P. Stevens Co., will become vice president and director of the Riegel Textile Corporation and general manager of the company's division at Ware Shoals, S.C., effective Jan. 17, it was announced yesterday.
A comprehensive Board of Education program to improve school facilities on the west side of Manhattan at an estimated cost of $15,000,000 got under way yesterday.

Boston, Mass., borrowed $5,000,000 on temporary loan notes yesterday at 1.02 per cent interest plus a premium of $132. The issue, which was dated Dec. 31, 1948, and will come due Oct 20, 1949, was sold to Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc. The notes were reoffered at a price to yield 0.95 per cent.

ALBANY, Dec. 22 -- Actual construction in 1949 of new institutions as part of the State University was forecast today as the university trustees conferred with Governor Dewey about the progress on the program they are charting to expand greatly the state's higher educational facilities.

Police Commissioner Arthur W. Wallander presided yesterday at a Christmas promotion of 103 detectives, fifty-one civilian employes and other members of the department. The ceremony was held in the gymnasium -- more commonly known as the "line-up" room -- at police headquarters.

BOSTON, Dec. 22 (AP) -- With Eddie Sandford scoring twice, the Boston Bruins broke a six-game winless streak by topping the crippled Detroit Red Wings, 5 -- 2, tonight before a crowd of 13,000 at the Boston Garden. The decision enabled the Bruins to shave the visitors' National Hockey League lead to only a point.
PARIS, Dec. 22 -- The European report to the United States on the Marshall Plan is expected to accept the probability of a dollar deficit of $1,500,000,000 in 1952 when American aid is to terminate.
