Kerstin Bernadotte, whose marriage three years ago to Prince Carl Johan of Sweden resulted in the latter's giving up his right of succession to the Swedish throne, was taken to Roosevelt Hospital early yesterday morning suffering from an overdose of sleeping pills.
William White, president of the Delaware, Lackawanna Western Railroad Company since 1941, was elected yesterday a director of the New York Telephone Company to fill a vacancy on the board.

The Amalgamated Clothing Workers, CIO, decided yesterday to allocate $1,000,000 from the union treasury as an "initial" expenditure in its drive to organize department store workers in New York and other large cities.

CAIRO, Egypt, Dec. 22 -- In spite of all the attention that has been devoted to international efforts to care for Palestinian refugees, 90 per cent of the relief they have received to date has come from Arab sources, private and public, Sir Raphael Cilento, director of the United Nations Disaster Relief Organization, said today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22--Of all the ties that bind Americans to the peoples of other lands, probably none is stouter than our link with the Dutch. For this reason alone the Government of the United States has little relish for the steps of disapproval it has felt constrained to take toward the Netherlands' "police action" in Indonesia, and for the more drastic steps that have been suggested if these are fruitless.

Four persons, who have made a study of the problem of Europe's displaced persons and the advisability of their entry into the United States, discussed that question last night during a forum of THE NEW YORK TIMES, "What's on Your Mind?" over station WQXR.

The American farmer has a Christmas present in store for the American housewife, one that will be well appreciated -- the end of the meat shortage that has plagued the shopper and sabotaged the family budget since early in the war.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 -- A decreasing foreign demand on the American economy was indicated in the third quarter of this year by a decrease in the net exports of goods and services, the office of business economics of the Department of Commerce announced today.

CHICAGO, Dec. 22 -- Evening; up in December contracts proceeded in an orderly manner in the early trading today on the Board of Trade, but a last-minute rush of short covering carried prices up drastically, wheat and oats selling at new highs since Feb. 4.

The city's 1949 capital budget, calling for $323,500,151 in outlays for improvements of a permanent nature, has been approved by the City Council. The Council's power is limited to striking out budget lines and it resisted several efforts toward such deletions, endorsing the work of the Board of Estimate.
NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 22 (AP) -- Santa Claus arrived early for holders of tickets on today's daily daily double at the Fair Grounds, the combination paying $1,010.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 22 -- Charles Custis Harrison Jr., founder of the local investment firm of Harrison Co. and member of a family long identified with the University of Pennsylvania, died today at The Plains, Va. He was 71 years old.

Low-end dress manufacturers seeking to liquidate piece goods inventories have cut prices on a limited number of styles by $1 and $2 a garment, it was noted yesterday. Buyers seeking promotional merchandise said they had been able to make satisfactory deals on dresses to be made up for nearby delivery.
CHICAGO, Dec. 22 -- Albert K. Epstein, the consulting chemical engineer, who died today in Tel Aviv, lived at 6715 Oglesby Avenue, this city.

The United States Smelting, Refining and Mining Company, in an estimate for the first eleven months of this year, reported yesterday a consolidated net profit of $4,020,756, equal to $4.76 a share on 528,765 shares of common stock outstanding.

PARIS, Thursday, Dec. 23 -- In an early morning session of the Finance Committee of the National Assembly, it adopted by a vote of 22 to 14 the revised text of the budget measure. The revised bill contained the essential item of a compromise raising the tax on production.

In this black hour for China, what can we do to help? The answer on the military and political side lies with the Chiefs of Staff and the Department of State. On the human relations side, there is something that we can do immediately that, in the years to come, may assure us of a friendly, understanding government in China.

Immediate and large-scale United States military aid to China to check the "very serious" advance of communism there and eventually throughout all Asia was urged yesterday by Dr. Tsingfu F. Tsiang, China's chief delegate to the United Nations.
The present high cost of a quart of milk is not only disturbing consumers but is also perplexing milk dealers.

ALBANY, Dec. 22 -- The Kings County Lighting Company, which supplies gas to 114,000 Brooklyn consumers, received authority from the Public Service Commission today to file new tariff schedules providing for an additional interim gas rate increase amounting to $376,500 a year.

Since ashtrays are a "must" on virtually every table in the living room, they should be good to look at as well as to use. Bright enameled pieces, as easy to clean as glass, come in rich colors hard to duplicate and in a variety of designs.

LONDON, Dec. 22 -- A special plea to concentrate upon the United States and other dollar markets was made to British exporters tonight by Sir Stafford Cripps, Chancellor of the Exchequer and Minister for Economic Affairs.

Proposals by the State Board of Regents to increase state aid to education by $41,600,000 were attacked as inadequate yesterday by the Joint Committee of Teachers Organizations and the United Parents Associations.
For those who can take the icy blasts and heaving sea there are enough codfish off shore to last the man with an empty barrel and some salt for the rest of the winter.

An appeal for "Christmas gifts of life" for 3-year-old Susanna Giardina has resulted in thirty donations of blood and more than seventy pledges of additional donations, the American Red Cross announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 (AP) -- James Forrestal, Secretary of Defense, said tonight that he was convinced that Air Force intelligence was not responsible for an erroneous intelligence estimate which produced a war scare last spring.

Edgar Bergen may not be retiring from the radio, after all. The comedian admitted last night, according to The United Press, that he was discussing terms with the Columbia Broadcasting System and that only a few details remained to be ironed out before an agreement might be reached.

Fire Commissioner Frank J. Quayle passed out Christmas cheer yesterday in the ranks of the Fire Department when promotions to become effective on Jan. 1 were granted to twenty men. The promotions, all from civil serevice lists, will mean increases in salary.

PARIS, Dec. 22 -- Excerpts from the statements of the Netherlands delegate, Dr. Jan Herman van Royen, and of Dr. L.M. Palar, Indonesian Republic representative, before the Security Council today, follow:

With the peace movement between the National Football League and the All-America Conference at a temporary standstill, Ted Collins went ahead yesterday with plans to transfer his Boston Yanks to the Polo Grounds.

The infant art of baby-sitting was raised to academic status here yesterday when twelve students of Girls High School in Brooklyn were graduated as certified "sitters." Seven other qualified students could not attend the ceremonies; they were minding babies.

In the editorial entitled "Fifteen Years After" in THE TIMES recently you accuse national prohibition of having been responsible for evils which were due not so much to the law as they were to human frailty. According to this oft-repeated charge, prohibition did nothing to improve the moral and economic welfare of the American people.

I.J. Fox will be the first to retail on a national scale Spring squirrel jackets and capes made by the new Nierenberg cutting process, it was announced here yesterday. It was indicated that savings derived through use of the cutting process, invented by Lou Nierenberg, fur manufacturer here, will permit substantially lower retail prices.

PARIS, Dec. 22 -- For the first time since its creation to try former Vichy officials the French High Court of Justice today delivered a verdict of simple acquittal in the treason case of Marcel Peyrouton, first Minister of Interior at Vichy.

Talks are to be resumed this morning between tugboat workers and operators, after a forty-eight-hour recess to permit the employers to formulate a set of written counter-proposals to the demands submitted by Local 333, United Marine Division, on Nov. 29.
PASADENA, Calif., Dec. 22 (AP) -- The Northwestern football team looked as dreary as the weather today in a workout for the Rose Bowl clash with California.
CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 22 (AP) -- Logan Batcheller, 19-year-old apprentice jockey, today rode four winners at Tropical Park and finished in the money in six of eight races.

A survey of 166 business organizations in New York shows that most guarantee a specified number of holidays with pay each year to office employes, according to a report yesterday by the New York Personnel Management Association.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 -- A protective committee for stockholders of the Central Railroad Company of New Jersey and the Inter-Municipal Group for Better Rail Service and the Jersey Shore Protective Committee filed today with the Interstate Commerce Commission exceptions to proposals of a commission examiner that the plan of the Jersey Central for the voluntary modification of its securities be approved.

A large-scale program to increase effectiveness or cooperative advertising through establishment of closer, more realistic relationships between manufacturers and retailers is being developed by a major advertising organization, it was learned yesterday.

The diamonds and gold jewelry that persons now on relief once bought as an investment of wealth failed them yesterday in their poverty. At a sale conducted by the Department of Purchase, more than 200 items surrendered by destitute men and women to the Department of Welfare netted less than $1,000 in cash.
SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 22 (AP) -- Football stars from the East and West buckled down to twice-a-day practice today for the Shriners Crippled Children's Hospital charity game New Year's Day.

Many of the 116 local hospitals, health and welfare institutions affiliated with the Federation of Jewish Philanthropies "will be forced to curtail certain urgently needed aspects of their medical and social service work" if the organization's campaign goal of $16,500,000 is not met, 12,000 volunteers were warned yesterday.

"Every Girl Should Be Married," which opens at the Capitol, is this morning's lone film newcomer. Cary Grant is starred in the RKO romantic comedy, which was produced, directed and co-written by Don Hartman. Stephen Morehouse Avery collaborated on the screen play.

The best skiing still remains in the Poconos of northeastern Pennsylvania and in an area within 100 miles of metropolitan New York while upper New York State and New England can find solace in the "threat" or "possibility," as the Weather Bureau said, of much-looked-for snow falling on Christmas Day or the day after.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 22 (AP) -- Eddie Lerner's field goal and foul in the last 35 seconds of play gave Temple University a 51-50 victory over Colorado tonight in the opener of the college basketball doubleheader at Convention Hall before 2,839.

RAMALLAH, Palestine, Dec. 22 -- United Nations truce observers, working in this Arab area, have begun their own small relief project which provides hot meals daily for sixty small, hungry Arab refugees. One United States captain has gone farther and adopted a small girl who reminds him of his daughters at home.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 -- Under-Secretary of State Robert A. Lovett gave the press today what was generally regarded as a mystifying clarification of United States policy on China.

Cottonseed oil futures on the New York Produce Exchange were active and mixed yesterday. Prices closed weaker, with declines of 10 to 25 points. Final prices were at the day's lowest levels. The crude oil market was barely steady in the South, with demands limited.
Better than normal refuse collections were achieved yesterday by the Sanitation Department as it worked away at the accumulated backlog while continuing to remove last Sunday's 19.6-inch snow.

A business agent for the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers, Local 3, AFL, was arrested yesterday on a charge of first degree arson after an alert taxicab driver reported seeing him set fire to an antique shop at 1025 Second Avenue in the early morning.

LONDON, Dec. 22 -- One of the privately discussed sensations of the newspaper world came into the open with a splash today when the Communist Daily Worker printed documents concerning The London Daily Mail and the Karen tribes' uprising in Burma last summer.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 -- The Interstate Commerce Commission today ruled that financial houses advising railroads in the preparation of issues of railroad securities would not be permitted to bid on those securities.

Butler University, traditionally strong Midwest independent, and the University of Colorado, of the Big Seven Conference, will invade Madison Square Garden tonight in the third college double-header of this crowded holiday week. Their respective local opponents will be Long Island University and New York University.
BATAVIA, Java, Dec. 22 (AP) -- The Dutch Army raced tonight to overrun the few large remaining Republican centers before the United Nations Security Council could take any decisive action.

I have been much interested in your editorial comment regarding the proposed wheat agreement and the response of the FAO organization, which, of course, could be expected to enlarge the scope of its operations should the world wheat trade be conveniently packaged and distributed under its auspices over a five-year period.

CANASTOTA, N.Y., Dec. 22 (AP) -- Joyful tears rolled down the cheeks of 11-year-old Jimmy Colclough today when the New York Central Railroad brought him Christmas gifts for reporting a rail defect near his home.

Traffic safety and the taxicab rider's taste in music and entertainment are more important than a cab driver's quest for enlightenment through his cab borne radio, Supreme Court Justice Denis O'Leary Cohalan decided yesterday.

Production of polished plate, window and safety glass by Libbey-Owens-Ford in 1948 increased about 12 per cent in dollar volume of total output over 1947 and doubled the sales volume of 1941, considered a normal pre-war year, it was announced yesterday by John D. Biggers, president.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Dec. 22 -- President Truman put in nearly two hours of work at his White House routine here this evening, following his arrival at his home at near-by Independence to spend the Christmas holiday with his family and relatives.

Kansas City Structural Steel Company announced yesterday a year-end dividend of $6 on the common stock, the first payment on the common shares since 1930. It is payable on Dec. 28. For the preferred stock a payment of $1.50 per share on arrears was declared along with the quarterly dividend of $1.50, both payable on Dec. 28.

Eric Rosenblith, violinist, gave his annual New York recital last night at Town Hall. The gifted young artist presented a program composed of Hindemith's Sonata, Op. 11, No. 2; the Adagio in E major (K. 261) and Rondo in C major (K. 373) by Mozart; Bach's Sonata in E minor and Fugue in G minor with figured bass; Sibelius' Concerto in D minor, Szymanowski's "Notturno" and the Paganini-Kochanski "La Campanella."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 -- William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, told Philip Murray, president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, today that he would take up with the AFL executive council on Jan. 31 Mr. Murray's proposal for joint action on legislative problems.
Vince Foster is coming back to Madison Square Garden Jan. 14, in a feature bout role, and as part of Promoter Harry Markson's campaign to revive interest in boxing through the medium of new faces.

NANKING, Dec. 22 -- President Chiang Kai-shek has been urged from within the new Sun Fo Cabinet to resign so that peace can be negotiated, it was learned reliably today. The suggestion was reportedly made on a personal basis by one or two Ministers Without Portfolio in the new Cabinet which has not yet taken office.
In his second campaign on the big time Jackie Robinson gained the distinction of leading the National League's second basemen in fielding excellence, though his margin was a slender one.

The women -- and the men, too -- who like to delight their guests with unusual party fare will find a hoard of ideas in a new cookbook from Denmark. It introduces a peculiarly Danish culinary achievement -- the open sandwich, the mainstay of that country's version of the smorgasbord.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 -- What are expected to be the final hearings of the present Congressional session in the Hiss-Chambers case were scheduled for tomorrow by the House Committee on Un-American Activities today.
Four industrial delegates have arrived in New York from Czechoslovakia for the Czechoslovak trade exposition opening here on Jan. 12, the Consulate-General announced yesterday.

CHICAGO, Dec. 22 -- Joseph D. Keenan, secretary of the Chicago Federation of Labor, who recently was named permanent director of the AFL League for Political Education at an annual salary of $20,000, reported today that the league's "educational fund" had received $125,000 to date from AFL unions.

THE HAGUE, The Netherlands, Dec. 22 -- The Netherlands Foreign Office refrained from commenting tonight on reports from Washington that the Economic Cooperation Association had blocked further aid to Indonesia. It said it had no official confirmation of the American move, although other officials said the reports were true.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 (AP) -- The Bureau of Mines said today that it appears that 1948 oil consumption will be 2 per cent less than the bureau forecast last August.

Converting orders out of inquiries has become the foremost project of heavy equipment and industrial supply manufacturers for 1949, it was announced here yesterday in the latest research report of the Sales Methods Committee of the American Supply and Machinery Manufacturers Association, Pittsburgh.

Torrey Cliff, the estate of the late Thomas W. Lamont and Mrs. Lamont on the west shore of the Hudson River at Palisades, N.Y., has been presented to Columbia University, it was announced last night by Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, president of the university.
SANTIAGO, Chile, Dec. 22 (AP) -- Chile called today on the democratic Governments of Latin America to take steps to end threats of overthrow by force.

PARIS, Dec. 22 -- Statisticians have now worked out an estimate of the damage to the French economy occasioned by this autumn's coal strike, which the Government maintained had been organized by the Communist party.
A Danish grandmother appealed yesterday to the conscience of a thief to return a family heirloom that could be of little value to him.

A wider response to the Christmas Seal letters sent to residents of Manhattan, the Bronx, and Staten Island earlier this year was urged yesterday by Dr. Herbert R. Schwartz, executive director of the New York Tuberculosis and Health Association, 386 Fourth Avenue.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 -- Appointment of twenty-three new Federal judges, including four for the Southern District of New York, was recommended today in a report of the Judicial Conference of the United States.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange had a typical pre-holiday session yesterday. Final prices were 2 points higher to 10 points net lower.

With one justice dissenting in the sentencing, two men convicted of assaulting a patrolman at a street rally last August received yesterday in Special Sessions suspended six-month terms. Presiding Justice Nathan D. Perlman pronounced the sentence, noting that Justice Joseph V. Loscalzo had concurred but that Justice William B. Northrop recommended a jail sentence.

In an expansion move to provide additional warehouse and distribution facilities, Peck Peck, women's specialty shops, have leased the entire East floor at 410 East Fifty-fourth Street from the All States Holding Corporation. Cushman Wakefield, Inc., were the brokers.

PARIS, Dec. 22 -- The United States, Colombia and Syria today introduced a resolution in the United Nations Security Council calling for an immediate ceasefire in Indonesia and a return to the positions held by the Netherlands and the forces of the Indonesian Republic under the truce agreement of Jan. 17, 1948.

Henry C. Alexander has been elected to the new office of executive vice president of J.P. Morgan Co., it was announced yesterday by George Whitney, president, following a meeting of the board of directors.
SYRACUSE, N.Y., Dec. 22 (AP) -- Jack Kiley tallied 31 points to pace Syracuse to an easy 67-46 basketball victory over Iowa State tonight.

NANKING, Dec. 22 (AP) -- Communist armies to the north rambled toward the Yangtze River today. Nationalist troops were in a southward retreat. All of North China and the area of East Central China north of the Yangtze appeared doomed. Jumpy Nanking residents fretted.

LONDON, Dec. 22 -- London has a warm welcome for the freshness and energy of American musical comedies. "High Button Shoes," the latest importation from the United States, judging by first-night reactions, seems destined to have the sort of success earned by "Oklahoma!" and "Annie Get Your Gun."
"I wouldn't show up if I didn't think I could win the battle for left field next season."

The nation's gasoline stocks last week increased an additional 1,115,000 barrels to 98,225,000 at the week-end, according to the American Petroleum Institute. A week earlier, they were 97,110,000 barrels and a year ago 87,056,000.

George Frankenthaler, Republican-Liberal who defeated General Sessions Judge John A. Mullen and who was the first nominee of his party to defeat a Tammany candidate in sixty-eight years, was sworn in as Surrogate of New York County yesterday morning by Presiding Justice David W. Peck of the Appellate Division, First Department, at the Appellate Di vision Courthouse, Twenty-fifth Street and Madison Avenue.

The Metropolitan Opera Association last night gave its first presentation of the season of Puccini's "Madama Butterfly." And a very good performance it was too. It was gracious, charming and touching -- practically everything, in fact, that "Butterfly" should be.
An American soldier stationed at Mitchel Field, L.I., and his war bride sent $5 yesterday to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

Dr. Edward Lasker, captain of the New York team in the cable chess match with Paris at the Marshall Chess Club, in which two games were drawn and six adjourned, announced yesterday that the contest was officially closed after adjudication by Miguel M. Najdorf of Buenos Aires, to whom the adjourned positions had been submitted, and that the result was a 4-4 tie.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 -- Paul G. Hoffman, Economic Cooperation Administrator, announced his intention today of continuing until Feb. 1 the requirement that United States ships be used for at least 50 per cent of bulk cargoes bought in this country for Marshall Plan countries.

HOLLYWOOD, Ca., Dec. 22 -- RKO has switched its casting schedule to assign Robert Mitchum to the leading role in "The Big Steal," which will go before the cameras late next month, the studio disclosed today. The Mitchum casting is technically described by the studio as "tentative" because of the actor's pending trial on narcotics charges Jan. 10.

Nature lovers and conservationists who have been vigorously opposing Park Department plans to fill in seven acres of a marshy, thirty-two-acre wild life sanctuary in Van Cortlandt Park are ready to cease hostilities provided the remaining twenty-five acres can be set aside for the permanent use of study classes and observation groups, it was learned yesterday.

The Department of Marine and Aviation intends to proceed immediately with the first stages of its waterfront rehabilitation program under the $10,400,000 expenditure approved in the capital budget, it became known yesterday.
An anonymous contributor sent $1,820 yesterday to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund to pay fully for the costs of aiding five distressed families.

The Metropolitan Opera programs list Thomas J. Hillary as "technical department." That is an unusual way to describe the Met's walking aspirin. For thirty years he has been its major domo in charge of unexpected minor crises.

LONDON, Dec. 23 -- With London getting its most lavish pantomime and circus season since 1938, the experts have been trying to estimate what London's impresarios and producers have put down. The conclusion is that close to 500,000 ($2,000,000) is at stake.

In a red green and white Christmas decor, the second arid final Junior Assembly for this season was held last night in the main ballroom of the Ritz-Carlton. Traditions observed since the "Juniors" were established several decades ago, were in evidence again last night.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Dec. 23 -President Truman reviewed foreign affairs today in a ten-minute telephone conversation with Robert A. Lovett, Acting Secretary of State, and otherwise devoted himself to Presidential business most of the day.

One of the last acts of the General Assembly in Paris was to approve continuation of the U.N. Appeal for Children in 1949. The Assembly combined the Appeal with the International Children's Emergency Fund, giving the Fund a virtual mandate to keep the Appeal alive in all the countries where it has operated.

ROME, Dec. 23 -- The State Prosecutor started judicial proceedingsh)0*0*0*itoday against the editor of the magazine So Tutto for having written that the battleship Giulio Cesare, which is to be delivered to Russia under the terms of the peace treaty, would be scuttled before reaching the Dardanelles.

Two locals of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, AFL, and the Railway Express Agency announced yesterday that they had agreed on a new contract granting 4,000 workers a general increase of 15 cents an hour.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Dec. 23 -a move by the Hudson Manhattan Railroad to curtail service at some of its facilities here, including the closing of the Henderson Street entrance to the Grove Street station of the line, has been stopped by a complaint by Jersey City officials to the State Board of Public Utilities Commissioners.

A mother of three children, accused of burning the hand of herh)0*0*0*i8-year-old son so severely that he lost a finger, was freed yesterday in Felony Court pending the action of a grand jury, because the court believed that holding her in lieu of $1,000 bail was a punitive measure.

FAIRBANKS, Alaska, Dec. 23 (AP) -- A B-50 bomber, flown north for rigid tests under severe Arctic conditions, crashed and burned on a training flight from the Eielson Air Force Base last night, killing its ten crew members.
TORONTO, Dec. 23 (AP) -- Buddy O'Connor fans couldn't be blamed if they tossed a few "razzberries" in the direction of the Montreal Canadiens tonight.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 -- The Senate's Republicans have completed a plan to challenge the majority Democrats in the new Congress to go to work immediately on the issue of President Truman's civil rights program.

WHAT is Santa Claus going to bring you on the morrow, kiddies? Not a creature will be stirring tonight when the jolly old elf comes sashaying down the chimney, his pack bulging with presents. The Christmas spirit is in the air and this is probably as good a time as any to take a peek into Santa's sleigh and see what he has stacked there for the sporting fraternity.

Officers of City, Brooklyn and Queens Colleges have joined in a protest to Mayor O'Dwyer and the Board of Higher Education against salary reductions of ninety-three provisional clerks employed in the four city colleges.

LONDON, Dec. 23 -- Brokers and jobbers devoted most of their last business day before the Christmas holiday to entertaining clients in city clubs. Business on the floor of the stock market was negligible.

First, signs of improvement in supplies of steel pipe have appeared in the New York market, large industrial purchasing sources said yesterday. So much improvement has occurred, they said, that installations of equipment are no longer being held back in commercial uses because of inability to obtain sizes of two-inch and smaller.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 -- Money refunded by the Government, principally for the overpayment of taxes, will be reported beginning in January as deductions from total receipts rather than as expenditures, the Secretary of the Treasury, the Director of the Bureau of the Budget and the Controller General disclosed today in a joint announcement.

A new 16-inch-screen television set selling for about $500 will be introduced early next month by the Radio Corporation of America, it was reported yesterday by The Associated Press, and a general reduction in other television prices is expected to follow.

C. H. Masland Sons announced yesterday an advance of approximately 6 per cent in wholesale prices of its Wooltred carpet line. At the same time the company, revised its suggested list price for the 9-by-12-foot size from $32.95 to $34.95.

There'll be excitement tomorrow around the Christmas tree as presents are opened. The kitchen, too, will be the scene of lots of activity. The housewife who doesn't want to spend most of her day there, preparing the festive dinner, will have a plan of action worked out beforehand.
CAIRO, Dec. 23 -- Egyptian military sources said today that the Israelis had lauached a major-offensive on the Negeb front but that they had been thrown back.

The Retail, Wholesale and Department Store Union, CIO, the future existence of which appeared in doubt last week when Philip Murray turned its department store jurisdiction over to the Amalgamated Clothing Workers, received assurances yesterday that it could stay in business.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 -- The Secretary of Agriculture, as required by law, today announced that 7,250,000 short tons of sugar would be needed for consumers in this country during the calendar year 1949.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 23 (AP) -Connie Mack, 86 today, said he wouldn't retire "until my brains wear out" and predicted a 1949 American League pennant for the world champion Cleveland Indians.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 -- The Navy announced tonight that it had ordered the aircraft carrier Saipan out of Norfolk, Va., to try to rescue eleven Air Force fliers marooned on a 7,700-foot Greenland icecap. The Saipan will carry helicopters, a type of craft which the Air Force had shied away from using because of the high winds sweeping the icecap in southwest Greenland.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Dec. 23 -- Consistent surveys of various categories of Western exports since the currency reform have reflected conditions so generally flourishing that decisions have been taken to retain the present 30-cent evaluation of the Deutsche mark for an indefinite period, Howard P. Jones, deputy director of the finance division of the Military Government revealed today.

The Pulmosan Safety Equipment Corporation has purchased the three-story factory building at 642-46 Pacific Street, Brooklyn, from Edith Weisman and Gloria Linn for cash above a purhase money mortgage of $36,500. The property, on a plot 75 by 110 feet, is assessed at $73,000.

Tempting inducement to make this a white Christmas -- in the dining room at least was offered by the table settings and displays at the new Wedgwood showroom, which opened officially yesterday at 24 East Fifty-fourth Street.
Cash registers jingled like sleigh bells yesterday at the three lots here where Elliott Roosevelt is selling Christmas trees grown on the Val-Kill farms at Hyde Park, N.Y.

A funeral service for Chief Inspector Martin J. Brown of the Police Department was held at 10 o'clock yesterday morning in St. Luke's Roman Catholic Church, Clintonville Street and Locke Place, Whitestone, Queens.

The special Christmas Midnight Mass service from the Church of the Annunciation in Nazareth will be broadcast over short wave this afternoon, according to an announcement by the New York information office of the Provisional Government of Israel.

Having recently been a philosophical waiter and a testy schoolteacher, Leo G. Carroll at the moment is a Catholic priest. In "Jenny Kissed Me," which was acted at the Hudson last evening, he paternally directs the love life of a growing girl.

Grief-stricken and ill since her son Seymour was killed in the battle for Eniwetok in 1944, Mrs. Nettie Le Voff of 672 Ocean Avenue died of a heart attack yesterday afternoon while attending a repatriation funeral service in Brooklyn, marking the return of the soldier's body from a Pacific cemetery.

Supreme Court Justice Felix Benvenga reserved decision yesterday after a trial committee ofh)0*0*0*ithe National Maritime Union, CIO, announced that it had recommended expulsion of Joseph Stack, a former vice president. The findings will be passed upon by a union membership Monday night in Manhattan Center.

The five-story and penthouse store and apartment building at 14 East Fifty-third Street has been sold by Cecil Charles Pecci-Blunt to Sherman Billingsley, owner of the Stock Club, and Fred H. Hill. The property was bought in the name of the Heldor Realty Corporation for altering and occupancy by the buyers when theh)0*0*0*ileases expire next year.

MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 23 (AP) -- Composing room employes of The Miami Herald went on strike today. Eddie Page, president of Local No. 430 of the International Typographical Union, said "the other daily newspapers are still negotiating with the union and we hope a satisfactory agreement will be reached."

PARIS, Dec. 23 -- Marshall Plan nations must revise their fouryear plans and greatly reduce their anticipated imports if they are to bring their collective deficit with the rest of the world below $3,000,000,000 in the first year after American aid ends, according to a report today of experts of the European nations involved.

The airlines, rails and a few specialties attracted speculative attention yesterday on the stock market but price changes again were insignificant. There were a few wide fluctuations but the general pattern was exemplified by the composite rate which rose 0.17 point on the day.

LONDON, Dec. 23 -- There were hundreds of persons in the Coventh)0*0*0*iGarden Opera House tonight who gave the impression of never having enjoyed a ballet so much before in all their lives. They cheered and they repeatedly applauded the first performance of Frederick Ashton's "Cinderella," the only three-act classical ballet ever written in this country and the first produced anywhere since one was offered in 1876 in Russia.
HERMANSVILLE, Mich., Dec. 23 (AP) -- A sharp curtailment in operations "for the next four or five years" was announced today by the Herbert A. Nieman fur ranching enterprises.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 -- A letter of praise from President Truman today gave recognition to the forty-one-year career service of William A. Jump, retiring as director of budget and finance for the Department of Agriculture.

Thomas "Mignon" received its second performance of the season last night at the Metropolitan Opera House. With the exception of Giuseppe Di Stefano, who assumed the role of Wilhelm Meister for the first time, the cast was composed of singers who had been heard previously here with the company in their respective parts.

The Police Department's first full-scale experiment of one-way avenue operation has speeded rush hour traffic on Ninth and Tenth Avenues by better than 30 per cent, according to detailed time studies made public yesterday by the Automobile Club of New York.

TIENTSIN, Dec. 23 -- The fate of Tangku, sea outlet for this large north China industrial center, was in doubt today following a Nationalist report that street fighting had broken out there. Air observation disclosed a number of villages burning in the vicinity of the seaport, which is about thirty miles down the Hai River from Tientsin.

HARRISBURG, Pa., Dec. 23 -- A special tax study committee created by the Legislature of 1947 proposed today a drastic revision of Pennsylvania's business tax structure. One of its most revolutionary recommendations called for imposing a 1 1/2 percent tax on unincorporated businesses and "professional activity."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 -- The Jersey Central Power, Light Company of Asbury Park filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration Statement covering $3,500,000 of first-mortgage bonds, due 1978, that are to be offered at competitive bidding.

Although the full tide of Christmas celebrations would not be evident until today and tomorrow, many Yuletide parties were held in New York yesterday. Entertainments for the poor, the sick, for disabled war veterans, and especially for children handicapped physically or socially, were favored.

DETROIT, Dec. 23 (AP) -- Motor vehicle exports from the United States have dropped sharply this year and a continued downward trend is indicated during 1949. The Automobile Manufacturers Association, in making this appraisal today, reported 442,000 cars and trucks were exported this year against 512,333 units sent abroad in 1947.

The Sea-Cal-Frank Corporation, first announced here recently as subsidiary distributing agency in this area for products of Distillers Corporation-Seagrams Limited, was granted official approval to operate yesterday by the State Liquor Authority, according to Commissioner George P. Butterly Jr.

TOKYO, Friday, Dec. 24 -- All Japan's remaining Class A war criminals, held since the autumn of 1945 for crimes against humanity, were released by order of Gen. Douglas MacArthur's headquarters today.
The Rev. Dr. Harry Emerson Fosdick, former pastor of Riverside Church, paid tribute yesterday to Laurence Duggan's "ministry to the cause of peace and to the welfare of the nation."

VIENNA, Dec. 23 -- Clyde King, of the Economic Cooperation Administration's mission to Austria, has, according to reports in high Austrian sources, straightened out a serious clash between the United States Army command in Austria and the ECA mission, which had threatened seriously to undermine American prestige here and the success of Marshall Plan operations.

More than half of the rayon mill selling offices in New York will be closed for a half-day today, according to a survey of the National Federation of Textiles. About 30 per cent of the offices will be closed all day. On New Year's Eve, 45 per cent of the offices will be closed for a half day and 15 per cent will be closed all day.

NORFOLK, Va., Dec. 23 -- A Navy commander, a sailor armed with a tommy gun, and a Navy driver climbed into the cab of a truck here last night for about ten hours of slow driving along Virginia roads. In the vehicle, securely padded and crated against bumps on the Norfolk to Washington highway, was the first original Michelangelo sculpture ever brought to the United States.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 -- The support of the CIO to the efforts of the United States to end "the Dutch aggression" in Indonesia through "every feasible step in the realm of diplomacy and economics," was pledged by President Philip Murray in a letter today to Secretary of State Marshall.
NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 23 (AP) -Invercork beat off a challenge by Prince Favor, the favorite, to breeze home winner by two lengths in the Cotlogomor Purse at the Fair Grounds today.

IN October, when more new books are published than in any other month, there are always several good ones that fail to attract the notice they deserve. One pleasant and diverting book that was trampled on in the general rush and overlooked as far as these columns are concerned was "Golden Opinions,"* by Richard L. Tobin.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 -- In a "warning" to the rank and file of organized labor, the House Committee on Un-American Activities declared today that twenty unions of the Congress of Industrial Organizations had been dominated by Communists.

A civilian Advisory Commission on Service Pay has recommended to Secretary Forrestal an upward revision in all ranks except that of buck private, whose pay is automatically increased after four months in uniform, anyway. The question of service pay in various grades is a complex one and the Committee's report is too detailed to discuss point by point.
ALBANY, Dec. 23 (AP) -- State Agriculture Commissioner C. Chester Du Mond issued on order today setting the price for Class 1-A fluid milk at $5.68 a hundredweight (about 47 quarts) beginning Jan. 1.

The best part of Christmas is not the day, itself, but the night before. Like anything else that is built upon anticipation, the climax is reached not at the event, but at the last moment before the event. For days, for weeks and, indeed, for months, the hopeful eye is turned towards Dec. 25, but that is the outer, the prosaic eye.

Coffee futures on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange were easy in the distant delivery positions under scattered liquidation yesterday. Spot December "D" held unchanged. The rest of the "D" contract declined 5 to 23 points.

YONKERS, N.Y., Dec. 23 -Former Supreme Court Justice William F. Bleakley, as counsel for the Empire City Racing Association, revealed today that real estate brokers are negotiating for the purchase of the Empire City race track here.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Dec. 23 -- Conditions within the Republic of Indonesia on this fifth day of Dutch military action were reported by Netherlands army intelligence sources as quiet and on the whole satisfactory. The populace in the countryside was described here as mildly pleased at the turn of events but that the townsfolk remained coldly indifferent to the invaders, perhaps partly because they were aware that former Republican soldiers were everywhere under cover.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 -- The National Labor Relations Board issued an order today directing District No. 31 of the United Mine Workers to cease restraining and coercing employes of four West Virginia coal-mining companies. It was charged that a union group detained workers in two mines until they signed union membership cards.

Cardinal Spellman, Roman Catholic Archbishop of New York, and the Right Rev. Charles K. Gilbert, Protestant Episcopal Bishop of New York, have written special pastoral letters on connection with the observance on Sunday of Freedom of Religion Day in the city's churches, J. Edward Shugrue, national director of the American Heritage Foundation, announced yesterday.

LONDON, Dec. 23 -- Three agreements, believed designed to help Yugoslavia insure against an economic boycott by the Eastern powers following her rupture with the Communist Information Bureau, were signed with Britain here today.
PASADENA, Calif., Dec. 23 (AP) -- Hard luck for the second time this season today hit Joe Zuravleff, 190-pound first-string left end of the Northwestern Rose Bowl football team.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on Dec. 18, 1948 totaled 754,545 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 28,731 cars, or 3.7 per cent fewer than in the preceding week, 77,585 cars, or 9.3 per cent fewer than in the corresponding week of 1947, and 81,640 cars, or 9.8 per cent fewer than during the corresponding week of 1946.

Ned Rorem, 25yearold composer of this city, was the winner of the fourth annual George Gershwin Memorial Contest sponsored by the New York Victory Lodge of B'nai Brith, it was announced yesterday by William Schumann, president of the Juilliard School of Music and acting chairman of the judge's committee.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 23 (UP) -The U.S. Circuit Court ruled today that a big soup manufacturer's contracts with farmers for their crops were "too one-sided and too tough." The court said that while the contracts were not illegal, they were not enforceable in the courts because the provisions "drive too hard a bargain for a court of conscience to assist."
Metropolitan skiers are being envied by their Northern neighbors for the grade of sport currently found so close to the "ravines" and "canyons" of Times Square.

Final estimates now being made on shoe production for the year indicate output may show a decline of less than 1 per cent in comparison with 1947. Production for the last quarter, however, fell off very sharply, and this may have some bearing on output trends for early next year.

Your issue of today contains in the form of an editorial a very grave accusation against the Government I represent in the United States of America. On the basis of a dispatch from your correspondent in The Hague dated Jan. 17 my Government is accused of a serious breach of promise and your editorial then proceeds to develop that theme.

Pre-holiday travel from the city began to gain momentum yesterday, with the migration expected to reach heavy proportions by tonight. Transportation officials predicted that the forecast of probable snow this week-end might lead many New Yorkers to a last-minute decision to spend an old-fashioned Christmas out of town.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was quiet yesterday, but the undertone was steady, and final prices were 1 to 11 points net higher than on Wednesday.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 -- During the week ended Dec. 22, member bank reserve balances decreased $536,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.
MOSCOW, Dec. 23 (AP) -- United States Ambassador Walter Bedell Smith said today:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 -- For the first time since the immediate pre-war period, employment in non-agricultural establishments decreased in mid-November, dipping 170,000 below the October level, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today.

Vast engineering projects not contained in the official Soviet announcements last autumn of the Russian afforestation and shelter-belt scheme, including the Great Volga Project, are behind the Soviet seventeen-year anti-drought plan, Dr. Solomon Schwarz said yesterday.

Almost two thousand years ago this Christmas Eve, three men traveled half the then-known world, knelt at the foot of an Infant and "* * * offered Him gifts: gold, frankincense, and myrrh." He was not the son of a great king whose favor they wished to obtain. His mother was the wife of a poor carpenter.
IOWA CITY, Iowa., Dec. 23 -The country's leading poll expert are going to get together here in February to try and figure out what happened Nov. 2.

CHICAGO, Dec. 23 (AP) -- The Chicago Black Hawks came to life too late tonight and as a result lost a National Hockey League game to the revived New York Rangers, 3 -- 2, before 15,682 fans. That ended a string of four victories and a tie in the Hawks' recent record and meant that the Rangers now have four triumphs and a deadlock in succession.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Dec. 23 -War broke out again today in southern Palestine, and a United Nations report indicated that a full-fledged Israeli offensive was under way. The activity apparently shattered hopes of Israeli-Egyptian peace negotiations this year.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 - Congressional investigators said in a report made public today that they could see signs of progress in labormanagement relations in the West Coast maritime industry after fourteen years of turmoil.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Dec. 23 (AP) -Navy announced its 1949 football captain and made its schedule official today, but remained uncertain about where to play its home games. Right end Philip J. Ryan, a 21-year-old 190-pounde: from Goodhue, Minn., is the captainelect.

WASHINGTON. Dec, 23 -- Department store sales in the week ended. Dec. 18 were unchanged from sales of the same week a year ago, the Federal Reserve Board reported tonight. The following lists percentage changes from like periods of 1947:

Twenty-five hatless and coatless employes of the Universal Brass Company, Inc., at 912 Courtlandt Avenue, the Bronx, chased a burglar suspect six blocks yesterday. He was finally captured by the police on the third floor of a tenement after the suspect had broken down an apartment door and knocked a woman to the floor.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 28 -Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer has borrowed Alexis Smith from Warner Brothers for the leading feminine role opposite Clark Cable in "Any Number Can Play," the studio announced today. Mervyn Le Roy will direct the film, starting next month, from a story by Edward Harris Heth which deals with the relationship between a professional gambler and his son.

Perhaps it was due to the distractions and anticipations of the holiday week that last night's concert of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, directed by Charles Munch, in Carnegie Hall, assumed the character of a routine observance rather than that of a particularly exciting occasion.

The Cunard White Star liner Queen Elizabeth sailed at noon from West Fiftieth Street yesterday for the Channel ports with 1,283 passengers, including Alfred Edwards, former member of British Parliament.

VIENNA, Dec. 23 -- Austria was severely censured by the Russians at today's meeting of the Allied Council for having done exactly what Russia has done for a quarter of a century -- concentrating on the output of the means of construction instead of consumer goods.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 -- The consumers' price index dropped 0.8 per cent between mid-October and mid-November, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today.

Leo Alexander, noted Boston neurologist, called for the development of "active and alert" hospital centers for the treatment of those suffering the various types of chronic illnesses in an address last night at the New York Academy of Medicine, 2 East 103d Street.

Unable to agree on a "master plan" for the full four-year term of the European Recovery Program, as requested by Economic Administrator Hoffman, the European Council for that Program is now considering a "progress report" which has one cheerful and one rather serious aspect.

The four-story forty-two-family apartment house at 86 West 183d Street, southwest corner of University Avenue, the Bronx, has been sold by Rimar Equities, Inc., to Sadye M. Levy and others. It is assessed at $140,000 and occupies a plot 87.65 by 100 feet J. Lemle Sons were the brokers and the attorneys were Joseph Timan for the seller and Samuel Bitterman for the buyers.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 23 (AP) -A spokesman for the Philadelphia Port Council said last night that "tens of thousands of union pickets" would see that European recovery cargoes were not carried on foreign vessels.
BATAVIA, Java, Dec. 23 (AP) -The Indonesian radio at Madiun went silent tonight, raising the possibility that the third largest city in the Republic might have fallen to Netherland forces.
TOKYO, Dec. 23 -- The conservative Government of Premier Shigeru Yoshida collapsed tonight under pressure of the Allies and leftwing opposition parties.
The scope of Federal activity in behalf of New York State veterans was outlined yesterday in a report issued by the Veterans Administration here on its 1948 activities.
CLEVELAND, Dec. 23 (AP) -- Two Cleveland area manufacturing concerns are helping find other employment for workers whom they have laid off.

" And Ride Forth Singing," Katharine Dunlap's first novel in eight years, will be brought out by Morrow on Jan. 4. It is a story of France today, set in the same little town as her last book, "Once There was A Village." The story presents the reaction of the French people from the violence of war to the complications of peace.

I would like to correct an impression caused by your editorial of Dec. 4 on the AVC. The editorial seems to set up the American Veterans Committee as the representative group of World War II veterans. For the information of all concerned, I wish to point out that AMVETS, the American Veterans of World War II, were chartered by Act of Congress on July 23, 1947.

HAMPTON BAYS, L.I. Dec. 23 -- The Shinnecock Lighthouse, at Ponquogue, Hampton Bays, which was erected in 1857 and condemned by the Federal Government about ten years ago was demolished today by the Goldfarb Contracting Company of New York.
NANKING, Dec. 23 (AP) -- The Chinese Civil War came to a virtual standstill today.
Protests against the Netherlands Government for the attack on the Indonesian Republic were voiced yesterday by several organizations in the city.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Dec. 23 -A daring "bush pilot," Roy Lamoureaux of Casper, Wyo., was standing by tonight awaiting a chance to attempt a single-handed rescue of the eleven men marooned on the Greenland icecap after he volunteered his services to Brig. Gen. Robert B. Landry, president Truman's Air Force aide.
The Philippine Scouts, famous in the "old Army," will pass into the limbo of history by July 1, 1949, unless the next session of Congress takes preventive action.

Many Christmas Eve services have been announced by the city's churches and other services will be held tomorrow, Christmas Day. The orders of service will include carols, the usual Nativity pageants, anthems, hymns, arias and oratorios.

Altea Alimonda, who made her Town Hall debut last night, is a violinist who should go places. She plays with great personal conviction; she has temperament and a feeling for style, and she is well schooled. In addition, she is young and attractive, attributes that should not be a hindrance in the making of a career.

New York City was the first capital of the United States. It is now the world's capital. Together with Philadelphia and Boston, it is one of the great historic cities of America. People come here from every corner of the globe. Culture cannot be reckoned alone in terms of bigness.

LAKE SUCCESS, Dec. 23 -- In a Christmas message to the United Nations, Secretary General Trygve Lie and Dr. Herbert V. Evatt, President of the General Assembly, joined today in expressing confidence that, despite critical problems endangering international security, the world organization would succeed in maintaining peace.

PEIPING, Dec. 23 -- Justice has been turned into a tragic farce in the last week here, with summary arrests and executions being carried out under the guise of "discipline supervision." The military authorities, seem to be making a final desperate effort to whip the populace into line by use of the one means left -- terror.

PARIS, Dec. 23 -- Jacob A. Malik announced today that the Soviet Union would submit its own resolution on the Indonesian question and would not vote for the joint resolution introduced in the United Nations Security Council yesterday by the United States, Colombia and Syria.

A counter offer of a 3 per cent cost-of-living increase in present hourly wages was made to tugboat workers by the Marine Towing and Transportation Employers Association at a meeting yesterday held under the auspices of the United States Mediation and Conciliation Service, at 341 Ninth Avenue.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 -- Francis B. Sayre, former Assistant Secretary of State, identified today three of the stolen secret documents in the Hiss-Chambers case as having definitely been removed from his "highly confidential" files.

Suspicious of their censored press, many Eastern Europeans rely for news on the United States Government's "Voice of America" broadcasts, George Venable Allen, Assistant Secretary of State for Public Affairs, reported here yesterday.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 23 -- Intimations that a showdown battle between the American Federation of Labor and the Congress of Industrial Organizations is shaping up on West Coast waterfronts came today in connection with preparations of the Sailors Union of the Pacific, AFL, for taking a strike ballot, beginning Monday.

New plans for retrospective rating and premium discount plans for workmen's compensation, automobile and general liability insurance were approved yesterday by Robert E. Dineen, State Superintendent of Insurance.

According to information obtained from Hollywood, there is a possibility, a remote one to be true, of Claude Rains being pried loose from the screen to act in the Dalton Trumbo play, "The Emerald Staircase," to be staged by Herman Shumlin and produced by Lee Sabinson.
SYDNEY, Australia, Dec. 23 (AP) -- Three more crack Australian race horses may follow Shannon II to the United States in 1949. They are Filipino, Royal Gem and San Domenico.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 -- A final tally of eighty-two women Democrats elected to state offices, eight of them as Senators and sixty-six as Representatives, was announced today by the Democratic Digest, official publication of the Women's Division of the Democratic National Committee.

Despite second-hand offering of eighty square parcels at sacrifice prices, all indications point to a firm diary market for the next thirty days, according to Worth Street sources. The lowest price quoted by a primary producer, textile men said yesterday, was 28 1/2 cents a yard, while the general market price ranged around 29 1/2 cents.
TOKYO, Dec. 23 -- Attempts by occupation officials to return the cotton manufacturing industry to something like its pre-war normal have bogged down over the exchange rate question.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 -- The Civil Aeronautics Authority tonight disclaimed responsibility for fires which beset the early modelsh)0*0*0*iof DC-6 luxury airliners, in a statement replying to a decision by the Civil Aeronautics Board yesterday laying part of the blame upon it.

Two hundred New York public school teachers who work a sixday week instructing crippled and ill children at home will go on a five-day week immediately as a result of a resolution adopted yesterday by the Board of Education by a vote of 8 to 1.

Stand-pat Republican leaders who are waiting for a depression or a national scandal to push them back into office are doing a disservice to the country by failing to organize dynamic minority opposition, Representative Jacob K. Javits, Republican, of New York, declared yesterday.

When you take a walk tomorrow to settle your Christmas dinner -- or to work up an appetite for it -- why not spread some of the holiday spirit among the lesser children. Take along a bag of bread scraps, suet or corn for the wildlife that is now on thin, winter rations.

HARTSDALE, N.Y., Dec. 23 -Current difficulties in the world are "birth pangs" and not "death throes," Gen. Evangeline Cory Booth said here today at her estate, Arcadia, in an annual prebirthday interview.

Three new films will open in first run theatres this morning. At the Strand, the attraction is "Adventures of Don Juan," a Warner Brothers period romantic adventure, starring Errol Flynn in the title role. Vincent Sherman directed and Jerry Wald produced the Technicolor offering from a screen play by George Oppenheimer and Harry Kurnitz and a story by Herbert Dalmas.

An alleged Indonesian Republican Army uprising scheduled for next New Year's Day "would have meant the Communists' taking control" there, thereby justifying current Netherlands "police action," Dr. Herman J. Friedericy, head of the Political Department of the Netherlands Ministry for Overseas Territories, declared here yesterday.

A haven of refuge for boys in their teens from Eastern Germany and orphans who lost their parents in World War II has been patterned after Boys Town, Neb., and opened near Delmenhorst, south of Bremen, Germany, in theh)0*0*0*iBritish zone of occupation, with joint participation by Lutherans and Roman Catholics.

TRENTON, N.J., Dec. 23 -- Uniformity in valuing property for taxation in New Jersey municipalities and economies in operations by joint action where possible were proposed today by the State Taxpayers Association.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Dec. 23 -- Santa Claus runs true to his post-war form in Scandinavia this year. In Sweden, he is still most bountiful while Norway and Denmark fare less well.
Americans for Democratic Action in New York State are amazed and delighted by Governor Dewey's recent announcements of his legislative plans.

BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 23 -- Foreign Minister Juan Atilio Bramuglia had his true home-coming today.h) 0*0*0*iMore than 300 employes of the Foreign Ministry gathered on the courtyard balcony of rainswept San Martin Palace to welcome him as he drove up after a long stay with President Juan D. Pe at Casa Rosada.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 -- When President Truman dropped in last Sunday on the reception the Arkansas Society of Washington was giving to the Governor-elect of that state -- a spontaneous courtesy that surprised everyone but the author of the idea, Leslie L. Biffle -- he used an expression which the United Press called "a new description for the recent election."

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 23 (AP) -- Apprentice Logan Batcheller, after going winnerless in the first three races at Tropical Park today, gave All in Fun, belonging to Harry B. Massey a great ride to land him home in front of seven opponents in the featured mileand-a-sixteenth Soldumeno Purse.

ROME, Dec. 23 -- A request has been made by Emperor Halie Selassie of Ethiopia to the InterAllied War Crimes Commission in London for delivery of former Marshals Pietro Badoglio and Rodolfo Graziani of Italy to be tried by an Ethiopian court for the part they played in the ItaloEthiopian war of 1935-36; but the move is not taken seriously in Italy, it was stated today.

New York University got caught on the low end of the seesaw at the wrong time last night. In a wild-and-woolly game at Madison Square Garden, marked by seventeen exchanges of the lead and ten ties, Colorado surged from behind in the last twenty-two seconds to shade the Violets, 68 -- 65.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 (AP) -This Government has protested to Czechoslovakia against the recent stripping and searching of three American citizens by customs and police officers.

Underwriting houses are watching the movements of the year-end stock market closely for clues that may be helpful in distributing two substantial blocks of equity securities next month. A First Boston Corporation syndicate is expected to bring to market 400,000 shares of the Koppers Company's common stock early in January.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 -- Secretary of State George C. Marshall has recovered sufficiently from his recent kidney operation at Walter Reed General Hospital that hopes were held out today that he would be able to leave the hospital next week.
Traffic accidents, some caused by vehicles skidding in slushy roadways, cost one man his life and caused injuries and shock among a number of persons in various parts of the city last night.

Miguel M. Najdorf, of Buenos Aires, world champion at blindfold chess, was the only winner in the first round of the international tournament at the Manhattan Chess Club last night. He defeated Herman Pilnick, also from Argentina, who resigned after forty moves.

Although the job of snow clearance is being accomplished to the satisfaction of city officials and the public, employes of the Department of Sanitation are encountering difficulties in putting their new snow removal equipment through its first "acid tests," it became known yesterday.
BERLIN, Dec. 23 -- German farmers and Politicians were warned tonight by an American spokesman that responsibility for maintaining ration levels in the Bizonal area was theirs.

PARIS, Friday, Dec. 24 -- By threatening the resignation of his Cabinet if he were defeated, Premier Henri Queuille last night drove the unpopular tax increases through the National Assembly, which was expected to pass the budget bill later this morning.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 -- The Department of Agriculture today announced a New York milk order amendment which would retain present price relationships between New York and Boston milksheds until June 30, 1949. The order requires producer approval to become effective.

SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., Dec. 23 (AP) -- Trailing by seven points midway in the first period, the Seton Hall basketball team came back strongly in the second half to defeat William and Mary by 59 -- 55 tonight.

Executive heads of department stores which have recently had alltime record days credited heavy newspaper promotions for their success in the special bulletin of the National Retail Dry Goods Association released yesterday. Other stores throughout the country which have had outstanding results this season also credit sales to "extensive use of newspaper space," it was reported.
CHICAGO, Dec. 23 -- To make certain that a Christmas tree fire will not turn holiday joy into tragedy, the National Safety Council has offered the following suggestions:

The four-story loft building on a lot 23 by 100 feet at 122 Westh)0*0*0*iTwenty-first Street was sold by the estate of George Cobban and the estate of James Cobban to an investing client of the Morgan Barry Company. It is assessed for $21,000.

No less than eighteen record feats dotted the National League's 1948 season, which ended with the senior circuit missing the distinction it values more highly than any other -- supremacy in the world series.
The Twenty-seventh and Fortysecond Divisions of the New York National Guard will train this summer at Pine Camp, N.Y., it was announced yesterday.
TOKYO, Dec. 23 (AP) -- Hidelki Tojo shouted defiantly a triple "Banzai" for the Emperor and then "Dai Nippon" (Great Japan) just before he was hanged this morning, his Buddhist priest disclosed.

CHICAGO, Dec. 23 -- Grain markets showed a strong tone on the Board of Trade today, scattered buying finding offerings light and the close was at about the top. Wheat gained 1 2/8 to 2 1/8 cents; corn, 5/8 to 1 1/8 cents; oats, 1 to 1 1/2 cents; rye, 2 1/2 cents, and soy beans, 1/4 to 1/2 cent. Lard rose 2 to 12 cents.

Reduced rates and the heavy fall of snow have spurred interest in winter cruising to the Caribbean and elsewhere in southern waters, but the cruise business generally is still plagued by an unprecedented instability, with some ships booking well and others lagging, travel men reported yesterday.

ALBANY, Dec. 23 -- Antagonistic RH blood factors threaten with tragedy 19,500 of the estimated 150,000 marriages of 1948 in New York State, Senator Thomas C. Desmond, Republican, of Newburgh, declared here today in announcing that he would sponsor a bill in the Legislature next month to make RH blood tests required in pregnancies.
BERLIN, Dec. 23 -- German farmers and Politicians were warned tonight by an American spokesman that responsibility for maintaining ration levels in the Bizonal area was theirs.

PARIS, Friday, Dec. 24 -- By threatening the resignation of his Cabinet if he were defeated, Premier Henri Queuille last night drove the unpopular tax increases through the National Assembly, which was expected to pass the budget bill later this morning.

SOFIA, Bulgaria, Dec. 23 -- A five-year plan to industrialize Bulgaria and mechanize her agriculture was introduced today at the fifth congress of the Bulgarian Communist party by Dobri Perpeshev, member of the Political Bureau.

Regional expansion has been going on apace in this country in recent years, particularly in the South and Southwest. Texas has made notable gains both in population and industry, while New Orleans has been having considerable success in enlarging its foreign trade.
SPARKILL, N.Y., Dec. 23 -Chief of Police Fred L. Kennedy of Orangetown had just finished a hearty breakfast today and was reading his morning newspaper when he heard a knock at the front door.

SUFFERN, N.Y., Dec. 23 -- A 14-year-old boy was wounded fatally here today by an accidental shot from the 22-caliber rifle of a fellow-student at the Herriman Farm School. The victim was Louish)0*0*0*iWalsleben Jr. of 523 West 134th Street, New York.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 -- The Chicago, Burlington Quincy Railroad Company asked the Interstate Commerce Commission today to authorize it to operate over tracks of the Gulf, Mobile Ohio between Rock Creek Junction, and Francis, Mo., about 158 miles.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 -- The Surgeons General of the Army, Navy, Air Public Health Service announced today a national campaign to be part of a drive against that disease by the World Health Organization.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 -- The Hoover Commission on Organization of the Executive Branch of the Government will recommend a major reorganization of the Departments of Agriculture and Interior to reduce expenditures, consolidate conservation programs and eliminate the "conflicting, confusing and duplicating" agricultural activities of the Government.

A comprehensive psychiatric program in which psychiatrists make the rounds in the hospital wards with the regular doctors, calling attention to the psychological aspects of the illnesses, is under way at Mount Sinai Hospital. This was learned yesterday in an interview with Dr. Martin R. Steinberg, director of the hospital.

In the Dec. 6 issue of THE TIMES there is an A.P. radiophoto showing a hospital patient in Berlin marking her ballot in municipal elections. When I came on this photograph I was brought up with a shock, for if the Berlin hospitalized are able to vote it is more than New Yorkers in hospitals can do.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 -- The United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit has upheld the constitutionality of a ban on peaceful picketing in a secondary boycott case under the Taft-Hartley Law.

Reflecting substantially larger sales, the net earnings of the Burlington Mills Corporation for the fiscal year ended on Oct. 2, were $31,219,943, compared with $23,887,711 in the preceding fiscal year, the twenty-fourth annual report disclosed yesterday.

The decision of the Amalgamated Clothing Workers, CIO, one of the nation's strongest, wealthiest and most respected unions, to undertake at the request of Philip Murray a countrywide organizing campaign among department store workers is full of significance for employes, employers, consumers and the labor movement in general.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 -- Four outstanding civilians today concluded a one-year study of military pay with recommendations for increases, plus other incentives, designed to place service careers on a comparable financial basis with civilian positions.

MONTREAL, Dec. 23 (AP) -- The Montreal Canadiens whipped the Boston Bruins, 4 -- 2, in a National Hockey League game tonight that was delayed an hour in starting by the late arrival of the Bruins' train.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 -- The Council of the Organization of American States will meet tomorrow to receive the report of theh)0*0*0*icommission of inquiry on its investigation of the border controversy between Costa Rica and Nicaragua.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 -- The National Labor Relations Board reported today that incoming cases declined 14 per cent in November from the preceding month, largelyh) 0*0*0*ias a result of fewer petitions for union shop elections.

The last allocation of funds from the Air Force's billion and a half dollars for airplane purchase in fiscal 1949 will bring important orders to two local plan makers, it was learned yesterday. Fairchild Engine and Airplane Corporation of 30 Rockefeller Plaza confirmed the fact that it will probably build several hundred of a newly designed primary trainer, and Republic Aviation Corporation will continue the production of the F-84 Thunderjet.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Dec. 23 -- A proposal for instituting a seven-day work week in the whole or parts of the steel industry of the Ruhr is under investigation now by Allied and German authorities. An exploratory meeting on the subject already has been held with trade union leaders.
MARBURG, Germany, Dec. 23 (AP) -- Mrs. Wilma Ybarbo, accused of slaying her soldier-husband, will have to wait until after Christmas to hear the verdict of a court now deadlocked.

GENEVA, Dec. 23 the Canadian Government has informed the International Refugee Organization that it would not be convenient for the executive committee of the organization to meet in Ottawa on Jan. 20, as scheduled. This may postpone action on the highly controversial question of assistance to refugees seeking to go to Palestine.

Business loans by banks in this area rose again in the week ended on Wednesday, increasing $19,000,000 to within $49,000,000 of the all-time peak reached on Nov. 10. According to the data issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, commercial, industrial and agricultural loans of the reporting New York City member banks totaled $5,622,000,000, with borrowings by finance companies, public utilities, meat packers and textile producers most prominent in the latest increase.
New York hung its last stocking, decorated its last tree and wrapped its last package last night--and waited joyously for the Christmas dawn today.
ALBANY, Dec. 24 (AP) -- Consumers in major New York cities are expected to receive a cut of 1 cent a quart in the retail price of milk on Jan. 1.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 -- The Government must revolutionize its methods of recruiting, paying, retaining and promoting first-rate men and women if the United States is to meet its responsibilities in the modern world, the Hoover Commission on Organization of the Executive Branch of the Government will tell the Congress next month.

The Yuletide spirit, swelled by the bounty of the fortunate to transcend barriers of race and station, spread over the city yesterday as its inhabitants gathered in churches and homes to mark the arrival of Christmas.
NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 24 (AP) -- Two top ring squads of the nation, Michigan State and Louisiana State, square off in the Sugar Bowl's tenth annual fistic highlight Tuesday.

The stock market ignored yesterday the usual pre-holiday caution and staged a selective advance although without the benefit of any expansion in volume. High-price issues showed substantial increases and the composite rate was increased 1.02 points.

The retelling of the story of Christ's birth was heard last night by thousands of devout Christians attending Christmas Eve programs in the churches. As usual, stories, instrumental music and pageants were linked with carols, anthems, hymns and Scripture readings.

THE festival we celebrate today has many elements that go deep into the mists of antiquity and bind together the people of the world. Christmas, Earl W. Count says in his simple and devout book, "4,000 Years of Christmas,"* is "a spontaneous drama of the common folk, a prayer, a hymn.

With the exception of a small segment of ultra-orthodox Jews, which still believes that restoration of Israel should remain in the hands of the Messiah rather than be achieved by political Zionism, Jewish religious leaders of Jerusalem are virtually of one mind regarding the State's future and how it should be attained.

OTTAWA, Dec. 24 -- An emphatic denial was given here today to a report from Geneva that political motives might have caused the Canadian Government to decline the suggestion that the Executive Committee of the International Refugee Organization should meet here next month.
NEW DELHI, India, Dec. 24--As viewed from here, the Dutch attack on the Indonesian Republic appears to have produced two reactions of possibly far-reaching significance. These...

MARSHALL, Mo., Dec. 24 (AP) -- The Missouri Valley College Vikings will fly to Tampa, Fla., Monday for their New Year's Day Cigar Bowl engagement with St. Thomas College of St. Paul, Minn., Coach Volney Ashford said tonight.

The 100th anniversary of the founding of St. Stephen's Roman Catholic Church, Twenty-eighth Street near Lexington Avenue, will be celebrated at a pontifical mass at 11 A.M., tomorrow, at which Auxiliary Bishop Joseph P. Donahue, vicar general of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York, will officiate.

New York's Knickerbockers, winners of twelve of their last fifteen Basketball Association of America games, tonight will play the Chicago Stags at Madison Square Garden. It will be the first meeting of the teams this season; last season the Chicagoans had a six-for-six record against the Knicks.

CINCINNATI, Dec. 24 (AP) -- The Donora, Pa., smog, which killed twenty persons last Oct. 30, barely missed being a "major catastrophe" Dr. Clarence A. Mills of the University of Cincinnati reported tonight.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 -- The Council of the Organization of American States by resolution today called upon the Governments of Costa Rica and Nicaragua to abstain from any hostile act as a result of their border controversy.
New York newspaper funds for the aid of needy individuals, underprivileged children and hospitalized veterans have received more than $580,300 to date, it was reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 -- Average primary market prices advanced 0.5 per cent during the week ended on Dec. 21, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. The index is now 163.8 per cent of the 1926 average, 0.7 per cent lower than four weeks ago and 0.4 per cent higher than in the comparable week in 1947.

Sugar futures on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange yesterday enjoyed the second most active day in the domestic No. 5 contract for the entire year with sales totaling 903 lots or 45,150 tons. This activity was due primarily to the announcement by the Secretary of Agriculture on Thursday after the close of the market of sugar quotas for 1949.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 -- The Economic Cooperation Administration signed with The New York Herald Tribune, Inc., today the first "information media" contract providing for circulation of newspapers in Bizone Germany.

Youth made a brilliant showing in the second round of the international tournament, five games of which were contested at the Manhattan Chess Club last night. George Kramer of Forest Hills carried off the honors of the session by defeating Herman Steiner of Los Angeles, United States champion, in a hard-fought match lasting 40 moves.
BOSTON, Dec. 24 (AP) -- The Boston Weather Bureau tonight issued these ski reports and forecasts:

MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 24 (AP) -- Fifty of the nation's leading college football players held final drills today and were pronounced ready for their meeting in the annual North-South charity game in the Orange Bowl tomorrow night.

A 37-year-old Brooklyn patrolman was arraigned yesterday in Brooklyn Felony Court charged with the fatal shooting of his invalid uncle. The accused, John Moore, attached to the Seventeenth Detective District, waived examination before Magistrate Thomas H. Cullen on a charge of homicide and was held without bail for action of the grand jury.
MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 24 (AP) -- Tropical Park race track announced today that it is more than $92,000 in the red after the first half of its forty-day meeting.

The National Education Association in a report presents the underlying facts that support the case for Federal aid to public schools. This presentation is made in a carefully reasoned, unimpassioned fashion which establishes beyond argument, to our satisfaction at least, that there will never be equal opportunity in education throughout this country until Federal intervention and help make it so.

TROUT RUN, Pa., Dec. 24 (AP) -- Members of the Volunteer Fire Department in this north central Pennsylvania community answered the fire siren tonight only to find their own firehouse ablaze. A fire which chief Eugene Bubb estimated caused more than $10,000 damage leveled the two-story frame firehouse and an adjoining building, destroying virtually all equipment.
