'Twas the night before Christmas and all through Trinity Church Cemetery tramped 400 children and adults in the thirty-eighth annual pilgrimage to the grave of Dr. Clement Clarke Moore.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Dec. 24 -- Vermont state detectives tonight began questioning Carl W. Rockel, 23 years old, an art student of Roxbury, Mass., in the disappearance two years ago of Paula Welden, 18-year-old Bennington College, Vt., sophomore.

The Brown Williamson Tobacco Corporation is preparing to revive its pre-war premium program, with Raleighs, its sales leader, slated to carry the first of the new coupons, it was reported yesterday by reliable tobacco, premium and advertising sources here.

SOFIA, Bulgaria, Dec. 24 -- Georgi Chankov, chairman of the State Control Commission and member of the Communist party's Political Bureau, in a report today on changes in the statutes governing the party, proposed that it change its name.

The text of President Truman's speech at his Independence home in connection with ceremonies marking the lighting of the community Christmas tree on the White House grounds in Washington, as recorded and transcribed by THE NEW YORK TIMES:

GREAT FALLS, Mont., Dec. 24 -- Julius C. Peters, oil producer, announced here today that he had sold his interest in the Silver Tip petroleum field in Wyoming to the Seaboard Oil Company of New York for $3,000,000.

Organized religion in Japan today faces two tremendous problems, first the re-building of a war-shattered Church economy and, second, the establishment of a new religious leadership, absolved from the taint of association in the public mind with the former militaristic, totalitarian regimes.

"North African Prelude: The First 7,000 Years," by Galbraith Welch, will be published on Jan. 4 by Morrow. It is a complete history of North Africa, from the legend of Antaeus, the giant slain by Hercules, to the end of World War II. Mrs. Welch, an American who now makes her home in France, is the author of "The Unveiling of Timbuctoo."

The Gibson Refrigerator Company transacted a new high volume of $47,659,023 in sales during its fiscal year ending last September, resulting in record net earnings of $3,766,884, according to the annual report of Charles J. Gibson, president, issued yesterday.

ROME, Saturday, Dec. 25 (UP) -- At the stroke of midnight, Pope Pius XII started two special masses for the Vatican City diplomatic corps in the beautiful Mathilde Chapel on the second floor of the Apostolic Palace.
ROME, Dec. 24 (AP) -- The official English text of Pope Pius' Christmas Eve address to the College of Cardinals.
Disestablishment of the Church in Yugoslavia and its separation from the state is a fundamental fact underlying every problem faced by Church leaders here since the end of the war.

Seeking to make up losses incurred earlier in the season, manufacturers of fur garments will liquidate stocks during January and February, it was learned yesterday. Markdowns on finished garments, they said, will bring prices to a level well below a theoretical level that might exist if the 20 per cent excise taxes were not in effect on this particular category of merchandise.
Your editorial of Dec. 9, entitled "New Housing Policy," does not go to the root of the matter, in the writer's opinion.

A petition has been sent to Mayor O'Dwyer, signed by two-fifths of the tuberculosis patients at Bellevue Hospital, asking him to take immediate action to ease the crowded conditions in the wards, it was learned yesterday.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 24 (AP) -- As Anthony J. (Tony) Morabito sees it, "the door is open for peace" between the two warring professional football loops, the All-America Conference and the National League.

A man who was mistaken for a burglar while doing a turn for Santa Claus was in a critical condition yesterday in the Rockaway Beach Hospital with bullet wounds of the abdomen and knee received in a fight with an off-duty policeman in Rockaway Park, also Queens.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 -- Inventions designed to keep waterpipes from bursting in winter, to safeguard textile and other materials from deterioration and destruction by mildew and mold caused by tropical heat, humidity and dampness and to prevent woolens of all kinds from shrinking no matter how frequently washed, were among those approved this week by the United States Patent Office in a total of 499.
The greatest number of contributions to the thirty-seventh annual New York Times Neediest Cases Fund was received yesterday, Christmas Eve. A total of $13,773.75 was donated by 656 contributors.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Dec. 24 -- The Hudson and Manhattan Railroad Company, in its annual report now in the mails, told its stockholders that it was preparing to file for increases in interstate and intrastate fares.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 24 (AP) -- Secretary of Agriculture Charles F. Brannan recommended a large increase in livestock today to eat what otherwise might be surplus grain.

ATHENS, Dec. 24 -- Units of the Communist-led rebels that attacked the towns of Edessa and Naoussa in western Macedonia three days ago have been defeated and are being pursued by National Army forces, a general staff communique said tonight.

SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, Dec. 24 -- The last remnants of the invading force fled from Costa Rican soil after Government forces occupied La Cruz yesterday, intelligence headquarters of the General Staff said tonight.

Joseph Bonavita, the liberal Brooklyn tavernkeeper who has been spreading cheer on the Bowery for two years to the consternation of the police and the bewilderment of Bellevue Hospital authorities, returned there yesterday with another fistful of cash.

NANKING, Dec. 24 -- Kalgan, a major center of the Nationalists in North China, fell to Communist forces today, according to the Communist radio. The broadcast said the troops defending the city, reckoned by the Communists at seven divisions, were "completely wiped out" by 3 P.M.

VIENNA, Dec. 24 -- Secretary of the Army Kenneth C. Royall, here on his tour of United States Army installations, was asked at a press conference today why Lieut. Col. Walter Reschel of the former American military mission in Budapest had been kept for sixteen months here awaiting court-martial.

CORNWALL, Conn., Dec. 24 -- Opportunists were out in great force this windswept day to enjoy the huge network of open slopes and trails that make up the lavish Mohawk Ski Area. While five inches of snow, drifted in places, is a far cry from the grand sport that should be available with another few inches of cover, the running was not too bad.

ALBANY, Dec. 24--The New York State Legislature, convening here next month, will be called upon to adopt the highest budget in the state's history for the fiscal year 1949-50. Commitments already made by the administration or required by statute will make it necessary for the legislators to find at least $107,000,000 in new taxes.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange experienced a quiet day yesterday and final prices were 2 to 4 points net lower.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 24 (AP) -- A 50-year-old woman, ill from giving her "golden blood" to save hundreds of lives in the last twelve years, got help herself today.

The first large collection of mutation minks offered this season by the New York Auction company met good buyer response for the better grades, it was reported yesterday at the conclusion of the sale. The auction was also marked by the introduction of a new mutation named "Golden Cross."

South America is so overwhelmingly Roman Catholic that, while there may be disturbing strains and pulls within the confines of that faith, Catholic leaders are not inclined to take seriously any outside threat.

YONKERS, N.Y., Dec. 24 Two men drank enough liquor today to weaken their sense of property rights but not enough to keep out the cold. The result was that about 3 o'clock this morning they made off with an empty trolley car.
Board of Transportation engineers began yesterday to replace 14,400 worn wheels on subway and trolley cars, using an appropriation of $910,249 voted by the Board of Estimate for the purpose.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 24 (AP) -- There was an upset in the featured six-furlong Philammon Purse at Tropical Park today when Dubious, the heavily backed favorite, could do no better than finish third.

CLEVELAND, Dec. 24 (AP) -- Admission of "cheap" foreign iron ore through the proposed St. Lawrence Seaway would discourage the Lake Superior ore program, according to Alexander C. Brown, president of the Cleveland-Cliffs Iron Company.

The plan to move the Phil Harris-Alice Faye show from NBC to CBS has fallen through. The Columbia network now is turning its attention to other means of further strengthening its Sunday night line-up following the acquisition of the Jack Benny program.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 -- Samuel Reber, the United States Deputy in the Austrian treaty negotiations, formally proposed today, as chairman of the Deputies, that they resume their efforts to draft a peace treaty for Austria in London on Feb. 7.
DETROIT, Dec. 24 (AP) -- Gar Wood probably will not drive a boat in the next Harmsworth Trophy race.

Joseph W. Frazer, president of the Kaiser-Frazer Corporation, predicted yesterday in a year-end statement that consumer demand for cars will continue to run ahead of supply in 1949. He declared, however, that automotive production in the new year will exceed the 3,900,000 passenger cars produced in 1948.
CAIRO, Dec. 24 -- The War Ministry stated that Egyptian forces had repulsed an Israeli attack in the Hebron area today, capturing some weapons. Hebron city is twenty miles southwest of Jerusalem.

PARIS, Dec. 24 -- The differences among the Marshall Plan nations over the recovery policy remained unbridged today. After a prolonged session their Executive Committee failed to agree on a report by their experts that urged revision of the national four-year plans in the direction of austerity.

By way of variety in items dealing with race relations in the South, perhaps your readers would be interested in the following paragraph from the current annual report of the Jasper County (S.C.) Department of Public Welfare; the physician referred to and all members of the Welfare Board and staff are white:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 -- The Interstate Commerce Commission approved today rates made by the Newtex Steamship Corporation in agreements with five local trucking companies, to pick up and deliver carload traffic between Port Newark, N.J., points in New Jersey from fifteen to twenty miles north and south of Newark, points in Manhattan south of the Bronx, Brooklyn and the remainder of New York City, and from five groups of New Jersey points.

Officials of the Teachers Union, Local 555, United Public Workers, CIO, charged last night that school authorities were responsible for the death of Mrs. Minnie Gutride, 40 years old, a teacher who was found Thursday night in her home, 200 West Sixteenth Street, with her head on a gas stove and two jets open.

A brokerage business specializing in securities of Palestine enterprises which Abraham H. Sakier established here ten years ago has been re-established after suspension during the war, Mr. Sakier announced yesterday. Its quarters are at 40 Exchange Place.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 24 -- In a surprise move, Howard Hughes, controlling owner of RKO, disclosed today that Robert Mitchum, who is scheduled to go to trial on narcotics charges here Jan. 10, will begin work in a new picture, "The Big Steal," next Monday or Tuesday.

LAKE SUCCESS, Dec. 24 -- The United Nations today told a story of Christmas sadness in the Holy Land, where 750,000 wandering refugees of the Palestine war share rude sanctuary in barns and stables of biblical towns such as Nazareth and Acre and Tyre.
ATHENS, Ga., Dec. 24 (AP) -- It might have been the Christmas spirit but for once Georgia Football Coach Wallace Butts wasn't in a weepy mood with a big game a week away.

Tomorrow night New Stages, Inc., the downtown producing group, will ring up the curtain on Thornton Wilder's adaptation of Jean-Paul Sartre's "The Victors" at its own playhouse on Bleecker Street, while John Yorke will unfold "Oh, Mr. Meadowbrook!" starring Ernest Truex, at the repatriated John Golden Theatre, until recently utilized as a movie showcase.
DALLAS, Dec. 24 (AP) -- Brad Ecklund, Oregon's durable oak of football, will start his ninety-first straight game Jan. 1.

BINGHAMTON, Dec. 24 -- The health of twenty-two nations was toasted fervently here tonight as forty-five men, women and children settled down by the firesides of this town and for its second United Nations Christmas celebration.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 (AP) -- The Department of Commerce today ended licensing requirements for the export of streptomycin, called the "wonder drug." The only exception will be for countries in Europe and adjacent areas in the Mediterranean.

CHICAGO, Dec. 24 -- Lumbermen were warned today to proceed cautiously in planning their 1949 operations, although they were assured that the current halt in the lumber business should be regarded as "a natural readjustment in mass thinking, when the economic machine goes over the peak and strikes a relatively level plateau."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 (AP) -- The dollar volume of November retail sales ran 3 per cent above last year at a total of $11,015,000,000, the Department of Commerce reported today. That bettered the November showing of department store sales, usually the quickest indicator of the general retail sales pattern.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Dec. 24 (AP) -- Two powerful all-star elevens, many of their players already drafted for pro football, will meet here tomorrow in the eleventh annual Blue-Gray classic. The game is rated a toss-up.
Seven new pictures will make their initial appearances on local screens today. They are:

Since the war Dutch churchmen of all persuasions have been primarily concerned with the task of winning the people back to the Ten Commandments. Waywardness that was encouraged in wartime still gives trouble among young people.

CHICAGO, Dec. 24 -- Prices of grains averaged higher today on the Board of Trade although some irregularity developed late in the session. A short-covering movement developed in soy beans and the March contract was up 4 cents a bushel at one time.

PARIS, Dec. 24 -- The United Nations Security Council today adopted a resolution calling for an immediate cease fire in Indonesia and the release of President Sukarno and other political prisoners taken into custody by the Dutch since the start of their offensive on Dec. 18.

Dr. D. Soemitro, acting head of the Indonesian delegation to the United Nations, in a press statement yesterday attacked the Security Council's cease-fire order as "meaningless and completely inadequate." He said that it would let the Dutch carry on "mopping up" operations in seized areas and would stand as a precedent permitting future use of force in violation of international agreements.
OMAHA, Dec. 24 (AP) -- A special session of the U.S. District Court was held today so a young mother and her 4-month-old daughter would not have to spend Christmas in jail.

Of China's 450,000,000 population not more than 5,000,000 are listed as Christians -- an estimated 3,500,000 to 4,000,000 are Roman Catholics and about 1,000,000 are Protestants. But wherever the traveler goes in China, in big cities, in remote provincial county seats, and often in obscure hamlets, he is apt to run into one or more of 10,000 foreign missionaries functioning here.
The Church of Sweden is Lutheran and the bulk of the Swedes are raised in the Lutheran creed as expounded by the state-ordained clergy.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 -- Attorney General Tom C. Clark departed from the Justice Department's policy of silence concerning its investigations today to say that Laurence Duggan, former State Department official who plunged to his death from his New York office window last Monday, had been "a loyal employe of the United States Government."

It becomes our pleasant duty this morning to express thanks to the several thousand readers of THE NEW YORK TIMES who have sent in contributions to the Neediest Cases Fund. The thirty-seventh annual appeal has brought a response of $272,549 in gifts from 8,186 donors since it was opened on Dec. 5.

Irving Sasnow has purchased the two five-story buildings at 350-53 West Twenty-third Street from Samuel Simms. The property is assessed at $78,000. One of the buildings is the Allerton Hotel Annex, which contains a store on the ground floor.
Contributions from groups of school children, office workers and student nurses were among the Christmas Eve gifts received yesterday by THE NEW YORK TIMES Neediest Cases Fund.

Santa Claus and his reindeer raced across the cold, blue sky last night, in from the North Pole on his annual visit, with gifts and good cheer. Children and Christmas carols -- "Silent Night, Holy Night" -- welcomed Santa, his bright red sleigh and racing team -- "now Dasher, now Dancer, now Prancer . . ."
LONDON, Dec. 24 (UP) -- There is more food available for Europe's Christmas tables this year than at any time since the war -- but at a price.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 -- President Truman's advisers have not yet agreed on the strategy they will recommend to the Chief Executive in approaching Congress on labor legislation, it was reliably reported today.

TOKYO, Dec. 24 -- Government circles have moved into high gear drafting policies implementing Gen. Douglas MacArthur's recent orders for Japanese industrial recovery. Today orders went out tightening price and distribution controls over staple foods, marine products, coal and leather.

Mayor O'Dwyer intervened yesterday in the contract dispute between tugboat workers and employers by appointing a three-man committee to attempt to save the city from a harbor-crippling work stoppage should one be called when the present contract expires Friday.

The Christmas shopping season ended yesterday with retailers disappointed over earlier sales expectations but unable to complain about business that in most cases came close to record sales of last year. Great concern was shown, however, over the obvious decline in buying enthusiasm during the last two months.

Many a father will have a vision this morning, for as he watches the face of his son when he removes the last Christmas wrapping from his "first gun," he will see there the promise of many years of real companionship in the field.

It is an old Chinese custom to "honor one's teachers." It is also an old Chinese custom to "remember one's friends." Because of both customs, this will be a memorable Christmas for a retired 74-year-old school teacher from Portland. Ore.

A charge of assault against five officers of the National Maritime Union was made yesterday when a summons was obtained in Lower Manhattan Court by a former seaman who in turn was charged with assault and unlawful entry at the union hall, 346 West Seventeenth Street.

Subway motormen on the New York City Transit System must complete 150 hours of training and pass a stiff civil service examination to qualify for their jobs, the Board of Transportation pointed out yesterday.
Harried housewives are finding at least one way to steal a "holiday from apron strings" with the help of Y.W.C.A.'s in, at last count, 294 cities throughout the country.

BETHLEHEM, Dec. 24 -- The birthday of Christ was never celebrated with more difficulty than this year in this, His birthplace. A clerical pilgrimage came easily from near-by Beit Jala, but those who journeyed from Jerusalem -- and they constituted the bulk of the pilgrims -- really had to demonstrate faith or determination.

SEOUL, Korea, Dec. 24 -- President Syngman Rhee announced today two major Cabinet changes. T.S. Chang, the Foreign Minister, has been named the President's special envoy to London. T.Y. Yun, Home Minister, was assigned a similar post in Manila.

In spite of the increased industrial activity, carloadings of the Class 1 carriers this year will be down almost 4 per cent from those of 1947. Through the week ended on Dec. 11, loadings were 41,470,118 cars, a decline of 1,600,586 below the 43,070,074 in the similar period of 1947.

The State Council of the Steuben Society of America has adopted a resolution urging New York State to acquire the properties of the Hudson River Day Line, continue operation of its two vessels and integrate Indian Point Park into the State Park System, it was announced yesterday.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 24 -- Prospects for peace on the Pacific Coast waterfront took on a Christmas sheen today after a meeting of representatives of shoreside unions, Harry Lundeberg's Sailors Union of the Pacific, ship operators and of the American Federation of Labor conferred for more than two hours.

The happiest holidays are those people "go home" for. Going home may mean youngsters returning from school or job, sometimes bringing their own younger youngsters with them. It may mean going to "Grandma-and-Grandpa's." Home is where Father and Mother are, or where one of them was brought up.
ALBANY, Dec. 24 (AP) -- Governor Dewey gave Christmas presents of freedom today to six men convicted of crimes ranging from first degree murder to robbery. The commutations were as follows:

Religious forces in foreign lands are tenaciously standing their ground against the challenge of communism and the unceasing onslaughts of their age-old adversaries, secularism and materialism, according to a survey of the spiritual climate by sixteen correspondents of THE NEW YORK TIMES in various parts of the globe.

WIESBADEN, Germany, Dec. 24 -- Secretary for Air W. Stuart Symington disclosed today that the United States was purchasing more new planes in support of the Berlin airlift. He would not reveal what type nor how many, explaining that an announcement would be made in Washington.

INDEPENDENCE, Mo., Dec. 24 -- Here in the midst of his kinfolk, where he is celebrating "the great home festival," President Truman rededicated himself this Christmas Eve to the cause of peace and brotherhood.

GAZA, Palestine, Dec. 24 (AP) -- The commander of the Egyptian forces in Palestine said today that fighting in the Negeb, desert area of southern Palestine, had ended this morning in victory for Egypt.
OTTAWA, Dec. 24 -- Canada has recognized de facto the Provisional Government of Israel, it was announced today by External Affairs Minister L.B. Pearson.

The Emergency Merchant Marine Council has sent to the CIO Maritime Committee in Washington the text of a proposed amendment to the National Selective Service Act extending draft exemption to seamen for war service. According to an announcement yesterday by Irving Banchik, chairman of the recently formed council, Hoyt Haddock, executive secretary of the CIO committee, has agreed to press for its introduction before Congress.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 (AP) -- Attorney General Tom C. Clark announced tonight that the simplified procedure for "unblocking" foreign assets in this country will end at midnight, Dec. 31.

CONWAY, Pa., Dec. 24 (UP) -- A special holiday mail and express train crashed into a derailed freight car in the Pennsylvania Railroad yards here tonight, killing the engineer and seriously injuring the fireman.

India, in her second year of independence, is engaged in a strenuous effort to divorce religion and state, while retaining great pride in what Hindus consider a superior spiritual depth in their national mentality, as compared with that of the West.

As with everything else in this country, politics is inseparable from religion. And politics means primarily the racial problem, not only as regards relations between whites and non-whites, but also between the whites themselves.

PARIS, Dec. 24 -- Gen. Enrique Lister, who held a command in the International Brigade during the Spanish Civil War, was released today after detention and prolonged interrogation by French security authorities.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 24 (AP) -- Long shot speculators whooped with delight at the Fair Grounds today over heavy prices posted on three winners, and the second daily double in three days to pay more than $1,000.
Two immediate organizational drives in New York department stores were announced yesterday by the Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America, CIO.

The Roman Catholic Church is under no illusions that the general election of April 18, 1948, eliminated the Communist menace in Italy -- at most it gave the anti-Communist parties a breathing spell. Its active opposition to communism therefore continues vigorously and shows no signs of faltering.

NORFOLK, Va., Dec. 24 (UP) -- An ice breaker was ordered today to assist the escort aircraft carrier Saipan in its attempt to rescue eleven fliers stranded atop a 7,700-foot ice cap in Greenland. The Saipan, her crew cut to 1,200, is due to leave the naval base here about noon tomorrow for the five-day journey.
PARIS, Dec. 24 -- Tonight the French began celebrating their most Merry Christmas since 1938 Food was plentiful in markets while shops were jammed with merchandise, most of it of pre-war quality.

THE HAGUE, The Netherlands, Dec. 24 -- An atmosphere of restrained optimism prevailed in the Dutch Foreign Office and Ministry of Overseas Territories here today on receipt of the news from Paris that the United Nations Security Council had adopted what was interpreted as a relatively mild resolution.

DETROIT, Dec. 24 -- Bishop Creighton, who maintained his residence in Detroit until his formal retirement last spring, was a native of Philadelphia and had been a successful business man for fourteen years before he entered a seminary.

Lumber production for the week ended Dec. 18 was 18.6 per cent below a year ago and 9.6 per cent below the previous week. Shipments were down 25 per cent compared with last year and orders 17.2 per cent, according to reports wired yesterday to THE NEW YORK TIMES by trade associations.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 (AP) -- President Truman declared today that in a large sense it was the American people -- not any special groups -- who won the Nov. 2 election. And, he added, the voters spoke so decisively that day that "no one in this country or anywhere in the world doubts the meaning."
Religious leaders in the Soviet zone of Germany feel they have one main problem -- survival.
ROME, Dec. 24 -- Pope Pius XII called on all Christian nations today to unite and resist aggression even "by force of arms" if necessary.

A large local home furnishings outlet has notified two top radio suppliers that it will no longer place commitments for months in advance, one of its executives reported yesterday. From now on, he said, all purchases will be made entirely on a fill-in basis as was done prior to the war.

The bedding industry will offer its first list of fair trade practice rules for Federal Trade Commission approval at a meeting to be held in Chicago on Jan. 6, it was announced yesterday. Irving Weisglass, president of Eclipse Sleep Products, Inc., and chairman of a manufacturers' committee which compiled the list, said that the move is necessary now because of increasingly competitive conditions.

PARIS, Dec. 24 -- After a debate that had lasted more than twenty hours the French National Assembly shortly after 11 A.M. today adopted a synthetic budget bill setting the maximum appropriation for each Government department.

The Army transport Thomas H. Barry, a veteran troopship in the service of the Army Transportation Corps since June 1941, is nearing the end of her military career, it was announced here yesterday by the New York Port of Embarkation.

There had to be a Christmas, for this day meets a deep need in human nature. It is true that some generations of the Christian era, so the old historians tell us, went by before this need was recognized; and after that it took a long time for the observance to grow and spread; and after that a long time for it to take the form it has today.

Religious leaders in France join their colleagues in other countries in being preoccupied above anything else with the current danger to world peace. To this danger they link the problems of social justice and understanding among peoples, for they believe that peace can flourish only where discontent and distrust are reduced to a minimum.

LONDON, Dec. 24 -- It was the night before Christmas in southeast London. Along a gloomy, misty street, past the endless rows of semi-detached houses, walked a happily overburdened man. His left arm was freighted with parcels and with his right hand he dragged a bright brand-new doll carriage.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 -- The State Department's Voice of America is taking overseas listeners on a Christmas radio tour of typical American homes and churches over the holiday.

PARIS, Dec. 24 -- Jacob A. Malik, Soviet delegate, charged in the Security Council today that Vassily D. Tarasenko, permanent Ukrainian representative on the Council, had been unable to return to Paris for the meeting because he had gone to Berlin and the French consul would not give him a visa.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 -- The Republican National Committee today was called to meet in Omaha on Jan. 26 and 27 for its first post-election analysis and to consider a plan for a national party policy conference next year to draft a program on which the GOP will seek control of the House and Senate in 1950.

The use of "tagged atoms" and other radioactive materials as "tracers" in industry is becoming so widespread that it is now advisable to incorporate special facilities for handling these materials in the design of all new laboratory buildings, Dr. Karl Cohen, director of the Atomic Energy Division of the H.K. Ferguson Company, industrial engineers and builders, said yesterday following a study of the problem.

Twenty-four hours behind schedule, the Maritime Commission transport liner Marine Marlin docked at the United States Line pier at West Twenty-first Street yesterday with 549 passengers from Hamburg. Heavy weather held her back.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 (AP) -- A displaced persons bill aimed at eliminating all of President Truman's objections to the present law will be pushed from both ends of the Capitol in the new Congress.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 24 (AP) -- The West team in the Shrine's charity football game Jan. 1 suffered a blow tonight with an announcement that Jack Kirby, University of Southern California halfback, would not be able to play because of an injury.

Verdi's "Aida" was the Christmas Eve offering of the Metropolitan Opera. The production was replete with brilliant colors, large-scale pageantry, pretty melodies, pretty dancing girls, the usual wooden operatic acting and a whiff of musty odor which might have come from Egypt itself, but which actually came from the ancient stage settings.

BATAVIA, Java, Dec. 24 (UP) -- The Netherland army today reported the capture of a central Javanese town as its commander in chief urged his men "to live up to the Christmas spirit" by bringing peace to Indonesia.
Alleged religious persecution in Spain of a Protestant minority must be viewed against a background of the country's laws.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., Dec. 24 -- The twenty-eighth annual community presentation here of the Pageant of the Nativity of Christ took place this evening on the hillside of the Reformed Church at Pondfield Road and Midland Avenue.

It is high time somebody came forward with a few kind words in defense of the Long Island Railroad. Until now it has shared, with the weather man, the dubious honor of being the object of more slurs, quips and gibes than a mongrel pup has fleas. Yet I have observed that seasoned commuters on the Oyster Bay branch recount their experiences with justifiable pride.

Greek Orthodoxy is not opposed to communism as such -- that is, as a political theory -- and emphatic pronouncements to this effect have been made within recent years by its head, His Beatitude Damaskinos, Archbishop of Athens and All Greece.

JERUSALEM, Dec. 24 -- The Christmas Eve pilgrimage to Bethlehem this year is the most restricted in modern times. The little town where Christ was born has been the backwash of many wars, but as long as anyone can remember the historic road from Jerusalem has been open to all who wished to attend midnight Mass in the Church of the Nativity.

HAMMOND, La., Dec. 24 (AP) -- The running and passing of Charley Justice today highlighted the North Carolina football team's last hard practice for this week, in preparation for the Jan. 1 Sugar Bowl game at New Orleans.

BERLIN, Dec. 24 (AP) -- Seven top cronies of Hitler who were sentenced to prison instead of the gallows were allowed to be together today for the first time in a year. Behind the walls of Spandau Prison, these seven sole inmates of a fortress built to jail 1,800 were assembled by guards of four nations and permitted to hold religious services for an hour.

There is nothing in Islam as a religion that infringes the rights and liberties of religious or other minorities. Islam preaches equality of rights within the State. It includes the concept of "the citizen," so that in principle, Christians and Jews would have nothing to fear as long as they remained good citizens.

FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Dec. 24 (AP) -- Many of the nation's finest collegiate swimmers, including members of the United States Olympic team, will compete here tomorrow in the tenth annual East-West swimming meet.

In winning the first game of the international chess tourney at the Manhattan Chess Club, Miguel M. Najdorf of Buenos Aires did not permit his opponent, Herman Pilnik, also of Buenos Aires, to recover from a cramped position in the opening. Najdorf triumphed in forty moves.

In the first conveyance since 1860, a large tract of vacant land in the Bronx, diagonally opposite the Yankee Stadium, has been sold by the William Waldorf Astor estate to a group which will improve it with a commercial development.
TRENTON, N.J., Dec. 24 -- The voters of New Jersey may be asked to approve an income tax to finance a veterans' bonus as the solution of a long-standing controversial issue.

LONDON, Dec. 24 -- Britain's Foreign Office officials will go on their Christmas week-end feeling somewhat relieved about the Indonesian problem. The first reaction here was more critical of the United States in some ways than of the Dutch, but the resolution, as worked out and passed today by the United Nations Security Council, is held to be a fair compromise.

On Christmas Eve the Security Council addressed to the Netherlands Government a resolution on the Indonesian situation which was so mild that it might almost be called a Christmas present. It called upon the Indonesians, who have, been attacked, as well as upon the Dutch, who are the attackers, to "cease hostilities forth-with."
TORONTO, Dec. 25 (AP) -- Rookie Ray Timgren and Veteran Max Bentley led the Toronto Maple Leafs to a 2-1 Triumph over the Detroit Red Wings in a National Hockey League game tonight before 13,019.
ROME, Dec. 25 -- Pope Pius spent a quiet Christmas, working in his library most of the morning and entertaining his relatives at an intimate reception in his private apartment this afternoon.

LONDON, Dec. 25 -- Lenin once described the Far East as the "back door of the capitalist and imperialist powers." It is at that back door that the Soviet Union, checked for the present in the West, is battering in furtherance of its long-term design of expansion and world revolution.

AT midnight Friday the 2,300 room Hotel Pennsylvania, which has in the past thirty years housed thousands of conventions, and sheltered, fed and entertained millions of travelers, will become the Hotel Statler.

ROME, Dec. 25 (UP) -- Vatican engineers are working to make St. Peter's Basilica, Christendom's largest church, completely safe for the thousands of visitors expected during the 1950 holy year, Chief Engineer Francesco Bacchini said today.

Suppliers and promoters of merchandise used by large national advertisers for premium campaigns are becoming increasingly active in deals for large quantities of Japanese products, it was disclosed yesterday by Howard W. Dunk, head of the New York Premium Club.

At a time when most of the airline companies are singing the blues, or just emerging from a holiday of the jitters, it is refreshing to find one skywise transport system that has buckled down to opening up new avenues of revenue.

THIS is the time of the year when precedent order a backward look at the events of the past twelve months. Sometimes that can be dangerous. Lot's wife once took a backward look and you know what happened to her. Bravely risking salt, the look is hereby taken.

Seating facilities in the City College library remain inadequate although the total number of volumes has been increased to 343,565, Librarian Jerome K. Wilcox said in his annual report, released yesterday. The report indicates a net growth of 12,188 volumes for the twelve-month period ended in June, 1948.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Dec. 12 -- After a series of much needed mergers for the sake of clarification and unity, Israel's multifarious political parties have narrowed the field down to about a dozen to stand the test of a general election, which is to be held. Jan. 25.

As the year draws to a close four major questions in Government-industry relations remain to be answered before many of the most important phases of the national defense program can move forward, industrialists here revealed last week.

It looked like a really merry Christmas for the New York Knickerbockers when the local entrant in the Basketball Association of America soared to a 10-point lead over the Chicago Stags last night at Madison Square Garden. Late in the third quarter the Knicks enjoyed a 47-37 pull and since all were going to a holiday party at Leone's later, there was peace and good will on Eighth Avenue.

CAIRO, Dec. 25 -- A Foreign Office communique denied tonight an Israeli allegation that Egypt had refused to enter into negotiations for a permanent truce in Palestine and in turn accused Israel of having failed to carry out the United Nations Security Council's order of troop withdrawals in the Negeb.
FORT MONMOUTH, N.J., Dec. 25 -- The Army Signal Corps has designed a new camera to be used in making pictures in an airplane while in flight for use in meteorological research.

A plea for peace that went unhedeed, the "Olive Branch Petition" of the American Colonists to King George III for a peaceful settlement of their differences, went on exhibition yesterday in the main entrance hall of the New York Public Library, Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Dec. 25 -- Israel has ordered a complete and unrestricted blackout effective tonight for the entire Jewish state. Israeli blackouts previously had been restricted to the battle areas.

SOME day, perhaps, this department will learn not to make rash statements. Only two weeks ago as this is published, I invited retribution by overconfidently remarking that "If there is a living person, aside from a few professors of English literature specializing in the eighteenth century, who has read through the eight volumes of Richardson's 'Clarissa,' I should like to know his name."

BERLIN, Dec. 25 (UP) -- Bob Hope and other Hollywood stars entertained GI's today, while United State Military Governor, Gen. Lucius D. Clay, was host to Vice President-elect Barkley and high United States officials at Christmas dinner.

For the twenty-sixth time, Dr. Lewis A. Leventen spent Christmas Day in a police station. Yesterday's sojourn was in the same Elizabeth Street precinct as the other twenty-five holiday visits. But, as usual, the visit meant no inscriptions on the police blotter.

SOME years ago a biography of William F. Cody carried the subtitle "Last of the Plainsmen." That was an excusable touch of drama, but not particularly accurate, since Buffalo Bill was considerably more of a showman than he ever was a plainsman -- nor was he the last, by a regiment or so, of either class.

CHICAGO, Dec. 25 -- Central Western employes who received Christmas bonus checks this week discovered that in many cases they were about half as large as those of the war years. Others were dismayed to find that employers had discontinued this Yuletide practice altogether.

The topic "Can We Make Ourselves More Popular Abroad?" will be discussed at 9:30 P.M. Wednesday at the forum "What's on Your Mind?" conducted by Delbert Clark for THE NEW YORK TIMES over station WQXR.

Renewal of the Olympic Games, last previously held in 1936 at Berlin, resulted in a sweeping triumph for the United States at London and the finest manifestation of the spirit in which they were conceived since their modern revival in 1896.
FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Dec. 25 (AP) -- A fast team of collegiate swimmers from the West defeated the East today, 66 to 42, in the tenth annual East-West swimming meet.

Activity in the wholesale apparel market here last week continued to center on retailers' last-minute calls for holiday merchandise, according to a report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell Company, resident buying office.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Dec. 25 -- King Ibn Saud of Saudi Arabia has definitely lined up against King Abdullah of Trans-Jordan on the question of uniting Arab Palestine to Trans-Jordan, according to a reliable Arab source here. However, there is good reason to believe that Abdullah intends to flout him and proclaim the union within the next few weeks.

LONDON, Dec. 25 (Reuters) -- Representatives of the Indonesian Republic in Burma, Singapore, Pakistan, Afghanistan and India met in New Delhi today and released a statement describing as "most deplorable" the rejection of the proposed clause in the United Nations Security Council's resolution demanding the withdrawal of the Dutch armed forces to their original positions, the New Delhi radio reported.

BINGHAMTON, N.Y., Dec. 25 -- Walter W. Harris, a United Nations information service officer who is shepherding forty-eight United Nations employes on Christmas holiday visits in homes in Binghamton, Johnson City and Endicott, had his first encounter today with Christmas turkey, American style.
COLORADO SPRINGS, Col., Dec. 25 (AP) -- Colorado College breezed to a 7-3 victory tonight over Yale's hockey team in a match before 2,000 at the Broadmoor Ice Palace.

THIS was the year of sharp controversy and loud argument about modern art. The topic spread from the art pages into the general magazines, became subject of a museum's manifesto and even turned up on television. The old lines no longer held.

* * * Park Commissioner Robert Moses complains that traffic problems are intensified by people "tearing down perfectly sound buildings in order to substitute bigger ones." May I suggest that he sponsor a law requiring a permit for such an operation predicated upon proof that it will not add to an already over-loaded traffic condition in that particular locality?

WASHINGTON, Dec. 25 (AP) -- Leslie L. Biffle, staff director of the Senate's Democratic Policy Committee, said today that he has more than 80,000 personal applications for the 10,000 special reserved seats at the inaugural ceremonies for President Truman and Vice President-Elect Barkley on Jan. 20.

James Smith, 73 years old, earns $31.55 a week as a porter at the New York Athletic Club. Last night he put on a heavy scarf and a pea-jacket over his shabby suit -- he wore no shirt -- and walked through the wind and snow from his $4-a-week furnished room at 110 East Eleventh Street to the quarters of Fire Truck Company 3, at 108 East Thirteenth Street.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 25 -- The Republican minority in the incoming Congress, which assembles eight days from now, will have a single really effective leader -- Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio.
PASCAGOULA, Miss., Dec. 25 (AP) -- Murdock Hinton, aged 48, a Lucedale farmer, gave up with a sheepish grin today and calmly told officers he had shot four persons to death.

MONTREAL, Dec. 25 -- The Christmas party was all New York Rangers and particularly Chuck Rayner's tonight when the New Yorkers handed the Montreal Canadiens a 2-0 shut-out and gave Coach Lynn Patrick, directing his second game, his second victory.

Another milestone in the history of American railroads will be recorded tomorrow when the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad celebrates the 100th anniversary of the arrival of the first New Haven train into New York City.

HENRI MATISSE, nearing 80, instead of looking back on a full and influential life, is looking forward to the completion of what he calls his chef-d'oeuvre: the designing, building and decorating of a chapel to Saint Dominic. Living in quiet and isolated seclusion, Matisse has been working the last five years in the sun-tanned, two-story Villa le Reve, which is a ten-minute walk from the hill-town of ancient Vence.
SOFIA, Bulgaria Dec. 25 -- The building up of Communist power in the Cominform states is today an economic problem, which leaders of these states do not find easy to solve.

Although awards have fallen somewhat short of their hopes, officials of airlines have been encouraged both by the size of recent mail-pay proposals of the Civil Aeronautics Board for several domestic carriers and also by the intimation that most of the industry will receive mail-pay adjustments before Feb. 1.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 25 -- While Secretary of State George Marshall is reported to be recovering satisfactorily from his recent kidney operation in Walter Reed Hospital, it is realized here that his operation was a major one, and that at 68 years of age he may feel compelled to step down from his office.

AS I prepared for the Cosmopolitan Little Symphony's second Town Hall appearance tonight I was increasingly reminded of a point of view contributed to this page more than a year ago by Leonard Bernstein.

WHEN 412 young military recruits started hupping and saluting in three new training schools this fall, something new was definitely added to the American way of life. These recruits were women -- girls, really -- the first in the nation's history to sign up for three-year hitches in the regular military services.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 25 -- The established interdependence of tropical medicine and world trade should enlist the support of the country's business men for the research program of the American Foundation for Tropical Medicine, in the opinion of Ernest F. Gamache, executive director of the foundation.

THE Interstate Commerce Commission conducted a two-day hearing here last week into charges of black marketing of railroad space to Florida and when Commissioner Richard F. Mitchell adjourned the meeting -- to be resumed in Miami Jan. 24 and in Los Angeles Feb. 28 -- the problem of getting Pullman and coach space to Florida was just about where it was when the hearing began.

THE HAGUE, The Netherlands, Dec. 25 -- Queen Juliana delivered a Christmas broadcast to her people this afternoon, a brief message bidding them to remember the relatives of the troops in Indonesia, the men themselves, and also "those who are the opponents of our soldiers."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 25 (UP) -- Senator Alexander Wiley, Republican, of Wisconsin, defended the Taft-Hartley Act tonight by citing a Government official's report showing strike losses have dropped 40 to 50 per cent since the law was enacted.

Playing in championship form and carrying a sacrificial combination to a successful issue, Dr. Max Euwe of Amsterdam yesterday defeated Arthur Bisguier, champion of the Manhattan Chess Club, after forty moves in the third round of the club's international tournament.

Glaucoma, a frequent cause of blindness, has been treated successfully with a German war gas which in larger doses drives its victims mad, Wayne E. White recently reported to the American Chemical Society. The discovery by German chemists of a series of synthetic compounds of phosphorus and fluorine attracted little attention until the beginning of World War II.

As part of a freshman scholarship program to give students of special ability an opportunity to pursue their particular interests in college, Radcliffe is offering for 1949-50 a competitive award of $800 in history. The winner will be chosen on the basis of an examination prepared by the Harvard-Radcliffe department of history, which will be given next April at the applicants' schools.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 25 -- President Truman has decided, a close associate said today, to wait out George C. Marshall's recovery in the hope Mr. Marshall can resume his duties as Secretary of State.

THOUGH the fashion grows for regarding the original cubism as a period of light-minded experimentation, something of a temperamental brother to the succeeding Jazz Age, it remains one of the most remarkable and fecund of artistic periods.

At first it seems to Randy that the Ranch of Friends is misnamed, for the neighbors, Rosa and her grandfather, old Tomas Garcia, are prepared to carry on the hundred-year-old fight between the two families.

OTTAWA, Dec. 25 -- The decline in Canadian exports to Britain and the failure to reach an agreement between London and Ottawa on the price of next year's wheat shipments have begun to cause considerable controversy in this country and some anxiety for the future.

"His Majesty's loyal opposition," translated into any suitable American idiom, now has an opportunity to do its stuff. But there is vast confusion among Republicans as to how the manifest patriotic duty of a fairly strong minority should be discharged, under our two-party system.

Activity in financial markets was circumscribed last week as a result of the Christmas holidays. Some markets suspended operations at noon on Friday. On the New York Stock Exchange action centered principally around stock issues affected by dividends and split-ups.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 25 -- Gilbert A. Harrison, national chairman of the American Veterans Committee, charged in letters today to Attorney General Tom C. Clark and Secretary of the Treasury John W. Snyder that the Associated Klans of Georgia was "identical with the Knights of the Ku Klux Klan, Inc.", which, he said, was on the Attorney General's subversive list.
ALTHOUGH his acrobatic days are over, Mr. Flip Flop, a retired circus clown, somersaults merrily into the affections of his readers, whether they are playground age or parents.
SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 25 (AP) -Long morning workouts in cold, rainy weather marked the Christmas Day preparations of the East-West squads for the annual charity football game here New Year's Day.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 25 -- A sweeping reorganization of Federal medical services, highly controversial in many of its aspects, was recommended today in a task force report made public by the Hoover Commission on Organization of the Executive Branch of the Government.
RICHMOND, Va., Dec. 25 -- A problem that was old when Jefferson was young held special interest in the Upper South this week -- the problem of land taxation in a changing society.

DRAWINGS made by hand with an ordinary pen nib and India ink directly on motion-picture film were projected as sound movies on last week's program of Cinema 16, Inc., a group devoted to the presentation of documentary and experimental films.

Since reading George Lawton's article "Proof That She Is the Stronger Sex," I have been living in a new burst of freedom which I world like to report on here and now. Because "muscular inferiority is due largely to nurture, not nature," I have spent the past few days at a gym, with the reward that muscles are protruding everywhere.
BEAR MOUNTAIN -- This mammoth state playground in New York City's back yard is open for business with a fine supply of snow and winter sports.

California's achievements in agriculture and allied fields have been notable. Commodities not indigenous to that state have been made to flourish there through the enterprise and perseverance of its people. Take the case of the Smyrna fig, as one example. Back in the Eighteen Sixties some fruit growers there decided that a profitable market existed in this country for that famous product of the Mediterranean lands if the fig could be grown here.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 25 (AP) -- The Congress of Industrial Organizations started today a drive for a much larger social security system.

The Whittaker Chambers "spy" investigation produced additional mystery but little enlightenment again last week as the strange and tortuous case added a new chapter and a new victim to a history full of incredible incidents and half-told tales.

The gentle spirit of Christmas hovered yesterday over the tiny campus of Curran University atop one of the rocky Chimney Sweeps -- the one that is above water at high tide -- just off the sands of Orchard Beach in the Bronx. It filled the hearts of Chancellor Henry H. Curran and Dean James J. Lyons with compassion and magnanimity.

MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 25 -- A team of Southern college all-stars rallied to score three touchdowns and a field goal in the second half tonight and down a North all-star team, 24 -- 14, in a Shrine charity football game before 33,056 spectators in the Orange Bowl.

The Yuletide Assembly for debutantes of this season and young women presented to society last year will take place tomorrow night in the Ballroom of the Pierre. Miss Bonnie May Murray is in charge of the dance, one in a series of three to be held this week.

The birth of the Christ-child was commemorated yesterday by thousands of devout worshipers as they gathered in the churches of their choice to pay homage to the humble carpenter who gave the world a new and revolutionary religion.

ABOARD THE SAIPAN, en route to Greenland, Dec. 25 -- "Operation Ice Cap" is the name that has been given to the rescue mission of this Navy aircraft carrier, which is speeding tonight northeast at twenty-seven knots through choppy Atlantic waters following twenty-four hours of urgent preparations.

Several prefatory dinners will be given by members of the New York City hospital visiting committee of the State Charities Aid Association before the benefit performance of "Kiss Me, Kate," on Jan. 3, at the Century Theater. Proceeds of the benefit are to be devoted to the work of the committee, which, for three-quarters of a century, has sought to help the less fortunate patients in this city's municipal hospitals.

I should like to call your attention to an error in William L. Weber's otherwise very informative article on employment agencies ("Help Wanted"). Mr. Weber states: "For temporary employment the fee is 10 per cent of all earnings or a time not exceeding ten weeks."

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 25 -- The Chinese Communist radio today broadcast a list of forty-five Chinese Government leaders and military men who, it said, were "war criminals well-known for their heinous crimes, and who, all Chinese agree, should receive the just penalty."
VIENNA, Dec. 25 -- The year 1948 ends in Hungary with 31 per cent of the Deputies elected in the Communist-run elections of September, 1947, out of Parliament.

PASADENA, Calif., Dec. 25 -- Northwestern and California head into the long practice haul next week that brings them face to face in the Rose Bowl New Year's Day, and a fine display of old fashioned rock-and-sock football is in prospect.
Felony prosecutions in Kings County Court during 1948 will total less than in the previous year, it was indicated in an interim report made public yesterday by District Attorney Miles F. McDonald.

With a number of hunters planning a Southern shooting trip, it was inevitable that the old argument on the comparative values of the shotgun with buckshot or slug, and the rifle for hunting white-tail deer.
BATAVIA, Java, Dec. 25 -- Dutch troops captured Madiun, the last major city of the Indonesian Republic, today and seized almost all of Java despite a United Nations cease-fire order.

THERE has been increased talk of late about the need to decentralize the American theatre. Indeed, to encourage this decentralization is one of the avowed aims of the American National Theatre and Academy. What is meant by decentralization, and why is there an increasing need for it?
LONDON, Dec. 25 -- From Buckingham Palace, where he has been confined by illness for more than a month, the invalid King George VI broadcast Christmas greetings today to his subjects far and near.

SINCE the world -- and that even includes Hollywood -- is in a state of flux, it is reasonable to assume that the intentions of those who plan pictures sometimes gang agley. Random rifling through the records turned up a variety of great expectations, which thus far, for reasons best known to the fates, have not come true.

LONDON, Dec. 25 -- Portsmouth regained the lead in the first division of the English Football League today by downing Chelsea, 2 to 1, as Newcastle, victim of an upset by Birmingham, toppled to a tie for second place.
The recent proposal by Albert A. Volk in his letter of Dec. 12 concerning adjudication of labor disputes by impartial juries merits critical comment.

Miss Juliet Thompson, chairman of the New York Vassar Club's Opera Committee, will give a luncheon on Wednesday at Sherry's for Miss Dorothy Kirsten and Miss Inge Manski. Miss Kirsten will sing the title role of "Madama Butterfly" at the Metropolitan Opera House on the evening of Jan. 29, the performance that night having been taken over for the twenty- seventh annual opera benefit for the club's scholarship fund.

THE year now closing brought to philately's gallery more portraits, figures and monuments of famous and obscure persons than in any earlier year in the hobby's annals. During 1948, postal tribute was accorded 163 men and women not previously identified with stamp collecting.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 25 -- Pennsylvania Railroad carloadings last week totaled 118,615 as against 128,934 last year, a decrease of 8 per cent, and for 1948 to date totaled 6,596,548 to compare with 7,086,663 last year, a decrease of 6.9 per cent.

IN one or another version -- from the Vulgate to the King James to the as-yet-unfinished Revised Standard American -- the Bible is still incomparably the best of best-sellers. No one seems willing to risk even a free guess at the number of copies, complete or fragmentary, published in this country in 1948: But it must run well into eight figures.

City College's basketball team recorded its highest point total of the season by beating Newark College of Rutgers, 90 to 45, at the Lavender court last night. Leading by 36-15 at half-time, the Beavers put on a 54-point splurge in the second half.

VIENNA, Dec. 25 -- As it is the only current attempt by the Soviet Union and the Western powers to settle their differences by negotiation, Russia's consent this week to reopening discussion of the Austrian state treaty was an important diplomatic event.

NEWARK, Dec. 25 -- The New Jersey State Congress of Industrial Organizations called today on Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll and two other state officials to aid them in barring the American Bowling Congress from holding, its annual tournament at Atlantic City from Feb. 12 to April 12, on the ground that competition is "limited to members of the white race only."
ITHACA, N.Y., Dec. 25 -- A Christmas gift of $1,500,000 to Cornell University from Myron C. Taylor, President Truman's personal representative to the Vatican, was announced today.

On Feb. 8 the Governors of eleven Southern states met in conference in Tallahassee, Fla., and drew up what has become known as the Compact of Southern Governors. This was a proposition to establish a geographical district embracing fifteen Southern states with cooperatively owned and operated regional schools to provide higher education for whites and Negroes on a segregated basis.

Forging ahead in the final surge of Christmas purchasing, retail sales here last week showed substantial gains over the corresponding period of last year. Department store sales were estimated at more than 50 per cent ahead of last year, but a major factor in the showing was that there were five selling days in the week against three last year.

THERE is an old saying about one man's meat being another man's poison, so it may be that the paragraphs to follow will be indignantly disputed by some and warmly endorsed by others. That is inevitable and so, donning a coat of armor in place of conventional attire, this operator will perform once again the departmental ritual of picking the year's Ten Worst pictures -- and let the brickbats fall where they may.

BOTH radio and television will observe the coming of the New Year with a variety of special programs. As usual, the chief emphasis will be special pick-ups from cities across the country as crowds in different geographical areas successively herald the advent of 1949.

CANTERBURY, England, Dec. 25 (AP) -- Western nations during this Christmas season are attempting to establish unity of spirit to meet the challenge of militant atheism, the Archbishop of Canterbury said today.

BROADCASTING in 1948 was a year of extremes. For television it was a banner period, the new art showing phenomenal growth both in the programs that were sent out on the air and in the number of homes equipped to receive them.
PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Dec. 25 (UP) -- Six hundred Jewish men and women, many of them trained for the Israeli Army by Czechoslovak Officers are en route to Palestine, informed sources said today.

Santa Claus disappointed the Best family yesterday. M/Sgt. William Best, his wife, Rose, Stephen, 5 years old, and 6-month-old Anita expected a special guest for Christmas dinner but Ellis Island immigration authorities had other plans.

NEXT month, when "The Greatest Story Ever Told" begins its third year on the air, radio listeners, and radio itself, looking back at the program's start and tracing its success, will find many things which have made it the fine program that it is; but standing above all others will be one simple thing: Sincerity.

ON Oct. 14, 1844, Herman Melville was discharged from the frigate United States in Boston. His adventure, which had begun in New Bedford nearly four years earlier, was over. Almost exactly five years from that date -- that is, on Oct. 11, 1849 -- he set sail for England as a passenger on the packet boat Southampton.

KEY WEST, Fla., Dec. 25 (UP) -- Warren R. Austin, this country's chief delegate to the United Nations, is recuperating from a recent operation at the "Little White House" here, it was revealed tonight.
LONDON, Dec. 25 -- Germany momentarily is the frontier of democracy, Peter Fraser, Prime Minister of New Zealand, said in a Christmas Day interview.

ROME, Dec. 25 -- The trial of strength that the Communists forced on the Government through the strike early this week of state employes and workers ended in a notable Governmental victory. The authorities proved their ability to keep essential public services going and it can hardly be doubted that if the strike had continued beyond twenty-four hours, the Communists would have been obliged either to resort to violence or confess defeat.

PROVIDENCE, R. I., Dec. 25 -- Banking institutions here are beginning to feel competition from the national insurance companies in the field of industrial loans, which until now was a business which the investment bankers considered their own.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 25 -- Marchons II, 4-5 favorite, won the $7,500 added Christmas Handicap at tropical Park today before 15,168 holiday fans, the largest crowd of the current meeting.

INDEPENDENCE, Mo., Dec. 25 -- The activities of President Truman today were closely shielded in the Christmas privacy of his family. The only message from him was that Santa Claus had been "too good."

A new record in long distance telephone calls for Christmas was set Friday and yesterday, according to a preliminary survey by the long lines department of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company.

Members of the first graduating class of Walter Hervey Junior College already have received financial returns on their education. In their two-year course the 140 members of the class have earned $210,000 under the school's work-study program.

LONDON, Dec. 25 -- Harold Beeley, career diplomat who has been for three and a half years the principal Palestine expert of the British Foreign Office, was receiving congratulations today on an unusually rapid promotion to the rank of counsellor in the British Embassy at Copenhagen.

BATAVIA, Dec. 25 (UP) -- The Indonesian Republic, while apparently receptive to the United Nations cease-fire plan, indicated today that it was unwilling to accept it unconditionally.

The largest concentration of luxury liners and other passenger vessels in New York harbor in almost a decade has kept waterfront activity here at a peak for the past seven days. A total of 13,396 travelers have passed through this port since last Sunday, creating a work boom for taxicab drivers, longshoremen and others who depend on busy piers for their livelihood.

VIENNA, Dec. 25 -- The Reparations Delivery and Restitution Branch of United States Army headquarters here has informed the Austrian Government that an existing cellulose factory in Lenzing, in Upper Austria, cannot be released from American trusteeship.

GENEVA, Dec. 20 -- The problems arising from re-exportation of goods supplied European countries entirely or in part by the Economic Cooperation Administration has only been scratched by United States authorities.

TIME to look back again as the old year wanes. The calendar below is necessarily sketchy, because space is small and a year is long, but it may provide a record for ambitious trend-spotters to work on.
LOS ANGELES, Dec. 25 -- Citrus areas were threatened and thin ice and considerable frost were reported in many sections as California experienced its coldest Dec. 24-25 in sixty-nine years.
MOSCOW, Dec. 25 (AP) -- United States Ambassador and Mrs. Walter Bedell Smith said good-bye to Moscow today -- a good-bye that may be final.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 25 (AP) -- The Department of Commerce announced today that Army-produced anhydrous ammonia will be allotted to three fertilizer plants to enable them to keep operating. THE Board of Education's frequency modulation station, WNYE, may operate on a shoe-string budget, but it has managed to prove three major promises usually alien to much of professional radio.

Retailers' mid-season promotions attracted a good response from Christmas shoppers last week, according to a survey made especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Meyer Roth Reports. The leading promotion item was men's nylon shirts, priced at $8.95 each.

THE first city-wide exhibition of prints by student photographers in the city's academic high schools opened last week at the Brooklyn Museum. It will continue through Jan. 9. The event initiates a proposed annual show to be known as the New York City High School Salon of Photography.

THE skier stands sharply etched at the top of the runway, a tiny and distant figure who is clearly seen against the glaring whiteness of the snow. He shuffles forward and down the chute he hurtles. There is a gasp from the watching thousands blackly ringing the landing apron at the bottom of the mountainside as he rockets precipitately into space.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Dec. 25 -- A prosperous Southland temporarily turned its back this week on controversial matters and opened its swollen coffers for a Yuletide celebration of apparent record proportions.

Patrolman John J. Reilly, 26 years old, was charged with felonious assault yesterday morning after the wounding of Robert Fogel, 31 years old, of 330 Madison Street.

FLORIDA-bound motorists report that U.S. Route 1 is in better condition on its Florida stretches than it has been since pre-war days. For the first time in many, many motoring years there is not a single detour between Jacksonville and Miami.

Contributions by an employer to an employes' pension trust, qualified under Section 165 of the Internal Revenue Code, are, within prescribed statutory limitations, deductible for income tax purposes (Section 23 (p) (1) (A)). Harry Truman, just as other people, likes to be home for Christmas. He has managed to be in Independence, Mo., for a few days at least, over three of the four Christmases since he became President. Last week he arrived home on Wednesday. Mrs. Truman and Margaret had already trimmed the ten-foot Christmas tree that stands in the parlor window of the white Victorian house at Delaware and Van Horne Streets.

With retail sales below expectations during fall and winter promotions, merchants are planning many revisions in merchandising policies for spring. Due to the general decline in unit sales, inventories have built up to a point in many cases where drastic markdowns are in order after the holidays.

THIS season is not half over, but already plans are being made for 1949-50. The concert halls will open their books the first of the year, since artists and managers have been asking for tentative bookings during the last month or so.

Sports in 1948 always will be remembered as having left in its wake a year of incredible events. Nothing ever seemed too fantastic for the fortunes of the game to serve up as the nation's millions of addicts spun from one surprise to another.

Swanton, who is also director of purchases for Winchester Repeating Arms Corporation division of Olin Industries, Inc., New Haven, pointed out that industrial activity confirmed the declining trend predicted by the November survey.

OMAHA, Dec. 25 -- The chief topic of conversation among Mid-west cattle feeders this week has been that the consumers' buying strike against meat prices may prove too successful.

TO the general rule that no new talent is permitted on Broadway, note three pleasant exceptions -- "Lend an Ear," "The Silver Whistle" and "The Young and Fair." In this respect "Lend an Ear" is the most notable.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 25 -- The State Department cables and other confidential documents which in 1937 and 1938 fell into the hands of Whittaker Chambers, a self-confessed spy, may represent only a fraction of the traffic in this illicit business.

The Yankees, who have always stuck pretty close to Conservative spring training lines with the exception of their aerial flights over the Caribbean during the tenure of Larry MacPhail and a couple of jaunts into Texas in the days of Babe Ruth and Lou Gehrig, are going to do a bit of spreading out again next spring with Manager Casey Stengel at the helm.

CHICAGO, Dec. 25 -- In a statistical review of the Methodist Church of the United States, the Rev. Albert C. Hoover of Evanston, Ill., its statistical director, reported today that as of last spring the active and inactive denomination members totaled 8,651,062.

Stronger anti-trust enforcement by Government is favored by 92 per cent of the members of the National Federation of Small Business, Inc., Washington, D. C., according to a nation-wide poll revealed yesterday by George J. Burger, director.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Dec. 25 -- A pair of fast, tricky backs and a line that wouldn't back up gave the Yankee All-Stars a 19-13 victory in the annual Blue-Gray gridiron battle today. A crowd of 15,000 saw the contest.

Chicago will play host to several national musical organizations this week. Tomorrow and Tuesday the College Music Association, Richard Donovan, president, will hold its second annual meeting. Wednesday and Thursday will find the Music Library Association holding joint sessions with the American Musicological Society and the Music Teachers National Association.

MAURY MAVERICK of Texas, in a moment of exasperation, called it "gobbledegook" (sometimes spelled "gobbledygook") because he thought it resembled the sounds made by that most stupid and pompous bird, the turkey cock.

ST. LOUIS, Dec. 25 -- With two more shopping days before Christmas than in the corresponding week last year, it was indicated the shopping season between Thanksgiving and Dec. 25 measured up pretty close to the dollar volume a year ago, although for the full season extending from early November there probably was a loss of 5 to 10 per cent.

In Robert Moses' invective-laden reply ("'Practical' or 'Long-Hair' Planning") to the "smart aleck" and "irresponsible radical planners," the "Vestal Virgins of radical mass planning," he admonishes us to remember that "an open mind is still the surest avenue to the truth."

Babe Ruth, whose funeral services thronged St. Patrick's Cathedral while thousands more lined the streets and millions listened over the radio, was not the only sports notable to pass away in 1948 as death again claimed a heavy toll.
A cold wave, instead of the threatened snowstorm, moved in on the city yesterday.
NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 25 (AP) -- Boden's Pal, ridden by Harold Keene, came from behind to win the $2,500 Christmas Handicap at the Fair Grounds today.

BOSTON, Dec. 25 (AP) -- The Boston Bruins regained the National Hockey League lead by defeating the Chicago Black Hawks, 2-1, tonight before a crowd of 13,900 at the Boston Garden. A blistering 30-foot shot by Nobby Warwick enabled the Bruins to overhaul the Detroit Red Wings, who bowed to Toronto.

GENERALLY speaking, Saturday was a normal day. As is customary on Christmas, the toys, for the most part, were well broken by noon. As is customary, everyone so overate at dinner that it was a real effort to wad up and throw the paper wrappings from the presents into the fireplace.

BOTH of these books are an invitation to enjoyment. Not that everything in them is of unalloyed excellence. But at their best -- and why can't the best be as good a criterion as any? -- they contain great beauty (sometimes too much to be true).

ALTHOUGH there was a stoppage on the making of records in 1948, there was the usual quantity of new releases to review. Some records were made secretly in this country despite the ban of the American Federation of Musicians; these were largely in the popular field.

The year 1948 saw the cold war between the United States of America and the Union of Socialist Soviet Republics fully joined. All over the world the two forces were in conflict. The struggle affected the lives of most of the world's 2.2 billion people.

HILLSDALE, N.Y., Dec. 25 -The snow came early and so did the skiers with the result that Jack Fisher and his crew at the vast open-slope area known as Catamount were caught unawares this cold Christmas Day. Most of the visitors were New Yorkers and for a while they enjoyed the use of the two tows in operation gratis as Jack sought to round up a staff to handle the unexpected turnout.

TWO new, specialized treatises on various aspects of newspaper work have now been made available to students of journalism, both amateur and professional Professor Waldrop of the University of Colorado has prepared a text on the writing and presentation of editorials.

If it seem presumption for me to address a Christmas letter to Your Excellency, may I plead that I represent a newspaper which believes most sincerely in better acquaintanceship between the peoples of Russia and of the United States?

ROME, Dec. 24 -- Count Carlo Sforza, Italian Foreign Minister, is expected to attempt to enter into direct negotiations with the Ethiopian Government in the forthcoming weeks in the hope of achieving a bilateral agreement on the disposition of Eritrea before the problem of the former Italian colonies is discussed at the United Nations General Assembly next April.

A CITIZEN of the Sunset Age, an Englishman, who saw the world's great darkness gathering, salute you, Stranger, across the Chasm. I strain toward the dawn of a new age, and offer you the story of events and persons, in a day when the light flared up before it failed.* * *

Announcement by Economic Cooperation Administrator Paul Hoffman cutting off ECA assistance to the Netherlands Indies tended to focus attention last week on a problem which has bothered American merchant exporters during the post-war years.

A contribution of $25 arrived by air mail from Sweden yesterday for the Neediest Cases Fund of THE NEW YORK TIMES, now in its thirty-seventh annual appeal. The check was sent by a TIMES reader in Djursholm.

With one year ending and another at hand with its beginnings, there is the instinctive feeling that here must be a time for new and deeper understanding, a time to leave old complexities behind and reach simplicity. We look upon the winter land at this simplest of all seasons, and we seem to see change suspended and verity revealed.

MANY exciting things can happen on a ranch, and the stories, rhymes and pictures in this Giant Golden Book prove it. Here are action and excitement enough to whet the appetite of any youngster from 4 to 8. Nor is this just a boy's book -- likable 5-year-old Sue is a main character in many of these tales.

A 40-year-old factory worker walked into the East 104th Street station house at 10 A.M. yesterday and disclosed that he had stabbed to death a woman with whom he had been living for the last seven months, the police reported.

SALT LAKE CITY, Utah, Dec. 25 -- Westerners put aside world problems and national affairs this week to trim Christmas trees, fill holiday stockings and make certain no neighbors, particularly young ones, would be forgotten this Christmas Day.

THE later years of Herman Melville's life have been variously designated by his biographers as "the long quietus," "the silent years" and "the long seclusion." After a decade of prolific authorship as a young man, Melville abandoned his pen in mid-career.

The "two pot" feeding system, a dead issue in recent years on American ships, was resurrected with Oriental trimmings recently aboard the Pioneer Wave of the United States Lines, according to the union delegate's report to the National Maritime Union.

TURIN, Italy, Dec. 25 (AP) -- Men in overalls, guided by Communist doctrines, have taken seats at directors' tables in Italy's biggest industries. They are members of "consigli di gestione" -- councils of management -- perhaps the most powerful long-range Communist weapon in Italy.

THE appearance of Andre Malraux's "Artistic Creation" (the second volume of his "Studies in the Psychology of Art") constitutes a major event in an otherwise slow season. Publishers, faced with skyrocketing costs and a sluggish market, have been cutting down their lists, going slow on new authors, reissuing old titles.

DETROIT, Dec. 25 -- The Kaiser-Frazer Corporation's social security program, covering life, illness and hospitalization insurance, and likely to be advanced in negotiations in 1949 between the United Automobile Workers, CIO, and other automobile manufacturers, now covers employes and their dependents, 44,357 in all, company records showed today.

AS this highly colored biography of George Catlin reminds us, the era in which he lived was a romantic one, in America as on the European Continent, in literature and philosophy, in art and architecture, even in science. It was the age, too, of the discovery of America by novelists like Cooper and Simms, by historians like Irving and Parkman and Gayarre, by the Hudson River school of painters, by naturalists like Wilson and Audubon.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 25 (UP) -- Tighe E. Woods, the rent director, disclosed today that he would ask Congress to give tenants a right to appeal from general rent increases passed out by local boards. Landlords, in the event they were not satisfied, would have the same right.
