PARIS, Dec. 25 -- As the budget bill went to the advisory Council of the Republic today for discussion and analysis, the chief topic of interest was the sharp altercation that occurred in the last moments of the prolonged debate in the National Assembly between Premier Queuille and a member of his own Radical party who is a known sympathizer of Charles de Gulle.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Dec. 25 -- A recent proposal by George Bernard Shaw that the alphabet be increased to forty letters has drawn criticism from H.L. Mencken, author of "The American Language," who classes the Irish playwright with "other spelling reformers" as "very imprudent, and even foolish fellows."

SHOW business is quite an adventure, and there are many examples. Chief among them this season has been the case of "As the Girls Go." On Broadway it is such a hit that at almost every performance at least one soul is willingly bartered for a standing room ticket, yet during its tryout it was eyed with the disdain only Boston can show.

SOME of the lighting schemes the specialists have dreamed up lately seem to involve so much in the way of complex architectural housings or custom cabinet work, we shouldn't wonder if many middle income families hadn't resigned themselves to living a while longer in turn-of-the-century gloom.

A STRANGE and paradoxical character was Gloomy Gil Dobie, one of the great football coaches of all time. His death on Christmas Eve brought him back into the headlines once more after ten years of retirement. The gridiron game probably never had such a perfectionist as he and he was even more of a stickler for detail than Jock Sutherland.

LONDON, Dec. 26 -- Britain is getting the wrong kind of white Christmas -- hoarfrost and fog that set in last night after a rare sunny Christmas Day. Today it has been freezing nearly everywhere except up north in Scotland, where one would expect it to freeze.
WASHINGTON, Dec, 26--The American Red Cross set a record in disaster relief in the last two years, Basil O'Connor, president, reported today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 -- The following excerpts from the report of a Senate subcommittee on the conduct of the Ilse Koch war crimes trial are a summary of the facts brought out at the trial and of the subcommittee's conclusion:
The residents of the Home for Aged Women in Newark, N.J., gave up one of their Christmas parties to send the money they saved to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

The sixth week of the Metropolitan Opera season, beginning Jan. 3, will see the revival of Mozart's "Le Nozze di Figaro" after a year's absence; the Metropolitan debut of Gertrude Ribla, American soprano. in the name role of "Aida" and a benefit performance next Sunday of "Il Barbiere di Siviglia" for the Mizrachi Women's Organization of America.

CHAPPAQUA, N.Y., Dec. 26 -- Robert Van Dyck, 7 years old, died today with a lead pellet in his brain. The pellet was fired from an air rifle, a Christmas gift handled by his 10-year-old brother, Donald. The shooting was accidental and took place while the brothers were carrying out a chore in the basement of the Van Dyck home.

Nat Holman, now in his thirtieth season as City College basketball coach, will be honored at a "Nat Holman Night" at Madison Square Garden on Jan. 11, it was announced yesterday. Ceremonies will be held at the intermission of the C.C.N.Y.-West Virginia game.

VIENNA, Dec. 26 -- Interpretation by refugees recently reaching Vienna from Hungary of conflicting reports regarding the present status of Joseph Cardinal Mindszenty, Primate of Hungary, indicates the Communist-dominated Hungarian Government won the first round in its fierce struggle with the Cardinal.

CHICAGO, Dec. 26 -- Corn prices held within comparatively narrow limits last week on the Board of Trade. The December delivery went off the blackboard on Wednesday without incident as a large supply of this grain is available for delivery purposes, and the bulk of the uncompleted contracts were cleaned up.

Having beaten the latest Communist-instigated strike wave in France, the Government of Premier Queuille scored another victory when the National Assembly approved a budget which is not only the largest in French history but also undertakes to balance revenues and expenditures by a substantial increase in taxation.

ROBERT SOUTHEY, a virtuous man and a prolific writer, is a wonderful example of the transitory nature of much literary fame. In his time he was considered one of the most eminent men in England, a major poet, an influential critic and an important historian. He was the good friend of half the distinguished writers who were his contemporaries and was heartily disliked by the other half.

PEIPING, Dec. 26 -- Gen. Fu Tso-yi officially admitted late last night the loss of his former stronghold, Kalgan, the Chahar capital, and Sinpaoan, forty miles southeast of Kalgan. General Fu's own best armies, his cavalry brigades, have been riddled and cut off in these two places within the past month.

LONDON, Dec. 26 -- Earl Russell -- better known to the world as Bertrand Russell -- devoted a broadcast today to an appropriate holiday theme of how to turn humanity's savage instincts into peaceful pursuits. This was first of six Reith lectures on "Authority and the Individual" that will be published later in book form.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 -- The Civil Aeronautics Administration is mapping a pilot-training center for the nation's airlines. It would be established next year.

Staten Island, the smallest borough in the city, upheld the honor of New York in the National Fire Prevention Week Contest, placing nineteenth out of 2,267 entrants, according to results announced today by the National Board of Fire Underwriters, 85 John Street, co-sponsors of the contest.

BINGHAMTON, DEC. 26 -- Forty-eight men and women of the United Nations Secretariat, most of whom arrived here Christmas Eve as complete strangers, left town tonight as the close friends of hosts who tried to make up for what the nationals of twenty-one countries miss the most -- Christmas at home.

Without Ernest Truex, the incident that occurred at the Golden Theatre last night under the label "Oh, Mr. Meadowbrook!" would have made pretty grim reporting indeed. For what Ronald Telfer and Pauline Jamerson have fashioned in a rather witless joke on sex which at best is only mildly amusing and for the most part more than obvious.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., Dec. 26 -- David Dubinsky's International Ladies Garment Workers Union, AFL, put forward today a detailed program of substitute legislation for the Taft-Hartley law. It was the first major union to do so.
AMES, Iowa, Dec. 26 -- Plans for a 1,400-acre livestock and poultry research farm on land formerly devoted to production of ammunition for World War II have been announced by Iowa State College.

Establishment at Princeton University and California Institute of Technology of two national centers for the study of rocket and jet propulsion should act as a major stimulant to development in this field. The project has been underwritten for a period of seven years by the Daniel and Florence Guggenheim Foundation.

Unrestricted glare from motor vehicle headlights has become a glittering harbinger of evil for millions of motorists and pedestrians on the highways. Research by the American Automobile Association and other protective agencies designate these insidious "death rays" Enemy No. 1 in night driving, as at least an estimated 60 per cent of car operators fail to dim lamps when encountering approaching traffic.

Hanukkah, the Jewish Feast of Lights, began at sunset yesterday when Jews throughout the world lighted candles to commemorate the rededication of the temple in Jerusalem by the Maccabees more than twenty-one centuries ago. The festival will last eight days.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., Dec. 26--How snow--in this instance the scarcity of it--can affect the way of living for an extensive area is quite noticeable in the popular Berkshires of Western Massachusetts. Instead of being over-run with winter sports enthusiasts, the 1,000-acre skiland starting at Sheffield and going to Williamstown, almost on the Vermont border, is comparatively serene this holiday period.

It's been nearly eight years since "Strawberry Blonde" was presented to a public, which pretty generally took its honest, sachet-scented sentiments to its heart. But in "One Sunday Afternoon," the remake of a remake, which took up residence at the Mayfair on Christmas Day, age apparently did wither and custom did stale.

In typical preholiday dealings, cotton futures prices in the local market held within a very narrow range last week. At the close of trading on Friday at noon, active contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange were 1 point higher to 7 points lower than the final prices of the preceding week.

With Tony Lavelli carrying most of the offensive burden, Yale makes its debut at Madison Square Garden tonight when the Elis tangle with Howard Cann's New York University quintet in the feature of the collegiate double-header booked for the Eighth Avenue arena.

Marcel Filion and the rugged Sherbrooke (Que.) Red Raiders made their season's debut at Madison Square Garden yesterday afternoon much to the dissatisfaction of the New York Rovers and 8,148 paying customers.

AMSTERDAM, Dec. 26 -- The Amsterdam Stock Exchange was dominated last week by the military action in Indonesia. On Monday, a sharp upward movement in Indonesian shares was seen, some issues rising as much as 20 points. The rally was not due to speculative activity but resulted from wholesale withdrawal of selling orders which had been trickling through for several months, plus small buying orders.

ARCADIA, Calif., Dec. 26 (AP) -- California-bred On Trust, loser by a nose in the last $100,000 Santa Anita Handicap, will have a 126-pound package to carry in the 1949 renewal of the big race next Feb. 26.

MANTEO, N.C., Dec. 26 (AP) -- Battling pounding seas, the Coast Guard rescued sixteen seamen late today from the El Capitan, an Argentine tanker, which broke in two while under tow off this treacherous North Carolina coast. Two crewmen were missing, believed helpless on the tanker's stern, and the Coast Guard raced seaward in an attempt to find them.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 26 -- More than a half century of archaeological investigation of the State of California, plus all such work in the future, will be integrated under a program announced today by the University of California.

First nighters will assemble this evening at the Belasco (warning: the curtain is advertised to rise at 8 o'clock) to pass judgment on the premiere of "The Madwoman of Chaillot." Imported from Paris, where it was presented in December of 1945, the comedy is the product of a distinguished French playwright, the late Jean Giraudoux.

The symbols of the kingdom that Jesus came to found are love, peace, gentleness, meekness, sacrifice, brotherhood and good will, the Rev. Dr. Robert James McCracken, pastor of the Riverside Church, Riverside Drive and 122nd Street, said yesterday in his sermon.

Consumer response to markdowns and specially priced merchandise just before the holiday brought retail inventories to a more manageable level, according to reports prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices.

The second and farewell visit of the Freedom Train to Manhattan will begin officially at 9 A.M. today with an opening ceremony at track 30 in Grand Central Terminal. The train with its exhibits of 127 major historical documents will be open to the public here through Jan.1 before resuming its tour, scheduled to end in Washington during inauguration week, Jan. 16 to 22.

CHICAGO, Dec. 26 -- Closing out of December grain contracts on the Board of Trade last week resulted in December wheat and oats advancing rapidly to the highest prices since Feb. 4. The fact that they went out at big premiums over May had considerable influence on the deferred months later in the week, the highest prices being made on Friday on scattered buying.

THE HAGUE, Dec. 26 -- Intense diplomatic activity has marked the week-end here as the Netherlands Government seeks to arrive at a formula on Indonesia acceptable to the United States and Britain. Foremost on the agenda is compliance with the Security Council's resolution calling upon the Dutch to cease fire in military operations against the Republic.
Jacob Panken, Domestic Relations Court Justice, declared yesterday that the Juvenile Aid Bureau should be "divorced from the Police Department and made an arm of the Children's Court."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 -- A plane described as carrying the heaviest concentration of torpedoes, rockets and machine guns ever built into a single-engined, carrier-based craft has been undergoing tests off the East Coast, the Navy announced tonight.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 (AP) -- A "fair solution" to the Netherland-Indonesian conflict is offered in the truce agreement signed by the two sides last January, a Foreign Policy Association report said today.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Dec. 26 -- Local Arab leaders from the Jerusalem area met in Ramallah today and agreed to support the move for the union of Trans-Jordan and Arab Palestine.

Miguel M. Najdorf, Polish chess expert from Buenos Aires, gained another notable victory yesterday in the fourth round of the international tournament at the Manhattan Chess Club. His opponent was George Kramer of Forest Hills, who resigned after thirty-five moves to give Najdorf a score of 3 -- 0 and the lead in the field of ten.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 -- The Senate's top investigating committee stated today that commutation of the life sentence of Ilse Koch was not justified on the record and recommended that other means be found to see that she gets the punishment she "so justly deserves."

ZURICH, Dec. 26 -- Since Dec. 16 the market rate for Deutschemark banknotes in Zurich has risen day by day. Starting at 19 1/2 francs for 100 Deutschemarks, the quotation rose to a peak on Christmas Eve, when the closing price was 23 francs.

Not all family gatherings for the Christmas holiday were unalloyed celebration. One in the Bronx, at the Kingsbridge Road Veterans Hospital, mixed happy tears with those of distress. Reunited with his family yesterday, a former Navy enlisted man suffering from leukemia heard from his wife that she and their five children no longer have a home.

In your editorial of Dec. 7 entitled "Those Thurmond Votes" the assertion is made, in commending the Supreme Court's rejection of a request for an injunction to require Alabama's Presidential electors to cast their votes for President Truman, that "if the electors in these cases (Alabama, South Carolina, Louisiana and Mississippi) could be enjoined to change their ballots, so could electors in other cases and every Presidential election would end in confusion."

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Dec. 26 -- Territorial disputes and national minority questions are moving to the forefront of the disputes between the Yugoslav Communists and the neighboring states of the Communist Information Bureau.

Things just didn't go right for the New York Rangers in their National Hockey League clash with the Chicago Black Hawks at Madison Square Garden last night. Resolved to make a successful showing on the occasion of Lynn Patrick's local bow as coach, the Blue Shirts had to accept a 2-to-1 setback from the close-checking, fast-skating Chicago sextet.

The Bosc, Comice and Anjou pears that are now so plentiful don't always attract as many buyers as they should. Often they are sold hard and unripe; housewives are repelled, not realizing that the specimens may easily be ripened to deliciousness simply by leaving them at room temperature. It is frequently said that pears are the one fruit that mature more flavorfully off than on the tree.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 (AP) -- A third glider carried by a C-82 transport arrived tonight at Goose Bay, Labrador, after a flight from Westover Air Base, Mass.

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 26 -- Because of the Christmas holidays steel ingot output last week was down 11.5 points from the week before to 89 per cent of rated capacity. This is less than a normal drop, because a few plants paid premium time and kept some furnaces going.

The public opinion polls failed to predict the results of the recent Presidential election because the executives showed poor judgment, although they acted in good faith, it was reported yesterday by the inquiry committee set up by the Social Science Research Council.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 -- A Chilean task force of three ships is about to sail into the Antarctic to carry out an extensive program of scientific exploration and complete the occupation of three permanent bases in polar territory claimed by the South American republic.
DETROIT, Dec. 26 -- John R. Franco, Democratic state chairman, frankly admitted today that he had paid commissions to professional fund raisers in the recent campaign.

How perishable a commodity is research when used to support a claim made continuously in advertising over a long period of time? This and other questions concerning ethical practices in research usage are scheduled for spotlighting at the annual convention of the American Marketing Association opening today in Cleveland.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 -- Leaders of the Congress of Industrial Organizations and the British Trades Union Congress will meet in London next month to discuss a global course for non-Communist labor that might lead to their withdrawal from the World Federation of Trade Unions.

People should reform their "urge to power" along Christian lines, the Rev. Dr. Russell H. Stafford, president of Hartford Seminary Foundation, Hartford, Conn., said in a sermon yesterday morning. The former pastor of Old South Church, Boston, was guest preacher at the Broadway Tabernacle Congregational Church, at Fifty-sixth Street.

Nicholas Monsarrat has written "My Brother Denys," a memoir of his brother who was killed in the war, which will be published on Jan. 11 by Knopf. Mr. Monsarrat recreates the life of his family in Liverpool and on the Welsh coast from 1912 to 1940.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 (UP) -- The Atomic Energy Commission announced today that it was trying to increase the production of plutonium, one of the materials used in atomic bombs.

Retailers should stop worrying about present "softening trends" and begin to plan for harder selling days through a combination of old-fashioned storekeeping and new guides that can be found in the records of successful stores. This advice was offered here last week by John Giessen, director of the Retail Division, Bureau of Advertising, of the American Newspaper Publishers Association.

Although possession of the title not a requisite to eminence, champions in the eight standard ring divisions are named boxing's No. 1 men in the annual ratings of Nat Fleischer, which will appear in a copyrighted article in the February issue of The Ring Magazine.

SAN JUAN, P.R., Dec. 25 (Overseas News Agency) -- The annual volume of business reported by 110 cooperative associations here totals $22,000,000, it was announced today. There are more than 21,200 members of these non-profit organizations, according to Luis A. Nazario, inspector for cooperatives.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Dec. 26 -- In a rush of Christmas shopping, Western Germany's Allied officials negotiated trade treaties with six countries last week. These treaties were made with Sweden, the Netherlands, Turkey, Egypt, Poland and Spain.
FAIRFIELD, Conn., Dec. 26 (AP) -- A Fairfield family of three was accidentally asphyxiated by carbon monoxide fumes in a Christmas eve tragedy in their Sasco Hills home, it was found today.

The children who stand before the judges in the Children's Court of New York City are lonely, lost, afraid and angry. They have broken laws which they know they should have kept. They expect to be punished, as they have been in their homes when they disobey. However, punishment helps but little in the long run.

PRICHARD, Miss., Dec. 26 (UP) -- Neither the spires of a cathedral nor those of a plain wooden church have ever pierced the skies over this tiny Mississippi Delta town, but the residents now have a worn out street car as their place of worship.

NANKING, Dec. 26 -- The issuance by the Chinese Communists of a new list of "first class war criminals," including seven leading members of Dr. Sun Fo's "peace with honor" Cabinet, has again silenced a flurry of peace rumors generated on the Nationalist side by a succession of military setbacks.
CHICAGO, Dec. 26 -- Retailers and others who were disturbed by November's sales trend have recovered some of their confidence as a result of the more favorable December trend.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 -- The shift of women away from domestic service was emphasized today in an analysis by the Women's Bureau of the Department of Labor of women's occupational trends since 1940.

Total assets of the Royal Bank of Canada in the year ended on Nov. 30 increased $128,846,567 to reach a new high record of $2,222,487,786, according to the bank's annual report, just published. Deposits, passing the two-billion-dollar mark for the first time, amounted to $2,067,488,996, an increase of more than $133,000,000.

Most of the Metropolitan Opera Company's leading soloists, conductors, choristers and dancers, as well as many luminaries from beyond the boundaries of the Thirty-ninth Street pale, gathered at the opera house last night for the American Guild of Musical Artists' second annual Artists' Christmas Party.

The Metropolitan Life Insurance Company has formally notified each of its 35,000 employes that there is no truth in the rumor that Governor Dewey will assume the presidency of that company when his term as Governor expires.

"When a woman gets to be 90 she sort of leans on everyone, but in our family, it's the other way around," Miss Sara Lewinson declared yesterday. "We depend on mother for very good advice -- if we're willing to listen to it."
LONDON, Dec. 26 (Reuters) -- Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru, Prime Minister of India, deprecated talk of a third world war in a speech today at Osmania University in Hyderabad, the New Delhi radio reported.

A "White Paper" charging the Egyptian and Iraqi Governments with persecution and discrimination against their residents of Jewish nationality in violation of international law was sent yesterday to Trygve Lie, Secretary General of the United Nations, by Dr. Robert S. Marcus, political director of the World Jewish Congress.
SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 26 (AP) -- Heavy rain today washed out the outdoor practice of both East and West football teams.
LONDON, Dec. 26 (UP) -- The Moscow radio today accused the United States and Britain of "connivance" with the Dutch in recent events in Indonesia.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Dec. 26 -- The mid-winter championship series of frostbite yachting at the Larchmont Club opened in rugged weather today, and Jack Sutphen at the helm of his Rum Dum, was the only double-winner during a seven-race session.
Intensified efforts to settle a contract dispute between tugboat workers and operators are expected this week. The present pact will expire at midnight Friday.
TOKYO, Monday, Dec. 27 (AP) -- Gen. Douglas MacArthur's Chief of Staff and several others among his key general officers will be reassigned on, authoritative sources said today.

SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, Dec. 26 -- A sudden dash by alleged invaders from the Nicaraguan border town of Los Mojones last night overwhelmed the Costa Rican garrison of sixty-four men at Port Soley who had observed the ceasefire orders after having occupied the port, the Government Junta charged today.

After an ownership of six months, Louis Schleifer, a leading trader in hotel realty, has resold the Hotel Murray, a sixteen-story building at 64-66 Park Avenue, southwest corner of Thirty-eighth Street, two blocks south of the old Murray Hill Hotel site, which Louis Adler and S. D. Leidesdorf plan to improve with a $20,000,000 office building to be known as 100 Park Avenue.

Our Park Department's project to use two equestrian statues to anchor, fore and aft, upon Sixth Avenue, the new name, Avenue of the Americas, conferred upon it by the late Mayor La Guardia, brought no comfort to the champions of the old name that's still to most New Yorkers no less a name because it's just a number.

SCARSDALE, N.Y., Dec. 26 -- Fire, started possibly by a short-circuit in electrically operated Christmas candles, caused the death early today of Allen E. Norman, secretary of Fawcett Publications, Inc.

A chilling story told yesterday by a turkish bath attendant of having been held up at pistol point and forced to drive from this city to Newburgh, N.Y., in scanty attire through biting weather lost some of its dramatic appeal last night when a more matter-of-fact report was made public by the Newburgh police.

Baptisms and confirmations in the Protestant Episcopal Church in the United States reached new high marks in 1948, according to the newly published "Living Church Annual," 1949 yearbook of the denomination. Contributions for all purposes attained the record figure of $61,097,062.

In a nation-wide poll conducted by the New York Dress Institute, 150 fashion designers and fashion and society editors have named Mrs. William Paley the best dressed woman of the year, it was announced yesterday. Three new names have been added to the list of ten and several standbys dropped.

Col. William L. Norvell has been appointed sales manager of the Vericon television department of Remington Rand, Inc. He was chief of special projects for the assistant chief of the Air Staff during World War II.
Three importations, including a pair from France and a newcomer from Sweden, comprise this week's list of film arrivals. The programs follow:

MOSCOW, Dec. 26 (UP) -- The Soviet Vice Minister of Cinematography said today that the American film, "The Iron Curtain," was "scurrilous" and "defamatory," and promised an all-out assault by Soviet film-makers against "Hollywood propaganda."

INDEPENDENCE, Mo., Dec. 26 -- President Truman wound up his holiday today with another "Christmas dinner" with his brother and will resume preparations tomorrow for his State of the Union message and for the hectic inauguration days next month.

No new play by Jean-Paul Sartre having opened for three weeks, New Stages has rushed into the breach with a performance of "The Victors," which opened at 159 Bleecker Street last evening. Like "The Respectful Prostitute," which choked Bleecker Street with taxicabs and lost tourists last season, "The Victors" is a melodrama.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 (AP) -- Marshall Plan authorizations during the last week totaled $132,784,000 and raised the volume of approved aid to date to $4,190,290,000, the Economic Cooperation Administration announced today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 (UP) -- Chairman Ralph E. Flanders, Republican, of Vermont, and his Joint Congressional Economic Committee were accused today by People's Lobby of "conspiring against consumers" in their recent profits hearings.

SAN SALVADOR, El Salvador, Dec. 26 -- The Council of the new revolutionary Government, composed of young Army officers who forced the resignation of President Salvador Castaneda Castro on Dec. 14, outlined its policies in a proclamation issued here yesterday.

Men and women who "want to live like the beasts of the fields" and who '"would impose naturalism and godlessness on education, government and anything that concerns our welfare" were denounced yesterday by Auxiliary Bishop Joseph F. Flannelly, administrator of St. Patrick's Cathedral, in his sermon at solemn mass there.

BIG BEAR, Calif., Dec. 26 (AP) -A Santa Barbara physician and three members of his family were found dead today amidst Christmas decorations and unopened packages in a cabin at this mountain resort, Sheriff's Capt. H.C. English reported.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 (AP) -Public construction will increase by 25 per cent in 1949, according to J.W. Follin, Assistant Administrator of Federal Works.

ROME, Dec. 26 -- The principal worry of the highest United States policy makers concerning repercussions of the Dutch action in the East Indies is that it will not only completely embarrass the American moral position in the basic political dispute with world communism, but that it has offered the Communist Information Bureau a magnificent propaganda gift upon a silver platter.

Thousands of boys and girls are expected to enjoy Yuletide cheer this week at seventeen parties scheduled by the Police Athletic League, it was announced yesterday by Deputy Police Commissioner James B. Nolan, president of the league.
ROME, Dec. 26 -- The Chinese Communist Central Executive Committee has instructed military commanders in occupied areas to stamp out the Catholic and all other religions, Vatican circles said today.

Two men were arrested yesterday on a charge of having taken from a restaurant a collection box left by the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis. The police said that they had received many complaints of this nature from the East Flatbush section of Brooklyn, where this theft occurred.

PARIS, Dec. 26 -- In the same way as the nations benefiting from the Marshall Plan, the French zone of occupation in Germany has submitted to the Organization for European Economic Cooperation a memorandum covering its program for production and of exports and imports for the period from 1949 to 1952.

John Haynes Holmes of the Community Church, 40 East Thirty-fifth Street, told his congregation yesterday that 1949 would be a year in which the decision for peace or war would be made. He placed the responsibility for this decision on the shoulders of the United States Government.

As two regularly-scheduled airlines announced yesterday that their reduced family and coach fare plans were succeeding, the Non-Certificated Air Carriers Association protested that a recent ruling of the Civil Aeronautics Board would drive them out of business.

The base price for New Year's Eve parties in hotel supper rooms will range, with few exceptions, from $7.50 to $15 a person, according to the Hotel Association of New York City. This does not include the liquor bill, the woman's corsage, the baby-sitter's fee, transportation, or rooms for those celebrants unable or unwilling to go home after the last bottle has been consumed.

ON BOARD THE SAIPAN, En Route to Greenland, Dec. 26 -- Despite increasingly heavy seas, 100-mile-an-hour winds and subfreezing weather, the carrier Saipan tonight was forging ahead off the Maine Coast in a race to reach the thirteen airmen marooned on a Greenland icecap.

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 26 -- William (Wild Bill) Donohoe said today he would leave his head football and basketball coaching posts at Carnegie Institute of Technology, at the conclusion of his contract on July 1, 1949.

The British Throne is an institution most Americans find it hard to understand. It is full of contradictions. Its occupant is often as beloved as though he had been elected by an overwhelming vote, yet he is chosen by the accident of birth alone. The British national anthem is a prayer for his preservation, he is treated as though he were in fact a ruler, yet his Ministers tell him what to say.

BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 26 -- President Juan Person is known to be considering a large-scale-anti-Communist campaign. It could be effected at any time, but in view of the uneasy labor situation and the economic problems, it is considered tied to the onset of the first big strike, or series of strikes.

LONDON, Dec. 26 -- While the city already had a good general outline of Britain's four-year economic-recovery plan owing to its premature disclosure in Paris, actual publication of its details here has provided a mass of material over which business men must ponder, wonder and indulge in doubts.
BATAVIA, Java, Dec. 26 -- Dutch authorities were reported today to have moved captured leaders of the Indonesian Republic from Jogjakarta to a secret point in the East Indies.
DETROIT, Dec. 26 (AP) -- The Detroit Red Wings regained the National Hockey League lead from idle Boston by beating Montreal, 3 to 1, tonight before 13,853 fans.

SHRUB OAK, N.Y., Dec. 26 -- The men who are building a community hall for the Shrub Oak Methodist Church may not be as handy with the hammer and the saw as were the men of grandfather's day, but they are no less energetic in beating the high cost of building.

LONDON, Dec. 26 (Reuters) -- Thousands of pounds are being contributed by British newspapers and periodicals to finance an appeal to the highest court in Britain -- the House of Lords -- against what has been described as a Hollywood attempt to "gag English criticism and intimidate English critics.

St Stephen's Roman Catholic Church in Twenty-eighth Street, near Lexington Avenue, celebrated yesterday the 100th anniversary of its founding at a pontifical mass of thanksgiving. Auxiliary Bishop Joseph P. Donahue was celebrant at the ceremony, which fell on the Feast of St Stephen, first Christian martyr and patron of the church.

The Cosmopolitan Little Symphony under Everett Lee, gave its second New York concert last night at Town Hall. Todd Duncan, baritone, was the assisting artist with the orchestra, an inter-racial unit, consisting of thirty-eight professional musicians.

SOFIA, Bulgaria, Dec. 26 -- Vassil Kolarov, Foreign Minister and member of the Bulgarian Communist party's Political Bureau, in a speech delivered yesterday before the party's fifth congress, vigorously attacked the "so-called theory of superiority of the West over the East."

PEIPING, Dec. 26 (UP) -- To all outward appearances the battle for Peiping is a deadly serious affair. Yet a non-combatant may stroll through the firing lines, chat with the commanders of both sides, and return unharmed to a dinner at the plush Peiping Club.
With the fulcrum of Zionism shifted dramatically to the new state of Israel, the power arm of the international movement to settle the Jews in Palestine now definitely is in the United States.

A certain economist who happens to be a stanch believer in the free enterprise way of life once declared to the writer: "If private enterprise ever really gets around to presenting its case to the public intelligently and in simple, understandable language, there is one thing I'd like to predict.
Under sunny skies but in biting cold, New York observed yesterday the anniversary of its record snowstorm of 1947.

Any rise in corporate income taxes will bring on a serious depression, according to Walter Hoving, president of the Commerce and Industry Association of New York, Inc. In a statement that will be filed today with Senator Ralph E. Flanders, head of the Senate-House special committee studying business revenues, he denounced the "prapaganda technique" and the "subtle attacks" on company profits being utilized by advocates of increased assessments.

A new Morey Amsterdam comedy series which would be heard Monday through Fridays from 5:30 to 5:45 P.M. will be auditioned by CBS, it was announced over the week-end. Philip Morris was named "a potential sponsor" of the program.
BERLIN, Dec. 26 -- Favored by clear weather, pilots operating the Berlin airlift marked today just six months of Operation Vittles by flying in 6,099 tons of food and other supplies.

The promotion of two high-ranking officials in the operating department of the United States Lines, to become effective next Saturday, were announced yesterday by John M. Franklin, president of the line.

Four Brownsville youth who, the police say, have held up and terrorized small storekeepers in various parts of Brooklyn in the last month were captured yesterday as the aftermath of an investigation into the accidental fatal shooting of the sister of one of the hoodlums.

CAIRO, Dec. 26 -- Although no large-scale movements yet have been reported, information reaching United Nations and foreign diplomatic quarters today was that Israel had thrown the weight of her entire army against the Egyptians in the Negeb.

Shipments for the principal women's, misses' and juniors' outerwear industries during the third quarter totaled $719,000,000, an increase of $120,000,000 or 20 per cent compared with the corresponding period of last year, the Bureau of Census, Department of Commerce, announced over the week-end. Cuttings of almost all outerwear garments covered in the survey showed increases ranging from 4 to 35 per cert.
Jean Cocteau, Penfant terrible of French art and letters, glided in from Paris yesterday half frozen but buzzing with his usual burden of revolutionary ideas.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 -- Tubs of live turtles, bogus clothes brushes, false heels and even fake toy watches do not fool Federal narcotics agents and Government sleuths any more.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 (AP) -- The Association of American Railroads said today that the railroad industry is closing a year of "all-time road efficiency" -- but with inadequate earnings.

The pastor of Calvary Baptist Church must have sources of information about British politics and church life denied to the vast majority of British Christians. At least, they are entirely unaware of the attacks upon the church by the "Socialistic Government" of Great Britain, of which he is reported as speaking in your issue of Dec. 13.

The subcommittee on profits of the Joint Congressional Committee on the Economic Report (better known as the Flanders Committee) has concluded its two weeks of hearings on the subject of corporate profits. After studying the testimony the subcommittee will make a factual report to the main committee.

Sixty players representing fifteen colleges appeared yesterday for the opening of the annual team championship of the Intercollegiate Chess League, a national fixture sponsored by the United States Chess Federation, at John Jay Hall, Columbia University.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 -- Sumner Welles, former Under-Secretary of State, was in a serious condition in a hospital here tonight after having been found semi-conscious this morning in a field near his home at Oxon Hill, Md.

RIVERHEAD, L.I., Dec. 26 -- The cauliflower growers of Suffolk County have had one of their most profitable seasons, Dwight T. Corwin of Riverhead, general manager of the Long Island Cauliflower Association, said today.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., Dec. 26 (AP) -- Sale of the Cole Brothers Circus, which winters at the Kentucky State Fair Grounds here, was announced today.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 26--Labor disputes affecting the economy are a perennial threat to attainment of economic stabilization and maximum production, the Council of Economic Advisers...
TOKYO, Dec. 26 -- Apparently blessed with ample funds, Japan's Communist party has announced it would nominate one candidate in every one of Japan's 197 electoral districts for the Jan. 23 election.
VIENNA, Dec. 26 (AP) -- Dana Superina has been admitted to an American sector hospital on the verge of a nervous breakdown, United States sources said tonight.

Within the last two weeks 3,000 persons intent on research for scholarship's sake, on pleasure and on gain have visited the Main Reading Room of the New York Public Library daily. Like the heavy attendance on the week-end following Thanksgiving Day and on other holidays, the recent influx is largely traceable to university and college students home for the holidays or on visits.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Dec. 26 -- The fifth congress of the Bulgarian Communist party, which yesterday wound up its meetings in Sofia, charted domestic policies of states of the Communist Information Bureau for consolidation of Communist power.

KINGS PARK, L.I., Dec. 26 -Four of six inmates of the Kings Park State Hospital, who escaped after beating an attendant, Vincent Colon, and stealing his keys, are back in the institution today. They were caught in a net thrown out by the Smithtown, Huntington and New York State Police. None of the four succeeded in getting out of Suffolk County.

The foreign exchange market accomplished little in the way of business or important price changes last week. Typical holiday atmosphere prevailed in all sessions from Monday right up to the close, as banks, commercial interests and the speculative fraternity were not in the least inclined to trade, even where there were two-way markets in evidence.
The State Legislature, which meets in Albany next week, will be asked to bring 480,000 workers in small shops under the protection of the state unemployment insurance system.

The foreign exchange market accomplished little in the way of business or important price changes last week. Typical holiday atmosphere prevailed in all sessions from Monday right up to the close, as banks, commercial interests and the speculative fraternity were not in the least inclined to trade, even where there were two-way markets in evidence.
The State Legislature, which meets in Albany next week, will be asked to bring 480,000 workers in small shops under the protection of the state unemployment insurance system.
TALLAHASSEE, Fla., Dec. 26 (AP) -- Slender Mrs. Celeste Roess, who likes to take alligators alive because "they look so pathetic when they're dead," has a job few men and fewer women would envy.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Dec. 26 -- Several bombs that caused no serious damage were dropped by planes today east of Tel Aviv, while United Nations observers in the Negeb, desert area in southern Palestine, disclosed that Israeli planes had dropped ninety bombs at El Arish, where an Egyptian airfield is situated, and at Rafah and Khan Yunis.
MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 26 (AP) -- The University of Georgia Bulldogs rolled into town today for their date with the University of Texas in the Orange Bowl on New Year's Day.

The growth of television has exceeded all estimates and is destined to become by 1953 one of the ten foremost industries in the country, Brig. Gen. David Sarnoff, president and chairman of the board of the Radio Corporation of America, declared yesterday in his annual year-end statement.

PARIS, Dec. 26 -- A detailed and severe criticism of Government waste in many departments of the Administration is contained in the annual report of the Accountancy Court [Cour des Comptes], which has just been formally submitted for the years 1946 and 1947.

In a move reflecting the declines in attendance and betting at its 1948 meetings, the Westchester Racing Association, which operates Belmont Park, yesterday announced a decrease in the addedmoney value of next year's eightyfirst running of the Belmont Stakes.

A tone of unusual quality and a technique of near-perfection marked the debut recital of Aaron Rosand at Town Hall last night. The young violinist displayed a mechanical perfection, which itself was enough to fill his program with interest, and made such resonant sounds that Arthur Balsam, his competent assistant at the piano, had to make no apparent effort to balance the two unequal instruments.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 -- A strong liberal voice within Democratic ranks was added today to the mounting appeal that the Truman Administration reject the excessprofits tax as a means of preventing a heavy budget deficit.

PARIS, Dec. 27 (AP) -- Here is the text of a report on the renewed fighting in Palestine's Negeb desert, submitted to the United Nations Security Council today over the signature of Dr. Ralph J. Bunche, acting Mediator:

PEIPING, Dec. 27 -- The siege of Peiping is by no means total. Planes are now landing on two airfields within the city walls. Telegraphic communication with the rest of the world is still open and telephone service to Nanking and Shanghai is still possible, although Tientsin is cut off.

Continuation of the Economic Cooperation Administration's export movement of cotton brought in buying of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday that left prices at the best levels of the day at the close with net gains of 16 to 32 points on active months.

For the first time since the early days of the war, scholarly research and serious programs of self-education are again in noticeable evidence, the New York Public Library reported yesterday in surveying its activities from Jan. 1, 1947, to June 1, 1948.

The Police Department's new helicopter put down in Jamaica Bay in the swift-falling twilight yesterday to pull Charles Rezba, 21 years old, of 2059 Sixty-seventh Street, Brooklyn, from an overturned light amphibian plane.

The presentation of thirty-one prizes, totaling $12,400, in the fourth annual Detective Short Story contest, sponsored by Ellery Queen's Mystery Magazine and Little, Brown Co., was announced yesterday.

American-LaFrance-Foamite Corporation has arranged with Bankers Trust Company, New York, to act as agent for holders desiring to purchase or sell script representing its common stock, through June 17, 1949.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Dec. 27 -- Although the Democratic minority charged "extravagance," the Westchester County Board of Supervisors adopted the 1949 operating, capital and special district budgets totaling $25,607,735 this afternoon, establishing a new record tax levy.
Contract talks between tugboat workers and operators before Mayor O'Dwyer's special threeman citizens' committee were opened at City Hall yesterday afternoon on a highly optimistic note.
INDIANAPOLIS, Dec. 27 (AP) -Forward Leo Barnhorst sank a free throw in the last ten seconds to give Notre Dame a 51-50 basketball victory over Purdue tonighth)0*0*0*iin Butler Fieldhouse.

BERLIN, Dec. 27 -- An increase in American troop strength in Europe is being sought by some Central European and Mediterranean countries, Kenneth G. Royall, Secretary of the Army, disclosed today. The Secretary refused to name the countries that made such requests.

What our young artists do! Last night Gary Graffman, winner of the special award in the national finals contest of the Rachmaninoff Fund last spring, gave the recital which that award confers in Carnegie Hall. Mr. Graffman has extraordinary equipment and is obviously an exceptional talent.

You recently published the ambitious program of the Board of Transportation. While no one can argue that the improvements suggested are not desirable, the question of payment for these improvements arises. Mr. Reid, the chairman of the Board of Transportation, refers to this phase of the problem as follows:

The report of the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service on the Mexican waterfowl situation will do little toward reviving the faith of the experienced wildfowler in the findings of the service, for a conducted tour of a few days' duration is hardly sufficient to justify the conclusions drawn by the Government officials.

PASADENA, Calif., Dec. 27 -The establishment of fellowships in "creative aeronautics" under the joint auspices of Howard Hughes, airplane manufacturer and film producer, and the California Institute of Technology was announced here today.

Favorites moved along without incident yesterday as play started in the Eastern boys' and junior indoor tennis championships on the boards of the Fifteenth Regiment Armory, 142nd Street and Fifth Avenue. Competition in both divisions will continue all week with the finals on Friday.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 (AP) -The Government today ordered a complete end to racial segregation at the Washington National Airport, which lies on Virginia soil across the Potomac River.

With nineteen of the twenty games of the first four rounds decided in the international masters' tournament at the Manhattan Chess Club, the United States champion, Herman Steiner of Los Angeles, and the former national open champion, Israel A. Horowitz of this city, had the arena to themselves last night.

" Confucius: The Man and the Myth," by H. G. Creel, the second book about Confucius in six months, has been scheduled, for April publication by John Day. It is a twenty-year study, showing that Confucius was in fact a reformer and an individualist, democratic and even revolutionary.

We hope that Sumner Welles, grievously stricken in the mishap which befell him early Sunday morning, will soon be sufficiently recovered to learn the esteem in which he is held and the general sympathy which goes out to him Mr. Welles has never been one to make emotional appeals to crowds.

TRENTON, N.J., Dec. 27 -- Nearly 500 high school boys and girls spent a day in Trenton today as "officials" and "legislators" of boys' and girls' state, finding out at first hand about government. The annual visit is sponsored under the youth program of the American Legion in New Jersey.

In your editorial "State and City Budgets," on Dec. 11, you point to the demands on both state and city in the coming year and conclude that "New York City public school teachers, who have mentioned demands of $1,500 to $2,000 per year per teacher in salary rise," must be denied on the grounds that "there just isn't the money."

BROOKLINE, Mass., Dec. 27 (AP) -- Miss Laura Lou Jahn of Hollywood Calif., the defending champion and Mrs. Harold Ayres of Baltimore, seeded second, advanced easily today in opening play in the national junior girls indoor tennis championships at the Longwood covered courts.

The State Racing Commission, in its annual report released for publication today, presents a bucketful of facts and figures on New York's 1948 turf campaign and again urges the abolition of the 5 per cent municipal and county tax on betting which was imposed in 1946.

HANCOCK, Mass., Dec. 27 -Massachusetts' most pretentious and expansive ski development, Jiminy Peak, with its 2,400-foot summit, is all set to start its Alpine lift -- the only one in the state -- and varied facilities, come a few more inches of snow.

LONDON, Dec. 27 -- The spirit of Christmas was invoked today on behalf of 200 to 300 Ukrainian prisoners of war threatened with deportation to Germany after having been rejected for work in this country.

GENEVA, Dec. 27 (AP) -- The Swiss Football and Athletic Association has asked the International Football Federation to lift the ban and permit "friendly and unofficial" soccer games with German teams.

PRINCETON, N.J., Dec. 27 -Over 100 hockey players from eight Eastern prep schools will participate in the Lawrenceville School invitation hockey tournament in Princeton University's Baker Memorial Rink on Jan. 3 and 4, according to plans released today by Charles R. Erdman Jr., Mayor of the Borough of Princeton and chairman of the tournament committee.

Operations of the steel industry are scheduled for this week at the near-capacity level of 97.3 per cent of ingot capacity, compared with 88.6 per cent in the preceding week when steel output declined because of the Christmas holiday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 -- The rash of anti-trust suits in the political year of 1948 is the second American public custom that has interested those Cornell University educators, headed by Prof. F. A. Pearson, who from time to time write and publish the meaty little pamphlet, "Farm Economics."

Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores increased 51 per cent last week over the corresponding period last year, according to the "flash" report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. Due to Christmas occurring at the end of the week this year, five shopping days were compared with only three last year.
ALBANY, N.Y., Dec. 27 (AP) -In a special Christmas week report the State Commerce Department listed good snow conditions today at three New York ski centers.

If demand for wool cloth shows any improvement early in 1949, American manufacturers will find themselves in a price squeeze for better foreign grades, it was asserted yesterday by Robert KahnSriber, president of Sociedada Comercial di Lanas, Buenos Aires and Montevideo.

Garod Electronics Corporation yesterday introduced a new type of television receiver at a preview of its 1949 line in the Park Central Hotel. A patented electronic circuit provides for reception of conventional rectangular images of the company's ten, twelve and fifteen inch direct-view tube sets and permits instant enlargement of one and one-half times on a superimposed circular screen by pushbutton control.

New York members of the National Maritime Union voted last night by nearly two to one to expel Joseph Stack, former vice president and left-wing opponent of Joseph Curran, president of the CIO affiliate.

PARIS, Dec. 27 (AP) -- United Nations observers accused Israeli forces today of having attacked Egyptian units in the Negeb, desert area in southern Palestine, in violation of truce agreements. However, Dr. Ralph J. Bunche, acting Mediator, said that he was not blaming either side.

ROME, Dec. 27 -- Pope Pius was said today to have been profoundly grieved and shocked at news of the arrest of Joseph Cardinal Mindszenty, Primate of Hungary. Confirmation of the arrest with no details was received by the papal Secretary of State late tonight.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Dec. 27 (AP) -- The arrest of Assistant Finance Minister Obren Blagojevitch on a charge of having attempted to escape from the country with Yugoslav Government funds was revealed yesterday.

Outgoing air shipments of checks by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York averaged 3,230 pounds daily in October, when total shipments by air express exceeded twenty-seven tons, the bank reported yesterday. The totals compared with a daily average of 1,232 pounds and a monthly total slightly above ten tons in June, 1947, date of the last prior report.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 -- Leading veterans' organizations today voiced strong opposition to the plan of a Hoover Commission "task force" to reorganize Veterans Administration hospitals and medical installations into a new national bureau of health to include also the general hospitals of the armed services and the medical care functions of the Public Health Service.

Opposition to a merger plan was continued yesterday by a group of preferred stockholders of the Long Island Lighting Company professing to represent holders of 129,930 shares, or 51 per cent, of its 6 and 7 per cent preferred stocks. They said they awaited a definite offer and a satisfactory allocation of stock in connection with the proposal of the Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., to acquire Long Island Lighting.

Figures illustrating the tremendous increase in the number of Blue Cross Plan subscribers using semi-private accommodations in hospitals were supplied by the Hospital Council of Greater New York yesterday in its December bulletin.

Italy's African colonies are the most important item of the unfinished business of the General Assembly of the United Nations, which meets here in April. Most important of the colonies is the one which the Italians used to call Libya, and which they are now willing to consider as Cyrenaica and Tripolitania.

CHICAGO, Dec. 27 (AP) -- The general level of the wholesale price of all meats in the United States has declined about 19 per cent since the mid-September peak, according to the American Meat Institute.

Yale led N.Y.U. a not-so-merry chase for twenty-six minutes last night at Madison Square Garden, but the Violets showed to greater advantage throughout the final fourteen and consequently walked off with a 76-67 victory over the Elis.

Two old real estate firms will begin 1949 with new names as the result of the withdrawal of Morgan Dix Wheelock as vice president and director of Brown, Wheelock, Harris, Stevens, Inc. He is joining the firm of Braislin, Porter Baldwin, Inc., which will be known as Braislin, Porter Wheelock, Inc.

The stock market failed yesterday to follow through on the preChristmas rise, raising some doubts in Wall Street over the possibility of the traditional yearend rally. Fluctuations were narrow, and while the composite rate gained 0.09 point due to outstanding strength in the chemicals, the list generally leaned to the lower side.
Richard Carney, 35 years old, an unemployed shipyard rigger, and his wife, Marie, 33, were under arrest yesterday charged with abandoning their five children on Christmas Eve.

Robert Burke, 25 years old, of 39-44 Forty-sixth Street, Sunnyside, Queens, was found guilty in Special Sessions, Long Island City, Queens, yesterday on charges of impairing the morals of a minor and indecent exposure. Sentence was set for Jan. 6.
New York University will start a specialized clinical in-service and graduate training program next February for personnel connected with the handling of delinquent children.

The vast tragedy that is being enacted in Eastern Europe under cover of a diplomatic word war is emphasized again by Army Secretary Royall in a statement in Berlin. Confirming many previous reports, Mr. Royall charges on the basis of a reliable intelligence survey made at his request that the Russian Government is holding no fewer than 13,000,000 prisoners in concentration camps in the Soviet Union, including a large number of women and children.

The House Committee on UnAmerican Activities and the Roman Catholic Church were depicted yesterday as working hand-in-glove for the destruction of Protestantism, the abolition of free public schools, and the breakdown of the principle of the separation of church and state.

SEOUL, Korea, Dec. 27 -- President Syngman Rhee today said that his administration would sponsor a "liberal" land reform program and urge its adoption "as soon as possible" by the National Assembly. Dr. Rhee added that although the administration intended to present such a bill, the program had not yet been agreed upon byh)0*0*0*ithe Cabinet.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Dec. 27 -- Of 120,000 forced workers in uranium mines operated by Russia near the Bavarian-Czech border, at least 30,000 are women, according to a young German who escaped ten days ago and reached Frankfort yesterday.

SYRACUSE, Dec. 27 (AP) -- Supreme Court Justice Clifford H. Searl issued an order late today to send to the Appellate Division at Rochester pleas of two sportsmen's groups to halt plans to construct a $6,000,000 Panther Mountain reservoir project.

The left-wing United Office and Professional Workers of America, warned by Philip Murray that it faced loss of its Congress of Industrial Organizations charter for lack of organizing effectiveness, announced last night that it had called a national conference for Jan. 8 and 9 at Manhattan Center to start an expanded organizing drive in the white-collar field.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 -- November tax collections on furs, jewelry, handbags and luggage ran ahead of last year despite the reported drop in sales of those lines.

MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 27 (AP) -- Notre Dame Coach Frank Leahy tonight picked the University of Georgia Bulldogs to win over Texas in the Orange Bowl classic New Year's Day by a point and maybe a touchdown.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 27 -Implementing Howard Hughes' decision to put Robert Mitchum to work in a picture before he goes to trial Jan. 10 on narcotics charges, RKO has sent Jack Gross, the producer, and Don Siegel, the director, to Veracruz, Mexico, to examine locations for "The Big Steal," in which Mitchum will star.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 -- The Federal Power Commission denied today that the rates of return fixed by it for natural gas companies forced them to seek "cheap money" rather than "risk venture capital" through junior equity financing.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Dec. 27 (Reuters) -- The movement of all goods except absolute essentials stopped throughout Czechoslovakia today when shops closed on Government order for the rest of the year. Exempted from the closure decree, made to allow stocktaking, were pharmacists, food, tobacco, fuel and newspaper shops and banks.

Jersey Motors, Inc., Ford agency, has assembled a plot in Jersey City, N.J., for the construction of a "motor center." The property, comprising 20,000 square feet, is bounded by four streets, with the principal frontage on State Highway 1 running through to Hopkins Avenue and from Collard Street to Bevan Street.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Dec. 27 -- After hearing testimony all day, City Judge William McKinley convicted four leaders of the American Labor Party here this evening. They were found guilty of disorderly conduct for having ignored police orders to disband a political mass meeting at Martine Avenue and Brookfield Street on the night of Oct. 25.
ATLANTIC CITY, Dec. 27--BayardL. England of this place waselected president of the AtlanticCity Electric Company at a meetingof the board of directors of theutility concern here today.

BATAVIA, Java, Dec. 27 (AP) Indonesian Republican troops were said today to have launched their first major guerrilla attack against the Netherland forces that drove them from the major cities of Java.

NEW ARK, N.J., Dec. 27 -- Public Safety Director John B. Keenan today formally requested Chief Justice Arthur T. Vanderbilt of the New Jersey Supreme Court to delay start of the new state-wide uniform "ticket" for traffic violations.

Yeshiva University players followed up their good start of the first round by defeating Rutgers, 3 -- 1, yesterday in the second of the series of matches for the championship of the Intercollegiate Chess League at John Jay Hall on the Columbia campus.

CHICAGO, Dec. 27 -- Grain markets fluctuated slowly within a moderate range on the Board of Trade today, closing irregular. Price changes were confined to a fraction of a cent a bushel, trading being of a holiday character. Wheat finished 3/8 cent off to 1/4 cent up; May showing the weakness.

Ingrid Bergman will appear in a radio adaptation of "Joan of Arc" for the opening presentation of "Command Performance," the series to be established by NBC in its 8:30 spot on Sunday nights, next week. For the greater part the incoming program will feature "top-line dramatic shows," the network explained, adding that from time to time a musical or a variety show would be scheduled.

Mrs. Jeannette Donnelly of Lockwood, N.Y., came yesterday to the aid of her daughter, Mrs. Anne E. Coker, 19-year-old mother of two infants she was accused of abandoning. In Brooklyn Adolescent Court Mrs. Donnelly assured Magistrate Vernon C. Riddick that she would find room on her farm for her daughter and the children although there are eight others in the family there now.
KANSAS CITY, Mo., Dec. 27 -President Truman asserted today that there were certain Russian leaders "who are exceedingly anxious to have an understanding with us."
CHICAGO, Dec. 27 (AP) -- The National Federation of State High School Athletic Associations, representing more than 20,000 schools, will hold its annual meeting here tomorrow through Friday.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Dec. 27 (AP) -- A pair of midget guards, 5-foot 7-inch Don Ferguson and 5-foot 8 Bob Petersen, led a second half scoring barrage that gave Iowa State's Cyclones a 56-to-54 victory over Harvard in the opening game of the Big Seven Conference's basketball tournament tonight.

Let's admit in the first place that Jean Giraudoux's "The Madwoman of Chaillot" is too long for the slight fable it has to tell. After a rapturously humorous and poetic first act, the second act grows increasingly languid, and obviously that is a fault in playmaking.
Cooperation between Carolyn Schnurer, designer, and Peck Peck, Fifth Avenue specialty shop, has produced a sports collection that is one of the most effective seen by this writer for some time.

The turkish bath employe who at first told police he was held up, robbed and then -- clad only in his underwear -- forced to drive his captors upstate, was brought back to New York yesterday to answer to the crime himself.

Sand is now plugging one of the biggest leaks in America's shortage of lead. Discovery of the new method of substituting sand for lead was described yesterday by officers of the National Lead Company, according to The Associated Press.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 27 (AP) -- A banner throng of 10,037 sun-baked fans was stunned at Tropical Park today when King Midas, a 9 to 1 shot, captured the featured Jaquemart Purse while the highly favored Education struggled home third in a field of half a dozen sprinters.

Nathan Wilson, operator, has purchased the apartment house property on the southerly side of Fairview Avenue, 100 feet east of Broadway, from the Title Guarantee and Trust Company as executor of the estate of Charles M. Rosenthal.

Harry F. Schroeter will become director of media for National Biscuit Company, effective Jan. 1, it was announced yesterday by George Oliva, director of advertising for the company. Mr. Schroeter joined Nabisco in 1945, coming from the advertising department of Procter Gamble in Cincinnati.
The legal tangre involving the estate of the late Ignace Jan Paderewski is moving toward a climax, it was indicated yesterday.

The death of two babies marred the arrival of a Seaboard Western Airlines plane from Munich yesterday morning at New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens. One child died in its mother's arms in flight and another died several hours after a premature delivery at the airport.

PARIS, Dec. 27 -- Alexandre Parodi, French representative on the United Nations Security Council, today expressed his regret over delay in granting a French visa to Vassily A. Tarasenko, Soviet Ukrainian representative, for his return to Paris from New York.

LONDON, Dec. 27 (UP) -- Portsmouth maintained its slim onepoint lead in the English football league's close first division race by trouncing Chelsea, 5 to 2, today as Derby County and Newcastle United, tied for second place, kept pace.

COMPARED to Harry Brunner, the neurotic hero of Ira Wolfert's ambitious war novel, "An Act of Love,"* the Prince of Denmark was a happy extrovert. No more unbelievably introspective character has ever appeared in print to my knowledge than this zombie-like abstraction whose search for his soul in a world at war is the theme of Mr. Wolfert's tortuous, turgid and tedious book.

PARIS, Dec. 27 -- The United Nations Security Council, after hearing what some members interpreted as a rejection by the Netherlands of the cease-fire resolution that it adopted on Christmas Eve, today rejected Soviet proposals calling upon the Dutch to cease fire in Indonesia within twentyfour hours and return immediately to the positions that they had occupied before they launched their offensive on Dec. 18.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 27 (AP) -Unbeaten La Salle College stormed back in a wild shooting second half tonight to overcome a 13-point deficit and win its seventh straight, 76 to 71, over Louisville in the second game of a basketball double-header at Convention Hall.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 -- Credit granted to private borrowers by life insurance companies, mutual savings banks and savings and loan associations increased about $9,000,000,000 in the year ended with last October, the Federal Reserve Board said today.
ATHENS, Dec. 27 (UP) -- The steamer Tampa, of Panamanian registry, with 500 passengers aboard, is floundering without a rudder in heavy seas off Crete, the Marine Ministry said today.

JOHANNESBURG, Dec. 27 (Reuters) -- The biggest crowd at a cricket match in South Africa witnessed the first day's play in the second test today between South Africa and England. At the close England had scored 387 for two wickets.

Frank Smith, a sprightly bachelor of 82, who patronizes the Union Settlement House at 237 East 104th Street, and Lynda Jackson, 4, a junior patron, yesterday delivered a letter of thanks from the settlement house to the Greater New York Fund for the funds gift of $13,338 this year.

A "squeeze" developed yesterday in the maturing December contract in hides on the Commodity Exchange here. At one time prices were driven up 545 points in that contract. Final transactions at noon, when the contract expired, were at 38.75 cents a pound.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 (AP) -The National Bureau of Standards has developed an "atomic clock," described as being more accurate than the rotating earth as a reference standard of time and of radio frequencies.

Response to the beginning of post-Christmas sales was reported yesterday by department and specialty store officials as "very satisfactory." Heavy Sunday newspaper advertising that announced clearances featuring price cuts ranging from one-third to one-half off regular retail prices drew large crowds to the shopping districts.
TOKYO, Dec. 27 (AP) -- Gen. Douglas MacArthur today ordered all Japanese-produced staple foods, except what farmers use, delivered into the controlled market.
Congress reorganizes itself Jan. 3, next. Unless changes are made in certain procedures we shall again see much of the legislation that voters desire stalled in committees and so defeated.

BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 27 -- A baby girl born on an incoming displaced persons' ship that docked here this morning touched off a celebration among 801 other passengers, who hailed her as a "little American" because the vessel was a United States Army transport.
TOKYO, Dec. 27 -- Leaders of all of Japan's major political parties today registered as candidates for the Diet in the new general election scheduled for Jan. 23.

The New York Film Critics will meet this morning at the New York Newspaper Guild Headquarters, 133 West Forty-fourth Street, to vote on the year's best American and foreign pictures. Members of the Metropolitan press, voting at the fourteenth annual meeting, also will choose the year's best actor, actress and director.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, Dec. 27 -Hungary's Communist - dominated Government announced today the arrest of Joseph Cardinal Mindszenty on suspicion of plotting against the Government, spying, treason and black market money dealings.
HONOLULU, Dec. 27 (AP) -- Two century-old Hawaiian statutes covering unlawful assembly, riot and conspiracy were held unconstitutional today by a three-judge Federal court.

CHICAGO, Dec. 27 -- Musicians and teachers of music numbering 1,000 gathered here today for a series of meetings this week of more than a dozen music organizations, including the Music Teachers National Association and the National Association of Schools of Music.
POUGHKEEPSIE, Dec. 27 (AP) -- Sheriff C. Fred Close said today he had been informed that Faye Emerson Roosevelt, actress wife of Elliott Roosevelt, had slashed her wrist with a razor early yesterday.
LONDON, Dec. 27 (Reuters) -Results of football matches in Britain today:

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Dec. 27 -- Premier Tito told Parliament today that Yugoslavia could no longer count on trade with the Soviet-bloc countries because they had broken their agreements to deliver heavy capital equipment to industrialize this country.

CLEVELAND, Dec. 27 -- The subcommittee of the Hoover Commission that surveyed the statistical agencies of the Federal Government has recommended that large-scale, repetitive enumeration and tabulation be centralized in the Bureau of the Census, it was disclosed here today.
Three hundred and ninety-six persons died in accidents over the Christmas week-end, The Associated Press reported last night after a country-wide survey.

ALBANY, Dec. 27 -- State relief payments are running behind the estimates, made when this year's budget was approved, at the rate of more than $20,000,000 a year, due chiefly to the failure of relief rolls to increase as rapidly as had been anticipated.

Workers and peasants in the Philippines regard the independence granted them in 1946 as "a mockery" and their leaders as subservient to the dictates of Wall Street and Army officials in Washington, Amado Hernandez, president of the Philippine Congress of Labor Organizations, declared yesterday at the Hotel Commodore.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Dec. 27 -- Fighting in the Negeb, desert area in southern Palestine, took an important turn tonight when Israeli troops, according to an Egyptian report to the United Nations, captured a strategic point on the coastal plain north of the Egyptian border.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 -- Sumner Welles, former Under-Secretary of State, continued to improve today from the effects of hours of exposure in a frozen, windswept field more than a mile from his home in Oxon Hill, Md., Christmas night.

Alexander's Department Stores, Inc., through one of its subsidiaries, Level Realty Corporation, has acquired title to a plot 135-65 by 172 feet at the southwest corner of 191st Street and Creston Avenue, the Bronx, which will be used in connection with the operation of its store at Fordham Road and the Grand Concourse.

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 27 (AP) -- Duquesne University put on a determined drive midway in the second half to pull away from a rugged Rutgers team and notch its fourth straight basketball victory, 53 43,h)0*0*0*itonight in the Gardens.

Following criticism yesterday of the city's lack of a master plan, Robert F. Wagner Jr., chairman of the City Planning Commission, said his agency was now working on an up-to-date revision of the Zoning Ordinances as a necessary first step.

PARIS, Dec. 27 -- An additional 20,000,000,000 francs from the counterpart fund under the Marshall Plan was released to the French Government tonight by the Economic Cooperation Administration. This brought the total released under the interim aid and European Recovery Program regimes to 110,000,000,000 francs -about $401,000,000 at the official rate at which the counterpart fund is translated.

Signs of a turn in the unfavorable situation that has developed in a number of consumer goods lines will be watched for closely during the first two months of this year, it was reported here yesterday.

David Dubinsky's International Ladies Garment Workers Union has submitted a detailed program of substitute legislation for the Taft-Hartley Act. It is the first major union to do so. And for this reason, as well as because these recommendations come from one of the most progressive, best led and most responsible trade unions in the country, the program deserves careful consideration.
Many gifts from children came in yesterday to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 -- President Truman was thought by State Department officials to have had the four-power accord for postwar control of Germany and the Berlin situation chiefly in mind today when, in a Kansas City speech, he referred to agreements the Russians had failed to keep.

Most American-flag steamship companies increased the size of their privately owned fleets during 1948, and our Merchant Marine is looking forward to attaining its proper post-war position in 1949, Frank J. Taylor, president of the American Merchant Marine Institute, said yesterday in a year-end review of the shipping situation.

Kenneth Herman is in the middle of a high-powered dispute between the Long Island Lighting Company and the Village Board of Old Brookville. Because of it the utility will not furnish electricity for the $30,000 home Mr. Herman built in the Long Island village several months ago and Mr. Herman and his wife and child have to live elsewhere.

NANKING, Dec. 27 -- Members of the Government are still maintaining pressure on President Chiang Kai-shek to step down as head of the Chinese state, despite a Communist broadcast naming seven leading members of Dr. Sun Fo's Cabinet as "first-class war criminals."

SHANGHAI, Dec. 27 -- American companies doing business in China are receiving mimeographed notices from the "Central Committee of the Chinese Communist party" that "the legal interests" of American firms will be protected if the United States keeps its hands off in China.

A third importation, the two others this week have been "The Victors" and "The Madwoman of Chaillot," hits the Broadway stage boards tonight when "Don't Listen, Ladies," Sacha Guitry's comedy as translated by Stephen Powys, opens at the Booth Theatre under the auspices of Lee Ephraim and Jack Buchanan, who also will be starred in the offering.
MOREHEAD CITY, N.C., Dec. 27 (UP) -- The Coast Guard today rescued two Argentine seamen who prayed through a wintry day and night on the drifting stern of a tanker which broke in two in heavy seas.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission said today that the Cenco Corporation, New York, had filed a registration statement with it covering $846,000 of ten-year, 5 per cent debentures, due in 1958, and 846,000 shares of $1 par value common stock.

CHICAGO, Dec. 27 -- Lawrence A. Barrett, former Democratic politician on trial before Judge Daniel A. Roberts in Criminal Court on a charge of embezzling $10,398.31 while acting as liquidating trustee of the Madison-Kedzie Trust and Savings Bank, offered today to pay over the amount to Judge Roberts.

In its first annual report, made public in December, 1946, the President's Council of Economic Advisers declared that the philosophy of the Employment Act of 1946, under which it was created, steered a course between "Spartan fatalism" and the Roman concept of "bread and circuses."
Ir. and 1Vfrs. Hooker Talcott of 126 East Seventy-ninth Street g4ye a supper dance last night in the Cosmnopo]itax Club to introdUCe co society their daughter, 1Vfiss Suzanne Hooker Talcott.

Operating subsidiaries of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company are meeting with active opposition by local governments to their applications for rate increases. City officials in Philadelphia, Pittsburgh and St. Paul already have intervened before state regulatory bodies on the requests of local Bell System companies for higher rates to meet increased costs.

Increases in the use of layaway purchases of watches, in the outright sale of watches, and in the sale of watch attachments were among the benefits enjoyed by retail jewelers who participated in the recent first nation-wide watch promotion sponsored by the Jewelry Industry Council.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 -- Army representatives in Europe are holding constant informal conversations, but without commitment, on the integration of United States forces in Europe with the troops of the Western European Union in the event of war.

GOETTINGEN, Germany, Dec. 8 -- After Dr. Otto Hahn and Dr. F. Strassman had split the uranium atom late in 1938 and released enormous amounts of energy why was it that Germany failed to make the most of the advantage thus gained and to develop atomic energy either for military or industrial purposes?
CLEVELAND, Dec. 27 (AP) -- A Catholic priest declared today that more workers tu the United States should join labor unions.

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 27 -- Thomas J. Fitzpatrick, left-wing president of Local 61, United Electrical Radio and Machine Workers, CIO, today conceded that his faction had been defeated in a bid for reelection to controlling offices in the 16,000 member local.

Consolidated net earnings of$5,593,238 after all charges wasreported yesterday by the Marathon Corporation in its annual reportcovering the fiscal year endedwith last October. This is equalto $4.11 each on 1,300,000 sharesof common stock and compareswith $4,654,457, or $3.39 a commonshare earned in the precedingfiscal year.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Dec. 27 (AP) -- Missouri's Tigers, headed by Coach Don Faurot, arrived today and lost no time in getting down to work for their New Year's Day football game with the Clemson Tigers in the Gator Bowl.

The Christmas week-end cold snap began yesterday to relax its icy grip on the city and its suburbs, and temperatures in the low 40's were predicted here for today. Both today and tomorrow are expected to be somewhat cloudy.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, Dec. 27 -- For the last three years Cardinal Mindszenty has been an implacable enemy of the Communist party. As that party's political opponents have, one after the other, been disposed of, fled, or yielded, he himself has become more isolated and unyielding.
