Clarence C. Walker, generalmanager of the General ElectricCompany's construction materialsdepartment, has been elected a vicepresident and Ralph M. Darrin hasbeen elected a commercial vicepresident, Charles E. Wilson, president,announced yesterday.

ON THE SAIPAN EN ROUTE TO GREENLAND, Dec. 27 -- Direct communications between this Navy aircraft carrier and the Air Force commander at Greenland were established today in an effort to have the joint attempt to rescue the thirteen airmen stranded atop the Greenland ice-cap come off as smoothly as possible.

CAIRO, Dec. 27 -- "The honest course" for the Security Council, following the reportedly renewed Israeli offensive against Egypt in the Negeb, according to Abdul Rahman Azzam Pasha, secretary general of the Arab League; would be to do one of two things.

Action will be taken if it becomes necessary to investigate communistic activities of teachers or other employees of the Board of Education but such an inquiry will not degenerate into a "witch hunt," Dr. William Jansen, Superintendent of Schools, said last night.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 -- A nine-point code of procedure designed to give greater protection to witnesses and persons accused at public and private hearings was recommended to the House Committee on Un-American Activities today by its acting chairman, Senator-elect Karl E. Mundt of South Dakota, and another of its most active members, Representative Richard M. Nixon of California.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 -- A decisive high policy conference of all Senate Republicans was summoned today for next Monday with the prospect that Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio would be retained as the party's leader on national affairs.

Failure of the Air Force and the Civil Aeronautics Administration to agree on tests for new freight planes is depriving the national defense system and the civil air lines of badly needed equipment, it was charged yesterday.

Col. Bernt Balchen, veteran Air Force expert in Arctic rescue operations, was scheduled to be in Greenland today with a planeful of specially designed gear with which to attempt the rescue of the thirteen Air Force men marooned on an icecap.

THE dictionary defines misogyny as "hatred of women." Let it be understood in the very beginning that this department has only the most profound respect for womanhood. Some of its best friends are women. Without them this would be the dreariest sort of world, and if all biological laws are to be believed, the world would soon cease to exist.

When the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad brought its first train from New Haven into New York City a hundred years ago seven other railroads already had either ferry or direct connection with Manhattan Island. Twenty-one omnibus lines were operating in the city, and they had 327 licensed omnibuses.

GENEVA, Dec. 22 -- A test of how far German industrial development is likely to be as helpful to western Europe, as German and United States officials repeatedlyh)0*0*0*imaintain, is being made in a so-far quiet tussle over the future production of electric power from brown coal in the Rhineland.

With seven of the entrants reaching the quarter-final round, play in the annual invitation intercollegiate squash racquets tournament got under way yesterday on the courts of the University Club. All six seeded players advanced as anticipated.

LONDON, Dec. 27 -- In bitterly cold weather, thousands of British parents and children hurried off from home today to see the pantomimes -- fairy tales embellished with songs, dances, jokes and vaudeville routines -- that traditionally are presented in hundreds of theatres during the Christmas season.

Though the 1948-49 pack of commerciallycanned fruits is somewhat smaller than that of 1947-48, consumption is expected to remain at a record rate. The carryover from last season to this one was large enough to augment current supplies considerably.

Resolutions calling upon educational accrediting agencies to lighten the "large student work load" as well as duties of teachers outside the classroom were adopted unanimously yesterday by the College English Association.

John B. Woodward Jr., president of the Newport News Shipbuilding and Dry Dock Company, will assume the national presidency of the Society of Naval Architects and Marine Engineers on Saturday as the organization enters its fiftyseventh year of activity.

One lodger was burned to death and a dozen others, several of them elderly, were rescued with ladders last night as flames raced through a men's rooming house on the second, third and fourth floors of a four-story building on the northwest corner of East Tenth Street and First Avenue.

By-product coke operations achieve a new record this year, with some 97,000,000 tons of coking coal being consumed in steelmaking and merchant coke plants. This is exclusive of the 10,000,000 tons used in beehive ovens for producing coke without regard to tars, gases and vapors recovered for synthetic chemicals.

ALBANY, Dec. 27 -- Governor Dewey, following an eight-hour conference on state finances with Republican legislative leaders, tonight listed a series of new projects that would increase next year's budget by a net of $208,000,000 as either urgently needed, highly desirable or worthy of very serious consideration.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 -- The Economic Cooperation Administration announced a contract today with Time, Inc., guaranteeing convertibility into dollars of earnings on its sale of the Atlantic Overseas edition of Time and the international edition of Life in Bizone Germany and the British-American sector of Berlin.

Back in Manhattan for a farewell visit, the Freedom Train attracted large crowds in Grand Central Terminal yesterday after an official opening ceremony on the platform of Track 30. The streamlined diesel-electric train containing exhibits of 127 major historical documents will be open to the public each day until 11 P.M. through Jan. 1.

Baltimore, Md., Housing Authority will receive bids on Jan. 5 on $13,105,000 of temporary loan notes dated Feb. 1, 1949, and due on Aug. 12, 1949. On the same day, New York City Housing Authority will offer an issue of $2,286,000 in temporary loan notes dated Feb. 1, 1949 and due on Sept. 16, 1949.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 (AP) -Albert Glen (Turk) Edwards today stepped out as coach of the Washington football Redskins and moved into the newly created job of Redskin executive vice president.

Henri Bonnet, French Ambassador to the United States, declared yesterday that his nation would lead in the movement toward a unified Western Europe and would do all in its power to cooperate with this country.

THE HAGUE, The Netherlands, Dec. 28 -- The problem of what to do with the captured leaders of the Indonesian Republic continues to baffle the Dutch authorities here, although their capture was one of the primary tactical objectives of the military assault.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 -- The House Committee on Rules, long under attack for blocking Administration measures from debate and voting decisions, was a focal point for strategy planning today as Democrats started arriving in the capital to take over control of Congress next week.
The Board of Estimate voted yesterday to increase the city's payment to hospitals treating tuberculosis patients from $5 to $7.50 a day. The annual cost of the increase is $163,000.

Mayor O'Dwyer said yesterday that he would fight "with everything I have" any move to abolish the 5 per cent municipal and county tax on horse-race betting that has been in effect in this state for the past three years. A recommendation that the tax be canceled was made in the State Racing Commission's annual report, released yesterday.

INDIANAPOLIS, Dec. 28 (AP) -Indiana drove from behind twice in the second half and guarded a narrow lead as time ran out to beat Notre Dame, 50 -- 47, tonight. The result gave each team an even break in the two-day Hoosier basketball classic, Indiana having lost to Butler and Notre Dame having shaded Purdue last night.
New York's five borough presidents were initiated as "fall guys" yesterday at the monthly luncheon of the Circus Saints and Sinners at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Dec. 28 -- Premier Tito's decisive speech yesterday to Parliament marked the turning point in the evolution of the struggle between the Yugoslavs and the Communist Information Bureau.
AKRON, Ohio, Dec. 28 -- The second best year in its history was realized in 1948 by the Firestone Tire and Rubber Company, according to the company's annual financial statement, announced today.
After appearances in two courts, charges of assault against a policeman and a bartender in connection with a disturbance in a Greenwich Village tavern were dismissed yesterday.
A record school budget of $217,247,000 has been recommended for the next fiscal year by Dr. William Jansen, Superintendent of Schools, it became known yesterday.
PARIS, Dec. 28 -- The counterpart fund set up under the Marshall Plan was used for the first time today to check inflation by a reduction of the debt of the French Government to the Bank of France.

Christmas trees were still fresh yesterday, but many gifts that were piled beneath their branches a few days ago had become so stale they were back in the stores. Well under way was the annual pilgrimage to rectify those excesses of sentiment over wisdom.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 -- President Truman's off-hand statement to a Kansas City luncheon of business men yesterday that "certain Russian leaders are exceedingly anxious to have an understanding with us" produced natural, prompt and violent repercussions.

More than 3,000,000 Persons have venerated a replica of the statute of Our Lady of Fatima, "the Pilgrim Virgin," since it arrived in October, 1947, from Portugal for a tour of the United States and Canada in a crusade for prayers for the conversion of Russia, Msgr. William C. McGrath of the Roman Catholic Scarboro Foreign Mission Society said here yesterday.

Mark Ferree has been appointed general business manager of the Scripps-Howard Newspapers, effective Sunday, it was announced yesterday by Roy W. Howard, president of the organization, Mr. Ferree, who has been with ScrippsHoward for sixteen years, succeeds Ray A. Huber, who will continue in general management of the newspaper enterprises as a member of the executive committee.

Visiting buyers registered in the market for the week ended yesterday totaled 377, against 390 last week and 180 in the similar week a year ago, according to the lists published in THE NEW YORK TIMES. There were 256 arrivals yesterday, compared with ninety-four last Tuesday.

One of golf's oldest tournaments, the metropolitan open championship which was discarded in the pre-war days, will be back on the schedule again next summer, according to the plans of the Metropolitan Golf Association.

Textured effects, tone-on-tone colorings and simplified designs rather than fussy naturalistic patterns will be offered in all price ranges of new carpeting next year. These highlights of new rug trends were outlined yesterday by Joseph O'Brien, style and design manager of the Bigelow-Sanford Carpet Company, in an interview at the Showroom, 140 Madison Avenue.
Negotiations related to the private placement of three issues of securities totaling $16,750,000 in behalf of newsprint, department store and bakery establishments, were announced yesterday.

A new book by Owen Lattimore, author of "Solution in Asia," has been scheduled for April 15 publication by Little, Brown in association with the Atlantic Monthly Press. The book will be titled "The Situation in Asia" and it is described as "a discussion of the revolutionary upheavals in Eastern Asia."

ATHENS, Dec. 28 -- The frosty winds blowing southward from the Sovietized Balkans over the snowcovered mountains of Greece are geographically significant of the sources of this country's misery as the fourth year since its liberation draws to a close.

Jacob Freidus has sold two more vacant parcels of land in the Bronx, in the area west of Grand Concourse between 149th Street and the Yankee Stadium. DwightHelmsley, Inc., was the broker. The plots comprise part of the six square blocks acquired by Mr. Freidus in 1945 from Vincent Astor.
E. C. Leeson has been appointed assistant director of the sales division of the Ranger aircaft engines division of the Fairchild Engine and Airplane Corporation.

In an effort to promote both international security and general economic recovery, the Western Powers have now reached complete agreement on the creation of an International Authority for the Ruhr, designed to convert this Pandora's box that has loosed so much evil on the world into an instrument for peace and prosperity.

William J. McCormack, chairman of the Mayor's special committee attempting to bring about a settlement of the dispute between tug workers and operators, continued optimistic last night after the adjournment of a long meeting with both sides.

BOSTON, Dec. 28 -- John DeFerrari, the 85-year-old former fruit peddler who last year gave $1,000,000 to the Boston Public Library to start a trust fund, dug deep again yesterday and gave $500,000 more to the library.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 28 -- Dedication ceremonies for the new $100,000 main building of the University of Judaism, West Coast branch of the Jewish Theological Seminary of America in New York, were held tonight at a dinner in a hotel.

A M Karagheusian, Inc., and Magee Carpet Company yesterday announced price increases averaging 3 per cent on their carpet lines. Both organizations emphasized that the 3 per cent increase does not offset higher costs of raw materials, particularly carpet wools.

Reporting on operations of the Joy Manufacturing Company in the fiscal year ended with last September, J. D. A. Morros, president, informed shareholders yesterday that sales rose to $62,653,038 from the previous year's volume of $51,325,094.

PARIS, Dec. 28 -- The United Nations Security Council today called on the Netherlands to release Dr. Sukarno, President of the Republic of Indonesia, and other political prisoners immediately, and to inform the Council that this had been done within twenty-four hours.

Looking something like Mickey Walker in build, with the facial appearance of a fighter and exuding confidence, Robert Villemain, French middleweight, arrived here yesterday for a campaign he expects will lead to the world championship.

LONDON, Dec. 28 -- Poland has made efforts in the last twentyfour hours to jolt the British Government into some action on the long-standing complaints by the Poles that the Germans are actively agitating to get back territory they lost to Poland in what used to be Eastern Germany.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 -- Liquid savings of individuals in the third quarter of 1948 were estimated at $3,100,000,000, an increase of $2,500,000,000 over the total for the second quarter, the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today.

ARCADIA, Calif., Dec. 28 (AP) -Duplicator, 2-year-old son of Beau Pere, won the $50,000 added California Breeders Championship Stakes today as Santa Anita Park opened for its twelfth winter meeting before an estimated 35,000 fans.

Dr. Lloyd H. Gaston has been appointed director of St. Luke's Hospital, 421 West 113th Street, Lincoln Cromwell, president of the hospital, announced yesterday. The appointment, made by the board of managers, will become effective Saturday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 -- The Hudson and Manhattan Railroad Company asked the Interstate Commerce Commission today for authority to increase its present 10-cent interstate fare to 15 cents "as part of an integrated program" for increasing all of its fares.

JOHANNESBURG, Dec. 28 (Reuters) -- A determined and so far unbroken third-wicket stand between two of South Africa's finest test cricketers, Dudley Nourse and Bruce Mitchell, prevented England from forcing home its advantage today in the second test match.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Dec. 28 -- Despite the news blackout here, United Nations observers reported today that the provisional ArabPalestine capital of Gaza in the coastal strip had been bombed and strafed three times by Israeli planes and that the Egyptians had complained of other attacks on Faluja and positions in the Negeb.

An increase in commitment of $54,200 for the financing of the Glen Oaks Village development in Bellerose, Queens, which brings the total to $54,695,000, of loans placed, was announced yesterday. J. Halperin Co., arranged the financing, the largest under the Federal Housing Administration program.

Italo Tajo, one of the important newcomers of the season, made his first appearance at the Metropolitan Opera last night in the seasons first performance of "The Barber of Seville" In the role of Don Basilio, the Italian basso could not display the full range of his talents as singer and actor, but he did enough to establish that he is an experienced, satisfying, professional artist.

A reciprocal agreement signed last summer between the two leading ship classification societies of this country and Great Britain has been canceled, it was announced here yesterday by the American Bureau of Shipping.

The Board of Estimate has done the sensible and just thing in raising to $7.50 the daily rate paid by New York City to voluntary hospitals for care of the indigent tuberculous patient. The $5 rate was entirely inconsistent with cost of the care under today's conditions.

TOKYO, Dec. 28 -- Allied headquarters will impose strict supervision not only over the Japanese general election on Jan. 23, but also over the preliminary electoral campaign, it was announced today. Allied observers are already being sent out to listen to the candidates' opening speeches and check on their campaign activities.
MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 28 -- A charter plane with two babies among the thirty persons on board disappeared without a trace today on a flight from San Juan, P.R., to Miami.

We hear often in the press about the fight of various peoples against communism, but we know little of liberation movements of the oppressed peoples inside the U.S.S.R. The other day THE NEW YORK TIMES printed an interview with the underground worker in the Soviet Ukraine, Mrs. Rebet, whose revelations about widely spread and well organized guerrilla action against Soviet rule and for Independent Democratic Ukraine were to most Americans quite new.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 -- The Army announced today that it was pulling the Seventh Infantry Division out of South Korea in accord with the agreement by the United States and the Soviet Union to withdraw their troops from all of Korea "as early as practicable."

The Schenley Distillers Corporation showed net earnings of $10,877,832 in the three months ended on Nov. 30, equal to $3.02 a share on the 3,600,000 common shares outstanding, it was announced yesterday following a meeting of directors.

CHICAGO, Dec. 28 -- The Tucker Corporation, which started in the automobile - manufacturing business two years ago with more than $20,000,000, now has only $200,000 cash on hand, Preston Tucker, president, disclosed today at a press conference.

PARIS, Dec, 28 -- The agreement on the Ruhr made public today signifies to the French chiefly that the United States has at last recognized the importance of security as well as of German economic recovery.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 28 (AP) -- Bruce Livie, Baltimore master of the Bobanet Stable, arrived at Tropical Park today in time to see his Tenabob capture the Felicitation Purse for that colt's third triumph in as many starts at the meeting.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec.28 -Samuel Goldwyn has acquired an option from Walter Wanger to purchase "Commencement," a screen story by Lionel Wiggam, which Wanger owns, as a prospective vehicle for Joan Evans and Farley Granger it was learned today.
Members of the Boys Club of New York collected and contributed $20.34 yesterday to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 -- Four national organizations gathered at the Hotel Statler today to discuss aspects of the American theatre in a three-day joint convention. They included the Speech Association of America, American Speech and Hearing Association, National University Extension Association's committee on debate materials and interstate cooperation, and the American Educational Theatre Association.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 -- The twelve Air Force men who had been stranded over Christmas on a Greenland icecap were rescued today by a two-engined transport plane equipped with skis and jetassisted take-off units.
A capacity audience watched stars of the theatre perform last night at the sixty-seventh annual benefit of the Actors' Fund of America at the Hotel Astor.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 -- President Truman sent a message of sympathy today to King Farouk of Egypt on the assassination of Prime Minister Mahmoud Fahmy Nokrashy Pasha.

RYE, N.Y., Dec. 28 -- Dartmouth's hockey team opened its season tonight with a 7-to-3 victory over New York's St. Nicholas Hockey Club before 2,000 fans at Playland Ice Casino. The Indians were never in danger, taking a 3-1 lead in the first period.
With only three leaves left to turn on the 1948 calendar, nearly every New Yorker who was not exchanging Christmas presents in the stores yesterday seemed to be at a party or planning one.

Beating the midnight deadline by only a few hours, six war brides landed at La Guardia Field at 8 o'clock last night aboard an American Overseas Airline plane. Earlier in the day a group of thirty-one German fiancees and ten children arrived at Idlewild airport.

Robert P. Patterson, former Secretary of War and now president of the Association of the Bar of the City of New York, has declined an appointment to the Court of Appeals offered to him by Governor Dewey, it was learned yesterday.
Cardinal Spellman yesterday termed the arrest of Cardinal Mindszenty as the "first grim step in another totalitarian mock-trial, another sacrilegious travesty on justice."

Time-limit pressure affected play in the fifth round of the international masters tourney at Manhattan Chess Club last night. One of the four games to be finished was won by George Kramer of Forest Hills when Isaac I. Kashdan, with only 37 moves on his scoresheet and his two hours up, overstepped the time limit and forfeited the match.

PASADENA, Calif., Dec. 22 (AP) -- The sun popped out at full strength today, matching in warmth the spirit of the two Rose Bowl football teams, invading Northwestern and host California. The Wildcats from Evanston, Ill., drilled in peppery fashion at Brookside Park and the same was true of the Golden Bears at nearby Riverside.

This is the time of the year that they fought the battle in the Ardennes that came to be called the Battle of the Bulge. The American divisions were spread thinly along the Eighth Corps front in Belgium and Luxembourg.

The New York Film Critics announced yesterday the selection of the Warner Brothers production "Treasure of Sierra Madre" as the best picture released in 1948 and named the picture's director, John Huston, as the man of the year among directors.
MINNEAPOLIS, Dec. 28 (AP) -The University of Minnesota hockey team opened its home schedule tonight by routing Yale, 10 -- 1, before 2,035 fans.

The Republic of Indonesia has again asked the United States to suspend Economic Cooperation Administration aid to the Netherlands until that Government, "having committed an act of aggression, is brought to order."

ALBANY, Dec. 28 -- Proposals of the Board of Regents to increase state aid for schools $41,000,000 above the amount required by existing law face an uphill fight at the approaching legislative session due to a reluctance to impose the additional taxes they would entail.

Elliott Roosevelt and his actress wife, Faye Emerson, said yesterday the cut in her wrist which put her in a Poughkeepsie hospital for thirty hours was caused by accidental contact with a razor blade.

The future American merchant marine probably will level of at about 11,000,000 deadweight tons, but the anticipated post-war pattern will be different, with more tanker bottoms than dry cargo ships, according to the December survey of the Association of American Ship Owners.
KARACHI, Pakistan, Dec. 28 -- India and Pakistan were reported today by sources close to Moslem leaders to have reached a complete agreement to end the Kashmir dispute.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 (AP) -Seven Norwegian labor officials, all wartime anti-Nazi underground leaders, are to start tomorrow a three-week study of American industrial production methods.

A letter from Thomas G. Greaves published by you on Dec. 17, while questioning the wisdom of eradicating segregation in Washington by federal "edict," suggests that such an edict would "violate the rights of local government by consent of the governed" and that there is "no reason to think that the past government of the city has been unresponsive to the will of the local people.

Favorites in the Eastern junior and boys' indoor tennis championships continued to advance yesterday on the courts of the Fifteenth Regiment Armory. Top-seeded William Long of Jackson Heights maintained his winning pace by defeating Edward Levinson, Sunnyside, 6 -- 2, 6 -- 0.

MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 28 (AP) -- The University of Miami defeated Princeton, 37 -- 35, in the feature game of a basketball doubleheader tonight. Pittsburgh halted the University of Florida, 50 -- 40, in the opener of the Orange Bowl week twin bill.

In a hands-across-the-seas-gesture of support for the principle of journalistic freedom, the New York Film Critics expressed themselves yesterday "in accord" with the Critics Circle of London in the case of E. Arnot Robertson. The London critics group is backing Miss Robertson, former film reviewer for the British Broadcasting Company, in her attempt to carry her suit against Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer to the highest court in Britain, the House of Lords.
Creation of furniture to fit the needs of children -- especially youngsters in small city apartments -- is one of the aims of the designers, Robert Limpus and Roger McGunigle.

William P. Murphy, an old friend of Mayor O'Dwyer, was named yesterday as the chief in charge of the Bureau of Fire Investigation by Fire Commissioner Frank J. Quayle. This is the position from which Thomas P. Brophy will retire as chief fire marshal on Friday.

Perhaps there never was any doubt about the ultimate rescue of the seven men who crashed on Dec. 9 in a C-47 on the Greenland icecap, 7,800 feet above sea level, and who were later joined against their will by five others who had come to grief in rescue attempts with a B-17 and with gliders.
MARBURG, Germany, Dec. 28 -- Mrs. Wilma Ybarbo of Malden, Mass., was convicted and sentenced to twenty years in prison today for killing her soldier husband.

YONKERS, N.Y., Dec. 27 -Twelve persons, nine of them firemen, were slightly injured late this afternoon in a three-alarm fire that severely damaged stores and the eighteen apartments in the four-story brick-frame building at Park and Ashburton Avenues, opposite Yonkers General Hospital.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 -- Commercial aviation is ending 1948 with an improved safety record indicated by fatalities considerably less than half those in 1947, based on passenger-miles flown, the Civil Aeronautics Administration reported today.

The city's fuel supply, already menaced by the towboat wage dispute, was further threatened last night by the possibility of a strike at midnight Friday by 2,500 drivers of coal and oil trucks in Manhattan, Brooklyn, the Bronx and Queens.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 -- The Council of the Organization of American States set up a five-man commission of military experts today to effect compliance by the Governments of Nicaragua and Costa Rica with its request that they end their border dispute.

VIENNA, Dec. 28 -- The arrest of Joseph Cardinal Mindszenty by the Hungarian Government has been accepted in both Catholic and Communist circles here as communism's answer to the Christmas message of Pope Pius condemning totalitarianism and praising the courage with, which Catholics of Eastern Europe were resisting it.

Henry Morgenthau Jr., former Secretary of the Treasury, has been elected chairman of the board of directors of the Modern Industrial Bank, it was announced yesterday. Robert P. Patterson, former Secretary of War, and president of the Association of the Bar of the City of New York, has been named a director.
Commercial flights both ways between the New York metropolitan area and Puerto Rico have been marred a number of times by crashes involving fatalities and other mishaps.

The Improved Benevolent and Protective Order of Elks of the World, Inc., a Negro organization with headquarters in Washington, D.C., has purchased for investment the Monterey Apartments, a sevenstory building housing thirtysix families at 351 West 114th Street, from J. Finley Wilson.

CLEVELAND, Dec. 28 -- An immediate problem in the management of the $252,000,000,000 Federal debt is the unbalanced term structure of our existing marketable obligations, Winthrop W. Aldrich declared here today.

With business generally good, 1949 will see growing competition and the return of a buyers' market, according to a survey of ninety-nine companies representing a cross-section of nine leading industries, released yesterday by the Commerce and Industry Association of New York, Inc.

WESTOVER, Mass., Dec. 28 (AP) -- A young Air Force pilot who was the hero in a "top-of-theworld" rescue of nine persons a year ago from a Labrador wilderness was the central figure in a dramatic air feat again today in the Greenland rescue.

Sudden embargo by Brazil of flour shipments to that country evoked protests yesterday to the State Department, urging particularly that the action be eased to cover shipments in transit and future shipments ordered prior to Dec. 28.

Veterans Day, a part of the Freedom Week program arranged in connection with the visit here of the Freedom Train, was observed yesterday by veterans' organizations of New York in a ceremony alongside the train at track 30 in Grand Central Terminal.

Although love is generally reputed to be an interesting topic, you would never suspect it from Sacha Guitry's "Don't Listen, Ladies," which was exposed to the public at the Booth last evening. Since M. Guitry is fast maturing now, it is probably not astonishing that he has nothing vital to contribute to a subject that other Frenchmen have paid attention to in the past.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Dec. 28 (AP) -- The National Amateur Athletic Union bobsled committee announced today that it had approved the entry of German teams in the National and North American championships at Lake Placid.

ATHENS, Dec. 28 -- Greece is full of outside observers official and unofficial. They are much in evidence, occupy far more than their share of space in an overcrowded capital, and spend a lot of time each according to his special interest shaking their heads over the military, political or economic situation.

Three civil anti-trust suits for more than $5,000,000 in damages were filed in Federal Court yesterday by Joseph Sachs, a Bronx wholesale liquor dealer, who alleged that a number of distillers had charged him considerably more than the current rate on his purchases of whisky.

BROOKLINE, Mass., Dec. 28 (AP) -- Fifteen-year-old Miss Laura Lou Jahn of Hollywood, Calif., the defending champion, led the field into the semi-final round of the 1949 National Girls' Indoor Singles tennis championship by defeating Miss Harriet Shannon of Malden in two love sets today at Longwood.

Those who wish to serve ham for New Year's dinner will have no trouble finding it in stores today. The United States Department of Agriculture reports that this meat is in more than adequate supply. Retail shops, however, are charging the same prices for it they have for the last two weeks, according to the City Department of Market's survey.

An unexpected avalanche of selling to establish tax losses caused the widest break in a month on the stock market yesterday. Prices fell an average of a point although there were much wider set-backs in some high-price issues. In effect, the rise in values of the last week were eliminated.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 -- The Labor Department has drafted a proposed amendment to the Wage and Hour Law to meet the problem raised by the Supreme Court's so-called overtime-on-overtime decision.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 -- The Air Force and Navy today refused to hazard a guess at the cost of their Greenland rescue missions.

The regional office of the National Labor Relations Board conceded yesterday that it could not unscramble the jurisdictional claims of rival unions at two major New York department stores through the holding of further conferences on an informal basis.

Serafino Romualdi, Latin-American representative of the American Federation of Labor, charged last night that the military dictators of that part of the world were out to destroy "any free labor movement in Latin America."

PORTLAND, Me., Dec. 28 (AP) -Federal Judge John D. Clifford Jr. said today that men who practiced "civil disobedience" by refusing to register for the draft should protest to Congress rather than the courts. He then sentenced Gerald Williams, 22 years old, of Vinalhaven, and Paul D. Cates, 23, of East Vassalboro, to prison for two years each.

PARIS, Dec. 28 -- Experts assigned by the United Nations Security Council to study the Berlin question have not been able to reach a decision and will have to resume their work on Geneva the first week in January, it was learned here today.
PARIS, Dec. 28 -- Henri Queuille will soon resign as Minister of Finance to devote himself entirely to the task of Premier, it was learned tonight on good authority.

Climaxing fifteen years of research and experience with investment programs, Distributors Group, Inc., sponsor of Group Securities, Inc., a mutual investment company, has developed a personal investment program for the twenty-two types of securities in which it invests individuals' funds.

Preparations for renewed action to legalize the sale of wine in retail grocery stores were made yesterday at a meeting in the Pennsylvania Hotel of the New York State Food Merchants Association. The group represents 5,000 independent grocers of the state.

After analyzing traffic figures for the IND subway extension opened in Brooklyn a month ago, William Reid, chairman of the Board of Transportation, said yesterday that the figures emphasized anew the city's need for a Second Avenue subway in Manhattan.

Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt told an audience of 2,800 at Carnegie Hall last night that she regretted that the Security Council had not admitted Israel into the United Nations. She spoke after the intermission of a concert for which the Junior Division of the United Jewish Appeal was sponsor.

Inveterate angels, the husband and wife team of Sherman and Marjorie Ewing have done exceedingly well with their investments in some forty shows. The most conspicuous one of the lot was "Oklahoma!" Several years ago Mrs. Ewing branched out unsuccessfully as co-sponsor of "Hickory Stick" with Marie Louise Elkins.
Juniors home from college and school had a chance to see an early showing of holiday and spring fashions in the Younger Set Shop of Saks - Thirty-fourth yesterday afternoon.

It is a rare pleasure to attend a song recital which has an original program, and a singer of such sincerity and intelligence, and prevailing skill in its interpretation as Doda Conrad, bass, offered last night in Town Hall. There was not a routine song on the list.
With a moderate volume of business, the cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange closed 14 to 24 points net lower yesterday. The distant months were relatively easier than the nears.

An American freighter, purchased by Iceland under a $2,300,000 loan from the Economic Coperation Administration, has been converted into a floating fish factory by that country, the ECA announced yesterday.

GENEVA, Dec. 28 -- The production of coal increased steadily but the movement of coal in Western European trade declined during November, according to the latest figures released today by the coal division of the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe.

In your editorial, "New Housing Policy," you state that "some houses go begging because of poor planning or undesirable sites," and that "many buyers are holding off for more reasonable prices." Let me present a builder's viewpoint. I have just completed several two-family homes on which I invite with confidence the criticism of an expert as to planning, construction and price.

TRENTON, N.J., Dec. 28 -- Police officials, magistrates, and directors of public safety in New Jersey municipalities reluctantly made plans today to start on Saturday a new state-wide system of "non-fix" traffic violation summonses.

BERLIN, Dec, 28 -- Announcement of a plan to establish an International Ruhr Control Authority today caused sharp and bitter reaction among all German political leaders from the Communists to the Christian Democrats.

Never in contention, the St. John's basketball team dropped its second decision of the campaign last night at Madison Square Garden, bowing to the all-round superiority of Utah. Although only nine points separated the quintets at the completion of a 66-57 count, the Brooklyn Redmen actually were not that close to the visiting Utes.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 (UP) -Pope Pius XII has created a new Roman Catholic diocese in Joliet, Ill., and has named three new American Bishops, it was announced here tonight.

After Yeshiva had played Pennsylvania to a 2-2 tie in the third round and had been blanked by Syracuse, 4 -- 0, in the fourth, Syracuse, with a score of 12 1/2 -- 3 1/2, was at the head of fifteen teams competing for the championship of the Intercollegiate Chess League at John Jay Hall, Columbia University, yesterday.
Dr. Edward M. Bernecker resigned yesterday, as city Commissioner of Hospitals to become administrator of hospital services for New York University-Bellevue Medical Center.

HEARTWELLVILLE, Vt., Dec. 28 -- Skiing enthusiasts who have been extolling the merits of the lavish Dutch Hill development carved out of Heartwellville mountain since its inception two years ago, have had reason to do so, for in this 425-acre playland that starts 1,900 feet above sea level and has a network of open and wooded trails radiating from the 2,470-foot mountain summit, there are ample facilities for the neophyte and the expert.
MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 28 (AP) -- Coach Wally Butts today named Georgia's starting line-ups for the Orange Bowl football game with Texas on Saturday.

I have known the Duggan family for a long time, and Dr. Stephen Duggan and I have been intimately associated in public work for the past twelve years. I knew Laurence Duggan slightly, but I know his background well. I can hardly think of any family I have ever known in my three-quarters of a century of experience to whom any thought of an unpatriotic or selfish action could have been attributed with less justification.

MANILA, Dec. 28 -- President Elpidio Quirino signed today the controversial import control executive order imposing 20 to 90 per cent volume cuts in imports of luxury and semi-luxury goods, using the fiscal year July 1, 1947, to June 30, 1948, as the base.

LONDON, Dec. 28 -- Winston Churchill left London for the south of France today to put in another intensive, uninterrupted spell of work on his war memoirs. He was accompanied by Mrs. Churchill and his daughter, Mrs. Sarah Oliver.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 -- Problems that the Atomic Age has precipitated on teaching of science were discussed here today by members of the Science Teaching Societies of the American Association for the Advancement of Science.
HARTFORD, Conn., Dec. 28 (AP) -- News of the rescue today of twelve men stranded on a Greenland icecap was received with thanksgiving by a dozen residents of the Hartford area.
SEOUL, Korea, Dec. 28 -- The reported appearance of units of the Seventh Infantry Division in Japan focuses attention on current troop movements.
TRENTON, N.J., Dec. 28 -- Milk price cqntrol in New Jersey, aside from producers' wholesale prices, was ordered suspended by Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll today. His directive is effective next Saturday.

ALBANY, Dec. 28 -- Asserting that the Republican state administration has indicated that it now will support many legislative measures which have been advocated by the Democratic minority in the past, Paul E. Fitzpatrick, chairman of the Democratic State Committee, has suggested to Gov. Thomas E. Dewey that a bi-partisan conference be called to discuss "these mutually agreeable matters."
BUDAPEST, Hungary, Dec. 28 (UP) -- Following is the text of the Hungarian Government communique on the arrest of Joseph Cardinal Mindszenty:

LONDON, Dec. 28 -- The United States, Britain, France, Belgium, the Netherlands and Luxembourg jointly announced today a tentative agreement to establish an international authority to supervise the industries of the Ruhr for an indefinite period and to insure that the Ruhr's resources are used solely for peaceful purposes.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 (AP) -Tougher anti-trust enforcement, with executives temporarily excluded from business for law violations, was recommended today by a Congressional committee.

GENEVA, Dec. 28 -- Ten international religious and relief organizations joined today in a special New Year appeal to the nations of the world to do something about the large and growing mass of homeless refugees.

SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico, Dec. 28 (AP) -- The following is the official passenger list for the chartered plane which disappeared today with thirty persons aboard on a flight from San Juan to Miami, Fla. Destinations of the passengers were listed as follows:

Bids will be received Jan. 11 on bond issues totaling $21,500,000 for Los Angeles, Calif., school districts, it was announced yesterday. For Los Angeles City School District, the borrowing will total $6,500,000; and for Los Angeles High School District, $15,000,000.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 28 (AP) -Rain came to this city today and the weather man said it might last all week, but the drizzle which fell at intervals had not spread by late afternoon to the training camps of the two football squads that will meet in the Sugar Bowl on Saturday.
CLEVELAND, Dec. 28 (AP) -- Bob Feller, baseball's No. 1 money man, thinks his pay envelope may be slightly thinner next season. And his boss, President Bill Veeck of the Indians, agrees.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 -- The Hoover Commission on Organization of the Executive Branch of the Government will ask for and get a sixty-day extension of the Jan. 13 deadline for submission of its final report, it was learned today.

Miss Eleanor Judd, 38-year-old former professional pianist, listened attentively yesterday to the children who were thanking her for her donations of blood. Her clear blue eyes turned toward the small boys and girls who are leading normal lives again because they can have regular transfusions.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, Dec. 28 -- The Interior Ministry announced today that it had uncovered documents that it said proved Joseph Cardinal Mindszenty had acted as a spy. The announcement said the documents had been found in a metal box in the basement of the Cardinal's home.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 -- In what was regarded as a major step toward actual unification of the armed forces, the National Military Establishment moved today to set up a permanent board to improve and coordinate personnel policies of the three services.
TOKYO, Wednesday, Dec. 29 (AP) -- Nine Japanese officers, including three generals, were sentenced today to be hanged for beheading thirty-three B-29 fliers.

DUBLIN, Dec. 28 -- The Government of Eire has informed the Hungarian Government of its "grave anxiety" over the arrest of Cardinal Mindszenty and has requested permission for its representative to visit the Cardinal.

ON THE SAIPAN, en route to Norfolk, Va., Dec. 28 -- Nineteen hours away from the Greenland shore, whither she was bound to rescue stranded airmen, this Navy aircraft carrier today turned around for the return trip to Norfolk at 12:45 P.M., E.S.T., upon receiving official word that the fliers had been saved.

After early advances in coffee futures which established new highs for the near-by delivery positions, scattered long liquidation and profit-taking eased the market 11 to 14 points on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange yesterday.
MOSCOW, Dec. 28 -- Sergei Prokofieff, who was among seven Soviet composers censured by the Communist party Central Committee last winter, is under critical fire again.

If television is in its infancy, education in television must be described as hardly out of the delivery room. Nevertheless, the first, hesitant steps toward solid programming are already being taken and we may be on the threshold of a new advance in educational techniques which will sometime be regarded as the beginning of an era.

CHANUTE FIELD, Ill., Dec. 28 (AP) -- The C-47 which rescued the twelve airmen stranded in Greenland was the same plane that made a jet-assisted take-off from a small field near Greenup, Ill., Dec. 8, the Chanute Air Force Base said today.
CHICAGO, Dec. 28 -- Ships driven by atomic power, the Navy's dream since the new form of energy was discovered, moved closer to reality today.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 (AP) -- Following is the text of the draft agreement establishing an International Authority for the Ruhr:

Food production in 1949 will be equal to that of this year and prices will be lower, John A. Hartford, president of the Great Atlantic Pacific Tea Company, predicted yesterday. He warned, however, that competition will be keener.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 -- The State Department has usually managed to restrain its enthusiasm for what it regards as the paradeground diplomacy of Gen. Lucius D. Clay, but today the environs of foggy bottom were rippling with left-handed bravissimos for the American Commander in Germany.

Willi Slykhuis of the Netherlands, who finished third in both the 1,500 and 5,000-meter runs at the Olympic Games, will tour the American indoor track circuit this winter, it was announced yesterday by Daniel J. Ferris, secretarytreasurer of the National A.A.U.

The New Yorkers Knickerbockers and the Rochester Royals will clash in a Basketball Association of America contest at Madison Square Garden tonight. Gimbel's and Metropolitan Life meet in the 7:30 preliminary, a Knickerbocker Industrial League engagement.

A plot of land comprising an entire city block in College Point, Queens, bounded by Twenty-second and Twenty-third Avenues and 129th and 130th Streets, has been purchased by Philip H. Grove, builder, from Henry L. Hoffmann. The parcel contains 106,200 square feet.

CHICAGO, Dec. 28. -- Removal of hedges against sales of cash wheat and corn gave the May deliveries of the two grains independent strength, but the markets closed irregular on the Board of Trade today with wheat up 7/8 cent to 3/4 cent down, the former on May.
WALTHAM, Mass., Dec. 28 -The ninety-nine-year-old Waltham Watch Company, a pioneer in its field, announced today the lay-off of most of its 2,300 employes.

A group occupying apartments in the twelve-story and penthouse building at 950 Park Avenue, southwest corner of Eighty-second Street, has purchased the property from the City Bank Farmers Trust Company, as trustee, for organizing into a cooperative.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Dec. 28 -With President Truman still declining an explanation, his statement yesterday that certain Russian leaders were eager for an understanding with this country was appraised today by informed observers as a psychological shot in the cold war.

Alice Hartman says her best friend is her dog Jock. But the 175 children at the Israel Orphan Asylum call Alice their best friend and would gladly join the rest of the younger set of the surrounding Bayswater community in electing the teen-age "tomboy" with the soul of a saint at least mayor of Far Rockaway.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 28 -Laurence F. Whittemore, president of the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad, said here tonight that the road would have earned $5,000,000 to $6,000,000 in 1948, but that this profit would be insufficient to fulfill its program.

PARIS, Dec. 28 (UP) -- Britain urged the Security Council today to order a cease-fire and immediate withdrawal in Palestine's Negeb, scene of ground and air battles between Israeli and Egyptian forces since Dec. 22.

CONNIE MACK wasn't the only sportsman to have a birthday last week even though his was the only one over which folks made a fuss. Walter Hagen also had a birthday, his fifty-sixth, and it's about time that a low obeisance was made in the direction of the Haig, one of sport's immortals and true Olympians. Ah, there was a man!

Charles W. Oliver of Army reached the final round of the annual intercollegiate invitation squash racquets tournament after completing two strenuous matches on the courts of the University Club yesterday.

ROME, Dec. 28 -- The Vatican withheld official comment today on Cardinal Mindszenty's arrest because any pronouncement would be based only on information received from authorized sources, Vatican officials said.

The American premiere of Bela Bartok's one-act opera, "Duke Bluebeard's Castle," will be performed by the Dallas Symphony Orchestra, under the direction of its regular conductor, Antal Dorati, on NBC's "Orchestras of the Nation," Saturday, Jan. 8, at 3 P.M.
DUBLIN, Dec. 28 -- The part that Eire proposes to play in the European Recovery Program was set out in a White Paper released here tonight giving details of the four-year plan for 1949-1953.
NASHVILLE, Tenn., Dec. 28 -- Reports that Senator K. D. McKellar punched Silliman Evans, publisher of The Nashville Tennessean, recently were confirmed today by the participants.

Retailers of Infants' and juvenile apparel will continue their policy of shorter term buying in the spring of 1949, it was learned yesterday at the opening of the spring showing of the Metropolitan Juvenile Style Mart in the New Yorker Hotel.
A survey to lay the groundwork for a thorough revision of city civil service classifications and pay schedules was ordered yesterday by Mayor O'Dwyer.

"The Eagle With Two Heads" ("L'Aigle a Deux Tetes"), a French-made period romantic drama, adapted and directed by Jean Cocteau from his play of the same name, will have its local premiere today at the Little Met. Edwige Feuillere and Jean Marais are starred in the offering which features Sylvia Monfort, Jean Debucourt and Jacques Varennes.

We believe the people of New York State are prepared to accept the necessity of a state budget considerably higher than the current year's, and it has been apparent for several weeks that Governor Dewey is moving in that direction. He has listed a series of new projects that have come up in his budget studies.

Retailers of Infants' and juvenile apparel will continue their policy of shorter term buying in the spring of 1949, it was learned yesterday at the opening of the spring showing of the Metropolitan Juvenile Style Mart in the New Yorker Hotel.
A survey to lay the groundwork for a thorough revision of city civil service classifications and pay schedules was ordered yesterday by Mayor O'Dwyer.

"The Eagle With Two Heads" ("L'Aigle a Deux Tetes"), a French-made period romantic drama, adapted and directed by Jean Cocteau from his play of the same name, will have its local premiere today at the Little Met. Edwige Feuillere and Jean Marais are starred in the offering which features Sylvia Monfort, Jean Debucourt and Jacques Varennes.

VIENNA, Dec. 28 -- United States Army headquarters here announced today the court-martial of Lieut. Col. Walter G. Rischel of the United States Air Force, formerly of the United States military mission in Hungary, would be resumed within forty-five days.

The apt definition of undistributed corporate profits as, "broadly speaking, in the nature of a social dividend in which the whole community shares" in your editorial on The Nature of Profits, Dec. 18, is one of the most illuminating contributions to the case of wages versus profits this reader has seen.

"Where can I try out my new rifle?" is the plaintive cry of the city-bound man whose letter to Santa received a favorable response, but whose chances of trying the rifle out in the near future are remote or impossible.

CAIRO, Egypt, Dec. 28 -- The Egyptian Premier, Mahmoud Fahmy Nokrashy Pasha, was assassinated three minutes before 10 o'clock this morning by a veterinary student member of the Moslem Brotherhood, which the Premier banned on Dec. 8.

Although yesterday was the last day this year in which sales of securities to establish profits for income tax purposes could be effected on the New York Stock Exchange in the "regular way" -transactions completed three days later by deliveries -- profits can be established through "cash" sales, i.e. immediate deliveries for cash, to the end of the year.

NANKING, Dec. 28 -- Vice President Li Tsung-jen, who was elected to office last April despite the opposition of President Chiang Kaishek and the Kuomintang [Government party] machine, has been persistently mentioned in informed quarters here as an imminent successor to Generalissmo Chiang as President of China.

We believe the people of New York State are prepared to accept the necessity of a state budget considerably higher than the current year's, and it has been apparent for several weeks that Governor Dewey is moving in that direction. He has listed a series of new projects that have come up in his budget studies.

Washington, Dec. 29 -- The American Educational Theatre Association, a national organization of school and college drama teachers, will ask President Truman to release the Belasco Theatre, owned by the Government, for use as a legitimate playhouse.

A Christmas story of an honest taxicab driver, of his grateful passengers and how they all cooperated to help the Neediest through The New York Times appeal was disclosed yesterday with the receipt of $10 from a man connected with a magazine publishing company.

BERLIN, Dec. 29 (UP) Germany's Russian-backed Communists called Allied plans for control of the Ruhr "the rape of western Germany" tonight and urged the country's 70,000,000 people to rise in "tremendous protest demonstrations."

Proctor Electric Company announced yesterday that it had authorized its dealers to allow customers $3 on old toasters to be applied toward purchase of its automatic toaster, which is fair-traded at $18.95. The action, applying to the first quarter of 1949 only, is the first post-war trade-in offer made by a top brand toaster manufacturer.
PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Dec. 29 (AP) Leaders of the Protestant churches in Czechoslovakia were warned tonight "to put their ranks in order with the state."

The committee acting for the 51/2 per cent cumulative preferred "A" Stock of the Alleghany Corporation announced yesterday that it has decided to dissolve. Harold R. Baxter, chairman, in a letter to the owners of preferred stock stated that efforts toward friendly cooperation with Alleghany management had failed and that "recent developments have convinced the committee that if anything is to be accomplished more drastic action is necessary."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- The condition of the national military establishment is "sound," but the cost of maintaining it demands safeguards for the total national economy, Secretary of Defense James Forrestal stated today.

DETROIT, Dec. 29 (AP) -- The Detroit Red Wings went on their wildest scoring binge of the National Hockey League season tonight to rout the second-place Boston Bruins, 10 to 2, before 13,717 fans and lift their circuit lead to three points.

One major and one minor upset featured the third day of competition yesterday in the Eastern junior and boys' indoor tennis championships being conducted on the boards of the Fifteenth Regiment Armory in upper Manhattan. Play in both divisions reached the semi-final round.
Ike, Williams, world lightweight champion, and Kid Gavilan, Cuban contender for the world welterweight title, are to battle again in the ring of Madison Square Garden.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, Dec. 29 (UP) -- The Hungarian Government charged today in a special statement that Joseph Cardinal Mindszenty was a Fascist plotter whose only resistance to the Nazis had been a battle over possession of his palace and 1,500 suits of underwear.
Three East Side fires kept men and apparatus busy yesterday from morning through late afternoon.

The shipbuilding and repair industry, in the last year has shown a marked improvement compared with the years just after the war, accordin@ to a yearend review of the industry made public yesterday by H. Gerrish Smith, president of the Shipbuilders Council of America.

Thi highly touted musical comedy production, "Kiss Me, Kate," co-starring Alfred Drake and Patricia Morison and featuring Harold Lang and Lisa Kirk, will set up shop this evening at the Century Theatre under the auspices of Saint Subber and Lemuel Ayers.
MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 29 (AP) -- An unconfirmed report that survivors of a DC-3 charter plane missing almost two days had been sighted on a beach in Cuba was being checked tonight by the Coast Guard.

BOSTON, Dec. 29 -- Judge George C. Sweeney appointed today in United States District Court three trustees to operate the Waltham Watch Company and the trustees immediately asked Reconstruction Finance Corporation officials here for a $9,000,000 loan to finance 1949 operations.
Ferdinand Eberstadt, president of F. Eberstadt Co., Inc., since its formation in 1931, has been elected chairman of the board of the investment banking firm, it was announced yesterday.

CAIRO, Egypt, Dec, 29King Farouk broke tradition today, by joining the mourners for Premier Mahm0ud Fahmy Nokrash Pasha who wasassasslnated by a member of 'the IVfoslera Brotherhood yesterday. The King prayed over the body at. Kekhya Mosque while a crowd of nearly 20,000 packed Opera Square and the'surrounding streets for the funeral procession.

A new edition of Marco Pallis' account of climbing in the Himalayas, entitled "Peaks and Lamas," will be published here on Feb. 7 by Knopf. It was originally issued in a small edition imported from England in 1940.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- The condition statement of weekly reportingmember banks in ninetyfour leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended Dec. 22, the Federal Reserve Board reported today:
WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 (AP) In his new position Mr. Gross will collaborate with Paul G. Hoffman, Economic Cooperative Administrator, in meshing economic aid with the military program.

The strong tides that have been at work in the market for Government and high-grade corporate bonds enabled underwriting syndicates yesterday to close subscription books on three new issues of securities totaling $64,000,000 on which sales had lagged most of the month.

A motion by the State Commissioner of Education for a change of venue of a proceeding involving the constitutionality of the Board of Education's released-time program for religious training was denied yesterday by Supreme Court Justice George J. Beldock in Brooklyn.

Wagner's "Die Walkuere" received its first presentation of the season last night at the Metropolitan Opera House. The performance had real mood, and the poetical atmosphere of the music drama was captured to a marked degree from the start.
Twenty-four fiancees of American servicemen and the American wife of a war bridegroom arrived here yesterday by air from overseas.
Mayor O'Dwyer moved last night to avert the threat of a strike of 2,500 truck drivers that would halt most of the city's movement of coal and fuel oil at midnight tomorrow.

The United Negro College Fund, an affiliate of the Tuskegee Institute, has acquired the five-story and penthouse Jewett Building at 22 East Fifty-fourth Street on assignment of a contract by William J. Trent, who bought the property from Fred H. Hill.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 29 (AP) -- Kentucky's national collegiate champions routed Tulane, 78 -- 47, in the Sugar Bowl basketball tournament tonight and will meet St. Louis University in the final of the four-team carnival tomorrow night.

Brilliantly executed strategy enabled Miguel M. Najdorf, Polish expert from Buenos Aires, to triumph again in the sixth round of the international masters tournament at the Manhattan Chess Club last night. He defeated Isaac I. Kashdan in thirty-five moves and, with a score of 5 1/2 -- 1/2, remained at the top of the standing.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -James Forrestal, Secretary of Defense, revealed tonight the existence of an "earth satellite vehicle program" within the Armed Forces.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29--President Truman landed safely in Washington this afternoon after circling over National Airport for forty minutes in rain and fog as flying conditions steadily worsened. Visibility was only three-eighths of a mile and the ceiling had closed down to 1,600 feet as the Presidential aircraft, the Independence, circled in a traffic pattern with three commercial planes.

A gilded bronze sculpture by Donatello and a group of 120 nineteenth century Italian paintings gathered from public and private collections throughout Italy arrived here yesterday aboard the Vulcania for a benefit exhibition.
Paul Livermore, son of the late Jesse Livermore, has been appointed general manager of Parfums Le Galion, perfume company owned by Morton Downey, Steve Hannagan and Sherman Billingsley.
PARIS, Dec. 29 -- The United Nations Security Council ordered another cease-fire in Palestine today after the British delegate had charged that Israeli forces had attacked a town in Egypt.

LONDON, Thursday, Dec. 30 -The sympathy of Britons for hardpressed Germans that is noticeably on the wane may be reduced still more by publication today of a pictorial graph showing that in some foods the Germans fare better than the British and their wartime allies.

Dr. Robert C. Darling has been named to coordinate the physical medicine program at Columbia University, Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, president, announced yesterday. Doctor Darling, an associate professor of medicine at the College of Physicians and Surgeons, will assume the newlycreated office Saturday.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 29 (AP) -San Francisco University moved into an early lead and then repelled repeated challenges to topple a battling La Salle team from the unbeaten ranks, 51 to 45, in the second game of a Convention Hall basketball double-header tonight.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 2O -- A strong earthquake shook northern California and western Nevada today, affecting an estimated 50,000 square miles but doing only minor damage largely because its center apparently was in a sparsely inhabited region.

Opera, in the truly modern sense of the word, blossomed last night on Broadway. The effect of the production of "The Rape of Lucretia'' in the Ziegfeld Theatre was as revolutionary as it was exhilarating. The text of `Ronald Duncan is not only singable, despite certain artificialities and some high-falutin,' but is an effective dramatic vehicle.

Mayor O'Dwyer announced yesterday the appointment of Assemblyman Irwin D. Davidson, Manhattan Democrat, as a Justice of the Court of Special Sessions to succeed Justice Maurice Simmons. Mr. Davidson will be sworn in at 1 P.M. today at City Hall.

PARIS, Dec. 29 -- Premier Henri Queuille's coalition Cabinet today made sharp advances toward the financial reforms that had been devised to win further Marshall Plan aid. In the Council of the Republic, a de Gaullist move to put the two Houses of Parliament in conflict was repulsed.
Ricardo Rivera Schreiber, former Peruvian Minister to Japan, declared yesterday that he warned United States officials of Japan's intentions to bomb Pearl Harbor a full year before the attack.

The stock market sharply reversed its trend yesterday and recovered the exact amount, as measured by the composite rate, lost on Tuesday. The lessening of tax selling brought out sufficient reinvestment demand to produce a spurt in prices after a weak opening.

Complete cessation of all United States aid to the Netherlands, as well as to the Dutch-held portions of Indonesia, was urged yesterday by Matthew M. Fox, president and chairman of the American Indonesian Corporation.

Cyrus G. Hill. nationally known expert and consultant on telephone rates, has been retained by the city to assist in opposing the application filed by the New York Telephone Company with the Public Service Commission on Nov. 16 for a permanent average rate rise of 15 per cent throughout the state.
LONDON, Dec. 29 - Although business in the stock market here today was on the small side, conditions were generally cheerful.

Increased civilian leadership in determining policies to govern the relations of the United States with other nations was asked yesterday in a letter to President Truman from the Congregational Christian Council for Social Action.

ALBANY, Dec. 29 -- Although New York State law permits the corporal punishment of school children provided it is "reasonable in manner and degree," the Department of Education is not a subscriber to the maxim, "Spare the rod and spoil the child."
WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- Following is the text of the official summary of the first report by Secretary of Defense Forrestal on the National Military Establishment.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- Remodelling of the White House now appears to be a job costing many millions of dollars, far more sweeping than at first thought, and of necessity including the building of a firm foundation to a depth of twenty feet below the present foundation.

CHICAGO, Dec. 29 -- Corn assumed leadership in the grain markets today with May bought freely by cash interests, and at one time the near-by months were 7/8 cent higher, selling at a new high since Dec. 9. `Closing trades were at a gain of 1/2 cent on May and 1/4 cent up to 3/8 cent down on the deferred deliveries.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 29 -Tony Owen and Joan Davis have concluded a deal with Columbia for the release of an independent production, "Travelling Saleswoman," to be based on a comedy idea by Owen and Miss Davis.

The old gentleman with whiskers usually gets somewhat confused by the time he has passed up and down a few chimneys, and a number of rod and gun clubs have set up "swapping posts" for the benefit of members who received undesirable items as a result of this confusion.
SEOUL, Korea, Dec. 29 -- The reduction of United States armed strength in Korea by at least one infantry division was accepted today in Korean quarters with complete calm.

Five New York and New Jersey women were officially sworn into the Marine Corps yesterday at the Marine Recruiting Office, 90 Church Street, to become the first regular 'lady leathernecks" enlisted in the New York metropolitan area.

The report of Defense Secretary Forrestal on the first year of operation of the National Military Establishment under his direction reaches and announces the same general conclusion as did the report of the Eberstadt Committee of the Hoover Commission. This conclusion is that unification of the armed services under one head is a sound idea that isn't yet working well and that needs strengthening.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- Conversations with Foreign Ministers in Latin America have developed in the present stage of exchanges a rather common belief that the withholding or granting of recognition is hardly an adequate method for discouraging revolutionary overturns in this hemisphere, Acting Secretary of State Robert A. Lovett announced today.

LONDON, Dec. 29 -- The British Government has accepted a United States proposal to make another attempt to draft, an Austrian peace treaty on or about Feb. 7 in London, the Foreign Office said today. It is taken for granted that France and the Soviet Union will agree to the time and place, as they accepted the Austrian proposal of Dec. 6 to resume the negotiations that broke down last May.

Theodore W. Kheel, who has played a principal role in building the City Division of Labor Relations into one of the most effective agencies for strike settlement in the country, leaves the municipal service tomorrow to resume the private practice of law. His "retirement" at the advanced age of 34 focuses new attention on the importance of measures to make government careers more attractive to men of demonstrated ability.

Nine days of snow removal after the 19.6-inch snowfall of Dec. 19 cost the city $1,873,070, as compared with $4,692,308 for the first nine days of similar work after the "big snow" of 25.8 inches on Dec. 26, 1947. In a report to Mayor O'Dwyer, made public yesterday at City Hall, Sanitation Commissioner William J. Powell attributed the $2,819,238 reduction in cost to increased efficiency of manpower and machinery.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- Registration statements covering $50,000,000 of first and refunding mortgage bonds and 15,000 shares of preferred stock were filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission by two companies.

The denial of James Melton, chairman of the Merritt Parkway Commission, that many accidents are attributable to blinding glare from automobile headlights on Merritt Parkway, as reported in THE NEW YORK TIMES of Dec. 11, is in disregard of conditions well known to every driver who uses the parkway regularly.

I have just read with interest Milo O. Bennett's letter in your issue of Dec. 22. Mr. Bennett proposes a sure-fire remedy for the conditions District Attorney Frank S. Hogan has exposed, with respect to New York County divorce actions. His suggestion is that the law should not be modified but enforced.

The Squadron A Regulars defeated the New York A.C., 10 to 9, in an indoor polo double-header last night at the Squadron A Armory. A shot by Billy Rand, former Yale star, a second before the final bell won the match for the Regulars.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- The Bureau of the Census reported today the population of the United States stood at about 148,000,000 at year's end, roughly 12.5 per cent higher than the 131,669,275 counted in the last decennial census in 1940.

Considering that it costs $45,500,000 a year to support modern language scholarship in the United States, scholars ought to make their findings intelligible to the public to help defend our "sorepressed democracy" Prof. Howard Mumford Jones of Harvard University declared here last night.

PARIS, Dec. 29 Vice PresidentElect Alben W. Barkley said here today that he had found the Marshall Plan operations "going very well all over Europe" and that he expected the coming Congress to vote "sufficient funds to fully cover the European Recovery Program for next year."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- President Truman, who has been charged with untidiness in the presentation of foreign policy programs to Congress, today directed all departments and agencies to get together and coordinate "all related aspects of foreign economic and military programs."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- The Government must give industry more information about atomic energy if private enterprise is to provide the assistance necessary to insure national security and maximum development for peaceful uses, an advisory group of prominent industrialists reported today.

LONDON, Dec. 29 -- Approximately 2,500 United States Air Force officers and men at Burtonwood air base near Manchester were entertained today by a troupe headed by Bob Hope, Jinx Falkenburg, Irving Berlin and other stage, screen and radio performers.

Men's wear industry leaders who were in agreement on the need for a nation-wide promotion plan voted yesterday to concentrate their efforts with the Men's Fashion Guild of America. A committee investigating the possibilities for promotion concluded that a new organization should not be set up at this time.

Charging that restaurant operators are damaging tea sales through improper preparation, Anthony Hyde, managing director of the Tea Bureau, Inc., an association representing the majority of tea producers in this country, disc]osed yesterday that to correct this situation a nation-wide promotion and educational campaign will be conducted Feb. 11 to 18.

PARIS, Dec. 29--The Netherlands today rejected a United Nations Security Council resolution calling for an immediate cease-fire in Indonesia, but promised to end hostilities in Java by midnight on Friday and in Sumatra two or three days later.

ASPEN, Col., Dec. 29 (AP) -- Crosby Perry-Smith of Colorado Western State tonight appeared to be leading the field in individual standings at the end of three events in the national intercollegiate fourevent ski championships.

Six couples who have been married fifty years were entertained by John J. Cavanagh at his restaurant at 259 West Twenty-third Street last night as an added recognition of their part in the city's Golden Jubilee Exposition last summer.
The New York City Housing Authority opened one low-rent development yesterday in Queens, and broke ground in Brooklyn for the construction of three more.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- Five officials of the Congress of Industrial Organizations were President Truman's first White House visitors today after his return from a Missouri holiday. They received his reassurance that labor legislation headed the agenda he would ask Congress to approve.
CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 29 (AP) -- Scoring his second triumph in as many local starts, Hash Night easily defeated five rivals in the Balmoral Purse, today's top offering at Tropical Park.

Wage increases on a bargaining basis are due to be discussed in the tugboat dispute for the first time today when representatives of the union and the operators meet with Mayor O'Dwyer's special committee appointed to assist in the settlement of the dispute before the present agreement expires at midnight tomorrow.

Miss Diane Greenberg of New York University won the Christmas Invitation Fencing Tournament conducted by the Women's Athletic Association of Brooklyn College last night. Competing against eight others in the final round-robin, Miss Greenberg won all her matches to gain the first place medal awarded by the Amateur Fencers League of America.

The first of a series of trade union groups from Marshall Plan countries to come to this country to study American production methods and labor-management relations, arrived at the New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens, from Oslo, Norway, on a Scandinavian Airlines plane yesterday afternoon.
CHICAGO, Dec. 29 (AP) -- Sharp declines in overall meat supplies in the first four months of 1949 were predicted today by the National Live Stock Producers Association.
ARCADIA, Calif., Dec. 29 (AP) -Jockey Johnny Longden today established a new modern riding record as he booted home Count Victor in the third race at Santa Anita.

TOKYO, Dec. 29 -- The Japanese Government today applied the "purge directive" against four of nineteen prewar leaders who were released by the Allies from Sugamo Prison after two years of confinement as suspected war criminals.
Mayor O'Dwyer told 350 Columbia University alumni yesterday that a transit bottleneck in Manhattan was hampering the successful development of the City's subway system.

The C.C.N.Y. chess team moved into first place in the Intercollegiate League championship tournament at Columbia University yesterday. Opposing Syracuse, the Lavender players registered a 4-to-0 victory to take their place at the head of the standing.

Evincing the determination of Transcontinental Western Air, Inc., to stay in the transatlantic business, Warren Lee Pierson, chairman of the board, said yesterday that it soon would add Milan as a stop. This would bring to eighteen the number of its overseash)0*0*0*istations, including Zurich, to which service will start on Jan. 17.

Mayor O'Dwyer's order for a survey leading to thorough revision of city civil service classifications and pay schedules constitutes recognition of a long-neglected and highly important problem. The need for such action has been admitted for many years, and the last authentic attempt at a general reclassification is said to have been made about thirty years ago.
BERLIN, Dec. 29--Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower's "Crusade in EUrope'' is achieving wide unpopula. ity in-Germany, the letters to the ed{tot column of the Britishlicensed newspaper Welt indicated today.

PARIS, Dec. 29 -- To attain the balanced trade that is the goal of the Marshall Plan, European nations must compete more vigorously in the next three years with the United States exporters in the American and in the world market, it is stated in a report on European recovery prospects.

The Schools Motion Picture Committee of the National Board of Review, a voluntary organization composed of teachers and parents of pupils in local public and private elementary and high schools, recommends as suitable for children between the ages of 8 and 14, a group of motion pictures to be shown, tomorrow through Sunday, unless otherwise specified.

Although the Yankees had two of their most cherished baseball attendance records surpassed by the Cleveland Indians during 1948 -one being the all-time major league seasonal total which the Tribe raised to 2,620,627, the other the 86,288 gathering that watched the fifth game of the world series -- the Bombers helped to do quite a bit of record wrecking themselves.

New York has agreed to complete its program to abate harbor pollution within ten years, according to a consent order served on the City Clerk's office yesterday by the Interstate Sanitation .Commission.

A 48-year-old man, who had ordered wreaths for his own funeral and paid for them with a worthless check, shot himself fatally yesterday in a Bronx flower shop during a struggle with a clerk who was trying to hold him for the police.

I cannot let pass without this brief reaction your on-the-whole constructive editorial of Dec. 25 on the subject of Federal aid to schools. It seems bad to me that the pertinent facts and cautions presented had thrown in with them the comment "for New Yorkers and others of prosperous states it is a step of generosity and altruism."

CHICAGO, Dec. 29 -- Current assets of $6,270,141, including only $731,401 of cash and United States Treasury notes, were reported in a balance sheet issued today by the controller's office of the Tucker Corporation, Chicago automobile company.

MINNEAPOLIS, Dec. 29 (AP) -- A refugee Polish countess who was active in the underground during the recent war tonight became the bride of Harry A. Bullis of Minneapolis, chairman of the board of General Mills, Inc. She is Countess Maria Smorczewska, 54, formerly of Vilno and Warsaw.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- James Forrestal, Secretary of Defense, proposed today that his office have greater authority over the three armed services and that wider "discretion" be allowed the President and the Government in general in providing military assistance and missions to friendly allies throughout the world.

A House of Representatives that contains 435 members (none of them loath to speak) is obviously too large a body to function successfully without strong committee leadership. There must be some "traffic bureau" to plan the order of business and to make certain that essential bills are not lost in the great welter of inessential ones.

The election of four vice presidents of Doherty, Clifford Shenfield, Inc., was announced yesterday by the agency's, board of directors. They are James F.
