Egan, copy director; Chester MacCracken,h)0*0*0*iradio and television director, who has been with the agency since its formation in 1934; Edward M. Raynolds, research director for the last four years, and Aldis P. Butler, executive on the Nestle Company account.

THE HAGUE, The Netherlands,Dec. 29 -- Commenting on the announcement in Paris by Dr. Jan Herman van Royen that Netherlands Premier Willem Drees would leave soon for Indonesia, a spokesman for the Cabinet said today.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- Robert A. Lovett, Acting Secretary of State, denounced today the arrest by Hungary's Communist-dominated Government of Joseph Cardinal Mindszenty as a sickening sham.

LONDON, Dec. 29 -- Faced with a wave of hunger strikes on the part of 400 Ukrainian former prisoners of war who were ordered deported to Germany, the Home Office announced today that it had changed its mind and would permit almost all the Ukrainians concerned to remain in the British Isles for the time being.

The State Committee of the American Labor party announced yesterday that it was starting a state-wide drive for signatures to petitions calling for repeal df the Taft-Hartley Act and complete restoration of the Wagner Labor Relations Act and the Norris-LaGuardia Anti-Injunction Act.

BATAVIA, Java, Dec. 29 (UP) In an appeal over the clandestine Republican radio, Major General Tomo, leader of Indonesian suicide troops, asked the populace today to strike against the Dutch in hit and-run raids.
Prices of bonds should remain reasonably stable and may possibly strengthen in 1949, Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., said in its annual year-end bond survey, to be issued today.

LONDON, Dec. 29 -- A team of British scientists has discovered a drug -- antrycide -- that, by defeating the ravages of the tsetse fly on cattle in tropical Africa, is expected to give the world a new area four times the size of Argentina for the production of meat.
Bert C. Lown, director of station relations and sales for theAssociated Program Service, a division of 1VIuzak Corporation, hasbeen elected . vice president ofthe parent organization.
Paris, Dec. 29 (AP) Following is the text of a statement by the Netherlands representative, Dr. J. H. van Royen, to the United Nations Security Council today on the Indonesian situation:

CHICAGO, Dec. 29 -- An appeal to extend Federal and state social security coverage to many music teachers not now included was contained in a resolution passed today by the National Association of Schools of Music before ending a threeday meeting here.

ROME, Dec. 29 -- Negotiations between Italy and Yugoslavia for the settlement of many economic and commercial questions will begin tomorrow, Italian circles said today. It is hoped here that this new development may lead to a lasting improvement of economic and political relations.

Plans for increasing the company's annual steel capacity by 243,000 tons, or 35 per cent, through replacement, improvement and rebuilding of its facilities at its Duluth, Minn., works, were announced by the American Steel and Wire Company.

Ingrid Bergman and Bing Crosby by have been chosen the favorite stars of rural moviegoers,according to the sixth annual rural motion picture poll conducted by The Country Gentleman magazine, June Allyson and Irene Dunne were next, in that order, among the actresses, while Gregory Peck Gary Cooper, Roy Rogers and Peter Lawford were runners-up to Crosby.

George Neikrug, young New York 'cellist who is one of the first desk men of the Baltimore Symphony Orchestra, gave his third Town Hall recital last night. He showed again that he is a serious and gifted artist who seems most at home in music of his own era.

Edgar Bergen's entry this spring into the ranks of television performers, presumably on a trial basis, was reported yesterday to be a strong possibility, should the pending deal between the ventriloquist and the Columbia Broadcasting System be concluded successfully.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 29 -Negotiators for American Federation of Labor sailors and West Coast ship-owners reached an agreement today on wages and overtime, apparently removing the last major threat to peace on this coast's waterfronts.
MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 29 (AP) -- Calumet Farm's Citation, triple crown winner in 1948, today was "fired" for a popped osselet on his left foreleg.

For the opening of its new Parkchester shop, Lichtman's Bakery is introducing another of its delicious pastries. Citronade pound cake is a less fruity edition of fruit cake, done simply with preserved citron and that in judicious amounts. It's light in color, with a tender, richin-butter texture and delicate flavor.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 29 -Solar flares, short-lived but tremendous outbursts of light on the sun that occur in the neighborhood of sunspots, may prove to be similar in nature to lighting in the earth's atmosphere. But such "solar lighting" may often have an extent of thousands of miles.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 (AP) -The Department of Agriculture today gave Cubaja 1949 sugar import quota of 2,091,550 short tons, raw value. Cuba's final quota for 1948 was 2,895,962 tons.
More than 1,600 policemen, afoot and mounted, were assigned yesterday to keep order among the crowds who will come to Times Square tomorrow night.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- The House Subcommittee on Procurement and Buildings asserted today that its activities in 1948 led to the return to the Treasury of millions of dollars improperly paid out by the Government.

Q. MR. BIANCOLLI, you are, are you not, sir, the editor of "The Book of Great Conversations,"* talks between Casanova and Voltaire, Shaw and Chesterton, Shelley and Trelawny, Stalin and H. G. Wells -- not to mention great conversations with Michelangelo, Franklin, Lamb, Dumas, Whitman, Heine, Lincoln, Rousseau, Masaryk, Tolstoy and any number of others?

The nation's gasoline stocks increased 2,061,000 barrels last week, according to the American Petroleum Institute. At the week-end, they amounted to 100,286,000 barrels, compared with 98,225,000 a week earlier and 91,269,000 a year before.

KANSAS CITY, Dec. 29 (AP) -The powerful University of Oklahoma Sooners won the right to meet the clever Kansas Jayhawks for the Big Seven conference's tournament championship by beating Iowa State, 55 to 45, tonight. Kansas whipped Kansas State, 60 -- 46, in the first semi-final game of tonight's double-header.
New England's promotion campaign to attract industry has been successful -- at least in the reconstructed New England village on the east balcony of Grand Central Terminal.

A tightening of the purse strings of credit is shown in the latest survey of 250,000 active accounts of Chicago manufacturers and wholesalers selling throughout the country, it was disclosed yesterday in a statement by the Chicago Association of Credit Men.
Establishment of the Carl Wallach Foundation to finance the education of refugee children was announced yesterday.

LONDON, Dec. 29 -- The inability of Lloyd's Register of Shipping and the American Bureau of Shipping to reach mutual understanding regarding shipping registry will in no way interrupt the "cordial relations which have always existed between the two societies," Lloyd's offices announced here tonight.

Reductions of $2.50 in the retail price of Surretwill suits and 55 cents on Surretwill slacks were announced yesterday by Rose Brothers, Inc., in a letter to the trade. The' new retail fair-trade prices, involving no change in normal retail mark-up, are $50 for the suits and $15.95 for the slacks.

In the first place, may I compliment THE TIMES upon its pre-eminence as a newspaper of record? To provide a complete text, especially when controversial issues are under discussion, is a splendid service to the nation.

CHICAGO, Dec. 29 (AP) -- An average price decline of 1.7 per cent is shown in the new 1949 catalog of Sears, Roebuck Co., the big mail-order and retail merchandise firm said today. It is the first cut, on a year-to-year basis, since the war, the company said.
The hide futures market showed increasing firmness yesterday on the Commodity Exchange.

Participation by 5,612,087 persons in the United States in activities sponsored by the National Conference of Christians and Jews in 1948 was emphasized yesterday by Dr. Everett R. Clinchy, the president, in a report to directors at 381 Fourth Avenue.

Left-wing forces in the Transport Workers Union, CIO, already stripped of their power within the union, suffered a setback yesterday in their efforts to obtain court aid against supporters of Michael J. Quill, the union's international presldent.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- General authority for the Government to provide military assistance to any country was proposed today by James Forrestal, Secretary of Defense, in his first annual report.

A photograph of Marion Lamorte, snapped by a friend shortly before she disappeared last Dec. 6 from her home at 1951 Paulding Avenue, the Bronx, and showing the clothing she wore at the time, was made public yesterday by her father, Col. Nicholas D. Lamorte, in the hope that the picture might be recognized by someone who had seen his daughter.

ATHENS, Dec. 29 -- Negotiations are now going on among British, Portuguese and Southern Rhodesian experts in an effort to organize the port and transportation facilities of Central Africa with a view to developing vast mineral resources lying in the hinterland and making them more available to the world.

The 1948 annual appeal of the Catholic Charities of the Archdiocese of lew York reached a totalof $1,937,119, the highest in itshistory, as the books were closedfor' the ' year, it was announcedTuesday by Frank C. Walker,treasurerat a meeting of the Cardinal's Committee of the Laityinthe Empire :S.tate Club, EmpireState Building.Contributions through parish organizations directly tbtaled $1,146,267. Special gifts through the Cardinal s Committee of the Laityamounted, to $790,852.I " Ust dth

Looking fit and trim, three of Europe's outstanding ski jumpers, Petter Hugsted, Olympic champion from Kongsberg, Norway, and Vilhelm Hellman and Bengt Jaderholm, both from Stockholm, Sweden, arrived yesterday aboard a Scandinavian airliner at Idlewild Airport with two ideas in mind.

The Bethlehem Steel Corporation, the nation's second largest producer steel, announced yesterday plans to sell $50,000,000 of thirty-year bonds next month and 627,960 shares of common stock when market conditions are considered satisfactory.

CHICAGO, Dec. 29 -- In his holiday greetings to the union's 87,000 members, Woodruff Randolph, president of the International Typographical Union, AFL, warns that "as matters shape up now" it may be necessary for them to vote again to reinstate a 4 1/2 per cent strike assessment after February, 1949.
Observances of Manhattan Freedom Week, arranged for the farewell visit of the Freedom Train, continued yesterday with a rally in the Astor Hotel.
The problem of the UnitedStates lKerchnt Marine, as a partof the economy of the nation andan importan, t auxi!iary of the national defense, ia likely to be presented to Congress next month.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., Dec. 29 -In simultaneous raids on four major hotels in this winter resort last night, state police and agents of State Attorney General Walter Van Riper seized five loads of gambling equipment, held twenty four persons for questioning and confiscated $6,000.

NANKING, Dec. 29 -- An extraordinary conference of regional leaders has been called here by President Chiang Kai-shek as part of a series of events that are expected to involve important new developments in the Chinese Government civil war policy.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29--An amnesty in the new Congress for I the Southern Democrats who bolto led President Truman in the Noyes!bet election was. indicated today, but formidable efforts were being made to reduce their collective power in the house.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 (AP) -The twelve Air Force men rescued from a Greenland icecap yesterday were still in Greenland tonight, but there were tentative plans to bring at least some of them home for a hero's welcome.

IRVINGTON-ON-HUDSON, N.Y., Dec. 29 -- Masons of New York State gave a New Year's Eve "preview party" this afternoon for 100 boys and girls at the Irvington House for cardiac children, a convalescent center for young rheumatic fever sufferers.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Dec. 29--Israeli forces are now "mopping up" in the Negeb, which indicates that their objectives have been either reached or neutralized. This secretive action, which has become known here as "Operation Blackout," had reached a "satisfactory stage when unofficial word arrived that the United Nations had ordered an immediate cease-fire.

If the Community Service Society allowed a single exception to its rule that requires women workers to retire at the age of 60, Miss Alta Elizabeth Dines would start on Saturday a second quarter century of making people as aware of good health as of sickness.

North American Aviation, Inc. reported yesterday a net income of $6,779,561 after $4,000,000 taxes and all charges in the fiscal year ended with last September, in contrast to the net loss of $28,259 after giving effect to a $11,700,000 carry-back tax credit in the preceding fiscal year.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- Robert A. Lovett, Acting Secretary of State, today assailed the Chinese Communists for labeling Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek, Mme. Chiang and other leaders in the Nationalist Government of China as war criminals.

Jonas Andersen has resigned as president and a director of the Blair Holdings Company and its investment securities subsidiary, Blair Co., Inc., and will leave the business at the end of this month, it was learned yesterday.

LONDON, Dec. 29 -- Gen. Sir Brian Robertson, British Military Governor in Germany, arrived in London today to hold a general discussion of German problems with Foreign Secretary Ernest Bevin before taking a vacation early in the new year.

Prices of dairy products appear to have reached their peak, Theodore G. Montague, president of the Borden Company, declared yesterday. The outlook presently is for a seasonal decline until early summer at least, he said, adding that it seemed unlikely that 1949 prices would touch the high level reached early in 1948.

Ice-glazed roads in the morning and a fog shroud last night bedevilled motorists in the suburbs yesterday, especially in northern New Jersey and Westchester. New Yorkers got rain and no other weather irritations. The temperature in the city rose to a high mark for the day of 55 degrees at 11:30 P.M.

Price increases amounting to about 15 per cent become effective on molybdenum products after Jan. 1 and all producers will share in the increase, trade spokesmen disclosed here yesterday. A few items will be increased more than that amount, while one item will be increased only 8 per cent, it was learned.
CHICAGO, Dec. 29 (AP) - The Transportation Association of America said today that the transportation bill in this country has run to more than $30,000,000,000 this year.

This is the time of year when the man who has begun to lose some of his zest for jousting with winter repairs to his kitchen to round up the makings for a few bowls of popcorn. With butter, salt, a corn popper or covered frying pan, a hot flame and a little popcorn a fellow can pass the time pleasantly stuffing himself with starch, keeping warm by his hearth the while.

The winter cruise business, which has been a source of concern to travel and shipping men because of a slow response instead of the expected rush for space, is steadily improving, chiefly as a result of the arrival of winter weather, booking men reported yesterday.

Western Kentucky's undefeated quintet and the University of San Francisco, appearing here for the first time, will be the visitors in tonight's college basketball doubleheader at Madison Square Garden. Long Island University will tackle the Hilltoppers in the opener at 8 P.M., with City College meeting the Dons in the nightcap.

Another battle between the Democrats and the Republicans loomed yesterday when Representative Sol Bloom, Democrat, who has been representing the Twentieth Congressional District on Manhattan's West Side for twenty-six years, challenged the Republicans to a marble-shooting contest.

ALBANY, Dec. 29 -- Governor Dewey announced today that he had requested the heads of all state agencies to re-examine their budget requests for next year with a view to making all possible reductions.
DETROIT, Dec. 29 (AP) -- Henry Ford II said today his company will welcome the return of a buyer's market in automobiles.

ALBANY, Dec. 29 -- Charles D. Breitel, counsel to Governor Dewey since he has been Governor, is rated a "good chance" for appointment to the vacancy on the Court of Appeals caused by the resignation of Judge Thomas D. Thacher.

New York's five racing associations announced yesterday that they had agreed on a proposed schedule of dates for the 1949 season at the Belmont, Jamaica, Aqueduct and Saratoga tracks. The list will be submitted to the State Racing Commission and the stewards of the Jockey Club for their consideration.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange closed 3 to 10 points higher yesterday.

Investors in municipal securities need methods of appraisal and selection quite different from those used during the pre-war period of uninfiated prices and costs, the Guaranty Trust Company of New York asserts in the current issue of its monthly review of business and financial conditions, published today.

Two vacant corner plots in Brooklyn Heights have been purchased by Victor Polstein and Maurice Magid for improvement with apartments and professional suites. One is at Remsen and Henry Streets and the other at Henry and Joralemon Streets.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- New leads in the Hiss-Chambers case, viewed as being vitally important in the telling of the whole story of pre-wartime espionage in the American Government, have been obtained during the last twenty-four hours by the House Committee on Un-American Activities.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Dec. 29 - The allegation by the Hungarian Government that Joseph Cardinal Van Roey, Catholic Primate of Belgium, acted as a "go-between" for Cardinal Mindszenty and former Archduke Otto of Hapsburg was dismissed today as unworthy of denial by a Catholic spokesman.

Moments after the curtain was raised yesterday on the squawking bedlam of the annual Madison Square Garden-Poultry Show, the directors found themselves in a predicament, wholly unfamiliar to the average American consumer. They had too many valuable eggs.

GETTYSBURG, Pa., Dec. 29 (AP) Plans were announced today for sale of $2,500,000 in stock to finance purchase of three fruit-packing plants by the newly organized Pen-Mar-Va fruit packing co-operative. The co-operative was formed recently by fruit growers in Pennsylvania, Maryland, West Virginia and Virginia.

New York's hustling, driving Knickerbockers won a thrilling 77-to-74 decision over the Rochester Royals, Western Division leaders of the Basketball Association of America, last night. A crowd of 14,915 at Madison Square Garden saw Joe Lapchick's team engineer this upset in its outstanding performance of the campaign.

A group of United States, British, French and Russian-born newspaper men generally agreed last night, in THE NEW YORK TIMES radio program, "What's On Your Mind," that a compromise between the American way of life and Russian communism was possible.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- Senators James O. Eastland of Mississippi and Allen J. Ellender of Louisiana probably will be stripped of all Federal patronage for bolting the Truman-Barkley ticket and giving active support to the States Rights movement, it was indicated in informed quarters today.

CLEVELAND, Dec. 29 -- Business economists speaking at the annual forecasting session of the American Statistical Association here today agreed, two to one, that the outlook for 1949 was for another year of business activity at an extraordinarily high level.

It is terribly sad that this Christmas, which poured out the fattest cornucopia of gifts in years, should also reap a near-record harvest of a grimmer sort. Three hundred and ninety-six persons died in accidents over the Christmas week-end, according to a country-wide survey by The Associated Press.

The City Rent Commission authorized hotel Operators yesterday to bill permanent guests whose leases expire in January at current rates. The authorization becomes effective Jan. 1, and is to last until the commission makes permanent decisions on individual cases.

CALCUTTA, India, Dec. 29 -Under the terms of an agreement reliably reported to have been reached by Pakistan and India, Pakistan would withdraw her forces and tribal raiders from Kashmir, leaving India free to maintain sufficient troops in the Princely State to preserve order and provide for defense.

The arrest by the Hungarian Government of Joseph Cardinal Mindszenty and ten other Catholic Church dignitaries on such patently trumped-up charges as treason, espionage and black market money dealings has revealed again the ruthless and cynical nature of the Communist state.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Dec. 29 -- Boris Kidritch, chairman of the State Planning Commission and Franz Leskoshek, Minister of Heavy Industry, told the Yugoslav Parliament yesterday that the Government had been forced recently to spend 1,000,000,000 dinars $20,000,00 for urgent supplies to fill gaps caused by the economic blockade imposed by the states within the Communist Information Bureau.

Church bells and chimes will ring out the old year and ring in the new at midnight tomorrow as congregations spend the closing hours of 1948 in singing and prayer in the city's churches. Social and musical programs will precede the period of watching and waiting for the sound of the bells, in many cases beginning as early as 9 P.M.

Although they arrived forty hours after the deadline requiring them to enter the United States with visas, the five war brides who arrived at La Guardia Airport last night were readily admitted by immigration authorities.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 (AP) -American Federation of Labor building and construction unions today were out to overhaul the peace machinery they set up nine months ago -- under Government prodding -- to reduce jurisdictional strikes.

Nicholas Rossolimo of Paris, new chess champion of France, was the only winner in the opening round of the annual international masters tournament sponsored by the Hastings and St. Leonards Chess Club, which opened yesterday at the White Rock Pavilion, according to a report received from England.

The New Year's week-end, usually a period of much hilarity and activity in the North Country, will be serene tomorrow and Sunday. For as the skies cried yesterday so did winter resort operators and thousands of skiers. The rain swept the mountainsides of snow and, with few exceptions, killed hopes of running ski slopes and trails.

Intensified competition expected to spur increased advertising expenditures next year also will increase pressure for more thorough studies of media effectiveness, a publication research official declared yesterday. Greater investigation of consumer preferences in reading matter has been an increasingly recurrent topic among advertising managers and directors during the year, he noted.

On the recommendation of the office of District Attorney Frank S. Hogan, 508 shopkeepers and tavern owners, accused of possessing pinball machines, were freed yesterday on their own recognizance by Special Sessions Justice Matthew J. Troy.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Dec. 23 -- The outstanding development in German attitudes noticeable to an American correspondent resident in this country who has returned after three months' absence is the widespread agitation for and against a German Army.

BERLIN, Dec. 30 (UP) -- German protests mounted against the plan of the Western Allies for international administration of the Ruhr, and Allied occupation authorities rejected a request by German officials for the merger of the Western sectors of Berlin.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- A marked speed-up in studies of the common cold, and perhaps other virus diseases, will be possible through discovery of a laboratory method to test the cold-virus strain, the Public Health Service reported today.

h)0*0*0*iThough dry skim milk may not sound particularly enticing, it has been the outstanding news in this column in 1948. Directions for using it in a whipped topping and frozen desserts were the most popular offered this year. As has been our custom in the past, we repeat these recipes today along with the others in which our readers showed greatest interest in '48.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- The State Department's Voice of America will open broadcasting studios here on Monday from which it will conduct world-wide short-wave broadcasts. The main programming operation, however, will remain in New York.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 30 -Meteors and galaxies, respectively the nearest, and most remote of celestial objects, are both yielding their secrets to radar and radio observations in the new science of microwave astronomy.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Dec. 30 -- The Yugoslav Parliament adjourned today after voting unanimously budget estimates for 1949 that total 161,900,000,000 dinars [$3,238,000,000], an increase of 37,000,000,000 dinars over 1948.

Prof. Albert Einstein, author of the relativity theory and also oneh)0*0*0*iof the founders of the quantum theory, was resting comfortably at the Jewish Hospital of Brooklyn pending the outcome of clinical tests he has been undergoing since his admission to the hospital Tuesday.

JOHANNESBURG, Dec. 30 (Reuters) -- Defying England's attack for six hours in scoring his first century in test cricket, Eric Rowan helped South Africa force a creditable draw today in the second test here.
LONDON, Dec. 30 -- A plea for tax relief to permit industry to expand its productive plant was included in a New Year's Eve statement of the Federation of British Industries.

Dr. Alfred J. Asgis, chairman and educational director of the Health Council Institute for Labor Education and Research, 7 East Forty-second Street, announced yesterday that the institute will cease to function with the end of 1948 after ten years' sponsorship of a labor health security program.

ROME, Dec. 30 -- Striking back at the Hungarian Government with the most powerful weapon at its command, the Vatican announced today that it had excommunicated all those responsible for Joseph Cardinal Mindszenty's arrest.

The salt pork diet of American sailors before the mast a century ago accounted for the development of the hearty Rhode Island Red, a director of the annual Madison Square Garden Poultry Show related yesterday.

ALBANY, Dec. 30 -- The Democratic party indicated indirectly today that it would oppose new taxes to finance capital improvements. Paul E. Fitzpatrick, state chairman, called for a reallocation of money within the state's post war reconstruction fund asserting that $540,219,797 was unexpended at the close of the last fiscal year on March 31.

Less than 8 per cent of the Protestant missionaries in China have withdrawn from their posts in the face of the increasing possibility that the Communists will gain control of the Government, according to a survey released yesterday by the Foreign Missions Conference, 158 Fifth Avenue.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., Dec. 30 -Two physicists of the University of Michigan reached today the three-quarter point in the building of their self-styled "race track" synchrotron, a 300,000,000 electronvolt apparatus which is expected to open new vistas in atomic energy research.
ASPEN, Colo., Dec. 30 (AP) -Crosby Perry-Smith of Western State College won the cross-country race of the national intercollegiate four-way ski championship today.
WARSAW, Dec. 30 -- In an fronic sequel to his fall from grace last summer, Wladyslaw Gomulka today offered a bill in the Polish Parliament to abolish his own job as Minister of Regained Territories.

CHATTANNOOGA, Tenn., Dec. 30 -- The Southern Association of State Planning and Development Agencies reported today that broad research programs in two Southern laboratories had brought new products and new processes to the region's industry.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- The National Committee for Strengthening Congress called on Congress anew today for further reform of its machinery to eliminate "four great dangers" to efficient functioning.
BATAVIA, Java, Dec. 30 (AP) -The Dutch tightened their hold on Sumatra today after announcing the capture of the only remaining economically important area.

The "potential" for future trade and travel in the Far East is "almost beyond comprehension," says Leo A. Mathews, general passenger agent of the American President Lines, who has just returned from a six-month tour for the company throughout the Orient.

City College came from ten points behind to tie San Francisco with four seconds to go last night, but it was to no avail. The Dons scored five points to two by the Beavers in the five-minute overtime session to capture a 54-51 decision in a contest that left 17,328 spectators at Madison Square Garden limp and emotionally exhausted.

LONDON, Dec. 30 -- A substantial backlog of orders more than sufficient to keep the industry operating full time through the coming year is held by British shipbuilders, H. B. Robin Rowell, president of the British Shipbuilding Conference, said in a statement issued here tonight.
CHICAGO, Dec. 30 -- Grain markets were unsettled on the Board of Trade today with an easy undertone apparent in many grains.

Directors of the American Light and Traction Company resumed cash dividends on the common stock with the declaration yesterday of 30 cents a share, payable on Feb. 1. This was the quarterly rate that prevailed prior to the beginning of 1948.

A North River waterfront dealer in raw materials was arraigned yesterday in General Sessions on charges of criminally receiving stolen goods after he had been cited by District Attorney Frank S. Hogan as the "key figure in a pier thieving ring."
BOSTON, Dec. 30 (AP) -- Fires caused a $725,000,000 record loss across North America in 1948 but took fewer lives than in other years, a survey showed today.

The Right Rev. James P. De Wolfe, Protestant Episcopal Bishop of Long Island, officiated yesterday at a memorial service in the Chapel of St. John's Hospital, 480 Herkimer Street, Brooklyn, honoring Mrs. Walter Gibb, former head of Frederick Loeser Company and a benefactor of the hospital.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- Alexander S. Panyushkin, Soviet Ambassador, asked the United States at a meeting of the Far Eastern Commission today for information concerning what he said were reports of plans Gen. Douglas MacArthur had for re-establishing the Japanese army.
MONTREAL, Dec. 30 (AP) -- A third period goal by Normie Dussault gave the Montreal Canadiens a 3-2 victory over the Toronto Maple Leafs in a National Hockey League game tonight.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- A direct challenge to the continued leadership of Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio was issued today from a war council of twelve of his dissident Republican colleagues who asserted that they spoke for the "modern" party.

NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 30 -- The theft of 750 guns from the Raritan, N.J., arsenal in an alleged conspiracy to ship them to Costa Rica for use in the revolution there was revealed today when six men were arraigned here on Federal charges before United States Commissioner Thomas W. Clohosey.

LAFAYETTE, La., Dec. 30 (AP) -Hardin-Simmons University outpassed and out-rushed the University of Wichita (Kan.) for a 49-to12 victory in the first Camellia Bowl football game today. Fewer than 5,000 persons attended the game, held in Southwestern Louisiana Institute's McNasty Stadium.

Rain splashed relentlessly yesterday against the leaded window panes of a block-long row of artists' studios on Washington Square South. The trees and shrubs in the tiny rear courtyard dripped and twisting flagstone walks wre spotted with puddles.
TRENTON, N.J., Dec. 30 -- The battle between court leaders and municipal police officials over uniform summonses for traffic violations ended tonight.
New York City will get, on Monday, an extra Supreme Court justice with twenty-five years of experience on the high courts of the state, and at a strictly cut-rate price.
Verdi's "La Traviata" will have its first performance of the season tonight at 8:30 at the Metropolitan Opera House, with a cast headed by Licia Albanese, Jan Peerce and Leonard Warren.

" Most of the World: The Peoples of Africa, Latin America and the East Today," edited by Ralph Linton, will be published by Columbia University Press on Jan. 24. It is a survey of ten general areas by fourteen social scientists. The subjects discussed range from topography to current cultural conditions.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on Dec. 25, 1948, totaled 609,239 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 145,306 cars, or 19.3 per cent fewer than for the preceding week, 9,885 cars, or 1.6 per cent more than for the corresponding week of last year, and 18,728 cars, or 3 per cent fewer than during the corresponding week of two years ago.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- After fifteen years of intensive effort, the program of regional development in the Tennessee Valley is "paying off," the Board of Directors of the Tennessee Valley Authority told President Truman and Congress today

Freedom and the welfare of mankind are doomed if scholars fail to keep the people enlightened, Dr. Waldo Gifford Leland, vice chairman of the United States National Commission for the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization, warned yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 (AP) -The Bureau of Internal Revenue has, it was reported today, advised Jack Benny, radio comedian, that he would have to pay the income tax instead of the capital gains tax on the money he gets out of the new contract which is switching him from the National Broadcasting Company to the Columbia Broadcasting System network Sunday.

MADISON, Wis., Dec. 30 -- Two societies of geographers joined forces to form the Association of American Geographers today. This was the name of one of them. The other was the American Society for Professional Geographers. The two have been holding a four-day joint meeting here.

Death claimed a veteran of World War II yesterday and left his homeless wife and five children with the immediate prospect of only about $62 a month to support them. The man was 33-year-old Emanuel C. Rohrbaugh of York, Pa., who died in the Veterans Administration Hospital, 130 West Kingsbridge Road, the Bronx, of lukemia complicated by a cerebral hemorrhage.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 30 (AP) -- St. Louis University won the Sugar Bowl basketball championship tonight, coming from behind in the closing moments to turn back Kentucky's national collegiate champions, 42 -- 40, in the final of the four-team tournament.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- Department store sales in the week ended Dec. 25 were 32 per cent above sales in the corresponding week of last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. This large increase reflects in part the fact that this year Christmas fell on Saturday, giving five days of heavy pre-Christmas shopping, compared with three days last year when Christmas fell on Thursday.

Despite the great increase in the number of hunters, of which a certain percentage falls into the classification of "trigger happy," the number of deaths and injuries sustained in the field is still well below that resulting from participation in most of the other popular sports.

Philippine restrictions on imports will mean a realignment of types of fabrics sold to that country, it was pointed out yesterday by textile exporters. They anticipate a considerable loss of dollar volume in rayon goods, they said, but pointed out that total yardage shipped to that market will hold up as the result of substitutions of lower priced goods.

ALBANY, Dec. 30 -- In a report on the operations of the State Public Works Department, Bertram D. Tallamy, superintendent, said today that 156 contracts for construction or reconstruction of 566 miles of highways for $85,073,000 had been let in 1948.

SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, Dec. 30 -- The Costa Rican Government has signed a new contract with the Costa Rican Banana Company, a subsidiary of the United Fruit Company. The contract, published today, obligates the company to extend its cocoa plantations by an additional 5,000 acres, and its African oil palms acreage by 3,000 during the next five years and to construct an experimental palm oil extraction plant within three years.

PARIS, Dec. 30 -- The European Council for the Marshall Plan approved today, but with some reservations, a laboriously drafted compromise report on the economic policies that might be followed during the remainder of the fouryear period of United States aid to enable Europe to pay its way by 1952.

Taking an obliging hint from Shakespeare, the makers of "Kiss Me, Kate" have put together a thoroughly enjoyable musical comedy, acted at the New Century last evening. Shakespeare has supplied a few bedraggled scenes from "Theh)0*0*0*iTaming of the Shrew."

A stockholders' suit to enjoin the American Woolen Company from putting into effect a retirement pension plan for salaried employes was dismissed yesterday by Federal Judge William Bondy after both sides had agreed to a stipulation modifying the plan.

Some smaller home furnishings stores and a few larger outlets have decided "at the last minute" to limit commitments to be placed at the Chicago home furnishings market to a maximum of sixty days, it was learned yesterday. Until a few days ago they were prepared to enter the market, which opens on Monday, on a ninety-day commitment basis, dealers said.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- President Truman made it clear today that Mme. Chiang Kaishek had failed, thus far, in her urgent plea for more American aid to China at once.

Marcus Wulkan, naturalized United States citizen, began a $250,000 libel suit yesterday against the British Iron and Steel Corporation, Ltd., as an outgrowth of an attack on his character by the British Attorney General before a British tribunal.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today that five companies had filed registration statements with it covering $62,500,000 of bonds and 2,730,460 shares of common stock.

Dr. William Edward Burghardt DuBois, 80-year-old stormy petrel of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, announced yesterday a transfer of allegiances to the left-wing Council on African Affairs, Inc., of 23 West Twenty-sixth Street.

Irving Caesar, once a well-known Tin Pan Alley lyricist, has in recent years been accomplishing the prodigious feat of getting young Americans to enjoy songs about safety, health and tolerance. His record albums are important fixtures in thousands of homes in this country.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Dec. 30 (AP) -Utah's basketball team closed a triumphant tour of the East tonight by defeating Cornell, 52 to 44, in the first game of a Memorial Auditorium double-header -- its eighth victory in nine starts this season.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- Stolen secrets of the American Government flowed steadily and in great volume weekly into the hands of Soviet agents for at least three years about a decade ago, the House Committee on Un-American Activities reported today.

Temporary city employes will be replaced as soon as possible by permanent employes appointed from civil service eligible lists but will suffer no pay cuts during their tenure as provisionals, Mayor O'Dwyer declared yesterday.

The city got a breathing spell yesterday in the threatened strike of 2,500 drivers of coal and fuel oil trucks and at the same time a full reprieve from the possibility of a strike originally scheduled for tomorrow that would have curtailed food deliveries to most of the city's independent groceries.

While debutantes of this seaonwere being feted last night at re!ceptions, dinners and dances, youngwomen of society who made theirdebuts a few seasons ago attendedthe Knickerbocker Assembly in themain ballroom of the RitzCarlton.The Assembly was the only one of"the Knickerbockers" planned forthis winter.

PASADENA, Calif., Dec. 30 (AP) Northwestern's Bob Voigts and Coach Lynn Waldorf of California met today at an annual clambake, styled the kick-off luncheon, but both refrained from shedding any light on the Rose Bowl football struggle on Saturday.

Attacking as "grossly unethical" the methods used by automobile finance companies in repossessing automobiles, the December term of the Brooklyn grand jury proposed yesterday a three-point program of reform.

Seven of the eighty-eight runners entered in the handicap mile event at the Metropolitan A.A.U. open games to be held at the 102d Engineers Armory next Wednesday night were given scratch rating by Handicapper Phil Keeley yesterday.

James Lees Sons Carpet Company yesterday increased prices of its carpet lines approximately 3 per cent, effective Jan. 3. Company spokesmen said the increase is necessary because of higher materials costs, particularly in carpet wools.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was moderately active yesterday and prices at the close were eleven points lower to eight points higher.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 (AP) -The House Interstate Commerce Committee recommended today United States financial aid in the development of Mexican oil fields.

Employer and union representatives in the city's millinery industry, which has not had a major strike since 1919, signed a new threeyear, nostrike agreement at City Hall yesterday. The contract, which provides a 10 per cent wage increase and other benefits, covers 14,000 workers in 650 shops in New York and northern New Jersey.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 30 -- Counsel for Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer Studios today confirmed their intention of appealing the decision of the Federal District Court here ordering the reinstatement of Lesterh)0*0*0*iCole, suspended screen writer.

As an "object lesson to others who are inclined to deliberately flout the law," Federal Judge Leo F. Rayfiel in Federal court, Brooklyn, sentenced yesterday two youths to a year and a day in a Federal penitentiary on their pleas of guilty to failing to register for the peacetime draft.

The New York Rangers will be at home tonight, opposing their traditional New Year's Eve opponents, the Boston Bruins. With the fortunes of the local sextet appearing brighter in their past few performances, it is expected that a capacity crowd of more than 15,000 will visit Madison Square Garden to see the Blue Shirts in action.

DALLAS, Tex., Dec. 30 (AP) -Southern Methodist and Oregon are ready for the Cotton Bowl game on Saturday with their teams in top physical condition except for one man. S.M.U. has lost its veteran offensive center, Fred Goodwin, with a torn knee cartilage, but has a strong replacement in Sam Wood, 190 pounds.

Howard Lindsay, chairman of the Arts Division of the Americans for Democratic Action made public yesterday copies of telegrams to President Truman and leaders of the Senate and House of Representatives, calling for reform in Congressional procedures.

The long record of managementlabor harmony in the men's clothing industry was carried forward yesterday when the New York locals of the Amalgamated Clothing Workers, CIO, sponsored a testimonial luncheon at the Brevoort Hotel for Simon Ackerman, a leading clothing manufacturer.

BOSTON, Dec. 30 -- Paramount Pictures, Inc., announced today the sale of its "entire interest" in a chain of fifty New England motion picture theatres to the American Theatres Corporation, formerly called the New England Theatres Operating Corporation.

Despite increased borrowings by sales finance companies, business loans by banks in this area declined $13,000,000 during the week ended on Wednesday. The report, issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, based on the weekly statement of assets and liabilities of the twenty-five New York City member banks, listed the banks' current total of commercial, industrial, and agricultural loans at $5,609,000,000.

DETROIT, Dec. 30 (AP) -- Canada and Italy challenged formally today for the Harmsworth Trophy, held by Gar Wood for the United States since 1920, and a 1949 renewal of the world's premier speed boat racing event thus was assured.

A lone gunman entered the eleventhfloor jewelry office of Oscar Fingerhut at 145 West Forty-fifth Street yesterday afternoon and, after striking Mr. Fingerhut twice on the head, escaped with an estimated $25,000 in diamonds.

Mr. and Mrs. Donald E. Leith of 520 East Eighty-sixth Street gave a dinner with dancing last night to present Mrs. Leith's daughter, Miss Carlys Ann King. The fete took place in the residence of Mr. and Mrs. Cecil Rhodes, long friends of the family, at 100 East Sixtyfifth Street.

A syndicate headed by Sol Henkind has resold the thirteen-story apartment building at 103 East Eighty-sixth Street, adjoining the northeast corner of Park Avenue, to a group of investors headed by Simon Bond. The sellers bought the property about nine months ago through Jack Stein, broker, who also made the resale.

The annual Golden Gloves boxing tournament will get complete television coverage over WPIX with a series of fifteen pick-ups, beginning with the preliminary bouts on Jan. 11 and continuing through the Intercity Championships on March 28.
NANKING, Dec. 30 (AP) -- The Communists' "war criminals" list was reported today to have caused Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek to determine angrily to continue theChinese civil war.

Grocers and butchers have slashed prices of basic foodstuffs drastically during the last six months in line with a corresponding decline in wholesale food prices, a survey of twenty-five cities revealed yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- President Truman today continued the mystery surrounding his statement that certain Russian leaders desired an understanding with the United States, refusing to amplify or explain it. He spiked one sensational rumor, however, that Vice President-Elect Alben W. Barkley's trip to Europe had been to prepare the groundwork for a Soviet-American settlement.

The stir that precedes the birth of a year increased yesterday all through the nation. Railroads began adding sections and air lines set up extra flights for holiday travelers, while hotel lobbies, neighborhood butcher shops and liquor package stores bustled with preparations for tonight's celebrations.

SEOUL, Korea, Dec. 30 -- The Soviet-crontrolled North Korea radio has begun a series of broadcasts explaining to the Korean people what it calls "the trueimeaning" of the United States economic aid program for Korea, recently ratified in an agreement.

The State Division of Placement and Unemployment Insurance is seeking an "advance" of $1,000,000 in state funds to prevent a collapse of its jobplacement service to employers and unemployedh)0*0*0*iworkers as a result of Federal appropriation cuts.

Despite increased costs and unstabilized world conditions, New Yorkers contributed well over $100,000,000 in 1948 to various local philanthropic fund raising drives. However, most of the campaigns failed to reach the goals set.

Scholarly discussion took a salty turn yesterday at the sixty-third annual Modern Language Association meeting when a former sailor, now teaching German literature to college students, read a paper on expressions used in the Navy in World War II.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- Following is the text of the report of the House Committee on UnAmerican Activities concerning espionage in the Government:

The Public Service Commission gave a New Year's present yesterday to most of the electricity consumers in the city by ordering a flat 10 per cent cut in the light bills rendered to them by the Consolidated Edison Company. The reduction was ordered effective Jan. 10.

Cardinal Spellman offered a "creed for capital and labor" yesterday at a Labor and Management Day luncheon of the Manhattan American Heritage Committee at the Cardinal Restaurant, 212 West Fifty-seventh Street.

GENEVA, Dec. 30 -- A purge of the Polish Administration to root out elements of doubtful loyalty to the Communist party objectives has been set for January, according to United Nations sources here in close touch with Eastern developments.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 30 (AP) -Although essentially it is a running team, Oklahoma may go into the air against North Carolina in the fifteenth annual Sugar Bowl football game on Saturday. In romping over nine straight opponents after an opening defeat the Big Seven champions had little need to supplement their strong ground game.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 30 (AP) -- A crowd of 8,822 at Tropical Park had a difficult time deciding whether to install Scipio or the Realtor-Kerry entry favorite in today's Shancrotha Purse, but when the six-furlong feature was over, Dr. Reed's number was on top for a $44.80 payoff.

Holiday liquor sales are expected to break even with those of last year despite early sluggishness, a survey of package stores disclosed here yesterday. Although sales during the first three days this week were slow, a pick-up was noted yesterday, and retailers are expecting a last-minute rush today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- In a move without precedent, Democrats in control of the incoming Senate are preparing to surrender a seat on the highly important Labor and Public Welfare Committee to enable a Republican, Senator Irving M. Ives of New York, to retain his committee post.

Still undefeated and playing at top form Dr. Reuben Fine of this city wrested the undisputed lead from Miguel M. Najdorf of Buenos Aires and administered the first setback sustained by the Polish master from Argentina in the seventh round of the tournament at the Manhattan Chess Club, last night.

A pair of outsiders, Pablo Eisenberg and Richard Dakin, continued their giant-killing roles yesterday in the Eastern junior and boys' indoor tennis tournament on Nick's courts in the Fifteenth Regiment Armory and thereby gained the final round, slated for today, in their respective divisions.

The stock market became enmeshed yesterday in a series of cross currents which left prices fairly level with the previous close. During the morning there was a slight advance, but this was largely eliminated by pressure in the afternoon.
A check for $250,000 was presented yesterday to Mrs. Bessie Gotsfeld by the National Board of the Mizrachi Women's Organization of America.

MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 30 (AP) -- Expectation of a passing duel between Texas and Georgia was strengthened by developments today that included a Weather Bureau forecast of "fair and warmer, around 70 degrees" for the Orange Bowl football game Saturday.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 (AP) -- A loan of $4,000,000 to the Republic of Haiti was announced today by the government-owned Export-Import Bank.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- The Interstate Commerce Commission authorized today a temporary increase of about 6 per cent in railroad freight rates pending action on the carriers' petition for a 13 per cent rise. The roads had asked for an 8 per cent interim increase.

Local 333, United Marine Division, which represents 3,500 tug workers in this port, rejected yesterday an employer offer of a 6 per cent wage increase, and described it as "wholly inadequate." The tug owners' offer was double their previous counter-proposal, but it contained no increase for Great Lakes workers.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 30 -Gloria Swanson, Erich von Stroheim and Montgomery Clift will appear in "Sunset Boulevard," the photoplay about Hollywood which Charles Brackett and Billy Wilder are preparing at Paramount, if negotiations are successful, it was learned today.

CLEVELAND, Dec. 30 -- The United States must face economic realities in planning its military security programs, economists studying the problems those programs present warned in addresses before the American Economic Association today.

Seven firemen and four other persons were injured yesterday afternoon in two explosions and a fire in a Bay Ridge, Brooklyn, garage. The injuries mostly were slight, and only one fireman remained in the hospital last night.

When withholding for federal income taxes became effective a few years ago, some workers demanded that their wages and salaries be increased to insure their receiving in future the same carry-home pay as before. Some even threatened to strike unless this was done.
ARCADIA, Calif., Dec. 30 (AP) -Mr. Ace won the Santa Anita feature, a six-furlong dash over a slow track in 1:12 2-5 today.

Hide futures continued to advance in yesterday's trading on Commodity Exchange. Abetted by commission house buying, particularly in the March delivery, prices at the close were 30 to 60 points higher. Steadiness of spot prices in the western markets was considered a factor in the firmness of the futures here.

Regardless of what 1948 has brought other New Yorkers, the city's weatherman will close his record books at the stroke of midnight tonight on a year that has been meteorologically speaking, a humdinger.

The three-year no-strike agreement signed at City Hall by representatives of 650 millinery manufacturers in the metropolitan area and 14,000 members of the Millinery Workers Union, AFL, is another heart-warming indication of the high level of industrial maturity that prevails among employers and unions in the city's apparel trades.

LONDON, Dec. 30 -- The visit of Robert Schuman, French Foreign Minister, to London on Jan. 13 is regarded here as the opening international event of a difficult and perhaps crucial year. There have been impatience, criticism and discouragement about France during the last few years in Britain, but Foreign Secretary Bevin, like his predecessors for decades, has made it clear that the basis for Britain's European policy must be AngloFrench cooperation.

OTTUMWA, Iowa, Dec. 30 (AP) -Sales and operating revenues of John Morrell Co., meat packers, reached a record high of $296,122,859 in the fiscal year ended on Oct. 30, G. M. Foster, president, reported to stockholders today. The former high was $286,072,041, set last year.

A vacant plot of land, 180 by 200 feet, on the south side of Sixtyfourth Avenue, about 276 feet east of 102d Street, in Forest Hills, Queens, has been purchased by William Soling, Louis Gordon and Irving Seidman for improvement with garden type apartments.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- State Department sources retorted today to criticism by German leaders of the Allied agreement for control of the Ruhr with an expression of hope that the Germans would understand the possibilities for an improvement in their own welfare through carrying out the terms of the agreement.

Charges that Howard Scott, director and chief of Technocracy, Inc., 155 East Forty-sixth Street, had displayed "an unquenchable thirst for power" and had received "excessive compensation in the guise of an expense account" were made yesterday in Supreme Court by Albert W. Atwater, a former assistant director of the organization, and Charles S. Horan who claims membership.
WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Dec. 30 A new channel for exploration in determining legal heirs to estates of the late Ignace Jan Paderewski and his sister, the late Mme. Antonina Wilkonska, was opened today.

There is a lesson for the United States in the tragic happenings in progress now in Indonesia. The present United States support of the Republic of Indonesia in the Security Council comes eighteen months too late. Had the United States taken a similar stand at the time of the first Dutch "police action" against the Republic in July, 1947, there might now be peace in the Indies instead of war.

Federal Judge Sylvester J. Ryan refused yesterday to transfer the Kaiser-Frazer Corporation's $19,276,069 damage suit against Otis Co. of Cleveland, investment bankers, to the Federal Court in Cleveland.

An increasing number of fraudulent sales-stimulator schemes are being revived as sharper competition develops, it was asserted yesterday by Kenneth B. Willson, operating manager of the National Better Business Bureau.

ALBANY, Dec. 30 Widely divergent views on methods to be used in financing a system of disability benefits and on the coverage such a system should provide were voiced today at a conference between Governor Dewey and spokesmen for organized labor.

City College retained the Intercollegiate Chess League championship yesterday by finishing with a score of 21 -- 7. The Beavers topped the list of fifteen teams in the annual tournament for the Harold M. Phillips trophy sponsored by the United States Chess Federation that ended last night at John Jay Hall, Columbia University.

KANSAS CITY, Dec. 30 (AP) -- A southpaw hook shot by Paul Courty with a minute and a half remaining proced the winning basket as Oklahoma's Sooners defeated the Kansas Jayhawks, 52 to 49, for the Big Seven Conference basketball tournament championship tonight.

BERLIN, Oct. 30 -- German authorities in the Soviet zone have instituted criminal proceeding against Ilse Koch, the witch of Buchenwald, an official United States military government report disclosed today.
LONDON, Dec. 30 -- Conditions generally were cheerful in the stock market again here today.

PARIS, Dec. 30 -- L. N. Palar, head of an Indonesian Republic delegation to the United Nations Security Council, charged today that the impending visit to Indonesia of the Netherlands Prime Minister, Willem Drees, was aimed at creating "a smoke screen to prevent foreign intervention either by the Security Council or by other individual countries or groups of countries."

A 13yearold boy who had beenh)0*0*0*iscolded by his older sister for quarreling with a younger brother was found hanged yesterday afternoon in the basement of his Brooklyn home an hourandahalf after the reprimand.
PRINCETON, N.J., Dec. 30 - -- The Princeton and Colgate sextets battled to a 4-4 draw tonight after a ten-minute overtime period in Baker Rink.

NICOSIA, Cyprus, Dec. 30 -- The perennial question of the union of Cyprus with Greece has taken a new twist, with Turkish student and press agitation for the island's return to the Turks if the British should ever give it up. The Turkish counter-claims have aroused varied and lively reactions here.

Mayor O'Dwyer announced yesterday the appointment of Alexander E. Frontera of Queens as City Collector to succeed John J. Fagan. Mr. Fagan resigned several weeks ago while his office was under investigation in connection with theh)0*0*0*isale of real estate tax liens.

LONDON, Dec. 30 -- The facts of life about Soviet diplomacy were given today by Christopher Mayhew, Parliamentary Under-Secretary for Foreign Affairs, to a young audience of "tomorrow's" citizens. It was the first of a series of holiday lectures organized by the Council for Education in World Citizenship.

Business in the building materials industry was exceptionally good in 1948, and the immediate outlook is encouraging, Herbert Abraham, president of the Ruberoid Company, declared yesterday in a year-end statement.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- The United States Air Force announced today the purchase, for delivery in about two years, of twenty-three new cargo planes, the Boeing C-97 Stratofreighters, to replace transports being rapidly worn out by their strenuous assignment on the Berlin airlift.

Simplified designs and clearer colors, plus several technical improvements, are making budgetpriced paper draperies suitable for almost any room in the home. New designs planned especially for living and dining rooms augment the pastel floral prints of the past and the patterns in cottage styles for kitchens.

LONDON, Dec. 30 -- Three-power discussions will be held here in January to attempt to resolve disagreements over the occupation statute for Western Germany. This became known here today While Gen. Sir Brian Robertson, British Military Governor in Germany, was conferring with Foreign Secretary Bevin.

ALBANY, Dec. 30 -- Governor Dewey disclosed today that the Port Authority of New York had appealed to him to use his influence to discourage any legislative move that would have an immediate bearing on the authority's immunity from suit.

Austin S. Igleheart, president of the General Foods Corporation, and Harold H. Helm, president and director of the Chemical Bank and Trust Company, have been elected to the board of directors of the Commercial Solvents Corporation, it was announced yesterday by Theodore P. Walker, chairman of the board.
Two employes of the Pennsylvania Railroad, who have served a total of 110 years, retired yesterday.

Beverly Somach, extraordinarily gifted 13-year-old violinist of this city, gave a recital last night at Town Hall. In an extremely exacting program, the young artist made a profound impression by the remarkable maturity of her interpretations, her innate musicality and technical proficiency.

Creditors' claims against Irving Poretz, so-called "master-plotter" in a $600,000 finance company windle, were compromised yesterday. Irwin Kurtz, referee in bankruptcy, signed an order in the United States Courthouse approving the settlement.

BERLIN, Dec. 30 -- An abrupt switch in tactics on the part of the Socialist Unity (Communist) party is indicated in an interview with its chairman, Wilhelm Pieck, in this morning's edition of Neues Deutschland, organ of the group.

CHICAGO, Dec. 30 (AP) -- Eight football players were killed during the 1948 season on the nation's high school gridirons, according to a report presented to the National Federation of State High School Athletic Associations today by A. A. Schabinger, Chicago.

The new year will be here at any moment, and with it will come the blackest half-hour of all '49. This gloomiest of periods luckily is short, lasting only from midnight until 12:30, and since it opens the year it luckily soon is over.

The United States Treasury issued yesterday a $311,000,000 call on its War Loan accounts, based on balances as of the close of business on Wednesday. Under its terms, the Class A banks will be required to provide 50 per cent of such deposits on Jan. 6.

The passenger business of the Alcoa Steamship Company during 1948 was described as the best year in the company's history -surpassing even the high mark set in 1947 -- in an annual statement by the company here yesterday.

The World Jewish Congress has asked the State Department to investigate the arrest of six leaders of the Jewish community of Sanaa, the capital of Yemen, in connection with the finding of the bodies of two Arab girls, it was announced yesterday.

We have long felt that the New York City Government failed, just as other big business has failed, to tell its story adequately to the public. It is a pleasure to note, therefore, that several departments are doing a better job in public relations than formerly. We believe the people have little understanding of the extent and diversity of services performed for them by their municipal government.

In line with efforts to unify theh)0*0*0*iarmed forces, the Government has also undertaken to unify our foreign policies, in particular the foreign economic and military aid programs that are destined for further expansion to safeguard our security and to meet our new responsibilities.

VIENNA, Dec. 30 -- Matyas Rakosi, Communist party leader and Deputy Prime Minister of Hungary, will resign shortly to become leader of the Communist Information Bureau, according to Hungarian refugees who recently fled from Vienna.
The students and parents of students of the Riverdale Country School at Riverdale-on-Hudson, N.Y., sent $800 yesterday to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 (AP) -- It is time for James Forrestal, Secretary of Defense, to "start knocking some heads together" and get the armed forces really unified, Representative Walter G. Andrews, Republican, of New York, said today.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- During the week ended Dec. 29, member bank reserve balances increased $339,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

Frank J. Looney, a Presidential Elector for the State of Louisiana, in his letter published in THE TIMES recently, quotes an ethics text-book written by Father Hill, S. J., and once used in Jesuit schools, to justify his statement that the FEPC is destructive of the rights of man.

The concert of the PhilharmonicSymphony Orchestra which Charles Munch directed last night in Carnegie Hall ended with its most important composition -- the Fourth Symphony of Arthur Honneger, then heard for the first time in America.

BERLIN, Dec. 30 (UP) -- A longrange program under which United States and German Government officials, health and welfare workers, university professors and students will exchange visits was announced today by the United States Military Government.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- A report from the Joint Congressional Committee on Labor-Management Relations, summarizing a year and a half's observation of the TaftHartley Law, said today the law was working well and recommended eight or more amendments to perfect its intent.

CAIRO, Dec. 30 -- Anglo-Egyptian negotiations to determine the amount of Egypt's frozen sterling balances that Britain will release in 1949 and the part that will be convertible into dollars began here today.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Dec. 30 -- As no official word had been received here tonight on the United Nations Security Council's cease-fire order, fighting continued in the Negeb, desert area in southern Palestine, and the news blackout was as severe as ever.
Two ways of starting the New Year right by saving lives were suggested yesterday by the Red Cross and the Greater New York Safety Council.

TOKYO, Dec. 30 Dr. Shumel Okawa, the man who slapped the former dictator, Hideke Tojo, was released from an insane asylum today. Thus he became the only one of the top twenty-eight Japanese war trial defendants to go free.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Dec. 30 (AP) -- Western Germany's exports have more than trebled in the last year, and now the area is paying for nearly half of its huge imports, according to a year-end report made today by William John Logan, head of the joint, exportimport agency that handles West Germany's foreign trade.

LAKE SUCCESS, Dec. 30 -- During the coming year, the International Refugee Organization will be faced with the problem of finding homes for thousands of "unemployable" refugees, William Hallam Tuck, director general of the relief agency, warned today.
NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 30 (AP) -Athletes from Texas and Louisiana schools dominated the Sugar Bowl track meet today, two victories of the five events going to each of those states.

Leopold Stokowski and Dimitri Mitropoulos have been named the regular conductors of the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra for the season of 194950, Charles Triller, chairman of the board, announced yesterday.

AL SCHACHT described the situation perfectly, except that he was applying it to himself rather than to the various bowl games which will be played on the morrow. He tells a quite hilarious tale of his debut in the big leagues when he was suddenly dispatched to the mound as a relief pitcher with the bases full and Harry Heilmann at bat. Ed Gharrity, the catcher, walked out to meet him.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- An investigation by the Department of Justice of practices of the legitimatetheatre industry that might run counter to the anti-trust laws is under way, it was learned today.

CHICAGO, Dec. 30 -- Eugene A. Tracey resigned today as president of Majestic Radio and Television Corporation, which is in reorganization under bankruptcy laws in United States District Court. The announcement of Mr. Tracey's resignation was made by John E. Dwyer and Donald J. Walsh, courtappointed trustees of the company.

" Jungle Jim," the first in a series of outdoor-action dramas starringh)0*0*0*iJohnny Weissmuller in the title role, will have its local premiere this morning at the Ambassador. William Berke directed and Sam Katzman produced from a story and screen play by Carroll Young and the newspaper feature of the same name.

Agreement that compromise is possible over the differences between the American way of life and European cultures, even while these differences are exaggerated by the present conflict between this nation and Russia, was reached by participants in the radio forum of THE NEW YORK TIMES, "What's On Your Mind," held Wednesday evening.

HARRISBURG, Pa., Dec. 30 (UP) -- High School sports are in danger of major scandal unless action is taken to control gamblers betting on school contests, Mark N. Funk, president of the Western Pennsylvania Interscholastic Athletic Association, said today.

The four-story building at 119 Seventh Avenue, Brooklyn, containing a store and six apartments, has been sold by Clarence Gilmore to Jeeves, Inc. Robert Levinson was the broker. The property is assessed at $29,000.

Weather conditions, which delayed the rescue of the twelve airmen stranded on a Greenland ice cap, wrecked plans yesterday for a reunion of Lieut. Col. Emil G. Beaudry, pilot of the jet-assisted C-47 rescue plane, and his wife, Eva.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, Dec. 30 (AP) -- The Hungarian Communist newspaper Szabad Nep said today that Joseph Cardinal Mindszenty "is the greatest and most reckless enemy of the Hungarian people and the agent of our most wicked enemies."

Henry A. Wallace, former Progressive party nominee for President, attacked yesterday Secretary of Defense James Forrestal's plea for greater authority over the three armed services and wider discretion for the President and the Government in providing military assistance to friendly nations.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 (AP) -Postage rate changes, which will add an estimated $125,000,000 to the nation's annual mailing bill, go into effect Saturday, Jan. 1.

NANKING, Dec. 30 -- President Chiang Kai-shek's ghost writer, Tao Hsi-sheng, was reported today to be still making revisions in the President's traditional New Year statement. Amid the unrelieved gloom of the civil war crisis the capital anxiously awaited word from the 62-year-old Generalissimo himself on future Government policy with regard to the Communists.

You ran a letter recently signed J.O.G., jogging the Mayor to appoint a special commission to survey and report on scenic and historic sites "still left" in the city "before it is too late." This dreary warning opens up a dismal vista of stealthy official removal of priceless hydrocephalic bronze heads from public places and sale of ancient landmarks to junk yards.

In deference to tradition, New Year's Eve always has been singled out as the biggest night in the theatre. Prices are jacked up and a merry rush ensues for coveted pasteboards to hit attractions. It is no secret that attendance has been off in 1948.

ALBANY, Dec. 30 -- Governor Dewey announced today the designation of Supreme Court Justice Francis Bergan, a Democrat, of Albany, as a member of the Appellate Division, Third Department, which for several years has consisted entirely of Republicans.
PARIS, Dec. 30 -- France today moved nearer to passage of a balanced budget bill, which will be set forth as her major claim to undiminished aid under the Marshall Plan.
TEL AVIV, Dec. 30 (AP) -- United Nations observers reported today that Gaza, main Egyptian base in Palestine, was virtually surrounded by Israeli forces.
A new pension plan for Norwegian seamen will become effective with a start of the new year, the Norwegian Information Service announced here yesterday.
PRAGUE, Dec. 30 (AP) -- The sixtieth birthday of Archbishop Josef Beran, celebrated here yesterday with a high mass in St. Vitus Cathedral, went virtually unnoticed by the Prague press.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- In the Presidential campaign of 1948 the Republican campaign management decided in effect on what lawyers call a plea of nolo contendere to the violent charges made against the Taft-Hartley Act by President Truman and the political leaders of labor unions.

h)0*0*0*iATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Dec. 30 -- Mayor Joseph Altman urged today that luxury tax funds be used to build a municipal theatre here to provide more entertainment for visitors, particularly during the resort's off-seasons.

TRENTON, N.J., Dec. 30 -- Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll named three more cabinet members today on a temporary basis to fill out his administrative organization for the beginning of the new year. All are incumbents. Three other appointments remain to be made to the fourteen-member cabinet.

The Republic of Colombia is preparing to register with the Securities and Exchange Commission a new issue of national governmentguaranteed bonds intended to be exchanged for outstanding obligations of certain of the Republic's departments and municipalities, it was made known here yesterday.

Comes now the formal invitation to New Year's cocktails, promising the company of ladies in their semi-formal prettiest and gentlemen at their informal best. Above all, the promise is of splendid holiday conversation, both witty and profound, genuinely philosophical about life yet never too far removed from sentiment and romance.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- The Army, in an official review of the year's news, decided today that "the Battle of Berlin" was "the top story" of 1948.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 (AP) -- Congressional committee said today there is "every indication" that the supply of newsprint in 1949 and 1950 will be "tight, if not short."

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 31 (AP) -North Carolina and Oklahoma will collide in the fifteenth annual Sugar Bowl game tomorrow with the fate of both teams depending upon the physical well-being of Carolina's Charlie Justice.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- The State Department said today that the United States continued to support Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek as the head of the Republic of China and that there "is nothing hanging fire from this Government based on the Generalissimo's resignation."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- Prospects are good for continued high employment and production in 1949, although the employment peaks of 1948 may not be duplicated, the Bureau of Employment Security said today.

Duquesne's Iron Dukes, winners of all five of their games this season, will oppose Long Island University tonight in the feature contest of the basketball double-header in Madison Square Garden. It will be New York University vs. the University of Connecticut in the opener at 8 o'clock.
The role of the American merchant marine in the field of international trading is the major question facing the maritime industry this year.

A man being examined for a driver's license on a steep country road in Westchester last month suddenly "froze" to the wheel of his car and crashed through a railing. Only the fact that a heavy cable on the railing wrapped itself around the car and held it suspended in mid-air prevented the vehicle from rolling down a 150-foot embankment.

OTTAWA, Ont., Dec. 31 -- Although the growth of Canada's exports to the United States has been the outstanding feature of the year's trade, C. D. Howe, Minister of Trade and Commerce, in a year-end review writes, "If Canadian-American trade is to continue at its present high level it is of fundamental importance to Canada and also, I believe, to the United States to establish lower tariffs and a more flexible administration of tariffs.

BENNINGTON, Vt., Dec. 31 -Snow and freezing temperatures that moved into this area late today eased flood conditions that had threatened since 2 A. M. Flood waters receded as colder weather closed in after a thirty-seven-hour rainfall totaling 3.98 inches.

Your editorial of Dec. 13 dealing with the adoption of the Declaration of Human Rights by the General Assembly of the United. Nations very correctly referred to, the document as a "yet uncompleted task." It expressed the hope that the principles of the Declaration would soon be embodied in a treaty which would bind its signatories.

The willingness of a Negro family in the Bronx to accept into their home a sister and her two brothers as children of their own was hailed by the Riverdale Children's Association yesterday as a good omen for the coming year.
CHICAGO, Dec. 31 (AP) -- Five major football rule changes were adopted today in the final session of the football committee of the National Federation of High School Athletic Associations.

PARIS, Dec. 31 -- The interim report to the United States adopted yesterday by the European Council for the Marshall Plan commits the participating Governments to seek a common solution of Europe's economic problems, in the opinion of officials of the Economic Cooperation Administration here.

TOKYO, Dec. 31 -- Japanese political circles are now talking of a National Government -- a coalition of all parties except the Communists -- as the regime that should be formed after the general election on Jan. 23.

VIENNA, Dec. 31 -- An attempt by the Hungarian Government the day before yesterday to gain control of the Bench of Bishops of the Hungarian Catholic Church by compelling four of them to resign under threat of imprisonment was revealed today by an unimpeachable ecclesiastical source who succeeded in reaching Vienna.
PRINCETON, N. J., Dec. 31 -- Two goals in the overtime period gave Colgate a 5-3 victory over Princeton tonight. The same teams had battled to a 4-4 stalemate last night.

LONDON, Dec. 31 -- The midnight bells of New Year's Eve will ring out freedom for Britain's last three German prisoners of war -- who are all too sick to be repatriated. Officially they then will become alien civilians and thus will end the mighty influx of captured German fighting men that began Sept. 14, 1939, when Captain Lieutenant Gerhard Glattes, young U-boat-commander, stepped ashore on English soil as this country's first prisoner of war.

ROME, Dec. 31 -- Minister of Defense Randolfo Pacciardi declared to the Senate on July 7, this year, that all Italian war prisoners had already been returned on that date except a few held for trial in Russia as war criminals. The official view is that any who still are missing must be regarded as dead.

LONDON, Dec. 31 -- Sportsmen, scientists, authors, politicians and trade union leaders figured in the New Year's Honors List that was issued today for publication on New Year's morning. Although hundreds of Britons and Commonwealth citizens received titles and orders, this is in some ways the most meager and least sensational of the twenty-five honors lists since King George VI was crowned.

PARIS, Saturday, Jan. 1 -- Just before midnight, the French National Assembly by a vote of 327 to 244 adopted on its second and final reading a bill that sets the maximum figures for the ministerial departments during 1949.

In the role of a friendly critic "anxious to be as helpful as possible" to the radio and television broadcasting business, the radio committee of the Northern Baptist Convention offered some suggestions for the improvement of the Sunday night programs of both in two resolutions made public last night.

When the antics of the elements are confusing even to the veteran meteorologists at the Weather Bureau on Whithall Street, then imagine how perplexing they must be to the skier who attempts to analyze snow conditions for a week-end of sport -- especially over New Year's.
The Greater New York Fund announced yesterday it had voted a minimum grant of $150,000 with a possible $225,000 maximum toward the 1949 budget of the Welfare Council of New York City.
