They sang out the old year with a will at the Metropolitan Opera House last night. The season's first performance of "La Traviata" had so much fire and vitality that possibly it presaged better things for the new year. There have been some shaky performances thus far this season, but last night's "Traviata" was not one of them.
On the last day of the year the cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday closed steady, 1 to 6 points net higher.
LONDON, Dec. 31 -- Scottish pipers, have got their wind up.

A bold thief who got every break out-distanced a young patrolman yesterday and escaped with $75,000 jewelry and $5,000 cash from an armed holdup of Saul G. Barnett's store at 9 East Fifty-eighth Street, two doors east of the Savoy Plaza Hotel.

PARIS, Dec. 31 -- The last repatriation contingent of 630,000 German prisoners of war once held by the French was shipped off on Dec. 7 so as to be home for Christmas. This group of 2,900, however, left 137,057 compatriots who had decided to stay in France as free laborers.
DETROIT, Dec. 31 -- Traces of the competitive spirit, with hope for customers on the waiting lists, abounded this New Year's Eve in this citadel of the automobile world.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 (AP) -- The Senate Postoffice and Civil Service Committee called on Congress today to end discrimination against Negroes in Federal employment.
LONDON, Dec. 31 -- Although buyers were holding off until the start of the new account on next Wednesday, the stock markets here today finished the year on a cheerful note.

The right of the city to impose a sales tax on the renting of automobiles by a funeral director was upheld yesterday in a decision by Charles C. Lockwood, Official Supreme Court Referee, in a proceeding brought by the Buckley Funeral Home, Inc., in which the latter sought a review of a sales tax assessment of $307.

A warning against what she called "the gray market" in babies was issued yesterday by Mrs. Helen L. Buttenwieser, chairman of the New York City Committee on Adoptions. She estimated that hundreds of children each year were victims of this practice, which she said was far more prevalent than "the black market" in babies.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- Twenty naval vessels will begin "intensive" carrier task force maneuvers in the Atlantic next week, with fourteen of the force later proceeding to the Mediterranean Sea to relieve a similar fleet now in that area, the Navy announced today.

LONDON, Dec. 31 -- Youths in Britain who have lived most their lives in war and under a rigid austere code of the post-war years were told today by Lord Woolton, chairman of the Conservative party, that they ought to forego the pleasures of life.

BERLIN, Dec. 31 (AP) -- Lieut. Gen. G. S. Lukyanchenko, Soviet Chief of Staff in Germany, accused the Western Powers today of having retained many thousands of German war prisoners, but he was silent on Russia's own policy.

YONKERS, N. Y., Dec. 31 -- Declaring the duties he formally lay down today, after a month's viction, constitute a "tough job." City Manager Thomas V. Kennedy Yonkers filed his written resignation with City Clerk Francis Heafy.
New financing showed a marked contraction in December over recent months, with flotations of bonds the smallest in three months and offerings of new stock the smallest since July.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., Dec. 31 (AP) -- Melita Ramirez of Mexico City today defeated Dorothy Watman of Chicago, 6 -- 4, 11 -- 9, to capture the junior girls' championship in the Orange Bowl junior tennis tournament.

I note that discussions are being held in order to limit the power of the Rules Committee of the House of Representatives. I have long believed that one simple alteration should be made in the rules of both Houses. It seems improper that a bill which has passed one House can be held from consideration in the other by committee action of any kind.
TEL AVIV, Dec. 31 (AP) -- After a year of war in the Holy Land, the prospects are that at least one more campaign would have to be fought before peace comes, perhaps by spring.

Snow-veiled Times Square was only partly filled last night when the old year ended. Sharp winds, icy streets and low temperatures reduced the number of revelers to the lowest point on record. When the glowing globe, snow-curtained, started down the flagstaff on Times Tower turret at midnight to signal year's end, horns blasted and cowbells clanged, but their volume was low.
PALM BEACH, Fla., Dec. 31 (AP) -- Yale's varsity crew today won the second annual regatta of the Palm Beaches by a length. Cornell won the junior varsity event before a crowd estimated at 10,000.

SEOUL, Korea, Dec. 31 -- President Syngman Rhee, commenting on a Moscow report of the completion of the Soviet troop removal from North Korea, said today that he would "like to accept the report at its face value," but added: "I will have to confess, however, that our information concerning the withdrawal of the Soviet Army from Korea proves contrary to this report."
DALLAS, Dec. 31 (AP) -- Oregon and Southern Methodist, two high-powered football teams that like to toss the ball around, meet here tomorrow before 69,000 in the thirteenth annual Cotton Bowl game.

PRETORIA, South Africa, Dec. 31 -- United States policy toward Japan was one subject discussed when Premier Daniel F. Malan met Dr. Herbert V. Evatt, Australian Minister of External Affairs, in Capetown today. The ship taking Dr. Evatt home from the United Nations General Assembly meeting in Paris made a twelve-hour call in Table Harbor and the occasion was seized for both sightseeing and conversations.
Rubin Raskin, formerly with Noma Electric Company, has become general manager of the Franklin Body and Equipment Corporation, Brooklyn, manufacturer of refrigerated truck bodies and special cabinets.
ARCADIA, Calif., Dec. 31 (AP) -- Jockey Johnny Longden wound up the 1948 turf season today by shattering his own modern riding record.

ALBANY, Dec. 31 -- Governor Dewey appointed six farm leaders today to examine the State Fair Grounds at Syracuse with a view to determining the cost of conducting a "full" State Fair in 1949. The fair grounds are in a serious state of disrepair.

No doubt, ours is a temperamentally optimistic nation. Other peoples may approach new years with a degree of apprehension. Other peoples may remember other years which began with high hopes and ended in disappointment. But we are temperamentally youthful.

Brick production in 1948 showed an increase over the previous year and indications are that the supply will be plentiful during the remainder of the winter, W. J. Goodwin Jr., president of the Structural Clay Products Institute, declared yesterday.

PASADENA, Calif., Dec. 31 (AP) -Northwestern University's football stock took a slight turn upward today but California's warriors of the Blue and Gold remained confident of victory in the Rose Bowl tomorrow.

A campaign to bring 1,500 foreign students to this country during 1949 under the Displaced Persons Act is being organized by the nation's student groups, it was disclosed yesterday. The students, coming largely from camps in Austria and Germany, would, as DPs, be eligible for American citizenship.

Miss Rachel K. McDowell retired as religious news editor of THE NEW YORK TIMES yesterday because of ill health after having served in that capacity with distinction for more than twenty-eight years. She will be 69 years old on Jan. 11.

The forty-story Fuller Building at 595 Madison Avenue, northeast corner of Fifty-seventh Street, has passed to out-of-town investment interests with the purchase of a controlling interest in the Fuller Building Corporation by the Penroy Realty Company, headed by Kenneth S. Keyes, realtor of Miami, Fla., it was announced yesterday. It is assessed for $3,600,000 and was sold through the Durand Taylor Company, broker.

Repeating his success in the opening round, Nicholas Rossolimo of Paris yesterday took a 2-0 lead in the annual international chess masters tournament sponsored by the Hastings and St. Leonards Chess Club at the White Rock Pavilion, according to a report from England.

ALBANY, Dec. 31 -- Modernization of the state's "creaky" legislative machinery to end the jam of bills in the closing days of sessions was recommended today by Paul E. Fitzpatrick, chairman of the State Democratic Committee.

BERLIN, Dec. 31 -- Midnight tonight marks the expiration of the deadline set by four-power agreement for the discharge of the last German prisoners of war. It is a deadline that finds about a half million acknowledged prisoners still missing from their homes -- but with Poland and the Soviet Union as the only defaulters.

A number of the elements which figured prominently in making 1947 a year of vigorous inflation have recently lost some of their force. One of these, which has not received as much attention as it deserves, is that of foreign trade.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- Inventions numbering 689 were approved this week by the United States Patent Office, almost equaling the post-war weekly record of 698, established Dec. 14. The total number of patents issued now stands at 2,457,796, as against 2,433,824 at the end of 1947 and 2,413,674 in 1946.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 31 (AP) -- Barney Ewell, veteran sprint star who placed second in the Olympic 100 and 200-meter dashes, has been declared a professional.

Mr. and Mrs. Arthur A. Houghton gave a dance last night in their residence at 3 Sutton Place for two debutantes of the season -- Miss Jane Olmsted Houghton, daughter of the host, and Miss Patricia Rinehart, niece of Mr. Houghton

" Interlude," a Swedish - made psychological drama with dialogue in five languages -- English, Swedish, German, French and Italian -- will have its local premiere today at the Little Carnegie. Viveca Lindfors, who has since come to Hollywood under contract to Warner Brothers, is starred in the picture, which will introduce to American audiences Hasse Ekman.

Santa Claus usually leaves the feminine head of the household at least one electrical appliance -- a toaster, waffle iron or something similarly useful. (Pre-Christmas sales of toasters broke records this year.)

LAKE SUCCESS, Dec. 31 -- In an optimistic New Year's message issued here today Secretary General Trygve Lie of the United Nations predicted that 1949 would be a year of continued progress toward the goal -- permanent peace for the world.

LONDON, Dec. 31 -- British dentists taking part in the National Health Service in the future will have their earnings limited under new regulations announced here today by Aneurin Bevan, Minister of Health.

Northeastern hardwood lumber mills have been hard hit by the slump in the last quarter of the year in the furniture business, an industry spokesman reported yesterday. Furniture factories operating in the region are using up lumber inventories and practically no orders are being placed for hardwoods, he said.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- Average primary market prices declined 0.2 per cent during the week ended Dec. 28, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. The index is now 163.5 per cent of the 1926 average, 1.0 per cent lower than four weeks ago; the index has also gone below the level of one year ago for the first time in 1948.

Miss Columbia, a wood - carved statue of dubious renown, had wound up in the front window of a Washington real estate office. For thirty years she reputedly graced the Society of Tammany or the Columbian Order, according to its present owner, Leo M. Bernstein of 1415 K Street, North West.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 (AP) -- The Group Health Association, which was set up several years ago to provide prepaid medical care for Government workers and other Washingtonians, expanded today into the dental field.

LONDON, Dec. 31 -- A sweeping legislative measure, potentially affecting an estimated 539,000,000 members of the British Empire, will take effect here tomorrow when the new British Nationality Act comes into force. This act creates three new types of citizens: United Kingdom citizens, Commonwealth citizens and Irish citizens.
The Kelsey-Hayes Wheel Company reported yesterday in its statement of operations covering the quarter ended on Nov. 30, net profit of $1,294,829 after taxes and all deductions.

Crowds of holiday travelers, swelled by automobile and air groups who generally parked their cars and shunned the airlines because of the ugly weather, jammed major rail terminals last night in the annual mammoth New Year's Eve movement in and out of the city.

Forty-nine federal agencies provide medical care of some kind to millions in this country. So large is the number that a suspicion is engendered, now reinforced by the Committee on Federal Medical Services, that there must be considerable overlapping of work. There are about 24,000,000 beneficiaries of federal medical bounty, and of these eighteen and a half million are veterans.

TEL AVIV, Palestine, Dec. 31 -- While the Israeli Government was considering the cease-fire order of the United Nations Security Council, the battle of the Negeb, desert area in southern Palestine, developed into a rout of the Egyptians today.

A syndicate of Chicago investors represented by Samuel M. Sprafkin, a New York attorney, has purchased the nine-story building containing thirty-two apartments at 120 East Seventy-fifth Street. The E. M. Simon Company was the broker, and Harald West was the attorney for the seller.

PARIS, Dec. 31 -- Six distinguished Europeans agreed with more or less optimism tonight that there would be no war in Europe in 1949. They took part in a forum broadcast over the French National Network.
ATHENS, Dec. 31 (AP) -- Military and press reports said today the Greek Army was making progress against Communist guerrillas in the Peloponnesus region of southern Greece.

The New York Shipping Association and the International Longshoremen's Association completed yesterday final details of a welfare program benefiting 20,000 longshoremen in the Port of New York. The program, stipulated in the agreement that ended an Atlantic Coast dock strike in November, will go into effect today.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- Automobile manufacturers were criticized in a report to the House today for failing to put a stop to gray market operations of dealers.

NICOSIA, Cyprus, Dec. 31 -- The case of 7,000 Jews of military age fighting for their release from Cyrus detention camps came before the Supreme Court again today. It was adjourned to Jan. 8 after the Government presented its case that detention was necessary under the United Nations truce order of May 29.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- Secretary of Labor Maurice J. Tobin and union leaders greeted the New Year in statements today express-ing thankfulness for the nation's freedom and confidence in the future.

The six-story forty-two-family apartment house at 1655 Monroe Avenue, the Bronx, has been sold by the Mirgreen Construction Corporation to Benjamin H. Leibman, builder, who took title in the name of the Webster Housing Corporation, of which he is president. Sale was subject to a first mortgage of $90,500. James J. Leibman and William Rosan were attorneys for the buyer and William Allen acted for the seller.

Contracts between the American Society of Composers, Authors and Publishers and the radio broadcasters were automatically extended for another nine years last night when the society did not serve notice that it desired any changes in the agreement.
The fifty-year tenure of the Peter B. Olneys as Federal bankruptcy referees came to an end yesterday with the retirement of the second Olney to hold that post since 1898.

Although they failed to win, the New York Rangers showed improvement for their new coach at Madison Square Garden last night. Engaging the Boston Bruins in the second local National Hockey League game under the direction of Lynn Patrick, the home forces were able to gain a 2-2 tie with the Hub skaters.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 31 (AP) -- Federal Judge W. Calvin Chesnut ruled today that Alger Hiss' lawyers could continue to take depositions from Whittaker Chambers, admitted former Communist, despite a Government plea they might weaken the case against Mr. Hiss on charges of perjury.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 31 -- The third most massive system of double stars has been found by Dr. J. A. Pearce of the Dominion Astrophysical Observatory, Victoria, British Columbia, Canada. It is composed of two very luminous hot stars which have, respectively, masses estimated to be thirty-four times and twenty-eight times that of the sun.

BOSTON, Dec. 31 -- Torrential rains brought flash floods today to my communities along the banks of the Connecticut River and its tributaries. Colder weather moving in from the West tonight gave western New England hope of relief by morning.
BURLINGTON, Wis., Dec. 31 (AP) -- A narrative of a big blow in Alberta, Canada, today was designated the gustiest in the annual contest of the Burlington Liars Club, Inc.

Edward G. Robinson, the screen's "tough guy," is being paged for the title role in the contemplated revival of "The Auctioneer," the Lee Arthur-Charles Klein play of decades ago in which David Warfield rose to dramatic heights. The movie star is reported to be amenable to the stage offer.

NEWARK, N. J., Dec. 31 -- Three additional arrests today brought to a total of nine men who were accused of stealing large quantities of military weapons and ammunition from the Raritan Federal Arsenal near Metuchen, N. J.

Seven of the twelve United States Air Force fliers rescued from the Greenland icecap last Wednesday and two of their rescuers arrived at LaGuardia Airport yesterday, a scant two hours ahead of a snow store such as they had met regularly for the last three weeks.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- Men with records steadfastly backing President Truman in his leaner days before the election were chosen today by the Democrats of the Senate as their active floor leaders in the new Congress

A "compromise solution" to the controversial question of allocation of export licenses on fats and oils to South America has been suggested to the Office of International Trade by the Independent Merchant Exporters Association, it was disclosed yesterday by Louis I. Freed, executive secretary, with offices in Washington, D. C.
The year that has just ended no doubt will be the subject of many a learned essay. To aid future scholars, the following information was compiled yesterday afternoon:

Firemen were kept busy yesterday by two four-alarm fires, one in the Bronx and the other in the Washington Market district of Manhattan. In the Bronx blaze three firemen were overcome but remained on duty after treatment.
BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Dec. 31 (AP) -Favored Baylor of the Southwestern Conference and Wake Forest of the Southern will match their T models in the Dixie Bowl tomorrow with a high-scoring affair forecast.
CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 31 (AP) -- A daily double pay-off of $2,386 for $2 made the last day of the year one for today's crowd at Tropical Park to remember.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Dec. 31 -- The Yugoslav Government issued a statement tonight placing responsibility upon the Soviet Government for an unsatisfactory trade agreement signed in Moscow on Dec. 28 reducing the total volume of exchanges between the two countries by seven-eighths.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., Dec. 31 (AP) -The William and Mary Indians arrived today for their football scramble with Oklahoma A. and M. in the second annual Delta Bowl game here tomorrow -- and found themselves favored by 6 points.

Seven rounds of the internanational masters tournament at the Manhattan Chess Club were completed yesterday, when three games, adjourned from the sixth and seventh rounds, were played to a conclusion. In every instance a draw resulted without materially altering the relative positions of the ten contestants.
JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Dec. 31 (AP) -The fourth annual battle for the gator skin tomorrow afternoon matches Southern Conference football champion Clemson and Big Seven runner-up Missouri.
Many visitors and residents of the city went to the churches last night to watch the old year pass and the new year begin. Chimes and bells marked the hour of passing.

On July 5, 1935, with little discussion and without a record vote, Congress adopted the Wagner-Connery Labor Relations Act, better known simply as the Wagner Act. When this law was enacted it was freely predicted that, instead of ending labor disputes -- a claim flatly made on the law's behalf by its sponsors -- it would multiply them.
Following is the text of President Chiang Kai-shek's New Year's message as received in New York by the Chinese News service:
WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 (AP) -- Army engineers turned thumbs down today on proposed naviga!tion improvements for Sandy Hook Bay, New Jersey.

Benjamin Parry, principal meteorologist of the New York Weather Bureau, wound up forty-five years of Government service last night. He closed his desk in the bureau's offices on the twenty-ninth floor of the Whitehall Building, 17 Battery Place, and headed for his Lyndhurst, N. J., home -- and retirement.
FRANKFORT, Germany, Dec. 31 (AP) --Eight German war criminals who won last-minute reprieves from the gallows got their death sentences commuted to prison terms today.

The negotiating committee of Local 333, United Marine Division, which mans approximately 450 tugs in this port, rejected last night a third counter-offer made by the Marine Towing and Transportation Committee Employers Association, and set midnight of Jan. 12 as the deadline for a strike.

Markets in non-ferrous scrap, remelted aluminum, imported nonferrous war scrap and lead have turned soft at the year's end, but an upturn is expected in the first week in January, metals importers and refiners reported here yesterday.

ROCHESTER, N. Y., Dec. 31 (AP) -- A limit to the number of pickets at the Red Creek plant of the Comstock Canning Company and free access into the plant was ordered today by Justice John van Voorhis of the Supreme Court. He granted the motion of Comstock counsel for a temporary injunction to prevent pickets from interfering with movements in and out of the plant.

JERSEY CITY, N. J., Jan. 1 -- A walkout was called at midnight last night against the Hudson Boulevard Bus Owners Association by division 1276, Amalgamated Association of Street Electric Railway and Motor Coach Employes of America, AFL.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, Dec. 31 (UP) -- Hungary today called Acting Secretry of State Robert A. Lovett a liar, and denounced him and other United States officials as "accomplices" of Joseph Cardinal Mindszenty, who has been jailed on charges of being a traitor and a spy.

The combination of three days rain with melting snow and ice caused heavy damage from floods in northern New Jersey yesterday. Rivers and streams overflowed, roads were covered with water and blocked to traffic, bridges were closed, cellars were flooded, machinery and goods were damaged, three towns were isolated and 500 persons had to be evacuated.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 (AP) -- Installment credits increased $100,000,000 in November despite control restrictions and some reported easing off in sales that month, a Federal Reserve Board report showed today.

Plans for merging the Broadway Savings Bank and the West Side Savings Bank to create an institution with assets of approximately $68,000,000 are being considered, it was learned reliably yesterday. The development follows the announcement two weeks ago of a similar merger of the North River Savings Bank with the Bowery Savings Bank, increasing the latter's deposits to $777,000,000.

New York's Knickerbockers, who have the best defensive record in the Basketball Association of America, will have their defenses tested to the limit this afternoon at Madison Square Garden. They are booked to meet high-scoring Joe Fulks and the Philadelphia Warriors.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- House Republicans elected by acclamation today retiring Speaker Joseph W. Martin Jr. as their floor leader in the Eighty-first Congress. He then disclosed plans to infuse new blood into the high command by selecting half a dozen "young and vigorous" members as unofficial assistants.

Institution of special six-week "travel leaves" with full pay and expenses for employes with five or more years of service was announced yesterday by Buchanan Co., Inc., as the first step in a carefully devised program of extended employee benefits.

LONDON, Dec. 31 -- Looking ahead to the days when the Old Vic Theatre Company will be the nucleus of a new national theatre proposed for the south bank of the Thames, governors of the Old Vic company, under the chairmanship of Lord Esher, have decided to make changes in preparation for the expansion.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 (AP) -- The Army and Air Force have ordered families of their personnel to stop calling in military doctors every time junior sneezes.

PARIS, Dec. 31 -- Tomorrow will not be just the start of a new year to the French but, by law, the opening of a new era of hope for the landlords of the nation. Since the start of the late war the landlords have been required to charge much the same rent despite the plummeting in the actual value of the franc.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- Operators of non-subsidized American shipping would be brought much closer to parity with subsidized operators under a proposed legislative program presented to Congressional leaders today by George W. Morgan, president of the Association of American Ship Owners.

Prof. Albert Einstein, world-famed physicist and mathematician, was reported to be resting comfortably and in satisfactory condition late last night in the Jewish Hospital of Brooklyn after an operation at 8 A. M. yesterday. He is expected to leave the hospital in about two weeks.
SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 31 (UP) -- New earthquakes jarred the West Coast today, shaking San Francisco and a 300-mile stretch of California and sending fresh tremors through the earth at Reno, Nev.

The Columbia Broadcasting System diclosed yesterday that the total consideration involved in its business transaction with Jack Benny was $2,260,000, with the comedian's personal share amounting to $1,356,000.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 31 -- "Incident in Illinois,'' a story by James Edward Grant, has been purchased by Jack Skirball and Bruce Manning, independent film producers, it was learned today from George Willner. Grant's representative in the sale.

The recent decision of Mr. Justice Null in Hamilton vs. Moses, forbidding the Park Commissioner to demolish the Battery Fort or Castle Clinton without the approval of the Municipal Art Commission, is the next to the last round in the long, hard fight to save the Fort.

ATHENS, Dec. 31 -- W. Averell Harriman, roving ambassador for the Marshall Plan, told the local and foreign press here today that "progress is being made" in Greece toward recovery. He said he had come to acquire first hand knowledge before testifying to Congress.
Elections of Alfred J. Hoefer as a director and A. C. Verbeke as a vice president, filling vacancies left by the late Scott A. Holman, were announced yesterday by Libby, McNeill Libby, food canners.
The annual meeting and luncheon of the American Horse Shows Association will be held at the Waldorf-Astoria on Thursday. About 300 are expected to attend.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Dec. 31 -- At the hour set by the Netherlands for the termination of hostilities in Indonesia, in compliance with the order of the Security Council of one week earlier, persons in authority here were trying today to determine what the situation was.

HARTFORD, Conn., Dec. 31 -The valleys of three rivers in Connecticut were awash tonight as torrential rains and melting snow caused a record-breaking flood in the Naugatuck valley and near-record floods along the Housatonic end Farmington Rivers.
An anonymous contributor sent fifty shares of stock, valued at $2,637.84, to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund yesterday.
CHICAGO, Dec. 31 -- Musical education is an effective weapon against juvenile delinquency, music teachers in convention here were told today.
MAIMI, Fla., Dec. 31 (AP) -About the only people in Miami today who aren't talking football and the Orange Bowl are the ninety-five men who play for Texas and Georgia.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- Total United States aid to the Chinese Government since V-J Day was placed at $1,079,832,500 in an analysis by the American China Policy Association today. The figure compared with a Chinese Embassy estimate of $1,503,100,000, which excluded as "business transactions" military and naval equipment costing $935,000,000, for which the Chinese paid $199,000,000.

A flash four-hour strike paralyzed all operations of the Hudson Manhattan Railroad yesterday, forcing thousands of commuters and holiday travelers to scramble for alternative transportation means at the peak of the storm.

A new novel by Pearl Buck, entitled "Kinfolk," has been scheduled for spring publication by John Day. The story, the scenes of which alternate between New York and China, deals with today's spreading civil war in China, the growth of rebellion among Chinese young men and women and the gulf between the intellectual and the common people.
A double-barreled storm hit large parts of New York, New Jersey and New England yesterday with two kinds of bad weather.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- The United States Book Exchange, a private corporation formed to centralize international exchange of books, is opening for business with the new year.

The continued steady climb of the break-even point in all food operations from manufacturing to distributing is a danger signal, M. L. Toulme, executive vice president of the National-American Wholesale Grocers Association, warned yesterday.

The Southern Governors' Conference at its meeting at Savannah adopted a regional plan for higher education which actually is the Southern region's answer to its racial perplexity arising out of the Supreme Court's rulings in the Gaines and Sipuel cases. Three years ago the Conference officially recognized that the Court had "ruled unequivocally that every state must maintain equal educational facilities within its own borders, if demanded, for all citizens similarly qualified."

NANKING, Dec. 31 -- In what was regarded here as the most tragic statement of his entire career Generalissimo Chiang Kaishek declared tonight that the Central Government of China would be "only too glad" to discuss with the Communists means to end the civil war if they "are sincerely desirous of peace, and clearly give such indication."
WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- The three Western Allies -- Britain, France and the United States -- are preparing notes to the Soviet Government asking it to account for all German prisoners...

This letter is a reply to criticisms by THE NEW YORK TIMES of my views on profits as presented to a Joint Congressional Committee on the Economic Report (THE TIMES, Dec. 9, 1948). The main issues revolve around the adequacy of profits.

All employes of the municipal transit system in twenty-seven annually-paid classifications will receive overtime pay hereafter at the rate of time-and-a-half, under a resolution adopted yesterday by the Board of Transportation.

William Long and Donald Thompson, the top-seeded players in the junior and boys divisions, respectively, came through as expected in their final-round matches yesterday to gain the individual titles in the Eastern indoor tennis championships at the Fifteenth Regiment Armory.

Prices were marked down steadily yesterday on the stock market as the year 1948 glided down and out of the late attempt at a December rally. Losses on the Stock Exchange were mostly fractional, although some reached a point, and the composite rate showed a drop of 0.38 point on the day, which increased the total recession for the year to 3.67 points.

The National Urban League, an organization for social work among Negroes, reported yesterday a falling off of gifts that will necessitate a reduction of staff operation and program activities. While individual memberships increased. A comparable increase in financial aid was not evident among corporation and foundation supporters," the statement read.

The annual Madison Square Garden Poultry Show entered its third day yesterday crowing over its own "success" as 6,000 birds strutted their fine feathers before several hundred rain-and-snow-bedraggled spectators.

All American, British and Canadian stock and commodity exchanges will be closed today, New Year's Day. About half the American exchanges, including the New York Stock and Curb Exchanges were open for full sessions yesterday.

ALBANY, Dec. 31 -- In a year-end statement, Commissioner Harold Keller of the State Department of Commerce predicted today that the economic prospect for the State in 1949 "is for continued prosperity at or near the levels established during the past six years, a period during which the State has enjoyed an unbroken prosperity that is almost unprecedented."
Active trading and advancing prices featured the hide futures market on Commodity Exchange yesterday. Closing prices were 45 to 75 points higher on a turnover of 114 contracts.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- The Republican - controlled Eightieth Congress, which President Truman had called the second worst in history and made of it a prime target in his successful election campaign, died quietly today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 (AP) -- Representative John W. McCormack, Democrat, of Massachusetts, said today he would make way for Representative William L. Dawson, Democrat, of Illinois, one of the two Negro members of Congress, to become chairman of the House Committee on Expenditures in the Executive Departments.
BATAVIA, Java, Saturday, Jan. 1 -- Dutch hostilities in Java, except against "rebellious elements," ended with the arrival of the New Year, Netherlands spokesmen announced today.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 31 (AP) -Gridiron stars representing the East and West -- picked warriors who earned their places on college fields this year -- will clash here tomorrow for the greatest prize of all -- the satisfaction of playing for the benefit of the Shriners crippled children's hospitals.

A call for 100 volunteers for reconstruction work in Europe next summer has gone out to Christian young men and women over 18 years old from the American section of the World Council of Churches, 297 Fourth Avenue.
LONDON, Saturday, Jan. 1 -Celebrated Big Ben boomed the old year out and the new one in here as winds blew and rain pelted down.

GROTON, Conn., Dec. 31 (AP) -- The body of Edward Allen Olds Jr., 69, Mystic industrialist, was found in his auto in a gully here today and state police launched an investigation to determine cause of death.

PATCHOGUE, L. I., Dec. 31 -- Miss Ruth Kaminski, 19, of Port Jefferson, who was being taken to a physician's office after cutting a finger, ended up in a hospital today after the car in which she was riding was struck by another car at Thorne Street and Jayne Avenue here.

The new year "begins a new era in relations between Holland and Indonesia" which, a year from now, "will also be hailed as the cornerstone of East-West cooperation and of anti-Communist resistance in the Far East," Dr. Herman J. Friedericy, head of the political department, Netherlands Ministry of Overseas Territories, declared here yesterday.
PELHAM MANOR, N. Y., Dec. 31 -- New obstacles for motorists trying to dodge tolls on the Hutchinson River Parkway here were set today by village officials.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- Arthur J. Goldberg, general counsel of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, said today the report of the Joint Congressional Committee on Labor-Management Relations was a "whitewashing" job by "a discredited committee of the discredited Eightieth Congress."

Although transactions on the New York Stock Exchange in 1948 increased to 302,218,965 shares, compared with 253,623,894 shares in 1947, the volume of business for the year was smaller than for 1946 or 1945. In the record year of 1929, 1,124,990,980 shares were dealt in.

Facts and figures on today's football bowl games, giving names of bowls, sites, competing teams with records in parentheses, kickoff times (all times Eastern standard); probable attendances, probable receipts and radio broadcasts:
WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- Former President Herbert Hoover is trying to decide these days whether to ask Congress for what he wants or to request what he thinks he can get.

In a brief ceremony at noon yesterday in an office of the rain-drenched Federal Shipyards of Kearny, N. J., the United States Navy took over the building ways and other structures of the thirty-year-old plant, famous for its construction of Navy destroyers.

HAMDEN, Conn., Dec. 31 -- Carl Gustave Swebilius, firearms inventor and manufacturer who died here Oct. 18, provided in his will that the major part of his large estate be used for research into the causes and cure of cancer and epilepsy, it was disclosed in Probate Court here today.

I wonder if you could find space in your paper to publish this letter of grateful thanks from an English housewife for Marshall aid? I know you will have been publicly thanked by our statesmen and politicians, but I thought you might like to have the private thanks of an ordinary citizen.

Retail trade here this week made a small decrease which is blamed mostly on bad shopping weather. Department store sales are estimated as about 2 per cent below the corresponding week last year. Sales last week were up 50 per cent.

GENEVA, Dec. 31 -- Marshal Tito's recent revelations of the significance of the Yugoslav-Soviet feud on trade relations among Eastern European countries are leading to a thorough re-examination by the United States and other Western experts of economic developments in the satellite countries of the Soviet bloc as a factor in East-West differences.

Year-end inventory liquidations by manufacturers of men's outerwear and underwear and mail order houses will provide a large bulk of the merchandise needed by retailers for promotional events this month, it was pointed out yesterday by Henry Modell, president of the chain of retail stores bearing his name.

ROME, Dec. 31 -- The Pope today released the text of a prayer he composed for Holy Year in 1950. Into it he poured all his grief caused by anti-religious persecutions and especially by the arrest of Cardinal Mindszenty, Primate of Hungary.

W. H. Upson Jr., president of the Upson Company, maker of processed and fiberboards used for walls and ceilings and tile-like materials for baths and kitchens, expressed optimism yesterday concerning the business volumes of the automobile and housing industries in 1949.
For most people, today will be a time for rest. But, with Robert Villemain, who is preparing for the most important ring battle of his career, it will be just another day.

BOSTON, Dec. 31 -- Two Massachusetts Representatives to Congress said today they would seek State Department help to aid three Boston merchant seamen said to be imprisoned under unsanitary conditions at Aruba in the Netherlands West Indies for missing their ship.
DALLAS, Dec. 31 (AP) -- Coach Matty Bell of Southern Methodist, whose team plays Oregon here tomorrow in the Cotton Bowl, rapped the Rose Bowl today as having "to second-place teams."

Looking back on 1948, many of those who devoted much of their free time to hunting and fishing may reach the conclusion that it failed to produce as much fish and game as they had anticipated, a conclusion that will be shared by more sportsmen as more years pass.

The new Congress which meets tomorrow is, of course, not composed wholly of new legislators. There are, as a matter of fact, only eighteen new Senators and 118 new Representatives. The new members in each House are a reflection in large part of the Democratic sweep of last November.

LONDON, Jan. 1 -- Britain's new year got off to a bleak start today, as winter gales and torrential rains flooded the countryside, lashed coasts, drove Channel shipping into port and left a blanket of sleet and ice over large parts of Scotland and northern England.
PASADENA, Calif., Jan. 1 (AP) -- The master took a lesson from a star pupil today in the Rose Bowl.
MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 1 (AP) -- Composing room and mailing department workers were absent at The Miami Daily News today and union men picketed the building.
THE dramatic rescue last week of twelve United States Air Force fliers stranded on the Greenland icecap was something more than just another rescue.

With fifteen days remaining before twelve leaders of the Communist party go on trial on charges of advocating the violent overthrow of the Government, the party and its Communist and non-Communist defenders started a campaign yesterday to "compel" the Truman Administration to dismiss the indictments.
American exporters will now have to fight more aggressively for volume than at any time since the end of the war, according to comment in the foreign-trade field last week.

THE phrase "The Barclay Street Boys" refers not to a gang of juvenile delinquents but, among Catholic clergy and laymen, to the church goods houses in lower Manhattan whence come the plaster images for most Catholic churches in America.

Local quintets had to settle for a split in the college court double-header at Madison Square Garden last night. N. Y. U. encountered little trouble in routing Connecticut, 70 -- 51, but L. I. U. suffered its fifth setback of the season, bowing to Duquesne, 64 -- 55, in the afterpiece.
FAIRBANKS, Alaska, Jan. 1 (AP) -- Ladd Field came within a footprint of whipping the University of Alaska today in the Ice Bowl game.

THIS account of John J. Pershing, by one who knew him well, has considerable value despite an obvious tendency to treat its subject with sympathy. Colonel Palmer's inclination to idealize is natural as that of a close and admiring comrade: but readers will find revealed the several elements of greatness in the leader of the A. E. F., even though he does not find full characterization.

BELGRADE, Jan. 1 -- Marshal Tito's speech to the Yugoslav Parliament on Monday established beyond any doubt that the Cominform states are seeking to crush and drive Yugoslav leaders from power through economic sanctions. They hope to produce a state of chaos in the carefully articulated five-year plan to industrialize this country and mechanize its agriculture.

The dying day of an old year brought an impotent conclusion in the stock market last week. While the final spurt in prices was missing, the prophecies for 1949 were not. But underlying the week-end holiday is the specter of Congressional action that lies ahead, as the stock market averages ended 1948 slightly below their starting point.
BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Jan. 1 (AP) -- Kentucky State stormed back in the second half to beat North Carolina A. and T. from Greensboro by 23 -- 13 today in the Vulcan Bowl football game before 5,000 fans.

DETROIT, Jan. 1 (AP) -- A spring exhibition schedule of thirty-two games, five fewer than last year and most of them with National League clubs, was announced today for the Tigers, who will open their baseball training camp March 1 at Lakeland, Fla.

Year-end statements of condition by commercial banks, scheduled for publication beginning this week, are likely in the over-all to show slight improvement in net current operating earnings for 1948. The thirty-five member banks in the Federal Reserve System, which in 1947 earned about $129,000,000, a return of 5.75 per cent on capital accounts, are expected to show for 1948 earnings of roughly $135,000,000, or about 6 per cent.

COPENHAGEN, Jan. 1 (Reuters) -- The first edition, which appeared under the title of Kobenhavnske Danske Post Tidender, had sixteen pages. The first three pages were devoted to tributes to the then King Frederik V, the next three to foreign news and the remainder to advertisements.

CARMELITA MARACCI is a unique phenomenon of our time, a dancer who really does not care very much whether she gives a performance or not, and yet one who can pack a house with the most select group of spectators the field has to provide, and can set them to cheering with excitement.
SCHENECTADY, N. Y., Jan. 1 -- General Electric Company engineers said today that sound pitched too high for the human ear to hear could burn cotton and float bits of cork in mid-air.

An optimistic report that, if the progress achieved during 1948 is maintained, the "essential recovery" of all displaced and needy Jews remaining in Europe can be assured within three more years was made yesterday by Edward M M. Warburg, chairman of the Joint Distribution Committee.

Winning again in the eighth and semi-final round of the international masters tournament at the Manhattan Chess Club yesterday, Reuben Fine increased his score at the top to 7 -- 1. His opponent was Isaac I. Kashdan, 1942 co-champion of the United States, who was defeated in forty moves, just as the time arrived for the sealing of moves.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Jan. 1 -- In the pre-dawn hours today, when the new year hardly had arrived, Egyptian naval craft staged a hit-run raid on Tel Aviv. There was a twenty-minute bombardment, but there was no noticeable damage.

The city's parks and playgrounds were visited by 101,804,000 persons in 1948, "justifying continued expansion of the variety and number of recreational facilities and activities," the Park Department reported yesterday in a summary of its year's work.

WHAT could turn out to be one of the most important moves in the drive against inflated production costs took place the other afternoon at the Dramatists Guild. A group of top playwrights there decided that perhaps the only way to meet the current crisis is for the various laboring craftsmen of the theatre to do something on their own.

THIS vigorously written book by the former public relations adviser to Prime Minister Attlee comes to us with a fanfare of praise from British critics. Wilson Harris, editor of The Spectator, writes that it "represents the best comprehensive defense of Labor party policy that has yet appeared."

AMONG contemporary novelists the role of John Dos Passos has been that of the rational social historian, and his value has been great. The three novels that are now collected under the title of "U.S.A." are surely a central literary achievement in our period; nobody can afford to ignore them.

Investment banking houses, unable to earn from competitive bidding underwritings a profit commensurate with the risk, are wondering now if a solution to their problem may lie in the means used for marketing the American Telephone and Telegraph Company's recent $150,000,000 issue of debentures.

News came from London last week that a team of British scientists had discovered a new drug -- antrycide -- which will protect cattle from the tsetse fly, carrier of African sleeping sickness. The British press makes much of the discovery. One paper predicts that "Africa will break the Argentine beef cartels."

NEW DELHI, India, Jan. 1 -- The Governments of India and Pakistan today ordered a cease-fire in their fourteen-month-old undeclared war in Kashmir State. The truce will be effective from "one minute before midnight of Jan. 1, 1949."

I got a kick out of the "Personalities" picture of Harry Truman fending off a gift Christmas turkey. What with all the livestock sent his way in the course of a year a President must have to keep a staff to maintain them. * * *

ARCADIA, Calif., Jan. 1 (AP) -- Autocrat, A. A. Baroni's 8-year-old gelding, won the eleventh running of the San Carlos Handicap today and took down $41,500 of the gross of $65,150, which made the seven-furlong Santa Anita race the richest all-age sprint in the world.

FOR something quite out of the ordinary on records try Tales From the Old Country, a Decca album containing three of Sholem Aleichem's short stories in an apt English translation by Julius and Frances Butwin.

NOT every poet can recite poetry. Even fewer can put on a pretty performance of their own work before a recording microphone. Nevertheless, it is excellent New Year's news that the first of the Library of Congress' "Twentieth Century Poetry in English" recordings will be released this week -- in five albums, each containing five double-faced, twelve-inch vinylite records.

CAMPO GRANDE, Brazil -- This is the principal city of the vast Brazilian state of Matto Grosso, which constitutes the very heart of South America. The state is a lush, steamy area utterly remote from the usual lanes of tourist travel to this continent.

A good deal can be said both for and against rain, for it is a not unmixed blessing. Rain can be trying when it falls in the middle of the Easter parade, for example, and it plays more hob with the picnic than do the ants.

PARIS, Jan. 1 -- Eastern and Western viewpoints were opposed in the French Parliament in the final phases of the financial debate as the military credits were adopted early this morning. The National Assembly adopted the budget, the financial ways and means measure and a large number of other laws, but did not conclude its program and both Houses will sit on Sunday in an effort to finish last year's legislation before adjourning.

PEIPING, Jan. 1 -- The staff of the leading independent Chinese daily newspaper, Ta Kung Pao, has been under virtual house arrest by Peiping garrison headquarters since Thursday night. The staff members have been told by the four gendarmes now guarding them that they are "under investigation."

THE correspondence that passed between Thomas Gray and Horace Walpole is surely of the first importance. Besides, Gray, the poet, distinguished himself as a letter-writer, and Walpole, the letter-writer, is famous as the author of an early Gothic novel, "The Castle of Otranto," and of a verse play considered by Byron (somewhat extravagantly) "a tragedy of the highest order."

BUDAPEST, Hungary, Jan. 1 (AP) -- President Arpad Szakasits said today that Hungary was determined to reach an agreement with the Roman Catholic Church despite the arrest of its primate, Joseph Cardinal Mindszenty.

CHERBOURG, France, Sunday, Jan. 2 (AP) -- The place where the Queen Mary went aground about 9:40 last night is within the Cherbourg Seawall, where the liner is safe from the worst buffetings of the storm.

WHEN the official figures were issued last week on Christmas trade, they showed the big gains for the final week which were expected because of the two extra shopping days. For the country as a whole, the jump was 32 per cent in department store sales over the same period in 1947, when the holiday fell on Thursday.

Rampaging floods receded and snow ceased falling yesterday. The toll of violent deaths across the nation on New Year's Eve and New Year's Day was 158, according to the latest count of The Associated Press. Of these, 112 lives were lost in traffic accidents.

More steel than it ever received before should be available to American industry in 1949, barring shortages of materials and labor strife, Walter S. Tower, president of the American Iron and Steel Institute, declared in a year-end statement issued for publication today.
KARACHI, Pakistan, Jan. 1 (Reuters) -- A joint India-Pakistan communique announcing the Kashmir cease-fire, released here today, said:

Maj. Gen. Roscoe B. Woodruff, chairman of the Northeast Area committee, announced yesterday that a three-service military team establised to push unification of Army, Navy and Air Force facilities and services in eight northeastern states had completed surveys of space utilization and consolidation of other facilities in the New York area.
MEMPHIS, Tenn., Jan. 1 (AP) -- A never-say-die William and Mary eleven scored a 20 to 0 victory over Oklahoma A. and M. in the Delta Bowl on three sudden thrusts and three terrific goal line stands.

LONDON, Jan. 1 -- The Lacock Abbey manuscript of Magna Charta was back in the British Museum tonight after having been "smuggled" across the Atlantic. The historic document had been on exhibition in the Library of Congress in Washington where 2,000,000 Americans saw it.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 -- Grassroots Republicans want the party to abandon any semblance of a "me too" attitude and carry forward a vigorous campaign of "reasonable conservatism" against President Truman and his program, it was indicated today.

The recent history of China is to a large extent the story of Chiang Kai-shek. Chiang, educated at Paoting and Tokyo military academies, fought in the Chinese revolution led by Sun Yat-sen, China's "George Washington." After Dr. Sun's death in 1925, Chiang became leader of the Kuomintang (Nationalist) party.
Everybody had his order fling at the stock market in 1948 and few called the turns correctly.

IF a garden is lacking in vines, except the occasional "wild" kinds that are quickly weeded out, now is a good season to select them for early spring planting. For there is a wide variety to choose from, with at least half a dozen places in even the smallest garden that would benefit from their use.

YOU may remember that a year ago this column referred to a series of eight pamphlets for parents put out by the New York Committee on Mental Hygiene, of the State Charities Aid Association. They dealt with specific problems which parents face day in and day out, such as the child's use of bad language, his fears, destructiveness, etc.

THREE new varieties of flowers are the first garden news of the year for 1949. Silver Medal petunia, Indian Summer hollyhock and Blue Star morning glory are the hybrids that have been awarded All-America Selections honors.

OF the realistic novel of the Twenties it was said that it was a subject not so much for the reviewer as for a conference of the author's family. They could best determine whether justice had been done. Something like that can be said of "The Truman Program."

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 1 -- Pennsylvania Railroad carloadings last week totaled 101,214 as against 102,957 a year ago, a decease of 1.7 per cent. For 1948 to date they totaled 6,697,762 compared with 7,189,620 last year, a decrease of 6.8 per cent
BATAVIA, Java, Jan. 1 (UP) -- Dutch forces today launched new drives on the southern, eastern and western coasts of Sumatra, threatening one of the last remaining outposts of the Indonesian Republic.

BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 1 -- Plans are progressing for the Intra-American Economic Conference to open here March 28 despite the feeling in some influential quarters that it may set the stage for a clash between the United States and Argentina on the issue of free versus controlled economy.

WHEN "Enemies of Promise" was published ten years ago, its author, Cyril Connolly, was an unknown young writer in his middle thirties. He had one novel behind him ("The Rock Pool," 1935). A year after his critical book came out, Mr. Connolly--it was then 1939 founded the mag7.ine Horizon.

THE seventy stories in this companion volume to "Favorite Stories Old and New" have been gathered from the four corners of the globe. Included are short stories, folk tales, excerpts from some of the children's favorite books (selections which make one want to discover the whole anew), and two complete books.

TELEVIEWERS tuning in on CBS-TV at 7:30 P. M. on weekday nights are met with a refreshingly relaxed presentation of the news by a personable young man of 31 -- by name, Douglas Edwards. Of medium build, with brown eyes and auburn hair, and pleasantly telegenic, Edwards has been a CBS newscaster since 1942 and a video regular for only the past year.

Nicholas Rossolimo, French chess champion, was held to a draw in his third-round match with Sir George Thomas of London in the international masters tournament at the Hastings and St. Leonards Chess Club yesterday. The result forced a two-way tie for first place.

VIENNA, Jan. 1 -- Jozsef Cardinal Mindszenty (pronounced Yozhef Min-senty), held under arrest in Budapest by the Hungarian Communist Government on charges of treason and espionage, is undergoing his third period of imprisonment since the first World War.

Fleets of cruising motor yachts, flotillas of speedy inboards and utilities, argosies of sailing windjammers and an indoor dry-land harbor full of boats for outboard motors are now headed New York-ward from factories in many cities for the annual January excitement Grand Central Palace on Lexington Avenue that this year will be the thirty-ninth annual National Motor Boat Show, to open Friday night at 7 o'clock.

TODAY is the day that the radio listeners will find new Sunday night schedules in effect on both CBS and NBC. The changes result from the Columbia network's "raid" on the National chain and Edgar Bergen's decision to leave the air for the time being.

Estimating that retail dollar volume for the first half of this year will be slightly ahead of the 1948 average, retailers foresee a readjustment to the pre-war pattern of "peaks and valleys." With supply and demand being brought into balance during the past twelve months, merchants are looking ahead to inventory adjustments as one of the major problems of 1949, according to a telegraphic survey made last week by THE NEW YORK TIMES.

JERSEY CITY, N. J., Jan. 1 -- Although the consensus of political observers in this city is that the next Mayor will be either Mayor Frank Hague Eggers or John V. Kenny, four hats were thrown into the ring today for election to the City Commission.
The letter of Albert Balink in THE TIMES of Dec. 19 and current developments in the Indonesian situation, require careful consideration to be evaluated properly.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 (AP) -- The Federal Bureau of Investigation announced that thirty-two cases of stolen Government firearms were recovered from a Mexican ship at San Francisco today.

In little more than fifteen months a group of American, Canadian and British financial and business interests of the top echelons have welded together an international trade organization that has been contributing importantly to the economic rehabilitation of countries outside the orbit of Russia's influence.

A departure in adult education programs will be initiated next month when the University of Wisconsin's Medical School offers by radio scientific instruction for medical practitioners. The university, which for many years has sponsored refresher courses for doctors in the state, says that "putting this service on the air will enable a larger group of doctors, who cannot leave their practice to attend campus sessions, to get the advantage of these refresher courses."

I note that Harrison Salisbury alludes, in "Russia Tightens the Iron Curtain," to the quaint claim made by the Russians of having first invented most of the comforts of our age. Manny years ago I had a friend whose sister was married to a Russian living in, Petrograd.

HERE is Thomas Costain at his best, in a well-constructed novel clearly destined to be the first big hit of the new year. "High Towers" has something for all: historical solidity, biographical interest, glamour. It is rich with learning, alive with adventure.

Boxing comes back to Madison Square Garden Friday night, and on an international scale. Steve Belloise, Bronx middleweight, and Robert Villemain, French fighter who recently surrendered the European welterweight title, are to collide in the feature of ten rounds.

HOLLYWOOD'S first consideration in the new year is always the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences awards competition, known to the trade as the "Oscar Derby." On Jan 20 a roster of the 300-odd pictures eligible for the competition will be mailed to the members of the Actors', Writers' and Directors' Guilds for nominations in each of their categories, and to the members of the academy for nominations in the best picture category.

The appointment of John N. Abbott as superintendent of floating equipment for the Pennsylvania Railroad was announced yesterday by H. H. Pevler, vice president of the company. Mr. Abbott, who succeeds Herbert B. Hilliker, will assume his new duties tomorrow.

ALTHOUGH the modern habit of indiscriminately disinterring the past amounts at times to a malady, a second revival of cubist work in the space of two weeks (paintings by Delaunay: shown at the Sidney Janis Gallery) is our distinct gain.

Repercussions already are being felt as a result of the announcement on Dec. 23 of a 7,250,000-ton sugar quota for 1949. This figure, as announced by Secretary of Agriculture Charles F. Brannan, compares with a 1948 marketing quota of 7,200,000 tons. Sugar dealers in New York last week declared that the Secretary was too conservative in his allotments regarding quota deficits.

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N. Y., Jan. 1 -- This vast public playground in the back yard of metropolitan New York was virtually transformed into a winter wonderland today as new snows buried Bear Mountain Park under a white blanket. While the winds blew hard, in many places clearing the snows from the slopes, and squalls broke through intermittently, there was rejoicing by the skiers able to get running, even though of a limited nature.

THE biography of the "divine". Sarah Bernhardt, long a cherished goal of film, actresses, may be done by Micheline Presle, the young Gallic star let it be known the other day. Mile. Presle, now en route to Hollywood to start a term contract at Twentieth Century-Fox, pointed out that she and William Marshall had acquired rights to a book, "Sarah Bernhardt, Ma Grandmere," by Lysiane Bernhardt, the actress' granddaughter.
The 1949 indoor track campaign, to be distinguished later on by the appearance of several European stars of the Olympics, will get under way locally this week with two armory meets.

THESE short stories deal with four separate exploits of members of the Royal Canadian Mounted Police. "Mystery of the Ghost Gold" tells of a thousand-mile trek by Sergeant Kirke to solve a murder, capture the guilty persons and clear the name of the girl he loves.

THE ninth annual midwinter garden course, sponsored by THE NEW YORK TIMES, will be held at Times Hall, 240 West Forty-fourth Street, New York City, on four consecutive Wednesdays, starting Jan. 19. Titled "Your Garden and Mine," the course will consist of a series of lectures by garden experts, with appropriate background displays.

ODD as it may seem, color has an important bearing on the production of so-called black and white television and is inseparably tied up with the lighting of a show. While the "color" range of our black and white television is from light gray to black, the effects cannot be obtained by using gray and black on the sets.
CAIRO, Jan. 1 -- A Foreign Office spokesman said today that Egypt would comply with the Security Council's cease-fire order the moment that Israel did so.

THE winter population of trailer camps in Florida and California, Arizona and Texas should be larger this season than ever before, judging from reports of the trailer manufacturers, whose business in 1948 established a new record.

WHEN the supreme journalist, James Boswell, induced one of the great literary figures of his day to sit for a full-length oral portrait, he could hardly have guessed that he was fathering a literary genre that would someday provide ample matter for a learned and entertaining anthology.

Acting Secretary of State Lovett reports a somewhat discouraging reaction by some American states to our Government's inquiry as to whether withholding recognition from a government that has come to power by force would tend to halt such revolutionary movements. This reaction is perhaps not too surprising. Election by revolution has long been a custom in some parts of Latin America.
TODAY is the day when the Christmas lights and the tinsel go back into hiding and the gifts which have been on festive display retire into a drawer or a closet along with more prosaic possessions.

ATHENS, Jan 1 -- To get an idea of what guerrilla war means to the Greek people and of the monstrous terrain that the National army has to fight over, a trip to the northern borders is worth weeks in Athens and volumes of second-hand description.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 1 (AP) -- A crowd of 4,886 basketball fans were treated to two court extremes tonight as a giant unbeaten Western Kentucky quintet raced to a 86-to-69 victory over St. Joseph's College of Philadelphia and under dog Lafayette methodically cut down Temple, 45 to 34, in a New Year night double-header at Convention Hall.

ALLAHABAD, India, Jan. 1 (Reuters) -- Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru, Indian Prime Minister, announced here today that his Government had invited thirteen other Eastern Governments to a conference to consider the Indonesian problem.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 1 -- A bitter controversy in the California legislative session, opening on Monday, was predicted today as the result of Gov. Earl Warren's determination to press for adoption of a compulsory state health insurance system and organized medicine's preparations to combat it.

Two old five-story store and tenement buildings at the northeast corner of Worth and Mulberry Streets, in Chinatown, are being replaced with a modern church structure for the True Light Lutheran Church at an estimated cost of $250,000.
RICHMOND, Va., Jan. 1 -- This region will enter 1949 with a high heart.

HESTER PRYNNE, gazing steadfastly at the clergyman, felt a dreary influence come over her, but wherefore or whence she knew not; unless that he seemed so remote from her own sphere, and utterly beyond her reach.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 (AP) -- A Special House Committee today called for laws to make clear beyond question that radio "must remain as free as the press."
CHATTANOOGA, Jan. 1 -- An optimistic South heralded the New Year this week with widespread conviction that its rapidly expanding economy and record profits would continue unabated.

CHICAGO, Jan. 1 -- Reports from metropolitan areas of the Central West indicate a slight resurgence of optimism in respect to the economic outlook this year. More confidence in the future is now evident in areas where "depression jitters" had been marked in the last few weeks.

THE late Mr. Filene (1860-1937) was notorious for nearly half a century in Boston for being a chronic innovator in the merchandising business. For better than half this time, United States public opinion and sometimes Europe's, too, was growing conscious of him in much the same way.

WASHINGTON -- Several new measures affecting domestic and international travel, and the revival of many bills that have been pending in recent Congresses, are scheduled for early consideration by the Eighty-first Congress.
BERLIN (By Wireless). ALL day the little boy leans eagerly out the window gazing at low-flying planes swooping over his house to land at Tempelhof airfield.

ALBANY, Jan. 1 -- A report urging additional state aid for education of at least $60,000,000 was released today by the Educational Conference Board and the Public Education Association, which a year ago sponsored the controversial Young-Milmoe bill to raise school aid $103,000,000.
On this final Sunday of the thirty-seventh annual Christmas appeal for The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, total contributions stand at $327,273.70.

John Kuesell, 15 years old, son of a Christian father and a Jewish mother -- who with this sister, Barbara, 10, survived the Hitler purges in Nazi Germany and came here from Berlin in 1946 -- told yesterday how his dislike of strong dring led him to seek a religion specifying abstinence, so that he became a Moslem.

THE fastest telephoto lens ever made available for amateur 8mm movie cameras, the Cine Balostar f/1.3 of 1 1/2-inch focal length, was announced last week by Dr. F. G. Back, its inventor. The price will be $187 when the lens appears on the market in about two months.

For 1949 Rabbi William F. Rosenblum urged yesterday in Temple Israel, 210 West Ninety-first Street, that everyone resolve to put down "five freedoms" as the most important part of his program for daily living. He listed these as "freedom from unwarranted suspicion, freedom from groundless worry, freedom from baseless fear, freedom from silly superstitions and freedom from stupid prejudices."

The New Year started off promisingly at the Metropolitan, yesterday afternoon, with an enjoyable performance of Donizetti's "Lucia di Lammermoor," which received its initial hearing of the season. With a cast headed by Lily Pons in the name part and Ferruccio Tagliavini as Edgardo, the presentation offered much that was vocally admirable, as well as dramatically cogent.
ROME, Jan. 1 (AP) -- The Italian Navy has carried out what may have been the quietest maneuvers in modern naval history.
TORONTO, Jan. 1 (AP) -- The world champion Toronto Maple Leafs turned back Montreal's Canadiens, 5 -- 3, tonight in a National Hockey League game.

THESE two historical novels are the first of The Land of the Free Series which deals with the several national groups which helped to build America and which, through their varied characteristics, enriched our heritage in many ways.

IN a bold and stimulating report, the President s Commission on Higher Education has proposed for 1960 an enrollment of 4.6 million students in American institutions of higher learning. Enrollment at the present time seems to be just about 2.5 millions and educators seem to be in agreement that universities and colleges will enroll 3 millions by the Fifties.

MR. LONG disarms his critics by acknowledging at the outset that the term "liberal" is a loose one, having many connotations. Yardsticks change from era to era: in the first seventy-five years of national independence, the general idea of economic controls by Government was considered illiberal; many of the beliefs held by Jefferson and Jackson would seem shockingly reactionary today.
OTTAWA, Jan. 1 -- A moderate decline in prices and the possible removal of the last of the wartime controls are among the forecasts made for the new year in Canada.

ORLANDO, Fla., Jan. 1 (AP) -- Murray State (Ky.) College scored twice in the last quarter to tie previously unbeaten, untied Sul Ross (Texas) State College, 21 -- 21, tonight in a wide open battle in the Tangerine Bowl. About 9,000 chilled fans watched the game on a windswept field.

Motorists in the metropolitan area who exercised normal caution fared far better yesterday than pedestrians, forced to wade ankle-deep through slush - filled city streets left in the wake of the 3.1-inch snowfall that, except for mild flurries, ended before many New Year parties.

Stressing the serious decline of the American merchant marine, the Congress of Industrial Organizations Maritime Committee has urged President Truman and the Eighty-first Congress to take immediate steps to strengthen the country's fleet and stem growing maritime unemployment.

With a large part of its potential sources of support still untapped, the New York Public Library has received $110,824 in contributions since its drive for funds began on Nov. 23, it was made known yesterday.

" THE attempt to single out certain diseases as psychosomatic is erroneous and futile. Every disease is psychosomatic because both psychological and somatic factors have a part in its cause and influence its course. This assumption is valid even for such specific infectious diseases as tuberculosis."

BY a happy chance, of which newspapers recently carried an account, this moumental treatise on the foundations of human knowledge does not appear as a posthumous work. But it will probably remain as Bertrand Russell's philosophical testament.

ON the opening page of this novel the reader discovers a boy of 7 standing wearily in a queue at a fish store in Frankfort on the Main on a dismal autumn morning in 1917. The armistice ending World War I is still a year away, but Frankfort is already subsisting on stinking dried fish from Norway and eternal turnips.

ANOTHER light week in the local dance field. Except for a few regular series events, there is nothing at all on the calendar. Time to catch up on the series events, apparently, and that looks anything but painful, as it happens.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 -- The troubled Government of the Republic of Korea, headed by Dr. Syngman Rhee, received full recognition from the United States today, in the first official act of 1949 by President Truman.

BUTTONING his blue overcoat with one hand and carrying his "bus bag" in the other, the interne walked to the ambulance. The motor was already running. The interne opened the heavy back door and climbed in, and the antiseptic-looking ambulance, with red lights blinking, prowled softly out of the hospital yard.

SALT LAKE CITY -- Transcontinental travelers arriving at the local Rio Grande station are a cheery lot these frosty mornings. Cast in the role of railroading pioneers, they've been enjoying long-anticipated Vista Dome views of winter in the Rockies.

SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico, Jan. 1 -- The greatest gathering of diplomats, government officials, bankers and industrialists ever assembled here is participating in six-day ceremonies that will culminate tomorrow in the inauguration of Luis Munoz Marin as first elected Governor of the island.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Jan. 1 -- After twenty-eight years of greeting more than 4,000,000 visitors from every state in the Union and every nation in the world, 89-year-old Herbert Wells Fay, custodian of Abraham Lincoln's tomb at Oak Ridge Cemetery here, retired yesterday.

THE convergence of Samuel Goldwyn Jr. and Martin Mooney as a film-producing team has aroused wide interest in Hollywood because their activities have the blessing of Samuel Goldwyn Sr. and are being carried on at his studio.

A DEVELOPMENT and improvement program for tourist facilities at Zion, Bryce and Grand Canyon National Parks is foreshadowed in the recently concluded twenty-year contract between the Department of the Interior and the Utah Parks Company a parks concession subsidiary of the Union Pacific Railroad.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 -- The Air Force looked back today over 1948, found that it had been a "memorable year," and chalked up the "overwhelming success" of the Berlin airlift as the outstanding achievement of the period.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 -- Democratic members of the House, in a tense five-hour caucus today, approved a basic change in procedure to make it easier to force action on measures blocked in the powerful Committee on Rules.

American graduate schools are placing greater emphasis on the preparation of doctoral candidates for college teaching, a recently completed nationwide survey has disclosed. Although the graduate courses still stress research and scholarship, many of them recognize the importance of training students to become good teachers.
LOS ANGELES, Jan. 1 -- Despite many signs of a leveling-off of the post-war boom, a general mood of firm optimism, tinged with some caution, is discernible in the Southwest as the new year begins.

Leading tugboat operators of the port declared yesterday that they had made their final wage offer to 3,500 employes who threaten to paralyze harbor activity after midnight of Jan. 12 if their demands are not met.

THE Marquis de Custine, perhaps the most intelligent observer ever to attempt penetration of the mass soul of Russia, wrote, more than a century ago. "Il faute etre Russe pour vivre en Russie" -- "One must be Russian to live in Russia." He concluded that the Russian form of government was suitable only to Russia and was also the only form of government which suited the Russians.

LONDON, Jan. 1 (Reuters) -- Wild weather, waterlogged pitches and shocks for the leading teams in three of the four English League sections ushered in soccer on the first day of 1949. From all over the country came reports of high winds, heavy rain, hail and sleet, and at Newport there was a violent thunderstorm.

COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Jan. 1 -- Denmark's oldest newspaper, the Berlingske Tidende, will celebrate its two hundredth anniversary on Monday. Older newspapers are to be found in Britain and France but the jubilee of Berlingske is unique in that this newspaper is believed to be the only one in the world that, for two centuries, has been published uninterruptedly under the ownership of the same publishing dynasty.

Senator Robert F. Wagner made public yesterday a letter to Senator Tom Connally, of Texas, asking for an investigation of the imprisonment of Joseph Cardinal Mindszenty of Hungary and Archbishop Stepinac of Yugoslavia by the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, of which Senator Connally will be chairman in the Eighty-first Congress.

PHOENIX, Ariz., Jan. 1 (AP) -- Drake University of Des Moines, Iowa, stopped two University of Arizona last-quarter threats -- one on the 1-yard line -- to win a 14-13 Salad Bowl football victory here today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 (AP) -- Measures authorizing a seventy-group Air Force and an 837,000-man Army were proposed today by Representative Carl Vinson of Georgia, who will head the House Armed Services Committee, in the new Congress.

A new year stretches ahead, and who would make the most of it must be stretching himself somewhat to meet it. The summing up is inevitable, and along with it a look into the days and weeks stud months ahead. Summer is long gone, and fall is well behind. The ice and snow of winter's nadir now are ours; and we can look forward to spring, the greatest of all new beginnings.

The Freedom Train wound up its New York visit last night with the close of Manhattan Freedom Week. New York Central Railroad officials estimated that 50,000 persons had viewed the train since it was brought into Grand Central Terminal last Sunday.

THIS reviewer must be slipping. In the awards which were voted last week by the august New York Film Critics for the best screen achievements of the past year, he found himself thoroughly agreeing with no fewer than four of the five.

VALETTA, Malta, Jan. 1 -- An officer and boarding party from an unidentified warship stopped and boarded a British merchantman between Cyprus and the Egyptian coast last night, it was disclosed here tonight.

The fourth round of price increases was given a stiff boost last week by four significant developments which indicate that most durable goods lines will be raised in price about 5 per cent during the first quarter.

BERLIN, Jan. 1 (UP) -- Gen. Sir Brian Robertson, British occupation commander, said tonight that he hoped that the New Year would bring the establishment of a "democratic Government for the whole of Germany."

A STATISTICAL analysis of the 1948 philatelic year discloses that it was the second most prolific calendar period in the hobby's annals. Not since 1920, in a time of boundary adjustments following the first World War, have so many major and minor varieties appeared.

No one can quarrel with the central theme of your Dec. 26 editorial, "What Is Americanism?" We are all for maximum freedom, against character assassination, against coercion in the sphere of ideas, etc. Yet some of your assertions seem curious when read in the light of the dominant reality of this period: the Communist conspiracy to destroy freedom everywhere.

The House Committee on Un-American Activities was set up as a special investigating body in 1938. Two years ago it was made a "standing" or permanent committee. In ten years the committee has spent $1,050,000. It has produced one legislative proposal -- the Mundt-Nixon Communist-Control Bill -- which died in the Eightieth Congress.
