WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 (AP) -- High Democratic sources predicted today that President Truman would continue to stress foreign aid, broader social security coverage, repeal of the Taft-Hartley labor law, and anti-inflation legislation in placing his program before the Eighty-first Congress.

The tenth annual series of historical lectures conducted by Dr. Curt Sachs, consultant to the New York Public Library's Music Division, begins tomorrow at 8:30 P. M. in Room 213 of the Central Building, Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street.

TAMPA, Fla., Jan. 1 (AP) -- St. Thomas spotted Missouri Valley two touchdowns in the Cigar Bowl tonight, then earned a 13-13 tie with a 59-yard drive in the closing minutes before a crowd of about 11,000.

CHICAGO, Jan. 1 -- Manufacturers of furniture and home furnishings are gearing their offerings at the winter furniture market to meet conditions of greater competition, Col. Lawrence H. Whiting, president of the American Furniture Mart, said today. The market opens on Monday.

Northern people with an interest in the welfare of the Negro will increase their understanding by spending part of their vacations in the South, friends of Negro education who are supporting private colleges in the South said yesterday. It was recommended that college campuses be visited.

WITH the Museum of Modern Art showing about half the American paintings in its permanent collection, the provocative 1948 Whitney annual closing today and the Metropolitan Museum overhauling and reshaping its program of purchasing and exhibiting contemporary American art, there is special occasion for surveying the work of the three institutions in this field and their relative positions.

MINNEAPOLIS, Jan. 1 (AP) -- The University of Minnesota basketball team built up a commanding 45-to-24 half-time lead over the Colgate Red Raiders and then coasted to its eighth consecutive victory, 70 to 46 tonight. A crowd of 9,297 saw the game.

PARIS, Jan. 1 -- With the Palestine and Indonesian questions hanging over it like two swords of Damocles, the United Nations entered the New Year with its prestige at the lowest since its establishment.

Officers of Freedom House recommended yesterday in a New Year's message that the American people seek this year improvement in certain civil rights, the end of racial discrimination, and abolition of the Electoral College.

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 1 -- Happy-go-lucky Oklahoma walloped North Carolina, 14 -- 6, in the fifteenth annual Sugar Bowl gridiron classic today, putting a dead serious finish to a post-season appearance it had undertaken with careless abandon.

On the stroke of noon tomorrow, the Republican-controlled Eightieth Congress will pass into history. At the same moment, the Democratic- controlled Eighty-first Congress will take over the task of legislating for the nation in the two years to come.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 -- Savings of $34,500,000 can be counted as a result of joint use of certain services and facilities by the three armed forces, James Forrestal, Secretary of Defense, stated today.

TOKYO, Jan. 1 -- Japan and the men of the occupation forces charged with Japanese reconstruction view with gravity the military operations of the Dutch in Indonesia and the resumption of guerrilla warfare as a new crisis in an Asia already tottering on the verge of anarchy.

TRAVEL men and travelers are awaiting with interest the arrival here next week of the new British liner Caronia, the largest post-war liner, for many believe that she presages a new trend in surface travel. With many big-liner innovations, she was designed particularly for cruise trade out of New York.

Istvan de Szemere de Genere Huba, who claims to be the only living descendant of Huba, one of the seven chiefs of Hungary who ruled there 1,200 years ago, arrived yesterday at the New York international airport, Idlewild, Queens, from Paris.

After a two-week lull, activities in New York's auction galleries will get into full swing again now that the holidays are over. Two sales will be held at the Parke-Bernet Galleries this week, one of modern paintings, the other of English furniture, silver and decorations.

At a recent Wednesday afternoon interpretation class at the Mannes Music School, Georges Enesco recalled some of his early experiences. Outside the snow was knee-deep, but inside the auditorium four groups of players had the music of Vivaldi, Schubert and Beethoven on the fire.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 -- A program to modernize the state-Federal unemployment insurance system and give its protection to about 7,000,000 more workers was recommended today to the Senate Committee on Finance by its Advisory Council on Social Security.

TOKYO, Jan. 1 -- The Japanese people were warned today in a Washington dispatch from Makoto Takano to the newspaper Asahi that increased aid from the United States could not be expected in view of the present American commitments.

Retail trade here last week was marked by a post-Christmas selling reaction and volume slipped under the 1947 period. Department store sales were estimated at about 2 per cent below the figures for the comparable week last year.

SINCE November 2 there has been much discussion of the failure of the public-opinion polls to gauge correctly the outcome of the Presidential election. In this discussion an important question has been generally overlooked. The question is: What about issue pools?

WHEN the Government recently forced La Prensa and La Nacion to suspend their Sunday supplements carrying extensive book-review pages, one of the last avenues of publicity for the distressed Argentine book publishers vanished.
Dr. Ordway Tead, chairman of the Board of Higher Education, has given his support to a campaign for the creation of a new medical school in Queens, it became known yesterday.
BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Jan. 1 -- The Baylor Bears grabbed a big first-half lead and held on grimly in the final periods today to defeat Wake Forest, 20 to 7, in the Dixie Bowl football game.

DALLAS, Jan. 1 -- All-America Doak Walker and his brilliant sophomore running mate, Kyle Rote, carried Southern Methodist University to victory over Oregon by 21 -- 13 in the thirteenth annual Cotton Bowl football game today Before a capacity crowd of 69,000.

ALMOST a third of the fatalities and slightly more than 40 per cent of the reported traffic accidents resulting in injuries to children in New York City during the winter months last year involved youngsters playing in the streets.

BERLIN, Jan. 1 -- Today's edition of the Soviet Army newspaper Taegliche Rundschau featured on Page 2 a reprint of an article from the Telepress news agency of Prague, in which the charge was made that negotiations resulting in the pact setting up the International Ruhr Authority also formulated a secret agreement for the rearmament of Western Germany.

WASHINGTON, Jan., 1 -- The consumer has found some relief at long last, according to the price charts. It has not been much, but even a leveling off would have been a comfort after the long uphill pull.

The old-line gun cranks are now beginning to put on pressure to insure that the 1949 National Matches will include the big bores, for many of them insist that while small-bore shooting is an amusing way to pass time, you don't separate the men from the boys until the range is pushed up to 1,000 yards.

WARSAW, Jan. 1 -- The Polish people got a New Year's present today when the Government lifted all rationing restrictions and instituted a wage reform designed to raise the workers' purchasing power by 10 per cent.

MOSS HART could scarcely have failed to note, as he sat down to redraft the second and third acts of "Light up the Sky" in Room 408 of Boston's Ritz-Carlton Hotel, that he was performing the identical chores required of the playwright at the final curtain of his theatrical comedy now happily installed at the Royale Theatre.

With Washington generally agreed that the development of the oil resources of Mexico is essential for the economy of that country and for defense of the Western Hemisphere, the oil industry hopes that some practical plan may be evolved which will result in this development being done by private industry without any cost to the United States Government.

OFFHAND, looking casually at a fellow named Lex Barker, there's nothing to distinguish him from a thousand other giants in Hollywood who stand six feet four inches, weigh two hundred pounds, wear shoulder-length hair and hang out at Schwab's Drug Store. But Barker is different -- 'way different -- for he's a man with a steady job, and that's practically an anachronism in this sad town these days.

John Gould's story on the deer problem, "Communique From the Maine Front," is amusing, but it fails to give the constructive side of the question. The deer population has increased more than 25 per cent since the last big game census before the war.
A committee of holders of preferred stock threatens to delay further the five-year-old reorganization plan of the $780,000,000 American and Foreign Power Company, Inc.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 1 -- Traditionally the West Coast's psychology has been strongly on the optimistic side. The buoyant "we can do it" spirit is still here with the advent of 1949, but the man in the street recognizes soft spots in the economy and is not carried away by his enthusiasm.

The first report on the progress of the army phase of Soviet Russia's revamped civilian military training program became available yesterday. It indicates that substantial progress has been made in putting the program on a realistic basis, but it expresses disappointment with the results thus far.

THE six titles listed above have not been seen in the publishers' catalogues. They have not been announced, more's the pity, for 1949 publication. Yet all of them, with one possible exception, will be published eventually -- if not in 1949 -- although they may carry different names, be signed by different authors and brought out by different publishers at different prices.

SALT LAKE CITY, Jan. 1 -- Westerners on both sides of the Continental Divide are exuding optimism with the advent of the New Year, despite indications of a possible drop in agricultural prosperity just ahead.

LAST week's column was, not inappropriately, devoted in part to a backward look, with a measure of confession regarding this department's sins of omission and commission during the year now ended. It seems only right, and much more comforting, that this week's should concern itself with fine resolutions regarding the year to come.

CHICAGO, Jan. 1 -- The Chicago Defender, Negro newspaper, has named eight Negroes, nine whites and nine organizations to its "honor roll of democracy" for 1948 "for their historic contributions to democracy and national unity in the past year."
MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 1 -- Texas put aside defense and went touchdown crazy in the Orange Bowl today to defeat favored Georgia, 41 -- 28.

PASADENA, Calif., Jan. 1 -- In one of the tightest seesaw football games ever played in the Rose Bowl or on any other gridiron, Northwestern University's doughty Wildcats took the University of California into camp, 20 to 14, today before a crowd of 92,000 in the thirty-fifth Tournament of Roses battle.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Jan. 1 -- In a New Year's message broadcast shortly after midnight, Premier Marshal Tito told the Yugoslav people that they were historically and psychologically incapable of crawling like "reptiles" on their bellies to anyone, and that they would therefore endure and triumph over the Communist Information Bureau as victoriously as they had emerged from all their wars in the past.

HONG KONG, Jan. 1 -- In this city where emmissaries of top level Nanking officials have been seeking to learn the Communists' peace terms, a Communist New Year's message today did not come as a surprise.

Cardinal Spellman made a surprise announcement yesterday afternoon at his tenth annual New Year's Day reception at his residence, 452 Madison Avenue, that a new Roman Catholic parish, to be named in honor of the Hungarian St. Emeric, would be established soon in the vicinity of Stuyvesant Town.
SAN DIEGO, Calif., Jan. 1 -- Villanova wrecked Nevada's famed passing attack and rolled to a 27-to-7 Harbor Bowl victory today.

LESS than five years have elapsed since the end of the world's greatest war, yet already it has become a cliche to note that World War II was the best documented conflict in history. Volume after volume -- not only of memoirs and personal experiences but of source documents -- has issued from the publishing houses of half a dozen countries.

Morris and Essex, America's foremost outdoor dog shows, also became biggest in the country indoors or out in 1948 as far as dogs actually present and competing were concerned, according to official A. K. C. records, which credit a club with actual dogs only and omit absentees in tabulating.

VIENNA, Jan. 1 -- Now that the campaign against religion has been brought to a climax in Hungary by the subordination of the churches to the Government, "bourgeois science" is to be reformed as it has been reformed in Russia.

OMAHA, Neb., Jan 1 -- The mood of Midwesterners generally toward the future appears accurately reflected in an action taken this week by the Kansas City (Mo.) Power and Light Company. The concern announced plans to build a $27,000,000 power-generating plant that will increase the city's available supply of electricity by 40 per cent.

IN rolling verses and vigorous pictures Mr. Daugherty catches the surging movement of the westward drive across our continent. Trappers and traders, plainsmen, Indians, cattlemen, Pony Express riders rush across these pages at top speed -- not even the trains and planes which bring the story up to the present seem to move any faster than these doughty frontiersmen.

NINETEEN months ago the closing notice for Gian-Carlo Menotti's musical plays, "The Medium" and "The Telephone," was posted on the backstage bulletin board of the Barrymore Theatre. They had opened a month earlier to a mixed reception from drama critics after being acclaimed by music reviewers at a pre-Broadway production at the Heckscher Theatre.

THIS year's exhibition of the London Royal Academy contained three paintings by Winston S. Churchill. Naturally the attention of the public was immediately directed toward them. The same kind of limelight shone on Paderewski when he became President of Poland. It was not a question of a great pianist becoming a great statesman.
BOSTON, Jan. 1 -- An air of uneasy optimism marks the New England economic attitude as this industrial area stokes up for a New Year.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Jan. 1 -- Buzfuz launched his 7-year-old season with a length triumph in the Dade County Handicap before 11,856 fans at Tropical Park today. Speeding the six furlongs in 1:10 4/5, Buzfuz earned $7,125 to increase his total to $248,145.

PARIS, Sunday, Jan. 2 -- The giant Cunard liner Queen Mary ran aground on a small beach near Cherbourg last night after being caught in a wind of almost cyclonic force. A gale has been battering France and her Atlantic and Mediterranean coastlines for two days.

SNOW pictures present a challenge to the photographer, with unique problems of texture, lighting, developing and composition. And one of the first principles of snow photography is an effective rendering of texture. The zeal to achieve it often prevents photographers from obtaining the real picture they are after.

Without waiting for a formal report to the United Nations of the terms of settlement, the Governments of India and Pakistan announce issuance of an immediate cease-fire order to their troops in the State of Jammu and Kashmir, where an undeclared war has been in progress for fourteen months.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 1 (AP) -- The victorious University of Texas Longhorns tumbled into their dressing room shouting "we showed 'em, we showed 'em," after their 41-to-28 triumph over Georgia in the Orange Bowl today.

ALBANY, Jan. 1 -- The Democratic party's program for the 1949 session of the State Legislature was issued today by Paul E. Fitzpatrick, state chairman, accompanied by an attack upon the fiscal policies of the Dewey Administration.

DEMOCRACY doesn't mean the same thing to the Negro cotton picker in Georgia, the Park Avenue banker and the CIO auto worker in Detroit. It is an elusive term, but it is also a tenable and clear philosophy for social living which can be categorically defined.

Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek's New Year's statement, though far from definitive, opens the way to a new chapter in the Orient. It is a chapter that, for the United States and its Allies, starts in gloom and foreboding; we are reaping the whirlwind we helped to sow.

BRUNO WALTER is going back to Salzburg. The conductor, who was one of the guiding spirits of the festivals there from 1925 until the Anschluss and who induced Arturo Toscanini to participate in them, will return to conduct at the 1949 festival.

Over-all financial strength, in New York's garment market has fallen off as the result of an extremely poor dress season, but the net worth of the women's apparel industries at the year-end shows no visible signs of cracking, according to bank executives and credit men on Seventh Avenue.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 -- The House Un-American Activities Committee asserted today that, in spite of $17,000,000 spent by President Truman in two years, an undetermined number of Communists were still in the Federal Government, all engaged in espionage and bent on eventual seizure of power.

Among the numerous problems the new Congress will face as it convenes in Washington tomorrow will be those involving the nation's health. Health and medical services are "big business" for the Federal Government, for last year more than forty-four Government agencies that dealt with health spent approximately $1,250,000,000, and gave services to more than 24,000,000 persons.

FOR use in Palestine areas which the Trans-Jordan Legion has invaded its Government has issued twenty-one provisionals: Trans-Jordan items overprinted "Palestine" in Arabic and in English, and in red or dark blue.

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 1 (AP) -- A jumping horse with an old habit of refusing to break won the feature at the Fair Grounds today. It was Gestapo, the horse that had failed to leave the gate last winter in a big Florida stake and had done the same thing at Suffolk Downs last summer.

Crawford Clothes yesterday announced a general price reduction of 20 per cent on all merchandise in its stores. The reduction affects women's apparel and men's accessories, in addition to all men's clothing on which a 20 per cent reduction has been in effect for several weeks.

ALTHOUGH melodrama has the reputation of being a primitive form of drama, it suits Jean-Paul Sartre. It is violent, it is shocking and it can usually get along with superficial characterization. M. Sartre is in a hurry.

The amount subscribed in the Greater Cornell Fund Campaign for $12,500,000 now totals $5,091,000, it was announced here yesterday by John L. Collyer, national chairman of the campaign and president of the B. F. Goodrich Company.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 (AP) -- Following is the text of the White House announcement that the United States will recognize the Government of the Republic of Korea:

BUFFALO, N. Y., Jan. 1 (AP) -- Canisius romped to its eighth victory in nine basketball starts tonight, routing Cornell, 56 -- 33, before 8,976 fans in Memorial Auditorium. Niagara topped Rice, 70 -- 57, in the first game of the double-header.

Secretary of Defense James Forrestal stated in his first annual report, issued last week, that the armed forces were studying the possibilities of a military outpost which would revolve around the earth. He calls this artificial moon an "earth satellite vehicle" but says nothing about its possible military uses.

PASADENA, Calif., Jan. 1 (AP) -- A gorgeous floral float, with a beautiful young girl depicting a fairy queen in fairyland and entered by Long Beach today won the grand sweepstakes prize in the annual tournament of roses.

ANYONE who writes about bridge knows that occasionally he will develop a blind spot so that the proper play of a hand will totally escape him. The same thing happens to everyone who plays bridge, of course, but the writer's errors are broadcast and the player's are not.
ARNOLD SCHOENBERG'S statements regarding style in his NEW YORK TIMES article of Dec. 19 telling why he goes back to the classics are inconsistent and disturbing.

HOUSELEEKS, or "hen and chickens," are appealing plants to grow and watch indoors. The curious habit of growth can be admired in winter wherever there is a little spare room in the house or greenhouse "Dish" gardens or terrariums often look well if planted with houseleek.

A large part of the deficits of the voluntary hospitals of New York can be traced "directly" to the low rate of reimbursement by the city to the hospitals caring for city charges, it was asserted yesterday by Roy E. Larsen, president of the United Hospital Fund, in the fund's sixty-ninth annual report.

PORT TOBACCO, Md. -- The Maryland side of the Potomac River, lacking such tourist attractions as Mount Vernon, Alexandria and Arlington, is now taking steps to remedy this situation. Two restorations are planned on the northern shore down-river from Washington: Old Fort Washington, ten miles away, and Port Tobacco, a dozen miles farther.

THE building of the Suez Canal was considered by Twentieth Century-Fox as a fitting dramatic exercise for Tyrone Power a couple of years back. Now a French producer named Albert Pink is of a mind to work up a romantic adventure film about the struggle that went into the making of the Panama Canal. Its title, "Panama," of course.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Jan. 1 -- The battle of the Negeb, which has become known here as "Operation Blackout," was designed for the sole purpose of either forcing armistice talks on the Egyptians or compelling them to fight for the territory they hold.

A brilliant sustained drive at the start of the second half supplied the momentum that carried the New York Knickerbockers to a stirring 88-to-80 triumph over the Philadelphia Warriors at Madison Square Garden yesterday. The victory was the fourteenth in their last eighteen games for Joe Lapchick's charges, who snapped the five-game winning streak of the visitors.

The "case system method" of teaching in law schools is sharply criticized by Dr. Karl N. Llewellyn, Betts Professor of Jurisprudence at Columbia University, in the current issue of the Duke University Law School's Journal of Legal Education.

WASHINGTON, Jan 1 -- The first "Truman Congress" assembles here on Monday amid indications that Harry S. Truman, who scored an upset victory in November when he won a full four-year term as President, will have easy sailing, at least at first, for the major parts of his legislative program.

BOSTON, Jan. 1 -- The Boston Bruins, driving hard for the National Hockey League lead, tonight outskated the fleet New York Rangers for a 4-1 victory before an overflow crowd of 13,900 at the Boston Garden.

LONDON, Jan. 1 (AP) -- Yugoslavia renewed demands today for territory and reparations from Austria. The issue wrecked the last four-power attempt to write a treaty for Austria, which fought as part of Germany during the war.
PORTLAND, Ore., Jan. 1 -- A political mystery of major proportions cloaks the failure of the Pacific Coast's vast horde of newcomers to appear at the polls on election day.

NEW DELHI, Jan. 1 (AP) -- Dispatches received today from Pakistan said India and Pakistan had agreed to withdraw their armed forces from the field in Kashmir and to divide the state into two zones, each having its own interim government.

THE most active and influential hand in this interesting volume of studies and reviews from the English literary quarterly Scrutiny is that of its editor, F. R. Leavis. A professor of English at Cambridge (where this sixteen-year-old journal of criticism is published), Leavis discusses the work of the critic, his relations with literary history, literary scholarship, and philosophy.

IT has always been a mystery why radio should avoid so studiously what could be a thoroughly rewarding form of programing -- the spoken essay. While there has been a deluge of authorities on politics and economics, there has been a dearth of thoughtful and reflective commentators on manners, morals and the arts.

THE cartoon shows two men with their pockets turned inside out; each extends the linings. Nothing has fallen from the pockets; nothing clings to the linings. Both gentlemen are broke. The caption: "The First Week of January."
Probably at no time in its history has this country been so divided in its economic thinking as it is now. This is particularly true in respect of matters of Federal taxes and governmental spending.

WHITHER piano playing? This is not an idle question in days when the technical and interpretive approach to the instrument has changed materially from what it was; when the piano, not only in the hands of many a modern performer, but in many a composer, is used as often for rhythmical and percussive effects as for lyrical ends in an age when science and mechanisms have made themselves strikingly evident in music.

NANKING, Jan. 1 -- A negotiated peace in China's civil war seemed virtually impossible tonight despite the Generalissimo's offer to step down from the Presidency if peace could be secured. The Communist radio denounced what it termed a combined Kuomintang-American "peace trick," talked about a crossing of the Yangtze River and announced the Communist aim as "liberation of all China."

IF laws of history were ever to be formulated, Henry Adams said half a century ago, they must of necessity be based largely on American experience. After the lapse of two generations whose wars and disasters gave some support to Adams' theory of the collapse of civilization itself, it is clear that the American experience is even more relevant to the formulation of laws of history than Adams realized.
EL PASO, Tex., Jan. 1 -- West Virginia's rugged Mountaineers spotted Texas Mines one touchdown today, then roared back for a 21-12 triumph in the Sun Bowl.
NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 1 (AP) -- The Oklahoma Sooners shouted and laughed as they ran to their dressing room after defeating the North Carolina Tar Heels in the Sugar Bowl today.
SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 1 -- Led by Fullback John Panelli of Notre Dame, the East squeezed out a 14-12 victory over the West today in the twenty-fourth annual Shrine charity football game.

IT is so smart in Paris to be blase about the Comedie Francaise that the French have not yet fully recognized the tremendous project which Administrator Pierre-Aime Touchard is gradually unfolding, play by play, before his public.

Raymond B. Fosdick's article, "We Need New Words and New Faith," is a display of scholarly nonsense which, were it not dangerous, would be ludicrous. Adding more words to the dictionary would have the same efficacy in solving world problems as the adoption by the U. N. of Sanskrit a working language. * * *
The necessity for putting currency stabilization ahead of other endeavors in Western Europe grows increasingly urgent.

THE auction season covered by this record was not one distinguished by the sale of many very expensive books: the high book price for the season was reached by Fernandez de Enciso's "Suma de geographia" [Sevilla, 1519], which brought $3,900; the highest for a letter, a two-page Lincoln letter on, the Emancipation Proclamation, was $5,800.

NANKING, Jan. 1 -- Although the Nationalists' civil war reverses have generated a groundswell of peace sentiment in Kuomintang China, there is little confidence here that the Nanking regime -- whether headed by President Chiang Kai-shek or Vice President Li Tsung-jen -- can work out a real coalition with the Communists.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Jan. 1 -- Jack Miller's perfect kicking gave Clemson College a surprise 24-23 victory over the University of Missouri in the fourth annual Gator Bowl game today. A crowd of 35,273 saw everything a football contest can offer.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 -- At the top of the back stairs in the Netherlands Embassy here there is a quotation by the Dutch poet Jacob Cats which reads as follows:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 -- J. D. Battle, executive vice president of the National Coal Association, said today it was essential that the work day of soft-coal miners not be shortened if the coal industry was to do its job in 1949.

Americans traveled 395 billion miles last year in 41,000,000 motor vehicles, a Federal survey, published yesterday, showed. The 1947 total was 370 billion travel miles. Many of the main routes are inadequate for traffic imposed upon them, particularly in urban areas, because they were not designed to meet modern needs.
FRESNO, Calif., Jan. 1 (AP) -- Occidental came from behind twice to upset Colorado A. and M., 21 -- 20, today in the Raisin Bowl before 10,000 fans.

Many youngsters who would like to visit the museums and other cultural institutions of the city are being deprived of that opportunity by traffic snarls, it was said yesterday by Mrs. Emory J. Barnes, president of the Women's City Club.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 (AP) -- The mines of the United States poured forth an unprecedented wealth, about $15,620,000,000, in 1948, Secretary of the Interior J. A. Krug reported today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 -- Senator Francis J. Myers, Democrat, of Pennsylvania, announced today that he would have a bill to increase the minimum wage from 40 cents to 75 cents an hour ready for introduction when the Eighty-first Congress convened on Monday.

NEW DELHI, Jan. 1 -- Dutch military action in Indonesia has evoked a strong reaction in India and the rest of Asia. Because India is the foremost friend of the Republic of Indonesia, New Delhi has become a clearing house of pro-Indonesian sentiment.

NICOSIA, Cyprus, Jan. 1 -- Keeping alive agitation for union with Greece, Archbishop Makarios of Cyprus devoted this year's New Year message for the Greeks of Cyprus to a demand for "national liberty, union and only union."

Although American book publishers had a busy year in 1948, there were relatively few gay faces as annual accounts were totted up. On the contrary, the general feeling was that the year as a whole had been a disappointment, and that 1949 might be more so still if means were not found to stem costs and increase sales.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 (UP) -- Senator Arthur Capper today marked the end of thirty years' service in the Senate with a nostalgic radio address to his constituents.

The treatment given by the Municipal Civil Service Commission to provisional employes on the clerical staffs of the four city colleges has imposed upon the Board of Higher Education "a system that authorizes hitting below the belt as contrasted with fair play," according to a letter written by Robert L. Taylor, Registrar of City College, to Dr. Ordway Tead, chairman of the board.

Sales during 1948 by the optical manufacturing industry, comprising 100 concerns, were about $150,000,000, a volume exceeded only in the war year of 1943, George B. Wells, president of the American Optical Company, Southbridge, Mass., reported at the year's, end.

Users and producers of advertising can look back at 1948 as a year of all-time highs in volume and expenditures approximating $4,000,000,000. In looking forward they find the prospects bright for still higher records.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Jan. 2 -- The Israeli Cabinet met tonight to consider the resolution of the United Nations Security Council calling for an immediate cease-fire in the Negeb, desert area in southern Palestine. There was no announcement made concerning the meeting except that the resolution was on the agenda.

HONG KONG, Jan. 2 -- Marshal Li Chi-shen, leading figure in China's leftist "Kuomintang Revolutionary Committee-in-Exile," secretly slipped out of this city on Dec. 27, en route to Communist-controlled North China, it was learned today.
WASHINGTON -- Officials of the Securities and Exchange Commission agree that the agency's legislative program for 1949 probably will be concerned with two important aspects of finance. These are:

SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico -- The Puerto Rican conception of the ideal "Americano" would seem to picture him as a man of substance who spends the winter in one of the island's tourist hotels, clamps native cigars between his teeth, has a predilection for Puerto Rican rum, uses local grown sugar and invests big wads in new industries for the island, thereby setting an example for all other Americans.

Heavy industry sales and operating rates are expected to jump 5 per cent above first quarter 1948 rates in the first quarter of this year, although physical volume of business may remain about the same. Increases are accounted for because of higher prices.
BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Jan. 2 -- A renewed demand for Federal Government financial assistance to alleviate the housing shortage here has been made by the Bridgeport Housing Authority.

PARIS, Monday, Jan. 3 -- With the calendars in both the Luxembourg and Bourbon palaces prominently displaying the date of Dec. 31 to support the fiction that the New Year had not started, the French Parliament last night concluded its 1948 legislation. Adjournment was taken to Jan. 11.

WASHINGTON -- The War Assets Administration was winding up at the close of 1948 the biggest sale of merchandise and real estate in history. Under law, the agency set up to handle the country's tremendous war surpluses will go out of business on Feb. 28.

Four major economic influences are at work to keep American business at a high level of operations during 1949, Herbert E. Smith, chairman of the board, United States Rubber Company, declared in a year-end statement. He said a serious recession was not likely but there undoubtedly would be some of the fluctuations and adjustments "normally experienced in a free economy."

Despite serious sales declines in most categories during the last quarter, total 1948 dollar volume for all home furnishings will exceed the record $10,500,000,000 set in 1947 by a small margin, according to estimates by industry leaders.

Gloria Van Dorpe, soprano, gave a recital yesterday afternoon at Times Hall. The program contained Italian offerings by Handel, Scarlatti and Giordani, German lieder by Schubert and Brahms, the aria "Mi tradi," from Mozart's "Don Giovanni," French lyrics by Hahn, Chabrier and Faure and a final group of English songs by Hadley, Nordoff, Thompson and others.

Time was when the children looked forward to having Mother and Dad read them a story before tucking them in for the night, when even Dad himself might keep the bedside lamp aglow for extra minutes while he finished a chapter of his favorite novel.

Student - sponsored activities ranging from square-dancing to fife-and-drum corps are being organized by the city's high schools as an inducement to academic endeavor, the Board of Education announced yesterday.

The Rev. Laurance I. Neale, minister of the Unitarian Church of All Souls, Lexington Avenue and Eightieth Street, suggested in his morning sermon yesterday that liberals begin acting like liberals again.

The year 1948 was marked by significant initial advances in several branches of the commercial air transport industry, but in the matter of profit and loss it was discouragingly similar to 1947. When the ledgers of most of the airlines were closed at year's end they were still ablaze with red ink.

The Broadway premiere of Boris Karloff's starring vehicle, "The Shop at Sly Corner," is now slated for Jan. 18. On that night it will be presented at the Booth by Gant Gaither. Residing there now is "Don't Listen, Ladies," which was brought over from London by Lee Ephraim with a cast headed by Jack Buchanan.

Bodil Giodvad, Danish pianist, was heard in her first New York recital last night at Town Hall. Her offerings included the Bach-Busoni Prelude and Fugue in D major; three sonatas by Scarlatti; Beethoven's Sonata, Op. 110; the Theme and Variations, Op. 40, by Carl Nielsen; two Etudes by Chopin, and Liszt's "Mephisto Waltz."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 -- Dollar value of trading in commodity futures markets in the year ended on last June 30 was the largest on record, it was brought out today in the annual report of J. C. Mehl, administrator of the Commodity Exchange Authority of the Department of Agriculture.

New Yorkers are at last to get a chance at sightseeing flights over the city -- and for a good cause. George E. Gardner, president of Northeast Airlines, announced yesterday that next Saturday and Sunday one of the company's 60-passenger DC-4 planes would make half-hour flights over the city and vicinity at a cost of $3 for adult and $1.50 for children under 12.

Retailers and manufacturers who do an aggressive selling job will enjoy continuing good business in 1949, according to a statement by G. R. Herberger, president of Butler Brothers, Chicago, dry goods wholesalers. Retailers, he said, must concentrate on the competitive battle that is shaping up.

The year just ended, marked by the fifteenth anniversary of repeal and new major setbacks to prohibitionists at the polls, brought a stronger social and economic position to the brewing industry, Edward V. Lahey, chairman and president of the United States Brewers Foundation, Inc., declared last week in a statement prepared for THE NEW YORK TIMES.

Nine specific proposals for changes in the Displaced Persons Act of 1948 to correct injustices and inequities have been sent to President Truman, Vice President-elect Alben W. Barkley, Congressional leaders and the chairmen of the Republican and Democratic National Committees, the National Community Relations Advisory Council announced yesterday.

DETROIT, Jan. 2 (AP) -- Five goals in 6 1/4 minutes of the final period brought the Detroit Red Wings roaring from behind to a 5-to-3 victory over the Chicago Black Hawks tonight. The triumph gave them sole possession of first place again in the National Hockey League.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 -- For the third time since the Wagner Act was passed in 1935, labor, management and the Government are coming to grips with the same problem -- how to increase the prospects of industrial peace by Federal statute.

As the Eighty-first Congress meets today interest will center on the effort to democratize the House by reducing the powers of the Rules Committee. Old-timers' memories may go back to 1910, when Representative (later Senator) George Norris of Nebraska led the revolt which clipped Speaker Cannon's wings.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 (AP) -- Many farmers, business and professional people have a tax date with the federal government Saturday, Jan. 15.

A marked revival in public housing operations under the impetus of new Federal and state legislation, a greater emphasis on lower-price homes, extension of Government rent controls and a decline in general building activity may be expected in 1949.

While 400 patrons sensed that something was wrong, because the motion-picture screen went blank and remained so for several minutes, two armed men help up the Normandie Theatre in East Fifty-first Street, just off Park Avenue, last night, escaping with receipts of $1,100 to $1,200.

The state's housing program can best serve municipalities when it is carried out in connection with a neighborhood development plan, Herman T. Stichman, State Housing Commissioner, declared in his annual report yesterday to Governor Dewey and the State Legislature for the fiscal year ending last March.

A two-alarm fire that was reported originally as having been of suspicious origin but later was listed officially as of "undetermined origin but under investigation" caused considerable damage last night to the School of Pharmacy building of Fordham University in the Bronx.

VIENNA, Jan. 2 -- Word from Budapest tonight was that the arrest of Cardinal Mindszenty would be followed within the next month by either the voluntary or arbitrary dissolution of the People's party, the only remaining organized opposition to the otherwise complete Communist domination of the Hungarian Parliament.

An African area of about four and a half million square miles, an area equal to that of the United States, Mexico and the Province of Quebec combined, is ruled by several varieties of tsetse flies, dreaded carriers of trypanosomiasis, or sleeping sickness. In that fly-infested tract lie agricultural, mineral and forest riches that cannot now be touched.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 (UP) -- Senator Tom Connally, incoming chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committe, promised top priority today to action on new recovery and military aid for Western Europe.

The American plastics industry completed to a large extent last year the tremendous expansion program begun after World War II, according to George H. Clark president of the Society of the Plastics Industry and vice president of the Formica Company, Cincinnati, Ohio.

The Kaiser-Frazer Corporation, a little more than three years old now, but the fourth largest producer of automobiles in the country, rose to its high estate by dint of several important plant acquisitions and by the efficient operation of a large purchasing staff in the procurement of materials for its own uses and those of its suppliers.

PARIS. Jan. 2 -- The Queen Mary was pulled out of Cherbourg Harbor mud at 10 A. M. and sailed for Southampton. The ship ran aground during a violent storm as she at tempted to leave the harbor shortly before last midnight.

Forty-five years ago Albert Einstein promulgated the then little-understood equation, E=MC2. It means that energy equals mass, times the square of the speed of light, which speed is roughly 186,000 miles a second.
Stock prices during 1948, as measured by THE NEW YORK TIMES average of fifty stocks, followed the pattern of a nursery rhyme. Like "Jack and Jill," they climbed up a hill and then came tumbling down.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 (UP) -- The American Federation of Labor would press for a thirty-hour work week to spread employment as soon as and if the national economy showed signs of slowing down, Daniel W. Tracy, president of the Brotherhood of Electrical Workers, said today.

The market for high-grade investments is carrying over into the new year a record of sustained stabilization following the progressive declines of two years ago. With the Federal Reserve System standing by its pledge to use full powers to prevent any disorderly decline in basic bond prices, the firmness of the pegged Treasury bonds seemingly has been communicated to the corporate list.
United States military aviation made major strides in its transition to the jet age in 1948.
LOS ANGELES -- Southern California's industrial and commercial area activities continued in 1948 the phenomenal growth which it has been undergoing almost without interruption for eighty years.

WASHINGTON -- After nine months and an expenditure of nearly $5,000,000,000, the most that can be said of the Marshall Plan is that Western Europe has been saved from communism and started on the road to economic recovery.

The most spectacular development of the year in the field of atomic energy was the successful testing of three new designs of atomic bombs at the secret proving grounds on Eniwetok in the Pacific. From the guarded announcement it is obvious that methods had been devised to improve the efficiency in the utilization of uranium 235 and plutonium, the active components of the A-bomb.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 (UP) -- Capt. K. A. Simko of Chicago, the pilot of a commercial airliner, tonight guided to the safety of the Pittsburgh Municipal Airport an Air Force pilot "lost" over western Pennsylvania.

Establishment of an annual award to the American "making the most outstanding contribution toward the fostering of better relations between the United States and Israel" was announced yesterday at the semi-annual conference of B'nai Zion, the fraternal Zionist Organization of America, at the Astor Hotel.
New life insurance purchased by United States policyholders in legal reserve companies in 1948 was estimated at $22,700,000,000, or within 2 per cent of the high record volume of 1947.
Higher reserve requirements, firmer money rates and a further expansion in demand for credit caused a marked alteration in the composition of bank assets in 1948.
WASHINGTON -- Peacetime military preparedness for the fiscal year 1950 will be the most costly effort of its kind ever undertaken by the United States.

Year-end changes in partnerships and personnel in the financial industry were announced yesterday. They include the admission of two general partners into the firm of Wood, Walker Co. The new partners are Allan H. McAlpin Jr. and John T. McClintock. The organization also announced the admission of Howard O. Wood Jr. as a limited partner.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 -- A National Labor Relations Board examiner ruled today that the agency had jurisdiction over a labor dispute involving a $325 electrical sub-contract on a $15,000 house in Greenwich, Conn.

Recent additions of new equipment have made the Standard Wholesale Phosphate and Acid Works, Baltimore, Md., the largest sulphuric acid producing plant in the world, William F. Nylander, chairman of the board, declared in a statement following installation of a new unit designed and built by Chemical Construction Corporation, a unit of American Cyanamid Corporation.
DETROIT -- The automotive industry, emerging from its twelve best months of production since 1929, is looking ahead confidently to an even better record in 1949.

A blunt warning that any further increase in wages paid to the nation's transport workers "must necessarily be passed on to the riders by further fare increases if the operating companies are to continue to furnish satisfactory service," was sounded yesterday by the American Transit Association.

During the war period it was assured that a basically sound post war Federal tax system would be devised; one which could be made sufficiently flexible to meet the requirements of changing national fiscal needs by the mere adjustment of rates.

On top of an almost 35 per cent increase in net sales in 1948 over 1947, the Avco Manufacturing Corporation is projecting an even larger sales volume of its various products this year, it was announced over the week-end by Raymond C. Cosgrove, executive vice president.

What is ahead for the stock market in 1949? Will it adhere to the base of operations used as a yardstick for the last two years -- a rate of approximately 117.00 as indicated by THE NEW YORK TIMES index of fifty stocks -- or will funds available for investment be coaxed through economic developments into channels of better employment?
WASHINGTON -- The year 1948, the third after the war, was supposed to be the year of depression, or recession, according to a majority of the economic doctors.

The "victory" hunger pangs remained with the New York Rovers yesterday afternoon at Madison Square Garden. Staying even with the visitors for only one period, the Red Shirts dropped their tenth straight contest to the Quebec Aces, 7 to 4, in a Quebec Senior Hockey League game.

The foreign exchange market encountered a mixed trend last week. This was due to the fact that adjustments for the year-end had been completed, and to the prevalence of the holiday spirit which ran over from the preceding week.
Evolution of the post-war money market pattern appears to have been arrested as the year 1949 opens.

NEWARK, N. J., Jan. 2 (AP) -- The New Jersey State Racing Commission made its eighth annual report to Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll today and expressed itself as eminently satisfied with the results of the 1948 campaign.
President Truman's State of the Nation message -- and Congress' legislative reaction to it -- will exert a decisive influence on the 1949 program of the copper industry.

Retailers can look forward with reasonable assurance to a continuance of good business for the next six months, J. Gordon Dakins, general manager of the National Retail Dry Goods Association, predicted last week.

Wagner's "Siegfried" will be performed at the Metropolitan Opera House for the first time this season on Friday, Jan. 14. Set Svanholm, Swedish tenor, will make his first appearance of the season in the title role.

For the third successive year new rubber consumption in 1948 in the United States topped the million-ton mark. It amounted to an estimated 1,070,000 long tons, compared with 1,122,000 in 1947 and 1,039,000 in 1946. Forecasts indicate that consumption this year will be nearly as large as that in 1948.

Earnings of American industry last year approximated $20,000,000,000, exceeding the 1947 returns by $2,000,000,000 and more than doubling the profits of the lush year of 1929. This new record probably will mark the final year of the continuing rise to high profits.

It is apparent that the general readjustment has not yet run its course and produced a price level acceptable to the majority of retail customers. Jack I. Straus, president of R. H. Macy Co., Inc., declared last week in a year-end review.
A man who turned in a false alarm to get a taxicab and then allegedly struck a policeman was held in $500 bail by Magistrate Vernon C. Riddick in Week-End Court yesterday.

SAN JUAN, P. R., Jan. 2 -- Puerto Rico inaugurated Luis Munoz Marin, former Greenwich Village writer, as its first elected Governor today in a colorful celebration that brought out the greatest crowd in the history of this Caribbean island in a festive mood.

PARIS, Jan. 2 -- The total dollar, aid asked for European recovery in the year from June 30, 1949, to June 30, 1950, has been finally fixed by the European Council for the Marshall Plan at $4,347,000,000. This is $528,000,000 less than the European states will have received for the twelve months that will end on April 30.

Editor and Publisher predicts a prosperous 1949 for American newspapers. In its Jan. 1 issue, the publishers and advertisers' weekly says advertising linage, barring unexpected developments, should surpass 1948's record total; circulation will remain at a high level; more newsprint will be available, and new equipment will be easier to get.

PROVIDENCE, R. I., Jan. 2 -- A downward revision of 1949 production schedules is being planned by top management in the textile machinery industry of southern New England in a move to spread operations equally over the next twelve months.
AMMAM, Trans-Jordan, Jan. 2 -- Appearing before a mass meeting at Ramallah, north of Jerusalem, today, King Abdullah spoke his personal approval of merging Arab Palestine with Trans-Jordan.

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N. Y., Jan. 2 -- A large array of "riders" today packed the improved Bear Mountain fifty-meter hill hopeful that the weather gods will be cooperative and permit the holding of the F. D. Roosevelt and Harold Nelson Memorial Ski Jump one week from today.

Shareholders in American corporations received more dividends in 1948 than in any year since the war ended, according to an estimate on the basis of payments made in the first eleven months of the year. Cash dividends publicly reported may approximate $5,750,000,000 for 1948, compared with $5,174,000,000 voted in 1947.

WASHINGTON -- Many observers believed the campaign attacks of President Truman against Wall Street, vested interests and powerful combinations, were just so much outdated political oratory, merely contributing to his expected defeat.

One billion dollars in Federal funds has been allocated to New York State since the Social Security Act became effective in 1936, Joseph B. O'Connor, regional director of the Federal Security Administration, reported yesterday.
Segal Safety Razor Corporation, a division of Segal Lock Hardware Company, to Cayton, Inc., for its Segalock three-way safety razor. Newspapers, radio and television.

WARSAW, Jan. 2 -- Even dressed in winter's grim garb of slush and snow, Warsaw is an impressive sight to a resident who has been out of Poland for three months. The reconstruction achieved in this short period takes one's breath away.

Ingvar Bengtsson and Eric Ahlden, Swedish runners who will compete in indoor track meets here, arrived in New York yesterday aboard a Scandinavian Airlines plane. Daniel J. Ferris, secretary-treasurer of the National A. A. U., greeted the athletes at Idlewild International Airport.

ALBANY, Jan. 2 -- An increase in state taxes will provide the main issue before the new Legislature when it convenes on Wednesday for its 172d annual session, it appeared today. It is the first time in ten years that a rise in state taxes is being seriously considered.

Young singers with a lot to give are apt to be prodigal with their resources. And Francine Falkon, New York contralto, who gave her second Town Hall recital yesterday afternoon, should be perhaps more careful in her expenditures

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 2 -- This city's all-Negro police unit, a special squad established in 1943 and believed to be the first of its kind in the country, reported today that it made 1,414 arrests last year and obtained convictions in 97 per cent of the cases that reached court.

After months of copper shortages, hope appeared at the year's end that sufficient metal would be available during 1949 to serve the needs of industry without diminishing the essential military and foreign aid programs, C. Donald Dallas, chairman of the board, Revere Copper and Brass, Incorporated, 230 Park Avenue, disclosed in a year-end statement for THE NEW YORK TIMES.

Seventy women representing professional, civic, political and fraternal women's organizations departed by train late yesterday afternoon for Washington where today they will pay tribute to Senator-elect Margaret Chase Smith of Maine and the eight women elected to the House of Representatives of the Eighty-first Congress.
JERUSALEM, Jan. 2 -- Unidentified warplanes bombed Jerusalem twice tonight, injuring at least five persons. It was the first time in nearly six months that the city had been attacked from the air.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 -- The National Farmers Union called today for the removal of James Forrestal as Secretary of Defense on the ground that he was "recklessly juggling" with the issue of war and peace.

PARIS, Jan. 2 -- French authorities could not be reached late tonight for comment on the report of a traveler from Indo-China that the French were losing the Viet Nam war. These reports, however, contradict the most recent pronouncements here.

STEVE O'NEILL was a complacent man and he had complacent coaches. He also had a much too complacent ball club. When Red Rolfe succeeded genial Steve as the boss one of his first moves was to hire a real holler guy as his assistant -- Rowdy Richard Bartell. The bellicose shortstop of yesteryear is just what the doctor ordered.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 (AP) -- A House subcommittee said today that "union-busting" activities of fur manufacturers were largely responsible for Communist infiltration of the CIO International Fur and Leather Workers Union.

One of the most notable industrial developments in the last year was the sharp increase in the supply of scrap metal for the steel and foundry industries. In the final months of the year scrap was available not only to permit near-capacity operations in these industries but also to permit slight additions to inventories.
David James has been appointed vice president and treasurer of Kass Fabrics, Inc., rayon converter, and the concern will be known henceforth as Kass-James Fabrics, Inc.,

ATHENS, Jan. 2 -- The visit of Averell Harriman brings into the foreground the question which most agitates Greece as it enters another year of exhausting war. At least the shooting has stopped in other countries of Europe. Here war has become a condition of life and the people see no end to their ordeal.
RANGOON, Burma, Jan. 2 -- Former Premier Ba Maw said today that a Burmese expeditionary force would leave soon for Indonesia to take up arms against the Dutch.

ALBANY, Jan. 2 -- Governor Dewey announced today the appointment of a committee to draft legislation putting operation of the state civil service system under a single director with a bipartisan board exercising rule-making and quasi-judicial powers.

DARIEN, Conn., Jan. 2 -- Peg's Pride, gray gelding from the Hutchinson Farms of New Rochelle, N. Y., today took two jumper blues at the nineteenth annual Ox Ridge Hunt Club indoor horse show, with Miss Peggy Johnson riding. Hydro Fashion, owned by Albertus A. Moore of Fairfield, Conn., scored in the working hunter competition.

Man-made "cold rubber" will be in large-scale production in America's chemical rubber plants by the latter part of 1949, James J. Newman, vice president of the B. F. Goodrich Company, said in a year-end statement of the industry.
PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., Jan. 2 -- Despite a continuation of the northwest wind, an attempt was made today to hold the eighteenth annual regatta of the Frostbite Yacht Club.
Probably the most significant single development in United States' foreign trade last year was the increase in imports to a new high figure approximating $7,000,000,000.

BOSTON -- Despite soft spots in several industries during 1948, New England business leaders generally faced the new year with confidence that complete returns would show this region's economy had continued flexible enough to withstand present pressures.
The highest food prices in history will ever be a blot on 1948. But fortunately, in the world of food, as this column viewed it, other things happened, too, of happier memory.
The year 1948 was a period of radical adjustment for the American merchant marine, and this year will be one of critical decisions for the industry.

ATHENS, Jan. 2 -- The Truman Administration plans to ask Congress to appropriate between $400,000,000 and $500,000,000 for economic and military aid to Greece during the 1949-50 fiscal year, it is reliably reported here today.

Radio and television have provided religion with a "new dimension" for the promotion of the gospel, the Rev. Everett C. Parker, newly appointed director of program and production of the Protestant Radio Commission, said yesterday.

CHICAGO, Jan. 2 -- Readjustment from a basis of war and scarcity to one of peace and a surplus supply of grains has been expected in the last twelve months, and brokers are unanimous in the belief that the high prices witnessed early in 1948 are a thing of the past.

Hazel Scott, the beauteous young Trinidadian pianist known to nightclub circles for a good many years, last night gave her first recital in Carnegie Hall. Her program was a mixture of familiar classical compositions and the sophisticated keyboard improvisations which made her famous.

The Rev. William J. Walter and the Rev. Thomas Xavier Lewis, Jesuit priests and former Army chaplains, received mission mandates to the Marshall and Caroline Islands yesterday at a departure ceremony in the Roman Catholic Church of St. Ignatius Loyola, Park Avenue and Eighty-fourth Street.

WASHINGTON -- Washington prognosticators prophesied weeks ago that President Truman, being opposed to deficit financing, would call for higher taxes to meet the increased requirements of national defense and foreign aid in the budget for 1950. The prediction still looks good today.
The supply of aluminum, which in 1948 fell far short of satisfying domestic demand, will be considerably tighter in 1949 as the nation starts its big aircraft production program for national defense.

AMSTERDAM, Jan. 2 -- Prof. Simon Posthuma, manager of the Bank of the Netherlands, in last week's issue of Economisch Statistische Berichten warned the Netherlands that Dutch recovery so far has been made possible only by liquidation of overseas assets, gold shares and foreign credits and by the aid of the European Recovery Program.

Three years after the cessation of hostilities finds the United States still in the throes of readjustment. Although production, employment and earnings increased to record levels in 1948, cracks were beginning to show in the inflationary trend as the new year began.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Jan. 2 -- What appeared to be Egypt's first attempt to set up a naval blockade against Israel-bound ships in the Mediterranean took place Friday night, just prior to the shelling of Tel Aviv, when two warships intercepted a British-registered freighter sixty miles off the Israeli coast.

There is need for hundreds more social workers to serve in the voluntary hospitals of the city, Mrs. Edith G. Seltzer, director of the Consultation Service in Medical Social Work of the United Hospital Fund, said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 -- The National Council against Conscription today branded as "false" any claims that the new Congress held a mandate from the people to continue the draft and create universal military training.

Belief that retail trade will continue strong for at least the first six months of 1949 is held by most merchants as the new year begins. Expectations of increased employment, a decline in living costs and higher wages are used as a basis for believing that consumer-buying power will increase during the year.

With the proposed Second Avenue subway at least eight years from reality, the Board of Transportation is contemplating two major steps, to cost $35,000,000, toward interim relief of bottleneck conditions on the city subway lines, it was learned yesterday.

Eight factors have combined to provide a bright outlook in electrical manufacturing despite the change of some lines from a seller's to a buyer's market, Don G. Mitchell, president, Sylvania Electric Products, Inc., said in a statement here last week.

Jesus Christ and the teachings of the Christian church can provide the leadership and the principles necessary for a plan of recovery for the world today, the Rev. Gustav J. Schultheiss, assistant chancellor of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York, declared yesterday.
WASHINGTON -- The year 1948 goes down in the annals of agriculture as bringing relief at last from the critical post-war world shortage of bread grains.

SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico -- Production of sugar in 1948 amounted to 1,108,260 short tons with an estimated value of $111,000,000. Of this total 1,007,000 tons were sold to the United States and the armed forces outside the continental United States.
Dangerous flood conditions were well past yesterday in the northeastern states, but there was no end yet to the discomfort and damage caused by swollen rivers and new snows.

Norman Atkins, gifted American baritone, who made his New York debut in 1947, was the performer in yesterday's Twilight Concert at Carnegie Hall. The recital, postponed from Oct. 31 when the young singer became suddenly ill, was attended by an enthusiastic audience.
The $16,000,000,000 private electric light and power industry received $3,870,000,000 in return for the 336,000,000,000 kilowatt-hours of electricity generated for 40,800,000 customers during 1948.
BERLIN, Jan. 2 -- Six years ago Field Marshal Gen. Friedrich von Paulus surrendered the remnants of his German Army of 330,000 men to the Russians at Stalingrad.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 (UP) -- Business had better resign itself to tax increases unless Congress trims President Truman's 1949-50 budget, Senator Ralph E. Flanders, Republican, of Vermont, said today.
PARIS, Jan. 2 -- The year 1948, according to French financial experts, was a poor one for holders of stocks. In fact, the gains that were registered were less than the average rise in prices.

A car that went out of control yesterday killed a 3-year-old boy who was walking with his father on a sidewalk in Astoria, Queens. The car then hit a building, crossed the street and crashed into a delicatessen. The driver was hurt slightly.

BATAVIA, Java, Jan. 2 (AP) -- Dutch forces nearly completed today the successful occupation of all key areas of the Indonesian Republic in Sumatra. All major Republican points in Java already are in Dutch hands.
WASHINGTON, Jen. 2 (UP) -- The Social Legislation Information Service, Inc., announced today it is expanding its list to include an additional 2,000 organizations.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 (UP) -- Senator Burnet R. Maybank of South Carolina, who may be chairman of the Senate Banking Committee in the new Congress, said today that he saw no need at present for any sort of price control legislation.

DES MOINES, Ia. -- With net income down this year for the first time in ten years, farmers in the Midwest "breadbasket" foresee a further decline next year to add to their worries and perhaps cause a national problem.

Virginia Shaw, soprano, chose a program of contemporary songs in English for her second New York recital last night at Times Hall. She sang groups by Ernst Bacon, John Duke, Gian-Carlo Menotti and Theodore Chanler, with her first set consisting of settings by six different composers of poems by James Joyce.

The Carver Federal Savings and Loan Association, an institution organized and sponsored by Negroes of this city in a spirit of community self - help, will be opened formally next Wednesday at 52 West 125th Street.

With their slightly lower volume of traffic augmented by higher freight and passenger rates, the nation's railroads last year pushed gross revenues to a new record level. The steadily increasing cost of operation, however, again took virtually all the increase in their receipts, with the result that the industry as a whole was unable to re-establish itself on a healthy financial basis.

Despite the fact that lead consumers and the Government were supplied with more lead in 1948 than in any pre-war year and an amount equal to peak wartime consumption, there was insufficient metal to take care of all demands, according to the Lead Industries Association.

An entirely new pattern of licensing for steel exports now confronts members of the National Association of Steel Exporters, after a year of complex negotiations on problems of international trade, Morris Rosoff, general counsel, revealed during an interview at his offices at 150 Broadway yesterday.

The post-war shortage of steel is expected to continue throughout 1949, but steel leaders are confident that the supply situation will have been eased considerably by the end of the year if their production goal of at least 90,000,000 tons of raw steel is achieved.

The last night of Hanukkah, the 8-day Jewish Festival of Lights, commemorating the victory of the Maccabeans in their war for religious liberty against the Syrians twenty-one centuries ago, was ushered in last night with the lighting of all eight candles on the traditional Menorah.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 2. -- Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer has named Gloria De Haven and Donna Reed to appear with Van Johnson in "Scene of the Crime," which Harry Rapf will produce, starting early in February. Roy Roland has been assigned to direct the photoplay which Charles Schnee has written from a magazine article by John Bartlow Martin dealing with Chicago bookmaking.
CHICAGO, Jan. 2. -- Chicago's leading financial institutions today began issuing their annual reports, all of which showed profits for last year.
LONDON, Jan. 2 -- British authorities were faced today with two mysteries that could well tax the ingenuity of writers of detective thrillers.

The Budd Company broke all its production records last year and sales, expected to exceed $200,000,000, would compare favorably with the 1947 total of $183,500,132, Edward G. Budd Jr., president, said in a year-end summary.

Pointing up the important place low-priced issues have taken in the volume of trading in recent years, a stock selling for less than $5 a share, for the fourth successive year, was the most active issue traded on the New York Stock Exchange in 1948, a survey of transactions in the twenty most active issues by THE NEW YORK TIMES for the years 1917 to 1948 inclusive, disclosed.

The rubber industry's statistical data for the last three post-war years show a rapid peacetime conversion in 1946, the soaring of tire production to a record high in 1947 and the leveling off to a more normal market in 1948, P. W. Litchfield, board chairman of the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company, said in reviewing the industry.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 2 (AP) -- Football stars who played in the New Year's Day East-West game scattered today, some to their homes, some back to school and others to Hawaii to participate in two more contests.

Creation by the state of an Enterprise Finance Corporation with adequate capital to be financed by bond issues was called for yesterday by the Liberal party in its legislative program, copies of which will be sent today to members of the Legislature.
DETROIT -- A shortage of automobiles at home and a lack of dollars abroad combined in 1948 to produce one of the worst peacetime export years in the auto industry in nearly a quarter of a century.

LONDON, Jan. 2 -- The mammoth Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary is safely back in Southampton tonight, and it is hoped she will sail for New York at midday tomorrow. She went aground last evening just outside Cherbourg and was refloated this morning.

ALBANY, Jan. 2 -- A proposal to require employers to carry sickness and disability insurance for the benefit of employes who become ill either with private companies or as self-insurers is being favorably considered by the Dewey administration, it was learned today.

SAN JUAN, P. R. -- Luis Munoz Marin, inducted into office on Jan. 2 as Puerto Rico's first elected Governor, hammered on the idea throughout the campaign resulting in an overwhelming victory for him, that the island's fundamental economic asset was free trade with the United States in the entry of goods in the American market not subject to tariff restrictions, a privilege envied by the world's richest nations.
The American petroleum industry has just closed its most momentous year.

The traditional observance of the Christmas holiday sharply cut activity in the wholesale apparel market here last week, according to reports prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices. A large number of out-of-town buyers plan to visit the market during January to round out orders for spring merchandise, it was said.
LONDON, Jan. 2 -- A British move to counter Israel's reported incursion last week into Egypt is expected tomorrow.

Six months of freedom from major strikes are likely to usher in the new year. What happens after that will depend largely on what limits organized labor sets to its demands for a fourth-round wage increase and how completely the rest of industry accepts the thesis of Henry Ford 2d that some increase is "inevitable."

A large collection of Hebraic and Talmudic literature, together with fourteen Holy Scrolls, was destroyed early yesterday in a two-alarm fire that wrecked the interior of Congregation Sfath Emeth at 1337 Forty-second Street, Brooklyn.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2. -- Within a period of less than a week President Truman will address three messages to the incoming Eighty-first Congress, repeating for the most part requests for legislation that the outgoing Eightieth Congress failed to heed.

The Himala International, an exporting and importing company at 82 Wall Street, has complained to the Maritime Commission that the North Atlantic Mediterranean Freight Conference is "inherently a conspiracy" and in unreasonable restraint of trade, it became known yesterday.
Five new films, including importations from England and France, will open in midtown theatres this week. The programs follow:
The 1949 business outlook for the variety store trade is good, Dr. Paul H Nystrom, president of the Limited Price Variety Stores Association, Inc., predicted last week

Continuing a trend that has been in effect since 1945, bonds called before maturity for payment in 1948 fell to the lowest total for any year since 1933. Prepayments last year totaled $417,510,000, against $1,844,505,000 in 1947, $3,649,132,000 in 1946 and $4,656,630,000 in 1945.

SEOUL, Korea, Jan. 2 -- Full United States recognition of the Korean Republic "has dispelled all shadows of doubt as to the ability of the Korean people to conduct their own affairs as an independent sovereign nation," President Syngman Rhee declared today.

At last Lynn Patrick knows how it feels to win on home ice. The new coach of the Rangers, whose charges lost and tied the first two games played at Madison Square Garden under his direction, finally came through for him before 15,545 fans last night by subduing the Toronto Maple Leafs, 4 to 2.
MOSCOW, Jan. 2 (AP) -- The Soviet Ministry of Cinematography released "Michurin," the new motion picture in color, throughout the Soviet Union today after a tremendous publicity campaign.

In reading Robert Moses' letter on monuments we may easily be misled by his bold words into believing that, as he would have us understand, he alone has long since known when a monument is a monument and when it is not. Let us see.

SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico -- Expansion of Puerto Rico's far-reaching industrialization program will be one of the major aims of the insular officials under the leadership of Luis Munoz Marin, the island's first elected native governor, who has just taken office.

Considerable evidence has appeared that high break-even points now just short of capacity in some industries may act as the triggers that set off "chain reactions of industrial cut-backs" during 1949, because in studies of a number of individual companies, it has been found that some financial contracts are hinged to conditions that require protection of specified amounts of surplus capital.

" The future of the selling profession and the maintenance of a free economy in this country are interdependent and interrelated," said Louis A. Capaldo, president of the National Council of Salesmen's Organizations, Inc., in reviewing the 1948 accomplishments and outlining the 1949 program of the council.

MANILA, Jan. 2 -- Quoting an observer recently returned from Indo-China, The Manila Daily Bulletin will say tomorrow that the French are losing the war there against Communist rebels led by Moscow-trained Ho Chi Minh, who already occupy more than one-third of the colony's land area.
Did President Truman talk over the heads of reporters the other day when he described the recent election as "the late unpleasantness"? (THE NEW YORK TIMES, Dec. 20.)

Back in the early days of the depression of the Thirties, a very wise man (if recollection serves, it was the late Dwight W. Morrow) was asked: "When will we know deflation has come to an end?" He replied: "About six months after it has happened."

The nation's 1948 cotton crop was the seventh largest in history. Officially estimated at 14,937,000 bales, it will bring farmers a record return of more than $2,600,000,000, despite the fact that it was about 20 per cent below the peak harvest of 18,948,000 bales from the 1937 crop.
PASADENA, Calif., Jan. 2 (AP) -- Did Northwestern Fullback Art Murakowski get the ball across the goal line before he fumbled it in the Rose Bowl thriller? Or didn't he?

Three books by Winston Churchill are scheduled for publication this spring by Houghton Mifflin. The second volume of his war memoirs, "Their Finest Hour," will be issued in April. Excerpts from this book, which covers the period from the time he became Prime Minister in 1940 to the fall of Tobruk, will run daily in THE NEW YORK TIMES beginning on Feb. 4 and weekly in Life magazine.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 -- Representative Hugh Scott Jr., Republican National Chairman, today claimed "overwhelming approval" by the GOP rank-and-file of his proposal for a party policy conference this year, which the national committee will consider at its meeting in Omaha, Neb., Jan. 26 and 27.

American business is entering a period of moderate readjustment. There are signs that the inflationary trend has been checked. There are no immediate indications of a recession or of dangerous unemployment. These are among the conclusions reached in a special section on business, industry and finance which this newspaper publishes today.

CHICAGO, Jan. 2 (AP) -- The famed Chick Evans caddy scholar house of Northwestern University in nearby Evanston will become golf's hall of fame, the Golf Writers' Association of America announced today.

ROME, Jan. 2 -- The Vatican announced tonight it had rejected an offer just made by the Hungarian Government to undertake direct negotiations for an agreement on the status of the Catholic Church in Hungary. The offer cannot be considered as long as Joseph Cardinal Mindszenty -- whose attitude the Vatican supports fully -- is in jail, it was stated.
Machine - printed wallpapers ranging in price from 75 cents to $5 a roll are fast catching up in distinction of design with the more expensive hand-screened variety.
The American people consumed more coffee in 1948 than ever before. A further increase is likely in 1949.
NANKING, Jan. 2 (AP) -- The Chinese Government apparently was struggling today to prevent its North China command from making a separate peace with the Communists.

The death rate from automobile accidents in New York last year was the lowest since the motorcar came into widespread use, the Health Department said yesterday in its 1948 report. The drop was laid to safety campaigns.

The year 1948 was one of adjustments, price and production-wise, for the textile and apparel trades. Despite talk of production cutbacks, over-all output in the textile industry was maintained at peak peacetime levels. That a large part of these goods went to fill pipelines of distribution and to build up inventories of wholesale and retail distributors has been shown by the downward trend of prices.
The Eightieth Congress last year passed the Sugar Quota Law to be effective for five years. Under this law the Secretary of Agriculture established a quota of 7,800,000 tons.

CHICAGO -- With a sizable part of next year's markets underwritten by the Marshall Plan, the great industrial, commercial and agricultural complex of the Central West expects to continue through 1949 with an economy of generally high employment, production and income.

The three men who provided the greatest news in the fields of aviation and aircraft manufacturing during 1948 were Juan T. Trippe, president of Pan American Airways Corporation; C. R. Smith, chairman of American Airlines, and Floyd B. Odlum, chairman of the Consolidated Vultee Aircraft Corporation.

Output of wooden household furniture in the United States reached a new all-time record high of $1,550,000,000 at manufacturers' prices during 1948, an increase of 8 per cent over 1947, Seidman Seidman, certified public accountants, reported over the week-end.

LONDON, Jan. 2 -- A gloomy view of the whole world, surrendering to a centralized totalitarian government, was taken tonight by Bertrand Russell (Earl Russell) in the second Reith Lecture, broadcast by the British Broadcasting Corporation.

LONDON, Jan. 2 -- Despite all worries, both political and economic, the past year was not an unfavorable period for investors. The gilt-edge stock index finished the year practically the same as it began it, while the industrial share index opened the year at 129.0, dipped to 109.2 in July and finished at 121.3, thus making good over half of its earlier loss.

The United States Lines announced yesterday that its ships had carried 102,061 passengers during 1948.
