In a review of ship activity for the year the company said that 101,685 travelers crossed the Atlantic on 497 sailings, including thirty-two sailings of the liner America and thirty of the one-class liner Washington.
Good business for the liquor industry marked by strong competitive tendencies during 1949 was predicted last week by W. L. Lyons Brown, president of the Brown-Forman Distillers Corporation.

Brazilian industry will be aided by a long-term licensing agreement between the Westinghouse Electric International Company and Eletromar, an electrical manufacturing company in Brazil, which has been signed here between William E. Knox, president of the Westinghouse company, and Senator Arthur Bernardes Jr., president of Eletromar, it was announced yesterday.

Reuben Fine of Flushing, recently returned from Los Angeles with a doctor's degree in psychology, emerged as winner of the international masters tournament at the Manhattan Chess Club last night after defeating Israel A. Horowitz, former national open champion, in twenty-nine moves.
From a financial standpoint, the year just ended was a most significant one for the domestic aircraft manufacturing industry, but prospects for 1949 are even better.

PITTSBURGH, Jan. 2 -- Steel makers greeted the new year with some caution but with the knowledge that more steel would be turned out this year than last year. The note of caution comes from belief that more steel pipelines will be filled this year and that more and more consumers will be revising their requirements.

The newest link in the growing chain of the Navy's reserve training facilities will be formally established on Jan. 15 at the New York Naval Shipyard, Brooklyn, with the dedication of an $850,000 naval reserve submarine training center.

Credit expansion during 1948 was especially marked in the field outside commercial banking, with life insurance companies, savings banks and savings and loan associations increasing their advances to private borrowers approximately $9,000,000,000 during the year ended in October.

MANSFIELD, Ohio -- Westinghouse Electric Corporation produced and sold during 1948 more than 2,500,000 appliances with a factory billing exceeding $150,000,000, J. H. Ashbaugh, vice president in charge of the electric appliance division reported here today in a year-end statement.

The nation's gold stock, which reached a record high of $24,230,000,000 on Dec. 15, probably will continue to grow during 1949 although at a diminishing rate, according to financial observers. During the twelve-month period prior to the December date, the increase in the Government's gold pile amounted to $1,507,000,000.

The twelve indicted Communist leaders mapped strategy over the week-end to delay their trial, set for two weeks from today, as the special Federal grand jury prepared to resume its espionage inquiry this morning.

JOHN DOS PASSOS has always been a sad and bitter man. When young he wrote "Three Soldiers," one of the first books which looked upon the First World War with angry disillusionment. As he grew older he looked upon modern society with the fury of a sensitive idealist who cannot bear that there should be cruelty, corruption and injustice in the world.

After the usual holiday inactivity in the art field, the new year opens with a large number of exhibitions in museums and galleries. Today's events include a selection of paintings and drawings at the Kraushaar Gallery -- work by William Glackens, illustrating his development from 1895 to his death.

Celebrating the enfranchisement of all American Indians last year, representatives of leading tribes will hold a powwow and exhibition in the Museum of Science and Industry in Rockefeller Center beginning tomorrow at 10 A. M. and continuing through Sunday, it was announced yesterday.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Dec. 27 -- The first draft of the constitution completed by the delegates to the West German parliamentary assembly at Bonn is being studied by political experts of the United States, British and French Military Governments.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 -- The new Congress, opening tomorrow with much feminine fanfare due to the swearing-in of Senator Margaret Chase Smith, Republican, of Maine, promises to be outstanding in its "woman-interest."
MOSCOW, Jan. 2 (AP) -- The Communist newspaper Pravda said today that continuing declines had occurred in the living standard of American workers.

The Rev. Dr. Charles B. Foelsch, pastor of the Lutheran Church of the Holy Trinity, Central Park West and Sixty-fifth Street, warned his congregation yesterday that "destroyers of Christmas are on the march today."

While Fordharn as a team ranked twenty-sixth in total offense in the national collegiate football ratings compiled by the National Collegiate Athletic Bureau, two Ram players gained the first ten in their specialty in the Eastern Collegiate Athletic Conference statistics, according to an announcement yesterday by Jack Coffey, graduate athletic manager.

Abundant United States food supplies are still Working to bring about a lowered food price level but the downward movement may be counteracted to some extent by the upward movement of the national economy, which serves to increase demand and to boost manufacturing and distributing costs, Paul S. Willis, president, Grocery Manufacturers of America, Inc., declared in a statement specially prepared for THE NEW YORK TIMES last week.
A family of newcomers to the United States sent $3 to the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund yesterday with this note:

Right-wing leaders of the Congress of Industrial Organizations in this city will take the first formal steps next week toward setting up a new central body to replace the old Greater New York CIO Council, which was dissolved by the national CIO on the ground that it had given "slavish adherence" to the Communist party line.

SAN JUAN, P. R. -- This Caribbean island is in the midst of the greatest housing and building boom in its history. The program includes $60,000,000 in new residential construction under the sanction of the Federal Housing Administration, almost $20,000,000 in commercial building and a variety of factories adding millions to the expenditures for private and public projects.

The Health Insurance Plan of Greater New York, 425 Avenue of the Americas, had an enrollment of 131,000 persons on Jan. I and will include more than 145,000 persons by Feb. 1, it was announced yesterday by David M. Heyman, the president.

The Brookhattan-Galicia F. C. gained the verdict over the Kearny Celtics, 3 goals to 2, in a championship fixture under the auspices of the American Soccer League at Sterling Oval, yesterday. At the change of ends, the New York team was leading by 1 -- 0.

WASHINGTON -- Two full years of free enterprise with prices unshackled by Federal regulation drew to a close last fall almost simultaneously with the November elections. The anniversary was accompanied by renewed agitation for resumption of controls that kept living costs from skyrocketing during the war.

A record total of more than $150,000,000 was raised in 1948 by the United Jewish Appeal for Refugees, Overseas Needs and Palestine, it was announced yesterday by William Rosenwald, Herman L. Weisman and Rabbi Jonah B. Wise, national chairmen of the appeal.

With ears cocked to the President's State of the Union message, most business men feel as the New Year starts that the bloom is off the boom. The prevailing opinion looks for some downward readjustment but not a sharp one. Fair confidence is expressed for the first half and less for the second.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 -- Indications pointed tonight to an immediate test of President Truman's strength in the Eighty-first Congress when the session opens at noon tomorrow.

NICOSIA, Cyprus, Jan. 2 -- Cyprus has had such spectacular success in its two-year battle to wipe out the malaria that was the island's scourge that only three new cases were discovered in all 1948, health authorities here stated today.

With regard to your editorial of Dec. 3, "Our Municipal Colleges," and letter from Harold Kellar, published Dec. 9, I also think THE NEW YORK TIMES has much to learn about the work-study programs conducted in the metropolitan area.

Circumstances surrounding the eviction of more than 5,000 families last year from apartments in this city will be an item of major interest to the New York State Temporary Commission to Study Rents, it was learned yesterday.
The "Lux Theatre" is rated first in the order of popularity among evening radio programs by The Pulse, which covers Cincinnati, Chicago, Boston, Philadelphia and New York areas.

WASHINGTON -- Executives of the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development and the International Monetary Fund contend that the various achievements of the two agencies in the field of international finance in 1948 amply justified their existence.

ROME -- The sector of the economy in which Italy has made the greatest progress since the end of the war is that of foreign trade. Exports in the first ten months of 1948, reckoned in dollars, were about 80 per cent above what they were in the same period of 1938.

FRANKFORT, Germany -- Repercussions of continuing political tensions in Berlin have consistently driven a wedge between Communist and anti-Communist trade union memberships in Western Germany. The most recent and dramatic demonstration of the widening rift was the rout of Communists from office in the mining industry union in the elections held in the first week of December at Recklinghausen in the British zone.

Lovers of the dramatic at yesterday's first meeting of the Eighty-first Congress did well to choose the House side. That was where the excitement was. The drama was in two acts, each significant in its own way. The first was the hearty display of good-will all over the Chamber when Sam Rayburn was elected Speaker.

ISTANBUL, Turkey -- After having had for eighteen consecutive years a favorable balance, Turkey showed a deficit of TL 60,000,000 in 1947 and of TL 150,000,000 for the first six months of 1948. This has resulted in a diminution of her gold and free currencies reserves by 22 per cent at the beginning of 1948 as compared with her holdings at the end of the war.

One-year workhouse sentences and the second highest total fine ever levied in a rent-gouge case were imposed yesterday in Special Sessions on Dorothy and Pearl Bloom, middle-aged sisters who operate a $1,000,000 realty business specializing in tenements.

St. John's and City College, the two schools that last season participated in one of the weirdest intercollegiate basketball contests ever seen at Madison Square Garden, resume their red hot rivalry tonight as they clash in the feature of a twin bill at the big Eighth Avenue arena.
Increases in corporate working balances are not considered by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York as a major factor, on the whole, in the inflationary spiral.

SHANGHAI -- Travel conditions in China in the last year have been so uncertain that generally only the air lines were dependable. As Communist armies overran the country even this mode of travel was curtailed.
Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores showed an increase of 0.5 per cent in December, compared with the same month last year, according to the survey made yesterday by THE NEW YORK TIMES.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- Convening in an atmosphere of good will that belied behind-the-scenes tensions, the Senate of the Eighty-first Congress took just fifty-nine minutes today to swear in its new members, elect officers and take the routine steps to ready itself for busy two years.
AMSTERDAM -- A definite improvement in foreign trade has been noticeable in 1948.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa -- With the price of gold likely to remain pegged for a long time to come, South Africa is paying greater attention to minor metals and minerals. Increasing American demand, with an eye especially for defense needs, has emphasized the wealth of the subsoil, not only of the South African Union but also of the two Rhodesias.
The city's first year-round indoor recreation center operated by the Park Department was reopened yesterday by Mayor O'Dwyer on Pier 6, Tompkinsville, S. I.

Mrs. Peter F. Lynch gave a luncheon yesterday in the Pierre Grill for members of the junior committee serving in behalf of the Blue Ridge dinner-dance to be given for the benefit of the Blue Ridge School of Virginia on Jan. 28 in the main ballroom of the hotel.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- Laws of three states barring the closed shop, which restricts employment in a company to members of a labor union, and the rights of all states to make similar laws, were upheld in two opinions by the Supreme Court today.

" Well, boys, here goes forty-one years of show business," boomed the latest patron of the New York Public Library as she entered the director's office to present to the library the hundreds of scrap books she has compiled in the course of her career.
OBERAMMERGAU, Germany, Jan. 3 (UP) -- For the first time in 300 years financial troubles threaten the famed Passion Play, produced once every ten years in this Bavarian mountain hamlet.

TSINGTAO, China, Tuesday, Jan. 4 -- The United States Marines announced today that they were withdrawing from China. The reason officially given for the surprise move was that "since the Chinese Government has now decided to negotiate for a peace set

OTTAWA -- Retail trade in Canada continued to rise through October, the last month for which full statistics are available. Consumers spent 14.5 per cent more for merchandise than in October, 1947, and 12 per cent more than in September.

With the recent agreement between the United States, Canada and the United Kingdom marking an important milestone, it is evident that international trade would be severely handicapped without standardization, according to a statement prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by the American Standards Association.

LONDON, Jan. 3 -- The first working day of 1949 saw business at a low ebb in the stock market here today. With investors keeping a close eye on expenditures before the end of twenty-one-day account tomorrow, some prices sagged.

ABOARD THE QUEEN MARY, Southampton, Jan. 3 -- More than 100 tons of cement were being poured into the Queen Mary tonight for repairs to her stern, damaged when she was grounded in Cherbourg Harbor Saturday night. The concrete is needed to block a leak in time for the ship with 1,700 passengers aboard to sail for New York at 1:30 tomorrow afternoon.

BUENOS AIRES -- One Argentine product that never has to look far for a buyer is meat. Argentina's famed beef is still in high demand and is likely to command a good market even with Miguel Miranda's determination to raise prices till they are 100 per cent above 1946 levels.

In accordance with the club's decision to adhere to the fourteen-game maximum in night baseball at the Stadium, the Yankees yesterday announced their 1949 schedule under the lights, setting the first game for May 17, against the champion Cleveland Indians. The final night game of the campaign is slated for Sept. 7, against the Boston Red Sox.

Bankers Trust Company has transferred the balance in its general reserve account as of Dec. 31, amounting to about $10,291,000, to undivided profits, thereby bringing its capital funds to $164,878,000, S. Sloan Colt, president, announced yesterday.
Talked over his State of the Union message with the Cabinet.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- Margaret Chase Smith, Republican, of Maine, today injected into her first statement as a United States Senator a woman-to-woman appeal to Queen Juliana of Holland to stop the Dutch-Indonesian fighting.

AMSTERDAM -- It has been said that although God made heaven and earth, the Dutch made Holland. Nowhere in the world is more extensive or concentrated use made of the soil per unit available and last year, blessed with a good season, the results were gratifying.
STOCKHOLM -- Ever since the exceptionally good shipping year of 1946 earnings of Swedish shipping companies have lost footing.

TOKYO -- Even without economic reforms forecast by Gen. Douglas MacArthur's mid-December directive, Japan's prospects are better today than at any time since the Pacific war started in 1941. This is not, however, the moment for optimism. There are too many things that need to be done and too few persons, among either Japanese or occupation officials, who appear to have the will to do them quickly.

The public is being penalized because hundreds of unqualified persons who call themselves "nurses" are practicing without licenses and with no formal training whatsoever, Mrs. Ethel G. Prince, chairman of the Nurse Practice Act Committee of the New York State Nurses Association, declared yesterday.

Robert Villemain, French middleweight who is to make his American debut Friday night in a ten-round battle with Steve Belloise of the Bronx at Madison Square Garden, passed the State Athletic Commission's physical examination yesterday and then, in the fluent French of Chairman Eddie Eagan, had the commission's rules and regulations interpreted and carefully explained.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa -- After successive modifications, import control, imposed early in November, has become clarified.

Prospects for ratification of the Havana charter for an International Trade Organization, which was put off by the Eightieth Congress, seem to have been improved as a result of the election of President Truman and a Democratic Eighty-first Congress.
CAPETOWN, Jan. 3 (Reuters) -- South Africa had scored 223 for two wickets in reply to England's first innings total of 308 when play ended on the second day of the third cricket test match today.

TEL AVIV -- Despite war conditions which prevailed during most of the year, Israel has kept its eye on the future and made every provision possible for business visitors who are sure to come in large numbers when peace is assured. All of its twenty consular representatives throughout the world have been instructed to grant visas readily and make every effort to expedite the travel of potential guests.

ROME -- The Italian aeronautical industry has fallen into hard times after the war. The nine companies that manufacture airplanes have, all together, produced only about seventy planes in 1948, and those that do not form part of a large and solid industrial organization (such as, for instance, the Fiat Motor Car Company) are undergoing a severe financial crisis.

The record of the plywood industry since its start in this country in 1925 demonstrates the fact that new frontiers of United States industry are by no means behind us, Owen R. Cheatham, president of Georgia-Pacific Plywood and Lumber Company, said in a year-end statement.

Sales of the Maytag Company for 1948 were the largest in its history, totaling between $65,000,000 and $70,000,000, Fred Maytag 2d, president, declared in a year-end statement. Profits probably will exceed the 1947 figure of $7,101,579, but will represent a slightly lower percentage of sales, he said.
With four billion dollars in Marshall Plan aid beginning to play a vital role, international economic recovery made slow but measurable progress last year.

WARREN, Ark., Jan. 3 -- Tornadoes ranging in force from brief twisters to storms of catastrophic fury raced through Arkansas and Louisiana late today and tonight, causing casualties estimated in the hundreds.

LONDON -- The British Defense Budget for the fiscal year 1948-49 amounts to 692,000,000 ($2,768,000,000). Of this sum approximately 44 per cent will be spent for the Army and about 25 per cent each for the Royal Navy and Royal Air Force.

Sales of porcelain enameled utensils in 1948 exceeded all previous years except 1947, the record year, according to D. S. Hunter, commissioner of the Enameled Utensil Manufacturers Council. He emphasized that 1947 sales would have been exceeded last year were it not for enameling steel shortages.

BRUSSELS -- The Inter-Allied Reparations Agency, comprising nineteen member Governments with headquarters in Brussels, had allocated 316 German plants by Dec. 1. A breakdown showing the type of equipment thus distributed follows:

VIENNA -- Austria, in a certain important sense, has had a Marshall Plan of its own for about three years. The deficit in her economy had been made up by the United States occupation forces civilian relief program and a similar smaller British program.

AVIV -- Because Israel is a large dollar-producing country, it is relatively easy for the United States to sell goods here, and every effort is being made to attract American business. At present, because of abnormal conditions, war essentials are consuming the money, but in the normal times expected to come, the field will be wide open.

During this period of the year, when Christmas Seals are on sale to aid in fighting tuberculosis, I would like to call attention to a lesser known aspect of T. B. This is the reluctance of employers to hire persons who have had the disease, despite medical certificates showing that it has been brought under control.
BATAVIA, Java, Jan. 3 (AP) -- Indonesian Republican guerrillas were said today to have launched a series of harassing attacks against the Dutch in areas adjacent to Batavia.

LISBON -- At the end of World War II, Portugal was frankly prosperous. In spite of widespread individual poverty and hardship, partly traditional and partly due to higher cost of living, there was plenty of money in the banks and substantial dollar credits.

LONDON -- The burden of taxation in the United Kingdom continues to run far in excess of comparable United States levels. In the first three-quarters of this year Americans paid in income tax or other direct taxation about 9.7 per cent of their incomes, as against 11.1 per cent in 1947.

There are 18,689 trucks and buses in service in Vienna compared to only 8,703 in 1937. The number of private cars in circulation is 10,834 which is still below the 1937 figure of 13,853. Motorcycles have increased from 9,219 in March of this year to 14,619 in October.

LONDON -- So far as the home market is concerned, British retailers, wholesalers and manufacturers expect this year to match 1948 in sales volume. They are trusting to the second half of 1949 to prove sufficiently active from a volume standpoint to make up for an expected drop of 5 to 10 per cent in retail sales volume in the early months of the year.

The Dominican Government looks forward to 1949 as another year of prosperity and progress, similar to the last ten years, according to a statement by the Dominican Information Center here. During this period the country's budgets have invariably been balanced and favorable trade balances have marked each year, with the result that dollar balances in New York have piled up steadily.

AMSTERDAM -- The Dutch declare that when the Marshall Plan came along their cupboard was bare. It saved them, they will say, from a renewal of the worst rigors of wartime hardship through scarcity. In a negative way, therefore, this is the first and great accomplishment of the plan here in the Netherlands.

ALBANY, Jan. 3 -- Neal Brewster, Syracuse Democrat, filed application today with the State Retirement Board for retirement as a member of the Public Service Commission effective as of Jan. 31. He has been a member of the commission since 1927.

BOGOTA -- The Grand Colombian Merchant Marine, owned and operated by the Governments of Colombia, Venezuela and Ecuador, with some private capital, appears to be the first step in closer business ties among the Bolivarian Nations.

BRUSSELS -- New industries established in Belgium since the war point the way to a fundamental change in the country's industrial pattern. Finished goods of high quality are beginning to take the place of semi-finished products that were the mainstay before the war.
PARIS -- Dominating the whole problem of French finances, the struggle against inflation remains the fundamental issue before the Government.

MELBOURNE -- Australian economic policy during 1948 has been steadily directed -- not by tariffs so much as by a system of export licensing -- toward curtailing imports from dollar areas and increasing dollar-earning exports. Trade with North America is now reacting sharply to these measures.

NICOSIA, Cyprus, Jan. 3 -- Turbulent Communist demonstrations, and even bombings that have stirred Cyprus for months, have been put down, but the Communists by no means have been eliminated. The question is not whether they will resume their activity, but in what form.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Jan. 3 -- An Egyptian charge that the Israelis had used poison gas against the Egyptian troops trapped at Faluja was emphatically denied here tonight by a military spokesman. He said that "not even phosphorous shells" had been used by the Israelis.

ROME -- After a great depression in 1947, the consequences of which Italy was able to overcome thanks only to United States aid, agricultural production staged a strong come-back in 1948, though it still remained below the pre-war level.

ROME -- Italy has never made the headlines for any startling advances on the road to socialization of industry, but is actually one of the countries where this process has progressed farthest. At the present moment the state, in addition to having a monopoly on
FRANKFORT -- Austerity days are long since past for the traveler in Germany. If it is luxury he demands, it is his for the asking -- and paying.

ABOARD THE QUEEN MARY, Southampton, Jan. 3 -- Jacob A. Malik, Soviet representative on the United Nations Security Council, was ordered today to fly back to New York rather than stay on the Queen Mary, now due there Sunday.
CAIRO, Jan. 3 -- Egypt accepted today the United Nations Security Council's new Negeb cease-fire order and called on the Council to impose sanctions against Israel.

Philip Weisberg has obtained a mortgage loan of $200,000 from the East River Savings Bank for ten years at 3 1/2 per cent on the newly altered one-story business building at 726-36 Franklin Avenue, Garden City, L. I. The building, 191 by 152 feet, is occupied by Oppenheim Collins, J. J. Slater and Peck Peck.
TOKYO -- Tight controls over credit and Bank of Japan note issues, coupled with an increase in production, have checked the rise of Japan's black market prices.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 (AP) -- The House today seated Representative John C. Davies, Democrat, of Utica, N. Y., but his defeated Republican opponent, Hadwen C. Fuller, Republication, of Parish, served notice he would continue a fight to unseat him.
On Dec. 23, under the title of "The Broken Promise," we published on this page an editorial which quoted a news dispatch from our correspondent in The Hague (dated Jan. 16, 1948) as follows:

LONDON -- With price controls and rationing as much a part of British everyday life as they were in the United States during war time, Government officials are pleased at the manner in which they have held back inflationary pressures.

MEXICO CITY -- Mexico's manument in the last five years has facturing industry has been developing steadily since 1939, when the Government launched its all-out industrialization plan. In this period manufacturing enterprises as a whole increased 25 per cent, especially in the steel, textile and canning branches.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 3 -- Warner Brothers will institute a program of television film production at its Burbank Studio as soon as the Federal Communications Committee approves the company's purchase of the Los Angeles Television Transmitter, KIAC, from Dorothy Thackrey, Harry M. Warner, president of the company, announced in a trade paper interview today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- No one, including radio and film artists, will be permitted to use the comparatively low capital gains tax rate with respect to sales of personal service, the Internal Revenue Bureau said today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- United States, British and Israeli officials would not comment today on reports that Britain and the United States had taken diplomatic action to induce Israel late last week to withdraw troops from Egypt.

Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores increased 5 per cent last week over the corresponding period last year, according to the "flash" report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. The rise for the four weeks ended last Saturday was also 5 per cent.

CHICAGO, Jan. 3 -- Grain prices rallied strongly today in the late trading on the Board of Trade, under leadership of wheat. July and September wheat led the advance and closed about the top. Net gains were 1 to 2 1/8 cents, the latter on September.

MOUNT HOLLY, N. J., Jan. 3 -- The Burlington County Bridge Commission, under fire from the state for its purchase of the Burlington-Bristol and Tacony-Palmyra bridges, submitted today an optimistic report on the economics of the transaction.
A soft Dublin brogue stole its way into Brooklyn hearts yesterday when a 17-year-old colleen who is here as an exchange student was welcomed on her first day at Bay Ridge High School.
SEATTLE, Jan. 3 -- Fourteen dead, eleven of them students at Yale, were counted today following the crash of a chartered plane on an attempted take-off for New Haven last night.

PARIS -- The European central agency for the Marshall Plan awkwardly called the Organization for European Economic Cooperation with offices in Paris-Organization for Economic Co- has led a lively existence since its formation in March, 1948.

Developments in the foreign oil industry, which last year were centered in the prolific oil fields of the Middle East, finally have resulted in the rest of the world being independent of United States petroleum resources. This was accomplished, however, largely by the "know-how" of the American industry which has been active in seeking oil wherever geological conditions were favorable for its accumulation despite the virtual inaccessibility of the region.

CAIRO -- Political disturbances kept the tourist trade down in Egypt last year. Although Government promotion of the tourist industry was reduced during the year there are plans to spend about $60,000 on advertising in the United States in 1949. Hamilton Wright, the Egyptian Government's advertising agents in the United States, probably will send a movie company to Egypt to make a promotional film during the year.

ROME -- Unemployment continues to plague the Italian economy, and all efforts to cure it have failed. The number of jobless is still in the neighborhood of 2,000,000. Though this is an improvement over the post-war maximum of more than 2,400,000 registered in May of 1948, it still represents a heavy burdens for Italy's slender finances.

LONDON -- As the year 1949 commences British aviation -- both civil and military -- is turning increasingly to jet propulsion. All day-interceptor squadrons of the RAF already have been equipped with jet fighters and night-interceptor squadrons are now in process of conversion.

CAIRO -- It was Egypt's problem in 1948 -- and will be in 1949 -- that she has plenty of pound sterling -- about 370,000,000 frozen in London -- with which she cannot buy the goods she wants, and very few dollars with which she can buy the goods she wants.

The letter of George Braden of New Haven, Conn., published in THE NEW YORK TIMES on Dec. 2, criticizes the National Association of Real Estate Boards for its resolutions favoring liquidation of federal public housing and elimination of residential rent controls.

An attempted plunge over the "suicide barrier" on the eighty-sixth floor of the Empire State Building was prevented yesterday by alert guards and the public relations director of the building, who happened to be on the spot.

ASUNCION, Paraguay -- The aid of the United States and more recently of the United Nations is being enlisted in the fight to resolve one of the greatest economic paradoxes of South America -- malnutrition, often in areas where the natural food supply could be plentiful.

ROME -- The Post-war period in Italy has been distinguished by an extraordinary epidemic of strikes, which had been growing more serious from year to year and reached its apex in 1948. Most strikes had an economic substratum, but many were either exclusively or prevalently political.

Jack Benny tallied a Hooper popularity rating of 27.8 for his first broadcast over the CBS network on Sunday night, according to the results of a survey made known yesterday. It was his highest rating of the season, exceeding by 2.2 the last figure for his show while it was on NBC.
LONDON, Jan. 3 -- The Soviet news agency Tass said tonight an "overwhelming majority" of German prisoners of war had been repatriated from the Soviet Union.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa -- For American business visitors there is only one practical mode of travel in South Africa -- by air. Although nearly twice as large as Texas, this country has only eight urban areas, separated by great distances.

VIENNA -- Monthly Austrian exports during 1948 in terms of the schilling approximately doubled in comparison with 1947 and somewhat less than doubled in terms of the rather theoretical quantitative scheme employed by the Austrian National Statistical Office.
LONDON, Jan. 3 (AP) -- Storms lashed western Europe today, killing 39 persons and disrupting shipping at sea.

LONDON, Jan. 3 -- Traditional January sales -- suspended during years of war -- drew thousands of consumers to London's fashionable West End shopping district today. Women seeking apparel for children and adults started forming queues outside better known stores as early as 5:30 A. M. awaiting opening of doors at 9.

CHICAGO, Jan. 3 -- Federal District Judge Michael L. Igoe today issued an order postponing for sixty days all bankruptcy, liquidation and receivership actions against the financially harassed Tucker Corporation.

Total deposits of the National City Bank of New York rose to $4,643,112,364 and total resources to $5,004,737,618 on Dec. 31, last year, compared with deposits of $4,567,484,131, and resources of $4,912,440,813 on Sept. 30, according to the bank's statement of condition published today.
MEXICO CITY -- Mexico continued to show an unfavorable trade balance in 1948, but it was not nearly as bad as in either of the first two years after the end of World War II.

The humanity of two fruit venders convicted of peddling without a license, a demonstration of interreligious good-will, the belief of a city magistrate that there were many people in New York who were prepared to help others -- these intangibles combined yesterday to aid in saving the life of a 14-year-old Brooklyn boy.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Jan. 3 -- The United States and British Military Governments have agreed on a plan to place 5,000 German police along the border between the British and Russian zones. Their immediate purpose would be to prevent smuggling.
ZURICH -- What the monetary reform of June 20 in Western Germany has done to revitalize trade is evident from the simplest facts about production.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- President Truman is expected to renew his plea for universal military training and to request higher taxes for corporations and for the top and upper middle brackets of individual taxpayers when he goes before Congress on Wednesday with his State of the Union message, it was learned today.

GENEVA -- Had it not been overshadowed by the European Recovery Program, the entry into force of the general agreement on tariffs and trade would undoubtedly have been the greatest international economic development of 1948. Negotiated at Geneva in 1947, the agreement affects more than half the world's trade and links twenty-two of the world's major trading countries in an effort to simplify and reduce trade barriers.

ROME -- The Italian armed forces are strictly limited by the peace treaty of Feb. 10, 1947. The maximum effectives allowed are: 175,000 combat troops and 75,000 Carabinieri, used almost exclusively on police duty for the Army: 25,000 men, plus 2,500 on minesweepers, for the Navy, and 25,000 men for the Air Force.

ROME -- The Italian system of taxation is one of the most complicated in the world, and the Government is at present working on a plan to simplify it and to distribute the burden of taxation more evenly. The Treasury account lists no less than forty-one principal taxes, many of which have several subheadings.

The money market continued to ease yesterday and Federal funds were quoted at 1/8 to 1/4 of 1 per cent, compared with 1/4 per cent on Friday and 3/8 per cent on Thursday. Member banks here which reported excess reserves of $165,000,000 on Wednesday night, held $170,000,000 the following day, and ended the weeks operations with $225,000,000.
BALTIMORE, Jan. 3 (UP) -- The Maryland Racing Commission today reported a betting slump at state tracks in 1948 and blamed it on the conflict of schedules with those in neighboring states.

MEXICO CITY -- The tourist industry of Mexico, fourth in importance in the national economy of the country, is looked upon now as even more important since the devaluation of the Mexican peso, brought about by the flight of United States dollars from the country's foreign exchange reserves.

The Port of New York Authority, which had tentatively set yesterday for ground-breaking exercises for its proposed $20,000,000 midtown bus terminal, has postponed the event until the end of this month, it was announced yesterday.
Buyers began to arrive in the wholesale markets here yesterday in large numbers, but the peak of arrivals is not expected until next week, according to a survey.

Blue, in a wide range, received recognition from B. Altman Co. yesterday when a spring fashion collection was presented. The tones, which ran from midnight to palest cloud, were exhibited in many fabrics. Styles for the mature woman and the young girl were included in the showing.

In a report on thirty-five years of activity the Professional Children's School announced yesterday its need for $50,000 to meet a deficit for the current school year and to provide a backlog for scholarships.

ROME -- Business activities in 1948, especially in the early part of the year, were adversely influenced by the depression that followed the stabilization of the economy in November, 1947. There were some signs of revival in the middle and the second half of the year,

The four-story loft building at 70 Greene Street, also containing a store, has been sold by Helen A. J. Wissmann and others to Herbert S. Baudesson in an all cash transaction. The building, which occupies a plot about 24 by 100 feet in the block between Spring and Broome Streets, has been owned by one family for almost 100 years.

NEW DELHI, India -- Sovereign India, less than a year and a half old as an independent nation, is in the initial stages of organizing trade and commerce for this vast country -- the world's second largest -- on a national scale. At the same time India is systematically arranging trade relations with several overseas nations.
LONDON -- A revolutionary change in the triangular relationship between labor, management and Government began to take place in Britain in 1948.

The role of Atlas which the United States has been playing in sustaining the economy of the free world is demonstrated again in this newspaper's review of industry, trade and finance -- the second section of which is published today. This review shows that the largest single factor that sparked whatever economic revival has been achieved in the rest of the world has been the American $7,000,000,000 foreign aid program.

PRINCETON, N. J., Jan. 3 -- Top-seeded Nichols School, living up to all advance ratings, crushed a strong Andover sextet, 9 to 1, in the semi-final championship play-off of the eight-team Lawrenceville invitational hockey tournament being staged today and tomorrow at Princeton University's Baker Rink.

PARIS -- The complicated French tax system is due to undergo complete revision to simplify both calculation and collection. Under the present system there are the tax on income from each source -- on profits of industries and business, on salaries and wages, on professional fees, income from investments and farm profits.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Jan. 3 -- Rumors circulated in the diplomatic corps to the effect that the Minister of the Interior, Alexander Rankovitch, had broken with Premier Marshal Tito and had been placed under arrest were finally dispelled today by a brief announcement in the newspapers reporting that Marshal Tito and the Minister yesterday had jointly received a delegation of factory workers.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 3 -- The flag in Hewitt Quadrangle at Yale University was lowered to half staff today as students and faculty members returning from the Christmas vacation period learned of the deaths of eleven students in a plane crash at Seattle.

LONDON -- Great Britain's economic chief, Chancellor of the Exchequer Sir Stafford Cripps, reviewing the country's achievements in 1948, concluded that the dollar problem, besides being the center of Britain's own difficulties, also was the crux of the whole European situation.

SEOUL, Korea -- Major factors controlling an unfavorable trade balance for the year 1948 in Korea were: currency inflation, consumer goods shortages, uncontrolled black market operations, short food supplies and general political instability.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- A rebellion of avowedly "modern" Senate Republicans was smashed today and every member of the old leadership, with Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio at the top, was returned to party command.

The trial of the twelve Communist party leaders accused of advocating the overthrow of the Government by violence moved a step nearer yesterday when Federal Judge Sylvester J. Ryan signed an order for the re-examination of William Z. Foster to determine his present physical condition.

LISBON, Portugal, Jan. 3 -- Portugal must be rid of its "Fascist'' Government and iniquities such as the Tarrafal concentration camp in the Cape Verde Islands must be abolished, Gen. Norton Mattos said today at the opening of his election campaign.

BERLIN -- The ultimate goal of the European Recovery Program in its spending in Germany's Bizonia, the United States and British occupation zones, is the economic recovery of the area to a point where it can participate effectively in the general recovery program in Western Europe.

ROME -- Italy comes third, after the United Kingdom and France, among the beneficiaries of the Marshall Plan. In the first year of operation, ending in June, 1949, Italy is to receive a total of aid under the plan aggregating $601,000,000. Of this amount a minimum

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- Five officers of the United States Air Force who participated in the rescue of the crew of a wrecked transport plane from the icecap of Greenland today received high decorations from Gen. Hoyt S. Vandenberg, Chief of Staff of the Air Force.

AMSTERDAM -- Industrialization is the keynote of Dutch postwar economic policy, because without it the problem of finding employment for the tremendously growing population and of bringing the trade balance into equilibrium is unsolvable.
ALBANY, Jan. 3 -- The State Youth Commission issued today a sixteen-page guide to be used by study groups interested in problems of family life.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- The United States Government today bluntly asked the Soviet Government how many German prisoners of war still were held in the Soviet Union in violation of a four-power pact requiring that all of them should have been repatriated by Dec. 31, 1948.

NANKING -- By the end of 1948, civil war and inflation had brought China to a state of prostration. The $275,000,000 United States program for economic assistance looked like the proverbial drop in the bucket as far as ending the crisis was concerned.

The first session of the New Year on the stock market was a decidedly weak affair. The day was punctuated by a short but intensive assault near midday which tumbled prices 2 points and more and the list thereafter only recovered fractions.
PARIS -- Agricultural and food production in France made sharp increases during 1948 owing to the excellent harvests of most products that were in great scarcity because of the drought of 1947.

ST. NAZAIRE, Jan. 3 -- Nearly 3,000 skilled shipyard workers are rushing reconstruction work here on France's two greatest liners, the Ile de France and Liberte, and on the success of their efforts this country is staking her hopes of regaining her pre-war maritime status on the North Atlantic.

The reports on the waterfowl shooting from the Currituck and Pamlico Sound areas have not been too good because of continued bluebird weather, although there are plenty of ducks and geese in both areas.
MEXICO CITY -- Mexico's cattle wealth is estimated at more than 18,000,000 head and still represents one of the most important divisions of the country's national economy.
HONOLULU, Jan. 3 (AP) -- Sad Sam Ichinose, the fight manager, was sadder than usual today.

BERLIN, Jan. 3 -- Although official confirmation was lacking because of the absence from Berlin of Gen Lucius D. Clay, it has become known here that Charles M. La Follette will be succeeded as Director of the Military Government in the State of Wuerttemberg-Baden by Maj. Gen. Charles P. Gross, currently deputy transport officer with the bipartite office in Frankfort.

PARIS -- The economic cost of the Marshall Plan is statistically known. The economic results in the countries benefiting from the European Recovery Program can be gauged approximately, although uncertain factors such as climate, with its effect on the power drain or crops, and strikes make this always a theoretical figure.

RIO DE JANEIRO -- Brazil continues to suffer from a shortage of dollars and unless American private capital enters the country, the situation is not likely to improve, according to influential Brazilian opinion. American foreign capital, these observers hold, is vitally necessary to develop Brazil's potential resources, especially petroleum and minerals.

Barring any sharp change in general business conditions, the demand for aluminum in 1949 will set new records for the industry, Richard S. Reynolds Jr., president of the Reynolds Metals Company, declared in a year-end statement.

SHANGHAI -- Since the war it has become increasingly difficult for American goods, apart from relief supplies, to enter China. Monetary restrictions, high tariffs, customs delays and the banning of foreign ships from inland waters have all worked against the free flow of goods.

PARIS -- A customs union between the Netherlands and the Belgian-Luxembourg economic union went into effect on Jan. 1, 1948. It established a common tariff "frontier" with respect to third powers and set about the removal of barriers between Belgium and Holland.

PARIS, Jan. 3 -- Creation of a committee to look into causes of alleged wastage and uneconomic operation on the part of Government agencies was announced today after a meeting of the Cabinet. The action was taken as a result of last week's critical report to the Assembly by the Accountancy Court, a judicial organization devoted to the checking of the Government's accounts.

MEXICO CITY -- The Mexican minerals industry, the most important producer of foreign exchange for the Republic and keystone of the industrialization program, operated at a reduced rate in 1948 in spite of the highest metal prices on record for the majority of its products.

LONDON -- In the month of October, deposits of the British clearing banks exceeded the 6,000,000,000 mark (about $24,000,000,000) for the first time in their history, and they have since moved higher still.

The Bank of America National Trust and Savings Association, largest bank in the world, reported yesterday that as of Dec. 31 its resources were $6,072,913,000. This was the first time in any non-war year that a bank had reached $6,000,000,000. The resources were $22,096,000 greater than at the end of 1947.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa -- Economically 1948 is likely to rank as a crucial year for this country. It has brought a latent situation to a head and disturbed complacency. Hitherto South Africa had been inclined to rest content with enumerating problems and trusting to windfalls to solve them.

RIO DE JANEIRO -- Except that the national territory has 250,000 acres of wooded lands, or an equivalent to 29 per cent of the entire country, no one knows what, or how many types of hardwoods lie hidden in the Brazil jungle.

SOUTH BEND, Ind. -- "The automatic household washer industry stands at the threshold of its golden era and prospects for a continued high level of business are excellent, regardless of the possibility of any downswing in the business cycle," Judson S. Sayre, president

Operations of the Minneapolis-Moline Power Implement Company and its subsidiaries for the fiscal year ended with last October, resulted in a net profit of $6,415,579, it was announced yesterday in the annual report.
CHICAGO, Jan. 3 (AP) -- A heavy outpouring of hogs sent prices tumbling in the livestock market here today.

ROME -- The year 1948 saw no great innovations in social and labor legislation in Italy. The fundamental reforms, and notably the agrarian reform that the Government promised during the election campaign early in the year have not been abandoned, however.
PANAMA, C. Z. -- Central American countries from Guatemala to Panama contended generally with inflation, unbalanced budgets, unfavorable trade balances and political and labor unrest throughout 1948.

ROME -- No sector of the Italian economy lost so heavily through the war as shipping. At the beginning of the conflict, the Italian mercantile marine ranked sixth in the world, with a gross tonnage of 3,448,453 after Britain, the United States, Japan, Norway, and Germany. It issued from the war with only 420,000 tons, or about 12 per cent of what it started with.

WASHINGTON -- When an Englishman asked recently how he would measure the success of the Marshall Plan, Paul G. Hoffman replied, "By its ability to take the United States out of the business of European relief by July, 1952."

This list includes fairs and exhibitions this year that may be of interest to American concerns. The dates given are those decided upon by the organizers concerned and may be subject to change. The Department of Commerce does not assume any responsibility with regard to the standing of the listed events.

ROME -- The Italian national debt, expressed in Lire, reaches astronomical figures. If due account is taken of the fact that the Lira has been reduced to 1.75 per cent of its pre-war value -- calculating both the depreciation of the Lira with respect to the Dollar
LONDON -- The United Kingdom's proud boast of building more merchant vessels than the rest of the world again proved true in 1948.

ROME -- Industrial production in 1948 was greatly, and adversely, affected by the stagnation of business that was brought about by credit restrictions and other measures introduced in November, 1947, to stabilize the Italian economy. The slump continued for many months, more for psychological reasons than for any other.

JOHANNESBURG -- Last year was one severe recession on the share market, affecting virtually all issues. There is a tendency to ascribe this condition to political factors, especially the defeat of Field Marshal Jan C. Smuts' United Party in national elections last May and the consequent advent of the Nationalists to office.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 (UP) -- Representative J. Parnell Thomas, Republican, of New Jersey, today won a seven-day postponement of his trial on fraud charges after his physician testified that any "nervous or mental disturbance" at this time might "very well prove fatal."

Expressing optimism on the outlook for men's clothing Jerome I. Udell, president of Max Udell Sons Co., Inc., makers of Gramercy Park Clothes, predicts that the next few months will see the end of the current period of liquidation of surplus merchandise.

MEXICO CITY -- The outstanding Mexican financial development in 1948 was the devaluation of the peso on July 21, made necessary by a condition of disequilibrium in the nation's balance of payments. After having supported the official peso-dollar exchange rate

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 3 -- With Tony Lavelli, its sharpshooting captain, tallying 26 points, the Yale basketball team halted the six-game winning streak of previously undefeated Duquesne tonight, downing the Iron Dukes, 71 -- 56, before a capacity crowd of 3,000 in the Payne Whitney gym.

When the New York Legislature failed, in its 1948 session, to approve a bill permitting this city to cede the Fort Clinton site at the Battery to the Federal Government for restoration as a national monument we were hopeful that we had written our last editorial on this moot issue, on which many of our good friends disagree with us.

BRUSSELS -- Prosperous little Belgium has been the happy possessor of lavish food supplies ever since the early days after liberation when a succession of governments adopted the much-discussed policy of plenty. This included, high on the agenda, imports of foodstuffs that now appear to have steadied away at about 50 per cent of home consumption.
WARSAW, Jan. 3 -- The biggest East-West trade deal since the end of the war will be made this week when British and Polish officials sign a five-year pact for a $600,000,000 exchange of goods.

LONDON -- The British motion picture industry has not benefited from the restriction on the import of films from the United States. Despite the Government's imposition of a protectionist 45 per cent quota -- or because of it -- in the opinion of some independent British producers, the British movie industry is going bankrupt.

Higher dividends for savings banks should not be adopted at the expense of appropriate loss reserves, Elliott V. Bell, State Superintendent of Banks, warns in his annual report today to Governor Dewey and the Legislature. The need for establishing adequate reserves out of operating earnings, he observes, has been brought into particular emphasis by reason of the substantial portion of savings bank mortgage portfolios represented by loans made in the postwar years.

LONDON, Jan. 3 -- As a result of a British complaint the United States Government has been reliably reported here to have given a friendly admonition to the Israeli Government against allowing its troops to trespass on the territory of neighboring Arab states allied with Britain.
PARIS -- The number of foreign visitors, including Americans, the poured into France this year was great enough to re-establish her at the world's number one tourist attraction.

International tourism in 1948 fell a bit short of the goal set for it under the European Recovery Program, but even so it set the pace for all other aspects of the Marshall Plan. Henry Ingrand, French General Commissioner for Tourism and president of the European Travel Commission, reports that international travel last year came closer to achieving its objective than did any other industry in all Europe.

Although held to a draw by R. G. Wade of New Zealand in yesterday's fourth round, Nicholas Rossolimo, French chess champion, regained the lead in the international masters tournament sponsored by the Hastings and St. Leonards Chess Club, according to a report from England.
HAVANA -- Last year was the most prosperous in the history of Cuba, but mounting inflation, declining revenue and the possibility of a drop in exports pose many problems for the future.

ATHENS -- The American Mission for Aid to Greece ceased to operate on July 1, 1948, on which date its functions were assumed by the Economic Cooperation Administration operating under the Marshall Plan. What in effect happened was a change in bookkeeping.

One of the most mystifying developments of 1948 involved the Aluminum Company of America. In November, six weeks after the Department of Justice had instituted a new suit to break up Alcoa on charges of monopoly, another Federal agency -- the War Assets Administration -- approved a deal to make the nation's largest aluminum producer still larger.

TOKYO -- Reparations removals from Japan to the end of last October had taken about $22,000,000 of machinery from former arsenals. A balance of $1,380,000 remained to go under the "30 per cent interim removal plan" announced last year.

RANGOON, Burma, Jan. 3 (AP) -- Peace negotiations between an outlawed Burmese Army group and the Government broke down today just as the nation prepared to celebrate its first independence anniversary tomorrow.

BERLIN -- Germany in 1948 shared her agricultural prosperity with the rest of Europe, and Bavaria even had the greatest potato yield in its history. As a result, the United States and British occupation authorities were able to free potatoes from control and made possible the departure from rationing according to calories, the system that had prevailed since the end of the war.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- Bills to repeal the Taft-Hartley Labor Law, expand the social-security and housing programs, and translate into law other features of the Truman program were among the host of proposals offered as Congress opened its eighty-first session today.

PARIS, Jan. 3 -- "The United States is in a greater hurry to build up Europe than the Europeans themselves are, and it seems to have decided to make the necessary financial sacrifices," said an editorial today in the outstanding Paris newspaper Monde.

Dr. Francis X. McHugh of 576 Fifth Avenue was installed last night as president of the First District Dental Society of the State of New York at its annual meeting in the Statler Hotel. He succeeded Dr. Sidney E. Riesner.

ISTANBUL, Turkey -- The main objective of R. Dorr, formerly chairman of the Tripartite Commission for the Restitution of Monetary Gold and chief of the United States delegation to the Interallied Reparation Agency in Belgium, is to prove that the Economic Cooperation Administration mission he is heading has not come to Turkey, as generally alleged, for "strategic" reasons but because this country is in a position to play an "integral" part in the European recovery.

Before the ski sport reached its "long pants" stage in this country those participating in it in the early Thirties knew little about "techniques." They probably cared just as little about them, too. If you could handle your trusty wooden runners -- in-variably warped, too long and poorly harnessed -- that was all that mattered. You had lots of fun and recreation "braking" down so- called trails.

TOKYO -- Japan's food situation improved considerably in 1948, but continued food imports will be required this year on about the same scale as last, financed largely by the United States until Japanese foreign trade recovers sufficiently to take up the burden.

The price of natural crude rubber in the futures market on the Commodity Exchange advanced 15 to 30 points yesterday under the influence of a 1/4d price rise in London and a somewhat smaller gain in the Singapore primary market.
PARIS -- Nearly four years after liberation, France is on a mixed system, of economy with certain products free of controls and others still rationed and subject to official prices.
PARIS -- Labor, employers and the French Government are all chiefly concerned in the economic field with the hitherto insoluble problem of prices and wages.

MEXICO CITY -- Mexico's oil industry regained much of its waning importance in 1948 for two reasons: (1) it remains a potentially valuable source of oil for the United States in case of war and (2) United States capital again is being used to find and pump oil in Mexico.

DUBLIN -- Ireland is already beginning to increase its agricultural production as a direct result of its European Cooperation Administration borrowings of $60,000,000 spread over the nine months of 1948, starting with April 1 and ending Dec. 31. In all, it is expected that Ireland's borrowing in the fiscal year from July 1, 1948, to June 30, 1949, will be around $79,000,000.
Tammany Hall, which has been a tenant in an office building for the last five and a half years, is seeking a new home that it will own, Hugo E. Rogers, Tammany leader, disclosed yesterday.

MAYS LANDING, N. J., Jan. 3 -- An indictment against Albert N. Shahadi, Atlantic City Commissioner, and three veteran policemen, charging them with conspiracy to obstruct justice in the disposition of a drunken driving case in 1946, was dismissed here today by Superior Court Judge Frank T. Lloyd Jr. of Camden.
LONDON, Jan. 3 -- British pilotless rocket-propelled aircraft have reached a speed of nearly 900 miles an hour in recent tests off the Cornish Coast, it was learned today.

BRUSSELS -- The development of the foreign trade of the Belgo-Luxembourg Economic Union over the last six months has been a matter of deep concern alike for Government and business interests. Logical customers do not possess the francs to buy Belgian goods in sufficient volume to support the industry of this country and, what is even worse, the purchases that are made comprise far too high a percentage of capital goods, notably steel.

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 3 (UP) -- The National Collegiate Athletic Association is almost certain to crack down on football bowl games, either banning them or limiting the number to four or five, it was learned today from a responsible source.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 3 (AP) -- Strong winds made strong golfers falter in a cold, blustery day of qualifying play today for the twenty-third Los Angeles open golf tournament, which opens Friday at Riviera Country Club. The temperature was no higher than 51 throughout the day.

ZURICH -- If the task of providing Europe with an abundant supply of power, indispensable for rehabilitation, were merely an engineering problem, Switzerland would be able greatly to accelerate recovery. This pregnant fact is the result of developments set in motion by World War II.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- Acting with cool precision under apparently firm Administration grasp, the House of Representatives marked the opening of the Eighty-first Congress today by stripping from its Committee on Rules the power that had enabled it to block prime Roosevelt and Truman programs for a decade.
BALTIMORE, Jan. 3 (AP) -- Dr. Isaiah Bowman, who helped set the boundaries of Europe after the first World War, retired today after thirteen years as president of Johns Hopkins University.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- President Truman's election was described today by Haakon Lie, secretary-general of Norway's Labor Party, as "the greatest victory the American people have yet won in the cold war with Soviet Russia.

The modern international trade fair has been utilized for the last thirty years in Europe with increasing success as an international marketing medium. In June of 1948 the Government of Canada, in cooperation with representatives of private business, held the First Canadian International Trade Fair in Toronto, which was the first event of that type ever attempted on a large scale in the Western Hemisphere.

ROME, Jan. 3 -- The Vatican was understood today to have informed the Hungarian Catholic hierarchy privately that any proposal on the part of Budapest for an agreement between the church and the state should be based on conditions it outlined in its statement yesterday.

BRUSSELS -- Belgium looks to the Marshall Plan for a solution to the one important economic problem affecting her welfare that seems to be beyond her power to remedy. Through the plan's operation it is hoped Belgium's neighbors again will be in a position to buy Belgian goods.

A new over-an peacetime peak in production and sales was established by the electrical industry during 1948, repeating the industry's performance in 1947, W. J. Donald, managing director of the National Electrical Manufacturers Association, disclosed in a year-end statement.

ATHENS, Jan. 3 -- The second major phase of military operations in the Peloponnesus, designed to rid the whole peninsula of rebel forces estimated at 3,000, began this morning, an official military source revealed.

Gyorgy Sandor's encores are often the best part of his program. And so it was last night when the Hungarian pianist played at Carnegie Hall within a few weeks of the tenth anniversary of his debut in this country.

MANILA, Jan. 3 -- President Elpidio Quirino today opened the Central Bank of the Philippines, a counterpart of the United States Federal Reserve System, by swearing in Miguel Cuaderno, former Secretary of Finance, as governor of the bank's monetary board.

ALBANY, Jan. 3 -- There is urgent need for $200,000,000 in new school construction during the next two years, all but $36,000,000 of which can be financed in the customary way, the Board of Regents informed Governor Dewey at a conference today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- A limited amount of dollar currency, which may be used to import certain goods formerly excluded as "non-essential," has been released by the British Government to its possessions in the Caribean area, the Department of Commerce disclosed today.

Peoples' drinking habits have always been powerfully affected by political circumstances and attendant economic conditions. According to The Manchester Guardian, the drinking habits of the British Islanders are in for something like another revolution as a result of the dollar shortage.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- The Standard Gas and Electric Company, Chicago, was ordered today by the Securities and Exchange Commission to recapitalize with all-common stock, or liquidate and dissolve. The order was handed down after many months of hearings and discussions before the SEC.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 (AP) -- Senator Johnson, Democrat, of Colorado, prepared a bill today to give business men the legal right to absorb freight charges in selling their products.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- The Army today designated fourteen foreign cemeteries where soldiers and airmen who died in World War II are buried as permanent American military cemeteries. They will be set aside perpetually as memorials to the dead interred there.

TOKYO -- Japan's labor situation changed sharply at the close of 1948 with Gen. Douglas MacArthur's December directive warning that the nation must increase production as the price of continued United States aid and that no interference either by labor or management would be tolerated.
OSLO -- Industrial production in Norway increased substantially during the first half of last year, but during the second half the development was more uncertain.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- In the interests of party responsibility and orderly procedure, the House of Representatives must always have a "czar," or -- holding to imperial Russian terms -- a "rada" of committee chairmen beholden to that "czar," the Speaker, and headed by him.

OTTAWA -- New records were set during the last year in the number of Americans who visited Canada and the amount they spent. Although the full statistics have not yet been worked out, it is estimated that approximately 6,000,000 American automobiles, including commercial vehicles, crossed the border in the first ten months and that the visitors spent between 275 and 280 million dollars.

BUENOS AIRES -- A combination of vast grain crops elsewhere plus their tendency to "price themselves out of the market," as one expert put it, served in effect to keep the Argentines out of the Marshall Plan. President Juan Peron as recently as late October

The long-delayed autobiography of Soetan Sjahrir, first Premier of the Indonesian Republic, has been scheduled for February publication by John Day. "Out of Exile" consists of two parts, the first written while he was imprisoned or exiled and the second covering political events since his release.

PARIS -- France in 1948 improved her position in foreign trade by increasing her exports and decreasing to some extent her imports, and at the same time reversed her position to a favorable balance in her trade with colonies overseas.

MADRID -- The non-inclusion of Spain in the European Recovery Plan has had little immediate physical effect on this country. It has had, of course, the effect of pricking the national pride, just as did its exclusion from the United Nations.

Requirement that railroads and public utility enterprises sell issues of securities at sealed - bid - and - deadline competition occasioned some sales in 1948 that were notable for close bidding, and other sales for the opposite.

FRANKFORT, Germany -- The tendency toward tax evasions in Western Germany comprises one of the most difficult problems affecting economic stabilization. The population generally regards the current tax schedules -- even after the downward revision following currency reform -- as prohibitively high.

ROME -- The United States has poured aid into Italy continuously since the end of the war -- first through Military Relief and the Foreign Economic Administration, then through the United States Foreign Relief program, United Nations Rehabilitation and Relief Administration and Interim Aid; and finally through European Recovery Program.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- Despite organized labor's demand for repeal of the Taft-Hartley Act and re-enactment of the former Wagner Act simultaneously the Administration is leaning strongly toward the "one package" approach to labor legislation.

LONDON, Jan. 3 -- Foreign Secretary Bevin has asked the committee of the five Western Union powers that is studying proposals for Western European cooperation to postpone its resumed series of meetings, scheduled to begin Thursday, so that the British Cabinet may have more time to study the committee's recommendaitons.

The hill folk of Jersey's Ramapo Mountains would be happy, if the matter were called to their attention, to supply you with a footnote to the philosophical comments on the winter solstice which appeared in THE TIMES of Dec. 19. As a part-time resident of the area, where the Cooper Union has a 1,000-acre engineering camp, I shall pass on to you their observations.

LONDON, Jan. 3 -- The possibility of the formation of an Asiatic Monroe Doctrine aimed against European powers resulting from the recent Dutch drive in Indonesia is becoming an increasing source of concern to high level British diplomats here.
Residential properties dominated the trading in Queens and other sections of Long Island, according to the reports of sales made yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 (AP) -- Following is the roll-call on a House test vote which assured victory for the Administration plan to curb the power of the House Rules Committee. The vote was on a motion designed to shut off debate and prevent amendments to the resolution to change the committee's authority.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 3 -- The Bell Telephone Company of Pennsylvania announced today that it had filed for registration with the Pennsylvania Public Utility Commission a securities certificate covering $25,000,000 of 25-year debentures.

BERLIN -- The most spectacular recovery in German industry in the last year occurred in ingot steel production which, by the end of 1948, rose to a rate of more than 7,000,000 tons annually, compared with less than 2,500,000 in 1947.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- The airlines of the United States probably finished 1948 with operating losses of about $6,700,000, a considerable improvement over 1947, when their losses aggregated $21,801,160, the Air Transport Association estimated today.

The United States Steel Corporation, the largest producer of steel in this country and in the world, expects to better in 1949 the peacetime production record it established during the last twelve months, Irving S. Olds, chairman, declared in a year-end statement.

IT'S a rather intriguing collection of sports stories that Fred Russell of The Nashville Banner has gathered together into his new book, "Funny Thing About Sports." He tells a quit interesting and illuminating tale about Wallace Wade, the Duke football coach, who always has been regarded by all his players with a feeling that actually bordered on fear.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Jan. 3 (AP) -- Herbert M. Woolf's Delegate made his winter debut in the Aurelius purse at Tropical Park today and won in a manner to indicate he'll be a formidable factor in the big Florida stakes to come.

Though it's comparatively small, the recent honey crop is nevertheless large enough for that food to be placed on the Government's plentiful food list for January. It is slightly lower in price than a year ago. Safeway stores offers its blend, Sioux Bee, for 31 cents a pound; last January the price was 35 cents.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Jan. 3 (AP) -- Herbert M. Woolf's Delegate made his winter debut in the Aurelius purse at Tropical Park today and won in a manner to indicate he'll be a formidable factor in the big Florida stakes to come.

Though it's comparatively small, the recent honey crop is nevertheless large enough for that food to be placed on the Government's plentiful food list for January. It is slightly lower in price than a year ago. Safeway stores offers its blend, Sioux Bee, for 31 cents a pound; last January the price was 35 cents.

CHICAGO, Jan. 3 -- Profit of the Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company for 1948 was $13,852,917, equal to $7.50 a share, compared with $14,014,380, equal to $7.79 a share in 1947, according to the annual report of Walter J. Cummings, chairman of the board.

NANKING, Jan. 3 -- An invisible selective censorship appears to have been instituted here under conditions in which correspondents are unable to find out why their dispatches have been held up and what words or passages have been deleted.

DUBLIN -- Latest trade returns for the first ten months of 1948 available in Dublin disclose an expanding two-way trade between Ireland and Britain, accompanied by a heavy cutting down of trade with hard currency and non-sterling countries.

MONTREAL, Jan. 3 (AP) -- Defenseman Ken Reardon of Montreal has been fined $200 and suspended for one game for his part in a stick-swinging duel with Center Cal Gardner of Toronto in Saturday's Canadiens-Leafs' game at Toronto, National Hockey League President Clarence Campbell announced today.

" This Was a Woman," a British-made drama, starring Sonia Dresdel and Barbara White, which opens at the Sutton Theatre, is this morning's lone film newcomer. Twentieth Century-Fox is releasing the offering, which was produced by Marcel Hellman and directed by Tim Whelan from the play by Joan Morgan and the screen play by Val Valentine.
RANGOON, Burma, Jan. 3 (AP) -- A Burmese Government spokesman said today that the Government did not approve sending a Burmese expeditionary force to fight against the Dutch in Indonesia.

BUENOS AIRES -- Venezuela's domination of the South American oil situation tends to obscure the fact that there are oil potentialities in virtually all the ten republics. These will become increasingly important if the world strategic picture throws the United States back on Western Hemisphere reserves.

Members of the Brotherhood of Railroad Trainmen on the Hudson Manhattan Railroad, irked by their union president's repudiation of last Friday's four-hour strike on the Hudson Tubes, talked yesterday of transferring their affiliation to Michael J. Quill's Transport Workers Union, CIO.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 (AP) -- The text of the Supreme Court opinion upholding the right of North Carolina and Nebraska to prohibit discrimination in employment against non-members of unions was as follows:

Having taken to heart the injunction, Seek and ye shall find, Thomas K. Scherman continues to seek and to find music worth the playing that others seldom get around to. For the sixth program of his Little Orchestra Society series at Town Hall last night Mr. Scherman came up with an American premiere of Darius Milhaud's Concerto for 'Cello and Orchestra, as well as rewarding compositions by Mozart, Mendelssohn and Stravinsky.

SHANGHAI, Jan. 3 (AP) -- The Shanghai City Council radioed a lace; plea tonight direct to the Commmists, by-passing President Clfiang A-shek's Central Government In N. auking, Chang Cmih'c]lumg, -a leading Cabinet member, .ave a."peace" nner for several hundred public officials and educators[

JERSEY CITY, N. J., Jan. 3 -- Joseph H. Kenny, Hudson County Freeholder, came away empty-handed today from a meeting of the Board of Chosen Freeholders that met to redistribute committee chairmanships. Mr. Kenny, who has supported his cousin, John V. Kenny, Hague organization opponent and probable mayoralty candidate against Frank Hague's nephew, Frank Hague Eggers, was apparently reaping his "punishment," political observers said.

CHICAGO, Jan. 3 -- The furniture industry has reached its price peak, in the opinion of three spokesmen for the trade who were interviewed at a news conference at the opening today of the midwinter homefurnishings market at the Merchandise Mart and the American furniture mart.

LONDON -- Convinced that the "sellers" market for Scotch as well as other types of whisky has disappeared in the United States, distillers in Scotland are planning to revive this year the pre-war drive for volume that characterized their United States operations in the years before the war.
LONDON -- A slow, steady gain in the productivity of British industry was shown in 1948, as indicated by the following figures for some representative basic commodities and manufactured goods:
ZURICH -- If Switzerland is to achieve what is expected of her in contributing toward the rehabilitation of Europe, her tourist industry must be permitted to exploit its earning power to the full.

LONDON -- New life has been injected into Britain's advertising agencies as a result of the 25 per cent increase in size of British newspapers that went into effect on New Year's Day. Agencies hope that space allotments accorded to them by newspapers will be at least 25 per cent higher than in 1948.

LISBON -- Increase of production in her great African colonies is part of Portugal's economic plan, but so far there has been a discreet silence as to details. The Government has not embarked upon a groundnut scheme, which, perhaps, is just as well.
NANKING, Jan. 3 -- Dissatisfaction with the wording of President Chiang Kai-shek's New Year message was expressed tonight by Shao Li-tze, a leading Kuomintang peace proponent.

SAN JUAN, P. R., Jan. 3 -- Puerto Rico dedicated its great Caonillas Dam today as the major link in a power system being developed as the hub of a movement to change the island from an agricultural to an industrial economy.
An 11-year-old girl sent $1 yesterday to THE NEW YORK TIMES Neediest Cases Fund to help another girl. The donor carefully printed the following note:

TOKYO -- Dollar shortages that appeared in the latter half of 1947 still are hampering the development of Japan's export trade. The aggregate for the first eight months of this year was only $126,000,000, against $116,200,000 for the same 1947 period.

LONDON -- The present nationalization program of Britain's Labor Government will be complete when a measure becomes law to take over the major companies in the nation's flourishing iron and steel industry by March, 1950, according to the present time table of the Government, according to officials here.
LONDON -- Rivaled only by cotton textiles, and ahead of automobiles, Scotch whisky, and all the other publicized industries, stands the tourist as a dollar earner for Britain.
