Another Fifth Avenue landmark is about to give way to modern housing. The old mansion of the late Thomas Fortune Ryan at 858 Fifth Avenue has been purchased by Jesse J. Secoles, builder, for replacement by a nineteen-story and penthouse apartment structure, it was announced yesterday.
GENEVA -- The formulation and operation of the European Recovery Program have dominated all other European economic developments of 1948.

Former Supreme Court Justice George Frankenthaler, Republican-Liberal who was elected by a plurality of 1,150 votes last November, was formally inducted as Surrogate yesterday by his colleague, William T. Collins, before a crowd that overflowed into the corridors and balcony of Surrogate's Court in the Hall of Records.
AMSTERDAM -- The position of the Netherlands merchant fleet today, in the number of ships in service or their gross registered tonnage, would seem to be very close to what it was before the war.

TUSKEGEE, Ala., Jan. 3 (AP) -- Legal machinery for registering voters, stalled for eight months, started up again here today, but Negroes who lined up to get their names on the list went away disappointed.

HELSINKI -- Finland's industrial production advanced steadily in 1948. In the third quarter, total production was 20 per cent above the level for the same quarter in 1947. This rise applies about equally to industries producing for the home market and to export industries.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Jan. 3 -- The strike of 200 delivery, repair and installation employes of coal and oil supply companies affiliated with the Westchester Allied Trades Association appeared to be ended tonight with a victory for the strikers.

It is disappointing but not surprising to learn from a comprehensive survey that in 1948 most of the fund-raising campaigns of charitable organizations in New York City failed to reach their goals. Mainly, these agencies are finding themselves squeezed between constantly increasing post-war demands upon them for help and the shrinking purchasing power of the dollar.

HOBOKEN, N. J., Jan. 3 -- The Fifth Street pier of the Holland-America Line is "strikebound" to- day -- by sixty-three Hoboken taxicab drivers, who refuse to take passengers debarking from Holland-America ships to New York unless they do it at their own stated rates, and the steamship line also discontinues its bus service to Times Square.

Austrian book exports have increased considerably since the end of the war, the Austrian Information Service reports. A survey taken during the recent Austrian Book Week shows the following growth of trade:

PITTSBURGH, Jan. 3 -- General Smith described the recent arrest in Hungary of Joseph Cardinal Mindszenty as "abhorrent and deplorable" at a press conference here today shortly before receiving an honorary degree of doctor of laws from Duquesne University.

Five new members, including Walter Reuther, international president of the United Automobile Workers, were elected yesterday to two-year terms as directors of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People. The action was taken at the fortieth annual meeting of the association at the Willkie Memorial Building, 20 West Fortieth Street.

STOCKHOLM -- Business developments in Sweden during 1948 were marked by the symptoms of "suppressed inflation." At the root of this situation was a fundamental unbalance between the supply and demand for goods and services and a resulting upward pressure on prices and wages.

The New York football Yankees yesterday announced the signing of three bowl game stars -- Tom Landry, Texas fullback, who was a terrific ground-gainer against Georgia in the Orange Bowl; Jerry Williams, Washington State halfback, who caught a touchdown pass in the East-West game, and Ken Sinofsky, East Rutherford, N. J., boy, who played in the Harbor Bowl for the University of Nevada.

OTTAWA -- Canada's 1948 experiment in holding an International Trade Fair in the tradition of the famous European sample fairs was so successful that it has been decided to hold another in Toronto from May 30 to June 10 this year.

Graybar Electric Company's eastern district will increase its dollar volume this year 10 per cent compared with 1948, Herbert Metz, district manager, predicted yesterday. In an interview during opening sessions of a two-day meeting in the Hotel Statler of all district branch managers, he said that 1949 dollar volume will reach a record peacetime peak.

LONDON, Jan. 3 -- Allied architects of victory, leaders of the land, sea and air arms of the British and United States forces in war, gathered here tonight to honor their former chief, General of the Armies Dwight D. Eisenhower, and to mark the publication in this country of his book "Crusade in Europe."

OTTAWA -- Since the embargo on the export of beef cattle from Canada was removed in the middle of last August between two and three hundred thousand head have been shipped to the United States. One result of this heavy export was to increase the available supply of American dollars, and there was of course wide satisfaction among cattle men that this immense market had at last been opened to them.

SHANGHAI -- United States business in China struggled through another year of crippling restrictions and in the end faced the spreading of a communistic regime over almost the entire country. Business prospects for 1949 depend on such a multitude of uncertain political and military factors that there is little agreement among Americans here on the future.
OTTAWA -- Canadian newsprint production established a new high record in 1948 with an estimated total output of 4,575,000 tons.

Your editorial of Dec. 22 on the International Trade Organization gives the reader the impression that the charter signed at Havana last March by the representatives of fifty-two nations will bring about a multilateral nondiscriminatory form of trade. I am convinced that it will not accomplish the purported aim.

Fifty days of competition at beauteous Belmont Park -- that's the feature of New York's 1949 horse-racing program, which was drawn up by the operators of the various tracks and approved yesterday by the State Racing Commission.

OTTAWA -- Imports from the United States declined during the last year, partly as a result of the dollar conservation measures taken by the Canadian Government just twelve months ago. Canada, however, has remained by far the largest customer -- and a cash one -- of the United States, while she continues to be also the largest supplier of raw materials and such necessary products as newsprint, woodpulp, timber, nickel, asbestos, etc.

QUITO -- Ecuador's unfavorable trade balance for 1948 is estimated at almost $17,000,000, with exports for the first ten months at $30,508,875, compared with $45,867,703 for imports, according to the Central Bank.
BUENOS AIRES -- The trade picture in South America is in broad strokes the old picture of the Latin - American Republics struggling against the inevitable effects of adverse balances.
SANTA MONICA, Calif., Jan. 3 -- Lewis Browne, writer and lecturer on Jewish questions and world affairs, was found dead today at his home here. His age was 51.
CHICAGO, Jan. 3 (AP) -- Field Judge Jay Berwanger, who ruled the score on Northwestern's controversial "fumbled" touchdown in the Rose Bowl game, was "put on the spot" by Referee Jimmy Cain.

PARIS -- Deficit positions of the various French industries that have been nationalized are reported by some critics to be one of the main causes of financial disorder in France. A survey of these industries shows:
Achieving increased production in both industry and agriculture, the Soviet economy made substantial strides during 1948 toward the goals for 1950 set by the current five-year plan.

AMSTERDAM The Dutch business situation seems to be in a period of transition. With industrial productivity around 80 per cent of the pre-war level, industrial production, due to a much larger number of workers employed, has been raised to the post-war record of 116 per cent.

Theatre Enterprises, Inc., the new theatrical firm comprising Anthony Parella and Leon Bronesky, has decided to bring Bernard Reines' four-character play, "Forward the Heart," into the Forty-eighth Street Theatre on Thursday evening, Jan. 20.

SACRAMENTO, Calif., Jan. 3 -- Gov. Earl Warren, opening the 1949 session of the Legislature today, called, for the third time, for adoption of a state system of compulsory, pre-paid medical care. Twice before, in 1945 and in 1947, he advocated, but failed to achieve, enactment of a similar program.
PARIS -- France's trade prospects are considered to be favorable by experts who, nonetheless, see several disqueting factors in the situation.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange developed some weakness on the first trading day of the new year yesterday, and final prices were 11 to 19 points net lower.
AMSTERDAM -- There are definite indications that 1948 brought the end to inflation in the Netherlands much quicker than had been expected.

BUENOS AIRES -- Every Argentine has a job and his family has plenty to eat. On the surface, the internal economy is holding up. The ordinary Peronista takes as gospel the recurrent pronouncements by the President and others of vast budgetary surpluses.

District Attorney Frank S. Hogan announced at midnight last night the arrest of four men charged with attempting to bribe the co-captain of the basketball team of George Washington University to "fix" the score of last night's game played by the team at Madison Square Garden.

Comic books, as a form of literature and entertainment, can be either "good" or "bad" and there is no basis for directing criticism against all publications because of the faults of a few, in the opinion of 700 eighth and ninth-grade students participating yesterday in an open forum on "Youth Looks at Comic Books."

The second annual Metropolitan A. A. U. open meet will launch the 1949 indoor track season tonight at the 102d Engineers Armory, 168th Street near Broadway. A twenty-one event program of invitation, handicap, novice, schoolboy and women's races has attracted a star-studded entry of 515 individual athletes and sixty-two relay teams.

PORTLAND, Me., Jan. 4 -- Reorganization of the American and Foreign Power Company, Inc., in accordance with a plan approved by the Securities and Exchange Commission and by a Federal court here last October, today was ordered back to the SEC, whose attorney, Harry G. Slater, said the plan "was no longer feasible."

CAIRO, Jan. 4 -- The Israelis returned today to the attack in the Negeb desert area in southern Palestine with the "largest forces they have ever used in any Palestine battle," Ibrahim Desouki Abaza Pasha, Egyptian Foreign Minister, announced tonight.

The six-story building at 111-113 South Third Street, Brooklyn, containing nine stores and thirty-six apartments, has been sold by Paul P. Brennan, referee, to Morton S. Tubin. The City Title Insurance Company insured title in the transaction, in which a purchase money mortgage of $20,000 was executed at the closing.

With an eye to the deadline-bidding sale announced by the Alien Property Custodian's office for Jan. 17, investment houses are looking over the properties and earning power of the plastics and chemical enterprise of the Rohm Haas Company.

Handmade silverware by the few American craftsmen who are combining traditional skills with modern designs is shown in the exhibition opening today at America House, 485 Madison Avenue. The display includes designs by craftsmen who are inspired by silversmiths of the past as well as works by promising students who are expected to continue the tradition in the future.

The world champion Cleveland Indians were voted the nation's outstanding team of 1948 in the annual poll of sports writers by the Associated Press. Of the ninety-eight voting, twenty-eight named the Indians as their No. 1 aggregation, twenty-seven as their second choice and sixteen picked them third. That gave the Tribe a total of 154 points.

May I compliment you on the editorial. "For Safer Trucking" in your Dec. 14 issue ? This organization agrees with your sane suggestion that "the saving of life and the prevention of injury are the first consideration of all efforts to reduce traffic accidents."

NANKING, Jan. 4 -- The Communist radio reacted tonight to Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek's New Year peace bid with another "New China News Agency" editorial denouncing the move as a "trick" and asserting that it had been engineered by "Kuomintang reactionaries" with United States backing.

Mrs. Oksana Stepanovna Kasenkina, the Russian school teacher who jumped to freedom from a third-story window of the Russian consulate here last August, was received yesterday morning into St. George's Ukrainian Greek Catholic Church, 22 East Seventh Street, which is in communion with the Roman Catholic Church.

Fort Hamilton, for two and a half years the scene of an American invasion by 30,000 European war brides, found itself in an unfamiliar position yesterday. There were only four foreign GI war brides left to send on to their new homes.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 (UP) -- Restaurants at the National Airport in near-by Virginia dropped their racial bars today in compliance with a Federal Court order upholding a Government ban on segregation. The order was issued yesterday by Judge Albert V. Bryan.

DURHAM, England, Jan. 4 -- Britain's coal miners have once again failed to reach the Government's annual target for deep-mined coal, according to figures for the last week of the year issued today. They came very close, falling short of the 200,000,000-ton target by only 3,310,800 tons and they actually exceeded the target of 11,000,000 tons for open cast coal by 729,300 tons.

Stern advice: Discard the pots and pans never used. Most of us, even in cramped city quarters, hoard the unused against what emergency we know not, then rail against crowded kitchen shelves. If cupboard-cleaning reveals any lack of utensils, select new ones tailored to individual needs.

The New Year 1949 is expected to bring to nearly 750,000 refugees in Europe their first real glimmer of hope for an end to the wandering and homelessness that have marked their lives since the upheaval of the war and its aftermath made them Displaced Persons -- men, women and children without a country.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 -- The Democratic leadership of the Senate greased the way for favorable committee action on the Truman program today by increasing the majority party's representation on seven key committees.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 (UP) -- The domestic scheduled airlines today claimed a safe-flying performance for 1948 that was bettered only three times in twenty years and then only by fractions.
Felix August Inslerman, a witness for the second successive day before the Federal espionage grand jury, emerged yesterday as the most important new figure to appear in the current inquiry.

PARIS, Jan. 4 -- It is expected that by the end of this month the expert staff of the European Marshall Plan Council will send to the member countries a questionnaire designed to elicit indications of how far they will go in revising their economic policies in conformity with the interim report on European recovery made public today.

A message of appreciation from British housewives for cupboards replenished with American aid was delivered here yesterday by Sir William Rootes, chairman of the Rootes Group, automotive manufacturers of London and Coventry, England.

For several weeks theatrical circles have been bandying around a humor that the Empire Theatre at 1430 Broadway, where "Life With Mother" is residing, was on the merge of being sold by Jacob Freidus, spectacular 35-year-old real estate operator.
PALM SPRINGS, Calif., Jan. 4 (AP) -- The Pacific Coast Conference tonight in effect banned all New Year Day bowl games except the Rose Bowl.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 -- Pleading for a nonpartisan atomic energy policy, Senator Brien McMahon, Democrat, of Connecticut, said after a White House visit today that the Administration would seek repeal of the two-year terms of the five members of the United States Atomic Energy Commission and the restoration of the original provision for staggered terms.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 -- Kenneth C. Royall, Secretary of the Army, revealed today that an appropriation of $1,100,000,000 for relief in occupied areas would be asked for the coming fiscal year, compared with $1,300,000,000 made available for the period ending this June 30.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, Jan. 4 (AP) -- A purported memorandum from arrested Joseph Cardinal Mindszenty saying big Hungarian estates up to 500 or 1,000 acres should be restored was published by the Hungarian Government today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 -- A hearing officer recommended today that the National Labor Relations Board set aside a decertification election at the Univis Lens Company, Dayton, Ohio, because of "the extreme campaign methods employed by the company."

Fire Commissioner Frank J. Quayle suspended Peter Loftus, chief of the New York Fire Department, last night for alleged violations of the rules and regulations of the department. He will receive a departmental hearing.

ATHENS, Jan. 4 -- Viewed from Greece, the Eighty-first Congress is the omnipotent body which decides the fate of this country. The Greek Parliament meets at the end of the month to deal with a demand for reform of government, but nothing the local legislators do has the life and death importance of American action on the aid program.

Earnings of the Glidden Company, manufacturer of paints and allied products, for the fiscal year ended with last October, declined $4,481,165 from the previous year despite the new high levels in dollar and unit volume of sales, the annual report showed yesterday.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., Jan. 4 -- The coat and suit industry has met the challenge of changing conditions and geared production to the high level of national income without hitting the snags that bogged down business after World War I, it was pointed out here today by members of the National Coat and Suit Industry Recovery Board.

PARIS, Jan. 4 -- It is understood that the seven prospective charter members of the proposed Atlantic defense pact has been discussing the geographical area to which it should be applied and, in this connection, the additional countries that should be included.

PEIPING, Jan. 4 -- The big question being asked in Peiping today is whether the outcome here depends upon action at Nanking or whether it may be precipitated by a Communist attack upon the city within the next few days.
CORAL GABLES, Fla., Jam 4 (AP) -- Mr. Buster, 9-10 favorite, outran six rival sprinters throughout the Cambuslang Purse, first of two $2,400 featured events at Tropical Park today.

British dinner tables will have more meat and less potatoes because of the industry of British farmers, Government controls and agricultural research, Prof. Harold Sanders, a university dean and practical farmer, declared here yesterday.

Mary Goodfellow used China as a source of inspiration for her spring hat collection, shown yesterday at 600 Madison Avenue. She borrowed her colors from porcelain tones and her silhouettes from Oriental shapes.

HARRISON, N. Y., Jan. 4 -- Renewing her request for a rezoning of part of her large acreage in the Purchase estate area of Harrison, Mrs. Ogden Reid told 600 residents by letter today that establishment of a $5,000,000 shopping center on the property would create employment, attract young persons to Harrison and reduce taxes in other parts of the town.

Announcement by the Department of Commerce that it is beginning new quarterly statistical reports on the packaging industry was welcomed by packaging authorities yesterday as recognition of the field's growing importance. It was said also that the reports will fill a long-Standing need for a centralized source of detailed information.

Providence, R. I., sold yesterday bond issues amounting to $2,450,000 and maturing Jan. 1, 1952 to 1973, to banking group headed by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc. The bid was 100.529 for 2s. The bonds were reoffered at prices to yield 1.05 to 2.15 per cent.
The Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York urged the Eighty-first Congress yesterday to put the public interest first in any changes it makes in the Taft-Hartley Law.
THE HAGUE, The Netherlands, Jan. 4 -- Premier Willem Drees left the Netherlands by air this morning for Indonesia where, it is hoped here, he will meet Republican leaders.

I have read with a great deal of appreciation your outstanding editorial article on the problems of Indonesia. It shows in the shortest possible way, clear and perfect, the whole catastrophe taking place on the remote and seemingly unimportant islands of what was formerly known as the Dutch East Indies.
A Federal grand jury in Brooklyn returned yesterday an indictment charging seven men with conspiring unlawfully to violate the Taft-Hartley Act.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Jan. 4 -- Israel will present a complaint to the Security Council charging that military pressure was being brought to bear against her by the British, according to a statement by a military spokesman tonight.

A 41-year-old basketball rivalry will be resumed tonight when Columbia and Fordham meet on the Lions' University Hall court at 8:30 for the twenty-fifth time Honors for the rivalry, which began in 1907, are equally divided with each school holding twelve victories.

Ralph H. Tapscott, president of the Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., declared yesterday that "the Consolidated Edison Company will resist with every legal means at its disposal the Public Service Commission's order to reduce electric rates by $21,500,000."

Negotiators in the threatened strike of harbor tugboat workers continued discussions in the Municipal Building yesterday without breaking the deadlock between employers and 3,500 members of the union. The strike deadline is at midnight, Jan. 12.
William F. Hurley, formerly assistant manager of the Atlantic branch of the National Lead Company, has been appointed manager of the pigment division of the branch.
The Brooklyn-Battery Tunnel, now 70 per cent completed, will be the first major traffic tube to be illuminated with fluorescent lighting, it was announced yesterday.

Although Broadway is a dead beat this week, Riverside Drive is enterprising. An unusually interesting drama opened at the Master Institute Theatre last evening. It is a serious study of a spiritual ordeal in a Shaker community, Marguerite F. Melcher's "Rose in the Wilderness," put on by the Abbe Practical Workshop with a cast that mixes student and professional actors and with a brief but vivid Shaker dance designed by Doris Humphrey.

" The Way of a Fighter," the memoirs of Maj. Gen. Claire Lee Chennault, United States Army (Ret.), will be brought out by Putnam on Jan. 31. General Chennault presents his account of what occurred in China, discussing several of the great wartime conferences and the confusion and personal politics that went on.

LAKE SUCCESS, Jan. 4 -- The United Nations summoned back today from Palestine its Chief Truce Supervisor, Brig. Gen. William E. Riley of the United States Marine Corps, to make a complete report on the renewal of fighting in Palestine.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 -- The United States and the United Kingdom have agreed in notes exchanged today to extend for three months from Dec. 31, 1948, the period of the operation of their bizonal fusion agreeement in Germany.
LONDON, Jan. 4 -- Although business on the last day of the account in the stock market here today was slack prices generally held up well.

Activity on a declining scale marked yesterday's trading in cottonseed oil futures on the New York Produce Exchange. Under liberal hedging pressure the market closed 9 to 30 points net lower. Declines were attributed to a one-half cent drop in crude oil prices in the South and continued weakness in the Western lard market.

ALBANY, Jan. 4 -- Senator Arthur H. Wicks of Kingston, chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, said today that he would sponsor a sickness-disability bill contemplating contributions by both employers and employes.

United States Marshall James E. Mulcahy was directed by Federal Judge Murray Hulbert yesterday to arrest Stephen Toth, landlord of a building at 536 East 134th Street, the Bronx, and confine him to the Federal House of Detention for violating an injunction forbidding him to evict a tenant.

ALBANY, Jan. 4 -- The State Civil Service Commission, estimating 3,000 employment vacancies for clerks, typists and stenographers in state departments and institutions, announced today that examinations for the positions and for establishment of eligibility lists will be conducted Feb. 19 in all sections of the state.

Willie Pep, Hartford, Conn., featherweight, is going to get a chance to regain his world championship Feb. 11 in Madison Square Garden. Sandy Saddler, Harlem boxer who won the title last Oct. 29 by stopping Pep in four rounds, agreed to the return he had promised the Connecticut lad in the contracts for the original bout.

In the first public new corporate financing transactions of the new year, the Illinois Central Railroad and the Missouri-Kansas-Texas Railroad borrowed a total of $8,200,000 from banking syndicates to help finance the purchase of new equipment.

This is the time of trial for the commuter. The weather is variable and uncertain but mostly bitter chill. Dressed for rough going, the commuter gets the mild snow that the Weather Bureau enchantingly describes as scaupel.

The Giants, who seem to be losing no time getting their house in order for what they hope will be harmonious spring training inaugural at Phoenix on March 1, bobbed up with two more contract signers yesterday.

CHICAGO, Jan. 4 -- The troubles of four consumers, who recently furnished homes varying from a remodeled basement apartment to a luxurious eight-room cooperative, were aired at the semi-annual home-furnishings market luncheon yesterday of the Fashion Group of Chicago.

Nearly one-third of the Republican members of the House of Representatives bolted their party on the first test of the new Congress and the new session -- the question of curbing the powers previously possessed by the mighty Rules Committee. These bolters were forty-nine in number.

The New York Rangers have a chance to move out of the National Hockey League cellar to within three points of third place when they skate against the Chicago Black Hawks at Madison Square Garden tonight.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 -- The United States in the note delivered to the Soviet Goverment asking how many German prisoners of war were still being held in Russia in violation of the agreement of the Council of Foreign Ministers in April 1947 declared that failure to comply with the terms of that agreement "can only be interpreted by world opinion as a breach of faith," it was disclosed today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 -- The White House today made public the list of groups invited to the inaugural reception at the National Gallery of Art in the order in which they will be received by the President and Mrs. Truman.
ABOARD THE CARONIA AT SEA, Jan. 4 -- The newest pride of Britain's merchant fleet, the Cunarder Caronia, sailed for New York on her maiden voyage today with 686 passengers aboard.

PRINCETON, N. J., Jan. 4 -- Registering two quick goals early in the final period and staving off a late rally by the Exeter sextet, Nichols' top-seeded hockey team edged the New Englanders today, 3 to 2, to capture championship honors in the Lawrenceville invitation tournament staged at Princeton University's Baker Rink.

SIR MALCOLM CAMPBELL died in bed the other day and that's a privilege not always accorded to the daredevils who race autos or speed boats. He had set world records on the water at 141.74 miles per hour and on land at 301.13 M. P. H., neither of which can be considered as dawdling. His escapes were miraculous.

Net income of the United States Trust Company of New York in 1948, amounting to $1,806,347, was 23.52 per cent higher than the 1947 net of $1,462,350, Williamson Pell, chairman, and Benjamin Strong, president, reported to stockholders at their ninety-fifth annual meeting yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 (UP) -- A House Labor subcommittee blamed the American Federation of Labor today for Hollywood's twenty-seven-month-old motion picture jurisdictional strike and rejected charges that the movie industry conspired to bring it about.

BUCK HILL FALLS, Pa., Jan. -- Participation of the Protestant Foreign Mission Enterprise in the proposed National Council of the Churches of Christ in the U. S. A. appeared unlikely today following a canvass of delegates attending the opening session here of the annual meeting of the Foreign Missions Conference of North America.

SEATTLE, Jan. 4 -- An incomplete record of a conversation between the control tower of Boeing Field and the pilot of a chartered plane in which fourteen persons died here Sunday night was the center of a controversy today as authorities sought an explanation for the fatal crash.

The square block bounded by Park and Lexington Avenues between East Forty-sixth and Forty-seventh Streets began taking on its annual nautical complexion yesterday. The early trickle of arriving boats, motors and yachting accessories will swell today and tomorrow into a tidal wave of hundreds of thousands of dollars' worth of bright, shiny equipment which will be exposed to public view Friday night at 7 o'clock at the thirty-ninth annual National Motor Boat Show.

The boys and girls of Class 3-2 at Public School 246, Brooklyn, sent $5 yesterday to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund. They specified that the money be used to aid Case 110, "Home Breaking Up." This is the story of the H. family.

State Attorney General Nathaniel L. Goldstein opened a new phase of his investigation into cemeteries "profiteering on sorrow" when he began court action yesterday against "a pseudo real estate corporation" charged with having made $1,600,000 in gross profits on a $200 investment since 1943 by "retailing" graves at excessive prices.

BERLIN, Jan. 4 -- Resumption of three-power talks designed to draft a revised list of prohibited industries in Western Germany has been authorized, General Clay said to day. The talks are expected to begin soon.
CAPE TOWN, Jan. 4 (Reuters) -- England led South Africa by 37 runs at the end of the third day's play in the third cricket test match.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 (AP) -- The Secretary of the Interior, J. A. Krug, said today that oil supplies were so greatly improved he would not have to revive his economy appeal of last winter. But he added that there had been no material improvement in the long-range picture.

CHICAGO, Jan. 4 -- Government investigations of the business practices of the Tucker Corporation were being continued today notwithstanding the sixty-day court stay authorized by Federal District Judge Michael L. Igoe on Monday.

The Teachers Union, CIO, was accused yesterday of seeking to "infiltrate" into the United Parents Associations, of trying to arouse parents against the Board of Education and of vilification and "smear tactics."

Art openings of the week include a joint exhibition of work by students and teachers of the Brooklyn Museum Art School at the Laurel Gallery, and one-man shows by Ruth Ray and Alfred Crimi at the Ferargil Galleries.

CHICAGO, Jan. 4 -- Closing of spreads between May wheat and the new crop futures gave the former a heavy undertone on the Board of Trade today, May closing 1/8 cent lower and the distant months were up 3/8 to 5/8 cent. Corn held within narrow pride limits, closing firm and 1/4 to 3/4 cent higher.
BATAVIA, Java, Wednesday, Jan. 5 (AP) -- The Dutch Army ordered a cease-fire on the island of Sumatra at noon local time (11 P. M., Tuesday, Eastern standard time) today.

The City Council has before it for early consideration two pieces of legislation whose aim is a revitalized attack on major problems affecting the welfare of all our residents. These problems are air pollution, more commonly thought of by the layman in terms of smoke and soot, and secondly, street traffic control and parking facilities.

The only record known to exist of the world's most famous business transaction -- the barter of Manhattan Island for a handful of trinkets -- will be displayed to the American public today for the first time. The record was brought here recently with three other items of early New York as a loan from the Dutch Government to the Museum of the City of New York, Fifth Avenue and 104th Street.
Former Postmaster General Frank C. Walker received the University of Notre Dame's Laetare medal for 1948 at a private ceremony yesterday afternoon in his apartment at 1035 Fifth Avenue.

The high earnings resulting from the vast post-war expansion of industry are a necessary component in the satisfying of American demands for more employment and production, the monthly bank letter of the National City Bank of New York declared yesterday in a section devoted to the recent Congressional hearings on business profits.

A Federal Court jury ruled early today, after deliberating for twelve hours, that the minimum basic agreements of the Dramatists Guild of the Authors League of America, Inc., in effect since 1926, were violative of the Sherman Anti-Trust Act.
PARIS, Jan. 4 -- The new Greek Army offensive against Communist led rebels in the Peloponnesus area is likely to take many weeks and no dramatic results are to be expected in the intervening period.

PARIS, Jan. 4 -- Paul Devinat, assistant to Premier Queuille, today complained that foreign countries had not credited France enough for the fight she has made against communism. He then appealed for foreign study of that situation and for a better understanding of French difficulties.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 -- The United States is hopeful that the eleven-member Far Eastern Commission will agree this year on a reparations policy affecting Japan, but, if it does not, would consider using its own unilateral authority to issue an "interim directive" settling war claims, it was indicated in commission circles today.
MUNICH, Germany, Jan. 4 -- (AP) --The United States Army disclosed today four Amef-ican military policemen had been rrested on bribery charges in connection with cigarette smuggling.

CHICAGO, Jan. 4 -- Joe Louis, world heavyweight boxing champion, today sued Look magazine for $500,000, alleging that it libeled him in the current issue in statements about his financial condition. The suit, filed in Cook County Superior Court, says that the article stated untruthfully that Mr. Louis was always broke, insolvent and owed $175,000 in back income taxes.

BALBOA, C. Z., Jan. 4 -- Attempts by the American freighter Mormacray to tow the disabled British tanker Adellen have failed, according to a report received by naval authorities here today. Only the master radioman and four others of the crew are still aboard the tanker.
SHANGHAI, Jan. 4 -- Vice Admiral Oscar C. Badger today denied that United States forces were being withdrawn from China.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 4 -- A wage review was sought today by two maritime unions that recently ended a ninety-five-day strike on the Pacific Coast, just as the Pacific American Shipowners Association ratified a new wage adjustment with the non-striking Sailors Union of the Pacific, an affiliate of the American Federation of Labor.

Westinghouse Electric Corporation will increase unit production of appliances 20 per cent this year, Reese Mills, assistant general manager, electric appliance division, revealed yesterday. He spoke before company distributors and their executives and salesmen from New York, New Jersey and the six New England States at a meeting in the Biltmore Hotel to introduce the 1949 appliance line.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 -- The American Federation of Labor is determined to seek a record vote in Congress on repeal of the Taft-Hartley Act even at the risk of adverse action.
TRENTON, N. J., Jan. 4 -- New Jersey dairy farmers started today a backfire in two directions against loss of their dealer markets to out-of-state producers who might undersell.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 -- The National Military Establishment and the State Department asked Congress today to strengthen laws designed to protect the Government's codes, ciphers and other classified information pertaining to its communications system.

Retail volume in boys' wear for the first quarter should at least equal that of 1948, while the late Easter should produce additional sales that will mean a gain over last year for the entire pre-Easter period, according to predictions yesterday at the convention of the Boys' Apparel Buyers Association at the Astor Hotel.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 -- A special House committee of the Eightieth Congress, which investigated speculation in the commodity markets, said today in its final report that it was unable to obtain "positive proof" that Federal employes and officials used confidential Government information to make speculative profits.

DOVER, Del., Jan. 4 -- Delaware's first woman State senator, Mrs. Vera G. Davis, Republican, of Dover, became the first woman elected president pro tem of the State Senate when the 115th session of the General Assembly convened today.

ABOARD THE QUEEN MARY, Southampton, Jan. 4 -- The departure of the Queen Mary for New York, scheduled for 1:30 today, was canceled when it was found 100 tons of concrete placed in her stern the night before had not yet hardened.
The cotton futures market was moderately active yesterday and final prices on the New York Cotton Exchange were 2 points lower to 18 points higher than on Monday.
A Bronx man led his four children up to fire-alarm box yesterday and turned in a false alarm so he could be arrested and possibly find someone to care for the youngsters.

ALBANY, Jan. 4 -- The Public Service Commission announced today that preliminary hearings would be held this month in New York City, Buffalo and Albany on the application of the New York Telephone Company for statewide rate increases calculated to give the company $49,000,000 more revenue annually.
Robert H. Patchin, vice president of the Grace Line and of W. R. Grace Co., has retired as an executive after thirty-one yeasts in shipping and international trading, it was announced here yesterday.

Each year at this time a number of bored legislators from various states, being unfamiliar with the Constitution, which, fortunately, was designed to protect ordinary mortals as well as politicians, decide it is time they came to public attention through the medium of new bills for firearms regulation.
The American Hospital Association, representing the majority of the nation's hospitals, went on record yesterday opposing any further extension of Government supervision in the health field.

ALBANY, Jan. 4 -- Faced with many potentially controversial issues, the new Legislature elected in November meets here tomorrow to receive Governor Dewey's recommendations for dealing with problems confronting the state. He is scheduled to deliver his annual message in person before a joint session of the Senate and Assembly soon after they convene at noon.

People along Fourteenth Street who hear roosters crowing about the time this evening's subway rush subsides will not be imagining things. The roosters with nocturnal habits -- ten of them -- will cut loose at 7 o'clock tonight in a crowing contest to call attention to the New York Poultry Show at the Ninth Regiment Armory, 125 West Fourteenth Street.
LONDON, Jan. 4 -- An issue of new Government of Australia twenty-three to twenty-five year conversion loan at 3 per cent was announced here today by J. A. Beasley, high commissioner for Australia.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., Jan. 4 -- The United States may be on the threshold of a major development in the use of alcohol as an engine fuel which would help soak up grain and other farm surpluses and extend dwindling oil reserves, a Government research chief indicated here today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 -- The Israeli Government notified the State Department today that its forces had been withdrawn from Egypt and that no Israeli troops now remained on Egyptian soil. They had not been sent there for purposes of occupation, it said.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Jan. 4 -- Food supplies for Palestine Arab refugees finally have begun to arrive in quantity, and general distribution win be under way within two weeks, Stanton Griffis, United States Ambassador to Egypt, now acting as Director of United Nations Relief for Palestine Refugees, said here today.

At a Public Service Commission hearing yesterday on an appeal for a 25 per cent increase in Westchester fares, the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad presented statistics to show that it is operating intrastate at a monthly loss of $34,487.

Gaining another half point over his nearest rivals, Nicholas Rossolimo of Paris increased his lead to four points after winning brilliantly from W. H. Muehring of Amsterdam in yesterday's fifth round of the international masters tournament at the Hastings and St. Leonards Chess Club, according to a report received from England.

PARIS, Jan. 4 -- Five French Cardinals addressed a letter of protest today to Count Michael Karolyi, Hungarian Minister in Paris, against the arrest of Cardinal Mindszenty. They asked it be sent to the head of the Hungarian Government.

CHICAGO, Jan. 4 -- A blizzard stalled transcontinental trains, buses and planes over a wide area of the West today and the Red Cross reported that at least 8,000 travelers were stranded in several states.

When, in the following, I take exception to your editorial "A Lesson from Indonesia," it is not due to your general attitude vis a vis the Indonesian problem, with which I heartily agree. It is rather because you voice, in your closing paragraph, an opinion regarding the general applicability of our form of democracy which, I feel, deserves critical examination.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 (AP) -- Federal Crop Insurance was a financial success in 1948, the Department of Agriculture reported today, and the Government is ready to start expanding it.

A revised license agreement in which Vacuum Foods Corporation, one of the large orange juice concentrate producers, relinquishes rights to exclusive use of the process developed and held by the National Research Corporation, was completed here yesterday by mutual agreement.

Fifteen hundred Macy department store workers pledged support to their independent union last night, despite bids for affiliation from the Amalgamated Clothing Workers, CIO; the Retail Clerks International Association, AFL, and John L. Lewis' United Mine Workers.

Bruno-New York, Inc., metropolitan New York radio and appliance distributor, has budgeted well over $1,000,000 for advertising in the local market during 1949, it was disclosed yesterday by Gerald O. Kaye, vice president in charge of sales, in announcing appointment of the Arnold Cohan Corporation as the company's advertising agency.

Walter Florell showed an imaginative collection of spring and summer hats yesterday morning at 29 East Fifty-third Street. His most extreme flight of fancy was expressed in what he terms his "Titus" hats.

Sherman Billingsley, owner of the Stork Club, 3 East Fifty-third Street, yesterday announced that the restaurant and night club has purchased the forty-acre farm of Benny Goodman, the orchestra leader, on Long Ridge Road, in the village of Bedford, Westchester County.

The excellence of the Philadelphia Orchestra and the admirable conducting of Eugene Ormandy at its concert last night in Carnegie PIall did not wholly condone for an ill-assorted program and music in two out of three cases distinguished by different kinds of ineptitude.

In a sharply worded formal note the United States has accused the Soviet Government of another "breach of faith" for failing to honor the Four-Power agreement of April, 1947, which provided for the return of all prisoners of war by Dec. 31, 1948. It has called upon Moscow for specific information as to how many prisoners it still holds and what it proposes to do about them.

The Chase National Bank, in its statement of condition as of Dec. 31, published today, reports loans outstanding of $1,482,834,294, the highest total since December 1930, when the total was about $1,535,000,000. The current figure compares with $1,449,812,201 on Sept. 30, and $1,324,264,034 at the end of December, 1947.

Mayor O'Dwyer announced yesterday that he would support the protest of the millinery industry against a proposal of the American Railway Express Agency to apply to the Interstate Commerce Commission for 50 per cent increase in freight rates affecting the millinery, men's hat and lamp shade industries.

Hugo E. Rogers, Borough President of Manhattan and leader of Tammany Hall, announced yesterday that he planned to be a candidate for re-election as Borough President this year and would seek a place on the Supreme Court bench in 1950.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 4 -- Twentieth Century-Fox has acquired "No Way Out," a screen story by Lesser Samuels dealing with the problems of a Negro interne in a metropolitan hospital, it was learned today. George Willner of the Nat Goldstone Agency negotiated the sale for Samuels at a price "slightly under $100,000."

MOSCOW, Jan. 4 (UP) -- The Communist party newspaper Pravda today accused President Truman of not telling the truth in an effort to excuse "obviously illegal" actions in the German Ruhr industrial area.

References to "a sick world" and "a world of gloom" mark the last report of Laurence Duggan, late president of the Institute of International Education, who mysteriously fell to death last Dec. 20 from his sixteenth-floor office at 2 West Forty-fifth Street.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 4 -- Bitter winds from the East drove temperatures in Southern California to record freezing lows today, threatening millions of dollars of damage to fruit and vegetable crops and causing extensive disruptions in life geared to a normally bland climate.

LONG BEACH, L. I., Jan. 4 -- City Treasurer Francis P. Callahan was appointed acting city manager of the city of Long Beach at an executive session of the city council today following the council's action in suspending City Manager Morris S. Karp.

Out-of-town buyers registered in the market for the week ended yesterday numbered 1,346, compared with 377 last week and 2,185 in the corresponding week a year ago, according to the listings appearing in THE NEW YORK TIMES. There were 920 arrivals yesterday against 256 last Tuesday.

ALBANY, Jan. 4 -- State foxes continue to be infected with rabies despite a three-year campaign of the State Health and Conservation Departments, but there are indications that the problem is being solved, Clayton Seagears, director of the Division of Conservation Education, asserted today.

While imports reached a new high last year, they were nevertheless insufficient in relation to our national income and the high prices prevailing abroad, according to a statement prepared for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Harry S. Radcliffe, executive secretary of the National Council of American Importers.

WOODSTOCK, N. Y., Jan. 4 -- After more than four days of searching, state troopers today found the body of George Ault, a painter of national prominence, in the Sawkill Creek. According to Coroner Ernest A. Kelly of Kingston, N. Y., Mr. Ault, who was 57 years old, had died by drowning. The coroner gave a verdict of suicide.

Supreme Court Justice Felix C. Benvenga denied yesterday a motion by Joseph Stack, former vice president of the National Maritime Union, CIO, and leader of the left-wing faction, for an order directing Joseph Curran, union president, to grant him certain rights under the union constitution.

The first section of THE NEW YORK TIMES annual financial review, published Monday, was devoted to economic and business conditions in the United States. The second section, published yesterday, was a round-up of conditions outside the United States as seen from the principal capitals of the world.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 -- The Eighty-first Congress marked time expectantly today, awaiting the signals to be given to it tomorrow by President Truman in his message on the State of the Union.

Membership in the New York Athletic Club was at its highest peak in nineteen years during 1948, it was revealed yesterday in the eightieth annual report of the Winged Foot organization. The club rolls for last year showed a total of 7,692 members in all classifications.

The Bank of America National Trust and Savings Association, the Blair Holdings Company and the First California Company and certain of their officers have been named as defendants in a suit for $150,002 brought in the Supreme Court here yesterday by Edwin J. Crofoot, who resigned on Nov. 9 as executive vice president and a director of Blair Co., Inc., investment securities subsidiary of the Blair Holdings Company.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 4 -- Deposits with the thirty-two Philadelphia commercial banks which have issued their reports declined about 1 per cent during 1948, a tabulation disclosed today. As of Dec. 31, these institutions had $2,950,500,000 on deposit, compared with $2,987,600,000 at the end of 1947.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 -- Labor leaders voiced keen disappointment today over the Supreme Court decision upholding the constitutionality of State laws banning the closed shop. Business spokesman saw in the ruling an opportunity to maintain some of the balance they believe was achieved by the Taft-Hartley Act in Labor-management relations.

Entering second weeks today are the French-made Jean Cocteau film, "The Eagle With Two Heads," at the Little Cine Met, and "Secrets of a Ballerina," the French romantic drama, at the Midtown. . . . "The Paleface" today starts its fourth and final week at the Paramount. . . .

" Friday Night Frolic," a weekly musical revue designed for television, will receive its premiere Friday, Jan. 28, over the combined Eastern and Midwestern chains of the Du Mont Television Network and the National Broadcasting Company, it was announced yesterday WNBT and WABD will be the local outlets.

ALBANY, Jan. 4 -- Governor Dewey announced tonight the appointment of Leon A. Swirbul of Bethpage, L. I., president of Grumman Aircraft Engineering Corporation, as a member of the State Racing Commission to replace David Dows of Locust Valley, L. I., who resigned recently.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 4 (AP) -- Curtailment of the rash of football bowl games that sprang up this season appeared certain today as members of the National Collegiate Athletic Association and related groups launched their 1949 meetings.
A 26-year-old Brooklyn mother carried out yesterday morning a threat she had made to her husband and jumped in front of a West End BMT train at the Eighteenth Avenue elevated station in Brooklyn.

NEWARK, N. J., Jan. 4 -- A four-count indictment charging four former afficials and members of the Harrison, N. J., Housing Authority with conspiracy to defraud the Government of an estimated $50,000 in connection with contracts for repairs, maintenance and improvements to Harrison Gardens, a low-rent Federal housing project, was returned today by the Federal grand jury here.

Tempers ran high at times yesterday in four courtrooms of Municipal Term Court as a backlog of ninety cases concerning apartment house landlords and superintendents accused of failing to supply adequate heat filled the chambers with more than 500 tenants -- some of them carrying babies.
In response to your article, "A Lesson from Indonesia," in THE TIMES of Dec. 31, I should like to pose the following questions:

FRANKFORT, Germany, Jan. 4 -- A military government directive based on Law No. Seventy-five, which is best known for its provision that trusteeship of Ruhr industries would be given temporarily to the Germans, has evoked strong protests here as a deterrent on socialization.

Representatives of 20,000 unionized elevator operators and other service employes in 2,000 Manhattan apartment houses are preparing to give formal strike notice before the end of this month, it became known yesterday. The notice would become effective April 20.

Deadly set-shooting in the five-minute extra session carried City College to a stirring 58 - 56 overtime conquest of St. John's last night. Performing before a partisan crowd of 17,521 at Madison Square Garden, the keen intracity basketball rivals waged a see-saw duel down to the wire and finished the regulation playing time in a 52-all deadlock.

The stock market yesterday scored its first general advance in four sessions although interest remained small awaiting the President's message to the Congress. Fluctuations were narrow most of the day but prices broke out of the rut in the final hour to reach the best levels of the day.
New York collected a total of $193,967,147 in the fiscal year ended last June 30 through eight special excise taxes, Controller Lazarus Joseph said yesterday.

PARIS, Jan. 4 -- A proposal submitted by six neutral experts to the Western Powers and the Soviet Union for settling the currency problem in Berlin calls for creation of two separate banking systems under the direction of the United States, Russia, Britain and France acting through a coordinating committee and a new bank of issue for the entire city.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 (AP) -- Democrats in New York, South Carolina and Nebraska have overriden their state administrations to enter floats at President Truman's inauguration, Carter Barron, parade chairman, said today.

Many home builders who are worried over increasing "buyer resistance" to their product need not look beyond the interiors of their own houses to find the reason for slackening sales. Even after due allowance is made for the reduced value of the dollar, it is obvious that the industry must offer a better value than it is now doing if it hopes to check a further decline in the market.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 -- Representative Clarence J. Brown, Republican National Committeeman from Ohio, declared today that Republican policy between elections would be made in Congress, and nowhere else.

Continued strength in Government bonds yesterday resulted in a mark-up of all Treasury obligations callable in more than three years. The Victory 2 1/2s of 1972-1967 ballooned a bit farther away from the Federal Reserve System's last buying peg.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 -- The regular Republican Senate leadership headed by Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio has no intention of making any significant alteration in policy to placate the rebellious "moderns" of the party.

SOMEWHERE in the scrub country of Texas not too long ago a 12-year-old boy named Cotton Kinney gave his father a brass-studded dog collar for Christmas and his mother an enamel dish just the right size for a dog to eat out of. But Cotton didn't get a dog for Christmas himself, his mother having ideas on the subject. Hound dogs she knew led to triflin' ways, to wasted time and to shirked responsibilities.
ALBANY, Jan. 5 -- The text of Governor Dewey's message to the Legislature today follows:

A formal official of the Ramapo Trust Company, Spring Valley, N. Y., was indicted yesterday by a Federal grand jury on a charge of making false entries in the bank's records to conceal the embezzlement of $10,000.
CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 5 -- The Egyptian Army repulsed renewed Israeli attacks against Egyptian positions opposite Rafah last night and this morning, a War Ministry communique stated tonight.

The first shipment of steel pipe of American Petroleum Institute oil country specifications is now en route to this country from Germany, foreshadowing larger shipments later, Kurt Orban, president, Kurt Orban Company, Inc., importers and exporters, 21 West Street, said here yesterday.

Operations of the National City Bank of New York during 1948 reflect the "tapering off" of certain of the strong inflationary trends that have characterized the war and post-war periods, according to the bank's annual report which will be mailed to stockholders today in advance of their meeting on next Tuesday.
Excerpts from editorial comment in newspapers on President Truman's message on the State of the Union include the following:

ROME, Jan. 5 -- Foreign Minister Count Carlo Sforza assured the Foreign Affairs Committee of the Chamber of Deputies today that French Foreign Minister Robert Schuman in their recent meeting at Cannes had pledged France's full support of Italy's claims for restitution of her pre-fascist colonies.

Brooklyn College's record of not having won a metropolitan basketball game since 1945 remained intact last night. The Kingsmen also ran their losing streak to six games as they were outscored by St. Francis, 55 -- 45, on the Brooklyn College court.
Purofied Down Products Corporation, pillows, comforters and upholstered cushions, to Moss Associates. Newspapers, national magazines, television and trade papers will be used.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- President Truman's one-sentence recommendation in his State of the Union speech that Cabinet status be given to the Federal Security Agency, "the Government agency which now administers the programs of health education and social security," today appeared assured of bipartisan support and early enactment.

Morris Ernst and David Loth have written an analysis of the polls and predictions made by columnists in the recent Presidential campaign, which Public Affairs Press of Washington plans to issue on Inauguration Day, Jan. 20. It is entitled "The People Know Best" and has been dedicated to "Our Favorite Pollster, Harry S. Truman."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- The Federal Reserve Board was urged today by its counsel, J. Leonard Townsend, to deny four motions of the Transamerica Corporation, San Francisco, and begin hearings on its anti-trust proceedings against the corporation.

Plans were furthered at a meeting held yesterday at the Ritz-Carlton for the annual Yorkville dinner dance in behalf of the Yorkville Community Association to be held on Jan. 14 in the ballroom of the hotel.

ALBANY, Jan. 5 -- Governor Dewey has narrowed to three the field of candidates he is considering to fill the vacancy on the Court of Appeals caused by the resignation of Judge Thomas D. Thacher, and may make a final selection before the end of the week, it was reported tonight.
LONDON, Jan. 5 -- A slashing attack on the working of the Covent Garden opera trust was made today by Sir Thomas Beecham, noted conductor.

OTTAWA, Jan. 5 -- Canada's official holdings of gold and United States dollar exchange has risen from the low point of $461,000,000 at the end of 1947 to $998,000,000 as of Dec. 31, last, Finance Minister Douglas Abbott told an audience in Edmonton, Alberta, today.

Grand jury indictments against four men, accused of seeking to "fix" Tuesday night's basketball game between. Manhattan College and George Washington University by offering a $1,000 bribe to the visiting team's co-captain, will be filed within a week, District Attorney Frank S. Hogan predicted yesterday.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Jan. 5 -- A more aggressive tone has crept into Yugoslav politics against the Communist Information Bureau.

Governor Dewey's seventh annual message to the Legislature breaks new ground in several respects. Current tax rates will "nowhere nearly balance our budget." A "serious setback" on the revenue side of the current budget has occurred, in that tax collections are falling below expectations. The program he proposes calls for "a very considerable increase in expenditures."

FRANKFORT, Germany, Jan. 5 -- If important records had not been destroyed the outcome of the I. G. Farbenindustrie trial last July might have been different, according to Judge Paul M. Hebert, Dean of Louisiana State University Law School, who was one of the judges in the case.

THE TIMES printed a letter from Professor Seymour E. Harris of Harvard, replying to its Dec. 9 editorial relative to his testimony before Senator Flanders' subcommittee investigating profits. On checking his statistics, I find that they give a one-sided picture.

The Public Service Commission recommended yesterday that the Staten Island Rapid Transit Railway Company restore to service many of the trains discontinued last September because of declining passenger revenue.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 (AP) -- Edwin H. Armstrong of New York. inventor of frequency modulation broadcasting, has challenged the authority of the Federal Communications Commission to make him shift the frequency of an experimental station.

It was rough going for the New York Rangers in their National Hockey League game with the Chicago Black Hawks at Madison Square Garden last night. Thanks to Buddy O'Connor's accurate eye, though, the local sextet succeeded in skating off with the honors by the score of 3 to 1, to the satisfaction of the greater part of the 14,626 fans on hand.

The Physicians Forum, Inc., states in a letter I received today it has been "deluged with calls about the $25 AMA assessment," and winds up requesting its own contribution of $2 or more. I am not impressed with the "deluge" of calls. Where the membership is large there are bound to be many dissenters as well as assenters, from star-gazing visionaries and fatuous puffers to down-to-earth realists with impeccable reason and logic.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- President Truman's recommendation to the Eighty-first Congress with respect to materials in short supply, specifically steel, was viewed with concern today by representatives of some of the country's largest steel companies. They considered the Chief Executive's proposal "a definite step toward nationalization of the steel industry."

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 5 -- Universal-International has acquired film rights to "Panther's Moon," a novel by Victor Canning published in England in 1947 and in the United States in 1948, and has engaged Joel Malone to adapt it to the screen.

Robert Bruce Mathias, the prodigious 18-year-old all-around performer from Tulare, Calif., who won the Olympic decathlon championship at London last summer, yesterday was announced by the Amateur Athletic Union as the 1948 recipient of the James E. Sullivan Memorial Trophy.

Although many themes, such as the use of pale colors, high crowns, manipulation through tucking and pleatings and the use of veils were woven into the Lenesta spring collection, it was this designer's strong emphasis on simple wearable silhouettes, on cloches, bonnets, brims and sailors, that dominated the showing seen yesterday at Fifteen East Fifty-third Street.

LONDON, Jan. 5 -- Although the stock market here today generally was cheerful brokers were disappointed that the opening of the new account brought about no revival of business. Although there were many small rises in prices, jobbers reported that there were more inquiries than actual business.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- The Interstate Commerce Commission received today for filing the tariffs of the country's railroads making effective on Jan. 11 the temporarily increased freight rates approved by the commission on Dec. 30.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 5 (AP) -- Football's most controversial rule of the 1948 season -- the free substitution system -- will be liberalized rather than curtailed if recommendations of the American Football Coaches Association are accepted.
TORONTO, Jan. 5 (AP) -- Jimmy Thomson, who didn't score a goal last season in regular play, got two tonight as Toronto defeated Boston, 4 -- 0, in a National Hockey League game.
BOSTON, Jan. 5 (AP) -- Putting on a nifty ball handling exhibition, Holy Cross defeated a taller Harvard basketball team, 64 -- 48, at the Boston Arena tonight.

A bugle fanfare, a dawn patrol breakfast and a few words of encouragement from Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, president of Columbia University, started 1,000 men and several women yesterday on a drive to raise $2,000,000 for the Greater New York Council of the Boy Scouts of America.
CAIRO, Jan. 5 -- Egyptian leaders and British diplomats here are studying the possibility that the Anglo-Egyptian treaty of mutual assistance of 1936 may become operative.
Collapsible milans emerged the biggest news in the large and versatile spring collection presented by Laddie Northridge yesterday at his 1 West Fifty-seventh Street salon.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- Kenneth C. Royall, Secretary of the Army, named a committee of twelve civilians and officers today to determine whether the National Guard and Organized Reserve Corps are "adequate and practicable" in their function of supplementing the national defense.
Announcing an expected promotion to the top post of the police force, Police Commissioner Arthur W. Wallander said yesterday that an extensive shake-up in police commands was imminent.

Contributions by and for children were received yesterday as money for The New York Times Neediest Case fund continued to come in from readers who had delayed their response in the Christmas campaign.

The news from China has of late been more confusing than enlightening, and some of it has been admittedly "premature." It does appear, however, that the seemingly irresistible Communist offensive has lulled, at least for the moment, despite yesteday's shelling of government positions around Tientsin, and that both sides are regrouping for battles still to be fought.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- The Atomic Energy Commission issued today a safety guide for officers who pass on the security of atomic workers.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- The decision of the ailing Senator Robert F. Wagner of New York not to return to the chairmanship of the Banking and Currency Committee was revealed today as the Democratic Senate Steering Committee announced committee assignments.

The $682,000,000 General Public Utilities Corporation, through its president, A. F. Tegen, disclosed yesterday plans for early disposition of its interest in the $144,000,000 New York State Electric and Gas Corporation, one of twenty of its subsidiaries serving parts of Pennsylvania, New York and New Jersey and the Philippine Islands.
R. H. Macy Co. notified its 8,000 employes yesterday that it had asked the National Labor Relations Board to hold an election Jan. 25 to decide which union the workers wanted to represent them.

Large increases in sales of lightweight, single - cylinder motorcycles, particularly in industrial areas, were predicted yesterday at the annual meeting of the Motorcycle Allied Trades Association in the Lexington Hotel. Because of the low retail price, high mileage and continued scarcity of automobiles, 1949 is expected to produce enormous sales gains.

The Appellate Division of the Supreme Court reserved decision late yesterday on appeals by six men and a woman from convictions in the Court of Special Sessions growing out of extortionate practices arising from the housing shortage.

Savage mid-winter weather continued to hold vast sections of the country in a paralyzing grip yesterday, causing an undetermined number of deaths and making thousands homeless as the result of blizzards and floods. Communication and transportation facilities were crippled and livestock losses and property damage were heavy.

PRETORIA, South Africa, Jan. 5 -- Political relations between whites and Negroes in South Africa were broken off today. The consequences cannot be foreseen. Whether they are immediate or remote probably depends more on world events than on domestic developments.
CORAL GABLES, Fla., Jan. 5 (AP) -- Fred W. Hooper's thoroughbred, Olympia, today beat the star quarter horse, Stella Moore, by a head in a special match race at Tropical Park.

A group of world-famous soloists and conductors, including Vladimir Horowitz, Artur Rubinstein and Alexander Brailowsky, pianists; Lily Pons, Metropolitan Opera soprano, and Andre Kostelanetz, conductor, have warned the Chicago Symphony Orchestra that they would not appear as soloists or guest leaders with that ensemble if Wilhelm Furtwaengler became principal conductor, it was learned yesterday.

Francis Cardinal Spellman, Roman Catholic Archbishop of New York, expressed the conviction last night that Joseph Cardinal Mindszenty, Primate of Hungary, would be found guilty "after a foul mock trial."

MIAMI BEACH, Jan. 5 -- Maintenance of a high plane of ethical operation has been one of the most important factors in stabilizing the women's coat and suit industry through the post-war adjustment period, according to trade leaders today at the annual meeting of the National Coat and Suit Industry Recovery Board.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- President Truman declared before the Eighty-first Congress today that the continued well-being of the nation would require a new tax load of $4,000,000,000 and an eight-point control program for coping with inflation.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- The American Box Board Company, Grand Rapids, Mich., registered today with the Securities and Exchange Commission $5,400,000 of fifteen-year, 4 1/4 per cent convertible sinking-fund debentures that are convertible into $1 par value common shares of the company at the rate of forty common shares for each $1,000 debenture.

" The NBC Theatre" will be presented in the network's 8:30 spot on Sunday nights, starting next week, with the cooperation of the Screen Director's Guild, it was announced yesterday. The first of the weekly productions will be "Stagecoach," starring John Wayne, with Howard Wiley directing for NBC. John Ford directed the film version.

Angling clubs within two days' walking distance of Grand Central Palace can begin selecting their representative for the surfcaster versus swimmer contest to be held during the Sportsmen's Show, which will open this year on Feb. 19.

CHICAGO, Jan. 5 -- Grain markets fluctuated in a nervous manner on the Board of Trade today but ended higher generally, with corn futures up 5/8 cent to 1 3/4 cents, September leading the advance. Wheat rose 1/8 to 3/4 cent and oats 1/8 to 5/8 cent.

In a petition proclaiming their belief that a person suffering continual pain from incurable illness "has the right to die," 379 Protestant and Jewish clergymen called yesterday on the State Legislature to enact a law permitting voluntary euthanasia, or "mercy killings.''

The Rev. Laurence J. McGinley will become rector and president of Fordham University on Feb. 2, it was announced yesterday by the Very Rev. John J. McMahon, Provincial of the New York Province of the Society of Jesus, on behalf the Very Rev. John B. Janssens, general of the society.
HARRISBURG, Pa., Jan. 5 (AP) -- President Truman's appeal today for increased public housing brought immediate opposition from the National Association of Real Estate Boards.

HARTFORD, Conn., Jan. 5 -- Chester Bowles, former head of the Office of Price Administration, puffed cigarettes in the executive offices for nearly four hours this afternoon while the Connecticut Legislature wrangled about a possible recount of his election as Governor.

PRINCETON, N. J., Jan. 5 -- Princeton's varsity basketball team, making its first home appearance since a holiday junket to Florida, downed a disorganized Pennsylvania five in Dillon Gymnasium tonight to open its 1949 Eastern League campaign successfully.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- To Theodore Roosevelt's Square Deal and Franklin D. Roosevelt's New Deal President Truman today added a program which he called the Fair Deal. But while he was doing so on the House side of the Capitol his party in the Senate was trumping up what the Republicans regarded as the rawest deal in the short history of the bipartisan foreign policy.
Dr. and Mrs. Vladimir G. Simkhovitch will be at home to their friends tomorrow afternoon, and more than 400 are expected to help the couple mark their fiftieth wedding anniversary.

WARSAW, Jan. 5 -- The murder of one of the rural leaders of the new Polish United Workers party was announced today and a Polish Government official, commenting on this murder, conceded that there had been a resurgence of underground activity in the last four months.

Ten well-rested roosters, in a crowing contest at the eighteenth annual New York Poultry Show, last night let loose with a long shrill cacophony that reverberated through the Ninth Regiment Armory, 125 West Fourteenth Street.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- Senator Henry Cabot Lodge Jr., Republican, of Massachusetts, introduced today a proposal to amend the Constitution to abolish the electoral college.
Lieut. Col. Charles D. L. Pepys, British Army, and the Hon. Mrs. Pepys of Camberley, England, have come to the Pierre from Newport, R. I.

Ship - shape motor cruisers, doughty enough for most any wind and weather and awaiting only next summer's vacation days to put to sea, cluttered up East Forty - sixth and Forty - seventh Streets all yesterday and most of last night on their way into Grand Central Palace, where the National Motor Boat Show will open tomorrow night.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- President Truman kept his campaign pledges today in a State of the Union message which, from the political point of view, promised additional Federal benefits for millions of Americans.

LONDON, Jan. 5 -- A dependable British source strongly intimated tonight that as a precaution against Israeli incursions into Trans-Jordan a detachment of British troops had been sent to the Trans-Jordanian port of Aqaba on the Red Sea.

Edward C. Werle, a partner in Johnson Wood, has been nominated for a third consecutive term as chairman of the board of governors of the New York Curb Exchange, Francis Adams Truslow, president of the country's second largest securities market, announced yesterday. The annual elections will be held on Feb. 14.

The stock market found nothing unexpected yesterday in President Truman's message to the Congress and there was little, if any, reaction. In fact, aside from a brief flurry after the President completed his addess on the State of the Union, the share list remained noncommittal, which to most financial observers indicated nothing more than a continuation of the passive role that the market has followed recently.
MILWAUKEE, Jan. 5 (UP) -- A wildcat strike of 2,400 street car and bus operators put thousands of Milwaukeeans on their feet today.

Victor H. McCutcheon, whose sudden death was a shock to many of us, was a man with a genius for friendship and an instinct for helpfulness in time of trouble. He was the rallying point for a wide circle which represented not only this city but all parts of the country and many points abroad -- and it was a circle not less varied because in the heart of it were his classmates at Harvard.

A committee representing top executive and supervisory jobs in the New York public school system has asked the Board of Education to approve a permanent 30 per cent salary increase for the Superintendent of Schools and 120 other key positions.

ALBANY, Jan. 5 -- With Governor Dewey and several members of the Legislature and the judiciary present, former Senator Fred A. Young, Lowville Republican, took the oath of office today as a judge of the State Court of Claims.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 (UP) -- Dr. Isaiah Bowman, retiring president of Johns Hopkins University, was recommended by Senator Arthur H. Vandenberg, Republican, of Michigan, today for membership on the Atomic Energy Commission.

St. Mark's School of Southborough, Mass., and Taft School of Watertown, Conn., opened their respective hockey schedules yesterday at Madison Square Garden before 3,000 spectators by battling to a scoreless tie. Three fifteen-minute periods and the five-minute vertime session produced some exciting play.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Jan. 5 -- Israeli forces penetrated about thirty miles into Egypt, wrecked three military airfields around El Arish and occupied an important communications center for more than three days before withdrawing, it was disclosed tonight.
Nature lovers and conservationists renewed hostilities yesterday to preserve seven acres of Van Cortlandt Park swampland as a wildlife sanctuary.

Americans are not known for their adventurous appetites, having a conservative preference for meat and potatoes and pie. But at least one new food introduced here during the last decade has caught on.

Reduction of 1 cent a quart in the price of homogenized milk sold in the retail stores of the Great Atlantic Pacific Tea Company and an equal price cut in the wholesale homogenized milk rate charged by three leading producers was requested yesterday by Commissioner of Investigation John M. Murtagh.

Isaac Don Levine told reporters yesterday that the public had not heard the last of the Laurence Duggan case but that he believed it would be shown Mr. Duggan had been "innocently victimized" by Soviet espionage agents.

Despite uncertainties of the current readjustment period in textiles, prospects point to a high percentage of activity in the textile field this year, Robert L. Huffines Jr., president of the Burlington Mills Corporation (N. Y.) said here yesterday. The corporation is the largest rayon weaver and hosiery producer in the country.
ALBANY, Jan. 5 -- Proceedings of the opening session of the State Legislature today were lightened with jocular references to the November election.

HARRISON, N. Y., Jan. 5 -- Leading representatives of a divided community met tonight to argue whether or not Mrs. Ogden Reid should be allowed to break up a large family estate she says she can no longer "carry" and to permit establishment in a portion of it as a large shopping center.

LONDON, Jan. 5 -- Harvey, the improbable rabbit who has lived for four years in the imaginations of Frank Fay and other actors in New York, turned up in London tonight at the Prince of Wales Theatre. He was greeted with gales of laughter by the first-night audience.
Issues of temporary loan notes aggregating $25,983,000 were sold yesterday by sixteen local housing authorities at interest rates ranging from 1.10 per cent to 1.21 per cent.

ALBANY, Jan. 5 -- Several Republican Assemblymen from New York City are exploring the possibility to organizing a bloc to force Governor Dewey and the legislative leadership to consult them on all legislation affecting the city. What they want, apparently, is a revival of the system in effect before Mr. Dewey became Governor.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 5 -- Yale University today paid final tribute to eleven of its students killed in a Seattle plane crash on Sunday night at a memorial service in Battell Chapel on the campus.
CHICAGO, Jan. 5 -- Television sets are being considered now for their effects on furniture design, on the arrangement of rooms and plans for home construction.

PRAGUE, Jan. 5 -- The introduction of a twofold price system, one for the rich and the other for the poor, was the chief feature of today's budget speech by Finance Minister Jaromir Dolansky. It was the first budget of Czechoslovakia's five-year plan.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows, the Federal Reserve Board announced today, the following principal changes for the week ended Dec. 29:
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 5 -- Owner Alexis Thompson decided today to sell his champion Philadelphia Eagles of the National Football League if he could get at least $250,000.

Mme. Pauline, known for her excellent millinery technique, insisted upon brim importance in the showing that took place in her establishment, 6 East 53d Street, yesterday noon. There were contours of many descriptions.
