CANBERRA, Australia, Jan. 5 (AP) -- An emergency Indonesian Republican Government laid down the conditions today under which it would cease its fight against Netherland forces in Java and Sumatra.

The recent news item that a "campaign to familiarize the public with the roof-lights that at night indicate whether taxicabs are vacant" was to begin is interesting. As this campaign is announced by the Police Department, it may be possible for the police to acquaint "Willies With Their Whistles" in uniform in front of various hotels that they are breaking the law.

The fourteen-story apartment house containing seventy suites at 365 West End Avenue and 309-311 West Seventy-seventh Street has been sold by the estate of Jules Bache to Newcraft Associates, Inc., a syndicate of investors headed by Morris Newman.

ALBANY, Jan. 5 -- When the State Senate convened today for its 172d session, it met without a woman among its members for the first time in fourteen years. This resulted from the retirement from public life of Mrs. Rhoda Fox Graves of Gouverneur, the only woman ever elected to the State Senate.
ALBANY, Jan. 5 -- Governor Dewey told the Legislature today higher taxes were needed to finance a spending program that would push the state's 1949-50 budget to a record $900,000,000.

Trade selling and scattered long liquidation yesterday resulted in a generally easier tone developing in the sugar futures market on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange. The domestic sugar futures contract dropped 3 to 4 points below Tuesday's close on transactions of 10,550 tons.

Accommodations for 1,000 families in the moderate-income groups will be provided in a $10,000,000 garden-apartment project which the Tishman Realty and Construction Company will erect on a ten-acre tract in the Rego Park section of Queens.

An odd mixture of jubilation and cautious, watchful waiting was apparent on Broadway yesterday, following the verdict of a Federal court jury in the case of Carl E. Ring, lawyer-producer who sought treble damages of $420,000 from the Dramatists Guild because he allegedly had been damaged by its minimum basic agreement.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange established only small net changes for the day yesterday, and final prices were 4 to 12 points net higher.

Mayor O'Dwyer's special committee continued efforts yesterday afternoon to avert a port tie-up at midnight next Wednesday. After a three-hour meeting of both sides, however, no progress was reported when the talks at City Hall broke up near 6 P. M.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 (AP) -- The Census Bureau reported today that shipping tie-ups caused by long-shoremen's strikes cut the export of goods during November to the lowest point in two years.

The City Council sent yesterday to its committee on state legislation a resolution introduced by Councilman Edward Rager, Manhattan Republican, asking the Legislature to name a committee to investigate Mayor O'Dwyer's administration.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- White House correspondents got standing positions on the floor of the House chamber while the President read his message, so they caught a few sound effects.

Winning his game in the sixth round of the international masters tournament sponsored by the Hastings and St. Leonards Chess Club, the French champion, Nicholas Rossolimo of Paris, drew away from the field yesterday. He achieved a hard-earned victory in 62 moves over T. H. Tylor of England, according to a report received from Hastings.

Despite political problems involved, the Government should extend some form of assistance to the great musical institutions of this country to insure their survival in an age of decreased private financial patronage, speakers on THE NEW YORK TIMES WQXR forum, "What's On Your Mind?" generally agreed last night.

There was a hit-and-miss basketball game in University Hall at Columbia University last night. Columbia did the hitting, Fordham did the missing, and the result was a 74-to-38 success for the home delegation in the twenty-fifth match of a series that dates back to 1907.
LAKE SUCCESS, Jan. 5 -- Secretary General Trygve Lie of the United Nations disclosed here today that he might take steps of his own to try to stop the Chinese war.

TOKYO, Jan. 5 -- Signs have begun to multiply that Japan's newly organized trade unions, which are argely Communist-led have already begun to test out the amount of determination that may be behind Gen. Douglas MacArthur's December directive declaring that neither labor nor capital can be permitted to hamper the increase of national production.

BUCK HILL FALLS, Pa., Jan. 5 -- The Foreign Missions Conference of North America refused tonight to affiliate with the proposed National Council of the Churches of Christ in the United States of America. Fifty-one delegates voted in favor and sixty-three opposed the proposition.

A Chelsea property passed to new control for the first time in more than fifty years when the two five-story houses containing thirty apartments at 323-25 West Twenty - sixth Street, between Eighth and Ninth Avenues, were sold by Jacob J. Tabolt and James P. Hatch, executors of the estate of Rosanna C. Hafner to Fred F. and John E. Desel for investment.

The opportunity that lies ahead for Robert Villemain, French middleweight, if successful against Steve Belloise in their ten-round bout tomorrow night at Madison Square Garden, yesterday was outlined by Promoter Harry Markson of the Twentieth Century S. C.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- President Truman significantly refrained from calling again today for an excess profits tax levy on corporations and thus enhanced the prospects, according to experienced legislators, of a tax increase to balance the record peacetime budget to be submitted Monday.

GENEVA, Jan. 5 -- Five countries are sharply criticized for permitting large increases in the consumption of heroin since the war, in a report of the United Nations permanent Central Opium Board issued today.

This country's imports during the first ten months of 1948 slightly exceeded the entire year's total for 1947 of $5,700,000,000. There is a reasonable probability that for 1948 as a whole they will amount to $7,000,000,000, a figure never previously reached.

Emerson Radio and Phonograph Corporation will begin dealer deliveries of a sixteen-inch direct view tube table television receiver to list for about $400 within sixty days, Benjamin Abrams, president, announced yesterday. The set will be the lowest priced sixteen-inch receiver on the market, retailing for almost $100 less than comparable sets.

Probably not since his first Presidential address on Capitol Hill in that turbulent and unforgettable April of 1945 has any message of Mr. Truman to Congress been awaited so eagerly as the message on the State of the Union which he read yesterday from the rostrum of the House. There are several reasons why this was so. To begin with, this was Mr. Truman's first message to Congress as President in his own right.

PARIS, Jan. 5 -- Practical results will be the aim of the mixed Franco-Italian Committee that today at the Foreign Office opened its third session for the purpose of drafting a plan for a Franco-Italian customs union.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- President Truman on several occasions has specified that the attainment of durable world peace and order is his fundamental goal and has always expressed confidence he would succeed. Therefore, his proposal to Congress today that could take the Government permanently into industry, particularly steel, could be viewed in the frame of peacetime.

LONDON, Thursday, Jan. 6 -- President Truman's message to Congress received generally sympathetic comment from British newspapers this morning. They emphasized the point that a strong, progressive United States was vital to the future of the democratic world. The only critical notes came from the Communist Daily Worker and from The Financial Times.

ABOARD THE CARONIA AT SEA, Jan. 5 -- A congratulatory radiogram from Princess Elizabeth and the Duke of Edinburgh, received last night over the ship's radio, was read over the Caronia's loudspeakers this morning as the new liner plowed through a heavy swell on her first day at sea.

HOBOKEN, N. J., Jan. 5 -- Dennis E. McFeely's claim to the position of Acting Chief of the Police Department here was sustained today by the New Jersey Civil Service Commission in a ruling that invalidated a previous order by Michael M. Borelli, Municipal Director of Public Safety, reducing him to the post of captain.

CHICAGO, Jan. 5 -- Withdrawal of the Tucker Corporation's license to do business in Wisconsin and a legal quarrel over the terms of an order staying bankruptcy and receivership proceedings against the company for sixty days were among today's developments involving the financially-troubled Chicago automobile company.
GENEVA, Jan. 5 -- European trade experts predict shipping of food from Eastern Europe to Western Europe will be revived on a considerable scale this year.

A request that all consumers be informed by notice that excise taxes have been included in the purchase price has been made to the American Retail Federation by the Illinois Federation of Retail Associations. It is suggested that a notice be attached to cash sales slips or included with monthly bills.

The National Maritime Union, CIO, threatened yesterday to hold up the sailing of a number of ships being used to transport Displaced Persons to the United States, because of a dispute with two shipping lines.
ALBANY, Jan. 5 -- A bill calling for a legislative investigation of the pier situation in New York City was introduced today by Assemblyman Louis Peck, Democrat, of the Bronx.

LAKE SUCCESS, Jan. 4 -- A steady increase in world production of fuel, energy and industrial materials has been recorded during the last year, United Nations statistical experts reported here today, in the latest Monthly Bulletin of Statistics.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- Organized labor acclaimed President Truman's labor proposals today as fulfillment of his campaign promises and support of its policies.

A 1949 target for sales 50 per cent higher than record totals in 1948 has been set by distributors of air-conditioning equipment of York Corporation, it was disclosed here yesterday by Dean C. Seitz, manager of distributor sales. Mr. Seitz' estimates were based on a survey of distribution executives.

Lillian Lefkofsky, pianist, who made her debut here eight years ago, gave a recital last night at Times Hall. Since she has given intervening recitals and played twice last season with the Wolff Chamber Players, there was a cordial audience on hand familiar with her work.
The resumption of fighting in Palestine obviously represents an Israeli attempt to achieve in the field what the Israelis have not been able to accomplish in the council chamber -- peace.

J. P. Humes of the Princeton Club, seeded fifth, won a second-round match from Ed Oppenheimer, unattached, as the New York State singles squash racquets championship got under way yesterday at the New York A. C. courts. The top seeded player to see action, Humes won by 15 -- 6, 15 -- 12, 15 -- 13. Calvin MacCracken, defending titleholder, is seeded first.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- The Economic Cooperation Administration reminded the Marshall Plan countries again today that the European Recovery Program would end on schedule in 1952 and took exception to a report by their central organization suggesting a dollar deficit of $3,000,000,000 when the program ends.

Now that New Year's is over, there will be no general holiday until Feb. 22, which marks the birthday of George Washington. To be sure, certain states will take days off in between, for the North will remember Lincoln, and the South, General Lee, but there will be no holiday on which the whole country is united.
MUNICH, Germany, Jan. 5 (AP) -- A planeload of refugees, after having made an aerial escape from Hungary, said today they had fled from "Communist terror."

About the time New York is getting out of bed and putting on its slippers, between 600 and 700 buyers of fruit are scurrying about on piers along the North River inspecting samples, to prepare themselves for the fruit auctions that are held five mornings a week at 8:30 o'clock.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 5 (UP) -- Official movies of the Rose Bowl game fail to settle the controversial Art Murakowski touchdown fumble in Northwestern's 20-14 victory over California, the United Press learned today. The pictures, taken from approximately the 50-yard line, show Murakowski approximately at the goal line before he fumbled in a secoid-period play that officials ruled a touchdown.

Reflecting the weather conditions, which were generally unfavorable for the use of automobiles, gasoline stocks in the United States increased 3,777,000 barrels last week, according to the American Petroleum Institute. At the week-end they amounted to 104, 063,000 barrels, compared with 100,286,000 a week earlier and 94,099,000 a year earlier.
DUESSELDORF, Germany, Jan. 5 (AP) -- Britain may use troops to overcome German resistance to dismantling the big Bochumer Verein steel works in the Ruhr.

CAPETOWN, Jan. 5 (Reuters) -- The third cricket test between England and South Africa ended today in a draw. South Africa, needing 229 runs in two hours to win after England had declared at 276 for three, was 142 for four wickets when play ended.

The area of activities of the New York Zoological Society during the last year ranged from the Pacific Coast eastward to the Belgian Congo, Fairfield Osborn, president of the society, reported to the fifty-third annual meeting of the group at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel last night.

The high-grade bond market, which has been contradicting the stock market pricewise ever since the November election, reacted in concert with equity values yesterday following delivery of President Truman's "State of the Union" survey.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- The Administration bill to provide for construction of 1,050,000 new units of low rent, publicly financed housing in the next seven years was introduced in the Senate today within a few minutes after President Truman set the goal in his State of the Union message.

Four stage attractions yesterday announced their intention of ending their Broadway careers within the next ten days, the foremost of these being the veteran "Annie Get Your Gun," starring Ethel Merman, which has been around for two years and eight months.
Following is the text of President Truman's State of the Union Message, as recorded and transcribed by THE NEW YORK TIMES.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 (AP) -- J. A. Krug, Secretary of the Interior, today appointed a ten-member advisory committee on Indian affairs.

NANKING, Jan. 5 -- Gen. Pai Chung-hsi, co-partner with Vice President Li Tsung-jen in the leadership of the so-called "Kwangsi clique," was reported tonight to have pulled his troops back into Hankow in a move that left the Ministry of National Defense guessing as to his political intentions.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- The Democrats were angrily accused today by Senator Arthur H. Vandenberg of Michigan of having struck at the outset of the new Congress a blow against the bipartisan foreign policy that was "implicit with hostility."

The Giants yesterday brought their sixth contract signer into the fold when Secretary Eddie Brannick announced that Carroll (Whitey) Lockman, fleet - footed outfielder, had accepted terms for the 1949 season. Although salary figures were not revealed it is understood the 22-year-old North Carolinian received a substantial boost.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- The Eighty-first Congress reacted to President Truman's message today with strong and widespread indications that most of his recommendations would be written into law. The proposals included many which Congress had turned down or ignored for years.

Seton Hall's Frank Fox won the first cup-racing test of the 1949 indoor track and field campaign last night, but Fred Wilt's impressive 9:18.1 clocking for two miles provided the highlight of the second annual Metropolitan A. A. U. open meet at the 102d Engineers Armory.

Post-holiday penny-pinching by housewives, slow trade in grocery stores and a reduction in oleomargarine prices combined yesterday to knock down the wholesale price of butter in this city 3 3/4 cents a pound. Retailers throughout the metropolitan area announced price reductions of 2 to 6 cents a pound.

LONDON, Jan. 5 -- Sir Basil Brooke, Prime Minister of Northern Ireland, who is scheduled to arrive here tomorrow for a meeting with Prime Minister Attlee, is expected to ask that the name of Northern Ireland be changed to Ulster.

Marine antiquaries, who have long pondered the mystery of the "Sir Galahad" figurehead which gazes at South Street shipping from above the entrance of the Seamen's Church Institute, have unearthed a new clue to its origin, it became known yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- The Federal Reserve Banks earned $304,000,000 during 1948, or $146,000,000 more than in 1947, the Federal Reserve Board reported tonight.
BERLIN, Jan. 5 -- The release of 33,423 tons of coal and 1,290 tons of liquid fuel from reserve stocks, ordered by the three-power Kommandatura at its second session yesterday, was announced today.

The modern boys' club can offer its greatest service, it was agreed yesterday, not in supplying recreation but in giving maladjusted children through personal guidance a measure of the affection, security and recognition denied them in broken homes.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Jan. 5 -- Recent attacks by the Israeli army have produced feverish diplomatic activity among the Arab states. The Presidents, Premiers and Foreign Ministers of Lebanon and Syria met today at the mountain resort town of Bhamdoun between here and Damascus for a two-hour conference on the situation.

Joseph S. Harris, formerly assistant manager of the aviation department of the Shell Oil Company, has been appointed head of the department. He succeeds Dr. R. T. Goodwin, who has been named manager of Shell's special products department.

John Creighton Murray, young American violinist, who gave two recitals in this city shortly before the outbreak of the war, returned to the local concert stage last night at Town Hall. In the interim he had served four years as a private first class in the United States Army and made a two-year tour of Europe.

Fire Commissioner Frank J. Quayle suspended three more top-ranking officers in the Fire Department yesterday as a result of a firehouse party in lower Manhattan on the night of Dec. 16. Chief Peter Loftus had been suspended for the same reason on Tuesday.

Undefeated North Carolina will place its seven-game winning streak on the line against New York University at Madison Square Garden tonight. This contest is the opener of a doubleheader that will conclude with a clash between North Carolina State, 1948 Southern Conference champion, and Long Island University.

Manufacturers Trust Company has been appointed trustee, paying agent and registrar for Jamaica Water Supply Company's first mortgage 3 1/4 per cent, Series B bonds, and registrar for the company's cumulative preferred stock, Series B.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 6 -- N. Peter Rathvon, whose resignation as president of RKO has become effective, today announced the formation of a new company under his own name, which will make available "a considerable amount of capital" for investment in independent film production.

Freedom of movement throughout the world is as important as freedom of the press, Miss Bertha McCall, former general director and new historian of the National Travelers Aid Association, said here yesterday.

DURHAM, England, Jan. 6 -- In Durham's wonderful Norman cathedral there is a memorial to coal miners of this region. The inscription is from the Book of Job. It reads: "He breatheth open a shaft away from where men sojourn. They are forgotten of the foot that passed by."

The New York Cotton Exchange announced yesterday that its president, Charles B. Vose, has written to the Commodity Exchange Authority protesting as "wholly unjustified" part of the recent annual report of the government agency, which, the letter said, created "the impression that the (Cotton) Exchange tolerated or in any way permitted outright fraud, confidence games, manipulation of prices and other undesirable and abusive practices."

The Salvation Army will seek $1,100,000 throughout Greater New York in its 1949 maintenance appeal beginning Jan. 15 and continuing through Feb. 15, it was announced yesterday by Ray Vir Den, general chairman of the campaign.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Jan. 6 -- Lieut. Gen. Joseph-Pierre Koenig, the French commander in Germany, has again protested to his American and British colleagues, Gens. Lucius D. Clay and Sir Brian Robertson, on an issue of security.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Jan. 6 -- Egypt's request for a cease-fire came shortly after the Government and Cabinet had decided to accept a similar Security Council order and had left the matter in the hands of Foreign Minister Moshe Shertok.

PANAMA, Jan. 6 -- Sources here in touch with Salvadorean affairs said today the removal of Colonel Cordoba had been expected for some time on the belief that he had not measured up to the liberal ideals of the Revolutionary Council.

A temporary gloom has descended upon Broadway. Staggering from the attendance slump, three additional shows are joining tomorrow night's procession of closings. Consequently, the number of week-end departures has mounted to eight. Just added to the list are "Small Wonder." "The Young and Fair" and "Don't Listen, Ladies."
MOSCOW, Jan. 6 (AP) -- Moscow newspapers printed a forty-nine-word item today on President Truman's State of the Union message.
MILWAUKEE, Wis., Jan. 6 -- This city's public transportation system was moving again today after about twenty-four hours of idleness enforced by the work stoppage of about 2,700 AFL employes.

After having served for almost sixty years as the family residence, the four-story private dwelling at 15 East Seventy-first Street, near Madison Avenue, has been sold by Mrs. Alex McMillan Welch to a client of Julius Haimowitz, attorney, for altering.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 (UP) -- An atomic clock that can split seconds with the extraordinary accuracy of one part in 20,000,000 was added to the arsenal of research science today.

The trial of twelve top Communist leaders, scheduled to begin a week from next Monday, is expected to last at least two months. This was made known yesterday by United States Attorney John F. X. McGohey, who will head the prosecution with five assistants.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 6 -- A city-state agreement for construction of a state park with landscaped mall to provide an impressive approach to Independence Hall was endorsed unanimously today by City Council's committee on public works.

" Unknown Island," an adventure filmed in Cinecolor for Film Classics release, will have its local premiere this morning at the Rialto. Philip Reed, Virginia Grey, Barton MacLane and Richard Denning head the cast of the offering, which was directed by Jack Bernhard and produced by Albert Jay Cohen from a story by Robert T. Shannon and a screen play by Shannon and Jack Harvey.

HONG KONG, Jan. 6 -- Evidence in this city, headquarters of Communist South China operations, indicates that the Communists are prepared to advance province by province to the borders of Indo-China and Burma.

January "white sales" were reported by leading merchants as being very satisfactory despite unfavorable weather conditions during the week. Larger mark-downs than those of recent years were credited with the results. It was predicted, however, that better shopping weather next week will result in substantial increases over the corresponding period last year.

NANKING, Jan. 6 -- Nanking wondered tonight whether one-eyed Gen. Liu Po - cheng, Communist guerrilla genius and commander in Central China was really dead this time. Lieut. Gen. Teng Wen-yi, Nationalist military spokesman, said at a press conference that General Liu's death had been confirmed and gave details of the alleged event as a result of a bombing attack on Dec. 13.

The stock market yesterday scored its best advance in eight months as prices rose 1 to 4 points in heavy trading. The rally was slow in getting under way, but once the list moved forward buying orders gained momentum. Particularly to the fore were the steels, which were not depressed by President Truman's suggestion of Government participation in the steel industry.
The Swedish American liner Stockholm arrived yesterday with 307 passengers and two 20-year-old Polish stowaways, who said they wanted to come to America to "study."

CHICAGO, Jan. 6 (AP) -- Field Judge Jay Berwanger, asserting he called the play "as I saw it," said today there is no question in his mind that Northwestern's Art Murakowski plunged to a touchdown before he fumbled in the Rose Bowl game.

ALBANY, Jan. 6 -- Governor Dewey's office announced that he would confer in New York City tomorrow with fifty representatives of organized labor to explore possible ways in which labor costs could be reduced for private home builders as well as the state.

The leadership of Local 333, United Marine Division, International Longshoremen's Association, was publicly challenged yesterday by the tugboat employers' negotiating committee to submit the latter's final offer of a 10 per cent pay rise and increased food allowance for each boat to a secret vote by the local's approximately 3,500 members.

There were no surprises yesterday when the House and Senate met jointly to watch the tellers count the vote of the Electoral College. Or if there was a surprise it was that President Truman, who happened to be at the Capitol for lunch, broke precedent by being present during part of the counting. Mr. Truman and Senator Barkley got 303 votes and were elected.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange were rather steady yesterday, and closing prices were 5 to 17 points net higher.

Edward Rager, Manhattan Republican, has startled the City Council by introducing a resolution charging that "the city administration has become a veritable cesspool of corruption and inefficiency." He wants the Legislature to name a committee to investigate the administration. Some of the city's employes are "corrupt," or "dishonest," while others are merely "useless."

LONDON, Jan. 6 (AP) -- Western Europe, most of it under Socialist control, today generally interpreted President Truman's State of the Union Message as evidence the United States will move further to the left.

An effort to seek restoration by the United States Army of an equestrian team to represent this country in international military jumping competition received the sanction of the American Horse Shows Association at its annual meeting at the Waldorf-Astoria yesterday.

LONDON, Jan. 6 -- The British Government is anxious that advertising of British goods be stepped up in the United States and will grant any reasonable application for currency for that purpose, D. De Grunwald, chairman of Incorporated Society of British Advertisers in London, said today.

A transaction in the vicinity of Rockefeller Center where the Astor Estate has been buying up property was reported by Henry Shapiro Co., brokers, who sold the five-story building containing hotel rooms and stores at 108-14 West Forty-ninth Street, near the Avenue of the Americas, for the Fershein Corporation to an investing client.

BUCK HILL FALLS, Pa., Jan. 6 -- The Protestant churches of the United States were called upon today by the administrative officials of the Foreign Missions Conference of North America to face with sober realism the world-wide advance of atheistic communism.

DOVER, Del., Jan. 6 (AP) -- Urging relaxation of Delaware's rape laws, Gov. Walter W. Bacon said today that it was a serious question whether the death sentence should be imposed in cases of conviction of rape.
BRUSSELS, Jan. 6 (AP) -- Bayeux, champion Belgian race horse left at the post in the $100,000 Empire City International Gold Cup at Belmont Park last October, has been sold to an American.

PARIS, Jan. 6 -- The European Recovery Program nations are capable of attaining a "manageable" situation by 1952-53, W. Averell Harriman, ERP Ambassador-at-Large, today told a press conference here to which he read a formal statement on the European report on the long-term program.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- An Army commission headed by Justice Gordon Simpson of the Texas Supreme Court recommended today that death sentences be commuted to life imprisonment or less for twenty-nine convicted Nazi war criminals, twelve of whom had taken part in the "Malmedy massacre" of American prisoners in 1944.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- E. Roland Harriman, New York investment banker and national chairman of the 1949 Red Cross fund campaign, today vigorously opposed any cutback in Red Cross services to pre-war levels. He made his statement in presenting to leaders of five cities the $81,000,000 budget for the fiscal year 1949-50.

The Paige Corporation, controlled by David Cronheim, broker, has leased the plot at the northeast corner of Park Place and Raymond Boulevard in Newark, N. J., from the Public Service Electric and Gas Company for improvement with a two-story taxpayer building, 117 by 230 feet.

The waterfowl season throughout the country will end tomorrow and although a marked increase in the number of ducks and geese was reported from almost every popular coastal hunting area from Maine to Florida, the indications are that the kill was under last year.

MINEOLA, L. I., Jan 6 -- The Nassau County Transit Commission announced today that it is conducting its own survey as a basis for recommendations to relieve overloading and "other inadequacies" on the Long Island Rail Road.

Crosley division, Avco Manufacturing Corporation, and its distributors throughout the country will increase their combined sales, advertising and promotion staffs 300 per cent by spring, W. A. Blees, general sales manager of the division, disclosed yesterday.
A complete program for increasing fire-protection equipment on city-owned piers was handed to Mayor O'Dwyer at City Hall yesterday by G. Joseph Minetti, Commissioner of Marine and Aviation.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- Thomas J. Fox, former Director of Missions for the War Relief Services of the National Catholic Welfare Conference, returned today the Medal of Honor awarded to him by the Hungarian Government in 1947 in recognition of his "meritorious service in behalf of the Hungarian Republic."
Terry P. Cunningham has been appointed director of advertising and sales promotion for Sylvania Electric Products, Inc.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 (AP) -- World cotton exports should increase by 2,000,000 bales in the 1949 crop year, the United States Department of Agriculture said today. It added: "Most of the increase must come from the United States if mill consumption abroad is to be maintained at the level anticipated for 1949 and possibly another year."
The United States Lines' freighter Red Jacket was renamed the American Reporter in honor of the newspaper profession in a ceremony yesterday aboard the vessel at her West Thirty-fourth Street pier.

International business circles will make major efforts in 1949 to obtain a free flow of capital across borders, according to a survey prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by the United States Associates of the International Chamber of Commerce.

Supreme Court Justice Morris Eder ruled yesterday that there was no labor dispute between the Manhattan News Company, Inc., and Local 471 of the New York Newsboys Union, AFL, and granted the company a temporary injunction restraining the union from picketnig or interfering with the 1,850 newsstands and stationery stores to whom the company delivers more than a hundred national magazines.

CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 6 -- Egyptian Minister of War Mohammed Haidar Pasha told correspondents, after he had conferred with his Premier, that "if the situation of the Egyptian forces in the Negeb region was very satisfactory yesterday, it is today considerably better than yesterday."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- The International Bank for Reconstruction and Development announced today that it had granted two loans totaling $34,100,000 to the Mexican Government for electric power development.

ALBANY, Jan. 6 -- With one eye on the municipal elections scheduled for next fall, several up-state Republican legislators have started a drive for additional state aid to education that may prove embarrassing to Governor Dewey and his fiscal program.

LAKE SUCCESS, Jan. 6 -- Details, disclosed here today, of the plebiscite plan to settle the year-long Kashmir dispute call for a special administrator and two commissions to guarantee an impartial election, quick repatriation of war refugees and release of all political prisoners.

Long Island University defeated North Carolina State, 65 -- 61, last night in one of the most bizarre basketball games Madison Square Garden has seen. The triumph of the Blackbirds followed on the heels of New York University's 72-48 rout of North Carolina.

BRIGHTON, England, Jan. 6 (Reuters) -- Sir Steuart Wilson, British Broadcasting Corporation director of music, said today that Covent Garden, London's historic opera house, had been rescued from where Sir Thomas Beecham, famous British orchestra conductor, "had left it -- from becoming a dance hall forever."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio and two of the Republican "modern," who had unsuccessfully fought his leadership, decided today to sponsor jointly a housing bill as a substitute for the Administration measure introduced yesterday.

LONDON, Jan. 6 (AP) -- Three American horses sent here by the Mellons will compete in the 103d running of the neck-breaking racing spectacle. The Grand National Steeplechase, next March 26 at Aintree.

BATAVIA, Java, Jan. 6 (AP) -- A Batavia newspaper quoted official sources today as having said that President Sukarno of the Indonesian Republic was being held by the Dutch Government at Balikpapan, Dutch Borneo, more than 700 miles from his capital of Jogjakarta.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- President Truman's proposal to Congress yesterday that could lead to the entrance of Government into the steel business -- Point 8 in his anti-inflation program -- was a surprise, not because the idea is new, but because he lent to it the power and prestige of his great office.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., Jan. 6 -- Farmer cooperatives appealed today for construction of needed grain storage facilities by private enterprise rather than by the Government. They asked also that farm price supports be adapted to the specific needs of each agricultural commodity.

A 14-year-old boy riding with a companion in an allegedly stolen automobile was shot and seriously wounded by a policeman at 167th Street and 111th Avenue, South Jamaica, Queens, last night. The boy's companion darted into a near-by alley and escaped.

The Chesapeake Ohio Railway sold yesterday an issue of $7,000,000 of equipment trust certificates maturing over ten years to a banking syndicate headed by Harriman Ripley Co., Inc., and Lehman Brothers at an interest cost of about 2.215 per cent.

Concentrated and intensive undergraduate college training that could be completed in less than four years, and modification of interne and residency training to alter the interne's "cloistered existence" within the confines of the hospital, were recommended last night by Dr. Benjamin P. Watson, incoming president of the New York Academy of Medicine.

SYRACUSE, Jan. 6 (AP) -- Charles E. Wilson, president of the General Electric Company, tonight branded the national legislative program of the Congress of Industrial Organizations as being "nakedly socialistic."

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., Jan. 6 -- Pointing out that a higher minimum wage would bolster consumer purchasing power in the income brackets where it is most needed, the National Coat and Suit Industry Recovery Board today unanimously endorsed President Truman's move for a 75-cent hourly minimum wage.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Jan. 6 -- Queen Juliana said in a broadcast today: "I sincerely hope that within a few weeks an Indonesian federal government will be established to shoulder the responsibilities and perform the duties inherent in the democratic system."

Efforts to interest youthful athletes in the game of golf will be made during the coming year by the Westchester County Golf Association, according to the decision reached yesterday at the annual meeting of the organization at the Hotel Roosevelt.

The immediate objective of economic stability can best be attained by the extension of credit on a conservative basis, "not by over-all restrictions that arbitrarily shut off access to legitimate loans for sound productive purposes," according to the annual report of the Guaranty Trust Company of New York, published today.
This being the time of season when such things are the fashion, George M. Weiss yesterday rendered his report on the state of the Yankees.

NANKING, Jan. 6 -- Lieut. Gen. Teng Wen-yi, Nationalist military spokesman, assured foreign correspondents today that the Government would take steps to insure "continued free transmission of press messages," pending a final decision on news censorship.

The City Rent Commission was under attack yesterday by both landlords and tenants of hotels here. Twenty-five witnesses representing both sides appeared before a subcommittee of the State Temporary Commission to Study Rents, at the Bar Association Building, 42 West Forty-fourth Street.

The nation's steel mills now have the capacity to produce 96,120,930 net tons of raw steel annually, greater than ever before in war or peace, Walter S. Tower, president of the American Iron and Steel Institute, announced yesterday after the annual survey of the industry's facilities.

Four persons were in serious condition last night in hospitals after a Department of Sanitation truck had collided earlier with a trolley in the Bensonhurst section of Brooklyn. Traffic on Thirteenth Avenue was tied up for nearly two hours after the crash.

Earning assets of the reporting New York City member banks of the Federal Reserve System dropped $148,000,000 during the week ended on Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York disclosed yesterday. Commercial, industrial, and agricultural loans, it was reported, accounted for $53,000,000 of the decline, largely reflecting repayments by automobile, airplane and tobacco companies and distillers.

LAKE SUCCESS, Jan. 6 -- Yugoslavia accused the Anglo-American authorities of Trieste today of having imposed a new system of identification cards in the territory detrimental to the interests of the Slovene population.

Children of a sixth grade class in a Brooklyn elementary school saved themselves tummyaches and gained the enjoyment of helping others when they contributed $5 to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund yesterday. They had collected the money for a Christmas party for themselves.
LONDON, Jan. 6 -- A plan to prevent communism in China from spreading throughout the Far East is rapidly taking shape in the minds of policy-making officials of the British Government.

Worried over the danger of a shutdown in city fuel deliveries at midnight next Wednesday, Mayor O'Dwyer appointed a three-man committee yesterday to represent him in efforts to bring about a peaceful settlement of the wage dispute between the coal and fuel oil companies and their 2,500 truck drivers.

More than one-third of the nation is protected by some form of voluntary hospital expense insurance, John H. Miller, chairman of a committee formed by several leading trade associations of the insurance industry, announced yesterday.
Sullivan County, Tenn., announced yesterday that it will receive bids on Feb. 14 on $1,200,000 of school and road bonds dated Feb. 1, 1949, due on Feb. 1, 1961 to 1964, and callable in 1954.
The Board of Education is studying the advisability of sending maritime-minded students of the Metropolitan Vocational High School to sea as part of their school training, it was announced yesterday.

ALBANY, Jan. 6 -- The State Board of Law Examiners announced today that 595 persons passed the October bar examination in which 1,330 candidates participated. Five hundred and fifty-five of the successful applicants live in New York City.

The 205,000 refugees who will get a chance to leave the vacuum of Europe's Displaced Persons camps and enter the United States in the next two years will help ease a shortage of skilled labor in this country and at the same time add several hundred million dollars to the national income, according to a survey for THE NEW YORK TIMES.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- The Truman Administration's campaign to knock out the Taft-Hartley Labor Law, which may be one of the greatest struggles of the new Congress, was opened officially today.

Mrs. Fanny Blankers-Koen, Dutch house wife who won three individual Olympic title in an unprecedented performance, was named woman athlete of the year for 1948 yesterday in The Associated Press annual poll.

CHICAGO, Jan. 6 -- Operations in the grain markets were restricted on the Board of Trade today as brokers awaited further developments as to farm legislation in Washington. Trading was slow except for a brief period at the opening and again at the close.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Jan. 6 -- The Prime Ministers, Foreign Ministers and Defense Ministers of Norway, Sweden and Denmark ended a two-day secret meeting at Karlstad, Sweden, today at which they discussed Scandinavian defense and political cooperation, the Swedish Foreign Office announced tonight.
For a long time I have felt that women of leisure should offer themselves for jury duty. I recently did so with the following disillusioning results.

The Lehman Corporation reported yesterday that on Dec. 31, the end of the first half of its fiscal year, its assets amounted to $90,834,385, equal to $46.57 a share, compared with $97,775,665 or $50.22 at the beginning of the year. Net assets on Sept. 30 were $46.31 a share.

TOKYO, Jan. 6 -- Reports that are now beginning to reach Tokyo from many sections of Japan indicate an increasing apathy on the part of the Japanese toward the democratic electoral process, which they will be called on to exercise for the third time since the occupation at a general election Jan. 23.

ATLANTA, Ga., Jan. 6 -- A warning that the Federal Government must "take its hand out of the venture capital till" and overhaul its tax structure to eliminate "waste and extravagance" if industry is to produce more goods at lower prices was made tonight by Morris Sayre, chairman of the board of the National Association of Manufacturers.

Photosensitive glass, developed by the Corning Glass Works after nine years of research, is finding wide uses in a number of fields, including the reproduction of important Government documents, it was learned yesterday.

Joe J. Haggerty Jr., 20-year-old Winged Foot player, yesterday scored the first upset in the New York State squash racquets championship tournament, which will enter the third round at the New York A. C. today.

HAVANA, Jan. 6 -- An alleged conspiracy to kill President Carlos Prio Socarras was denounced late last night to the judicial police by two former revolutionaries who took part in the ill-fated revolutionary expedition against President Rafael Trujillo of the Dominican Republic in 1947.

Supreme Court Justice Ferdinand Pecora reduced the bail of four alleged gamblers accused of trying to arrange the outcome of a college basketball game by a $1,000 bribe offer to a player, from $50,000 each to $20,000 each.
Life begins at 77, at least when air travel is concerned, for Mrs. Dora Keen Handy of West Hartford, Vt.

NORTHPORT, L. I., Jan. 6 -- The scene was the Veterans Administration hospital here. The players were a 23-year-old veteran, classified as a latent schizophrenic, and a Red Cross volunteer worker acting the role of his "mother" in a drama therapy class.

The development of charts of New York Harbor from crude sketches to modern maps will be shhown by a United States Coast and Geodetic Survey exhibit at the National Motor Boat Show opening today in the Grand Central Palace.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- Former Ambassador William C. Bullitt reported to Congress today that only "American direction and control" of the armies of Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek could prevent the conquest of South China and a Communist sweep through Asia to the Indian Ocean.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- Following the archaic procedure set down in the Constitution almost a century and a half ago, the Senate and the House of Representatives met in joint session today to check the electoral vote and officially declare a President and Vice President elected.

The Court of Special Sessions in Long Island City, Queens, set aside yesterday its Dec 27 verdict of guilty in the case of Robert Burke, 25 years old, of 39-44 Forty-sixth Street, Sunnyside, who had been charged with indecent exposure and impairing the morals of a minor.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- The first direct indication came today that Southern Democrats who were either lukewarm or hostile to President Truman's candidacy in the recent campaign would not be ignored on patronage.

ALBANY, Jan. 6 -- A measure that would empower the New York City Board of Water Supply to inspect all land within the watershed furnishing the city's vater supply was introduced in the Legislature today by Senator Elmer F. Quinn and Assemblyman Irwin Steingut, Democratic minority leaders.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- President Truman appealed today for early Congressional action to raise the pay of all high ranking executive officials of the Government.

Richard Tucker, the Metropolitan tenor, appeared as assisting artist with the Vinaver Chorus, under Chemjo Vinaver, at its second concert of the season, last night at Town Hall. He was heard as soloist in two choral works by Mr. Vinaver, the Sacred Suite from the Sabbath Eve Service, "The Seventh Day," and "The Twenty-fourth Psalm," and also participated in the performance of A. M. Bernstein's "Yimschu."

ALBANY, Jan. 6 -- In a report to the Legislature, the World Trade Corporation, headed by Winthrop W. Aldrich, recommended today that it be officially dissolved and that the unexpended part of its appropriation be returned to the state treasury.

ROME, Jan. 6 -- The Italian Government has informed Washington that it is ready to discuss Italy's participation in the Atlantic defense pact, authorized circles said today. Premier Alcide de Gasperi made this decision on Tuesday after he had consulted all Italian political leaders except the heads of the Communist and left-wing Socialist parties who, of course, are against the pact because they regard it as anti-Soviet.

Increased sales of alloy and stainless steel nuts and bolts is expected to continue on a long-term basis, M. J. Jacobs, partner, Atlas Screw and Specialty Company, 450 Broome Street, disclosed here yesterday. For the first time, he said, British competition is being felt in foreign markets and is curtailing sales of American products in some nations abroad.

CHICAGO, Jan. 6 -- The American Medical Association, in a forthcoming issue of its Journal, will challenge the assertion of President Truman in his State of the Union message delivered Wednesday that "tens of millions lack adequate medical care."
OAK RIDGE, Tenn., Jan. 6 (UP) -- Plans for a new $70,000,000 plant here for the production of uranium-235 were revealed today by David E. Lilienthal, chairman of the Atomic Energy Commission.

Russ Hodges, who spends most of his time at the microphone as a sports announcer, will become the proprietor of a weekly quiz over WOR-Mutual tomorrow at 5 P. M. The half-hour program will be entitled the "Russ Hodges Quiz Show," and its questions will be confined to sports and motion pictures.

SEOUL, Korea, Jan. 6 -- Eric H Biddle, acting chief Economic Cooperation Administration in Korea, today informed Koreans that President Truman officially turned over responsibility for rehabilitation aid for Korea to the ECA yesterday.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Jan. 6 (AP) -- Fighting Fan, flying the Kentucky-owned silks of W. J. Walden, scored a popular triumph in today's Tropical Park feature, named in honor of the National Cardiac Foundation.

Some fifty-odd years ago an American girl studying in Berlin met a Russian youth in one of Prof. Adolf Wagner's famous courses in economics. In 1898 the Russian came to this country and in January, 1899, the two were married. In 1904 the husband became a Professor of Economic History at Columbia, where he served with distinction until his retirement in 1942.

CHICAGO, Jan. 6 -- Federal District Judge Michael L. Igoe today enjoined Preston Tucker, president of the Tucker Corporation, and others connected with the company from disposing of any of its assets for the duration of the sixty-day postponement of court proceedings involving the automobile manufacturer.
LONDON, Jan. 6 -- Up to the day of agreeing with Egypt for a cease-fire in southern Palestine, the Israeli forces were still operating on Egyptian soil, the British Foreign Office stated tonight.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 (AP) -- Following is the text of President Truman's letter asking higher salaries for top-ranking government officials:

PARIS, Jan. 6 -- The problem of preserving the independence of Greece along the lines expressed by the majority of the people in the internationally supervised elections of 1946 is both grave and urgent.
Protestant laymen were urged yesterday to speak boldly in the name of Christ against race discrimination and terror and to stand by the outcast, the prisoner and the refugee.

Sir Oliver Franks, British Ambassador to the United States, called yesterday for more tourist travel between America and Great Britain as one of the forces leading toward greater stability in the world.

LAKE SUCCESS, Jan. 6 -- Egypt and Israel informed the United Nations today that they would cease fire on all fronts at 2 P. M. tomorrow, Greenwich mean time (9 A. M. Friday, New York time), and would enter at once into direct negotiations to establish an armistice throughout the Holy Land.

ALBANY, Jan. 6 -- The Court of Appeals affirmed unanimously today the bookmaking conviction of Emetia Polizio, alias Joe Pledge, whose charges that members of the Police Department and the Queens District Attorney's office sold protection to bookmakers touched off a grand jury investigation last year.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- The Senate Republican Conference approved today selection of Senator Irving M. Ives of New York, a recent rebel against the continued leadership of Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio, as one of the six appointed members of the party's Policy Committee in the upper chamber.

Robert Villemain of France will make his American ring debut tonight when he trades punches with Steve Belloise of the Bronx in the star bout of ten rounds at Madison Square Garden. Although little is known here of Villemain's ability, interest in foreign performers has grown tremendously since the victorious showings here of world middleweight champion Marcel Cerdan.

LONDON, Jan. 6 -- Two happenings in the Middle East today seemed to be bringing peace in Palestine a little nearer. One was the acceptance by Israel and Egypt of the cease-fire in the Negeb preparatory to entering armistice negotiations. The other was the return to power of General Nuri as-Said as Prime Minister of Iraq.

Dr. Philip C. Jessup, deputy United States representative to the United Nations Security Council, and Jacob A. Malik, the Soviet representative, arrived here yesterday, the former expressing himself as "very hopeful" about the future of the world organization and the latter dismissing questions about anything and everything with "no comment."

As a cold weather interlude and invariably a welcome one between the hauling-out rite of last fall and the fitting-out ritual of next spring, the annual midwinter excitement known as the National Motor Boat Show will start tonight in Grand Central Palace.
Most persons, we suspect, will find little in President Truman's eight-point program for price and production controls about which to become either enthusiastic or apoplectic.
GENEVA, Jan. 6 -- German products of high potential military value are being sold to Russia and other Eastern European countries through Switzerland.
CLEVELAND, Jan. 6 -- The Lake Carirers Association has reported that movement of iron ore, coal, limestone and grain on the Great Lakes last year set a new record high of 185,359,835 tons.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on Jan. 1, 1949, totaled 584,628 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 24,611 cars, or 4 per cent, fewer than in the preceding week; 97,491 cars, or 14.3 per cent fewer than in the corresponding week last year, and 102,800 cars, or 15 per cent, fewer than in the corresponding week two years ago.

A Federal search for a ring of munitions smugglers, believed to be shipping or attempting to ship war materials from this country to the Arabs, was made known yesterday, after the seizure in a warehouse near Newark Airport of five crated War Surplus airplanes.

LONDON, Jan. 6 -- Sir Basil Brooke, Prime Minister of Northern Ireland, arrived here today and with three members of his Cabinet held a meeting with Prime Minister Attlee and other British Ministers on the effects of Eire's severance from the British Commonwealth.

The New York Film Critics awards for 1948 will be presented to the winners in a ceremony to take place on the Radio City Music Hall stage on Friday night, Jan. 21, it was announced jointly yesterday by the critics and Gus S. Eyssell, managing director of the theatre.

The affirmative reaction of the stock market to the President's "State of the Union" address has lent reassurance to the banking syndicates that have been grooming certain issues of equity securities for offering during recent weeks. Most attention centers on the pending marketing of 400,000 new common shares of the Koppers Company, which is in the hands of a First Boston Corporation syndicate.

Soviet leaders are now engaged in a "power drive" in the world that dwarfs the earlier drive of Adolf Hitler and that is really "an attempt by the gang in the Politburo to take over the world," Paul G. Hoffman, Economic Cooperation Administrator, declared yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- The United States gave notice today that it would not "endorse or condone" the "police action" of the Netherlands for solving the problem of Indonesia. At the same time this Government expressed the hope that The Hague would "seize the present opportunity to make concrete demonstration of its intention to satisfy the legitimate aspirations of the Indonesians for self-rule."

INDIANAPOLIS, Jan. 6 (UP) -- Young Philip H. Willkie, filled with ideas to fire new strength in the Republican party, started out today in the political footsteps of his father, Wendell L. Willkie, as a new member of the Indiana Legislature.

Trade buying and short covering was evident in the hide futures market on Commodity Exchange yesterday. Prices advanced 45 to 60 points in increased volume. The heaviest volume was in the nearby March delivery which closed at the best level of the day.

ROME, Jan. 6 -- President Truman's state of the union speech dealt so prevalently with internal problems to the exclusion of international ones that it drew few comments from the Italian press. Almost all the newspapers, however, published ample summaries with considerable typographical emphasis.

MANHASSET, L. I., Jan. 6 -- The town of North Hempstead, after a delay of several months, is ready to sign contracts to start a $2,000,000 low-cost housing project that will wipe out slum areas of Manhasset and Port Washington.

The four-story garden type apartment house accommodating fifty-nine families at 41-26 Seventy-third Street, Jackson Heights, has been purchased by the Lyndave Realty Corporation from a syndicate headed by the Harris Block Company.
Six major milk companies serving the metropolitan area made a profit of only three-tenths of a cent a quart on the milk they sold in the year that ended on June 30, it was reported yesterday.

LAKE SUCCESS, Jan. 6 -- The brief hope that United Nations Secretary General Trygve Lie would take steps to try to stop the war in China faded today when Mr. Lie himself announced that he was dubious that such a course would be beneficial.

The celebration of Christmas by churches adhering to the Julian rather than the Gregorian calendar began last night with Christmas Eve devotions, including midnight masses at some churches. Ukrainian Greek Catholic churches that are in communion with the Roman Catholic Church but have not accepted the Gregorian calendar were among the churches celebrating.
BERLIN, Jan. 6 -- In this city inured to ordeals, the office at 54 Kantstrasse has taken its place as one of the most doleful of agencies.

BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 6 -- The Rev. Jose Maria Dunphy, who acknowledges that "four or five times in sermons or letters" he has spoken out against President Peron in accordance with his priestly duty as he saw it, has been relieved from his post at the Church of Corpus Domini by Santiago Luis Cardinal Copello and has asked an ecclesiastical trial.
The man in the leather jacket leaned over to address the doctor. His knuckles were white as he clenched his fists.

CHICAGO, Jan. 6 -- Gustav Metzman, president of the New York Central Railroad, proposed today that railroads be permitted to adjust their rates without prior Federal authorization, but subject to Federal review and modification of the adjustments, to give the carriers more "business flexibility."

Harold L. Cross, Professor of Newspaper Law in Columbia's School of Journalism, has been appointed associate dean of the school, Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, president of the university, announced yesterday. His appointment is effective immediately.

It was some Greek philosopher who said that music should inspire a gentlemanlike joy. Two symphonies and the Third Brandenburg Concerto of J. S. Bach, the symphonies admirably performed by Charles Munch and the Philharmonic-Symphony last night in Carnegie Hall, communicated this agreeable sensation.

NANKING, Jan. 6 -- For the third successive day the Communist radio heaped abuse upon Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek and declared that the peace conditions set down in his New Year statement were merely "a trick" to preserve the present "ruling economic groups." Tonight's broadcast was heavily sarcastic.

The Oliver Corporation, farm and industrial equipment manufacturer, had net earnings of $7,906,070 after all charges including $6,708,000 for taxes, in the fiscal year ended with last October, Alva W. Phelps, president, reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- Bills for bringing to this country outstanding international experts on cancer research to join in a "supreme effort" to find a cure for that disease were introduced today by Senator Matthew M. Neely of West Virginia and Representative Helen Gahagan Douglas of California.

Prices on many vegetables are higher today and supplies considerably shorter because of the recent cold in Florida and California. Local markets that depend heavily on these states during winter are receiving curtailed shipments of snap beans, cucumbers, peppers and peas.

Drawing his seventh-round game, Nicholas Rossolimo, champion of France, strengthened his hold on first place in the annual congress of the Hastings and St. Leonards Chess Club at the White Rock Pavilion, according to a report received from England yesterday.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 6 (AP) -- Dr. Karl E. Leib, president of the National Collegiate Athletic Association, declared today the so-called "sanity code" to clean up proselyting and other evils was making definite progress.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -Department store sales in the week ended Jan. 1 were unchanged from sales in the same week a year ago, the Federal Reserve Board reported tonight. The following lists percentage changes from like periods of a year ago:

A study of anthropology's relation to modern life by Clyde Kluckholm, winner of the $10,000 Whittlesey House - Science Illustrated Science Fellowship Award, will be brought out on Jan. 25 by Whittlesey House. Entitled "Mirror for Man," the study shows what anth pology has to offer toward clearing away prejudices that exist between peoples and nations.

Such is the discipline of the Jesuit Order that neither place nor distinction is permitted to outweigh the instant obedience with which each of its members accepts whatever duty is assigned to him. Whether the task be lowly or of commanding importance, he yields without murmur to the behest of his Superior General, knowing that in the care of souls the real criterion is not worldly honor but the long and searching critique of eternity.

DETROIT, Jan. 6 (AP) -- Coming from behind with two goals in two minutes of the second period Boston climbed into a tie with Detroit for the National Hockey League lead by beating the Red Wings, 3 to 2, tonight before 13,343 fans. It was Boston's first victory on the road in nine games.

Two of Finland's greatest ski jumpers, 21-year-old Matti Pietikainen and 30-year-old Leo Laakso, both Olympic aces, arrived here yesterday after a stormy trip aboard the Stockholm of the Swedish American Line.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., Jan. 6 -- This Southern resort center is winding up the busiest construction period in its history in preparation for the influx of a vast number of visitors during the winter season which opens unofficially on Jan. 15.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- Large-scale naval and amphibious assault maneuvers by the Navy, Army and Marine Corps and units of the Royal Canadian Army will get under way in the western Atlantic and Caribbean next month to "advance the combat readiness" of the Atlantic Command and Fleet, it was announced today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- The Far Eastern Commission rejected by an overwhelming vote today a proposal by Alexander S. Panyushkin, the Soviet Ambassador, for a condemnation of the Japanese law prohibiting strikes by employes of the Japanese Government and its enterprises.

PROVIDENCE, R. I., Jan. 6 -- Nine associated factory mutual insurance companies here -- five of them out-of-state concerns -- have organized a $2,000,000 company with headquarters in this city to underwrite fire risks which do not meet the high standards of the sponsoring companies, it was announced today.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 6 -- Proposals for Government financial assistance to Southern California's frost-stricken fruit and vegetable growers were made today after a three-day cold wave of virtually unprecedented intensity.

The American Telephone and Telegraph Company held the first public demonstration yesterday of a new electronic switching system designed eventually to reduce by 50 per cent waiting time on long-distance telephone calls.
MONTREAL, Jan. 6 (AP) -- The Montreal Canadiens jumped from a last-place tie to fourth in the National Hockey League tonight by trouncing Chicago, 7 -- 2, before a Forum crowd of 11,213.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- The American Legion said today that the strongest forces ever marshaled behind Universal Military Training had been organized and were ready to press an apparently reluctant Congress for action on President Truman's new call for enactment of this program.

The Prudential Insurance Company and Orville E. Beal, a vice president, filed papers in Federal Court yesterday asking dismissal of a $1,000,000 libel suit filed last November by two officials of the United Office and Professional Workers of America, CIO.

DETROIT, Jan. 6 (AP) -- Coming from behind with two goals in two minutes of the second period Boston climbed into a tie with Detroit for the National Hockey League lead by beating the Red Wings, 3 to 2, tonight before 13,343 fans. It was Boston's first victory on the road in nine games.

Two of Finland's greatest ski jumpers, 21-year-old Matti Pietikainen and 30-year-old Leo Laakso, both Olympic aces, arrived here yesterday after a stormy trip aboard the Stockholm of the Swedish American Line.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., Jan. 6 -- This Southern resort center is winding up the busiest construction period in its history in preparation for the influx of a vast number of visitors during the winter season which opens unofficially on Jan. 15.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- Large-scale naval and amphibious assault maneuvers by the Navy, Army and Marine Corps and units of the Royal Canadian Army will get under way in the western Atlantic and Caribbean next month to "advance the combat readiness" of the Atlantic Command and Fleet, it was announced today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- The Far Eastern Commission rejected by an overwhelming vote today a proposal by Alexander S. Panyushkin, the Soviet Ambassador, for a condemnation of the Japanese law prohibiting strikes by employes of the Japanese Government and its enterprises.

A one-man show by a regular exhibitor of water colors, a debut in oils and a group exhibition by young painters working in advanced abstract modes are among the attractions this week in local galleries.
PARIS, Jan. 6 -- A large crowd including French war veterans, Government officials and Americans went to the Montparnasse station today to bid Godspeed to the French "Thank You Train."
Dr. Mary Ann Payne, a research associate of New York Hospital, was chosen yesterday for one of the five fellowships of the New York Heart Association for work in cardio-vascular research.

Formation of an alliance with members of the Legislature from Buffalo, Rochester and other upstate cities in a movement to get greater state aid for municipalities was suggested last night by Adolf A. Berle Jr., state chairman of the Liberal party.

Support for voluntary standards to control the use of comparative-price claims in the advertising and selling of furs and fur garments is being sought from fur retailers by the Better Business Bureau of New York City, Inc., it was disclosed yesterday by Hugh R. Jackson, executive vice president of the bureau.

TAMPA, Fla., Jan. 6 (AP) -- Gardnar Mulloy began his campaign in the Dixie tennis tournament today with two straight-set victories. The international star beat Keg Toole of Tampa, 6 -- 0, 6 -- 1, then stopped Tom Molloy of New Orleans, 6 -- 3, 6 -- 2.

A forthcoming report on the need for new construction in the New York public school system was discussed here yesterday by Governor Dewey and James Marshall, a member of the Board of Education from Manhattan, at a forty-five minute private meeting in the Governor's suite at the Roosevelt Hotel.

Hyman Blumberg, executive vice president of the Amalgamated Clothing Workers, CIO, and Louis Hollander, co-manager of the union's New York joint board, were named yesterday to supervise the organization's drive to enroll department store workers in this city.

The Democratic party has made its first major bungle of the new session. It has reduced the Republican membership of the powerful Foreign Relations Committee to its lowest permissible minimum; five, and it has packed the committee with several additional Democrats.

CHICAGO, Jan. 6 -- Edward L. Ryerson, president of the Chicago Orchestral Association, refused today to comment on reports that efforts are being made to withdraw an offer to engage Wilhelm Furtwaengler as a guest conductor of the Chicago Symphony Orchestra for next season.

It's no small feat when a millinery designer creates a spring collection without the use of a single flower, but this Emme accomplished with fine effect in her presentation yesterday at 21 East Fifty-sixth Street. Instead of the usual blossoms, colorful raffia embroidery was employed, preserving the simple, uncluttered lines that made these hats so pleasing.

Mayor O'Dwyer urged yesterday broader executive powers for Fire Commissioner Frank J. Quayle to improve the morale of the Fire Department personnel and to protect the city against graft and corruption.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- Labor chieftains feared today that the procedure for handling the controversial labor relations issue in Congress decided upon by chairmen of the two labor committees would mean a "run-around" instead of the quick repeal of the Taft-Hartley Act and re-passage of the Wagner Act that they desire.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- Camille Gutt, managing director of the International Monetary Fund, said today, "We are nearing the time when a new par value will be set for the Mexican peso."

Whether the cutting of a motion picture after it has been opened to the public officially is detrimental and misleading, or whether the result provides better entertainment for the public, was the the main point of contention yesterday in an action by the Government against United Artists Corporation, film distributors.

The abuse of interne training time on ambulance duty has long been a source of resentment by the young doctors involved. Everyone agrees to the desirability of having immediate skilled medical care in case of emergency. The problem is how to prevent the abuse of the ambulance doctors' time.

Pressure for increased corporate taxes has caused business groups seeking repeal of the 20 per cent Federal retail excise tax to revamp their strategy, it was learned yesterday. Greater emphasis will now be given arguments contending that revenue from higher taxable earnings of affected companies will more than offset that lost through lifting the sales levy.

GARDEN CITY, L. I., Jan. 6 -- The Rev. Jonathan Goodhue Sherman, who was rector of St. Thomas' Protestant Episcopal Church, Bellerose, when he was elected suffragan bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of Long Island last October, was consecrated to that office this morning at the Cathedral of the Incarnation, here.

Johnny Rauch, Georgia's brilliant passing quarterback, has signed a three-year contract with the Boston Yanks, who will play in New York under a new name next fall, it was announced yesterday by Ted Collins, owner of the National Football League club. Terms were not divulged.
LOS ANGELES, Jan. 7 (AP) -- E. J. (Dutch) Harrison led the way through the first round of the annual $15,000 Los Angeles open today as the nation's leading golfers launched the 1949 season.
Robert Villemain was beaten last night in Madison Square Garden, but he was far from disgraced.

Frank S. Stuart's study of a year in the life of a colony of bees will be issued on Feb. 24 by Whittlesey House. It has been titled "City of the Bees." Mr. Stuart, author of two novels and five nonfiction books, worked for seven years as a beekeeper.

A fresh note yesterday amidst all the gloomy announcements of Broadway closings for this weekend was the decision by "Oh, Mr. Meadowbrook!' to keep going instead of shutting down after tonight's performance. Fresh money has been raised, and the engagement will be continued at the John Golden Theatre indefinitely.

Voluntary rent increases provided in leases on controlled hotel accommodations automatically are ended when those leases expire, Nathan W. Math, counsel to the City Rent Commission, told the commission at an open hearing yesterday at 500 Park Avenue.

Three war veterans, one a former New York City rookie patrolman, who joined the Christian Brothers and completed their religious studies last Thursday at St. Joseph's Normal Institute, Barrytown, N. Y., were honor guests at a reception given yesterday by Brother Bonaventure Thomas, president of Manhattan College.
VINELAND, N. J., Jan. 7 -- After a year's uncertainty, State Senator Elmer H. Wene, Democrat, announced at his office here today that he would be a candidate for Governor of New Jersey this year.

The city's expense budget for the fiscal year beginning July 1 cannot be "much more" than the current record budget of $1,160,538,857 and should be "within" that total, Budget Director Thomas J. Patterson declared yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- The bill of Senator Elbert D. Thomas to repeal the Taft-Hartley Act would abolish the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Services, leaving the Labor Department without conciliation power, according to legal authorities who have examined the measure.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 7 (AP) -- The Freedom Train returns tomorrow to the place of its beginning in the final chapter of a sixteen-month criss-crossing pilgrimage through 35,000 miles of the United States.

Counsel for the twelve Communist leaders charged with conspiracy to "teach and advocate" the forcible overthrow of the United States Government announced yesterday a petition to the United States Supreme Court to void the indictments.

Sunday is a day of rest for everyone except the feminine head of the household who more often than not needs a day of rest when it's ended. Sunday dinner, an occasion for the clan to collect, is often the most festive meal of the week, which, of course, means more work in the kitchen.

THE HAGUE, The Netherlands, Jan. 7 -- The Dutch were taken aback by the first reports of Secretary Marshall's resignation, but once the initial surprise had worn off the prevalent opinion in well-informed quarters was that little real change could be expected.

DETROIT, Jan. 7 -- The Detroit and Wayne County Federation of Labor, AFL, seeking the expulsion of Homer Ferguson, Republican, of Michigan, from the United States Senate, has petitioned the Treasury and Justice Departments and the Senate Committee on Elections and Privileges to investigate four charges allegedly disqualifying the legislator, it was disclosed today.

Predictions that the world may face a food shortage as a result of mismanaged agricultural lands and natural resources were parried by a 70-year-old Chicago chemist at the Commodore Hotel last night who pointed out that technological advances are providing ever-increasing improvements in the quantity and type of food available to mankind.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 (AP) -- Following is the text of President Truman's economic report to Congress today:

For almost a year Soviet propaganda has abstained from using the columns of our newspapers for its nefarious outpourings. Recently we have been treated to an outburst from the poet and lecturer Semyon Kirsanov, whose letter of a column and a half was published in your issue of Dec. 18, and Prof. L. A. Leontyev, whose two and a half columns appeared in THE TIMES of Dec. 20.

Jail terms ranging from one to three years were imposed yesterday by General Sessions Judge John A. Mullen on three former employes of the General Electric Credit Corporation, 570 Lexington Avenue. They had pleaded guilty to grant larceny charges in connection with a swindle of $182,000 from the credit concern.

The Lafayette National Bank Brooklyn in New York reported as of Dec. 31, 1948, total deposits of $38,314,996 and total assets of $40,809,026, compared, respectively, with $37,174,333 and $39,717,795 on Sept. 30, 1948. Cash on hand and due from banks amounted to $12,247,051 against $10,649,013; holdings of United States Government securities to $15,488,933 against $15,323,258 and loans and discounts to $11,155,433 against $11,776,043.

With one more round to go, Nicholas Rossolimo, the French champion, and I. Koenig of Yugoslavia, held first and second places, a full point apart today, in the international masters tournament sponsored by the Hastings and St. Leonards Chess Club, according to a report from England.

TEL AVIV, Jan. 7 -- Despite the United Nations announcement that the cease-fire became effective in the Negeb at 2 P. M., local time, fighting continued at the border town of Rafah and the Israelis stated that they had shot down five Egyptian planes during the day.

ARCADIA, Calif., Jan. 7 (AP) -War Trophy established a new track record for one mile today at Santa Anita Park, spinning around the oval in 1:35 2/5 under 116 pounds to capture the $10,000 San Bernardino Handicap.

UPTON, L. I., Jan. 7 -- Atomic research is a cold business, but those engaged in it have warm hearts judging by the work that will be started tomorrow by employes of the Brookhaven National Laboratory here to build a house for one of their co-workers.

OTTAWA, Jan. 7 -- The appointment of Dean Acheson to succeed Secretary of State Marshall has given great satisfaction here, for Mr. Acheson is considered one of the best informed men on Canadian affairs ever to have been in the State Department.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 (AP) -- Following are texts of an exchange of letters between President Truman and resigning Secretary of State Marshall and Under Secretary of State Lovett:

A late wave of selling failed yesterday to stem the upward movement of the stock market, which reached the best levels since early last November. The recovery embraced even a wider range of issues than in the two previous sessions and gains of 1 to about 3 points were shaded only slightly at the close.

VIENNA, Jan. 7 -- The Catholic Church, according to trustworthy advices from Prague, is facing the same situation in Czechoslovakia as in Hungary. The Communist assault upon it there, however, is taking a different form.

CHICAGO, Jan. 7 -- Illinois today got its first Director of Labor from the ranks of the Congress of Industrial Organizations. Gov.-elect Adlai Stevenson finally made his expected appointment of Frank Annunzio, secretary-treasurer of the CIO Political Action Committee.

ALBANY, Jan. 7 -- The political overtones in the taxing relationship between the state and local governments was pointed up today with the announcement by two Monroe County Democratic legislators that they would sponsor legislation for repeal of the permissive tax law.

Sixty-one contributions totalling $1,099 were received yesterday by The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund. Thus far there have been 10,999 donations to the thirty-seventh annual appeal aggregating $337,874.62.

Virtually all European refugees admitted to the United States under special immigration programs since the end of the war are self-sufficient today and independent of outside aid, the survey for THE NEW YORK TIMES on displaced persons has disclosed.

Demands of the armed services for brass and aluminum castings are increasing rapidly and may bring about an unbalanced condition in the industry during 1949, James W. Wolfe, executive secretary, the Non-Ferrous Founders Society, disclosed in a year-end review and forecast statement.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Jan. 7 (AP) -- Favorite followers in a crowd of 8,482 maneuvered unsuccessfully for five races at Tropical Park today before putting over a winner in the featured Maneuvre Purse. Tight Squeeze, taking that dash at 3 to 5, was the only winning choice.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- Fifteen Department of Justice officials conferred here today on continuing and expanding investigations of espionage and other subversive activities. They came from New York City, the District of Columbia, Pennsylvania, California and Colorado.

HONOLULU, Jan. 7 -- The 13,680-foot volcano of Mauna Loa on the island of Hawaii was still spewing streams of molten lava today after its violent eruption yesterday. One stream of lava was approaching the road along the richly tropical Kona coast on the southwest side of the largest island in the Hawaiian chain.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 (AP) -- The Air Force said today that it would send a B-36, its largest type bomber, to Alaska next week for several months of cold weather tests.
