MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 7 (AP) -- A jet-propelled "Shooting Star" F-80, fighter plane crashed and exploded only eight seconds away from a crowd of 5,000 persons at the All-American air maneuvers here today.

CHICAGO, Jan. 7 (AP) -- The New Orleans, Pittsburgh and Boston Stock Exchanges will be represented at the next meeting of exchange men studying a possible merger of several regional exchanges, it was announced today by James E. Day, president of the Chicago Stock Exchange.

NORFOLK, Mass., Jan. 7 (AP) -John F. Noxon, 52, prominent lawyer of Pittsfield, today won a four-and-a-half-year fight for freedom after his conviction of murdering his mentally deficient infant son -and immediately began hunting a job.

CHICAGO, Jan, 7 -- Grain markets broke sharply on the Board of Trade today under liquidation and closing trades were about at the bottom. Wheat finished 1 7/8 to 2 1/2 cents a bushel lower than yesterday; corn was down 3/4 to 1 3/8 cents, oats were off 1/8 to 3/4 cent, rye lost 2 1/2 cents and soy beans, 4 1/2 to 5 3/8 cents.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- The appointment of Dean Acheson as Secretary of State ends one fight in Washington and, as usual, opens another. It terminates a natural struggle within the Administration itself over who should replace Secretary Marshall and starts the customary confirmation wrangle over the new appointee's opinions on Russia.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- Dean Gooderham Acheson, newly appointed Secretary of State, has had a notable career as a lawyer and long experience in Government service.

After showing promise of settlement throughout more than eighteen hours of almost continuous meeting, negotiations between tugboat workers and operators bogged down in the early hours of this morning.

A crew dispute on the Government-owned emergency liner Marine Carp may tie up the vessel in this port, members of the crew said yesterday, after the ship docked with 457 passengers from Mediterranean ports. The vessel arrived at the American Export Line pier at West Forty-fourth Street with crewmen demanding the removal of the chief mate, George R. Miller.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 7 -- Gary Cooper has paid $40,000 for screen rights to "The Girl on the Via Flamina," a novel by Alfred Hayes which Harpers will publish in February, the actor disclosed today through a press representative. The story involves a romance between an American soldier and an impoverished Italian girl during the occupation of Italy in the latter phase of the war.

The psychoanalytic documentary films put out by the Canadian Government's National Film Board, and believed to be the first movies of their kind to be shown to the public, are in great demand in this country, it was learned yesterday.
MIDDLEBURG, Pa., Jan. 7 (AP) -- District Attorney Horace W. Vought reported today that Ray G. F. Leach, 22-year-old Treasurer of Snyder County, had been missing for four days.

Restriction of Wall and Pine Streets and adjacent thorough-fares in the financial district to one-way operation and extension of enforcement of the no-parking rules to two more north - south routes and eight mid-Manhattan cross-town arteries was announced yesterday by Police Commissioner Arthur W. Wallander.

BOSTON, Jan. 7 -- Judge George C. Sweeney of the Federal District Court approved today issuance of $350,000 in trustees' certificates to enable the financially embarrassed Waltham Watch Company to meet last week's final payroll for 2,300 workers. He declined, temporarily, to approve $1,000,000 worth sought by three court-appointed trustees.

PARIS, Jan. 7 -- Although the capital cities of Europe and most continental newspaper readers had been expecting it, the announcement of Secretary of State George C. Marshall's resignation undoubtedly will come as a great shock to the man in the street who had come to associate the General's name with a synonym for transatlantic aid and support.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 7 (AP) -- Television and the effect it may have on college sports, notably football, was the subject of lengthy discussion by representatives of the leading institutions of the country today.

Medley, campus humor magazine published by students of the University Heights section of New York University, was suspended 'until further notice" yesterday because of material in the Christmas issue considered to be in bad taste.

YONKERS, N. Y., Jan. 7 -- A newly married ex-GI who at last had found a house worth buying moved in with his bride this week to find that he had acquired a labor dispute as well as shelter, he told Judge Alfred L. Fiorillo in City Court today.

Distributors of building hardware are now experiencing an unprecedented prosperity with no indication of a recession in business during 1949, John R. Schomer, managing director, the National Contract Hardware Association, declared here yesterday.

Seven amendments to liberalize the Displaced Persons Act of 1948 were proposed yesterday by a subcommittee of the national legislative committee of the Liberal party at a conference with Representative Emanuel Celler, chairman of the Judiciary Committee of the House of Representatives, at Mr. Celler's local office at 1450 Broadway. The Liberal party committee was headed by Ben Davidson, state executive director.

MOSCOW, Jan. 7 (UP) -- A Tass dispatch from New York, widely printed in the Soviet press today, said President Truman's State of the Union message "frankly admitted" the United States would continue its policy of world conquest and destruction of independence in other countries.

Bernard M. Baruch, elder statesman, urged support of the program being conducted in behalf of veterans with impaired hearing at a brief ceremony yesterday in the audiology clinic in the New York Regional Office of the Veterans Administration, 252 Seventh Avenue.
Directors of the Hoving Corporation decided yesterday to take no action on a common dividend. Explaining the board's action, Walter Hoving, president, said:
Aiming at wide-scale construction of new homes in the $6,500-$7,000 bracket, Governor Dewey announced yesterday that sixty leaders in building trades unions would support his program.

The presence of Olympic Champions Harrison Dillard and Mal Whitfield, along with a sizable contingent of other topflight performers, lends distinction to the seventeenth annual Columbus Council, Knights of Columbus, track and field games at the Twenty-third Regiment Armory in Brooklyn tonight.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- Inaugural week now includes a Truman-Barkley dinner, an electoral dinner, a "Gala" -- described as a big-name variety show -- a two-and-a-half-hour parade including thirty bands and forty floats, an official invitation-only afternoon reception, and a grand ball.
Much has been written about delinquent children, and what should be done about them. It seems to me that any concerted attack on the problem should include two elements:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 (UP) -Agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation today arrested John Benjamin Walling of Washington on charges that he was the "contact man" who arranged a sale of stolen Government guns to the Costa Rican Government.

Whatever temporary gains may have been achieved by the strike of the employes of the Hudson-Manhattan transportation system on New Year's Eve, let no one be deceived as to the permanent and irreparable harm done to the cause of labor.

Horace Heidt and his prize protege, Dick Contino, 19-year-old accordionist, are involved in a legal dispute, it was disclosed yesterday. According to The Associated Press, Mr. Heidt has instituted suit in Superior Court in Los Angeles to prevent Contino from appearing with any other orchestras.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 (UP) -- The Government agreed today to finance a $7,590,000-dollar power line project to bring low-cost electricity to farmers in most of South Carolina.

Two Japanese churches here will merge under the name of Japanese American Church of Christ (Reformed) at a special service at 2:30 P. M., tomorrow, at the Japanese Christian Institute, 330 East Fifty-seventh Street, one of the merging groups.

BUCK HILL FALLS, Pa., Jan. 7 -The Foreign Missions Conference of North America today lauded the United States Government for refusing to "buttress" colonialism in Indonesia and called on the Administration to hold in abeyance any further Marshall Plan aid to the Netherlands Government until it complies fully with all demands made by the Security Council of the United Nations.

Industrial employment is expected to remain steady during the next six months of the year, according to a survey of forty manufacturing companies in the Stamford, Conn., area, covering approximately 16,000 employes. This forecast marks a change from a downward trend reported in an earlier study made in December. Because of the diversified industries in Stamford, these reports have been considered as having some barometric significance, industrially.

Those who have any doubts concerning the strong current trend toward light tackle for salt-water fishing can eliminate them by looking at the results of the last month's contest conducted by the Miami Beach Rod and Reel Club.

An intensive investigation was begun yesterday in an attempt to recover twenty-five pieces of jewelry, valued at $160,000, stolen Thursday night from the fourth floor apartment of Mr. and Mrs. Erhart Ruegg at 25 East End Avenue. Mr. Ruegg is a textile manufacturer.
The Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company promised Commissioner of Investigation John M. Murtagh yesterday an early answer to his request that it reduce the price of homogenized milk 1 cent.

The eighteen-story Park-Murray Building at 9-15 Park Place and 8-12 Murray Street has been sold by the 11 Park Place Company to a client of the Durand Taylor Company. E. T. Van DeWater Co. were co-brokers in the transaction. Title was insured by the Title Guarantee and Trust Company. Kalman Ress was attorney for the buyer.

Nursery pin-up lamps that may be tilted to throw light upward or downward, and a large serving tray with a heating unit built into its glass surface are among new products introduced yesterday by the Appleman Art Glass Company at a showing in the Shelton Hotel.

The annual report of Warner Bros. Pictures, Inc., issued yesterday by Harry M. Warner, president, disclosed a consolidated net profit of $11,837,253 after all charges, including $8,300,000 provision for taxes, for the fiscal year ended on Aug. 31.

When the noise of the children starts dying down in the Department of Parks playgrounds with the coming of winter, the attendants may understandably sigh in relief. But for other members of the department, their work is beginning in earnest.

A New York County grand jury investigating a charge that four alleged gamblers sought to "fix" a basketball game in Madison Square Garden heard testimony from six detectives and investigators who had been assigned to the case since last September.

WHIPPANY, N. J., Jan. 7 -- A four-and-a-half-day-old strike of 400 employes at the two paper mills of the Desiderio Brothers here ended this afternoon through the intercession of Allan Weisenfeld, secretary of the New Jersey State Board of Mediation, in Newark.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- President Truman flatly and angrily denied today that he was contemplating any change in American foreign policy.
CHICAGO, Jan. 7 (UP) -- A new storm headed for Montana and Wyoming today on the heels of the great Western blizzard that left eighteen persons known dead and killed countless numbers of livestock.

New state and municipal financing during December, 1948, totaled $125,416,119, compared with $101,194,501 for December, 1947, according to The Daily Bond Buyer. The revised total for November of last year is $213,808,213. Total financing for 1948 was $2,983,427,653, compared with $2,353,771,562 in 1947.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 (AP) -- President Truman said today that his recommendations for the expansion of steel production contemplated progressive steps rather than immediate Government construction of plants.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- One million new jobs for the youth of the country, higher production and more and balanced purchasing power were the main goals set by President Truman today to insure prosperity in 1949.

United States customs agents expressed confidence yesterday that they would soon find the owner of the five crated airplanes seized Thursday by Federal authorities in a warehouse near the Newark airport which they believe were intended for use by Egyptian or Arab forces.
Christmas was celebrated yesterday in this city by several churches adhering to the Julian, rather than the Gregorian, calendar.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- The tiny "supersonic" X-1, the swiftest rocket-powered plane yet revealed by the Air Force, has taken off under its own power and climbed to 23,000 feet at the record rate of 13,000 feet a minute. The Air Force told today of the flight made Wednesday at the base at Muroc, Calif.

MIAMI BEACH, Jan. 7 -- Building mechanics are reaping a harvest of overtime in this resort area as the result of the limited supply of skilled union workers and unique construction regulations in Miami Beach prohibiting certain noisy operations during the winter tourist season. Nowhere else in the country are the men in these trades getting so much money.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- President Truman's Council of Economic Advisers told him today that to fulfill 1949 goals for maximum employment, production and purchasing power it would be necessary to make certain "wise economic adjustments" in seven areas of the national economy.
LONDON, Jan. 7 -- Negotiations for a long-term Anglo-Soviet trade agreement appeared to have collapsed here tonight although British official circles would not concede the fact.

ALBANY, Jan. 7 -- The State Banking Department announced today that it had approved a verified certificate to continue business of Brown Brothers Harriman Co., 59 Wall Street, New York. Authorization to transact business as private bankers was issued.

Overruling the report of a referee who recommended a divorce in an uncontested action, Supreme Court Justice Henry Clay Greenberg assailed yesterday the existing divorce procedures as being "rooted in hypocrisy, connivance and deception" and declared that he would seek to end "this monstrous sham."

FRANKFORT, Germany, Jan. 7 -- American Military Government legal experts, in response to cautious economics division officials, have rendered an opinion that longbows, crossbows and arrows "are not arms or war materials" and thus may be authorized by the zonal commander without fear of violating control council law No. 43, which forbids transport and export of war materials.

Combined group buying power of the four stores comprising the Gimbel Brothers organization will be brought to bear Monday in an all-out drive to obtain lower wholesale prices from housewares manufacturers at the opening of the Chicago Housewares Show. This was made known yesterday by Ralph M. Chipurnoi, merchandise manager of the New York store.

Jacques Abram had arranged an unusually interesting program for his piano recital last night at Carnegie Hall. The offerings comprised the Partita in C minor by Bach; Schubert's Sonata in A minor, Op. 42; the Sonata by Bartok and Chopin's Sonata in B minor.

LAKE SUCCESS, Jan. 7 -- Reaction to the appointment of Dean Acheson to succeed George C. Marshall as Secretary of State on the part of United Nations diplomats could be summed up in one word: "Surprise."

LONDON, Jan. 7 -- The appointment of United States Ambassador Lewis W. Douglas to be an "observer" on the important Western Union Military Supply Board here has been approved by the United States Government, it is reliably learned.

Four seeded players came through theic third-round matches in the New York State squash racquets singles championship tourney at the New York A. C. yesterday, but only the No. i man, Cal D. MacCracken of the Princeton Club, was able to dispose of his opponent in straight games.

In your issue of Dec. 27 there appears a letter from Joseph E. Kallenbach of Ann Arbor, Mich. Neither Mr. Kallenbach's letter nor the editorial note thereon made mention of the central fact in the choice of Presidential electors in Alabama.

COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Jan. 7 -- Before the end of this month the Scandinavian states will meet in a joint Cabinet and Parliamentary meeting in Copenhagen to decide their political attitude between West and East.

The City Marshal's Office postponed yesterday for a week the eviction of the Lutheran True Light Church, largest Protestant organization serving Chinatown, from its top-floor quarters in a loft building at Canal and Mulberry Streets.

The left-wing United Office and Professional Workers of America has barred officers of its right-wing local representing office employes of the National Congress of Industrial Organizations from attending a national conference to be held by the union today and tomorrow at Manhattan Center.
Five champion fowl were chosen yesterday from among nearly 7,000 birds entered in the eighteenth annual New York Poultry Show, Inc., at the Ninth Regiment Armory, 125 West Fourteenth Street.
LONDON, Jan. 7 (Reuters) -- Lord Beaverbrook, British press lord and stormy petrel of Conservative politics, has dropped out of the Conservative party.

LONDON, Jan. 7 -- Uneasiness in Manchester over the extent to which Japanese textile industry and exports are being revived was evidenced today at the annual meeting of the Dominions Section of the Manchester Chamber of Commerce.

Two Florida National Guard fliers piloting jet propelled F-80-C fighter planes flew from Chicago Municipal Airport to La Guardia Airport in 1 hour 21 minutes 8 seconds yesterday, setting what may be declared an official record for the 711-mile course.

OLD FORGE, N. Y., Jan. 7 -- The sight of four inches of new heavy powder snow on ten inches of Settled base in this picturesque central Adirondack area is eye-opening to this snow-famished skier, like thousands of others in the East, but it remains our assignment to report another grim outlook for skiing prospects this week-end.

A distraught father who, according to police, was for several months a patient in a mental institution, walked across the Kosciusko Bridge, joining Brooklyn and Queens, yesterday. With him were his son, Arthur, 6 years old, and daughter, Gail, 5.

Hide futures declined sharply in the final hour of trading on the Commodity Exchnage yesterday. Closing prices were down 60 to 70 points from the noon high and were 10 to 45 points net lower on the day. Spot prices in the Western centers continued firm.
The Legal Aid Society, which for seventy-three years has been providing counsel to persons unable to pay for legal service, extended its activities into the Federal Courts yesterday.

ATLANTA, Ga., Jan. 7 -- The armed services must awaken to the national dependence on scientific progress and should use the services of scientific personnel called up in the draft, for the advancement of science, the Southern Association of Science and Industry was told today.

Retail trade declined here this week, mainly because of wet weather in comparison with dry weather during the corresponding week last year, according to merchants. Department store sales were estimated as about 4 per cent below last year. Sales last week were up 6 per cent.

DURHAM, England, Jan. 7 -- Prophecies are dangerous, but sometimes they are a useful and informative indulgence. The prophecy for 1949 is that Britain almost certainly will not meet her coal production target. She will probably come 4,500,000 to 5,000,000 precious tons short.
BALTIMORE, Jan. 7 -- A little bit of Ireland -- 436 feet long -sailed into Baltimore harbor today to forge the city's newest link with the Emerald Isle.

Three buildings belonging to the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York, which were rented temporarily in 1947 on behalf of the New York Protestant Episcopal City Mission Society on payment of an annual "token rent" of $1, had been used last year to care for 800 homeless and unattached women and children, it was learned yesterday.

PARIS, Jan. 7 -- Official tributes to Secretary Marshall and polite words in official circles for his successor did not conceal today French anxiety at the disappearance from the political scene of a man who has so thoroughly identified himself with the European Recovery Program.

CHICAGO, Jan. 7 -- The Chicago trade promotion office of the Port of New York Authority, a very successful postwar ramification of the authority's activities, has proved so valuable both to the port and to its present and potential users that the Port Authority last fall opened similar offices in Washington and Cleveland.

GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., Jan. 7 -- The first Waters award for achievement in design was presented here tonight to Herbert Ten Have of this city at the furniture market's Press Day dinner. It was given in recognition of Mr. Ten Have's ingenuity in designing the "butler-buffet" of the Sligh originals group manufactured by the Grand Rapids Chair Company.

The Century Federal Savings and Loan Association sold the five-story thirty-eight-family apartment house at 754 Coster Street, corner of Hunts Point Avenue, the Bronx to Ettore DeTorres. The seller took back a first mortgage of $72,000 at a 4 1/2 per cent for twenty-five years. The property, assessed at $95,000, occupies an irregular plot about 158 by 78 feet. Adolph Bretz was the broker.
WATERBURY, Conn., Jan. 7 (AP) -- Police today arrested four men and a woman and seized $1,000 in counterfeit $10 bills of the issue which recently flooded New York City.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- Average primary market prices declined 0.6 per cent during the week ended on Jan. 4, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. The index is now 161.3 per cent of the 1926 average; this is 0.7 per cent lower than four weeks ago and 2.5 per cent below the comparable week in 1948.

LAKE SUCCESS, Jan. 7 -- Egypt and Israel were called upon today by Dr. Ralph J. Bunche, acting United Nations Mediator in Palestine, to meet next Tuesday or Wednesday, probably on the Greek island of Rhodes, to open armistice negotiations.

CHICAGO, Jan. 7 (AP) -- Armour Co., the nation's second largest meat-packing and food-processing concern, reported today it had a net loss of $1,965,291 in the fiscal year ended Oct. 30, 1948. This was in contrast with net earnings of $30,907,658 in the previous fiscal year, which was equal, after an appropriation of $8,000,000 for inventory price decline, to $4.91 a common share.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 7 -- Two scientists of the University of Southern California reported today that they had observed and photographed genes, the mysterious infinitesimal particles that transmit physical characteristics of living things from one generation to another.
LONDON, Jan. 7 -- Israel has rejected a bid from Britain for closer relations between the two countries. Tel Aviv's price was British recognition of the Provisional Government of Israel.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- Former Ambassador William C. Bullitt told an executive session of the Congressional "Watchdog" Committee yesterday that United States policy on China represented a triumph of Soviet psychological warfare in this country and had furthered the ends of world communism.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- The Civil Aeronautics Board today postponed from Jan. 24 to Feb. 14 the start of its hearings on proposals to transfer routes of National Airlines, Inc., to other carriers.
Spring designs by New York and Paris milliners vied for favor at a luncheon meeting of the millinery division of the Fashion Group yesterday at the Biltmore Hotel.

Ksenia Prochorowa pianist, and Stanley Weiner, violinist, were the performers on last night's Debut and Encore Concert at Town Hall. Miss Prochorowa paid homage to Chopin (on the 100th anniversary of his death) and to Sibelius in his eighty-third year, and Mr. Weiner gave the first performance of Georges Enesco's "Impressions d'enfance."
LAKE SUCCESS, Jan. 7 (AP) -- The Netherlands said today that nine arrested leaders of the Indonesian Republic had been released.

William R. Bayes, who was defeated for District Attorney of Kings County by Mayor O'Dwyer in 1939, was appointed yesterday by Fire Commissioner Frank J. Quayle as third deputy commissioner to preside at the departmental trial of Chief Peter Loftus and eleven other firemen who were present at the party in a downtown Manhattan firehouse on Dec. 16.

After a preview yesterday afternoon, the Whitney Museum is opening to the public today an exhibition of the paintings and drawings of Thomas Cole (1801-1848). Shown from Nov. 13 to Jan. 2 at the Wadsworth Atheneum, Hartford, Conn., on the centenary of the artist's death, the exhibition will be on view at the Whitney until the end of January.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 (AP) -- Midwest grain interests are asking the Interstate Commerce Commission to delay freight rate increases on grain and grain products, pending further study. The increases are scheduled to become effective next Tuesday.

Jerry Giesler, California lawyer, will act as co-counsel with Robert Daru, New York attorney, in an investigation of unlawful search and seizure practices here, it was announced yesterday by the New York County Criminal Courts Bar Association.

CLEVELAND, Jan. 7 (UP) -- James E. Lee of the Amateur Athletic Union's national executive committee today demanded abolition of the Sullivan Trophy because it was won for 1948 by 18-year-old Bob Mathias, Olympic decathlon champion, and not by Harrison Dillard, Negro sprinter and hurdler from Baldwin-Wallace College.

LAKE SUCCESS, Jan. 7 -- In a report on Trieste, which marks the end of the first year of Allied Military Government under the Italian peace treaty, Maj. Gen. T. S. Airey, Allied commander, emphasized that there had been a continuance of the "growth of confidence in the future" that he detected and reported in memoranda earlier this year.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 (AP) -- Plans for a steel industry development in East Texas were outlined to President Truman today by a group of Texans.
M. J. L. Schulte has been appointed general sales manager of Stow Manufacturing Company, flexible shafts and equipment. He formerly was with the Keystone Bolt and Nut Corporation.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Jan. 7 -- The whole balance of power in the Arab League countries has been altered by Gen. Nuri as-Said's formation of a new Cabinet in Iraq yesterday, it is believed here. It is expected to be followed reasonably soon by the union of Trans-Jordan and Arab Palestine.

For four tantalizingly short hours last night, nearly 20,000 men, women and youngsters, some of whom had queued around Lexington and Park Avenue sidewalks waiting for the doors to open, inspected the dazzling nautical glitter that makes up a National Motor Boat Show and decided the 1949 version was a huge and wondrous display.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- The Democratic chiefs of the House have agreed not to reduce the ratio of minority Republican membership on the Foreign Affairs Committee.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Jan. 7 -- Col. Yigal Yadin, 33-year-old chief of operations for the Israeli Army, lifted the blackout curtain today on operations in the Negeb and in Egypt and reported that the desert area was completely free of Egyptians except for a narrow coastal strip that has been virtually halved.

Now that Christmas has come and gone and to the New Year has begun to fly about with its new wings, it is time to see about those virtuous resolutions we made on New Year's Eve. They were born with a high determination to do better, but if they should fail -- and we have a feeling that some of them will -- there must be mitigating circumstances, as they say in the courts.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- Lieut. Gen. John E. Hull, who commanded the atomic bomb tests at Eniwetok last year, was named director today of the National Military Establishment's agency for choosing the weapons and weapons systems believed best for the national security.

Fire Commissioner Frank J. Quayle admitted yesterday that he was responsible last month for the transfer of a fire captain and a lieutenant in a downtown Manhattan station because of the theft of a $825 Christmas fund from one of the firemen.

A modishly-dressed woman, who refused to divulge her name and address when arraigned in Felony Court yesterday on a forgery charge, was held in $10,000 bail for grand jury action after she was accused of stealing $5,000 in merchandise from local department stores.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- President Truman announced today the resignation of George C. Marshall as Secretary of State and the appointment of Dean Acheson, former Under-Secretary of State and Washington lawyer, as his successor.

LAKE SUCCESS, Jan. 7 -- Meeting for the first time here since its Paris sessions the United Nations Security Council heard a gloomy report today from its Good Offices Committee in Indonesia. In discussing the new fighting between the Dutch and Indonesians the committee made the suggestion that it be dissolved in view of its inability to do anything about the latest outbreaks.

CHICAGO, Jan. 7 -- Furniture buyers attending the winter home furnishings market are no longer worried over securing the items they believe they can sell in the quantities they require, a spokesman for the American Furniture Mart said today following a check of exhibitors at the conclusion of the first week of the two-week show.
PINEHURST, N. C., Jan. 7 (AP) -- General George C. Marshall, who resigned today as Secretary of State, said at his home here that he had no plans for the immediate future.

NANKING, Jan. 7 -- Attacking Communist troops broke into the southwest corner of Tientsin, leading North China industrial center, today and heavy fighting is taking place around the campus of Nankai University. This information was obtained through a telephone conversation with a foreign diplomat in that beleaguered city.
CAIRO, Jan. -- The Egyptians and Israelis ceased fire in the Negeb today at noon, Greenwich Mean time, Egyptian Foreign Minister Ibrahim Desouki Abaza Pasha announced tonight.

WARSAW, Jan. 7 -- The nomination of Bishop Stephan Wyszynski of the Lublin diocese to the vacant Metropolitan See of Gniezo and Warsaw, and to the post of Primate of Poland was announced today by the Roman Catholic Press.
Although cotton futures prices on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday ended at the lows of the day, off 7 to 16 points, net, the undertone was steady.

A nation-wide promotional campaign will be started in February by Champ Hats, Inc., to combat hatlessness and increasing general carelessness in dress among younger men, it was announced yesterday by Bernard L. Salesky, the company's president. Hatlessness, Mr. Salesky asserted, is the key to a general habit of "going without things" that extends to undershirts, garters, ties and dozens of other items stocked by good men's wear dealers.

LONDON, Saturday, Jan. 8 -- Britain gratefully accepted the word of President Truman today that there would be no change in United States foreign policy as a result of the replacing of General Marshall with Dean Acheson as Secretary of State.

Two high scoring stars are members of teams in tonight's basketball double-header at Madison Square Garden when Jack Kerris of Loyola of Chicago goes into action against St. John's University of Brooklyn and Paul Senesky of St. Joseph's College of Philadelphia faces City College.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Jan. 7 -- The long-awaited formal reaction of the Bonn Parliamentary Assembly to the six-power statute on internationalization of the Ruhr turned out today to be a rather mild series of statements by political parties in the steering committee. No plenary session was held to debate the issue.

TOKYO, Jan. 7 -- Japanese in increasing numbers are flocking back to the Shinto shrines at which the imperial ancestors and supposedly divine antecedents of Japan are traditionally worshiped. Thus further proof has now become available that the theory announced by Allied headquarters in the early days of the occupation that the Shinto faith would disappear as the result of the elimination of state support was incorrect.

In presenting his annual economic report to Congress yesterday President Truman reviewed the changes that had occurred in the nation's economic affairs during 1948 and outlined the Administration's program -- short-term and long-term -- for carrying out the general objectives of the Employment Act of 1946.

BERLIN, Jan. 7 -- A political coup that would have established a Communist administration inside the boundaries of the American sector fizzled this afternoon when Western sector police occupied a building in which an "elective session'' was to have been held.
LONDON, Jan. 7 -- The stock market finished the week on a cheerful note today. Brokers found more business to do than in any other day for some weeks past.

With the resignation of George Marshall on Jan. 20 one of the great Americans of this generation will step down from public office. Circumstances beyond human control have forced this decision. There cannot be the slightest doubt that President Truman wished Mr. Marshall to continue to head the State Department in the difficult and uncertain days that lie ahead.

Business leaders who speak of the imminence of a recession are "apostles of doom" whose pessimism will help to bring about what they fear, Paul D. Bagwell, president of the United States Junior Chamber of Commerce, declared here yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 (UP) -- The Agriculture Department said today that agricultural research was "paying off" for the farmers.

CHICAGO, Jan. 7 -- The leaders of the United Farm Equipment Workers Union moved toward an open break with the Congress of Industrial Organizations today over the CIO's order for transfer of the UFE's 40,000 members to the United Auto Workers.

Smuggled heroin and opium having a quick-sale value of $350,000 and a retail value when diluted that was said to approach $1,000,000 were seized yesterday by Customs agents aboard the French Ministry of Marine vessel Bastia.
CHICAGO, Jan. 7 (AP) -- Jimmy Conzelman today tendered his resignation as head coach of the Chicago Cardinals because he wants to settle down to normal family life.

Dr. and Mrs. Vladimir G. Simkhovitch gave "just a jolly party" yesterday for several hundred friends who filled the auditorium of Greenwich House with flowers for the couple on their fiftieth wedding anniversary.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 (AP) -- The Atlantic City Electric Company, Atlantic City, N. J., today asked the Securities and Exchange Commission for authority to borrow $850,000 from two banks in New York. It said it planned to use the proceeds to pay part of $500,000 in short-term notes due next month, and to add the remainder to its treasury funds.
MOBILE, Ala., Jan. 7 (AP) -- White supremacy advocates lost a major round today in their fight to restrict Negro voting in the South.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- The Presidential appointment of Dean Acheson to be Secretary of State to succeed George C. Marshall met with immediate and not entirely partisan praise in Congress today. But accompanying signals indicated that Mr. Acheson would undergo searching examination -- on Russia, Latin America and other areas of diplomatic issue -- before a confirmation vote was taken in the Senate.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- President Truman today named Frank Pace Jr. as Budget Director to fill the vacancy created by the selection of James E. Webb as Under-Secretary of State.

Pitcher Floyd (Bill) Bevens, loser of a one-hitter in the 1947 World Series, has been sold conditionally to the Chicago White Sox by the New York Yankees, it was disclosed yesterday. The Sox have until opening day to make up their minds on Bevens.

Next week will bring to the public market for new capital issues its most active and varied period in many weeks. Corporate flotations -- both debt and equity -- are scheduled in volume, and tax-exempt issues will be swollen by heavy borrowing by California school districts.

CLEVELAND, Jan. 7 -- Nine photo-mounting supply companies, including the Emil Koudelka Company of New York, and six of their officers were fined a total of $36,500 today by Federal Judge Paul Jones in an anti-trust action instituted by the Government. All the defendants pleaded nolo contendere, which means they were not contending the action, but were not admitting any guilt.
DETROIT, Jan. 8 -- The Ford Motor Company initiated Yesterday a "management development program" designed to clear channels for progress from the bottom to the top for all of its 125,000 employes.

St. Barnabas House will be the beneficiary of the performance of "La Boheme," with Bidu Sayao as Mimi and Richard Tucker as Rodolfo, on the night of Jan. 25 at the Metropolitan Opera House. Mrs. Frank Lyon Polk is chairman and Mrs. John McMaster co-chairman of the benefit committee.

If credit and financial executives will adopt selective policies, instead of general policies, necessary adjustments in business can be made without any plug-pulling "washout" George A. Renard, executive secretary-treasurer, the National Association of Purchasing Agents, declared in a year-end statement.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 8 -- The University of Pennsylvania quintet surprisingly upset Yale in an Eastern Intercollegiate League contest here tonight. The score in a game played before a capacity crowd of 3,000 was 72 -- 62.

A couple of Olympic champions found the unresisting boards of Brooklyn's 106th Engineers Armory less to their liking than the fast red clay of London's Wembley Stadium last night in the seventeenth annual Columbus Council, Knights of Columbus, games.

Undefeated after nine rounds of intensive play against representatives of six other nations, Nicholas Rossolimo, French champion, yesterday was crowned victor of the annual international masters tournament sponsored by the Hastings and St. Leonards Chess Club at the White Rock Pavilion, according to a report received from Hastings, England.

ALBANY, Jan. 8 -- After seven years in which state revenues far outstripped expenditures, making possible substantial cuts in tax rates and the accumulation of huge reserves, New York is now confronted with the necessity of raising more money to finance its urgent and growing needs, according to Governor Dewey.

Grover Cleveland won the city P.S.A.L. soccer championship for the second successive year by defeating Commerce, 3 -- 0, at Wingate Field yesterday. The game was previously postponed on four different occasions as a result of rains and snows.

I think you owe it to the public to correct the seemingly deliberate falsehood propagated by J. Arthur Rank in his film "Scott of the Antarctic" and so relayed by your contributor Russell Owen, that Evans was lost in the Antarctic.
There are more northern yachts converging on Florida than ever before, according to all of the accepted methods of tabulation.

VIENNA, Jan. 8 -- Austria's Interior Minister, Oskar Helmer told a deputation of women today that thousands of Austrians still were held as war prisoners in the Soviet Union despite an appeal by the Austrian Government and the Chancellor to Premier Stalin.
A NEW production device which doubles the usefulness of the average motion picture sound stage in England has been put into operation by the Asssociated British Picture Corporation.

THE fact that the amateur approach to the subject of architectural photograph can find its best expression in interpretative details rather than an entire structure was demonstrated last week by the first-prize winner in the Manhattan Camera Club's competition on "Architecture and Bridges." The print, by Harold Arrigoni, showing a corner of the Cloisters highlighted by a spot of late afternoon sunlight, is reproduced on this page.

Increased engine performance was emphasized in the 1949 Champion and Commander lines announced yesterday by K.B. Elliott, vice president in charge of sales of the Studebaker Corporation. There are nine Champion and ten Commander models.

PARIS, Jan. 8 -- Ambassador Jefferson Caffery will attend the unveiling tomorrow in the town of Alet near Carcassonne of the monument erected to Lieut. Paul Swank, United States Army paratrooper, who died fighting with the French resistance forces in that region.

Dr. V.K. Wellington Koo, Chinese Ambassador to the United States, will receive the 1949 Alexander Hamilton Medal, awarded annually by the Columbia College Alumni Association, at the annual Alexander Hamilton dinner to be held on Tuesday in the Biltmore Hotel, it was announced yesterday.

TO readers allergic to the genre, here is fair warning that this newest life-with-father is complete with Remarkable Parent, long-suffering household and -- as an added attraction -- an even dozen offspring. American family life -- as anyone but a jaded reader of family reminiscences will tell you -- lends itself quite effortlessly to good humor.

LAKELAND, Fla., Jan. 8 -- Freezing weather in the West and Southwest has come as a lifesaver for Florida citrus growers, many of whom were facing bankruptcy after two lean years, a survey of the major centers of the industry in this state indicated today.

VASILI KOTOV (whose real name is something else) was born in Moscow in 1914. He went to work in a factory at 15 when his father died, later became a Soviet Air Force engineer, and rose to the rank of colonel as a bomber pilot in World War II. From adolescence onward, he had some inner qualms about the Soviet system.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Jan. 8 -- Dean Acheson's appointment as Secretary of State was duly mentioned without comment in today's press, but an indication of the eventual propaganda attitude toward Gen. George C. Marshall's successor can be found in the manner in which President Truman's State of the Nation address to Congress was reported.

Hope that the Eighty-first Congress will liberalize the Displaced Persons Act of 1948 to permit thousands of homeless people in European camps to enter this country in 1949 was expressed last night by officials of the United Service for New Americans and Harry N. Rosenfield, United States Displaced Persons Commissioner.

Old people tell the truth about their age, University of Chicago racial scientists reported yesterday the first annual scientific session of the Gerontological Society, meeting at the Commodore Hotel. The session authorities in several fields of science discussed research findings regarding the aging process.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- There is every indication that the Republicans, cast again in the minority role in Congress, will give far greater support to the Truman program than they even thought of giving as "top dog" on Capitol Hill during the last two years.

WHEN dwarf apple or pear trees are trained to grow flat against fences or trellises, they are called espaliers. It is easy to train them this way, and some of the necessary pruning and shaping can be done in the dormant winter season.
LOS ANGELES, Jan. 8 -- Lloyd Mangrum and his protege, Eric Monti, tied at 138 today to lead the field at the midway mark of the $15,000 annual Los Angeles Open golf tournament.

For the United States Power Squadrons the past year has been one of solid growth and of strengthening. Latest reports show that membership now stands at 13,358 in 109 squadrons, an increase of 190 men and seven squadrons over a year ago.

Soviet economists have held another meeting of the Institute of Economics of the Soviet Academy of Science in a vain effort to find out why the United States has not had the economic crisis infallibly indicated for it by Marxian theory, it was learned yesterday.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Jan. 2 -- The organization of Federal and State administrative authorities and the operational procedures of the executive and legislative branches of government constitute the most complicated sections of the draft constitution completed by the West German Parliamentary Assembly at Bonn.

The forty-three-man crew of the French Ministry of Marine vessel Bastia was subjected to questioning for twelve hours Friday night and early yesterday in an effort to ascertain the source of the huge cache of narcotics uncovered in her engine room Friday afternoon.

SAN FRACISCO -- The effect of the Marshall Plan upon the West Coast Economy so far has been indirect. Relatively few consumer goods have been purchased although there have been some exports of wheat from the Northwest and dried fruits from California.

During the summer of 1948, the United States Coast and Geodetic Survey accomplished coastal topographic and hydrographic surveys along the Atlantic coast which are of basic interest to yachtsmen. Included were new surveys of Point Judith Pond and the Harbor of Refuge; hydrographic and wire drag surveys in Boston Harbor; new basic surveys at Bar Harbor, Me., and surveys of the James River and lower Hampton Roads.

SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, Jan. 8 President-elect Otilio Ulate said today there was no truth in a news-agency report from Managua that he had been arranging a "peace treaty" with Col. Julio Somoza, secretary general of the Nicaraguan National Guard, with a view to ending the present tension between Costa Rica and Nicaragua.

IN the white silences of the North Woods a social barrier exists as wide as the Yukon River and as high as a Ponderosa pine. Climbing Mount St. Elias or winning an Eagle Scout badge is simple compared with surmounting it.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- The housing situation is quite as critical in the radio broadcasting field as in the cities, where people anxiously search for homes, the Federal Communications Commission reported today.

City College and St. Joseph's last night waged another of the heated contests that have marked their series at Madison Sqaure Garden and despite the fact that the Beavers won by 60 to 53, the score hardly indicated the closeness of the struggle.

BOSTON, Jan. 8 -- Floods and the inaugurations of four new Governors held paramount interest this week in New England. There was evidence, however, that the region also was keeping tuned to developments in Washington as the Eighty-first Congress began shuffling its papers.

The stock market coasted along yesterday, apparently content with the current price level, and showed only minor changes on the day. The short session on the stock exchange ended a week, however, which witnessed the best rally since last spring and placed the combined averages at the highest rate in two months.

The Giants, who already have their key outfield operatives lined up for 1949 along with their clouting Johnny Mize and crack short-stop Buddy Kerr, concentrated on their mound staff yesterday and by nightfall Secretary Eddie Brannick was able to announce the signing of three of the Polo Grounders' more prominent hurlers.

It was almost twenty years ago that Ruggiero Ricci made his debut as a 9-year-old prodigy. The serious young violinist has given many concerts since, but at his annual recital yesterday afternoon at Carnegie Hall he gave the impression of being still in the process of finding himself as a mature artist.

The number of "small-boaters" has increased from one-and-a-half to two-and-a-half million since the end of the war, according to close estimates made by the Outboard Boating Club of America. This tremendous increase was partially occasioned by servicemen who had their appetites whetted when they used outboards in the services, but was due chiefly to the huge technical advancements and new developments achieved by the industry in producing new and better models.

Bay relating the problems of the Negro community to the needs of the city as a whole, there has been a measure of progress for everybody, the Urban League of Greater New York said yesterday in reviewing its record for 1948. The league has branches in Jamaica, Queens, the Bronx, Harlem and Brooklyn.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla. -- The Chambers of Commerce of the resort communities on Florida's West Coast are almost, but not quite, speechless with joy. With the peak of the winter season still a month away, visitors from the north are pouring into the West Coast towns at a rate never before seen, not even in the rush periods of the biggest boom years.

Forty-seven per cent fewer students were dropped from the rolls for scholastic deficiencies during the fall term just ended at the Georgia Institute of Technology than a year ago. The number of failures is the lowest in relation to enrollment in the sixty-one-year history of the institute.

THE prediction made last year by W.W. Watts, vice president of RCA, that by 1953 more films would be made for television than for movie houses, provoked much skepticism, but it will have been a conservative forecast if all the present announcements, plans and projects involving film production for video materialize.
OTTAWA, Jan. 8 (Canadian Press) -- Big world wheat crops for 1949 have been forecast by Canada's Bureau of Statistics.

HARRISBURG, Pa., Jan. 8 (AP) -- Bishop John S. Stamm, new president of the Federal Council of Churches of Christ in America, declared today that the success of recent Protestant Church mergers pointed to additional unions.
HAVANA -- Although Cuba's winter season has been slow in starting, present indications are that the coming weeks will find many tourists here.

THE newest edition of that perennial best-seller, The Information Please Almanac, opens with a ninety-page section on "How Man Lives Under Capitalist- Socialist-Communist Governments." This is in accordance with the established practice of its editors of including the equivalent of a full-length book on a current topic every year -- in addition to extensive statistical and review material.
The sixteenth annual Polka Ball, to advance the cultural and philanthropic projects of the Kosciuszko Foundation, will take place the night of Feb. 11 in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria.

An intensive program to promote public understanding of education by lifting the "academic curtain" is being mapped by the Tuition Plan, 424 Madison Avenue. Now in its eleventh year of service, the organization has distinguished itself by its attempt to popularize private education.

On the Yale Club's courts yesterday, the annual Bull Dog handicap squash tennis tournament, which will end on Jan. 21 when the finalists will receive a bronze miniature of the famed Eli mascot, Handsome Dan, got under way with nineteen matches being completed.

PALM BEACH, Fla. -- The Palm Beaches, the original Gold Coast section of Florida, are preparing for one of their busiest seasons on the basis of advance reservations and inquiries received by the two cities -- Palm Beach and West Palm Beach.

quarter of 1948 showed a marked improvement over the preceding quarter, condition statements of the fifteen largest commercial banks here for Dec. 31 disclosed. Combined loans and discounts of the instittuions reached a new peak, with the gain in the period double that of the third quarter. Earnings improved and sales of Government bonds fell off to the smallest total for any quarter in more than a year.

If the Metropolitan Opera Association had given more performances this season and in late seasons of the admirable quality of the representation of "Le Nozze di Figaro" given yesterday afternoon, the apologia for the shortcomings of its offerings, delivered before the last act by George A. Sloan, chairman of the board of directors, would not have been necessary.
Speed-boat racing made its debut in Mexico last year with unprecedented success. Races for both 225 and 135 cubic inch craft and also A, B and C outboards, were held at Acapulco and Lake Chapala.

THIS is the season of cat shows, a cultural activity not invented by cats. For humanity to stand around gaping with admiration, of course, strikes cats as eminently fitting. However, they prefer the emotion to be registered in the home and to take the form of a generous serving of turkey or lobster.

LONDON, Jan. 8 -- On the eve of the restoration of an uneasy peace in Palestine, the fighting along the Egyptian border and beyond it -- against which the United States had warned the Israelis at Britain's instigation -- led to an actual clash of arms between the Israelis and the British.
Vice President of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, in charge of its Long Lines Department

ERIC BENTLEY, one of our most interesting and controversial critics of the drama, is a Brecht disciple and an advocate of the master's theories of "epic" drama, a stylized method of production invented by Brecht and the Berlin director Piscator.

IN spite of the care with which the Founding Fathers of this nation wrote into the Constitution a ban on the official establishment of a national religion, they were religious men and they served a people who were likewise religious.
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 8 -- The traditional New Year's Day parade of Mummers, delayed a week because of bad weather, was held today by old King Momus, the age-long personification of ridicule.
NEWARK, N.J., Jan. 8 -- The Newark Polo Club outlasted the Meadow Larks of Elberon, 11 -- 10, in a hard-fought contest tonight at Essex Troop Armory.

Last Friday at 7 A. M. EST a truce went into effect between Israel and Egypt. It brought a formal cessation in the intermittent struggle that has been waged between them for eight months. The truce appeared to open the door for a settlement in the Middle East which would end the Arabs' fight against Israel.
CHICAGO, Jan. 8 -- President Truman's annual message to Congress overshadowed reports of skidding wholesale food prices as a main topic of conversation among Central Westerners this week.

Harold R. Sleeper, president of the New York Chapter of the American Institute of Architects, said yesterday that his organization backed Governor Dewey's plan for a new state-wide minimum building code and speedy construction of 250,000 new low-cost homes.

THE variety and vitality of French poetry in recent times are illustrated in this anthology of French verse and translations by English poets. It represents most of France's well-known poets of the past hundred years, as well as some of the less great who seldom cross linguistic frontiers.

Belief that 90 per cent of the people of Czechoslovakia were dissatisfied with their Communist-dominated Government was expressed here yesterday by Mrs. Nana Benes, niece by marriage of the late Czech President Eduard Benes. She arrived aboard the French liner De Grasse, which docked at 9 A.M. at Pier 88, North River, with 681 passengers from Le Havre and Southampton.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- Milton S. Eisenhower, chairman of the United States National Commission for the United Nations Economic, Social and Cultural Organization, announced today that the American Booksellers Association had been appointed to administer the UNESCO book cupon program in this country.

Yeast cells lap up alcohol which they themselves produce. This strange discovery, expected to help in the cultivation and utilization of various types of food and industrial yeasts and thus aid in fighting hunger in all lands, has been reported by Dr. P.N. Agarwal, an Indian scientist, jointly with Dr. W.H. Peterson of the University of Wisconsin.

THE debates preceding the national election made it clear that people of all shades of opinion look upon the stability of the American economy as our domestic problem No. 1. The best sign of the spirit in which that problem will now be faced resides in the legislative and executive record of those who have molded national policy in peace and war since the end of the great depression fifteen years ago.

Retail sales here turned downward for the first week of the new year. Department store volume was estimated at about 4 per cent under the like week of 1948. Many promotions and clearances at lower prices got under way, with more to follow.

LIKE a weary but tidy housekeeper, who finally gets around to picking up the odds and ends of Christmas after the long holiday, the custodian of this column herewith finds time, at last, to put in their proper places two or three items which have been opened in the past two weeks.

THE problem of building autograph mobiles more quickly and at less cost will be among the major topics to be discussed at the annual meeting of the Society of Automotive Engineers opening in Detroit tomorrow, Technical experts from half a dozen countries will take part in the program, which is to continue through Friday and cover topics ranging from better mechanical performance to improved motor fuels.

ALL-AMERICA vegetables for 1949 total seven new varieties. They have been chosen, as are the flowers, through nation-wide trials conducted in test gardens across the country and in southern Canada. All seven are recommended as superior to others of their kinds.
THE necessity of appraising television's place in the homes of our country is becoming increasingly apparent now that its importance as an industry has been confirmed.

IN 1908, two years before his death, Leo Tolstoy finished a brief treatise, "The Law of Love and the Law of Violence." Its explosive contents prevented the work from being published in full in Russia at that time, but it did appear in a Russian edition in England in 1909.

THESE little books are well written, readable and inexpensive. Their publication in England was heralded there as "the most important literary event since the publication of the English Men of Letters series." There are to be thirty-three titles, compact studies of eminent English novelists from Thomas Nashe to D. H. Lawrence.

ROME, Jan. 8 -- Allocation for public works in southern Italy of 20,000,000,000 lire [about $35,000,000] from the lire counterpart fund of the European Recovery Program has received definite approval from the Economic Cooperation Administration.

IF the Postoffice Department's plans are carried out, fewer United States stamps will be issued during 1949 than were released last year. A statement to that effect was made by Joseph J. Lawler, Third Assistant Postmaster General, in a radio broadcast sponsored by the Washington Press of Newark, N.J., makers of albums and philatelic stationery.

ALBANY, Jan. 8 -- Another attempt to return to the direct primary system of nominating party candidates for statewide office was made today by Senator Thomas C. Desmond, Republican, of Newburgh, with chances for passage of the bill said to be remote.

A quickening tempo of public thinking toward motor-boating in New Jersey is definite and there is ample evidence to prove the assertion. The establishment of state-owned marinas is one of the most important undertakings and Governor Alfred E. Driscoll, recognizing the trend as desirable, established a policy for state acquisition and operation, generally directing that:

Evinrude, celebrating the fortieth anniversary of outboard motoring, offers two new Elto models, the "Sportster" at five horsepower and the "Speedster" at twelve. Both are of the two-cylinder, alternate firing type. The five horsepower has full reverse.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 8 -- The Yale University varsity swimming team defeated La Salle College of Philadelphia, 48 -- 27, in the Payne Whitney pool today. The event was much closer than the final score indicated.

WHAT he dubbed the "Fair Deal" was put before the President Truman in his State of the Union message. For the most part business interests were not surprised by the program because most of its points already had been offered by the President and emphasized during his successful campaign.
CHICAGO, Jan. 8 (AP) -- Heavy selling swept soy beans and lard down sharply on the Board of Trade today, causing weakness also in wheat, corn and oats.

The prime problem of American business management is to improve the operations of the world's largest industrial organization to meet the greatest challenge it ever has faced, according to Lawrence Appley, president of the American Management Association, a national business group.

ATHENS, Jan. 8 -- George Papandreou, Social Democratic leader and hitherto a sharp critic of the present Populist-Liberal coalition government under Premier Thermistocles Sophoulis, agreed tonight to join the Cabinet.

By breaking existing production and refining records, the oil industry has surmounted the supply difficulties it faced a year ago, and today the supply of petroleum products is running ahead of demand, Robert G. Dunlop, president of the Sun Oil Company, said in his year-end review.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- The Democratic House, with the help of forty-nine Republicans who perhaps had in mind the events of last Nov. 2, has now laid it down in the rubrics that its Rules Committee shall be forever "curbed."
WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- Exhaustive examination of Dean Acheson by the Senate Foreign Relations Committee was guaranteed today, but confirmation of his appointment as Secretary of State seemed certain.

New York City's junior high school students indicated their aspirations to be "citizens of tomorrow" by discussing domestic and foreign affairs in a current events quiz yesterday on the Youth Forum sponsored by THE NEW YORK TIMES and broadcast over WQXR.
Mr. Tibor Serly, in his interesting letter published in THE TIMES last Sunday, states that "no outstanding creator ever went back to a previous style."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- W. Stuart Symington, Secretary of the Air Force, urgently appealed today for sharp increases in American air power to bring the Air Force to seventy groups and the capability by 1952 of instantly waging a full-scale war.

LONDON, Jan. 8 -- A sharp policy shift in Europe's Western Union defense set-up here is expected in about a month. The organization has decided, after weeks of discussion, to throw off -- party at least -- its cloak of secrecy and in the near future to appoint a press officer.

IT is a question whether a sampling of recent art publications is more to be recommended for the obvious merit of the material or for the negative virtue of making us demand more exacting standards in our art writing, even at the popular level.

In issuing its recent "task force" reports, both the Vorhees and Eberstadt sub-committees of the Hoover Commission on Organization of the Executive Branch of the Government have stressed the need for reorganizing our Federal medical services, so that the needs of the military services, veterans and other governmental medical dependents can be met without aggravating the present and continuing critical medical shortages in the nation as a whole.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- When the newly appointed Secretary of State, Dean Acheson, first became active on Capitol Hill several years ago, Senator Alben Barkley counseled him to have patience and forbearance, and told him a story which is not entirely irrelevant to Mr. Acheson's new responsibilities today.

The average tugboat worker in the Port of New York earns between $300 and $400 a month, according to a survey of earnings, made public yesterday, covering the 3,500 men who threaten to paralyze harbor activity at 12:00 A.M. on Thursday.

The chickadee is a delightful bird. The reference, of course, is to the black-capped chickadee of these parts, which flits about the naked woodland all winter long, twitters merrily in the midst of a snowstorm and doesn't even sulk when caught in a cold, driving winter rain.

The arrest of the Hungarian Cardinal Archbishop Mindszenty has been described by Acting Secretary of State Lovett as a sickening sham. Similarly strong and picturesque language was used by President Truman last year as he denounced the Communist coup in Hungary as an outrage.
The up-and-coming New York Rangers, hottest team in the National Hockey League for the past month, will tackle the Montreal Canadiens tonight in Madison Square Garden.

THE greatest experiment in social service ever attempted by a democratic Government -- Britain's "cradle-to-grave" National Health Service -- has been in operation for six months. That is too short a time to pronounce it a success or a failure, but not too short to describe and assess its early life.
Investment banking must do two formidable jobs this year if the nation's machinery of securities distribution is to continue as a major means of financing business enterprise.

The old Milwaukee, survivor of a naval era that is gone forever, will again fly the Stars and Stripes instead of the Hammer, and Sickle at her gaff next March when the Soviet Union is scheduled to return the ship to the United States at Lewes, Del.

THE sudden death of Horace Medbury Hicks a few days before his thirtieth birthday is most inconvenient for his widow, Edith. Instead of inheriting half a million, she will receive only a few thousand as compensation for seven years of an unhappy marriage.
ROME, Jan. 8 (AP) -- Charles (Lucky) Luciano, former New York underwrold character, angrily denied tonight charges that he was involved in the shipment of illicit drugs to the United States.
BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 8 -- President Juan D. Peron is expected to open Monday, Jan. 17, the constitutional reform convention that is held certain to make it legal for him to succeed himself in 1952.

GENERATIONS of schoolboys have been familiar with the glowing exposition of Magna Carta in the history texts: it is less well understood that for long periods subsequent to the encounter of barons and King at Runnymede, the Charter was quite obscure and for the most part neglected.

Somebody should introduce author George Lawton to artist Abner Dean. Dr. Lawton obviously keeps his eyes and mind open, but the "melancholy Dean" needs new glasses. Or perhaps he just needs to be introduced to more "30-plus" American women.

Clifford Curzon, the English pianist, who gave a recital yesterday afternoon at Town Hall, again impressed as one of the most poetic, sensitive and refined keyboard artists of the day. His performances were always those of a profoundly sincere musician, for whom the message of the works under consideration was the foremost consideration, and, despite his highly perfected technical equipment, he never employed it as an end in itself, but only as a means.

In Nanking last week a rickshaw boy said to an American correspondent, "Sir, pray to heaven to bring us peace. Then prices will not increase any more." At a dinner party, a painter toasted, "Let there be peace. Food and warmth is what keeps art going."

Customers at the Indian Show in Rockefeller Center were not quite scalped yesterday, but the outcries many of them made to get their money back were much more genuine than the simulated war cries of the costumed braves.

ALTHOUGH there are pessimists around town who are certain nothing will emerge except the usual assortment of high-sounding resolutions, ANTA is seriously preparing its industry-wide conference on the state of the theatre which Equity called for not so long ago.

The average boat owner who combines pride of possession with an ability to be his own mechanic, painter, interior decorator, chef and navigator does not look upon the past decades with as much nostalgia as his non boat-minded fellow citizen might do.

The Eighty-first Congress, settling down to business this week, begins its labors with a long list of chores requested by the gentleman now temporarily inhabiting Blair House. It has had a State of the Union Message, it has had an Economic Report, it will have a budget message.

The nation's machine tool industry is currently operating at a rate that is surprisingly low, roughly one-fourth of the wartime peak, but slightly ahead of 1939 levels, L.D. McDonald, president, the National Machine Tool Builders Association, disclosed in a year-end statement.

A 48-year-old woman was fatally injured yesterday by a riderless police horse that broke away as its patrolman master tried to stop a runaway in Central Park. Neither the policeman nor the 13-year-old equestrienne he was trying to rescue was hurt.

WILLIAM TEMPLE, who died in 1944 at the early age of 63, was one of the most remarkable men of this century. He was outstanding as ecclesiastic, statesman, educator, philosopher and theologian, social diagnostician, and as leader in efforts to reunite a Christendom split both denominationally and within denominations.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 (AP) -- Jimmy Conzelman said today that his resignation as coach of the National League Chicago Cardinals will take him entirely out of football "at least for the time being."

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Jan. 8 -- The need for training Southern youth in the field of science has reached a "crucial" stage and the lack of such training constitutes a "stumbling block" in the region's efforts to take its place as an integral part of the national economy, according to a research monograph released today by the Southern Association of Science and Industry.

Steelcraft, the metal power boat that has been sold in large numbers in various 26-foot models, becomes available for the first time in a larger and a smaller size at the show. The new Steelcraft, built by Churchward Co., are a 35-foot Luxury Cruiser and a 20-foot hull in two models.

The growing importance of industrial advertising will be reflected this year in budgets expected to total a record high of well over $500,000,000, according to Blaine G. Wiley, executive secretary of the National Industrial Advertisers Association. Mr. Wiley based this forecast on information received from a cross-section of the association.
ATLANTA, Jan. 8 -- Bobby Jones -- golf's greatest master -- probably will miss this year's Masters tournament.

A cultural center for the Bronx, where tired business men and busy housewives will be able to hear a symphony or see a play without traveling into crowded midtown Manhattan, is being established at Walton High School, Jerome Avenue and 196th Street.

PARIS, Jan. 8 -- Communist propaganda has visibly and not entirely unsuccessfully sought to link Greece, Spain and China in the minds of that portion of the world not anaesthetized by Moscow. These three countries and their political situations bear scant resemblance to one another.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 8 (AP) -- Yale announced today the establishment of a "living memorial" to its eleven students who died in the plane crash at Seattle last Sunday. A scholarship fund will be set up for students from the Pacific Northwest.

WHILE the Deep South is still busily welcoming its winter guests, it is already looking forward to Mardi Gras and the series of colorful festivities that make the spring such a gala time there. Dates for these events are always announced far in advance because limited accommodations and the great number of people who wish to attend make it necessary for visitors to plan weeks and months ahead.

TRENTON, N.J., Jan. 8 -- A state-operated lottery, similar to the Irish sweepstakes, to finance a New Jersey veterans' bonus will be proposed to the 1949 Legislature by Senator-elect Vincent E. Hull, Democrat, of Passaic.

HOUSING the Mazda lamp seems to have stumped designers longer than any other problem posed by twentieth-century inventions. At first a bare bulb hung from the ceiling was all people asked for, so grateful were they for the miraculous light it gave. When something fancier seemed in order elaborate fixtures were designed to dress up the strange new lamp in the more familiar fittings of the gas lamp, the oil lamp or even the candle.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Jan. 8 -- Four Royal Air Force planes and an Egyptian aircraft were shot down by Israeli fighters and anti-aircraft fire during yesterday's air battles in the Negeb, Israeli authorities announced tonight. One of two British pilots captured was said to have declared that one mission had been sent on armed reconnaissance o photograph Egyptian and Israeli positions in the border area around Rafah.

Containing features less drastic than had been expected, President Truman's messages to Congress had a favorable effect on financial markets last week. They included a combination of both inflationary and deflationary aspects, and represented a restatement of his campaign promises.

THE big cruise news of the season is the fact that consumer resistance to original cruise rate schedules has left more than enough space open on southbound ships for latecomers. Rates that a month ago averaged around $30 a day for minimum accommodations, have been slashed heavily in the past week or two, some up to 25 and 30 per cent.
SYDNEY, Australia, Jan. 8 (AP) -- The price for Australian wool today is the highest in history. Many believe it has not yet reached the ceiling.

BATAVIA, Java, Jan. 8 (AP) -- The Netherlands Government said today that Republican President Sukarno had written his Dutch guards that 95 per cent of the Netherlands nation was just as much a victim of colonialism as the Indonesians.

" YOUR Garden and Mine," the ninth annual midwinter garden course sponsored by THE NEW YORK TIMES, will be held on four successive Wednesdays, starting Jan. 19, in Times Hall, 240 West Forty-fourth Street.
Retail activity here last week was considerably stimulated by January white sales and ready-to-wear clearances, according to a survey made especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Meyer Both Reports.

WORCESTER, Mass., Jan. 8 (AP) -- A bucket twister by six-foot nine-inch Larry Foust with four seconds to play gave La Salle College of Philadelphia a 63-61 upset triumph over Holy Cross before 2,500 fans here tonight.

On an afternoon more suited to strolling in the sunshine in Central Park, 12,943 persons, most of them leather-lunged small fry who were guests of the management, sat in Madison Square Garden yesterday and saw New York's Knickerbockers face Baltimore's bullets in a Basketball Association of America game.
Francis Cardinal Spellman announced yesterday that in July, 1947, he had asked the United States Government to keep the sacred crown of Hungary out of the hands of the Communists.

TOKYO, Jan. 8 -- The debate within Japanese Government circles over the establishment of a single exchange rate appears to have narrowed to two proposals. The first is 350 yen to the dollar and the second 300 yen. The Board of Trade favors the first and the Economic Stabilization Board the second.

EASTERN railroads announced last week their winter ski-train schedules and simultaneously indicated that this season would serve as a test of the popularity and profitability of these special trains. This winter represents a somewhat delayed post-war comeback for winter sports trains; last year shortages of equipment and, even more important, of snow, made it impossible to judge the worth of the trains to the railroads.

CARMEL, N.Y., Jan. 8 -- The resident deputy sheriff of the Putnam County jail here was in his own prison tonight, accused of grand larceny. His arrest, for converting seized property to personal use, stemmed from an investigation into a cozy New Year's Eve party in the prison at which the deputy reportedly was host to other members of the Sheriff's staff and two inmates.

The Brooklyn Post Office in 1948 handled the greatest volume of mail in its history and its revenue for the year reached a new high, according to the annual report made public yesterday by Postmaster Edward J. Quigley.

LONDON, Jan. 8 -- The Air Ministry reported today that five British reconnaissance planes had been shot down yesterday over Egypt by Israeli fighters. The British planes, operating from bases in the Suez Canal zone, were out in search of information on the Israeli Army, which recently had carried the Palestine war over the border into Egypt.

TOKYO, Jan. 8 -- The Japanese tonight displayed considerable interest in the resignation of United States Secretary of State Marshall and the appointment of Dean Acheson as his successor.
CLOSED SHOP. A shop in which union membership is a requisite of permanent employment. -- Webster' New International Dictionary.

REPORTS from Waterbury, Conn., indicate that that city is in a tizzy over the concert on Jan. 25 by Walter Gieseking, the German pianist, Veterans' organizations have been trying to organize a boycott on the basis of Gieseking's record under the Nazi regime, and have been threatened, together with the local newspapers, with damage suits if the concert has to be cancelled.

CAIRO, Jan. 8 -- Executives of the Suez Canal Company, which is embarking on an important program of developing the canal, are at present in Cairo negotiating with the Egyptian Government regarding their refusal to increase the percentage of Egyptian directors and employes to the extent stipulated by the Egyptian Companies Act.

NEWLY opened exhibitions include one which affords us a comprehensive view of the lifelong development of one of America's outstanding painters and another which may almost be regarded as a one-picture show. The former is a carefully selected exhibition of work by the late William Glackens from 1895 to 1935, at the Kraushaar Gallery.

ROME, Jan. 8 -- At the same time that it recently indicated its willingness to join the Atlantic pact the Italian Government made arrangements to bring its Air Force materiel up to date. A four-year plan has been drawn calling for a total expenditure of 80,000,000,000 lire [about $140,000,000].

In an interview of Dr. Werner Heisenberg, which appeared in THE NEW YORK TIMES of Dec. 28, this foremost German scientist is cited as maintaining "that the top nuclear physicists of Germany were not far behind American physicists in their theoretical knowledge of chain reactions and of the general principles that would have to be applied in making an atomic bomb."

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 8 -- American President Lines announced today that the keel of the first of three $11,000,000 round- the-world luxury liners would be laid early in March at the Camden, N.J., yards of the New York Shipbuilding Corporation.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 (AP) -- Senator Margaret Chase Smith of Maine said tonight that the Republicans lost five straight Presidential elections because too many party leaders thought the government should not intervene in economic affairs of the people.

The city's waterfront police squads, which are aiding in the current departmental drive against crime, have been increased to a total of thirty-eight men, Police Commissioner Arthur W. Wallander announced yesterday. Fifteen men were added during the week.

WEST Florida was a pioneer land in 1826 when Hart Whitley, capable New England farm boy, and Charles Parkson, inexperienced young dandy from Louisiana, arrived in the frontier town of Tallahassee coincidentally and decided at once to farm Charles' bequeathed acres together.

The Squadron A Regulars defeated the Morristown (N.J.) Polo Club, 11 to 9, in the top game of a double-header last night at the Squadron A Armory. Three goals by Walter Nicholls in a five-goal period was the biggest item.

ARCADIA, Calif., Jan. 8 -- Stepfather, the $200,000 "lemon" that Louis B. Mayer sold to Harry M. Warner, captured today's $50,000 Santa Catalina Handicap at Santa Anita, beating the California money-winning champion, On Trust, in a photo finish.

It has been known for years that it is possible to suspend the flow of blood to all organs except the brain for ten minutes to half an hour without causing death. One Swedish surgeon, Crafoord, double-clamped the aorta (the big artery that supplies blood from the heart to the entire arterial system) in thirty-three patients who needed operations, and this without causing any disturbances internally.
