The United States Attorney's office for the Eastern District of New York obtained convictions in 97.8 per cent of its criminal cases in 1948, according to the annual report made public yesterday by J. Vincent Keogh, district prosecutor.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- President Truman, Congress and organized labor set the stage this week for another historic struggle over labor legislation.

GREENWICH, Conn., Jan. 8 -- Charles Brinton and Samuel Pearson, national squash racquets doubles champions, today reached the semi-finals of the annual Greenwich invitation tournament. They defeated Paul Maguire and Gordon Lindsay of Greenwich in the first round, 15 -- 12, 15 -- 4, 6 -- 15, 15 -- 7, then turned back the New York team of Donald Grant and John Smith, 15 -- 7, 15 -- 5, 18 -- 17.

Arrangements were completed last week for invasion of the metropolitan area by automatic grocery stores in which customers' selections are picked up at the check-out counter. Known as Keedoozle Stores, the new grocery will be granted operating rights and furnished with equipment through Keedoozle Eastern Corporation, formed here last week.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- The National Military Establishment issued today a list of terms from "acceleration, axial" to "zoom" in a seventy-two-page "Glossary of Guided-Missile Terms" that represented the first publication of a language primer to be used by experts of all three armed forces.
CHICAGO, Jan. 8 (AP) -- Motorola, Inc., of Chicago, filed suit against Admiral Corporation, also of Chicago, charging infringement on patents on a low-priced Motorola television receiver.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 (AP) -- A room housing the private library of President Woodrow Wilson was dedicated today at the Library of Congress.

Now entering its fiftieth year of service, the National Jewish Hospital at Denver has made significant contributions to the never-ending struggle against tuberculosis. The work of its research section has helped save many lives the world over, and the efforts and achievements of its surgeons have developed new techniques which have brought the institution to a position of eminence in the world of medicine.

A lecture on sixteenth-century music, the second in a series on the history of music over the past 500 years, will be held tomorrow at 6 P.M. in Room 213 of the New York Public Library, Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street. Dr. Curt Sachs, consultant to the music division, is conducting, the series, scheduled to run to March 7.
MOSCOW, Jan. 8 (AP) -- The Journal of the Moscow Patriarch said today an "agent of the Vatican" assassinated Dr. Lvov O. Gavriil Kostelnik, protopresbyter of the Russian Orthodox Church, last fall.

MORE than two million Mexican-Americans, this lively but outstandingly documented book shows, are the step-children of America's race-discrimination problems. They are of mixed Indian and white blood -- mestizos -- and are shunned, or mistreated, by neighbors whose prejudices follow color lines.

To any skier, the significance as a social document of Arthur Daley's article is immediately apparent. Mr. Daley discusses a dozen sports. The eleven he likes are for the most part performed by paid athletes, and all but golf are watched by comfortably seated spectators.

ON a recent afternoon a lady boarded a Broadway bus in midtown and dropped her fare in the coin box. "Nice day, isn't it?" said the driver cheerily. For a moment the passenger stared at him, stupefied. Then, obviously mistrusting her senses, she muttered agreement and shakily sought a seat. A courteous bus driver! In her eyes was the blank look of one who has just seen a miracle.

HONOLULU, Jan. 8 -- The lava stream flowing out of the southwest rim of the crater of the erupting volcano, Mauna Loa, had come to virtual standstill today at the 8,000-foot level and there were indications that the summit eruption might be drying up.

American furniture, silver and paintings, among them heirlooms of the Few-Christie family, and Oriental art objects, books and manuscripts will be auctioned in three sales this week at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 30 East Fifty-seventh Street.

Studies of protein synthesis by a new technique made possible by atomic energy have brought University of California scientists a little closer to understanding the subtle mechanism by which nature builds up living material. The new research has been reported by Drs. David M. Greenberg, Theodore Winnick, Felix Friedberg and Martin P. Schulman of the Department of Biochemistry.

IT becomes dally more evident that the straining theatre is no longer to be imprisoned in the confines of Broadway. It is too vital a force to be so exclusively bottled. Economic restrictions are too rigid to permit its free movement, so the theatre which, for years, has been finding unsatisfactory release in the hundreds of thousands of amateur groups is now demanding mature expression.

THE most impressive qualities of folklore are its durability and its changeability, qualities strikingly illustrated in this collection of over 400 rhymes currently chanted by American childhood. Many of them are traditional, harking back to such old favorites as "The bear went over the mountain" while others have a startlingly modern flavor with their references to Charlie Chaplin, Popeye and -- for better or worse -- bubble gum.

WE have it on the authority of the editor of this volume that all the stories in it are true. In some cases fictitious names are used in order to avoid embarrassing innocent persons, and in other cases dialogue has been invented to fill gaps in the narrative, but the essential facts are as stated.

FOR THIS WEEK: Cut off and destroy bagworm cocoons that are seen hanging on the branches of cedar and other evergreens.... Save wood ashes from the fireplace and keep in a covered barrel for fertilizing peonies, roses and lilacs in spring.... Paint and repair any garden furniture and trellises while they are in winter storage.... Feed calla lilies by watering them once every two weeks with liquid manure.

In a recent number of the Physikaliache Blaetter appears Max Planck's own account of an interview with Hitler in 1933 on the Jewish question. As head of the Kaiser Wilhelm Institute, Planck had to call to pay his respects.

LATEST literary communique from the Russian sector of Berlin: the current best-selling American books in translation are (1) "Sowing the Wind," an old (1945) novel of Germany between wars, by Martha Dodd, daughter of the former American Ambassador, and (2) "I Too Am American," an anthology (apparently locally compiled) of poems by such Negro authors as Frank Marshall Davis, Paul Laurence Dunbar and Richard Wright.

THERE is a play in bridge known as the "double trump squeeze" that is at the same time as difficult to recognize and execute, and as unlikely to be actually dealt in a bridge game, as any other play known to the game.

NANKING, Jan. 8 -- An avalanche of peace sentiment was released among the Chinese people following Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek's New Year statement in which he offered to step down if peace with the Communists could be obtained.

The jurisdiction of the New York District, Corps of Engineers, extends to all Congressionally authorized navigation projects on waterways tributary to the Atlantic Ocean from Manasquan Inlet, N.J., to the Connecticut boundary line, and on the Hudson River and Lake Champlain watersheds to the Canadian boundary.

CHICAGO, Jan. 8 -- Traffic on the country's inland waterways this year is expected to top the record volume handled in 1948, Chester C. Thompson, president of the American Waterways Operators, said today. The association's members are private operators who use rivers, canals and the gulf-intercoastal system to move freight by barge and ship.

The Metropolitan Opera Association is considering proposals for a new opera house along with the alternative of making extensive alterations of the present building, it was made known yesterday by George A. Sloan, chairman of the board of directors.

Negro organizations in Virginia have launched a campaign to fight segregation in approximately 124 divisions of the public schools of that state, officials of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People who have been assigned that work announced yesterday. Steps will be taken to equalize the wages of the teachers and the school facilities for the two races, in the Counties of King George, Pulaski, Gloucester and Arlington.

THERE is a legend, partly true perhaps, that every newspaper man has the manuscript of a piece of fiction in his desk. To anyone who has ever seen a number of these manuscripts one fact is likely to become curiously apparent.

Many out-of-town buyers visited the wholesale apparel market here last week to look over new lines and to order fill-ins of spring merchandise, according to a report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell Company, resident buying office.
There will be no bright harbinger of a car buyers' market concealed in the General Motors exhibition opening at the Waldorf- Astoria Hotel Jan. 20.

When the Legislature reconvenes tomorrow, Senator Elmer F. Quinn and Assemblyman Irwin Steingut, the Democratic legislative leaders, will demand a complete accounting of the $285,000,000 already spent from the Post-war Reconstruction Fund.

THE general upheaval in the Sunday radio schedules, highlighted by Jack Benny's switch from NBC to CBS and Edgar Bergen's temporary absence from the air, finally came to pass last week. As suggested by all the advance excitement, the results were far-reaching in their implications.

Are the pituitary hormones of cattle the same in physiological effect as those of chickens and fish? It is generally assumed that they are. But along comes George F. Weisel, graduate student of the University of Calfornia (Los Angeles division), with a doctoral thesis that raises doubts.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 8 -- Alarmed at the growing number of bowl games, the National Collegiate Athletic Association today told its 243 member schools to make no commitments for post-season football engagements after January of 1950.
It was nice to hear that Nona Brown and Uncle Sam ("The Forces Find Woman Has a Place") think that now woman can teach blind flying, solve cryptograms, run radar "and do almost anything else."

ON a winter afternoon of early 1937 in Somerville, Mass., a group of seven grammar school kids remained after the day's classes to scuffle around the gym floor with a basketball. It was the youngsters' first introduction to the game, and they found it vastly exciting. Next day they were back for more.

WASHINGTON, Jan 8 -- President Truman got what was for him a rousing reception to his State of the Union message which he delivered before a joint session of the Senate and House of Representatives Wednesday. He was interrupted by applause on an average of once a minute during his half-hour address.

Television will be used as a medium in starting the Salvation Army's 1949 annual maintenance appeal in New York, it was announced yesterday. The start will be at a meeting of several hundred campaign chairmen and volunteers next Wednesday in the Rainbow Room, RCA Building, 30 Rockefeller Center.

Nineteen Forty-nine will be a faster, but safer year in power-boating. The big event, of course, will be the International (Harmsworth) Trophy Race in Detroit in July. Already boat-owners have begun mulling over several "jokers" in the unique set-up of the Harmsworth race.

A balmy springlike Saturday came as a surprise to New Yorkers expecting January's worst. It readily turned men's thoughts toward a play-time summer ahead and let them imagine they were sniffing salt sea breezes, wearing yachting whites and twirling spokes of a steering wheel.

IN this country, it seems there only needs to be one vacant conductorial seat to precipitate a game of musical chairs. This year the scramble has begun early. For when it was announced that Dimitri Mitropoulos and Leopold Stokowski were to be the conductors of the New York Philharmonic-Symphony, it became known that Mr. Mitropoulos was leaving the Minneapolis Symphony.

An innovation at the show is a 21-foot stock cruiser that can be bought for either outboard or inboard power. It's one of the CruisAlong hulls with cabin and berths and is called the Converter because the buyer can operate with an outboard or install an inboard motor when he's ready for one.

AS one of those filmgoers who feel that the entire art of the motion picture can be saved from utter disaster only by the sort of freshness which such as Jean Cocteau can bring to it, I was rather dismayed by THE TIMES review of his latest film, "The Eagle With Two Heads."

THIS is a first novel by a 28year-old marine veteran who came home to write about the Negroes he knew in Texas instead of the fighting he had been through in the Pacific. Mr. Wilson was born in the Navasot and Brazos River country of Southeast Texas, and it is apparent he knows the region and its people well.

Cruise skippers of the New York Squadron, who have logged over 1,000 nautical miles on the last two cruises, have just been notified that this year's event will be arranged and conducted by Past Commander Ambrose Day.

A "fighter for teachers' rights," Miss Lucille Nicol, who has served the city's school system for fifty-one years, first as a teacher and then as an assistant superintendent, was honored yesterday by 1,100 colleagues at a golden anniversary luncheon in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

PRINCETON, N.J., Jan. 8 -- Taking advantage of 32 foul shots called against Navy, Princeton's varsity basketball team extended its undefeated home record tonight with a 52-44 decision over the middies before a capacity crowd of 3,200 in Dillon Gymnasium.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Jan. 8 -- His task simplified by the enforced withdrawal of heavily favored Marchons II, at Cat Bridge suddenly regained top form today and won the $11,700 Coral Gables Handicap by three lengths at Tropical Park.

AS many house plants begin to reach their peak of bloom, a humid atmosphere in home or apartment will help assure success. For the most meticulous schedule of feeding, watering and ventilation without drafts cannot make up for a lack of moisture in the air.

ONE never can be sure where the lightning will strike in this matter of dealing with provocative opinions and ideas. This department had expected to provoke much more controversy than it has by discussing John Chamberlain's bill of indictment against the treatment accorded the American business man in our fiction.

Many boxes and seats have been purchased for the Verdi Festival for the benefit of the Free Milk Fund for Babies, Inc., to be given on Tuesday night at the Metropolitan Opera House. The occasion will mark the twenty-second year of service of the fund of which Mrs. William Randolph Hearst is president and founder.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 (UP) -- Charlie (Choo Choo) Justice, North Carolina's all-America back, tonight received the Walter Camp Memorial football award. The award was presented to Justice at the fourteenth annual dinner of the Touchdown Club, which picked him as the player of the year.
Improved prospects for more imports of consumer goods this year were cited by executives of the import divisions of leading American retail stores in special statements to THE NEW YORK TIMES.

JOHN P. FRANK, an able craftsman of the law, now teaching at the University of Indiana, has an interesting way of writing about a judge and the law. The novelty of approach, stemming from Jerome Frank's important volume, "Law and the Modern Mind," assumes that law is written not on Sinai tablets but in the hearts and minds of men.

THE weight of evidence mounts that "Kiss Me, Kate" is a hit. Sent casually to Philadelphia for a three-and- a-half-week tryout, it ruined Christmas shopping there for everything else. Opening in New York ten days ago, it found the critics tossing not only the hat but the underlying toupee into the air. Since critics, like the fifty million Frenchmen, can't be wrong, "Kiss Me, Kate" is solid.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 8 (AP) -- Betty Skelton, 22-year-old pilot of Tampa, today set an unofficial national altitude record for light aircraft by climbing to 25,760 feet in a Piper PA-11 aircraft. The previous record of 24,400 feet was set before the war.

Three Negro colleges and a medical association have received, since 1945, $1,966,683 from the funds of the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis for the teaching and study of aspects of poliomyelitis, the foundation's division of interracial activities announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- Officials were hopeful today that a general acceptance of the United Nations order for a cessation of hostilities in Palestine would prevent any grave turn in that situation as a result of the shooting down of British fighter planes over Rafah, in the border area of Palestine and Egypt.

ROME, Jan. 8 -- The Repubblica d'Italia is the first extreme Left Wing Italian paper to comment on Secretary Marshall's resignation and Mr. Acheson's appointment. It paints Mr. Acheson as a hide-bound reactionary and clearly indicates that the Communists hardly think that from their point of view he is any improvement over Secretary Marshall.

AT the Willard Gallery this week has been assembled a group of contemporary abstract sculpture by regular exhibitors and three who are less familiar. It makes a balanced and attractive exhibition. While the particular experimental mood of the show has issue in work that is occasionally fitful and inconclusive, it also offers an adventurous and vital moment in today's sculpture doldrums.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- President Truman in a letter today to Senator Walter F. George of Georgia, chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, and Representative Robert L. Doughton of North Carolina, chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, urged action "at the earliest possible date" by Congress to restore the Reciprocal Trade Agreements Act to the full force of its original form and extend it to June 12, 1951.

The beginning of a new year, a new Congress and a new census leads me to ask permission to outline in your columns the present situation of a problem on which the country has worked at intervals since 1790, the problem of federal legislation dealing with the apportionment of seats in the House of Representatives among the states.
A second meeting of pro football club owners in an effort to settle their cold cash-war is a distinct probability for Chicago on or about Jan. 20.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Jan. 8 (AP) -- A historian reported evidence today that Abraham Lincoln had at least four White House secretaries. This would be one more than previously established. Jay Monaghan, Illinois State Historian and Lincoln authority, named the fourth man as Gustave E. Matile.

ALEX COMFORT, a young English intellectual who appears to have belief in nothing save the worth of the individual, has selected as protagonist of his novel an individual unlikely to arouse sympathy for his belief. In these times of encroachment by highly organized states and institutions, most of us welcome any voice raised on behalf of the unorganized and blessed perversity of the individual.

THE American Museum of Natural History, which for the past seven years has been presenting an annual free series called "Around the World with Dance and Song," under the direction of Hazel Lockwood Muller, will branch out next month with its first paid subscription series under the same title.

NANKING, Jan. 8 -- The Ambassadors of the United States, Britain, France and Russia were reported tonight to have communicated to their home capitals a message from the Chinese Foreign Ministry officially stating the Nanking Government's desire for peace with the Communists and asking the four powers to make known their attitudes on the knotty China question.

Bela Bartok's one-act opera "Bluebeard's Castle" was given its first American performance yesterday by the Dallas Symphony Orchestra, playing in Dallas. The hour-long work, capably conducted by Antal Dorati, was sung in English by Olga Ferrai, soprano, and Desire Ligeti, bass-baritone, and was heard as it was broadcast by NBC in its "Orchestras of the Nation" series.

THERE is a belief, especially on the part of wounded composers, that a new modern musical creation which goes uncomprehended by critics and audiences at a first hearing will, with repeated hearings by opaque-minded reviewers and audiences prove its merit and come into its own in the public consciousness.

Asserting that with the vast military expenditures proposed by President Truman in his message to Congress there can be no assurance of the passage of his social welfare program, the national executive committee of the Progressive party called upon the President yesterday to meet with Premier Stalin to negotiate the differences between the United States and Soviet Russia and end the "cold war."

HAS anybody seen Bob Wing? He has disappeared, and his brother, Christopher, is convinced that the police aren't trying to find him. Chris sets out to check the route Bob is believed to have followed on the day he left home. Chris meets with no success until he reaches the White Horse Tavern in the Finger Lakes region.

OPENING of the coaxial cable link joining the Eastern and Midwestern television networks will be celebrated on Tuesday with elaborate ceremonies beginning at 9:30 P.M. The presidents of the participating television chains, and Wayne Coy, chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, will speak and each of the networks will present a fifteen-minute sampling of its top-ranking talent.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- David E. Finley, director of the National Gallery of Art, today announced the acquisition of Murillo's canvas, "The Return of the Prodigal Son." The painting is being given to the gallery by the Avalon Foundation, through Mrs. Ailsa Mellon Bruce.

IN starting off his "The Unprejudiced Palate," Angelo Pellegrini quotes Dr. Johnson's remark that he could write a better book about cookery than ever was written, and one "upon philosophical principles." Well, the Grand Cham never did.

LOS ANGELES -- The beat of hooves at suburban Santa Anita and the gasps of the Los Angeles Open Golf gallery this week signified once again the "official" advent of California's winter recreational season.

Two men and a woman, arrested early yesterday morning on charges of passing counterfeit money in an East Side cafe, were released under bail after arraignment before United States Commissioner Garrett W. Cotter in Federal Court.

MIAMI BEACH -- The news from Florida's East Coast resorts is that there are fewer tourists here and that there should be adequate accommodations at moderate prices this season for all visitors. To prospective guests from the North this is cheering.

HOLLYWOOD. SESSUE HAYAKAWA, whose Hollywood salary in 1917 and 1918 was $6,000 a week, as he remembers it, came back to town last Monday after a fifteen-year absence to play the villain in "Tokyo Joe," with Humphrey Bogart, at Columbia.

OMAHA, Jan. 8 -- A rip-roaring blizzard, the opening of Legislatures in most states and the marshaling of farm strength behind the 90 per cent price-support formula ran closely behind the opening of Congress in conversational ranking throughout the Midwest this week.

TORONTO, Jan. 8 (AP) -- The Toronto Maple Leafs moved into a fourth-place tie with the Canadiens in the National Hockey League race tonight when they came from behind to earn a 3-3 tie with the third-place Chicago Black Hawks. It was the seventh tie for the Leafs this season and the third for the Hawks.

THE Southern cook simmers a fowl, serves it with creamy gravy and fluffy dumplings, and you have a great regional dish -- old-fashioned chicken stew. The French housewife cooks cubed lamb with meat stock and vegetables and ends up with the sort of ragout -- or stew -- to which poems have been penned.

Athenagoras I, Patriarch-elect of the Greek Orthodox Church, will be enthroned in Istanbul, Turkey, on Jan. 21 and became Ecumenical Patriarch of the Greek or Eastern Orthodox, Churches throughout the world. His title will be Archbishop of Constantinople, New Rome and Ecumenical Patriarch.

Vin Lombardi, first assistant football coach at Fordham, who had been prominently mentioned as a possible successor to Ed Danowski as head coach, yesterday resigned his position at Rose Hill to accept an offer as assistant to Earl (Red) Blaik at Army.

There is a seagoing branch of the Girl Scouts of the U.S.A., known as the Mariner Scouts, which has adapted its regular Girl Scout program to seaworthy projects, sea lore, the "shanty" song, and sailing. The 7,149 Mariners from all over the country are Senior Girl Scouts from 14 to 17 years of age. They wear a royal blue uniform topped with a white sailor hat when on Mariner duty.

UNTIL a full examination has been made by the Civil Aeronautics Board, no one can be sure of the cause of the airplane crash in Seattle last week that took the lives of three crew members and eleven Yale University students.

MANY good scholars leave behind a filing case of half-prepared notes for the last book that never gets written. Edith Rickert, the eminent Chaucerian at the University of Chicago, was no exception. At the time of her death in 1938 she had assembled a vast amount of material from medieval documents -- much of it never previously published -- to illustrate the day-by- day life of Chaucerian England.
THIS week sees the return of the new New York City Ballet Company to the City Center for its first season independent of the New York City Opera Company.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Jan. 8 -- Center Walter Ashbaugh caged 16 points as Cornell's quintet broke a tie with four minutes remaining to hand Harvard its second Eastern League loss, 51 -- 42, before approximately 1,400 in Harvard's indoor athletic building tonight.

Mrs. Lila Tyng and Mrs. Richardson Pratt are co-chairmen of the hostess committee for the three-day preview of the exhibition of paintings by Edna Reindel, which will open on Jan. 24 at the Macbeth Gallery, East Fifty-seventh Street, for the benefit of the Spence-Chapin Adoption Service.

The nomination of a Californian (by adoption) as president of the American Power Boat Association is a tribute to the position Western inboard, outboard and power cruiser racing has attained in the past two decades. It is the first time in the forty-five-year history of the Association that the West has been accorded this recognition.

President Truman's "State of the Union" message was praised yesterday by Rabbi Louis I. Newman in Temple Rodeph Sholom, 7 West Eighty-third Street, for opening up "vistas of enlarging opportunity, stability and progress in this country and elsewhere."

Each year that the Coast Guard is invited to place an exhibit in the Motor Boat Show the officer designated chairman of the exhibit committee calls together heads of departments whose activities in connection with boating merit their representation.
During the temporary absence of Catherine Mackenzie, her column is being conducted by Mr. Frank, director of the Caroline Zachry Institute of Human Development.
The National Soccer Coaches Association selected a 26-member All-America squad yesterday and named the University of Connecticut as the nation's outstanding college team for 1948.

OLIVET, Mich., Jan. 8 -- Dr. Tucker P. Smith, Vice Presidential candidate last fall on the Socialist party ticket, received a notice of dismissal today from James F. Mathias, dean of Olivet College. He is an economics instructor.

BERLIN, Jan. 8 -- The political complexions of the German press in regard to the replacement of Secretary of State George C. Marshall by Dean Atcheson inevitably dictated the tone of the opinions expressed as to the possible future significance in United states policy.

A NEW-TYPE camera, the Vidax, which combines the features of the rollfilm and press types, is announced by the Vidmar Camera Company, 282 West Twenty-fifth Street. Price of the camera, depending on the lens supplied, ranges from $267 to $326.

During the summer of 1940 we made an extensive survey of the habits of the New York yachtsman to determine where he went on his annual cruise, and when he went there. The results were subsequently published in THE NEW YORK TIMES.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- The Administration's draft of legislation to carry out President Truman's anti-inflation program was expected today to be sent to Congress next week.

Twenty-three newspaper publishers and editors representing twelve states will attend a three-week seminar on the problems of newspaper publishing that opens at Columbia's American Press Institute tomorrow, Floyd Taylor, director, announced yesterday.

There is general agreement, even among the most ardent advocates of low-rent public housing, that our main reliance to meet the housing shortage must be on private industry. Our neighboring states, and even the nation as a whole, will watch with deep interest the steps taken by Governor Dewey as he assumes leadership in a broad program to construct homes costing about $7,000.
LONDON, Jan. 8 (Reuters) -- Results of football games in Britain today:
Modern boys and girls are too ambitious, concludes a report made public yesterday by the counseling and employment service of the Children's Aid Society.

BERLIN, Jan. 8 -- After three and a half years service abroad, Jack Bennett, chief of the Finance Division of the American Military Government, will leave Berlin next Saturday to return to the United States. His departure will leave vacant one of the most important posts in the Military Government nominations for which are not expected until an official announcement is made, within the next few days, of his withdrawal.

LONDON, Jan. 8 -- British Dominion High Commissioners for Australia, New Zealand, India, Pakistan and Ceylon called on Foreign Secretary Ernest Bevin today and delivered a statement advising that Britain's hands-off policy in the Dutch-Indonesian strife might play into Communist hands.

LONDON, Jan. 8 (UP) -- British Commonwealth representatives today urged the British Government to take the initiative in creating some form of Eastern Union to prevent the spread of communism in Asia, similar to the Western Union in Europe, it was learned.

Debutantes of this season headed by Miss Julia Beals are aiding Mrs. Harold Ruckman Mixsell and members of the executive committee in the sale of tickets for the performance of "Kiss Me, Kate," the new musical production, tomorrow night at the Century Theatre.

LAKE SUCCESS, Jan. 8 -- Arthur Lourie, Israeli Consul General and head of the Israeli United Nations office here, refused tonight to transmit to his government in Tel Aviv the official British protest note about the shooting down of British planes near or over Egyptian territory.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 8 -- When California, even rugged northern California, shamefacedly pleads guilty to having the lowest January temperatures in the nation; when nonplussed residents find their water pipes and automobile radiators frozen; when record low thermometer readings are reflected at once in higher citrus prices, other domestic and world happenings find a meager place in the West Coast's thinking.

ABOUT this time of year most gardeners are feeling pretty pleased with themselves. They have mulched, provided protection wherever necessary and are now sitting back, enjoying their leisure. These, then, are the hours when a plan, at least, could be made to reclaim those bare and ugly spots in the garden.

THIS is a picture of China -- the China which has now become a focal point in the world struggle -- a vast problem that calls for close study, especially by Americans, for we are deeply concerned with the present and the future of the country.
EAST HAMPTON, L. I., Jan. 8 -- This week the second of East Hampton's two gondolas was trundled through Main Street to a new resting place.

With reference to the double crostic in your Dec. 19 issue, perhaps I am mistaken and Edith Wharton did write something called "The Valley of Decision," but that title is certainly associated with Marcia Davenport, and I suspect that it is actually an error * * *.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- The health and hospitalization project of the United Mine Workers Welfare and Retirement Fund is now in operating order, John L. Lewis, UMW president, reported today.

MONTREAL, Jan. 8 (AP) -- The Detroit Red Wings racked up two goals in the first period tonight against the Montreal Canadiens and then coasted to a 4-1 victory over the Montrealers. The winners regained undisputed possession of first place in the National Hockey League.

A new measurement of the earth's distance from the sun, based on more than 5,000 observations of the moon, comes from Prof. Dirk Brouwer, director of the Yale University, Observatory. His figure is 92,960,000 miles, subject to an uncertainty of not more than 35,000 miles.

The reduction of $21,500,000 annually in electric rates that goes into effect tomorrow for customers of the Consolidated Edison Company of New York -- the largest single rate reduction in the state's history -- will be fought with every legal weapon the utility can muster.
RICHMOND, Va., Jan. 8 -- Residents of the Upper South kept their thoughts pretty well focused on their legislators this week.

I liked Dr. Lawton's article "Proof That She Is the Stronger Sex" (Dec. 12) in spite of the fact it makes my sex look like a tribe of parasites. I liked it because I would like to see my husband change his ways and stop competing, at the expense of his health and peace of mind, with every man around, for more money, a fancier house and a big shiny car. * * *
CHICAGO, Jan. 8 -- The Chicago Cardinals may invade the lair of their crosstown rivals, the Bears, and try to lasso Luke Johnsos as their head coach to succeed Jimmy Conzelman.

HANOVER, N.H. Jan. 8 -- While a capacity crowd of more than 3,000 held its breath, Columbia's Negro forward, Norman Skinner, dropped in two foul shots to give the Lions a 50-48 victory over Dartmouth tonight.

Robert Villemain is flying back to his native France Tuesday, bruised and battered, disillusioned after the savage beating he absorbed in his American ring debut. His confidence, however, is unshaken and he is eager to come back for a return battle with his conqueror, the balding Steve Belloise.

An expanded program of adult education is planned for New York City under the sponsorship of the New York Adult Education Council, it became known last week. The council, headed by Dean Harry J. Carman of Columbia College, is engaged in an active campaign to raise the educational standards among adults in the metropolitan area.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., Jan. 8 -- The startling growth of farmer petroleum cooperatives within the last ten years is revealed in a compilation of production figures presented this week to a meeting here of the National Cooperative Oil Committee.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Jan. 8 (AP) -- The St. Louis University Billikens continued their merry way as the nation's leading basketball power tonght with a 64-55 victory over Canisius, but they had trouble most of the way. A sell-out crowd of 11,538 jammed Memorial Auditorium for the fray.

The domestic steel industry does not share the alarm over the present steel supply situation that President Truman expressed last week in his State of the Union message to Congress. Nor do steel leaders endorse the President's suggestion that the Government enter the Steel business if it is concluded that private industry is not expanding sufficiently.

FRANKFORT, Jan. 8 -- The Germans reacted to the Ruhr internationalization statute pretty much like a man who has caught his finger in a door. They let out a deafening roar of woe, but so far there is no sign that they are going to try to break the door down. Instead, while still muttering angrily, most of them realize that they saw it coming.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- A trial examiner for the National Labor Relations Board found today that a strike against Oppenheim Collins Co., New York, for recognition was a violation of the Taft-Hartley Law in view of the board's certification of another union as exclusive bargaining union.
ALBANY, Jan. 8 -- New York state may have established during 1948 one of its lowest motor-vehicle death tolls in modern history, Motor Vehicle Commissioner Clifford J. Fletcher said today.

A total of $596.17, representing forty-seven contributions, was received yesterday by The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund. The thirty-seventh annual appeal has thus far attracted 11,046 donations aggregating $338,470.79.

A belated Christmas and New Year's party, operated and financed entirely by teen agers of New York's crowded West Side just off Times Square, was held yesterday afternoon for fifty orphans and children from broken homes.

Because 1948 has passed without any progress made in securing Federal aid for the improvement of Jones Inlet, Fire Island Inlet, Moriches and Shinnecock Inlets, the committee on ports and waterways of the Long Island Association will shortly hold a meeting to consider action on these projects as well as several others in Long Island's waters.

MIAMI -- More than 150 charter boats will render navigable waters around Miami unsafe this winter for any marine life except a barracuda with a lively pick-up. The boats that draw little water will be poking their bows down through the Florida keys.

PITTSFIELD, Mass. -- Since the first snow train arrived in the Berkshire Mountains in 1935, this area has come a long way. Today the Berkshire winter playground, only three hours from New York and less than four from Boston, has thirty-nine ski tows, one Alpine lift, several new canteens, parking areas, inns and restaurants all waiting to welcome skiers.

The informality shown by Brooklyn students toward their teachers, which at times may prompt them to say, "Hello, how are you ?" has amazed two students from Iceland and Norway who are here to study the American way of life.

Try Cob's Ace High, a 9-month-old solid black cocker spaniel owned and handled by Mrs. R. Kenneth Cobb of Whitehouse, N.J., gained a victory of considerable moment yesterday when he took the Futurity Stake that featured the opening program of the thirty-second annual national specialty of the American Spaniel Club at the Hotel Roosevelt.

SEOUL, Korea, Jan. 8 (UP) -- The Emergency Guard's tactics chief, Choi Chi Whan, said today that three Russian submarines had surfaced off South Korea four days ago and signalled Communist guerrillas to launch an attack on the provisional capital of Cheju.

John S. Radosta's article, "Bastogne: '44-'48," has quite noticeably neglected to mention that Combat Command B of the 10th Armored Division fought in Bastogne together with troops of the 101st Airborne Division.

SAVANNAH, Ga., Jan. 8 -- The judicial and the executive branches of the Federal Government captured the attention of the South this week with actions involving Dixie's attitudes on labor and racial relations.

ATLANTA, Ga., Jan. 8 -- The Congress of Industrial Organizations' "revitalized" campaign to organize the workers of the South formally got under way today with a notice to Southern industry that "the jig is up and you can have organization the reasonable way or the hard way, but you must make your choice."

Symbolic of the world's speedboat classic is the British International Trophy Race to be held in Detroit on July 29 and 30. The country first winning two heats will be proclaimed the winner of the trophy. In the event of a tie between two countries, there will be a special elimination run on Aug. 1 to determine the winner.

PITTSFIELD, Mass. -- Since the first snow train arrived in the Berkshire Mountains in 1935, this area has come a long way. Today the Berkshire winter playground, only three hours from New York and less than four from Boston, has thirty-nine ski tows, one Alpine lift, several new canteens, parking areas, inns and restaurants all waiting to welcome skiers.

The informality shown by Brooklyn students toward their teachers, which at times may prompt them to say, "Hello, how are you ?" has amazed two students from Iceland and Norway who are here to study the American way of life.

Try Cob's Ace High, a 9-month-old solid black cocker spaniel owned and handled by Mrs. R. Kenneth Cobb of Whitehouse, N.J., gained a victory of considerable moment yesterday when he took the Futurity Stake that featured the opening program of the thirty-second annual national specialty of the American Spaniel Club at the Hotel Roosevelt.

Rapidly developing buyers' markets in one industry after another have forced many business organizations to begin "drastic shakeups" of top executives, W. Gail Camp, board member of the Association of Private Office Personnel Agencies, disclosed in an interview last week.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Jan. 8 -- In the feature event of its first big day on the winter sports program, Army lost its basketball game to Brown University today, 47 -- 42, blowing a lead that went as high as 33 -- 20 six minutes after the second half got under way.

OF all the continents, Africa presents the most Janus-like visage to the world. South of the Sahara its fledgling communities and untapped territories have still to reach maturity. North of that line, especially in the thin green ribbon along the coast, Africa's past recedes into the farthest vastnesses of recorded time.

YOUR article, "The Radio Essay," somewhat overstates the case. While radio has never been overly hospitable to gifted conversationalists, it has welcomed at least a few others to the microphone in addition to Alexander Woollcott and J.B. Priestley.

LONDON, Jan. 8 -- Government sources confirmed today the fact that the Government has promised to allow the Great Universal Stores, Ltd., one of Britain's largest chain store and mail order houses, to acquire $750,000 to purchase an interest in department stores in the United States.

BRIGID KNIGHT'S latest novel falls automatically into the Good Works division. With some gentle philosophy, a number of authentic pictures of her chosen territory and any amount of goodwill, she sets out to explain the ingredients of South African feeling toward Britain.
With a moderate volume of business, the cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange lost 8 to 24 points net yesterday, with the far months weakest.

OLD FORGE, N.Y., Jan. 8 -- Rising temperatures that softened the new four-inch snow surface on an eight-inch base made for tricky skiing today at this pioneer central Adirondack center. The fact that running on both trails and slopes was available was something that the rest of the Eastern United States would have been thrilled to tell about.

THEY will be rolling out the red carpet in Madison Square Garden on Tuesday in order to make a low bow in the direction of Nat Holman, the dean of the basketball coaches in point of service if not in age. For thirty seasons the man they call Mr. Basketball has been directing the Busy Beavers of City College -- and doing a bang-up job of it.

Power boat racing in its early days was a sport that only the very wealthy could afford. The names of owners of speed boats could be found in the Social Register more often than not. In 1904 the Vingt-et-Un, fastest Gold Cup craft of its day, had a top speed of 25.3 miles per hour.

CLIFTON, N.J., Jan. 8 -- International problems constituting threats to peace in all parts of the world were topics of panel discussion and study groups today at the seventeen semi-annual conference of the New Jersey International Relations Forum at Clifton High School here.

SALT LAKE CITY, Jan. 8 -- Snow and state politics figured argest in mountain region thoughts this week. As travel unsnarled after the winter's worst blizzard, observers became increasingly aware of potential legislative tangles in the wake of November's election upsets.

CHILDREN who have so delightedly come across Miss Coatsworth's poems in her story books will be especially pleased with this new collection of poems about things they like: polar bears and kangaroos; wind, rain and snow; trains and engine's bells, and other things within their ken.

WITH "Lend an Ear" likely to fill the National Theatre for months to come, William Eythe and Franklin Gilbert, two of the hit musical's producers, are turning to independent film production, it was learned last week. The project is "The Perfect Round," a novel by Henry Morton Robinson, which the pair plan to film here in its entirety.

Sergio Osmena Jr., son of the late President of the Philippines, has been named president of the De La Rama Steamship Company, it was announced yesterday. Mr. Osmena is in New York and has taken charge of the company's office here. It is the only Philippine- flag line maintaining regular service between the Far East and the United States.
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 8 -- The Freedom Train returned today for a final, six-day visit to the city whence it set out on its inspiring odyssey sixteen months ago.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Jan. 8 -- With Co-Captain Bob Kelly providing most of the spark when they needed it, the Kelly Greens of Manhattan went on a second-half spree to down the Hofstra five by 73 to 60 in Calkins Gymnasium tonight.
New Yorkers basked in spring-like weather yesterday while many sections in the western half of the nation were in the grip of a new blizzard and an accompanying cold wave.
TRENTON, Jan. 8 -- Numerous controversial issues will confront Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll and the New Jersey Legislature when its 1949 session convenes at noon Tuesday.

LONDON, Jan. 8 -- When the Dutch moved swiftly last month to clean up the Republic of Indonesia there was angry reaction in the United Nations. For twenty-four hours the Netherlands appeared to have no friend in the whole world.

THE hound-dog of the title of Fred Gipson's contagiously funny novel is a Texas version of Rousseau's "noble savage." Though he is not a redskin, he is one of nature's finest. He lives, till a woman's wits trap him into love (or, in any event, marriage), a free existence in the woods, suitably scornful of book larnin' and of daily-breaders who slave at the same routine every day.

I strenuously object to Arthur Daley's denunciation of skiing in "Which Sport? Survey of a Paramount Issue."*** I always thought a sports writer would be interested in all athletics. Certainly skiing is the last that should be attacked, as it is one of the most cleanly conducted and beneficial sports, whereas in baseball -- which Mr. Daley praises -- there may be 50,000 shuffling, pushing, swearing spectators and only a score or so participants.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 7 -- The Boston University Hockey team scored its sixth victory of the season tonight, defeating Yale, 7 to 2. The game was rough throughout as fourteen penalties were assessed. Red Czarnota and Goalie Jim Burns were guilty of fighting in the second period and both were banished for the balance of the game.
LONDON, Jan. 8 (AP) -- The Manchester United eleven routed Bournemouth, 6 to 0, today and moved into the fourth round of the Football Association Cup tournament.

ALTHOUGH the tone of Jean Giraudoux's "The Madwoman of Chaillot" is gay and some of the scenes are hilarious, the impression it leaves is strangely moving. Amid the normal brummagem of Broadway, it speaks a few words of the immortal truth with candor and simplicity.
Rex Harrison asks, "Could it be possible to finance through outside sources, stock companies in the major American cities?"

A George III mahogany break-front bookcase, which sold for $1,400, and a Hepplewhite inlaid mahogany swell-front sideboard, which brought $1,050, were among articles of eighteenth century furniture in several collections sold at auction yesterday in the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 30 East Fifty-seventh Street.

Today the United States is the greatest recreational maritime nation in history. On Jan. 1, 1949 we had in the United States about 440,000 Coast Guard numbered motor boats of 16 feet, 3,540 documented yachts and literally millions of unnumbered boats, of all sizes, operating out of the domain of Coast Guard regulations.
THE Caribbean islands, that strange collection of exotic places scattered in a blue-green sea, are at last beginning to attract their full share of winter vacationists.

SO many times has the Napoleon story been told, there is small excuse for a retelling that does not develop some relevant detail, unless one is prepared to write interpretive prose rather than history. (In the late Mr. Ludwig's celebrated biography, interpretive writing went rather far to prove the writer's inability, to understand his protagonist -- precisely the danger in that type of book, which too often becomes a foolish exercise in author-egoism.)

There is no indication whatever that the essentials of American foreign policy will change because there has been a change in personalities in the State Department. Secretary Marshall is laying down his duties because he is not now physically able to carry them on.
The Palisades Interstate Park Commission, which pioneered public marinas in this area more than twenty-five years ago, had its boating facilities filled to capacity again during 1948.
ROSLYN, L. I., Jan. 9 -- Another landmark of the once-fabulous Harbor Hill estate of the late Clarence Mackay -- the huge glass-roofed indoor court tennis building -- vanished tonight.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 -- The Army's suspension of draft calls for February and March, admittedly because of the high rate of voluntary enlistments, offers "final proof" that Selective Service and universal military training were not necessary, the National Council Against Conscription said today.

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N. Y., Jan. 9 -- This was to have been the big day of the year for skiers, but they just stood around in their ski suits glowering at the green lawn outside the inn while the hikers and fishermen poured into Bear Mountain Park from buses, trains and automobiles.
PEIPING, Jan. 9 (AP) -- Reports from Tientsin said there were clashes around the city today and that the east railway station was hit by more than ten Communist shells.
A behind-the-scenes trade war in the record-producing industry, which eventually will involve the nation's 16,000,000 owners of record-playing machines, broke out into the open yesterday.

Wild game birds are not truly such when bought in a city store; laws prevent the selling of real wild game birds. Rather, the birds come from farms where they have been allowed to be just about as "wild" as a chicken or turkey.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 -- The National Negro Council called upon President Truman today to issue an Executive Order before his inauguration on Jan. 20 outlawing segregation in the capital.

ALBANY, Jan. 9 -- An emergency statewide committee of public library trustees has been formed to rally all trustees in the state and friends of the public libraries to obtain immediate state aid for the libraries, it was announced here today.

FORT KNOX, Ky., Jan. 9 -- In the rolling hills near Louisville this post, headquarters of the Armored Center, now has -- with some 27,000 soldiers and 4,000 to 5,000 civilians -- the largest population of any continental Army post.

"The Rape of Lucretia" winds up an engagement of twenty-three performances next Sunday night at the Ziegfeld. The withdrawal is attributed to "the present slump in theatre interest [which] makes it financially unfeasible to keep the musical production running," according to its sponsors, Marjorie and Sherman Ewing and Giovanni Cardelli.

DETROIT, Jan. 9 (AP) -- The Detroit Red Wings came from behind with a goal in each of the last two periods tonight to tie Toronto, 2 to 2, and retain sole possession of the National Hockey League lead. A. crowd of 14,791 saw the game.
CHICAGO, Jan. 9 -- Salaries of state legislators have been increased in at least sixteen states in the past two years, the Council of State Governments reported today.

WARSAW, Jan. 9 -- Although one-third of its membership now is drawn from the former Polish Socialist party, the new Polish United Workers party will maintain its full position in the Communist Information Bureau headed by the former Communist party.

Benjamin Britten's "Peter Grimes," which was added to the Metropolitan Opera repertory last year, will have its first performance of this season on Jan. 21 in the company's eighth week, starting Jan. 17. In a cast, which essentially duplicates last year's, Lawrence Tibbett will sing his first Captain Balstrode and Margaret Harshaw her first Auntie.

Advertising in New York City daily newspapers totaled 150,018,903 lines during 1948 compared with 141,560,517 during 1947, an increase of 5.9 per cent, according to an analysis of Media Records issued over the week-end. All categories showed increases except financial advertising, which declined 0.16 per cent in the year.

The city's vast post-war program of arterial highways, estimated three years ago to cost $429,000,000, has been cut virtually in half, mostly because of rising costs of material, equipment and labor, Robert Moses, City Construction Coordinator, declared yesterday.

ALBANY, Jan. 9 -- Thomas A. Murray and Harold Hanover, president and secretary, respectively, of the State Federation of Labor, announced today their opposition to an all-private carrier system of financing disability insurance. Governor Dewey has been reported to favor such a plan.

The American International Singers will contribute a group of songs at the concert for civil and human rights to be given by Miss Carol Brice, Negro contralto, at Carnegie Hall Feb. 2, it was announced yesterday.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Jan 9 -- There are two approaches to Palestine and this correspondent has tried both. One is to fly in from the outside and survey with outsiders a scene on opposite sides of a wall that divides and shadows but can never separate the two peoples involved.
ATLANTA, Jan. 9 (AP) -- The Congress of Industrial Organizations hammered out a plan today to capture the South's non-union workers by drives in the major industry in each of eleven states.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 9 -- A 12-year-old boy was found murdered this morning behind a garage in the Wynnefield section of Philadelphia. He had been slashed with scissors, beaten and bound with clothesline.
Plenty of spring chicken within the price range of lower-income families was predicted yesterday at the New York Poultry Show by John Kriner Sr., veteran poultry breeder of Stetlersville, Pa.

CHICAGO, Jan. 9 -- The grain markets had a heavy undertone on the Board of Trade late last week. Liquidation developed in soy beans, and wheat and corn weakened in sympathy. However, corn showed considerable resistance to selling pressure, due in large measure to the removal of hedges against sales of the actual grain to the Government.
AMSTERDAM, Jan. 9 -- The Netherlands' military action in Indonesia, contrary to expectations, had only a moderate effect on Amsterdam Stock Exchange.
GENEVA, Jan. 9 -- A great improvement in the condition of Europe's railway rolling stock is reported by the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe in the figures released here today.
PARIS, Jan. 9 -- Two events illustrating the shortage of gold and hard currencies in France were noted by financial circles here last week. Both have more than local meaning.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 (UP)-Staff investigators for a Congressional committee have given high praise to the labor relations of the Tennessee Valley Authority, it was disclosed today.

NEWPORT, R. I., Jan. 9 -- In the largest movement of personnel at this naval base since the war, 1,900 reservists from the northeastern section of the country arrived today to embark in eight warships for a two-week training cruise in Caribbean waters.

The Rev. James Pike, rector of the Protestant Episcopal Christ Church in Poughkeepsie, N. Y., has been named chaplain of Columbia University, Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, president of the university, announced yesterday. The appointment will become effective Sept. 1.

Unless the Marshall Plan nations unite their economies, they face the threat of reduced standards of living and possible conquest by Communist fifth columns, William C. Bullitt, former United States Ambassador to Russia and France, declares in a preface to a pamphlet on the proposed federation of Western Europe published yesterday by New York University.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 -- The State Department in a recent policy statement, said this country favored eventual return of the Ruhr industries to denazified non-cartel German owners, it was learned today.

Prominent in a week of some two dozen new art exhibitions are revivals of two foreign reputations -- that of Jose Maria Valasco, the nineteenth century Mexican, in a show of his paintings and drawings opening at the Brooklyn Museum tomorrow, and the first postwar exhibition of the Belgian Frans Masereel's paintings and graphic work.

THE query propounded in the letter was a teaser. What made it all the more intriguing was that it came from Berlin and from a chap who knew what he was talking about. The question-popper was Drew Middleton, the chief Berlin correspondent of this newspaper and a reformed sports journalist. But before we get around to the answer, if any, the proper procedure would be to start with Drew's Information, Please, request. He writes:

TEL AVIV, Israel, Jan. 9 -- British arms deliveries to Egypt during the last few months have amounted to 50,000,000 [$200,000,000] and included shipment of the most modern design jet fighters, according to a reliable source close to the Israeli Government.

Dr. Paul H. Linehan, for nearly forty-six years a member of the mathematics department at City College and former director of its evening session, will retire on Feb. 1, it was announced yesterday. Dr. Linehan will reach the mandatory retirement age of 70 next Saturday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 -- The Congress of Industrial Organizations today released its proposals for a Federal tax program. Its blueprint calls for a drastic shift in the burden from the low and middle incomes to corporation profits and high personal incomes.

Your editorial comment on the tragic case of Laurence Duggan, published in your issue of Dec. 23, during my absence from the country, has just come to my attention. As your references to me are based on inferences and assumptions not warranted by the record and which do me an injustice, I hope you will permit me to set forth the facts.

MOUNT HOPE, N. Y., Jan 9 -Ross Tarlton's Hamilton, Ont., rink retained the Douglas Medal in the season's outstanding bonspiel on the St. Andrews Golf Club curling calendar by turning back the Ardsley Club No. 2 foursome, skipped by George Ogden, 17 to 8, in the 14-end final-round this afternoon.

Two salient facts emerge from the annual report of Dr. Harry S. Mustard, Health Commissioner, on his department's public health activities during 1948. The first is a clear indication that the city can save more lives by expanding its health services for infants.

LONDON, Jan. 9 -- Although President Truman's message to Congress has had little or no immediate effect on the financial or commercial markets in London, it has formed a lively topic of conversation and argument in the City.

PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., Jan. 9 -- Picking up the eighteenth annual frostbite regatta, which was blasted and washed away after one race last week-end, the winter sailors assembled again today at the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club. They dropped their dinghies overboard into smooth water and a gentle easterly breeze and went through seven contests.
This week's scheduled municipal financing amounts to $92,264,980, compared with $44,057,480 last week, according to The Bond Buyer.

There were 27,658 reported cases of infantile paralysis in 1948, the second highest figure in the history of the disease in the United States, a statistical study by the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis showed yesterday. In fighting the disease, the organization spent an estimated $17,000,000 from the March of Dimes.

WEST ORANGE, N. J., Jan. 9 -- From the front, the eight-room brick and stucco house at 8 Clearview Terrace here looks no different than its well-groomed neighbors. Even on the inside it seems far from out of the ordinary. But that might be a tribute to the craftsmanship of Earl Eby, whose ingenuity would tax the abilities of a latter-day Swiss Family Robinson.

CHICAGO, Jan. 9 -- A 22,000,000 volt betatron, science's newest source of high energy X-rays and electrons, will be delivered on Tuesday to the campus of the University of Illinois College of Medicine, on Chicago's West Side, for use in cancer treatment and research.
SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 9 (AP) -A permanent site for football's projected Hall of Fame will be chosen this year.

Bank stockholders should be alerted to the "ever-increasing" demands on Congress for greater power by bank regulatory bodies N. Baxter Jackson, chairman of the Chemical Bank and Trust Company, asserted in his annual report published today.

Msgr. John S. Middleton, education secretary for the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York, yesterday condemned "mercy killings" as "murder." Preaching at solemn mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral, at which Cardinal Spellman presided, Msgr. Middleton declared that the 379 Protestant and Jewish clergymen who recently called on the State Legislature to enact a law permitting voluntary euthanasia were disobedient to the law of God.

Appeals to Henry Morgenthau Jr. urging that he return to the leadership of the United Jewish Appeal were made public yesterday by Milton Kahn, president of the Associated Jewish Philantropies of Boston and chairman of a committee that would draft Mr. Morgenthau for the chairmanship of the 1949 drive.
Frank Vincent DuMond, one of the grand old men of American painting and for many years an instructor at the Art Students League, yesterday looked down the vista of the generations he had taught.

LONDON, Jan. 9 -- Immediate action on the part of the United Nations Security Council in dealing with the situation created by the shooting down of British planes by Israeli forces is to be demanded by Britain, it was learned authoritatively tonight.

Prices of cotton in the domestic market continued mixed last week and closed the period with moderate losses. Active futures on the New York Cotton Exchange at the week's end were 10 to 23 points lower than the week before. In the preceding holiday week the market had advanced 7 to 19 points.

The New York University-Bellevue Medical Center has received a gift "in excess of $8,000,000" from the Samuel H. Kress Foundation, Dr. Harry Woodburn Chase, university chancellor, announced yesterday.
OLD FORGE, N. Y., Jan. 9 -This central Adirondack vacationland echoed the gayety of 500 skiers today as the first snow train of the season arrived from Rochester.

The twenty-second annual report of the General American Investors Company, Inc., issued for publication today by Frank Altschul, chairman, and Harold F. Linder, president, shows that net assets, as of Dec. 31, 1948, amounted to $34,714,682. This was after deducting dividends of $3,278,183.

ALBANY, Jan. 9 -- The Democratic legislative program, particularly the parts calling for additional spending by the state, was denounced here today as demagogic and reckless by Speaker Oswald D. Heck of the Assembly and Senator Benjamin F. Feinberg, Republican Majority Leader of the Senate.

PARIS, Jan. 9 -- Likening the present close French-American economic relationship to that of the war period, Ambassador Jefferson Caffrey said today that both nations were fully engaged "in a battle for economic liberation and lasting peace."

Fifteen schools and eleven churches of five Protestant denominations held yesterday the first in a series of three vesper services at St. James Protestant Episcopal Church, Madison Avenue at Seventy-first Street.

LAKE SUCCESS, Jan. 9 -- The United States Government was urged today by the American Association for the United Nations to take the lead at Tuesday's meeting of the Security Council in condemning the Netherlands Government for what it termed a deliberately planned coup in Indonesia.

American generosity and British steadfastness have done much to save the world from disaster and lead it on to a better age, Sir Francis Evans, British consul general in New York, said yesterday at the annual Epiphany festival service of the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest, Fifth Avenue and Ninetieth Street.
The number of accidents to workers reported last year by employers in this state reached a high record of 818,694, the New York State Workmen's Compensation Board said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 -- The injunction weapon in national emergency disputes helped in some cases but further study of the problem is warranted, the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service implied today in its first annual report as an independent agency.

The left-wing United Office and Professional Workers, threatened with loss of its Congress of Industrial Organizations charter for lack of organizing effectiveness, called on its 34,000 members yesterday to set up a $100,000 "fighting fund" to protect the union and extend its membership.
BERLIN, Jan. 9 (Reuters) -- German audiences like American drama. Their first post-war reaction to plays from abroad was suspicion, then surprise, and now enthusiasm.

PARIS, Jan. 9 -- A new portent of conflict within the Cabinet came in the national council of the Popular Republican party today when Georges Bidault, at a secret session, was understood to have given an account of his recent meeting with Charles de Gaulle.
MALONE, N. Y., Jan. 9 (AP) -- Joe, a robin stranded in this bleak Canadian-border village and buffeted by wintry blasts, began his fastest flight south today -- on a Colonial Airlines luxury plane.

The New Friends of Music entered the second half of its season late yesterday afternoon when it presented its ninth concert of its 1948-49 schedule at Town Hall. The program consisted of one part Mozart to two parts Brahms.

The Rev. Dr. Wallace Woodsome Robbins, president of Meadville Theological School at the Univevsity of Chicago, yesterday morning advised Christians to "stop polishing God's apple by posing as do-gooders." He preached at the Unitarian Church of All Souls, Lexington Avenue and Eightieth Street.

Rugged individualism, which was the outstanding feature of American life in the nineteenth century, is fast disappearing and standardization is taking its place, the Rev. Dr. Robert James McCracken, pastor of Riverside Church, 122d Street and Riverside Drive, declared yesterday on "The Peril of Conformity."

VIENNA, Jan. 9 -- Peace treaty or no peace treaty, Austria will hold general elections in the autumn of this year, and Chancellor Leopold Figl began today the election campaign for his People's party with a speech in which he announced the party would never forget in its campaign against its Socialist coalition partner the concept of "fair play."

Ray Blum of the Paterson Skating Club will head the parade in the Race of Champions, grand finale of the annual Silver Skates competition at Madison Square Garden tonight. The program is the twenty-fifth sponsored by The Daily News Welfare Association.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 9 -Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer has switched Spencer Tracy's schedule to make "Operation Malaya," which the studio recently acquired from RKO, his next assignment. The picture will start early in March with Edwin Knopf producing, and Tracy will play an Alcatraz prisoner who was released by Government order during the war because of his knowledge of the Malay Peninsula to go to Malaya to obtain rubber for the Allies.

Buyers who visited the wholesale apparel market here last week showed less caution in placing orders for spring merchandise, which were for the most part substantial, than had been expected by ready-to-wear manufacturers, according to reports prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices.

Calling this an age of "too many scientists who have taught us more about killing than about living," the Rev. Albert L. Neibacher, pastor of St. Luke's Lutheran Church, 308 West Forty-sixth Street, declared yesterday that because there were so few theologians it was the laymen's task to restore a balance of power between science and religion.
CLAREMONT, Calif., Jan. 9 (AP) -- Dr. Charles K. Edmunds, former president of Pomona College here, was struck and killed yesterday as he crossed United States Highway 66. He was 73 years old.

NANKING, Jan. 9 -- The Communist radio asserted tonight that Red troops had intensified their offensive against two Government Army groups trapped southwest of Suchow. Nanking waited for an official reaction from the Big Four on its indirect request for outside mediation in China's civil war.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 (AP) -- The Navy said today that billets for 8,920 Naval Reservists were available in four training cruises scheduled for the Caribbean area in February and March. Fifty-one ships of the Atlantic Fleet will be used.

Based on their productivity, sales persons in retail stores generally are efficient only to an extent about 71.4 per cent of a satisfactory norm, it was declared over the week-end by Maxwell I. Schultz, executive vice president of Willmark Service System, Inc.
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 9 -- Haym Salomon, Revolutionary War patriot, was honored today at a ceremony marking the 164th anniversary of his death.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, Jan. 9 (UP) -- Josef Revai, top Hungarian propagandist, said today that Joseph Cardinal Mindszenty's supporters, backed by the Vatican, were "collaborators of Hitler and Franco," or advocates of fascism.

A well-attended program of contemporary American music was presented late yesterday afternoon by -- and for the benefit of -- the Metropolitan Music School. All the composers, several of whom are on the faculty, were present, and two of them performed their own compositions.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 -- In a move to speed consideration of the nomination of Dean Acheson as Secretary of State, Senator Tom Connally, incoming chairman of the Foreign Relations Committee, said tonight that he planned to convene the group on Tuesday "for an informal meeting."

Because of a sharply increased birth rate, the nation's public schools now face a critical teacher shortage, particularly in the elementary grades. Every state in the union needs more qualified teachers. As a result of the shortage, 105,000 teachers, or more than one out of every nine in the country, are employed on substandard or emergency certificates.

MOBILE, Ala., Jan. 9 -- Jefferson Davis West could see again today after two years of blindness. When doctors gently removed the bandages from his eyes, the 80-year-old Mobile man said he wanted to "thank all those fine people who did this for me."

Shura Dvorine, who gave his third New York piano recital Saturday night at Town Hall, has altered his style of playing. There was little of the tender, poetic quality that distinguished it when he played last season. Instead the emphasis was on bravura.

Senator Matthew-M. Neely. West Virginia Democrat, called yesterday for the immediate repeal of the Displaced Persons Act of 1948 and the substitution of a "humane" immigration law that would permit the entrance of 400,000 displaced persons to the United States within the next two years.
CHICAGO, Jan. 9 (AP) -- The Chicago Black Hawks tonight defeated the Boston Bruins, 4 to 2, in a National Hockey League game before a season's record crowd of 17.386.

Although doors to Grand Central Palace were closed yesterday, there was lots of activity at the National Motor Boat Show with corps of workmen cleaning, buffing and polishing the shiny pleasure craft, engines and nautical gear for this morning's resumption of the exposition at 11 o'clock.

LONDON, Jan. 9 -- The stock markets here opened the new year very soberly. Some revival of business was apparent, but that was only to be expected following the restrictive influences of Christmas and the year-end. It did not denote any more hopeful view of the outlook, concerning which it is customary at this time to attempt some assessment of prospects.

Ernest E. Novotny, divisional vice president of the chemical division of Borden Company, has been appointed in charge of production to succeed Hugh P. Fell, who will retire on March 31. Nils Anderson Jr, has been appointed vice president in charge of sales.

The dictionary, as usual, is terse and impersonal in its definition of Snow: small tabular and columnar crystals of frozen water formed, directly from the water vapor of the air when its temperature at the time of condensation is lower than 32 degrees F. But this makes no distinction among the varied pictures when snow is falling.

A report proposing a permanent Federal commission on civil rights will be delivered to President Truman in the White House on Wednesday morning by a delegation from the National Citizens Council on Civil Rights, 20 West Fortieth Street, it was announced yesterday.

To the account of the life of the late James Stuart Douglas (published Jan. 3) may I add that it was he who bought the home of Georges Clemenceau in the Rue Franklin in Paris and presented it to the French people to be kept as a museum.
A study of bad weather operations at La Guardia Airport shows that already the airlines are well on the way to doing something about the weather.

VIENNA, Jan. 9 -- Communism, which until it had consolidated itself in Hungary, gave the Jews there the status of a preferred minority, is now turning on them as it has already turned on the Catholic church and on the peasantry.

While prospects for the tanning industry in 1949 are generally favorable, the outlook will be influenced to a large extent by broad economic and business trends in this country, according to a statement prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Irving R. Glass, executive vice president of the Tanners Council of America.

Without the spirit of Jesus, the world would become an intolerable place, Dr. Donald J. Cowling, former president of Carleton College and president of the Congregational Christian Conference of Minnesota, declared yesterday. He spoke at the morning service of the West Park Presbyterian Church, Amsterdam Avenue and Eighty-sixth Street.

Mechanized cotton production emerged in 1948 as the phone of farm mechanization most likely to jump into largest scale advancements in 1949, agricultural equipment experts disclosed here last week. Production of mechanical cotton pickers will move into larger massive quantity output and operators report savings in picking costs of ten to twenty-five dollars a bale.

LAKE SUCCESS, Jan. 9 -An order has been sent out to United Nations military observers in Palestine by Dr. Ralph J. Bunche, Acting Mediator, calling for an on-the-spot investigation of the shooting down last Friday of British warplanes by Israeli forces.

Rose Dirman, soprano, gave the first of a series of three recitals yesterday afternoon at Town Hall. According to her custom, the artist had devised a program of interesting offerings, including many infrequently presented, which she sang with understanding and taste.

Curtains either in new dark colors or of strong synthetic fibres that resist dirt are the latest answers to the ravages of soot, which has been one of the strongest arguments against using curtains at city windows.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 -- Details of the largest peacetime American budget in history reach the Eighty-first Congress tomorrow in President Truman's annual budget message.

In a wild and woolly contest that saw a greater part of the action in the third period, the New York Rovers and Shawinigan Falls Cats battled to a 6-all overtime deadlock in a Quebec Senior Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden yesterday afternoon before 8,763 fans.

THE HAGUE, The Netherlands, Jan. 9 -- Some obscure political difficulties that have dogged the Dutch negotiations with the Javanese Republicans for months and now once more threaten the talks in Indonesia have been traced to intervention on the part of the Vatican, it was reported here today by a source close to the Foreign Ministry.

"The season of Christmas and Epiphany reminds us that the life of Christ is an epiphany, a showing forth of the light of the world and the light of truth and power which can guide us through whatever this life holds and beyond it," said the Rev. Robert C. Hunsicker of the staff of Trinity Protestant Episcopal Church, Broadway at Wall Street, in his sermon yesterday.
MOSCOW, Jan. 9 -- Komsomol Pravda said today that a Russian had flown the first airplane twenty-one years before the Wright brothers.

A surprisingly heavy volume of spot sterling which hit the market on Monday and Tuesday causing a break to $4.02-13/16, highlighted the trading in the foreign exchange market last week. This was a new low for the pound since last April.

President Truman's letter to Senator George and Representative Doughton asking Congress to restore the Reciprocal Trade Agreements Act to its original form and extend it to June 12, 1951, is in keeping with our foreign policy, our national honor and our national interests.
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 9 -- More than 3,500 persons packed the Academy of Music today at a two-hour rally honoring the Freedom Train and the ideals for which it stands.
The status of public school education in the United States at present, in contrast with its status a year ago, as shown regionally in a nationwide survey by THE NEW YORK TIMES, follows:

BERLIN, Jan. 9 -- Brilliant sunshine and mild temperature marked the 200th day of the Berlin blockade. Airlift planes roared ceaselessly and triumphantly into and out of Tempelhof and Gatow at precise three-minute intervals, their clocklike precision a promise of even greater records of tonnage deliveries as warmer weather permits expansion of facilities.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Jan. 9 -- An official protest was made today to the United Nations by the Provisional Government of Israel concerning British forces "recently landed at Aqaba." This is considered a hostile act and, according to the Israeli Government view, could have no other purpose than to threaten Israeli territory in the southern part of the Negeb.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Jan. 9 -- Nuri Pasha as-Said of Iraq appears to the Arab world to be the key man of the Palestine situation at present rather than King Farouk, despite the announcement of impending Israeli-Egyptian peace talks in Rhodes.
Five rabbinical groups here urged Governor Dewey and the Legislature yesterday to set up a commission to study the divorce laws and procedures of New York State and to recommend improvements.

A retired sea captain acted according to the best traditions of his former calling last night when a smoky fire started in an apartment house at 55 East Sixty-fifth Street, where he has been employed as an elevator operator for the last nine months.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 (UP) -- The Public Roads Administration urged the states today to spend more money to speed construction of an interstate network of super-highways and improve "thousands of miles" of poor roads.

Unionized tugboat workers voted yesterday to empower their negotiating committee to call a strike at 12:01 A. M. Thursday if no agreement with New York employers was reached before the deadline.
