A tie-up would cut off virtually all the city's fuel supply and would disrupt many phases of the city's economic life.

The Civil Aeronautics Board's newly proposed regulation for irregular or non-scheduled passenger airline operation will put more than 100 such airlines out of business, spokesmen for the so-called independent carriers said here yesterday.

CHICAGO, Jan. 9 -- General liquidation developed in lard futures on the Board of Trade last week as the result of continued weakness in the general fat and vegetable oil markets, with all deliveries selling at a new seasonal low. Cash lard which closed Saturday at $15.50 a hundred pounds was at new low since the Office of Price Administration ceiling of $15.05 was removed in July, 1946.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 -- Recommendations looking to better management of privately-owned timber lands were urged today by the Forest Service in its annual report.

The national health insurance program that President Truman has asked Congress to enact was described yesterday by Federal Security Administrator Oscar Ewing as "no more socialistic than fire insurance" while Dr. Morris Fishbein, editor of The Journal of the American Medical Association, attacked the program as a possible "first step toward socialization of the entire United States economy."
MOSCOW, Jan. 9 (AP) -- The Russian Government has virtually ended wartime subsidies to industry and transport, the Soviet Journal of Economic Questions disclosed today.
In these days when special drives and promotions are conducted with rare skill the man who is not "week"-conscious must be one who is unable to read, quite deaf or is otherwise unimpressionable.
DENVER, Col., Jan. 9 (AP) -- Still suffering from the blizzard that killed twenty-five persons the Rocky Mountain section staggered today from another icy blow.

The thirty-fifth annual convention of the National Lutheran Educational Conference opened at Wagner College on Staten Island yesterday afternoon. The conference president, Dr. J. N. Brown, stressed the work of Christian colleges.

Winner of the National A. A. U. indoor high-jumping title the past three years, John Vislocky Jr. of the New York A. C. has never won the Metropolitan A. A. U. indoor crown. The Winged Foot star is favored to win the championship in the annual Metropolitan title meet at the 102d Engineers Armory Saturday night.

BATAVIA, Java, Jan. 9 -- The latest Dutch "police action" in Java and Sumatra, besides darkening the outlook for a durable settlement here, appears to have done perhaps irreparable damage to the stability of all Asian colonial areas.

LONDON, Jan. 9 -- Sir Stafford Cripps, Chancellor of the Exchequer and Minister for Economic Affairs, chided tonight those British workers seeking to enforce pay increase demands. He told a Labor party gathering at Workington, in Cumberland, that such demands were unfair to other workers and, if granted, would wreck all hopes of national recovery.

PARIS, Jan. 9 -- The two giants of the present political world are apparently eyeing each other these days in an effort to detect whether any fundamental change in policy can be anticipated at either international pole, Moscow or Washington.

DETROIT, Mich., Jan. 9 -- The Kaiser-Frazer Corporation, blaming the credit restrictions of the Federal Reserve Board, disclosed today that it would either sharply cut back its work week within a few days or lay off more than 25 per cent of its working force of 15,000 at the Willow Run converted bomber plant.
CAIRO, Jan. 9 -- Marking the first attack of its kind in the Arabic press, an Egyptian newspaper today urged the dissolution of the Arab League as it now stands.
The Philadelphia Nationals, leaders of the American Soccer League, rallied to defeat the Brookhattan-Galicia eleven, 5 -- 3, before 3,000 fans at Sterling Oval in the Bronx yesterday.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 9 -- A new consultant service to assist industry with the problems of alcoholism among its employes has been established under the expansion program of the Yale Plan Clinic. The work will be confined to the Eastern states during its first year.
TAMPA, Fla., Jan. 9 (AP) -- Gardnar Mulloy won his first Dixie tennis tournament today with a 1 -- 6, 6 -- 2, 6 -- 3, 6 -- 2 victory over Gardner Larned of Chicago.

OYSTER BAY, L. I., Jan. 9 -Four hundred members of lodges of the Brooklyn-Long Island District of the National League of Masonic Clubs made their second annual pilgrimage this afternoon to the grave of Theodore Roosevelt in Young's Memorial Cemetery to commemorate the thirtieth anniversary of his death.

Your apology to Mr. Van Kleffens and the Netherlands Government for the editorial "The Broken Promise" is a graceful apology for one specific error and is a credit to THE NEW YORK TIMES. Your insistence on the basic soundness of the line which you have followed -- both in your editorials and in your treatment of the news -- leads me to hope that the sinner might still be brought to further repentance.

OSLO, Norway, Jan. 9 (AP) -Kees Broekman, 21-year-old Dutch star, decisively beat all his competitors, including world, European and Olympic champions, by winning three out of four races in the international ice skating meet at Bislet Stadium yesterday and today.
Should the American steel industry embark upon an expansionist program designed to increase its producing capacity without delay from the present 96,000,000 tons to 106,000,000?

Rabbi Joseph H. Lookstein of Congregation Kehilath Jeshurun received the degree of Doctor of Divinity yesterday from his alma mater, Yeshiva University. The award was made at a ceremony marking the twenty-fifth anniversary of his ministry at the synagogue, which is at 117 East Eighty-fifth Street.

Regular daytime programming will be instituted in mid-February on WJZ-TV, key video station of the American Broadcasting Company, Charles C. Barry, vice president in charge of television, has announced. The outlet thus will become the second in the New York area offering daytime television programs on a regular basis, WABD, the Du Mont station here, having started a similar service Nov. 1.
LOS ANGELES, Jan. 9 (AP) -Battling sweeping cold winds, rain and hail, four golfers wound up in a tie for first place today at the end of the third round of the $15,000 Los Angeles open tournament.

TOKYO, Jan. 9 -- The Japanese Government is drafting a sweeping revision of the national labor laws for presentation to the next Diet. preliminary information regarding the increased curbs on trade union activities that it proposes is now available here.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 9 -- Yale University announced today that Sven Markelius, famed Swedish architect, is to be the recipient of its Howland Memorial Prize. The presentation will take place in the spring when Mr. Markelius arrives here to serve as visiting critic in advanced architectural design at Yale.

The New York Maritime Register, the only shipping guide of its kind in this country, announced yesterday that it had suspended publication. It was established in 1869. The editor, Tom Morris, well known along steamship row in lower Manhattan, said that increased costs and changed conditions made it impossible to continue.

Ch. Penrock's Prize Package, a black cocker spaniel owned by the Penrock Kennels of New Canaan, Conn., cut a major place for himself in the canine world by taking best in show at the close of the two-day national specialty of the American Spaniel Club at the Hotel Roosevelt last night.

THE French Revolution, according to Fletcher Pratt, destroyed a political system but failed to replace it with another. The guillotines of the Jacobins chopped off the heads of the annointed king of France and many of his nobles, and abolished forever the sacred authority of the ancien regime. But the men and women who had shouted so loudly for liberte, egalite and fraternite soon found that what they got was terror and chaos.

It should not be necessary-in this country to emphasize the savings and standard-of-living benefits due to mass production and the tools that make it possible. However, judging from the resistance to technical advances which still appears in some quarters, the lesson of our industrial miracle must continually be restated.

The New England Motor Rate Bureau, Inc., is attempting to treble motor carrier freight rates on nylon hosiery valued between $3 and $5 a pound and desires the right to refuse to transport any nylon hosiery by motor carrier valued in excess of $5 a pound.

It took Alex Kaleta a long time go get his first at-home goal for the New York Rangers. As a matter of fact, the hustling blue-jerseyed forward had to wait until last night in the game with the Canadiens of Montreal before he experienced the thrill of causing the enemy red light to glow in Madison Square Garden.
MADRID, Jan. 9 (AP) -- Generalissimo Francisco Franco moved today to permit the descendants of Jews expelled from Spain in 1492 to return to the fatherland.

Far-reaching changes in the basic structure of the law admitting 205,000 refugees here during a two-year period will be recommended to Congress by the Displaced Persons Commission in a special report that is expected to point out that the program has bogged down seriously because of current restrictions.
Five new films, including a newcomer from England, are slated to arrive in first-run theatres this week. The programs follow:...

The New York Zoological Society is constantly increasing the area and variety of its activities. At the fifty-third annual meeting of the Society, Fairfield Osborn, president, reported that the New York Zoological Park had more than 2,500,000 visitors last year. He added that the animal collections were at a high point with regard to the number of varieties on-display and with regard to their general health and well-being.
A birthday party that attracted unbidden guests ended in a burst of shooting that killed one youth and wounded another early yesterday in the Bedford-Stuyvesant Negro section of Brooklyn.

The plan to reorganize the courts system in New York to ease calendar congestion has reached the stage of approval by leaders of the Association of the Bar of the City of New York and by a number of important political leaders, it was learned yesterday.

PITTSBURGH, Jan. 9 -- Steel demand last week was strong. Talk of future easiness was still talk. Most steel people were still expecting that the heavy pressure for steel would be off, but that would not happen, they said, for several months.

At a moment when the conflict between Israel and the Arabs appeared to be nearing a solution, a new and even graver issue has arisen between Israel and Britain as a result of the action of Israeli forces in shooting down five RAF planes near the Egyptian-Israeli border.

LAKE SUCCESS, Jan. 9 -- The United Nations International Children's Emergency Fund reported here today that a recent survey of conditions in both Greece and the Middle East had disclosed that refugee populations in both areas were suffering from acute overcrowding and inadequate shelter.

EAST ORANGE, N. J., Jan. 9 -The body of Edward M. Cooke, 83-year-old retired mining engineer and consultant, was found on a second floor extension roof of the Hotel Suburban in South Harrison Street, here, early this afternoon, after what police described as a plunge from a ninth floor hall window.

Paul McGuire, Australian historian, economist, lecturer and novelist, whose latest book was "Experiment in World Order," has a new book on Morrow's spring list. "There's Freedom for the Brave: An Approach to World Order" presents a plan of action to build a better world.

With their increasing numbers of aged and retired persons, Western nations may find it necessary to adopt the attitude of the Chinese toward old age, Dr. Albert R. Chandler of Ohio State University said yesterday at the annual meeting of the Gerontological Society in the Hotel Commodore.

BELOIT, Wis., Jan. 9 (AP) -- Five Scandanavian "riders" imparted an obvious moral to a crowd of 10,000 persons at the annual Big Hill ski meet today. The foreign quintet pocketed the first five places and 120 American entrants had to be content with what was left.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 -- American shipping has set as its goal enough cargo tonnage to carry all domestic freight and at least half of American imports and exports, plus a modern fleet of passenger ships to serve the principal overseas routes, the National Federation of American Shipping said today.

The latest reports from General Clay, American Military Governor in Germany, make it plain that if the Russians counted on "General Winter" to defeat the Berlin airlift they have made a grave mistake, and that the blockade they established to drive the Western Powers out of the German capital has boomeranged against its authors.

BATAVIA, Jan. 10 (Reuters) -- Indonesian Republican forces in Java were today reported to be carrying on "intense" guerrilla warfare in districts south of Batavia. Fighting was said to be going on around Tasikmalaya, 120 miles southeast of Batavia and at Sukabumi, about fifty miles south.

A new system of reproducing music from records was announced yesterday by RCA-Victor Records, together with a denial that it was engaged in any "trade war" with its chief competitor in the record field, Columbia Records, Inc.
ALBANY, Jan. 10 -- Governor Dewey acted tonight to head off a split in Republican legislative ranks over additional state aid for education and increased taxes.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 (AP) -- By taking in washing, peddling ice and turning in empty containers the Federal Government hopes to raise some of the $41,858,000,000 that will be required to run itself next year.
Minneapolis, Minn., announced yesterday that it would receive bids until Feb. 2 on an issue of $2,000,000 of refunding bonds dated March 1, 1949 and due on each March 1, 1956 to 1969.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 10 -- More than 7,000 executives from throughout the country jammed Convention Hall here today to study $5,000,000 worth of new devices in the third national materials handing exposition. Displays by 240 exhibitors of trucks, elevators, hoists, conveyors and power shovels featured the event.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Jan. 10 -- The Yugoslav Government announced today that over-all industrial production in 1948 was 61 per cent higher than in 1947 and that targets for 1949 had been increased by another 30 per cent. These figures, broadcast by Radio Belgrade, were not elucidated by units of production nor tonnages and it therefore was impossible to gauge the size of Yugoslav production in 1948 or targets for 1949.

CAIRO, Jan. 10 -- The opposition nationalist party Wafd offered today to enter an Egyptian Cabinet under a "neutral" Premier in response to the King's appeal for unity and "in view of the critical times through which the country is passing."
WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 (AP) -- John J. McCloy, president of the World Bank, said today he saw no need now for the bank to raise additional lending capital.

Rubber futures continued yesterday their upward movement. In a turnover of 1,450 long tons, prices on the Commodity Exchange were up 28 to 35 points at the close. Smaller shipments from Malaya in December accounted in part for the rise.
Concern over the reported position of the Vatican in the present Dutch-Indonesian dispute was expressed here yesterday by a high official of the Republic of Indonesia.

Privately owned shipyards of the United States have scheduled for delivery during the next two years seventy-eight vessels of 1,000 gross tons or more, aggregating 1,215,102 gross tons, according to the Shipbuilders Council of America. These figures, compiled by the council, are as of Jan. 1.

Leon Barzin and the National Orchestral Association, who give consistently interesting programs in their annual series at Carnegie Hall, outdid themselves last night. The all-French program featured Samson Francois, pianist, and the American premieres of Elsa Barraine's Second Symphony and Claude Delvincourt's Prelude Choreographique.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 10 -- Before an excited throng of both "bobby-soxers" and adults, Robert Mitchum, 31-year-old motion-picture actor, with two co-defendants was found guilty today in the Superior Court here of criminal conspiracy to violate the California state health code by smoking marijuana.

ALRA1N-Y, Jan. IO--A full-scale legislative investigation of the New York Fire Department was proposed in a resolution introduced in the Assembly tonight by Assemblyman Angelo Graci, Republican,i of Queens. The resolution calls for l the investigation to be conducted by a joint committee of the Assembly and the Senate with the aid of a $10,000 appropriation.

The proposed 50 per cent increase in Railway Express Agency rates on millinery would have a dire effect on New York's millinery manufacturing industry, according to Samuel Finkelstein executive director of the Millinery Stabilization Commission.

The city's investigation into milk prices will be broadened to include a study of prices of cheese, butter, ice cream and other milk products. Commissioner of Investigation John M. Murtagh declared yesterday.
The Midwest, already covered with snow, ice and sleet, braced for a dangerous freezing rain late yesterday.

Smuggled narcotics valued conservatively at $5,000,000 on the illicit market, and diamonds, jewelry and numerous other types of merchandise worth hundreds of thousands of dollars were intercepted by alert customs officers in the Port of New York last year.
ROME, Jan. 10 (AP) -- The Vatican Radio said today that the recent arrest of Joseph Cardinal Mindszenty took place after a Hungarian commission had abandoned the possibility of an "accidental death."

Sixteen tenants of 31 West Twelfth Street started an action in Supreme Court yesterday before Justice Carroll G. Walter seeking redress for alleged deterioration of services in the eleven-story apartment house. It is owned by Cinemas Francais, Inc., which was named defendant.

As a New York County grand jury handed up indictments yesterday against four alleged gamblers, accusing them of seeking to "fix" a college basketball game by offering a $1,000 bribe to a player, a Federal grand jury in Washington also indicted three of the men on similar charges.

CONTRARY to popular belief, the St. Louis University basketball team consists of four other fellows besides Easy Ed Macauley. The first chap to admit same is Easy Ed himself, a tall, talented, handsome and humble guy who suddenly has become the Cover Boy for practically every sports magazine in existence. But all the acclaim has failed to change his dimensions one cubit.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture said today that conditions on Jan. 1 indicated a 1948-49 orange crop of 114,600,000 boxes -- 4 per cent more than last season.

LAKE SUCCESS, Jan. 10 -- United Nations Secretary General Trygve Lie interceded directly today with the British in a determined effort to keep the dispute on the shooting down of Royal Air Force planes by Israel out of the world organization.
Fresh design ideas in scarfs and jewelry and novel ways of wearing the accessories provided color for the Ann R. Silver showing of Coro jewelry and Glentex scarfs yesterday at the Roosevelt Hotel.

Having read the first draft, Richard W. Krakeur is convinced that he has a winner in the script N. Richard Nash is fashioning at the moment. The opus bears no name, but, in the words of Mr. Krakeur "it is a comedy-drama with a love story." Other descriptive details, says the producer, will have to come later.

Proposals that the American Heritage Foundation take over operation of the plant and community phases of the ANA-4-A's program to improve public understanding of the American economic system present difficulties comparable to the controversy that held up agreement on content of the Advertising Council's current series of ads in behalf of the program, it was asserted yesterday by Thomas D'Arcy Brophy, chairman of the Foundation.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 -- President Truman announced in his budget message today that he favored a North Atlantic security pact, backed by a United States arms program for Canada and Western Europe, but it was immediately evident that this program was going to require a long debate and would provoke considerable opposition.

ALBANY, Jan. 10 -- A bill to provide a system of prepaid medical and hospital care, which contemplates a 2 per cent payroll tax shared equally by employer and employe, was introduced in the Legislature tonight by Assemblyman Joseph A. Martinis, Democrat, of the Bronx.
New York University is negotiating to acquire property owned by Sailors Snug Harbor in an area north of Washington Square, it was learned yesterday.
Sir Carl Berendsen, Minister from New Zealand, and Lady Berendsen have arrived at the Waldorf-Astoria from Washington.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 -- President Truman today recommended further increases in postal rates to help overcome a Post Office deficit of $402,000,000.
I respectfully submit that the steps most urgently needed to prevent further large-scale fighting in Palestine are the following:

Joseph M. Roebling's record-cracking colt, Blue Peter, and the Maine Chance Farm's remarkable filly, Myrtle Charm, who ran away from the opposition for a one, two finish in Belmont Park's fastest Futurity last September, share top-of-the-roster honors in John Blanks Campbell's 1949 Experimental Free Handicap weights, announced yesterday.

ROME, Jan. 10 -- Two columns of motorized police were rushed from Bari to Andria to quell rioting that broke out there as a result of demonstrations of unemployed. Disturbances also took place in Bari itself and in other places in the heel of the Italian boot where the situation was described as "tense."

TEL AVIV, Israel, Jan. 10 -- All Israeli troops have been withdrawn from Egyptian territory, it was announced here tonight by Lieut. Col. Moshe Pearlman, military spokesman. At cease-fire time some were about three miles within Egypt, just south of Rafah, he said.

In contrast to the extreme conservatism displayed during the last quarter of 1948, wash dress buyers are taking an optimistic stand on early spring business, according to exhibitors at the first national wash dress market in the Astor Hotel.

The coaxial cable joining the Eastern and Mid-Western television networks will be opened formally this evening with a special program running from 9:30 to 11 o'clock. The program, which is expected to enjoy the largest audience in television's history, will be carried by all stations within reach of the cable.

ROME, Jan. 10 -- Negotiations between Hungarian bishops and the Budapest Government on economic questions arising from confiscation by the State of Church property have been suspended, Vatican circles said today. The bishops, it was stated, informed the Hungarian Government that before making a final decision they must consult the Vatican.

The Musicians' Guild is finding no difficulty in maintaining a program policy that calls for the balancing of meaningful contemporary scores with familiar items of the repertory. At the second concert of its third season at Times Hall last night it presented the premiere of a new quartet by Bohuslav Martinu, his seventh.

The City Hack Bureau has issued an order to taxicab companies and private taxi owners that all cabs in New York must be stripped of their radios immediately, it was learned yesterday. The order actually affects only owner-drivers, since virtually all fleet operators have eliminated radios in their post-war automobiles.

CHICAGO, Jan. 10 -- The estimates by the Department of Agriculture on farm reserves of wheat, corn and oats as of Jan. 1 were about in line with expectations, although the amount of wheat remaining in farmers' hands was slightly smaller than last year.

The Board of Education proposed yesterday a record-breaking budget of $220,599,648 for 1949-50, amounting to an increase of $23,628,350 over the current school year, but deferred the request of Dr. William Jansen, Superintendent of Schools, for funds to raise teachers' salaries.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 -- If President Truman's budget is an index, the country is going to make more atom bombs next year or the cost has gone up.

BATAVIA, Java, Jan. 10 -- A United States correspondent gave a personally witnessed account today of a four-hour Indonesian attack late last night and early this morning on Jogjakarta, Republican capital captured by the Dutch in the Dec. 19 police action.

Concerned over a deadlock in City Hall negotiations for a new wage agreement covering 2,500 drivers of coal and fuel oil trucks, Mayor O'Dwyer warned employer and union representatives last night that a strike in their industry would be even more damaging to the city than the parallel threat of a work stoppage by 3,500 tugboat and oil barge employes.

The average rate charged on commercial and industrial loans of more than one-year terms made by twelve selected banks in this area during the first half of last December was 2.17 per cent, compared with 2.02 per cent in the first half of September and 1.89 per cent in the first half of December, 1947.

Maj. Gen. Maxwell D. Taylor, retiring superintendent of the United States Military Academy at West Point, will leave for Germany this month to become chief of staff to the commander of United States military forces in the European theatre, it was learned yesterday.

Retailing can play a vital part in the successful operation of the Marshall Plan, Saul Cohn, president of City Stores Company, told delegates to the thirty-eighth annual convention of the National Retail Dry Goods Association in the Statler Hotel yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 -- Following is the text of President Truman's budget message:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 -- Insistent demands from a united Republican minority for a quick change in Senate rules to curb the threat of filibusters evoked Democratic assurances today that the matter would receive "promptest consideration."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 (AP) -- Monongahela Power Company, Fairmont, W. Va., today registered with the Securities and Exchange Commission $6,000,000 of thirty-year first mortgage bonds and 67,000 shares of common stock.
Mayor O'Dwyer endorsed yesterday the fund-raising campaigns of the Salvation Army and the New York Heart Association.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 -- President Truman was reported today to favor the "one package" approach to labor legislation.

To ease the minds of housewives who use Laundromat automatic washing machines in self-service laundries, the Westinghouse Electric Corporation reported yesterday that all disease-carrying bacteria in clothing were eliminated in recent tests of its machines made with water at 140 degrees temperature.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 -- Efforts to have the Supreme Court intervene in the trial of twelve Communist leaders, set for next Monday in New York, were rejected today by the high tribunal.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 -- President Truman asked Congress today to approve a spending program without peacetime precedent to meet what he regards as the "minimum requirements" of our world program and of domestic well-being.

BERLIN, Jan. 10 -- Political realignments currently in progress in the bizonal area are generating some confusion, especially as between two groups representing different attitudes, but with similar names. Clarification of objectives probably can be expected only as time familiarizes the public with the distinctive characters of both.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 -- President Truman in his budget message today reiterated his stand for a new cabinet post in the social welfare field and estimated 1950 budget expenditures for social security, health and welfare at nearly $2,400,000,000 -- up about $349,000,000 from fiscal 1949.

In the First World War the peak of spending was reached in fiscal 1918-1919. Expenditures for national defense that year were $14,400,000,000 and "other" expenditures $4,100,000,000, making the over-all total $18,500,000,000. Once the fighting ended, the budget steadily shrank in size, until in 1923, the fourth post-war year, it stood at $3,300,000,000.

The project through which Brooklyn, N. Y., has aided Breukelen, Holland, with food, clothing and other necessities will become a permanent organization, mainly concerned with establishing a cultural exchange, Miss Marguerite A. Salomon, founder and chairman, announced yesterday.

This is the season for ice. It coats the ponds, the gutters of the roof and certain roads of the Southern Tier. It is slippery, mean and treacherous. Bearing the casual look of an inanimate object, it springs suddenly to life to trip the unwary, and the bigger they are the harder they fall.

MOSCOW, Jan. 10 (AP) -- The weekly Soviet Art gave Eric Johnston an editorial pummeling today, describing him as an imperialist agent with the face of a model and the smile of a "toothpaste advertisement."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 -- The Truman Administration's displaced persons bill, which would open the United States to 400,000 European refugees and fundamentally soften the entire Republican version of 1948, was put before Congress today.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 10 -- President Charles Seymour of Yale University announced today the coming retirement of the Rev. Dr. Luther A. Weigle after twenty-one years as dean of the Yale Divinity School. He will be succeeded June 30 by the Rev. Dr. Liston Pope, a member of his faculty.
Your editorial of Jan. 4 on Fort Clinton leads me to believe that you do not have a clear understanding of what Fort Clinton will look like when it has been restored.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 -- President Truman proposed to Congress today a national defense budget for the 1950 fiscal year of nearly $15,900,000,000, greatest in peacetime history but considerably less than the total sought by the three armed forces.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Jan. 10 (AP) -- Technical discussions on two side issues in Federal Court today delayed hearing of objections to the Interstate Commerce Commission plan for reorganization of the Florida East Coast Railway.

William J. McCormack, chairman of the Mayor's special committee mediating the tugboat dispute, expressed the opinion yesterday afternoon that a harbor-crippling tug strike could be averted. The United Marine Division, Local 333, International Longshoremen's Association, has set 12:01 A.M. Thursday as the deadline for an agreement.

Nikolai Graudan and his wife, Joanna, who have made many appearances here in the ten years since their New York debut as a 'cello-piano team, gave a program last night at Town Hall that featured the first performance of a new work by Victor Babin.

HOW much and how little can be done with slight material by a gifted writer is wonderfully demonstrated in "My Brother Denys,"* by Nicholas Monsarrat. Everything which a delicate ear for the rhythms of English prose and an unusual faculty of capturing the nuances of atmosphere in words can do is done in this attractive but woefully insubstantial little book.

CHICAGO, Jan. 10 (AP) -- Dick Button of Englewood, N. J., will defend his title in the world figure skating championship at Paris, Feb. 16-17-18, while Miss Yvonne Sherman of New York is this country's best bet for the women's crown.

The $91,000,000 recommended for new ship construction by President Truman in his 1949-1950 budget will be sufficient to build seventeen vessels proposed by shipping companies and other agencies, according to Maritime Commission spokesmen.

What began last week as preparations for the first public demonstration of soup a la Eisenhower had been transformed last night into dinner a la protocol. Lexicographers had strayed into the kitchen and the menu for tonight's Columbia University Hamilton Award Dinner was simmering over a hot dictionary late last night.
MILFORD, Va., Jan. 10 (AP) -- Ten cars of the Florida-to-New York Orange Blossom special were derailed here today, injuring more than a score of persons. One car, a diner, overturned.
American colleges and universities lack integrity and are more interested in getting additional buildings than good faculty members, a responsible spokesman for higher education charged yesterday.
The threat of another strike on the Hudson Manhattan Railroad loomed last night with the announcement that its 170 members of the Brotherhood of Locomotive Engineers would vote today on a walk-out.

The newest report of City Construction Coordinator Robert Moses to Mayor O'Dwyer, this one covering arterial highways, parkways and expressways, is less a description of the many traffic arteries in the city -- completed, under construction and projected -- than it is a recital of the difficulties and hardships encountered in building them and an argument for more funds to speed road construction programs and prevent them from bogging down.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 10 (AP) -- The outgoing president of the American Football Coaches Association lashed out at the National Collegiate Athletic Association's year-old "sanity code" today. He said coaches "are fearful we have another prohibition act on our hands."

Supreme Court Justice Aron Steuer yesterday denied Screen Test, Inc., owner of a radio program of that name, a temporary injunction to restrain the American Broadcasting Company, Inc., from televising a program called "Hollywood Screen Test," over the ABC television network on Sunday nights.

The clans McLaughlin and Fitzgerald took the spotlight yesterday afternoon at the annual registration of junior members of the Police Athletic League at the Bussey Youth Center, 509 West Fortieth Street.

The twenty-fifth annual Silver Skates championship was presented at Madison Square Garden last night with a capacity crowd of 15,000 fans on hand. The competition was sponsored by the Daily News Welfare Association.

A banking group headed by Union Securities Corporation will place on the market today a block of 144,200 shares of common capital stock of Mississippi River Fuel Corporation, owner and operator of a natural gas pipeline extending from northern Louisiana to St. Louis. The stock is priced at $30 a share.
Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday closed 8 points higher to 3 points lower.

The principal influences that will affect the earnings of banks in 1949 are beyond the control of bank managements, George V. McLaughlin, president of the Brooklyn Trust Company, asserted yesterday. Reporting to the bank's stockholders at their annual meeting, Mr. McLaughlin observed that a decrease in the volume of bank lending was a possibility this year.

LONDON, Jan. 10 -- Britain's nationalized airlines today won the right to order their own planes. The concession, which has come after more than two years of agitation by airline executives, was announced at 10 Downing Street.

" A Charter for World Trade," a study by Clair Wilcox of the charter for an International Trade Organization, which was completed last spring at Havana, Cuba, has been set for Jan. 25 publication by Macmillan. Mr. Wilcox, who is Joseph Wharton, Professor of Political Economy at Swarthmore College, represented the United States in various capacities while the charter was being formulated.
CHICAGO, Jan 10 -- Luis Kutner, an attorney, alleged in Federal District Court today that the current financing project of the Tucker Corporation was a "vague subterfuge" and "without good faith."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 -- The United States urged the British Government today to regard as "a regrettable incident only" the shooting down by Israeli fighters of Royal Air Force aircraft near the Israeli-Egyptian border. The British had taken "a grave view" of the attack and had planned to ask strong United Nations action.
DETROIT, Jan. 10 -- The Lincoln plants of the Ford Motor Company cut down production 10 per cent today and ordered that 1,230 employes be laid off at once for an indefinite period.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture reported today that stocks of corn on farms on Jan. 1 totaled 2,520,000,000 bushels -- a record high for this date. A year ago the total was only 1,506,283,000. For the ten-year (1938-47) period, it averaged 1,944,272,000.

Robert Villemain sat back at the St. Nicholas Arena last night and through the bandages which cover his scars of battle saw just how the other fellow looks doing exactly what he did last Friday against Steve Belloise.

At the opening yesterday of an investigation into illegal search and seizure, a special committee of the New York County Criminal Courts Bar Association adopted two recommendations to protect constitutional rights.

Gross income of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York in 1948 amounted to $73,223,000, compared with $38,907,000 in the previous year, Allan Sproul, the president, reported yesterday. In presenting the bank's thirty-fourth annual profit and loss account and statement of condition, Mr. Sproul explained that the regular annual report was being prepared and would be issued to each member bank.

Stung by criticism heaped upon them by individuals connected with the game for too much whistle blowing and other alleged faults, college basketball officials have organized. This was announced yesterday by Sam Schoenfeld, prominent arbiter and former Columbia cage star.

Peter J. Loftus, chief of the Fire Department, will go on trial today on departmental charges resulting from a pre-Christmas firehouse party. The hearing will be held at 10 A. M. in Room 601 of the Municipal Building.

BATAVIA, Jan. 10 (AP) -- Leaders of individual Indonesian states outside the former Republican areas of Java and Sumatra gathered today to discuss their role in the Dutch plan for a United States of Indonesia. Former Republican areas are not represented at the meeting, which is under the temporary chairmanship of Hamid II, Sulton of Pontianak, West Borneo.

PARIS, Jan. 10 -- The French Government is seeking a quick peace with the Indo-Chinese nationalists to counteract the Communist pressure on all Southeast Asia that is expected to grow as the Chinese Red armies move southward, high authorities here said today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 -- Initial Congressional reaction to the President's $42,000,000.000 budget was generally cautious today. Details of the budget were far from having been absorbed. Comparatively few members of either House sat through even these parts of the bulky White House message that were read by clerks.

Tonight is "Nat Holman Night" at Madison Square Garden. Officially, the occasion celebrates Holman's thirtieth anniversary as basketball coach of City College. But to basketball fans it will commemorate the growth of the game itself. For Holman's career has paralleled the amazing popularity which basketball has enjoyed since the end of the First World War.

The Long Island College of Medicine, in Brooklyn, and the College of Medicine, a part of Syracuse University, were offered to the state yesterday for absorption into the projected State University of New York. New York University also offered to expand its College of Dentistry, with state subsidy but without giving over control of the institution.
Marshall Plan aid is "money down the drain" unless Europe creates a sovereign European state, R. W. G. Mackay, Labor member of the British Parliament, declared yesterday.

MINEOLA, L. I., Jan. 10 -- The Board of Supervisors today rejected the application of Rene A. Carreau, Democratic leader of Nassau County, to be named a commissioner on the bipartisan Nassau County Board of Elections. The vote was along party lines, with the four Republicans voting against naming Mr. Carreau and the two Democrats voting for him.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 -- The President's budgetary request of $6,700,000,000 for foreign assistance in 1949-50 is a half billion dollars under the estimate for the current fiscal year.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 -- Business inventories increased $800,000,000 during November to a new record high of $55,300,000,000, the Department of Commerce reported today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 -- Dr. Ralph McDonald, executive secretary of the National Commission on Teacher Education and Professional Standards, today told the first 1949 regional conference on that subject that elementary teachers are too often looked upon as a "high grade community maid service."

GENEVA, Jan. 10 -- The International Bank for Reconstruction and Development is considering new means to help alleviate critical shortages of certain European currencies now impeding the growth of intra-European trade, it was learned today.

Three airlines asked the courts yesterday to compel the Port of New York Authority to let them use the New York International Airport at Idlewild, Queens, for their big new Boeing Stratocruisers for service to Europe and the Orient.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 -- Individual incomes again set a record in November, the Department of Commerce reported today, but none of the increase was accredited to wage earners or salaried workers in private industry.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 10 -- United Artists and Monogram have concluded a deal whereby Roy Del Ruth's "Red Light" and the King Broilers' "Gun Crazy" will be distributed by United Artists instead of Monogram, it was learned today from the latter studio.

The stock market apparently anticipated yesterday President Truman's budget demands and took a bearish course from the start. Support for a few scattered issues helped arrest a downward movement and left final prices only slightly lower on the day. Alterations of a point or in excess were few and the composite rate ended with a loss of 0.33 point.

Fines totaling $36,250 were imposed by Federal Judge Sylvester J. Ryan yesterday on the Metropolitan Leather and Findings Association, Inc., and twenty of its members on their pleas of nolo contendere to an indictment charging violation of the Sherman anti-trust act.

HARTFORD, Conn., Jan. 10 -- The Telephone Order of Personality and Smiles organized its Hartford chapter at a dinner in the Bond Hotel tonight. About 100 chief telephone operators for aircraft, newspaper and other industries attended.

BERLIN, Jan. 10 (UP) -- Gen. Lucius D. Clay, United States Military Governor, said in an economic report today that German steel production was exceeding the goal set by the Allies. In the six-month period ending Nov. 30, he said, the ingot steel output in the combined United States and British zones was 3,126,500 tons, or about 600,000 tons more than the target.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 -- The Supreme Court refused today to consider an attack on the constitutionality of those sections of the Taft-Hartley Law that relieve employers from the obligation to bargain collectively with foremen.

LONDON, Jan. 10 -- As a result of the latest developments in Palestine the cheerfulness which was evident last week was absent when the stock market opened here today. As a precautionary measure dealers quoted prices wider and a little lower but no selling developed and the fractional losses recorded in most sections were due to absence of demand.
The report of the Superior Oil Company of California showed yesterday a net profit of $2,733,505 for the quarter ended on Nov. 30, last.

With a fifty-ton concrete patch on the aft end of her hull, the British liner Queen Mary docked at 7:10 o'clock last night at Pier 90, West Fiftieth Stret, after a voyage on which she was subjected to delay on both sides of the Atlantic.

FORT KNOX, Ky., Jan. 10 -- The old pre-war vision of an armored army is coming closer and closer to reality if the tactical and organizational concepts here at Fort Knox, the armored center, are any criterion.

The moral rights of an artist were asserted before the bar of justice yesterday as attorneys for Alfred D. Crimi, prize-winning mural painter, opened their case against the Rutgers Presbyterian Church, which had obliterated the artist's mural.

LONDON, Jan. 10 -- The British Cabinet Defense Committee met in the Prime Minister's office this morning to discuss the grave Palestinian conflict and to decide on the next measures to be taken. It is understood no drastic immediate action is planned, but it seems certain that Britain is strengthening her military position in the Middle East and especially in Trans-Jordan.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 10 -- Joe, the New York State robin that was grounded after an encounter with a cat, flitted somewhere over the Miami area today after having been flown here in a commercial airliner.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Jan. 10 -- Despite many additions to facilities, the Westchester County Airport in Purchase had a record deficit of $200,000 in 1948, County Executive Herbert C. Gerlach told the Westchester Board of Supervisors this afternoon in an annual 8,000-word message on county affairs.

ALBANY, Jan. 10 -- The Law Revision Commission reported to the Legislature tonight that it believed the privilege of withholding sources of information in judicial proceedings could safely be granted reporters provided such privilege were accompanied by "safeguards."
Pink and purple were featured in Anita Andra's presentation of spring hats yesterday afternoon in her salon at 558 Madison Avenue.

Although thousands of spectators crowded into the National Motor Boat Show again yesterday at Grand Central Palace and stood in long queues to climb boarding ladders, delegates from many member clubs of the American Power Boat Association from coast to coast culminated three days of pow-wowing about speed boat regattas and late in the evening elected C. King Brugman, a Los Angeles insurance man, president for 1949.

PEIPING, Jan. 10 -- In the five days since the Communist ultimatum to the Government's North China troops was issued over the North Shensi radio, the Communists have intensified their attacks on Tientsin. Observers here believe that the Reds intend to take that city before pressing an all-out offensive on Peiping.

The city has a new weather man. Ernest Julius Christie, formerly chief of the Albany Weather Bureau, arrived here yesterday morning and immediately took over as meteorologist in charge, United States Weather Bureau, 17 Battery Place, where he succeeds Benjamin Parry, who retired on Dec. 31 after forty-five years.

CHICAGO, Jan. 10 -- The big four packers -- Swift Co., Armour Co., Cudahy Packing Company and Wilson Co., Inc. -- filed today motions in Federal District Court to dismiss the Government's civil anti-trust suit against them.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 (AP) -- President Truman asked Congress today to provide another $1,000,000 of capital to the Federal barge lines, which continue to operate in the red.

" Mexican Hayride," a Universal-International comedy with music starring Bud Abbott and Lou Costello, will have its local premiere today at Loew's Criterion. Charles T. Barton directed and Robert Arthur produced the offering from a screen play by Oscar Brodney and John Grant and the musical play by Herbert and Dorothy Fields and Cole Porter.
The reports on Florida hunting and fishing are much better than they were during this season a year ago, with quail reported to be plentiful in most of the popular hunting areas.

A campaign for $10,000,000 to build a Christian international university in Japan will be started in the United States and Canada on April 18 by the Japan Christian University Foundation, Dr. Ralph E. Diffendorfer, chairman of the board of directors, announced yesterday.
LOS ANGELES, Jan. 10 (A) -- Steel-nerved Lloyd Mangrum, refusing to crack where others did, launched golf's golden winter tour today with a victory in the $15,000 Los Angeles open.

St. Louis University's Billikens, one of the nation's few unbeaten college squads, fresh from their important triumph over Kentucky, and Nat Holman, observing his thirtieth year as C. C. N. Y. basketball mentor, will be the centers of attraction as another twin bill is staged at Madison Square Garden tonight.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 -- The commission headed by former President Hoover, which was created by Congress to study the functioning of the Government of the United States and to recommend improvements, has been debating a proposal that it take a stand on a constitutional issue.

NANKING, Jan. 10 -- The final liquidation of Gen. Tu Yu-ming's two army groups southwest of Suchow, where they had been trapped with insufficient food and ammunition for more than a month, was claimed tonight by the Communist radio.

When the Japanese started their Pacific war of conquest one of their most powerful weapons was the slogan "Asia for the Asiatics." At first this propaganda had some influence -- except perhaps in China, where its real meaning had long been evident. In time most of the native peoples of Eastern Asia found out that what was really intended was "Asia for the Japanese."

Efforts to "draft" former Secretary of the Treasury Henry Morgenthau Jr. as head of the 1949 United Jewish Appeal were questioned last night by ranking Zionist leaders who charged that Mr. Morgenthau had set as one of his conditions the re-employment of Henry Montor, former executive director of the United Palestine Appeal.

Development of airline "day coach service" will be seriously retarded, if not set back for years, should the Civil Aeronautics Board follow through on its proposed new economic regulation and put more than 100 large irregular air passenger carriers out of business, a spokesman for the independent airlines said here yesterday.

While the New York Football Yankees continued building of the club yesterday with the announcement that George Bernard (Barney) Poole, University of Mississippi end, had promised to sign a three-year contract in the fall, there was talk in the official family of moves to be made by the All-America Conference in the projected peace meeting with the rival National League in Chicago on Jan. 20.

John E. Blunt 3d, R. Winfield Ellis and Richard W. Simmons, formerly vice presidents of Lee Higginson Corporation have formed the investment and brokerage firm of Blunt, Ellis Simmons, with offices at 208 South La Salle Street, Chicago.

ALBANY, Jan. 10 -- Twelve Senate and eight Assembly committee chairmanships changed hands here tonight in a general reshuffling of committee assignments made necessary by Democratic gains and Republican losses in the recent elections, and by retirements.

MIAMI, Jan. 10 (AP) -- Three Jewish refugees -- all former inmates of Nazi concentration camps -- and three suspected alien smugglers were arrested at Marathon yesterday after a twenty-eight-hour watch by border patrolmen.
A syndicate of seventy-five underwriting houses headed by First Boston Corporation marketed yesterday an issue of 400,000 new shares of common stock of Koppers Company, Inc., at $31 a share.

ROME, Jan. 10 -- Catholic Action endorsed today United States efforts to conclude an Atlantic pact and Italy's eventual inclusion in it as a means to protect this country against possible Soviet aggression.

On a recent radio quiz program a young couple were asked what they quarreled about most often. "Spaghetti," both answered at once. The husband (his background was Italian) asserted his wife overcooked it. She was equally insistent it should be boiled until very tender.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Jan. 10 -- The Government was informed today by Dr. Bunche that the Egyptians had prepared to send three army officers and two representatives of the Foreign Office to the armistice conference at Rhodes on Wednesday.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Jan. 10 (A) -- After failing to win in eighteen starts last year and in one this season, Ben Lewis finally found the right spot in today's featured Gislebert Purse at Tropical Park.

CAIRO, Jan. 10 -- Discussing last Friday's air clash, a British military source asserted today that the reconnaissance was being carried out over Egypt only on behalf of United Nations observers to establish whether and how far the Israelis had penetrated into Egyptian territory.

The money market was tight yesterday and Federal funds were quoted at 1-7/16 per cent, compared with 1-3/8 per cent on Friday. The member banks here, after reporting excess reserves of $215,000,000 on Wednesday night had a deficiency of $130,000,000 on Thursday, and by Friday it was further increased to a deficiency of $225,000,000.

The city's investigation of milk prices, begun last June, produced its first dividend for consumers yesterday in the form of a reduction of one cent a quart in all A. P. food stores in the five boroughs.

ALBANY, Jan. 11 -- A special committee of the New York City Board of Education is planning to recommend erection of semi-temporary buildings to house the overflow of pupils in schools that are now overcrowded, Governor Dewey reported tonight.

With expansion of trade with the United States as it aim, the Czechoslovak Industries Fair at the New York Museum of Science and Industry in Rockefeller Center had a preview here yesterday. More than $1,000,000 in Czech goods was imported for the fair, which opens officially today and continues through Jan. 30.

There is abundance of evidence from former workers of UNRRA, IRO, and various American voluntary agencies active in the American occupation zone of Germany that the Displaced Persons camps there contain many former Nazi collaborators and other persons who are imbued with Nazi-like racist ideas.

The sale of one of the finest town houses on the East Side was reported yesterday with the purchase of the five-story and penthouse dwelling with limestone front at 8 East Seventy-ninth Street by Dr. and Mrs. Gaetano Andronaco for occupancy.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan 11 -- Paramount today announced plans for five pictures to be produced in March, April and May, bringing the studio's program for the first half of 1949 to thirteen films.

A second book of war memoirs by Field Marshal Viscount Montgomery of Alamein has been scheduled for publication. Almost a year ago Houghton Mifflin issued "Normandy to the Baltic," his book about the European theatre. In February, Dutton will bring out "El Alamein to the River Sangro," his story of the campaigns of the Eighth Army in North Africa, Sicily and Italy.

PARIS, Jan. 11 -- Increasing hints may be detected that none of the great powers is calculating that another world war is an imminent short-term risk. On the contrary, there are symptoms that the big powers are budgeting upon the theory that war is by no means near, although it may well be inevitable.

Fredric Popper, the young pianist who made his debut last night at Times Hall, played Poulenc Very well. So well, in fact, that he practically redeemed a recital that had been uninteresting the first three quarters of its length.

Taxation of co-ops by Congress was predicted yesterday by Joseph Leopold, Southwestern manager of the National Tax Equality Association, at the annual convention of the National Association of Retail Secretaries at the Statler Hotel.

CANTON, China, Jan. 11 -- A federation of the South China provinces might delay a Communist advance to the southern borders of China for two years, according to foreign observers here. Such is the maximum delay that they believe possible, given the best "breaks" and assuming extensive American aid. Yet they see no sign that such aid will be forthcoming.

Space on the ground floor and in the basement of the new twenty-two-story office building at 445 Park Avenue has been leased for twenty years from the Tishman Realty and Construction Company for use as a restaurant, Norman Tishman, president, announced yesterday.

Forty-five thousand workers were added to the state unemployment insurance rolls last week, one of the largest increases in the thirteen-year history of the insurance system. The increase brought the total drawing job insurance and veterans' readjustment benefits to 455,000, a rise of 65 per cent in the last three months.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- Announcement by Senator Carl Hayden that the Senate Rules and Administration Committee would meet tomorrow "purely for organization purposes" set the stage today for the initial showdown on proposals to outlaw the filibuster.

In an effort to protect and develop the industry's export trade and to combat unfair restrictions on American textiles in overseas markets, four major associations in the cotton textile industry have banded together, it was announced yesterday. The groups are: American Cotton Manufacturers Association, Association of Cotton Textile Merchants of New York, the Cotton-Textile Institute and the Textile Export Association of the United States.
LONDON, Jan. 11 -- Middle East influences, Wall Street dullness and Rand miners' demand for a 30 per cent increase in wages overshadowed the stock market here today and the tone generally was heavy.

We were amazed to find in THE NEW YORK TIMES of Dec. 30 a report of THE NEW YORK TIMES radio program, "What's on Your Mind?" on which we, together with Alex Faulkner, correspondent for The London Daily Telegraph; Andre Rabache, chief of France-Press in North America, and Delbert Clark of THE NEW YORK TIMES, appeared on Dec. 29, so far aloof from reality.

" Born Yesterday," Garson Kanin's first Broadway play, unqualifiedly stamped the author as a successful writer of comedy. In his second play, "The Smile of the World," opening tonight at the Lyceum, where "Born Yesterday" was a fixture for more than two and a half years before moving to Henry Miller's recently, Mr. Kanin adopts a serious tone.

The end of the seller's market is being seen in many store departments, Harold V. Manzer, president of the National Advertising Executives Association, declared yesterday at the annual convention of the National Retail Dry Goods Association in the Statler Hotel.

The Sadler's Wells Ballet, resident company of the Royal Opera House, Covent Garden, London, will make its American debut in a three-week season at the Metropolitan Opera House early in October, under the management of S. Hurok. A brief tour of cities in the United States and Canada will follow.
The twelve Communist leaders accused of conspiring to advocate the forcible overthrow of the Government made another attempt in Federal Court yesterday to delay their trial.

The long-standing question of whether Staten Island commuters should eat breakfast at home or whether they should be able to absorb their "coffee-and" on ferryboats will be carefully discussed at a Friday morning conference in the Department of Marine and Aviation, it was learned yesterday.

Significant shifts in the city's residence density are taking place now and others will begin soon, the Consolidated Edison Company estimated yesterday. These changes may reverse the present population trends of a number of areas in Manhattan and Brooklyn, according to preliminary conclusions presented by the company.

After ten straight home games in the Garden, Joe Lapchick's Knickerbockers move into the Sixty-ninth Regiment Armory tonight to welcome the Boston Celtics on the latter's first visit of the season to these parts.
Whittaker Chambers has told the espionage grand jury that Felix August Inslerman, 38-year-old electrical engineer, developed the pumpkin microfilms, it was learned yesterday.
Strength developed in the cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday, and closing prices were at virtually the best levels of the day, or at gains of 20 to 23 points.

Election of Winthrop Rockefeller as chairman of the board of trustees of the New York University-Bellevue Medical Center, was announced yesterday by Dr. Harry Woodburn Chase, university chancellor, after a meeting of the board.

ALBANY, Jan. 11 -- Governor Dewey disclosed tonight that he had cut departmental requests for new capital construction funds from $290,000,000 to $89,000,000 in an effort to keep next year's budget below $900,000,000.

Rapid expansion of television's programming schedule was assured yesterday with the announcement of many shows for early presentation. The increased production activity comes as a sequel to last night's opening of the link joining the Eastern and Midwestern television networks.

Stockholders of the National City Bank of New York, at their annual meeting yesterday, received a hint of the possibility of a higher dividend payment from William Gage Brady Jr., chairman of the board. The bank's management, he said, is "hopeful" that its earnings this year will be as good as in 1948.

After a third of a century of service on the Yale faculty Dr. Luther A. Weigle will retire this summer as dean of the Divinity School, where he succeeded on the resignation of Dean Charles R. Brown in 1928. His work is not ended by any means, for he continues as chairman of the revision committee for the Standard Version of the Bible, which completed its New Testament in 1946, a project conceived in 1930.

Two new films will open in midtown theatres this morning. At the Palace, the attraction is "The Boy With Green Hair," an RKO drama filmed in Technicolor, with Pat O'Brien, Dean Stockwell, who plays the title role; Robert Ryan and Barbara Hale heading the cast.
Allow me to congratulate you on your editorial of Jan. 7, in which you so ably discussed the relinquishment of the presidency of Fordham University by the Rev. Robert I. Gannon, S. J.

The New York Board of Trade announced yesterday that it had asked Governor Dewey and Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll of New Jersey to favor legislation making the Port of New York Authority suable and capable of bringing suit. The letters, over the signature of Mortimer E. Sprague, president of the board, transmitted a resolution said to represent the views of the 2,000 concerns with representatives in the board's membership.

DETROIT, Jan. 11 -- Development of additional sources of power and greater efficiency of fuel consumption will supplement petroleum reserves within twenty years to assure adequacy of supply, R. J. S. Pigott, chief engineer of the Gulf Research and Development Company of Pittsburgh, said today in a paper read at the annual meeting of the Society of Automotive Engineers.

HARRISON, N. Y., Jan. 11 -- In a controversy that has drawn national attention of planners and caused controversy among estate owners here, the Harrison Town Board denied today the application of Mrs. Helen Rogers Reid, widow of Ogden Reid, for a rezoning of 90 of her 677 acres in the Purchase estate area.

Financial data submitted by taxicab companies in support of their request to the City Council for a 30 per cent rise in taxi fares will be checked closely by the Council, Walter R. Hart, Brooklyn Democrat and acting chairman of the Council's General Welfare Committee, said yesterday. Public hearings on the companies application ended yesterday before the committee.

BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 11 -- Foreigners who spend two years in Argentina must become citizens or leave the country, according to President Juan Peron's new draft of the Federal Constitution. From 3,000 to 4,000 citizens of the United States would be affected.

There is general agreement in the press that the most satisfactory compromise yet put forward to end the Electoral College anachronism is that advanced by Senator Lodge and Representative Gossett. Their proposal is to divide a state's allotted electoral votes proportionately between the candidates on the basis of that state's popular vote.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- The Department of Commerce announced today two new voluntary steel allocation programs, one of which is designed to build up the American Government's strategic materials stockpile by increasing shipments of manganese ore to this country from South Africa.

Mr. John, who presented his first collection in his new establishment at 53 East Fifty-seventh Street yesterday morning, has individual and pronounced ideas on what millinery should mean to women this spring. Many of his thoughts were voiced in an interview just before the opening when he was putting together some of the hats seen yesterday.

The Giants increased their total of contract signers to an even dozen yesterday when Secretary Eddie Brannick announced Don Mueller, hard-clouting rookie outfielder, and Bobby Rhawn, utility infielder, had accepted terms for 1949.

What a good wife does on and off the campus may prove her the "better half" of a college president, the wives of three college presidents at the thirty-fifth annual meeting of the Association of American Colleges suggested yesterday.

Mrs. Genevieve B. Earle, Brooklyn Republican and minority leader in the City Council, introduced a resolution in the Council yesterday demanding full police protection on the city's transit system to prevent crime. Mrs. Earle's resolution, which was referred to the Committee on City Affairs, said that "experience in the last few years has shown that crime, especially sex offenses, is on the increase in the subway system."

TOKYO, Jan. 11 -- Japanese political experts, who have been traveling in all parts of the country on the campaign trips of the major candidates, now predict that the Communist party will more than double its previous vote in the general election on Jan. 23.

Tapioca was gone but far from forgotten during the war, when hostilities cut off our main source of it, Java. That unhappy island is still out of the supply picture, but Brazil has taken its place, and shipments from there put tapioca back into excellent distribution about a year ago.

Favored by the clear skies and balmy temperature of the last several days, work has been speeding along on the demonstration house under construction near the Fifty-fourth Street boundary of the garden behind the Museum of Modern Art.

QUEBEC, Jan. 11 -- Quebec ilmanite, a mixture of iron, oxygen and titanium, is expected to supply United States industries with topflight metal for many years to come. Quebec Mines Department officials here believe that the "minimum" of 125,000,000 tons in the deposit will insure operations for the next century, based on a maximum of 4,000 tons per day ore extraction.

CHICAGO, Jan. 11 -- The grain markets developed a strong undertone on the Board of Trade today under leadership of soy beans, which rose 4 to 4 1/4 cents as the result of buying on reports that the Government's export allocations of fats and oils for the first quarter of this year would be increased 109,000,000 pounds, including a liberal amount of bean oil.

CAIRO, Jan. 11 -- An Egyptian Foreign Office spokesman emphatically and completely denied today a dispatch from Tel Aviv printed in THE NEW YORK TIMES Jan. 10, in which it was stated that Britain had delivered to Egypt in recent months 50,000,000 or $200,000,000 worth of military supplies, including aircraft, naval vessels, heavy artillery, tanks and aviation fuel.

LINDEN, N. J., Jan. 11 -- Tied in such a peculiar way that police were inclined to attribute the death to an accident, the body of Frank Hudowicz Jr., 21-year-old GI student at the Newark Industrial Arts School, was found half-dangling from a rafter and half-leaning against the coal bin in the cellar of his home at 35 Raritan Road here tonight.
BERLIN, Jan. 11 (UP) -- The British barred former Black Front leader Otto Strasser from their zone of Germany today amid indications that his reported plans to return here would fail.

Net current operating earnings of The Commercial National Bank and Trust Company of New York in 1948 were $1,192,141, equal to $3.41 per share, compared with $1,279,362, or $3.66 per share in the previous year, Waiter G. Kimball, chairman, reported to stockholders yesterday.

Dr. Marcus D. Kogel, general medical superintendent of the Department of Hospitals, was named Commissioner of Hospitals by Mayor O'Dwyer yesterday. He will succeed Dr. Edward M. Bernecker, who retired recently to accept an executive position with the New York University-Bellevue Medical Center.

PARIS, Jan. 11 -- The visit that W. Averell Harriman, Marshall Plan Ambassador, will pay tomorrow in London to Sir Stafford Cripps, Chancellor of the Exchequer, will be part of the preparation for the next stage in the European Recovery Program, which for the first time will affect if not determine the long-range policies of the European governments.

NEWARK, N. J., Jan. 11 (AP) -- Mrs. Effa Manley, owner of the Newark Eagles, formerly of the Negro National League, today filed protests with the Dodgers and Baseball Commissioner Albert B. Chandler over the signing of Monty Irvin, former Eagle player.

The struggle for sectional advantage in state aid to education that Governor Dewey is trying to referee is a highly unedifying spectacle in which politics, rather than a sincere desire to do what is best for the state's education system, seems to be dominant. Members of the Legislature give the impression of trying to legislate for their own districts rather than for the state.

The First Presbyterian Church, Fifth Avenue between Eleventh and Twelfth Streets, announced yesterday that it was opening its own "television center" for children in hope of keeping the youngsters out of Greenwich Village bars and grills.
M. N. McIlwain has been appointed vice president and plant manager of the John Wood Manufacturing Company, Inc., Conshohocken, Pa., and Chicago.
As the new ban on waterfront parking in Brooklyn went into its second day yesterday police officials joined with business executives in expressing satisfaction with its effectiveness.

Television extended its westward progress from the Atlantic to the Mississippi last night, over an area encompassing one-quarter of the nation's population, as the Bell System of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company opened its coaxial cable linking the Eastern and Midwestern networks.

It is established American practice for the President to present his first budget estimate for a given fiscal year six months before that year begins. It must, in other words, take into account, so far as possible, all the forces bearing on government receipts and expenditures for a period running eighteen months into the future.

Norman Forster of the New York A. C., Howard J. Rose of the Princeton Club and J. L. Porter of the Yale Club, seeded first, third and fourth, advanced to the third round of the Bulldog handicap squash tennis tournament at the Yale Club last night.

BATAVIA, Java, Jan. 11 -- A request of members of the United Nations Good Offices Committee to visit President Sukarno and other interned officials of the Republic of Indonesia on Banka Island today brought an explanation from Netherlands officials that President Sukarno was not on Banka as had been announced by the Dutch representative, Dr. Jan Herman van Royen, in the Security Council on Friday.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 11 -- While not all Philadelphia banks held their annual meetings on this traditional "bank day," those issuing annual statements reported higher net earnings than in 1947, chiefly as a result of better interest rates and a larger volume of loans.
MOSCOW, Jan. 11 (AP) -- President Truman has been making news for the Soviet press since the beginning of the year. He now is being quoted more than Henry Wallace, which is saying a great deal.

No important drop in price levels on regular new lines of men's clothing will develop during the spring and summer seasons, it was predicted yesterday by Jerome I. Udell, president of Max Udell Sons Company, in his "open letter" to the industry.

Maintenance workers employed in all parts of the country by the American Airlines have voted in favor of a strike that would paralyze all domestic and overseas operations of the lines, it was announced yesterday.

If you may permit me to say so, your editorial on Palestine was a shade unfair to the new State of Israel, its wording being such as to tip the scales, if only by implication, in favor of Great Britain.

The stock market operated yesterday in a narrow range. Minor price changes occurred, although there was a little pick-up in the last hour. Indicative of the thinness of trading was the fact that the composite rate only showed a gain of 0.01 on the day.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Jan. 11 -- Although the Presidential elections are a year off, a movement already has started to select a candidate on whom most parties can agree. Dr. Oswaldo Aranha, former President of the United Nations General Assembly, former Ambassador to the United States and former Minister of Foreign Affairs, is gaining ground as that candidate.

Peter Loftus returned to active duty as chief of the New York Fire Department just before noon yesterday when the departmental trial in which he was accused of violating the rules and regulations of the Fire Department was adjourned for two weeks.
